text:
Hello!
I've been wanting to write for years and finally today I'm doing something about it. Not that I'm trying to excuse myself, it's been very difficult to sit and write, as I've been moving so much. Since the last time we met, I've unpacked my bags in four different cities. This work has turned out to be more of a whirlwind than I expected, but everything is fine!
I went from London to Prague to establish a new regional office there. You know I always wanted to go, but maybe I was imagining Prague in the spring when I used to talk about it. Winter was very hard, with less than 15 degrees in the morning and dark very early at night. But at least they were blue skies and white snow and not days at the end of gray skies and rain, as at home. It's hard to be away from home on Christmas, though, and Skype on Christmas Day wasn't the same as being with everyone.
From there I was on another three-month mission to oversee the installation of the New York office. Beloved, beloved, beloved New York! It's like being on a big TV show, since everywhere it seems a little familiar. I did all the tourist things you could think of when I wasn't working, and I must have spent most of my salary on eating out. It was very difficult to get out for the next job, especially when I met someone (!) More information about Michael later...
So they sent me to Los Angeles, which felt like another country compared to the East Coast. I could definitely get used to that kind of outdoor lifestyle on the beach, but I didn't spend as much time getting to know California as I could because I flew back to see Michael every two weekends. He came to see me when he could, but his job means he often works on weekends, so he couldn't make the flight very often. Those three months flew by and then I went back to Frankfurt, which is where I am now. And... Michael too! He's got a month's work off and we're trying to figure out how we can be in the same place at the same time for a while. We imagine the first step in that direction is getting married, which is also why I wanted to write – I can't get married without my oldest friend there! The wedding will be home in London in September and I hope you can come.
Anyway, tell me all your news and I promise not to leave it that long this time!
A lot of love,
Kath

It was not so hard how people found the challenge, but how far they would go to avoid what left the researchers swallowed. The homework? Sit in a chair and do nothing but think.
Some found it so unbearable that they took advantage of the safe but alarming opportunity to give themselves mild electric shocks in an attempt to break the tedium.
Two-thirds of the men pressed a button to deliver a painful shock during a 15-minute spell of solitude.
Under the same conditions, a quarter of the women pressed the shock button. The difference, scientists suspect, is that men tend to look for more sensations than women.
The report by the psychologists of the Universities of Virginia and Harvard is one of the few surprising ones to address the question of why most of us find it so difficult to do nothing.
In more than 11 separate studies, researchers showed that people hated being left to think, regardless of their age, education, income, or the amount of time they spent using smartphones or social networks.
Timothy Wilson, who led the work, said the findings were not necessarily a reflection of the pace of modern life or the spread of mobile devices and social networks. Instead, those things could be popular because of our constant desire to do something instead of nothing.
The first series of experiments began with students who were introduced – alone, without phones, books or anything to write with – into a room without ornaments and were told to think. The only rules were for them to sit down and not fall asleep. They were informed – specifically or vaguely – that they would have six to fifteen minutes alone.
The students were interrogated when time ran out. On average, they did not enjoy the experience. They fought to concentrate. Their minds wandered even with nothing distracting them. Even giving them time to think about what it didn't help.
In case the unknown environment hindered the ability to think, the researchers carried out the experiment again with the people at home.
They got the same results, only people found the experience even more miserable and deceived by getting out of their chair or checking their phones.
To see if the effect was found only on the students, scientists recruited more than 100 people, aged 18 to 77, from a church and a farmers' market. They, too, disliked being left in the hands of their thoughts.
However, the most amazing result was yet to come. To see if people could really prefer something bad to anything at all, students were given the option of managing a mild electrical shock.
Before they had been asked to assess how unpleasant shocks were, along with other options, such as looking at pictures of cockroaches or hearing the sound of a knife rubbing against a bottle.
All students chosen for the test said they would pay to avoid mild electric shocks after receiving a demonstration.
To the surprise of the researchers, 12 of the 18 men were given four electric shocks, as were 6 of 24 women.
“What draws attention is that simply being alone with your thoughts was apparently so aversive that it led many participants to self-manage an electrical shock that they had previously said they would pay to avoid,” writes scientists at Science.
Jessica Andrews-Hanna at the University of Colorado said that many students would probably go away to encourage a tedious lecture. But, he says we need to know more about the motivation of surprises in Wilson's studio.
“Imagine the setup – a person is told to sit in a chair with cables attached to his skin and a button that will give a harmless but uncomfortable impact, and is told to sit there and entertain with his thoughts,” he said.
“As you sit there, tied to this machine, your mind begins to wander and naturally goes to that shock – was it really that bad?
“What are experimenters really interested in? Perhaps this is a case where curiosity killed the cat.”

Keith recently returned from a trip to Chicago, Illinois. This midwestern metropolis is located along the shore of Lake Michigan. During his visit, Keith spent a lot of time exploring the city to visit important monuments and monuments.
Keith loves baseball, and he made sure to pay a visit to Wrigley Field. Not only did he tour this spectacular stadium, but he also had to watch a Chicago Cubs game. At the stadium, Keith and the other fans cheered up the Cubs. Keith was happy the Cubs won with a score of 5-4.
Chicago has many historic places to visit. Keith found the Chicago Water Tower impressive as it is one of the few remaining landmarks to have survived the Chicago Great Fire of 1871. Keith also took a stroll through Jackson Park, a large outdoor space that hosted the 1892 World Fair. The park is ideal for a quiet walk, and still has some of the original architectures and replicas of monuments that were presented at the World Fair.
During the last part of his visit, Keith managed to climb the stairs inside the Willis Tower, a 110-story skyscraper. Despite the challenge of climbing the many flights of stairs, Keith felt that reaching the top was worth the effort. From the roof, Keith received a beautiful view of the city's horizon with Lake Michigan in the background.

text:
Griffith Observatory is a planetarium and exhibition hall located in Griffith Park in Los Angeles. It features several astronomical screens and telescopes on the Hollywood hills in the city's Los Feliz district. The Observatory was built on land donated by Griffith J. Griffith in 1896. Griffith was a Welsh-born philanthropist and miner tycoon who wanted to give the public access to a state-of-the-art observatory, making it free for visitors. He felt that ordinary people should be able to enjoy the wonders of the universe, and not just for the scientific community.
Griffith donated 3,015 acres of land specifically to house the observatory that opened its doors on May 14, 1935. During the first five days after the inauguration, the planetarium averaged more than 13,000 visitors a day. One of the main attractions was the Foucault Pendulum which is designed to show the rotation of the earth and the Zeiss reflector telescope. The observatory has an impressive view of Los Angeles and Hollywood, and the Pacific Ocean can be seen on clear days from there.
In 2002, the planetarium underwent a $93 million renovation and expansion, which closed the museum for four years. After its reopening in 2006, the facility expanded underground with new exhibitions, a coffee shop, a gift shop and a theatre. The Wilder Hall of the Eye section focuses on the astronomical aspect of the observatory. It is where people can see the stars through the observatory telescope, and has an interactive exhibition that is very popular. The Ahmanson Hall of the Sky is another popular attraction to see images in the night sky that are visible to the naked eye. The observatory often sets observation nights when the public is invited to bring their own telescopes. It is open every day and is still free of charge.

text:
There may be different types of entertainment at a wedding reception. There will usually be a Master of Ceremonies, or MC, who helps move the reception by making announcements of what will happen next. For example, the MC will announce when the newly married couple enters the reception room, and all guests will stand up and applaud. A wedding reception usually has music and guests are expected to dance. The music can be provided by a DJ or a live band. Sometimes the DJ or live band will accept requests from guests to play a particular song. When the newlywed couple enters the reception, they will share a dance for themselves to a song they chose beforehand. Usually, the song is romantic and represents the couple's love for each other. Sometimes the bride shares a dance with her father and the groom shares a dance with his mother. After these special dances, guests are invited to the dance floor.

The meal at a wedding reception can be buffet style, where everyone serves himself, or it can be a sitting meal served by waiters. Guests can choose from an offer of meat, chicken or fish. Guests usually make their decisions when they respond to initial wedding invitations.
During a wedding, guests should not expect to spend too much time with the bride and groom. The new couple is usually very busy waving to all their guests. Sometimes the couple don't even have a chance to eat. What almost all newly married couples can eat at their wedding reception is the wedding cake. The bride and groom traditionally cut the wedding cake together, and then feed the other person a bite.

text:
Facebook has lost millions of users a month in its larger markets, suggesting independent data, as alternative social networks attract the attention of those looking for new online playgrounds.
While Facebook is preparing to update investors on their performance in the first three months of the year, with analysts predicting revenue an increase of 36% over last year, studies suggest that their expansion in the US, UK and other major European countries has peaked. In the last month, the world's largest social network has lost 6 million American visitors, a 4% drop, according to the Socialbakers analysis firm. In the United Kingdom, 1.4 million fewer users were registered in March, a drop of 4.5%. The descents are maintained. Over the past six months, Facebook has lost nearly 9 million visitors per month to the United States and 2 million in the United Kingdom.
Users are also disconnecting in Canada, Spain, France, Germany and Japan, where Facebook has some of its biggest followers. A Facebook spokesperson refused to comment.
“The problem is that, in the United States and the United Kingdom, most people who want to sign up for Facebook have already done so,” said new media specialist Ian Maude at Enders Analysis. “There is a boredom factor in which people like to try something new. Is Facebook going to follow MySpace's path? The risk is relatively small, but that doesn’t mean it’s not there.” Alternative social networks such as Instagram, the photo sharing site that won 30 million users in 18 months before Facebook acquired the business, have seen increases in popularity among younger age groups.
Path, the mobile-based social network founded by former Facebook employee Dave Morin, which restricts its users to 150 friends, is earning 1 million users a week. It has recently surpassed 9m users, with 500,000 Venezuelans downloading the app in a single weekend.
Facebook continues to grow rapidly in South America. Monthly visitors to Brazil increased by 6% in the last month to 70m, according to Socialbakers, whose information is used by Facebook advertisers. India has seen an increase of 4 per cent to 64 million, a fraction of the country ' s population, leaving room for further growth.
But in developed markets, other Facebook tracking is reporting declines. Bank analysts Jefferies have developed an algorithm that interacts directly with Facebook software and that “sugges user levels in [the first quarter] may have declined since the peak.”
Jefferies saw the world peak of 1.05 billion a month in January, before falling by 20 meters in February. The numbers increased again in April. The network has lost nearly 2 million visitors to the UK since December, according to research firm Nielsen, with its total of 27 million inhabitants a year earlier.
The number of minutes Americans spend on Facebook seems to be falling, too. The total was 121 billion minutes in December 2012, but that fell to 115 billion minutes in February, according to comScore.
As Facebook itself has warned, the time spent on their pages of those sitting in front of personal computers is rapidly decreasing because we are changing our screen time to smartphones and tablets.
While smartphone minutes have doubled in one year, to 69 per month, that growth is not guaranteed to compensate for the decrease in desktop usage.
Facebook is the most authoritative source in its own user numbers, and the firm will update investors on its performance for the quarter. Wall Street expects revenues of about $1.44 billion, compared to $1.06 billion in 2012.
Shareholders will be particularly interested in learning how fast Facebook’s mobile user base is growing, and whether advertising revenue is growing at the same pace.
Mobile usage accounted for almost a quarter of Facebook's advertising revenue at the end of 2012, and the network had 680 million mobile users per month in December.
The company warned in recent stock exchange presentations that it might be losing “younger users” to “other products and services similar to, or as a substitute for, Facebook.”
Hot competition from the services that were invented for the mobile phone instead of the PC, founder Mark Zuckerberg has recently driven through a series of new initiatives designed to attract smartphone users. The most significant is Facebook Home, software that can be downloaded on certain Android phones to feed news and photos of friends – and advertising – directly to the owner's blocked home screen.

text:
Easter is a Jewish feast that recalls and celebrates its liberation from ancient Egyptian slavery as described in the Old Testament of the Bible. It is traditionally held in spring and lasts about a week.

According to Bible history, God punished ancient Egypt with 10 plagues. The last plague killed first-born Egyptian men. The Jews were told to mark their doors with lamb's blood so that God would know how to pass over these houses and not kill any firstborn male within. From here comes the name of the feast, Easter. After this last plague, the Egyptian king, known as Pharaoh, agreed to free the ancient Jews from slavery. Bible history also says that the Jewish people left their homes in such a hurry after they were released that they had no time to wait for the bread to rise. That is why at the Passover memorial dinner, Jews eat matzo, unleavened bread, also known as unleavened bread. Matzo and other foods are eaten at a special meal called seder.
There are very specific rituals that happen in the Seder food. These rituals are all in a book called the Haggadah. Within the Haggadah is also the story of the Jewish exodus from Egypt. During the meal of the seder parts of the Haggadah are read aloud. The first part of the meal is a blessing on wine. The second part of the meal is hand washing. The third part of the meal is when someone dips some kind of vegetables in salt water and then eats the vegetables. The vegetable symbolizes the humble origins of the Jewish people. Water symbolizes their tears. The fourth part of the meal is when three pieces of matzo are broken.

- LSB- Last minute alert, 6:23 a.m. GMT - LRB- 01:23 a.m. ET-RRB-RSB-
Scotland will remain part of the United Kingdom -- together with England, Wales and Northern Ireland -- after a historic referendum vote. A majority of voters rejected the possibility of Scotland breaking up and becoming an independent nation.
With 31 of the 32 councils declared, the campaign has not won the referendum on Scottish independence.
Scottish Prime Minister Alex Salmond admitted defeat in Scotland's independence referendum on Friday, and urged the rest of Scotland to do the same.
In a televised statement, he thanked Scotland for 1.6 million votes in favour of Scottish independence. An 86% share is one of the highest in the democratic world for any such vote, he said.
-LSB- Original story published at 12.37 p.m. ET-RSB-
Voters in Scotland made their election on Thursday -- they're still part of the UK, or they're their own independent nation. They decided to stay.
With 31 out of 32 councils reporting, the campaign had not obtained enough votes to secure its victory, and with it the continued place of Scotland within the union.
The first councils that declared everything went to campaign No, like the capital, Edinburgh, which overwhelmingly voted to remain in the union with 123,927 votes in favour and 194,628 votes against. Argyll and Bute and Aberdeenshire also voted No.
Glasgow won a solid victory for the field of independence with 194,779 votes in favour of Yes, and 169,347 against, but the advantage was not big enough to overthrow the general majority of Camp No so far, which maintains 8 % - LRB- 54 % to 46 % -RRB - over the pro-independence camp.
Most of the first results have gone on the path of the anti-independence camp. The campaign did not extend leadership with the results of the council of Angus and East Dunbartonshire, along with a landslide in Dumfries and Galloway. The oil-rich city of Aberdeen also voted strongly for the trade union camp.
The city of Dundee was the first big gain for the independence campaign, voting yes with 53,620 votes in favour, 39,880 against.
The individual recounts of local authorities are ultimately irrelevant, as it is the total number of votes across the country that will determine the outcome.
Surveys in more than 5,500 stations in all districts, from the remote highlands and islands to the major cities of Edinburgh and Glasgow, closed at 22.00 local time - LRB-5 p.m. ET-RRB-. People who were still online to vote at that time were allowed to cast votes.
High participation
The first districts to report participation reported high participation -- much more than 80 per cent in most cases -- Mary Pitcaithly, head of counting, announced in Edinburgh.
Participation in Glasgow, one of the focal points of the Yes campaign, was a relatively disappointing 75%.
More than 4.2 million people registered to vote on the issue: Should Scotland be an independent country?
A vote for independence would mean that Scotland, with a population of about 5.3 million, is divided from the rest of the United Kingdom, consisting of England, Wales and Northern Ireland, in addition to Scotland.
The people of Scotland have participated in this conversation, Phil MacHugh, a spokesman for Yes camp, told CNN on Thursday night. They've really come out, they've discovered the information they wanted to know, and they've made that decision today.
Address by the Prime Minister
British Prime Minister David Cameron will make a speech on Friday morning. The content will depend on the outcome of the vote, but in case Scottish voters decide to remain in the union, Downing Street says it will refer to plans for further redistribution of powers from central government to the Scottish Parliament, signed by Westminster leaders earlier this week.
Edinburgh counting officer Sue Bruce explained shortly after 10 p.m. that each vote will be verified twice, to verify the decision of each voter.
Addressing dozens of election workers, Bruce added, I look forward to working with you throughout the night to offer a precise and transparent Edinburgh count where you and Edinburgh voters can have full confidence.
The vote was quick at an election table in Glasgow when polls opened on Thursday, with many people voting on the way to work or before taking their children to school.
Bad weather or the large volume of votes cast could slow down the counting process. However, the weather forecast seems good so far; it is important that some ballot boxes are collected by helicopter, plane or boat from polling stations in distant islands.
Allegations of electoral fraud were reported by Glasgow City Council, with several instances of people appearing in the polling booths in Scotland's largest city to vote, only to be informed that they had already voted.
The Council stressed that there was never really a double-vote situation and that the ballot papers concerned are now being sought and withdrawn.
Scottish Prime Minister Alex Salmond, who has led the campaign for independence Yes Scotland, cast his vote Thursday morning in the village of Strichen, Aberdeenshire.
Labour legislator Alistair Darling, who has led the pro-union campaign Better Together, backed by Westminster's main parties, voted in Edinburgh, while former Prime Minister Gordon Brown, another pro-union activist, voted in the city of Kirkcaldy.
For the first time, the vote was extended to 16- and 17-year-olds living in Scotland. Almost 110,000 persons under the age of 18 have registered to vote.
Voters in the referendum did not have to be British citizens; Commonwealth, Irish and EU citizens living in Scotland and registered to vote there can cast a vote. However, Scots living outside Scotland have nothing to say.
Almost 790,000 people applied for a postal vote, the largest volume of registration for postal votes in Scotland.
After the polls closed, Salmond tweeted, “This has been a remarkable day. Scotland's future is really in Scotland's hands.
Nic Robertson of CNN reported from Glasgow, Laura Smith-Spark wrote and reported in London and Euan McKirdy wrote and reported in Hong Kong. Richard Allen Greene, Lindsay Isaac and Greg Botelho of CNN contributed to this report.

text:
A
In 2010, the NASA planetary defence team had identified and recorded 90 per cent of the 1 km wide near-Earth asteroids. These 'near-Earth objects', or OCTs, are the size of mountains and include anything within 50 million kilometers of Earth's orbit. With an estimated 50 to record, NASA says none of the 887 it knows is a significant danger to the planet.
B
NASA is now working on the felling of some of the smaller asteroids, which are 140 meters wide or larger. Of the estimated 25,000 asteroids of this size, some 8,000 have so far been recorded, leaving 17,000 missing. Considering that a 19-meter asteroid that exploded over the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these medium-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they entered Earth's orbit.
C
If NASA can find the remaining medium-sized OCTs, it depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5 meter space telescope that would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If he got the money, he could probably reach his target in ten years. Once registered, the planetary defense team would still have to find a way to defend the planet against the impact of truly worrying asteroids: PAHs.
D
"Potentially dangerous asteroids" are rocks close enough to pass less than 7.5 million kilometers from Earth's orbit. NASA has created a map of 1,400 PAH, none of which is expected to be a threat in the next hundred years. With the technology already available, NASA can track these objects and make predictions about possible impacts, at which point two defense solutions could be launched.
E
The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 meters wide, orbiting its 800-meter mother, and it is expected that DART's impact will take her out of orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to capture.
F
Another suggested defense against an ongoing PAH hitting the Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a movie, and it was the theme of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Emergency Response Asteroid Mitigation Mission (HAMMER) is a genuine proposal from NASA. Eight-ton rockets would be fired at an asteroid approaching in the hope of hitting it off course. If the asteroid were too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up.

Ahmad Tourson, Abdul Ghappar Abdul Rahman, Edham Mamet, Anwar Hassan, Dawut Abdurehim and Adel Noori were resettled in Palau, the Department of Justice said in a statement on Saturday.
Seven Uighurs remain at Guantanamo Bay, where 215 prisoners remain. Uyghur is an ethnic group in western China.
Since January, 25 detainees have been transferred to other countries.
The United States has coordinated with Palau to ensure that transfers are carried out with appropriate security measures and will continue to consult with the Republic of Palau on individuals, the Department of Justice said.
The 13 Uighurs were accused of receiving weapons and military training in Afghanistan. Some of them have been released since 2003, and others Uighurs have been released in other countries. The United States said it would not send them back to their homeland because of concerns that they would be tortured by the Chinese authorities.
The Chinese government has said that no returned Uighur would be mistreated and has repeatedly warned other countries against the taking of men. Beijing officials again urged the United States this summer to hand over all remaining Uighurs instead of sending them elsewhere.
China claims that the men are part of the East Turkestan Islamic Movement, a group considered by the United States Department of State as a terrorist organization operating in the Xinjiang region. East Turkestan is another name for Xinjiang.
On October 20, the Supreme Court provisionally undertook to accept an appeal from the 13 Uighurs to be released in the United States from U.S. military custody.

Most of the artistic directors first day leading a new ballet company is about meeting the dancers. But for Nacho Duato it's a challenge to find the rehearsal room.
The labyrinthine corridors of the magnificent Mikhailovsky Theatre in St. Petersburg are confusing and inspire some twists and turns without Duato's chronology before he finally identifies the right room and his new company, the 140 dancers of the Mikhailovsky Ballet.
It is unlikely that the stage plan will be the last challenge for the Spanish choreographer who, this month, took over the company's leadership.
He is the first foreigner to lead a Russian ballet company in more than a century and has been charged with bringing modern choreography to Mikhailovsky's classical repertoire.
“Looking at the past but always taking a step forward and walking into the future... this is what I think they want and that’s why I think they called me,” Duato said. I think they're clear they want to change; they want something new.
A modern ballet dancer and choreographer with an international pedigree, it is expected that he can revitalize the ballet for the Russian public. While performances at Mikhailovsky are well attended, there is growing concern that Russians will tire of seeing the standard repertoire of classical ballets.
Russians love ballet. That goes without saying, but the attitude towards Russian ballet in the West is more passionate, said Vladimir Kekhman, a multimillion dollar fruit importer and director general of the Mikhailovsky Theatre.
I would like us to have the same attitude in Russia because as we say we do not treat what we have until it is gone.I consider ballet a national treasure, he added.
Kekhman is a relatively recent convert to ballet, but he has become something of a cultural entrepreneur, investing $45 million of his own money to restore the buildings of Mikhailovsky and, hopefully, his reputation.
Kekhman needed new talent to oversee his vision and for that, he said, he had to look beyond Russia.
I looked inside our industry to see who were considered living legends of choreography, and when I looked inside Russia, I realized that we didn't have choreographers who had the ability not only to choreography, but also to run the company, he said.
He approached Duato, a non-Russian speaker, who has spent the last 20 years choreographing new works as Artistic Director of the Spanish National Dance Company.
At first Duato was reluctant to change direction towards classical ballet. But then Mikhailovsky offered him the opportunity to take modern choreography to a classical ballet company and proved to be too tempting an offer to put aside.
“I know a lot of people who think that he is crazy, that I am crazy and that this is never going to work,” Duato said. That this mixture is like a bomb, an atomic bomb. But it made me feel like we're gonna try, let's do it. Why not? Maybe we can do it.
Bringing a modern approach to ballet in Russia, where it is rooted in culture could numb some, but it is a task that Duato is enjoying.
It's not a pressure. It's a pleasure. It really is a pleasure to be in a place where ballet - LRB- has been -RRB- part of the cultural tradition for -LRB- a -RRB- a long time, and at the same time they want to break in and do new things, said Duato.
Duato has set himself a challenging calendar, choosing three dancers to create a ballet so new that it doesn't even have a name yet. They have weeks before the world premiere.
The main dancer Ekaterina Borchenko is the jewel of Mikhailovsky's imperial crown. The company's star dancer has danced leading roles in classical ballet productions such as Swan Lake, Giselle and La Sylphide.
Now, she's enjoying the opportunity to stretch her skills. In this repertoire, I can show a different side of myself, express myself differently and find something new in me, he said.
The opening night will be a test of fire of how receptive the Russians are to this new direction.
Duato believes that ballet is a living organism, which needs to evolve constantly to keep the audience interested. It's a philosophy he shares with Kekhman.
“Together we will work on something,” Duato said. We don't know what it's gonna be like, but I think it's gonna be beautiful. If we put all our hearts and soul into it, it's going to be fantastic.

One of the most historic and significant milestones in the United States is the San Francisco cable car system. It is the only manually operated cable car system in the world. It is run by the San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency. The system dates back to 1878, when the California Street line was first opened. In total, there are three lines currently operating in the city, and it has a fleet of 12 cable cars. There were 23 lines in use throughout the city connecting the various communities that make up San Francisco. Outdoor cars are an important tourist attraction, and are still used by San Francisco travelers on a daily basis.

The simple reason why the cable cars were used for the first time in the city was because of its landscape. San Francisco is very mountainous, which makes it impossible to climb municipal buses. The solution to this problem was the cable car. These cars are literally pulled by cable, climbing up and down the steep hills of the city, making it easier for people to get from one end of the city to the other.
There are two types of cars in use today. Single end cars and double end cars. Single end cars have open side sections with seats facing out onto the street. The rear section of these cars is closed with seats facing inwards of the car. These cars can accommodate 29 passengers. They travel in both directions using a swivel-based swivel that rotates the car at the end of the line. Double end cars are a little larger, and can contain up to 68 passengers. It has 34 seats and handles for another 34 passengers standing. The best feature of these cars is the pure fun they are to ride. The people who ride the San Francisco cable cars are entering part of California's history.

text:
In a bold operation worthy of a film, three men escaped from a Canadian prison by helicopter, provoking massive persecution, authorities said.
The men escaped from a detention center on Saturday night in Quebec City.
A helicopter landed briefly in the courtyard before taking off with the three prisoners, said Ann Mathieu, spokesman for Quebec Provincial Police.
We are talking closely to the detention center to find out exactly how the escape occurred, Mathieu told CNN partner CBC. The priority... is to find the helicopter.
A hunt is underway for Yves Denis Yvon Lamontagne, 35, Denis Lefebvre, 53, and Serge Pomerleau, 49.
The first two men were arrested in a drug bust in 2010 and were awaiting trial. Police found guns, dozens of cars, and a plane during the arrest, he said. No information was provided on the third suspect.
It marks the second blatant escape from jail in Canada in just over a year.
In March 2013, two men posing as tourists seized a helicopter from a Canadian travel company, ordered the pilot to fly over a detention centre near Montreal, hoisted two inmates on the plane in the air using cables and left with a zip.
It was a real moment James Bond, witness Francis Emond said about last year's escape from the facility in Saint-Jerome, northwest of Montreal.
Although airborne leaks are spectacular, they are not unprecedented.
Albanian prisoner Alket Rizaj twice left a maximum security prison in Greece in 2006 and 2009.
On both occasions, the accomplices entered the prison courtyard by helicopter. The inmates boarded with rope stairs.
On both occasions, Rizaj was recaptured.
Last year, another prison escape in Greece tried to use the same tactic.
But the plot was thwarted when the prisoner was shot and the helicopter was forced to land in the prison parking lot.
In 1971, Joel David Kaplan escaped from a Mexican prison aboard a helicopter. The flight of the New Yorker inspired the book The 10 Second Jailbreak: The Helicopter Escape of Joel David Kaplan and the 1975 film Breakout.
And in France, Pascal Payet did not escape once, not twice, but three times from French prisons.
Every time, he was recaptured.

He was also unanimously elected to a second term in 1793, the only president to obtain 100% of the electoral votes. Washington was also the Commander-in-Chief of the First Continental Army who fought the British when the country had not yet established itself.

Its epic "Crossing of the Delaware" river to recover New York City is still considered one of the largest military movements in the history of war. By the time of the crossing, the British had taken Boston and New York. The Continental Army was running away and disorganized, but Washington had a plan. He decided to take his troops across the Delaware River in the middle of winter. This was a movement that many military minds thought impossible, but not Washington. The Americans were able to take New Jersey, and change the course of the war.
Another historic moment for Washington was winter in Valley Forge. In 1777, Washington led an army of more than 11,000 soldiers to Valley Forge in Pennsylvania, where the army suffered during a cold winter that claimed the lives of 3,000 men. When spring came, instead of a group of demoralized and beaten soldiers, the army emerged ready for battle, and able to continue the fight against the English in New York. The army was able to survive the ferocious winter due to the training and preparation of Washington officials. Washington earned the nickname, "The Father of His Country," because of its military intelligence, and its concern for the people of the United States.

text:
Emmanuel Limal, serial dater, was tired of meeting women who were not ready to form a family, or at least did not admit that they were. The 43-year-old actor, originally from France, had spent 20 years living in Copenhagen and seeking love in the hope of raising children. He recently took his online search, but was dismayed by the results.
“I was frustrated that everyone tried to sell themselves as really active, always traveling or with a long list of hobbies, but not to mention the children,” Limal said. “In some places, there was an option to click, saying, ‘I would like children someday,’ but you would read the person’s profile and think, ‘You’ll never have time!’ If someone goes to the gym eight times a week and travels every month, they won’t put a family first.”
Limal has a six-year-old daughter from a previous relationship, but coming from a large family – her father is one of 11 – she has always wanted more children. “It seems like I couldn’t meet anyone willing to give priority to forming a family and struggled with when to mention that I wanted to have children at any time that I knew someone new. It’s the ultimate taboo for dating,” he said. “Then one day I read a profile of a 38-year-old girl who said she knew it was really bad to admit it, but she wanted to have children. And I thought, "You shouldn't be ashamed of this. '"
Limal remodeled his apartment to finance the creation of Babyklar.nu – or 'it's ready for the baby' in English. It works as a normal dating site, but every potential dating person is asked to be honest about their desire to start a family soon. “We ask people if they’re okay with someone who already has children, as well as if they want another baby,” Limal said. “But we don’t make them specify how many children they would like. That would be a little too much like online grocery shopping.”
The response to the site has been overwhelming, he said. “We had 50 registrations per hour when we launched in June and we are already listening to couples who have gathered through the site and are now together. I am fully waiting for the first baby Babyklar.nu for next summer.” More men have enrolled than women (53% to 47%), with testimonies such as “It’s so lovely to be able to say this out loud” and “Finally I dare be honest about what I want.”
The site has arrived at an opportune time for the country of five million people. According to a report from the Rigshospitalet Hospital in Copenhagen, Danes are not having enough babies, and the current rate of 1.7 children per family is not enough to support the population of Denmark. The usual suspects are being blamed for the new bass – the women who leave it “too late” and the couples who cohabit and wait to form families.
“Now, I hope, men and women who want to form a family but have not met the right person will still have another choice,” says Limal. He is interested to note that this is not just about baby - raising: “I want this to be about children and love. My goal is to match people who really want a family and a partner – and who will stay together. I am a romantic of heart.”
There are plans to launch the site in France and the UK later in 2013, but for now it is the Danes who are reaping the benefits. “The Danes have no problem having children before marriage so things can move quickly and, because the country is so small, a jutlander can go out with a Copenhagener without traveling too much,” Limal said. Besides, Limal has finally found love. “I’ve met a nice woman and she wants a baby too, so we’ll see.”
label: B2

text:
-LRB-CNN-RRB- As one of the world's leading financial capitals, Hong Kong is a dream destination for business travelers.
With more skyscrapers than any other city in the world and some of the best restaurants on the planet, the city could well leave you begging for a flight cancellation so you can squeeze on an extra day.
To help you enjoy some of the highlights of the city, here is a guide to get into the city, eat and sleep well, buy the best memories and go out with an expense account you'll be proud of.
Easier and more comfortable airport transfer
Forget everything you know about subways: Hong Kong Express Airport Train Service makes even the most tired traveler fly.
The trains are clean, comfortable, spacious, always on time and take you to the city in 24 flat minutes, faster than any car service can aspire.
Better yet, trains are easy to walk and the simple procedure to find out on arrival -- there is virtually no stress about how to get tickets or where to get trains on leaving the arrival terminal.
At HK$100 per trip, trains depart at intervals of 10 minutes from 5:54 a.m. to 11:28 p.m. and 12 minutes from 11:28 p.m. to 12:48 a.m. every day.
Memorable meals
There is no shortage of Michelin-starred restaurants in Hong Kong.
But finding a memorable local meal that you'll be thinking about for months is much harder.
Luk Yu Teahouse has it all: a historical sensation inspired by deco art, waiters who have stayed in place over decades, murderous Cantonese food is nowhere else to be found, a glamorous clientele and a history past that includes a massive blow to the dining room.
You'll have to come early for an old-fashioned dim sum breakfast, like duck and chestnut pastry.
Luk Yu Teahouse, Luk Yu Building, 24-26 Stanley St. Central; +852 2523 1970
Central room with views
For a real home-out-of-home feeling, the attic suites at The Upper House are a good choice.
With over 180 square meters of discreet elegance, enveloping views of Hong Kong and a spa-inspired bathroom, this is the ultimate stay in the city.
Additional feature: the possibility of colliding with a celebrity in elevators.
La Casa Alta, Pacific Place, 88 Queensway, Admiralty; +852 2918 1838
Where to get a unique addition to your wardrobe
Hong Kong's fashion design scene is young, eclectic and fun.
A place to taste it is K11 Mall, known as Art Mall for its support of Chinese contemporary art and renowned gallery in the basement.
The shopping centre houses local designer brands and offers its own selection of design products at the K11 Design Store.
K11, 18 Hanoi Road, Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon; +852 3118 8070
Where to take a murder photo
Of course, you can ride the historic Tranvía Peak with tourists and take a big picture of Hong Kong on top of Victoria Peak -- it's infallible.
But you could also join the local hikers - LRB- of which there are many -RRB- to walk to Pico Lion Rock through the most incredible panorama of Kowloon, all surrounded by pristine nature.
Experience the heart of the city
To see Hong Kong, past and present, in short, go to the Central Districts and Sheung Wan.
Some of the oldest parts of the city, with ruined colonial-era housing buildings and decades-old shops, can be found in these areas.
Gentrifying comfortably, Soho and Poho - LRB- the neighborhood between Po Hing Fong and Hollywood Road -RRB- areas offer thoughtful restaurants and unpretentious boutiques.
General Directions: Keep walking west along Queen's Road Central, or the Hollywood Road parallel.
Graham Street is where things start to get interesting.
Souvenir elegant and easy to pack
Some of the best memories that visitors take out of Hong Kong focus on food.
To bring some local flavor home, you can pick up a couple of bottles of XO sauce.
Each restaurant that deserves its reputation will have its own secret recipe for the slightly spicy local seasoning made of dry and often precious seafood as well as Chinese ham.
We love the one from the East Mandarin cake store -LRB- $35, small, $45, big jar -RRB-.
Mandarin Oriental Cake Shop, M/F, Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong, 5 Connaught Road, Central, +852 2825 4008

California is the largest state in the United States of America. It is home to more than 10 percent of the country's total population. It also has the largest education system in the country. The university and university system is divided into four parts. These parts are the system of the University of California, the system of the State University of California, the system of community universities and private institutions.

The UC system has more than 230,000 students on its 10 campuses. It is considered the state's most prestigious system. It includes top universities such as UC Berkeley, and the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). Both schools are among the top 25 universities in the country, with Berkeley among the top 10. A title of the UC system is highly sought after, and academic standards are higher than the other systems. They're also more expensive.
California State Universities have 23 universities in their system. It is a diversified system that includes two polytechnic universities, and a maritime university. These schools offer professional and maritime education, but also offer traditional academic programs. The enrolment system is approximately 450,000 students, with some 45,000 faculty members.
The California Community Colleges system is the largest higher education system in the state and in the world. It has 112 campuses, and serves approximately 2.4 million students. It offers transfer degrees, vocational training and associated degree programmes.
California is also home to a large number of private and managed schools. These schools have no links to the state school system, but some accept the transfer of students from community universities. The state's most notable and prestigious schools are Stanford University, Palo Alto, and Southern California University, Los Angeles.

In general, the two pastel graphs show that smartphones and tablets are used for the same purposes, but in very different degrees.
The first circular graph shows how people spend their time on smartphones, while the second circular graph illustrates how time is spent on tablets. For both types of devices, the higher usage is for games, but the figures differ greatly. 57% of the time spent on a tablet is given to games, while only 35% of the time spent on a smartphone is used for this. In contrast, smartphone users spend 29% of their time on their social media access devices, compared to only 15% of tablet time devoted to the same activity.
The third most popular use of the tablet is to consume entertainment, with users spending 13% of their tablet time watching videos and listening to music. Smartphone users, however, devote only 8% of their smartphone time to this type of entertainment, preferring to spend 20% of their time in their phone access services. These may include maps, weather information, and calculators.
There is a clear difference in the way people are using their smartphones and tablets. In general, while tablets are used more for games and other forms of entertainment, smartphones seem to be the preferred choice for tasks as well as communication with the world around us.

As the Ice Bucket Challenge added $100 million to an American charity against neuron disease and $4.5 million to a British organization, as well as thousands more to charities in Hong Kong and Australia, the cold water of a rapid reaction has quickly followed.
Famous narcissists exhibiting toned bodies, people having fun without donating, complaints about water waste – attacks have come from commentators, animal rights groups and environmentalists. Meanwhile, the challenge continues to grow. For anyone who doesn't know how it works, someone gives a brief speech to the camera about charity, then throws a bucket of ice in the water over his head, or gets a friend to do it, before proposing to three people to do the same or donate.
It started in the U.S. in July, though whether it was on a golf course or a baseball course depends on the version you prefer, and first appeared on American television on July 15. Douglas Graham, director of fund-raising at the MND Association, said: “The reaction is to be expected, but, in reality, this is just a wonderful surprise and we are very grateful. We didn’t see it coming, but suddenly the donations just started.” The momentum is a huge help for a small charity that cares for the sick of a debilitating and misunderstood disease that has no cure and kills five people a day in the UK.
Former Baywatch star Pamela Anderson, a long-standing animal rights activist, wrote an open letter to the ALS Association, saying she could not support her record in animal experimentation. Another criticism has been that small charities will not be able to cope with the extra money, but the MND Association rejected this. “Oh, we can cope here,” Graham said. “We finance world-class research on causes and, ultimately, to find a treatment or cure. We provide care and support to 3,500 people and they need it because this is a disease that progresses rapidly and is costly to manage. More than 50% die two years after diagnosis. It is heartbreaking to see the decline of the people we work with for a few months.”
But, for many people with a connection to the disease, the awareness that the challenge has created is as valuable as cash. Graham says it's priceless. Normally, the MND Association receives around 300,000 visits a year on its website. Recently, in one day, I was 330,000.
“We couldn’t have created this if we had tried. Charities are all worthwhile causes and I understand even that some people might want to donate to a different one. Just two hours from Paris, the Loire was once a playground to Renaissance royalty. Now their castle professors are attracting young enterprising couples and artists who have turned them into captivating and surprisingly affordable inns.
Surrounded by 10 foot high limestone walls, Le Clos d'Amboise offers an unexpected sanctuary in the city of Amboise.
CHINON
Hôtel Diderot
If you've never eaten a brioche with fresh Ste. Maure goat cheese, honey and nuts for breakfast, then he hasn't been to the Loire, says Laurent Dutheil, who is justifiably proud of the simple breakfasts he serves at his 23-room hotel on the western corner of the valley.
Dutheil also produces dozens of fragrant handmade jams such as apple-lavender and quinceme. - LRB- Sadly, they're not for sale, but you can buy Dutheil's recipe book, Jam in the Cupboard. -RRB- The traditional foods adapt well to the venerable atmosphere of the hotel: Diderot is located in an extensive house of the fifteenth century that the Chinese Dutheil, together with his two sisters, Martine and Françoise, bought and renovated six years ago. Travel Budget: See the hotels
Dutheil addressed structural issues, taking care to keep intact the exposed oak beams and original stone walls, while his sisters remodeled the rooms with cheerful paper painted with stripes, toilet linen and 19th century cabinets that they collected on trips to Paris. The largest room, with capacity for four people, has double windows overlooking a patio. In the distance you will find vineyards full of the red grapes of Chinon dear to the novelist and satirist François Rabelais of the sixteenth century.
4 rue de Buffon, 011-33/2 -47 -93 -18 -87, hoteldiderot.com, rooms from $72.
THÉSEE
Le Moulin de la Renne
A tunnel of imposing fir trees leads to the entrance of this 19th century mill converted into Thésée, on the banks of the Cher River. Guests are greeted by a huge Bernese mountain dog named Alpha and its equally friendly owners, Véronique and Christophe Villanfin.
There are 13 rooms, decorated with items like embroidered duvets and framed puzzles of boats assembled by the fan of the Véronique puzzle. Jazz enthusiasts, Villanfins organize occasional concerts with local groups, including Les Bras Coeurs, a quartet that interprets the standards of Georges Brassens.
The evenings are celebrated in the restaurant, known locally for its coq au vin: rooster stewed in cabernet bottled in the winery Le Chai des Varennes next door.
11 route de Vierzon, 011-33/2 -54 -71 -41 -56, moulindelarenne.com, closed on January 10th -- February 10th and 10 days in November, 76-dollar rooms, $15.75 tickets.
CIVRAY-DE-TOURAINE
Château de l'Isle
The Château de l'Isle is quiet to the bottom, unless you count the chorus of charlatans coming from the duck pond on the 35-acre grounds. The 18th century manor house had been abandoned for 10 years when Denis Gandon bought it in 1986 and transformed it into a 12-room hotel.
However, the castle somehow feels like a private house: a portrait of Gandon's grandfather hangs on a 100-year-old table in the dining room, and a friendly Jack Russell terrier entertains guests with endless rounds of searching. The elegant rooms have exposed wooden beams and covered beds in crimson and calendula tones. Travel Budget: See the hotels
In summer, breakfast is served on a large glazed terrace overlooking the garden. A nearby potager -LRB- or kitchen garden -RRB- supplies products for some of Chef Fabrice Cherioux's breakfast delicacies, such as a spicy tomato jam.
1 rue de l'Ecluse, 011-33/2 -47 -23 -63 -60, chateau-de-lisle. com, rooms $69, breakfast $13.
CHENONCEAUX
La Roseraie
This 18-room hotel in Chenonceaux was a must on the itineraries of notable politicians after World War II, when the Allies were trying to figure out how to rebuild Europe. Winston Churchill, Harry Truman and Eleanor Roosevelt all, at one time or another, put their heads on La Roseraie. A letter from Roosevelt still hangs in the breakfast room. - RRB-
In 2000, Sophie and Laurent Fiorito acquired the property and completed a top-down renovation. There is no such thing as a standard room here -- small singles have enough room for a double bed, while a suite fits a family of five. The decoration is equally varied. One room has a comfortable Louis Philippe style and a glass lamp; another features a modern pink sofa.
The best asset of the hotel is its proximity - LRB- to Château de Chenonceau, five minutes walk from the Château de Chenonceau, which Henri II gave to his beloved lover, Diane de Poitiers; the huge building of the 16th century hovers over the Cher River.
7 rue du Docteur Bretonneau, 011-33/2 -47 -23 -90 -09, hotel-chenonceau. Com, closed November -- Jan and Mar., $85 rooms.
AMBOSE
Le Clos d'Amboise
Surrounded by 10-foot-high limestone walls, in the heart of the old market centre of Amboise, this 17-room inn offers an unexpected sanctuary of the bustling and narrow streets of the city.
The rooms are equipped with decorative elements such as mahogany canopy beds and original fireplaces, while the common room has wooden floors modeled according to those of the Palace of Versailles. Most rooms overlook the hotel's private park, landscaped with 100-year-old magnolias and a pine tree that survived the French Revolution.
A swimming pool next to the rose garden is perfect for a fresh dip after relaxing in the wooden sauna, located in an old stable. Just a 10-minute walk from the hotel is the castle by the river belonging to King François I -- part medieval fortress, part Renaissance royal house. The king became famous fascinated by Leonardo da Vinci during a 1515 trip to Italy, and established the painter in a red brick castle on two legs - LRB- now a museum -RRB-, just at the end of the road of his castle.
27 rue Rabelis, 011-33/2 -47 -30 -10 -20, leclosamboise.com, closed Dec. -- Jan., rooms from $98.
LIMERAY
Auberge de Launay
Between the two, François and Hélène Thévard have perfected their hospitality skills in some of the most respected hotels in the world, including Le Meurice in Paris and the Savoy in London.
After years of helping manage other people's properties, the couple, with their two young children, Emma and Alexandre, packed their apartment in Paris and bought a modest farm in the isolated village of Limeray to become a 15-room inn.
I grew up in the region, so when we made the decision to open our own place, I knew I had to go back to the Loire, says François. According to the spare design of the house, the decoration in the Auberge is simple -- the bedrooms are equipped with neutral suede sofas, blonde wooden floors and minimalist photographs of daisies and landscapes.
The duo oversees the daily lunch and dinner service at the hotel's restaurant, which serves local specialties such as the Loire eel with butter and chicken with mustard cream. The house dessert, a salted caramel fruit cake, is baked with apples collected in the hotel's orchard.
Le Haut Chantier, 011-33/2 -47 -30 -16 -82, aubergedelaunay.com, closed on December 15 -- January 15, $72 rooms, $26 two-course dinner.
ONZAIN
Château des Tertres
This mansion in the heart of the Loire once belonged to the mother of novelist Marguerite Duras -LRB- who mentions the castle in her famous play The Lover -RRB-. Later, in the 1960s, its marble corridors were filled with students from a nearby engineering school, which used the building as a bedroom.
In 1992, another curious owner took over the management of the 14-room castle: Bernard Valois, an artist who kept the details of the 19th century -LRB- high ceilings, gold mirrors -RRB-, but added the contemporary design blooms, as a photograph of a mysterious pair of eyes in the lobby.
Last year, Valois and his wife, Christine, redecorated an old doorman's house as a contemporary four-room house with Jackson Pollock paintings and sculptures that resemble huge eggs.
My husband likes to turn things that seem ordinary into something extraordinary, Christine says. He designed a Sputnikbidet that has Japanese robots parked around the tank.
Valois also has a 12-acre garden of roses and clematis, where guests can find a shed full of complimentary bikes to explore the 186 kilometers of trails.
11 rue de Meuves, 011-33/2 -54 -20 -83 -88, chateau-tertres. com, closed on 19 October-Apr. 1, rooms from $94.
CHITENAY
Auberge du Centre
When Gilles Martinet's grandmother found herself a widow at the end of World War I, she began selling milk and eggs to make ends meet. One thing led to another, and his house finally became a guest house and restaurant specializing in French food, like chicken sautéed in fresh cider.
Three generations later, Martinet is now the owner and chef of this inn, which features 26 rooms with bright décor in sage and pink tones, as well as a garden terrace full of flowers on the back. He has maintained the breakfast area the way his grandmother designed it, with rustic stone walls, a large fireplace and simple country furniture.
Bicycles are available to rent -LRB- $14.50 per day -RRB- for excursions to Château de Cheverny, about five kilometers away.
34 Grande Rue, 011-33/2 -54 -70 -42 -11, auberge-du-centre. com, closed Feb., $78 rooms, $17 tickets.
Loire Basics
Two hours drive southwest of Paris, the Loire Valley is known for its terross wines of Franco Cabernet and hundreds of majestic castles.
It is impossible to see them all -LRB- a visit to a castle can take half a day -RRB-, so it is wise to focus on the worthy: Chenonceau, the elegant fluvial palace that once belonged to Henri II -LRB- chenonceau.com, $13 -RRB-; Chambord, which has a double propeller staircase inspired by the designs of Leonardo da Vinci -LRB-chambord.org, $12.50 -RRB-; and Cheverny, known for its dazzling and golden interiors -LRB-chateau-cheverny. Com, $9.75.

Saint Patrick's Day, March 17, is a Christian religious feast celebrating the patron saint of Ireland. According to legend, St. Patrick took all the snakes out of Ireland. St. Patrick's Day has also become, especially in the United States, a day to celebrate Irish culture. In the country's major cities, such as New York and Boston, there are parades and festivals. People dress in green and decorate with clubs, a type of three-leaf clover. Some people wear buttons or t-shirts that say, "Kiss me, I'm Irish." In the United States, St. Patrick's Day is not a legal holiday, which means government offices and schools are open.

The largest and oldest parade takes place in New York City. It actually started about 250 years ago before the United States was its own country. Every year thousands of people gather to see hundreds of Irish dancers and bagpipe players march. The Irish pass dance is done in groups or solo. The dancers make complicated movements with their feet and legs while keeping their upper bodies rigid. The parade has also been a source of controversy because the parade is associated with the Catholic Church in New York City; gay and lesbian organizations have not been allowed to march. Many people protest the parade or boycott it.
St. Patrick's Day has also been associated with the consumption of a lot of alcohol, specifically beer. A drink that is often seen around the holidays is "Green Beer". This is really just regular beer with green food coloring. Many people feel that parties celebrate stereotypes about the Irish, such as the myth that everyone likes to drink and get drunk. Others complain that holidays have focused too much on drinking, with public intoxication as a problem in the major cities around the holidays.

text:
Commemoration Day is a United States holiday to remind men and women who have died while serving in the armed forces. The armed forces include all branches of the U.S. military. Those branches are Army, Navy, Marines, Air Force and Coast Guard. Commemorative Day is a federal holiday, meaning government offices, banks, post offices and schools are closed. Commemoration Day is always celebrated on the last Monday in May. Commemoration Day has its roots in the U.S. Civil War when a holiday, Decoration Day, was established to honor both the Union and Confederate soldiers who died. On Decor Day people used to "decorate" the graves of dead soldiers with flags and flowers. The name Memorial Day was more widely used after World War II in late 1940. However, the party was not officially called Memory Day until 1967.

Commemoration Day is commemorated by ceremonies in cemeteries throughout the country. The best known is located at Arlington National Cemetery, near Washington D.C. Arlington is a military cemetery, which means that only military personnel are buried there. Volunteers place U.S. flags in military tombs in Arlington and other national cemeteries. There are also parades in honour of the fallen service people held in different cities and towns. Another tradition of Commemorative Day is to fly the flag of the United States at half a person until noon, which means that it flies at half its normal height. This is considered a sign of mourning. The flag rises to its full height after noon as a sign that the military will rise despite the loss. There is also a National Memorial Day concert that takes place on the lawn of the American capital.
Commemoration Day is also known as the unofficial start of the summer season. Many beaches and pools open for Memorial Day weekend. Many people also organize barbecues on the Memorial Day weekend.

Moore was born in Flint, Michigan in 1954. His father was an assembly line worker at General Motors, a car manufacturing plant; his mother was a secretary. He attended the campus of the University of Michigan, Flint, where he left after his first year. He found work as a journalist with a couple of different local publications, but was fired from one of his jobs due to controversy. Moore wanted to publish a story about U.S. participation in Nicaragua, but its editors refused, leading to his dismissal. He was awarded $58,000 in an out-of-court settlement after he sued his employers.
Moore used the money to start making documentaries. The first was "Roger & Me", which was a piece designed to expose the closure of the Flint plant by GM and its decision to open a plant in Mexico, where wages were much lower. His film exposes greed corporations like GM by cutting the lifeline of many American workers so that GM can make more profits. GM had reported record profits before closing, which irritated Moore a lot.
He followed this film with a series of documentaries that touched on many of the social and political problems that Americans face every day. His film "Fahrenheit 9/11", investigates the aftermath of the 11/11 terrorist attacks in the United States in 2001. He is not kind to the George W. Bush administration for his lack of response to the attacks, and with the Bush family's alleged ties to Osama Bin Laden, the mastermind of the attack.

Thailand's rice bowl is now Thailand's nightmare.
The Chao Phraya River Delta nourishes the nation's vast rice fields. But on Friday, the river and its many tributaries looked at the capital, Bangkok, like a ferocious animal stalking its prey.
Monsoon rains have flooded the plains of Thailand and now the river that explodes threatens to drown Bangkok.
The water has already turned the parking lots into marinas, markets in lakes and houses into fish-only houses. It has sunk into the houses of the saints -- Buddhist temples were in the midst of rising water -- and in sanctuaries of the vulnerable.
Fifteen elephants, including seven mothers with babies and a 9-year-old child known for their painting skills, are stranded at the top of Ayutthaya's Royal Elephant Kraal. Elephants climbed to the top of the building last week and are starving now that food can only be brought in small quantities in rowing boats. Elephants can swim, but babies could drown in an attempt to escape.
In Bangkok and other bewildered towns and villages, the forts carried the weak on their backs. The young people helped the old ones.
Everyone helped each other.
It was hard to imagine that last year, the Red Shirts fought the Yellow Shirts in deadly political street protests that caused a state of emergency in Thailand and left a nation deeply divided.
The disaster brought them together again this week.
A Facebook page in English created to help foreigners in Thailand saw a frenzy of action on Friday.
Patients with renal impairment who wish to undergo dialysis may contact HSRI co. with NE Kidney Medic.

With 283 dead and 8 million others affected by the floods, fears were real in Bangkok.
The workers filled the sandbags furiously and backed up the barriers. Evacuation centres began to be filled with people.
Banjong Palim, 43, said he had never seen anything like it in his life. He was forced to flee when his suburban home in Bangkok drowned.
Some recalled the devastating 2004 tsunami that destroyed everything with water walls. And he panicked.
Ed White observed the flow of the river over the retaining walls in Ayutthaya. He stacked the furniture as high as he could in his house, and he felt fortunate that it was made of concrete and brick, not wood, like so many traditional Thai houses.
White grew up in Ocean City, Maryland. I was used to hurricanes and the fury of the Atlantic. But this was different.
The water wasn't furious. There were no torrents.
He just kept inlaying himself up. Slowly, but surely.
In the market where White cuts her hair, people run, spreading rumors born of fear. In two hours, they said, everything would be underwater. The flood was coming! The flood was coming!
White moved to Thailand in 2003 to work for a rubber company. On Friday, he said he had moved to a second-floor company apartment in Bangkok, sure he would be safe there. Meanwhile, his employer had made a fortress of the rubber factory, erecting concrete barriers around everything as if it were a war zone.
For many it was a lost battle.
The military helped evacuate them, rubbing them by boat or carrying them through the chest water.
Almost every day now, the rain has come down hard, exacerbating concerns. This is already the worst flood Thailand has seen in decades. Some wondered on Friday how much worse it could get.
The head of the Government Flood Support Center said Bangkok would be saved. But with the possibility of storms in the forecast for the next few days, Friday's assurances were hard to swallow.

The United Nations has its own flag, its own post office and its own postage stamps. However, there is no need to change currency. The UN uses the US dollar. Six official languages are used in the United Nations. They are Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian and Spanish. The UN rules prevail over the laws of New York City. This does not mean that people can commit crimes there and get away with it. There is no immunity for those who commit crimes there.

The assets in which the United Nations is currently located used to belong to a slaughterhouse. The current buildings were completed in 1952. The UN perimeter is covered with a flagpole with the flags of the 193 UN Member States and the UN flag. They are organized in alphabetical order in English.

Anti-China protesters gathered Saturday in Tokyo and six other major cities in Japan to protest against what they call an invasion of disputed islands that both claim to be part of their territories.
Protesters raised Japanese flags and sang: We will not allow communist China to invade our territory.
Beijing says that the Diaoyu Islands and most of the South China Sea belong to China, contesting neighboring countries it claims. In Japan, the islands are known as Senkaku.
The demonstration was organized by Toshio Tamagomi, a former Japanese chief of staff for the Self-Defense Force.
Japan rejects China’s demand for an apology
The Senkaku Islands are the traditional territory of Japan, Tamogami said. If we do not protect it, China will take steps to take it.
Tamogami called China a thief and promised to protect the islands.
Beijing and Tokyo have been colliding over the arrest of a Chinese fishing captain by Japan outside the disputed islands.
The captain was accused of beating two Japanese coastguard ships and obstructing public officials while they were in office.
“I am very angry with China,” Shohei Fukumoto said.
China should apologize and pay for the ship's repair because the captain was on Japan's territory at the time of the accident, according to Fukumoto.
Japan has since released the fishing captain, who returned to the welcome of a hero in China.
Yoko Sakamoto, 55, said Japan has been too easy for China.
I would like to criticize the Japanese government’s weak attitude towards the question of China and the Senkaku Islands, rather than China itself, Sakamoto said. We should regain our national pride.
The captain's arrest caused the suspension of diplomatic talks and cancelled travel between nations.
Beijing has apologized and paid compensation for the arrest, which Tokyo has rejected.
Japan has also sought compensation for damage to coastguard vessels.
Journalist Chie Kobayashi contributed to this report.

Malian authorities have found a mass grave with 21 bodies believed to be dead soldiers while a junta leader was in power after a 2012 military coup, a spokesman for the Ministry of Defence said on Wednesday.
Investigators found the bodies in a tomb near a military camp in the village of Diago, just north of Bamako, spokesman Alasane Diarra said.
Last week, General Amadou Sanogo, who led the March 2012 coup, was arrested on charges of complicity in the kidnapping.
A failed backlash soon after taking power faced two factions of the army: the green berets loyal to Sanogo and the red berets loyal to the overthrown President Amadou Toumani Toure.
At the military camp in Diago, there were green berets and red soldiers berets. “We do not know which group the soldiers belonged to in the tomb,” Diarra said.
Investigations into alleged kidnappings and killings following the military takeover that plunged West African country into chaos have been ongoing since 30 April 2012.
Investigators have been working on the case since April, so right after the coup. “They have known about the tomb for a while, but when they finally went there and opened the tomb, there were more bodies than they thought before,” Diarra said.
The bodies are all male and of different ethnic groups, he said.
As the bodies are removed from the grave, forensic investigators will begin the process of identifying the men.
The families of the soldiers who disappeared during the coup will be asked to come and identify their relatives, Diarra said.

Most of us are happy to label clouds “spongy” or “nauseabunda black ones, ” but meteorologists identify more than 50 types of clouds depending on shape and altitude. These fit into categories given numbers from one to nine. Cloud nine is the huge, imposing cumulonimbus, so being “in cloud nine” means being on top of the world.
3 Around the Rainbow
There's no better place to see a rainbow than from a plane. Rainbows occur when sunlight reaches raindrops. We see a bow because the Earth stands in the way, but, from a plane, a rainbow is a complete circle. Passing over the clouds, the shadow of the plane appears clearly at the center of the effect.
4 Mr. Blue Sky
The sunlight is white, it contains all the colors of the spectrum but, as it passes through the air, some of the light disperses when it interacts with the gas molecules. The blue light scatters more than the colors of less energy, so the blue seems to come from the sky.
5 There's life out there
Apart from clouds and other planes, we do not expect to see much directly outside the window of a flying plane, but the air is leaking with bacterial life – up to 1,800 different types of bacteria have been detected in cities and can reach twice the cruise height of an airplane.
6 Terror of turbulence
Even the most experienced steering wheel can be turned green by turbulence. The result can be anything, from repeated blows to sudden and dramatic dives. The good news for nervous flyers is that no modern aircraft has been shot down by turbulence. People have been injured and sometimes killed when they are not tied up, or beaten by poorly insured baggage – but the plane will not be hit out of the sky.
7 Radiation in flight
When body scanners were introduced at airports there were fears of radiation, but the level produced is the same as the passengers receive in a minute of flight. The Earth is constantly bombarded by cosmic rays, natural radiation from space that has more impact at altitude.
8 Jet lag cannot be cured
The world is divided into time zones. The result is that the long journey results in a difference between the local time and the time of your body, causing jet lag. However, its effects can be minimized by keeping food soft for 24 hours before traveling, drinking lots of fluids and living in your destination time from the moment you arrive on the plane.
9 Supersonic 747s
Many of us have traveled faster than sound. There are a number of jets in the upper atmosphere, especially on the U.S. journey. to Europe, where a temperature reversal causes an air corridor to move as fast as 250 mph. If a passenger plane with a speed of 550 mph enters a stream jet, the result can be to fly at 800 mph, above 740 mph of sound.
10 Fly Through Time
Time zones provide an artificial journey through time, but special relativity means that a flight involves a journey in real time. It is so minimal, however, that crossing the Atlantic weekly for 40 years would only move you 1/1,000 of a second in the future.
11 Terrible Tea
Don't blame the cabin manager if your tea isn't great. The water should be below 100°C when poured over the tea leaves, but that is not possible on an airplane. It is impossible to get water beyond 90°C during the flight, so choose the coffee.
12 I cannot hear my food
The airline's food has a reputation for being bland and insipid. However, some of the problems may not be poor catering services. An airplane is a noisy environment and there is evidence that food loses part of its flavor when we are exposed to loud noises.
13 Needle in a haystack
With modern technology, it seems strange that Malaysia's MH370 flight can disappear without a trace, but finding a missing plane is a needle problem in a Haystack. The aircraft knows its location, both from GPS and inertial tracking, but this information is not transmitted elsewhere in real time. That would be perfectly possible. Ships sailing through the oceans have been monitored since the 1980s; the limitation is not technology, but the lack of legislation that requires it.
14 Volcanic sequelae
Air travel can be cancelled by volcanic activity. The glass-like ash particles melt into the heat of the engine, then solidify into the rotors. A clear sky policy in a cloud of ashes may be inconvenient, but the risks of ignoring ash are clear.
15 The myth of the wing
For many years, we taught the wrong explanation of how the wings keep the planes in the air. In fact, most of the lift on a plane comes from Newton's Third Law of Movement. The wing has the way to push the air down. As the air is pushed down, the wing gets an equal and opposite push up, lifting the plane.
16 Forget electric aircraft
When we see ultralight, experimental and electric aircraft, it is easy to assume that there will soon be clean, green and electric aircraft, but it will not happen at any time. The fuel packages of the aircraft in a remarkable amount of energy. Batteries are much less efficient. To provide the same energy as a ton of fuel would require 100 tons of batteries, and a 747 uses 150 to 200 tons of fuel. Unless battery technology is much more efficient, electric aircraft will not take off from the ground.
17 Watch out for the vortex
Pilots often wait a long time to get clearance. This is to allow the air to settle after a previous takeoff, as the wing tips of an airplane generate vortexes in the air, which can take two or three minutes to disperse. If the next aircraft takes off immediately, the rapidly moving air would make the aircraft difficult to handle. The delay gives air time to recover from miniature whirlwinds caused by the anterior plane.
18 Doors are not closed
In practice, the doors of an airplane do not need to be closed. If you see an open plane door, it swings in an unusual way. First it has to be opened inwards before maneuvering it out of the way. Once the plane has taken off, a significant pressure difference soon accumulates between the inside of the plane and the outside. This differential forces the door in place. To open it, you'd have to throw it against air pressure, far beyond the capabilities of human muscles.

On the London subway train five years ago, the thirty-something marketing manager never imagined that his morning trip could lead to the Paralympic Games. Now, that's exactly where Martine Wright from Britain is putting his sights.
Wright lost both legs when a suicide bomber flew on an underground train near Aldgate station in London on the morning of 7 July 2005. He also suffered a skull fracture and severe arm injuries.
Although it was one of the most seriously injured that day, Wright is now targeting a spot on the British paralympic volleyball team in 2012.
