But going back to London, where I was born, and doing something so positive -- after leaving something so negative -- would be absolutely incredible.
That day, in July, four bombs were dropped on three underground trains and a bus. Fifty-six people were killed, including the four bombers, and more than 770 were injured.
The bombings occurred the day after the International Olympic Committee announced that London would host the 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games.
Wright said he made a promise to himself and his family after the attacks to seize every opportunity he could.
I think I've done more than I did before, he told ITN. I've learned how to fly planes, and I've jumped off a plane, I've learned how to ski again.

Some 640 athletes from 20 countries are participating in the event, the largest international competition before London 2012, according to Lisa Wainwright, executive director of Volleyball England, the national governing body of sport.
John Bestebroer, the lead coach of the women's team, calls the championships a great training opportunity for 2012.
Sitting volleyball is a version of the sport that allows anyone to participate, including those with a disability. The men's event has been part of the Paralympics since 1980 and the women's since 2004, according to British Volleyball.
International volleyball rules apply in the sitting version, with certain amendments for disabled players: During the game, a player should play the court with some part of the body between the buttocks and shoulders, and players are allowed to block services. In addition, sitting volleyball is played on a smaller court with a lower net.
Wright told Evening Standard in London that the 2012 Games will have an added poignancy because his last real memory before the bombings was celebrating with his colleagues when London was chosen to host the Olympic Games.

Anthony made his family farm available for people with similar ideas to have anti-slavery meetings. She was involved in the abolitionist movement until the end of the American Civil War, when slavery was abolished. She then turned her attention to women's rights.
Anthony founded a weekly publication called "The Revolution," which used to publish literature on women's rights. The newspaper's motto was "Men are their rights, and nothing more; women are their rights, nothing less."
In 1872, after travelling around the country trying to boost women's rights, he illegally voted in the presidential elections. She was arrested and fined, even though she fought. Anthony never paid the fine. The incident served to raise awareness of the struggle women had to endure. Anthony fought the good battle until his death in 1905 at the age of 84. If we look around at the things we have bought at some point in our lives, we would certainly notice that not everything we own is being put to good use: the thick wool coat that we thought seemed fashionable even though we lived in a tropical country, the smartphone that was saved when we bought the newest model, the car that is only used on weekends, or even the guest room in our house that somehow became a warehouse.
Those underutilized items may seem useless to some, but they could be an asset to others. With the advent of the Internet, online communities have discovered a way to generate benefits from the distribution of these underutilized assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the purchase and sale of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer exchange activities to take place. And this is known as the shared economy.
These democratized online platforms are providing an opportunity for people to win a dollar or two. To give an example, previously occupied parents have not bothered to establish a position on the local market or selling car boots to sell their children's old equipment, but with online markets, parents are now able to sell on those barely worn baby clothes that their children have overcome and the expensive strollers and baby equipment they have invested in, in order to put some money in their pockets.
Companies have also acquired the profitability of the delivery economy and are seeking to benefit from the use of underutilized resources. A business model that has grown rapidly in popularity sees companies providing an online platform that puts customers in contact with those who can provide a particular product or service. Companies like Airbnb act as intermediaries for people to charge in their unused rooms and houses and let them out as lucrative accommodation. Another example is Uber, which encourages people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra money in their free time.
This move towards a shared economy is not without criticism. Unlike companies, unregulated people do not have to follow certain regulations, which can lead to poorer and incoherent quality of goods and services and a greater risk of fraud. However, in the consumerist society in which we live today, increasing opportunities to sell our unwanted and underutilized goods can have a lesser impact on our environment.

Rosa Parks is an excellent example of how an ordinary American can change the world around him. He was born in 1913, in the southern state of Alabama. Parks became famous for challenging a discriminatory policy in the city of Montgomery, Alabama. During the 1950s, Black Americans in the South were not allowed to travel in the front seats of public buses if a white person needed that seat. Blacks were expected to leave their seats and head to the back of the bus, which was designated as "Only Colored."

On December 1, 1955, Parks refused to obey the bus drivers' order to hand over their seat to a white passenger who had boarded the bus. Even though Parks was sitting in the Colored Only section, the bus was full, and she was forced by law to give her seat to the white rider. Parks was arrested and charged with civil disobedience. He later said he had grown "tired of yielding."
His arrest and subsequent trial made Parks a national symbol for the Civil Rights Movement. His arrest also led to the Boycott Montgomery Bus which was a political and social protest campaign against racial segregation. Although the boycott lasted only 21 days, it was fundamental in the Supreme Court's decision to declare Alabama's practice of segregation unconstitutional.
Parks has remained a symbol for the Civil Rights Movement even after his death in 2005 at the age of 92. She has been called the "First Lady of Civil Rights," by the United States Congress, and "The Mother of the Freedom Movement." It has been honored by the U.S. government with prestigious awards such as the Presidential Medal of Freedom and the Congressional Gold Medal. She has been honored with her own museum in Michigan, and has received several other civil rights awards both before and after her death.

From all over Rwanda, and even parts of neighbouring Burundi, people go to the southern city of Butare to a small shop called Inzozi Nziza (Dulce Dreams). They come to taste the unknown, something most have never tasted: the sweet, cold and velvety embrace of ice cream.
Here, in the first ice cream shop in the Central African country, customers can buy spoonfuls of sweet cream, passion fruit, strawberry and pineapple flavors. Ingredients include fresh fruit, honey, chocolate fries and granola. Black tea and coffee are also for sale.
The store, which has “ice, coffee, dreams” through its signage, is milking local curiosity about dessert – and “changing lives” in the process, says Inzozi Nziza manager Louise Ingabire.
“Ice cream is important,” he says in between bites of a honey-flavored offering. “Some Rwandans like ice cream, but it’s something new. We still have some work to do, to tell others that they will enjoy it.”
True to Inzozi Nziza's motto, the store can certainly make dreams come true. “I didn’t have a job before: I just stayed home. Now, I have a vision for the future. I’m making money and I can give something to my family,” says the 27-year-old.
Butare, which has 89,600 residents and is 135 km south of the capital, Kigali, is home to the National University of Rwanda. Inzozi Nziza has become a center for tired students who seek to treat themselves to something fresh and different.
“It’s something that unites people here,” says Kalisa Migendo, a 24-year-old agricultural student. “If you need to go out and talk to a friend, girl or child, you come to Inzozi Nziza for an ice cream.”
Most of the ingredients are locally sourced and the milk comes from a deposit in nearby Nyanza. Vanilla beans and cocoa are imported.
Inzozi Nziza was opened by theatre director Odile Gakire Katese. She met Alexis Miesen and Jennie Dundas, co-founders of Blue Marble Ice Cream in Brooklyn, New York, and formed an association to open the store in 2010.
“An ice cream shop, Katese proposed, could help rebuild human pieces by rebuilding spirits, hopes and family traditions,” says Miesen.
At first, Miesen and Dundas owned the store in association with their staff and had shares in the business, which is a cooperative and non-profit. They did not set financial targets, but waited 18 months before transferring their shares to the women, who by then had demonstrated their commercial credentials.
The success of the store is no exception, says Fatuma Ndangiza, deputy executive director of the Rwandan Government Board. “Small businesses are mainly run by women, but when it comes to large companies where you have to compete for large tenders, very few women are there. Women are newcomers to big business,” she says. “We have more women entrepreneurs. It is an area where women are interested, both inside and outside Kigali.”
Although ice cream is something new in Rwanda, Ndangiza is excited about the idea of the store. “I think it’s great. It requires a lot of skills and changing people's mentality because selling and eating ice cream is not part of our culture. I think being able to innovate and introduce this into the market, and the process of doing so, is quite interesting.”
The Butare store employs nine women, who spend their free time practicing with Ingoma Nshya, Rwanda's first and only female drum company, which was established by Katese ten years ago.
The musicians are Hutu and Tutsi women, some survivors of the 1994 genocide, during which almost a million moderate Tutsis and Hutus were killed.
Some members of Ingoma Nshya are widows, some orphans. Others have been affected by the massacre in different ways.
Historically, Ingabire says, Rwandan women were banned from playing drums and many people considered the drums too heavy for women to carry. “But it’s something that brings unity.”
Ingabire's father, two brothers and many cousins were killed in the genocide. “Some of us are survivors; some of us know someone who was murdered,” he says. “When I’m playing with them, it gives me power because we’re still alive and alive.”
The popular restaurant is featured in a documentary by Rob and Lisa Fruchtman, film-makers' brothers. Sweet Dreams, which tells the story of how women have forged a promising post-genocide future, also includes female drummers.
The film, which has been screened in more than a dozen countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom and several African states, premiered in Rwanda in 2014. “We feel that the film is about resilience, hope, courage, ingenuity and the ability to change the course of your own life,” says Lisa Fruchtman, who won an Academy Award for film editing in 1984.

Other anonymous Twitter celebrities started their accounts to educate and bring -LRB- hilarious -RRB- consciousness to things that they cannot speak for themselves, like the fog of San Francisco that brings a cold to the summers in that city.
I love everything about the fog, said the man who created @KarlTheFog in August 2010. I think the way he hides on the hills is beautiful, mysterious and even a little romantic. I love how it stops at certain points above the city, creating a wall of clouds. And after moving here from a city where there were more than 100 degrees in the summer, I was excited not to be dripping in sweat for three consecutive months.
The man, who also requested anonymity, was inspired by @BPGlobalPR, a popular parody response to the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Through the lens of Karl the Fog, he reports on the public's feelings towards the fog and acts as a public relations representative for the defamed form of the climate - with an ingenious inclination. Karl already has over 5,000 followers.
Giving Karl an identity has drawn emphatic and sometimes superficial answers, especially when the fog blocked the July 4 fireworks, but Twitterverse has been receptive in general, he said.
- LSB- I have -RSB- a lot of time word games and haikus. My favorite tweets are when people take photos of Karl and post them on Twitter or Instagram, the man said. Seeing so many people take it and label Karl in their photos has been overwhelmingly great.
The Orange Cone
Like Karl the Fog, @TheOrangeCone loves it when followers interact with it online.
The Orange Cone was originally a MySpace account, but came to Twitter after its creator discovered the ingenious Cobra tweets of the Bronx Zoo, last year's famous escape snake, and motorsport satirist @nascarcasm. Today the Orange Cone keeps track of more than 20,000 users a day about NASCAR events.

People notice cones in their daily lives and send me pictures by hundreds, said the man behind the Cone, who asked that his name not be used. I find it funny... people stop what they're doing in the real world to take a picture of an orange cone. I love it.
He added, “Every time the cone is hit during the course of a NASCAR race, my power explodes.
When driver Kasey Kahne hit the cone during a February practice in Daytona, Twitterverse came to Orange Cone's aid.
Kasey made an apology on Twitter and I added about 1,200 followers in the next hour, she said. It was crazy.
Remaining in character
For some, the prospect of actually interacting with followers is off the table.
I'm kind of like Banksy. No one knows who I am, said the man behind the bird character @PigeonJon of bad temper, referring to the anonymous artist based in Britain. If possible, I'd like to keep it that way. He wrote CNN in an e-mail.
Apart from that statement, Jon never broke character. Instead, he offered clues to his personality.
I like cookies. I don't like Velcro, he wrote.
The person behind the popular @BronxZoosCobra, who narrates the exploits of a real-life snake who briefly escaped from its enclosure at the New York City Zoo, also refused to break character in an email exchange with CNN. The account has more than 200,000 followers.
The strangest thing that tweeted to the snake, said its creator, was a request for support from a high school student running for the student government. I backed him up, she wrote CNN. He lost. Snake intolerance at its best.
Alter egos online
Many new tweeps with great followers are bewildered by their popularity, which has led them to think about the relationship between the Internet and the real world.
“I have the feeling, and I might be wrong, that the people who follow The Orange Cone find it to be more real than some of the drivers on the track,” his creator said. They can arrive and in most cases get an answer. And the fact that no one knows who he is, which means that he could be anyone, just adds to the mystery and enjoyment.
He added the man behind KarlTheFog, I think people in the Bay Area like Karl because the fog was already a character in their lives. In a world that is becoming more and more personalized, you can surround yourself with a cast of friends on the Internet that matches your exact interests and sense of humor.
Being Karl has challenged him to think about sports, pop culture and politics in ridiculous ways, he said.
It forces me to be disciplined by sticking to a subject. Since my work is not creative by nature, it gives me the opportunity to be as resourceful as I want.
Other Twitter users say that embodying non-human entities gives them the opportunity to create alter egos. “The Cone can say and do the things I think we all wish we could do,” his creator said.
The man behind @WeirdHorse, a decidedly strange flow of reflections on, well, horse life, thinks he knows why his 137,000 followers appreciate his peculiar humor.
It's a breath of fresh air because it's not malicious, he said. It is not forced by a brand with an agenda or a political motive and is capricious, discarded and easy to digest. People respond well to that kind of thing.
Whimsical, yes. But let's be honest: @WeirdHorse may have a small agenda.
The recent demand for Strange Horse T-shirts and mugs from my site... has been another advantage, he said.

text:
There are worse things to do in life than stroll along the Copacabana beach of Rio under the sun on the way to watch a World Cup match, so maybe it wasn't surprising that England's fan Anthony McDowell of Liverpool wasn't having any of the fatality and dimness that preceded part of the tournament's accumulation in Brazil. “The place is lovely. People are great. There’s a party atmosphere,” McDowell said. “The only thing that could be better is the England team.”
He and half a dozen friends are among the crowds of supporters from all over the world who have made the beach a party area of colors and national songs. Some danced, others posed for the photos, others drank, but mostly they just walked and talked about football, hoping the next game would start on FanFest's nearby big screen. The last time there were so many people here during the day, the Pope was visiting.
The cheerful, largely peaceful mood was far from the protests, the chaos of transportation and the stadium problems that plagued preparations for the World Cup. But, now that football is well and truly underway, visiting fans are determined to enjoy the experience. “If I had known, when I started planning, how complicated and costly it would be, I would not have come. But now that we’re here, it’s great,” said Brian Hill, a retired Sunderland executive.
The trip hasn't been trouble-free. Hill travelled for more than 20 hours to reach Rio, then suffered long road delays from the airport at 6:30 am. His son, Andrew, had his sunglasses stolen almost as soon as he sat on the beach. And, they have been surprised that many bars are not installed with large screens for games. But, like many fans, they said they loved the atmosphere, if not the logistics, of this tournament that has had a spectacular start in the field.
Even the most shrewd cynic can't help but get excited by Robin van Persie's extraordinary headboard for the Netherlands against Spain. In other places, there has been an excess of goals: 28 in the first eight games, almost three times more than at the same stage in South Africa in 2010. Adding to the carnival mood in the streets, where most fans are from neighboring nations, Latin American teams won in every game they played until the time they wrote.
So far, the tournament has avoided the worst scenarios of Judgment Day, although it is far from trouble-free. Stadiums may have been delivered late and, in some cases, not completely completed, but there have been no reports of structural problems or difficulties entering the field from the start.
As in previous World Cups, tickets have been a problem, with many empty seats in several games, including the Netherlands against Spain. FIFA spokesman Saint-Clair Milesi confirmed that only 48,000 of the 51,900 seats on the floor were filled. FIFA is also investigating security flaws that allowed Chilean fans to fire fireworks during their victory over Australia.
The newspaper Globo listed a number of shortcomings in the 12 host cities. Almost all suffered worse traffic congestion than usual. The worst transport problems were in Natal, where bus drivers have been on strike since June 12. In Salvador, some travel times were five times longer than usual. “The traffic was already bad, but this week is chaotic,” Jecilda Mello, president of the group of residents of the Association of Friends of the Historic Center, told the newspaper.
However, protests have declined since the opening day, when small demonstrations took place in several cities, leading the police to use tear gas and pepper spray. Since then, the only security threat has been petty theft and overly excited fans. A spontaneous street party of Argentine fans was dispersed with pepper spray after the fans blocked the roads.
The huge distances have led to some highly contrasted World Cup experiences. The tournament has made only a small mark in São Paulo, the most populous city in South America, but far away in Manaus – the remote Amazonian city where England played Italy – visitors said the World Cup fever was in full swing with brightly decorated streets and flags waving in many cars.
FA president Greg Dyke said the mood change was palpable. “We have had a warm welcome in Manaus. It's a great thing for them, even if it's a little strange to spend so much on a stadium without anyone to play on it. But we were in São Paulo for four or five days in the run-up to the inaugural match and you wouldn't have known until the last day that there was even a World Cup. It was weird.”

text:
Help dripped Thursday, three days after a magnitude-7.7 earthquake hit Indonesia, triggering a tsunami that killed at least 311 people and left more than 400 missing.
An assessment team of the non-profit group SurfAid International had arrived in the disaster area, but the remoteness of the area prevented further contact with the headquarters in Sumatera Barat, Indonesia.
SurfAid had sent 1,000 shelter kits to the victims, and is preparing to send more supplies once communication is established, spokesman Jossi Syahrial said on Thursday.
He said that the group was working with government officials to establish an information and coordination centre for all non-governmental organizations.
The Mentawai Islands region is one of Indonesia's countless islands.
It is very difficult to reach the region either by boat or by road, said Andrew Judge, CEO of SurfAid.
The trip lasts at least 10 hours in good condition, according to aid agencies.
The Indonesian Red Cross has also sent at least two aid teams. An aid shipment included about 400 body bags.
Urgent needs are expected to include safe drinking water, food, blankets, clothing, medical care, emergency shelter and hygiene kits, said Ita Balanda, program manager of the World Vision aid organization in Padang, Indonesia.
It is estimated that 7,900 households were affected, he said.
The most affected area is North and South Pagai Island. Reports of flattened villages come from there, said Antorizon, from the Western Sumatra disaster management agency, which like many Indonesians bear a name.
The first images of North Pagai Island showed damaged and flattened structures.
Monday's earthquake generated a significant tsunami, said Pacific Tsunami Warning Center. Some of the missing persons may include missing persons after fleeing to higher ground, said Henri Dori Satoko, head of the Mentawai Islands parliament.
Although communication poses a challenge in the remote area, some witnesses in Western Sumatra reported seeing a wave of 6 meters - LRB- almost 20 feet -RRB- high. Other reports described the tsunami as about 3 meters - LRB- nearly 10 feet -RRB- high.
At least one village with a population of about 200 people was razed, with only 40 people recovered, Satoko said.
The earthquake struck at 9:42 p.m. Monday, triggering a tsunami warning. Its epicenter was 240 kilometers -LRB- 150 miles -RRB- south of Padang, at a depth of 20.6 kilometers -LRB- 12.8 miles -RRB-, according to the U.S. Geological Survey. The magnitude was revised upwards from a preliminary magnitude of 7.5.
In Mentawai, a tsunami-LSB-RSB warning was issued seven minutes after earthquake detection, which is what the existing system is capable of doing. The preliminary report indicates that the destructive waves hit the Mentawai Islands after five minutes... For the villagers of Mentawai, the warning is late, as they are very close to the source of the tsunami, said Sanny Jegillos of the United Nations Development Programme. It monitors the Indian Ocean tsunami warning system, including Indonesia.
Since then, the Indonesian government has warned residents of West Sumatra Province to stay alert and away from the coast for up to five days due to the possibility of further earthquakes, Balanda said.
The city of Padang and the Mentawai Islands are at the meeting point of two tectonic plates, making them vulnerable to earthquakes and tsunamis.
On 26 December 2004, a 9.1 magnitude earthquake struck northern Sumatra. A tsunami generated by that earthquake killed more than 225,000 people in 14 countries, mainly India, Indonesia, Maldives, Sri Lanka and Thailand. The Indonesian region of Banda Aceh was severely beaten: about 150,000 died there.
Kathy Quiano and Stan Grant of CNN contributed to this report.

text:
Egypt's revolution has made life even harder for the 80,000 taxi drivers in Cairo, struggling to make a living in the chaotic, congested and congested streets of the city, says the author who has written a best-selling book about them.
Khaled AlKhamissi's novel Taxi, first published in 2006, has been translated into 10 languages. It has 58 fictional monologues with taxi drivers recreated from their own experience. A new post-revolution English edition has just been published.
Despite Egypt's optimism after President Hosni Mubarak was overthrown in February, AlKhamissi said taxi drivers, and the rest of the country's poor, have suffered more since then.
My taxi drivers are among 55% of the population living below the $2-a-day poverty line, AlKhamissi said. That 55% wasn't on the streets during the revolution and now it doesn't have a real voice.
They're wise, they're watching, they're analyzing, but they're not acting.
He added: Life has changed for them in the wrong direction. It's worse for them because we don't have security and living on the streets without security is dangerous.
There's less tourism and more chaos on the streets.
AlKhamissi said it was too early to say whether life was improving for the middle classes who took to the streets during the revolution.
We are in the middle of a battle, and during the battle we cannot see whether life is improving or not, he said.
AlKhamissi, whose second novel Noah's Ark, also a bestseller, was published in 2009, said he stopped writing his third novel at the beginning of the uprising on January 25 of this year and has not been able to concentrate on writing since.
It is impossible to write because my mind is taken with what is happening day after day, hour after hour, he said.
Since January, AlKhamissi has filled his time with a weekly column of newspapers, conferences and speaking events. But the author wants to rewrite fiction.
Every night I want to write because it's my only job, my only happiness, he said. I have to find a solution soon or I'll die.
According to its publisher Bloomsbury Qatar Foundation, the taxi was credited with a single reliving an interest in reading in Egypt, but AlKhamissi denies that his book is responsible.
He said: Some journalists have said that about my book, but it makes no sense to say that a book or 10 books can change reading habits.
Reading has increased over the past six years, but it has taken many social factors. We have had a cultural revolution in the last six years in all matters: theater, music, fiction and editing.
This cultural revolution is related to the youth who are looking for a dream.
AlKhamissi said he dreams of an Egypt where taxi drivers can have the time and education to read his book, or anyone else.
They don't have time to read because they're struggling to survive, he said. When we can increase the quality of education and reduce poverty, then you will be able to read. I don't care if they read my book, I just hope they read something.
Another novelist accredited with the change of reading habits in Egypt is Ahmed Khaled Towfik, a 49-year-old medical professor described by Bloomsbury Qatar Foundation as the best-selling author of fantasy and horror in the Arab world. He's written over 200 books, selling millions of copies.
He said he was one of the first Egyptian authors to write for young people.
Twenty years ago there was nothing to read for 16, 17, 18 years, Towfik said. We invented popular literature. I think I made young people like to read.
I think most of my readers were in Tahrir Square. I changed a part of his thinking, although that cannot be compared to his economic disappointment or the scourge of the police system.
Towfik Utopia's book, which has just been published in English, is a grim futuristic account of Egyptian society in 2023 with wealthy communities isolated from external poverty.
Towfik said that despite Egypt's revolution, he still fears that the scenes in his book, first published in Arabic in 2009, can come true.
The first uprising came from the middle class, but I think another bloody one might come from the lower classes, as described in my book Utopia.
I still think there's a danger that my book will come true.
He added: After nine months, nothing has been achieved except getting rid of Mubarak. We got rid of the snake's head, but the snake's body keeps governing everything.

text:
After about 30 hours of deliberation, on Monday a jury convicted music producer Phil Spector for second-degree murder in the death of actress Lana Clarkson more than six years ago.
Phil Spector will not be released on bail until his sentence of May 29.
In a black suit with a red tie and a square pocket, Spector showed no reaction while the verdict was being announced. Now 69, he faces a sentence of 18 years to life imprisonment when he is sentenced on 29 May.
When asked if he agreed with the date of the sentence, Spector replied quietly: Yes.
Attorney Alan Jackson said he believed the jury had reached the correct verdict, and recognized the strength and support of Clarkson's family. But defense attorney Doron Weinberg said Spector's defense team disagreed and planned to appeal.
“We do not believe that justice has been done,” Weinberg said.
High Court Judge Larry Paul Fidler refused to allow Spector to remain on bail until sentence was handed down, citing the pattern of violence years ago that Spector involved firearms. Watch the lawyers give their opinion on the verdict
This was not an isolated incident, said Fidler, pointing to Spector's two previous convictions related to firearms from the 1970s. Taking an innocent human life doesn't get more serious than that.
Spector's wife, Rachelle, was in court to hear the verdict on Monday, just like Clarkson's mother, Donna.
Clarkson, 40, was found dead, collapsed in a chair in the hall of the Alhambra in Spector, California, a mansion with a gunshot wound to the roof of her mouth in February 2003.
A mistrial was declared in Spector's first trial in September 2007. After 15 days of deliberation, the jurors told Fidler that they could not reach a verdict. Spector was also charged with second-degree murder in that trial. Juries stalled 10-2 in favor of conviction.
To conclude the arguments in the new trial, prosecutor Truc Do called Spector a very dangerous man who has a history of playing Russian roulette with women, six women. Lana's just been sixth.
Weinberg argued that the prosecution case depended on circumstantial evidence. He said the possibility of Clarkson committing suicide could not be ruled out.
However, he pointed out to the jurors that Clarkson bought new shoes on the day of his death, something a suicide woman would not have done, the prosecutor said.
A woman who refused to be identified told reporters that the jurors considered all the evidence and testimonies to reach their verdict.
“This whole jury took it so seriously,” he said with tears in his eyes, before adding that it is difficult to be on a jury, because someone else’s life is in the hands of the jury.
Clarkson starred in the 1985 B-Movie Barbarian Queen film and appeared in many other films, including DeathStalker, Blind Date, Scarface, Fast Times at Ridgemont High and the Amazon Women on the Moon Spoof. She worked as a VIP hostess at Hollywood's House of Blues at the time of her death.
In the 2007 trial, Spector's lawyers argued that Clarkson was depressed by a recent break-up and took a 38-caliber pistol to commit suicide while at Spector's house.
But prosecution witnesses painted Spector as a weapon threat. Five women took the stand and claimed that he had threatened them with firearms. His driver testified that he heard a loud noise and saw the producer leave the house, with the gun in his hand, saying, I think I killed someone.
Spector's new trial began in October. Fidler ruled that jurors could consider the slightest charge of manslaughter against Spector.
Spector's professional trademark was the Wall of Sound, the layer of instrumental tracks and percussion that sustained a series of successes on his Philles label, named after Spector and his business partner, Lester Sill, in the early 1960s. iReport.com: What do you think of this verdict?
The roaring arrangements were the heart of what he called little symphonies for children -- including No. 1 hits like the Ronettes Be My Baby and the righteous brothers you've lost that LovinFeelin.
Spector co-produced the final album by Beatles, Let It Be, and worked with ex-Beatles George Harrison and John Lennon on solo projects after the band split up. His recording of the 1971 Harrison benefit concert for war relief in Bangladesh won the 1972 Grammy Award for the album of the year.
Spector has won two Grammy Awards and was included in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1989, but remained out of the public eye for two decades before his arrest in 2003 in Clarkson's death.

text:
Having your child physically attached to you probably doesn't sound like fun, but an American pediatrician, William Sears, promotes a parenting style that keeps young children as physically united as possible. This is called the attachment of parents.

The idea behind parental attachment is that if a young baby feels protected and secure by physical contact with his parents, especially his mother, that child will grow up to be a more independent adult. One way parents are encouraged to be close to their babies is by wearing a sling or coat to take the baby instead of putting him in a carriage. This is often called "wearing" of your baby. Parents are also encouraged to sleep with their babies. Parents are too big to fit in a crib, so instead parents are told to take the baby to the adult bed. This is supposed to teach the baby about sleep regulation, as well as since the baby will learn to imitate adult sleep patterns. However, this co-bedroom is controversial. There is concern that babies sleeping with adults may suffocate, be accidentally crushed, or fall out of bed. There is also concern about sudden death syndrome in infants, or SIDS, where babies suddenly stop breathing.
Another indicator of parental attachment is not to worry about spoiling a baby. Many times parents feel that paying attention to every cry of a baby makes them too needy or spoiled. Parenting feels that each baby's cry should be answered and that the baby should never be left to "weep." Instead, the baby should be comforted and crying should be taken as a sign that the baby needs something. Most parents who stick to the demand also breastfeed, feeling that this is not only physically healthier, but also promotes a link between the mother and the child.

text:
Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin, known by many people more as an aggrieved movie character or perceived tax evader than as a real person, has finally spoken.
In an interview with a magazine in his family's native Brazil, Saverin, a billionaire just minted after Facebook's public stock offer, spoke about his taxes, his relationship with co-founder Mark Zuckerberg and life after The Social Network.
Many observers believe that Saverin, who, according to the history of Facebook's origin was despised by Zuckerberg as the site grew, was a primary source for the book The Accidental Billionaires, on which the Social Network is based.
Surprise: Internet hates rich people
But the end result was fantasy, he said. And, no, he never threw an angry laptop at Zuckerberg as his Hollywood counterpart, Andrew Garfield, did in the movie. It is a statement Fabio Altman, from Veja magazine, writes is instantly credible given Saverin's reserved nature.
That's Hollywood, not a documentary, says 30-year-old Saverin in an interview at his multimillion-dollar residence in Singapore.
Saverin filed a lawsuit against Facebook for its reduced stake in the company, and the legal dispute was settled outside the courts. But despite the well-documented friction over the years, Saverin says he has no ill-will towards Zuckerberg.
“I can only speak well of Mark; it does not bother me,” Saverin said. His approach from day one to day is admirable. He was a visionary and always knew that Facebook would only grow if it remained true to his central idea of people who presented themselves truly and without pseudonyms.
That is the great power of Facebook that allowed it to become an instrument of protest, as in Egypt, but also as an instrument of business and, beyond that, a natural way of having contact with friends.
Saverin has had little to do with Facebook in recent years. But he re-entered public consciousness recently when, days before Facebook's actions were going to hit Wall Street, he renounced his American citizenship in favor of Singapore, where he has lived since 2009.
Many saw it as an evasion, a way to avoid paying U.S. taxes on their share of the company, valued somewhere around $2 billion. He says that is not the case and noted that, as reported, he is paying his taxes.
The decision was based strictly on my interest in living and working in Singapore, he said. I am bound and will pay hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes to the U.S. government. I already paid and will continue to pay the taxes that I owe based on my time as an American citizen.
Saverin's father, Roberto, echoed those thoughts in the article.
It was difficult for me, because of the life I was building in the United States, to hear from Eduardo that he had to give up his citizenship, he said. But he did it not because he wanted to, but because he had no other option as a foreigner who lived in Singapore, where financial transactions are more restricted and bureaucratic for those who have an American passport. There was no other way.
Roberto and his family emigrated to the United States of Brazil in the midst of political turmoil, and Saverin's registered birthplace is Miami.
Saverin continues to work as an investor and partner in Internet startups from his apartment in Singapore, where an office contains three 27-inch Mac monitors in which he constantly monitors everything, from stock prices to weather, writes Altman.
As for Facebook itself? Saverin still has his own profile, with over 1 million people subscribed to it. But he uses it almost exclusively for news about his new startups, keeping personal details to himself.
I don't like to show my private life online, he said.

text:
He won six medals at the Winter Olympics, including a gold in 2008, and a bronze a few months ago in Sochi. However, Bode Miller's methods have never been orthodox.
I've never worked very goal-oriented, admit. I think I've had some good results and I've had a long run, so, I mean, I'm happy about that. But I never had goals, like most people.
Miller has always intrigued the media and fans alike. Unconventional breeding in a New Hampshire log cabin without electricity or running water gave way to a ski race in which, for Miller, his natural talent and love of sport always won, well, winning.
In fact, his goal, as indicated in his book Bode: Go fast, Be good, Have fun was skiing as fast as the natural universe would allow.
Back home after emotional Olympics in Sochi, where Miller wept during a live interview with NBC's Christin Cooper when asked about his brother's recent death, Miller is focusing on another project: his Turtle Ridge Foundation.
Miller began the foundation after his close friend Cameron Shaw-Doran suffered a traumatic injury that left him paralyzed from the chest down.
I was trying to help him get back involved in sports. He was a great athlete before his injury and he was really having a kind of difficult adaptation, which is a very difficult process when you are hurt that way, Miller says. Just to watch it happen that I saw how difficult it was and how little support there was for him.
The experience motivated Miller to find ways to help get disabled and injured athletes more involved in sports. We offer the sports equipment for them and the environment that allows them to participate in whatever sport it is, Miller explains.
Shaw-Doran serves as team development director for Turtle Ridge, and Miller has called on friends and partners from around the sports world to create and adapt teams to help adaptive skiers and adaptive athletes in other sports.
An important annual event for Turtle Ridge is Bodefest, an extravagance of skiing and barbecue all day in Miller's territory in Cannon Mountain, New Hampshire, complete with autographs, an auction and an opportunity for children to run their idol.
Watching Miller fall down the mountain, swarming by an accelerated army of little Bodefilos, it's a wonder and a testament to his abilities that the whole thing doesn't end up in a giant human snowball.
All the kids want to try to get on the elevator with me at least one race and there are 400 kids about. It becomes a bit of pandemonium on the way down, Miller says.
Bodefest is not only a fundraiser, but it is also an opportunity for adaptive athletes to try out some of the new teams in the snow at the end of the season.
The program changed my life, says adaptive skier Owen Anketell, who has a condition that affects the muscles of his legs. I never thought I'd be able to ski even though I'm in a wheelchair -- or bicycle -- but this program has really changed my mind about adaptive sports.
The key is to empower, Miller says. When we build part of our ski team and you give it to a kid who never had the chance to climb up and experience what it's like to ski on a giant mountain and see how it can change their lives, I think it's really... it's pretty amazing.
The feeling seems to fit Miller's overall philosophy of focusing on how sport makes you feel, instead of the final game, a feeling that you think everyone is entitled, regardless of their ability.
It may not be competition, but it's a goal you can take in retirement -- and still win.

text:
When Lukas Hartmann, 29, enrolled in the genetic testing service of 23 and Me at home, there were no surprises in his results.
The Berliner learned that he would probably die of a mixture of heart attack and prostate cancer, he wrote on a friend's blog, but nothing special there.
Then, a few months ago, he received an update from the company.
Hartmann's genetic code showed two mutations that are related to the muscular dystrophy of the extremities, says the site told him. Some people with muscular dystrophy of the extremities-girl lose the ability to walk and suffer from severe disability, their results page read.
This cannot be true, he thought. Must be a mistake.
Genetic testing can be a powerful tool. You can provide information about your family history, tell you how your body could respond to different medications, and identify your risk factors for disease.
It can also be misleading.
On Monday, the Food and Drug Administration ordered 23andMe to stop sales of its $99 home genetic testing kits, saying the Google-backed company has not proven the validity of its product.
The FDA warned that clients who received inaccurate results could suffer from undue mental distress or undergo unnecessary medical procedures. The government agency has asked 23yMe to review its marketing strategy to comply with federal regulations.
The action provoked outrage among some of the supporters of 23 and Me.
So GMOs, aspartame, artificial flavors and colors, pink drool... no problem! a poster called Laura Ann wrote on the company's Facebook page. But in no way should we be allowed the right to know our own genetic material as a means of making better decisions about our health.
In a statement, 23andMe said that he has received the letter from the FDA and will work to address the concerns of the agency.
There are over 3 billion letters in our genetic code. Although it's been 10 years since the Human Genome Project was completed, scientists still don't understand what each gene does, and what a mutation could mean to someone's health.
It is one of the most often encountered problems by opponents of home genetic testing kits. If DNA experts do not understand 100% of what a genetic mutation means, how can we expect consumers to do so?
5 great things DNA tests can do
Scientists have identified more than 2,000 individual genetic disorders, says Rebecca Nagy, president of the National Society of Genetic Counselors. These are disorders that can be diagnosed based on the mutation of a single gene in the body; some examples include Huntington's disease or cystic fibrosis.
But conditions like type 2 diabetes or Alzheimer's are more complex. Hundreds of genes can contribute to the development of these diseases, Nagy says, and a person's risk is also influenced by their environment. The test of risk markers scattered in someone's genome is really just the test of the tip of the iceberg.
That's where it's a little scary, because if a person has a normal 23andMe result, they're thinking they don't have a risk, he says. It's not that the science behind -LRB- this kind of genetic testing -RRB- isn't good. The science behind them is not complete.
The advantage of these genetic testing kits at home -- and 23andMe is not the only company that sells them -- is that they have generated a lot of buzz about genetics, Nagy says. He says he believes that most of the first adopters of the tests are knowledgeable of the information and understand that the results are not in stone.
I don't think anyone thinks this kit replaces formal tests by a doctor, Heather Armstrong posted on the 23andMe Facebook page. I seriously doubt that a doctor will agree to perform, say, a double mastectomy, based on these results.
Joseph Stolarski posted, “If you find something interesting, then take it to a medical professional for an additional evaluation. No one is or should trust him for medical diagnosis.It's just a tool, like personally checking his heart rate with a clock or checking his weight on a scale.
But Nagy says she's worried about what will happen when the tests become more conventional.
Giving this kind of information to someone who doesn't know the limitations of genetic testing could be dangerous.
Nagy recommends that anyone who wants to do genetic testing first talk to a genetic counselor. Counselors have specialized postgraduate degrees and extensive knowledge of the human genome. They are also trained to explain the test results to laymen.
Our message is to be an intelligent consumer, says Nagy. Know what you're doing so that when you get the results back you can really use them for your best benefit.
Hartmann did an intense investigation, saying he looked at the raw data 23 and provided me with it. Eventually he found that he had two mutations, he says, but they weren't in the same gene. He says he filed his error report with the company and apologized.
In general, Hartmann believes that it is good for every person to have affordable access to their genetic data. But he's been looking at the community forums of 23 and Me. and has seen how seriously some people take their results, without fully understanding them.
Hartmann says he now believes he won't get muscular dystrophy in his limbs, although he says there's a risk that he can pass the genetic mutations on to his children.
I can live with that, he wrote. For quite some time, I hope.

CNN's Dorrine Mendoza and CNN's James O'Toole and CNNMoney's Aaron Smith contributed to this report.

In today's world, it's not unusual for people to get on a plane, and be halfway around the world in a matter of hours. Jumbo jets used today are common in most developed countries, but there was a time, not long ago, before air travel was even possible. That was before Orville, and Wilbur Wright built and flew his first plane in the early 20th century.

On December 17, 1903, the brothers made their historic flight to Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, officially inaugurating a new era in travel. His contributions to the new aeronautics science continued for at least 10 years after that historic day. What separated the Wright brothers from other aviation pioneers was that the brothers developed an effective mechanism to control their plane. Its three-axis control system is still in use today, more than 100 years after its development.
The first flight wasn't very long. It was only 120 feet long, 10 feet high, and only 12 seconds long, but it was flight. Orville flew the plane, while Wilbur was running next door. There were only five eyewitnesses to the flight, but one photographer captured the image in a movie, and the rest was aviation history.
The brothers were very protective of their new invention, and it made it difficult for reporters to chronicle their efforts. This led to widespread rumors that the whole thing was a hoax. Over the next few years, the brothers worked to secretly refine their flying machine, leading to further doubts. However, in 1908, the brothers took their invention to Le Mans, France, to set up an exhibition. Wilbur guided his plane by making turns and other maneuvers, which surprised the crowd. Soon, the Wright brothers were famous. They changed the way people travel.

David Goldman says he doesn't understand why he can't have custody of his son after his ex-wife's death in Brazil. The U.S. government agrees.
David Goldman is fighting for custody of his son after Bruna Bianchi Goldman died during another delivery.
Goldman told CNN's Larry King that he had no idea when he left his wife and 4-year-old son at Newark International Airport in 2004 for a two-week vacation to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, that he was about to get tangled up in an international custody battle.
Shortly after Bruna Bianchi Goldman arrived in her homeland, she called to say she wanted the divorce, which she obtained in Brazil, and would stay there with her son, Sean.
The battle for custody has taken many twists and turns and gained the attention of the State Department and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.
A child belongs to his family, and there is no reason why David Goldman should not get his son back, Clinton said in a recent interview on the NBC's Today program. And we hope that will be resolved very soon. Obviously, if not, we will continue to discuss it with the Brazilian government.
For almost five years, Goldman has struggled to regain custody of his son. It is a case that has been complicated by Bianchi Goldman marrying again, becoming pregnant and dying during labor last summer. Sean Goldman is said to live with his stepfather, who has been granted interim guardianship.
I went down... to bring my son home, Goldman said in CNN's Larry King Live on Wednesday, thinking that his ex-wife's death had made the custody issue questionable, and we discovered that this man did not file custody, but filed to remove my name from a Brazilian birth certificate that had been issued for my son, who was born in Red Bank, New Jersey.
Goldman continues to press his case through the U.S. government.
The State Department is working diligently to ensure that David and Sean Goldman enjoy their rights under the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Rights Aspects of International Child Abduction, the agency said in a statement. We will continue to insist that the Brazilian government comply with its obligations under the treaty and international law.
The Convention, of which Brazil is a signatory, is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the harmful effects of abduction and retention across international borders through a procedure for their prompt return, according to the Hague Convention web site.
Brazilian courts have refused to return Sean Goldman to the United States for any custody hearings the New Jersey courts have ordered and the Brazilian government has not intervened. As a result, the case remains a deadlock.
I'd say he's been very brave, as he's struggled to get his son back, Clinton said in the NBC interview. His son is the most precious person in the world for him and has gone not only the extra mile, but mile after mile, round and round, trying to make it clear that his son Sean deserves to be returned to him.
But in Larry King Live, Helvecio Ribeiro, a spokesman for the Bianchi family, questioned Goldman's ability as a father.
I don't question biological law, he said. The fact is, to be a father, you have to be more than a DNA donor, Mr. King. Paternity is not about making home movies and taking pictures, it's about sacrifice. It's about providing support to your child. It's about being there even when you're not there.
“And Mr. Goldman, while Bruna was still alive, did not,” Ribeiro said.
Goldman visited his son for the first time in more than four years last month, a bittersweet experience that was heartbreaking when the time came to return to the United States.
He asked me why I haven't come to see him all this time, Goldman told Larry King, and that was very, very painful -- and the anguish on his face when he asked me that question. I didn't want to tell you that... you're holding him.
International custody struggles are common and were supposed to be simplified with the 1980 Hague agreement, but conflicting judicial systems and conflicting relations may prevail over international law. The next step in this case is uncertain.

Junior Smart knows a lot about gangs. She is now 36 years old and her life can be divided into two distinct phases. He tells how in his adolescence, after his mother's death, he became a southern London gang, which, at that time, helped fill a huge void.
“They became my new support group,” he says. “At first it was just a little fun, but then it became more serious, more and more about making money. They got involved in crime. That’s how it was.” At Smart School he failed his GCSE, then returned to college and passed the lot. He secured a full-time job in the administration and worked as a DJ. But on the other hand, he was making money illegally as part of the gang.
He was finally arrested for serious drug-related crimes and sent to prison for 12 years. Immediately, he says, his sense of invincibility broke. “The first night after I was arrested was the biggest wake-up call of my life,” he says. “I had been living a dual life. I had been living as a person for my companions and another person for the enemies of my companions. I spent a lot of time solving myself.
Today, Junior Smart leads a team of 12 full-time workers and six volunteers, which aims to drive young criminals and gang members away from crime. Most of those who work there are, like Smart himself, ex-criminals. A few continue to serve their sentences, but are considered sufficiently reformed to be allowed to leave during the day to help. They work with the police, the probation service and other voluntary organizations to help those who feel trapped and frightened in the violent criminal gangs operating throughout London.
For Smart, the extraordinary trip from gang member to mentor began when he witnessed, from within, a prison system that was obviously failing its inmates. He reminds a drug addict who became friends that, to his dismay, he kept coming back. “I was moved by the people who kept coming back,” he says. “I couldn’t believe that nothing was being done about it. I was talking to the inmates and they knew what needed to be changed in their lives, but the problem is that the prison system only deals with the crime of the 'index'.”
“One guy had a cocaine habit of £300 a week, which he financed through theft. He told me things about how he'd get into a house, even when he knew there were people there. So even though he had a drug addiction, he never dealt with it. What convinced me of that is that it is simply a revolving door.”
That case and many others persuaded Smart to start working as a “listener” of the prison, a prisoner who helps reassure newcomers and speaks to them during their early days inside. From there he developed what he calls his own “little plan” to execute his own plan once out of prison, using the experience of former criminals to help others reject the revolving door of prison life. He was released early, after five years. “At the end of my sentence I had the opportunity to put my little model into practice,” he says.
So, what do you think now? Do you think that, after last August's riots and the government's promise to suppress gangs, things are getting better? He is careful to offer some praise to the police and says that much of his work in transporting gang members has been good. But in general it is highly critical with a disarticulated government approach that believes that once a gang leader is arrested, the problem is solved. He agrees with the conclusions of a report that arresting gang leaders can make things worse. He says the effect of removing the leader is often to destabilize the entire gang.
Draw a diagram of the hierarchy on a pad. “When you arrest the boss, people start fighting for the position up to the top. Who was the most loyal? Who had more respect? It's kind of like a family. They are more likely to act, through violence. It means that the arrest of gang leaders has been overturned because it has not had a long-term effect. They haven’t even given the community a break.”
Can you make the streets more dangerous? “You can do this, because in a vacuum the recruitment and manipulation of young people becomes even more frequent, creating new lower levels until the end... People take sides. If a band or other territorial street network knows that an old [leader] has been eliminated, then suddenly they think that band is weak... And that's why we have disputes between states. And what happens when that old man is in prison? He forms alliances with other gang members, or when he is released he tries to regain control. That’s when violence occurs.”
In order to spread the risk to lower levels, he said that gangs were recruiting much more in primary schools. The younger members are called “tinies”. “In recent years we have seen more and more of this. Small children can be as young as eight to eleven years of age.” Young people are brought in to protect their seniors from risk. It is often they who are accused of doing street treatment or even stabbing, he says.
Smart says that, with the lack of government funding and commitment to long-term rehabilitation, the challenges are immense, particularly in the current economic climate. “I try to involve a young man who has been earning £300 a week by illegal methods. Before, it was hard to try to convince him. But with high unemployment and cuts in profits, it makes things more difficult.”
Having said that, your project, which has more than 1,000 clients, is yielding results. Less than 20% of those who come for help repeat. From personal experience, Smart refuses to dismiss a single individual as beyond redemption and that is what drives him. “I don’t think that about anyone,” he says.

Prosecutor Rodolfo Rios Garza said the security cameras in the bar weren't working, but the authorities trusted the city's cameras in the neighborhood.

After a weekend of intense investigation, authorities are gathering more details about Friday's fatal shooting at Los Angeles International Airport, including the suspect's behavior at the beginning of the week and a warning from his family that he may have arrived minutes too late.
Officers sent to check Paul Ciancia's welfare arrived at his apartment less than an hour after the shooting began, police said Monday.
Here is a summary to update you:
Suspect
Cianncia, 23, from Los Angeles, is accused of murdering a federal officer and committing violence at an international airport.
He was shot by officers on Friday and was in critical condition at Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center on Sunday.
One source said Ciancia couldn't talk to the investigators.
Tracks on a Motivation
Attorney General Eric Holder said Monday that further investigation is needed to find out the motive for the attack.
But a note found in Ciance indicated that he wanted to kill employees of the Transportation Security Administration to instill fear into what the suspect called the agents' treacherous minds, said FBI Special Agent in charge David Bowdich.
According to someone who knew Ciancia and his three roommates well, Ciancia began asking for a trip to the airport days before the shooting. He said he needed to fly to New Jersey to help his sick father, but he never said what day he needed to leave, the source said.
On Friday, Ciancia broke into a roommate's room and demanded a trip to the airport immediately, the source said, who spoke to CNN on condition of anonymity.
The forced roommate. Investigators don't think the roommate had any idea of Ciance's plans.
The almost-saved
At the same time, Ciancia was texting family members in Pennsville, New Jersey.
One suggested something bad would happen.
Although Ciancia has no known history of mental illness, she said in the texts that she was unhappy, and the messages were alarming enough for Ciancia's father to decide to call the police.
I felt it was pretty serious. It sounded like Paul Ciancia in California was thinking of hurting himself, so obviously he knew he needed to make a phone call to the LAPD, Pennsville Chief of Police Allen Cummings told Jake Tapper of CNN on Monday.
Cummings spoke to a lieutenant there, who told him the department was in the middle of responding to a shooting in LAX.
At this point, we weren't connecting the dots, he said. They did so later when a reporter called the police chief, asking him to comment on the shooting.
L.A.P.D. Station. Andy Smith says the police were called for the first time to check Ciance at 10:06 a.m. Officers arrived at his apartment six minutes later, according to Smith.
Ciance was already gone.
The timeline provided on Monday by the police differed from that offered earlier by representative Michael McCaul, R-Texas, chairman of the House's National Security Committee. He said the police had arrived at Ciancia's apartment about 45 minutes after the suspect had gone to the airport.
According to the L.A.P.D. account, they arrived 52 minutes after the shooting, which began around 9:20 a.m., according to the police. It was not immediately clear when Ciancia left for the airport.
The attack
Around 9:20 a.m. on Friday, Ciancia approached a Transport Security Administration checkpoint at Terminal 3. He pulled a 223-caliber assault rifle out of a bag and shot TSA officer Gerardo Hernández at close range, according to a court document filed by an FBI agent.
Ciance then climbed a escalator but shot Hernández again, apparently after seeing him move.
He kept walking and shooting. Witnesses said he went from person to person, asking, "Are you from the AST?"
I shook my head, traveler Leon Saryan told Anderson Cooper of CNN. And he moved on.
Chaos and terror inside LAX Terminal 3
Victims
Hernández, 39, was the first TSA officer to die in the line of duty since the agency was established in 2001.
He was proud of his duty to the American public and to the TSA mission, said his wife, Ana Hernández.
The couple, who married in 1998, have two children.
Two other AST officers, James Speer, 54, and Tony Grigsby, 36, were injured but released from the hospital.
Grigsby, who was shot in the foot, told reporters on Monday that he was injured while helping an old man move to a safe area.
I turned around and there was a gunman, he said. He shot me twice.
A traveler who was shot in the leg, Brian Ludmer, 29, from Lake Forest, Illinois, was in good condition on Sunday.
The Police Response
TSA officers are unarmed. So it was the airport cops who finally shot Ciancia several times in the chest, also hitting him on the face and neck.
The chief of police at the airport Patrick Gannon said the FBI told him his officers were 60 seconds behind Ciance. He commended his response, although acknowledging that he had removed his officers from positions within checkpoints last year.
The threat... at the airport does not exist behind security on that podium; the threat exists from the edge, Gannon said. So... we've got our people parked all over the airport.
Holder said Monday that the investigation will include a review of security measures at LAX and other airports.
The responsibility to protect airport security is not a function of the TSA, but something I think we need to examine, given what happened in Los Angeles, he said.
Delays in travel
The incident forced the authorities to close parts of the airport, evacuate the passengers and place a temporary hold on some departures and landings.
More than 167,050 air passengers were affected by the incident on Friday as a result of cancellations, delays or detours to other airports, according to LAX. An airline, JetBlue, temporarily moved its operations to Long Beach Airport.
On Saturday, another 40 flights were affected, including 30 that were cancelled, involving some 4,000 passengers, according to Los Angeles International Airport.
According to FlightAware, a flight tracking website, airlines cancelled 236 flights to or from LAX after the incident on Friday morning and 27 more on Saturday.
Another 919 flights were delayed during the two days, FlightAware said.
However, some of these cancellations and delays may have been caused by problems other than shooting.
The airport normally operated on Monday morning.
Suspect's family responds
The Ciance family, in a statement read Monday afternoon by attorney John Jordan in New Jersey, said they were shocked and numbed by last Friday's tragic events.
It is very important for us, as a family, to express our deep and sincere sympathy for the Hernández family, said the Ciance family. -LRB- By -RRB- all accounts, Officer Hernández was an exemplary member of the police community and a good family man. Our hearts are directed to his family and to many others who mourn his death.
We also wish to convey our hope that those who were injured during this incident will recover quickly and fully. We also regret the inconvenience experienced by thousands of travelers, as well as by the Los Angeles airport administration and employees.
The Ciance family said they would continue to love and care for Paul.
We will support him in the difficult times ahead. Although we do not want to minimize the pain and anguish experienced by many other families, we hope the public understands that this is a very difficult time for our family, too, the family said.
What's next?
If convicted, Ciancia could face the death penalty or life imprisonment without parole. The U.S. Attorney General I'd decide whether to pursue a death sentence.
TSA Administrator John Pistole said the shooting has led to a review of the security protocol with partner agencies.
McCaul said better coordination with local police could improve security at checkpoints.
But the congressman recognized that it's very difficult to stop these types of attacks.
It's almost like an open mall, he said.

Kenya’s national football team may not have reached the World Cup final in Brazil, but a man will be there for his African nation.
In the role of Kenya's representative is Aden Marwa, the country's first lineman to officiate in the biggest event of the beautiful game.
Football is my life, football has made my life a big change, Marwa tells CNN.
Like many young people, Marwa became obsessed with football, often walking long distances to reach a TV set to watch a game. However, despite his passion for the game, he wanted nothing to do with arbitration and for a good reason.
These times it was difficult because a game would hardly end without a referee being beaten, he explains. Fans were noisy and you know, the facilities weren't very good.
You were playing in open fields so that the referee could be attacked at any time so that when I could see that as a child, I didn't love it. So I was scared.
By the time Marwa became a lineman in 1998 at the age of 21, however, the game had changed dramatically as more resources and education had been channeled into sport.
Once you decide you want to become a football referee there are three pillars. One is your physical state, two is your physical state and then three is your technical physical state, so you can't compromise.
In 2006, the ambitious referee got his big arbiter break in a game at the Kenya Premier League before making his international debut as an assistant referee for FIFA only two years later.
Today he has the recognition of the best arbiter assistant in the Premier League of Kenya and his talent has taken him to the sunny shores of South America for the 2014 World Cup, where he has been acting as an assistant reserve arbiter.
The 37-year-old knows that this will be the biggest test of his career so far and is prepared to have the eyes of millions of football fans reviewing each of his decisions.
Arbitrators have to make decisions in the shortest possible time. I see it once, but you, on TV, you'll see it and you'll see a repeat and you can even pause with the technology and even check it out, he says.
As an umpire I only have one angle to see him... so the challenge we have as referees, the biggest one, is how to place you in the right position and at the right time to make that crucial and very important decision.
Take a look at the video below to find out how Marwa prepared for her best time to date and earned her dream job by officiating in this year's World Cup.

When Larry Pizzi, an executive veteran of the bicycle industry, first learned about electric bicycles nearly 20 years ago, he asked, “Why would anyone want to ruin a bicycle by putting a motor and batteries on it?”
It is a question that still intrigues the traditionalists. Bicycle shops have been slow to store electronic bicycles, although they have existed since the late 1990s. Sales in the United States have been modest.
Pizzi, who is now CEO of Currie Technologies, the number one seller of e-bikes in the United States, believes that this is about to change. Others in the industry agree. Family brands such as Trek, Raleigh and Specialized offer electric models and are betting on the market is about to take off.
“We’re at the height of ordinary adoption,” Pizzi said. “It seems that there are more players who enter the category with each passing month.”
USA is an atypical when it comes to electric bicycles. In 2014, nearly 32 million e-bikes were sold, the vast majority in China, where they are mainly used for transport. They are also popular in much of Europe. They are common in the Netherlands and Switzerland; German postal workers use them to move and BMW offers one for about $3,000.
Electric bicycles are different from motorcycles or mopeds, which depend on motorized power; they are bicycles that can be pedaled with – or without – assistance from an electric motor. Riding an electronic bike feels like riding a conventional bike with a fast tail wind; the engine helps you go faster or climb hills, but is usually not the main source of propulsion. Unlike mopeds, electronic bikes are generally allowed on bicycle lanes and can travel no more than 20 mph.
There is a debate about how many electric bicycles are sold in the US. And there's no official count.
Estimates of annual sales range from 50,000 to 175,000. That's comparable to the number of electric cars sold in the US. – 118,000 in 2014. However, although many people are aware of the Nissan Leaf, Chevy Volt and Tesla, few have heard of e-bike companies Currie, Pedego or ElectroBike.
To succeed, the electric bike business in the US it must remove legal, cultural and financial obstacles. Electronic bicycles are prohibited in some states, including New York, although the law does not strictly apply. The traditionalists they own and the bike shop staff do not like to put engines on bicycles, citing, among other things, the added weight. Some e-bikes are about 30 kg.
Electronic bicycles are also expensive. While low-end models sell for as little as $700, Court Rye, the founder and editor of ElectricBikeReview.com, a popular website, says drivers should expect to pay at least $1,500 for a quality electronic bike with a good battery. First-line models cost more than double.
Companies that manufacture and sell e-bikes say they can overcome these obstacles.
Electronic bicycle technology, particularly batteries, is improving. “The batteries are getting smaller, they’re getting lighter, they’re getting more reliable and they last longer,” says Don DiCostanza, founder and CEO of Pedego, an electric bicycle manufacturer and retailer.
Companies like Bosch, the German electronics giant, and Shimano, the leading manufacturer of bicycle gears, are entering the business, which should help erode the resilience of bike shops. “This has really caught the attention and imagination of bike dealers,” says Larry Pizzi of Currie. Pedego and ElectroBike startup are not waiting for the shops to arrive; they are building their own shops. Meanwhile, lobbying efforts are being made to allow the use of electronic bicycles everywhere.
Perhaps most importantly, as more cities build cycling infrastructure, including dedicated bike lanes, cycling has become more popular. As reported by the United States Census Bureau in 2014, the number of bicycle passengers increased from about 488,000 in 2000 to 786,000 in 2012. That is a “greater percentage increase than any other mode of displacement,” the report notes. Electric bicycles make travel more practical and fun by alleviating concern for hills, winds, fatigue and sweat.
Most of our customers are “aging baby boomers who want to rekindle the experience they had as a child,” says Don DiCostanza de Pedego. “The main reason they stopped riding a bike was through the hills.” Pedego has opened nearly 60 stores in the US. and has sold bicycles to tour companies in San Francisco and Washington, DC.
ElectroBike, which operates 30 stores in Mexico, opened its first American store in Venice Beach, California in the fall of 2014 and expects to grow to 25 U.S. stores in a year. CEO Craig Anderson says: “We want to help reduce traffic, help reduce our carbon footprint and promote a healthy lifestyle.”
Startups as Pedego and ElectroBike will have to compete with large companies such as Trek and Currie, which, in 2012, was acquired by the Accell Group, a public company based in the Netherlands that is the leader of the European e-bike market. Accell has the Raleigh brand, as well as Haibike, an award-winning German electric bicycle.
“Accell has high expectations about electronic bicycles in North America,” says Larry Pizzi of Currie. “Although baby boomers are still a very important segment, we are finding that many young people are using electronic bicycles for transportation, rather than cars.”
Accell's Yuba brand even sells a cargo bike with a stronger engine and rear rack. “You can have two children,” Pizzi says. “You can carry 45 kg of shopping. It’s a minivan alternative.”

The balls have fallen down the parachute and the six numbers match, so it's time to buy that Audi, book your vacation in the US. and call the realtor. At least, that's what most lottery millionaires do, according to an analysis of spending and investment by the jackpot winners.
Since its launch in 1994, the lottery has created 3,000 millionaires who have earned more than 8.5 billion pounds in total, on average 2.8 million pounds each. The drip effect means that among them have created another 3,780 millionaires among their children, family and friends, according to the authors of the study, Oxford Economics.
Most of the winners (59%) quit work immediately, but 19% continue to do daily work and 31% do unpaid volunteer work. The good news for the economy is that 98% of the winners' spending remained in the UK. Through their spending on property, vehicles and vacations, it is estimated that each winner keeps six people on a full-time job for one year.
The winners have contributed nearly £750 million to gross domestic product (GDP), and have generated more than £500 million in fiscal revenue for the Treasury. Most of the money went to the property, with £2.72 billion spent on the main properties of the winners, and £170 million in the payment of existing debts and mortgages.
The maintenance of revenues was a priority, with £2,125 million spent on investments. Gifts to family and friends represented £1.17bn, and £680m were spent on cars and holidays.
The study, commissioned by Camelot, the operators of the UK National Lottery, to mark the milestone of 3,000 winners, was based on research of 100 £1m-plus winners. It was found that in total the 3,000 winners have bought 7,958 homes or flats in the UK, or 2.7 each, spending £3.3 billion. Most of the winners (82%) changed their main residence, spending an average of 900,000 pounds.
The new house is likely to come with a hot tub, with almost a third (29%) putting that on their shopping list. A walk-in dressing room was a necessity for 28%, almost a quarter (24%) opted for a property behind the electric doors, and 22% had a playroom, with 7% installing a billiard table.
Larger properties need maintenance, and 30% of winners employ a cleaner and 24% a gardener. A small proportion (5%) employed a beautician.
Audis were the favourite cars of 16% of the winners, with Range Rovers and BMWs also popular purchases (11% each), as well as Mercedes (10%) and Land Rovers (5%). The winners spent 463 million pounds on 17,190 cars, with the average price of their favorite 46,116.
Holidays were also a priority. Most (68%) choose five-star hotels abroad. The United States was the preferred destination of 27%, followed by the Caribbean (9%). Closer home, however, UK caravan sales have benefited. Over the past 18 years, 10% of millionaires have bought a caravan, generating sales worth approximately 7.4 million pounds.
Some winners (15%) have started their own businesses, 9% have helped others to do so, and 6% have invested or bought the businesses of others. Companies initiated or supported by lottery winners employ 3,195 people, according to the study.
Andy Logan, author of the report, said: “The effect of a victory extends far beyond what we expected. Not only does it transform the lives of friends and family, but every victory has a measurable effect on the UK economy, especially with so much of it spent in the UK. The use of each victory creates a wave effect throughout this generation and very often the next.”
