The Boston Bruins won their first Stanley Cup in 39 years, defeating the Vancouver Canucks 4-0 on Wednesday night in the seventh game and deciding on the annual National Hockey League championship.
The loss didn't go very well with hundreds of Canuck fans, who took to the streets and set fire to several overturned vehicles a few blocks from Rogers Arena, where the game was played.
Some fans stopped to pose in front of the flames. Others danced on top of another overturned vehicle. A boring cloud of gray smoke drowned some areas of the city centre.
iReport: Fires, riots and looting in Vancouver
The aerial images showed the Vancouver police wading against the undisciplined crowd who continually mocked and threw things at the officers. Members of the crowd jumped over a street fire, and officers fought several fans to the ground.
We can't release anything formal right now but the officers are busy dealing with some major groups of people determined to commit criminal acts such as pranks, vandalisms and fights, Vancouver Media Relations Officer Lindsey Houghton said in a statement.
We're working hard to get everyone home safely.
Freelance journalist Jorge Contreras told CNN that between 1,000 and 2,000 people were on the streets of downtown Vancouver, and that six police vehicles had been set on fire.
After dropping the first two games in Vancouver, the Bruins took four of the last five games of the Canucks, who fought to stay in Game Seven after dropping 1-0 in the first period.
The Bruins opened the game in the second, after rookie Brad Marchand got off on a bounce from Canuck goalkeeper Roberto Luongo to put away his second goal of the game.
We knew the second goal was going to be huge, Marchand, the 23-year-old rookie said in a post-game interview. It was nice to get that one, and we kept moving forward after that.
Marchand would finish the game with two goals and one assist.
But the game was really decided by Thomas, who polished his spectacular playoffs performance with a closed Seven game to take Conn Smythe's coveted trophy. Tim Thomas, whose unorthodox goalkeeper bewildered the Canucks all night long, set the NHL record for most of the shots faced and most of the savings in the history of playoffs.
He also broke Johnny Bower's 1960 record for most of the saves in a Stanley Cup final.
As he entered the series, Vancouver was considered the top team in special teams, especially in power moves. But that wasn't the case at this year's Stanley Cup, as Boston put five power-playing goals to the two of Vancouver. Vancouver also surpassed 10-0 in the second period.
Finally we brought our home game on the road, Zdeno Chara told Team Radio Canada. We play physics and take care of the disk, play extremely hard and pay attention to the details.
Patrice Bergeron's first goal should have been enough for fans to know the result of the game, as the team that scored the first goal won each game in this series.
The Bruins have now won the Stanley Cup six times, fourth among all NHL franchises, but they had not captured the sport's most coveted prize since 1972. They had been in the final five times since the last time they won, but this time it marked their first appearance since 1990.
The Canucks have been in the final three times in their 40 league seasons, but they have never won. Keeping the home-ice lead, they won the first two games in the series, but lost the three games played in Boston before losing home on Wednesday.
They were looking to become the first Canadian team to win the NHL title since the Montreal Canadians in 1993.

Yao Ming is one of the most influential people in the United States of America. So how does a 22-year-old Chinese man, born in Shanghai, become an international superstar, changing the way both cultures look at each other? Ming is at 7'6", which makes him one of the highest players in history to play the game, but that is not the extent of his power. Ming was tall and talented.

Ming began his career in China, where he played for the Shanghai Sharks of the Chinese Basketball Association. That was the season when the Sharks won a CBA championship. He was able to negotiate a release of his contract with the Sharks, which made him eligible for the draft of the National Basketball Association in 2002. Ming was one of the most wanted players in China, and was eventually recruited by the Houston Rockets.
Ming found moderate success in the NBA. His size and strength made him a formidable presence. He was so big and talented that he could dominate any game just because he was on the court. Ming led the Rockets to the team's first playoffs appearance in several years, but their statistical totals weren't that impressive. However, Ming was one of the most popular players in the history of the NBA. Fans loved him, and they voted him on the All-Star eight times.
Ming created some degree of resentment from other players, especially Shaquille O'Neal from Los Angeles Lakers. O'Neal was one of the most dominant players in the game for a short number of years, and in 2003, Ming surpassed O'Neal in an NBA fan vote by more than 250,000 votes. This angered O'Neal, who promised to beat Ming every time the two giants met on the court.

The United States of America is the only country to land a manned spacecraft on the surface of the moon. The first person to walk on the moon was Neil Armstrong. Armstrong set foot on the surface of the moon on July 20, 1969, in what was one of the most viewed broadcasts in the history of the country. Armstrong became an instant celebrity, whose name became a domestic word for generations to come.

The lunar landing mission was carried out on the Apollo 11 spacecraft. Armstrong was the mission commander for the historic flight, and it was the second and last mission he carried out. There were complications in the landing module Armstrong treated at the time of landing. The module was arriving faster than planned. He was destined to miss the landing site several miles away, but some quick thoughts from Armstrong prevented a potential disaster.
When Armstrong went up to the lunar surface, his words resounded throughout the country and the world: "That is a small step for man, a giant leap for humanity." Years later, Armstrong and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) insisted that the appointment was incorrect and obscured by interference. However, the quote is remembered forever in its original form.
Armstrong received the Congressional Freedom Medal from President Richard Nixon, and was later awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor by President Jimmy Carter. The program was interrupted in the early 1970s. Other countries have landed unmanned missions to the largest satellite on Earth, but to date, no other person has walked on the moon since then. Neil Armstrong, a real American hero, died in 2012 complicating a surgical procedure.

Investigators expanded their search in Texas on Monday for a 7-year-old girl who was reported missing after her mother was found dead in Oklahoma on Sunday night.
Authorities are also trying to find the husband away from the dead woman, Oklahoma State Bureau of Investigation said in a statement.
The girl -- Aja Daniell Johnson -- was reported missing from Geronimo, Oklahoma, late Sunday, the office said.
His mother, Tonya Hobbs, 37, was found dead in a caravan parked on Sunday night, the office said. Hobbs and his daughter were visiting Hobbsestranged husband, Lester William Hobbs, at his sister's house, said the office.
Lester Hobbs, 46, and Aja are missing and supposed to be in Hobbscar, researchers said they issued an amber alert to try to find her. Lester Hobbs is not Aja's biological father, police said.
Texas authorities also issued an amber alert, said Lisa Block, spokesman for the Texas Department of Public Security. Authorities believe Hobbs has connections to Rockport, Texas, and the alert was issued preemptively, he said.
Tonya Hobbs and her daughter were last seen on Saturday night. Authorities didn't say how Hobbs died, but the office said investigators believe someone killed her.
The motorhome belonged to Lester Hobbs, and was parked in his family home, Richard Goss, an agent in charge of the state investigation office in Lawton, Oklahoma, office, told reporters on Monday. Hobbsrelatives became suspicious Sunday after they did not see Tanya Hobbs or Aja, and one of them opened the door and discovered Tanya Hobbsbody, he said. Lester Hobbs and Aja were gone, Goss said.
The Hobbs were separated, but apparently Tanya Hobbs was visiting Lester Hobbs in an attempt to reconcile, Goss said. The couple had been together for about five years.
A forensic doctor was doing an autopsy, the office said, and the police want to question Lester Hobbs about his death.
He and the girl are believed to travel in his car, a 1992 white Toyota Walk with the Oklahoma label number 577-BPW. The two-door car has no hub cap, and the passenger rear window is covered in plastic, the office said.
Comanche County, Oklahoma, the Sheriff's Office said Aja has a medical condition that requires medication.
Our main concern right now is to find the girl, Sheriff Kenny Stradley told reporters. We know she needs some medicine, and the authorities were checking clues about that, she said. He didn't specify Aja's medical condition.
Goss said Lester Hobbs has an extensive criminal history, but he hasn't worked it out. Sheriff's office said he had prior convictions for serious crimes.
Lester Hobbs had to appear in court in Lincoln County, Oklahoma, on a DUI charge, Goss said, and he did not show up, so an order has been issued for him.
Aja's biological father received emergency custody from her in November, according to Oklahoma County District Court documents obtained by KWTV from Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. In an audience, Tonya Hobbs -- identified as Tonya Dunkin in the documents -- and the girl's father, John Johnson, agreed that she would have overseen the visit with Aja and kept the girl away from Lester Hobbs, the documents said.
Aja is 4 feet tall and weighs 59 pounds, Goss said. She has brown eyes, and her hair is brown with the ends dyed black.
Lester Hobbs is about 6 feet-1 and 190 pounds, with hazelnut eyes and brown hair, according to Oklahoma State Bureau of Investigation. The agency posted a photo of him and said he has a mustache but no longer has a knob.
Geronimo is about 12 miles south of Lawton, Oklahoma, in the south-central part of the state.

text:
In the Arctic of Canada, summers are marked by a bright light that bathes the treeless tundra for more than 20 hours a day. For some, it is a welcome change from the relentless darkness of winter. But, for the small but growing Muslim community of Iqaluit, Nunavut, life in the land of the midnight sun poses a real challenge during the month of Ramadan, during which Muslims usually fast from dawn to sunset.
“I have not fainted once,” said Abdul Karim, 29, one of the few in the city who has carefully timed his fast from Ramadan to the Arctic sun since he moved from Ottawa in 2011. This year, that means eating around 1:30am before the sun rises and breaking its fast around 11pm when the sun sets. “The only reason to stop would be if my health was damaged,” Karim said. Pointing out his considerable frame, he laughed as he added: “But, looking at my condition, I don’t think fasting will hurt me.”
As the end of Ramadan approaches for Muslims around the world, much of the holy month's focus on community work, prayer and reflection has been a constant in communities around the world. But in Iqaluit and the other Muslim communities in the Arctic, the long days have forced a change in how the element of fasting is approached.
Most in Iqaluit adhere to the schedule followed by Muslims in Ottawa, about 1,300 miles south of the city – following the advice of Muslim scholars who have said that Muslims in the far north should observe Ramadan using the schedule of Mecca or the nearest Muslim city. It still means fasting about 18 hours a day, said Atif Jilani, who moved to Iqaluit from Toronto in 2015. “They are long days, but more manageable.”
Many of the 100 inhabitants of the community break their fast together, meeting in the new mosque of the city, finished in February in the middle of temperatures that went down to -50C with the cold wind- for evening dinners. As they get into traditional foods like dates and currys of goat or lamb, the sun shines through the windows.
It is a scene that takes place in Canada's northernmost mosques during Ramadan, while Muslim communities struggle with the unique geography of the country. The approximately 300 Muslims in Yellowknife, in the Northwest Territories, have several options when it comes to fasting during Ramadan, said Nazim Awan, president of the Yellowknife Islamic Center, with exceptions for those who are pregnant or ill. “There may be some superhumans who want to fast for 23 hours, but the other option is to follow the intention and spirit of fasting by following nearby cities or they can follow the times of Mecca and Medina.” In recent years, much of the community has chosen to follow the Ramadan calendar of Edmonton in Alberta. Some, such as Awan, the father of two young children, including a 12-year-old boy who recently began fasting, follow the times of Mecca. He hopes to encourage his son with the most manageable schedule of about 15 hours of fasting compared to about 18 hours in Edmonton.
“If I shake the times of Yellowknife or Edmonton, my son could say, ‘Dad, you’re really crazy. What are you doing? ',” he said. In the face of the inability to follow local sun movements, the approximately 100 Muslims of Inuvik, a small town 125 miles north of the Arctic Circle, have also been following the Edmonton calendar. “We currently have 24 hours a day of sunshine,” said Ahmad Alkhalaf. “There is no sunrise or sunset.”
Adherence to the Edmonton agenda was already underway in 2001 when it moved from Toronto to the small northern community of 3,500 people. “My first Ramadan here was in December. There is no sun at that moment; it is dark all day and night. So we use Edmonton time.” “Sometimes it can be psychologically difficult to follow the clock instead of what is happening outside,” Alkhalaf said. “You are supposed to break your fast when it’s dark and we eat when the sun is out. It is not usual to have iftar [the food that breaks the fast] when the sun rises,” he said. In Inuvik, where much of the population is Inuit, the Muslim community has sought to strike a balance between Ramadan and local culture and traditions. Iftar food includes dates and rich currys, as well as local hunting such as reindeer, prepared in accordance with Islamic law. “We make a soup or curry... but instead of using beef, we use reindeer.”
In Iqaluit, as the Muslim community prepares to mark the end of Ramadan, some reflect that the 2016 schedule, which extends over some of the longest days of the year, has made it one of the most challenging in recent years. It is particularly true for those like Karim who have resolutely followed the local sunrise and sunset. “But their efforts will be rewarded in years’ time,” Karim said, thanks to the lunar calendar. Ramadan will finally fall during the winter, which, in Iqaluit, sees the sunrise and sets in a few hours each day. “I’ll also follow those hours,” he said laughing. Oh, yeah, definitely.

Berenstain Bears co-creator Jan Berenstain has died at the age of 88, according to a Facebook page dedicated to the hairy characters Berenstain and her husband created.
It is with a very sad heart that we inform you that our dear Jan died on Friday, February 24. We are grateful for all your very kind thoughts. Please remember your family at this very difficult time, said a statement on Berenstain Bears' Facebook page.
Berenstain and her husband, Stan, were already successful cartoonists when they decided to transition to writing children's books.
According to editor Harper Collins, The Big Honey Hunt, published in 1962, was the first book starring the bear family.
Since then, more than 330 Berenstain Bears books have been published in the last 50 years, the editor said.
More than 260 million copies have been sold, making it one of the best-selling series of children's books in history, Harper Collins said.
Berenstain Bears' stories were so popular that history became a special animated TV show on NBC in 1979 and then on a daily success TV series that began on PBS in 2002.
After Stan Berenstain died at 82 in 2005, Jan Berenstain and his son Mike continued writing and illustrating new adventures for Berenstain Bears, according to Berenstain Bear's Facebook page.
Berenstain lived in Bucks County, Pennsylvania, according to her editor.

Poligamous sect leader Warren Steed Jeffs, who is awaiting trial in southern Utah, was charged with eight additional Arizona felony charges in two separate cases, authorities said on Thursday.
Polygamist Warren Jeffs faces eight additional charges related to alleged incest and sexual contact with a minor.
A grand jury charged Jeffs on May 10 with two counts of sexual conduct with a minor and two counts of incest for alleged incidents in 2002, according to a statement issued by Mohave County Attorney Matthew J. Smith.
On Thursday, another grand jury charged him with two additional sexual conduct charges with a minor and two additional incest charges. These crimes took place in Colorado City, Arizona, in 2003, according to the prosecution.
Both allegations claim that Jeffs, leader of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints - LRB- FLDS -RRB-, committed the crimes as an accomplice.
Under Arizona law, sexual conduct with a minor is a class 6 offence punishable by up to one year's imprisonment. Incest is a serious class 4 offence punishable by up to two and a half years ' imprisonment.
The cases involve two separate victims, Smith said in the statement. Mr. Jeffs will not come to Mohave County to face these charges or have an initial appearance in them until his Utah case is resolved.
Jeffs, 51, is awaiting trial in Washington County, Utah, accused of being an accomplice in rape by organizing the marriage of a 14-year-old girl to her 19-year-old cousin.
The trial began in April, but Fifth District Judge James Shumate postponed it to the beginning of this year, and no new date has been set. At that time, Shumate said the delay was due to recent information in the case, but did not explain.
The judge in March rejected a defense request to move the trial out of Washington County due to press coverage, but said he could reconsider whether lawyers encounter difficulties during jury selection.
Utah prosecutors say that because Jeffs forced the underage girl to marry, and therefore forced her to have sex with the adult man, and because Jeffs insisted that she stay married, he is an accomplice to rape.
During his preliminary hearing in December, Jeffsdefense lawyers said he never knew whether the marriage he had arranged had been completed and, if so, whether the sex was consensual.
The girl, identified only as Jane Doe, testified at the preliminary hearing that she was so scared during the forced wedding.
The whole time I was crying, he said. I wanted to die.
Rape as an accomplice is a first-degree crime in Utah, with a prison sentence of five years to life imprisonment.
Jeffs was previously charged in Arizona with two counts of sexual conduct with a minor for allegedly presiding over arranged marriages, along with an additional conspiracy charge.
Those charges, in 2005, were suspended while Jeffs was facing trial in Utah.
Jeffs was captured on August 28, 2006, at a traffic stop near Las Vegas, Nevada. By that time, I had been on the FBI's top 10 wanted list for months.
FLDS freely practices polygamy in the cities of Hildale, Utah, and Colorado City, Arizona, which extend along the state line. The sect maintains groups of followers in Texas, South Dakota, Nevada, British Columbia and Mexico.
The sect separated itself from the main Church of Jesus Christ from the Latter-day Saints, based in Salt Lake City, Utah, on the practice of polygamy.
The Mormon church, which renounced plural marriage more than a century ago, has no ties to Jeffsgroup. E-mail to a friend

When it comes to deciding where the money goes, the Lotus Formula 1 team says that their top priority is the car, not the star driver sitting in the cab.
Kimi Raikkonen said last week that he decided to leave and return to Ferrari for the 2014 season because Lotus doesn't have my salary.
But the team, owned by the Luxembourg-based investment group Genii Capital, has now responded by explaining that it prefers to focus its finances on car development, even if this means seeing how its driving talent moves away.
Raikkonen has published Lotusonly's victory this year, with him and the team in fourth place in the respective classification of drivers and builders.
Our suppliers and key car developers were our priority -- perhaps not Kimi, Lotus team manager Eric Boullier, told the F1 official website.
Kimi was in a similar position last year and everything was settled by the end of the year. And Genii had a plan to do the same this year.
It's public knowledge for now that we're late to pay him, and he got angry.
To manage the cash flow -- and I don't mean the money itself or the budget we have, which is guaranteed by Genii, or at least most of it, since we don't have the revenue stream to allow us to live independently of Genii -- this cash flow is a problem if you have fixed costs and want to maintain the level of development.
You have to decide where you want to spend your money.
Genii Capital took full control of the team, which has run in F1 since 1981 under his former Toleman, Benetton and Renault costumes, from the former owner Renault in 2011.
The ownership of a private investment company, rather than car manufacturers such as Mercedes and Fiat, which owns Ferrari, or a global company such as Red Bull, can provide a more risky financial backdrop for an F1 team.
But Boullier says that the Lotusalternative business model does not mean that it is plunged into a financial crisis, as rumors circulating in sport would suggest.
Red Bull or Mercedes, those companies are sponsoring the teams, said Boullier, whose driver management company Gravity also has connections with Genii. Genii has a different strategy: they lend the money.
It is part of the strategy for partners to join the team and Genii will recover their investment.
Seventy-five percent of Lotus's debt comes from Genii. They could cancel it tomorrow by saying that this money is a sponsorship, and then our debt would be drastically reduced. Our normal debt is similar to that of most other teams.
Genii's strategy of choosing to fund the team before seeking sponsorship agreements to recover your investment is a bet.
Having world champion Raikkonen on board in 2007 would inevitably have helped attract sponsors, but now Boullier is looking for alternatives.
He says the team plans to emulate the business strategy of some rivals, including Red Bull and McLaren, looking for a sponsor of the title.
“It is no secret that for quite some time Genii has been looking for partners to make sure we can bring more money to the team and have access to a larger portfolio of sponsors,” the Frenchman added.
We must assure the sponsors, as this is the only way forward.
Formula One depends massively on people, and to attract the best people to a team you need to have money, so you can build something in the long run.
Genii's plan was to bring the team in five years -- what we're trying to do -- but to move on to the next step it takes another five-year plan instead. And that's what we're working on.

text:
One of the darkest days in American history was September 11, 2001. This is "a day that will live in infamy" for most Americans. It was the most tragic day in the country's history since December 7, 1941, when the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor. September 11 was the day when Muslim extremists hijacked four commercial planes in an attempt to destroy the American spirit by hitting those planes in four buildings. Three of the four aircraft reached their targets, while one was stopped by a group of everyday heroes who gave their lives for their country.

In the early hours of the morning of September 11, 2001, American Airlines Flight 11 crashed into the North Tower of the World Trade Center in New York. A few minutes later, flight 175, also an American Airlines flight, hit the south tower. Both suicide attacks knocked down the towers, but not immediately. It took time for the extreme heat of the burning jet fuel to weaken the towers until their eventual collapse. At the same time, American Airlines Flight 77 crashed into the Pentagon, which is a government building in the country's capital, Washington, D.C.
The fourth flight, United Airlines Flight 93, was also on its way to the capital city. Most people think his target was the Capitol building, or the White House, the president's house. A group of brave passengers, hearing the news of what was happening in the country, decided to shoot down the giant plane even though they knew they would not survive. They raided the cabin and took control of the kidnappers. The plane flew out of control, colliding into a camp in the state of Pennsylvania, where all passengers were killed.
In total, some 3,000 Americans lost their lives that day, but the American spirit was not suppressed. Those responsible for the attacks quickly faced each other, and the country soon began its path to recovery. September 11, 2001, a day America will never forget.

text:
Is this the moment when transmission becomes truly ordinary?
According to the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI), in 2014 there were only 41 million subscribers using music streaming services worldwide. It may be the largest revenue growth area for the record business, but it's still incredibly niche. Not only that, but a significant number of those subscribers come from agreements with mobile phone operators, so it is questionable how “active” their users are. Apple's biggest conjuring trick is to take something that already exists on the market – downloads (iTunes), digital music players (Ipod) and smartphones (the iPhone) – and adapt it to make it irresistible to the main consumer. The leaked information recently suggests that Apple is trying to reach 100 million subscribers, which, based on a subscription fee of $120 per year, would generate $12 billion annually. To put it in context, the entire world value of recorded music in 2014 was just under $15 billion. Apple is good at mainstreaming products, but it's not that good.
Is this the end of the discharge?
The iTunes Store arrived in 2003 (2004 in Europe) at a time when MP3 piracy seemed insurmountable. Apple succeeded in persuading consumers to pay for the downloads and grew a huge, dominant business with an estimated 70% market share. The downloads still have most of the digital revenue for recorded music, accounting for 52% of the total digital income in 2014 according to IFPI numbers. Apple has most of this, making it the largest music retailer in the world. But discharge revenues peaked in 2013 in the UK at £283 million and fell to £249 million in 2014. The decrease in download sales hit the US. in 2013 so Apple bought Beats in 2014 for $3 billion, not only to enter the premium headphones market, but also to make the transition from music ownership (downloads) to music access (subscription transmission). Apple, and the record industry, cannot afford to get rid of the download market for the moment, so transmission and downloading will have to coexist under the Apple brand, one that represents the future while the other becomes slower and sicker. The vast majority of people like music, but they don't like it enough to pay $120 a year to listen to it; a sporadic download purchase here and there is good for them. The average cost of a music buyer in the UK in 2014, for example, was only £39.52, according to the investigation. Expecting most of them to triple their annual spending on recorded music is something even Apple is going to fight seriously.
Has Apple Connect made Apple the most artist-friendly service?
Apple has previously tried to build an artist-friendly platform through iTunes. They called it Ping and it didn't work. Apple Connect is something very different, somewhere in the middle of YouTube, Facebook and SoundCloud, letting artists post music, videos, photos and more on their profile pages. It couldn't be more 2015 if I tried. Apple, partly because of its scale and also partly because it treats music as “art” rather than “content,” has generally had strong relationships not only with the music industry but with the artists themselves and, in general, has a good reputation among artists. Compare that to Spotify, which has been criticized by Thom Yorke's Radiohead artists with Taylor Swift. In contrast, Apple is like a benevolent guy. There's the smell of revolution in the air and Apple is making sure it's on the right side of the battle lines when they're drawn.
Where are the artist's exclusives?
This is going to be the interesting part when the service actually goes live. Getting exclusive to big albums is going to be crucial to the broadcast. Spotify paid a lot of money to get Led Zeppelin and Metallica exclusively. Apple will have been watching this carefully and making its own notes. You already have AC/DC and Beatles catalogs exclusively to download to iTunes, but it remains to be seen if you can persuade these two to make the jump in streaming. He also managed to get Beyoncé's surprise album in 2013 before anyone else, so it's inevitable that he wants more like this. There is a lot of speculation about Apple seeking exclusive rights for Adele's new album.
Giving iTunes the exclusive download on an album wasn't a big leap of faith for acts given how much of the download market it controls, but trying to do that on streaming isn't the same. Add to this the fact that streaming now counts towards the album's chart in markets like the UK and USA. and artists, who still see the letter as a measure of success, will not want to limit their audience by restricting themselves to a single service.
Is this gonna kill Spotify?
Some people are already saying Apple Music will destroy rivals like Spotify. However, it is not that simple. Apple is entering a market where others have been working and gaining experience for many years. He's got a lot to do to catch up. The winner of this battle will not be the company with the best service; it will be the company with the most money. Apple's competitors have an advantage in the market, but they are losing huge amounts of money. Spotify, for example, lost €93.1 million in 2013. Apple, on the other hand, began 2015 becoming the most profitable company in corporate history, with $178 billion in the bank. If Apple Music loses money from Apple, the company will not continue for long, but will not stop the investment without at least trying to beat the competition.

text:
At the age of 16, my innocence was shattered when two gunmen murdered 13 people in my school and injured many others.
Columbine High School promised to be a safe place to learn. And that promise was broken on April 20, 1999.
That morning, I went to school worried about my tenth grade math exam and my next track meeting. Useless concerns: The test was never given and we never held the meeting.
The scars have remained since that day that no one can see. Scars that made my concerns about math tests or follow-up performance pale compared to whether my scientific partner would live or whether my classmate's speech would be affected by the shrapnel lodged in his skull. Today, those mental scars are pounding in large crowds and forcing me to scan the room for exits. They make my heart beat faster when I hear the blades of a helicopter above it.
Now, as a teacher in my eighth year in the classroom, I consider every day I'm going to work a privilege. I appreciate the joy and enthusiasm of my students, and most importantly, their innocence.
I think it's our job, as a society, to protect these virtues in our young people. I want you to worry about math tests and follow-up meetings and science fairs and student council elections, the kind of normal school stuff that builds character. But our epidemic of armed violence is creating a culture of fear in our schools, where students are anxious for safety and intruders. These are concerns that no student should have.
This becomes even more evident when we perform our monthly emergency drill at our school. It's a way to be prepared for the worst, so we practice closures, fire drills and evacuations.
The other day, I was explaining to my third graders that we were going to practice a lockdown just in case a bear was in the playground... a real setting for our Colorado school. I have used this example all my teaching career because it is an easy and non-threatening reason to practice a blockade.
A girl raised her hand and asked: Is this what we would do if a bad boy came with a gun to hurt us? I felt kicked in my stomach when I heard this question. A bear is no longer the worst thing students can anticipate: they fear what is happening in our nation.
It is a shame that my students learn these exercises at such an early age, a shame that they learn them at all. I thought, this is the result of the Columbine shootings, along with many other acts of violence. This is my reality, and now it's theirs too.
It's a sad reality, but we're not helpless. I teach at a wonderful school, which has done everything within its resources to keep our students safe. But it's not enough. If there was a simple solution, then this epidemic of violence would have ended. The solution is complex, multifaceted and achievable. I believe that a global approach can help ensure a safe learning environment.
â $cents Our children deserve more mental health resources to identify, treat, and track people who need help.
â $cents Our children deserve greater school security: This includes identifying who is in school and sensible steps to keep the building safe -- without bringing weapons to the learning place or turning it into a fortress.
â $cents Our children deserve common sense weapons legislation: I think this should include a ban on high-capacity magazine clips. And at the very least, it should include comprehensive and mandatory background reviews to help keep weapons out of the hands of dangerous people. Unfortunately, our Congress refused to take this step of common sense and rejected this legislation.
The shooters at my school got their guns illegally, through private sales and straw purchases. Today they could easily go online and buy those same weapons without a background check. What is it to stop the next person who chooses to do exactly that?
We can do better.
I think I can speak on behalf of all of us that the murders at Columbine High School, Aurora cinema, Sandy Hook Elementary, and so many others surprised us to the bottom and created lasting feelings of sadness. But we cannot let these events create feelings of vulnerability. We have the power to work together to create a safer world for our students.
Learn from my experience -- don't wait until you experience first-hand violence to realize that we need to take action. We have to take action now.
The opinions expressed in this commentary are only those of Katie Lyles.

text:
Seven police officers were killed and nine injured on Tuesday in a series of attacks on security checkpoints in the western Iraqi province of Anbar, police said.
The attacks occurred in the city of al-Rutba, a predominantly Sunni Muslim community that for a few years was an al-Qaeda stronghold after the U.S.-led invasion of the country in 2003.
In Tuesday's first attack, a suicide car bombing at a police checkpoint in the north of al-Rutba killed four police officers and injured three others, police officers said in Ramadi, the provincial capital.
Later, armed men attacked several security checkpoints in the city, killing three police officers and wounding six, the police said.
No information was available on the accidents of the attackers, beyond the suicide bomber. Al-Rutba is about 435 kilometers - LRB- 270 miles -RRB - west of the country's capital, Baghdad.
Also on Tuesday, a car bomb exploded near a crowded market in the centre of the Iraqi city of Musayib in Babil province, killing one person and wounding 11, police said in Baghdad.
Musayyib, a largely Shiite village, is about 70 kilometres (LRB-43 miles) south of Baghdad.
Iraq has seen a sharp increase in tension between its Shia and Sunni populations since April, when security forces raided a place used by Sunni protesters to protest against the Shia-led government.
The Sunnis, who represent a minority of Iraqis, have felt politically marginalized since the overthrow of Saddam Hussein in 2003. Shia make up the majority of Iraqis.
So far in 2013, more than 6,000 people have died in Iraq. More than 350 of those deaths occurred this month, and nearly 1,000 occurred in September.
Journalist Mohammed Adnan de Falluja contributed to this report.

text:
Maria is sitting in a black plastic chair in a community center in a cold Tuesday afternoon waiting for them to call her number. She's number 34.
When it comes to her, Maria is called to pick up a bag of brown paper full of essentials, including pasta, eggs and corn flakes, and is invited to choose between pumpkin or carrots like this week's vegetables.
Maria is the 34th “client” to date in East Hampton Food Pantry, a community initiative set up a few blocks away from some of the world’s most expensive and exclusive properties. At the end of the day, the pantry organizers expect more than 400 families to have followed Mary through the gates to pick up their weekly meal package to help them overcome the cold and dark winter of Long Island.
In summer, the Hamptons, a collection of historic seaside towns and villages 100 miles from Manhattan, is a multimillion-dollar playground. But, Labor Day comes in early September, when the rich and famous close their mansions and return to Manhattan or Beverly Hills, the glow gives way to the sandy reality of life for the mostly immigrant community living here all year round. “The people who come here are rich and famous, but we who live here are not,” says Maria, who works 14 hours a day in summer cleaning mansions but spends months without any work in winter.
Maria laughs when asked if she has enough money. “There is no work in winter, only in summer,” says Maria, who, like many workers in Hamptons, is from Latin America. “Here, many people live in a single room because they can’t afford the rent.”
She says that some families with up to five children are crowded in basements and still pay more than $1,000 a month for rent. “People come here looking for work but, in winter, there is nothing.”
Many of his friends can't afford heating or medication and many would starve if it wasn't for the East Hampton food pantry, he says, which is just one of several food pantryes in the city.
Vicki Littman, president of the East Hampton food pantry, which provided more than 31,000 food parcels in 2015, says the number of people looking for food pantry is increasing. “Once Labor Day arrives and the season ends and people’s hours begin to shrink, our numbers amount to about 400 families a week,” he says. “When they come to us on Tuesday, they receive two to three days of food. Without us, they would fight much more.” Littman says it can be difficult for outsiders to realize that there are people struggling to survive in a place known to the world for their excess.
“When I discuss with the summer community that comes here about food breads, they are always surprised because there is that glamorous side of the Hamptons where there are galas and the beaches and mansions that are here. “But what people don’t realize is that there is that service industry. It's the landscapers, the nannies, the waitresses, they all depend on that summer income to spend the winter, but people don't see it when they go on vacation.
“There are older people who sometimes have to choose between paying for their medicines or paying their bills or buying food, and that shouldn’t be the case.”
Littman says the city has lost too many people working on key jobs – such as teachers, police, and even doctors and dentists – because they cannot afford to live in the community and the pantry board is determined to do more to ensure that people have a better chance of staying. Housing is by far the highest cost in the Hamptons. At $147m, the nation's most expensive property is 18-acre Barry Rosenstein hedge fund manager facing the sea at 67 plus Lane, a stone's throw from Maidstone Golf Club, which is considered "the most elite, prestigious and difficult to enter" of all Hamptons clubs.
Larry Cantwell, an East Hampton city supervisor and a lifelong resident, says that households regularly switch hands to more than $25 million and the rapid price inflation at the top end has been reduced to the city's most modest floors.
“Finding your first home is a challenge in an area like this,” says Cantwell. “Not only the people you would characterize as poor, working and middle-class families are also having a hard time. If you can find a house to buy anywhere in East Hampton for $500,000, you are very lucky.” Cantwell says that more than half of the city’s houses are empty for most of the year, which makes the population decrease to just 10,000 in the winter months compared to 80,000 in August. “It’s kind of a history of two cities. There is certainly a lot of wealth here, but almost all that wealth is in second homes only used in the summer,” says Cantwell, the son of a fishing father and a house cleaning mother. “But, the rest of us live here all year.
“There are famous and very rich people, but then there are working and poor people who struggle to survive. It should be remembered that this community was founded as an agricultural and fishing community of people living on land and water, a true working class community.”
Cantwell says saving enough money to buy his first home while working as a farmer or fisherman is almost impossible in East Hampton today “and it’s not just the poor – cops, teachers, young professionals and others all struggle to find a place to live here and many of them can’t afford to have their own home.”
Being homeless in the Hamptons means spending a lot of time on a bus. Several houses of worship have come together to make sure there is somewhere where homeless people can spend the night during the winter. Churches up and down the north and south fork of Long Island assume the burden one night at a time and approximately 50 homeless people are transported between them every day. Eddie Vallone, 22, is one of those on the bus every night. “People see the Hamptons as some kind of rich town and there are no problems. But there are a lot of problems here, especially drugs.
“It’s hard to understand –”OK, summer is coming to an end. What am I going to do for winter?'' Vallone says in Maureen’s Haven, a charity that coordinates the homeless shelter program. “I want to work, but there is no work to do.”
Vallone, who works cleaning pools and doing occasional jobs on luxury estates, says that if she saves well and doesn't buy by impulse, she can make her summer profits extend until November. “But the work doesn’t start again until May or early June.”

text:
Why do it? Talking to men destined to be the elite referees of the future, the question provokes a conscious smile. This season, criticism of referees has increased to the point where some former referees have felt compelled to complain about the rules. That is quite surprising because, the more you talk to referees, the more obvious it is that leaning on each other through thick and thin is fundamental.
Then why do it? Why spend countless hours driving around the country to eliminate the rules, some of which are inevitably going to bother people, trying to climb the ladder until you have the opportunity to make decisions on television in front of millions of people who examine you and your ability with the help of umpteenths of different angles and slow-motion reproductions?
A look at an answer appears on Lee Swabey's face moments after he blows the final whistle of a 2-1 victory for Grimsby over Woking, a match at level 5 of the English league system. He gets what all the referees expect every time they submit a game. Twenty-two handshakes, he then proudly explains. Symbolically, a complete set of handshakes, plus a “well done” of both managers, represents maximum satisfaction. “The buzz,” as he calls it, of a game that passes smoothly, is something he loves. “I wouldn’t spend so much time away from my family if this didn’t mean anything to me.”
As one of the groups that is highly regarded by the Professional Game Match Officials Limited (PGMOL) for its potential, Swabey knew it was being watched in that game. PGMOL chief Mike Riley was present, along with Steve Dunn, who is the coach of this level, armed with notes and chronometer to catalogue every significant movement that officials make.
A few weeks earlier, Riley, Dunn and another former referee, Peter Jones, made their way to another level 5 match to monitor another arbiter inclined to progress: John Brooks. “I hope to have the opportunity to ascend the Premier League and officiate some of the best games in this country,” Brooks says.
Most of PGMOL's delegation could observe, however, was the way Brooks handled the somewhat complicated situation of cancelling the game due to a frozen pitch. It's all part of the experience Brooks needs to acquire before more high-profile games are entrusted to him, the different problems they need to deal with – often, clubs are very reluctant to have a late postponement, especially when they have to pay for all the staff that has appeared but won't receive any door money.
Brooks called his coach to ask for advice and made the difficult but correct decision. A little later, the secretary of the football club arrived with envelopes to pay officials for their time – the match rate at level 5 is £95, so it is safe to assume that these men do not do it for cash.
Brooks, like Swabey, has clear ambitions for progress. It is under no illusion that developing thick skin and perfecting strategies to deal with disappointments is a large part of that. How does it feel to watch football on TV when a referee is vilified? “Erm... it’s not great,” he admits. “I have been in that situation once I have made an incorrect decision and was a decisive target that was out of place. Your heart is sinking. You can't stop thinking about it.
“Sometimes I want people to understand the time and effort we put in. It is very easy to criticize a decision, but we do everything we can to make these decisions right. In certain situations, you’re going to be unpopular but, if you’re uncomfortable with that, you’re probably in the wrong job.”
The former referees agree that the support, education and tools that referees have today is a world far from what they experienced in their own days. Riley, as a young referee, went out and bought books on psychology and nutrition, as there was no information offered to him.
Contrast this with Brooks, who has a coach at the end of the phone. They consult weekly, discuss how their games have gone, study images of key decisions and discover how to improve. It also has the support of a sports psychologist, Liam Slack, for regular guidance and an exercise regimen to help you manage the 11 km you run during a game.
Brooks says psychology is vital in its development. “One of the things we’ve talked about is forgetting decisions and moving forward,” he explains. “There can be a big decision to make in the first 30 seconds of the game. Once you have done that, you need to stay focused for the next 89 minutes and not be wondering if that was right or worrying about that decision. Liam has taught us some techniques to release that decision. Working with the sports psychologist is very important for mental hardness.”
Jones believes that the whole approach can only help. “I referred to professional football but, looking back, I was an amateur,” he says. “I was going to work – I worked for British Telecom – and I could be a referee in Newcastle on a Wednesday night and, at 9 a.m. the next morning, I was in Leicester trying to talk to customers. Maybe I hadn't slept. The training was special. We were amateurs in a professional environment compared to now.”
When the issue of technology arises, the three former referees are unanimous in their support for it. “We are all in favour of anything that improves the referee’s work and makes them more effective in the field of play,” Riley says. Minimizing errors is the goal. After all, a bad decision can stay with you for a while. “The rest of your life,” Jones says with a laugh.

text:
Yesterday Stephen returned from a trip to Washington, D.C., the capital of the United States. His visit took place during the week before 4 July. Logically, there were many activities and celebrations in the city in preparation for Independence Day. During his stay in the city, Stephen visited many historic sites and important monuments, and left with a deeper understanding of the political history of the United States.
Stephen spent a lot of time outdoors exploring the important monuments surrounding the Capitol. Of course, he saw the White House from his outside door on 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. Stephen also visited the Washington Monument, the Jefferson Memorial and the Lincoln Memorial. These statues and pavilions are dedicated to former American presidents. They commemorate the contributions these leaders made throughout American history. One of the biggest barriers during the childhood of air travel was the speed of sound. It was considered impossible to build and fly a plane that could exceed this speed, but that was before the world was introduced to Chuck Yeager. Yeager was already a combat pilot consummated in World War II, but his greatest achievement was after the war when he served as a test pilot for the United States Air Force. It was thought that it was impossible to fly faster than sound during that period, and no one knew if a pilot could survive flying at that speed, or how it would affect him if he survived. But that didn't deter Yeager.

Yeager was born on February 13, 1923 in Myra, West Virginia. He served during World War II as a combat pilot. However, he did not start as a pilot. Yeager enlisted as a soldier who worked as an airplane mechanic in the former Army Air Forces, where Yeager enrolled in a special program that trained enlisted men to become pilots. Yeager benefited greatly from having a higher view. He was considered a natural pilot at the beginning of his flight career.
As a fighter pilot at the European Theatre, Yeager was shot down in France by German fighter planes. He avoided capture, and helped a fellow pilot to be safe after the pilot had lost his leg in the accident. Yeager was awarded a medal for his actions. He showed exceptional talent as a pilot and once shot down five enemy fighters in one day. After the war, Yeager began a new race as a test pilot, where he flew the experimental Bell X-1 aircraft in the history of aviation.
On October 14, 1947, Yeager flew his X-1 faster than the speed of sound. He became the first human to fly faster than sound, and continued to break more records during his 60 years of flight history. Yeager retired from the army with the rank of Brigadier General, and has earned many honors for his contributions to aviation.

text:
The American Revolution was a war of independence waged by those living in the 13 colonies of North America against Britain. Those who lived in the colonies were especially angry at the taxes the British were forcing them to pay. People felt that taxes were unfair because there was no colonial representation in the British parliament. One tax was the stamp tax, which taxed printed materials as newspapers. The settlers called this "imposition without representation." The settlers who wanted to free themselves from English rule were known as Patriots. Those who supported the British government were known as loyalists. Before the large-scale war broke out, there were many acts of protest by patriots, such as the Boston Tea Party when the Bostonians boarded British ships and threw 342 boxes of tea into the port due to a tea tax. On April 19, the first shots were fired in Lexington and Concord, Massachusetts, which officially started the war.

Many people participated in the struggle for independence. Benjamin Franklin, Thomas Jefferson and John Adams worked together to write the Declaration of Independence. On July 4, 1776, the patriots declared themselves free. Most people know that George Washington was the first president of the United States. Before that he was the commander-in-chief of the patriot army. Most of the battles in the American Revolution were fought in the northeast in places near Boston and New York.
The British, known as red coats because of their red uniform jackets, were assisted by German mercenary soldiers called Hessians. The patriots had the support of other Europeans. France entered the American Revolution on the colonists' side in 1778. This helped force British surrender in Yorktown, Virginia, in 1779. However, the struggle would not formally end until 1783 with the Treaty of Paris, when Britain recognized the United States as an independent nation.

text:
You could see it in his eyes.
Even before Pope Francis spoke his first words to the crowds of St.Peter's Square, he could look into his eyes and feel the wonder.
The world looked at him. But he also looked at something: on all those scrambled faces. With all eyes looking at him.
Nothing can prepare a person for such a vision.
In this life, there are moments, and then there are Moments. The first appearance of a new Pope on the balcony of St.Peter's Basilica has always been a moment like no other.
Before telegraphy, before radio, before television, before the Internet, before Twitter, the vision - the solemn orchestration - of a newly elected Pope standing on the balcony was the most dramatic way possible to bring great news to the world.
Somehow it still is.
“I would like to thank you for your embrace,” the new Pope said, looking into all those eyes.
When authors and speakers have sought ways to express the last example of reverential exaltation, the scene periodically repeated in St.Peter's Square, over the centuries, has often been the one they have addressed.
Tom Wolfe, in his book The Right Stuff, on Mercury's original astronauts, wanted to describe to readers the level of devotion that the newly appointed astronauts had received from the American people. The seven pilots had been precisely that -- combat pilots, test pilots -- before being selected for the space program. Suddenly, they were something else. People saw them and started crying.
Wolfe came up with the only ideal analogy to portray the phenomenon:
The kids wouldn't have cared about the following. They would not have cared to appear once a year on a balcony over a huge square where half the world meets. They greet each other. The world roars its approval, its applause, and it breaks in a storm of thirty minutes of cheers and tears... A little flattery in the order of the Pope; that is all the True Brothers at the top of the pyramid really wanted.
But humility is not required by combat pilots and astronauts. Nor is it required of rock stars or professional athletes or any of the many other public artists, in disparate places, who are regularly presented with carefully planned and commercialized majesty designed to elevate them in the eyes of their audiences.
A Pope is different, and his introduction to the world is like no other. When Wednesday morning dawned in Rome, a man named Jorge Mario Bergoglio was one of millions of people preparing to begin the new day.
When the day ended, he was no longer Jorge Mario Bergoglio, and he was no longer one of the millions.
As Pope Francis, he climbed that balcony and was received by that view.
From behind his glasses, he took everything.
The eyes of the world met theirs.
He asked for prayers.
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of Bob Greene.

Thousands of people protested on the beaches of Australia against a shark massacre in Western Australia. They asked the state's prime minister to stop the sacrifice, and RSPCA Australia and Virgin Atlantic owner Richard Branson criticized him. The capture and killing of sharks over three metres began after several shark attacks on the west coast of Australia. A 35-year-old surfer, who was killed in November 2013, was the sixth person to die of a shark attack in two years.
But all of Australia has had, on average, a single shark-related death a year over the past 50 years. Kate Faehrmann of the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society said of a protest in Perth, the capital of Western Australia: “We have always said that this idea will not work. The drums, used to catch sharks, kill sharks if they are one, two, three meters or more, and also dolphins, turtles and other things. That’s why we don’t want the sacrifice.”
Thousands of people protested on the beaches of Perth, Sydney and Adelaide, and on the beaches of Victoria and Queensland. Faehrmann said the protests showed that Australians wanted sharks to be protected: “The amazing thing is that so many people in Australia love sharks. This has shown that people are scared, but thousands of people are going across the country to say, ‘That’s the ocean of sharks.’ We respect them, we love them and we don’t want them killed.’ Anthony Joyce, a surfer who once had his foot stuck in a shark’s mouth, said: “The number of sharks they’re going to kill is not going to make any difference.”
The state government will not say how many sharks they have killed, but some people say that sharks under three meters were released after they were caught on drums, floating drums fixed to the seabed with bait on hooks under them. Conservationists say there is no evidence that the sacrifice reduces the number of shark attacks on humans, because no other sacrifice has only used drums. Researchers at the University of Western Australia say that the increase in the number of shark attacks in the state may be due to the fact that Western Australia has the fastest growing population in Australia, not due to an increase in the number of sharks.
Richard Peirce of the UK-based conservation charity Shark Trust said the sacrifice would not work and could bring more predators to the coast. “The activity in Western Australia is in addition to the human tragedy of shark attacks. It is very sad that a government has ignored the best advice and chosen an ineffective and counterproductive method,” he said, “and, although they monitor drum lines during the day, leaving the lines at night could attract other predators to the area, attracted by those sharks and other species attracted and injured.”
Around the world, in 2012, there were 80 shark attacks. Seven of the attacks were fatal. This compares to nearly 100 million sharks killed by humans each year. RSPCA Australia says she thinks the sacrifice is wrong. “There is no evidence that the increase in attacks is the result of an increase in the number of sharks. We believe it is the result of a change in the population and a change in human behavior; that is, there are more people in the water,” he said.
Richard Branson said the idea wasn't working. “I’m sure one of the reasons Western Australia’s Premier Colin Barnett did this was because he was thinking it would promote tourism. He's gonna do the opposite, I think. You are announcing a problem that does not exist in a big way and you will stop people from wanting to come to Perth and your beautiful field around you. All you’re going to accomplish, I think, is worry people.”

The 32-year-old boy from Pasadena, California, recently filed a petition at Change.org asking Disney to make an animated character from a pangolin, a little-known and scaled mammal that is notoriously shy and, according to Kit, can protect himself from almost anything in nature -- lions, tigers -- rolling in a ball.

Disney could give the pangolin the celebrity he needs to survive.
I encourage you to sign Kit's petition on Change.org.

She doesn't think she can persuade her father to change, but younger generations may be the ones saving animals like pangolins and rhinos, she said.

text:
The problem with Google Glasses, Takahito Iguchi says, is that they are not great. He's right. There is already a website dedicated to people who use them look ridiculous or cocky or, more often, both. It probably wasn't Google's smartest move to launch the first 10,000 pairs to software developers instead of, for example, supermodels or Scarlett Johansson. Google Images search and one of the first hits is an image of a big, naked man taking them in the shower. And this is what Iguchi, a Japanese businessman, hopes can be Google's Achilles' heel. He's throwing a competitor that's a little more stylized. A little more Blade Runner. A little more Japanese.
Iguchi's augmented reality goggles, which are actually not as much glasses as a single piece of metal with a camera and microprojector, are called Telepathy One, and after unveiling them at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Texas, they have attracted $5 million venture capital. Like Glass, Telepathy One will be launched in 2014.
It's a stripped, simplified version of Google Glass. While Glass is, he says, “a selfish device” with a wide range of uses – it can navigate the network, read emails, take photographs, do unspecified things with yet unspecified applications – Telepathy will be “more than one communication device.” Connected via Bluetooth to your phone, it will focus on real-time visual and audio exchange. You can post photos and videos from your line of view on Facebook or send them as email. Or watch and talk with a floating video image of a friend.
“It will help you get close to your friends and family. We are very focused on the possibilities of communication and sharing,” says Iguchi, who has worked in the Japanese technology industry for 20 years, the most recent of which is developing a location-based telephone application called Sekai Camera.
Of course, not everyone wants to approach the man in the futuristic headphones, I point out. Iguchi shakes his head. “I am a visionary. I have a dream that people will understand other people. When I go to London, I'm a stranger. Sometimes I feel scared. But I think everyone wants to be understood and understand each other. And, with this device, you can learn more about people before you even talk to them.”
Compared to Google's tastes, of course, Telepathy is a minnow. Not that this seems to dazzle Takahito Iguchi. In his shared office space in San Francisco – a fresh and converted warehouse in the heart of the land of startup, full of 20-year-olds – he quotes Sun Tzu's Art of War and points out that even small armies can sometimes defeat powerful forces. When it was growing, Japanese technology ruled the world: the Sony Walkman was the iPhone of its time. Now, to compete, he had to leave Tokyo for Silicon Valley.
“Tokyo is very rich in fashion and culture, but it is still an island. He's isolated. There's no way to expand. Whereas, in Silicon Valley, they're all from everywhere. It’s where you come to connect globally.” Hardware will be done in Japan, while he’s gathering a team of software engineers in the US. to develop their applications. The day I meet him, a Japanese news crew is following him and is interested in the new wave of Japanese businessmen who are forced to leave their homeland.
We're losing our confidence, correspondent Takashi Yanagisawa tells me. “And we need to find a way to regain our power. Iguchi is like the new border. We hope it can be a new solution. Building the prototype of Telepathy One was easy, says Iguchi. “We have all kinds of technology in Tokyo. He is presenting it to the world that is the challenge.” The main manufacturers line up to work with him, he says, because they have the technology, they just struggle to sell it. “There has to be a story for the product. Like Apple did with the iPod – 1,000 songs in his pocket. And the way they positioned themselves against Microsoft and IBM was like the story of David and Goliath. And Steve Jobs was inspired by Akio Morita, Sony’s co-founder, and he inspired me, so he might come in a circle.”
Maybe. He certainly has the confidence of Jobs, although, with a strong Japanese accent, he sometimes struggles to make himself understood, a fact that may have contributed to the conception of Telepathy One. When he went to London to present the headphones at the prestigious Founders Forum, he stayed at an Airbnb. “The owner of the house was not my friend, but I talked to him for three hours, and now he’s my friend. That is the time it takes to understand, to share our feelings, background and career. Maybe telepathy makes it shorter. If you are getting information from the cloud and social media, that will happen more easily. And this man is involved in getting investments from the UK to Africa, and he was very excited about telepathy, which would be a way to educate people about Africa, to show them the point of view of other people.”
This is Iguchi's most affectionate hope – that seeing someone else's literal point of view will help you see his metaphorical point of view. As a student, he explains, studied philosophy by day and was taught to code at night. “And one day, I opened the door to my apartment and suddenly realized that everything is code. That was my enlightenment. Everything is encoded and shared among humans. And everything can be coded and decoded. And, if the code is interchangeable among humans, that will end all war between them.”

text:
Millenniums in the workplace
Background
The millennials (born between the early 1980s and the early 1990s) constitute a large part of our workforce, but seem to lack loyalty to companies and leaders for those who work. Multinational companies are seeing higher millennial turnover rates as employee retention rates decrease. This report analyses the results of two large-scale surveys on the mentality of the millennial generation and explores how organizations can strive to address these needs, increase employee engagement and encourage retention.
Research
In a global survey conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), more than 40,000 millenaries (born between 1983 and 1993) were collected and non-millenary responses on the themes of workplace culture, communication and working styles, wage structure, professional development, work-life balance, etc.
In a separate global survey conducted by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials participated in a study on their perceptions of threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.
Main findings
Millennials are as committed to their work as their senior colleagues.
The millennia value interesting work and a good balance between work and life. They do not believe that demands for excessive work are worth sacrifices in their personal lives.
Millennials want flexibility in their working hours and are willing to give up wage increases and promotions for flexible working hours. They believe that success should be measured by productivity and not by the number of hours seen in an office.
The Millennials want to feel supported and appreciated by their company and superiors.
Millennials want more opportunities to develop their skills. These include technological skills, teamwork and interpersonal skills.
Millennials believe that companies and business leaders should contribute to the improvement of society and are more likely to be loyal to a company with strong ethics.
Recommendations
Organizations and administrators wishing to retain millennials should consider:
Monitor your workload and levels of satisfaction with your work-life balance
create a flexible working culture in which employees have more control over their working hours and workplace location;
provide meaningful work and interesting opportunities
offer help and support in continuous professional development
change the organization's objectives from primarily profit-making to reasons that address social concerns and address broader social problems.

text:
Robert Mysłajek stops dead. Between two footprints on a muddy mountain track, the scientist finds what he's looking for. Get down! He was excited. Wolf sightings are so rare that the sighting of his feces marks a good day, even for an experienced tracker.
But it's getting easier. It is estimated that there are now 1,500 wolves in Poland. The number has doubled in 15 years. Wolves are, along with the brown bear, the lynx and the worm, the last major carnivores in Europe. Conservationists in Britain, Germany and the Netherlands are beating a road here to discover how the country has saved this protected species, slandered even in fairy tales.
Pieces of bone and hair stand out from the precious black feces. “He ate a red deer,” says the University of Warsaw biologist. “In my lab, I can tell you all about this wolf, not only his diet, but also his gender, sexual habits, age, state of health and family connections.”
DNA tests have established that Polish wolves are travelers. “A wolf arrived in the Netherlands, where unfortunately he was hit by a car. They have tremendous reach. They need space. The average territory required by a Polish package is 250 km2,” Mysłajek said.
“Is there any chance that we can ever reintroduce wolves into Scotland?” asks student Alex Entwisle, 23, on a trip to southern Poland from his university in the UK. Animal science students have spent the day observing excrement and footprints in the Beskidy Mountains of the Polish Carpathians.
Their hot topic of discussion is whether to reintroduce wolves into the British Isles for the first time since the 18th century.
As a guest of a British charity, the Lobos and Humans Foundation, Mysłajek toured the Scottish Highlands in 2015 and took questions from the villagers about the Polish experience. “The big difference between Scotland and Poland is that we eat pork. We don't have many sheep here.
“The similarity is that we have many animals – 300,000 red deer and more than 800,000 deer. In Poland, we also have a massive overpopulation of wild boars – some 200,000 – and are devastating farmers’ cereal crops. Here, wolves are part of the solution,” he says.
The scientist, who is a familiar face on Polish television, says that wolves are exceptional animals that are able to move up to 30 km during a single hunt. “The Beskidy package is a strong unit, eight or nine individuals. This year, we have registered five puppies, two aged and two adults.
“We tracked them using motion-activated cameras in the forest and following their tracks in mud and snow. In each family group, only one pair is reproduced once a year. All the members of the herd care for the young with solidarity and devotion.”
Mys łajek, the son of a shepherd, is bewildered by the bad reputation of wolves. “Why is there talk of a lone gunman? Why did we have to have Little Red Riding Hood?"
He is fascinated by these distant canines that remained in nature 33,000 years ago, when others decided a much more comfortable existence as domestic dogs.
Wolves aren't faggots. Mysłajek says that only scientific arguments – the need to regenerate forests and control the wild animal population – can save Europe's wild carnivores, especially the unpopular wolf. “Natural predators balance the ecosystem. They keep the herbivores under control, thus allowing the trees to grow tall so that the birds nest in them.”
Shoot the deer? “It’s just a partial solution,” he says. “In a diverse environment, you have the so-called ‘landscape of fear’, where herbivores no longer spend all day grazing in the tender grass on the riverbank. They move away, as a precaution, to avoid being caught by a predator. This gives vegetation a chance.”
The ban on wolf hunting in the Western Carpathians came into force in 1995 and throughout the country in Poland in 1998. There are now resident packages in virtually every major forest in the country. Predators coexist with humans instead of being surrounded, as they are in African safari parks.
The Polish government pays compensation for cattle killed by wolves. Mysłajek advises farmers on the construction of electric fences. It has helped revive the use of two deterrent elements that, for reasons that no one understands very well, the wolves find particularly frightening: the red buzz (hanging around sheep pens) and the crust of the spongy white sheep of the Tatra mountain.
The survival and mobility of the wolves of Poland have been helped by the late development of the country's infrastructure. In 1989, when the communists renounced power, Poland had only one highway. Following Poland's accession to the European Union in 2004, major road projects were launched requiring impact studies on wildlife. The country now has one of the highest densities in the world of crossings and underground crossings for wild animals.
Attitudes have also changed. “For many years, hunting was cultural. In 1975, there were fewer than 100 wolves in Poland. Beginning in the 1950s, the authorities had encouraged wolf hunting. They paid a reward for killing a wolf that was worth a month's pay. It was a butchery.”
Mysłajek says that the improvement of the chances of survival of Polish wolves has been considerable, but remains fragile. The packages are mobile across borders and hunting still continues in neighboring Russia, Lithuania, Belarus, Ukraine and Slovakia.
He claims that Poland's new government, elected in October 2015, is hostile to wolves. “The Minister of the Environment, Jan Szyszko, makes no secret of being a hunter. There are 120,000 authorized hunters in Poland and they are influential in parliament.
“ Hunters claim that wolves are a plague and that there are 4,000 of them in Poland, which is a spurious figure based on a non-scientific recount. This government is capable of reversing.”
Being a wolf advocate isn't easy. “It’s not like you can argue to politicians that wolves are a great tourist attraction. Most tourists want to see animals but wolves stay away from humans. They have a tremendously sensitive sense of smell.
The 12 British students of animal science leave the Polish Carpathians without a sighting of wolves; only photographs of footprints and excrement. Entwisle is convinced that Scotland will never be able to match Poland's success.
“It would be amazing for the environment to have them back because of the problem of too many deer. But it would not be viable because of the roads and the sheep.
“There would be problems with farmers. We had our industrial revolution too long ago. We ruined it for ourselves. In Britain, we like predators to be far away and watch them on television, Entwisle said.

text:
The third Monday of January is an American federal party, Martin Luther King Jr. Day. It falls near the birthday of the civil rights leader, who was murdered in 1968. King, a minister, made himself known for protesting not violently against the treatment of African Americans in the United States and the laws that discriminated against Black people. Specifically, King protested the segregation that separated blacks and whites in public baths, public pools, public schools, buses and restaurants. King led many marches in the United States, especially in the South, where segregation was practiced and enforced, and in Washington, D.C. His march in Washington, D.C., was perhaps the most famous, where he delivered the speech "I Have a Dream."

On Martin Luther King Jr.'s day, federal, state, and local offices are closed, including public schools and post offices. During the holidays many people participate in marches and vigils remembering Dr. King. Others use the day as a day of service and volunteer in their community cleaning garbage in a local park or serving food to the homeless. However, the party was controversial. Some states did not want to honor Dr. King and tried to change the name of the holiday or combine the day with another holiday.
Only two other people have a U.S. national holiday, Christopher Columbus and George Washington. Martin Luther King Jr. Day became a party in 1983 after pressure from civil rights activists and marches, similar to what the king used to lead. Efforts to create a king's party began the same year King was murdered. The first state to recognize King's Day as a holiday was Illinois. The last state to recognize the party was Arizona.

text:
The first time I went to Libya in 2010, I was arrested two days after my trip. Filming a documentary for VICE, I was stopped for shooting where the authorities thought I shouldn't, starting endless rounds of questions, screaming emphatically and pushing my head with disbelief at my claims of innocence... and, of course, the necessary implications that I was a spy. When I was finally released, I swore I would never return to the Great Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya. But that promise quickly broke, and I found myself back in the country almost exactly a year later, in the midst of a chaotic and violent revolution.
My second trip to Libya was to travel from the Egyptian border to Benghazi and then to the front lines in Misurata, embedded with some different rebel groups along the way. I was surprised by the youth of many of them. Just after puberty and struggling with what they could find - LRB- a guy had a spear gun -RRB-, they showed so much heroism and courage that he broke me while talking to them. A rebel I spoke to had left the hospital that night -- despite losing a leg -- so that he could return to the front. An NGO offered him a flight to Germany and a new prosthetic member, but instead he snuck out of the hospital to meet with his comrades.
But the big question that was coming up above all was: Why are they fighting?
All those I asked -- bankers, shopkeepers, students, construction workers, oil engineers and former Gaddafi loyalists -- offered the same answer: Freedom. It was like the end of Braveheart every time a rebel looked into my eyes and said so. A 16-year-old boy told me he'd die so the others could at least breathe outdoors. Ugly things for a teenager, especially when most rebels are not old enough to have known a political system other than Gaddafism. Risking your life for freedom is one thing. But risking the concept of freedom is something else.
See the rest of Libya's rebels at VICE.COM
When we finally reached Misurata, he was surrounded by Gaddafi's troops and only accessible by sea. Little by little we head to the front, stopping periodically to talk to the rebels. A 15-year-old boy I met was preparing a Grad-missile truck for battle. Beaming wondered if he could ask Clinton and Obama for new weapons so they could beat Gaddafi and fulfill his dream of playing for the Miami Heat or the Dallas Mavericks. As we talked, I was surprised how much I had changed in such a short period. This was a different Libya than I experienced last year, a completely new country.
