text:
As the outrage over a Sudanese woman sentenced to death for refusing to renounce her Christianity grows, the government defended the verdict, but said it is only preliminary.
Last week, a Khartoum court sentenced Miriam Yehya Ibrahim, 27, for apostasy or renunciation of faith.
Ibrahim, who is eight months pregnant, is a Christian, her husband said. But the court considers it Muslim.
I'm so frustrated. “I don’t know what to do,” her husband, Daniel Wani, said. I'm just praying.
100 tabs
The court also convicted her of adultery and sentenced her to 100 lashes because her marriage to a Christian man is considered null and void under sharia law.
Wani is an American lawyer, Ibrahim's lawyer, Mohamed Jar Elnabi, told CNN.
The lawyer said he'll file an appeal in a few days.
Fatih Izz Al-Deen, spokesman for the Sudanese parliament, said the verdict is not final and is in the hands of the judiciary.
The verdict will pass through all judicial stages to reach the constitutional court, the speaker told the radio station Um Dorman. His comments were quoted on Friday by the Sudanese official news agency.
Ibrahim says he was born to a Sudanese Muslim father and an Ethiopian Orthodox mother. Her father left when she was 6 years old, and was raised by her mother as a Christian.
However, the lawyer representing Ibrahim's family said on Sunday that the mother is a devout Muslim.
The court had warned Ibrahim to give up his Christianity by Thursday, but he held fast to his beliefs.
But the speaker in parliament said that the claims that she was raised as non-Muslim are false.
She is a Muslim raised in an Islamic environment and her brother, a Muslim, filed a complaint against her, according to Izz Al-Deen.
The complaint alleges that he disappeared for several years and his family was surprised to learn that he had married a Christian, according to his lawyer.
However, because her father was a Muslim, the courts also considered her one, which would mean that her marriage to a non-Muslim man was null and void.
Attempts to contact the Minister of Justice and the Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Sudan were unsuccessful.
Pregnant with a child in prison
Ibrahim's husband is struggling to survive.
He uses a wheelchair and depends entirely on it for all the details of his life, said Jar Elnabi, his lawyer.
In addition to her pregnancy, the couple's 20-month-old child is with her in prison, and he is receiving regular ailments due to lack of hygiene and the presence of insects, the lawyer said.
She is having a difficult pregnancy, and a request to send her to a private hospital was denied, the lawyer said.
There is also the question of the timing of a possible execution.
In previous cases involving pregnant or lactating women, the Sudanese government waited until the mother weaned her son before executing any sentence, Christian Solidarity Worldwide Kiri Kankhwende spokeswoman said.
Global condemnation
Foreign rights groups and embassies around the world condemned the verdict.
The fact that a woman can be sentenced to death for her religious choice, and to flogging for being married to a man of a supposedly different religion, is abhorrent and should never be considered, said Manar Idriss, an Amnesty International researcher in Sudan.
Katherine Perks of the African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies said the verdict goes against Sudan's own constitution and commitments under regional and international law.
The foreign embassies in Khartoum, including those in the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada, urged the Government to reverse the course.
CNN's Catherine Shoichet, Christabelle Fombu, Mohammed Tawfeeq and Mohammed Osman contributed to this report.

text:
Julie was tired of living with her parents. He was 22 years old and just finished college. She started a new job in an office, and she didn't want her parents to tell her what to do more, so Julie decided to start looking for an apartment. He started by looking at classified ads in the paper and reviewing websites like Craigslist.

The first apartment he went to see sounded perfect in the paper. It was announced as a cozy one bedroom apartment with views. He made an appointment to see the apartment. When the landlord opened the door, Julie was very disappointed. The cozy bedroom barely fits a double mattress and a bedside table. The window really offered a view of a brick wall.
Julie didn't lose hope. The next apartment you saw was announced as having a renovated kitchen. Since Julie loved cooking, she imagined cooking gourmet meals in shiny new kitchen appliances. However, the corridor that showed Julie explained that the only renovations were new knobs in old wooden cabinets. Julie was starting to lose hope. He then saw a list of an apartment in the basement with access to a low maintenance yard. Julie imagined organizing barbecues for her friends until she saw that the low maintenance yard was a small slab on concrete.
Julie decided to stop looking for apartments that had characteristics she liked. Instead, he was going to look for an apartment near his job. He read a list of a studio near a highway. This meant a shorter journey. When he saw the place, he found that the studio really overlooked the highway, and traffic could be heard from the bedroom.
Julie was discouraged. She decided not to move yet.

text:
Ronan
I work in a pretty traditional office setting doing a typical nine to five job. I like my job, but it's annoying that my trip to work takes an hour and a half each way and most of my work could really be done online from home. But my boss doesn't seem to trust that we're going to do any work if they leave us to our own devices, and everyone in the company has to go in and out every day. It is frustrating that they feel the need to monitor what we do so closely rather than judge ourselves on the basis of our performance of tasks, as most companies do these days.
Jo
I used to do a typical five-day week, but after leaving my maternity leave, I decided I wanted to spend more time with my kids before they started school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to reduce my workweek to three working days. This, of course, meant a major cut in my salary as well, as I am paid pro rataly. However, since then I have realized that my workload has not diminished in the slightest. Now I'm doing five days of work in three days, but I get paid a lot less for it! I find myself having to take the work home just so I can meet the deadlines. I'm getting tired of trying to juggle about taking care of my kids and my family, but I don't dare talk about this with my boss because I think it feels like he made a big concession letting me come here just three days a week.
Marcus
I work for a global IT company, but because its headquarters is in the United States, I do all my work online from home. That means I don't waste time commuting or idle chatting with colleagues. I work on the basis of a project, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The disadvantage is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the night, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task. It can also be pretty lonely working on my own, and sometimes I miss sharing ideas with colleagues.
Lily.
I'm a freelancer and I work for myself. This is great because I have control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it very difficult to concentrate. There were too many distractions around: household chores I needed to do, another cup of tea, family members who wanted my attention for various things. So I started going to a café close to work, but the Wi-Fi connection was not ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a coworking space with five other freelancers like me. I liked dressing to go to work in the morning and be able to concentrate on an office environment. Other freelancers do similar types of web-based work for me and so it's good to have coworkers to bounce ideas off too.

text:
The small space is configured to resemble a classroom. Its corrugated iron walls are hung with educational letters – illustrated letters from the alphabet and a map of Bangladesh.
But, the constant sound of hammering and chemicals in the air that trap in the back of the throat and irritate the eyes make it difficult to concentrate. However, the children who learn in this three-square-meter room are the lucky ones. They've escaped working in factories across the street.
For 14 years, SOHAY, a grass-roots non-governmental organization funded by the Global Fund for Children and Comic Relief, has been working in slums in Dhaka to get working children to attend school. It focuses on children working in dangerous conditions: in aluminium and plastic factories and in tannery.
The classroom is one of the 23 urban development centres that SOHAY has established throughout the capital. The centres prepare children for primary school with classes that help them catch up in their education. Once they are in primary school, children can do their homework in the centers, with the help of their peers.
Ten-year-old Alamin, who worked in a plastic factory, attends one of the centers. Her father is a street vendor and her mother is a part-time domestic worker. Everyone is happy that he is now in school and away from dangerous work. His friend Rabi says he wants to forget his past at the factory. “I like school,” he says.
“Urban development centres aim to create a favourable educational environment in communities and change their cultural mindset towards children,” says SOHAY program director Mohammed Abdullah al-Mamun. SOHAY also organizes sessions for parents and employers to discourage child labour and provides training to increase family income.
“Introducing child workers into formal education is really a challenge,” says Mamun. “His psychological and physical condition is not like the other children in society. After leaving work, they sometimes find it difficult to make friends and adapt to school. It is also very difficult to make sure they stay in school – the dropout rate is very high for these children. In this context, it is important to work with schools to make them more sensitive and concerned about them.”
Zhorna Akter Sumayya, seven years old, has two older brothers, both at work (one at a restaurant and one at a local club). But, after being introduced to education in one of the SOHAY centers, now he goes to a state primary school. His family lives in the poor neighborhood and his parents cannot survive without the income their children bring home. Her father works in a rickshaw garage and her mother is a domestic worker, but they were interested in her daughter going to school.
In 2015, SOHAY helped 1,540 children leave hazardous jobs and 2,125 vulnerable children – those at risk of entering work – at school. Some 780 more children are preparing to enter school in 2017. The organization is also helping 635 children working in hazardous conditions to know their rights under the Bangladesh Code of Conduct for the Elimination of Child Labour 2010. The policy aims to eradicate all forms of child labour by 2015, but this goal has not been achieved.
Bangladesh ' s Labour Act 2006 prohibits children under the age of 14, but according to the UN Children ' s Agency, UNICEF, 4.7 million children under the age of 14 work in the informal sector and 1.3 million children between the ages of 5 and 17 work in hazardous industries.
“It was difficult to take them to school without any compensation for their time,” says Sadia Nasrin, who runs Sonjag, another grassroots NGO in Dhaka. “To overcome this challenge, Sonjag began working closely with the community in the slums where children live.”
The organization talked to community members about why it was important for children to enter school. They selected community volunteers motivated to change children's lives and formed groups with social workers, community leaders, mothers, youth volunteers and local government.
“Groups play a vital role in motivating employers to let children drop out of school for two or three hours a day and to ensure a safe workplace for children. The main agents of change are the people of the community,” says Nasrin.
He adds that people living in slums face threats of eviction, police raids and displacement. “The national plan of action for children does not recognize the needs of street children,” says Nasrin. Legislative measures are limited.
When children have lost school at the age of five, it is a race against time to prevent them from growing up without education. “After crossing school age, it’s really very difficult to admit them to school,” says Mamun. “Children are spending their time without education and waiting to participate in dangerous jobs. We are working to block the flow of child labour.”

text:
Carl Sagan was possibly the most famous American astronomer in history. He was an astronomer, scientist, author, cosmologist and television presenter. His historic show "Cosmos" was one of the first scientific shows to win acceptance by the general public in the United States. Sagan challenged Americans to think of their place in the universe as no other person before him. Using the scientific method, Sagan challenged long-standing beliefs about the genesis of life on earth. This has been done to the enlightened scientific community, and to the wrath of the religious community. Many of Sagan's teachings contradict the creationist belief of the beginning of life. He was also interested in the search for life beyond planet earth, and participated in the only human message sent to space destined for an alien race.

Sagan was born in Brooklyn, New York on November 9, 1934. His interest in science began at an early age. He wrote and co-wrote 20 books, and published over 600 scientific research papers. His most popular work was "Contact", which tells the story of the first contact with an intelligent alien species. The book was made in a 1997 film starring Jodie Foster. The book and film irritated many religious groups because of their message that humans are not alone in the universe.
Sagan obtained his bachelor's and master's degrees in physics from the University of Chicago in the 1950s. His scientific curiosity led him to develop the television series "Cosmos". It was one of the most watched scientific series, and has been recreated and is currently in the air. His work on the Galileo project continues today. The spacecraft is accelerating its way through infinite space today with its message of greeting to any race of beings that finds it. Sagan died at the age of 62 from complications resulting from pneumonia.

The United States is also home to many of the best colleges and universities in the world. The California Institute of Technology is a world-class university that focuses heavily on science and engineering. It is located in the city of Pasadena. It is located in the state of Massachusetts. University of California, Los Angeles is another recognized institute. Located next to Hollywood, UCLA has distinguished itself as a prestigious and selective university due to the number of people applying for admission across the United States. The above-mentioned universities are just some of the many other excellent schools that make America so outstanding.
America is also known for being at the forefront of freedom and equality. Although our history may be contradictory to these ideals, we have progressed and now live in a land of equal opportunity. Whether you want to become a doctor, lawyer, or librarian, America is the best place to be in achieving these dreams.

text:
The worst secret kept in Formula 1 is finally out, Fernando Alonso leaves Ferrari and will be replaced by Sebastian Vettel.
Red Bull's four-time world champion has signed a three-year contract with Scuderia, F1's oldest team, starting in 2015.
After finishing his five-year period in Ferrari, Alonso remains shy where he will drive next season.
The double movement of two of the world's high-profile sports champions is the most significant in this season's driver market.
But in the fickle world of F1 there is no guarantee that it will work for any of the ambitious runners.
There are still seats to fill in McLaren, Force India and Toro Rosso. With the curtain about to fall in the 2014 season in the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix on Sunday, hopeful drivers only have one more chance to bet on the remaining seats.
Where's Alonso going?
Alonso is considered to be the best driver of the entire route today at the elite level of motor racing, a fact that many of his companions are even happy to recognize.
The Spanish, the world's double champion with Renault in 2005 and 2006, is considered the key to the F1 driver market.
The 33-year-old made it clear that he wanted to leave Ferrari, although he had two years left to run in his contract with the Italian team, but he has not yet confirmed where he will go next.
A return to McLaren seems very likely, despite his bitter departure from the team after a single season as a teammate of Lewis Hamilton in 2007.
McLaren is about to embark on a new phase after restarting its relationship with the Honda engine manufacturer.
Alonso is expected to lead this new era in McLaren, although the fiercely ambitious driver may first want assurances that the Honda engine will be a success.
Keeping the media guessing about their future -- and perhaps also their future employers -- seems to have provided Alonso with a lot of off-track sport.
Speculation in the media has seen Alonso linked to the purchase of the Lotus team, joining forces with German specialists in Audi sports cars and even evicting Nico Rosberg or Hamilton in Mercedes.
Alonso remained typically tight about his future plans when he was interrogated by the media at the end of the Abu Dhabi season.
Has Vettel made the right decision?
Vettel has endured his worst season at Red Bull in 2014, failing to win a race compared to three wins for his novice team-mate Daniel Ricciardo.
Since his full season debut with Toro Rosso in 2008, the German has won at least one race a year, not to mention winning four consecutive world championships between 2010 and 2013.
The 27-year-old now hopes to succeed where Alonso failed in Ferrari by adding to his collection of world titles.
The next stage of my Formula 1 career will be spent with Ferrari and for me that means that the dream of a life has come true, Vettel said.
When I was a kid, Michael Schumacher in the red car was my biggest idol and now it's an incredible honor to have the chance to drive a Ferrari.
I'm very motivated to help the team get back to the top. I'll put my heart and soul into making it happen.
Vettel will partner with Kimi Raikkonen, the last man to win a world title with Ferrari in 2007, but there is no guarantee that the car and its Ferrari engine will be any match for the power of Mercedes.
Who's driving for McLaren?
McLaren has tried to dampen speculation about who will be in their cars in 2015 in the accumulation of this weekend's end-of-season race.
We know you're expecting news from our driver alignment. We'll announce it after December 1. They'll hear it here first, the team said on Twitter.
Alonso is still the hot-red favorite to take one of the seats, but the future of the current drivers Jenson Button and Kevin Magnussen remains unclear.
Button, the 2009 world champion with Brawn Grand Prix, who has since become Mercedes, has remained optimistic about his future and has even explored the idea of moving on to sports car racing.
Danish rookie Magnussen is fiercely passionate about staying with McLaren, the team that gave the 22-year-old his F1 debut in 2014.
There is no Plan B, the Danish told CNN when asked if he had explored his options if he was not held back by the eight-time world champions.
What other teams have seats to fill?
Mercedes, Red Bull, Ferrari, Williams, Lotus and Sauber have confirmed their pilot pairs for 2015. There are still seats in McLaren, Force India and Toro Rosso.
Force India has already announced that it will keep the German Nico Hulkenberg by 2015, but Mexican Sergio Pérez has not confirmed his position with the team.
There is also a single seat for sale in Toro Rosso, which blooded 17-year-old Max Verstappen as the youngest F1 driver in history next season.
Red Bull Junior driver Carlos Sainz Jr is in pole position for the second seat -- and the Spaniard has been named as a test driver for Red Bull at the end of the season test in Abu Dhabi -- although Toro Rosso can still retain French driver Jean-Eric Vergne.
Sauber announced Swede Marcus Ericsson and Felipe Nasr as his 2015 pilots in November, to the great displeasure of the current driver Adrian Sutil, who believed he had a contract with the team for the next season.
Ericsson and Nasr are payment pilots, backed by sponsors who provide an estimated $30 million funding to the Swiss team.
Is the grid reduced to 18 in 2015?
The F1 market may be flooded with a lot of anxious runners, but the number of seats has been tightened.
Financial pressures on Caterham and Marussia teams, which entered the administration in October, mean, in theory, that there are only 18 points in the F1 network in 2015.
After missing the Great United States and Brazil Prix, Caterham has used crowdfunding to help fund a return in Abu Dhabi.
Japanese Kamui Kobayashi retained his driving while the team has also given British and former Will Stevens his F1 debut.
Both Caterham and Marussia remain on the official entry list for the 2015 season, but their future depends on a harsh winter getting funding to stay in the sport.
With teams spending a minimum of $70m per season, employing a driver who offers pace, performance and a pot of personal talent is more important than ever for those teams to not afford super-talented like Alonso.

text:
The largest boxer in the modern era is Muhammad Ali. There is usually no doubt about this in boxing circles. However, some would argue that there were others who were just as great. Ali was born in Louisville, Kentucky, and was first named Cassius Marcellus Clay Jr., but changed his name in the late 1960s after adopting Islam as his religion.

Ali was not only one of the greatest heavyweight boxers to enter the ring, but also a deeply spiritual person who challenged the U.S. government in defending its ethics. He was a controversial and divisive man who caused great emotion from those who loved him, and from those who wanted him imprisoned.
Ali was at the top of his profession in the late 1960s when his draft classification was changed. He was ordered to join the army, but refused. He claimed that he could not go to war because of his religious convictions. Many saw this U.S. government movement as a way of silencing the frank boxer because it was far beyond the age that most American youth were being recruited at the time. Ali was stripped of his title, and was banned from boxing, while his case went through the U.S. judicial system. Ali was inactive during his last years, from 25 to almost 29 years. It is not known how many more wins and titles he could have won during his stolen cousin.
Eventually, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in an 8-to-0 decision in favor of Ali, overturning his conviction for recruitment evasion. His position was not popular at the time among conservative Americans; many people disliked him very much, but his determination and moral principles defended his decision. He is now considered one of the most influential people in U.S. history. He was named "Sportsman of the Century" by Sports Illustrated magazine, and "Sports Personality of the Century" by the BBC.

text:
The era of the great British summer music festival, including Glastonbury, is coming to an end, according to lead rock promoter and manager Harvey Goldsmith.
The man who has produced and worked with most of the largest musical stars in the Western world, from The Who, the Rolling Stones and Queen to Madonna, Bob Dylan and Luciano Pavarotti, said the biggest problem was the lack of large new bands to succeed the old ones.
“The festival circuit has reached its peak,” he said, speaking at the Hay Festival of Literature and Arts in Powys, Wales. “It really peaked about two years ago. There are too many of them and there are not enough great acts to lead them. That's a big, big problem in our industry. And we are not producing a new generation of such acts, such as the Rolling Stones, Muse, not even the Arctic Monkeys, which they can headline.”
There were about 900 music festival events in the UK between May and September 2014, he said, and there is no way everyone can continue. “Musical festivals have probably followed their course. What is going to happen is a growth in events where it is not just music but, like this one, with poetry or books or magic shows. There will be a lot of small combined festivals that give something more, not people standing in a large massive field unable to go to the bathroom because they could miss the band.”
Clearly, the way the music is being delivered has changed, he said. “People don’t seem to want to hear a body of work anymore, an album. And, most rock bands built a reputation in a body of work – they could take three albums to really perfect their art, to become great, but young people don't want that. They arrive on a track, a sound, then, ping, again to the next. Pop penetrates, not that there's anything wrong with pop. I think it'll happen again, but it'll take time.
Goldsmith, 69, also revealed that he has partnered with Robin de Levita, the Dutch rock producer Tommy of Who’s 1970, in a new 1,100-seat theater in Wembley, which is about to finish in time for the first stage adaptation of the phenomenally successful series of teen films and books The Hunger Games in June 2016.
From Levita, Goldsmith said, he would take his experimental concept of SceneAround to London – theatre that places the audience sitting on a rotating table that revolves around a series of scenes built around its circumference, accompanied by projections on panel screens. The concept was a pioneer in an airplane hangar outside Amsterdam and has been a great success.
Goldsmith, who is already planning to take a production of Anne Frank’s story to the nameless place, said, “It’s a completely different way to produce shows.”
During his appearance in Hay, the businessman also revealed some of the secrets of “access to all areas” of his long career in the music industry, talking about Keith Moon putting dynamite in a toilet in Sydney’s hotel room in an effort to unlock it and witness the paralyzing stage scare that gripped John Lennon just before an appearance at Madison Square Garden in 1974 and led him to be dragged, vomited, out of his dressing room and pushed onto the stage. “It’s the strangest thing, really, how common that is among artists. It’s strange what’s affected by the fear they’re going to put on, but as soon as they hit the first chord, they’re fine,” he said.
He also put to rest a long-lasting rock and roll mystery: why Elvis Presley never acted outside North America. Presley's manager, Colonel Tom Parker, admitted to him during tea, said the real reason Goldsmith tried to take the singer to London had failed was Parker's uncertain immigration status.
“He explained that it was because he was an illegal Dutch immigrant. He didn’t want to risk leaving the United States, it was him, not Elvis,” Goldsmith said.

text:
Ryan Braun must now sit at home ashamed. If the press reports are accurate, Alex Rodriguez and a dozen other major league cheaters could do that, too. But the houses you sit in are $1 million mansions. That seems to be the lesson young athletes learn from the latest steroid scandal.
Sure, they look bad. But both Braun and Rodriguez have millions of dollars to fall back. The most worrying thing about this issue is how many of today's youth believe that cheating could be the only way to break up in sports.
In a recent Zogby survey, nearly half of men aged 18 to 25 thought that taking performance-enhancing drugs is critical to doing so in professional sports or helping their athletic performance. And more than half of the respondents thought that at least a third of the major league players in the recent All-Star Game had used performance-enhancing drugs, often called PEDs, to get to where they are.
The problem is that, for every Braun and A-Rod, a thousand young people will never reach older ones, but they are willing to risk their health, even their lives, taking PEDs. These young athletes need to hear more about Taylor Hooton than Ryan Braun.
Taylor Hooton was a high school star pitcher who turned to steroids to reach the next level. Although steroids filled his body, they wreaked havoc on his emotions until one day he hanged himself. His father, Don Hooton, has committed his life to trying to help other young athletes stay away from steroids.
Tragic decisions come when you combine motive with opportunity. That's what we have here. Young athletes see athletes squeezed into a series of sports get fame and glory and multimillion dollar contracts. They want to be like them. You can go online and find dozens of websites that offer to sell anabolic steroids and other PEDs online.
You don't have to find a gloomy figure lurking in a corner in a long coat. Teenagers know how to find just what they think they need on YouTube, eBay, and other websites that parents haven't even heard of. But these children know nothing about the dangers of even the purest of steroids, not to mention those that are contaminated with dangerous substances. The Taylor Hooton Foundation has found PEDs containing pollutants such as lead and other heavy metals, liquid mixers such as cooking oil, horse urine and other dirty contents.
What can parents do to keep their children safe?
Pay attention to sudden fluctuations in weight and muscle growth. If your child suddenly accumulates, it may be cause for concern. Also, pay attention to an extreme change in personality. Teenagers are prone to mood swings, but if your teen athlete is suddenly filled with unexplained anger, talk to him or her about what may be causing extreme emotions.
It is also important to pay attention to the use of the Internet and credit cards. Many teens have credit cards, which can be easily used to purchase PEDs online. Recently, the group of consumers I led, Digital Citizens Alliance, made four purchases online, and illegal drugs arrived in just under a month.
Talk to your teens regularly about why they shouldn't use PEDs. Using them is cheating, they are illegal to own without a prescription, and they can do serious harm to teens and their minds. It is a sad fact that if you play high school or college sports, these young people probably already know about someone who has taken PEDs. Don't assume it's someone else's problem.
Most importantly, do not ignore warning signs, even if it leads to a difficult conversation. Make sure young athletes listen to the whole story.
Most of the media coverage around the MLB scandal is whether the use of PED is worth the risk of millions of dollars in lost wages and the shame that it entails being caught. But the real risk to young athletes is their health. Young athletes who appear to be our best health condition may be facing decades of health problems - including liver abnormalities and tumors, increased risk of heart attacks, depression, and more - from taking PEDs.
Make sure for every story about A-Rod, they find out about Taylor Hooton. Let them know that fame and money -- and the risk of shame -- are not really at stake here. When they use PEDs, they're risking their lives and their health. And that's never worth the risk.
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of Tom Galvin.

text:
Martin Luther King Jr. is one of the most famous Americans in history. He was a pastor and humanitarian, but he is known mainly for being a civil rights activist. King was the leader of the African American Civil Rights Movement during the 1950s and 1960s. Their use of nonviolent protest to affect social change was based on their Christian beliefs. King was born Michael King, but his father changed his name in honor of the German reformer, Martin Luther.

King lived during the most divisive era in American history. White and southern culture in the United States wanted nothing to do with social change during the 1960s. There were segregation laws that prohibited Black Americans from eating in the same restaurants as whites, or traveling in the same section on public buses with white Americans. King led the famous Montgomery 1955 Bus Boycott in reaction to Rosa Park's refusal to deliver his bus seat to a white passenger as required by law in Montgomery, Alabama at that time.
King began his activism while serving as Baptist minister of the Baptist church on Dexter Avenue. He firmly believed in the Christian belief that loving your neighbor as yourself, which was a philosophy he used throughout his years of civil rights. He was also a great speaker. His speech "I Have a Dream" is considered one of the most famous oratorios in American history. In it, he talks about how his dream is for black and white Americans to walk hand in hand as brothers. The speech also stated how his dream was that all Americans would be judged, not by the color of their skin, but by the content of their character.
On 14 October 1964, King received the Nobel Peace Prize for his participation in the fight against racial inequality in the United States. He was murdered in April 1968, in Memphis, Tennessee, at the age of 39.

Born in the small town of Tupelo, Mississippi, Elvis Aaron Presley grew up in poverty. His working-class parents moved frequently throughout the state, going from work to work. Presley grew up to be one of the most recognizable and famous American celebrities the country has ever known. He recorded countless albums, starred in the big screen, and his songs were heard on the radio by more fans than any other artist in history.

Presley received his first guitar at the age of 10, and soon began a musical career that would last more than 25 years. His first success was winning a high school talent contest in Memphis, Tennessee, while he was still in school. Shortly after graduation, Presley was discovered by Sam Phillips, owner of a record company. His first commercial success came in 1954 with his successful single that is fine. Much of Presley's success could be attributed to his unconventional dance, and to his live acting style. Her hip movements and sexually suggestive movements won Presley much praise and controversy.
In 1956, Presley recorded his first No. 1 hit Heartbreak Hotel, and its first No. 1 album, self-titled Elvis Presley. He also signed a contract with Paramount Pictures Studios, which was, and remains, one of the largest Hollywood studios in the industry. He starred in several films with Paramount. In 1957, Presley was recruited into service by the United States Army, where he served abroad. His time in the army didn't hurt his career. Shortly after his service ended in 1960, Presley began recording music and starring in films.
Presley married in 1967, and had a daughter the following year. Unfortunately, his marriage ended in divorce in 1973. He fell into prescription drug abuse, and got into a lot of weight. He died in August 1977, due to complications of his drug abuse. It remains one of the most profitable artists in the world today.

The Duchess of Cambridge gave birth to a son on Monday, July 22. Third in line to the throne, the baby is destined to be monarch number 43 since William the Conqueror obtained the English crown in 1066.
Kensington Palace announced at 8.30 p.m. that the baby was born at 4.24 p.m. at the exclusive Lindo Wing in St Mary’s Hospital, Paddington, West London. “We couldn’t be happier,” said the Duke of Cambridge.
In a statement, Kensington Palace said: “His Royal Highness the Duchess of Cambridge was delivered safely from a son at 4:24 p.m. The baby weighs 8 pounds 6oz. The Duke of Cambridge was present for birth.” The Duchess experienced at least ten and a half hours of work, which Kensington Palace said had “progressed as usual.”
The Queen, the Duke of Edinburgh, the Prince of Wales, the Duchess of Cornwall, Prince Harry and members of both families were informed and delighted with the news that His Royal Highness and his son were well.
It is understood that the couple delayed the announcement immediately so that they could enjoy some private time with their newborn. William telephoned his family to give them the good news, talking to the Queen, her father, Charles and her younger brother, Prince Harry.
The birth of the little prince means that the monarchy has three generations of heirs to the throne for the first time since 1894.
The baby is the first Prince of Cambridge to be born for more than 190 years since Prince George of Cambridge, a grandson of George III and the only son of Prince Adolf Frederick, the first Duke of Cambridge.
In a statement, Prince Charles said: “Both my wife and I are delighted with the arrival of my first grandson. It's an incredibly special time for William and Catherine and we're very excited about them at the birth of their baby.
“Paternity is a unique moment in anyone’s life, as countless kind people have told me in recent months, so I am enormously proud and happy to be a grandfather for the first time and we are eager to see the baby in the near future.”
The new royalty will be named H.H. Prince George of Cambridge. When Kate was three months pregnant, a decree issued by the Queen said: “All children of the eldest son of the Prince of Wales must have and enjoy the style, title and attribute of the Royal Highness with the titular dignity of Prince or Princess prefixes their Christian names or those other titles of honor.”
Following tradition, a formal notice was published on an ornate rococo-style easel, which was used to announce the birth of Prince William in 1982, in the front yard of Buckingham Palace shortly before 9:00 p.m. Within an hour, the number had increased from hundreds to thousands outside the palace, with locals and tourists alike eager to share the historical moment.
New Yorker Sharon Surloff was delighted with her photo of the real newsletter phone, which broke after she and her niece and mother had squeezed into the crowd to take a picture of the easel.
“The police were saying to everyone, ‘OK, 20 seconds and then the next person.’ It's just great to be here, though. We arrived this morning, at nine in the morning, so everything worked out very well.”
The palace announced the birth in a press release. Minutes later, while the crowd of well-desired outside cheered, “It’s a child,” the formal medical bulletin was taken from the hospital to a waiting car by Prince William’s press secretary Ed Perkins. He handed it over to a soldier, who then took notice, who was signed by Marcus Setchell, the Queen's gynecologist, to Buckingham Palace under police escort.
The Prime Minister was one of the first to congratulate him. Speaking on the outskirts of 10 Downing Street, David Cameron said: “It’s wonderful news from St Mary’s, Paddington, and I’m sure that, across the country, and indeed across the Commonwealth, people will be celebrating and wishing the best for the real couple.
“It’s an important moment in our nation’s life but, I guess, above all, it’s a wonderful time for a warm and loving couple who have a new baby. It has been remarkable years for our royal family: a royal wedding that captured the hearts of the people, that extraordinary and magnificent jubilee and now this royal birth – all from a family that has given this nation such incredible service.”
Congratulations also came from the White House, Barack Obama and his wife. The president said: “Michelle and I are very happy to congratulate the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge on the joyful occasion of the birth of their first son. We wish you all the happiness and blessings that paternity brings.”
The Archbishop of Canterbury, the most Reverend Justin Welby, tweeted: “Delighted for the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. May God bless you all with love, health and happiness.”
Labour leader Ed Miliband said: “Many congratulations to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. I wish them and their child all happiness and good health.”
The campaign group, Republic, which launched its Born Equal initiative calling for all children to be born equal in political status and rights, said that real birth raised questions about Britain and democratic values. Chief Executive Graham Smith said the baby should be able to grow without “constant interference and intrusion.” He said: “Here is a new baby whose career, religion, even personal relationships have already been traced. In the meantime, this is an opportunity for the rest of us to consider whether this circus is the best way to run things.”

It was Tuesday rush hour, and Dorothy Otto was sitting in traffic at her Pontiac Bonneville on the lower level of the Cypress Highway in Oakland, California, when the voice on the radio said, "We're having an earthquake.
Suddenly, the concrete around her began to wave.
There was a giant accident, and a big heavy beam fell on the front of his car, crushing the engine, barely missing his face. The car fell 20 feet, and when it settled, Otto's left foot was trapped.
The two-story highway had collapsed, driving motorists into their cars.
Otto found a pen and decided to write a note to her husband, just in case.
Jack, the earthquake hit while I was under concrete, the worst happened, he wrote. It collapsed in the car. I'm alive, only my left foot is stuck under the car. I hope they don't kill me to get me out. I love you so much, good luck to both of you.
Fireman Lorenzo Frediani was running out of time as he struggled to free Otto's foot and put it to safety. Each replica lowered the top deck, approaching it to crush Otto and Frediani. So Frediani was able to push the crushed dashboard enough. Otto was free.
His section of the Cypress collapsed 20 minutes later.
That was October 17, 1989. The 6.9 magnitude earthquake, now called Loma Prieta, killed 63 people, 42 of them on the Cypress Highway. The earthquake caused damage of $10 billion, ultimately inspiring California and the rest of the region to re-examine their earthquake security measures.
Near Oregon it is located on a huge line of faults separating two of the Earth's tectonic plates. A plaque is located below the Pacific Ocean, off the Oregon coast, and is being pushed under the North American continent, according to Ian Madin, geologist and chief scientist of the Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries.
Is the earthquakes on the rise?
The fault line, known as the Cascadia Subduction Zone, could cause an even greater earthquake.
As the two plates collide, says Madin, the failure gets stuck, eventually slipping when enough stress accumulates to produce a big earthquake.
With an ultra-exact GPS, Madin says scientists know that the collision continues to occur because they can measure motion. Oregon actually moves around 1Â 1/2 inches each year, typical of a region near a subduction zone.
These mega earthquakes can cause strong tremors over large areas for several minutes. They can also lead to landslides, tsunamis, and widespread liquefaction, turning the soil into soup.
After the deadly 9.0 magnitude earthquake and tsunami that hit Japan in March 2011, Oregon lawmakers commissioned a study on the impact a comparable earthquake could have on the state. Madin was one of the authors of the Oregon Resilience Plan, which aims to reduce risk and improve recovery for the upcoming Cascadia earthquake and tsunami.
Oregon is not ready for a mega earthquake, and few areas are, says Madin. He says Japan is the most prepared, and look at the results of his mega-earthquake. The 2011 earthquake and tsunami caused more than 15,000 deaths.
Prior to 1974, there were no specific construction requirements in Oregon to ensure that structures were built to withstand major earthquakes, and design codes have only been suitable for the mega earthquake since 1993, so many structures are not designed to withstand such a large earthquake, Madin says.
Rapid events of the earthquake
In addition, we have a lot of mountainous terrain that is highly susceptible to landslides, large areas that are susceptible to liquefaction, and 300 miles of coastline that will be flooded by tsunamis that will arrive within 15 to 20 minutes of the earthquake and can locally reach 100-foot elevations above sea level, he says.
It is these factors that led the Oregon Resilience Plan to conclude that in the worst case scenario, 10,000 people could be killed, and large areas of Oregon could be without transportation, electricity, water and sewerage for several months to several years. The damage could result in an economic loss of $30 billion. Madin says $30 billion is almost certain to be understated, and death estimates might also be out.
Based on the study of geological characteristics that record prehistoric earthquakes, scientists generally agree that there have been 42 mega earthquakes along the Cascadia fault in the last 10,000 years, with the most recent in January 1700.
Using historical data, scientists such as Dr. Chris Goldfinger, marine geologist and professor at Oregon State University, can predict the probability of another major earthquake.
The Cascadia Subduction Zone is actually composed of different clusters, according to Goldfinger. At the southern end of the fault, data show that every 250 years an earthquake occurs with a magnitude between the high sevens and the low eights.
We are 300 years in a 240-year cycle, says Goldfinger.
On the other hand, the northern end, with large population centers, sees a great event closer to every 500 years.
But before the Oregonans panic, consider Goldfinger's assessment of statistics. For the southern end of Cascadia, there is approximately 35-40% chance of having a major earthquake in the next 50 years. At the northern end, there is only a probability of 10-15 %.
Even if there's still a lot of time before the next big earthquake, there's a lot of work to do to make sure Oregon's ready.
The most important thing is to strengthen or replace the infrastructure to ensure that our lifeguard systems such as energy and water are not so damaged that it takes years to repair them. We also need to strengthen or replace critical facilities such as hospitals, police and fire facilities and schools, says Madin.
Following the publication of the Oregon Resilience Plan, the Oregon Legislature established a working group to present specific recommendations for action at the 2015 legislative session.
Oregon has already turned the corner because the institutions are no longer asking, why should I do anything to prepare and now they are asking, how do I pay for the preparation I know I need?

The second Monday of October is celebrated Columbus Day in the United States and in other countries around the world. For a long time it was observed on a specific date, October 12. It bears the name of Christopher Columbus, the Italian sailor who led three Spanish ships to reclaim new lands in 1492. There's even a poem about a child remembering the date. It says, "In 1492, Columbus sailed through the blue ocean." Some people say that Columbus "discovered" North America, although not everyone agrees with this interpretation. For example, Columbus never came to North America properly. It only reached the islands of the Caribbean Sea.

Columbus Day has been a federal holiday since 1937; government offices, schools and post offices are closed. Many Italians take the day as a day to celebrate their own ethnic heritage since Columbus was born in Genoa, Italy. Columbus' explorations, however, took place on behalf of Spain. Major cities, such as New York and San Francisco, host large parades. Some cities, such as New York City, also hold a parade to celebrate the Hispanic or Latino community.
Not everyone thinks Christopher Columbus should be honored. Some states like South Dakota don't watch vacations at all. Instead, they call Native American Day or Indigenous Peoples Day. In Hawaii holidays are also known as Landing Day or Discovery Day. This is because the arrival of Europeans in North America meant the loss of land and lives for many indigenous people. Many people hold protests or vigils on this day to remind Native Americans that they were killed or enslaved as a result of the arrival of Europe. Another name for the party is "Dia de la Raza", which is translated into English as Carrera Day.

text:
Two mothers in South Africa have discovered that they are raising each other daughters after being mistakenly changed at birth in a hospital in 2010.
But while one of the women wants to correct the mistake and claim her biological son, the other refuses to return the child she has raised as her own, which poses a huge legal dilemma.
Henk Strydom, a lawyer for one of the mothers, who cannot be identified due to a court order, described the inadvertent exchange as a parody and tragedy that is unlikely to have a happy ending.
Both mothers gave birth at Tambo Memorial Hospital in Boksburg, east of Johannesburg, on the same day in 2010. “No one suspected anything,” Strydom said.
But in 2013, one of the mothers, who is 33 years old and unemployed, sued her ex-partner for the maintenance of her daughter. Strydom continued: “The man denied that he was the father. He ran a DNA test and found that it wasn't his baby and not his baby. I was devastated. She didn’t know what to do.”
Finally, she met the other mother and, since December 2013, they have attended joint counselling sessions organized by the hospital. This has included meeting her biological daughters.
Strydom said of her client: “She said there are similarities with herself. She told me it was traumatic. You can see it's not easy for her. She has to take care of a child who is not her own while her child is with someone else.”
The woman was reportedly dissatisfied with the process and went to the juvenile court in an attempt to obtain custody of her biological child, but the other mother refused. Strydom agreed to represent the woman, who has an older son, pro bono.
“It’s a tragedy. He wants the baby back, but it looks like the other mother is reluctant. It’s four years later: you can understand that she doesn’t want to give up her baby.”
The Pretoria High Court has appointed the Centre for Children ' s Law at the University of Pretoria to investigate what will now be in the best interests of children, which is the guiding principle of South African law. It must be reported within 90 days.
Strydom added: “Your guess is as good as mine what the court decides. It's a parody. How is it rectified after four years? The longer you wait, the more traumatic it will be. But no matter what happens, someone will not be happy.”
He said that at this time, he and his client do not want to sue the government's hospital or health department, which is currently helping with the case and providing advice.
The Child Law Centre will now interview mothers and fathers, as well as any other person who has a “significant relationship” with any of the girls. Children and mothers will be subjected to “full and comprehensive” clinical assessments and can be seen by a psychologist.
Karabo Ngidi, a lawyer at the center, said: “What is going to happen must be in the best interests of the children. Biology is an important aspect, but not the only one.”
The families are of Zulu ethnicity, so Zulu tradition, culture and customary law will be a factor, he added. It is also possible that the former partner of the mother taking legal action could be the biological father of the girl who was changed.
This is not the first case of children's exchange to come to light in South Africa. In 1995, two mothers received damages after their children, born in 1989, were accidentally changed at the Johannesburg hospital where they were born.
In 2009, in Oregon, in the United States, Dee Ann Angell and Kay Rene Reed discovered that they had been mistaken at birth in 1953 when a nurse brought them back from the bathroom. In 2013, in Japan, a 60-year-old man, exchanged at birth from his wealthy parents to a poor family, received compensation. He grew up in welfare and became a truck driver, while his biological brothers – and the child raised in his place – attended high schools and private universities.
Bruce Laing, a clinical psychologist in Johannesburg, said the long-term effects of a baby change could be “deep”, “terrible” and “unbelievably traumatizing.” He told The Times in South Africa: “An increasingly complicated situation is that some resentment may occur towards a child who is not his. Parents could always be thinking, "What if? '"

text:
A Cleveland police officer shot 12-year-old Tamir Rice about two seconds after the officer and a partner stopped in a car to investigate reports that someone was wielding a gun in a park, surveillance video that the police posted on Wednesday shows.
Tamir, who had what the police said was an air pistol that looked like a real gun, died on Sunday, the day after he was shot outside a recreational center.
Police also released two audio recordings on Wednesday, a 911 call that preceded the shooting and a tape from a dispatcher asking officers to go to the park.
The shooting occurred after a person called 911 to report that a black man -- probably a minor -- was pointing a gun at people outside the recreation center. Twice the caller said the gun could be fake.
The dispatcher spoke over the radio to the officers about a black man pointing a gun at people, but he did not mention that caller's belief that he could be a minor and that the gun might not be a real gun, one of the footage published shows.
The police previously said it was unclear whether the responding officers received information about the age of the suspect or whether the weapon was possibly false.
Authorities are investigating the shooting, and the two officers -- identified on Wednesday by the police as Timothy Loehmann, 26, and Frank Garmack, 46 -- are out of work.
Loehmann joined the department in March, Tomba said.
Police Deputy Chief Ed Tomba noted that his department published the video at the request of Tamir's relatives, who had seen it privately with the permission of the authorities.
“We are honoring the wishes of the family,” Tomba said. This is an obvious tragic event.
In a written statement obtained by CNN affiliate WWS, the family thanked the police for making the video public.
“We believe that this situation could have been avoided and that Tamir should still be here with us,” the family said. We ask that the community remain calm. Please protest peacefully and responsibly. Your prayers, your kind words and your condolences have meant a lot to us.
Video shows official shoot Tamir
The video shows Tamir walking down a sidewalk and finally sitting on a picnic table under a gazebo on Saturday afternoon, sometimes pointing out what appears to be a gun.
Eventually, Tamir emerges from the bench and walks to the edge of the vantage point. A police car drives to the lookout, leaving the road and rolling over the snowy grass to do so.
One of the officers, the one in the passenger seat, told Tamir three times to show his hands, Tomba told the journalists.
“The officer’s door was open as they stopped,” Tomba said. He screamed three times as they stopped.
The eight-minute surveillance video has no audio.
The police said Tamir got in his waist and pulled out the gun. The video shows Loehmann, the officer on the passenger's side, leaving the car, and Tamir falls, apparently shot.
Between 1.5 and two seconds passed from the moment the car stopped until the moment Tamir was shot, Tomba said. At that time, only the passenger side officer was out of the car, the video shows.
One of the officers, radioing the office, reported that a black man, perhaps 20, was down, according to the radio traffic released between the officers and dispatchers.
The driver was Garmack, a six-year veteran of the force, according to Tomba.
Chief Calvin Williams said four minutes after Tamir was shot by an FBI detective and agent were at the scene. The FBI agent started first aid and the paramedics arrived three minutes later.
Investigators determined that Tamir's gun was an air pistol, and that an orange tip that is intended to indicate that it is not a real firearm had been removed, police said.

Bill Gates is an American inventor, computer programmer, philanthropist, and entrepreneur born in Seattle, Washington. It is said to have a value of nearly $80 billion, making it one of the richest people in the country. He founded, and was head of Microsoft Corporation for years, and is still on the board for the computer software giant.

Gates was born into a upper-middle-class family. His father was a lawyer; his mother was a banker, who worked for United Way for many years. He is credited for being the father of the modern computer, and for almost just starting the revolution of the personal computer. He studied at Harvard University, but did not graduate because of his desire to develop new software.
As a 13-year-old student at Lakeside School, which was an exclusive college high school, Gates was introduced to computer programming. That year he developed a program that allowed users to play tic-tac-toe against the computer. Gates was fascinated by the computer's ability to play software code. In 1975, Gates approached a company called Micro Instrumentation and Telemetry Systems (MITS). He convinced the owner that he had written a program that would work with his platform. The owner of the company bought Gates' innovations, and the two men reached an agreement to develop MITS software. The Microsoft Company was born.
Gates continued to develop the Windows operating system with IBM Corporation. However, the two companies had differences, and their association quickly ended. Gates left Microsoft in 2000, but remains on its board of directors. He remained active with the company for several years before resigning in February 2014, becoming a technical advisor to the company.

text:
Halloween is October 31st. It is also called Vesper of All Saints or Vesper of All Saints. This is due, according to some, to the fact that the feast has its roots in a Christian feast reminiscent of the dead. Others say the holiday has its roots in the ancient traditions of Ireland's harvest season. In the United States, however, the focus is less on the memories of the deceased or agriculture. It's about kids getting dressed in scary costumes and going door to door asking for candy. This is called trick or deal. When children knock on a house door or ring the doorbell, they usually say "Trick or Deal." The "trick" part is a false threat that indicates that children will make a joke if they are not given something delicious. Homeowners give sweet children, raisins or some other food delicacies. Many homeowners decorate their homes to prepare for the holidays and let the children know that they are participating and can ring the bell for the sweets. Traditional decorations often include jack-o'-lanterns, which are pumpkins with carved faces on them and candles on the inside. Jack-o's lanterns were thought to frighten evil spirits when Halloween was celebrated for the first time among ancient Christians. Turnips, not pumpkins, were also used originally. People often decorate using the colors black and orange.

Halloween is not just for children; adults have fun attending costume parties. There are often contests for who has the best suit. There are also bobling games for apples, where people have to get an apple using only their teeth from a large bucket of water. Other people celebrate scaring themselves by going to haunted homes, homes where people dress up as ghosts, zombies and werewolves and jump to scare the guests. People also tell scary stories or watch horror movies.

text:
Scarlett Johansson sues a French novelist for 50,000 euros in damages, claiming that her fictional work makes fraudulent claims about her personal life.
The Premiere chose qu’on mirae (the first thing we looked at) by Grégoire Delacourt tells the story of a French model that looks so much like the American actor that the main male character in the book thinks it is Johansson herself. In the novel, the appearance of the model means that men only see it as a sexual object, while women are jealous of it. She has a series of adventures like Johansson until she finally discovers herself and eventually dies in a car accident.
Johansson herself is not flattered by the best-selling literary work. His lawyer, Vincent Toledano, told Le Figaro that Delacourt’s novel constituted “a fraudulent and illegal violation and exploitation of his name, reputation and image.” He said the novel contains “defamatory claims about his private life” and has now gone to court to try to stop the translation or adaptation of the film book. The trial began in Paris on Wednesday afternoon, although neither Johansson nor Delacourt were present.
“The freedom of expression he defends as an artist is not in doubt,” Toledano said. “Such activities for purely commercial purposes have nothing to do with creativity.”
Delacourt has tried to explain that she chose to refer to Johansson because she is “the archetype of today’s beauty.” He said: “I wrote a fictional work. My character is not Scarlett Johansson.
The author recently confronted the actor on French radio, saying that the legal action was "rather sad". He said: “I’m afraid to think that when you talk about a character in a novel, judges can get involved.”
Delacourt has become one of the most beloved authors in France; his previous novel, My Wish List, was translated into 47 languages and is now adapting to a film. But he said he was "no talking" when he found out that Johansson was suing him.
“I thought she would contact me to ask me to go have coffee with her. I didn’t write a novel about a celebrity,” he said. “I wrote a true love story and a tribute to feminine beauty, especially inner beauty.
“If an author can no longer mention the things around us – a brand of beer, a monument, an actor – it will be difficult to produce fiction.
“It’s shocking, especially because I’m not sure I’ve read the novel, as it hasn’t been translated yet.”
Emmanuelle Allibert, spokesman for editor JC Lattès, said the legal action was “crazy.” “We have never known anything like this. It is even more surprising by the fact that the novel is not even about Scarlett Johansson. This is a woman who is twice Scarlett Johansson.”
Delacourt’s lawyer, Anne Veil, who also represents editor JC Lattès, said the charges were “totally scandalous.” “This is a literary, not a commercial approach. She has not been used as a product,” she said. “Grégoire Delacourt is not a paparazzo, he is a writer!”
Ironically, the author's legal situation would be much easier if he had published the book in the country of origin of Johansson, rather than France. Lloyd Jassin, a New York intellectual property attorney, told Time that the case would be unlikely to be considered in the United States because the book would be protected by the First Amendment.
“The First Amendment does not see most books as commercial uses or commercial proposals,” he said. “If his name or likeness is relevant, literaryly, if there is meaning and literary merit to use his name among the covers, the First Amendment comes into action.” However, in France, the legal position is more complicated and personality rights are taken “much more seriously,” says Jassin.
“I thought I could send flowers because it was a declaration of love for her, but I didn’t understand,” Delacourt said. “It’s a strange paradox, but very American.”

text:
Indignant waiters are asking for public support in a battle to hold on to their tips. PizzaExpress branches will be targeted by protesters as part of an attempt to get the restaurant chain to stop frizzing a proportion of tips for staff who have been paid with credit and debit cards. Activists have also launched an online petition in the hope that restaurant visitors will support their demands.
In a policy that has outraged some employees, PizzaExpress maintains, as an administrative fee, 8p of each £1 paid when tips are given by card. The chain, which has 430 branches throughout the UK and is particularly popular among families, makes an estimate of £1m per year of practice, according to the Unite union.
“We believe that this 8% rate is unfair and that, if the chain values its staff, it should be paying them the total advice given to them by customers,” said Chantal Chegrinec, Unite’s campaign officer. “We started with PizzaExpress, but they are not at all the only criminal and after this we will be focusing our attention on other companies.”
The protests are being organized by local Unite branches, and the first takes place at the branch office of the British PizzaExpress Museum in London. The union has also written to the CEO of the restaurant chain, Richard Hodgson. Unite started the campaign after a survey of its PizzaExpress members after the chain was sold to a Chinese private equity company, Hony Capital, in 2014. One of the main problems was the deduction of 8% of their advice.
A disgruntled PizzaExpress employee, who wants to remain anonymous, said the administration fee was costing him £3 per night. “I’ve worked at PizzaExpress for 15 years,” he said in a letter to Unite. “After all this time, I still get paid only the national minimum wage of 6.50 pounds an hour. So you see that my colleagues and I rely heavily on customer tips to supplement our low wages. I work hard and I’m good at my job, but when PizzaExpress thinks she can get away with taking a percentage of the tips we have left on a card, I get angry.”
PizzaExpress joins the Restaurant Chains Ask and Zizzi to extract 8% of the tips paid by card, but other chains deduct even more. Café Rouge, Bella Italia and Belgo deduct 10%, as do Strada and Giraffe, owned by Tesco.
A PizzaExpress spokesperson said his administrative position was to cover the cost of running a “tronc” – a standard payment arrangement used to distribute tips to staff. “We do a lot of work to establish this log system, which is chaired by a troncmaster and led by a committee of waiters and pizziers who decide independently how tips made by paying for electronic cards are then distributed to teams of front and back restaurants; a system run by employees for employees,” he said.
The chain, which sells 29 million pizzas a year through its UK restaurants, denied that it benefits from the administration fee. But other groups of restaurants do not deduct a board administration fee. Wagamama, Pizza Hut and TGI Friday don't drink anything. The Restaurant Group, owner of Frankie & Benny’s, Chiquitos and Garfunkels, used to charge 10%, but abandoned this policy several years ago.
Unite recently focused on ten PizzaExpress restaurants in southern London, distributing brochures to customers who were “disturbed and disgusted” by the practice. PizzaExpress says the charge is mentioned in small print at the bottom of its menus, but the employee who wrote to Unite said that, when she mentioned the charge to customers, it was always a surprise. Most would pay the cash tip. Almost 6,000 people have so far signed Unite's online petition.
A waiter, who does not work for PizzaExpress but has worked for 11 years for another chain of restaurants, said that at least a third of his income comes from tips. He doesn't want to be identified for fear of retaliation. “I work at a busy branch in London and, on a half-night, I will serve 150 people and take home 40 to 50 pounds in tips,” he says. “That may sound a lot, but that money is crucial to me, as my basic salary is only £6.50 an hour.”
Conservative MP Andrew Percy, who has asked for a change in the law that would give restaurant staff more control over tips, said he plans to raise the issue in parliament after the summer recess.”
label: B2

text:
Afghan President Hamid Karzai said on Sunday that his country would join the strategic review of the U.S.-led war on terror.
Afghan President Hamid Karzai, on the right, meets Richard Holbrooke in Kabul on 15 February 2009.
Speaking at a joint press conference with U.S. diplomat Richard Holbrooke, Karzai said he is very, very grateful that President Barack Obama has accepted his proposal to join the review.
Holbrooke is visiting Afghanistan after a trip to neighboring Pakistan. Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton took advantage of Holbrooke as a special representative for the two countries, a sign of how the new administration considers Afghanistan and Pakistan to be intertwined in any solution to the war in Afghanistan and the terrorist threat along its shared border.
At the Kabul press conference, Holbrooke said on Sunday that he conveyed the administration's support for the upcoming elections on 20 August, a date recently set by the Afghan electoral commission.
President Obama and Secretary Clinton and the U.S. government were very pleased to hear President Karzai reaffirm their support for the August 20 decision, Holbrooke said.
Holbrooke's visit comes as Obama plans to send another 30,000 troops to Afghanistan to fight what he has called the central front in our long-lasting fight against terrorism and extremism.
In an interview with CNN's Fareed Zakaria GPS, which aired on Sunday, Karzai said that, with a resurgent Taliban, a still flourishing drug trade and a border with Pakistan believed to be the base of al-Qaeda, his country cannot afford to allow American troops to leave soon.
“American forces will not be able to leave Afghanistan soon because the task is not over,” Karzai said. We have to defeat terrorism. We will have to allow Afghanistan to stand up. We will have to allow Afghanistan to be able to defend itself and protect for its safety...
Then, the United States can leave and, at that time, the Afghan people will give them lots of flowers and gratitude and send them home safely.
At the same time, Karzai said that the actions of the troops currently in Afghanistan have turned some of the citizens against them.
It is the question of civil cases. It is a matter of risk for Afghans. It's the question of home searches, he said. These activities are seriously undermining the confidence of the Afghan people in the joint fight against terrorism and undermining their hopeful future.
We'll still be friends. We'll remain an ally. However, Afghanistan deserves respect and better treatment.

Levi Aron was prosecuted in a New York court on Thursday for charges of murder and first-degree kidnapping in the murder of an 8-year-old boy and remained under suicide surveillance until a mental evaluation was completed.
Aron, 35, showed no emotion as he entered the court handcuffed and did not make a plea. He said earlier in a statement that he regretted the problems he has caused, New York Police Commissioner Ray Kelly said.

Charles J. Hynes, Kings County District Attorney, had said he would ask a grand jury for the maximum legal charges for the cruel and insensitive murder and dismemberment of eight-year-old Leiby Kletzky.
The police found human remains in Aron's freezer and a trash can that they think are the boy's, who disappeared Monday afternoon.
Kelly called the heartbreaking case.
Obviously there is a lot of violence in this business, but there is usually some kind of twisted irrational logic that is given to why a violent event took place, Kelly said.
Here, I mean, it's just, it challenges all logic and I think that's what's really so, so terribly disturbing about this case. There is absolutely no reason. There's nothing more innocent than an 8-year-old boy and being, you know, murdered this way is just... heartbreaking.
Police said 35-year-old Aron made statements on Wednesday involving himself in Kletzky's death. They are both members of the nearby Jewish Orthodox community in Brooklyn.
Kelly said the detectives found the remains in a freezer in Aron's third floor attic and in a trash can more than two miles away, wrapped in a black plastic trash bag inside a suitcase.
The cause of death has not yet been determined, but the police believe Kletzky was suffocated.
Kletzky was supposed to meet his parents after walking seven blocks from his summer camp, but he got lost and asked the suspect for directions, Kelly said.
The surveillance video showed Aron entering a dentist's office on Monday while Kletzky waited across the street for seven minutes, Kelly said.
Aron claims he took Kletzky to a wedding Monday night in Monsey, New York, and then brought him back, Kelly said. The police said Aron went to the wedding, but they couldn't confirm that Kletzky really went with him, since no one said they saw him.
According to Kelly, the police showed up at Aron's residence at 2:40 a.m. on Wednesday and asked him about Kletzky's whereabouts. The suspect pointed them to the kitchen, where the blood was visible on the freezer handle. Inside the refrigerator was a cutting board with three blood-stained cut knives, Kelly said.
Aron, an employee of a maintenance supply company, did not seem to have met Kletzky, Kelly said. His only known criminal subpoena was for urination in public last year.
Kelly said the statements made by the suspect indicated that he kidnapped Kletzky and, when the search for the child in the neighborhood intensified, panicked and killed him.
“We are all in shock,” State Assemblyman Dov Hikind said of the people in his district. What kind of people are able to create these crazy acts?
Aron's former wife, Debbie Aron from Memphis, Tennessee, said she's been in total shock since she heard the news.

I can't believe it. She's definitely not in her character as... the person I met, she told CNN affiliate WMC. Even when I spoke to him not long ago, everything was fine, with no indication that something was wrong.
After Kletzky disappeared on Monday, residents joined local and federal authorities in a massive search effort.
FBI spokesman Jim Margolin said the FBI helped interview witnesses and deployed the FBI Children's Crimes Brigade in the case.
CNN's Jesse Solomon contributed to this report.

“In most cases, if we have nothing, they will eventually be released,” Brig said. General David Quantock, who oversees the operations of detainees in Iraq.
Quantock said many cases are purely intelligence-driven.
Intelligence doesn't win a fight in a court of law. He doesn't win the fight in a court of law in the United States. He doesn't win in Iraq.
According to the U.S. military, 76,985 detainees have been released from the 87,011 captured during the Iraq war.
An investigation by CNN found that frustration with the Army's policy on detainees could have led to the death in 2007 of four Iraqi men by three army sergeants decorated on a Baghdad canal.
Former first sergeant. John Hatley, who led the mission that day, told CNN in a letter that the detention policy has extensive flaws that repeatedly frustrated the soldiers.
On the Army interrogation tapes obtained by CNN, other soldiers complained about Army standards for gathering evidence.
Despite the high rate of liberation, Quantock said he is confident that soldiers can take basic evidence from a crime scene in Iraq.
We ask them to take basic evidence, for which they have been trained, said Quantock, who oversees the operations of the detainees in Iraq. We have the best soldiers in the world. And I don't accept that they can't get basic evidence from the crime scene.
CNN asked Quantock to explain why, if it was so easy to gather evidence, so many detainees had been released.
It took us a while to realize, it goes back to my point that we were trying to make the fight fit into the Army instead of the Army fitting into the fight, Quantock said.
I think many times we thought the insurgency would dissipate, we were working closely with the Iraqi government, we were trying to improve the Iraqi security forces, but at the end of the day, it didn't work out very well. We had to get better to get evidence from the crime scene.
A memorandum of 9 January 2005 imposed detailed rules on the evidence that soldiers needed before they received alleged insurgents in Iraq. Quantock told CNN that the rules detailed in the memorandum were in force until the end of 2008.
The memorandum states that evidence of criminal activity should include photographs of physical evidence, the detainee at the crime scene or the place of arrest, as well as photographs of the detainee along with evidence. Other evidence must include statements written by first-hand witnesses of criminal activity, the memorandum states.
Earlier this year, the rules became even stricter. A security agreement with the Iraqi government now requires an arrest warrant signed by an Iraqi judge to arrest someone.
