They call it the Robin Hood of the banks, a man who took out dozens of loans worth almost half a million euros, with no intention of ever paying them. Instead, Enric Duran handed over the money to projects that created and promoted alternatives to capitalism.
After 14 months in hiding, Duran does not apologize, even though his activities could lead him to jail. “I’m proud of what I did,” he said in a Skype interview from an undisclosed location. The money, he said, had created opportunities. “It generated a movement that allowed us to advance in the construction of alternatives. And it allowed us to build a powerful network that brings together these initiatives.”
From 2006 to 2008, Duran took 68 commercial and personal loans from 39 banks in Spain. He took the money out of social activists, funding anti-capitalist talk tours and television cameras for a media network. “I saw that, on the one hand, these social movements were building alternatives but lacked resources and communication capabilities,” he said. “In the meantime, our dependence on perpetual growth was creating a system that created money out of nothing.”
The loans he was swindling banks were his way of regulating and denouncing this situation, he said. It started slowly. “I filled out some credit requests with my real details. They denied me, but I just wanted to have an idea of what they were asking for.”
From there, the former table tennis coach began to weave a intricate network of accounts, payments and transfers. “I was constantly learning.” By the summer of 2007, he had discovered how to make the system work, applying for loans under the name of a fake television production company. “Then, I managed to get a lot.” €492,000, to be exact.
Duran was arrested in Spain in 2009, on charges brought against him by six of the 39 banks that had lent him money. He spent two months in prison before being rescued for 50,000 euros. In February 2013, in front of eight years in prison, he decided to flee instead of being tried. “I don’t see legitimacy in a judicial system based on authority, because I don’t recognize its authority,” he said.
His actions, he said, were at the forefront of a global debate on the economic crisis. Time brought the anti-capitalist movement to light, as many Spaniards sought alternatives to a system that had wreaked havoc on their lives.
Although the same actions are likely to be better understood in Spain today, he said they would not be necessary. The anti-capitalist movement has grown from a marginal movement to one supported by thousands of Spaniards, he said, evidenced by broadly supported movements such as the Indignados.
Success has helped make the movement self-sufficient. “We now have the capacity to generate resources,” Duran said, ironically adding that this is exactly what banks issue credit for – “to move forward and generate a situation that allows you to be independent.” Duran is expanding its approach to include the Spanish justice system, promoting restorative justice. “People in Spain who think banks don’t work, think I don’t owe anything. I’ve already done my job,” he said. “But there is a part of a population that disagrees with us and I think it should respond to that.”
In his case, he said, the element of reciprocity that he could offer to banks could be in the perception that he obtained of years of fraudulent bank loans. He could share his ideas about “what best practices work and which ones don’t,” he suggested, “for the general population and for the bank’s workers.”

Apartheid is a South African system of government based on racial segregation between the minority white population and Black South Africans. It was a controversial form of government that was in effect from 1948 to 1994, and caused great social upheaval. The system was launched after World War II, but racial segregation began much earlier in the country. apartheid separated South Africans by race, placing people in four classifications: white, black, colored and Indian. Each group had different levels of privilege, with white South Africans being the most favored.
From 1960 to 1983, 3.5 million Black South Africans were forcibly expelled from their homes; in 1970, all non-white politicians were expelled from government. Mandela's movement to end apartheid began in 1949 when he supported and organized non-violent boycotts, strikes and civil disobedience. He was arrested and charged with treason in 1956 for his role in the social uprising, and was finally imprisoned for 27 years. During this time, most countries of the world called for their release and put trade embargoes against the white regime.

Gabriela worked for a multinational company as a successful project manager in Brazil and was transferred to manage a team in Sweden. She was excited about her new role, but soon realized that managing her new team would be a challenge.
Despite her kindness, Gabriela did not feel respected as a leader. His new staff openly questioned his proposals at meetings, and when he gave them instructions on how to carry out a task, they often did so in their own way without consulting her. When she announced her decisions on the project, they would continue to give their opinions as if they were still under discussion.
After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about the problems she faced with her team. His manager simply asked him if he felt that his team was still acting, and what he thought would help him to better collaborate with his team members. Gabriela found her manager lazy and didn't feel like she was managing the situation satisfactorily.
What Gabriela was experiencing was a cultural clash in expectations. She was used to a more hierarchical framework in which the team leader and manager took control and gave specific instructions on how things should be done. This more management style worked well for her and her team in Brazil, but it was not well transferred to their new team in Sweden, which were more accustomed to a more flat hierarchy where decision-making was more democratic. When Gabriela took the matter to her Swedish manager, instead of intervening with instructions on what to do, her manager took on the role of coach and focused on getting her to come forward with her own solutions instead.
Dutch social psychologist Geert Hofstede uses the concept of "distance from power" to describe how power is distributed and how hierarchy is perceived in different cultures. In her previous work environment, Gabriela was accustomed to a culture of high power at a distance where power and authority are respected and each has its legitimate place. In such a culture, leaders make great decisions and are not often challenged. His Swedish team, however, was used to working in a low-powered distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thinking and hope to be challenged.
When Gabriela realized the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative of having an open conversation with them about their feelings about their leadership. Delighted to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more space for initiative and creative freedom. When you told your team exactly what you needed them to do, they felt that you didn't trust them to do your job well. They realized that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes in their decisions, and they were able to explain that it was the way they had always worked.
With a better understanding of the underlying reasons behind each other's behavior, Gabriela and her team were able to adapt their way of working. Gabriela was then able to make adjustments to her management style to better match her team's expectations and motivate her team more effectively to achieve her goals.

Among those present was a Mexican prelate, Monsignor Oscar Sanchéz Barba of Guadalajara. Before assuring the Pope of the loyalty and devotion of the cardinals, he said that he and the others present “had listened to them with a feeling of bewilderment, almost completely unbelieving. ” At the end of his speech, the Pope blessed those present, and left. “It was so simple; the simplest imaginable,” said Sanchéz Barba. Then we all went quietly. There was absolute silence... and sadness.
John Thavis, who spent 30 years reporting about the Holy See and whose book, The Vatican Diaries, will soon be published, said he had had an intuition that the Pope might be about to resign and timed his return to Rome from the US. Consequently. A fellow Vatican surveillance officer confirmed that this is the case. Thavis pointed out that in the long interview Benedict gave to a German journalist, published as Luz del Mundo in 2010, he had made it clear that he felt it would be right to go if he felt he was no longer up to the job. “I wondered: if I was Pope and I wanted to quit, when would I choose? He has completed his series of books and most of his projects are under way. What's more, there were no dates in his calendar of events that he had to attend personally. I thought the most likely date was February 22, which is the feast of the Chair of Saint Peter. So I was wrong.”
The line that emerged from the Vatican within hours of the announcement was that the Pope's decision was courageous. For this reason, Benedict, who never retreats from the statements and decisions that shock him, had been in charge of addressing the reality of his Church: the reality that contemporary medicine can keep men alive well beyond the age in which they are willing to meet the demands of leading a vast world organization. Do you know more about your state of health than the Vatican has made public so far?
Benedict’s own account of his reasons makes it clear that he took into account not only his physical condition, but also his psychological condition: “To govern the crust of St. Peter and proclaim the Gospel, both the strength of the mind and that of the body are necessary, a force that in recent months has deteriorated in me to the extent that I have had to recognize my inability to properly carry out the ministry entrusted to me.” Other theories will undoubtedly revolve around the Vatican in the days and weeks ahead, just as they did after the death of Pope John Paul I in 1978, 33 days after his election. There are already speculations that something was about to come out about Benedict's past. The Vatican will reject these notions with contempt in the same way that can be predicted. But they are understandable anyway, because the transcendental importance of what Benedict has done cannot be overstated.
From St.Peter's Basilica, Julia Rochester of London, who described herself as an expired Catholic, was still turning to the implications of the Pope's resignation. “If you are God’s chosen one, how do you choose not to be chosen?” he thought. It is a question that many practicing Catholics will be asking their priests in the coming weeks. In his first address as Pope, humbly renouncing his aptitude for the task, Benedict said: “I am comforted by the fact that the Lord knows how to work and how to act, even with insufficient tools”. text:
New Year's Day officially begins as soon as people shout "Happy New Year" at midnight. Most people still party well after midnight in the early hours of the first day of the new year. In fact, many New Year's parties include breakfast or brunch. Sometimes at midnight there will be fireworks and couples often kiss. One of the most famous New Year's celebrations takes place in New York's Time Square, where a huge cut crystal ball falls at midnight in front of millions of people standing in the cold. Many millions more watch on TV. Some groups, called Polar Bear Clubs, jump into the cold ocean water on New Year's Day as a literal way to start the fresh New Year.

New Year's Day, January 1, is a national holiday in the United States. This means that schools, banks, government offices and post offices are closed. Given the number of people who tend to drink alcohol on New Year’s Eve, many people wake up on New Year’s Day with hangover. The national holiday is a good day to recover.
Many people party with their friends on New Year's Eve; many people use New Year's Day to visit their family. New Year's Day is also when many people start with their New Year resolutions. A resolution is a promise to change a lifestyle habit. The most common resolution is to lose weight. Many people also join the gyms as part of their resolutions.
On New Year's Day there are also parades such as the famous Rose Parade Tournament in Pasadena, California, where all floats are made of roses of different colors and compete for prizes. Many people also watch professional and college football matches, including the Rose Bowl, which is also held in Pasadena, California.

text:
Over the years, the Memorial Day weekend has become largely something that was originally not meant to be:
Seventy-two hours of barbecues and ball games, swimming pool openings, high decibel sales pitches by traders in hopes of charging at the unofficial start of summer.
Which, to some extent, is understandable. The climate is becoming warm, there is a sense of vacation for rest from work, and solemnity and mourning for those who gave their lives in search of peace seems sometimes to be cast aside.
But the search for peace, with all its contradictions and all its sacrifices, remains the centerpiece of the Day of Commemoration.
And this weekend might be worth stopping, if only for a moment, to reflect on a quote that has been attributed in various ways to Winston Churchill and George Orwell:
We sleep deeply in our beds because tough men are ready at night to visit violence over those who would hurt us.
Throughout history, peace in the world has often been achieved, by necessity, by the most brutal means available during military conflicts. There is an intrinsic dichotomy to wars that are waged in search of peace, an uncomfortable gap between lightness and shadows. Tranquility is born of bloodshed; happiness is the end result of horror. We don't like to think about it too much, and it's no wonder. The truth behind it goes against our best nature.
What is the most beloved image celebrating the happy end of World War II?
It's Alfred Eisenstaedt's picture of the sailor and nurse hugged in Times Square. Even now, more than 60 years later, that photo makes people cry with joyous emotion, makes them smile with exultation throughout generations. That photo, often declares, says it all.
But there would be no picture of the sailor and nurse except for the scenes that no one likes to see in the photographs: the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki that put an end to the terrible years of war. It is perfectly explicable that we prefer to bathe in exuberant images of the first hours of peace, rather than the appalling images of the last hours of war.
One person who was present during the last hours of World War II was Paul Tibbets. During the many days and nights I spent with him during the last years of his life, there were times when the conversation focused on that picture of the sailor and nurse. Sometimes, when we traveled together and he attended a military meeting, someone approached him with a copy of the photo.
Paul would never say anything. He looked at me and just raised his eyebrows, almost imperceptibly. He wasn't the photographer, but Eisenstaedt wouldn't have had anything to photograph if it wasn't for him.
It was the man -- the military aviator -- assigned by the U.S. government to arm, in no way secret, the unity that would be carried out by atomic raids in Japan. When the day came, he did not delegate; he flew the B-29 called Enola Gay, his mother's name, to Hiroshima with a goal in mind: to stop the war. Let the soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines go home at last, to reunite with their families or to form new families, in order to somehow, after all the suffering and all the broken heart, find peace.
Of course, the sailor and nurse are the favorite visual representation of victory. What Paul Tibbets, sailor Dutch Van Kirk, bomber Tom Ferebee and his crew were invited to do about the skies of Japan is something that is hard to think about for many people; it is much nicer to smile at the kiss in New York.
Peace is the result starred by the sun, but getting there can be a path of darkness over darkness. Therefore, on the weekend of Memory Day, it is probably reasonable for some people to turn back thoughtfully from the thoughts of the battlefields and death. The people who turn away are not usually those whose family members have walked that dark and lonely path in times of war.
On occasions throughout the centuries when long wars have come to an end, many newspapers have chosen to go with the most glorious title of a single word, all letters of capital of all:
PEACE!
Is there a word in English that is more welcome, more appreciated? That is more likely to be received with joy and prayer relief by all who see it? Almost every desire a person, or a nation, can have is embodied in that syllable.
All the lightness and all the shadows, all the wars fought at terrible costs, all in search of peace. Reaching such a state of harmony has never been a peaceful journey.
That's why the word is so beautiful, so longed for:
Because it sounds so simple while it stays so weird.
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of Bob Greene.

text:
Chanuka, which can also be spelled as Hanukkah, is an 8-day Jewish holiday. It is known as the Feast of Lights, which celebrates the dedication of an ancient Jewish temple in Jerusalem thousands of years ago. According to the Hebrew, or Jewish, Bible, then a miracle occurred. A one-day oil supply miraculously lasted eight days. Hanukkah dates always change, but usually occur anywhere at the end of November at the end of December.

The main way to observe the holidays is to light a candle in a candlestick, a special candle holder with space for 9 candles in each of the 8 nights. This candlestick is called menorah. Now there are also electric menorahs. Some people also use oil lamps. The ninth candle space is generally higher than the others and lights up every night. This ninth candle is there so people can see the other candles they're lighting. So, two lights go on on the first night, three on the second and so on. Some families have the head of the house light the candles. Other families share responsibility. The menorah is supposed to be placed somewhere visible like in a window facing the street. The candles are supposed to remain lit at least 30 minutes after dark. There are also special prayers that people say and holy songs sung when the candles are lit.
Schools and government offices are open to Hanukkah as celebrations take place at night. Some families exchange gifts every night of the holiday. Some foods traditionally eaten in Hanukkah include latkes, potato pancakes and doughnuts. These and other fried foods are eaten because they are cooked in oil and remind people of the oil that lasted 8 nights. Children play with a special four-sided spin called dreidel.

text:
In the central square, there was once an orgy of music, street dancing and unparalleled fun for any other nation in the Americas, Haitians say.
But where there was joy now lies a vast settlement of people without loved ones, without homes, without belongings of life.
Haitians have celebrated Carnival through dictatorships, military coups and bloodshed. The popular belief was that if a government failed to comply with Carnival, Haiti’s equivalent to Mardi Gras would surely fall, said Marie Laurence Lassegue, Haiti’s minister of culture and information.
But this year, the three-day festival has been cancelled, another indication of the enormity of the earthquake's devastation.
The musicians shut up, the seamstresses stopped sewing costumes and the ghost skeletons of unfinished floats lay scattered outside Port-au-Prince. One month after the devastating January 12 earthquake, the Champs de Mars square is home to the displaced people of the capital, where thousands of people have taken out a small space in which to survive.
Full coverage of the aftermath of the earthquake
This is the first time Carnival is not happening, said Roberto Martino, lead singer of the popular Kompa T-Vice band. I don't even think about music anymore.
Less than a week before the start of Carnival on Sunday, the fun is replaced by mourning. The nation's leading concert producer, Charles Jubert, died. So did the members of four bands who were practicing inside a studio that collapsed. Other musicians lost legs, arms and hands. They won't be able to play again.
“I don’t think we have time to think about Carnival,” Lassegue said. Maybe when we're done crying.
The three days of liberation and celebration of Carnival have an enormous importance in the lives of Haitians, Lassegue said. But this year? I don't even remember when it is.
Instead, the displaced are planning days of prayer.
“We are living in a city that is like a cemetery,” said Ronide Baduel, a nurse who lost her home and all her belongings in the earthquake. His brother died and suddenly found himself far from his middle-class existence, relegated to an improvised shop and burlap bags he used for pillows at night.
I had four good walls all around me. Now I have four sheets, he said. She's going to work with a big black fake leather bag that contains toothpaste, soap and a change of underwear. There, she can bathe properly.
“We do not know how many days, how many months, how long we will be like this,” he said. I'm always stressed out. It's like living in a jungle. How can I dance at Carnival?
Baduel and his neighbors in the shopping community said that the money that would have been spent on Carnival should be used to build houses.
Very close, the 44 members of Relax Band, who were usually revolutionizing their street performances in the days before Carnival, were concerned about their next meal.
They played Sunday before the earthquake, marching through the streets, preparing for the great performance. Now, everything was gone, including all of his instruments that were crushed when the band's coordinator Ernst Beauvaishouse collapsed.
A small setting with the red and white logo of Relax Band now houses a huge tank of water bladder dropped by a help group and mattresses to sleep under the stars.
“It is one of the greatest tragedies in our country,” Beauvais said, pointing to the rubble of his home. He said it was the band's 30th anniversary; the musicians were looking forward to showing their new song. Almost all bands in Haiti debut new pieces at Carnival.
Outside the city, the skeletons of three floaters feel like ghosts, reminders of what might have come next week.
One of the floaters belongs to T-Vice.
Bandmates Roberto Martino and Eddy Viau would have been practicing with the rest of the band for their performance at Carnival... it's an honor to win the first prize.
“If you have a good show at Carnival, you are ready for the rest of the year,” Martino said. This year, the band had planned a football program with a song called The End of the Match.
Instead, it recently launched Nou Pap Lage - LRB- We Won't Give Up -RRB-, dedicated to earthquake victims.
iReport: Looking for loved ones in Haiti
Martino tried to sing a few verses. There are so many things going through my head, he said. Overtaken by emotion, he had to compose and start again.
People say Haiti is finished, but no, no, no, we'll get up, he sang softly. We'll do our best. We will rebuild Haiti. We'll stick together.
Don't get discouraged. There will be light at the end of the tunnel. My Haitian people. I won't let him go.
The revenue from the song downloads goes to the non-profits Sow A Seed and MedShare. Music, Martino said, was so essential to Haitian life. But I didn't know when this weird silence would end; when I would be able to write lyrics, put them to the melody.
We're all so traumatized, he said. Carnival, he said, was Haiti's musical showcase. We've lost our greatest tradition. Carnival was part of us.

text:
On one of the most famous avenues in New York City, Fifth Avenue, is Museum Mile. Museum Mile is a 23 block stretch that houses some of the most famous museums in the world. Museum Mile starts on 85th Street and Fifth Avenue with the huge Metropolitan Museum of Art. There are thousands of years of art and artifacts inside. A visitor can visit an entire Egyptian tomb, sit in a Japanese-style garden, see Renaissance paintings and ancient Greek and Roman sculptures. There's even a gallery with musical instruments. In summer, there is a rooftop garden where there are spectacular views of the city, especially the Central Park.

The Guggenheim, on 88th Street and Fifth Avenue, looks a little like a snail shell from the outside. When it opened in the 1950s, the swirling architecture, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, was considered ugly by many. This museum focuses on modern art, but sometimes presents special exhibitions as one they had a few years ago of ancient Mexican ruins. The National Museum of the Academy and the School of Fine Arts on 91st Street and Fifth Avenue is the oldest school of art in the city, dating from 1825. The Jewish Museum on 93rd Street and Fifth Avenue, tells 4,000 years of Jewish history. Ten blocks from 103rd Street and Fifth Avenue is the New York City Museum, showing the history of the Big Apple since its colonial beginning.
One block from 104th Street and Fifth Avenue is El Museo del Barrio. This museum began as a space to reflect the great community of Puerto Rican migrants in the city. It now has exhibitions focused on art throughout Latin America. On the other side of the avenue is the Central Park Conservatory Garden, with a fountain that has a sculpture of three women dancing of life size.

text:
Canadian tennis player Frank Dancevic beat Australian Open organizers for forcing players to compete in “inhuman” conditions after it collapsed on the court while temperatures rose to 41C.
Dancevic, who collapsed during the second set of his first round against Frenchman Benoît Paire on track discovered six in Melbourne Park and collapsed for a minute, said the conditions were clearly dangerous for players. He also said the heat had made him hallucinate: “I was dizzy from the middle of the first set and then I saw Snoopy and I thought, ‘Wow, Snoopy – that’s weird. '"
“I think it’s inhuman. I don’t think it’s fair for anyone – for players, for fans, for sport – when you see players break out of games, faint,” he added. “I’ve played five set games all my life and being out there for a set and a half and fainting with a heat stroke, it’s not normal.
“Having players with so many problems and complaining about the tournament is too hot to play; until someone dies, they simply go ahead with it and putting matches in this heat. I personally don’t think it’s fair and I know that many players don’t think it’s fair.”
Other participants generally agreed. Number one Britishman, Andy Murray, said: “It’s definitely something to look at. As easy as it is to say that conditions are safe, it only takes one bad thing to happen. And it looks terrible for the whole sport when people are collapsing, the guys in the ball are collapsing, the people in the stands are collapsing. That's not great.
“I know that when I went out to strike before the match, the conditions between 2.30 and 3 p.m. were very, very harsh. Whether it's safe or not, I don't know. There have been some problems in other sports with players with heart attacks.”
Caroline Wozniacki said: “I put the bottle of water on the court and started melting a little under the plastic. So, you know it was warm.
John Isner, who retired from his first round match with a right ankle injury, said: “It was like an oven when I open the oven and the potatoes are made. That’s how it is.”
defending champion Victoria Azarenka took the same line. “It felt really hot, like you were dancing in a frying pan or something,” he said.
The tournament’s “extreme heat” contingency plan was put into effect for women’s matches on Tuesday, allowing for an additional ten-minute break between the second and third sets. However, under a change in the rules for 2014, the decision on whether to stop matches in the tournament is now at the discretion of the tournament director, Wayne McKewen. Instead of using Celsius raw readings to assess heat, organizers prefer to use the wet bulb balloon temperature compound, which also measures humidity and wind to identify perceived conditions. Organizers said temperatures peaked at 42.2C in the early morning of Tuesday and conditions had never reached the point where the game would stop. “We have to reach a minimum threshold and have a forecast that it will remain for a reasonable time,” McKewen said in a statement. “That didn’t happen. While the conditions were warm and uncomfortable, the relatively low level of humidity ensured that the game would continue.”
Dancevic, who said he had felt dizzy since the middle of the second set, resumed after medical attention, but, as expected, ended up losing 7-6, 6-3, 6-4. “It was very close to stopping completely,” he said. “I wasn’t running too far toward the end. I wasn’t tired; I just felt that my body temperature was too high.”
A boy from the ball had previously required medical attention after collapsing during the victory of Milos Raonic 7-6, 6-1, 4-6, 6-2 over Daniel Gimeno-Traver on the equally exposed eight court and the tournament shortened the rotations for the boys from the ball to 45-minute shifts. Peng Shuai of China also said that the heat had made him twist and vomit, and had to be helped by the court after his defeat of 7-5, 4-6, 6-3 to Kurumi Nara of Japan. Officials played with health risks, saying that most of the matches were completed without calling for medical attention.
“Of course, there were some players who experienced heat-related illness or discomfort, but none required significant medical intervention after completing their match,” said Tim Wood, the tournament’s medical director, in a statement.
Most of the competitors, however, followed Roger Federer's line which, although the conditions were difficult, were the same for both players. “It’s just a mental thing,” the Swiss said, although before Dancevic collapsed. “If you’ve trained enough your whole life, or the last few weeks, and you think you can do it and get over it, there’s no reason. If you can’t deal with it, throw away the towel.”
Dancevic disagreed. “I don’t think it has much to do with the way players are. Some players are used to heat – their bodies can genetically handle heat and others’ can’t,” he said. “It’s dangerous to be out there; it’s dangerous. An hour and a half ago since my game and I still can’t pee.”

text:
The roof is plastic supported by a crooked tree trunk and desks just a gypsum of plaster chairs, but students within the Chemin des Dunes school are studying with the same intensity as they would be at a seminar at Oxford University. The hope of a new life in France is at stake.
“The French language is very difficult, but we work hard. If we come every day, we may be able to touch our dreams,” says Kamal, a Darfurian refugee devastated by the war in Sudan who comes to three or four hours of class every day. “It’s a good thing to keep your brain active.”
The 29-year-old electrical engineer is one of the tens, perhaps hundreds, of refugees living in the “jungle” camp outside Calais who have applied for asylum in France and are eager to learn the language of what they expect to be their new home.
Like many of his fellow students, he is frustrated that the media coverage of the extensive villa-shop has focused only on those who use it as a rally for risky night deals to board trucks or trains across the canal.
“I have to tell people in the UK that they think everyone wants to go there. But there are many people here who want to stay in France,” Kamal said.
According to United Nations data, France already has more than a quarter of a million refugees; the country has hosted more than twice as many as the United Kingdom, despite the fact that countries have similar populations.
There are another 56,000 asylum seekers waiting for their asylum application to be processed in a French safe haven, the second highest in Europe, while in the UK there are 36,000.
Although applicants await a response, France does not provide them with any financial support or allow them to work, and the slow process may take many months. The jungle camp offers a free meal a day and a plastic roof over their heads so many decide to endure basic conditions for a few more months, rather than potentially endangering their offer of asylum by working illegally.
The idea of the school was first promoted by some of that group at the beginning of the summer, when they were bored of sitting waiting and nervous about starting a new life in France totally unable to communicate. It was a reality in a few weeks, which opened on July 11.
“We did it to bring together the ‘brothers’ and, at the same time, they can learn French,” said Zimarco Jones, the Nigerian founder of the school, who arrived in Calais in 2013 and is still waiting for his asylum application to be processed. “Now, we have to build another,” he says with a smile.
In its most crowded classroom, the small classroom has 30 students, piled up in five rows of desks in front of a large green slate and pictures of cartoon animals for each letter of the French alphabet. There are also English, art and t’ai chi classes, but the most attractive are French classes, taught by volunteers from Calais and beyond.
“French isn’t as easy as English, but two weeks ago I decided there was no way to get to the UK,” says George, another Darfur refugee and dedicated student. He wanted to cross the Canal because he speaks English fluently but, with language classes, he says he is happy to settle in France.
“Anywhere there is peace, I can stay, there’s no problem,” he says, already waiting in the classroom for more than half an hour before his teachers arrive.
He admits that he doesn't know much about France, but he says the classes help him gradually to understand the country, as well as the language.
Many of the volunteers in the jungle school are local teachers who are giving up their summer vacation.
Jenny Flahaut, 33, who works in a children's home, was inspired to volunteer after seeing an ad on Facebook. “I saw these people in Calais every day and wanted to do something for them,” he said.
She is particularly frustrated by the representation of migrants in the media and by politicians who have never visited the countryside, most recently David Cameron, the British Prime Minister, who in a highly criticized speech spoke of “heating” of people trying to get to the UK.
“They don’t know them and they have a bad vision, but they’re not,” Flahaut said as he prepared for an afternoon lesson. “Most of them are very good people. They're cozy and friendly. They want to improve their lives and improve them, and learning is part of that.”
The teachers and Zimarco now focus on creating a separate classroom to cater for about 200 women and two dozen children. Women are outnumbered by about ten to one by men in Calais camp and most feel uncomfortable attending classes with male students they don't know, say volunteers.
When this ends, the former hotel worker whose work takes the school off the ground is remembered in his unofficial name – everyone in the camp simply calls it “the school of Zimarco” – has more dreams to make the camp a place to live, not just survive. He wants to set up a football team for migrants, explains through an instant cappuccino in the immaculate shop he calls home, and even dreams of changing the name of the camp. He hates “the jungle” because it implies that residents are not people.
“We have a discotheque, a house, a mosque, a school, shops,” he says. “We are not animals.”

text:
The director of a local university has asked him to write a report on the advantages and disadvantages of working abroad on summer holidays. He would like to know if the university should recommend "work holidays" to its students.
A report on students' experiences of working abroad
Introduction
Currently, approximately 25% of Hawthorne College students work abroad during summer holidays. This report aims to show the benefits and disadvantages of working abroad to decide whether the university should recommend the experience to its students.
In preparing this report, a sample of 100 students was interviewed, 23 of whom had worked abroad. This is a summary of his remarks.
Benefits
According to the students interviewed, working abroad during summer holidays can bring several benefits. Above all, students can improve their language skills by working in a non-English speaking country. This can help them get a better job in the future. In addition, learning about a different culture and way of life makes people more open-minded. Another advantage is that students can be more confident when learning practical skills to help them live independently later in life, for example, finding accommodation and cooking for themselves.
Inconvenient
However, a large number of respondents also mentioned drawbacks. Students who need to study during the summer will have difficulty doing so while working abroad. Most important of all are financial issues: only a minority of students can afford travel, accommodation and visa expenses. In addition, students may have to accept low-income jobs if they do not master the local language, so they may have difficulty covering their expenses.
Conclusion and recommendation
Working abroad can improve the language skills and confidence of students. However, students often need to earn money during vacation to support their studies and work abroad may not provide the opportunity to save. In addition, the cost of travel means that only students who are able to pay for it have the opportunity to do this. Therefore, the university should only recommend working abroad if there is financial support from the university for students who need it.

text:
An atmosphere of melancholy and changing times permeates the opening to the final series of Downton Abbey. The year is 1925 and there are already the first noises of economic storms that will ravage the end of the decade. Neighbors are selling their own stately home, while Lord Grantham tries to trim the servants after declaring that the underdogs are no longer affordable.
But in the true abbey of Downton, the castle of Highclere – a stately house owned by George “Geordie” Herbert, eighth Count of Carnarvon – the financial perspectives have rarely been brighter. According to Lady Fiona Carnarvon, Downton's huge global success has funded a renewable building repair program designed to safeguard Highclere for the next generation.
“It’s been an amazing magic carpet ride for all of us,” he said. “It has given us a wonderful marketing platform, an international profile. I'm extremely grateful. My husband and I love the house, and the people here. Now, without a doubt, he is loved by millions of people.”
Currently, only the ground and first floors of Highclere are used at the borders of Hampshire. However, a project has been initiated to restore the rooms of the abandoned towers that will eventually allow visitors to climb to the tower to an exhibition showing the work of the architect of the Houses of Parliament, Sir Charles Barry, who rebuilt the house between 1839 and 1842.
When Downton Abbey producers first approached Highclere in 2009, the family faced a repair bill of nearly £12 million, with an urgent labour price of £1.8 million. But, by 2012, the Downton effect had begun to remove the pressure. Lord Carnarvon then said: “It was just after the banking crisis and it was gloomy in all directions. We'd been doing corporate functions, but everything got pretty thin after that. Then Downton arrived and became an important tourist attraction.”
The number of visitors doubled, to 1,200 a day, as Downton Abbey, written by Julian Fellowes, came to be projected around the world after becoming a success in the UK in 2010 and then in the United States. It is currently broadcast in 250 countries. The policy of ticket sales, which was previously a basic one, has become a computer-based early reservation system, which helps to guarantee the admission of foreign visitors. Highclere Enterprises accounts for 2014-15 show that current assets have nearly tripled to around £1m since 2012. Gareth Neame, the executive producer of the series, said, “I think Downton Abbey secured Highclere’s future.”
Peter Fincham, ITV's television director, remembers the moment Highclere was booked. "I thought, 'So what? 'Cause I've never heard of Highclere Castle. One stately house looks just like the other. How wrong I was. The castle has also been a huge character.
Downton tourists are part of a growing phenomenon. VisitBritain estimates that almost 30% of foreign visitors, or nearly nine million people, include castles and historic houses in their itineraries. Nearly half of potential visitors to Britain now say they want to enjoy the “stage ” and visit places that appear in movies or on television. More than a million embark on a tour of historic buildings each year, spending more than £1 billion. From the largest emerging tourist markets, 51% of Brazilians, 42% of Russians and Chinese, and 35% of Indian visitors are likely to include a visit to a site of interest in their travels. VisitBritain’s director, Patricia Yates, said: “The links between tourism, film and television are powerful.” He added that the dramas of the time have also increased the popularity of regions outside London.
Neame is now the ambassador of the great British campaign, which is supported by government departments and the British Council, using it to promote the United Kingdom around the world. Events include special Downton theme receptions at British embassies.
Neame said: “They approached me by reach. A lot of people here think of it as soapy entertainment. In other parts of the world, people venerate our actors, our talent for writing and production. It's something I'm passionate about; I'm a very strong believer in soft power. We are not as proud of our achievements as we should be.
“The Downton Abbey is iconic to express the British. Really, it's a fantasy world, based on a particular moment in history. It is the first drama of the television period that has really jumped off the screen and become part of popular culture.”
Lady Carnarvon is still interested in emphasizing that Highclere's long-term future is not necessarily safe. “The conclusion is pretty thin,” he said. “The program has allowed us to spend faster on buildings, restore madness.”
In the pipeline there is an event of the centenary of Tutankhamon in 2022, 100 years after the fifth Count of Carnarvon, along with Howard Carter, discovered the tomb that revolutionized our understanding of Egyptology. Another opportunity to keep Highclere in the public mind is the 300th anniversary of the birth of Lancelot “Capacity” Brown, who designed the grounds.
What you do is never sit on your laurels. Every day, don’t take anything for granted,” said Lady Carnarvon. “For all these big houses, you have to invest in them. And, there's been a deficit since the 1930s. Perhaps, in the past, a farm and a house defined and supported the family and their lifestyle but, today, it is quite the opposite: the challenge is how Geordie and I seek to support and care for Highclere.
“From my point of view, I have tried to persuade people that it’s fun and to have specific events with which they can participate, not just a stroll through a dusty house. We have to compete with attractions like the London Dungeon.”

text:

The Caribbean Princess is expected to be in Houston early Friday. The seven-day cruise is being cut off for a day.
Sick passengers are asked to stay in their cabins, while staff disinfect public areas, such as bathrooms and lifts.
The decision to cut the short trip was made on the basis of forecasts of heavy fog, not the outbreak, Benson said.

He continued his education on his own after that. With his new reading skills, Douglass began teaching other black slaves the New Testament. He had a nice owner, who saw no harm in this activity, but his neighbors didn't see him closely. It was not long before the lessons ended, after members of the white community took violent action.
Douglass finally escaped slavery, and settled in the state of Massachusetts, where he began his struggle to end slavery. Douglass became one of the most influential people of his generation. He made powerful friends in the U.S. government. During one of his lecture tours in 1843, Douglass was almost beaten to death by an angry mob, who disagreed with his message of abolition. -LRB-CNN -RRB- Craigslist reports about 80 million ads on their site every month, so even if you haven't met a stranger to buy or sell something online, you're likely to meet someone who did.
The vast majority of transactions go smoothly, but the site has a history of being co-opted by criminals sometimes.
A couple from Georgia were traveling to a Craigslist transaction last month when they left their suburban home in Atlanta hoping to buy a 1966 Ford Mustang. They did everything right... they went together, and they told their family they were going to the transaction.
However, the bodies of Elrey Bud Runion and his wife, June, were found on January 26, according to the police. A man from South Georgia has been charged with murder in their deaths.
In a separate incident on Friday, two men in Georgia met with a salesman to buy a dog. The seller pointed a gun at them in an attempted robbery, but one of the buyers carried a gun and shot him fatally, the police said. The investigation is ongoing.
Recent incidents should remind those involved in this type of online trade that it is desirable to be vigilant. So what can you do to make sure you don't fall prey to ne'er-do-wells next time you respond to an online ad?
Philip Holloway is a law adviser and defense attorney with some tips on things to remember when buying and selling goods online:
10. Do not disclose personal information
Remember that this is a business transaction, so never disclose Social Security numbers, home or business addresses, or bank information.
9. Keep your cell phone close
Have a cell phone in your hand throughout the transaction and be ready to call 911 at the first sign of trouble.
8. Don't use your personal email
Use an anonymous email address to communicate with the buyer or seller.
7. Disable caller identifier
Disable the caller ID when calling the buyer or seller on the phone. Most cell phone and landline companies offer this by dialing *67 before making the outgoing call.
6. Do not pay cash
Do not accept cash and do not offer to pay cash. Use a cash check instead and make it a non-negotiable transaction term.
5. If it's a high-priced transaction, do it in a bank.
The higher the price of the item in question, the greater the risk of the transaction. Carry out these transactions in a banking service so that a banking professional can confirm that the funds have been successfully delivered.
4. Meet always during the day
Never make your transactions at night.
3. We never see each other at home.
Find a neutral place to meet... never in your home or someone else's.
2. Tell someone.
Tell a trusted friend or family member what you are doing and have another trusted friend or family member accompany you to the transaction.
1. Meet always in a public place
Most police departments will be happy to accommodate you, and are open 24 hours a day.

text:
There comes a time in the lives of some men when the days seem darker, the mortality safer, and the only sensible answer is to blow up life savings in a sports car.
Radical and often inadvisable lifestyle changes have become the cards of the mid-life crisis, but, if it is more than a myth, then humans may not be the only animals to experience it.
Now an international team of scientists claims to have found evidence of a decline in well-being between chimpanzees and middle-aged orangutans. Calm in happiness in the middle years, they say, is the mono equivalent of the mid-life crisis.
The study, which was published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, has raised eyebrows among some scientists but, according to the authors, the findings suggest that the mid-life crisis may have its roots in biology that humans share with our closest evolutionary cousins.
“There is a common understanding that there is a decline in well-being in the Middle Ages,” said Alex Weiss, a psychologist at the University of Edinburgh, to The Guardian.
“We take a step back and ask if it is possible that, instead of the mid-life crisis being human-specific and driven solely by social factors, it reflects an evolved trend for middle-aged individuals to have a lower well-being,” he said.
The U.S., Japan, Germany, and UK team asked zookeepers, caregivers, and others who worked with male and female apes of various ages to complete animal questionnaires.
The forms included questions about the mood of each ape, the enjoyment they obtained from socialization, and their success in achieving certain goals. The last question asked how caregivers would feel about being the monkey for a week. They scored their answers from one to seven.
The study included more than 500 apes in three different groups. The first two groups were chimpanzees, with the third consisting of orangutans from Sumatra or Borneo. The animals came from zoos, sanctuaries, and research centers in the United States, Australia, Japan, Canada, and Singapore.
When the researchers analyzed the questionnaires, they found that the welfare in the apes fell into middle age and rose again as the animals approached old age. In captivity, great apes often live up to 50 or more. Nadir in animal welfare occurred, on average, at 28.3 and 27.2 years for chimpanzees, and 35.4 years for orangutans.
“In all three groups we find evidence that well-being is lower in chimpanzees and orangutans at an age that corresponds approximately to middle age in humans,” Weiss said. “On average, welfare scores are lower when animals are about 30 years old.”
The team explains that the temporary fall in the welfare of apes may result from seeing depressed apes dying younger, or through age-related changes in the brain that are reflected in humans. Weiss admitted that, unlike men, apes are not known for pursuing radical and often disastrous lifestyle changes in middle age.
Robin Dunbar, professor of Evolutionary Psychology at Oxford University, was doubtful about the findings. “What can produce a sense of well-being or contentment that varies throughout life like this? It's hard to see anything in the life of an ape that has that kind of pattern, that they'd think of. They are not particularly good at seeing the future; that is one of the great differences between them and us.” Alexandra Freund, professor of psychology at the University of Zurich, was also skeptical. He said that the concept of a mid-life crisis was unstable even in humans. “In my reading of literature, there is no evidence for the mid-life crisis. If there is any indication of deterioration in emotional or subjective well-being it is very small and, in many studies, it is not at all there.”
But Weiss believes that the findings could point to a deeper understanding of the emotional crisis that some men may experience. “If we want to find the answer as to what is happening with the mid-life crisis, we must look at what is similar in middle-aged humans, chimpanzees and orangutans,” he said.

Unfortunately, many of those men often ended up without a job, a place to stay, or even food to eat. To help these people, many churches began to establish shelters in the Los Angeles area that would eventually become the center of the city. Although the agricultural landscape changed to a large city environment, these shelters remained a refuge for many homeless people

Many economic and social changes have led to men and women of all ages going to the streets of Los Angeles. Some of them are there as a result of substance abuse that has left them out of money and out of work. Others are veterans of various wars who cannot find the resources to return to their normal lives. In addition, many of these people suffer from mental disabilities that prevent them from finding a job or being accepted into the rest of society.
Since there are many different causes leading to homelessness, it is easy to see why finding solutions to help all homeless people is so difficult. While there are many programmes that focus on the daily provision of food to the homeless, it is much more difficult to find programmes that seek to help the homeless find work and stable housing. In order to finally find a solution that effectively helps to reduce the number of homeless people in the city, much more individualized care must be given to people according to their physical and mental health, and their circumstances.

Many of us know that we are deprived of sleep, but imagine if we could fix it with a fairly simple solution: get up later. In a speech at the British Science Festival, Dr. Paul Kelley, a clinical research partner at the Sleep and Circadian Neuroscience Institute at Oxford University, asked schools to scale their start times to work with the natural biological rhythms of their students. It would improve cognitive performance, test results, and student health (sleep deprivation has been associated with diabetes, depression, obesity, and an impaired immune system).
It follows an article, published in 2014, in which he pointed out that, when children are about ten years old, their biological awakening time is around 6.30am; at 16, this rises to 8am; and at 18, someone who can think like a lazy teenager actually has a natural waking hour at 9am. The start time of the conventional school works for children aged 10, but not for children aged 16 to 18. For older teens, it might be wiser to start school day at 11 a.m. or even later. “A 7am alarm call for older teens,” Kelley and her colleagues in the newspaper said, “is the equivalent of a start at 4.30am for a 50-year-old teacher.”
He says it's not as simple as persuading teenagers to sleep first. “The natural rhythm of the body is controlled by a particular type of light,” Kelley says. “The eye not only contains rods and cones; it contains cells that then report to the suprachiasmatic nuclei in the hypothalamus.” This part of the brain controls our circadian rhythms over a 24-hour cycle. “It is light that controls it. It's like saying, 'Why can't you control your heartbeat? '"
But it is not only students who would benefit from a later start. Kelley says the working day should be more indulgent with our natural rhythms. Describing the average sleep loss per night for different age groups, he says: “Between 14 and 24, it is more than two hours. For people between the ages of 24 and 30 or 35, it is about an hour and a half. That can go on until you're about 55 when you're in balance again. The 10-and-55-year-old wakes up and sleeps naturally at the same time.”
That is why, he adds, the traditional nine to five are so entrenched; it is maintained by the bosses, many of them in the mid-50s and upwards because “it is the best for them.” So should workplaces have staggered start times as well? Should 50-year-olds or older arrive at 8 a.m., while 30-year-olds begin at 10 a.m. and the inmate or apprentice is encouraged to show up at 11 a.m.? Kelley says synchronized hours could have “many positive consequences. The positive side of this is people's performance, mood and health will improve. It is very upbuilding in a way because it is a solution that will make people less sick, happier and better at what they do.”
There would probably be fewer accidents as drivers would be more alert, he says. I could spell the end of the rush hour as people stagger their working and school time. A later start of the day for many, Kelley says, “is something that would benefit everyone, particularly families. Parents go and try to wake up teenagers who are waking up three hours earlier. It creates tensions for everyone.”
So what time does Kelley start working? “I’m 67 years old, so that means I’m ten years old again and I get up right after six. And, yes, he says he finds the start of his working day much easier now than when he was younger.

During the first part of the twentieth century, poliomyelitis was considered one of the greatest health threats in the United States of America. Polio was a vicious disease that claimed the life of the victim, or left her with severe disabilities. In 1952, the United States suffered one of its hardest polio epidemics in its history. More than 58,000 polio cases were reported that year and 3,145 people lost their lives. In addition, more than 21,000 people suffered some form of paralysis ranging from mild paralysis to extreme cases in which people became disabled. Dr. Jonas Salk is responsible for ending that plague.

Born in New York on October 28, 1914, Jonas Salk grew up in a modest environment. His parents were not rich, but they could put food on the table, and keep a roof over the head of their children. Salk demonstrated great academic success since childhood. At the age of 13, he was enrolled in a school for gifted children. He was considered a perfectionist by his colleagues, and was successful academically in a very competitive environment. In college, Salk chose to go to medical school even though his mother wanted him to become a lawyer. After graduating from medical school, Salk began his research on poliomyelitis, which was considered a scourge of Western society.
Polio had bewildered medical science since its discovery in the mid-19th century. When Salk turned his attention to the disease, there was little hope that someone could find a proper cure. Salk developed his vaccine in the early 1950s, and in April 1955, his achievement was announced in newspapers across the country. Salk became a national hero. His vaccine effectively ended the polio epidemic in the United States and in many countries around the world.

Some of the world's largest and most expensive transportation projects have involved building bridges. Bridges are crucial links that transport cars, trucks, and trains through bodies of water, mountain gorges, or other roads. As a result, they are one of the most important aspects of civil engineering and are subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.
The collapses of the bridge can be tragic events, leading to loss of life and serious material damage. That is why engineers, designers and bridge builders must always take their jobs very seriously. The best way to prevent these accidents is to understand why bridges collapse in the first place. Understanding the collapses of bridges can lead to significant changes in the design, construction and safety of future construction projects. The following are the main reasons why bridges fall.
Fire
Historically, more bridges were made of wood and were much more susceptible to fire. This was particularly true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark created by steel wheels and steel tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to burn and burn on the ground.
During construction
A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly to the workers at that time.
Earthquakes
Earthquakes damage all structures, including bridges. Fortunately, this type of collapse is relatively rare, especially with modern bridges. Engineers have learned to design bridges in seismic areas in areas that are much more resistant to movement.
Default
Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realize why after conducting a full investigation. In some cases, this could happen because inferior quality material was used in the construction, or because of a defect in a key piece of the bridge. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to withstand a certain amount of weight and no more.
Boat or train crash
Both types of accidents are extremely rare, but ships and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. With trains, it's impact speed that can bring down a bridge. With ships, it is the very large mass they have that can cause collapse, even if they are moving very slowly when it happens.
The best way to avoid bridge flaws is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can detect structural weaknesses, safer working environments, and better designs can help reduce these terrible accidents.

July 4th is the celebration by the United States of its independence from England. It is the day the Declaration of Independence was adopted by the ancestors of the new country, and it is a national holiday. It is celebrated every year since 1776. Americans celebrate this day as one of the most revered festivals in the country.

Independence Day celebrations include fireworks that are organized by various organizations across the country. The shows are held in stadiums, recreational parks and private houses. In addition, many companies have special gifts and discounts for all residents on this day. Fireworks shows are the best in stadiums, where they attract a large number of people. This is a recent change in the way Americans celebrate the day. In the past, most people bought their own fireworks from vendors who sell their products in supermarket parking lots.
The reason why many cities no longer allow the sale, or the use of fireworks, is due to the fire risks they pose. That is why large stadiums and professional celebrations parks have become popular in recent years. Of course, many people still celebrate at home. There are some cities where the sale and use of fireworks are still legal, and many Americans take full advantage of this.
Another tradition of July 4th is the backyard barbecue. Holidays take place in the middle of the summer, and Americans love to roast outdoors to avoid heat inside the house. Burgers and hot dogs are the food of choice, but steaks are also often prepared. There's nothing better than a great American meal and a cold drink celebrating July 4th. It's a popular party, and it's one that has great significance for most Americans.

text:
Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it's easy for customers to buy without thinking, while big brands offer clothes so cheap that they can be treated as disposable items – used two or three times and then thrown away.
In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 a year on new clothing, which accounts for about 4% of his income. That may not sound much, but that figure conceals two far more worrying trends for society and the environment. First, much of that consumer spending is through credit cards. Currently, the British owe approximately £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66% of the average closet budget. Besides, people don't just spend money they don't have, they're using it to buy things they don't need. Britain throws 300,000 tons of clothes a year, most of which go to landfills.
People may not realize that they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothing to charities. But charity stores can't sell all those unwanted clothes. "Fast fashion" goes out of fashion as quickly as it comes in and is often of very poor quality for recycling; people don't want to buy it second hand. Large amounts end up being discarded, and a lot of clothes that charities cannot sell are shipped abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.
However, a different trend is emerging in opposition to consumerism – the tendency to "buy nothing." The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the United States, where it became a rejection of the excessive spending and consumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during the Thanksgiving weekend. On the day of buying nothing people organize various kinds of protests and cut their credit cards. Throughout the year, the Buy Nothing groups organize the exchange and repair of items they already own.
The trend has now reached social media influencers who usually share clothing and makeup posts that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods like a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working to buy only food. During the first three months they learned to live without buying electrical items, clothing, or things for the house. For the next stage, they abandoned services, such as haircuts, eating in restaurants or buying gasoline for their cars. In a year, they had saved $55,000.
The changes they made meant two fewer cars on the roads, a reduction in plastic and paper containers and a positive impact on the environment of all the energy saved. If everyone followed a similar plan, the results would be impressive. But even if you can't handle a full year without shopping, you can participate in the anti-consumer movement by refusing to buy things you don't need. The Buy Nothing groups send a clear message to companies that people are no longer willing to accept the environmental and human costs of excessive consumption.

A wave of small earthquakes rumbling near Mammoth Mountain volcano have been categorized as volcanic disturbances by the United States Geological Survey.
Nearly three dozen earthquakes ranging from magnitude 2.6 to 3.8 have swarmed the area, northeast of Fresno, California, in the last two days.
Earthquake swarms in this region are not uncommon. David Shelly, a seismologist at the California Volcano Observatory, said this swarm is larger than we've seen recently, but normal in the area. He adds that they are closely watching the movement, but in the broader scheme of things, it is within the range of activity over the last decades.
Mammoth Mountain is located in an area called Long Valley Caldera. The center of the boiler has been rising slowly over the last few decades and seismologists continuously monitor it. We believe there is fluid coming from the crust that triggers the earthquakes, Shelly said.
The last swarm of earthquakes from 1997 to 1998 produced more than 2,500 earthquakes a week at its peak, according to the USGS. Since then, the region has been relatively quiet.
In July, USGS scientists installed a volcanic gas monitoring station on the mountain. It tracks gases that fluctuate with seismic activity to better track changes in real time.
The level of awareness on the United States General Service website remains ecological/normal. Mammoth Mountain, standing at 11,053 feet, last exploded about 57,000 years ago, according to the USGS.

On December 7, 1941, the United States of America was attacked by the Imperial Japanese Navy in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. The surprise attack was intended to destroy the American Pacific Fleet that stood in the way of Japan's complete domination of the Pacific Ocean during the 1940s. The attack was coordinated with attacks in the Philippines, Malaysia, Singapore and Hong Kong. Pearl Harbor was attacked by more than 350 Japanese fighter planes, bombers and torpedo planes that were launched from six aircraft carriers.

The attack of the early morning sank four U.S. battleships, and four others were seriously damaged. Six of the eight battleships were restored, and returned to service, but the Japanese also destroyed, or damaged, three cruisers, three destroyers, a mine hunter and an anti-aircraft training ship. In addition, 188 U.S. aircraft were destroyed, many of them on land. The attack was devastating. It took the United States years to recover from all the damage caused in that fateful morning. However, the Japanese were unable to destroy their main targets, the Navy carriers. So some call a stroke of luck, the U.S. fleet of aircraft carriers. I was at sea at the time of the attack.
The country was shocked by the news of the disaster. U.S. President Franklin Delano Roosevelt described the attack as cowardly, and declared December 7 as "a day that will live in infamy." On December 8, the United States formally declared war on Japan. This plummeted the country in World War II, which Roosevelt had long hoped to avoid. Shortly after the U.S. declaration of war against Japan, Germany, which was a Japanese ally, declared war on the U.S. and the country was now fully involved in the largest war in world history.

BP said on Sunday that it is satisfied with the way in which the operation of placing a new stop in its broken underwater well is proceeding.
Officers expect the containment cap to prevent oil from pouring into the Gulf. But while robots replace the old lid, crude flows freely.
The procedure, which is expected to take four to seven days, continued to progress on Sunday as teams worked to place a transition reel over the effusion well to prepare for the new connection, according to Kent Wells, Senior Vice President of BP.
“We are pleased how it goes,” Wells said, but warned that the operation, which began on Saturday with the removal of the old cap, is only on its second day.
Robots removed six giant bolts from the device early Sunday so that the new lid could be positioned.
If successful, the effects of the containment operation could stop the oil spill that began on April 20 after a deadly explosion on the Deepwater Horizon platform in the Gulf of Mexico.
But officials have said that the new containment cap would be a temporary solution, and the permanent solution would still be completing a relief well. There are two relief wells under construction.
Wells said Sunday that one of the relief wells could intercept the break-up by the end of July.
“We feel very good about how we have positioned ourselves so well,” he said.
The other relief well is expected to be completed in August.
The old cap had been diverting about 15,000 barrels a day - LRB- 630,000 gallons -RRB- to a boat. BP is still recovering 8,000 to 9,000 additional barrels per day - LRB- 336,000 to 378,000 gallons -RRB- via a line connected to another ship, the Q4000.
As we begin to increase the capacity for additional containment, we should see less and less flow, Wells said.
The recovery vessel Helix Producer is expected to start collecting oil on Sunday night, Wells said, and officials expect to reach their total collection capacity from 20,000 to 25,000 barrels - LRB- 840,000 to 1.5 million gallons -RRB- per day within three days.
Over the next two or three weeks, between 60,000 and 80,000 barrels - LRB- 2.52 million to 3.36 million gallons -RRB- a day must be collected as part of the containment process, Wells said. Scientists estimate that between 35,000 and 60,000 barrels of oil emit daily from the broken BP well.
BP says there will be a period of decrease in the capture of oil and gas from the well head during the replacement of the lid. He said another recovery vessel, the Q4000, should continue to capture and light oil and gas. There will be other recovery vessels and skiers deployed.
Two more oil skiers were added to Gulf Sunday, bringing the total to 48 collecting a mixture of oil and surface water, BP officials said. And another 15 burns were carried out in calm seas.
“It was a good day trying to contain the oil that came to the surface,” Wells said.
Wells also said there will be a significant measurement capability added to the new cap so that officials can get a good idea of the flow.
BP said in a statement that the new cap should improve containment efficiency during the hurricane season by allowing shorter disconnection and reconnection times.

text:
Veterans Day is an official holiday of the United States that is celebrated on November 11 of each year. As Memorial Day remembers those who have died while serving in any of the branches of the U.S. Armed Forces: Army, Navy, Marines, and Coast Guard, Veterans Day honors all members of the armed forces, especially the living. As a federal holiday in the United States, government offices and schools are closed, and most people have a day off from work. Banks are closed, too. If November 11 falls on a Sunday, then the party is observed on the following Monday.

The feast was first observed after World War I, which ended on November 11, 1918. It was then called Armistice Day and it was more about celebrating the absence of war and honoring those who served in that one war. It was not known as Veterans' Day until 1954 after World War II and the Korean War, when there were many more members of the armed forces.
Many restaurants offer free meals to veterans today. There is always a special ceremony at the Arlington National Military Cemetery in Washington, D.C. This ceremony involves a crown placed on the tomb of the Unknown Soldier. Many major cities also hold parades on this date. Usually the American flag is waved to half as a reminder of those soldiers who have died and many ceremonies observe a moment of silence for the same reason. In Canada the party is called Remembrance Day. A symbol of the day is the poppy flower. It is said that the red poppy flower represents or is a symbol of the blood of the soldiers. Many people use or give away poppy flowers in the day.

In 2005, when BlackBerry brought instant messages to the mobile phone, the company was just entering its booming times. While the iPhone remained a flash in Steve Jobs' eye, BlackBerry's innovations ensured that his smartphone was one of Canada's largest exports.
Six years later, in the summer of 2011, when violence enveloped London and spread to Birmingham, Nottingham, Liverpool and Manchester, BlackBerry Messenger (BBM) was so effective in mobilizing protesters that politicians called for the service to be temporarily shut down. But two years later, it is the users themselves who are pulling the plug. As demand for BlackBerry phones fades, the old, noisy BBM vine is falling silently. Dozens of alternatives have emerged to take their place, from Facebook and Apple's own instant messaging apps to independent start-ups like WhatsApp and Kik (which is also Canadian). Free to download and use, they use the Internet to exchange text messages, images, voice clips, stickers, and even videos in the case of WhatsApp, among most types of phones.
In an attempt to maintain its next, BBM has been released on Android and Apple phones. Despite the competition, the response has been overwhelming, with an announcement that there have been more than 20 million downloads. But, despite the initial interest, many believe that the broader version of BBM will do little to save the service.
“The move to take BlackBerry to the iPhone is four or five years too late,” says James Gooderson, an 18-year-old student blogging about technology. “WhatsApp has eliminated the reason why young people would use a BlackBerry.” BBM claims 80 million users a month after its update, but WhatsApp has 300 million. Other services expose the limitations of BBM: unlike Skype and Viber, it does not yet offer video or voice calls; unlike Path, it does not share location; there is no video exchange, such as in iMessage; and stickers (a more sophisticated version of the smiling face), adored by children around the world, are also unforgivably absent. Even contacts and the shared calendar that BBM made possible on BlackBerry phones have not migrated to versions of Apple and Android.
The messaging is moving from verbal to visual. Photos uploaded to Instagram trigger a wave of comments and Snapchat photos, which are deleted within ten seconds, have opened up a world of other possibilities. Like BBM, all these services are free of charge for any phone with Internet connection. However, in 2011, BBM was so powerful that it was attributed the start of a revolution in Egypt; and, at the time of the London riots, it was a more urgent news source than the television screen.
“We could see in our BlackBerry messages where the troublemakers were going; TV news would catch up four hours later,” said Jean-Pierre Moore, 28. He runs a youth club in Stockwell, South London, an area with some of the highest levels of crime and economic deprivation in Britain. Moore communicates mainly on an iPad now. It rejects the idea that the BBM curfew urged by some parliamentarians would have stopped the looting. “Social media was not the reason,” he says. “I know a lot of people who mutiny. People had been angry for a long time. Mention the words 'stop and search' here and immediately you have a room full of angry young people."
Nearly 80% of young smartphone owners regularly use a social media app, says the research company Enders Analysis, but two-thirds use more than one. Among 16-24 year olds, 60% use Facebook every day, but 46% use alternatives. “It’s a much more complex and multifaceted environment,” says Benedict Evans, digital media specialist at Enders. “The smartphone itself has become the platform. All of these apps are connected to your phone book and photo library. Applications go up and down like fireworks. Some, like Instagram, last; others disappear into the air.”
Bennett, 13, has three devices, all hand-held by family members. He keeps his BlackBerry for messaging, uses an iPhone over wi-fi to play games and makes phone calls on an Android phone branded HTC. His friends are still at BBM – the four phone robberies at his school so far this term was all BlackBerrys. With just a few buttons, a single BlackBerry message can be sent to the entire phone owner's contact schedule – several hundred people in some cases; on WhatsApp, the limit for a transmission message is 50. But, for Bennett, Instagram is now an important social network. “Instagram is Facebook without parents,” he says. “Facebook has been taken over by the older generation. Once I saw my mother on Facebook, I deleted my account.”
For families who may have difficulty paying their heating bills this winter, the low price tag attached to buying and communicating on a BlackBerry retains its appeal. Unlimited BBM messages are available to anyone with a second-hand device and an offer of £7-per-month T-Mobile. But confidence in the privacy of the BBM system has eroded. Part of the attraction to entrepreneurs, revolutionaries, protesters and protesters was the belief that encrypted words sent over the company's secure servers could not be traced to their writers. The accusations after the riots ended that belief.
Across the city from Stockwell, outside the doors of a private school in South Kensington, older students have Apple logos on their phones. Everybody uses WhatsApp. For many, BBM is a distant memory. “I still have a Blackberry, but I’m the only one,” says a teenager standing with a circle of friends. And how does that make you feel? “Isolated,” he replies.
