The number of trips including a night stay has almost halved in the last decade, from 1,045 million in 1999, according to figures from Tourism Research Australia cited in the Sydney Daily Telegraph.
They show a fall of 18 percent in a year, from 687,000 in 2008 to 563,000 last year.
The New South Wales government now wants to increase both the number of tourists and spending by attracting visitors interested in a more comfortable and less robust experience.
His tourism strategy has attracted criticism for refusing to rule out development within the park.
Mark Jarvis, who runs a hotel in Katoomba, the main tourist city of the Blue Mountains, just an hour and a half away from Sydney, said: "We are very concerned because the uniqueness of the area revolves around the fact that we sit among World Heritage parks.
So the fact that they're looking for development, the fact that if there's a potential to do it, it's not right for this area.
It is not in Sydney's interest to see this area develop; the attraction for the people of Sydney to come here is our lack of development.
Cameron agreed: What I see happening in New South Wales is a distraction and distraction away from nature conservation as the main purpose of parks -- and if we don't focus on that standards and the state of our parks will slowly decline.
However, Randal Walker, president of Blue Mountains Tourism, argued that it is possible to develop sustainable tourism without damaging the natural beauty that visitors come to see.
If there was a greater interest in development, I think those investors would only do so in terms of: is it sustainable? He said Walker. Is there going to be a return on investment? Penelope Figgis, government advisor on conservation and tourism, also believes that the park has to develop.
She said: Everyone is looking for how we can make national parks relevant in the future. We have a very urbanized population that is not so connected to nature.
The New South Wales government wanted to see how we could connect with nature, but at the same time stimulate regional economies through nature conservation-related tourism activities.
I cannot think of a better way to persuade someone to be a defender of a beautiful and wild area than to go there and dive into that experience, he added.
The danger in this quest for something new, is to turn nature into a commodity, Cameron argued.

Leaving his car, the wife of a government worker with permission walked into a small building full of free food.
He approached the door with his head down. A stewardess asked for his name, looked up and began to cry.
“It’s okay, it’s not your fault,” the volunteer said as she wrapped her arms around the woman crying.
Chesapeake Cares Food Pantry, located 30 miles from the political impasse in Washington that resulted in the closure, collected a gift of adapted food for the affected workers who are not in their jobs and receive no remuneration.
About 200 people received bags of frozen meat, canned vegetables and other commodities on Monday morning.
These people - LRB- government employees with permission -RRB- do not know how to be poor, Rev. Robert Hahn, the head of End Hunger in Calvert County, a consortium of food bakeries in the area. These people are fish out of the water and feel humiliated, as if they had lost their dignity.
This is the second offer Hahn's group has made to federal employees. Last week, the group distributed 2,700 pounds of food to 71 different families. And if the government's closure continues, Hahn said he anticipates that his group will continue with this kind of offerings.
The closure that began on October 1 has impacted hundreds of thousands of federal workers and contractors in the Washington region, including people at the epicenter of the party confrontation of the shutdown in Congress.
The food banks in the Washington area have responded to an unexpected need created this fall by the closure, their already proven efforts for a continuous and uneven economic recovery and a hard labour market.
Men and women were on both sides of the aid on Monday in Calvert County, who received and distributed food.
Those who helped included one person working for the Department of Justice and one person employed by the Navy.
CNN agreed not to identify workers with permission who received food due to a combination of their shame and not wanting to hurt their employer.
“Receive payment help, but it doesn’t help right now,” one said, acknowledging that he will probably be paid once the closure is over.
Still, the woman said she was struggling to put food on the table.
Some told CNN they were living paycheck to paycheck.
The biggest thing - LRB - that people feel -RRB - is fear, Hahn said. Even a lot of federal employees who know they're going to make their checks, they're still going to be shy if they miss a couple of pay periods.
President Barack Obama visited a food pantry in downtown Washington on Monday, where he helped make peanut butter sandwiches.
He told reporters that he stopped at Martha's Table because many of the volunteers there had been discharged.
They are here contributing and surrendering to the community and I think that demonstrates the kind of spirit we have among all kinds of federal workers across the country, people who dedicate their lives to public service, Obama said.
Hahn, who has worked for the Chesapeake Church for 20 years, said that many of the men and women he saw picking up food on Monday were new faces that had never sought his help in the past.
While a Main Street study showed that Calvert County was the 13th richest county in the United States in 2012, Hahn said the ranking does not show how many poor workers live in the area.
It's a damn shame, Maryland government. Martin O'Malley told CNN. It's not his fault, but now they're in a position to, to have to come here for help.
O'Malley, who attended the event, said he would recommend that those who for ideological reasons feel that closing our government is a good idea to come here and see the families who are appearing for help feeding their families for the first time in their lives.
As volunteers spread food, there was obvious frustration with political leaders in Washington.
Those in line lamented the fact that they were expected to run out of pay.
Hahn said he had more important things to do than worry about how things will shake at the Capitol.
I would say this to the president and Congress, your job is to solve problems, not to create problems, Hahn said. We're here to solve problems.
Jim Acosta of CNN contributed to this report.

text:
In 2010, the old city of Srinagar was the kind of place where the police would only venture to wear armor. A bulwark for violent separatists waving for an independent Kashmir was the center of uprisings that left more than 100 people dead, buried together with dreams of peace in the mountainous region of northern India.
How fast things change. Now carefree tourists line up on the same streets for the roast lamb tikka and rogan josh steam dishes. The Nowhatta mosque, where in the summer of 2010 young people would gather after Friday prayers to throw stones at security forces, will become part of an official walking tour focused on heritage, crafts and markets. In Dal Lake, the houseboats have been booked months in advance. In the stunning gardens bordering the green slopes of the lake, visitors can take a photo with one of the most beautiful backgrounds in Asia. Until the snow melted, nearby ski resorts were also filled with rich Russians.
In 2002, only just over 27,000 tourists dared to visit the Kashmir Valley, frightened by the anti-Indian insurgency, which has claimed up to 70,000 lives. So far in 2012, the area has received almost a million tourists, more than 23,000 of them from outside India. But among them there were less than 150 British, largely because the UK Ministry of Foreign Affairs refuses to change its somewhat chilling advice, which deters most travellers by providing a list of recent security incidents in the region.
Omar Abdullah, the Chief Minister of Jammu and Kashmir, born in the United Kingdom, has pressured the British High Commission in Delhi to relax the guidelines, but in vain. “It’s a source of frustration,” admitted Abdullah, who has been in charge of India’s most sensitive state since early 2009. “Today, unfortunately, as a result of that travel notice, people’s insurance is null and void when they visit here.” The last published case of foreign tourists killed in J&K was in 1995, when six Westerners, including two British, were abducted by Al-Faran, an Islamist militant group in Kashmir. Only one escaped with his life.
“They have killed British citizens more recently in countries that have not yet prevented people from visiting. I mean, how many British citizens did you lose on 9/11? Did you keep people from visiting New York? You have lost them in Spain, in Bali; tell me where you haven’t lost them,” Abdullah said. “We lost Indians in London. There is still the possibility that Al-Qaida can do something stupid as they have done in the past, but we have not prevented the Indians from travelling to London. There is no reason to point to Jammu and Kashmir, or even Srinagar, as an insecure fate.”
Germany relaxed its guidelines for those planning to travel to the region in 2011. “Foreigners are generally not the direct target of clashes,” the amended German council advised. At that time, it was seen by many outsiders as a bold movement, coming less than a year after the 2010 riots finally died out. A national holiday on August 15 marked 65 years of Indian independence – in the past, a day full of dangers in a state where many do not feel part of the greatest democracy in the world. But this time in the independence celebrations there were no problems.
Abdullah insists that tourists are safe in the state, “as long as you take the kind of precautions you would normally take. ” In other words, do not go trekking near the border separating the controlled Indian and Pakistani parts of J&K. Syed Ali Shah Geelani, leader of the pro-Kashmiri independence party, disagrees with much of Abdullah's policy. But on the subject of tourism, the two are united. At the beginning of the summer season, Geelani wrote an open letter to tourists and pilgrims saying: “Whatever your faith, whatever language you speak and whatever region you belong to, we are bound by a common bond, the bond of humanity. You are our guest of honor – respecting and protecting guests is not only our moral obligation, but an article of faith.”
Some visitors may worry about the ethics of having fun in a place with a population suffering from record levels of anxiety and mental health problems. But all the locals we talked to in Srinagar were heartily in favour of tourism. Amjid Gulzar, 26, said Abdullah could seek truth and reconciliation, as well as encourage foreign visitors. “It has to do both; but without tourism, our economy will be in chaos,” he said, adding that while welcoming the millions of tourists who visited this year, Kashmir had to do more to attract visitors at great expense, especially foreigners.
“We need better infrastructure, better roads, reliable electricity. We need more for tourists to do at night: we don’t even have a cinema in this city and there isn’t enough for tourists to do after night,” he said. But will tourists feel welcome? In June, a local Islamic group published a “dress code” for foreign tourists. Abdullah sighs at the mention of that fury. “No one expects tourists to come here and cover their faces. I think what they were talking about was shorts and sleeveless vests, which even then wouldn't be something that would attract too much attention... I think the basic point they were doing was to be sensitive to our cultural identity and dress properly. I think that’s common sense.”
Abdullah said he was on a tourist campaign “for no reason other than the fact that I need to stimulate economics. ” J&K's finances are in a terrible state after more than two decades of turmoil. The state receives only 72 million pounds a year in taxes, and yet the salary of the 500,000 public employees is 155 million pounds, he said. It's clear why you need to find more funds, fast. For now, however, he is cautiously pleased to see the tourists back. “I’m not suggesting that because we’ve had a million tourists here that’s a sign of normalcy,” he said. “But it gives me some satisfaction that people can come, have a good time and come back.”

text:
Not all parents wait for the day their child goes to school. In fact, some parents are not sending their students to school at all. Instead, they are choosing to teach their children at home. This is called home school. Private parents, caregivers or guardians educate children individually at home rather than send them to be formally educated in public or private schools. In the U.S. Only about three percent of children are educated at home.

There are many reasons why some parents choose school at home. One reason is that some parents do not feel that their children are safe in school due to bullying and a growing trend of the police in school. Other parents want their children's education to be based on their religion or moral beliefs. However, other parents feel that school education is not good enough. Home education is also considered an option for families living in rural areas and families travelling, such as actors.
There are many different ways of school at home, and home school allows parents to customize lessons according to their children's needs. Families can buy textbooks to use or create their own materials. Some parents follow a philosophy called non-schooling, which allows the child to determine when and how they want to learn based on their natural curiosity. Some worry that home school means that students will not have opportunities to socialize. To respond to this concern, some families have created cooperatives, where a group of students studying at home will learn and play together and participate in activities that usually happen at school such as field trips and dance.
Being educated at home doesn't mean a student can't go to college. Most universities accept students at home. However, it is important for parents and students to create a portfolio or proof of what has been learned.

As a psychiatrist, former university president and defender of Arab women in science, Rafia Ghubash is one of the most influential women in the United Arab Emirates.
But his latest project is possibly his most ambitious so far: the creation of the first museum in the Middle East dedicated to women's achievements.
The museum, Bait al Banaat, or Women's House, in Dubai, was officially opened in late 2012 by Dubai's ruler Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, showing women's contribution to the country's history.
The women here were empowered a long time ago, but they haven't had a chance to tell our story, Ghubash said. Don't think that because we're covered we're not empowered.
The women here were not in the media, but they were economically engaged and ran businesses.
The museum is the culmination of five years of work for Ghubash, who financed the museum with $3 million of his own money.
For me it was a full-time job, but I had 20 volunteers of all nationalities working with me in their free time. It was nice having people with different backgrounds involved, he said.
Looking for a house for the museum, Ghubash rejected a free site in Dubai's official heritage district for an old house in the historic Gold Souk neighborhood where he grew up.
I was looking for a place to build and I found a very old house that I remember from childhood, he said. It used to be called Bait al Banaat because three single women lived there. Something about the name came to life for me.
Ghubash said his generation of grandmothers contributed much more to politics, economy, education and literature in the region than has been recognized.
Arianna Huffington says to women: Less stress, more life '
The museum contains a room dedicated to the Emirati poet Ousha Bint Khalifa, known as the Arabian Girl, a gallery dedicated to temporary art exhibitions, a collection of Arab fragrances and oils, traditional jewelry and a women's study centre.
It was very important for me to present the museum in the best possible way to attract a younger generation. “I want you to enjoy your culture and heritage,” Ghubash said.
Ghubash, 56, has undertaken the museum project while taking a sabbatical year of a career that led her to be included in the 36th edition of Arabian Business magazine of 100 most powerful Arab women in 2011.
He grew up in Dubai in a family where he was encouraged to study.
It came from a family where both parents made sure there were books available in the house, he said. I was free to read and think for myself.
Ghubash was trained as a doctor at Cairo University and for a doctorate in London, before returning to the United Arab Emirates as an assistant professor of psychiatry.
In 2001, she became president of the Arabian Gulf University in Bahrain, a position she held until 2009.
She also founded the Arab Network of Women in Science and Technology, and served as its president for four years.
My journey in life is very interesting, he said. I was focusing on becoming a doctor and practicing as a psychiatrist.
Recently, I was attracted to something different: history and culture.
Having achieved his goal at the opening of the museum, Ghubash is not content with rest and delight in glory. He is already working on his next project to compile an encyclopedia of women in the United Arab Emirates.

text:
An octopus has made a brazen escape from the National Aquarium in New Zealand as it exits its tank, sliding through a 50-meter drainage tube and disappearing into the sea.
In scenes reminiscent of Finding Nemo, Inky - a common octopus of New Zealand - made his career for freedom after the lid of his tank was accidentally left slightly ajar. The staff believes that in the middle of the night, while the aquarium was deserted, Inky stayed to the top of his glass enclosure, on the side of the tank and traveled through the aquarium floor.
Rob Yarrell, national manager of the National Aquarium of New Zealand in Napier, said: “Octopus are famous escape artists. I don't think he was unhappy with us, or lonely, since octopus are solitary creatures. But he's a very curious boy. He'd want to know what's going on outside. That’s just his personality.”
One theory is that Inky slipped through the aquarium floor - a trip of three or four meters - and then, the sense of freedom was at hand, in a drain that led directly to the sea. The drain was 50 meters long and opened towards the waters of Hawke Bay, on the east coast of the northern island of New Zealand.
Another possible escape route could have involved Inky by pressing an open pipe at the top of his tank, which led under the ground to the drain. “When we arrived the next morning and his tank was empty, I was very surprised,” said Yarrell, who has not started a search for Inky. “The staff and I have been pretty sad. But then, this is Inky and it has always been a surprise octopus.”
Reiss Jenkinson, in charge of the exhibitions at the National Aquarium, said he was absolutely certain that Inky had not been taken. “I understand very well the nature of octopus behavior,” he said. “I’ve seen octopus on ships slide through bilge bombs. And is security here too tight for someone to take to Inky and why would they do it?
Because octopus do not have bones, they are able to fit in extremely small spaces and have been filmed pressing through holes the size of coins. They are also understood to be extremely intelligent and capable of using tools. At the Wellington Island Bay Marine Education Centre, it was discovered that an octopus had the habit of visiting another tank during the night to steal crabs and then return to its own place. Another in the center, Ozymandias, was believed to have broken a world record to open a jar before being thrown into the ocean.
Inky was taken to the National Aquarium several years ago by a local fisherman who found him trapped in a pot of crabs. He had scars and "look rough," with shortened limbs, Yarrell said. “I had been living on the reef and struggling with the fish so I wasn’t in the best shape.” According to Yarrell, Inky – which is the size of a rugby ball – was an “unusually smart” octopus. “He was very kind, very curious and a popular attraction here. We have another octopus, Blotchy, but it's smaller than Inky and Inky had the personality.
The aquarium has no plans to increase safety as a result of the leak, as Inky was a “uni-off”, but the staff is “increasingly aware of what octopus can do.” Although the aquarium is not actively looking for a replacement for Inky, if a fisherman brought another octopus, he might be willing to accept it. “You never know,” Yarrell said. There's always a chance Inky can come home with us.

text:
A cardinal from the Philippines, another from Austria and an archbishop from Ireland would be the worst options for being the next Pope, according to a group representing victims of abuse by priests.
The Network of Survivors Abused by Priests, or SNAP, published their list on Thursday as cardinals who met in the Vatican in a prelude to the selection of the next pontiff.
The three are Cardinal Luis Tagle of the Philippines; Cardinal Christoph Schoenborn of Austria; and Archbishop Diarmuid Martin of Dublin, Ireland.
Martin is not a cardinal, but SNAP pointed out that a man does not need to be a cardinal to be elected Pope. Historically, the role has passed to the cardinals, however.
CNN analyst at the Vatican, John Allen, also a National Catholic Reporter correspondent, wrote last month that Schoenborn certainly has the right pedigree for the job.
And Tagle has been a leader in pressuring the church in Asia to take an aggressive stance on clerical abuse, Allen said in a series he wrote about papal contenders.
Tagle would normally be considered too young for the role, but Benedict XVI's almost unprecedented resignation could have changed the cardinals' thinking, he said.
On Wednesday, the SNAP named its Dirty Dozen list of men whom it judged to be the worst candidates for the Pope due to their handling or comments on past allegations of child sexual abuse against the clergy.
The scandal has shaken global trust in the church in recent years.
A Pew Research Center poll published on Wednesday indicates that American Catholics see it as the greatest problem facing the Vatican.
When asked what is the most important problem, 34% of the American Catholics questioned mentioned sexual abuse, paedophilia, or some other reference to scandal. No other problem obtained more than 10% of the answers.
A report for the Italian news magazine Panorama on Thursday states that the church hierarchy was alerted to the problem decades ago, in 1965, but buried the warnings.
`Absolutely key '
Since Monday, the assembled cardinals have been holding meetings, known as general congregations, to discuss the most serious issues facing the church.
The last of the cardinals summoned to elect the next Pope, Jean-Baptiste Pham Minh Man of Vietnam, arrived at the Vatican on Thursday.
No date has been set for the conclave, or secret election, for the new Pope, said Rev. Federico Lombardi, Vatican spokesman.
But Cardinal Roger Mahony, the retired Archbishop of Los Angeles, suggested that the announcement would not be far off in a tweet published on Thursday.
Days of General Congregations coming to a conclusion. Date set for the nearby conclave. The mood of excitement prevails among the cardinals, he said.
The 115 cardinal-electors -- those under 80 who are eligible to vote for the new pontiff -- are taking time to prepare for what many see as their greatest responsibility.
Although some wonder why it is taking so long to set the date for the conclave, Lombardi opposed the idea that the cardinals were dragging their feet.
The discussions they are having in the general congregations are a vital part of the process, he said, as once the conclave begins there is not much time among the vows for reflection or exchange of ideas.
Cardinals have to have all the information they need to make a mature and responsible judgment in the election, especially at a time when the church faces complex problems, he said. Preparation is absolutely key, Lombardi said.
Celibacy for priests is a burning issue, not just for church leaders.
The cardinals of the United States. gagged?
The Italian media reports focused on Thursday on the Vatican's decision to end the briefings held this week by American cardinals, amid concern over leaks of confidential discussions among cardinals.
Sister Mary Ann Walsh, director of media relations at the Conference of Catholic Bishops of the United States, wrote on a blog that Wednesday's decision came after a media report in the Italian newspaper La Stampa, which gave details of who had said what.
I compared the closure to the old Catholic school style of a child speaks and everyone stays after school, he wrote, saying something similar happened before the last conclave in 2005.
We will continue the briefings, but without cardinals, to help the U.S. media especially cover this exciting time in the church, Walsh added.
It has been a week since Benedict XVI became the first pontiff in six centuries to renounce the role. Popes usually serve until their death.
With Easter around the corner, many within the Catholic Church would like to see a new pontiff in place to lead ceremonies.
Watch out for smoke: How do you choose a new Pope?
`Mix and mix '
All cardinals, including those over 80, have the right to participate in the general closed congregations.
Lombardi said 152 cardinals met on Thursday morning. A second meeting will take place in the afternoon, as the cardinals try to resume the rhythm before agreeing the date for the conclave.
Thursday morning's affairs included reports on the financial status of the Holy See, Lombardi said. He appointed the cardinals who handed over the reports but did not reveal their content.
The cardinals could continue their meetings on Saturday, Lombardi added, but it is unlikely that they will meet on Sunday when mass can be celebrated.
Interactive: A look at possible papal contenders
Some of the discussions take place on coffee, as a Vatican spokesman revealed on Monday, the first day of the general congregations.
There is a coffee break for about 30 minutes in a special buffet area at the front of the audience room, Rev. Thomas Rosica. Cardinals have the opportunity to come down, mix and mix.
They mean what the next Pope will hear, because he is probably in that room, and they also want to alert people who have not spent so much time in Rome just what the situation is really here, as they see it, said Cardinal Francis George of Chicago.
Voters also want to enter the conclave with fairly clear ideas about who to vote for, said Boston's Cardinal Sean O'Malley. They, too, have no interest in seeing it continue, and there is no reason to believe that it will.
The last 11 conclaves have not lasted more than four days, wrote the diocese of Providence, Rhode Island, on its website.
That wasn't always the case. In the thirteenth century, the election of a pope took two years and nine months, the diocese said. Catholics were so angry with the cardinal's decision from 1268 to 1271, when Gregory X was elected, they boarded them in his chamber and pulled up the ceiling to expose them to the elements.
The fiasco led to the creation of the conclave and its precise protocol, in part to speed up the process.
What's in a name? Tracks found in the Pope’s next nickname
CNN's Fairy Messia, David Schechter, Jo Shelley and Ben Brumfield contributed to this report.

text:
The hijacking of aircraft, or the hijacking of aircraft, is the intentional taking of an aircraft usually done for political purposes. Unlike the hijacking of land vehicles, which is mostly done for financial gain, aerial hijacking is a darker, more dangerous and life-threatening action. Between the mid-60s and the mid-70s, about 160 planes were hijacked all over the world. In the United States, many had taken control of the aircraft, but no one had ever escaped within the reach of law enforcement, with a clear exception, D.B. Cooper.

D.B. Cooper's real name is Dan Cooper, but his legend started as D.B. Cooper for a media mistake in 1971. On November 24, Cooper hijacked a Boeing 727 aircraft after buying a one-way ticket from Portland to Seattle, Washington. Cooper demanded $200,000, and four parachutes to be delivered upon arrival in Seattle. Authorities complied with their ransom request, and Cooper let the 36 passengers and most of the crew get off the plane at that time.
Once back in the air, Cooper directed the pilot to fly to Mexico, but the fuel from the plane was not enough to get there without stopping to refuel. It was decided to land in Reno, Nevada to refuel. When the plane arrived in Reno, Cooper was not on board. Cooper is believed to have jumped off the plane somewhere in the wooded forests of Oregon. He had ordered the plane to fly at the lowest possible speed, and to fly at only 10,000 feet high. The legend of D.B. Cooper was born.
To date, the aerial hijacking of Cooper is the only case that has not been resolved in the United States. Cooper was never found, nor any proof of the $200,000, and his parachute. Many believe that Cooper could not survive such an altitude drop, while others say that the absence of money, or any evidence of his death proves that he survived. Anyway, D.B. Cooper's a real American legend.

A California Republican official has apologized for sending an email that represents President Barack Obama as a young chimpanzee.
To my American compatriots and everyone else who has seen the email I sent and who was offended by my action, I humbly apologize and ask for your forgiveness of my reckless behavior, Marilyn Davenport said in a statement obtained by CNN.
Davenport, who is a Tea Party activist and an elected member of the central committee of the Orange County Republican Party, said he felt that email was a joke, reported CNN affiliate KTLA.
The email contains a retouched photo of what appears to be a family portrait of two adult chimpanzees posing with a young chimpanzee with Obama's face stuck on it.
The legend that was posted with the photo says Now you know why no birth certificate, reported the affiliate.
Davenport said he would not repeat his mistake in the apology that included two Bible passages.
I am an imperfect Christian woman who does everything possible to live an honest life like that of Christ, the statement said. I would never do anything to harm or reprimand others intentionally, regardless of ethnicity. So I'm sorry, because I'm really sorry.
Despite criticism, Davenport told the affiliate that he does not need to give up his position due to email.
Scott Baugh, chairman of the Orange County Republican Party, said he was surprised by the email.
There is no doubt that email is racist. The only question is what was in Marilyn's heart, what was her intention. But I don't think there's anyone on his committee or in the world who doesn't see him as racist, Baugh said on CNN's AC360.
Baugh said he thinks Davenport should quit.
The conclusion is to be sorry for something and to have a sincere apology does not undo the action, does not stop the consequences, Baugh said. There are still consequences for what you have done and what you have done will continue to bring controversy to my party, so I am inclined to think right now that I should still resign from the committee.

I am writing to express my dismay at the service at your Eden Hill branch on Saturday, January 14.

On this occasion there were two recipes: one for 10 x 50 mg Kendomol and one for 50 x 100 mg Leoprona. They served me quickly even though there seemed to be only one service pharmacist. Critics of the 2015 Star Wars: Episode VII – The Force Awakens have called the film non-original and predictable because the story so closely reflects the first Star Wars movie in 1977. But, in fact, both films follow a structure that precedes all Hollywood films, the 'myth hero'. That's because director George Lucas based Star Wars on the ideas of Joseph Campbell's 1949 book, The Hero with a Thousand Faces. The later editions of Campbell's book even included Star Wars hero Luke Skywalker on the cover.
In his book, Campbell analyzes myths from all over the world to describe the "monomitto", a pattern that can be seen in the myths of all cultures. In short, a hero leaves home on a journey, where he overcomes obstacles and defeats enemies to return with a prize. It is a story that has been told for thousands of years, from the ancient Greeks with The Odyssey to JK Rowling's Harry Potter books.
George Lucas was one of the first film directors to base his story directly on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero begins the story by living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the start of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When you find Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi within the R2D2 robot, it is 'the call to adventure' that initiates the hero on his journey.
According to Campbell, the hero at first rejects the call to adventure, but appears a mentor who helps them and decides to "cross the threshold" and travel to the "special world" where the adventure occurs. The next stage is to pass the tests, fight the enemies and meet friends as the hero prepares to face his greatest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader within the special world of the Death Star.
Then the hero overcomes the obstacles on the way to facing his greatest challenge. Often comes a time when they face death or loss and that experience gives them the strength to finally defeat the enemy. Luke loses his mentor when he sees Darth Vader kill Obi-Wan, which helps him find the strength he needs later. When heroes succeed, they return from the special world, changed by their experiences forever. Luke's change comes when he remembers that Obi-Wan said, 'Use strength,' and uses it to help him point his laser at the heart of the Death Star. Luke takes his first steps to become a Jedi, and the hero's myth is rebooted in The Return of the Jedi, except this time his mentor is Yoda.

It is credited with the development of technology that has customized computers. Jobs, along with his childhood friend Steve Wozniak, co-founded Apple Computers in 1976, working in Jobs' garage.

Jobs was born on February 24, 1955, to parents who gave him up for adoption shortly after his birth. It was adopted by Clara and Paul Jobs. His father was an engineer who liked to spend time with his son dismantling electronic components and rebuilding them. This is when and where Jobs developed his interest in mechanical reconstruction. Jobs wasn't the best student in high school. He was known as a class clown, although he was very smart. It was in high school that he met Wozniak.
Both Jobs and Wozniak had a great interest in electronics, and the pair was known to make computer technology smaller, cheaper and more accessible to average people. Jobs began working as a video game designer for the Atari Corporation. Once Jobs launched Apple, he sold his first computers, which were called Apple I, for $666.66 each. Apple I won jobs almost $800,000 its first year, and that was just the beginning. Apple II won the budding company nearly $140 million, and by 1980, the company was worth $1.2 billion.
Jobs expanded his financial realm by venturing into other businesses such as Pixar Animation Studios, which was also very successful. He briefly left Apple to found the NeXT Corporation, which produced both software and hardware, but NeXT failed, and Jobs returned to Apple to develop iPhone and iPad. Jobs was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in 2003, and finally lost his battle against cancer in October 2011.

The women's continued relegation to the ranks of football was well kicked when France appointed its first professional director. It didn't matter if it was a second division club. It didn't matter if it was, like some bad sports – male, of course – suggested, just a cynical trick to increase advertising for a minor team, Clermont Foot 63, which currently ranks 14 out of 20 in its league.
What mattered was that Helena Costa had received the first place, a movement that saw her make history of football by becoming the first female manager to be named in the two highest divisions of any European professional league. “As a woman, it has made me happy,” said Véronique Soulier, president of the club’s supporters’ association, to journalists. “When I first heard the news, I was quite surprised, but once it happened, we were quite unanimous that it was good news. We all agree that a woman at the head of a group of men is not a bad thing.”
The new manager of Clermont Foot 63, whose average crowd at the stadium in Clermont- Ferrand in the Auvergne region in central-south France is about 3,800, is a former talent observer for the Celtic side of the Scottish Premiership. Costa, 36, was born in Alhandra, on the Tagus River, southeast of Portugal, and graduated with a master's degree in sports science. She is also a licensed UEFA coach. Previously he trained the male youth teams of Benfica, the Qatari women's team, which led to his first international victory in 2012, and, more recently, the Iranian women's national side, which he left in September 2013.
Costa was named in a two-year contract by Clermont Foot 63's president, Claude Michy, who is a champion in hoarding the headlines of his club. In 2013, he announced that the team had signed Messi. They did. Not the Argentine striker and FC Barcelona Lionel Messi, but Junior Messi Enguene, a 20-year-old midfielder from Cameroon.
Najat Vallaud-Belkacem, France’s Minister of Women’s Affairs, tweeted: “Bravo to Clermont Foot to understand that giving women a place is the future of professional football.”
Carolina Morace, an Italian woman who was the only former coach of a male professional team, said: “I don’t know Helena, but if she has been hired by a team, then it means she knows how to do her job. I hope that, one day, this can become normal.” Morace was a prominent player in the women's game. He was the top scorer for 12 seasons in Italy's A Series and played for Italy in 153 internationals. In 1999, she was named coach of Viterbese in the male C1 Series. But, after only two games, he quit work after a clash with the club's mercurial owner, Luciano Gaucci, who at that time also owned a Serie A, Perugia.
Morace said he had rejected Gaucci's request to fire his assistant and coach on the side. “He let me know that I could continue working with anyone I wanted. But by then, there was a lack of mutual trust and I didn’t like to continue in that climate of uncertainty,” he said. Morace works today as a lawyer in Rome and as an expert football commentator in television and on the pages of the daily Gazzetta dello Sport.
She said: “At the moment, I see too many men, even in the game of women, who are working, despite not having the same experience as women, who, on the contrary, are not working.” Raymond Domenech, former manager of the French national team, said: “Women know how to play football and how to handle it and are good at it. Why shouldn't they lead the men's teams? The opposite happens and does not cause any problems. It is a natural choice and reflects our society in which women are equal to men. I say well done to President Michy. I told myself that if I took over a club again, I'd hire a woman like my number two. He beat me.
A statement on Clermont Foot 63’s website said that Costa’s appointment would allow the club to enter “a new era.” On the club's supporters' website, the reaction to Costa's appointment was a mixture of surprise and a certain cynicism. “In my opinion, it’s just a publicity stunt to make people talk about the club and she won’t last the season. I find it hard to believe that I can get the respect of the players, especially when he is the same age as the older one,” wrote a fan. “Your resume is not bad, but now the question is: will it be good enough?” added another. A third wrote: “I wish her welcome and success, but I think it will be difficult for her to make her brand as a woman in such a macho business. Has our president achieved a coup in the media?”
But Soulier had hopes: “I hope that, with the new manager, the club can find the motivation they lack right now,” he said. “Team kids can be hard to handle. With a woman in charge, they may be less demanding.”
If Costa's reputation is something to go through, she'll be the one to make the demands. After making work experience in Chelsea during the first season of his compatriot José Mourinho as club manager between 2004 and 2007, it was described as “Mourinho with skirt”. Costa quickly contacted the sexist comment. “Like Mourinho, I always want to win. As far as that goes, yes, I am happy to be compared to him,” he said.

In the United States, people love partying for many reasons. Of course there are regular birthday parties, but some people even have parties to celebrate divorces! No matter what kind of party you're going to, it's a good idea to make sure you're really invited. It is considered rude to appear unless the host, the person who throws the party, invited you. You will receive a newspaper, email or verbal invitation to a party. Alternatively, you can also go as a guest of another guest, such as his appointment. Once invited, it's very important for the host to know if you're really going to show up. Many times the hosts have a attended party, which means that other people prepare the meal. They need to know how much food to eat. Let them know if you are appearing or not helping the host and consider yourself polite.

It is also important to be relatively punctual for a party. Most parties in the United States never start exactly when they say they will. Many people like to be "fashiony late", that is, appear about 30 minutes after the party is supposed to start. People like to do this to make a big entrance. Appearing more than 30 minutes before or after is considered rude, however. If you show up too early, you are likely to interrupt the host's valuable preparation time. If you show up too late, you're being rude.
Even if it's not a birthday party, it's polite to bring a present to the host. It doesn't have to be a fancy gift. A bottle of wine, or even flowers, is courteous and will be appreciated.

text:
Sleep deprivation used to be a badge of honor: a sign that he was busy and important and highly sought after. Snoozing was losing and the dream was for the cowards. Now, however, Arianna Huffington's Sleep Revolution, a "call to bed" that promises to transform your life "one night at a time," is a New York Times best-seller, and Huffington is urging people to "sleep to the top." Meanwhile, the sleep industry has woken up big and a wide range of start-ups are reinventing where, when and how we sleep, as well as how much we are willing to pay for it. For the most luxurious, luxury hotels offer “sleeping retreats”; over $1,000 give you dinner and a movie about sleep. And, if you stay at home, you can improve your bedroom with everything, from a mattress cover with a sensor that tracks your sleep ($249) to a brain wave monitoring sleep mask that allows you to sleep more efficiently ($299).
The dream has not only been corporate, but has infiltrated the corporations. Several companies already have naps and Huffington predicts that naps in offices will become “as common as conference rooms” in the next two years. So how did this happen? How did they sleep, something humans have done long before Huffington woke up, suddenly got so fashionable?
Having enough sleep is a natural fit for the kind of lifestyle in which to pay $10 for green juice and $34 for a SoulCycle class is the norm. Then, there is the increase in self quantified through usable technology. Our bodies have become input/output devices that we monitor and optimize for greater efficiency and sleep has become another set of data to follow. What Huffington emphasizes about sleep, after all, is not that it rests you, but that it restores you. Sleep, he says, is the ultimate performance enhancer and getting eight hours of rest has become the ultimate status symbol.
Do you know how Arianna Huffington has eight hours? Well, first of all, he has “nine or more” attendees, according to a recent New York Times profile. Huffington calls them “A-Team”; they do everything, from doing their errands to planning their journey to loading the Huffington Post on their computer in the morning. According to the Times, most of team A can only take about 12 months of work because it's so exhausting. Low pay also means that many of them take second jobs. Basically, they don't sleep so Huffington can... and sell books about it.
Sleeping enough isn't just a matter of valuing sleep enough to go to bed at the right time; it's a matter of going to bed in the right neighborhood and in the right body. Numerous studies show that you are more likely to sleep badly if you are poor. It's hard to sleep if you're worried about your safety or haven't had enough to eat. It's hard to sleep if you're one of 15 million American shift workers working irregular hours. The research has also found that there is a white/black sleep gap. One study shows that while white people sleep an average of 6.85 hours, African Americans sleep an average of 6.05 hours. They also have a lower quality of sleep. Researchers have attributed this, in part, to the stress of discrimination.
Do you want to know who sleeps most and what is the best quality of sleep in the United States? Rich white women. Which, if I risk guessing, is probably the same demographic Huffington is pointing to his book. Huffington describes his promotion of sleep as a “revolution” but, in reality, it is a brand change. The real sleep crisis we face is not because a few rich people think it's a waste of time; it's because 99% can't afford to spend time sleeping.
While the dream is currently enjoying a moment, it will probably be short-lived. Sleep can be a performance enhancer, but it is inefficient. The real prize is to find a way to deny sleep deprivation so that humans can function with less sleep. As expected, the military are at the forefront of this investigation. In 2008, the Pentagon published a report called “Human Performance” which examined the possibility of a future in which soldiers could act at their peak with just a couple of hours of sleep. “Suppose a human could be designed to sleep for the same amount of time as a giraffe (9.9 hours per night).
This would result in a decrease of approximately double the rate of casualties. An adversary would need an increase of approximately 40% in the level of troops to compensate for this advantage.” The report goes on to examine the effects of ampaquines, a class of medications that modulate neurotransmitters in the brain, to eliminate the effects of sleep deprivation.
In time, humans will find a way to get rid of sleep. Spending a third of your unconscious life will no longer be a luxury; it will be something only the poor will be forced to do. At that point, we may need a new kind of dream revolution.

Former Republican Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska has been authorized by the Justice Department's request to dismiss his convictions for federal corruption and drop all charges against him, his lawyer said on Wednesday.
Former Senator Ted Stevens, 85, from Alaska, lost his candidacy for reelection in November.

But in December, an unnamed FBI complainant accused prosecutors of withholding evidence from the defense, and the Department of Justice asked a judge to dismiss the charges against Stevens on Wednesday.
His name is clear, Stevenslawyer, Brendan Sullivan, told the reporters. He's innocent of the charges, as if they've never been brought.
Stevens, 85, lost his candidacy for a full seventh term in November after his conviction for seven counts of lying on Senate ethics forms. Sullivan said the Department of Justice was forced to apply for dismissal due to extraordinary evidence of government corruption. See more about the dismissal of the case
Not only did the government not provide evidence to the defense that the law requires them to provide, but they created false testimony that they gave us and actually presented false testimony in the courtroom, he said.
And one of Stevenslongtime's friends, Utah Senator Orrin Hatch, said Wednesday that Stevens was screwed by our own Department of Justice.
In a statement issued Wednesday morning, Stevens thanked the Department of Justice and Attorney General Eric Holder for requesting that the charges be dropped.
“I always knew there would be a day when the cloud around me would be removed,” Stevens said. That day has finally arrived.
The U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan has scheduled a hearing on Tuesday about the Justice Department's request to dismiss the case.
Sullivan, who is not a relative of Stevenslawyer, excommunicated the prosecutors during the trial and kept the prosecution in contempt at any given time. In the motion filed on Wednesday, the Department of Justice acknowledged that Stevens did not have access to the notes taken by prosecutors during an April 2008 interview with Allen, the former president of an oilfield services company at the center of a corruption investigation in Alaska. The notes show that Allen's responses, the prosecution's star witness, were inconsistent with the testimony he gave against Stevens, and that the interview information might have benefited Stevens in the trial, says the motion.
In the light of this conclusion, and taking into account the full circumstances of this particular case, I have determined that it is in the interests of justice to dismiss the indictment and not to proceed with a new trial, Holder said in a written statement.
Hatch, a senior Republican on the Senate Judicial Committee, said he called Stevens in Alaska on Wednesday and the former senator sounded euphoric, like anyone else would.
Here's a guy who gave over 60 years of service to the country and was fucked... fucked by our own Department of Justice, Hatch said. But he praised Holder for standing up and fixing this bad situation.
“I think he is more than proven integrity and decency in this matter, and it is not easy for him to do that,” Hatch said. By looking at it, you've realized that now what people like me have been saying is 100% correct.
Senate majority leader Harry Reid, D-Nevada, also commented on the Justice Department's petition, saying Ted Stevens is 85 years old. He's been punished enough. I'm satisfied.
And in a statement Wednesday, the governor of Alaska. Sarah Palin said Stevens deserves to be very happy today. What a horrible thing you've endured. The blatant attempts of adversaries to destroy one's reputation, career and finances are an abuse of our well-protected process and violate our God-given rights in the Constitution.
It is frightening to contemplate what we may be witnessing here: the weakening of the political process through unscrupulous schemes and professional misconduct. Senator Stevens... never lost hope. It is regrettable that, as a result of the questionable procedures that led Senator Stevensconviction days before the election, the Alaskas lost an esteemed statesman in the Capitol. His presence is lost.
The Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility will review the conduct of the prosecution team in Stevenscase, Holder said. Asked if prosecutors should be charged themselves, Sullivan told journalists, “That’s not my job. I'm a defense attorney.
During the trial, Deputy Attorney General Matthew Friedrich said Stevens hid hundreds of thousands of dollars of gifts he received from Allen's company, VECO, and Allen himself. Many of the services allegedly free of charge were provided as part of the renovation of the StevensAlaska house, prosecutors said.
Terry Frieden of CNN, Paul Courson, Ted Barrett and Deb Krajnak contributed to this report.

That millennials rely heavily on technology is not a secret. More than eight in ten say they sleep with a mobile phone next to their bed, almost two-thirds admit they send text messages while driving, one in five has posted a video of themselves online and three-quarters have created a profile on a social networking site.
Compared to other generations, millennials are the most active on social media, according to a 2010 report, and 75% of them have created at least one social media account. In contrast, only 50% of Generation X, 30% of baby boomers and 6% of those over 65 use social media. But there's a small percentage of millennials who don't use social media at all. Meet the millennials rejecting the trend.
Celan Beausoleil, 31, Oakland, California Beausoleil is a social worker and has had an “on and off, more off than on” relationship with Facebook.
For the last time he deactivated his account in December 2015 after finding the amount of personal information shared by other “too heavy” to deal with his work demands.
“A lot of my job is to listen to people’s lives all day, every day, and it started to feel so overwhelming to go to social media and see every detail of everyone’s life, including people I don’t really have a relationship with,” he said. “It feels almost like an overload of intimacy.” He added: “I am holding a lot in my working life for people and sometimes I felt it was too heavy to do in my personal life as well.”
But Beausoleil loves the way social media connects the world in a truly unique way, citing as one of his only reasons to stay on Facebook as long as he did. “One thing I really liked about Facebook was that I could sit down for hours and click on a friend and then click on one of his friends and one of his friends and one of his friends and literally end up on someone’s Facebook page on the other side of the world,” he said. I used to do that all the time.
“One day, I realized that I’m spending so much time doing this. These seconds add up. I wonder what it would be like if I didn't spend these seconds here and spend them doing something else. What if I was doing other things with these seconds? What would they become? Would you enjoy it?”
Mathias, who works for the Baltimore City government, had Facebook and Twitter accounts for years before they were eliminated in November 2012. But “he quickly forgot that Facebook existed” after his improvised decision to end his presence on social media. You can still appreciate the benefits of having accounts on social media, like when you first met your girlfriend’s friends and realized that “humanizing 20 people you’re going to meet at a party” is much easier if you can connect their faces, their places of origin and their jobs with a photo later. Or how easy it is to organize big events online. Mathias is based on friends for the party invitations and is sure that there are times that he “slides through the cracks.”
But, now, he enjoys the time he's free. He spends his trips by lift and his moments of rest at work reading news articles and books instead of travelling through a news source. And without having friends to stay online, he has to “pick up the phone and call them,” something that has come to “definitely enjoy.”
Lauren Raskauskas, 22, Naples, Florida Raskauskas describes herself as a “pretty private” person. So social media, which can open you up to scrutiny and analysis of others, is not so attractive to her. “I am more reserved and have concerns about giving my data,” said Raskauskas, who is currently looking for a job.
He recently deleted his Twitter account and deactivated his Facebook account two years ago after realizing that “he didn’t like everyone knowing what he was doing.” But Raskauskas, who came late to the Facebook game because his “parents were very strict with technology,” can see the positive aspects of social media. When a friend of hers who had lost track of moving to Naples for a month, Raskauskas did not even realize that she was there until after she had left, that the 22-year-old said it was “a nuisance.”
But in the end, his privacy concerns overcame any benefits social media could provide and he saw a clear advantage when he went through a recent breakup. The last time a relationship of hers ended and she was online, it wasn't nice.
“Once, I broke up with someone while I was on Facebook and I was like ‘Oh, my God, should I change my profile picture? Should I change my state?’ And, this time, I don’t have to worry about any of that because that kind of thing is pretty hard,” he said.
Rajagopalan, a Boston College student, sees no inconvenience in abstaining from social media.
He states that “he has not seen any effect at this time”. Even though classmates post about parties and events on Facebook, they make sure to send you a text message, too, he said. “Since I was young, I was always a step back in that kind of thing, so I never cared,” he said.
In fact, the only time Rajagopalan made use of social media was when it was inevitable: it was the only way to reach his new roommate in college. Before starting her first year at college, she enrolled for her first, and unique, social media account. He joined Facebook to get in touch with his future roommate and talk about his plans for that year.
Months later, he still has the bill, but admits: “I don’t use it. I don’t check it or anything like that.” The biggest activity you see is when your two sisters tag you in family photos. He has avoided social media accounts in all other situations, although he has felt the appeal of Twitter. As a sports fan, he acknowledged that “that’s where most of the news comes out.” But he refused to get an account, saying, “I really don’t need one to read tweets.”

If you have a low income, are old, or are disabled, there are a number of public housing options in the United States. Public housing options are handled by federal, state and municipal government agencies. Living in public housing is often called "living in projects", but this is a negative term based on stereotypes. Not all public housing options mean living in huge and degraded buildings with a lot of crime.

Public housing programs come in all sizes and types. A guy's a single-family house. Another type includes living in a high-rise building, or apartments in tall buildings. All public housing options are rental options, which means that you do not own the place where you live.
The right to public housing is based on a number of factors. One factor is your annual gross income, that is, how much money you make in a year. Another factor is whether you are elderly or have a disability. Another factor that is taken into account is your U.S. citizenship or eligible immigration status. Most public housing options are only available to U.S. citizens or legal residents of the United States. As with any rental, your references are checked to ensure that you and your family will be good tenants. This means looking at your credit history and your criminal record. People with a criminal record are generally prohibited or unable to use public housing options.
To find out if you are eligible for public housing, you need to visit a government housing support office near you. You can find your local home help office by checking the yellow pages or by looking online. You will have to fill out an application. In the application you will have to list the names, sex and date of birth of all people who would live in the house or apartment.

John is a busy lawyer, whose whole day revolves around two things: work and his two daughters. Balancing the two often turns out to be very difficult, so John spends most of his day in a hurry to do everything he has to do, and get to wherever he needs to be. With such a hectic schedule, it is common to find John and his children in line at a McDonald's drive-thru, waiting for some burgers, fries and smoothies.

"I know fast food is not the healthiest thing I can give to my daughters," admits John. "But it's most convenient when we're in a hurry. Besides, it makes them happy." Unfortunately, this attitude toward the unhealthyness of fast food is an attitude that so many parents in the United States maintain, and it is easy to understand why.
Today, almost every city in America is equipped with its own McDonald's. Only in L.A., sometimes you can feel like there's one in every other corner when you drive around. As if this didn't make it difficult enough for parents to avoid it, McDonald's directs his famous "Happy Foods" to the children so that every time they drive through the giant golden arches, the children demand to enter to get a new toy with their food.
Although it can be very difficult for parents to have healthier food options for their children, doing so is a need that this country can no longer ignore. The constant consumption of fast food is becoming a norm in American society and is leading to millions of people suffering from obesity and diabetes for the rest of their lives. Instead of teaching children that it is OK to give in to the temptation of a fast, greasy meal, parents should lead their children into the habit of eating healthy wherever they go. In the end, children will be more grateful for living a long, healthy and happy life than for getting a cheap toy in a cardboard box.

Once the children grow up and marry, they move, leaving their elderly parents to fend for themselves. When these aged parents are no longer able to take care of themselves because of their age or illness, it is not uncommon for adult children in the United States to place their elderly parents in a nursing home.

A nursing home is a centre that offers care to the elderly and sick 24 hours a day. As the name suggests, nursing homes have medical nurses, doctors, social workers, and therapists to help older adults cope with the challenges of everyday life. Most nursing homes also have social activities for older persons to participate and stay active. These activities range from games to dance classes and movie nights. The nursing homes are supposed to provide three nutritious meals to their residents.
However, nursing homes are controversial. There have been cases across the country of officials in nursing homes abusing and even stealing from resident elders. There are different states and federal agencies that are supposed to oversee the facilities of nursing homes. Some people believe that it should be the responsibility of family members, especially adult children, to care for their elderly or sick parents. However, many adult children have their own children and families to care for, and do not have the means to care for their elderly parents; others worry about the medical skills needed if their elderly parents are seriously ill.

Viewers were invited to tweet and post their questions on the Facebook page Finding Jesus during the show. Below are some of the most interesting questions and my answers to them. My apologies to everyone I didn't reach. Feel free to tweet your questions directly to me.
Herb Scribner: Can anyone explain to me what the Bible deals with 40 days/nights?
Moss: It's more of an interest in number 40. In the Hebrew Bible the people of Israel roam the desert for 40 years before reaching the Holy Land. The flood lasts 40 days and nights; Moses spends 40 days and nights on the mountain; Goliath spends 40 days encouraging the Israelites to challenge him before David rises; 40 is a common age for the people when they marry; in the book of Judges there are always 40 years among the judges; and David and Solomon each reigned 40 years. What we can take away from all of this is that people in the ancient world saw 40 as suggesting a full-time and full-time period. It's like a number of narrative actions, in the way that modern jokes follow the rule of three.
Yalanda M. Price: Was there any division between the followers of Jesus and the followers of John the Baptist?
Moss: One of the interesting things about the relationship between Jesus and John the Baptist is that John does not put in his tools and follows Jesus after baptizing him. Apparently, neither did John’s disciples. They had separate ministries and, although there might have been contact between the two groups, they were also de facto competitors in the former religious market. There are some indications in the New Testament that Jesus and his followers had to differentiate themselves from John by claiming that Jesus' baptism was better—LRB-Acts 11:6—RRB—and by counteracting the idea that Jesus was really John risen from the dead—LRB-Matthew 14:2—RRB- Some scholars argue that these references are evidence of tension between Jesus' followers and John's followers.
Mark Goodacre answers your questions about the Shroud of Turin.
Jeffery Graff: Can DNA tests on the bones indicate whether he is Jewish or even from the tribe of Levi?
I'm glad someone got DNA. DNA tests on Bulgarian bones produced only mitochondrial DNA - LRB- DNA transmitted by the mother -RRB-, not the most reliable nuclear DNA - LRB- the type of DNA mentioned in forensic investigations -RRB-. In the original study of Bulgarian relics - LRB- of which it was a part -RRB-, mitochondrial DNA revealed that Bulgarian relics were of probable Semitic origin. Thinking about my time in the lab with the scientists in Copenhagen, I remember that the lead investigator estimated the probability to be around 75%. Last night's episode said things a little abruptly when it said the bones were from a Middle Eastern man.
As for the more specific question about the genetics of Jews and members of Levi's tribe: Current scientific technology does not reveal this type of information, even if start-up genetic testing companies promise this type of information.
Cyndi Rosenthal: Is there any other historical reference of John the Baptist outside the Bible?
Daniel José Camacho: Any extra-biblical fountain that sheds light on the historical figure of John the Baptist?
Moss: -LRB- These questions are on a similar subject, so I have chosen to answer them together. -RRB- Actually there is an external testimony for the life and importance of John the Baptist. This is important because it is quite rare to find this kind of evidence for ancient figures outside the writings of their followers. The Jewish historian Josephus mentions John the Baptist in his book, The Jewish Antiquities. Josephus describes John as a good man who possessed virtue and had great influence on the people. According to Josephus, Herod killed John the Baptist because he was afraid to raise a rebellion. This gives us another -- possibly more historical -- perspective on why John was executed and provides more evidence about how important John was in his own day.

Moss: I am also very happy that someone brought this up, because I was also wondering about it. In the Gospel of Luke, one of Jesus' disciples says: Lord, teach us to pray, as John taught his disciples. It is an interesting request that tells us something about the ministry of John the Baptist and the demanding characters of Jesus disciples! In Luke, Jesus responds to this request by teaching them the Lord's prayer. We don't know that the Lord's prayer came from John, and I personally don't think he did it; I think that's how Luke formed his version of events. But if you were reading Luke you could come to that conclusion.

text:
Brazilian public notary Claudia do Nascimento Domingues started a storm of fire by granting the first Brazilian civil union a trio, an act so unprecedented that there is no word for it in Portuguese.
Uniao polyafetiva is the label she created. The polyfidelite bond is your best guess in English.
The relationship involves three professionals in their 30s -- a man and two women -- who, he says, live together, love each other as equals and are like any other couple who is not married, except that they are three.
What Domingues did was legally register the trio as a stable union, a civil union that extends all the benefits of marriage, although there is debate about the rights that the trio will actually enjoy. In short, it recognizes the trio as a family entity for public legal purposes.
Domingues has not released the identities of the three.
But not everyone is embracing the unique alliance.
This union is null and void of all legality, said Regina Beatriz Tavares da Silva, head of the family law committee of a law association in Sao Paulo.
Brazilian law defines marriage as a union between two persons, so it is impossible for a three-person civil union to have the rights of a two-person marriage.
It goes directly against the Constitution, said da Silva. Monogamy is defined as the relationships between two, not between three or four or five.
The first of its kind civil union has led to a protest by religious groups, too. Those who fear the slope of the shoe feel the ground moving under their feet.
The institution of the family cannot be defended with the approval of actions that seek to distort its definition, said in a statement the religious and conservative Instituto Plinio Correa de Oliveira. The purpose of this - LRB- union -RRB- is not to build families, but to destroy them.
The controversial civil union is proof that there is a plurality of family relations, although not all deserve a judicial or legal position, said Rolf Madaleno, director of the Brazilian Institute of Family Law, in a statement. The action carried out does not provide protections and does not confer rights.
In his view, the legal action in question merely reaffirms that the trio in question believes that they are a trio.
Domingues, 39, argues that they deserve some benefits. They live together in Rio de Janeiro, share a bank account and want protection in case of separation or death, he said.
Brazil is known for its progressive social policies and openness, as reflected in the status granted to the trio, although the country is also stereotyped. Although Brazil seems to be a permissive place, it is also a country where more than 86% of the population identifies as Catholic or evangelical.
There was a similar protest when stable same-sex unions were allowed for the first time. The country's Supreme Court ruled that a gay couple in a civil union had the same rights as a married heterosexual couple, but there is debate as to whether those rights can be extended to a trio.
But for Domingues, a notary public of the city of Tupa in the state of Sao Paulo, nothing prevents non-traditional relations from receiving a stable union status.
The trio is considered a family and has the right to be seen as such in the public register, Domingues said.
By registering them, I only confirmed that they recognize themselves as a family, he said. I don't grant them rights. That's up to a judge to decide.
The civil union was granted three months ago, but the news spread this week.
Da Silva called the civil union deceitful, an escape to grant status to a polygamous relationship.
Such relationships are not new; they have simply not been recognized, Domingues said.
She says she simply put her approval stamp on a relationship she was surfing in a wave of cultural currents, but it was no accident that the application landed on her desk.
The Rio trio, rejected by other public notaries, found its way in the rural state of Sao Paulo and Domingues because it is a student of polyfidelite relations - some involving more than two partners, but where there is fidelity among members.
Previously IT manager, Domingues is now a PhD student at the University of Sao Paulo, studying family law.
His dissertation, he said, is about how you can love more than one person at the same time. His research analyzes cultures, places, sociology, anthropology, religion and the history of family and intimate relations in Brazil.
Through mutual friends, the trio found Domingues and traveled more than 600 miles from Rio, to the interior of the state of Sao Paulo, to Tupa.
Domingues does not hesitate to call herself married, although she and her husband are united by a stable union and not a civil marriage. Her husband works with her as an assistant public notary.
We've had all the reactions you can imagine, he said.
Other polyfidelite groups have contacted her in search of the same status as a civil union.
Domingues is studying the cases of one quintet - LRB- two men and three women -RRB- and another threesome -LRB- one woman and two men -RRB-.
label: B2

text:
Prince Harry has flown out of Afghanistan at the end of a four-month tour, during which he admitted to killing insurgents while driving his Apache helicopter and spoke in depth about the tensions and frustrations of being a king who longed for life outside the spotlight.
He also revealed his disdain and distrust towards some sections of the media and described how his father constantly reminded him to behave more like a member of the royal family.
Commander of the army's most sophisticated attack helicopter, the prince said he had fired on the Taliban during operations to support ground troops and rescue wounded Afghan and NATO personnel. His comments may be taken advantage of by the insurgents to awaken anti-British sentiment, but the prince said he was only doing his job. Most of the time the helicopter acted more as a deterrent, he said.
In a series of interviews during his stay in Camp Bastion in Helmand province, he hinted at the difficulty of reconciling the different roles of his life. The prince, known as Captain Wales in the army, explained his 'three months'. “One in the army, one socially in my private time and then one with the family and stuff. So there is a switch and I press it when necessary.”
He admitted that he sometimes "let himself fall" with his Laddish behavior, which justified "probably being too army and not enough prince," but said he had the right to privacy, too.
In another unusually frank exchange, he addressed biting criticisms to the media, especially the Sun, the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph, three of the most ardent supporters of the royal family on Fleet Street. He said he was particularly upset about the items comparing his role as an Apache co-driver with Spitfire's teams that were hoping to roll over during World War II. “No, it’s not like that at all,” he said.
The prince said that his suspicion of the media was rooted in the treatment of his family when he was “very small,” but that he could not stop monitoring the stories written about him. “Of course I read them,” the prince said. “If there is a story and something has been written about me, I want to know what is being said. But all he does is bother me and get angry because people can get away with writing the things they do; not just about me, but about everything and everyone. My father always says, 'Don't read it.' Everybody says, "Don't read it, because it's always garbage."
The prince was sent to Afghanistan last September to command an Apache £45 million helicopter, one of the army's most sophisticated and well-armed aircraft. During their tour, Apaches flew support missions to NATO troops fighting the Taliban and accompanied British Chinook and American Black Hawk medical helicopters during casualty evacuations.
Four years ago, the prince had to be expelled from Afghanistan during his first tour after an Australian magazine mistakenly broke an embargo on the media. This time, the Ministry of Defence decided to publicize its deployment on the understanding that newspapers and broadcasters would not comment on its life out there to allow it to move on with its work. Two BBC teams, Sky and ITN, were sent once each to report on their visit, while a photographer and a reporter from the Press Association were incorporated into the three visits.
When asked if he felt more comfortable being Captain Wales than Prince Harry, his answer was one of the most revealing he has given about his relationship with Prince Charles. “Definitely. I've always been like this. My dad's always trying to remind me who I am and stuff like that. But it's very easy to forget who I am when I'm in the army. They all wear the same uniform and do the same kind of thing. I get along with the kids and I enjoy my job. It’s really as simple as that.”
Shortly before going to Afghanistan, the prince was caught in another media rage, when photos of him spun around naked in Las Vegas during a private party. Harry said he was disappointed, but he also blamed the media. “I probably got disappointed, disappointed my family, disappointed other people. But, at the end of the day, I was in a private area and there should be a certain amount of privacy that one should expect. It was probably a classic example that I was too much army, and not enough prince. It's a simple case of that.
“The newspapers knew I was going to go out to Afghanistan anyway, so the way I was treated I don’t think it’s acceptable.” He added, “Certain people remind me: ‘Remember who you are, so don’t always let your guard down.’”
Asked where he and his brother came from, he said: “Probably the fact that you can only fit a certain number of people in a helicopter, so no one can follow us, like you.”

I had the most wonderful childhood. I grew up in San Diego, where it rains about two days a year, and it's always sunny and bright. He could ride a bike almost any day of the year, and he had many friends. My best friend was George Kenny. George lived in a few houses on my block and we were the same age. Actually, I was about 28 days older than him, a fact I always threw in his face. "You must respect your elders," he said sometimes. That usually received an unpleasant response from him. Anyway, George came up to me one day and said, "Hey, Richard, why don't we set up a bike club?"

I thought about it for a while, and then he said, "We could give ourselves a great name and get hats and stickers and have a lot of fun. What do you say?" I immediately fell in love with the idea. "Of course, Georgie Porgy!" I used to call him that all the time even though I knew I hated him. Well, before we knew it, we had a couple of other guys together and we came up with the best name for a club. We were the White Skulls. Why we chose that name, I'll never know, but all the kids seemed to like it, so I agreed, too.
The four of us went to the local bike shop and each chose a skull sticker to put on our bikes. I chose a green one, while Georgie Porgy chose red. He shouted, "I am the red skull! I'm the king of the club! If you don't like it, try to take it off!" George was a pretty big guy, so no one argued with him. We rode our bikes everywhere and had a great summer. That's how we formed the best motorcycle club ever!
