Many studies on language learning ask the question: What does a good language student do? There are some things good language students do and some things they don't do. These are some of the most useful suggestions of the studies.
Don't be afraid to make mistakes. People are often wrong. Good language students notice their mistakes and learn from them.
Do group activities. People use language to communicate with other people. A good language student always looks for opportunities to talk to other students.
Take notes during each class. The notes help you remember a new language. Look at your grades when you do your homework.
Use a dictionary. Good language students often use dictionaries to check the meaning of words they don't know. They also make their own vocabulary lists.
Think of the language you're learning outside the classroom. When shopping or walking down the street, remember useful words and phrases. Sometimes, when you're home, say new words to practice your pronunciation.
Do extra practice. Test and improve your language, reading and listening skills with self-study material. You can find a lot of this online.
Imagine speaking in the language. Many good language students can see and hear themselves speaking in the language. This helps your motivation.
Enjoy the process. Good language students have fun with the language. Watch a TV series or movie, listen to songs, play video games, or read a book. It's never too late to be a good language learner.

The supermarket was a block away. He took his shopping cart and got what he needed for the week easily. When I didn't feel like dragging the shopping cart, the supermarket even delivered for free. All I had to do was tip the driver. He used that same shopping cart to bring clothes to and from the laundry, which was just a block away. While Meryl's work wasn't a block away, the subway station was. Every day I walked around the block to take a 45-minute underground trip to work. He repeated the journey backwards to return home at night.

Although the Alhambra was different. The ride from Meryl's house to the supermarket was almost a mile away. I didn't feel like walking this far as I pushed the shopping cart full of a week's food. The laundry was a mile away in the other direction. She wasn't gonna push her dirty clothes through so many streets. There were no trains nearby to take her to work, just buses. Buses always took a long time to get there. For the first few weeks, Meryl was always late everywhere. Sometimes, when she had an urgent appointment, Meryl asked her friends to take her somewhere. Almost all his friends had cars and they knew how to drive. Most of them learned it when they were in high school.
After a while, his friends were tired of taking Meryl walks everywhere. "You have to learn to drive, Meryl," they said. I knew they were right, but Meryl was scared.

text:
It was four o'clock when Jenny and her father arrived at the pet shop on Slauson Avenue. The pet store's name was Pet Wonders. Jenny couldn't keep up her excitement and cried while she and her father were getting out of the car. Jenny's father smiled at his enchanted daughter. He remembered his first pet. It was a Chihuahua called Taco. He wondered if Pet Wonders was selling Chihuahuas.

Jenny and her father were greeted by a short bald man, who smelled like dog food. "Hello, how can I help you today?" The man said. "We're here to buy a pony!" Jenny exclaimed to the man. "Actually, we're here to sail," Jenny's father said right after. "Let me know when you're ready to make a purchase," the man replied. Jenny and her father proceeded to look through the halls.
"What do you think of this, Jenny?" He asked his father. "They're too small," he said. Jenny saw a variety of colorful fish. "What about these, Jenny?" His father asked. "They're too viscous," Jenny said. Jenny met snakes and turtles. "Do you want one of these?" He asked his father. "I don't think so," Jenny replied. An hour passed and Jenny had not yet decided on which animal to choose.
Jenny and her father finally came to see cats and dogs. "It's one or the other," Jenny's father said, pointing at cats and dogs. Jenny had to think long and hard about which pet to get. After what seemed like an eternity, Jenny looked at her father and said, "I can't choose one." His father stopped for a minute, smiled and said, "Then pick two." Jenny went home with a white cat and a black dog, which were the best birthday present she had ever received.

text:
"Did you do your costume last night?" I asked my girlfriend Audrey in the early morning of October 31. "Of course, I was ready, but you're not going to see him until tonight," he said. That was a real disappointment. I really wanted to see his latest Halloween creation. Audrey is a good seamstress, and every year she makes the best costumes for the Halloween parties we try to attend. On the other hand, I usually wear some old rags and go like a bum or a pirate or something, but Audrey doesn't. He's going everywhere. Last year, she was like a beautiful witch complete with the pointed hat and the witch broom. She looked beautiful.

The Halloween tradition is very old in the United States. No one really knows how it was held for the first time, but it came from somewhere in Europe. It was originally called "All Holy Vespers", and was celebrated on the last day of October. Precedes the "Day of All Saints", which is a day to honor dead relatives. Today, it means parties for adults and "Trick or treat" for children. "Trick or treat" is where children also dress up in costumes and go door to door to get treats. It's a lot of fun.
Some people say Halloween is a Welsh tradition, or Celtic, while others say its roots are Christian, but it doesn't really matter anymore. We like to dress like fools, go to parties and eat a lot of candy! Audrey finally showed up at my door. She was amazingly beautiful. She was dressed like a fairy princess and shone in her white dress. "You look amazing," I said. He laughed and said, "I know," and he touched me with his wand.

text:
Checklist for store opening
It starts at 8 a.m.
First, when you enter the store, remember to turn off the alarm.
Do this by holding your key card on the alarm panel. It's behind the door near the light switches.
Open all the blinds and turn on the lights.
Please do not forget to start the coffee machine so that your colleagues have fresh coffee by the time they arrive.
At 8.15 a.m., watch out for fresh deliveries at the back door. They usually arrive at that time.
Pay attention to the order list and what is actually delivered.
Remember not to sign at all that is not in delivery, as there are often missing items.
Check the reply phone and email account of the store for any new message.
Leave the heating and air conditioning alone. They're on an automatic timer. So please, stay away from the control panels.
Finally, you have to finish all of the above before 8.45 a.m. and open the store at 9 a.m. There is a red log book under the counter. Be sure to sign for each day when you have completed all the points on this checklist. Take note of any problems.
If you have a problem, call your supervisor or the next 24-hour support line number.

text:
Dennis had always been a terrible student. When he was a child, his parents sent him to a Catholic school. I didn't know much about school. Of course he didn't know much about anything when he was 6 years old, but he did know one thing: all his friends in the neighborhood went to a public school. Dennis was the only guy who went to private school, and his friends often made fun of him. "You're not one of us! You're not one of us," they sang sometimes. But I wasn't really alone. Her friend Patricia also went to Catholic school, but she was a child. After a while, they started walking together to the little school every morning. Pat was the first friend Dennis ever had. She wasn't his girlfriend. She was just a friend who turned out to be a girl.

The nuns at school were very bad. They ran the school like it was a prison. Dennis was afraid even to raise his hand to ask a question. His mother was often called to meetings with the director about Dennis, who also sat in the office listening to the director telling his mother how smart he was, but he was very lazy. Needless to say, Dennis didn't do well at school and ended up going to college after high school. He didn't do very well there either, and he soon abandoned him.
All that changed after Dennis grew up and started working. He had worked for many years before deciding that he wanted to get a degree after all. Dennis returned to school at the age of 30, and was soon a college graduate with a degree. It turned out Dennis wasn't as lazy as those nuns thought he was.

text:
"When are you going to cut your hair?" Johnny's relatives asked every time they saw him. Johnny's answer was always the same: "When pigs start flying." Although Johnny was aware that his relatives thought it was funny, he was also aware of his concern regarding his long shoulder hair. Johnny's hair was black and wavy. He started growing it after high school. It had been two years since then, and Johnny had no intention of cutting it off soon.

Johnny loved his long hair, and he took good care of it. Every day he washed it and brushed it fifty times. Johnny felt so good with his long hair. He made him look like a rock star. While in high school, Johnny always had short hair. Although he did not seem unattractive, he was not too fond of his short hair, and wished to grow out one day. He promised himself to do it after graduating. Johnny had kept his promise.
Johnny's hair got a lot of attention. As I walked down the street, I often heard "nice boy of hair" from strangers. "Thank you very much," Johnny replied, being flattered. Once, Johnny passed by a group of girls who laughed and looked at him. "I like your hair," one of them told Johnny as he walked away. Being the cool cat he was now, Johnny loved every minute of having long hair.
Johnny wondered why he didn't decide to let his hair grow earlier. It was the best decision I had made, and nothing in the world could make him cut it.

text:
Police and neighbors were looking for three young guys from Michigan on Saturday who have been missing since their father claimed he left them with a woman before attempting to commit suicide a day earlier.
The father survived his suicide attempt and is being treated at a mental health center, said Morenci, Michigan, chief of police Larry Weeks on Saturday.
But the Michigan authorities do not know what has happened to their children, Tanner Skelton, 5 years old, Alexander William Skelton, 7 years old, and Andrew Skelton, 9 years old, urging them to issue an amber alert on Friday.
Weeks said the children's father, John Skelton, told the police that he left the children outside Friday morning with a woman who identified as Joann Taylor, partly to make sure they didn't see him while and after he tried to commit suicide.
John Skelton told the police that the woman, whom he allegedly met on the Internet, should leave the children at his home in Morenci, a city in southern Michigan of about 2,400 people about 40 miles west-northwest of Toledo, around 3 p.m. on Friday.
But the boys never went home and, Weeks added, the authorities are still not sure whether the story of John Skelton, including the existence of Joann Taylor, is true or an invention.
We haven't been able to locate a Joann Taylor or confirm that he even exists, Weeks told reporters on Saturday night.
The last non-family saw the boys at 5 p.m. on Thursday, according to the boss.
His mother, Tanya, has been with the police almost all day Saturday, answering questions and serving as what Weeks called a valuable resource right now.
Weeks said Tanya Skelton had contact with someone who claimed to be Joann, adding only that this communication was not necessarily by phone or in person.
According to Amber Alert, Taylor may have been from Jackson County or Hillsdale County and may be driving a silver van. However, Weeks reiterated that they have not yet confirmed that she is real and, if so, if she is with the boys.
Saturday's press conference was full of media and residents of Morenci, many of whom have been looking for young people. Dozens spent Saturday searching Bean Creek, Wakefield Park and Riverside Natural Area, all in Morenci, according to WUPW, a CNN affiliate in Toledo.
We just hope they're somewhere safe and warm playing video games, volunteer Carol Garcia told WUPW.
But the authorities so far have offered few advice pointing community members to places where young Skelton might be.
“We understand your urge and desire to be out there,” Weeks said. The fact is, I can't tell the community that there's a specific location they should be looking for.
The alert indicates that Tanner is 3 feet, 6 inches tall, has strawberry blond hair, has blue eyes and weighs about 40 pounds. Alexander is 3 feet, 9 inches tall, has brown hair and eyes, weighs around 45 pounds and has scars on his hairline and chin. The older brother, Andrew, is 4 feet, 1 inch tall, has brown hair and eyes and weighs approximately 57 pounds.

text:
At least 26 people were killed on Monday in the Syrian government's current crackdown on dissidents, the pro-democracy group Syrian Local Coordination Committees said.
Among those killed was a 12-year-old boy shot dead when Syrian security forces fired in a funeral procession, according to the Syrian Human Rights Observatory based in London.
The funeral procession was for a protestor killed on Sunday, the observatory said.
In addition, 17 people were killed during the operations of the military and security forces in Hama while the authorities were looking for wanted activists and protesters, the organization said.
Meanwhile, an advisor to Syrian President Bashar al-Assad said that parliamentary elections could be held in the country by the end of the year, Russian media reported on Monday.
Bouthaina Shaaban, al-Assad's political and media advisor, was in Moscow on Monday to talk to journalists about the situation in Syria.
I can say provisionally that these elections can be held at the end of this year or at the beginning of the next year, Shaaban said, according to the RIA-Novosti news agency.
The number of people killed in riots in Syria since mid-March has reached at least 2,600, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights said on Monday.
Meanwhile, the U.S. State Department is condemning the murder of a key Syrian opposition organizer who says he died while in the custody of Syrian security forces.
Ghiyath Mattar, described as a key organizer of protests against the al-Assad regime, was killed after being arrested last Tuesday in the Darya suburb of Damascus, State Department spokesman Victoria Nuland said in a statement published on Sunday.
His courageous commitment to confront the regime's despicable violence with peaceful protests serves as an example for the Syrian people and for all those who suffer under the yoke of oppression, the statement said.
Mattar was arrested along with main opposition activist Yahya Sharbaji and several other activists, Nuland said.
Mattar was a symbol of what the Syrian revolution should be, peaceful and nonviolent, said one of Mattar's friends. His death is an attack by the regime on peace. Their attack says: We want to destroy the messengers of peace in Syria and the ideals and values they have.
His personality was perfectly built to take the role of a leader, said another man, a mate of Mattar's. Everyone loved him and had so many close friends and relatives.
Both men asked not to be appointed for fear of retribution.
On September 6, Mattar was with Sharbaji when he received a call from Sharbaji's brother saying he was wounded and needed help, according to the friend. In fact, the security forces had forced the brother to call Sharbaji. The operation led to the arrests, the friend said.
The riots have ravaged Syria for more than six months, as protesters demanding more freedom, democratic elections and the end of the al-Assad regime have been hit by brute force.
The government has maintained a consistent narrative: it is following armed terrorists. But opposition activists say the regime is behind a systematic and sustained killing.
Mattar, 26, was on the run for three months before being arrested, according to the Syrian Observatory.
The group, citing reports from other members of Mattar's opposition, said he was tortured to death.
Syria's repression of protesters has been strongly condemned by many world leaders and the United Nations. The Arab League has publicly called on the Al-Assad regime to show restraint and put an end to the violence.
The United States has imposed sanctions on Syria, freezing the assets of certain regime members and banning Americans from doing business with the country. The European Union banned the import of Syrian oil and imposed a travel ban.
Navi Pillay, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, put the number of deaths in the riots at 2,600, citing reliable sources on the ground, in comments prepared for delivery on Tuesday during the commission's session.
The Syrian Observatory has said that more than 2,000 people -- mostly demonstrators -- have died since the uprising began in mid-March.
In his statement, Nuland repeated the calls of the United States for al-Assad to resign.
We call on the regime - LRB - al-Assad-RRB - to put an immediate end to all violence against the Syrian people and release all political prisoners. Once again, we ask - LRB - al-Assad-RRB - that they step aside and allow the Syrian people to embark on the democratic transformation they demand, he said in the statement.
A video posted on YouTube supposedly showing Mattar's funeral in Darya showed people marching on the street and singing: We're going to sacrifice our lives and our blood for you, Ghiyath and Freedom, freedom, we're the young people of freedom.
Mattar's colleague said that Syrian security forces fired on the mourners, and that a man was shot and later died.
CNN cannot independently verify the authenticity of the video, claims, or number of deaths because the government has repeatedly denied journalists' requests to report inside Syria.
Salma Abdelaziz, Maxim Tkachenko, Mohammed Jamjoom and Yousuf Basil of CNN contributed to this report.
label: C1

text:
For many who saw his long and rambling video statement, Boko Haram Abubakar Shekau's leader seemed strangely distracted, out of focus, perhaps under the influence of drugs while boasting of kidnapping nearly 300 Nigerian schoolgirls.
But there is calculation in such cruelty, and method where some see madness. The kidnapping serves Shekau on many levels, and Boko Haram observers say it should not be underestimated.
Shekau's acting on camera is the opposite of the composite appearances of the late leader of Al Qaeda Osama bin Laden and the current head of the terrorist group, Ayman al-Zawahiri. Jacob Zenn, Boko Haram expert with the Jamestown Foundation, a research and analysis firm based in Washington, D.C., says Shekau has even recognized the intellectual chaos of his presentations. But they impress their followers.
Shekau speaks classical Arabic and Hausa, the language of northern Nigerian Muslims, and had a religious education. As a deputy of the former leader of Boko Haram Mohamed Yusuf, who was murdered in 2009, Shekau delivered sermons full of references to Islamic scholars. He also expressed admiration for Al Qaeda as a jihadist movement, although Boko Haram is not an affiliate of the group.
Shekau’s rejection of the Christian calendar and loyalty to the Nigerian flag resonates in a region where the resentment of a corrupt and distant government is deep. And his frequent reference to the great Bornu Empire, a Muslim kingdom that ruled northern Nigeria for about 500 years, returns to a golden age.
He's also ruthless in dealing with dissent. Shekau has no attachment and Zenn says the videos broadcast by the group never show other commanders. He kills anyone who challenges him, but blowing him up like a madman would underestimate his abilities, Zenn says.
Twice injured himself -- in 2009 and 2012 -- Shekau seems to delight in violence. After a series of attacks in Kano in 2012, he said: I like to kill anyone God commands me to kill, the way I enjoy killing chickens and rams.
Nor would Zenn be surprised that Shekau was under the influence of drugs when he recorded his statement on video; sometimes the Nigerian military has found them in Boko Haram camps.
I said I would...
Once again, the mass abduction of adolescent girls faced a threat that Shekau has repeatedly made. Western education is a prime objective of Boko Haram because, in the group's view, it reinforces colonial and Christian influence and suppresses Islam.
In a July 2013 video, Shekau promised that schools would be burned and teachers killed. He's been faithful to his word. In February, a school in Yobe State in northern Nigeria was attacked and burned, leaving 29 children dead. And last September, more than 40 students from an agricultural university were killed.
By abducting so many schoolgirls, Shekau may also have wanted to humiliate the Nigerian government just as the World Economic Forum met in the Nigerian capital, Abuja.
Shehu Sani, a human rights activist in northern Nigeria who has previously been involved in mediating with Boko Haram, believes that kidnapping and other recent attacks are messages to the Nigerian government that the recent arrest of Boko Haram supporters in Islamic schools will be avenged. In 2012, Shekau's wife and three children were reportedly placed in military custody.
Every time people have started talking about Boko Haram's decline, it has emerged as more deadly and fierce, Sani told CNN. This is a strategy of violence rather than ideology.
Rewarding Fighters
Boko Haram has suffered several setbacks in the last year. The emergence of civilian vigilante groups in cities such as Maiduguri has pushed him into rural areas and the Nigerian army has gone on the offensive against the group.
According to Sani, Boko Haram now recruits most young people in the countryside, coercing or financially inducing vulnerable young people from poor households to join their ranks. The mass abduction of Chibok teenagers may have been part of Shekau's effort to strengthen the loyalty of these largely uneducated young women, providing them with free servants or sex slaves, Zenn suggests. In her video, Shekau said of the girls: We would also give her hands in marriage because they are our slaves.
It is likely that many will end up becoming mothers, it is a real horror and in the coming years we will slowly hear the stories of little girls by few as they succeed, Zenn told CNN.
Shekau's almost medieval inflexible salafism sees girls and women as servants for whom education is a sin. Women must get married, he said in the video statement.
You can't get them back.
The location of the abduction and the figures in question were clever decisions by Boko Haram. The girls were taken from their school beds, loaded with buses and trucks and quickly transported to remote, mountainous and wooded areas on the northeast corner of Nigeria. Boko Haram fighters can cross the permeable borders with Cameroon and Chad to restock and hide, and U.S. officials believe that some of the girls have already been taken out of Nigeria.
Sani said the time was not an accident: the school was full of Muslim and Christian students taking their final exams.
They are likely to be in rural, mountainous and wooded areas on the move with fighters, with some forced to marry, he told CNN.
Zenn says it'll be very difficult to get them back.
Boko Haram has probably been separated or sold to girls in many small groups, and can be used as human shields in case of an attack, he said.
Sani also fears any military operation.
Any attempt to rescue the girls by force will end in a tragic result, it could be the Beslan of Nigeria, he said, referring to the attempt to release hostages in a school in Russia in 2004 that left more than 300 dead, many of them boys.
Prisoner negotiation chips, cash or concessions
Shekau is not beyond negotiating with the Nigerian government, despite its apocalyptic rhetoric and frequent denials of the legitimacy of President Goodluck Jonathan. According to the International Crisis Group, a year ago negotiations in Côte d'Ivoire were about to produce an apparent peace agreement that was to begin with a ceasefire. Shekau was then designated a terrorist by the U.S. State Department and abandoned the talks.
Sani believes that Boko Haram targeted the girls to force concessions from the Nigerian government, perhaps beginning with the release of Boko Haram supporters from the prisons.
The fact that Shekau said he would sell the girls and not kill them is a clear indication that negotiation is possible. Shekau's video isn't gonna be the last word of the group about the girls.
And Sani suggests that the idea of selling girls shouldn't be taken literally. People don't buy girls in this part of Africa, he said.
But at least some of them can be traded for ransom money. Boko Haram has begun trading hostages for cash, especially in the case of a French family abducted in northern Cameroon last year and allegedly released for about $3 million. It also threatens Northern business leaders with kidnappings or worse unless they pay.
The international outrage caused by the kidnapping also serves Shekau.
He doesn't care at all about international opinion, but he knows he's pressured the government to get in touch with him, Sani said.
It is not clear how that process could work, but Sani has asked that a group of Islamic clergy and others be set up to seek mediation. That would require the renunciation of recent laws prohibiting anyone from having contact with Boko Haram.
Few believe that Boko Haram will wither until the government addresses the inequalities in the allocation of funds between the southern Christian oil producer and the Muslim north.
Sani says the stakes couldn't be higher for the region.
For now, the focus of Boko Haram remains Nigeria, but as they become emboldened they will spread like cancer throughout Central and West Africa.
label: C1

text:
The night Bob Hawke lost his Labour leadership 20 years ago, I was a recruit from the Canberra press gallery who I found, fortunately, abandoned at the door of the Prime Minister's office while the Labour caucus was dispatching the occupant.
Wronged by the security guards - and then hurriedly clearing the nearby corridors - as a member of the Prime Minister's staff, I was allowed to witness Hawke's return to his office and his waiting family as former Prime Minister, at that time the only one who was rejected by his own party.
Hawke came out of the caucus room, chin forward, wet eyes forward, a clutch of cane down behind. At the same time as his office door opened and his then wife, Hazel, burst out, sobbing. Either he had been waiting for the worst or, more likely, there had been a telegraph phone call.
She threw herself at her husband. Hawke picked her up, telling her not to cry, don't cry. And when she disappeared in her office, she barked: I need a bloody cup of tea.
If the humiliation of that night's historical rejection disrupted him, Hawke didn't show it.
Soon after, liquor carts rolled along the corridors of the House of Parliament and Hawke hosted a wake that was for hours, open to all visitors. He was angry, in my view, only once that night; he reviewed a particular reporter who had bathed him with sympathy but who, in Hawke's opinion, had long been fulfilling the victor's order, Paul Keating.
Australian FM Kevin Rudd resigns
Never before had the Labour Party left a Prime Minister in service, but Hawke's equanimity, at least outwardly, was surprising. You could have said that he seemed resigned and released because of the loss of work he had had for almost nine years. Of course, the long competition with Keating had been aggravating for Hawke and sapping for his government; Keating had effectively launched his challenge at the end of the previous year, in 1990, when he held, in his speech to Plícido Domingo, that Australia had never had a great Prime Minister. He then challenged Hawke in mid-1991, lost and went to the back bench until his second -- and successful challenge -- late that year.
Hawke, the Labour Party and most Australians knew that Keating had Hawke in line to kill.
Not so Kevin Rudd.
It has been an undeclared underground campaign to reinstate Rudd in the Prime Minister's office, a campaign from which the candidate has been able to stay distant so far. Rudd has presented himself as busy and contented within the Cabinet under Julia Gillard. As he described it last week, he has been a happy little Vegemite as Australia's Foreign Minister.
Invariably for Rudd, the questions about the quality of the leadership of the Labour Party, the convenience of those who took him out of the Prime Minister's office or those who published the now infamous video of his anger on YouTube, are questions that, according to him, should be asked to others. It therefore causes those others -- and most of us know who they mean -- to fall under suspicion.
And in the resulting public image, it is not Rudd who is trying to return to the Prime Minister's office; rather, it is a semi-remnant Rudd who is being transported by a group of ministers, parliamentarians and labor fixators who believe that the only way Labour can win against Tony Abbott and the Coalition in the upcoming elections is for Rudd to resume leadership.
Gillard calls for Australian Labour Party leadership vote
His tactic has been to prevent Rudd, unlike Keating, from being seen as an active seeker of his Prime Minister's work. The reasons are double. Rudd's camp has not wanted to give the Prime Minister a reason to confront them head-on because to do so would risk provoking a leadership vote before Rudd has gathered the numbers he needs, and it is still doubtful that he has. Second, for Rudd to be seen publicly tearing away Gillard's leadership would play a series of strong negatives -- that Rudd is motivated by revenge, that he has no respect for the government, that he is attacking a woman, that has a monstrous sense of right.
It may even be true, as some of Rudd's activists have claimed privately in recent days, that Rudd did not intend to recover his old job after Gillard deposed it in mid-2010. That, on the other hand, the current bad electoral opinion for the Labour Party, some pitfalls avoidable by Gillard, stubborn resentment within the electorate about the way of his ancestry and the blandishments of some of his colleagues combined to persuade Rudd that his return was feasible.
But Rudd had to be seen to be recruited by his party again in the Prime Minister's office.
Behind the scenes of Australia's political soap opera '
That plan still seemed intact until 1338 hours on Saturday, February 18, when a user of You Tube, under the name HappyVegemiteKR, uploaded a video showing a frustrated and increasingly furious Rudd trying to complete a video message in the Chinese language, but bumping into the words. Filmed at least two years ago in his office, while he was Prime Minister, the video contained Rudd's unusable and profane shots, a bunch of gnashing teeth, wild-eyed rage, and blaming others including the assholes at the embassy.
Because the images were likely to have been held in a Government archive, suspicions lie with the Prime Minister's office or somewhere nearby as a source of HappyVegemiteKR. This conspiracy Gillard denies, but the investigation, Rudd says, is another one of those questions for others.
Whatever its source, the HappyVegemiteKR video will probably be remembered for both the entertainment provided by a dirty Rudd, and the trigger that brought his leadership challenge to light.
Rudd learned about the activity of HappyVegemiteKR's You Tube on Saturday night while eating a Thai meal to take home in Brisbane with Bruce Hawker, the Sydney-based political strategist who has led many Labour election campaigns.
Hawker is now openly connected to Rudd's campaign camp and helped advise Rudd that night.
Conspiracy theorists are in number, Hawker says. But I was with him, and he was embarrassed and worried and understood that he had to handle the problem quickly. The complication was that he was leaving the country the next morning. So the decision was made to contact Sky, which is a 24-hour news channel, and do an interview. In the end, I think it was appropriate.
Driven and legitimized by the leaked video, by midnight on Saturday Rudd was on Sky News, effectively sending the Labour Party and Australians a revised curriculum that set their qualifications for another opportunity in the Prime Minister's work. Apologize for his language on the video, he said he had changed since he was deposed by Gillard almost 20 months ago. He had learned to delegate more, to become less angry and to listen, especially to his colleagues.
It was a coded request for the return of his old job. And it was reinforced on behalf of Rudd on Monday morning when the former Queensland Labour Prime Minister, Peter Beattie, publicly urged the Prime Minister to hold a leadership vote. Queensland's band of brothers -- Rudd, Beattie and Bruce Hawker -- finally managed to publicly expel the prime minister's main ministerial supporters to recognize what they have been careful about for weeks: Gillard's leadership is under siege within his own cabinet and party hall.
Tactically the day was a victory for Rudd; the issue of leadership was in public and now, sooner or later, it will have to be confronted.
There's anxiety and uncertainty on both sides about whether they have the numbers. Gillard will not vote, however, and behaves as if life were as usual in his dealings with the man he calls his foreign minister, usually - LRB - and unusually -RRB - not by his name. And Rudd is in the Mexican tourist town of Los Cabos at a G20 meeting and will not return to Australia until the weekend.
Will it force a challenge when parliament returns on February 27th?

Gillard, it's to be expected, you know. She's held that spear before.

text:
Swedish prisons have long had a reputation throughout the world for being progressive. But are the country's prisons a soft option?
The head of the Swedish Prison and Probation Service, Nils Oberg, announced in November 2013 that four Swedish prisons would be closed due to a “out of the ordinary” decrease in the number of prisoners.
Although there has been no drop in crime rates, between 2011 and 2012 there was a 6% drop in the prison population of Sweden, now just over 4,500. A similar decrease is expected in 2013 and 2014. Oberg admitted to being perplexed by the unexpected fall, but expressed optimism that the reason was the way his prisons were executed. “We certainly hope that the efforts we invested in rehabilitation and crime relapse prevention have had an impact,” he said.
“The modern prison service in Sweden is very different from when I joined as a young prison officer in 1978,” says Kenneth Gustafsson, governor of Kumla prison, Sweden’s safest prison, 130 miles west of Stockholm. However, he did not believe that the system had softened. “When I joined, attention was very focused on humanity in prisons. Prisoners were treated well – perhaps too well, some might say. But, after a series of high-profile leaks in 2004, we had to rebalance and put more emphasis on security.”
Despite the tightening of attitudes towards prison security following the escape scandals, the Swedes still managed to maintain a broadly humane approach to sentencing, even for the most serious offenders: prison sentences rarely exceed 10 years; those who receive life imprisonment may still apply to the courts after a decade for commutation for a fixed term, usually in the region from 18 to 25 years. Sweden was the first country in Europe to introduce electronic labelling of convicted offenders and continues its efforts to minimize short-term prison sentences, wherever possible, using community-based measures, which have proven to be more effective in reducing recidivism.
The overall rate of recidivism in Sweden is between 30% and 40% in three years; compared to another European country, the figure is about half that of the United Kingdom. A probable reason for the relatively low recidivism rate and the low incarceration rate in Sweden (below 70 per 100,000 inhabitants) is that the age of criminal responsibility is set at 15 years. In the United Kingdom, for example, children aged 10 to 17 and young people under 21 have the highest recidivism rates: nearly three quarters and two thirds respectively. A good proportion of these criminals are going to populate adult prisons. In Sweden, no young person under the age of 21 can be sentenced to life imprisonment – this is not the case in many other countries – and every effort is made to ensure that as few juvenile offenders as possible end up in prison.
One of the main reasons for the decrease in the number of prisoners could be the amount of post-prison support available in Sweden. Probation insurance – a government agency – has the task not only of supervising those on parole, but also of providing treatment programs for offenders with drug, alcohol, or violence problems. The service is assisted by about 4,500 lay supervisors – members of the public who volunteer to be friends and support criminals under supervision.
Gustafsson talks about broader goals and objectives for the Swedish Department of Justice: “In 2013 and 2014, the priority of our work will be with young offenders and men with convictions of violent behavior. For many years we have been running programs to help drug addicts. We are also now developing programmes to address behaviours such as aggression and violence. These are the important things for our society when these people are released.” I spoke to a former prisoner who now runs a social enterprise called X-Cons Sweden. Peter Soderlund served almost three years of a four-year sentence for drug and weapons offences before being released in 1998. He was helped by a newly formed organization run by former prisoners named Kris (Return of Criminals to Society).
“The big difference between Kris and us is that we’re happy to let people who are still taking medication for addiction join us,” he says. Both organizations work with the same objective: to help prisoners successfully reintegrate into society after their release. And what is life like for the prisoner in Sweden? “When I was inside, I got lucky. In Osteraker prison, where I served my sentence, the governor was enlightened. They treated us well. But I knew that not all Swedish prisons were like this. I met so many people there who needed help – after receiving help from Kris, I knew I wanted to help others. With X-Cons, we find them at the door and support them in accommodation and offer a support network.”
“In Sweden we believe a lot in the concept of rehabilitation, without being naive, of course,” says Gustafsson. “There are some people who are not going to change or cannot change. But, in my experience, most prisoners want to change, and we must do what we can to help facilitate it. It is not always possible to achieve this in a single prison sentence.
“In addition, it is not only prison that can be rehabilitated, it is often a combined process, involving probation and a larger society. We can provide education and training, but when they get out of jail, these people need housing and work.”

From: Jo Backhouse
A: Karl Anderson
Date: October 17
Subject: Support for Judy
Dear Karl,
I got a call from Judy a couple of days ago to discuss some of the problems she was having and I thought I'd give you a heads-up on what was said, as you're the leader of Judy's project team.
Judy really enjoys working with you and the team and finds the project very interesting, but I think she feels a little lost and struggling to see the overall picture. It seems that you have been given a good deal of autonomy to carry out the tasks you have given you, and of course this level of delegation is not uncommon in your branch. But I believe in her Tokyo office, she's used to a little more direction and management guidance, and she's also finding this international project rather discouraging.
When I asked her about meeting her deadlines, she mentioned that due to recent changes in the timeline of the project, her goals have moved, and she doesn't really seem to understand why this has happened. Considering that he also faces simultaneous deadlines from his Tokyo department, we can assume that he might feel a little stretched.
Looking forward, I wondered if we could make it easier for Judy to offer her more direction when she sets up her tasks, at least until she learns the ropes and gets used to working unsupervised. I think I would also appreciate it if you gave him a clearer idea of how his role in the team fits into the overall picture of things. Do you think maybe you could sketch out the group and individual goals at your next team meeting and that way, everyone doesn't just get a reminder of the ultimate goal, but every team member, including Judy, could have a more holistic view of the whole project?
I was also thinking that I could help touch the base with her every once in a while to make sure she's up to date with any changes in the overall attack plan. In the meantime, I'll write to your manager at the Tokyo office and see how aware they are of the deadlines you've given him, and if somehow they can review their responsibilities and coordinate their tasks so that he doesn't feel constantly dragged in both directions.
Judy is an extremely conscientious worker and is eager to contribute positively to the team. Personally, I think she is someone with high potential and will be an asset for our international projects if she is properly targeted. I am interested in knowing your thoughts on the subject and am open to any suggestions on how we could best support Judy for a smoother sailing experience on the team.
Greetings.
Jo Backhouse
Head of Department
International projects

A lonely old man who lives in a crater on the moon is the unlikely focus of John Lewis' 2015 Christmas announcement, as department stores take a beneficial turn in their latest multimillion-dollar campaign.
Amid the surge in season advertising by John Lewis, which has come to mark the start of the Christmas shopping season for many, department stores will try to use their profile to raise hundreds of thousands of pounds for Age UK. It will also encourage staff and customers to join their local charity branch to care for older people who might otherwise be alone during the holiday.
The retailer has spent £7 million on a campaign ranging from the television ad to a smartphone and merchandise game, including bright pajamas in the dark, as well as covered areas such as the surface of the moon in 11 stores.
After two years of successful advertisements with tender animals – a bear and a hare, then a penguin – this time, the retailer is pulling the strings of the heart with a story of a young girl, Lily, who sees an old man living in a hut on the moon through her telescope. The particular child tries to send him a letter and shoot a note through bow and arrow, before floating a gift from a telescope tied to balloons, which finally allows them to make contact.
The clipline of the ad is: “Show someone you love this Christmas,” echoing Age UK’s own campaign: “No one should have anyone at Christmas.” The benefits of three products – one cup, gift label and card – will go to charity.
“Charity really resonates with people at this time of year and the announcement lends itself to thinking of someone who lives on their street who might not see anyone,” said Rachel Swift, marketing director at John Lewis.
The campaign features the Oasis Half the World Away track reinterpreted by the little-known Norwegian artist Aurora.
The announcement costs £1 million to make. The lunar scenes were shot at Warner Bros Studios, where Harry Potter's films were made, and the specially built set was created by one of the teams behind the latest Star Wars movie, The Force Awakens.
As in recent years, John Lewis has aroused interest in his latest ad with a teaser campaign on television and social media using the hashtag #OnTheMoon. There will be a full moon on Christmas Day 2015 – a complete coincidence, according to Swift.
In 2014, the retailer also spent £7 million on a campaign with a realistic animated penguin and a young man playing John Lennon’s Real Love son together, sung by British singer-songwriter Tom Odell. In the first week of January, before the 16.6m that marked Sainsbury's announcement with World War I soldiers sharing a chocolate bar, the next most popular announcement in the UK in 2014.
Swift said that, despite the hype, John Lewis had followed the same strategy for the past five years. “It’s all about a thoughtful little gift and going to the extra mile for someone you love at Christmas,” he said. “We don’t go into it thinking, ‘This is going to be huge’, just get something right for the brand at this time of year and something we hope customers really like.”
Sarah Vizard, news editor of the commercial magazine Marketing Week, said John Lewis seemed to have slowed down his efforts this time, with a smaller key presence in the stores despite a growing army of competitors. “There are certainly many more brands making Christmas announcements this year, but I think many of those brands that tried to compete with John Lewis doing something emotional and creative have come back to what you can buy at the store,” he said. “John Lewis still makes the emotional piece the best. This campaign is another great way to put that in a way that will resonate with customers. I think people will think it’s really nice.”
Among those fighting for attention in the flood of Christmas commercials was sister network Waitrose, who launched her online Christmas ad on social media before a television debut during The X Factor. He used the agency that has created John Lewis' Christmas ads for years.
Burberry has released what is just his second festive film, with Romeo Beckham and Elton John, while the Currys electric network wrote on Jeff Goldblum for their first dedicated Christmas ad. Asda, Lidl and Morrisons also launched their campaigns in early November.
Marc Bolland, executive director of Marks & Spencer, who also launched his Christmas announcement in early November, said that, in the first week of September, the most sought-after term on his website was Christmas.
Boots, another retailer who launches his holiday campaign in early November, is returning to a more traditional approach after a critical announcement in 2014, which featured a family that goes long distances to meet at Christmas.

text:
The approval by the House of Representatives of a comprehensive bill on health care foreshadows a difficult ongoing struggle for President Obama and his fellow Democrats to get a bill in the Senate and in the law.
The House voted 220-215 at the end of Saturday, with 39 opposing Democrats and one Republican in favor, to approve what would be the largest expansion of health coverage since Medicare was created more than 40 years ago.
The U.S. Affordable Health Care Act, or H.R. 3962, restricts insurance companies from denying coverage to anyone with a pre-existing condition or charging higher premiums depending on gender or medical history. It also provides federal subsidies to those who cannot afford it. And it guarantees coverage for 96 percent of Americans, according to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office.
But turning the bill into law remains uncertain. The Senate must now pass its own version of a health bill, and Senate majority leader Harry Reid of Nevada last week pointed out uncertainty as to whether that will happen this year.
Once both chambers have passed a bill, a congressional conference committee will merge the two proposals into a consensus version that would require final approval by each chamber and Obama's signature.
On Sunday, Obama praised the historic vote of the House of Representatives to pass the bill and asked the Senate to take the baton and complete its work.
For years, we have been told that this cannot be done, Obama said, citing decades of failed health reform efforts. Last night, the House proved to be different.
The president described the support of many members of the House for the heated and often misleading rhetoric surrounding this legislation as courageous.
It is now up to the U.S. Senate to take the baton and bring this effort to the finish line on behalf of the U.S. people, Obama said. And I'm absolutely sure they will.
However, Republicans and an independent senator who sits with the Democratic caucus said Sunday that difficulties remain for Obama at his top domestic priority.
Senator Joseph Lieberman, an independent from Connecticut, reiterated that he would join a Republican filibuster against a health bill if it contains a government-run public health insurance option after the House's amendment process.
Speaking on Fox News Sunday, Lieberman called the controversial public option, which is in the House of Representatives bill and Senate version being prepared by Reid, an unnecessary provision aimed at bringing government-run health insurance into the future.
If the public option is there, as a matter of conscience, I will not allow the bill to reach a final vote, Lieberman said. He has previously said that he did not oppose the opening of the Senate debate on the bill despite the provision of public choice, and maintained that position on Sunday.
Lieberman's stance is crucial because the Democratic caucus has a minimum of 60 votes to overcome a Republican filibuster. Senate Republicans unanimously oppose the public option, although Maine Senator Olympia Snowe has launched the possible idea of compromise for an activation mechanism that would order a public option in the future if thresholds for expanded coverage and lower costs are not met.
The only Republican in the House who supported the bill, Representative Anh Joseph Cao, told CNN on Sunday that he put the needs of his district over the desire of his party.
The vote in favor of Cao ended up being unnecessary for House Democrats, but gave House President Nancy Pelosi license to support the two parties to the controversial move.
“I felt that last night’s decision was the right decision for my district, even though it wasn’t the popular decision for my party,” said Cao, a top-notch representative of the traditionally Democratic 2nd District of Louisiana. Many of my constituents have no insurance, many of them are poor. It was the right decision for the people of my district.
Cao acknowledged that he drew some promises from the White House to help his district deal with the continuing effects of Hurricane Katrina in exchange for his vote. Asked about the reaction of the Republican comrades, Cao said that party leaders respect my decision, and I respect theirs.
Also on Sunday, Indiana representative Mike Pence, the House's third-ranking Republican, said on the Fox program that Democrats were ignoring the wishes of the American public by pushing through the huge health law.
Pence said the health care bill would increase costs, increase deficits, and lead to a government takeover of the health care system.
I think the American people are deeply frustrated with the liberal establishment in Washington, Pence said. If the Democrats continue to ignore the American people, their party will be history.
Democratic Representative Chris Van Hollen of Maryland responded on the same program as the Congressional Budget Office reported that the bill would reduce the deficit.
Van Hollen rebuked Republicans for not facing the rising costs of health care that harmed the U.S. economy during the years that controlled the White House and Congress.
We have had a great system for insurance companies, Van Hollen said, citing the big profits of the industry as Americans face what he called unfair practices, such as having coverage denied by pre-existing conditions. This is a message to the American people; we are trying to reduce their costs to help more Americans pay for health insurance.
The House voted less than an hour before midnight on Saturday was full of drama. With eight seconds in the voting period, the Democrats began counting down and burst into roars when Pelosi declared, “The bill was passed and the hammer hit.”
Republican legislators stood silently on the ground, some with arms folded in their chests.
Well, it was about what I thought it would be, said Republican House leader John Boehner of Ohio as he came out quickly.
He later issued a statement saying that the $1.2 trillion legislation would increase the country's debt.
“I came here to renew the American dream, so that my children and their children will have the same opportunities as me,” Boehner said. I came here to fight the monstrosities of the great government like this bill that attenuate the light of freedom and diminish opportunities for future generations.
Michael Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, published an equally smooth statement.
Nancy Pelosi and her liberal lieutenants made many promises today to get the votes they desperately needed, she said. Make no mistake: the guarantees of the Democratic leadership were based on political expediency, not on principle. Anyone who receives a promise from Pelosi will be disappointed in the end when their vows are no longer needed.
Earlier that day, Obama met behind closed doors with Democrats to support the bill, calling it an opportunity for a generation.
In the run-up to the vote, conservative Republicans and Democrats joined forces to pass an amendment to the bill to ban federal funds for abortion services.
It was considered a great victory for them and for the Conference of Catholic Bishops of the United States, which used its power, especially with conservative Democrats in Congressional swing districts, to help force Democratic leaders to allow a vote on the amendment.
The ban, introduced by Democratic members, including Indiana representative Brad Ellsworth and Michigan representative Bart Stupak, would exclude rape, incest, or if the mother's life is in danger.
The Republican Party represented 174 of the votes in favour of the amendment, with a Republican vote present.
On the Democratic side, 64 voted in favour of the measure, and 194 voted against.
Shirley Hung of CNN, Brianna Keilar, Deirdre Walsh, Lisa Desjardins and Elaine Quijano contributed to this report.

text:
The noise emanating from passing ships can disturb animals such as killer whales and dolphins much more than was thought, with new research demonstrating that the communication of animals and their ability to find prey could be hampered by the underwater din. The roaring under passing ships has long been connected to the disturbance of large whales. But American researchers have documented persistent noise that also occurs at medium and higher frequencies, including 20,000 Hz where killer whales, also known as orcas, hear better.
These sound disturbances may be hindering the ability of killer whales to communicate and eco-localize – the process of using sound to bounce off objects such as prey and identify where they are. Dolphins and porpoises, which also operate at higher frequencies, may be suffering from the same problems. The findings suggest that noise may well affect the endangered population of killer whales near the waterways. A population of only 84 killer whales feed on the U.S. west coast. and Puget Sound.
“The main concern related to this is that even a slight increase in sound can make ecolocation more difficult for whales,” said Scott Veirs of Beamreach, who led the investigation. “That is worrying because its prey, Chineseok salmon, is already quite scarce. Listening to a click of a salmon is probably one of the most challenging things a killer whale does. Listening to that subtle click is harder if there’s a lot of noise around you.”
The researchers used underwater microphones to measure the noise created by some 1,600 individual ships as they passed through the Haro Strait in Washington State. The two-year study captured sounds made by 12 different types of ships, including cruise ships, container ships and military vehicles, which passed through the Strait about 20 times a day.
Some ships are quieter than others, but the average noise intensity next to all ships was 173 underwater decibels, equivalent to 111 decibels by air – on the sound of a strong rock concert. Whales are generally not located right next to boats and would therefore be subject to noise from about 60 to 90 decibels – around the level of a lawn mower or vacuum cleaner.
Veirs said scientists have already identified the impact of underwater noise on whales – a kind of fauna that contains the largest animals on Earth. But the new investigation highlights the threat posed to smaller whales, dolphins and porpoises. “The ships have been considered as sources of low frequency noise, such as the noise of trucks or trains,” he said. “Most of the noise is at that low frequency, but the ocean’s background noise rises even at high frequencies. This could be causing a major problem that we need to investigate further.”
There are several consequences of a noisy marine environment. Whales may have to group more closely in order to be heard. And, if they don't find prey with the same effectiveness, they'll have to use their excess fat reserves. This is problematic, as this fat often contains artificial contaminants that are toxic to whales if they are completely released into their systems.
Veirs said more work needs to be done to identify how bad the noise is affecting the whales and also to calm the ships that pass near the cetaceans. “It should be easy to reduce noise pollution,” he said. “Military ships are a little quieter and there could be direct ways to transfer that technology to the commercial fleet. Another way to reduce noise is to slow down. The decrease in speed by six knots could decrease the intensity of noise by half.”
While the fortunes of some whale species, such as humpbacks and blue whales, the largest mammal on Earth, have improved as whaling has decreased, others continue to be threatened by a number of factors. The U.S. federal government has recently protected nearly 40,000 square miles of the Atlantic in an attempt to avoid losing the North Atlantic right whale, a species with only 500 individuals left.
In Europe, killer whales carry dangerously high levels of banned polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) chemicals in their fat. Scientists are still trying to determine whether the contaminants caused the death of five sperm whales stranded on the east coast of Britain in January 2016. Meanwhile, around the coast of Australia, whales face a growing threat from ship attacks and oil and gas drilling, as well as Japan's recent promise to resume whaling in Antarctic waters.

The Statue of Liberty, possibly one of the most emblematic symbols of New York City, is a popular tourist attraction for city visitors for the first time. This 150-foot monument was given to the United States from France to celebrate 100 years of U.S. independence. The statue is located on Liberty Island, and is accessible by ferry from Battery Park in New York City or Liberty State Park in Jersey City.
When Claire first visited the Statue of Liberty, she instantly admired it as a symbol of freedom. Claire made sure to make reservations before her visit because only 240 people are allowed to climb the ladder to the top of the statue every day. After climbing almost 400 stairs, Claire received spectacular views of the city from the crown of the statue.
During her visit, Claire learned that the Statue of Liberty was not always the color it is now. She discovered that because the exterior of the statue is made of copper, the statue rusted over time, giving it the greenish appearance it has today. When it was first built, the statue was the same color as a bright penny!
After visiting the Statue of Liberty, Claire spent the rest of the day in New York City visiting other important monuments and historical monuments. Claire left New York in the hope of having had time to explore more sites, but she cannot wait to return to the city in the future.

text:
Writing in Nature magazine, former president of the Royal Institute of Navigation Roger McKinlay argues that our reliance on GPS technology (global positioning system) is out of place and could be eroding our innate search skills. “If we don’t appreciate them, our natural navigation skills will deteriorate as more and more depend on smart devices,” he wrote.
McKinlay believes that a major investment will be needed before navigation systems are good enough to allow technologies such as autonomous vehicles to take off. Meanwhile, he argues, we need better research on navigation systems, while children should be encouraged to learn to find their way through more traditional means. “Schools should teach navigation and map reading as life skills,” he wrote.
According to Ofcom (Communications Office), about 66% of adults in the UK owned a smartphone in 2015, compared to 39% in 2012, making GPS technology widely available. But McKinlay, a satellite communications and navigation consultant, believes we should be careful to leave our navigation needs to our devices. “Navigation is an ability to use or lose it,” he wrote.
Although few scientific studies have explored the topic, 2009 research supports the notion. “What we did was look at a group of current London taxi drivers and a group of London taxi drivers who had been retired for about four years,” said neuroscientist Dr. Hugo Spiers, head of the Spatial Cognition Group at University College in London, who is the author of the study. The results showed that retired taxi drivers behaved worse in navigation tests than those still at the wheel. “We have been able to show that their skills are gone if they were not using their knowledge in that particular test.”
Spiers also believes that there is a danger of relying on technologies such as GPS, but it is quick to point out that the greatest risk lies in users being unintentionally driven to dangerous situations. Among the deaths attributed to Satnaves (satellite navigation devices) was the death of a driver who, in 2010, sank in a reservoir in Spain. “There is a real potential risk of relying on a satellite,” Spiers said. “But the real risk to health of not using your brain effectively is not known.”
The way navigation technology is used could also affect its impact on our own skills, Spiers says. While audio instructions for drivers eliminate the need to think about navigation, he says, the use of smartphone applications such as digital maps is very different. “In the old days, you had to print or take a map of A to Z in your pocket – what we’re doing now is just the use of computer-assisted information and you’re having to think really hard about where you’re going and interact with this device,” he said. “Modern technology is not just completely cheating on us.”
McKinlay remains convinced that navigation technologies have a long way to go before futuristic scenarios involving driverless cars and smart cities become reality. “For really critical applications – security applications such as aircraft landing or navigation aircraft – GPS is still not good enough,” he said.
Although Spiers believes that the development of artificial intelligence based on machine learning could lead to a new wave of navigation aids, McKinlay remains skeptical. “We’ll see more and more intelligent machines that are very, very task-specific, but the big breakthrough will be when they’re able to tune into what you might be thinking and what you might be wanting to accomplish,” he said.
Ultimately, McKinlay believes, it is essential that human beings continue to be able to take control of their navigation. “Do you really want to encourage people to reach a point where, when they disappear or when the battery flattens, they are in total shock and can’t do anything?” he said. “Technology is not magic, it’s just a tool.”

A Lufthansa Jumbo aircraft almost collided with another plane at John F. Kennedy International Airport on Monday after an EgyptAir flight apparently headed its way just as the plane fell down the runway, according to air traffic controller tapes.
The near loss was captured on audio recordings, revealing an air traffic controller communicating with the Lufthansa pilot, shouting "Cancel takeoff!" Cancel takeoff plans! while the two planes were moving towards each other.
The Lufthansa plane pilot acknowledged that the plane stopped.
Lufthansa Flight 411, an Airbus 340 full of 286 passengers and crew, was authorized to take off by air traffic control shortly before 7 p.m. on Monday, according to a statement by the spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration Kathleen Bergen.
EgyptAir Flight 986, a Boeing 777, was instructed to take a taxi from the ramp area to the airfield for departure.
The plane was instructed to turn in another taxi, but instead it was direct, the statement said.
A spokesman for EgyptAir said the flight was delayed 40 minutes because Lufthansa's departure was delayed.
The plane did not move until the tower issued the authorization, spokesman Mohamed Rahma said.
After a brief inspection at the door, Lufthansa's flight continued on his flight to Munich, Germany, and arrived safely, according to Lufthansa's spokesman, Martin Riecken.
The FAA is investigating the incident.
Mohamed Fadel Fahmy contributed to this report.

text:
Gary Johnson and Virgil Goode have no chance of winning the November 6 presidential election, but the two third-party candidates could have an impact on who.
Together, Johnson of the Libertarian Party and Goode of the Constitutional Party are in a position to draw a few thousand votes from Republican Mitt Romney and perhaps President Barack Obama in some of the few battlefield states considered to be at stake and therefore decisive in determining the winner.
Goode, a former Democratic congressman who became a Virginia Republican known for an anti-immigration stance and other strongly conservative policies, usually won more than 120,000 votes in his home district in elections from 1996 to 2008.
If this time only receives 10% of that support, it could be enough to balance what is currently considered a death-even race for the 13 Virginia election votes to Obama.
Gary Johnson: A Uphill Battle to Catch a Wave, Win the Presidency · Global Voices
Virgil Goode is a wild card, particularly in Virginia, said Stuart Rothenberg of Rothenberg's Political Report, adding that it could be a factor even if he wins only a handful of votes.
A similar scenario involves Johnson, New Mexico's former Republican governor, in other states considered too close such as Colorado, Nevada and New Hampshire, said Wendy Schiller, professor of political science at Brown University.
The three states, with a total of 19 electoral votes, are known to independent voters, he said, quite a few of which might be inclined to support a Libertarian rather than Romney.
In Nevada, a CNN/ORC International survey last month showed Goode gaining 4% support and Johnson 3%, with Obama maintaining a 47% to 44% advantage over Romney in the state. Based on the 2008 participation in Nevada, support for Goode and Johnson would amount to some 67,000 votes.
The president of the Republican National Committee Reince Priebus reduced the impact of third-party candidates earlier this month, telling CNN that Johnson's candidacy was almost a non-factor.
Could Obama’s struggles with white voters cost him the election?
Voters will not throw their vote overboard when we have an election here that is about the future of America, Priebus said. I don't see that happening.
CNN polls show that support for Obama and Romney changes little when third-party candidates are taken into account in state careers, CNN voting director Keating Holland said.
In all the states that CNN has polled so far, candidates from smaller parties are not receiving more than 4% of the vote, and usually closer to 1% -2%, Holland said, noting that including them does not change the margin between Obama and Romney. Statistically speaking, it is difficult to make the case that minor party candidates are affecting race.
The influence of third-party candidates has fallen dramatically since Texas billionaire Ross Perot won almost 19% of the vote in 1992, provoking conservative anger for hurting current Republican President George H.W. Bush's chances of re-election against Democrat Bill Clinton.
Eight years later, Green Party consumer activist and candidate Ralph Nader won 2.8 million votes, including more than 94,000 in Florida that secured the loss of Democratic Vice President Al Gore to Republican George W. Bush in the state by 537 votes.
Despite the fact that the votes for third party candidates fell sharply in the recent elections, this year’s tenacious race between Obama and Romney makes even split support for others potentially decisive in a key state, and hence election.
Who's awake? Take a look: CNN Voting Center
If the race is close enough, 100 votes can matter, said Scott Rasmussen, president of the electoral company Rasmussen Reports. This year's fierce race competition means fewer undecided voters and fewer people choosing a third-party option, he said, adding: It's not a Ross Perot year.
Goode rejects any hint that he seeks to play a saboteur role, saying that his policies would be better for the country than those of Obama or Romney.
If he managed to win, he would shake Washington that an average citizen would be president instead of someone who is backed by super-PACs, he recently told CNN.
Johnson describes himself as more liberal than Obama on social issues and more conservative than Romney on fiscal matters. She says same-sex marriage is a constitutional issue and should be legal, supports the legalization of marijuana use, and also says it would abolish the Internal Revenue Service.
For Schiller, Johnson represents a potential threat that should concern Romney's campaign.
I think it can be argued that Gary Johnson will deviate from Romney's votes, he told CNN, arguing that hardcore conservatives who consider the former governor of Massachusetts too moderate could opt for the Libertarian.
Do the Calculus: CNN Election Map
If Colorado approaches, I think it will matter if Johnson is in the race, Schiller said, pointing out that 1,000 or 2,000 Romney votes -- makes a difference.
To counter that dynamic, Romney's campaign must argue that a vote for Johnson is the same as voting for Obama, according to Schiller.
Every time you have a third game in a very tight race and that third candidate looks a lot more like Romney than Obama, then if you're Romney, you have to discredit that candidate, he said.
However, Johnson's campaign told CNN in September that part of the candidate's support came from former Obama supporters in Colorado, New Mexico, and Nevada.
By running for the Libertarian Party, Johnson hoped to get the support of the relatively small but fiercely loyal supporters of Ron Paul, the Texas congressman who has failed in three offers to win the Republican presidential nomination. So far, the vote suggests little progress for Johnson in winning over Paul's supporters.
A poll by NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist earlier this month in Virginia showed that 1% of likely voters -- about 38,000 according to state participation in 2008 -- supported an unspecified candidate other than Obama or Romney. Most of that support seemed to come from younger voters who were strongly liberal or moderate, a population closer to Obama's base.
Obama could be injured by two other minor party candidates -- Jill Stein of the Green Party and Rocky Anderson of the Justice Party -- but both are considered far less likely to get enough support to undermine the president.
A national CNN/ORC survey at the end of September showed Stein at 3% compared to 4% for Johnson, while Goode and Anderson had negligible support. However, Stein did not register in CNN/ORC surveys in recent weeks in Florida and Nevada, and obtained 1% support in Ohio compared to 3% for Johnson.
According to Schiller, the possible apathy of the disillusioned liberals with Obama's first term helped motivate the president's campaign to organize a major effort to boost participation both in early voting and on election day.
I think they understood that they had to take people who would definitely vote for Obama to the polls, period, without hesitation or indecision, he said.
CNN's Holland warned against assuming that supporters of third party candidates changed their opinion of a major party contender.
Supporters of smaller parties often fall into that category because they don't like the party's two main candidates, he said. So in a hypothetical world where the race was only between the party's two main candidates, many smaller party voters would have stayed home.
The other candidates, the other debate
Dan Merica and Lisa Sylvester of CNN contributed to this report.

text:
Maybe no other name in daytime variety shows brings more excitement than Jerry Springer. Springer has been the host of an interview program for several years on the show named after him, the Jerry Springer Show. His program is described as a tabloid talk show due to the controversial topics covered, and due to the people appearing on the program. Springer doesn't invite celebrities to his show. Instead, he chooses to show regular Americans from all walks of life. He is a former politician who served as mayor of the city of Cincinnati, Ohio, in the 1970s.

His show debuted in 1991 as a political talk show, where he invited celebrities like Oliver North, and Reverend Jesse Jackson. The program was designed to mimic another popular day interview program, Phil Donahue's program. The show found a moderate success, but in 1994, to increase the ratings, the show became a more sensational format. In this new format, everyday people faced family and friends on controversial issues.
The program has been highly qualified for decades, but it has also been attacked by many groups who claim that the topics are not appropriate for daytime television. Springer doesn't get away from any topic. Guests face issues such as adultery, prostitution, homosexuality, and belonging to hate groups. Often, these clashes become violent, where guests participate in physical clashes. Springer's show has generated numerous copycat shows over the years, but still surpasses all other shows of its kind.
In May 2000, the controversy reached the program when a guest on Springer's show was killed by her ex-husband after watching the episode. Springer, his producer, and the network were sued by the woman's children. The suit alleged that the controversial nature of the series led to the murder, although the lawsuit was eventually withdrawn.

text:
It's a skillful production with a nefarious goal: A 55-minute video released by ISIS, praising its victories and warning the United States to stand in the way of its goal of creating an Islamic caliphate in parts of Iraq and Syria.
It's propaganda, say terrorism experts. A recruitment video aimed at English speakers.
But the American intelligence community is focused on a jihadist who appears briefly at the end of the video. The ISIS fighter, who speaks perfect English with an American accent, shows himself orchestrating the mass execution of a group of men.
It's too early to know if this militant comes from North America, or maybe spent some time there, or what his exact story might be.
But the intelligence community is already analyzing the video in an attempt to identify the man's origin, an American official told CNN. “It is too early to say where your dialect is,” the official said.
In the video titled Flames of War, the jihadist appears for the first time speaking Arabic in a classical dialect and with the ease of a native Arabic speaker, said Paul Cruickshank, CNN terrorism analyst.
But the ISIS fighter, who is masked and wearing a camouflage uniform, seamlessly changes to English. There are a number of men digging a ditch behind him. The jihadists claim that they are Syrian soldiers assigned to a 17th Division military base near the Syrian city of Raqqa, and that now, after an ISIS attack, they are digging their own graves in the same place where they were stationed.
CNN cannot independently verify that the men in the video were soldiers, as the propagandistic video claims.
How the Islamic State Runs From Oil to Decapitations
The video shows a group of militants who execute the men, who fall into the ditch.
The man who committed this atrocity in cinema could be an Arab who was educated in the West. Or it could be American or Canadian. If so, Cruickshank said, he would be the first American jihadist to commit a war crime on camera.
ISIS clearly had a calculated step to put this guy on camera, said Frank Cilluffo, a security analyst at George Washington University. Why? Because he looks American. The message is addressed to a Western audience.
The intention, CNN Cilluffo said, is to project fear of Americans and project power.
The Difference Between ISIS and Al Qaeda
Intelligence officials will sift every detail of man's voice, looking for clues from a particular dialect that can lead researchers to local communities to look for additional clues, Cilluffo said.
The United States will also compare the clues of jihadist language to see if it is consistent with those individuals who are known to have gone to fight for ISIS.
The video is certainly propaganda and a piece of recruitment for the terrorist group, Cruickshank said. But it is also a warning to the West that if it engages in the struggle, it will be a hard way out for foreign troops.
The video does not exactly incite the United States and the West to launch attacks against ISIS, but those appearing in the video try to convey a sense of harshness, Cruickshank said.
The video glamorizes ISIS, according to SITE Intelligence, which monitors terrorist groups.
It serves not only as a powerful piece of recruitment, but a stern warning to their opposition to the flames of war against them by the fighters, according to an SITE summary.
ISIS, ISIL or Islamic State?
