text:
In recent months, Americans have experienced numerous extreme weather-related events, including droughts, forest fires, and heat waves.
We have witnessed the warmest spring since the search began in 1895.
Thirty-one states reached record temperatures.
The period between July 2011 and June 2012 was the hottest of the 12 months recorded.
And last year 14 extreme weather-related events caused an incalculable loss of human life and cost the U.S. economy more than $55 billion. Understandably, many Americans wonder if these events are manifestations of a longer-term change in the climate.
At present, we cannot definitely link any extreme events to climate change. But it is worth considering whether the apparent increase in some extreme events has roots in a larger and longer-term trend, as that would predict a continuation of these events in the future.
That kind of understanding can be of practical importance because it can inspire action to reduce economic losses and human suffering â $ often in relatively simple ways. For example, if a region is likely to continue to have heavier rains than it has historically been, then it is wise for city planners to consider installing higher storm drains when the time comes to replace the ageing infrastructure.
Science in this area is getting stronger. In a recently published study, six international research teams led by NOAA scientists and several countries investigated seven extreme climate events in 2011. In six of the seven, there was sufficient evidence to conclude that climate change caused by human activities played a factor in events that affect their severity, probability, or frequency.
News: Extreme Time -- Prepare to See More Of It
Among those events exacerbated by climate change were heat waves in Texas and Oklahoma, drought in East Africa and extreme temperatures in Europe and England. On the other hand, the study found no evidence that the devastating floods in Thailand last year were related to climate change.
Another new peer-reviewed article, the 2011 climate status report compiled by nearly 400 scientists from 48 countries, documents some of the longer-term trends underlying some of these changes. The Committee concluded that:
- Carbon dioxide and other major greenhouse gases continue to increase, the annual global average for 2011 being the highest to date;
- Excess carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is making the oceans more acidic;
-- The Arctic is warming approximately twice as fast as the rest of the planet, and its sea ice is thinning dramatically;
-- And the average global heat stored in the upper ocean was the highest since records began in 1993.
These surprising trends have important implications for climate, climate and environment and human health.
An upward trend is indisputable: at NOAA, requests for climate data have skyrocketed, and these data are increasingly helping stakeholders to cope with extreme events. Last year, for example, firefighters in Texas used long-term climate information to prepare for the 2011 spring/summer forest fire season. Emergency managers along the Mississippi, Missouri and Red River basins used NOAA climate data to help reduce flooding months before it started.
Coastal managers are using sea-level data to protect crucial infrastructures.
Businesses and governments rely on climate information to make smart investments.
Power utilities have climate data to anticipate maximum power requirements and distribute energy where necessary.
These are the types of practical actions that inspire me in my work as we work to put the best science available to understand and reduce the impact of extreme events on families, communities and businesses. These and other measures are essential for reducing the effects of extreme weather events and forging a safer future.
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of Jane Lubchenco.

The table illustrates some interesting facts about some of the most popular languages in the world to learn. It allows comparisons between the number of people who study a language and those who speak it as a mother tongue, and shows how many countries have speakers of each language.
The prominence of English is surprising. 1.5 billion people are learning English, compared with only 82 million studying the second most popular language, French. In terms of native speakers, Chinese is the most spoken language, more than double the English language with 1.390 million. It is the third most popular language to learn with 30 million students. Spanish has more than five times more native speakers than Italian, but proportionally fewer students at 14.5 million for Spanish and 8 million for Italian. As for Japanese, it is the least studied language for 3 million pupils.
In general, more people are learning English than the other combined languages and English is spoken in the largest number of countries. However, Chinese has the largest number of native speakers. There seems to be little correlation between how many native speakers there are from a language and the number of students, but there is a stronger link between the number of students and how many countries have speakers.

text:
A common benchmark in the United States to determine when a driver is legally drunk is not doing enough to prevent alcohol-related accidents that kill about 10,000 people each year and should become more restrictive, transport safety researchers say.
The National Transportation Safety Board recommended on Tuesday that all 50 states adopt a blood alcohol content - LRB- BAC-RRB- cut of 0.05 compared to the standard 0.08 in today's books and used by law enforcement and courts to process drunk driving.
Most Americans think we've solved the problem of poor driving, but in fact, it's still a national epidemic, said NTSB president Deborah Hersman.
The idea of a stricter standard is part of a safety board initiative outlined in a staff report and approved by the panel to eventually eliminate drunk driving, which accounts for about one third of all road deaths in the United States.
NTSB Seeks Technology to End Drunk Driving in the U.S.
Hersman said that over the years progress has been made to reduce drunken driving, including a series of federal and state policies, stricter law enforcement and greater defense. But he said too many people are still dying on American roads.
The board recognized that there was no silver bullet, but that more action was needed at the federal and state levels.
Over the past 30 years, more than 440,000 people have died in this country due to alcohol driving. What will be our legacy in 30 years? Hersman asked. If we don't tackle alcohol driving now, when will we find the will to do so?
Lowering the rate to 0.05 would save about 500 to 800 lives a year, the safety board said.
Under current law, a 180-pound male will typically reach the threshold of 0.08 after four drinks for an hour, according to an online blood alcohol calculator published by the University of Oklahoma. The same person could reach the threshold of 0.05 after two to three drinks during the same period, according to the calculator.
Supreme Court delivers sentence against police in case of drunk driving
Many factors besides gender and weight influence a person's blood alcohol content, and many states prohibit lower levels of driving intoxication.
NTSB investigates transport accidents and advocates safety issues. It cannot impose its will through regulation and can only recommend changes to federal and state agencies or legislatures, including Congress.
But the independent agency is influential in public safety matters and its decisions can stimulate the action of legislators and transport agencies with related ideas across the country. States establish their own BAC rules.
The board also recommended Tuesday that states expand widely laws that allow police to quickly confiscate drivers' licenses that exceed blood alcohol limits.
And it's pushing for laws that require all criminals for the first time to have ignition blocking devices that prevent cars from starting until breath samples are analyzed.
In the early 1980s, when grassroots safety groups drew attention to drunken driving, many states required a BAC rate of 0.15 to demonstrate intoxication.
But over the next 24 years, Mothers Against Drunk Driving and other groups pushed states to adopt the 0.08 BAC standard, the last state to fall online in 2004.
Meanwhile, the number of alcohol-related fatalities on roads decreased from 20,000 in 1980 to 9,878 in 2011, according to NTSB.
Drunk driving blood tests divide the Supreme Court
In recent years, about 31 percent of all fatal road accidents were attributed to alcohol deficiency, NTSB said.
I think.05 is coming. How long it takes to get there, we don't know. But it will happen, said Robert Molloy of NTSB, who helped guide the staff report.
For some, the vote came close to home.
Robert Sumwalt, a member of the NTSB board of directors, pointed out that one of his relatives had been murdered by a drunk driver and another was serving a 15-year sentence in a related death.
Many of the recommendations are going to be unpopular, Sumwalt said. But if we keep doing what we're doing, we're not gonna make any difference.
NTSB cited an investigation that showed that most drivers experience a decrease in cognitive and visual functions with a BAC of 0.05.
Currently, more than 100 countries on six continents have BAC limits set at 0.05 or less, the safety board said.
NTSB has asked all 50 states to do the same.
CDC: Adolescent consumption and driving rates are halved
A restaurant trade association, the American Beverage Institute, attacked the main recommendation, saying that the average woman reaches 0.05 percent BAC after consuming a drink. The group said it based this conclusion on a chart that said it was used by car safety regulators in the National Road Traffic Safety Administration (LRB-NHTSA-RRB).
But NHTSA told CNN on Tuesday that it no longer uses that graph as there are many variables that contribute to an individual's level of intoxication. A new NHTSA table shows a person with a level of 0.05 BAC experiences reducing coordination, reducing ability to track moving objects, steering difficulty, -LRB- and -RRB- reducing response to emergency driving situations.
A commercial group in the beer industry said it would examine NTSB's recommendation to lower the blood alcohol threshold.
However, we strongly encourage policymakers to direct their efforts to where we know we can achieve results: focusing on repeat offenders and increasing penalties for those with BAC of -LRB-0.15 -RRB- or more, said Joe McClain, president of the Beer Institute.
The safety board also recommends that NHTSA provide financial incentives to states to effect changes.
NHTSA, which oversees road safety as a federal regulator and analyzes traffic accident data, said it would work with any state that wants to look for a lower BAC standard to gather more information about that approach.
At Tuesday's meeting, the security board also defended laws that allow the police to confiscate a driver's license at the time of arrest if the driver exceeds a BAC limit, or refuses to take the BAC test.
Some 40 States already use the administrative tool, which NTSB considers effective because it is fast and immediate.
And the board recommended a more widespread use of passive alcohol sensors, which the police can use to smell air during a traffic stop to determine the presence of alcohol.
The sensor is able to detect alcohol even in cases where the driver has tried to disguise his breathing with chewing gum or mints. If the sensor alerts, it is a reason for more thorough testing.
NTSB recommended last December that states require ignition locks for all DUI offenders and said states should improve interlock compliance.
Tuesday's recommendations were scheduled to coincide with the deadliest alcohol-related accident in U.S. history. On May 14, 1988, a drunk driver drove his truck on Interstate 71 near Carrollton, Kentucky. The truck hit a school bus, killing 24 children and three adults. More than 30 people were injured.
What makes teenagers not drink, drive? Stories, not statistics

text:
You can be Aagot, Arney or Ásfríður; Baldey, Bebba or Brá. Dögg, Dimblá, Etna and Eybjört are fine; so are Frigg, Glódís, Hörn and Ingunn. Jórlaug works well, like Obba, Sigurfljó, Urania and – if you wish – Vagna. But you can't, as a girl in Iceland, call yourself Harriet.
“The whole situation,” said Tristan Cardew, with a very British euphoria, “is really pretty silly.” With his Icelandic wife, Kristin, Cardew is appealing against a decision by the National Registry in the capital Reykjavik not to renew the passport of his ten-year-old daughter Harriet for not recognizing her first name.
Since the record does not recognize Harriet's 12-year-old brother Duncan's name either, the two children have so far travelled in passports that identify them as Stulka and Drengur Cardew: Girl and Boy Cardew. “But, this time, the authorities have decided to apply the letter of the law,” said Cardew, a British cook who moved to Iceland in 2000. “And that says that no official document will be issued to people who do not have an approved Icelandic name.”
The impasse meant that Kópavogur's family was at risk of losing their vacation in France until they asked the British embassy for an emergency British passport, which should now allow them to leave.
Names matter in Iceland, a country of just 320,000 people, whose phone book lists subscribers by their first name for the very sensible reason that the vast majority of Icelandic surnames simply record the fact that you are the son or daughter of your father (or mother). The offspring of Jón Einarsson, for example, could be Ólafur Jónsson and Sigríður Jónsdóttir.
The Act provides that the names of children born in Iceland, unless both parents are foreigners, must be submitted to the National Registry within six months of birth. If they do not appear on a recognized list of 1,853 women ' s names and 1,712 men ' s names, parents must apply for approval from a body called the Icelandic Name Committee.
For the approximately 5,000 children born in Iceland each year, the committee receives about 100 applications and rejects approximately half under a 1996 law aimed primarily at preserving the language of the sagas. Its requirements include that the names given must be “able to have Icelandic grammatical endings”, cannot “confront with the language structure of Iceland” and must be “written in accordance with ordinary Icelandic spelling rules”.
What this means in practice is that there are outside names containing letters that do not officially exist in Iceland’s 32 - letter alphabet, such as “c. ” Similarly, names that cannot accommodate the terminations required by the nominative, accusative, genitive and dative cases used in Icelandic are also systematically rejected. “That was the problem with Harriet,” Cardew said.
The country’s designation laws have been subject to increasing fire in recent years: in 2013, Blær – “Light Breeze” – Bjarkardóttir Rúnarsdottir won the right to be officially known by name, rather than “Chica”, when a court ruled that denying it was a violation of the Icelandic Constitution. Former mayor of Reykjavik, Jón Gnarr, has also called the Icelandic name law “unfair, stupid and against creativity.”
Cardews could solve Harriet's problem by giving him a middle Icelandic name. “But it’s a little late for that and too dumb,” Cardew said. “Are you saying you don’t want us here?”

text:
How far are we from a world where drones deliver packages? If you believe in Amazon, not far away. Others are not so sure: technical progress past this point is not simply a matter of invention; it is a matter of public safety.
Paul Misener, Amazon's vice president of global public policy, recently said in a congressional hearing that his company would be ready as soon as all the rules were in place, but Misener gave no clue as to what that would look like beyond joking with a congressman who had a fresh fruit basket on the way to his door to prove the viability of technology.
The Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) will finally have regulations governing the commercial use of unmanned aircraft by June 2016. But technology has a long way to go before then and larger machines are not legal at all yet – only drones of up to 25 kg will be covered and the FAA points out in the proposed rules that, if you are going to pile the skies with radio-controlled flying robots, it will be better for everyone to use different radio frequencies that no one can jam or hijack. Professor Sajiv Singh of Carnegie Mellon University Robotics Institute, who runs a “critical cargo delivery” company called NearEarth, said piloting a state-of-the-art drone was a little more like leaving a trail of breadcrumbs: go to this altitude, do this short task, go home. But even short flights from a mobile landing platform pose serious logistical problems, he said.
“They are not proposing to deliver from an uninhabited place to another uninhabited place; they are proposing to deliver from a warehouse to where the consumer is, which is probably an urban area or a suburban area,” he said. “In such particular cases, there will be dangers along the way that the vehicle will have to detect. Maybe there'll be land that the map doesn't know, unless you've mapped that exact route before. Even then, maybe there's construction equipment that wasn't there but it's there now. Perhaps the GPS signals are blocked or partially blocked, in which case you will have an incorrect idea about where it is.” All this is overcome, he said – but it is difficult. A major problem is to maintain radio contact with a drone and plan what happens if that contact breaks. “If you have an unmanned aerial vehicle, it will go ahead and hit the ground,” said the robotics Daniel Huber.
That is not a difficult problem to solve for an engineer; it is just that the solution is not yet an industry standard.
In addition, “you can’t do everything with a 25 kg plane,” said Jay McConville, director of business development for unmanned defense systems and contractor Lockheed Martin MST. Much of Lockheed Martin's focus has been on making drone driving interfaces less as elaborate flight simulators. “Those of us in the airplane business have to remind ourselves that the operator doesn’t really care about every little thing about the plane and instead wants to focus on the final result,” he said. “Operators want to see the vehicle’s status information; they want to watch video on their portable device or laptop.” “Technologyally, most of the things that are needed for this are in place,” Huber said.
He is working on a program that proposes the use of drones to inspect infrastructure – pipes, telephone lines, bridges, etc. “We have developed an scanning algorithm where you draw a box around an area and it will fly autonomously around that area and look at each surface and then report.”
Huber, senior scientist at the Carnegie Mellon Robotics Institute, where he works on 3D systems images, said regarding a program like Amazon: “I’ve heard them say that many packages are lightweight – a drone can take a kilogram for 15 minutes. If you have a vehicle that can go to a neighborhood, you can deliver from that base. It takes a distance of 15 minutes and the typical drones off the platform have that distance.” It is one way, he said, to make sure that the surrounding population is relatively safe. “The bigger you get, the more dangerous you get.” Logistical problems are in the middle of being solved in some very dramatic ways, Huber said. At a recent conference, he said, a disaster relief drone firm, SkyCatch, demonstrated a robot that could take off autonomously and, when tired, land at its own loading station. “It would land and take off and, when it ran out of batteries, land, exchange batteries and take off again,” he said.
Of course, security remains a major concern – Singh points out that, for a commercial plane to be considered skyworthy, it has to demonstrate a rate of serious failure every 1m hours. The drones, he said, are “one or two orders of magnitude far away” from that point of reference. The Reaper drone has a failure in 10,000 hours, Singh said. An oil leak, by the way, does not count as a catastrophic failure – something has to fall from the sky. “We’re closing the gap,” Singh said. “There’s a lot of interest.”
Part of this is simply that air travel is inherently dangerous and therefore the rules are much higher. “If you fly commercial airlines, they will often say, ‘Oh, a component has failed – we have to go back to the door,’” Singh said. “And that is an established industry with 60 years of legacy! It thrills me to think that one of these things could fall on a busy road.” Part of the solution, Singh said, is a simple contingency planning: “If things fail, the vehicle has to do something reasonable.”

text:
Seven-Eleven killed the minibar.
The feelings of a Hong Kong hotel manager could well be extended to hotels around the world.
The hotel minibar, loved and cursed by millions of desperate midnight snacks/drinks, is in decline.
Hilton Hong Kong installed the world's first hotel minibar in 1974 with liquors and refrigerators in each of its 840 rooms.
The measure reportedly resulted in an increase of 500 % in the sales of beverages per room service and an increase of 5 % in the company’s net revenue that year.
Soon, the minibar became an almost universal industry standard.
But Hilton recently began to reverse some of its properties, removing alcohol and leaving refrigerators in its rooms, so that guests would fill up.
Other hotel giants, such as the Grand Hyatt, Starwood and Marriott brands, are also gradually eliminating this feature that was once omnipresent in the room of some of their properties.
It's because we don't seem to enjoy them as much as we once did.
TripAdvisor recently published a survey that found that the minibar was the least popular among all hotel amenities; only 21% of respondents found the room fridge an important feature compared to 89% who wanted a free wireless connection.
PKF Hospitality Research found that in the United States, revenues from mini-bars, which account for only 1% of total hotel revenues, decreased by 28 % between 2007 and 2012.
Robert Mandelbaum, director of research information services at the firm, says that properties in the United States have adapted their food and beverage offerings, installing food outlets that resemble mini-markets.
The tendency to eat comfortably is also contributing to a decrease in the hotel's traditional restaurant serving three meals a day, he says.
They are being replaced by casual food outlets that offer items like pre-packaged salads.
Everything is part of what Mandelbaum calls the Starbucks phenomenon, a philosophy of design and property management that allows and encourages interaction among strangers.
Combine this with the appearance of millennials sociables who prefer to mix in the hotel lobby rather than order room service, and you have an industry and the consumer move away from inbibing in the room.
Is this something that bad?
For those who think that inflated prices on items like small bags of macadamia nuts and mediocre chocolate bars are offensive, especially when nearby convenience stores offer the same stuff for a fraction of the price, the room bar has always been an irritant.
Simon Dell, vice president of operations at ONYX Hospitality Group, based in Thailand, agrees.
We don't want to sell mini-macadamia nuts for $8.50. It's not what people want, he says.
In addition, by removing minibars from rooms, hotels can save costs, says Dell.
When -LRB- we -RRB- remove any contents from the minibar you need a considerable number of tasks of each -LRB- housekeeper -RRB- day, so there is time saved, head account saved, therefore the money saved, which is reflected in the overall price -LRB- of the rooms -RRB-, says.
Better for a property to focus on the amenities that guests prioritize, such as Internet access.
Connectivity is as pervasive as the phone 20 years ago, when it had to be in the room, or as your own shower or bathroom has to be in the room.
$10 Coca-Cola isn't right.'
Others think that the minibar simply needs to evolve to the changing needs of guests.
We can't just give hot and cold running water, says Dean Winter, Chief Operating Officer at Hong Kong Hotels & China Projects at Swire Hotels.
Take the example of the property of Swire in Hong Kong, Upper House -- each room has a courtesy selection -LRB- beer, soft drinks, healthy juices, coconut water and snacks -RRB- and an independent and paid wine fridge.
We wanted to differentiate ourselves to attract the most demanding business and leisure travelers without following the traditional five-star hospitality routes, explains Winter.
He believes that charging $5-10 for Coca-Cola is not the right thing to do, as people are still aware of prices.
People appreciate a free minibar or Wi-Fi or movies, and paying a fee and not all of these supplements, he says.
Less hard drink
Today there is much less hard liquor, courtesy or not.
Ten years ago, JW Marriott took the small bottles of liquor out of its billable mini-bars at his Hong Kong hotel, citing low consumption.
In The Mira Hong Kong, miniature spirits were phased out in 2011.
According to the property, hard liquor was eliminated as we preferred to tempt our guests with drinks and entertainment in our outdoor lounge bar Vibes, and cocktail bar Room One with a live band.
Only corporate or high-paying guests receive the minibar completely free of charge.
Cheap wins are convenient
The minibar is also increasingly part of an all-inclusive package.
At the Ovolo Hotel in Hong Kong, the courtesy plan is extensive: guests receive a free minibar, breakfasts and two-hour free alcoholic beverages at their O Lounge, including all liquors and wine.
Eliminating prices has also helped eliminate the headache of arguing with guests about exactly what they did or did not consume, says the hotel manager at the Ovolo branch office in Aberdeen, Chum Roa.
He was a source of many disputes in hotels, he says. If the customer persists he had nothing, hotels often absorb the cost of not ruining relations with guests about the minibar items.
Now, he doesn't have to deal with that.
Roa imagines a future in which the traditional minibar is extinguished.
The competitor of the minibar is not nearby hotels, but the 24-hour shops where you can get everything you need just a few blocks away, he says.
The convenience of drinking a cold drink in your room is not enough if you have to pay three times more for it, it seems.
Will you miss the minibars in the hotel rooms or say goodbye to beer at amazing prices and M&M's? Leave a comment.

Senator Tim Kaine said Wednesday there is no legal authority for the current U.S. mission against ISIS in Iraq and Syria.
We have been involved in a war, not an imminent defense of the United States, without legal authority, said the Virginia Democrat at the Wilson Center on Wednesday, before a panel discussion on the legal authority for military intervention, moderated by CNN's Jim Sciutto.
The mission is not covered either by the wording or by the intention of the 2001 and 2002 authorizations for the use of military force, as argued by the White House, Kaine said, adding that such an argument is ridiculous and inconsistent with the previously declared interpretation of AUMF by President Barack Obama.
Kaine, a member of the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, has proposed a new and limited authorization, specifically for the current mission against ISIS. He said that we should address it immediately, stressing that it could be achieved at the Congressional session.
Rand Paul on the ISIS response: This war is now illegal '
It is also calling for changes in the Resolution of War Powers that will result in a better process for the authorization of war.
In a statement last week, Kaine said she was encouraged by Obama's recent willingness to work with Congress on a new authorization, but also concerned about today's suggestions that Congress should wait until the next session of Congress in 2015 to take this vote.
We have already asked too many American military to risk their lives without a political consensus behind this mission, he added.
What to expect from the pathetic Congress
The current AUMF was approved in 2001, a few days after the September 11 attacks. Although the language of the authorization covers only military action against those who planned, authorized, committed or assisted the terrorist attacks that occurred on 11 September 2001 or hosted such organizations or individuals, in recent years it has been used to cover the action against any group or individual that the administration considers associated with Qaeda.
A second authorization for the use of military force against Iraq was approved in 2002, allowing the President to defend the national security of the United States against the continuing threat posed by Iraq and to enforce all relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions concerning Iraq.

On an average day its outlets are a hive of social activity, which welcomes everything, from business meetings to reading groups looking for this important morning caffeine fever. But Starbucks must be careful what he wants.
The UK Uncut direct action group plans to convert dozens of coffee empire branches into day-care centers, shelters and homeless shelters to highlight chain tax evasion tactics.
The announcement of the action comes on the day a Starbucks executive faces questions from the House of Commons Committee on Public Accounts about why the company did not pay any corporation tax in the UK for the past three years, despite the fact that the U.S. senior management preached the company's profitable operations in Britain.
In his appearance before the committee, the financial director of Starbucks, Troy Alstead, will attempt to repair the reputation of the company, which continues to suffer due to the controversy.
Parliamentarians accused HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) officials of having friendly relations with large companies. Speaking of arrangements with Starbucks, conservative MP Richard Bacon said: “It smells bad. And it doesn’t smell like coffee, it smells bad.”
The UK Uncut campaign group is trying to establish a link between government cuts, particularly those affecting women, and tax avoidance by multinational companies.
Sarah Greene, British activist Uncut, said funds for shelters and rape crisis centers faced cuts unless companies paid their fair share of taxes. HMRC estimates that around £32 billion were lost due to tax evasion in 2011.
Greene said the government could easily bring in billions that could fund vital services by suppressing tax evasion.
The group, which became prominent after organizing a sit-in at Vodafone, Topshop and Fortnum & Mason stores, turned its attention to Starbucks last month after a Reuters investigation found that the company had paid only £8.6 million in corporate taxes since its launch in the UK in 1998, despite accumulated sales of £3 billion.
Anna Walker, an independent and long-standing campaigner, said: “We have chosen to really highlight the impact of the cuts on women. So there's going to be a real focus on transforming Starbucks into those services that are being cut off by the government... [like] shelters and day care centers.
“Starbucks is a great target because it’s on every high street in the country and that’s what UK Uncut really finds important: people can take action in their local areas,” he said.
Several international organizations have faced criticism of their UK accounts, with Amazon, eBay, Facebook, Google and Ikea all paying little or no corporate taxes despite large British operations.
However, according to YouGov’s BrandIndex surveyors, Starbucks has suffered the deepest damage to his image.
The chain of cafes insists that it pays the right level of taxes. The group’s chief executive, Howard Schultz, said in a statement: “Starbucks has always paid taxes in the UK despite recent suggestions to the contrary.
“In the last three years alone, our company has paid more than £160 million in various taxes, including contributions to National Insurance, VAT and business fees.”
Margaret Hodge, who chairs the Public Accounts Committee, told parliament last month that Apple, eBay, Facebook, Google and Starbucks had avoided nearly 900 million pounds of taxes. Prime Minister David Cameron responded to the statement by saying: “I am not happy with the current situation. I think [HMRC] needs to look at it very carefully. We need to make sure that we are encouraging these companies to invest in our country as they are, but they should also be paying fair taxes.”
A spokesperson for Starbucks said: “Although the issue of tax law can be extremely complex, Starbucks respects and complies with accounting laws and standards in each of the 61 countries where we do business, including the UK, a market we remain committed to in the long term. We have posted the facts about our tax practices in the UK on our website.
“Starbucks’ economic impact on the UK goes far beyond our [employee] stores and partners. We spent hundreds of millions of pounds with local suppliers on milk, cakes and sandwiches, and on store design and renovations. Taking into account the indirect employment created by Starbucks' investments in the United Kingdom, the company's expanded economic impact on the British economy exceeds £80 million a year.
“We hope UK Uncut respects the well-being of our partners and customers, and recognizes the value we add to the economy, creating jobs and learning, as well as paying our fair share of taxes in the UK.”

Each of us spent an average of three years of our lives sitting in them, King George II of Britain died while in his in 1760 and 2.5 billion people still do not have access to one.
The humble bath is the unlikely theme of the world celebration on Monday, as one of the most essential inventions in the world, but without which many people still struggle.
Although many of us tend to take ours for granted, activists expect World Bathing Day 2012 to draw attention to what they call the global sanitation crisis, with more than a third of people around the world living without a clean and private place to go.
This means that one in three people still have to defecate outdoors, using fields or bushes, rivers, railway lines or roads, or simply a plastic bag. Others use unhealthy latrines or buckets loaded with diseases and smells.
Most of those who do not have access to toilets live in sub-Saharan Africa or Asia, and more than half of the Asian population does not have adequate sanitation, according to the United Kingdom-based charity WaterAid.
Ajara lives in a marginal neighborhood in the city of Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh Province, India. He told WaterAid how people in his community have to defecate on a nearby hill.
There are no trees and privacy right now and so we have to wait until night to go there. It's hard for older people to go and it's hard to go at night. It is also difficult for adult girls because of the risk of sexual assault, Ajara said.
On World Bathing Day, international aid agencies are highlighting the particular risks for women of poor access to toilets. WaterAid says women are more vulnerable because they are not only exposed to disease, but also have additional shame, harassment, and risk of attack when they go outdoors.
Sandimhia Renato in Mozambique described to WaterAid how he has to cross a very dangerous bridge every time he goes to the bush to defecate.
I think it takes 15 minutes to get to the bridge, says Renato. I come here once a day, between 4 pm and 5 pm. At night it's very dangerous. People die. A woman and a child were killed with knives. A woman I know has been raped.
But it is not only the shame and inconvenience of not having a private place to go to the bathroom, but a major public health problem.
When one gram of stool is considered to contain 10 million viruses, one million bacteria, one thousand parasitic cysts and one hundred worm eggs - LRB- according to UNICEF -RRB- you can see why outdoor defecation is so damaging to the health of a community. Without a sewage system to eliminate human waste and make it safe, cholera, typhoid and other infectious diseases spread rapidly.
The United Nations says that more than 2.7 million people die each year from lack of sanitation. With diarrhoeal diseases killing more young children in developing countries than HIV/AIDS, malaria and measles combined, it is the second leading cause of death in children under five, according to the World Health Organization.
Addressing it, says the World Bank’s Water and Sanitation Program, is extremely cost-effective. Poor sanitation is estimated to cost African countries about $5.5 billion a year and $53.8 billion is lost in India due to related economic impacts.
The study of the program in 18 African countries found that even the time it takes people to find a discreet place to use the toilet represented almost $500 million in economic losses. That is before examining the cost of medical care, premature deaths, and days of work lost due to the illness.
In fact, according to the organization of World Bathing Day, every dollar invested in sanitation produces a return of five dollars. Its message is that the solution to the global sanitation crisis lies not in any miraculous technological breakthrough, but in stronger political leadership and a commitment to invest in sanitation and education infrastructure.
Mahatma Gandhi for one seemed to recognize the value of the toilet for humanity when he said sanitation is more important than independence. Campaigners for World Toilet Day will be waiting for these words to resonate with today's leaders.

Camping is a popular way for many people in the United States to spend their holidays. Camping involves people who leave the comfort of their home and drive to spend a few nights or more in the open air.

When people camp, they can sleep in a tent, in a caravan, or if they want to be extravagant, they can sleep in a cabin. Some people really like to "take it" and don't use shelter except a sleeping bag and sleep under the stars. Some people drive through the U.S. in what is known as a recreational vehicle or RV, which is a trailer. Inside there are beds, a small bathroom and a kitchen.
There are campsites all over the United States. These are places where campers gather and usually pay a fee to set up a tent or place a caravan in a designated outdoor location. Many of these campsites have water hoses and electrical connections so that people can wash dishes and themselves and connect a radio or their computers. Most campsites also have a fire ring or moat, which is a hole in the ground where people can make a safe fire to roast marshmallows, a popular camping activity. Usually there is also a picnic table for people to eat their meals. Many of these campsites also have shared bathrooms with showers. Some campsites have playgrounds, swimming pools and playrooms. Some also organize activities for people who like singing, where people will gather and sing songs. It is usually illegal to camp in an undesignated official campsite, which means you can't just put a tent in a forest.
When people go camping they often do other outdoor activities such as fishing, canoeing, hiking, kayaking, swimming, horse riding and mountain biking.

Himalayan lakes, space walks, and presidential primaries helped Scott Kelly keep his wits for 340 days in space, the astronaut told reporters, after landing again on Earth from a search mission. “It seemed like I lived there forever,” Kelly said. The veteran of past missions said that his greatest surprise was simply how long this one felt. “Perhaps, from time to time, you go crazy,” he said.
Kelly and a Russian counterpart, Mikhail Kornienko, spent almost a year at the International Space Station (ISS) to study the effects of weightlessness, radiation and narrow space flight rooms on human beings – research that NASA considers essential for a possible mission to Mars.
Kelly said the duration of the mission was her greatest challenge and that she felt significantly more pained when she returned to gravity than after shorter trips. Kelly and her twin brother, Mark, a retired astronaut, have spent the last year doing physical and mental tests. The tests will continue, to help NASA learn about how the body copes with the severe tensions of space flight.
Kelly said she was in pain and had extremely sensitive skin, but so far, her balance has felt mostly decent. However, he said, “the first thing I tried to put on a table that I missed” because “you tend to underestimate the effects of gravity.”
He said that the discomfort of returning to gravity, which reduced it to normal height after stretching 1.5 inches in orbit, did not take away anything of the astonishment he felt after his capsule landed again on Earth. When the Russian capsule opened to the fresh air of Kazakhstan, Kelly said, it smelled “a fragrance like a plant that flourished in that area.” It was the fresh air mixed with the charred smell, “a little sweet” of a spaceship that had survived the reentry through the atmosphere.
As he moved away from the ship, he said, the scope of the mission began to sink in: 340 days at a 15-year space station that is “a million pounds, the size of a football field, the internal volume, some say, of a six - bedroom house. ” The ISS, he said, is a place that uses the power of the sun and was built with the help of an international team and millions of contributors.
“There are things we’re going to discover about our space experience at the space station that we don’t even know now,” Kelly said, comparing research on more than 450 missions there with the work done by computer scientists at NASA in the 1960s and 1970s. He added, “The sight is great, too.”
Kelly made the most of that view, posting spectacular photos on the social networks of Earth's cities, landscapes, oceans, and atmosphere. “The Earth is a beautiful planet,” he said, describing the striking colors of the waters around the Bahamas and the colors of the rainbow of lakes dotting the northern Himalayas. He said he would like to visit that region, although first he would have to learn “which country really owns them”. But, “predominantly, you can see how thin the atmosphere is, how fragile it looks,” Kelly added. “That, combined with these large swathes of pollution, is a little alarming.”
The astronaut said he could see entire pollution systems: clouds of forest fire smoke covering parts of the US, sections of Asia with continuous and visible pollution almost all year round. He said that the message “we need to save the planet” lost the point a little: “The planet will improve; it is we who will not be here because we will destroy the environment.” The thin shield of the world’s atmosphere “makes you more environmentalistic after spending so much time looking down,” he said.
“It is for us to take care of the air we breathe and the water we drink. And I think we have an impact on that and we have the ability to change it, if we make the decision to do so.” Kelly's active social media life, which she said was a joint effort with her girlfriend, earned her a huge online follow-up. But he said he didn't know, instead he was seeing the chaotic drama of the 2016 presidential election. One of the first questions he asked the crew who pulled him out of a space capsule was “How was the Super Tuesday?”
But the astronaut died when asked about his thoughts about Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders. “I would say that, as a government employee, I am subject to the Hatch Act,” he said, referring to a law that prohibits any political activity for federal employees. “So I can’t say how I think about all the news all year round.”
In addition to the news, he said, constant work helped him stay sane: “I tried to have milestones that were near, like when the next crew arrives, the next spacewalk, the next robotics, the next scientific experiment. That made a difference to me, keeping my sanity.” Being back on Earth with the rest of humanity had not completely sunk, he added, recalling how surprised he had been to see a multitude of people after a previous mission. “There will be a point here very soon where I will begin to feel that kind of cultural shock,” he said.
Although a NASA scientist said Kelly embodied the qualities needed for a mission to Mars, the astronaut himself predicted that he would not fly with the space agency again. “But I don’t think I would ever say I’m absolutely 100% done,” he added, pointing to the sudden successes of private space flight companies like SpaceX. “They might need a guy like me someday,” he said. “Perhaps, in the next 20 years, you can buy a cheap ticket, you just have to go visit yourself a little.”

text:
One of the most controversial figures in the history of the United States of America was Dr. Jack Kevorkian. He was a pathologist, an advocate of euthanasia and author, who came to fame in the late 1990s. He died in 2011. Kevorkian firmly believed in euthanasia for the terminally ill. He designed a suicide machine that helped 130 people end their lives. Kevorkian was pursued throughout his career as a suicide facilitator, and was convicted in 1999 for his involvement in assisted suicide. He served eight years in prison, and was released in 2007 after agreeing not to continue helping with anyone's suicide.

Kevorkian had difficulty working as a pathologist at the University of Michigan, where he obtained his doctorate. He disagreed with his employers, and decided to leave the hospital to pursue his own interests. In 1987, Kevorkian bought advertising space in Detroit newspapers as "killer." His first known assisted suicide was for a 54-year-old woman suffering from advanced Alzheimer's disease. Kevorkian was not charged in the case because Michigan did not have a law in force on assisted suicide. The state filed murder charges initially, but those charges were dropped. The Michigan Medical Board, however, stripped Kevorkian of his medical license.
Kevorkian defended himself in subsequent trials by claiming that he did not take any action to help his patient's suicide. He had invented a machine that was designed to be operated by the patient using the machine. Therefore, Kevorkian argued that he had no hand to cause the death of his patients. His patients had complete control of suicide from start to finish. Kevorkian's role in the deaths was simply to help connect his patients to his machine. The rest is up to them. Some called Kevorkian an angry madman who lost his mind, while others called him an angel for helping to put an end to the suffering of his patients.

text:
An international agreement to improve security in Bangladesh's garment factories faces the threat of legal action, as factory owners demand compensation for the cost of closures and repair work. With some repair programs that are expected to take months, factory owners say they cannot afford the costs of paying staff while factories are closed, along with the costs of some major works needed to ensure the safety of buildings. The renovations of the building are taking place following the collapse of the Rana Plaza complex in the capital of Bangladesh, Dhaka, in 2013, in which 1,138 people died.
The problems arise as hundreds of garment factories in Bangladesh are inspected monthly for fire safety and structural problems under the Agreement on Fire Safety and Buildings in Bangladesh, which is supported by over 170 international brands, including Primark and Marks & Spencer, and international trade unions, including IndustriALL.
The owner of a factory based in Dhaka, Softex Cotton, has threatened legal action against the Agreement after its factory was shut down due to structural problems, prompting a lawsuit for a $100 million report in compensation.
Another factory owner, who refused to be named, said that once a factory closed its doors, even for a few months, it would lose orders and close permanently: “There is no such thing as temporary closure,” he said. The factory owner said the agreement had “discalced” around the issue of who paid for the factory closures in the midst of efforts to get as many brands as possible to sign an agreement following the Rana Plaza disaster. He said there was no clear process to manage the costs involved.
Jenny Holdcroft, policy director at IndustriALL, who has been closely involved in the Agreement, said the agreement ensured that factories would not lose orders during the closure because brands had committed to keeping orders with suppliers for two years.
While 12 factories have so far been identified by the Agreement as requiring significant work, Holdcroft said that many of them only needed partial closure to reduce stress in the building so that production could continue on other floors. The Agreement also legally obliges brands to ensure that workers receive remuneration during factory closures. He said that details of who would make the payments had been left open to ensure that all factory owners who could pay repairs and compensation to workers made the necessary contribution.
“This was always going to be a negotiation issue. Brands do not want to commit themselves to paying for the owners of the rich factories that have just pocketed the profits and have not been spending in their factories for years to continue doing so. Obviously there was going to be an interruption. If there were no interruptions, there would be no change,” he said. A spokesman for the Agreement said that negotiations on payments and even legal actions would not delay their work to improve safety in factories.
However, pressure on the Agreement to contribute to the payment of posted workers has increased after a rival factory security group backed by U.S. retailers, including Walmart and Gap, the Bangladesh Workers Security Alliance, set aside $5 million to help pay factory workers for a period of up to two months while working in buildings that it has identified as requiring improvements. To date, it has identified five factories in four buildings where production had to be suspended.
“The Alliance is sharing workers’ wages with employers, so there is now a lot of confusion. We had a big meeting with the Agreement to make them understand that they have to come forward or how are we going to help our workers?” said Shaidullah Azim, director of Bangladesh’s Association of Clothing Manufacturers and Exporters.

text:
Chemical dispersants continue to flow into the Gulf of Mexico at virtually unchanged levels despite the Environmental Protection Agency's order to significantly reduce blood pressure, according to a CNN analysis of the daily dispersal reports provided by Deepwater Horizon Unified Command.
When the May 26 directive was issued, EPA Administrator Lisa Jackson said the use of dispersants should be reduced by 75 percent.
Public statements made at that time by the EPA administrator gave the impression that federal officials were trying to reduce the use of dispersants in general.
We hope to see a substantial reduction in the total amount of dispersant used, Jackson said in May.
Before May 26, BP used 25,689 gallons per day of the chemical dispersant Corexit. Since then, CNN analysis shows that the daily average use of dispersants has fallen to 23,250 gallons a day, a decrease of 9 percent.
Environmentalists on the Gulf Coast say it's another sign that federal agencies monitoring dispersal use are not being tough enough with BP.
I think the EPA has been struggling to respond to this crisis, said Aaron Viles with the Gulf Restoration Network. Everything is really a giant scientific experiment and we are terribly concerned that in the long run the impacts are going to be significant and we don't really know what we're doing to the ecosystem.
But the EPA argues that it deserves credit for getting an alarming use of dispersants under control. The directive states that BP should reduce the use of dispersants by 75 percent compared to the maximum daily amount used.
And that's the trap. The highest number of dispersant used occurred on May 23, when 70,000 gallons were injected into the Gulf of Mexico. Officials of the EPA say they feared that that number would have become the norm and so, they say, the directive was issued.
This escalation quickly reversed, ensuring BP only uses the smallest amount of dispersant needed, EPA spokesman Adora Andy said.
But even according to EPA standards, BP continues to routinely exceed the daily threshold. EPA and Coast Guard say they're trying to keep dispersing use at about 18,000 barrels a day.
But according to CNN's analysis, BP has exceeded that amount 50 percent of the time since the May 26 directive was issued. To do this, BP must apply to the United States Coast Guard for permission.
Coast Guard officials say that the use of dispersants is evaluated on a daily basis and that it is using the safest and most effective methods available to protect the marine environment.
The EPA-Coast Guard directive has been successful in ensuring that BP uses the lowest volume of dispersant required, the U.S. Coast Guard Lieutenant. Erik Halvorson, spokesperson for the Unified Area Command.
EPA continues to test the chemical dispersant Corexit 9500, which has been used by BP since the beginning of the oil disaster. So far, more than 1.6 million gallons of the chemical have been injected into the Gulf of Mexico.
But the struggle for the daily use of dispersants has attracted the attention of representative Ed Markey, D-Massachusetts, one of the strongest critics of BP's response to the cleanup of the oil spill.
I think it is obvious that we can never again allow a repetition of what is happening right now, where the scientific experiment is being carried out without having any idea what the impact on marine life will be in the long term, said Markey.

text:
There are seven days of the week, or 24-hour single-name periods designed to provide programming context and make time easier to measure. Each of these days is identifiable by specific plans, moods and tones.
Monday is seen by many as the "worst" day of the week, as it marks the return to work after the weekend, when most full-time employees receive two days off. Most students attend school in the morning and return home in the afternoon (usually from eight o'clock to three o'clock or seven o'clock to two o'clock), and most workers go to work in the morning and return home at night (usually from nine to five or eight to four).
Tuesday is the second day of the week, and it is in many ways similar to Monday. There are not many changes, in terms of schedule, between Tuesday and Monday; most people go to school or work and return home to watch TV, play video games, make plans with friends, spend time with family, read or participate in a similar leisure-related activity.
Wednesday is the third day of the week, and serves as the "half" of the workweek; some individuals refer to Wednesday as "hump day", as once their workday is complete, employees will have spent the workweek "hump", and will be in recession, as only two days at work will remain in the week.
Thursday is the fourth day of the week, and is viewed favorably by many, as it is quite close to the end of the workweek.
Friday is the fifth day of the week, and marks the end of the work week and the school week for the vast majority of employees and students. By Friday afternoon/afternoon, most students/workers cannot wait to leave and go home, as they will not have to return to school/work until Monday.
Saturday is perhaps the most respected day of the week. Because Sunday follows (and presumably there is no work or school to attend, for most people), everyone is free to stay out (or awake) until late at night, having fun with plans or other leisure-related activities. To be sure, Saturday is generally considered a day to participate in hobbies that otherwise could not be enjoyed during the regular week.
Sunday is the last day of the week, and is used by most as a day off. On Sundays fewer night plans are made, compared to Saturdays, as most people have to wake up for work or school on Monday morning.
label: C1

text:
Unusually for someone who likes to chat, Kenton Cool can barely talk. Exercising at high altitude has left his voice a grunt of throat. He is now in Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal, after flying from Everest base camp that morning. Cool is reflecting on a surprising sequence of climbs completed over the previous weekend. Early on Saturday morning, he reached the summit of Nuptse, the first and lowest of the three main peaks in the Everest “horse house” surrounding the glacial valley called west of Cwm.
That same day, he climbed to the summit of Everest himself, reaching the top in complete darkness early on Sunday. He and his fellow climber continued to the Lhotse summit, the third of this spectacular three-step challenge, on Monday morning.
“It was an opportunity taken away,” he says. “For the first time since the late 1990s, there were fixed ropes in the three mountains. That doesn't take away the physical achievement of what I did. I've put the bar on a certain level. But whoever comes next will move the bar further and make it without ropes or bottled oxygen.”
Sixty years after Everest's first ascension, much of the coverage goes back to Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay and their age of innocence from the modern era of commercialism and environmental degradation. I've asked Cool to look forward and imagine what higher climbers they might be doing in 60 years.
“I hate to think,” he says, but he mentions the Swiss climber, Ueli Steck, who fled the mountain in April after what Cool calls “an altercation” with a crowd of sherpas at Camp 2. Steck, he says, planned to climb the western crest of Everest, made for the first time in 1963, descend to South Col and then immediately climb to Lhotse by a new route, all without fixed strings. “Ueli had been training like a machine,” says Cool. “It’s a climber in a class of its own. He is technically brilliant, but he had also taken his physical condition to an astronomical level. It would have been amazing to see what I could have done.”
Another issue is what tourism will look like. One clue is the impressive helicopter rescue by Simone Moro, Steck's climbing companion, whose intemperate language provoked confrontation at Camp 2. Moro flew to Everest on Tuesday to command a high-powered helicopter to rescue an injured climber at an altitude of 7,800 metres.
It was the highest rescue ever made in Everest and highlights the exponential increase in helicopter flights in recent years. By 2073, the mountain infrastructure could include a helipad at the South Col, bringing tourists breathing bottled oxygen. Meanwhile, they are transforming the potential to rescue the climbers and the many more numerous walkers heading to base camp.
According to Alton Byers, a mountain geographer and environmentalist, it is not yet known whether the Everest region can continue to face a booming tourism sector. The combination of climate change and tourism, he says, is creating new tensions in the Sherpa homeland. The withdrawal, and in some cases the disappearance, of glaciers in the Everest region is already having a major impact. “ Everywhere you go, people are talking about how there is less water. There is less water for agriculture and less water for all the new lodges being built.”
In the Sherpa city of Namche Bazaar, he says, a new five-mile pipeline is being put in place to bring water to serve the growing tourist demand for showers and toilets. The local current has been contaminated with human waste and does not provide enough water for a place that, in high season, is bursting into seams. “Every town is digging a hole just beyond homes in search of garbage. Khumbu has the highest landfills in the world,” he says. Human waste in base camp is now well managed and removed in plastic barrels. But, according to Byers, these barrels are emptied into a huge well a few hours into the valley that could leak into the watercourses of the region.
“These problems can be solved, but we have to take ourselves seriously,” he says. “A climber can spend $85,000 on climbing Everest. And that's fine. But at some point we're going to have to address these other priorities. For half a million dollars a year, you could solve most of them.”
Climate change is another issue. Byers works with local conservation committees to identify and plan the impacts of climate change, most of the time finding new sources of water or introducing rainwater harvesting. The rapid accumulation of glacial lakes that threaten to explode and flood the Sherpa homeland is a constant threat. “There will come a time when people will have to get out of their way.”
Changes in weather patterns are also having an impact on tourism. The increase in cloud coverage in periods of normally clear weather is closing the airport of Lukla, the gateway to the Everest region, more often. A new road for 4x4s to Lukla is being built to ensure the flow of tourists and their money, but Byers is concerned that the rapid expansion of the road network in Nepal is being done at low cost, with disastrous consequences in terms of soil erosion and landslides.
“Everest is the icon everyone knows,” he says. “It is the canary of the coal mine that everyone understands. It is the perfect laboratory to find out how to address some of these problems, such as the impacts of climate change and tourism.”

text:
From bright trees in the dark to underground bicycle sheds and solar-powered containers, we look at some of the most left-wing solutions to help make our cities more habitable.
Life in the city has many advantages, but a sustainable lifestyle is increasingly not among them. Pollution, traffic and the loss of green spaces are just some of the daily tests that the city's inhabitants have to face.
Step forward, the inventors. We consider ten of the craziest solutions to make our cities more habitable.
1 Emerging parks
Today's cities sometimes seem to be built more for cars than for people. The pop-up park is a simple idea. Take an empty parking lot, a pocket full of change and a pot plant or two, and make your own private park. The PARK(ing) project began as an artistic experiment in San Francisco and has since spread around the world. Temporary urban farms and ecological demonstrations are just some of the ideas that have emerged from the movement, which celebrates a day of action every September.
2 Underground storage
Not all urban inhabitants are hooked to the car. The bikes are increasingly in vogue. The question is: where to keep it safe? Giken, an engineering company based in Tokyo, has devised a concept for a solution: an “underground anti-seismic and eco-friendly bicycle park”. Just seven metres wide, the cylindrical storage facility is buried deep enough in the ground to house 204 bicycles. Owners can recover their bike by pressing a button, with the automated system that returns it on the ground in about 13 seconds.
3 Bright Trees in the Dark
When most people think of trees that shine in the dark, usually come to mind Christmas trinkets and fallen pine needles. No Daan Roosegaarde. The Dutch designer-artist has devised a “bioluminescent” plant. Experimental technology impels DNA from luminescent marine bacteria with a plant's chloroplast genome to create a jellyfish-like glow. Trials are being conducted to create an industrial-scale version of biomimetics-inspired technology that Roosegaarde hopes will one day replace conventional street lighting.
4 Harvest of Footsteps
Every day, hundreds of travelers and buyers in West Ham's East London neighborhood cross the elevated pedestrian walkway near the subway station. Few are likely to notice spring under their feet. Less still connect that five-millimeter flexion on the rubber surface to the power of the top lanterns. The paved pavement is covered with smart tiles that capture the kinetic energy of pedestrian steps and turn it into electricity. Pavegen, the British firm behind innovation, has installed a similar system at London's Heathrow Airport, among other international locations.
5 Supertrees
It had to happen over time: trees made by man. In Singapore’s Gardens by the Bay there is a small sketch of them. Up to 50 meters high, these steel "supertrees" not only have flowers and ferns that grow them, but their metal awnings act to absorb and disperse the heat as well. They are also equipped to harvest rainwater, as well as to provide air ventilation for two “climate controlled biomes” (large conservatories, in other words) below. Eleven of the 18 trees also feature solar panels along their ‘branches’.
6 water production billboard
We live in a world of consumption. And, so that we don't forget, advertisers wallpaper our cities and roads with billboard banks. Researchers from the University of Engineering and Technology of Lima have presented a poster with a difference. Using a system of capacitors and filters, it traps the humidity of the air and extracts the water vapor to produce about 96 liters of drinking water per day. The public can help itself free of charge.
7 Neo-walled wall gardens
The gardens ceased to be just the reserve of people's front lawns a long time ago. For a while, the rooftop gardens were all rage. Now, it's all about walls. Taking advantage of the advances of hydroponics (plants of cultivation without soil), the facades of a growing number of libraries and offices, shops and hotels are bursting in bloom. One of the companies that is at the forefront of the “living wall” boom is the UK-based company Biotecture. The company’s “vertical gardens” can be seen to grace the Taj Hotel in central London and the exit wall of Edgware Road Metro Station, among other places. Apart from aesthetics, green walls are credited with reducing air pollution and improving air quality.
8 Building powered by algae
To demonstrate the dynamism of the concept of “living wall”, look no further than the Hamburg International Construction Exhibition. Instead of sweet-smelling flowers, the south facing facades of the zero-carbon apartment complex are tied with green algae. The outer fabric of the walls includes a “bio-skin” of hollow grass panels in which the photosynthetic algae and grows. Periodically, algae are harvested from walls and fermented in a biogas plant to produce electricity.
9 Smart Wastebaskets
Forget about the gas dump trucks and stinky jumps. City authorities around the world are now turning to solar-powered “shock compactors” to keep garbage off the streets. The 150 gallon capacity garbage cans are equipped with an engine that pushes down the trash as it approaches the top. The engine is powered by solar panels embedded in the lid. BigBelly's newest bins include a wireless monitoring system that notifies garbage collectors when the bins are full.
10 Spray paint
Finally, desperate times sometimes require desperate measures. That is clearly what was going through the minds of the authorities in Chengdu, one of the fastest growing cities in China. To cheer the place up, the municipal landscaping department has led to spraying the green of the yellow grass. The use of non-toxic green spray has now spread to Tianjin and many other cities in northwestern China.

I don't think the euro should exist, said Saxo Bank Lars Seer Christensen's co-CEO to CNN's Richard Quest, in terms that could hardly be less fractional for supporters of the single-currency bloc of 17 nations.
It is quite clear that what is missing here is fiscal union, but it is also very clear that the people of Europe do not support that objective.
The eurozone will also split as competitiveness continues to develop in different directions, said the head of the Danish online investment bank. He added that the eurozone population, in particular Germany, as the main pillar of the monetary area, will not sacrifice for the weakest part of the eurozone: Greece and other countries in southern Europe.
Christensen's controversial comments contrast strongly with what eurozone supporters have said, advocating austerity to keep the union together.
Germany, Europe's largest economy, fears that a Greek exit from the eurozone may lead to a domino effect in which other massively indebted countries -- Ireland, Portugal, Spain and Italy -- can withdraw from the common currency, leading to the disintegration of the eurozone.
In December 2012, German Chancellor Angela Merkel won more support for bailout funds for Greece. In July, Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, promised to do everything necessary to preserve the euro that triggered demonstrations for Greek, Spanish and Italian bonds.
However, Christensen of the Saxo Bank believes that the euro will disappear at some point in the future, and despite reaching the maximum of 13 months, because he believes that general support does not exist.
I am not saying that it is bad that support is not there, Christensen said, because the ability to adjust its currency is an important balance between different economies and different developments. When that's over, you'll have a whole different set of problems.
The bank's executive director refused to give a timeline, but said it depends on how long the Germans resist... how long the German population is willing to buy to support the tax union.
I can tell you that the problem is going to be bigger instead of smaller... I'm afraid the markets will end up dismantling the thing.

text:
David Cameron has declared a “clear result” in the Scottish independence referendum after Scotland voted for a margin of 10.6 points against ending the 307-year-old union with England and Wales. The Prime Minister promised a decentralization revolution throughout Britain, including votes on English issues by English parliamentarians in Westminster, as he celebrated Scotland's decision to stay within the UK. “There can be no disputes, no repetitions – we have heard the determined will of the Scottish people,” Cameron said in a statement
Previously, Scottish Prime Minister Alex Salmond remained defiant at a Scottish National Party rally in Edinburgh, saying he accepted that Scotland had not, “at this stage,” decided to vote for independence. He paid tribute to what he called a “triumph for democratic politics” and said he would work with Westminster in the best interest of Scotland and the rest of the UK – warning the leaders of the three main parties to keep their promises of further return to Scotland. “We have touched sectors of the community that have never been touched by politics before,” he said.
The campaign did achieve four major successes, winning 53% of the vote in Scotland's largest city, Glasgow, 57% in Dundee and 51% in North Lanarkshire. However, the camp was not victorious in 28 authorities. He won overwhelmingly in areas where he was expected to do well, including Edinburgh, Aberdeenshire and Borders, but also in areas that might have gone to the yes campaign, including the western islands. In the final count, the camp did not win 2,001,926 votes (55.3%) to 1,617,989 by itself (44.7%).
In his speech, Cameron made it clear that constitutional reforms, even in Scotland, would not be delivered until after the general elections, and that Scottish measures would be carried out along with changes in England. “We have heard Scotland’s voice and now we have to listen to the millions of voices in England,” he said.
Cameron added: “The people of Scotland have spoken and it is a clear result. They have kept our country from four nations together and, like millions of people, I am delighted. As I said during the campaign, I would have broken my heart to see our UK come to an end. And I know that that feeling was shared by people not only throughout our country but all over the world because of what we have accomplished together in the past and what we can do together in the future. Therefore, it is now time for our United Kingdom to meet and move forward. A vital part of this will be a balanced deal, just for the people in Scotland and, more importantly, for everyone in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, too.”
Ed Miliband, the Labour leader, said the referendum was a vote by the Scottish people for change. “We know that our country needs to change in the way it is governed and we know that our country needs to change in who is governed. We will gain stronger powers for a stronger Scottish parliament, a strong Scotland.” But he said that would go beyond Scotland. “We will also satisfy the desire for change throughout England, throughout Wales, throughout the UK.”
Nick Clegg, the Deputy Prime Minister, said the referendum “marks not only a new chapter for Scotland within the UK, but also a broader constitutional reform across the union.” Echoing the SNP’s argument, he said a vote against independence was “clearly not a vote against change.” “We must now deliver the radical package of powers just transferred to Scotland on time and in full,” he added.
However, that result increases the risk of further agitation, with Cameron Conservative Party MPs threatening to rebel against the Prime Minister's late and potentially vital promise to quickly increase the powers of the Scottish parliament while protecting its spending.
UK Independence Party leader Nigel Farage said Cameron's offer of more decentralization to England was not far enough. “The English are 86% of the population of this union. They have been excluded from all this for the past 18 years. We still have a situation in which Scottish Members can vote in the House of Commons on matters that concern only the English. I think what most English people want is a fair settlement,” he said.
Cameron and the Queen will move to calm tensions when they make statements about the outcome. The Prime Minister will try, in the words of a cabinet minister, to “cement” the negative vote by outlining how he will carry out the deepening of Scotland’s return agreement, including the handing over of greater powers over taxes and welfare to the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh.
The Queen, who has monitored the referendum with interest, will make a written statement. It is understood that his remarks will focus on reconciliation. The Prime Minister wants to act quickly to show that the three leading leaders of the UK party will live up to the commitments made during the referendum campaign to fulfill what former Prime Minister Gordon Brown called “domestic governance” within the UK.
Ministers believe that it is important to act quickly to avoid a repetition of the 1980 referendum in Québec. Ontario's triumphant behavior fueled the separatist cause that almost succeeded in a second referendum in 1995.
For the campaign no, there was relief: a lot of authorized polls in the last days of the campaign had said that the vote was on a knife edge, taking Yes Scotland a moving distance from victory after a dramatic increase in support.

A man who is believed to have been exposed to the deadly ricin poison in a hotel room in Las Vegas, Nevada, is out of his coma and is being questioned by the authorities, said FBI Special Agent David Staretz on Friday.
Ricin, weapons and an anarchist-type textbook were found in a room at this Las Vegas hotel, according to the police.
Staretz no longer commented on Roger Bergendorff, 57, to whom authorities said he was taken to a hospital on 14 February after complaining about respiratory difficulties.
He is in critical condition, said Naomi Jones, spokesman for the Spring Valley Hospital Medical Center in Las Vegas.
Bergendorff, an artist who neighbors said had lived in his cousin's basement before moving to Las Vegas, was exposed to poison at a long-stay hotel in Las Vegas, a law enforcement officer said.
The Riverton, Utah, home where Bergendorff previously lived belongs to Thomas Tholen, who along with his wife and daughter tested negative for the ricin, according to authorities. That house and three storage areas in nearby West Jordan, Utah, were searched for ricin earlier this month and declared safe by the authorities.
A relative who went to the hotel room in Bergendorff after being sent to the hospital found the substance and alerted the police on 27 February.
Ricin is a poison that can be produced from waste left over after processing castor beans, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It can come in the form of haze or pellet and can dissolve in water or weak acid, the agency said. E-mail to a friend
