text:
There's nothing terribly surprising about Apple's renewed tablet line, but that's fine.
We spent some time testing and playing the new iPad Mini and iPad Air after Tuesday's press conference. As promised by Apple executives, the new devices were lighter, thinner and seemingly faster, as were many incremental product updates from the past.
iPad Air
There were no important new features, such as the fingerprint scanner or the update of the camera that came with the iPhone 5S.
The most unexpected news of the day was a new name for the $599 iPad, which is now the iPad Air. The iPad line has been a little washy with the names.
He started by counting each version, but then dropped the number and asked only to be known as iPad, like Cher. The iPad 2 kept its number and a place in stores, where its slightly lower price - LRB- now $399 -RRB- could appeal to someone considering a cheaper Android or Windows tablet.
Physically, the iPad Air is actually lighter and thinner than its predecessor. It is 20% thinner than the third generation iPad, measuring at a slight 29 cm. An ad shown at the press conference showed an iPad Air lying on a tablet, quietly hidden behind a No. Two pencils. It has also lowered a little weight and the Wi-Fi version is now exactly 1 pound -LRB- the cellular version is 1.05 pounds -RRB-.
Unfortunately, I didn't have an older iPad on hand to make a weight comparison, and I had taken an iPad Mini first. Nothing makes a normal iPad feel heavy like holding an iPad Mini. You can't feel a Mini; it's so deliciously small.
The iPad Air has a 64-bit A7 processor, the same chip recently introduced on the iPhone 5S. The A7 should benefit heavy graphics programs like iMovie and iPhoto, and Phil Schiller said it would double the performance of the previous chip.
It is difficult to judge speed increases for a few minutes in a crowded room without proper testing and an equally empty previous generation device to use for comparison.
Apple's fresh produce always feels more zippier than previous generations. Part of that is the constant improvement of processors inside, but it is also the benefit of working on a new device that has not been slowed down gradually by application pages, hundreds of cat videos and the latest OS update.
Mini iPad with Retina display
The iPad Mini got its first update since it was first released a year ago.
Physically, the device is a dead bell for the original. Turn it on, and you'll see that it addresses one of the biggest complaints about the first version updating the screen to a 2048 by 1536 screen containing 326 pixels per inch, a big jump of the 163 pixels above per inch. Several Apple products already have the Retina display: the iPhone 4S and higher, the fourth generation iPod Touch, the 10-inch iPad and some MacBook Pros. -LRB- Apple says Retina Display is so good that the human eye cannot detect individual pixels on the device -RRB-.
Like the iPad Air, the iPad Mini with Retina has the A7 chip inside. Previously the Mini was a generation behind its biggest iPad brother in processor speed. But this update and the new screen put the devices on the same level, so choosing a smaller screen no longer means opting for the lower product.
The smaller size of the tablet is a competitive market, and the iPad Mini with Retina Display is finally Apple's premium offer for the size of 7.9 inches. The $399 tablet is now in a better position to take on products like Google 7 Nexus, Samsung Galaxy Tablets and Amazon Kindle HDX. Although other products can usually be kept for much less, any practical time with Apple products reminds you that one of their largest points of sale is solid, high-quality construction.
The missing update
Shave excess volume and change faster processors is of rigueur for any product update these days. Other companies could launch in price drops, but Apple is comfortable in place in the high end of the consumer market. You cannot start cutting devices for your flagship devices. Instead, the company keeps older models available, although even those have a somewhat high price.
Unfortunately, there is a key feature where all tablet manufacturers seem to have stalled: battery life.
Faster processors absorb more battery power, so keeping 10 hours of battery life from an old tablet to a new tablet probably requires battery upgrades. Both new iPads have the same M7 motion coprocessor that handles sensors, such as accelerometer and gyroscope, saving battery power by not using the main processor.
Apart from an hour here or there, mobile device manufacturers seem stuck in the mid-day mark, a frustrating limitation for people who have adapted when loading chargers and returning when they see an empty exit in a cafe, airport or friends' house.
For now, Apple is comfortable enough with the competition to simply iterate on its popular and well-designed products, making the usual round of upgrades and launching on the occasional eye-catching feature to catch attention, such as fingerprints on the iPhone 5S.
It may not be so much fun for technology fans that they were used to new spattered products and well-kept secrets, but it's probably a solid business decision.
According to Forrester analyst Sarah Rotman Epps, replacement tablet sales are growing faster than new tablet sales around the world. Manufacturers need to compete to keep customers who already have to consider upgrading an old model.
All tablet manufacturers are competing with what are essentially the same minor settings.
The competition will stay close until the first company leaves the usual upgrade cycle faster, thinner and faster and solves the battery problem.

text:
A thick bark of bird droppings accumulates in the golden balustrade of one of Britain's most expensive properties. The skeletons of pigeons are found between broken mirrors and streams of water through broken carnage. This is The Towers, a 30 million-pound palace in “Billonaires’ Row” in northern London, whose spectacular ruin has been kept secret so far.
It is one of the ten mansions in the center of Bishops Avenue, the heart of London's spiral real estate market, which have remained almost totally vacant since they were purchased a quarter century ago, is believed on behalf of members of the royal family of Saudi Arabia. Their Greek columns are cracking into pieces and the mosaic pools are full of rubble. Nature has taken control to the extent that owls have moved.
It is a desolate scene repeated up and down the supposedly prestigious avenue that Lloyds Bank has calculated is the second most expensive street in Britain. While more and more people are struggling to climb the London real estate ladder as housing prices rise by 11.2% a year, 16 mansions on the most expensive stretch of Bishops Avenue are empty, many behind padlocked doors, with their windows closed with steel grills and covered grounds patrolled by guard dogs.
On the other side of the street is another abandoned mansion, worth 18 million pounds, with windows and broken walls covered with anti-climb paint. The metal grids block the windows of another, which has been sold for 20 million pounds.
But that doesn't stop prices from going up. Dryades, a mansion until recently owned by a Pakistani politician, was sold for £12 million in 2007 and is believed to be worth about £30 million today. Heath Lodge, the scene of the 1984 murder, by silver bullet, of fashion tycoon Aristos Constantinou, is worth £13 million today, after being sold in the late 1970s for £400,000.
Neglect can be agonizing for people struggling to keep a roof over their heads in one of the most expensive cities in the world. A security guard working on the avenue said it was exasperating to see so many tens of thousands of square feet of property – enough to house dozens of people – fall apart.
Royal oil-rich Nigeria and Saudi Arabia were the first to reach this curved road near Hampstead Heath. The Iranians fled here after the fall of the Shah. Now, Chinese house hunters are following Russians and Kazakhs who have spent millions securing an address from real estate agents tell them he is as famous in the world as the Champs-Elysées and Rodeo Drive. Recently, two mansions have been for sale for £65m and £38m, promising endless Italian marble, leather padded elevators and luxurious panic rooms.
However, on the grounds of empty mansions, the stone fountains crumble and the lawns have become swamps. Inside one, the water drips through a huge glass candlestick over a thick carpet that rots under sections of the collapsed ceiling. The moss grows through broken bricks and mirrored tiles scattered through a bathroom. The pool is filled with a salty water foot and has flowers that grow through its tiles. The wooden slats move away from the sauna.
But it is the shipwreck of Las Torres, a large mansion located between acres of hornbeams, oaks and lime trees, which is more dramatic, with its huge high ceiling rooms occupied by pigeons and its walls turned bright green by algae while the water pours through three floors and plinks into a vast, empty pool, basement. Unopened wooden boxes marked as “bullet-proof glass” reveal the security fears of previous owners.
Today, very few people live on the Avenue of Bishops full time. A security guard patrolling the pavement outside a mansion said the owners weren't there. Another, outside Royal Mansion, refused to say if anyone was at home, while a staff member from another mansion simply warned the Guardian about the guard dogs. Magdy Adib Ishak-Hannah, a private health tycoon born in Egypt, whose personal wealth is 45 million pounds, said he was in the minority of permanent residents.
“It’s not a neighboring place, where you can chat about the fence,” he said. “To be honest, I’ve never seen what my neighbors look like. Next door, a Saudi princess spent 35 million pounds on a new house and I've never seen it. There are about three houses that live in 24/7 and half of the properties are occupied from three to six months a year. The other half, who knows if they're coming or not?
The shipwrecks of several million pounds are evidence of a property culture in which the richest people in the world view British property as investments. A Hyde Park, a block of apartments in Knightsbridge, is another example in which more than half of the flats are registered on the council as empty or second homes.
However, the talk on the avenue is about the construction of £5m apartments, instead of £50m mansions, in an effort to draw people back.
Anil Varma, a local real estate developer, has decided to rebuild one of the most valuable sites on the avenue as a collection of 20 apartments with concierge, cleaning service, 25 meter swimming pool, spa and cinema.
“If you build a big house and try to sell for £30m to £40m, it won’t sell,” he said. “The locals will not buy and therefore you have to bring foreign buyers.”
But the prospect of empty ownership of the avenue being used to help resolve the housing crisis remains distant. Andrew Harper, a local conservative councillor, laughed when asked if some of the abandoned houses could be converted into affordable homes. He said the price of the land would be prohibitive.
“Very rich people own properties there,” he said. “Sometimes they live in them and sometimes they don’t.”

text:
Again, there are rumors that the third - and fourth largest wireless aircraft carriers in the U.S. can merge to form a No. 3. But would this be enough to keep the U.S. market wireless? competitive for consumers?
Last week Bloomberg reported that Deutsche Telekom AG, T-Mobile's parent company, is negotiating a possible sale of T-Mobile to Sprint Nextel Corp..
According to The Hill and The Washington Post, some industry analysts believe that the US government would approve this merger. Rumors of this merger have existed since 2009, when DT was looking at a purchase of Sprint.
And last weekend, TMOnews reported on an ambiguous non-confirmation/non-denial memorandum sent to T-Mobile employees by CEO Philip Humm.
Given the nature of wireless networks and the current business landscape, T-Mobile probably needs to make some kind of important move if he hopes to survive somehow.
In the overall picture, a lot of capital is needed to build high-speed wireless broadband networks that can support an increasing number of data-hungry devices, such as smartphones and tablets, especially if streaming mobile video becomes popular, and if the Obama administration takes its national wireless initiative seriously to make wireless broadband available to 98% of the American population.
Carriers with the largest customer base, especially those with the most customers secured expensive two-year contracts, are in the best financial position to build their 4G networks.
Having those networks, in turn, makes larger companies even more likely to attract even more customers. And this is the economic dynamic that could turn the wireless market in the U.S. in a Verizon/AT & T duopoly, with only a few discount carriers surviving on the margins.
For US mobile users, further consolidation of the wireless market is good news/bad situation. It offers the promise of omnipresent high-speed wireless broadband networks available in markets outside major metropolitan areas, thus reducing the geographical aspect of the mobile digital divide.
But just because wireless broadband is available in a region doesn't mean that everyone there can afford to use it. A less competitive wireless market could mean that wireless broadband is not much cheaper. It could even be more costly, especially if staggered data plans became the norm, which would make more sense for carriers in a less competitive environment.
That would be bad news on the revenue/class front of the mobile digital divide.
Lately, T-Mobile has been getting a little bit of a beating on the U.S. market. Bloomberg noted: T-Mobile... has lost customers at an accelerated pace, as it outpaced its rivals in building a third-generation mobile network and missed the possibility of selling Apple's iPhone. About 56,000 customers left T-Mobile USA last year, while Sprint, AT&T and Verizon Wireless increased their accounts.
Consequently, DT may not be satisfied with what Sprint may be willing to offer for T-Mobile -- so who knows if this merger is going to happen.
In addition, a T-Mobile/Sprint merger could be difficult for technical reasons.
Wireless Week noted: T-Mobile currently markets its HSPA+ network as 4G, but lacks the bandwidth to implement LTE or WiMAX. Sprint and T-Mobile use different network technologies and operate in different spectrum bands, which would complicate a possible merger of companies' wireless services.
If T-Mobile hopes to survive intact, it will need access to much more bandwidth in more U.S. locations. So if the Sprint merge doesn't happen, T-Mobile has options -- mainly rent extra spectrum or access to other provider networks, such as LightSquared, a wireless wholesale LTE network.
The opinions expressed in this post are only those of Amy Gahran.

text:
It is not only the largest hamburger chain in the world; it is also a global emblem of U.S. consumer capitalism. But these days, McDonald’s golden arches are a little tarnished. After a decade of expansion, customers around the world no longer seem to love them. McDonald’s has revealed that world sales dropped 3.3% in 2013 in a set of results that were described as atrocious.
The problems are accumulating almost everywhere. In China, sales sank 23% after a food scare when local media showed workers apparently captured in the chamber of a local supplier claiming to use beef and chicken in products destined for McDonald’s and KFC. In Europe, sales have fallen by 4%, mainly due to riots in Ukraine and the bitter anti-Western mood in Russia. About 200 of McDonald’s 450 restaurants in Russia are being investigated by health inspectors in seemingly politically motivated food safety controls. Ten have been closed.
But it is in the United States, where McDonald’s has about 40% of its restaurants, where the crisis is deepest. Almost 60 years after Ray Kroc opened his first restaurant in Des Plaines, Illinois, consumers are losing their appetite for a Big Mac and chips.
McDonald’s has seen 12 consecutive months of declining sales in its massive real estate market, with sales of 4.1% in the last quarter. Younger diners are deserting from the restaurant in herds to eat in rivals like Chipotle Mexican Grill. The number of young people aged 19 to 21 visiting McDonald’s once a month has decreased by 13% since 2011, according to Technomic food analysts, while the number of young people aged 22 to 37 visiting McDonald’s has not increased.
To add to the company’s problems, McDonald’s burgers were recently named America’s worst in a poll of over 32,000 American diners, who said they would prefer to eat a burger at Five Guys, Smashburger or Fuddruckers. The fast-growing Chick-fil-A chain in the United States was considered the best for chicken. McDonald’s is also widely perceived as less healthy than most of its rivals, especially Chipotle, who trumpet their antibiotic-free meat and "seasonal local products," although "local" for Chipotle can mean 350 miles away.
Consumers’ deep distrust of McDonald’s was exposed by a consumer outreach exercise that the company launched in the United States in October. “Have you ever used pink drool on your burgers?” was a question on the Our Food Your Questions website – referring to the controversial filler of beef (grastle and fat) used for dog foods sprayed with ammonia to make it “fit” for human consumption. The meat product, banned in Europe since the BSE crisis, was abandoned by McDonald’s in 2012.
But the pink drool has left doubts in the minds of American consumers. “Donald’s meat contains worms?” another person asked (“No. Gross. End of story,” the company replied. Others wanted to know if he used real eggs or whether the McRib was made with the same plastic contained in yoga mats. Don Thompson, Managing Director of McDonald’s, acknowledged that the company had a job to do to address the misconceptions about the freshness, quality and integrity of its ingredients.
However, just like McDonald’s has been losing customers who will pay a little more for fresher and healthier foods, it has also lost its advantage in essential fast food products: fast service at low prices. Since he introduced $2 items into his dollar menu, he has earned a reputation for being more expensive than his rivals, while many consumers complain that the service is slower.
The label “caro” was unjustified, said Mary Chapman at Technomic. “Prices have gone up, but they haven’t gone up as fast as the rest of the fast service chains in the US.” Prices at McDonald’s have increased by 4.8 per cent since 2009, well below the average for the “fast service” sector (19.4 per cent), while the cost of fast casual food, a category that includes Chipotle, is rising by 16.9 per cent, according to the Technomic menu monitor. United States consumer prices increased by 11 per cent during the same period.
But critics have a point when it comes to longer queues. McDonald’s has a bigger menu than some, with more complicated elements – its McWrap chicken takes 60 seconds to make. “I think it’s worth waiting, but the guy behind me who wants his double cheeseburger for a dollar may not,” Chapman said.
In the UK, McDonald’s has turned its business around, making Britain an exceptional place for the company. A competitive breakfast menu, improved coffee and free Wi-Fi had given McDonald’s a wide appeal in the UK, said Peter Martin of the CGA Peach consultant whose figures show that 56% of British adults have visited a McDonald’s restaurant at least once in the past six months.
Executives promise to address misconceptions about their food in their domestic market. Thompson has promised more organic food and custom-made burgers, but, to reduce queues, he also wants to introduce simpler menus. Analysts are scratching their heads on how the company can square the circle of simpler menus and a greater choice over fillers.
“They want to simplify the menu but improve their ability to customize and that sounds complicated,” Mark Kalinowski said at Janney Capital Markets. Only four of McDonald’s’s 14,000 American restaurants had so far tried “building their own burger,” he said, asking questions about how it could be expanded. “Right now, we are skeptical; we would like to see more details.”
Meanwhile, despite declining sales, the chain continues to expand globally: by the end of 2014, it hopes to have opened 1,400 new restaurants. Kalinowski expects McDonald's market share to continue to decline, but he, too, warned against the company's cancellation. “You can never really count McDonald’s out. We believe it will be number one in terms of total sales for not only years but decades to come.”

text:
JMW Turner, one of the best painters in Britain, is going to be the face of the new £20 note, after a nationwide vote.
It will be the first time an artist has appeared on a British ticket, after the Governor of the Bank of England, Mark Carney, asked the public to nominate a deceased cultural figure who felt deserved the high honor.
Turner, famous for his spectacular marine landscapes, beat the competition of 590 painters, sculptors, fashion designers, photographers, filmmakers and actors proposed by 30,000 members of the public.
The list included Alfred Hitchcock, Alexander McQueen, Derek Jarman, Laura Ashley, William Morris and Vanessa Bell, which was then reduced by a panel of artists, critics and historians to a final choice of five.
The last five – Barbara Hepworth, Charlie Chaplin, Josiah Wedgwood, William Hogarth and Turner – were selected on the basis of their “unquestionable” contribution to both the visual arts and British society as a whole, as well as their lasting influence.
Properly, the announcement of the new ticket was made at the Turner Contemporary gallery in Margate, which is located on the former site of Mrs Booth's guest house, where Turner always stayed when he visited it. The announcement was made jointly by Carney and artist Tracey Emin, who grew up in the city.
Carney said it had been “so important to do this well and have a proper process involving the public,” adding that, far from being a purely practical necessity, “if done correctly, they can be a piece of art in everyone’s pocket.”
“Money is a memory for a country and its people,” said the Governor of the Bank of England. “The Bank of England notes are a celebration of the heritage of the United Kingdom, a greeting to its culture, a testament to its great achievements, including those of its most notable citizens. In short, money not only has economic value, it also has cultural value.
“Turner is undoubtedly the most influential British artist of all time. His work was transformative and endures today. And his work will now be presented in another 2 billion works of art – our new £20 notes.”
“The fact that we have Turner in the £20 note now shows that the British people are a nation of people who appreciate creativity and the arts,” Emin said.
The note will feature Turner's 1799 self-portrait, which currently hangs on Tate Britain, as well as one of his most recognizable works, The Fighting Temeraire, a tribute to the boat that played a distinguished role in Nelson's victory at the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.
The note will also include a quote from the artist – “light is therefore color” – as well as his signature, taken from his will, in which he bequeathed many of his works to the nation.
The new £20 note, which replaces the one presented by social philosopher and economic theorist Adam Smith, will come into circulation by 2020. This is the first time that the public has been given an opinion on whose face appears on a British ticket.

text:
1 racing engineer
A racing engineer maintains contacts between the driver and mechanics.
Typical salary: New graduates start at £25,000 to £30,000 and quickly progress to junior engineer positions, earning more than £40,000 with only a few years of experience. Senior racing engineers earn between £50,000 and 90,000 and promotions often lead to six-figure wages.
What the work involves: “A racing engineer acts as an interpreter between racing mechanics and the driver,” says racing engineer Jamie Muir. “The engineer takes feedback from the driver, analyzes the available data and makes decisions about the configuration necessary for maximum performance, then transmits this to the mechanics to instigate.”
Qualifications: A university degree, typically in automotive/mechanical engineering or motorsport technology. Practical experience is essential.
To succeed as a racing engineer, you need to be able to deal with the pressure.
The worst thing about work: long hours. “The race engineers work 24 hours a day,” says Chris Aylett, CEO of Motorsport Industry Association.
2 Ethical Hacker
Typical wage: £60,000 to £90,000 at team leader level, while a newly qualified hacker can expect a minimum wage from £35,000 to £50,000.
What the job involves: A company will pay an ethical hacker to hack into its computer system to see how well it could face a real attack.
Qualifications: You do not necessarily need a degree in computer science. The sector accepts people with a wide range of academic qualifications and competences.
To succeed as an ethical hacker, you need a passion for technology and detail. You should also have a very good analytical mind and enjoy solving difficult problems.
The worst of the job: When you are called to test a new client's network security just to find out that they have already been victims of a data breach.
3 Pump Removal Diver
Typical wage: In the private sector, you can earn up to £100,000 by working only two months out of every three.
What the work involves: Descending to the seabed and searching for unexploded ordnance (bombs, projectiles, grenades and landmines), then either recovering and collecting the weapons safely or discarding them safely.
Qualifications: To dive on the high seas, you must have diving inspection and medical-technical qualifications. In order to safely dispose of the bombs, you will also need an explosive ordnance disposal rating and years of experience.
To succeed as a bomb disposal diver, you need to... stay calm in stressful situations. You work on your own in depth, with little visibility and, if you don't like living in small spaces confined to many other people, forget it.
Worst of work: Expect to be away from home at least six months of the year.
4 Social engineer
Typical wage: Between £50,000 and £80,000, on average. Graduates start at £25,000, but wages increase rapidly with qualifications and experience.
Work: A social engineer is paid by a company to try to trick its employees into disclosing confidential information that allows them to access sensitive company data or the company's computer network.
Qualifications: Typically, social engineers have a degree in IT, although an understanding of psychology is useful, as is training in marketing, teaching and customer service.
To succeed as a social engineer, it takes... the confidence to lie convincingly and the ability to fit in almost anywhere without looking too out of place. It also needs a strong sense of personal ethics and an understanding of the law.
The Worst of Work: Other people can misunderstand your work: social engineers are not spies, but most people think they are.
5 pilot electric line helicopters
Typical wage: Pound65,000
The job: to fly near high-voltage power lines in a helicopter so that the lines can be inspected with a camera and any failure or potential problem can be identified by the electrical company.
Qualifications: A private helicopter pilot's license, a commercial pilot's license and about 2,000 hours of low-level flying experience in the type of helicopter the company routinely uses.
To succeed as a power-line helicopter pilot, you need... a firm hand and a cold head. Typically, pilots must fly next to the power line, sometimes only 20 feet away and only 30 feet off the ground.
The worst part of the job: “There are no negatives,” says Robin Tutcher, chief helicopter pilot at Western Power Distribution.
6 private butler
Typical wage: 60,000 to 90,000 pounds sterling
Work: A private butler can be called by your employer to do anything, from costume management to driver and pet care. Typical duties include managing other staff, serving at each meal, running errands, caring for guests, booking restaurants, home security, cleaning, cooking and anything else the home needs.
Qualifications: You do not need any specific qualification, but you can take a course at the British Academy of Butler or the British Institute of Butler.
To succeed as a butler, it takes... the mentality of someone who really thrives in caring for others.
The worst thing about work: Long hours and unpredictable working hours mean it's hard to have a family life. Butlers also suffer from isolation, cultural differences with their employer, and “having to work for people who are not always kind,” says Sara Vestin, director of the British Academy of Butler.

Representative Mike Rogers, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee and a key Congressional voice on national security, announced Friday that he will not run for re-election this year.
The Republican of Michigan made the announcement at the WJR radio station in Detroit, saying he will host a syndicated radio program that will talk about national security issues and other news of the day.
I had a career before politics and I always planned to have one later, Rogers said in a statement. The genius of our institutions is that they do not depend on the privileged individual temporary occupants to serve. That is why I have decided not to seek re-election for Congress in 2014.
Rogers, who has held a seat in Congress for more than a decade and is close to House President John Boehner, has been a strong supporter of the National Security Agency's surveillance programs, which were set on fire after Edward Snowden's leaks publicly revealed their nature.
This week, he and Representative Dutch Ruppersberger of Maryland -- the top Democrat on the Intelligence Committee -- developed a plan to end the NSA's extensive collection of massive telephone records.
Obama, Congress working on NSA changes
Rogers has said in the past that the phone and electronic surveillance programs were not abused and has shrillly criticized Snowden, a former NSA contractor.
It has also recognized public concerns about government storage of surveillance data.
That's really what we're trying to do here is to ease the concern that there could be abuse in the future of these programs, Rogers said recently.
Authorization for those programs expires on Friday, but President Barack Obama is expected to seek temporary renewal while Congress is working on reform legislation, a senior administration official said.
Rogers is also one of the favorites of Sunday public affairs programming in which he frequently criticizes Obama.
He joins a cadre of House members who are not seeking re-election in November, but his seat in Congressional District 8 is still considered relatively safe for Republicans.
But Rothenberg's Political Report and Cook's Political Report changed his analysis of the district from probably Republican to Republican inclined for the November elections after Rogersannouncement.
The Democrats sought to unite Rogers and Boehner.
The main chairmen of the Republican committees continue to flee John Boehner's broken Congress instead of defending their indefensible record of agreeing with special interests over middle-class families who have earned them a record low approval ratings, New York's Steve Israel representative chairing the Democratic Congress Campaign Committee.
Rogers became a key figure in the development of U.S. national security policy, informed by his experience as an Army officer and special agent of the FBI.
U.S., other powers drive Russia out of the G8
Mike has spent his whole life making sure that our country has been safe from both domestic and foreign threats, Congressional Republican National Committee Chairman Greg Walden said in a statement. He never let partisan politics stand in the way of doing what is right for our nation and its security. I can't think of anyone who enjoys more respect from both Republicans and Democrats.
Before Rogers became president, he published an Intelligence Committee report on Iran's nuclear ambitions, wrote a bill to protect against chemical and biological threats, and co-authored legislation that reauthorized the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, his biography of the Intelligence Committee said.
Mike Rogers is as solid as they come... one of those patriots willing to go to the wall to keep the American people safe, no matter the tension or sacrifice, Boehner said in a statement.
Jim Acosta, Tom Cohen, Lisa Desjardins and John Helton of CNN contributed to this report.

text:
There are eyes on you, behind the bright lights and the mirror panels. Pick up a boot and a camera will make sure it doesn't slide into your bag. Get into a department store and they'll keep an eye on you. But new technology is leading retailers to grow a different set of eyes – less focused on shoplifting and more interested in their age, sex, size, head, shoulders, knees and toes.
A few months ago, Computer Sciences Corporation (CSC) produced a report stating that about 30% of retailers use facial recognition technology to track customers in the store. Facial recognition is a technology that can identify people by analyzing and comparing the facial characteristics of a database, using devices such as Intel RealSense cameras, which are able to analyze everything, from particular expressions to the clothing brands that someone wears.
Joe Jensen of Intel’s Retail Solutions Division says that the goal of bringing RealSense technology to stores is not to create databases of specific people’s lives, but rather to build generalized models of people’s lifestyles and buying habits. “It’s not so much that you need to meet a particular customer. It is necessary to know that this buyer has these characteristics and, in the past, that when those characteristics are present, this is what a person tends to do.”
If you combine recognition technology with databases of past customer patterns, you can start predicting a lot about what a person can or can't do in a store. If, let's say, there's a woman size 10 who wears a gold necklace walking fast into the sock aisle, you can use that data to predict what she wants, well, to buy socks. This could allow a retailer to automatically place targeted ads on screens specifically aimed at that person. If you look like the kind of person who wants to buy socks, they'll show you socks ads.
If it sounds familiar, it's because the online world has been using techniques like this for years.
If you look for something on Amazon, you will be chased by targeted banners for similar products elsewhere. Express a vague interest in canoeing and you will receive canoe ads wherever you go. However, bringing these systems into the physical world is not a simple case of copying and pasting. It turns out that people don't react to cameras the same way they do to browser cookies.
Hoxton Analytics, a London-based team of data scientists, has developed a technology that uses machine learning and artificial intelligence to categorize people according to the shoes they wear. By analyzing the style and size of people's shoes when passing the sensor, the system can identify the gender of a customer with between 75 and 80% accuracy.
Owen McCormack, CEO of Hoxton Analytics, says that the system's approach emerged in part as a reaction to facial recognition. “My idea was, why don’t we just consider the clothes someone is wearing to understand demography?” he said. “If I just showed you a picture of someone’s body, you could probably tell me what kind they are. However, it turns out that pointing a camera to someone's chest or hips feels as creepy as facial recognition. The idea was – what about people’s shoes?”
The word “crepey” appears a lot during discussions about follow-up in the store. For retailers and data scientists, the goal is to find a way to obtain information without becoming intrusive.
For Hoxton Analytics and retailers who use technology, the answer is to look down. This tactic of avoiding the face and staring at the shoes says a lot about how we, as physical beings, react to being observed. He suggests that there are limits that do not exist on the Internet. Look at our torsos and we feel invaded. But is it less invasive to make calculated judgments about a person based on his shoes?
For McCormack, the argument is based on the fact that identifiable personal information is not being collected. “At the moment, stores are doing a lot of incredibly invasive things, but we don’t know anything about it. The angle that Hoxton Analytics is taking is, well, if you know that someone is a man or a woman, then your advertising will be much more efficient. If you know that everyone in your store is a man right now, you will be advertising PlayStations not hair dryers.”
Keeping it hidden and invisible monitoring allows stores to optimize their output while keeping the customer unconscious. Put adaptive monitors and targeted advertising in the mix, however, and it becomes harder to hide the fact that a machine is watching you. The argument of retailers is that they do this to provide a personal shopping experience, but it is still a grey area. It still feels creepy.
From the point of view of retailers, it is understandable that physical stores want some of the online information points to collect. We let this happen online, so why not off-line? The thresholds of a shopping mall are different from those that exist between the websites and, when you can freely wander from one place to another without a pop-up asking you to accept cookies, the consent rules change.
On the other hand, for a generation that grows with online first, the second physical store, online gambling modes may not be so invasive. In the CSC report, a survey indicated that while 72% of respondents aged 55 and over said they were very uncomfortable with this type of technology used in physical stores, only 51% of young people aged 16-24 said the same.
Is this relative openness derived from greater familiarity with digital technology or from a blind belief in the goodwill of omnipresent organizations offering free services? Is the chill of a technology an instinctive and invariant certainty or flows with degrees of social acceptance? Whatever the case, there's a growing number of eyes on the shelves and they care a lot about what you're wearing.
label: C1

text:
With its palaces, sculpted parks, concert halls and museums, Vienna is a city full of culture.
In Vienna, for centuries, composers Beethoven, Mozart and Johann Strauss, and artists Gustav Klimt, Oskar Kokoschka and Egon Schiele, as well as the father of psychoanalysis, Sigmund Freud, have been at the forefront of major cultural movements.
But that does not mean that it is stuck in the past; Vienna also has a youthful side, and is visited annually by backpackers as much as fans of the main culture, something that Richard Linklater celebrated in his 1995 film Before Sunrise, in which two strangers fell in love over the course of a day, with Vienna as a romantic backdrop.
Whether you visit in winter the Christmas markets that shine under snowflakes, or in spring, when the flowers in the city's many parks are in bloom, the city will surely love it.
CNN World's Treasures selects some of the best places to experience the Old World of Vienna, from galleries and parks to historical monuments.
SEE
The year 2012 marks the 150th anniversary of the birth of Austrian painter Gustav Klimt, one of the founding members of the Vienna Secession, an avant-garde artistic group at the beginning of the century.
In fact, one of the architectural masterpieces of the city, the art nouveau Secession building, was commissioned by the group as a refuge for the latest in contemporary art.
The Museum presents the mural of Klimt Beethoven, but to see his famous gold painting The Kiss, head to the Belvedere Museum, located in a magnificent palace built in the 1700s. It has a complete collection of Klimt paintings, along with works by Kokoschka, Schiele, Vincent van Gogh and Auguste Rodin, among others.
The painters at the end of the century in Vienna owed much to the new theories of mind from Sigmund Freud, and no trip to Vienna would be complete without visiting the Sigmund Freud Museum, where the founder of psychoanalysis lived until he was forced to flee in 1938. Take a lecture or just wander around the original waiting room and imagine that you are about to be examined by the great man himself.
For those who seek to delight themselves with their eyes in earlier examples of the opulent past of the city, look no further than the Schatzkammer, the imperial treasure and the home of the Crown Jewels of Habsburg, which is located in the vast Hofburg Palace, seat of the dominant Habsburg dynasty.
Hear
For lovers of classical music, Vienna is a must, as it was in the 18th century, when it attracted the young Mozart.
You can visit the apartment in which Mozart lived when he composed Figaro's marriage among other great works, which has become a museum and has temporary exhibitions, in addition to the permanent collection of objects in the house itself. You can even listen to their music through the rooms as you wander around.
For concerts, head to the Musikverein for Wiener Philharmoniker performances and smaller camera concerts. Or for operas, reserve a seat at the great Staatsoper, or at the Theater-an-der-Wien, where works by Beethoven and Strauss were originally premiered.
STROLL
Vienna has a lot of open spaces and parks, from the sculpted alpine gardens of Belvedere Castle to the most relaxed and youthful sensation of Danube Island. The Rathauspark features an ice skating rink in winter and an outdoor cinema in summer. Alternatively, take a walk through the Baroque gardens of Schonbrunn Palace. A well-timed tourist activity is riding the wheel in the Prater Attractions Park, which appears in Graham Greene's film The Third Man.
Stay
Places to stay in Vienna are abundant and cater to all budgets. Hotel Altstadt is located in Spittelberg's artistic district, right behind the MuseumsQuartier and boasts an impressive collection of contemporary art and design; Das Tyrol, an old monastery with a small spa, features works of art by young Viennese artists; the Konig von Ungarn has the advantage of being in the same 300-year-old building complex as Mozart's living rooms; and the Hilton Vienna Danube has views over the river.
EAT
Viennese cuisine is not for those who observe their waists; watering snacks and cakes, breaded meats and beer and wine in abundance make the city a banquet for the palates. Steirereck serves an impressive variety of delicious Viennese dishes, although not exactly slimming, while Demel serves coffee and cakes for an afternoon treat between sightseeing.

An American jailed for nearly a month in the United Arab Emirates for taking pictures has been released from custody and has returned to Georgia, a family spokesman said.
Robert Alan Black, who had been in the United Arab Emirates to speak at an international creative conference, had been held at Al Wathba prison in Abu Dhabi since October 21 after being accused of taking photos of restricted areas, said Rosemary Rein, spokesman for Friends of Alan Black.
Former architect, Black often takes photos of buildings, according to Rein. This is prohibited in some parts of the United Arab Emirates, in particular in government buildings, embassies, military installations and other places considered sensitive.
He made a brief appearance in court on Monday, and was released the next day.
The court concluded that the action was committed without bad intent, and ordered the minimum fine of 500 dirhams -LRB-United Arab Emirates or about $135 -RRB-, according to Rein's statement, which was posted on a Facebook page by Robert Alan Black.
After his release, the 70-year-old boy went home in Athens, Georgia.
“We are relieved and happy with this news,” Rein said. The international community of creativity was concerned about our dear friend and colleague, and we are glad that the matter has been resolved.
Black is characterized as an architect, cartoonist, graphic designer, teacher and creative consultant on its website. He has made presentations at more than 150 creative lectures on six continents since 1978, and has written more than 600 articles and a book, Broken Crayons: Break Your Crayons and Draw Outside the Lines.
Rein said Black's next stop, after the Abu Dhabi conference, was supposed to be Malaysia. But after noting that he had not posted on social media, she touched the ground with mutual acquaintances and learned that he had never made it to Malaysia.

text:
Every last one, David Bowie, who died of cancer, was still able to generate surprises. His last album, Blackstar, appeared on his 69th birthday on January 8, 2016 and showed that his gift to make dramatic statements as well as challenging and disturbing music had not abandoned him.
Throughout the 1970s, Bowie was a pioneer of musical trends and pop fashion. Having been a mimo and cabaret artist from the late 1960s, he became a singer-composer, a pioneer of glam-rock, then turned to what he called “plastic soul,” before moving to Berlin to create innovative electronic music. Its ability to mix brilliant changes in sound and image supported by genuine intellectual curiosity is rivaled by few in pop history.
Bowie was born David Robert Jones in southern London. In 1953, the family moved to Kent, where David showed ability to sing and play the recorder. Later, he studied art, music and design. In 1961, David's mother bought him a plastic saxophone, introducing him to an instrument that would become a recurring ingredient in his music.
At the age of 15, David formed his first band, the Kon-rads. It was clear that David’s talent and ambition dictated that he should go alone. David adopted the name Bowie to avoid confusion with Davy Jones of the Monkees.
Bowie's first album, released in June 1967, was simply titled David Bowie. In July 1969, Bowie released Space Oddity, the song that would give him his initial commercial breakthrough. Time to coincide with the landing of Apollo 11, was a success among the top five in the UK.
In March 1970, Bowie married Angela Barnett, an art student. Artistically, Bowie was ahead. The Man Who Sold the World was released in the U.S. At the end of 1970 and in the United Kingdom the following year, and with his bold composition and broody, hard-rock sound, was the first album to do complete justice to his writing and performance of gifts. The album's themes included immortality, madness, murder, and mysticism, evidence that Bowie was a composer who was thinking far beyond the usual limits of pop.
He followed it with Hunky Dory of 1972, a mixture of elaborate composition and wordy. It was an excellent collection that had only moderate success, but everything changed with The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders of Mars at the end of that year.
This time, Bowie emerged as a full-fledged science fiction character – an intergalactic glam-rock star visiting a doomed planet to Earth – and the album effectively wrote the script for its own stardom. The success of the single Starman brought instant success for the album, while Bowie's dazzling costumes and provocative performances sparked fan enthusiasm from Beatlemania.
Everything Bowie touched turned into gold. He had his first album number 1 from the United Kingdom with Aladdin Sane (1973), which generated the single hits The Jean Genie and Drive-in Saturday. But Bowie was already planning new professional moves.
His growing interest in funk and soul music came to the fore in delightfully listenable American youths (1975), which gave him a US record with Fama (with John Lennon as guest vocalist).
Station to Station (1976) introduced a new character, the Thin White Duke, which Bowie had taken from his main performance as a melancholy space traveler in Nicolas Roeg's film The Man Who Falled to Earth.
Bowie's relationship with his wife had been disintegrating under the pressures of success and the couple divorced in 1980. This was a year of more creative triumph, bringing a good album, Scary Monsters (and Super Creeps), and his spin-out single, Ashes to Ashes, followed by Bowie's welcome time as John Merrick at The Elephant Man on Broadway stage. He obtained a single number 1 with his 1981 association with Queen, Under Pressure as he became increasingly involved in crossovers between different media. He appeared in the German film Christiane F (1981) and wrote music for the soundtrack. He had another graphic success with Cat People (Putting Out Fire) from Paul Schrader's film Cat People (1982). Bowie continued to make progress as a screen actor with appearances in The Hunger and the drama of the Second World War Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence, both released in 1983.
Musically, this was the year he put his energy into a commercial attack with the album Let’s Dance and follow-up concerts. Let's Dance molded Bowie into a crowd-friendly global rock star, with the album and its singles Let's Dance, China Girl and Modern Love becoming great international hits.
This was the peak of MTV and Bowie's Knack for eye-catching videos fueled this commercial waste, while the six-month Serious Moonlight tour attracted massive crowds. It was going to be the most commercially successful period of his career. His profile gained another boost from his appearance at the 1985 humanitarian aid concert at Wembley Stadium, where he was one of the leading artists. He also partnered with Mick Jagger to record the single for fundraising Dancing in the Street, which went to number 1. A few days after his appearance at the Freddie Mercury tribute concert at Wembley Stadium in April 1992, Bowie married Somali model Iman and the couple bought a house in New York. This new beginning in his private life coincided with a search for fresh musical inspiration.
For the album Black Tie White Noise (1993), he sprayed elements of soul, electronics and hip hop in the mix. He led the UK album list and produced a top 10 single, Jump They Say. New media and technology also influenced their recordings. His 1999 album Hours... was based on music he had written for a computer game called Omikron, in which Bowie and Iman appeared as characters. The birth of Bowie and the daughter of Iman, Alexandria, followed in August 2000.
As an adopted New Yorker, Bowie was the opening act at the New York concert in October 2001, where he joined Paul McCartney, Jon Bon Jovi, Billy Joel, The Who and Elton John in a charity program six weeks after the September 11 attacks. Bowie was back in the studio the following year for Reality. However, in the middle of his 2004 Reality tour, Bowie was beaten with chest pain while performing in Germany and underwent emergency surgery in Hamburg to clean a blocked artery.
He took the medical emergency as a warning and slowed down his activities. In 2006, he announced that he would take a year off tours and recordings. In February of that year, he received a Grammy Award for Life, having been included in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1996.
The Next Day (2013) was their first new album in a decade. It contained the single Where Are We Now?, which gave it its first hit in the UK's top 10 since 1993. The album led the charts in Britain and around the world. In 2014, Bowie received the Brit Award for Best British Man, making him the oldest British winner in the history of the awards. He is survived by Iman, his daughter, Alexandria, his stepdaughter, Zulekha, and his son, Duncan, from his first marriage.

text:
When night falls on Rwanda, many rural communities far from the country's electricity grid descend into darkness.
Disconnected from power lines, households in these areas rely mainly on fuel-based devices such as kerosene lamps for access to light. However, these flashlights are polluting and costly: they emit toxic gases, pose fire risks and also put pressure on family budgets.
However, an innovative solution has recently emerged to provide affordable and efficient electricity to low-income households while benefiting communities by providing employment to local populations.
Called POWERcycle, Nuru Energy says it has developed the first commercially available pedal generator, a foot or handheld device that can recharge up to five modular light-emitting diodes -LRB-LED-RRB- lamps in about 20 minutes, as well as mobile power phones and radios.
The company says that each of its portable LED lamps provides a week of light to a rural home. It also states that its products are more affordable and reliable than other off-grid forms of supply that have developed in recent years, including solar lamps or solar home lighting systems.
We looked around and said, well, what is the only energy resource that is not exploited in this environment? And human power really came to mind, says Sameer Hajee, executive director and co-founder of Nuru Energy.
We think, well, if we can harness human energy in a way that we can create economic opportunities and low-power electricity, wouldn't that be a game-changing solution?
Watch: Can hand-made bicycles change lives?
According to Lighting Africa, a joint programme of the World Bank and the IFC developed to increase access to clean sources of energy for lighting, 589 million people on the continent live without access to a public electricity facility.
The group says poor rural African households and small businesses pay $10 billion a year for lighting purposes, while communities that are not connected to the network spend $4.4 billion a year on kerosene.
To address the issue of energy poverty, Hajee, a social entrepreneur with a lot of experience in international development, spent more than a month in Rwanda in 2008, trying to figure out what the energy needs of the country's people without a network connection were.
What he discovered was actually quite basic - LSB- energy needs -RSB-, he says. It's light, kitchen, mobile phone recharge and radio.
With the help of the World Bank, Hajee co-founded Nuru Energy and in 2009 the company began testing its products in the field.
However, Hajee quickly realized that innovative technology was not enough for the project to succeed in a place like rural Rwanda. His company also needed to take a creative approach on the distribution front.
We couldn't just sell the product -- we had to really get involved in the downstream value chain, he says. We thought, well, if the generator can recharge five lights so quickly, couldn't this be the basis of a recharging business for a local entrepreneur?
As a result, the company decided not to sell its products directly to customers. Instead, it established a network of village-level entrepreneurs who are responsible for marketing, selling and recharging the lights.
Hajee says this unique distribution model has revolutionized the lives of both micro-entrepreneurs and customers.
If you look at this from the customer's point of view, Hajee says, they would buy the light for $6 and then pay about 20 cents a week for lighting. This compares to about $2 a week that would be spent on kerosene earlier. So it's 10 times cheaper solution for them.
From the businessman's perspective, in 20 minutes of pedaling, they're charging five lights, earning about $1, any of us who work in Africa know that's a lot more than people earn in a whole day. So it's a great value proposition for the client and the entrepreneur.
Hajee points out that this model can easily be emulated throughout rural Africa. He says that Nuru Energy, which is currently focusing on East Africa and India, has already been approached by a number of potential joint venture partners to launch the project in other parts of the continent.
I really hope that what we are providing here is a temporary solution to the immediate energy needs of... the rural populations, Hajee says. What I really hope is that, you know, there is definitely effort needed to provide quality grid electricity to these populations. It'll take some time.

Five days of shootings between the Indian army and separatist militants in Indian-run Kashmir have left at least 25 dead: eight Indian army soldiers, including one officer, and 17 militants, the Indian army said Tuesday.
An Indian army soldier puts a crown during the funeral of a dead soldier, northeast of Srinagar on Tuesday.
Minister of Defence A.K. Antony, meeting with Indian military leaders in Delhi, examined the situation in the Himalayan region and told the Army to address the situation in the Himalayan region with the utmost firmness.
Kashmir has been in the midst of a violent separatist campaign for nearly two decades during which authorities say 43,000 people have been killed. However, several non-governmental organizations and human rights groups have doubled the number of deaths.
In Srinigar, Kashmir, the Army spokesman, Lieutenant Colonel J.S. Brar told CNN that the Army was moving against militants based on solid intelligence as well as human intelligence provided by our own sources.
Battles in the Shamsbhari forests in the northern district of Kashmir Kupwara have caused minimal collateral damage to the property, Brar said.
The spokesman denied media reports that the army had used combat helicopters and heavy weapons during these operations against militants.
This month's meeting between the Indian army and militants is the second longest in Kashmir this year. In January, a fierce encounter took place for seven days in the Poonch district of Jammu in Indian-administered Kashmir. Two soldiers, one policeman and four militants were killed at the meeting.
Kashmir has been the source of bitter dispute and two wars between India and neighbouring Pakistan. Both control parts of the region that are predominantly Muslim.

The security for Pope Francis' visit to Brazil has risen after an incident related to his caravan, a Brazilian federal official told CNN.
The papal visit is now ranked at the highest level of safety - it was raised to high risk of average risk after your car got stuck in a crowd of enthusiastic followers on Monday, the official said.
The source says that the problem was partly due to the Pope's ordering drivers not to avoid crowds.
After Francisco arrived in Brazil on Monday, he got into a silver Fiat hatchback for the trip from the airport to downtown Rio de Janeiro. Along the road, the vehicle was caught between a bus and a crush on well-wishers who were coming to the car to touch the Pope.
The federal authorities are now taking on a more important role in Francis' security during his stay in Brazil.
Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from all over the world have come to Rio for World Youth Day, a week-long festival held every two years. The Vatican told journalists that 500,000 people came to Copacabana Beach for the opening ceremony and mass.. Crowds stretched over the beach for more than half a mile from the main stage.
Brazil: Police Found, Destroyed Bomb Before Pope's Visit · Global Voices
A Call to Hope
The Pope traveled Wednesday morning to the city of Aparecida, the place of a shrine to Our Lady of Aparecida, a clay statue of the Virgin Mary and one of the patron saints of Brazil.
A large crowd - courageous rain - hailed as the Pope left the helicopter that took him to the place where he celebrated the Mass..
In his homily, the Pope called on the faithful to find hope in God.
It is true that today, to a certain extent, everyone, including our young people, is drawn to the many idols that take the place of God and seem to offer hope: money, success, power, pleasure, Francis said. Often, a growing sense of loneliness and emptiness in the hearts of many people leads them to seek satisfaction in these ephemeral idols.
His message was optimistic, encouraging openness to be surprised by God and proclaiming that Christians cannot be pessimistic.
The Pope also announced that he will return to Brazil in 2017, the 300th anniversary of the appearance of Our Lady of Aparecida to three fishermen.

Mariano Castillo de CNN contributed to this report.

text:
Government of Texas. Rick Perry's decision to send up to 1,000 National Guard soldiers to the southern border is the latest movement in a controversy over the influx of young migrants from Central America, many unaccompanied, arriving in the United States.
It represents concrete action on the concerns raised by Perry and other Republicans that border security will receive more resources in general and specifically in this case to address what is most appropriate is a humanitarian crisis.
The White House, which has refused to approve the federal authorization of the National Guard in response to the immigration situation that has erupted this year, considered Perry's idea as short-sighted and politically motivated.
These are the questions we wanted to know about Perry's plan.
Why did Perry call the guard? Perry said those troops are needed to fight crime because the border patrol is busy dealing with the flow of immigrant children crossing the border from Mexico.
The National Guard will be a force multiplier to help state law enforcement reduce the crime of cartels, traffickers and criminals crossing the border, Perry said.
But isn't this a crisis about children? Perry said the border patrol is consumed by handling the influx of migrant children and partial family units, who cannot be deported but must be treated and treated humanely in accordance with U.S. law.
However, if unaccompanied children approach the troops, Texas Assistant General John Nichols, who is head of the Texas National Guard, said they will be on the phone to a border station for children to receive water and medical care.
How does that stop the influx? Perry doesn't say he will. He said he wanted to stop the border crime.
So what's the border patrol gonna do? The National Guard troops will refer the alleged criminal activity to the Texas Department of Security. They will also patrol the border by air, especially at night. And they will meet at the border to provide a strong vision that Perry hopes will deter criminals from carrying out illicit activities across the border.
What don't they do? The National Guard won't make any arrests. “If we were asked, we could stop people, but we did not plan,” Nichols said.
How much will it cost and who will pay for it? Texas taxpayers are on the hook, and it'll cost about $12 million a month.
Will it work? The former head of the National Guard and a former commissioner of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection Bureau have said Perry's plan has limited scope.
The real solution to basically help the border patrol is going to be a holistic approach to this that goes far beyond more boots on the ground, said David Aguilar, the interim CBP commissioner from 2011 to 2013.
Aguilar said one thing that will help ease the workload of border patrol officers is to relieve CBP from being the only government agency to prosecute and care for unaccompanied youth immediately after their arrest.
The former head of the National Guard echoed Aguilar's sentiment.
That measure alone will not solve the current problem. It is much more complex and requires a unity approach that incorporates state, local and federal resources, said retired Lieutenant General H. Steven Blum.
When will this happen and for how long? The troops will be deployed immediately in the next 30 days, according to Nichols. It is not known how long they will remain. Perry is asking the federal government to hire and train 3,000 other border patrol officers to replace the National Guard. That part of the plan depends on Congress and the comprehensive immigration plan that would have provided more resources for border security is paralysed in the House, and neither body has yet revealed how they would resolve the current border crisis.
Is politics playing a role? Perry is considering another presidential race in 2016. He previewed his National Guard plan in Iowa, a key presidential designation state, over the weekend and announced it the following day.
Perry has something to do to reconcile within a Republican Party that has used the current border crisis to move to the right on the issue.
Ron Brownstein, a CNN political analyst and editorial director of the National Journal, said Perry's approach to border security allows him to shore up his resistance to good faith in security in what has become a big moment for the Republican Party in immigration.
Has the National Guard been sent to the border before? Yeah. The National Guard is already at the border, but in smaller numbers.
A recent and much broader example was Operation Jump Start, a two-year deployment that began in 2006 to stop the more than 1 million people who were caught crossing the border each year.
What's the situation at the border? The Rio Grande sector, where most immigrant children are becoming the border patrol, currently has 3,000 border patrol officers covering 320 miles of land and 250 miles of water, equivalent to 5.4 officers per mile. The Tucson sector, for example, has approximately 15.7 agents per mile.
While the number of unaccompanied young people crossing the border has doubled to almost 60,000 in the past year, the total number of immigrant crossings has decreased mostly. Nearly 1 million people have been caught crossing the border almost every year between 1983 and 2006, but that figure has fallen to about 400,000 in 2013.
At the same time, resources for border security have increased steadily: more than 18,000 officers patrolled the border in 2013, compared to 10,000 a decade ago.
And the amount spent on border security has more than doubled. The Customs and Border Patrol budget increased from $5 billion in 2002 to $12.4 billion this year.

text:
Two car bombs directed against Christians killed at least 38 people in southern Baghdad at Christmas.
In Afghanistan, two rounds of indirect fire hit the United States Embassy compound in Kabul, but no one was injured.
The incidents highlight the security challenges facing both Iraq and Afghanistan.
Both countries have had a strong US military presence until recently.
The departure of U.S. forces from Iraq has done little to curb the almost daily cycle of violence. In Afghanistan, U.S. and Afghan officials are working on an important security pact to outline the future of U.S. troops in Afghanistan.
18 Killed in Christmas Day Attacks Near Iraqi Churches · Global Voices
Attacks in Iraq
In Iraq, a car bomb exploded outside a church in southern Baghdad just as the worshipers left a Christmas day service, killing many. In another attack on Wednesday, a car bomb exploded in an outdoor market where many Christians buy, police said.
In total, at least 38 people were killed and 70 others injured, the Ministry of the Interior said. The bomb outside the church killed 27 and injured 56. The market attack left 11 dead and 14 injured.
The U.S. Embassy in Baghdad condemned the attacks on Christians celebrating Christmas in the Dora area of Baghdad.
The Christian community in Iraq has suffered deliberate and senseless attacks by terrorists for many years, as have many other innocent Iraqis. The United States abhors all such attacks and is committed to its partnership with the Government of Iraq to combat the scourge of terrorism, according to a statement issued by the Embassy.
Iraq has experienced a surge of sectarian violence this year as tensions simmering between the disaffected Sunni minority and Shia, who dominate the government.
The U.S. International Religious Freedom Commission notes that many people from small minority religious communities in Iraq, including Christians, have fled the country over the past decade and those who remain particularly vulnerable, facing discrimination, marginalization and neglect.
The sectarian war, especially between Sunnis and Shiites, became enraged during the Iraq war. It is believed that half or more of the pre-2003 Iraqi Christian community left Iraq, the commission said in its 2013 annual report.
In 2003, it was thought that there were between 800,000 and 1.4 million Chaldean Catholics, Assyrian Orthodox, members of the Assyrian Church of the East, Syriac and Orthodox Catholics, Armenian and Orthodox Catholics, Protestants and Evangelicals in the country, the group said.
Now, according to community leaders, the estimated number of Christians is about 500,000, the report said.
Attack on Afghanistan
Two rounds of indirect fire hit the U.S. embassy compound in Kabul, the embassy said. No one was hurt.
At approximately 6:40 local time in Kabul, approximately two rounds of indirect fire hit the United States Embassy compound. All Americans are counted and there were no injuries, the embassy said in a statement on Wednesday. The Embassy is still investigating the attack.
The embassy did not explain in detail what type of shots were fired, or where they landed in the complex.
A liability claim was posted on the Taliban official website. The group said it fired missiles at the U.S. Embassy and NATO's main base, leading the military coalition known as the International Security Assistance Force.
The incident comes at a crucial moment in relations between the United States and Afghanistan. The two countries are working on an important security pact. The agreement will establish the U.S. military presence in Afghanistan after 2014, when the NATO-led force of some 80,000 troops is scheduled to leave.
This month, U.S. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel was in Afghanistan and said the security pact will be agreed despite a failure so far to forge an agreement.

text:
How long can you hold your breath? I'm trying right now. The first 30 seconds are easy. I'm ready to give up at 45 seconds, but I'm moving on and it seems to be easier for a while. But, as the second hand goes by for a minute, I know I'm in borrowed time. My heart is beating. I let out a little breath and this helps. Eventually, I give up, ejecting the spent air into my lungs and taking a big gasp. (And keep panting for a few more breaths, which leads my husband to ask what the hell I'm doing.) I manage for a minute and 12 seconds. I'm pretty impressed with myself.
Breathing capacity becomes extremely important in some sports, especially free diving. In 2006, he was filming a program on anatomy and physiology of the lungs for a BBC series called, a little strangely, Don’t Die Young. I was lucky enough to meet Sam Amps, who was captain of the UK liberation team. In a pool in Bristol, she taught me some simple exercises to help me hold my breath longer while swimming underwater. By the end of the session, I think I had achieved a prodigious 90 seconds of breathing, long enough to let me swim a width. Sam swam three wide with ease. He could hold his breath for five minutes, while swimming. Five!
I asked him how he did it: very slow breathing for several minutes before each dive, then a great deep breathing before diving. She also said the training helped her resist the urge to breathe for much longer than most people.
Some have suggested that the ability to voluntarily contain breathing is evidence of an aqueous episode in human evolution. It has even been said that humans have the ability to reduce heart rate and metabolic rate in order to hold their breath longer. Other anatomical and physiological bits and bobs – our lack of hair, the distribution of our subcutaneous fat and even our tendency to walk on two legs – have been linked to an aquatic phase of evolutionary development. Unfortunately, the “aquatic monkey hypothesis” cobbled cannot contain water. It is a romantic notion that can attract us but, with the cold light of day falling on scientific evidence, it is revealed that it is nothing but a fiction.
Looking at the voluntary suspension of breathing, it turns out that we are certainly not unique among non-aquatic mammals in being able to contain breathing. (Having said that, it is somewhat difficult to investigate in other mammals as, unlike humans, they tend to fail when asked to breathe.) And experimental evidence shows that heart rate does not decrease during breathing. At least it doesn't if you're holding your breath on earth. When you're immersed in cold water it's a different story: cooling the face leads to a slower heart rate in most people. But, once again, this is not evidence of an aquatic ape ancestor, as it turns out to be a very general characteristic of air-breathing vertebrates. This reduction in heart rate is only one of the physiological responses that are sometimes described together as the “mammal diving reflex”. But physiological responses that could be useful in diving are also – and perhaps even more important – useful to avoid drowning.
Although our ability to breathe may not be so special, when compared to other animals, it is now proving to be very useful in a particular area of medicine. Radiation therapy for breast cancer involves directing radiation, very precisely, to the tumor. This may require several minutes of radiation and therefore is usually done in short bursts, between breaths. But, if the patient can keep her chest perfectly still for several minutes, it means that the entire dose can be given, in the right place, at once. The problem, of course, is that most people, like me, struggle to hold their breath for much more than a minute. However, doctors at Birmingham University Hospital have recently conducted careful experiments that show that, if patients are ventilated with oxygen-rich air before attempting a breath suspension, they can manage to hold their breath for five and a half impressive minutes.
Surprisingly, the trick does not seem to be tricking the body's usual sensors by low levels of oxygen or carbon dioxide in the blood, but by deceiving the diaphragm. When you breathe, you are contracting the muscle from your diaphragm, pulling it flattened so that the volume of your chest increases - and the air is dragged into your lungs. When you hold your breath, you keep the diaphragm in this state of contraction. Artificial increase in oxygen levels and reduction of carbon dioxide levels before breathing, as in Birmingham radiation therapy experiments, can work by delaying fatigue in the diaphragm. And – it’s not as useful if you’re trying to keep your chest perfectly still – breathing a little air allows the diaphragm to relax a little bit, and helps you prolong a breath of breathing, exactly as I found it when trying my breath.
And, therefore, it is your diaphragm, the main muscle of breathing, which is also in charge when it comes to reaching the breaking point of your breathing. Eventually, even if you've fooled him for a while, the diaphragm signals are too strong and you have to give in – and take a breath.

Some cities have pigeons. Lima has black vultures or chickens. They circulate in groups on the most emblematic buildings of the city: the decrepit churches, of the colonial period and the 18th century piles that crumble in the center of the city.
In many ways, with their heads wrinkled and their eyes crowded, they remind the residents of Lima of the side of their city that they would prefer to ignore: negligence, poverty and dirt. But the natural affinity of these carrions for dead and decaying things is becoming a virtue. Environmental authorities are giving these highly slandered birds a public relations image change, equipping them with GoPro action video cameras and GPS trackers, and giving them a new mission in the fight against the dumping of flies and illegal dumping. Samuel is one of the ten atratus of Coragyps certified disease-free project who have been accused of doing what they do best: sniffing garbage. Equipped with its tracker, it is released over the city, where it identifies clandestine landfills and records the GPS coordinates ona live map.
His coach at the Huachipa Zoo in Lima, Alfredo Correa, shines with admiration. “They can eat dead animals because their metabolism protects them from viruses and bacteria,” he says. “They have the strongest intestinal flora in the natural world.” The effort is a collaboration between USAID and the Peruvian Ministry of Environment to address the problem of garbage in Lima.
Samuel's other air companions have been given more evocative names: Captain Huggin, Captain Fenix (so called by the mythological creature rising from the ashes) and Captain Aella ( "Whirlwind"). A video in the tongue adds a melodramatic voice off, in which the noble “carhatidae lineage – vultures” face pestilence and disease, while “humanity is placidly ignoring danger”. The project makes a serious point. With only four landfills in a city of almost ten million inhabitants, there are countless illegal landfills. One fifth of the garbage ends there, according to the Ministry of Environment. The runoff of the waste pollutes Lima's main water source, the Rimac River, as well as the Chillon and Lurin Rivers, which flow into the Lima Bay.
The environmental monitoring agency, the OEFA, says that three poorer neighborhoods, despite having only 12% of the population of Lima, have by far the most fly tips: Villa Maria del Triunfo (39.4%), Villa El Salvador (25.3%) and El Agustino (18.3%). The problem, in part, is unpaid taxes. Many residents, especially in neighborhoods, simply don't pay. This means that some of the 43 district municipalities lack resources for basic services such as garbage collection.
It also means that no one will necessarily clean up where vultures identify illegal garbage. “We share the GPS coordinates of the vulture with the municipalities,” says Javier Hernández, director of the project. “It’s your job to pick up the trash and try to change the habits of your residents.”
The aim of the project is to encourage citizens to be “vulgaes on the ground ” — to report fly cleaning, cut their own waste, and recycle. Some residents are responding, posting photos of illegal landfills on the Twitter and Facebook page. The idea emerged at the 2014 United Nations Climate Change Conference, held in Lima. “We are looking for ways to involve not only the authorities but also citizens to generate environmental awareness,” Hernández says. The artist Cristina Planas had placed huge vulture heads carved over 25 dead palms in a wetland reserve in the south of the city. The rich hated it as an ugly imposition, but Planas invited citizens to “adopt a vulture” in support of conservation and recycling.
“We’re a little scared of the vulture’s appearance,” he said. “But actually, he’s out there sacrificing himself for us. It’s out there recycling, in the last place we throw away our garbage.”
