The sunlight shines through the drops of water falling down the edge of the cliff. Painted on the rocky face behind the small waterfall there is a pair of discolored elas, the largest antelope in Africa. Behind them are two barely visible human figures.
This is a sacred place, says Raphael Mnkhati, a guide to the Kamberg Rock Art Center. Water is important for life, and it was important for the people who lived here.
The small cave behind the waterfall is just one of thousands of secret shelters hidden in the Drakensberg-Ukahlamba Mountains of South Africa. They were home to the Bushmen, the original inhabitants of this country, who fled to these mountains to escape from other Africans coming down from the north of the continent and white settlers coming up from the Cape. The Bushmen were annihilated in the countless conflicts that resulted.
Some 60,000 individual images are scattered along these mountains, visible in some 600 different places. The artists used the earth's blood and fat, as well as bleached clay, bird droppings and charcoal as pigments. The delicate lines of the figures were engraved with twigs, porcupines and ostrich feathers.
Scientists believe that these figures were created by the Bushmen while in trance states, and that the paintings reflect the deep reverence of the people for the beauty and power of the natural world around them.
On the top of the mountain, hidden in a gigantic ledge on its very crest, is a remarkable fresco of hunters, antelopes and mythical figures, known as terianthropes, who are partially human beings, part animals.
The paintings extend in a long gallery through the rock face that extends for at least 30 meters under the stone ceiling. It frames a spectacular view of the high peaks and the distant valley very down.
He's not allowed to touch anything, or pick anything up here, it's like a church, Raphael tells us. And that's why it's important for the Bushman people. Still today many people take off their shoes when they visit here, as a sign of their respect.
One of the most well-preserved and mysterious panels in the Kamberg series shows a mythical human figure pulling from the tail of a land. Some scientists believe that this is a sign of human recreation, almost sport, created by the artist -- or artists -- in a transcendent state of consciousness.
Rafael has come here for years, and now he is studying rock art through college, but the beauty of this ancient gift left by lost generations has not vanished for him.
The Bushmen are very special, reflecting as they look down into the wide landscape, because they lived here peacefully in the mountains. We are all of the same origins. I'm very proud of this place and the rock art that's here.

In the 1950s, Central American commercial bananas faced the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor, the Cavendish.
With its easy transport, thick-skinned fruit and sweet taste, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, South America's leading producer and exporter at the time, massed its bananas as efficiently as possible: cloned shoots from plant stems instead of growing seed plants, and cultivated them in dense fields.
Unfortunately, these conditions are also perfect for the propagation of the fungus Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense, which attacks the roots of the plant and prevents it from transporting water to the stem and leaves. The TR-1 strain of the fungus was resistant to crop sprayers and traveled with boots or truck tyres, slowly infecting plantations throughout the region. In an attempt to escape the fungus, farmers abandoned the infected fields, flooded them and then replanted crops elsewhere, often cutting down the rainforest to do so.
Their efforts failed. So, instead, they looked for a variety of bananas that the fungus didn't affect. They found the Cavendish, as it was called, in the greenhouse of a British duke. It was not as suitable for shipping as Gros Michel, but its bananas knew well enough to keep consumers happy. Most importantly, TR-1 didn't seem to affect him. Within a few years, United Fruit had been saved from bankruptcy by filling its plantations with thousands of new plants, copying the same monoculture conditions in which Gros Michel had prospered.
While the operation was a great success for the Latin American industry, the banana cavendish itself is far from safe. In 2014, South-East Asia, another major banana producer, exported four million tonnes of bananas cavendish. But by 2015, their exports had decreased by 46% thanks to a combination of another fungus strain, TR-4, and bad weather.
Increasing practices in South-East Asia have not helped things. Farmers cannot always afford expensive laboratory-based methods to clone plants from outbreaks without spreading the disease. In addition, they are often not strict enough about cleaning up agricultural equipment and quarantine of infected fields. As a result, the fungus has spread to Australia, the Middle East and Mozambique – and Latin America, which depends largely on its monoculture Cavendish crops, could easily be the next.
Fighting the inevitable, scientists are working to solve the problem by genetically modifying Cavendish with genes from TR-4 resistant banana species. Researchers at Queensland University of Technology have successfully cultivated two types of modified plants that have remained resistant for three years so far. But some experts think this is just a sophisticated version of the same temporary solution that the original Cavendish provided. If new bananas are planted in the same monocultures as Cavendish and Gros Michel before it, the risk is that another strain of the disease may increase to threaten modified plants as well.

The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, better known as the Veterans Administration, is an organization dedicated to serving all veterans of the U.S. Army. It was formed in July 1930, and today employs approximately 280,000 people in hundreds of its offices across the United States. Its annual budget for fiscal year 2014 is almost $153 billion, making it one of the largest government agencies in existence today.

The Department is divided into three main branches. It consists of the Veterans Health Administration, the Veterans Benefits Administration and the National Cemetery Administration. The VA Health Administration is responsible for providing veterans with all health care issues, while the Benefits Administration is designed to assist veterans in areas such as secured mortgage loans, professional rehabilitation of insurance and educational benefits. The National Cemetery Administration provides funeral and commemorative benefits, and is responsible for the maintenance of AV cemeteries.
The VA has served American veterans of several wars starting with survivors of World War I. The tradition of serving former military personnel has continued to serve veterans who need help in adjusting to civilian life. Many of these veterans, especially those who saw combat during their time in the army, need basic medical services for the wounds sustained in the conflicts. This was the original concept for the creation of the AV.
Since then, AV has expanded considerably and now offers additional services, such as educational benefits and assistance in the purchase of housing. It also helps veterans who had been left homeless after their services in their country ended. There are approximately 30 million military veterans living in the United States today. That figure represents almost 10 per cent of the country ' s population today.

Half of the registered voters in Iraq went to peaceful provincial elections this weekend, the election commission said on Sunday.
Residents of the province of Ramadi in Iraq cast their votes this weekend during the provincial elections.
The participation of 7.5 million voters contrasted sharply with the 2005 elections, when the violence and intimidation of Al Qaeda in Iraq kept voters away from the polls and only 2% of eligible voters participated.
Faraj al-Haidari, head of the Independent High Electoral Commission, called participation this year very high for provincial elections in any country. Fifty-one per cent of the 14.9 million registered voters cast votes.
Al-Haidari called at the weekend the vote for the most important elections in Iraq's history since the fall of Saddam Hussein.
The vote took place in 14 of Iraq ' s 18 provinces. The biggest participation -- 65 percent -- took place in Salaheddin Province, northern Iraq, the commission said.
The lowest -- 40% -- was in Anbar, the Sunni heart west of Baghdad. The vast desert area was dominated in 2005 by Al Qaeda in Iraq.
The preliminary results of the electoral commission are expected within five days. Final numbers are due at the end of February.
Arwa Damon of CNN, who toured the polling stations with UN observers, said she noticed a greater sense of conscience and optimism among voters, who said they felt their participation would have an impact on their lives and the country.
Political analysts said this election could correct some of the political imbalances that resulted from the 2005 elections. Saturday's vote was also seen as a referendum on the popularity of Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki.
We are trying to build a new system of government in the heart of the Islamic Middle East, Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Barham Saleh told CNN.
The vast majority of the Iraqi people are participating in this process and are participating in this democratic process.
The elected will have regional power over the essentials that Iraqis have been desperate for... basic services and jobs, Damon reported.
Observers believe that provincial voting will be an indicator of the country's political leadership and an indication of what parliamentary elections will be like at the end of this year.
The results should explain the situation of the Sunni Arab awakening movement -- which opposes Al Qaeda in Iraq -- and the popularity of Shia factions, such as those supporting al-Maliki, Shiite clergyman Muqtada al-Sadr and the Supreme Islamic Council of Iraq.
Officials put in place harsh counter-terrorism measures for the elections, including security rounds around polling stations and vigorous voter registers.
Despite increased security, three mortars exploded near a polling station in downtown Tikrit, about 100 miles (LRB-160 kilometers) north of Baghdad, on Saturday morning, an official from the Ministry of the Interior told CNN. There were no casualties.
In another incident in Tikrit, the police arrested four people wearing Iraqi police uniforms who were said to have thrown stun grenades at voters in front of a polling station.
CNN's Jomana Karadsheh contributed to this report.

Agios Efstratios is so remote, so forgotten by banks, the government and most of the modern world that the mobile phone network cannot process data and there is not a single ATM or credit card machine on the island. Before Greece plunged into financial chaos, the residents of this quiet position in the north of the Aegean managed quite well. They made their seats at the post office and the few dozen rooms to rent were booked every summer with people who had heard – from mouth to mouth – of their spectacular empty beaches, clear seas and fresh seafood.
But, because the island is still running with cash, the closure of banks across the country has been devastating. Residents have been forced to make nine-hour trips to the nearest big island to get cash and Greek visitors say they cannot raise enough money to come. “Tourism numbers have dropped by 80% this year,” said Mayor Maria Kakali, in an office in the village where she grew up, home to some 200 people. “Even people born here and living in Athens, who have their own places on the island, do not come.”
Kakali has harassed the government and a major Greek bank to promise an ATM in a matter of weeks, but still believes it can arrive too late for this season on an island where tourism angers the other two sources of income: fishing and agriculture: “We almost have no reservations in August, when there are usually people calling us to find a room and we can’t help them.” A harsh winter ahead may be slightly improved by 50 workers staying in the village to expand the port, but there is an even greater crisis that is coming because the government has said it will end a decades-long tax relief for the islands.
Created to help island communities survive when they suffered from mass emigration, a lower sales tax contained living costs in places where everything had to be imported and made tourism more affordable. Tourist favorites like Mykonos fear losing tax relief will make it difficult for them to compete with Turkey, but for Agios Efstratios it poses a much greater threat. “If we have to pay a tax of 23%, I’m sorry to say, but we will all die on the island,” Kakali says.
Food and fuel are already more expensive than on the continent, there are no economies of scale and little economic flexibility on an island that, even in summer, has only three shops, two restaurants and no official hotel. “This is an expensive island. Everything, including milk or bread, has changed hands three or four times before reaching us and each intermediary has to take advantage of it,” said Provatas Costas, a 58-year-old fisherman.
For Agios Efstratios and his closest neighbor, Lemnos, the moment of the crisis is particularly cruel. They were condemned to relative darkness for years in part because they are served by slow and unreliable ferries. In 2015, the government had finally given the contract to a new and efficient company, attracting floods of new visitors to explore the charms of the islands largely overlooked, before bank controls hit.
“It started out as the best season in 30 years and, in a week, it became the worst,” said Atzamis Konstantinos, a travel agent in Lemnos who earned 15,000 euros a month as a captain of oil tankers and other large ships, but came home because he missed it so much. “I always loved this island, even when I was young. I'd dock at the Piraeus, the port of Athens, take my paycheck, and then get the first boat. People would say 'You're crazy. You can go anywhere, but I just wanted to come here.
Lemnos has dozens of wild beaches, where even in the height of summer you can swim and sunbathe practically alone, a small night scene and numerous cultural sites. It is the eighth largest island in Greece, so it is online for the first round of tax increases in autumn 2015, but much less rich than many smaller. It has just over 3,000 guest beds, compared to tens of thousands on an island like Rhodes. Their councillors say they will fight against tax increases, although no one can say how. “We’ve been suffering economically in recent years and, now, we’re going to suffer more,” said Lemnos Mayor Dimitris Marinakis. “When there is not enough money, consumption is reduced and, therefore, the whole economy declines.”
The crisis has been particularly difficult for people under 40 years of age, who often do two or three jobs to make ends meet and still feel that they cannot afford a family. Young people fear losing their contemporaries in an exodus to match the one that scattered their grandparents' friends to America, Australia, and Canada. “What is the future for our generation?” said Katerina Fikari, who feels she is extremely fortunate to work for local government in Lemnos. “If you work just to pay your bills, how can you have dreams for your future?”
If taxes increase, even more young people will leave, warns Mayor Kakali, who has dedicated her year in office to improving education on the island to help keep it as an attractive place for families. Because it is one of the smallest islands, Agios Efstratios has until 2017 before the ascent arrives, so Kakali hopes that the roller coaster of Greek politics means that it can still be saved. However, if not, he plans to travel to Athens to remind the government what the tax increase would cost.
“The truth is that the government does not pay much attention to the islands of the North Aegean,” he said, “so I would take all the children of our school to the doors of parliament, to tell them, ‘There is life on these islands’.”

What's the latest about something like that? To contemplate the passage of a unique wonder that will soon disappear from the face of the earth? Sudan is the last white rhino in the north of the planet. If you do not mate soon with one of the two female northern white rhinos in Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya, there will be no more of your class, male or female, born anywhere. And it seems like a small opportunity, as Sudan is ageing at the age of 42 and parenting efforts have failed so far. Apart from these three animals, there are only two other white rhinos from the north of the world, both in zoos, both females.
It seems like an image of human tenderness that Sudan is lovingly guarded by armed men who remain vigilant and loving to him. But, of course, it's an image of brutality. Even at this last desperate stage in the fate of the northern white rhinoceros, Sudan is under threat from poachers who kill rhinos and cut off their horns to sell them in the Asian medicine market, even though they have cut off their horn to dissuade them.
Sudan does not know how valuable it is. Her eye is a sad black dot on her huge, wrinkled face as she wanders through the reserve with her guards. His head is a wonderful thing. It is a majestic rectangle of strong bone and choriaceous flesh, a head that expresses pure strength. How terrible that such a powerful head can, in fact, be so vulnerable. He descends melancholy under the sinister sky, as if he were burdened by fate. This is the noble head of an old warrior, his armor struck, his appetite for struggle fades away.
Under his immense shoulder that is coming, his legs stand out like squatted columns from the hard tank of his body. The way his forearm emerges from his thick layer of skin reminds us of how long humans have been wondering about the natural spectacle that rhinoceros is. For Sudan it does not look so different from the rhinos that Albrecht Durero portrayed in 1515. They have the same small protruding legs of a majestic body and even lower their heads in the same contemplative way. Dürer was a Renaissance artist imagining an exotic beast from the exotic lands of which Europe began to see more and more. In 1515, a living Indian rhinoceros was sent by the ruler of Gujarat in India to the king of Portugal: in turn, he sent him to the Pope, but, on the way, he died in a shipwreck.
Human beings – we always kill the things we love. We've been doing it since the Ice Age. There are beautiful images of European woolly rhinoceros in caves in France that were painted up to 30,000 years ago. These ancient relatives of Sudan share their heroic volume, powerful power, and paradoxical air of sweetness. A woolly rhino in Chauvet's cave seems agile and young, a creature full of life. But the same people who painted such sensitive portraits of rhinoceros from the Ice Age helped kill them. As the weather turned against the woolly megafauna with the end of the last Ice Age, human spears probably delivered the coup de grace.
Today, immense love is being invested in rhinoceros, yet they are being sacrificed in an increasing number. The northern white rhinoceros is the rarest species of African rhinoceros. There are a much larger number of southern white rhinos and black rhinos. But the demand in some countries for rhino horn as a traditional medicine that is believed to cure everything, from flu to cancer, is fueling a boom in poaching. Since 2007, when only 13 rhinos were killed by poachers in South Africa, the murders have grown horribly. In 2014, 1,215 rhinoceros were slaughtered for their horns in South Africa. 2015 already seems sure to beat that terrible record.
The vulnerable northern white rhinoceros has been hunted almost to extinction – despite all precautions, despite the guards and their weapons – and other varieties of African rhinoceros are under a sustained attack by poachers that is totally out of control. The Javan rhino is also on the verge of extinction. India has successfully protected the Indian rhino after it was almost annihilated by British hunters in colonial times, but here, too, poaching is a threat. What a majestic creature and what a vain human destruction. Haven't we learned anything since the Ice Age?

Without a doubt in your mind? Ashton asked.

A woman who claimed to have lost a child in a car accident that required extensive police investigation was also fired. He said he considered the accusation that Anthony had lied to the investigators to be proof of guilt by omission.

After extensive questioning by lawyers, she told a grandmother that she remembered Caylee's sweet photos, but said she had no preconceived notions of the case to be on guard.

A memorandum of understanding between the United States and Qatar on the agreement that freed Bergdahl offered no guarantee that the five Taliban commanders exchanged by the captured army sergeant would be tracked, a Democratic member of the House Intelligence Committee told CNN.

We have recognized that some of these people might try to return to activities of concern. The President said so explicitly on her trip last week, she said. But we are confident that we will be able to go after them if, in fact, they are participating in activities that threaten our defences.

Administration officials gave a classified report to the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday after a similar session on Monday with members of the House.
On Wednesday, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel will appear before McKeon's armed service committee to discuss the exchange, which he signed as head of the Pentagon.
He looks forward to explaining why the President's decision to secure Sergeant Bergdahl's release was the right one, and why the process we undertook in doing so was in line with our national interests, Rear Admiral John Kirby, spokesman for the Pentagon, told the journalists on Tuesday.
After the briefing to members of the House, some said they were told that between 80 and 90 administration officials knew about the pending exchange ahead of time, while Congress did not.

Schiff told Erin Burnett OutFront of CNN that White House officials should have told Congressional leaders, even if the law gave them room for manoeuvre.

Polls show division, with more disapproval
More Americans disapprove of approving Bergdahl's release in exchange for five Taliban detainees, according to two new national polls.
Polls also indicate a broad partisan divide, with most Republicans opposing the deal while most Democrats approve.
Bergdahl disappeared on 30 June 2009 in Paktika Province in Afghanistan, where it was deployed with the 1st Battalion, the 501st Infantry Regiment, the 4th Brigade Combat Team, the 25th Infantry Division.

Was Rand Paul's red meat joke too raw?
Slow recovery
Bergdahl continues to improve every day while recovering in a military hospital in Germany, Pentagon spokesman Colonel Steve Warren said Monday, but he has not yet spoken to his family.
The decision to talk to the family is a decision the returnee has to make when he is emotionally in the right place to make the phone call, Warren said.
When ready, Bergdahl will be taken to the San Antonio Military Medical Center in Texas, where he can meet with his parents.
As Bergdahl recovers, the details are slowly emerging on the conditions he endured during five years of captivity.
Citing an American official, The New York Times reported on Sunday that Bergdahl told medical staff that the box he was in for weeks was very black and like a shark cage.
CNN reported Friday that Bergdahl said he was kept in a small box after trying to escape, according to a senior American official, who spoke on condition of not being identified. The official also told CNN that Bergdahl suffers from psychological trauma caused by physical abuse.

As Halloween approaches, my 10-year-old daughter gets excited about choosing a scary costume for the trick or deal and the prospect of a bucket full of candy.
I usually accompany her, but this year she has awakened memories of a truly creepy encounter, re-awakened by a recent assignment to CNN.
The British Film Institute is about to release the full 144-minute version of The Shining -- 24 minutes longer than previously seen in Europe. If you are nervous, the idea of submitting to additional minutes than many consider the most terrifying movie ever made could be less than attractive. But true fans of horror lick their lips in advance.
The film, directed by brilliant Stanley Kubrick in 1980, is now considered a master class in cinema, but at that time it was largely received with the scratch of heads and a state of disappointment.
Kubrick adapted the film from the book written by horror novelist Stephen King, and that's where my connection begins.
In 1974 King and his wife stayed at the majestic Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, a small town at the foot of the Rocky Mountains. The hotel was to close for the winter season and the kings were the only guests in the place, echoing the long empty corridors and the silent dance hall. By the time they left room 217 the next morning... Halloween... King had the bones of his chilling story.
Stanley Kubrick treasures on display
I visited Estes Park 34 years later and decided to take my family to the Stanley Hotel.
Although Kubrick's film was shot at Timberline Lodge in Oregon - LRB- outdoors -RRB- and Elstree studios near London -LRB- interiors -RRB- the resemblance is strange.
Our guide told us that the hotel was inhabited by a series of ghosts, sometimes appearing in photographs as balls of energy. The warning was received with a mixture of laughs and eyebrows raised suspiciously.
We were about to shuffle along another carpeted hallway when my wife screamed in surprise: Look at this!
We gathered around your camera to see an image of the ladder where there were three orbs of light -- different sizes, different opacity, different from anything I'd seen before. They had not appeared at first sight and had not appeared on anyone else's camera.
During the rest of the tour our group achieved a lesser degree of celebrity by repeating the feat in several other places within the hotel. There was one on the wooden ceiling of the ballroom and later, when we looked at all the photos, we discovered that another had appeared in the photograph we took from the reception before the meeting or tour guide.
The images were taken in different places, with a very different lighting and of the 200 photographs we took during our vacation did not appear in any other photograph -- nor in any photograph ever taken in that camera before or after. We were entertained and bewildered, but we quickly forgot about them when we returned to London.
This month, covering the story of the extended version of The Shining came my way and while I was investigating it I remembered the photographs.
So when I went to interview executive producer Jan Harlan at his home in the old English city of St. Albans, an hour's drive north of London, I took them with me. He spoke eloquently about Kubrick and his film.
It was a film that shows nothing but ambiguity. And this is what Stanley wanted, he said.
I showed him the pictures. It seemed fun, but since I couldn't offer a plausible explanation. They too remain ambiguous and I am happy that they remain so.
But for some fans of the film, ambiguity leaves a void that must be filled with conspiracy theories. Some claim to have discovered hidden messages about anything from the Holocaust to the plight of Native Americans, and the apparent use of Kubrick from the film to confess that he helped the U.S. government make the Apollo landings.
It's amazing how this movie invited speculation and fantasy into the audience. Which is good, Harlan said. It's a big compliment for Kubrick to get people into orbit about it.
Orbit, huh? Is that another deliberate lead? No, I'm not going that way. I'll take my own photographs instead. And if there's someone out there with a good theory - LRB- conspiracy or some other kind -RRB- that we'd love to hear about from you.

Two sisters from Texas, the Connecticut family perish

The plane pushed the wall of our building, and hit everything, said Kingsley Okeke, who was inside at the time. There was fire everywhere.

He is the world's largest cocaine producer and a key supplier of heroin to the United States.
According to the CIA, Colombia produces 535 metric tons of cocaine a year, mostly for the U.S. market. The South American country has retained its status as a key cocaine producer despite an ambitious anti-drug agreement launched a decade ago with financial support from the United States.
The agreement is called Plan Colombia.
Since 2000, the plan has cost the United States $7 billion, according to the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington study group that has closely followed the implementation of Plan Colombia.
The money has been used mainly to help Colombia strengthen its police and military. Prior to the implementation of Plan Colombia, 50% of Colombian territory had no governmental security presence.
Marta Lucía Ramírez, former Colombian Minister of Defense and one of the architects of Plan Colombia, says the agreement has helped her country strengthen democracy and government institutions. It has also increased the Colombian government's ability to fight what she calls narcoterrorism.
But Ramirez also says the high demand for drugs in the United States makes it difficult to eradicate home production.
I really don't think the U.S. drug strategy is enough. It's probably a failure. It is -LSB - a policy -RSB - that they have to review, Ramirez says.
Colombia welcomes U.S. Tsar Gil Kerlikowske this week. Kerlikowske, in his role as director of the White House's Office of National Drug Control Policy, will make an assessment of the progress of the Colombia plan as part of his trip.
Before his visit, Kerlikowske told the Colombian daily El Tiempo that he sees a commitment from the government of President Juan Manuel Santos, who took office in August.
We will talk about the continuation of the relationship between the two countries, not only in terms of reduction, but also in terms of prevention and demand, Kerlikowske said.
Security experts, including Colombian Aurelio Suárez, say Plan Colombia has improved security, but has not reached its original goal of reducing drug production in the region. In what is known as the balloon effect, the increase in army attacks on drug traffickers in Colombia has displaced coca and opium poppy crops elsewhere.
And the amount of drug production in Andean countries like Bolivia, Peru and Colombia is the same as 10 years ago, says Suárez.
Salud Hernández, a journalist who has traveled extensively in areas where coca is grown, has witnessed the balloon effect. He says drug traffickers have just moved to other countries, but they also move inside Colombia.
There are still drug traffickers -LSB- in Colombia -RSB-. There is still a lot of drug trafficking, and there are still many crops in many regions of the country, Hernández says.
Even more problematic, the Washington-based Inter-American Dialogue says that about 90 percent of cocaine sold in the United States still comes from Colombia.
Michael Shifter, president of the organization, says the many critics of Plan Colombia correctly point to the failure of the policy to fulfill the fundamental purpose for which the program was developed: Reduce the availability of drugs, particularly cocaine in American communities, says Shifter.
In Colombia, there is a new impetus to redirect government efforts towards improving the socio-economic conditions of the population as a means of making organized crime and guerrillas associated with drug traffickers less attractive to peasants living in marginalized areas. Colombia's problems go far beyond drug trafficking and security.
About 50 per cent of Colombians live in poverty and 60 per cent do not have regular employment. Now that security has improved, many Colombians, such as security analyst Suárez, say it is time for the Colombian government to address issues such as social inequality and long-term development as a way to curb seemingly endless production of illicit drugs in Colombia.

text:
The eight-hour rule at the office is over. The most important work of the day is done; what remains can wait until the morning. This is the point at which many workers would think of going to the door.
However, for millions of Japanese employees, the idea of cleaning their desks and being home in time for dinner is enough to invite accusations of disloyalty.
But, after decades of giving companies carte blanche to order every last drop of their labor productivity, a challenge to Japan's entrenched culture of overwork has come from the government, which is considering making a legal requirement for workers to take at least five paid vacation days a year.
Currently, Japanese employees are entitled to an average of 18.5 days of paid leave per year, only two days less than the world average, with a minimum of 10 days, as well as 15 days of one-day national vacation. In fact, according to the Ministry of Labour, few even come close to assuming their total quota, usually using only nine of their average 18.5-day rights. While many British workers consider a two-week summer vacation an inalienable right, workers in Japan have come to see a four-night vacation in Hawaii as the height of self-indulgence.
The bill, which will be discussed at the current parliamentary session, comes after companies started encouraging employees to take a nap at work to improve their performance.
At the end of the decade, the government expects that, if passed, the law will encourage Japanese employees to follow the example of British workers, who use an average of 20 days of paid annual leave, and those of France, who take an average of 25.
Japan's relentless labor culture may have helped turn it into an economic superpower, its corporate soldiers revered in the rest of the world for their commitment to the company, but this has often been the exclusion of everything else.
Japan ' s low birth rate and predictions of a rapid decline in the population are partly attributed to the lack of time for couples to form a family. More employees are getting sick from stress, or worse, succumbing to karoshi, death from overwork.
Despite studies that suggest that longer hours in the office or workshop or on the factory floor do not necessarily make people more productive, today's workers are still nursing a collective hangover from the 1980s bubble years.
About 22% of Japanese work more than 49 hours a week, compared to 16% of American workers and 11% in France and Germany, according to data compiled by the Japanese government. With 35%, South Korean workaholics are even worse.
By spending 14 hours a day at work and giving up many of his paid vacations, Erika Sekiguchi is not even an extreme example. The 36-year-old employee used eight of her 20-day paid vacations in 2014, six of which were on sick leave. “No one else uses their vacation days,” Sekiguchi said.
He faces the dilemma shared by his colleagues in companies across Japan: never take time off to recharge or risk inviting criticism for seeming to leave more committed colleagues in the lurch.
Yuu Wakebe, a health ministry official who oversees the working hours policy, who admits that he has spent 100 hours extra a month, blames the irresistible pressure of matching his colleagues, hour by hour. “It’s a worker’s right to take paid vacations,” Wakebe said. “But working in Japan implies a lot of voluntary spirit.”
This fear of exclusion from work is being blamed for an increase in stress-related diseases, premature death and suicide. According to official data, about 200 people die each year from heart attacks, strokes and other karoshi events caused by the punishment of working hours.
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is not known for taking long vacations. However, even he has protested against the unreasonable demands that companies impose on their employees as they struggle to stay afloat in a more complex globalised market. Japan’s working culture, Abe recently said, “falsely beatifies long hours.”

text:
The DNA extracted from the mill of the wisdom of a European hunter-gatherer has given scientists an unprecedented view of modern humans before the rise of agriculture. The Mesolithic man, who lived in Spain about 7,000 years ago, had an unusual mixture of blue eyes, black or brown hair and dark skin, according to analyses of his genetic composition.
It was probably lactose intolerant and had more difficulty digesting starchy foods than farmers who transformed diets and lifestyles when they took tools in the first agricultural revolution. The invention of agriculture led humans and animals to much closer contact and humans probably evolved stronger immune systems to defend themselves against the infections that animals transmitted. But scientists may have overestimated the impact that agriculture had on the formation of the human immune system, because the hunter-gatherer's DNA tests found that it was already carrying mutations that drive the immune system to tackle several unpleasant insects. Some live in modern Europeans today. “Before starting this work, I had some ideas about what we were going to find,” said Carles Lalueza-Fox, who led the study at the Institute of Evolutionary Biology in Barcelona. “Most of those ideas turned out to be completely wrong.”
The Spanish team began their work after a group of speleologists stumbled upon two skeletons in a deep and complex cave system at the top of the Cantabrian mountains of northwest Spain in 2006. The human remains, which belonged to two men in the early 1930s, had been extremely well preserved by the cool atmosphere of the cave. Carbon dating put the remains in about 7,000 years old, before agriculture had swept Europe from the Middle East. Time was suited to the ancient artifacts found on the site, including perforated reindeer teeth that were hung and hung from people's clothes.
Scientists focused their efforts on better conservation of the two skeletons. After several failed attempts, they were able to reconstruct the entire genome of man from the DNA found at the root of a third molar. This is the first time that researchers have obtained the complete genome of a modern European who lived before the Neolithic revolution.
DNA launched a series of surprises. When Lalueza-Fox looked at the genome, he found that, instead of having clear skin, man had genetic variants that tend to produce much darker skin. “This guy had to be darker than any modern European, but we don’t know how dark,” the scientist said.
Another surprise was that the man had blue eyes. That was unexpected, Lalueza-Fox said, because it was thought that the blue eye mutation had emerged more recently than mutations that cause a lighter color of the skin. The results suggest that the color of blue eyes was the first in Europe, with the transition to lighter skin in progress through mesolytic times.
In addition to the scientific impact, artists may have to rethink their drawings of people. “There are many reconstructions of these people hunting and collecting and they look like modern Europeans with clear skin. You never see a reconstruction of a mesolithic hunter-gatherer with dark skin and blue eye color,” Lalueza-Fox said.
The Spanish team went on to compare the genome of hunter-gatherer with those of modern Europeans from different regions to see how they could be related. They found that ancient DNA corresponded more closely to the genetic composition of people living in northern Europe, in particular Sweden and Finland.
The discovery of mutations that reinforced the immune system against bacteria and viruses suggests that the shift to an agricultural crop in Neolithic times did not drive all the changes in immunity genes that Europeans carry today. At least some of those genetic changes have a history that extends further back. “One thing we don’t know is what kind of pathogens were affecting these people,” Lalueza-Fox said.
Martin Jones, professor of archaeological sciences at Cambridge University, said immunity genes were the most surprising result. “There is certainly a great oversimplified narrative that moving from a hunter-gatherer lifestyle to a settled agriculture was initially bad for our health. Several factors contributed, including close coexistence with other humans and animals, the reduction of the food network and the displacement of water supplies. The authors draw attention to the role of pathogens in pre-agricultural life and that is interesting.”

Are you in Yemen? Share your photos and videos of the scene, but please stay safe.

At least 15 people died in Abyan on Monday night and Tuesday morning in clashes between Islamic militants and security forces, according to a security source in Abyan.
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula has a presence in the southern province of Abyan, a U.S. official said. It is also home to an Islamic militant movement that has targeted government troops in recent days.
Abyan's dead include nine soldiers, four militants and two civilians in Zinjibar and other suburbs of the province, according to the source, who asked not to be appointed because he is not allowed to speak to the media.

The man, described as an infiltrator who tried to cross the metal and sand barriers at the border, shot at the security officers as they approached him, the agency said. Security personnel tracked down the man and killed him in an exchange of fire, he added.
The turmoil in Yemen peaked on Friday, when a mosque in the presidential compound of Saleh was attacked. Yemen's state news agency SABA, citing a source in Saleh's office, reported last week that three guards and a magnet were killed.
Western diplomats said the attack came from a bomb. Yemeni investigations focus on what happened inside the mosque, not on a rocket or mortar attack, diplomats said on Monday. One diplomat said that the attack was not a suicide attack and that the Yemeni investigation was ongoing.
The description of the attack as a bombing differs from what a Yemeni official told CNN last week. The official, who asked not to be identified, said Saleh was in the mosque when two shells were fired during Friday prayers.

In response, Yemeni security forces bombed Al-Ahmar's house on Friday, killing 10 people and injuring 35 others, according to Fawzi Al-Jaradi, an official of the Hashed tribal confederation.

A U.S. official told CNN Monday that the riots hinder U.S. anti-terrorist efforts in Yemen.
We trust the Yemeni government as partners, the official said. The more distracted the government is by political unrest, the more difficult it is for us.

Nic Robertson, Elise Labott, Pam Benson, Tim Lister and Jill Dougherty of CNN contributed to this report.

text:
The view from the visitor centre at the southern end of the Doñana National Park in southern Spain is surprising, to say the least. This is the dream of an ornithologist: 200,000 hectares of marshes of incomparable importance for the life of birds in Western Europe. Dozens of Britain's most beloved migratory birds, including domestic martins, swallows, cuckoos and gorges, rest here in their annual migrations from Africa. Doñana, a UN World Heritage Site, is also home to some of the rarest birds in Europe, including the Spanish imperial eagle, while its mammalian inhabitants include the highly threatened Iberian lynx.
It is a glorious and vibrant landscape. However, it exists on a knife edge, a point dramatically illustrated in 1998 when almost two billion gallons of highly acidic contaminated water, mixed with waste metals, pour into the park from a dam that had exploded its bank in the Los Frailes mine 45km north. A toxic tsunami of waste spilled over the Guadiamar River and its banks, leaving a thick metal crust on a vast stretch of park. More than 25,000 kilos of dead fish were collected later and nearly 2,000 adult birds, chicks, eggs and nests were killed or destroyed.
It was the worst environmental disaster in Spain and cleaning cost 90 million euros. Suddenly, aware of Doñana's status as the nation's most important natural site, Spain decided to spend another 360 million euros, part of EU money, on landscape restoration, which, in the 1950s and 1960s, had been drained into places to create rice and cotton fields. Some of these agricultural lands are being returned to their original wetland state.
It has been an expensive but encouraging process. However, Doñana’s fate is still pending thanks to the increasing pressures of modern life. Plans to build a pipeline through Doñana have been outlined, while other developers have announced proposals to expand local resorts whose new hotels and golf courses would require water supply that would further erode the local table. The Silto washed from nearby farms is also drowning the canals that cross Doñana.
However, the real coup d'état for conservationists has been the recent decision of the Andalusian government to reopen the Frailes mine that nearly destroyed Doñana in 1998. “This is the most precious bird sanctuary in Europe, both in terms of native species and as a resting place for birds migrating between Africa and Britain and other parts of northwest Europe,” says Laurence Rose of the RSPB (Royal Society for the Protection of Birds). “Doñana already faces a large number of threats, but now they want to bring back the very cause of her almost finalist 16 years ago. It is extremely worrying.”
Having spent so much on restoring Doñana to her past glories, it may seem strange that the local government decides to announce that it wants mining companies to bid to rework The Friars. However, a brief review of the state of the local economy provides an explanation. The collapse of Spanish banks in 2008 affected the region catastrophically and unemployment in some parts of Andalusia is now over 30%. The reopening of the mine would provide more than 1,000 valuable jobs.
“Here there are riches, riches that are very necessary for the local inhabitants,” said Vicente Fernández Guerrero, Secretary General of Innovation, Industry and Energy for Andalusia. “We believe that mining is a good way to allow the local population to continue living in the area. This is a mining area. People have been digging metals and minerals here since Roman times, after all.
More to the point, Fernández added, the mining license would stipulate that only modern mining techniques, which avoid the creation of poisonous wet waste, would be allowed. (It has also stipulated that the Canadian company that ran Los Frailes cannot bid for the contract. Sixteen years after the accident, the two parties remained blocked by the claims for compensation.) “The best technology in the world will be used here,” Fernández insisted. “No liquid will be used. Let's insist on it. Our tenderness makes it clear.”
The proposal has some support in the area, but it also has a lot of opposition. A road sign I passed was liberally dotted with obscenities over the UGT workers union, which supports the reopening of the mine. For his part, Carlos Dávila, who works for the Spanish Ornithological Society in Doñana, was also alarmed by the proposal. “This is a very, very bad idea,” he told me. “They say the new mine will be safe, but they said it was safe in 1998 and look what happened. We have the worst ecological disaster in Spain’s history.”
What alarms people like Dávila is the threat that a new mine represents to the intense investment in ecotourism that has been made in Doñana in recent years. An example is the restaurant Dehesa de Abajo, where you can have a drink or a meal surrounded by trees in which storks and black kites nest.
Virtually every visitor was equipped with a telescopic camera and lens or a pair of binoculars. There is a clear tourist trade to make of the life of the birds of Doñana. This should also not be surprising, as this is a truly special place. A vast hemisphere of sky hangs on this completely flat landscape, but certainly not without features. Birds of all shapes and sizes fill the air and sometimes the road. At one point in my visit, a stork stood quietly in front of our car until she felt ready to fly.
“The problem is that Spain does not have the public resources it owned 16 years ago. A repeat of the toxin spill today would have a much, much more harmful impact,” Rose said. This point is backed by Dávila. “After the disaster, Spain woke up to the fact that it had a place of real ecological importance and did a lot to clean it up and protect it,” he added. “Now, we seem to be forgetting that lesson. It’s very depressing.”

A girl born today in the UK can expect to live almost until the average age of 82, while her brother will live up to 78. They would have a longer life in Andorra (85 and 79, respectively), but are marginally better than in the United States (81 and 76), while if they lived in the Central African Republic, they would barely reach middle age (49 and 44). However, almost all over the world, with the exception of countries such as Lesotho, which have been affected by HIV and violence, life expectancy is lengthening and the best news is that young children are far less likely to die than they were four decades ago. There has been a decline in deaths among under-fives from almost 60 per cent, from 16.4 million in 1970 to 6.8 million in 2010.
That in itself justifies the huge project that the Seattle Institute of Metrics and Health Assessment (IHME) has led over the past five years, involving nearly 500 researchers, to assess the global burden of disease. Knowing how many children die and why the world can concentrate its efforts and resources on keeping them alive. There are many lessons to be drawn from the vast database they have created, which will help global organizations and individual governments to better care for all of us, from a renewed diet approach to the fight against alcohol to sustaining HIV efforts in Africa.
The seven articles published by The Lancet represent a large company and are not without controversy. IHME has been ambitiously radical in some of its methods. In the absence of death records or medical records, they have been willing, for example, to take verbal autopsy tests – deciding the cause of death through an interview with the family. The most striking result has been the malaria figure, published in early 2012. IHME said that 1.2 million die of the disease every year – twice as much as previously thought. The big increase occurs in adult deaths. Malaria is known to kill mostly children under five years of age.
“The way I was taught as a doctor and everyone else is taught that, in malaria areas, one becomes semi-immune as an adult,” said Dr. Christopher Murray, Director of IHME and one of the founders of the Global Burden of Disease project. “Originally we went with the prevailing opinion, but there has been a change as we have become more empirical. African doctors write in hospital records that adults are dying a lot of malaria.” But, he adds, his fever could be something else. The results have led to further studies.
Although Margaret Chan, Director General of the World Health Organization, gave the IHME study a warm official welcome, some staff members are cautious. “We need to be very careful in evaluating the validity [of the figures],” said Colin Mathers, a high-level scientist at the Evidence Cluster for Information and Policy. “We have to wait to be persuaded by the evidence.” His colleague, Dr. Tiers Boerma, Director of the WHO Department of Health Statistics and Informatics, added: “People must understand that some of the numbers are very different and the WHO cannot jump with any academic publication indicating a different number.” However, Mathers said, “the fact that IHME pushed the envelope with some of these analyses is stimulating.” One of the main themes, Murray said, was “an incredibly rapid change in the main causes of death and the pace of that change is much faster than we expected.”
The reduction in fertility and the prolongation of life expectancy have meant an increase in the average age of the world population in a decade, from 26 years to almost 30 years. It has been dramatic in Latin America, for example, where countries like Brazil and Paraguay had a life expectancy of less than 30 in 1970 and almost 64 in 2010. This is an increase of 35 years in the average age of death of more than four decades. “In a place like Brazil, the speed of change is so fast that most institutions are poorly equipped to face it,” Murray said.
The second theme, interwoven with it, is the shift outside Africa from communicable diseases and the common causes of maternal and infant deaths to what are sometimes referred to as “life-style” diseases, such as heart disease, strokes, diabetes and cancer, some of which have important genetic triggers. That change has been particularly marked in Latin America, the Middle East and the south-east and even South Asia, he said.
The third big find was, Murray said, “a surprise for us.” That was the total extent of disability and the cost to people who lived longer but did not have a healthier life. “The main causes of disability are different from those that kill you,” he said. These were mental health problems such as anxiety and depression, musculoskeletal disorders such as arthritis and lumbar pain – of which he complained in all countries of the world – anemia, loss of sight and hearing, and skin diseases. In addition, there was substance abuse. “The rates for these are not going down over time,” he said. “We are not making progress in reducing these conditions.”

Since then, 42 days have passed -- twice the maximum known incubation period for the virus -- without another case, allowing Spain to be declared Ebola-free.
Spanish authorities had been monitoring 87 people who came into contact with health worker Teresa Romero Ramos, 15 of whom were considered high-risk and quarantined in a hospital in Madrid, WHO said.
Another 145 hospital employees who helped care for Romero during his one-month stay at Carlos III Hospital were also monitored.
The WHO statement praised Spain for the measures taken to identify possible cases and prevent further transmission of the Ebola virus.
Romero contracted the disease while helping to care for an infected missionary who had been brought from West Africa. He died of the disease.

text:
Helen Keller was an American educator and journalist, who became one of the leading humanitarians in the history of the United States. Born on June 27, 1880 in Tuscumbia, a small town in Alabama, Keller suffered from a childhood illness that left her deaf and blind. The disease Keller suffered is a mystery to this day. His family doctor diagnosed him with "brain fever," but most people speculated that he suffered from scarlet fever or meningitis. Unable to see, or hear, Keller became difficult to handle, as his behavior was described by his family and friends as wild.

Soon Keller and his family developed their own type of sign language that allowed them to communicate in a limited way. Helen's mother sought help for her distressed son, which eventually led to Anne Sullivan, who was a recent graduate of the Perkins Institute for the Blind. The school had succeeded in the past in educating blind students, and Sullivan was one of its star graduates. Once Sullivan and Keller overcame the difficult beginnings, their friendship and association lasted 49 years.
Keller was determined to educate himself and teach himself to communicate. After attending several schools, she became the first deaf and blind person to obtain a university degree. She became well known, and began a lecture tour where she addressed social and political issues, including women's suffrage, and birth control.
In 1920, he helped found the American Civil Liberties Union, which is still active today. He went to Congress to raise awareness of the plight of the blind. Through all his achievements, he fell at a disadvantage with the American public because of his socialist views later in his life. She died asleep a few days before she turned 88, but lives in the American conscience for her tireless work and perseverance.

Evangelical leaders are taking a step back from their decades-long struggle against gay marriage, softening their tone and recalibrating their goals.
In recent interviews with about half a dozen prominent evangelicals, no one listed opposition to gay marriage as their top priority. Leaders said they are more focused on protecting religious freedoms, as same-sex marriage becomes legal in a growing number of states.
Is it time to differentiate between religious ceremony and civil ceremony? Jim Daly, the president of Focus on the Family, said in an interview with CNN. The civil ceremony to the Christian community is no different than getting your car registered.
The changing attitude comes as the Supreme Court could take gay marriage as soon as next year. Meanwhile, Republicans, who will take full control of Congress in January, are largely ignoring the issue, as are most potential GOP contenders for the 2016 presidential nomination.
There is a recognition that while the struggle should not give up on defending the definition of marriage of several thousand years old, the courts are likely to undo that very quickly, said Erick Erickson, a conservative expert and editor at RedState.com. Behind the scenes, many evangelical leaders within and outside politics are laying the foundations for religious freedom and protections of conscience.
Implications for the GOP
The new stance could have great implications for Republicans heading for the 2016 presidential election. Evangelicals are an influential bloc of the party and if the community alleviates their opposition to same-sex marriage, that could make it easier for candidates to do the same. The party is under pressure to extend its appeal to young people and minorities, and openness to gay marriage could contribute to that effort.
Hambycast: The Challenge of Rand Paul Campus · Global Voices
Of course, there is still much opposition to same-sex marriage between Republicans. And the issue is a great motivation to raise funds for the party and its allies.
Vincent Harris, a 26-year-old digital strategist who has worked for evangelical favorites like Ted Cruz and Mike Huckabee said social problems, including gay marriage, remain very powerful for the Republican electorate.
` notion of joke '
Brian Brown, president of the National Marriage Organization, refused to speak of an evangelical change as a notion of a joke.
People are still accused of this, Brown said. There has not been enough standing for marriage, especially as a result of what is essentially a constitutional crisis.
Daly, whose daily Focus on the Family reaches more than 2.9 million listeners weekly, is nowhere near supporting same-sex unions and insists that the legalization of gay marriage in the United States is not a fait accompli. But his vision for the evangelical movement focuses on reaching, rather than attacking or rejecting, other segments of society, what he calls taking a kind attitude.
He often mentioned his friends in the gay rights community.
One of those friends is Ted Trimpa, a prominent gay activist and Democratic strategist. The two made an unlikely friendship after Daly contacted Trippa's office about two years ago to join in and fight child trafficking in his native state of Colorado.
They see their bond as an example of where the dialogue is headed, through Trippa they said that people faint when they see us together.
`Common reason '
“With Jim, it is a new day,” Trimpa said. The reality is that gays don't leave and evangelicals don't leave, so we're finding common ground.
Russell Moore, chairman of the Ethics and Religious Freedom Commission of the Southern Baptist Convention, is also advocating a more open approach and has asked Christians to love their gay and lesbian neighbors.
If we do not recognize - LRB - the change of culture -RRB-, we have no idea what is going on, Moore said in an interview.
How the Supreme Court’s lack of decision helps gay marriage
Matthew Vines, meanwhile, is an openly gay evangelical who recently published a book trying to discredit biblical interpretations that define homosexuality as a sin. He went to a conference sponsored by Moore's group in October and was surprised that even his strongest critics interacted constructively with him. He said he would have been completely ignored at the convention five years ago.
There is definitely a next division among evangelicals, but it is not yet public, Vines said. During the coming year in particular, people will begin to show their true colors.
Generational division
About 43% of white evangelical millennials support same-sex marriage, according to a 2014 survey by the Public Religion Research Institute, while 7 out of 10 white evangelicals generally oppose same-sex marriage. The generational divide is even more pronounced among the Republican Party: almost two thirds of Republicans under 30 favor same-sex marriage compared to 39% of all Republicans, according to the Pew Research Center survey.
Republican Party leaders are watching these polls closely and in the past two years, four Republican senators have announced their support for same-sex marriage. This year, the GOP presented two openly gay Republican candidates to Congress, although none of them won.
Some, like Margaret Hoover, a Republican strategist and LGBT activist, say the party is changing too slowly and needs to end its opposition to gay marriage.
I believe that the fact that most Republicans do not support same-sex marriage or LGBT freedom is detrimental to reaching and connecting with a new generation of voters, said Hoover, who is also a CNN political commentator.
Hoover leads the American Unity PAC, which spent more than $4 million in the 2014 cycle to support gay marriage and LGBT rights Republican candidates, according to the presentation of the Federal Electoral Commission prior to the group's elections.
The Republican Party could see at least one pro-marital gay presidential candidate in the 2016 elections if Sen. Rob Portman, who has a gay son and supported same-sex marriage in 2013, decides to seek the nomination of the party.
When Mitt Romney was the party candidate, could you have imagined there might be a Republican candidate the next time he's in favor of same-sex marriage? “Even I could not have imagined that,” Hoover said.

LRB-CNN-RRB- After days of turmoil, the President, the Prime Minister and the Cabinet of Yemen have withdrawn, leaving the troubled nation of the Middle East without clear leadership and potentially on the brink of armed conflict.
President Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi's resignation came Thursday after the Houthi rebels kidnapped his chief of staff, took control of key government buildings in the capital, Sana'a, and failed to comply with the provisions of a provisional peace agreement that was signed on Wednesday.
The chaos in Yemen is a cause for concern far beyond the country's borders.
For the United States and its allies, the government of Yemen has been a key ally in the fight against al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, the Yemen-based group linked to attacks such as the recent massacre in the French magazine Charlie Hebdo.
For the moment, uncertainty rules. Beyond that, it yawns the prospect of a political vacuum and a growing sectarian divide that terrorist groups like AQAP could exploit.
Meda Al Rowas, senior analyst at IHS Country Risk, told CNN that unless Hadi is reinstated, the chances of the country avoiding armed conflict are slim.
Our forecast is really a civil war in Yemen because we have a lot of non-state armed groups that are prone to compete for territory and have many competing agendas, he said.
Who is in charge right now really depends on where you are in Yemen, he said.
Houthis -- Shiite Muslims who have long felt marginalized in most of the Sunni country -- have taken control of Sanaa and the northern provinces of Amran and Sadaa.
But there has already been resistance to his attempt to take over the institutions of national government of different groups in Yemen, particularly in the south, where there is a long-standing secessionist movement, and in the oil-rich province of Marib east of Sanaa.
This really creates a situation in which even if the Houthis maintain control over Sanaa, they have little chance of taking control of the whole country, Al Rowas said. We hope to see armed resistance.
Hadi, himself a Southerner, may be able to rescind his resignation and launch an initiative of the Gulf Cooperation Council for a negotiated transition of power.
But that seems unlikely today.
According to the national news agency SABA, the Yemeni Parliament must hold an extraordinary session on Sunday, convened by the Speaker of Parliament Yahya al-Rai.
Analysts suggest that because there is no vice president, the speaker could be next in line of succession, assuming the role of acting president. He is close to former President Ali Abdullah Saleh, who held onto power until he was forced to abandon him under international pressure two years ago.
Despite their takeover of Sanaa, it is unclear whether the Houthis really want to take over the country.
It is more likely that the group would want Hadi to remain in power as a figure behind whom they could pull the strings, without having to take over the burdensome governance business, Al Rowas said.
Under Wednesday's failed peace agreement, Hadi's government had agreed to rewrite parts of the country's constitution to give the Houthis more political power in exchange for the withdrawal of their militias from the main government institutions and the release of the kidnapped president's deputy.
The government finally obtained parliamentary approval in December, said Sama'a Al-Hamdani, an analyst from Yemen based in the United States. Hadi's resignation seems to be a recognition of the fact that he was not able to lead the country as he wished because of Houthi's inauguration, he said.
Houthis are Shiites from northern Yemen, representing approximately 30 per cent of the population. They have been at war with the central government for the best part of a decade and are also fighting the Sunni AQAP.
In early 2014, they won a series of battles near the Saudi border. And in September, Houthi fighters suddenly descended over Sanaa, where they took over government buildings, the main airport, and some of the power. In the last week, he's been taken to another level.
Although they have been fighting AQAP, they are not friends of the United States. One of the main slogans of this group historically backed by Iran is Death to the United States.
Houthis have more recently forged an alliance with former President Saleh's supporters, Al Rowas said.
This facilitated the expansion of the Houthis to the south, but the alliance is fragile, he said, among other things because Saleh in the past carried out military campaigns against the Houthis.
Al Qaeda's Yemen-affiliated AQAP is perhaps the most internationally known group.
It first emerged in Saudi Arabia in 2002, but thanks to the efforts of Saudi authorities it was a force largely spent in 2005, according to Jane's World Insurgence and Terrorism analysis. It re-emerged, revived, in Yemen in 2009 after the Saudi team merged with an al-Qaeda Yemeni counterpart.
In addition to fighting the Yemeni government and the Houthis, he has been involved in international terrorist attacks, including the failed attempt in 2009 to shoot down a plane over Detroit.
The Muslim Brotherhood is also a powerful group in Yemen, in the form of the Al Islah Party, and is well represented in the transitional government. It abhors the Houthis and has its own militias.
The struggle in Yemen also offers an opening to ISIS, which is willing to overcome Al Qaeda and demonstrate that it is the true defender of faith. In November, ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi called on the Yemeni Sunnis to resist the Houthis.
There are also a number of heavily armed rural tribes that will fight for control of their territories.
While in power, Hadi and Prime Minister Khaled Bahah's government have been trying to fight AQAP on the ground and have also authorized U.S. drone attacks on terrorist targets in the country.
As part of these efforts, the United States has several hundred United States diplomats and military personnel in Yemen. But the U.S. Embassy. He's been on reduced personnel since September.
Houthis have publicly said they are opposed to U.S. drone attacks and U.S. involvement in Yemen.
There are currently no conversations with the Houthis, but there are discussions about whether to talk to them, according to U.S. officials. Staff members said that multiple policy options are being considered, although there is still no consensus on how to proceed.
The safety of U.S. personnel is our top priority in Yemen, State Department spokesman Jen Psaki said. We are constantly assessing the security situation on the ground. We urge all parties to fulfil their public commitments to ensure the security of the diplomatic community, including our staff.
Al-Hamdani, Yemen's analyst, said she saw no immediate need to remove U.S. personnel from Yemen.
I think Yemen is safe at the time, told Wolf Blitzer of CNN. Houthis have been in charge for a while. They have popular committees all over the capital of Sanaa, and they've been running the security program.
However, I mean that Americans might have to start talking to the Houthis. And if the Americans are talking to Iran on the back channels, they have to do the same with the Houthis.
Since Hadi's resignation, there has been a lot of anger against Houthis in some parts of the country, said Al Rowas, the country's risk analyst for IHS.
Although Hadi was unable to unify the country while in power, he said, since the capture of Sanaa by the Houthis, he has become the popular symbol of anti-Houthi sentiment throughout southern and central Yemen.
Many there are asking for his return, he said.
A major anger point for popular anger may be the center of Marib province, he said. There have already been some low-level clashes, and tribes are mobilizing in the area.
There have also been large-scale protests in Aden, the main seaport in the south of the country, where the current chaos plays in the hands of the secessionist movement.
7 Things You Should Know About Yemen
CNN's Tim Lister, Nick Paton Walsh and Jomana Karadsheh contributed to this report.

Beyond reasonable doubt or not? USA It says that both

Now, do we have an image or do we have irrefutable evidence, beyond reasonable doubt? This isn't a court of law. And intelligence doesn't work that way, he told CNN's Union State.
But Kerry said last week, we can tell you beyond any reasonable doubt that our evidence shows that the Assad regime prepared for this attack, gave instructions to prepare for this attack, warned their own forces to wear gas masks.
Kerry says the amount of information that has been declassified is unprecedented.
That information is reduced to summaries of what the evidence is.
` Concrete evidence: Described, not declassified
Physical and concrete evidence shows where the rockets came from, when they were fired, and that none fell into regime-controlled territory, Kerry said.
According to a declassified White House report, satellite detection corroborates that attacks in a regime-controlled area hit neighborhoods where chemical attacks would have occurred. ... The lack of aerial activity or missile launch also leads us to conclude that the regime used rockets in the attack.
The White House published a map, but no satellite images.
The report also cites multiple intelligence streams, without giving details.
" Interceived communications "
In the three days leading up to the attack, we collected currents of human intelligence, signals and geospatial that reveal that the activities of the regime we assessed were associated with preparations for a chemical weapons attack, says the U.S. report.
Syrian chemical weapons personnel operated in the Damascus suburb of Adra... near an area the regime uses to mix chemical weapons, including sarin. On 21 August, an element of the Syrian regime prepared for a chemical weapons attack in the Damascus area, including through the use of gas masks.
We have a set of information, including the previous Syrian practice, which leads us to conclude that regime officials were ignoring and directing the attack, the report says. We intercepted communications with a senior official intimately familiar with the offensive which confirmed that chemical weapons were used by the regime on 21 August and referred to United Nations inspectors obtaining evidence.
The intelligence services show that Syrian chemical weapons personnel were ordered to cease operations in the afternoon of 21 August and that the regime intensified artillery shelling in the area, the report says.
The material is still classified.
United States: Opposition Has No Capacity ' · Global Voices
American, British and French intelligence reports agree that the opposition could not have achieved such an attack.
We are sure that none of the opposition has the weapons or the ability to carry out an attack on this scale, particularly from the heart of the regime's territory, Kerry told the legislators.
The White House report points to the well-known stockpiles of chemical agents in Syria. And he says the U.S. is confidently assessing that the Syrian regime has used small-scale chemical weapons against the opposition several times in the past year, even in the suburbs of Damascus. This assessment is based on multiple sources of information, including information on Syrian officials planning and implementing chemical weapons attacks and laboratory analysis of physiological samples obtained from several individuals, which revealed exposure to sarin.
We believe that the opposition has not used chemical weapons.
In May, a United Nations official said there were strong suspicions that the Syrian rebel forces had used sarin gas. But the findings were inconclusive, the UN. The International Independent Investigation Commission for Syria said at that time, and the Syrian opposition coalition condemned any use of chemical weapons. The U.S. State Department He said that at that time he had no evidence to suggest that the rebels had used chemical weapons.
Russia, a Syrian ally, says that its investigation of a March attack in Aleppo, which apparently involved chemical wear, found that the load used was homemade and similar to the projectiles produced by the Bashaar al-Nasr group, part of the opposition Islamic Liberation Front. Sarin was discovered on samples from the scene, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
Assad’s motive is unclear
Some experts in the region wonder why Al-Assad would have ordered the attack.
Al Assad has no credible motivation to use these weapons at this stage and at this stage of the conflict. He is not losing, writes Ed Husain of the Foreign Relations Council in a CNN opinion column. He pointed out that some suggest that the Al-Nusra Front affiliated with Al Qaeda or other elements of the opposition might have carried out the attack to incite the United States to the conflict.
William Polk, who served the U.S. administrations during the Cuban Missile Crisis and the 1967 Middle East War, writes in The Atlantic, I don't see what Assad could have won with this gas attack.
Analyst: No way in hell USA can support the death toll
Questions about the alleged death toll in last month's attack also raise questions about the solidity of the information that the U.S. is using.
A preliminary assessment found that 1,429 people died in the chemical weapons attack, including at least 426 children, the U.S. report says.
According to Anthony Cordesman, former director of intelligence evaluation at the U.S. Department of Defense, Secretary Kerry seems to have had to use an absurdly exaggerated number.
Now, with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, Cordesman writes on the CSIS website, Put simply, there's no way in hell that the U.S. intelligence community will be able to do that. I could have made a credible estimate of this exact one.
The methodology used to reach the figure remains classified.
Rebel leaders have said that more than 1,300 people were killed. The British Joint Intelligence Organization says at least 350 people were killed. A French report says several sources estimated at least 355 deaths, while others estimate 1,500.
The United Nations blames no one.
The United Nations is calling on world leaders not to take action until the results of the United Nations investigation arrive. But it's not clear how soon it can be.
And the mandate of the United Nations team was only to determine whether chemical weapons were used, not by whom.
And Obama says that cat is out of the bag.
Frankly, no one is really arguing that chemical weapons were used, he said.
Therefore, in the absence of a shocking finding that chemical weapons were not used, it is unclear how much effect the UN results will ultimately have.
Meanwhile, the Syrian regime continues to insist that the rebels were behind any chemical attack. But he doesn't offer any proof to back that up.
After it became known on Sunday that al-Assad had conducted an interview with Charlie Rose of CBS and PBS denying any involvement in chemical attacks, Kerry was asked for a response.
The evidence speaks for itself, he said.
