Former hostage Sigifredo López landed in the Colombian city of Palmira to receive a hero on Thursday afternoon, free after nearly seven years of captivity by Marxist rebels in the jungle.
A Brazilian helicopter takes off Thursday from an airport in Palmira, Colombia, to pick up Sigifredo López.
Lopez was found in the helicopter that led him to freedom by his wife and two children, who cried openly and deeply as they embraced him. One son held his father’s head in his hands and spoke fervently to him as he kissed his forehead.
Lopez's mother also hugged him before the released hostage was swallowed up by a mob of relatives of other hostages who had died in captivity.
After hugging the well-wishers for more than 20 minutes, López climbed into a white Red Cross sports utility vehicle and left in a four-vehicle convoy.
The former regional legislator was kidnapped on April 11, 2002 by rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, better known as FARC.
López's release was the sixth unilateral of the rebels in a week, but few of the kidnappings were as dramatic as the one in which López and 11 other legislators were kidnapped.
He's the only one in that group who stays alive.
A video taken by the FARC that day in April 2002 and published at the end of 2006 shows the first minutes of the bold kidnapping that led to his captivity.
The rebels had been training for months. In a FARC camp, they practiced in Colombian army and police uniforms and simulated the regional parliament in Cali with tarpaulins and plastic sticks.
A rebel camera was rolling as the 20-person commando group drove a bus to Cali, Colombia's third largest city. The salsa music was very striking. See FARC's Images of the Dramatic Kidnapping of López and Other Legislators · Global Voices
They pretended to be government soldiers. The motorcycle racers have cleared the way.
Once they arrived at the Parliament building, they faked a bomb alert.
The bus stopped in front of the building, and the video shows people running from the perceived threat.
In the video, one hears an invisible rebel say: For deputies, we have a special vehicle.
Twelve congressmen took their seats, believing the military were shepherding them safely. The minutes passed, and a politician asked where they were headed.
A few minutes later, you can hear the muted response: ladies and gentlemen. We're the FARC.
Back in the mountains, the hostages were piled up aboard a truck. The guerrillas greeted and hugged as they celebrated their bold mission.
In 2003, Lopez and some of the other hostages appeared in a life-proof video. One of his colleagues just wrote, "How long?" in his hand and held him to the camera.
Another, Jairo Hoyos, sent a prophetic petition to the President: Mr President. Those who are about to die greet you.
Eleven of the congressmen died in captivity in June 2007. FARC said they were killed in crossfire during a military rescue mission. The Colombian army rejects that claim.
When the bodies were recovered three months later, autopsies showed that most had been shot multiple times in the back.
Lopez was the only survivor. Thursday night, you may be able to tell the rest of the world what happened that day.
The FARC released five other hostages last week. On Tuesday, Alan Jara, former governor of the state Meta de Colombia, arrived at Villavicencio airport, southeast of Bogotá.
Four hostages -- three police officers and one soldier -- were released during the weekend.
Colombian senator Piedad Córdoba has negotiated the releases with the help of the International Committee of the Red Cross and a group called Colombians for Peace. Brazil has also helped by providing the aircraft used in the releases.
The FARC, Colombia's largest and oldest guerrilla group, announced the release on December 21 and appointed Córdoba as coordinator. Some analysts see these releases as a first step towards a possible peace agreement. Others suggest that this is just another sign that the government's military gains combined with a hard right-wing political line are gradually beating the FARC into submission.
Colombia has said that the rebels still have about 700 captives.
The government has recently offered rewards to guerrillas who surrender and release hostages. Last month, two guerrillas fled their camp deep in the jungles of southern Colombia, carrying with them two captives, a 14-year-old boy and a male adult who were abducted in December.
And a July rescue operation released former presidential candidate Ingrid Betancourt, who had been captive since 2002, along with three U.S. military contractors and 11 Colombian police and military.
The government has said that the FARC military force has been seriously compromised in recent months, but the authorities still accuse it of trafficking large amounts of cocaine to finance its decades-old insurgency.
Security analysts said that the FARC, established in the early 1960s, has between 9,000 and 12,000 armed guerrillas and several thousand sympathizers, mainly in rural areas.
The guerrilla group operates mainly in Colombia, but has carried out extortions, kidnappings and other activities in Venezuela, Panama and Ecuador, analysts say.

Doctors completed an autopsy of Moammar Gaddafi on Sunday, and the chief pathologist confirmed that the former Libyan leader died of a gunshot wound to the head.
Dr. Othman el-Zentani would not reveal whether the findings revealed whether Gaddafi suffered the wound in crossfire or at close range, a key question that has led the United Nations and international human rights groups to call for an investigation into the last moments of the life of the Libyan fort.
Doctors performed the autopsy at a hospital in Misrata in the presence of prosecution officials, Zentani said. Autopsies were also carried out on the bodies of Gaddafi's son Mutassim and his former defense minister, Abu Baker Yunis.
No foreign or independent official was present, Zentani said.
The autopsy report will go to the Attorney General's office before it is released to the public, he said.
Meanwhile, the three bodies would probably return to a cold storage unit in a Misrata meat market for public viewing, Zentani said.
The long rows of people showed up all weekend to see the bodies.
Gaddafi's family issued a statement on Friday asking the United Nations and Amnesty International to pressure Libya's new leadership to hand over the bodies of its tribe's martyrs so that they can be buried according to Islamic rites, a pro-Gadafi television station reported.
Gaddafi's death on Thursday solidified the power of the Transitional National Council, which marked the liberation of the country on Sunday in the eastern city of Benghazi, where the uprising began.
But uncertainty continued to revolve on Sunday over the death of the Libyan leader, who the Libyan and world powers wanted to capture and prosecute for war crimes.
The leaders of the interim government of Libya have said that Gaddafi died in crossfire after the fighters captured him on Thursday.
But others have questioned that account.
Peter Bouckaert, emergency director of Human Rights Watch, told CNN that the fight was over when Gaddafi was cornered in a drainage ditch. He said the crowds beat Gaddafi in what was a humiliating end for the former dictator.
“When he left the area, he was very alive,” Bouckaert said. There is no reason why he should have been subjected to this kind of popular justice.
An amateur video distributed by Reuters news agency on Sunday showed NTC fighters congratulating a man the fighters say killed Gaddafi. CNN could not independently verify this claim.
The video, allegedly shot near an ambulance carrying Gaddafi's body, shows a jubilant group of fighters pouring water into a man's head.
He's the one who killed him, says a man, pointing.
He killed him in front of me, I swear to God, another man screams.
A lawyer for Gaddafi's son, Saadi, who fled in September to Niger, issued a statement on Sunday saying, Saadi Gaddafi is shocked and outraged by the fierce brutality that accompanied his father and brother's murders.
The contradictory statements issued by the NTC that excuse these barbaric executions and the grotesque abuse of corpses make it clear that no person affiliated with the former regime will receive a fair trial in Libya or receive justice for the crimes committed against him, the statement said.
Mahmoud Jibril, chairman of the NTC executive board, has said that Gaddafi's right arm was wounded when an arms battle broke out between fighters and Gaddafi loyalists while his captors tried to load him in a vehicle. More shots exploded as the vehicle moved away, and Gaddafi was shot in the head, dying moments before arriving at a hospital in Misrata, Jibril said, quoting the city's coroner.
The United Nations human rights office and activist groups such as Amnesty and Human Rights Watch have called for an investigation into Gaddafi's death.
The U.S. supports these requests for research, U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton told CNN on Sunday about the state of the Union.
As the Libyans move towards the future once again, they must do so with a sense of unity and reconciliation. They have to take responsibility for each other. Those who have no blood on their hands should feel safe and included, regardless of whether or not they supported Gaddafi in the past, he said. So we believe in the rule of law and accountability, and that investigation would contribute to that.
U.N. human rights spokesman Rupert Colville told reporters in Geneva on Friday that there were at least two cell phone videos, one showing - LRB- Gaddafi-RRB - alive and the other showing him dead.
Taken together, these videos are very disturbing, he said.
We believe that an investigation is necessary and that further details are needed to determine whether he was killed in the fighting or after his capture.

Thursday the U.S. Supreme Court He declined to hear an emergency request for a suspension filed by a Florida deep-water rescue company that wanted to maintain possession of $500 million in gold and silver coins until a final decision was made on who owns them.
Spain has been victorious at all levels in U.S. courts, from Tampa to Atlanta to Washington, said Jim Goold, who defended Spain's claim to treasure. I'm happy and proud of all of us.
Odyssey Marine Exploration had made an emergency appeal to the higher court in an attempt to block the order of a lower court last week to hand over the treasure to Spain.
Judge Clarence Thomas, who has jurisdiction over Florida's applications, denied the motion in Odyssey Marine Exploration Inc. against the Kingdom of Spain without comment.
The company has filed at least one application for suspension with the judges.
Melinda MacConnel, Odyssey's vice president and general advisor, expressed disappointment, but said she recognized that the court rarely grants such motions. How we proceed from here will depend on whether it is a mandate and how it could be a subsequent order, especially given that the courts have determined that they have no jurisdiction in the case, he said in a statement.
Goold said it was unlikely that the Supreme Court would review the case. The Supreme Court accepts 1% or less of such applications and today's decision makes a strong statement about their possibilities, he said.
The dispute dates back to 2007, when Odyssey announced that he had found a 19th-century sunken ship in front of Spain. The company claimed ownership of the coins and said it had transported them to a guarded location in the United States.
Spain filed a lawsuit before a federal court in Tampa, Florida, also claiming the treasure.
Spain says that their warship Our Lady of the Mercedes was carrying the coins. The 34-gun frigate left Peru in 1804 and crossed the Atlantic less than a day's sail from Spain when British ships attacked the Spanish fleet.
In the subsequent Battle of Cape Santa Maria, south of Portugal, the Mercedes was hit in its dust magazine and exploded, according to the presentation of the Spanish government to the Florida court.
In 2009, the Federal Court of Tampa ruled in favor of Spain and the Federal Court of Appeal of Atlanta upheld the ruling last September. Last week, the appeals court denied an Odyssey motion, which Odyssey appealed to the Supreme Court.
The appeals court is expected to send the case back to the Tampa court, which would establish and oversee the procedures for sending the coins to Spain, Goold said last week.
Spain believes that most of the nearly 600,000 coins are currently in Florida, Goold said.
Spanish Minister of Culture José Ignacio Wert told CNN in Madrid on Wednesday that the case was never really about money.
We are not going to use this money for purposes other than the artistic exhibition, but this is something that enriches our material, artistic capital and has to be appreciated as such, Wert said in an interview.
He said coins would be displayed in Spanish museums, and perhaps elsewhere.
Peru, too, has followed the fate of the coins, which came from Latin America when Peru was a Spanish colony.
Formally, they have not claimed anything, but we are fully open to considering the possibility of distributing some part of the treasure also among Latin American museums, Wert said.
The treasure includes fable pieces of eight, some coined in 1803 in Lima, Peru, have said Spanish officials.

text:
Benjamin Carle is 96.9% made in France, including his underpants and socks. Unfortunately, six Ikea forks, a Chinese guitar and wall painting without sources stopped him to be declared a 100% economic patriot, but no one is perfect.
Carle, 26, proposed, in 2013, to see if it was possible to live alone with French-made products for ten months as part of a television documentary.
The idea was triggered by the call of the Minister of Economic Renewal of Arnaud Montebourg for the public to buy French to save the industrial production sector of the country.
The experiment cost Carle his smartphone, television, refrigerator (all made in China); his glasses (Italian); his briefs (Moroccan); morning coffee (Guatemala) and his beloved music by David Bowie (British).
Fortunately, his long-suffering girlfriend, Anaïs, and his cat, Loon, (both French) stayed with him.
“Politics say all kinds of things and expect us to agree. He wanted to see if it was possible and feasible to do what the minister asked us to do; to hold him accountable for his words,” Carle told The Guardian for a non-French coffee in a Parisian café after finishing his documentary.
It established only three rules: to eat only food produced in France, to eliminate contact with products manufactured abroad and to do so at 1,800 euros per month (above the minimum wage of 1,430 euros to cover the additional costs of living in Paris).
The journalist was surprised to learn at the beginning of the experiment that only 4.5% of the content of his apartment was made nationwide – and that the rest would have to go, including light bulbs (China) and green beans (Kenya).
The moving men left their house almost naked.
He ran out of refrigerator (no one is made in France) or nail cutters, was forced to cool his food on the window shelf and was seen on his toenails with a knife.
His foreign-made clothing, even his underwear, was replaced by more expensive alternatives: French-produced briefs (€26), socks (9€), polo (€75), alpargata sandals (€26), but without jeans as they are not produced in France.
During the experiment, Carle went through supermarket shelves for 100% French-made products, learned to cook seasonal fruits and vegetables grown in France, proudly brushed his teeth with the latest toothbrush made in France by a company in Picardie that employed 29 people and washed their little ones by hand until he found the last French-made washing machine (which, being first opened, does not fit under the kitchen counter).
Dating friends was problematic: there were no American movies, no Belgian beer, no sushi or pizza. Staying home, without a sofa during the first months and without television, meant listening to singer Michel Sardou and reading French novels. French wine was, of course, allowed and French-Canadian singer Céline Dion, but not, according to her advisors, French bands like Daft Punk, who sing in English.
Unable to use his British-made bike or even a French car after discovering that the only affordable models of Peugeot, Renault and Citroën are mostly manufactured abroad, he invested in an orange Mobylette moped that emits leaks.
The last things to do were the computer, replaced by a Qooq, a tablet of recipes that connects – slowly – to the Internet and iPhone, exchanged by an old mobile Sagem.
The documentary shows Carle, who realizes that he is addicted to his iPhone, destroying it with a new French pan from Tefal, while his girlfriend screams: “Are you crazy? Those are new pans!”
Carle tells viewers that his goal is “to save the French economy. After all, I like the Impossible Mission.” He admits that the experiment was partly serious and partly joking. At one point, consult a French-language expert to see if he should use “cool” and other Anglicisms – he was advised to change it to the nearest French equivalent: “chouette”.
Discovering that France does not make refrigerators (apart from wine coolers) or televisions, but is large in airplane seats and windmills, he sighs and says: “Great. Nothing that fits in my apartment.”
At the end of the experiment, Carle takes a bank loan to remodel her house and get dressed. A special “auditor” declares him 96.9% “made in France” and Monteburg visits to give him a medal.
Carle’s conclusion: “It is not entirely possible or even desirable to live 100% made in France, particularly in terms of new technology. But that wasn't the point.
“It wasn’t about French nationalism or patriotism. I was trying to show that we need to reflect on how we consume and make different decisions, and that applies in all countries. If we want to save jobs and industries, wherever we are, we could think of supporting them.
“A T-shirt is more expensive in France, but I can be sure it has been produced by workers who are properly paid and have good working conditions. I can’t be sure of a cheaper shirt produced in Asia or Morocco.”
He added: “It’s hypocrisy to go around blaming capitalists for a country’s economic decline when people could be doing more as consumers.”
Carle says he hopes to continue supporting the French industry and producers, but not 100%. “It’s a full-time job just to find things,” he said.
The first thing he did when the experiment ended was to invite his friends to enjoy “a plate of cheese and listen to David Bowie Aladdin Sane’s album.”
“It was hard not to be able to invite people because there was no place to sit... but I would choose the Bowie on a sofa any day.”

text:
Recently, investors celebrated the birthday of the current bull market, which turned five years old. On this anniversary, it is worth reflecting on how valuations are being calculated, particularly of technology companies.
On Thursday, the Wall Street Journal reported that Airbnb, a travel rental company, which has failed to disclose information about its revenue or profitability, may be close to a $10 billion valuation. Other startups in the OPI pipeline include a number of unprofitable companies like Box and Square, with rumors of valuations in the billions.
Have multi-million dollar or multi-million dollar ratings become the norm? Is it all about hype and greed these days? What happened to the wisdom of investors like Warren Buffet who evaluated companies based on their fundamental profits and results?
The value of any company is a function of the cash flow that it will generate in the future. A healthy cash flow allows a company to reimburse its shareholders and initial investors who understandably expect their investment to be repaid.
Ordinary investors who trust the hype around a company instead of the company's foundation can make decisions that regret later. Ask anyone who invested in OPI Pets.com about the danger of falling into overvalued companies.
It is true that everyone in the technology industry, from startups founders to venture capitalists, is eager to find and bet on the next big thing. Still, the money you throw around is amazing.
Even a decent business model and growth potential do not justify a multimillion dollar valuation. However, Facebook recently offered an amazing $19 billion to buy WhatsApp, a popular messaging service. Although WhatsApp has been able to make a small profit, this excessive acquisition price is higher than the market limit of 275 companies in the S&P 500.
Some market observers have argued, as Michael Wolf did at CNN.com, that the acquisition of WhatsApp is indicative of a fundamental change, and that the traditional methods of determining the valuation of the old world have been replaced by new global metrics.
For example, Wolf cited the acquisition of WhatsApp by Facebook at $42 per user, which is in line with price acquisitions per user from companies such as YouTube, Tumblr and Instagram. This is a way of looking at things, but it is severely flawed.
The value of a customer is in the income the customer provides, not in its mere existence.
If we look at the price metric per user without evaluating the income per customer, the analysis becomes strangely similar in the late 1990s during the dotcom boom when, for example, the number of eyeballs was a metric used to evaluate technology companies.
Counting balloons or user bases or potential only works in a bull market when market momentum can make bad decisions seems wise. We may remember the NASDAQ peak of 5048.62, during the height of the technological boom, and not when it fell to 1114.11 in 2002 when the technological bubble burst.
But bull markets do not last forever, and it is important to make sure that we are evaluating companies on the basis of their long-term value, regardless of the market cycle.
Of course, not all overvalued companies are bad companies. Twitter, for example, has a considerable user base, solid revenue growth and unquestionably disruptive and innovative technology. It's safe to say that Twitter has a lot of potential. However, the valuation of the company is not justified simply by its fundamental results. Twitter shares are trading almost 45 times its 2013 revenues, and its multiple profits – LRB – a company’s market value expressed in terms of its profits –RRB – is non-existent, as it has not yet established a profitable business model.
Of course, there are some companies, such as Amazon, that do not meet the traditional metrics of financial strength that end up functioning incredibly well in the stock market. But they're the exception, not the rule.
Consider the example of Vonage, one of the hottest IPAs in 2006. Despite losing 97 cents of each dollar in sales, the company had a valuation of 2.6 billion dollars. The basis of the company did not coincide with its assessment. The results speak for themselves, with Vonage shares currently listed at $4.53, below their price of $17.00 IPO.
We are forced to access the most logical and rational valuation methods; otherwise, there is no structure for making investment decisions. For every Amazon, there are several Vonages.
Despite what some market observers say, the old-world method of valuing companies remains the best way to value companies.
I suppose it's true that Christopher Columbus made a great discovery sailing the wrong way around the earth trying to find India. Here is a case in which someone had a great success based on incorrect data and methods. However, investors who bet on technology companies without basic foundations are more likely to look like Ponce de Leon: without maps and desperately looking for the Source of Youth.
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of Brian Hamilton.

In 2012, photographer Matika Wilbur sold everything in her Seattle apartment and took the road on a cross-country trip.
Your goal? To photograph individuals from each of the 562 federally recognized Native American tribes in the United States and remember their stories.
Since then, the number of federally recognized tribes has increased to 566, and Wilbur is still crossing the country, diving into the native American worlds from Brooklyn to the confines of Alaska for his ongoing photo series, Project 562.
Stereotypes in the media reduce the Indian country to India from Plains in a headdress, said academic Adrienne Keene, a member of the Oklahoma Cherokee Nation whom Wilbur photographed for the series. -LRB-Project 562 -RRB- gives people the opportunity to see diversity in the Indian country and rethink what they think when they think of Native Americans.
A selection of photos from Project 562 is on display at the Museum of Tacoma Art in Washington until October 5, with audio from Wilbur's conversations with his subjects.
Fans of the series say their time couldn't be better. With the United States showing more support for efforts to end the appropriation of Native American images in sports and fashion, they say Project 562 provides positive examples to fill the void.
Having these counternarratives and counter-representations to the negative stereotypes and representations we see in the media every day is really important to help people understand Native Americans contemporary, Keene said.
The project is also building relationships in the Indian country, cultivating ties between Wilbur, the participants, and also connecting them with elite institutions such as the Tacoma Art Museum, Keene said.
What he's doing isn't just photographing. She is building relationships and ties that will last far beyond physical photographs.
Native American Designers Fight Cultural Cartoons · Global Voices
" The project is for the people "
Wilbur, whose first name means the messenger, said the images allow Americans to see a diverse representation of a group they rarely see and hear from. Positive models also stand out in the Indian country for the next generation.
The project is for people, not just for the natives, but for everyone, Wilbur said. I believe that there are truths that remain unspeakable and that we can really learn a lot from each other. Let's hope it can inspire the next generation to seek that authenticity.
Questions about American indigenous identity are central to Project 562. Wilbur asks each person 15 questions about their family history, self-determination, sovereignty and the future. Then he asks his subjects how and where they would like to be photographed and take his portrait. Some use traditional Regalia and pose in sites relevant to their tribe's history. Others stand on their porches in t-shirts and jeans, or on the roofs of buildings. Letting them decide is fundamental to the project, Wilbur said.
Participating in Project 562 was an opportunity for Keene to reflect on what it meant for her to be a contemporary Native American.
Wilbur and Keene knew each other before Project 562 through their efforts in a larger movement in the Indian country to change the negative perceptions of Native Americans. Keene, a Harvard postdoctoral researcher at Brown University who focuses on natives' access to higher education, deconstructs the stereotypes of Native Americans on her Native Appropriations blog. Like Keene, Wilbur left India for higher education and spent part of his career in fashion photography before lighting up his camera in indigenous communities in South America and the United States.
Taking American Fashion Beyond Buckskin
The two met at Keene's apartment in downtown Phoenix in January, when Keene was writing his thesis as a predoctoral scholarship at Arizona State University. Keene told Wilbur how her Cherokee ancestors were forced from their ancestral lands in western North Carolina to Oklahoma. They lived in Oklahoma until they were displaced by the construction of a river.
It wasn't until Keene was working on her Harvard dissertation that she visited her ancestral land in North Carolina for the first time. He said it was a powerful experience he'll never forget.
We talked about how to me, being a real Cherokee means I can go to those places and feel a connection to the earth and know that my ancestors stayed there thousands of years ago, he said. This is something that happens through me, and that connection makes me a true Cherokee person, being able to say that with full authority and full knowledge. I hadn't felt it until I was there.
Creating a legacy for native youth
The concept of identity is fluid from person to person and generation to generation, Wilbur said. Some Native Americans lost their language and traditions through assimilation into Native American boarding schools. Others are fighting for federal recognition of their tribes under the broad regulatory criteria of the United States Department of the Interior of the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The project has led her to reflect on what it means to be a Native American for future generations.
Code talker Chester Nez and the tragic history of mother tongue
Recently I have come to recognize that it is really about actions, the way we choose to live our lives on a daily basis, is -LRB- what -RRB- will really control the outcome of what happens to our people, Wilbur explained.
He has high hopes for the legacy of Project 562. This year, a second Kickstarter campaign surpassed its $54,000 goal, to raise more than $213,000. She is using the money to continue traveling and plan the next iteration of Project 562 as books, websites, perhaps even educational materials.
“The life we live is for people,” Wilbur said. That's what I was raised for, to find my gift and share it with the community.

text:
Galina Zaglumyonova was awakened in her apartment in the center of Chelyabinsk by a huge explosion that blew into the windows of the balcony and smashed clay pots containing her few plants. When she jumped out of bed she could see a huge trail of steam hanging in the morning sky and hear the cry of car alarms from down the street. “I didn’t understand what was going on,” Zaglumyonova said. “There was a big explosion and then a series of small explosions. My first thought was that it was a plane crash.
What she had actually witnessed was the agony of death of a ten-ton meteorite that plunged into Earth in a series of fireballs right after dawn. Officials estimate the number of injured at almost 1,200, with more than 40 taken to the hospital, mostly as a result of flying glass broken by the sonic boom created by the descent of the meteorite. No deaths were reported.
The meteorite entered the atmosphere traveling at a speed of at least 33,000 mph and was divided into pieces between 18 and 32 miles above the ground, according to a statement from the Russian Academy of Sciences.
The event caused panic in Chelyabinsk, a city of more than a million people south of Russia’s Ural Mountains, as mobile phone networks were quickly jammed by the volume of calls. The amateur video images of the area, often spattered with the obscene language of frightened observers, showed the pieces of meteorite shining brighter as they approached the moment of impact.
The steam trail was visible for hundreds of miles around, even in neighboring Kazakhstan. Tatyana Bets was working in the reception area of a hospital clinic in downtown when the meteor hit. “First we realized the wind, and then the room was filled with a very bright light and we could see an unspecified cloud of smoke in the sky,” he said. Then, after a few minutes, the explosions came. Subsequently, at least three craters were discovered, according to the Ministry of the Interior, which were being monitored by the military. A crater was more than six metres wide, while another piece of meteorite was reported to have crashed into the thick ice of a nearby lake. Radiation levels at impact sites were normal, according to local military officers.
In Chelyabinsk itself, schools and universities were closed and many other employees told him to go home early. Among the wounded were about 200 children.
A steady flow of slightly injured people, mostly suffering flying glass cuts, reached the clinic where Bets works. He said that a nearby dormitory building for college students was particularly affected and many of the students were brought in the suffering of fear. “There were many girls in shock. Some were very pale and many of them fainted,” he said.
According to early estimates, more than 100,000 square metres of glass had been broken and 3,000 buildings had been affected. The total cost of damage to the city was being valued at over a billion rubles (£20 million).
The meteorite over Chelyabinsk arrived less than a day before the asteroid 2012 The DA14 was expected to make the closest step to Earth (about 17,510 miles) of any registered cosmic body. But experts said the two events were linked by nothing but coincidence.
Rumors and conspiracy theories, however, swirled in the first few hours after the incident. Reports on Russian state television and local media suggest that the meteorite was used by local air defence units and flew at an altitude of more than 15 miles.
The ultra-nationalist leader of Russia's liberal Democratic party, Vladimir Zhirinovsky, said it was not a meteorite but a military action by the United States, echoing much of the speculation expressed in amateur films. “It’s not a meteor shower, it’s a test of new American weapons,” Zhirinovsky said.
Some quickly took advantage of the confusion. Entrepreneurs were offering chunks of meteorite for sale via Internet sites within a few hours of impact.
President Vladimir Putin and Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev were briefed on the incident, and Putin convened a meeting with the head of the Ministry of Emergency Situations. “It’s proof that not only are economies vulnerable, but the whole planet,” Medvedev said at an economic forum in Siberia.
Dmitry Rogozin, Russia’s Deputy Prime Minister and former NATO ambassador, went to Twitter to call for an international impetus to create an alert system for all “objects of foreign origin.” Neither the United States nor Russia had the ability to tear down such objects, he added.

text:
Since he was diagnosed with HIV positive, Moses Rey, 48, has had a major problem. It has been able to cope with the stigma of being HIV-positive, widespread in Liberia, and has been able to access antiretroviral drugs provided by the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria and distributed by the Government of Liberia. But King and his family of six couldn't get the right food to eat. A subsistence farmer would grow vegetables and buy rice.
But meat and fish, expensive and luxury products in Liberian markets, but essential sources of protein, remained difficult to obtain. “Sustainable agriculture allowed us to survive, but we had so many problems,” King said. “We couldn’t get any protein, and we weren’t getting the nutrients we needed to stay.” Pate K Chon, a counselor working with HIV patients in Liberia, provided an unlikely solution. Since she saw a documentary about a farm in Thailand several years earlier, she had thought of establishing a similar project in Liberia, allowing HIV patients to have work and also access to a stable source of protein.
“I saw this movie about fish in a cement pool and thought it was a good idea,” said Chon, herself diagnosed with HIV in 1992. “Many of the people I work with don’t have the means to have a balanced diet of protein and fish is as clean a source of protein – it doesn’t cause health problems as other sources, and it’s something we can cultivate.”
Chon, founder of a faith-based NGO, began building a swimming pool in which to fish. In June 2012, Chon met John Sheehy, a strategic philanthropist and founder of Emerging Business Lab, who raised money for the non-profit farm in northeastern Monrovia, the capital of Liberia, and began learning aquaculture, doing an online course through Cornell University and talking to other fish producers in Africa.
“I raised the money and built the farm, learned the right tank design and water flow system,” Sheehy said. “Much of my knowledge was self-taught, and now I would love to write a manual and share it with others,” he added.
The project has now become the Grow2Feed Liberia Fish Farm, with 12 tanks, which, when fully populated, will each have 5,000 fish, providing up to 200,000 fish a year, serving a community of 1,200 predominantly HIV-positive people, including King and his family.
In addition to fish, tank waste is collected and used to irrigate crops, also providing food and income to the community, consisting of 503 women, 206 men and 346 children.
“Community members live near the farm, and have agreed to be part of the cooperative,” Sheehy said. “Many work on the farm, or tend the crops, and what they receive in return – when the fish are fully grown after 90 days – is fish. They can use these fish to feed and sell on the market so that they get money to buy other basic items.
“The farm gives these people with HIV a way to get back into society, they are now trading and trading with people on the market every week.”
According to the Liberian Demographic Health Survey, 1.5 per cent of Liberia ' s 3.5 million people are HIV-positive, and 60 per cent of these women or girls. Stigma and discrimination continue to surround the disease, leading to about half of all cases in the country not being treated.
Good nutrition is particularly important for people with HIV. Research has shown that they need much higher levels of protein to prevent their health from deteriorating and allow healthy growth. “Nutrition is one of the key things if you are taking antiretroviral drugs,” Chon said. “Drugs are toxic and, if you don’t have food to eat, they can make you very sick. But food in Liberia is very expensive. We buy expensive imported rice, although we should grow it ourselves and fish is hard to pay for most people.”
Sheehy says Grow2Feed is the first cooperative farm in Liberia to operate for the benefit of a HIV-positive community. The project has attracted the interest of the Government of Liberia, and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, which has worked with Grow2Feed to provide training, will also support education at the University of Liberia.
Fish farming experts say that the practice has enormous potential in Africa.
“Fisheries farming is absolutely viable in Africa,” said Paul White, owner of the HydroFish farm in Ivory Coast, which produces 3,000 tons of fish each year. “A large part of the fish on the market comes from China and is imported frozen. It is of a quality that could never enter Europe or America. There has been a serious lack of investment and technical expertise in fish production. Everything is coming to the forefront now,” he added.
Some critics are skeptical of farmed fish, citing inbred fish and high levels of toxins. But Sheehy said good practices mitigated these problems. “Many fish from fish farms are endogamic, which does cause problems, but we are using a process with local fish from Liberia, not fish from another region,” Sheehy said. “That means we can continue to use local fish to bring in new offspring. “And we are not using lakes that are cornered, where fish absorb all the toxins in the lake. We can control the environment using tanks, and we test the water and constantly monitor it.”
Sheehy hopes to replicate the model throughout Liberia and the region. “A rice-growing cooperative in Sierra Leone asked us if we could do this on our property so they can feed their workers and we have had an interest in Nigeria and Central America,” Sheehy said. “But we operate 100% non-profit and we will never lose our aspect of social justice.”

text:
They call it the Richie Rich Club and it's about to get even richer. India's richest will quadruple their net worth between now and 2018, according to a report, with hundreds of thousands of new entrepreneurs and heirs becoming billionaires. The survey, based on interviews with 150 individuals of ultra high net value, comes amid signs of restoring business confidence in the world's greatest democracy.
In recent years there has been little growth, an increase in basic food prices and a weakening of the currency. But the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won a landslide victory in May 2014 with the promise of revitalizing the sick economy. Despite the slowdown, there are almost a sixth more Indians valued at more than $3.75 million than in 2013, the report for Kotak Mahindra Bank notes. “Cities are multiplying, the middle class population is growing, opportunities have multiplied and the political environment has improved greatly in recent months,” said Murali Balaraman, co-author.
Among them, the rich in India own assets worth one trillion dollars, representing about one fifth of the country's total wealth. By 2018, that total is likely to reach $4tn, the report says, making it three times the number of billionaires.
Serving the new rich – and old money – is a booming luxury market. “They really want to show or talk about their wealth in a very subtle way and the consumption of luxury goods is a good way to do it,” Balaraman said. Abhay Gupta, CEO of Luxury Connect brand consulting, said the high-end product and experience market “will only get bigger.” “There is a huge aspiring class that admires what the very rich are doing and then copy it,” he said.
Cars are among the most popular items purchased, says the report. While, in 2009, locally made SUVs were shown by the rich, now only foreign cars will turn their heads. Mercedes recorded a 47 per cent increase in sales in India in 2013. BMW has launched a new $200,000 model in Delhi. However, India’s terrible infrastructure restricts demand. Lamborghini’s chief executive, Stephan Winkelmann, admitted, in 2013, that traffic and roads in India “are not as suitable” for the $450,000 sports cars. In India, Lamborghini sells two models: the Gallardo and the Aventador, which has a maximum speed of 217 mph. Winkelmann said Lamborghini's Indian customers were much younger than those in Europe, with a typical buyer at 30. However, the most popular investments remain real estate, mainly within India, and jewelry.
The super rich in India have raised their eyebrows for a long time all over the world with their spectacular expense. Mukesh Ambani, the richest man in the country, has built the world's most valuable home in Mumbai, the commercial capital. The 27-storey tower, with helicopter pads, indoor cinemas and staff of more than 600 people, has an estimated value of $1 billion.
The three-day wedding of Lakshmi Mittal's niece, the UK-based steel tycoon, worth approximately $16 billion, was reported to cost $80 million. Hundreds of guests were transferred to Barcelona for the ceremony and party, which took place in a museum of the city.
But buyers of luxury goods seeking psychological satisfaction of exclusivity are increasingly demanding, says the Kotak Mahindra report. One ordered nine boxes of Japanese whiskey that cost more than $750 a bottle for a wedding reception. The attraction of imported whisky was that no one attending the wedding would find out how to get the same drink in India, the report adds. Another big spender systematically bought identical pairs of Louis Vuitton bags, and then cut half of them to make clothes that matched his accessories. Even the traditional wedding is rapidly evolving. Gifts such as silver dishes, dried fruits or sweets once sent with wedding invitations are being replaced by gifts from the best brands of Western designers. “Today, these are Rolex watches and Louis Vuitton bags,” Gupta says.
Nearly half of the new individuals of ultra high net value live in smaller provincial cities. A high proportion gives substantial amounts to charity, although the report notes that “the growth of philanthropic expenditures in India has not been proportional to the overall growth of individual wealth of ultra high net value”.
Co-author Balaraman says growth in the number of rich people would not give rise to social tensions, as a large income and wealth gap is an “accepted norm” in India. “People know that someone is rich and someone is poor and continues with their lives,” he explains.

text:
When you imagine climbers climbing Mount Everest, what probably comes to mind are teams of climbers with Sherpa guides leading them to the summit, equipped with oxygen masks, supplies and tents. And in most cases you would be right, as 97% of climbers use oxygen to ascend to the summit of Everest to 8,850 meters above sea level. Thin air at high altitudes makes most people breathless at 3,500 meters, and the vast majority of climbers use oxygen beyond 7,000 meters. A typical climbing group will have between 8 and 15 people, with an almost equal number of guides, and will spend weeks to reach the top after arriving at Base Camp.
But the mountain corridor and ultra-distance Kilian Jornet Burgada ascended to the mountain only in May 2017, without oxygen mask or fixed ropes to climb.
And he did it in 26 hours.
With food poisoning.
And then, five days later, he did it again, this time in just 17 hours.
Born in 1987, Kilian has been training for Everest all his life. And that really means his whole life, as he grew 2,000 meters above sea level in the Pyrenees in the ski resort of Lles de Cerdanya in Catalonia, northeast of Spain. While other children his age were learning to walk, Kilian was on skis. At the age of one and a half years he made a five-hour walk with his mother, completely under his own steam. He left his companions even further behind when he climbed his first mountain and competed in his first cross-country ski race at the age of three. At the age of seven, he had climbed 4,000 and, at ten, made a 42-day crossing of the Pyrenees.
He was 13 years old when he said he started taking it 'seriously' and was trained with the Mountaineering Skiing Technical Center (CTEMC) in Catalonia, entering competitions and working with a coach. At the age of 18, he took over his own ski-mountain and trail-running training, with a schedule that allows only a couple of weeks of rest a year. It does up to 1,140 hours of endurance training per year, in addition to strength training and technical training, as well as specific training in the week before a race. For his record ascent and descent of Matterhorn, he prepared himself climbing the mountain ten times until he knew every detail of it, even where the sun would shine in every part of the day.
Sleeping only seven hours a night, Kilian Jornet seems almost superhuman. His resting heartbeat is extremely low at 33 beats per minute, compared to an athlete's average of 60 per minute or 40 per minute. It also breathes more efficiently than average people, taking more oxygen per breath, and has a much faster recovery time after exercise, as your body quickly breaks down the lactic acid, the acid in the muscles that causes pain after exercise.
All this is thanks to his childhood in the mountains and genetics, but it is his mental strength that distinguishes him. He often faces challenges to see how long he can endure difficult conditions in order to truly understand what his body and mind can cope with. For example, he almost gives himself kidney failure after only drinking 3.5 liters of water in a 100 km run at temperatures around 40 °C.
It would take a book to list all the races and prizes you have won and the mountains you have climbed. And even here, Kilian's achievements surpass the average person as he somehow finds time to record his career on his blog and has written three books, Run or Die, The Invisible Border and Summits of My Life.

text:
John Travolta, still mourning the death of his teenage son earlier this year, issued a rare public statement urging fans to watch his latest film, The Taking of Pelham 123, which he filmed last year.
John Travolta stars as an ex-prisoner villain in Pelham 123, which opens in theaters on Friday.
“I promise you won’t be disappointed,” Travolta said, playing a deranged former prisoner taking hostages in a subway in New York City.
Travolta did not join co-star Denzel Washington on the promotional tour for the film -- which arrives at theaters on Friday -- because he said his family needed more time to reconcile our loss.
His 16-year-old son Jett was found unconscious on 2 January while on vacation with his family in the Bahamas. The teenager was taken to a hospital, where he was declared dead upon arrival, local police said.
Washington, who plays a subway train dispatcher forced to face Travolta's character, said he spoke to the actor about three weeks ago.
Needless to say, he's struggling, Washington said in an interview last week.
Travolta's statement, which can be read on its official website, said that Washington, director Tony Scott and producers intensified unhesitatingly to help promote this wonderful film, and their selfless efforts have allowed my family additional time to reconcile our loss.
Making the film was a love job, Travolta said.
Tony gave me the freedom to define, and after becoming, the last evil genius, he said. This role as an actor gave me the opportunity to dispense with all moral and ethical limitations, and explore how bad this character could really be. I think you'll like the result.
Much of the film is a dialogue between Washington and Travolta's character through a two-way radio.
Many of the action shots were filmed in underground tunnels in New York City.

text:
Ingredients
1 lemon grass stick
1 shallot
5 cm ginger piece
3 fresh red chilies
6 lime leaves (fresh or dry)
100 g unsalted peanut
1 tablespoon tomato puree
2 tablespoons fish sauce
1 lime
1 x 800 g whole bass, scaled, gutted, from sustainable sources
1 large banana leaf, optional
1 tablespoon low salt soy sauce
PICKLE
3 mixed-coloured chilies
1 pinch sugar
2 tablespoons white wine vinegar
SALAD
1 fresh coconut
75 g of sugar peas
75 g mangotout
1⁄4 of a Chinese cabbage
1⁄4 of a red cabbage
1⁄4 cucumber
1 mature handle
1⁄2 a lot of fresh mint, (15g)
1⁄2 bunch of fresh cilantro, (15g)
1⁄2 a lot of fresh basil, (15g)
1 lime
RICE DE COCONUT
2 tablespoons vegetable oil
1 tablespoon cremated coconut
1 lime
1 cup jasmine rice
SHARE THIS BOX
FACEBOOKTWITTEREMAILPINTEREST
TAP FOR INGREDIENTS
Method
Preheat oven to 220°C/425°F/gas 7.
Beat the lemongrass against the working surface and remove the hard outer layer. Peel the shallot and ginger, disseminate the chilies, then chop everything with the lemon herb. Add to a large latch and mortar with a good pinch of sea salt and lime leaves (discard the stems) and pound to a paste.
Roast peanuts in a large skillet over medium heat for 3 minutes, or until golden brown, then beat half the pasta. Add the tomato puree and fish sauce, grate finely in the lime zest and squeeze into all the juice, then roll together.
With a sharp knife, note the sea bass skin at intervals of 1 cm in a crosswise way, then rub it all over with the paste, both inside and out.
Get your banana leaf (if used), or rip off a piece of paper to bake five times longer than fish and fold it in half to give it double thickness. Place the fish in the middle, then double to seal the fish snugly inside. Place on a large baking and roasting tray for 25 minutes, or until the meat is succulent and is easily removed from the bone.
To make the rice, sprinkle the vegetable oil in a saucepan over medium heat. Dismember in the cremated coconut, then squeeze in the lemon juice, throwing the squeezed lemon halves. Incline the rice and fry for 2 minutes, then pour over 1 cup of boiling water and lower the heat to low. Cover and cook for 12 minutes, then remove from heat and let the steam for another 3 minutes.
For chili pickle, finely chop the chilies and place in a small bowl with sugar, vinegar and a pinch of salt, then mix and set aside.
Now make the salad. Crack the coconut and grate finely 50g of meat in a serving bowl. Cut in half the sugar snaps and handle, finely crush both the cabbages and cucumber, then peel and finely cut the handle and add everything to the bowl. Collect on most grass leaves, squeeze over lemon juice and throw together.
Put the fish on a serving tray. Crush approximately the remaining peanuts in a latch and mortar, then spread over the salad and fish. Drizzle the fish with the soy sauce and spread over the remaining herbs of the salad.
Take the fish, pickled chili, rice and salad to the table and let everyone help themselves.
Tips
You can collect banana leaves from good Asian supermarkets or online. If you use it, keep it briefly on the flame of your gas plate – this will make it flexible, and therefore easier to wrap around your fish, but it will also get the oils going to get the maximum flavor.

text:
The world shares it and London claims it, but Stratford-upon-Avon intends to spend 2016 celebrating William Shakespeare as his man: the Bard of Avon, born in the market town of Warwickshire in 1564, who died there 400 years ago. Stratford remained very important throughout Shakespeare's life, argues Paul Edmondson, the head of learning and research at Shakespeare Birthplace Trust.
“People have seen Shakespeare as someone who turns his back on Stratford and his family, goes to London to earn his fortune and only dies again,” he said. “But Stratford is where he bought land and property, where he kept his library, where he lived and read and thought. We will spend the year highlighting the importance of Shakespeare, Stratford’s man.” The diarist, antiquarian and gossip of the 7th century John Aubrey, born 11 years after Shakespeare's death, had the penalty of pointing out that the bard had nothing so special. Aubrey, educated at university, unlike Shakespeare, said that he acted “excessively well” and that “his Playes got along well. ” The world has not agreed with Aubrey. The anniversary of the death of Stratford man, the most famous and most represented playwright in the world, will be marked through Britain and the world.
Macbeth will open its doors in Singapore, Romeo and Juliet in Brussels. Shakespeare’s Globe is completing the first world tour in theatre history, in which it has taken Hamlet to almost every country – North Korea continues to resist. In London, they are also creating a 37-screen pop-up cinema, a screen to display each of Shakespeare's works, along the South Bank.
The National Theatre, the Royal Shakespeare Company and virtually all other theater production companies in the country will commemorate the anniversary. The interpretations range from the decidedly traditional to the Brighton-based Complete Spymonkey Deaths, a spin through the 74 deaths – 75 including a crushed fly in Titus
Andronicus – stabbing, poisoning, suffocating and crushing through the works. There will also be hundreds of conferences, recitals, international academic conferences, films, concerts, operas and large exhibitions.
For a famous man in his own life, there is little documentary evidence of Shakespeare's life and times. The works would hardly have survived if their friends and fellow actors had not gathered together all the fragments of each work they could find – erasers, quick scripts, scribbled actors' pieces and 17 works not known in any other version – in the precious First Folio published in 1623, seven years after Shakespeare's death.
Actor Mark Rylance has called it his favorite book in the world and most of the first surviving Folios will be on display, including those belonging to the British and Bodleian libraries, and a recently destroyed copy discovered in France. Some of the most valuable surviving documents will be gathered at an exhibition at Somerset House in London, organized jointly by the National Archives and King’s College in London, including four of its six known firms, which are all slightly different.
The exhibition, By Me, William Shakespeare, will include his will, court documents related to the bold movement when Shakespeare and his fellow actors dismantled a theater on the north side of the Thames and rebuilt it as the Globe at the Bank of the South, and accounts showing the royal treasury payments for Boxing Day performances for James I and Queen Anne.
The outgoing Globe director, Dominic Dromgoole, recently said jokily that Shakespeare was a true Londoner, although he admitted “some spurious assertion” from Stratford-upon-Avon. Stratford, however, will insist that the people did and educated Shakespeare. Your old school room is being restored with a £1.4m Heritage Lottery scholarship and will open as a permanent visitor attraction.
Shakespeare bought the splendid New Place, the second best house in the city, where he died, according to literary legend, on St. George's Day, April 23, the very day of his birth. “You don’t buy a house like New Place and you don’t live there,” said Paul Edmondson. “The general public and many academics have constantly underestimated Stratford’s importance to Shakespeare.”
Edmondson believes that, after Shakespeare bought the house in 1597, all his time of thought was spent there and that the late works, including The Tempest, were at least planned in his library and probably written there. The Shakespeare Birthplace Trust describes New Place as “the jewel in the crown of the 400th anniversary celebrations,” but, in reality, it is rather an open hole where the jewel should be.
Shakespeare's house was demolished 300 years ago and the house that replaced it, probably incorporating part of the original fabric, was flattened in 1759 by an irascible cleric, Francis Gastrell, in a tax row. He had already cut Shakespeare's mulberry tree, under which it is said that the writer sat and worked, because he was irritated by all tourists looking in his garden.
Stratford's urban landscape gap has never been filled, but a five-year archaeology project has been detached from the years and the news that Shakespeare's cuisine had been found in partially surviving wineries went around the world. The whole site is being reproduced for the anniversary, with the foundations marked and the garden restored. Without Stratford, Edmondson said, there would have been no Shakespeare.

Advertising Age also recently pointed out that even though Starbucks is the world's largest coffee chain with more than 13,000 locations in more than 50 countries, even its most devoted customers buy only three out of 10 cups of coffee they drink from Starbucks.

text:
Our new international survey in 33 countries shows how wrong the world is about a number of key social realities.
The British believe that 1% of the richest households own 59% of their country’s wealth, while in reality they “only” own 23%. Americans think that 33% of their population are immigrants, when in fact it is only 14%.
Brazilians think the average age in their country is 56, when they are only 31 years old. Russians think that 31% of their politicians are women, when it is only 14%.
In Britain, people think that an extraordinary 43% of young adults aged 25 to 34 still live at home with their parents, instead of the real 14%. In India, the online population thinks that 60 per cent of the country as a whole also have access to the Internet, when in fact only 19 per cent have it.
Why do people around the world so often have no idea of these realities?
It is in part that we simply struggle with basic mathematics and some of us clearly misinterpret the questions or interpret them differently. For example, most countries overestimate how many people do not join a religion: in all 33 countries, 37 per cent do not, according to respondents, but the average is actually only 18 per cent. This will be partly because we will be thinking about how many people practice their religion, rather than what they put on census forms.
People also take mental shortcuts, where they grab to get information easily available, even if it doesn't fit the question. Our enormous overestimation of the rural population in most countries will be affected by the amount of land that makes up rural areas, rather than a careful calculation of the overall unemployment. In Daniel Kahneman’s terms, answers to these kinds of questions are classic examples of “fast” thinking, rather than “slow”.
We are linked to our own perspective and we strive to imagine the variety in our countries, as our Indian show emphasizes by massively overestimating their population's access to the Internet. Our study was conducted mainly through an online survey – and, in developing countries, this will be representative of a richer and more connected group rather than the population as a whole. Somehow, we could have expected this more educated sample to come closer to reality – those with higher education levels tend to be more accurate in these kinds of questions. But what we find, throughout the study, is that people grossly generalize their own situations, forgetting how unrepresentative they are.
We suffer from what social psychologists call “emotional numeration” in estimating realities: this means that we are sending a message about what concerns us as much as trying to get the right answers. The cause and effect run both ways, with our concern leading to our misperceptions as well as our misperceptions creating our concern.
For Britain, this is probably part of the explanation for the enormous overestimation by people of how much the richest are their own, how many young people still live at home, and what proportion of the population are immigrants (the guess is 25%, when in reality it is only 13%, according to official estimates). People are concerned about the concentration of wealth, the housing pressures faced by young people and the levels of immigration, and this is reflected in them by exaggerating the magnitude of the problems.
But, the survey suggests that there are also some problems where people are not as worried as they should be. For example, most countries greatly underestimate the proportion of their population who are overweight or obese. The worst case is Saudi Arabia, where people think only 28% are, when 71% are. The British think it is 44%, when in reality it is almost half of what again – 62% are overweight or obese.
And, in many ways, it is not our misperceptions, but these realities in different countries that are the most interesting and important aspects of the study. Russia's top 1% owns 70% of the nation's wealth, while New Zealand's top 1% owns only 18%. Half of Italians aged 25 to 34 still live with their parents, when in Norway it is only 4%.
The median age in India is 27 years; it is 47 in Japan. Only 10% of politicians are women in Brazil, Hungary and Japan, when 44% are in Sweden.
When reality is so strange and varied, it is no wonder that we are so wrong.

text:
Britain joined the United States and its allies in the fight against ISIS, but any mission will have a huge price.
The British parliament has approved air strikes in Iraq against the terrorist group that Prime Minister David Cameron has called one of amazing brutality.
Cameron had said that Britain should join international allies in the fight against ISIS, an action that he warned would take not only months, but years.
While the total cost will depend on the intensity and duration of the operation, past experience may give some guidance, said Malcolm Chalmers, research director at the Royal United Services Institute.
Chalmers noted the UK's seven-month stake in Libya until 2011, which cost about $390 million, including missiles and flying hours.
The bill is additional to the standard defense budgets, which include personnel costs and spending on weapons. Last year, the UK defence budget was $60 billion.
Chalmers said he would expect the cost of the ISIS air strikes to be in the stadium, the Libyan operation, assuming we only used air power and the campaign lasted a couple of years.
Cameron said the mission against ISIS could last for years. However, it is led by the United States instead of the operation in Libya, in which European countries took the lead.
` Unique missiles
Cameron, in Friday's debate aimed at convincing parliament to approve air strikes, said Britain has unique assets that no other coalition ally can contribute.
Cameron named the Brimstone precision missile, which he said minimized the risk of civilian casualties, as only Britain could contribute. Missiles can attack convoys, as well as fleeting targets that were previously harder to attack, according to IHS arms analyst Jane Ben Goodlad.
The Brimstone, which travels at supersonic speed, is a 1.8-meter missile weighing just under 50 kg. Advanced radar equipment allows you to steer towards the target, so pilots do not need to maneuver to release it. IHS Jane's estimates that each missile costs about $240,000.
Brimstone missiles are compatible with UK Tornado GR4 aircraft. The planes were used by British troops for relief missions in northern Iraq just over a month ago. Six of them are ready for deployment at the UK RAF base in Cyprus.
Flying the Tornadoes costs about $57,000 an hour, according to information published in a parliamentary debate on Libya in 2011. From the base of Cyprus, the aircraft could arrive in Iraq in just over an hour.
Goodlad said RAF also has Tornado Storm Shadow cruise missiles, which cost $1.3 million each, and Tomahawk cruise missiles launched by submarines. These can be used to target areas that cannot be accessed by aircraft, for example because of defenses, and cost about $1.5 million each.
U.S. forces have been using Tomahawk missiles for air strikes in Syria earlier this week, dropping 47 of them on Monday night.
In total, the United States has carried out 20 strikes in Syria and 198 in Iraq from August 8 to September 23.
Many of these operations were not included in the Pentagon's average daily expenditure of $7.5 million at the end of last month.

text:
Barack Obama has urged young people to reject pessimism and interact with those who have different beliefs if they want to make changes in the world.
On the last day of his last visit to Britain as president of the United States, Obama told 500 youth leaders at a public meeting in London: “I’m here to ask them to reject the idea that there are forces we cannot control. As JFK said, our problems are man-made and can be solved by man.
“You’ve never had better tools to make a difference,” he said at level A and to UK-US exchange students in the Q & A session. “Reject pessimism, cynicism and know that progress is possible. Progress is not inevitable; it requires struggle, discipline and faith.”
But Obama recognized the challenges that young people face: “I don’t mean that their generation has had it easy, in a time of impressive changes, since September 11, 7/7...and during an era of information and Twitter where there is a steady flow of bad news.”
The audience applauded when the president was introduced and continued to talk about his policies, including health and education.
He urged the audience to interact with people with different political beliefs: “Find people who disagree with you and it will also help you commit.”
Obama also said: “You should feel that social attitudes are changing. That doesn’t mean it’s fast enough, but you have to keep pushing and it’s partly because of the brave acts of young people like you.”
When asked about his presidential legacy, Obama said he was proud of the health reforms, which received great applause from the audience, and said of America’s response to the 2008 financial crisis: “Save the world from a great depression – that was pretty good.”
He also listed diplomatic agreements with Iran and the response to the Ebola crisis as highlights of his presidency. “I am proud; I believe I have been faithful to myself during this process.”
But he added: “Do not give up and succumb to cynics if, after five years, poverty has not been eradicated... It’s okay. Dr. Martin Luther King says that the arc of the moral universe is long but leans toward justice.”
Asked about the controversial Transatlantic Trade and Investment Association (TTIP), he said: “The response to globalization is not to lift the drawbridge and close it,” although it was crucial to pay attention to workers’ rights.
Before Obama arrived, Tanya Williams, a community engagement officer, told the Guardian: “I love Michelle, but I like Obama, and it’s exciting to have the opportunity to listen to someone who has changed so much and galvanized so many people who didn’t vote before.”
Oliver Sidorczuk, 26, said: “Everyone is very excited to hear what he has to say. I'm going to ask him about election rights and try to ask him if he would join our campaign to ask David Cameron to register automatically."
Obama ended the session by taking a question from a young Sikh from London, who asked about the issue of racial profiling at airports and being confused with a Muslim.
Obama said that while there were people with “mad ideology,” pluralism was important. “I visited a mosque a few months ago and said that our biggest allies are American Muslims who are more integrated and economically well,” he said.
Furqan Naeem, an activist from Manchester, said: “I recently visited the United States through the American embassy on the community leaders program and saw first hand a really important job the president did in celebrating America’s diversity and bringing communities together.”
Kenny Imafidon, director general of the ClearView Research youth organization, later said: “It was a great opportunity and what will accompany me is what he said about meeting people who have a different policy than yours and having to make commitments. Besides, what he said about being a good leader and finding great talent.”
Later, Obama met Jeremy Corbyn, who said they had an “excellent” 90-minute discussion.
The Labour leader said he spoke about “the challenges facing post-industrial societies and the power of global corporations, and the growing use of technology around the world and the effect it has.”
When asked if they were talking about the President's intervention in the debate on Britain's accession to the EU, Corbyn said it was briefly discussed.
After the meeting, Obama joined Cameron to play golf at Grove in Chandlers Cross, Hertfordshire. Obama ended the day at dinner with U.S. Prime Minister and Ambassador Matthew Barzun at the ambassador's residence before traveling to Germany.

text:
When two islanders saw a small fiberglass boat dragged into a remote Pacific atoll, they decided to take a closer look. What they found inside was an adventure and survival story unlikely to rival the book and the film Life of Pi: a gritty man with long hair and beard, who claimed to have been drifting for 16 months after leaving Mexico, more than 12,500 km away.
The man, dressed only in a pair of torn underpants, told his rescuers that he had been drifting in the 7.3-meter fiberglass boat, whose engines were missing his propellers, since he left Mexico for El Salvador in September 2012. A companion had died at sea several months earlier, he said.
“His condition is not good, but he is improving,” said Ola Fjeldstad, a Norwegian student of anthropology who investigates the isolated Ebon Atoll, part of the Marshall Islands archipelago. The man had said his name was José Ivan and had indicated that he survived by capturing turtles and birds with bare hands, but, as he spoke only Spanish, more details were scarce. There was no fishing equipment on the boat, but a turtle was inside when it left. “The boat is really scratched and seems to have been in the water for a long time,” Fjeldstad told reporters.
According to the researcher, the islanders who found the man took him to the main island on the atoll, which is so remote that he has only one telephone line and no internet, to meet with the mayor, Ione de Brum, who contacted the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Majuro, the capital of the Marshall Islands. Ministry officials said they were waiting for more details and expected the man to be taken to the capital.
The only government airline aircraft that can land in Ebon is currently under maintenance and is not expected to return to service for several days. Officers are considering sending a boat to pick up the castaway. “He’s staying at the local council house and a family is feeding him,” said Fjeldstad, who added that the man had a basic medical checkup and found that he had low blood pressure, but did not seem to have any life-threatening conditions and was able to walk with the help of men on the island. “We’ve been giving him a lot of water and he’s gaining strength.”
Fraser Christian, who teaches maritime survival courses at his Coastal Survival School in Dorset, said that man's story, if true, would be remarkable, but far from unique. It was entirely possible to catch turtles or small fish by hand, he said, as “they are curious and will approach a small boat to take refuge under it.” Christian advises customers who are forced to eat turtles to start with their eyes – “many fluids” – and then move into blood.
The main problems that man would have faced were exposure and dehydration. “The basic rule is: there is no water, there is no food. You need water to digest proteins. If you don’t have fresh water and it doesn’t rain for a few days, so you can’t collect rainwater, you’ve basically had it.” Individual physiology also plays a role, he said, with some people more suited to survive than others. “Mind is key and that often depends on the situation of people in life and how they are used to deal mentally with difficulties.”
Survival stories in the vast Pacific Ocean are not uncommon. In 2006, three Mexicans came out to international headlines when they were discovered drifting, also on a small fiberglass boat near the Marshall Islands. They claimed to have survived for nine months at sea on a diet of rainwater, raw fish, and seabirds, and their hope was kept alive by reading the Bible. But Cliff Downing, who teaches marine survival to sailors, said he was skeptical about the latest story. “It doesn’t sound right to me. There are 1,001 dangers that would make your survival so long very unlikely. One would like to know much more.”
More shipwrecked: Poon Lim, a Chinese sailor from a British ship sunk by a German submarine in 1942, survived 133 days on a wooden raft floating in the South Atlantic before being rescued by Brazilian fishermen. In 1971, experienced Scottish sailor Dougal Robertson and his family sailed to the Galapagos Islands from Panama when their boat was sunk by killer whales. They survived 38 days in a lifeboat before being rescued by a passing trawler.
In 2006, three Mexican fishermen were discovered drifting on a small boat near the Marshall Islands, nine months after embarking on a shark fishing expedition. Apparently they survived on a diet of rainwater, raw fish, and seabirds. Before being rescued by the U.S. Coast Guard, the men remained alive eating tuna. A Panamanian fisherman sued Princess Cruises in 2012 after one of his ships ignored his cry for help and two comrades who were stranded on his broken ship. He survived 28 days adrift, but his friends died of thirst.
label: C1

text:
Egypt has agreed to allow two Iranian warships to cross the Suez Canal in a movement that places the country's new military regime in a thorny position with its Israeli neighbour.
The post-Hosni Mubarak interim government gave the green light to Iranian warships on Friday, state media reported. It is expected that they will be the first Iranian warships to sail through Suez since the 1979 revolution of the Islamic Republic.
The canal is an internal body of water, and as such Egypt has sovereignty over it. But Egypt is also bound by the 1978 Camp David Agreements, which guarantee the right of free passage by ships belonging to Israel and all other nations on the basis of the 1888 Constantinople Convention. Before that, Egypt did not allow Israeli ships to navigate the canal.
Last week, Egypt's new military government said it would honor all its international treaties. That would include Camp David.
This is uncomfortable, at a minimum, said David Schenker, director of the Arab Policy Programme at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy.
Schenker said the Iranians had asked for a frigate -- the Alvand -- and a military supply vessel -- the Kharg -- to cross into the Mediterranean. They are both armed with missiles, he said, and added that their passage would create more uncertainty in the region.
It's destabilizing. Tension increases, particularly at this time of transition in Egypt, Schenker said. This is typical of Syrian-Iranian opportunism.
Egypt's decision, analysts said, could show the direction military caregivers intend to take in the most populous nation in the Arab world.
It raises an unwanted political issue that needs to be resolved, said the Commander. James Kraska of the United States of America Naval War School in Rhode Island.
Iran previously said that the flotilla was on a one-year intelligence and training mission to prepare cadets to defend Iranian cargo ships and oil tankers from the threat of attack by Somali pirates, according to the semi-official Fars Agency.
Asked about Iran's claim that ships go to Syria for training, State Department spokesman P.J. Crowley said Friday, my initial answer to that would be that we are highly skeptical of that.
He asked if he was concerned about travel plans, he said, “It’s not really about ships. It is what ships carry, what their destination is, what is the cargo on board, where it goes, to whom, for what benefit. We have, you know, continuous concerns.
Those concerns were shared by the White House, where Press Secretary Jay Carney told reporters aboard Air Force One, We are monitoring that, obviously, but we would also say that Iran does not have a great record of responsible behavior in the region, which is always a concern for us.
Israel's Foreign Minister, Avigdor Lieberman, said Israel's allies should pay close attention to the situation.
We hope that the international community will act quickly and decisively against Iranian provocations, aimed at deteriorating the situation in the area, and put the Iranians in their place, he said.
The Israeli Ministry of Defense said it was monitoring the movement of Iranian ships and alerted its allies.
The Suez Canal is a key channel for international trade. It connects the Mediterranean Sea with the Red Sea, allowing ships to sail between Europe and Asia without having to cross Africa. Millions of barrels of oil move through Suez every day on their way to Europe and North America.
