text:
During the height of the 2009 financial crisis, when there was a real and present danger that banks would take over due to lack of liquidity, then British Prime Minister Gordon Brown altered geopolitical architecture.
Brown moved with a sense of urgency to formalize the Group of 20 nations.
The strategy was good. I wanted to include the countries that accounted for 80% of GDP under the same umbrella, to narrow the gap between the developed and developing worlds and, more importantly, to take advantage of the $4 trillion of surplus funds that still exist in the BRICS economies.
In the context of a financial crisis, the strategy worked. Four years later, however, geopolitics is surpassing the economy. The G20 has become a hard-to-manage group of countries with different priorities, and without Washington's political backing.
According to Brown, whom I interviewed earlier this year, the United States should be more alert to the possibilities of international cooperation in both trade and growth agreements.
A global trade agreement, the so-called pivot to Asia, and even serious concerns about capital flight from emerging markets and their currencies will be overshadowed in this G20. Syria will be the top of the agenda when leaders gather at Russia's western outpost in St. Petersburg.
The focus is on the tensions between host Vladimir Putin and his American counterpart Barack Obama. His just verbal could further divide the G20, the strategists suggest. As a general rule, the BRICS are not in favour of Washington and Paris calling for military intervention.
The business has taken a back seat and must move to the front seat, Mustafa Abdel-Wadood, chairman of the executive committee of the private capital group Abraaj told me. Politics is at the top of the agenda.
The business agenda is led by the close reaction to the panic of a planned reduction in bond purchases by the United States Federal Reserve. Since Federal Reserve President Ben Bernanke spoke of that strategy change in May, money has been flooding emerging markets.
Prior to this week's summit, high-ranking Chinese finance officials stepped out of their way to suggest, during a press conference in Beijing, that the Federal Reserve should be more cautious with its approach.
Zhu Guangyao, China's Deputy Minister of Finance, welcomed the signs of America's recovery, but said Washington should consider the effect of spreading its monetary policy, especially the opportunity and pace of its exit from ultra-luggish monetary policy.
The end of easy money or loose monetary policy in the United States is exposing the cracks in emerging markets, which rode a powerful wave of commodity-driven growth for a decade.
Without that demand for exports of grains, gold, palm oil, rubber, minerals and even manufactured goods, economies such as Brazil, India, South Africa, Turkey and Indonesia have seen their current account deficits plummet and their currencies plummet.
India's rupee has fallen by more than 20% this year, most of that loss just in the last quarter, as the country registered the worst growth in four years. Brazil and Indonesia have seen their currencies fall by 10%, forcing central banks to use monetary reserves and, in some cases, interest rate increases to stop the bleeding.
The trend is for investors to make comparisons with the Asian financial crisis 1998/1999, when these economies had large current account deficits and a mountain of foreign currency government debt.
Most of Asia learned a lesson, Marios Maratheftis, global director of macro research at Standard Chartered Bank, told me. Most emerging market debt is now issued in local currencies.
Maratheftis said the sudden stoppage of capital flows to emerging markets will create problems for those with rising current account deficits, but this should not become a crisis as long as there is greater policy coordination.
He has no great hope for discussions in St. Petersburg. They talk globally when they meet, he said of the G20. But act local when you go home.

text:
Many of the major supermarket chains have been set on fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They have wasted tons of food, mispaid their suppliers and contributed to the excess of plastic waste in their packaging, which has had an impact on our environment.
But supermarkets and shopkeepers are starting to sit down and take note. In response to a growing consumer reaction to the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the UK's largest supermarkets have signed a pact that promises to transform packaging and cut plastic waste. In a commitment to reuse, recycle or compost all plastic waste by 2025, supermarkets are beginning to assume some responsibility for the role they play in contributing to the damage to our environment, with a major supermarket announcing their plan to remove all plastic packaging in their own branded products by 2023.
In response to criticism of food waste, some supermarkets are donating part of their food surplus. However, charities estimate that they are only accessing 2% of the supermarket's total food surplus, so this hardly seems to be solving the problem. Some say supermarkets are just not doing enough. Most supermarkets operate under a veil of secrecy when asked for exact food waste figures, and without more transparency it is difficult to find a systematic approach to avoiding waste and redistributing food surpluses.
Some smaller companies are taking things into their own hands and offering consumers a more eco-friendly and environmentally friendly option. Shops such as Berlin's Original Unverpakt and London's bulk market are free plastic stores that have opened in recent years, encouraging customers to use their own compostable containers or bags. Farmdrop online eliminates the need for department stores and the risk of a huge surplus of food by delivering fresh produce from local farmers to their customers daily through electric cars, offering farmers most of the retail price.
There is no doubt that we still have a long way to go to reduce food and plastic waste. But perhaps large supermarkets could draw inspiration from these small traders and gradually move towards a more sustainable future for all of us.
label: C1

text:
Music subscription services, including Spotify and Deezer, have broken the $1 billion sales barrier around the world, as a growing number of fans choose to pay for online music.
Transmission and subscription revenues increased by more than 50% in 2013 to $1.1 billion, helping total sales of recorded music in Europe grow for the first time in 12 years, according to figures released in March 2014.
It is estimated that there are now 450 music rental services around the world, and although many people still listen for free, the desire for more options is persuading more music lovers to separate from their money. Over a three-year period, the number of subscribers paid increased from 8 million to 28 million, according to the 2014 International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI) digital music report.
Easily accessible from smartphones and tablets, subscription services are popular with people looking to try new music without committing to buying a download or CD. Consumers say they are attracted to a cheap, easy-to-use and legal alternative to pirate downloads. “It is now clear that music transmission and subscription is a traditional model for our business,” said IFPI Executive Director Frances Moore. There are signs that, in Britain and America, streaming can soon generate more revenue for the music industry than downloads from online stores like Apple's iTunes. Subscription services now account for one third of all digital sales worldwide, with downloads constituting the balance, but IFPI data show that the two formats are growing at different speeds.
In the United States, the percentage of people claiming to use subscription and streaming increased from 19 per cent in 2012 to 23 per cent, while the percentage of people downloaded decreased from 28 per cent to 27 per cent. In Britain, downloaders remained static, by exactly one third, while subscribers grew from 19% to 22%. In Sweden, France and Italy, streaming is already more popular than downloading.
Digital formats now account for 39% of all music sales, or nearly £5.9 billion of £15 billion, and while sales of CDs and vinyls declined sharply in 2013, they continue to contribute just over half of the industry's revenue. A recent music sales accident in Japan, which accounts for one fifth of the sales of the music industry and where physical formats remained popular for longer than elsewhere, meant that sales in all formats fell globally by 3.9%.
However, vinyl continued to return in some markets. Sales increased by 32 per cent in the Americas and by 101 per cent in the United Kingdom in 2013.
IFPI also said that One Direction was the best-selling artist of 2013, with physical and digital sales of 4m for its album Midnight Memories. Katy Perry's Prisma was the best-selling album by a female artist, in sixth place behind Eminem, Justin Timberlake, Bruno Mars and Daft Punk.
Consumer technology companies have been competing to join the trend of music transmission, with Apple launching iTunes Radio and Google promoting its Play Store, with smaller players like Beats Music, created by the team behind the Beats headset brand, also joining the fight.

text:
In higher education, science subjects are usually dominated by male students. This has a negative impact on the world of work, as fewer women enter the science, technology and engineering sectors. This essay will explore the reasons for the lack of gender diversity in science and suggest ways to create equal opportunities in this area.
The most likely reason for the imbalance is that society reinforces the idea that boys and girls have different interests and capacities. We see this from a very early age when young children receive cars and Lego while girls receive dolls. The former are encouraged to build things, while the latter learn to take care of others. Later, we are told that girls are better in languages or that boys have a better spatial consciousness. In fact, there is no evidence that biological differences between the sexes make one gender more talented than another in a given subject. It is society, not nature, that tells us that girls must favor the arts and humanities and leave mathematics and physics to boys.
Along with this is the lack of positive female models that young people see doing science-related work. Cartoons and stories often show the mad scientist, inventor genius, or adventurous astronaut as a man. In addition, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and separated from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they can mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and they see science as an unattractive career. If girls saw more positive female role models in science, it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging to those issues.
In view of these points, it is important to address this issue from the first stage of the child's education. At a time when young women are in college, it may already be too late to refute the view that science 'is not for them'. For very young children, therefore, it is necessary to promote gender-neutral play. As children age, both the education system and the media must raise awareness of women's achievements in the field of science, as well as expose them to a more diverse set of characters in books and films. We need to find ways to show young women that science is fun, interesting and, most importantly, theirs too.
label: C1

text:
Lego's profits increased sharply in the first half of 2014, helped by the success of his Lego Movie, which has raided lockers in the United States and the United Kingdom.
Sales of the Danish toy company increased in Europe, America and Asia while children were taking out products linked to the film. The film, released in February, took over 250 million dollars in the United States. and £31 million in the UK for the first weekend of April.
The film costs about $60 million to make and has been described as an almost flawless piece of content marketing by creating entertaining content aimed at consumers who are likely to go out and buy the company's products.
Lego’s financial director, John Goodwin, said: “The strong performance of Lego Movie’s products had a positive effect during the first half of 2014, and it remains to be seen how the line will continue to develop after the much-anticipated release of the film on DVD in the second half of 2014.”
The operating profit of the first six months of Lego's financial year increased by 12% to 630 million dollars. Sales increased 11% to more than three times the figure six years earlier.
Jørgen Vig Knudstorp, executive director of Lego, said: “It is a very satisfactory result that shows our significant growth in recent years in a difficult economic environment. The result for the first half of 2014 is a result of our ability to develop, launch and distribute Lego products, which children around the world put at the top of their wish lists.”
Lego, based in the small town of Billund, began producing its plastic bricks in 1949 and became a basic toy for children around the world by the 1970s. But the group lost its way and was on the verge of collapse in 2003. Knudstrop took over as executive director, ending with 70 years of family rule, and abandoned hundreds of surplus products to redirect the business into its trademark bricks.
The company opened its first factory in China in April and opened an office in Shanghai to head the expansion in the second largest economy in the world.
label: C1

text:
Servers hosting the House of Representatives websites and their members have been overwhelmed by millions of emails in recent days, forcing administrators to implement the digital version of a traffic cop to handle overload.
Servers hosting House of Representatives websites have been flooded by millions of emails in recent days.
This is unprecedented, said Jeff Ventura, communications director of the House’s chief administrator.
The waves of emails and page views began after negotiators announced on Sunday that an agreement had been reached on legislation to promulgate a $700 billion bailout of the country's financial system.
In making the announcement, lawmakers said the public could see the deal at financeservices.house.gov.
In a short period of time, many Web users rushed to the digital door to get a copy of this thing, Ventura told CNN in a telephone interview.
While millions of people were trying to see the details of the rescue plan, the House.gov system was overwhelmed and many people saw ads on their computer screens saying that this page did not appear. iReport.com: Support a rescue?
Ventura compared the situation to the old days, when you heard a radio show and the tenth person who called got a toaster. So everyone calls the same number 1-800 at the same time and all you have was a busy signal.
This was a massive busy digital signal, he said.
As more people gained access to the page and the details of the ransom proposal were published in the media, voters began sending an email to their representatives, Ventura explained.
We know that there are millions, he said of the number of e-mails that the House legislators have been receiving. But we haven't counted yet, because when you're about to be hit by a tide wave, you don't count the drops of water in the wave.
After the House failed to approve the proposed agreement on Monday by a vote of 228-205, the volume of email increased again, Ventura said.
Because there were so many emails, which was impacting even House.gov's presentation, he explained.
This morning, our engineers blew the alarms... and we installed a digital version of a traffic cop. We promulgate stops we planned for last night. We were hoping we wouldn't have to.
The office of the administrative director of the House of Representatives issued a statement on Tuesday saying: This measure has become temporarily necessary to ensure that Congress websites are not completely disabled by the millions of emails flowing into the system. The engineers are working diligently to accommodate this huge flow of traffic and we appreciate your patience in this matter.
Now, when House.gov or individual member sites begin to overload, a message will appear on the computer screen saying, in effect, try to come back later, Ventura said.
This really tells us that the level of constituent commitment on this issue is extremely high, he added.
He said that after the failed vote on Monday and the initial reaction, the administrators of the House website thought there would be a drop in web traffic, especially with the Rosh Hashana holiday.
We monitored the situation all night, and technicians and engineers saw that we were facing the same demand as yesterday, Ventura said.
He predicted that traffic on those websites would begin to decrease once there is some guidance on the market and the political picture on what comes next.
Ventura said House.gov's website experienced a very high number of visits when the September 11 commission released its final report on September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on the United States, but nothing like what the site has seen in recent days.
label: C1

text:
High music through huge speakers, front-row guests rejoice and a parade of stunning models electrifies the dazzling catwalk, welcome to Africa Fashion Week London.
Today, in its third year, the glamorous event saw dozens of great names and emerging designers from across the continent descending into the modern Shoreditch district of the British capital to reveal their latest stylish creations.
Our platform seeks to promote emerging and established African-inspired designers, said Ronke Ademiluyi, founder of the event, held from 1 to 3 August.
The main thing is to draw attention to them, show their creativity to the world so that they get a more global recognition for what they do and more appreciation for their brands as well.
Vibrant colors
The tracks had designs from countries such as Nigeria, Ghana, South Africa, Congo, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Kenya and Morocco, but also from the diaspora, including Great Britain and the Caribbean.
In many ways, the event reaffirmed why African-inspired designs are quickly drawing the attention of the fashion world.
Mixing current trends with traditional patterns, more than 60 designers adorned the walkway with a wide range of colorful creations, ranging from high night dresses and modern informal urban clothing to bold textured prints and lines of elegant accessories.
Glorious colors in the desert: the fashionable women of Darfur
Ademiluyi says that the fashion of the continent today represents a fusion of contemporary and African designs flooded with a lot of vibrant colors and tribal trends.
Among those that give a modern twist to traditional styles is Nigerian designer Fashola Olayinka with her brand based on Lagos MOOFA Designs. His latest collection, Ashake is celebrating the very powerful and strong women who turn their heads wherever they go.
That's basically what the collection is about, says Olayinka, who started the label about four years ago. Women who are very feminine and sexy.
The young designer says that despite existing challenges, such as frequent power outages, it is very exciting to be part of Nigeria's fashion scene right now.
We work hard and have a lot of fun, so it's been a lot of fun and it's a growing process in Nigeria, he says. Nigerians like to dress and many people in Nigeria now wear their own fabrics.
Profile boost
But despite growing interest in African designs, Ademiluyi says that many of the continent's promising talents still find it difficult to get into major international shows.

The government relies on thousands of legal claims from people who were imprisoned and allegedly mistreated during the last days of the British Empire after the London High Court ruled that three Kenyan elders arrested and tortured during the Mau Mau rebellion have the right to sue for damages.
On Friday the court rejected the claims of government lawyers that it had been too long since the seven years of insurgency in the 1950s, and a fair trial was no longer possible. In 2011, the same High Court judge, Judge McCombe, rejected the government's claim that the three plaintiffs should be suing the Kenyan government, as it had inherited Britain's legal responsibilities for independence in 1963.
Human rights activists in Kenya estimate that more than 5,000 of the more than 70,000 people detained by British colonial authorities are still alive. Many may file claims against the British government. The ruling can also make it possible for victims of colonial atrocities in other parts of the world to sue.
But many more men and women around the world who were imprisoned and allegedly mistreated during the conflicts that often accompanied the British withdrawal from the empire may also be considering claims: cases that could expose evidence of brutal mistreatment of colonial subjects and result in a new and uncomfortable understanding of recent British history.
The Foreign Office acknowledged that the ruling had “potentially significant and far-reaching legal implications, ” and said it was planning to appeal. “The normal time frame for bringing a civil action is three to six years,” a spokesperson said. “In this case, that period has been extended to more than 50 years despite the fact that the main decision-makers are dead and unable to account for what happened.”
The historic victory of Friday for Paulo Muoka Nzili, 85, Wambugu Wa Nyingi, 84, and Jane Muthoni Mara, 73, was the result of a three-year battle through the courts. They had suffered what their lawyers described as “unspeakable acts of brutality,” such as castration, beatings and serious sexual assaults. A fourth claimant withdrew, while a fifth, Susan Ciong’ombe Ngondi, died two years ago, 71 years old.
In the capital of Kenya, Nairobi, news from London was transmitted to two of the complainants, Nyingi and Mara, by mobile phone. They had been sitting quietly with their supporters in a sunburned garden and reacted with joy when the word came, hugging, dancing and eventually raising their hands to heaven to pray.
Nyingi, who was detained for about nine years, beaten unconsciously and bears the marks of the leg mannacles, lashes and lashes, said: “For me... I just wanted the truth to come out. Even my children's children should know what happened. What should happen is that people are compensated so that they can begin to forgive the British government.” Mara said, “I am very happy and my heart is clean.” When asked what he would say to his four children, he simply said, “I’ll tell them I won.”
McCombe said in 2011 that there was “evidence... that there could have been systematic torture of detainees. ” On Friday he ruled that a fair trial was possible, and highlighted the fact that thousands of documents came to light in 2011 after the Ministry of Foreign Affairs admitted in a secret archives file of the colonial era.
In the course of his attempts to eliminate the claims – efforts that the plaintiffs’ lawyer, Martyn Day, described as “morally disgusting” – British government lawyers accepted that the three Kenyan elders were tortured by colonial authorities.
Day said: “The British government has admitted that these three Kenyans were brutally tortured by the British colony and yet have been hiding behind technical legal defenses for three years to avoid any legal liability. There is no doubt that there will be victims of colonial torture from Malaya to Yemen, from Cyprus to Palestine, who will read this trial with great care.”
Among those known to have been watching the case closely are several veterans of the Eoka insurgency in Cyprus in the 1950s. One has already met with the lawyers of the Mau Mau plaintiffs. Cypriot claimants could rely not only on British documentation, but also on the archives of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva. Those files are kept secret for 40 years, and then open to public scrutiny. The Red Cross documented hundreds of cases of torture in Cyprus, where reporters covering the conflict referred to British interrogators such as HMTs – torturers of His Majesty.
There may also be claims from Malaysia, where a large number of people were arrested during the 12-year war with communist insurgents and their supporters that began in 1948. Family members of 24 unarmed rubber plantation workers massacred by British troops are currently fighting through British courts for a public investigation. Many former British prisoners in Aden may also have claims against the British government, although, as Aden is now part of Yemen, British lawyers may have difficulty making contact with potential clients there.

He had the taste of a typical millionaire. It had a gold and silver Rolex and a fleet of expensive cars. He liked to meddle in modern art. But, although this Chinese businessman had several companies and a palatial village in the suburbs of Madrid, he had almost no money in the bank, a detail that aroused the interest of the Spanish authorities.
Gao Ping, who had lived most of his adult life in Spain, had a monopoly on supplies to 4,000 Chinese bazaars throughout the Mediterranean country. But the authorities suspected that he was not paying taxes on clothes, furniture and other goods that he was importing from China.
When the police slid into their warehouses in 2012 they found lots of cash: wads of €100, €200 and €500 notes were wrapped in elastic bands. About 12 million euros were transported in cars, the largest seizure of cash ever made by the Spanish police. The gang, along with Gao, the alleged ringleader, is accused of washing up to 300 million euros a year, as well as selling counterfeit goods and toys with fake safety marks. The prosecutor said Gao's illegal business was so big that it was damaging Spain's competitiveness. Gao is on bail; the case has not yet come to trial.
Law enforcement officials have been concerned for a long time about €500. Small and easy to transport in relation to their value, they are the method of payment of choice for tax evaders, money launderers and drug barons. The sum of € 1m in € 500 bills fits easily in a small portable bag, where the same amount in € 50 bills would require a small suitcase. Cash mules are known to double notes into plastic pellets and swallow them. A less dangerous method of concealment is to put the tickets in a car chassis.
The United Kingdom suspended the distribution of the Euro500 note in 2010 on the grounds that the claim was “almost entirely for criminal purposes. ” In 2009, the central bank of Italy warned that banknotes were widely used by money launderers and terrorists. Other countries have limited their own high-denominational notes due to links to organized crime: Canada ruled out its $1,000 note in 2000 with the advice of law enforcement officials.
In an era of electronic payment systems and contactless cards, more wonder if the printing of these notes can be justified. Peter Sands, former director of the Standard Chartered Bank, has called for the abolition of high denomination tickets, including 500 €, 100 €, 1,000 Swiss francs and 50 £. In a report for the Harvard Kennedy School of Government, Sands argued that it was time to get rid of the high-value notes that make life easier for “bad people” who pursue tax evasion, financial crime, terrorist finance, and corruption. Although criminals would switch to smaller denomination notes, gold or diamonds, these substitutes are more voluminous and more traceable, making them more likely to be captured, he said.
At a conference on the financing of terrorism in London, the Head of Europol, Rob Wainwright, asked the European Central Bank (ECB) to examine whether it “should continue to produce and distribute these notes to facilitate criminals and terrorists to hide their activities and finance illegal activities”. According to Europol, the 500 euro purple bill represents 30% of the value of all euro banknotes in circulation, although most people have never seen it.
The EUR 500 note was introduced in 2002 when the euro was born: it replaced the DM 1,000, the Belgian francs 10,000 and the Italian lira 500,000. Several European countries were in favour of high-value banknotes. “It’s definitely a preference that has been there for a long time,” says Pia Hüttl, a fellow member of Bruegel’s thinktank. “Preference is based on the idea that cash has a lower cost and is accepted everywhere.”
Cash remains king in Germany and Austria, where more than half of all transactions are made with money in paper and coins. Former president of the German Constitutional Court, Hans-Jürgen Papier, told Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung of Germany that restrictions on cash were at odds with individual freedom, while sensationalist newspaper Bild has launched a petition in defense of paper money, including the €500 note – “send my cash.”
Law enforcement authorities are less convinced, amid a steady stream of reports of suspicious cash packages. In a case that has caught the attention of the police, two men entered a bank and tried to deposit 200,000 euros of torn and muddy 500 euro notes. In the same week, €1.3 million was found in 500 € notes stuffed in the false bottom of the suitcase. But a suspicion of criminality is not enough to keep people in custody. “Our frustration from the point of view of law enforcement is that, in many jurisdictions, it is impossible to provide sufficient evidence to satisfy judicial authorities of a link between suspicious cash detections and crime,” says Jennifer MacLeod, a specialist in Europol’s financial intelligence group. “The search for these links is further complicated by time constraints and fragmentation of cooperation and information exchange”.
The agency would like the central banks to assume more responsibility for the “attack anomalies” in the use of 500€ banknotes. Luxembourg, for example, issued more than twice its annual banknote GDP in 2013 alone, despite being one of the countries with the highest cash revenues in Europe. Europol asked the central bank of Luxembourg for explanations. “The answer we received from Luxembourg is that they simply issue the notes requested and have no explanation for the reasons behind the lawsuit,” says MacLeod. “I am surprised that a central bank does not consider itself responsible in this area.”
This could be changing. Mario Draghi, the head of the ECB, said it is determined that the bank’s income from issuing the notes should not be “a comfort to criminals.” Other members of the ECB’s core team, such as Yves Mersch, argue that there is no evidence of the criminal uses of the 500 euro note. However, in the midst of growing fears about terrorism, this argument may no longer cut off any ice. EU Finance Ministers have asked policy makers to study and report on the “appropriate restrictions” of high-value notes by 1 May 2016.

President Obama's top collaborators indicated on Sunday that some U.S. troops could start returning from Afghanistan in July 2011, but most would probably stay there for several years.
In the appearances in all the big talk shows, Cabinet officials and military advisers clarified the president's position after walking a loose political line announcing that he will send 30,000 more troops to Afghanistan and that some will start returning home in 19 months.
National Security Adviser General James Jones told the State of the CNN Union that the beginning of the withdrawal in July 2011 was not a cliff, it is a ramp to begin handing over security responsibility to Afghan forces.
Taking note of the strategic interests of the U.S. in the region, including nuclear power Pakistan next door, Jones said, "We're going to be in the region for a long time.
General David Petraeus, head of the U.S. Central Command, said in FOX News on Sunday that Obama's strategy does not rush out, while Defense Secretary Robert Gates told CBS Face the Nation that there is no deadline.
What we have is a specific date when we will begin transferring responsibility from the security districts by district, province by province in Afghanistan to the Afghans, Gates said.
The challenge has been to meet the need that military leaders have cited for more troops and resources to end terrorist networks in Afghanistan and help the Afghan government overcome the Taliban insurgency, while satisfying the liberal base of the Democratic Party, which opposes the deployment of more troops.
Gates explained the reason for sending more forces to ABC's This Week, saying that the Afghan-Pakistani border is the epicenter of extremist jihad.
And Al Qaeda has close relations with the Taliban in Afghanistan, and they have very close relations with the Taliban in Pakistan, Gates continued. The Taliban in Pakistan have been attacking Pakistani civilians, Pakistani government officials, military officers, trying to destabilize the government of Pakistan.
Any Taliban success in Afghanistan or Pakistan benefits Al Qaeda, Gates said, adding that any safe haven on both sides of the border creates opportunities to recruit, raise new funds and make operational planning.
And what's more, the Taliban renaissance in safe havens in western Pakistan is a lesson for al Qaeda that they can return, if they are provided with the kind of safe haven the Taliban were, Gates said.
In addition, Gates warned the NBC's Meet the Press that U.S. casualties will likely continue to grow as troops face the Taliban strongholds. However, Gates rejected a comparison with the Soviet Union's decision in 1985 to send more troops to reinforce its occupation of Afghanistan, which ended in failure less than two years later.
The parallel doesn't work, Gates said. The reality is that the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan. They killed a million Afghans. They made 5 million refugees from Afghanistan.
In addition, he said, the Soviets acted unilaterally, while the U.S.-led mission in Afghanistan involves 42 countries with a NATO mandate.
In Congress, Republicans generally supported Obama's deployment plan, but complained that announcing the start of a retreat was a signal to the enemy of a committed commitment.
Arizona Senator John McCain, the failed Republican Party presidential candidate last year, told the NBC Meet the Press that a strategy must be flexible to succeed, rather than be limited by a set timetable.
In FOX News Sunday, Senator Dick Durbin, second Democrat of the House, called the beginning of the retreat in July 2011 a necessary signal for Afghan President Hamid Karzai.
According to Durbin, Obama's message to Karzai was: "We are not going to make Afghanistan a protectorate of the United States. You have to change your government. They have to prove that they are willing to stand up and fight for their own country.
“I think that message is too late,” Durbin said.

In the broader reform of the Obama administration's national security team to date, the president will appoint the director of the Central Intelligence Agency Leon Panetta as his nominee to succeed Robert Gates as defense secretary, senior US officials said on Wednesday.
General David Petraeus will be nominated to assume the post of CIA director, and Lieutenant General John Allen will succeed Petraeus as head of the U.S.-led international military force in Afghanistan, a senior administration official told reporters. In addition, diplomat Ryan Crocker will be nominated as the next U.S. ambassador to Afghanistan, the official said.
President Barack Obama will formally announce the changes on Thursday, according to the senior administration official. It is the biggest remodeling of Obama's national security team since he took office in January 2009 and reflects Gates' long-standing plan to set aside this year.
More changes are also approaching. Both Admiral Mike Mullen, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and FBI Director Robert Mueller are not eligible for re-nomination for terms expiring this year.
Gates will resign from June 30, assuming Panetta is confirmed by Congress on time and ready to begin July 1, according to an administration official and a congressional assistant familiar with Gates' phone calls to legislators and senior officials.
Petraeus will remain in command in Afghanistan until Allen is ready to take over in early September, officials said, which might require an interim director of the CIA if Panetta moves to the office of the defense secretary as scheduled on 1 July.
In addition, Petraeus will resign from the military once confirmed to serve as a civilian director of the CIA, officials said.
The initial reaction of the Congress was positive, with key lawmakers on intelligence and security issues praising both Panetta and Petraeus as good options.
The sum total of these elections is that the president has chosen experienced people with unique capabilities to serve our nation at a dangerous time, Republican Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina said. This team will provide leadership to help make our nation safer. I couldn't be more satisfied with these selections. I hope that these nominees will receive the swift approval of the United States Senate.
Gates was telling lawmakers and staff members that he recommended Panetta to work six months ago, and joked that Panetta stopped talking to him for days for doing so, officials said. In addition, Gates was saying that Allen was a consensus option to succeed Petraeus, according to officials.
He took a meeting with Obama to convince Panetta to accept the job, a source familiar with the discussions told CNN. Panetta has been happy serving in the CIA, but believes firmly in public service and responding to the call of the commander-in-chief, the source said.
Panetta, 72, took over the CIA in February 2009. He served as Chief of Staff for President Bill Clinton between 1994 and 1997, and was previously Director of the Office of Management and Budget (LRB-OMB-RRB). The California Democrat served in the House of Representatives from 1977 to 1993.
Before coming to the CIA, he spent 10 years co-leading a public policy institute with his wife, Sylvia.
He was brought as an alien relative, with no practical intelligence experience, to run an agency that had been shaken by the exposure and criticism of his controversial interrogation and detention program. Panetta's long-standing ties with Congress were seen as a way to restore the administration's relationship with oversight committees. He has been given high ratings on both fronts from inside the agency and in Congress.
David Berteau, senior advisor to the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said Panetta brings several important qualities to the table.
He learned many lessons about the defense budget during his time as head of the OMB, and knows how to deal with a Republican Congress, as he did during the Clinton administration, Berteau said.
The former Panetta Congressional district in northern California had a huge defense presence, Berteau said.
Panetta has earned Obama's confidence as a CIA leader, and has name recognition, which is important, Berteau said, adding: It's a name Americans recognize. Filling Bob Gatesshoes is gonna be hard work.
Berteau said the election of Petraeus president to lead the CIA indicates that Obama is interested in his views and national security efforts and indicates that the president cares about the way all those pieces fit.
Earlier this month, Petraeus took a very unusual step for a military officer when he publicly recognized the possibility of competing for a presidential appointment.
It is probably not appropriate for me to comment on what might be considered along the way, he told journalists in Kabul when asked about the possible nomination of the CIA. I have had discussions, but again, it would not be appropriate to comment.
Petraeus, 58, assumed command of NATO's International Security Assistance Force (ILB-ISAF-RRB) and the United States. Afghanistan forces on 4 July 2010, after serving for more than 20 months as commander of the United States Central Command. Previously he commanded multinational forces in Iraq, leading the so-called increase. During his time commanding the United States Army/Fort Leavenworth Combined Arms Center, he supervised the development of the Army/Marine Corps Counterinsurgency Manual.
Crocker has previously served as U.S. ambassador to Iraq and Pakistan, while Allen became U.S. Central Command subcomandante in July 2008.
Gates is the only cabinet member of the previous administration who held office when Obama took office. President George W. Bush nominated Gates as the nation's 22nd Secretary of Defense in December 2006 to replace Donald Rumsfeld, one of the architects of the Iraq War facing widespread criticism.
Gates didn't expect to stay after Bush's presidency ended. When asked if I would continue under another administration, Gates said in 2008, I learned a long time ago never to say, so my answer is: The circumstances under which I would make it inconceivable to me.
But those circumstances arose. In December 2008, then-elect President Obama expressed his desire for continuity at the Pentagon, given ongoing conflicts abroad in Iraq and Afghanistan.
I spent a lot of time waiting for the question never to be asked, Gates admitted the day after Obama announced his nomination. But, he said, Obama impressed him.
It's unclear who can replace Mueller at the FBI.
Attorney General Eric Holder on Tuesday did not rule out Mueller staying in the short term when his 10-year term expires in September if a successor has not yet been confirmed. “Mueller will leave hard shoes to fill,” Holder said.
Holder said he's been discussing possible nominees with White House officials, including Vice President Joe Biden. Holder said he believes that if a candidate is selected in May, the administration should have time for the new director to be confirmed in August.
However, if that timeline fails, Mueller's mandate would end on September 4, a week before the tenth anniversary of the September 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Mueller has often pointed out that he barely had the opportunity to find his desk before the September 11 attacks occurred, and his entire decade was dominated by the fight against al-Qaeda and its scattered followers both in the country and abroad.
Barbara Starr, Joe Sterling, Terry Frieden, Tom Cohen, John King and Chris Lawrence of CNN contributed to this report.

Israeli troops fired on protesters attempting to cross the fortified border between Syria and the occupied Golan Heights on Sunday, and Syrian authorities reported more than a dozen deaths and hundreds of injuries.
The protests took place on the anniversary of the 1967 Middle East war, when Israel captured the Syrian Golan Heights. Israel Defense Forces did not immediately confirm any casualties, although a spokesman said Israeli troops used tear gas and war ammunition against members of an angry mob.
We verbally warned them - LRB- and -RRB- with warning shots into the air, Lieutenant Colonel Avital Leibovich told CNN. And when these two options failed, we had to fire selectively in the area, and this prevented those Syrians from reaching the Israeli-Syrian fence.
Syrian state news agency said 23 people were killed and more than 350 injured in the protests, which continued after dark. Doctors were seen taking the wounded into vehicles and moving away from the border.
A spokesman for the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, condemned the violence and called for restraint.
The events of today and 15 May on the Golan threaten the prolonged ceasefire. The Secretary-General calls for maximum restraint on all sides and strict observance of international humanitarian law to ensure the protection of civilians, he said.
Up to 500 people participated in the demonstration, celebrating midday prayers on the Syrian side of the border, and then crouched behind the walls that Israel built in response to similar demonstrations three weeks ago. Later, the number was reduced to about 50, with protesters waving Palestinian and Syrian flags.
On Sunday, clashes also broke out between Palestinians and Israelis at the Qalandia crossing between Jerusalem and Ramallah in the West Bank. At least six Palestinians were wounded there, one seriously, by rubber bullets. Israeli forces also fired tear gas, while Palestinians threw stones.
The clashes occurred three weeks after similar demonstrations marking the birth of the Jewish State in 1948, a day of mourning for Palestinians, more than 700,000 of whom were displaced from their homes during the ensuing fighting. Those protests left at least 12 dead.
Leibovich accused Syria of trying to use the protests to create a distraction from the bloodshed that is taking place inside Syria, where the United Nations says that a crackdown on anti-government protests has left more than 1,000 dead.
“There is no doubt about it,” he said. The cops, the Syrian armed forces look back and do nothing.
Protesters arrived on at least eight buses before the protest began, and then came down a hill known locally as Shouting Hill, where people yell at family and friends across the border, at the walls that Israeli forces built last month.
Leibovich said Israeli troops were better prepared to deal with demonstrations than with the May 15 protests, reinforcing forces along the border and making it clear that we would not tolerate any infiltration on the Israeli side.
Mike Schwartz, Kevin Flower and Kareem Khadder of CNN contributed to this report.

During the 1970s, one of the biggest movements in the United States was the struggle for equal rights. Many members of American society felt deprived of rights and discriminated against, especially in the workplace. Some American workers enjoyed a full living wage with benefits and other advantages, while others struggled to earn enough to survive. One of the most oppressed groups of workers during this period was the California farmers.

Peasants were migrant workers who arrived in the country mostly without documentation to work in the fertile fields of California's Great Central Valley. This region of central California has often been described as the country's fruit basket due to its rich soil and high yields. Agricultural workers cared for these fields during the day, and lived and slept on the farm at night. They earned less than the state's minimum wage, and had no marginal benefits enjoyed by other American workers. Cesar Chavez changed all that.
César Chávez, the Arizona-born civil rights activist and worker leader, became the voice of these workers, and began a movement to bring basic rights to this group. Taking the lead of the great Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Chávez began a series of nonviolent demonstrations protesting the deplorable conditions the peasants had to endure. Many of these workers worked much more than eight hours a day, and were not paid overtime. Chávez, who was an agricultural worker in the 1950s, led marches and called for boycotts. These activities were very effective in changing the working conditions of peasants and other oppressed workers.
Chávez was highly recognized during his life, and his legacy increased after his death in 1993. It has achieved an iconic status among the Mexican-American community.

text:
Report on staff participation in Girox Foods
Introduction
At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of around 12%. Although this may not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is 7%. The main objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the company and, based on them, to provide recommendations for improving employee experience in the workplace and increasing employee retention.
Research methods
This study was conducted with more than 500 employees of Girox Foods between March and August 2018, with the aim of understanding their experience and expectations in the workplace. The study covered the 80 branches of Girox Foods located in 20 European countries. In addition to the 500 questionnaires filled out by Girox employees, 120 also participated in ten different discussion groups, in which participants participated in discussions about their levels of engagement in Girox and their hopes for the future.
Main results of the investigation
The main reason for the separation of employees given by 35% of respondents is the lack of difficult work, followed by too many working hours (34%).
Forty-three per cent of respondents said that the main reason for employees to leave their jobs was lack of recognition, while 31 per cent stated that it was due to mismanagement.
There was no correlation between salaries and employee participation.
Forty-seven per cent stated that their levels of participation would improve if they felt more in charge of their work. 45 per cent wanted more flexibility in terms of both working hours and workplaces. 42% wanted the company to invest more in its professional development.
Fifty-nine per cent believed that their commitment to the company would be enhanced if they were given training opportunities to improve their entrepreneurial skills. 64% considered social and intercultural intelligence to be the most important skill needed in the workplace.
Forty-one per cent of respondents felt that there should be greater transparency in corporate communications, as this would lead to increased confidence and more informed decision-making.
Recommendations
Based on these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we need to explore ways to offer more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can allow employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers should consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of their work. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.

Emotionally, the remains of that stay for a long time, he said.
Domestic violence is the most common cause of injury to women aged 15 to 44, according to the National Institutes of Health. With the entertainment world buzzing about the pop Rihanna sensation, whose boyfriend Chris Brown has been formally accused of assaulting her, the public interest in domestic violence has been revitalized.
Abuse can influence the victim's future behavior in relationships and even friendships, depending on whether the victim stays or leaves, said Mark Crawford, a clinical psychologist based in Roswell, Georgia. Those who stay are likely to stop relying on their own perceptions and become passive in both romantic and non-romantic relationships.
Victims who leave -- which is the healthiest option, Crawford said -- often become too well-off because they want to avoid conflicts, even verbal disputes, at all costs. Some women do not trust people easily, if they do, and are not able to handle even normal expressions of anger. Visit CNNHealth.com, your connection to a better life
What you have to do when you leave the relationship is make sure you are aware of your own anger, and then you can learn to express it freely in a healthy and normal way, he said. If someone still has problems 10 years later, they just haven't worked on it. They haven't healed; they need to do that.
New investigations show that victims of abuse feel the impact of violence long after it occurred. A recent study in the Journal of Women's Health revealed that African American elderly women who were exposed to high levels of family violence at some point in their lives -- whether by their partner or by a family member -- were at increased risk of poor mental and physical health.
Not only does violence continue, which everyone thinks, but even when it is over, there is something about what happens that seems to have a persistent effect that we still don't understand, Dr. Anuradha Paranjape, co-author of the study and associate professor at the School of Medicine at the University of Temple.
It makes sense for abused women to report worse health, as people in stressful situations have higher levels of stress hormones, which interfere with immune function, Crawford said.
Other studies show a clear connection between depression and abuse. Adult women who have been abused in a relationship in the last five years have rates of depression 2 1/2 times higher than women who have never been abused, according to a different study of more than 3,000 women. They are also more likely to be socially isolated, said author Amy Bonomi, an associate professor at Ohio State University.
Women who have been abused before, but not during, the last five years had depression rates 1 1/2 times higher than those with no abuse experience, said Bonomi, who has collaborated with Dimer in research on abused women.
“People like to think that, well, abuse is just when you have a black eye, you hold a broken bone,” Bonomi said. But we see a lot of different effects in other areas, like depression and social isolation, and we have actually shown that with the data.
Women who have experienced violence also seem to be more likely to abuse substances, but it is not clear how the two are related -- one does not necessarily cause the other, and there may be other factors involved, Bonomi said.
A 2008 study of 3,333 women, in which Bonomi worked, revealed that middle-aged women who suffered child abuse, sexual abuse or other physical abuse were more likely to be depressed, as well as a higher body mass index. These women also spend as much as one third more than the average on health care costs. About 34 per cent of women in the sample said that they had been abused.
While the Paranjape study found that women with the highest levels of abuse reported poor health, the same number of diseases were reported among those women as the women in the sample who had less or no abuse. This indicates that there is something else that makes battered women report feeling bad, he said.
When your patient says they don't feel so good, you might want to think about asking what other problems may be going on, he said.
People who have come out of a relationship must go through the work of learning what problems set them in that situation, and reflect on the warning signs, Crawford said.
Experts recommend finding a counselor and other means of support, but people who have been abused should think twice about revealing too much in online support groups, because their abusers might find out what they are saying, Dimer said. Research has also shown that violence is intensifying in abusive relationships between couples who go to marriage therapy, he said.
Some women feel stronger after having gone through the experience of abuse, Dimer said. She herself found healing through advocacy and research on the subject, she said.
Calling a domestic violence phone line is a good first step for anyone who is experiencing abuse, Dimer said.
Whether you're a pop star or someone who's working on the front line -- an employee at a grocery store selling the pop star magazine -- you're at the same risk for having this, he said.

text:
It fits in four minutes. Sounds like a headline in a health magazine; an unattainable promise on nighttime satellite television. Then you try Dr. Izumi Tabata's training protocol – 20 seconds of total effort, 10 seconds of rest, repeat eight times – and between sounding like Darth Vader while you desperately aspirate in oxygen and collapsing into a messy package of sweat and defeat, you realize how wrong you were.
Tabata's seen it all before. “They were dead!” he laughs as he remembers the first time he inflicted the system that bears his name on his college students in the early 1990s. “After four minutes of hard exercise they were eliminated. But after six weeks they saw the results and were surprised. We all were.
His research followed extensive follow-up to Japan's fast skating team in the early 1990s, when he – along with team coach Irisawa Koichi – noticed that short bursts of brutally hard exercise seemed to be at least as effective as moderate training hours. Tabata set out to show this with a simple experiment. A group of moderately trained students performed one hour of constant cardiovascular exercise on a stationary bike five times a week. The other group warmed up for ten minutes on the bike, followed by four minutes of Tabata intervals, four times a week – plus a 30 minute session of constant exercise with two minutes of intervals.
The results were surprising. After six weeks of testing, the group that followed Tabata’s plan – exercising only 88 minutes a week – had increased its anaerobic capacity by 28% and its maximum VO 2, a key indicator of cardiovascular health and maximum aerobic potency, by 15%. The control group, which trained for five hours each week, also improved its maximum VO 2, but by 10% – and its training had no effect on anaerobic capacity. “We have also measured increases in heart size after three weeks of making the protocol,” Tabata says. “And there’s also a next investigation that shows that the risk of diabetes in humans is decreasing, which we’ve already shown in rats.”
But there are no half measures here. You can't go steady on a cross trainer, chew gum and read the latest issue of HELLO! The regime requires head-down bursts on a stationary bike or rowing machine; explosive body weight exercises, sprints or the like. Do you remember how you felt after running 100 meters at school? Imagine doing eight of them with just a 10-second break to recover.
“A total effort at 170% of your VO 2 maximum is the protocol criterion,” says Tabata. “If you feel good afterwards you haven’t done it properly. The first three repetitions will feel easy, but the last two will feel impossible. In the original plan the goal was to reach eight, but some lasted only six or seven.”
As one commentator at the popular T-Nation exercise forum says: “When it is done correctly you must know God. Most people are unable to do it properly and should not even try.”
Tabata doesn't quite agree. “Everyone can do it, but beginners must start with educated coaches so they can work with the right intensity for them,” he explains. He says he will soon publish research that shows that doing the program only twice a week, less than half the volume of the original research, still provides significant health benefits.
Another soon - to - be - published finding, which Tabata describes as “rather significant, ” shows that the Tabata protocol burns 150 additional calories within 12 hours after exercise, even at rest, due to the effect of excess oxygen consumption after exercise. So while it is used by most people to get fit – or by people in shape to get even more fit – it also burns fat.
It is a little surprising, therefore, that the plan remains the reserve for the serious multitude of athletes and musclehead – although that may change now that Tabata has agreed to an agreement with Universal Studios that will lead to a network of instructors and a range of DVDs released towards the end of the year. “I decided to do this because I often go on YouTube and, while I’m honored that people are doing it, some are doing it wrong because they don’t realize the intensity you need to work on,” Tabata says.
So should we start incorporating this plan into our fitness regimens? Richard Scrivener, a former assistant trainer of strength and conditioning at Northampton Saints Rugby Club, says that while the benefits are clear, Tabatas are an addition, not a replacement, to a favorite sport or training method. “The runners, for example, need a high level of functioning economy, which comes from acquiring skills and putting them in the miles,” says Scrivener, “but they could effectively ease long runs and reduce overall mileage by introducing Tabata training. This will download the skeleton and give the joints the opportunity to rest and recover, especially if you are prone to niggles or have a history of injuries – and therefore, you would probably get more of the long runs when you perform them.”
The gym rats can benefit by doing three strength sessions and three Tabatas a week. And the rest of us can build session by session, week by week, all the time knowing that it will never be easier because each session requires maximum effort. That is the cruel genius of protocol: it is implacable – and effective.

text:
When the Taliban sent a gunman to shoot Malala Yousafzai in October 2012 while traveling home on a bus after school, they made clear their intention: to silence the teenager and kill her campaign for girls' education.
Nine months and countless surgical operations later, he rose at the United Nations on Friday on his 16th birthday to deliver a defiant raffle. “They thought the bullet would silence us. But they failed,” he said.
As he turned 16, he was one of the most unusual. Instead of blowing candles on a cake, Malala sat in one of the main halls of the Council of the United Nations, at the headquarters, usually reserved for world leaders.
She listened quietly when Ban Ki-moon, the UN Secretary General, described her as “our hero, our champion”; and as the former British Prime Minister and now UN Education Envoy Gordon Brown pronounced what he called “the words the Taliban never wanted me to hear: happy birthday 16, Malala.”
The event, called Malala Day, was the culmination of four extraordinary years for the girl of Mingora, in the turbulent Swat Valley in Pakistan. She was pushed into public glare after she wrote a blog for the BBC Urdu service describing her experiences struggling to get an education under the growing power of Taliban militants.
At the age of 11, he was showing exceptional determination, personally asking the U.S. Special Representative in Pakistan, Richard Holbrooke, to use his influence to combat the Taliban's campaign against girls' education. At the age of 14, she was on the radar of Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who presented her for the International Children's Peace Prize, and at the age of 15, she became the youngest Nobel Peace Prize ever nominated.
But such dizzying global attention came at a price. The death threats followed their growing recognition, and on 9 October 2012, following a meeting of Pakistani Taliban leaders, the gunman was sent to eliminate what they called the “symbol of the infidels and obscenity. ”
Several operations in Pakistan and the United Kingdom followed the attack on the bus, including the placement of a titanium plate on its left forehead and a cochlear implant to restore its hearing. He now lives with his family in Birmingham and does what the Taliban tried to stop: he goes to school every day. “I’m not against anyone,” he said in the UN camera, having pulled this day out of the classroom. Nor am I here to speak in terms of personal revenge against the Taliban or any other terrorist group.”
Malala responded to Taliban violence with his own compensatory force: words against bullets. I don't even hate the talib who shot me. Even if I had a gun in my hand and it was in front of me, I wouldn't shoot him.
She spoke with confidence, with only one injured eye and a slightly fallen left side of her face to insinuate such fresh traumas. There was another undeclared allusion to the horror of his past: he wore a white shawl belonging to a woman who was also a target of extremists but who, unlike Malala, did not survive to tell the story: Benazir Bhutto, Pakistan's former prime minister.
“Extremists are afraid of books and pens,” the teenager continued. “The power of education frightens them. They're afraid of women. The power of women's voices frightens them.
He cited the June attack on a hospital in Quetta, capital of Baluchistan, and the killing of female teachers in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. “That’s why they are bombing schools every day, because they were and are afraid of change, fear of equality that we will bring into our society.”
And he gave his own opposite interpretation of Islam to that of the Taliban. “They believe that God is a little conservative being who would send the girls to hell just by going to school. Terrorists are misusing the name of Islam and Pashtun society for their own personal benefits. Islam is a religion of peace, humanity and brotherhood. Islam says that it is not only the right of every child to receive education, but that it is his duty and responsibility.”
Such ability to articulate what is not normally articulated – to give voice to young people normally silenced – has generated their own response. The “Stand with Malala” petition, which calls for education for 57 million children around the world who do not go to school, has attracted more than four million signatures – over a million have been added shortly after Malala’s speech.
At the beginning of his speech, Malala said: “I don’t know where to start my speech. I don’t know what people would expect me to say.” She doesn't have to worry.

North Korea has confirmed to Swedish diplomats that it has a U.S. citizen, the U.S. Department of State said Friday.
The State Department has refused to confirm the identity of the citizen, citing privacy issues. But Merrill Newman's 85-year-old family from Palo Alto, California, has said he has been detained in North Korea since October 26.
Washington has no diplomatic relations with Pyongyang, and has been working through Sweden -- the protective power of the United States in North Korea -- to obtain information about Americans.
We are working closely with representatives of the Swedish Embassy to resolve this issue, and they have also requested consular access on a daily basis, State Department spokesman Jennifer Psaki told journalists.
The revelation came on the same day as Newman's wife, Lee, pleaded for his release.
The family feels that there has been a terrible misunderstanding that led to his arrest and asks that - LRB-North Korea-RRB- work to resolve this issue quickly and to return this 85-year-old grandfather to his anxious and concerned family, he said in a statement.
Newman, a retired Korean War veteran and financial consultant, was last seen aboard a Pyongyang flight to Beijing. A few minutes before the plane departed, he was withdrawn from the flight by the North Korean authorities, the family said.
He has been detained somewhere in North Korea since then, Newman's wife said in the statement.
According to the family, Newman and a fellow traveler, Bill Hamrdla, had been on a 10-day private tour of North Korea.
The family said that Newman suffered from a heart condition and only had enough medication for the trip.
We have not heard about the state of his health, whether the drugs sent to him through the Swedish Embassy in North Korea have been delivered or why he was arrested, the statement said.
The day before Newman left North Korea, he and his tour guide met with one or two Korean authorities, his son said.
During that meeting, Newman's service record was discussed, Jeff Newman said.
I understand my father was a little upset, Newman told CNN. But neither he nor his traveling companion believed there was a problem.
This week the U.S. issued a warning to U.S. citizens against any trip to North Korea, which has become a magnet for adventure travelers after Pyongyang lifted some of its travel restrictions.
Newman was a customer of Juche Travel Services in London, said the spokesman for the company David Thompson in a written statement.
The arrangements for the tour were handled by the Korea International Travel Company, Thompson said. Mr. Newman had all the travel documents necessary and valid for his tour. We have no information on what has occurred as a result of the current situation.
The 10-day private tour, which included the use of a tour guide, was the culmination of months of planning, Newman's wife said.
The postcards sent to friends during that trip describe good times, good weather and knowledgeable guides, he said in the statement.
The family statement came one day after U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry asked North Korea to release the detained Americans, calling the arrests very, very disturbing elections of the North Koreans.
Newman is one of two U.S. citizens detained in North Korea.
The other, Kenneth Bae, was arrested in November 2012 and sentenced in May to 15 years of hard labour. The North Korean government has said he was found guilty of hostile acts and attempts to overthrow the government.
North Korea has not publicly said why it is holding Newman.
Is the American man detained in North Korea a currency?
Among the possibilities is his military service. He served as an Army infantry officer during the Korean War, which saw North Korea fight South Korea, the United States and the United Nations between 1950 and 1953.
An armistice signed in 1953 ended the three-year war between North and South Korea. Both sides technically remain at war.
It is also possible that the North Korean authorities confused him with another Merrill Newman, a Korean War veteran who awarded the Silver Star for combat value.
It is known that North Korean authorities systematically carry out background checks on foreigners, travel agencies warn potential visitors.
The first decorated combat veteran who learned about Newman's arrest was in a phone call from the San José Mercury News, which reported for the first time the American's arrest.
I thought it was a coincidence. I didn't think much about it, Merrill Newman from Beaverton, Oregon, told CNN.
From his service during the war, he just said: I went there, did what I was told and went home, went to college and started a family... That's what you did in those days.
How to travel to North Korea
News of the apparent arrest came as talks were taking place between the United States and China, North Korea's closest ally, on the resumption of negotiations to dismantle Pyongyang's nuclear program.
The moment raises questions as to whether North Korea plans to use Newman as a currency in the negotiations, a measure that the West has previously accused of doing to try to obtain concessions with the negotiations.
Newman's arrests raise the number of U.S. citizens who have been detained by North Korea to at least seven, including four who allegedly entered the country illegally, according to the State Department.
Two other U.S. citizens who entered the country on valid visas were arrested for other reasons, and U.S. officials have received reports that other Americans were arbitrarily detained, according to the State Department.
Americans previously detained in North Korea have been released when high-profile visitors have traveled to the country to defend their case. In particular, former Presidents Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter were on two separate occasions in 2010.
Former governor of New Mexico. Bill Richardson, former ambassador to the United Nations, has visited North Korea several times over the years, most recently this year to discuss Bae's release.
Richardson's spokesman, Caitlin Kelleher, said she has been in contact with her North Korean contacts regarding Newman's arrest.
The pictures of North Korea don't want you to see them.
Augie Martin, Christopher Laible, Sarah Baker and CNN's Elise Labott contributed to this report.

text:
Henry Ford was an American inventor who was credited with the invention of the auto assembly line. The German car manufacturer, Karl Benz, was credited with the invention of the first vehicle in the late 1880s, but Ford was the man who made it possible for everyday citizens to have one. Before Ford came up with his assembly line process, the cars were built one at a time by hand, which was a very costly and inefficient production method. Ford's assembly line revolutionized the way cars were built, and their methods are still in use today.

In 1886, Benz patented its Motorwagen, which was a four-wheel and two-passenger motor vehicle that was designed to replace the horse and cart. These vehicles were expertly crafted, but were available only to the richest people of the time. Thanks to Ford, everything changed in 1906. Your Ford Motor Company, the first car company to use assembly line techniques to build cars. transformed the car from an expensive curiosity to a practical tool that could be used to transport people and goods easily and efficiently. Its first serially produced product was Model T. It remains one of the best-selling vehicles in history, and was the first to reach 15 million sales.
Ford's impact on the 20th century cannot be overstated. At one time it was estimated that nine out of 10 vehicles on American roads were Fords. Their cars boosted the U.S. economy like no other factor. The country's roads were built in response to the large number of Ford vehicles and subsequent American car manufacturers produced. In addition, Ford vehicles created a network of support industries such as parts, repair and maintenance services. It also caused a revolution in how the goods were transported in the country. Henry Ford was a real American icon.

Massachusetts Port Authority officials issued an apology Wednesday after conducting a fire training exercise at Boston Logan International Airport on the 12th anniversary of the September 11 attacks.

It's silly, Governor. Deval Patrick said. The moment couldn't be worse.

The terrorist attack organized by Al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden killed 2,977 people in New York City, Washington, DC and Pennsylvania, in the worst such attack in U.S. history.

Security is our top priority and constant vigilance and preparedness is critical, but the exercise should not have taken place on the 11 September anniversary, Massport's apology said. The de facto president of Honduras denied Wednesday that his government would put out power at the embassy where deposed President José Manuel Zelaya reappeared surprisingly this week, and said that people inside were free to come and go.
A soldier takes a photo Wednesday of the Brazilian Embassy in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.
Honduran forces will also not enter the Brazilian embassy, where Zelaya has been hosted since Monday, de facto President Roberto Micheletti said in an interview with CNN in Spanish.
But these events do not forgive Zelaya, who was overthrown in a coup d'état on 28 June, from being arrested and facing charges for violating the Constitution if he leaves the safe haven of the embassy, Micheletti said.
President Zelaya should stand before the courts of our country where he has charges against him, Micheletti said.
The de facto president challenged the versions of events surrounding Zelaya's return.
Despite local reports quoting police officers that the authorities turned off power to the embassy and its surroundings apparently to discourage looting, Micheletti said a congregation of pro-Zelaya protesters in the embassy shortened power themselves.
Starting Wednesday, the energy was restored to the building, Micheletti said.
A national curfew was lifted on Wednesday, but a security cordon remained in the area around the embassy.
Micheletti said the police were there because the people inside the embassy asked for protection, and said: We are not preventing the departure or entry of absolutely anyone.
Zelaya's announced return has rekindled a confrontation between the two disputed leaders of Honduras. Brazil is now involved because of its embassy.
Brazil wants an emergency meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss the situation, the official Brazilian news agency reported.
In another event, Micheletti said he is willing to meet anywhere with the deposed President José Manuel Zelaya as long as Zelaya agrees to abide by the presidential elections scheduled for November 29. But the de facto leader said in a statement read by his chancellor on Tuesday that his offer to speak to Zelaya does not nullify an arrest warrant issued against the deposed president by the nation's Supreme Court of Justice.
I think what the whole world should understand about this country is that there is no immunity for anyone, for anyone, Micheletti told CNN in Spanish. And no one can be above the law.
Micheletti's willingness to involve Zelaya seemed to be a change of position. On Tuesday, he had said in an interview with the local network Televicentro that Zelaya's sudden appearance would not revive the negotiations for him to return to power.
The United States and Brazil have said they support the dialogue between the two parties, focused on the San José Agreement, an agreement negotiated by Costa Rican President Oscar Arias. That agreement requires Zelaya to be returned to power.
The Brazilian request for a Security Council meeting came after the Honduran government isolated the embassy by cutting water, electricity and telephone lines to the building, U.S. State Department spokesman Ian Kelly confirmed to reporters Tuesday in Washington.
This was the same action that Micheletti denied on Wednesday.
Micheletti said other nations have not given his government a fair hearing of his position.
This is what we Hondurans want: to be heard, to read our constitution, to read our laws, and to see what happened before June 28, said Micheletti.
The de facto government maintains that Zelaya was not removed in a coup, but in a constitutional transfer of power.
Zelaya, a centrist whose policy took a strong left turn once in office, was overthrown in a military-backed coup on June 28. Despite growing political, diplomatic and economic isolation, Micheletti has strongly resisted pressure to allow Zelaya to return to power and Micheletti thwarted two public attempts by Zelaya to return to his homeland.
“Yes, we are alone, but we are surviving,” Micheletti said. Two months ago, people didn't think we'd hold on all this time, but here we are almost three months later.
Amnesty International issued a statement on Wednesday in which the human rights group denounced a sharp increase in police beatings, mass arrests of protesters and intimidation of human rights defenders in Honduras since the June coup d'état and warned that fundamental rights and the rule of law in the Central American nation are in grave danger.
The organization said the police fired tear gas on Tuesday in a building that houses a prominent human rights organization. About 100 people, including women and children, were inside, Amnesty International said. Many were there to denounce what they said were police abuses when they broke the demonstration outside the Brazilian Embassy, the human rights group said.
The situation in Honduras can only be described as alarming, said Susan Lee, director of Amnesty International for the Americas. Attacks on human rights defenders, the suspension of the media, the beating of demonstrators by the police and the increasing reports of mass arrests indicate that human rights and the rule of law in Honduras are in grave danger.
It was not yet publicly known on Wednesday how Zelaya entered the country and refused to give details, just telling CNN in Spanish on Tuesday that it was a 15- to 16-hour trip he made with the help of Hondurans.
Journalist Elvin Sandoval contributed to this report for CNN in Spanish.
