Lakshmi Tatma, two years old, an Indian girl born with four arms and four legs, made her first public appearance on Tuesday, a week after surgeons in India successfully removed her extra limbs.
The doctors said Lakshmi was recovering well and appeared Tuesday at a press conference.
Lakshmi, carrying a cast lying on her legs to keep her feet up and her legs together to help heal her wounds, was taken to a press conference on Tuesday when her doctors announced that she would be released from intensive care.
“She is doing very well,” Chief Surgeon Dr. Sharan Patil said. It's taken by her mother and father.
Several of his doctors, all smiling, described his recovery during the past week as very steady and good progress, one of whom says he is out of danger in terms of serious medical problems. See the recovery of the girl know the media

The additional members of Lakshmi were part of a bonded twin that stopped developing in the uterus. He had a torso and limbs, but no head, and joined Lakshmi in the pelvis.
Doctors said that without surgery, Lakshmi would have been unlikely to survive beyond early adolescence.
The surgery involved removing the additional limbs and repositioning of Lakshmi's organs.
When Lakshmi was born into his poor Indian rural family, villagers in the remote settlement of Rampur Kodar Katti in the northern state of Bihar believed it to be sacred. As the news of their birth spread, the locals lined up to receive a blessing from the baby.
Her parents, Shambhu and Poonam Tatma, called the girl for the Hindu goddess of wealth that has four arms. However, they were forced to keep it hidden after men who offered money came to them in exchange for putting their daughter into a circus.
The couple, who earned only $1 a day as casual day laborers, wanted her to have the operation, but could not pay for the rare procedure, which had never been done in India before.
After Patil visited the girl in her village from Narayana Health City hospital in Bangalore, the hospital foundation agreed to fund the $200,000 operation.
Surgery planning took a month, Patil said, and Lakshmi spent that month in the hospital.

text:
If your vision of the world comes from watching the news and reading the newspapers, you could be forgiven for being awake at night worrying about the future. Apparently, increasing violence and population rates mean that human beings are killing each other in increasing numbers and are born at rates that the world's resources cannot sustain. To make matters worse, all wealth is concentrated in a handful of people in the richest countries in the world. People in low-income countries live in poverty while the West enriches. Depressive, isn't it?
But do statistics support our negative view of the world or is the world really improving?
Let's take the world's population first. It's about 7 billion now, in line with the figures predicted by the UN in 1958. By the year 2100, the same experts predict that it will be about 11 billion. But did you know that 11 billion is probably as high as that number will come? The rate of increase will decrease in the second half of this century due to the decline in birth rates today.
Falling birth rates? Yeah, that's right.
Over the past two centuries, improved technology and health have led to fewer young children dying, fueling rapid population growth. These numerous families produced even more children who survived adulthood and had their own children. However, with the increased availability of contraceptives in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six to two.
Poverty is the highest infant mortality factor. And while it is still true that only 20% of the world receives about 74% of the world's income, 60% of the world now falls into a middle-income group, with 11.6% – the lowest number of people in history – still living in extreme poverty. If most of the world's population has money, international aid could realistically achieve the United Nations goal of eradicating poverty by 2030. As poverty declines, life expectancy increases, birth rates decline because parents can expect their current children to survive and the world population to stabilize.
As for the news that makes us think that the world is an increasingly violent place, there is also reason for a certain optimism. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but most countries coexist more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has skyrocketed in recent years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. However, even for civilians, statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to result from violent crimes than from political conflicts, the global murder rate declined slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to approximately 5.3 in 2015.
Of course, none of this means that the world is perfect, and if you personally are affected by war and poverty is often reduced to the lottery from where you are born. Furthermore, we continue to face enormous problems of our own creation, in particular environmental ones, such as global warming, and wealth and natural resources must be distributed more fairly. But not all the news is bad news, whatever the television and the newspapers say.

text:
A proposal for a digital version of the university newspaper
Introduction
This proposal aims to outline how a digital version of the university newspaper, The Scallion, could work and aims to show that an online newspaper is viable for the future of the newspaper. It is based on the opinions of 3,000 students surveyed in May.
Background
The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free of charge in the faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural enrichment and work experience.
Current challenges
The cost of printing newspapers is significant. In addition, some students do not have easy access to the newspaper, as the only way to get a copy is to go to college physically. An additional environmental problem is that a large number of copies end up as garbage on campus.
Proposed solution
It is proposed that the newspaper be changed to an online format. An overwhelming majority (95%) of respondents were "keen" or "very interested" in this.
The main benefits would be:
Lower costs. Electronic publishing is much cheaper than printing, and the website would require minimal maintenance. Although the development of a website entails considerable initial costs, they would be offset over time.
Improving accessibility. Students unable to pick up a copy and those with visual impairments would be able to read the paper online.
Eco-friendlyness. A website would reduce paper use and not produce garbage.
Experience in digital media. For student journalists, gaining experience in managing a web-based news site would be invaluable for any work involving digital communication.
Inconvenient
One issue is information management. The site would have to comply with data protection and privacy laws. Advice should be sought from the IT department.
Another drawback may be personal preference. Twenty-five percent of respondents liked to have a physical newspaper in a coffee shop. However, since this is a minority view, I suggest that the benefits of the online document outweigh the drawbacks on this issue.
Conclusion
The results of the consultation suggest that moving the document online is the best option, as it would reduce costs, be more environmentally friendly and reach a wider audience. Therefore, a switch to a digital format is recommended to maintain the benefits of the newspaper while addressing its current difficulties.
label: C1

text:
Work on the world's largest solar bridge has begun in central London.
The new solar roof covering Blackfriars Railway Bridge over the Thames River will cover more than 6,000 square meters when it is finished, according to developers.
More than 4,400 individual photovoltaic panels are expected to produce about 900,000 kilowatts per hour of electricity each year, providing the station with half its energy needs, according to Solar Century, the British company that installs the solar roof.
Annual CO2 emissions are also expected to decrease by more than 500 tonnes.
It is fantastic to see that this project finally comes to a successful conclusion. Blackfriars Bridge is an ideal place for solar energy, said Derry Newman, CEO of Solar Century, in a statement.
For people to see that solar energy is working is a vital step towards a clean energy future, he added.
Built in 1886, the railway bridge is being transformed as part of an update of Network Rail -- the owner and operator of the railway infrastructure in the UK -- to the existing Blackfriars station.
The Victorian railway bridge in Blackfriars is part of our railway history. Built in the era of steam, we are updating it with 21st century solar technology to create an iconic station for the city, Lindsay Vamplew, Project Manager for Network Rail for Blackfriars said in a statement.
In addition to the solar panels -LRB- manufactured by SANYO Electric Co. Ltd -RRB-, the station will also include rain capture systems and solar tubes for natural lighting.
The solar roof and the new station will be completed by summer 2012.
label: C1

A: steve@red-ribbon.com
From: sanjit@red-ribbon.com
Subject matter: Questions relating to the process in the team

Dear Steve,
Since you asked me at our recent line management meeting to inform you of any problems, I am writing to tell you about a recent incident. Last week, after experiencing some difficulties with the order processing system, tensions arose in the equipment and there was a clash between two team members.
I have outlined what led to this incident as follows:
1. There was a system update we didn't expect last week. The update slightly changed the interface menu. Everything is still there, but people have said that it is not easy to find some of the menu items they are looking for.
2. There seems to have been a period of time after the update that the new entries were not being saved. This led to the loss of some work. We work overtime to catch up on everything and all orders have been processed. But as a result there was a general feeling of pressure and tiredness in the team.
As a result of these difficult circumstances there was some tension, leading to a disagreement between Johann and Mary. Johann lost his temper and made some inappropriate remarks to Mary.
I met with them to reflect and resolve the conflict. Johann has apologized for his behavior and realizes that Mary could have chosen to initiate disciplinary proceedings. They have worked together on a plan to improve communication and thus ease tensions within the team.
I have also asked our IT department colleagues to organize a training session for all of us on how best to use the system in the light of recent software updates.
There's no specific action you can take, but I thought it was important that you keep up with it.
I'll keep you posted.
Greetings,
Sanjit

text:
Shortly after visiting China for the first time in the fall of 1971, I saw a contingent of militia soldiers doing marching exercises in Tiananmen Square. I was told that they were rehearsing for the annual National Day parade on October 1, that people were eagerly waiting.
Mao Zedong proclaims the founding of the People's Republic of China in Beijing on October 1, 1949.
Weeks later, however, I was informed that the civil and military parade had been cancelled in the spirit of a simple and hard struggle, as President Mao decreed. The real reason: Lin Biao, then Defense Minister and Mao's anointed successor, would have died in a plane crash while trying to flee the country after a failed coup attempt.
China's achievements over the past 60 years have come in zigzags and zags. The best place to look back at what China has been through in the last six decades is Tiananmen, or the Gate of Heavenly Peace. Behind it is the Imperial Palace, or Forbidden City, where the emperors of China lived. The emperor is now history, but Tiananmen remains the political center of Beijing.
It was in Tiananmen's rostrum that President Mao formally proclaimed the foundation of the People's Republic. The Chinese people have risen! He declared with shrill Hungarian accent. For decades, the whole nation loyally followed Mao. He emphasized the political mobilization of the common man, especially the peasantry. In Mao's ideology, the Chinese people found hope in a New China, in which citizens would always have a bowl of rice to eat and clothing.
Mao proved to be good in the fight, but poor in government. He pushed for broad socio-economic initiatives and strident ideological campaigns, often with disastrous results. During two political campaigns in the late 1950s, more than 550,000 right-wing intellectuals were persecuted and imprisoned. The Great Leap Forward led to widespread famine and the death of some 30 million Chinese.
In the late 1960s, Mao again stood at the Tiananmen rostrum to launch the Cultural Revolution. There, he gathered hundreds of thousands of young Chinese -- the radical Red Guards -- who brought him in like a demi-god. It is justified to rebel! They proclaimed. They rebelled against everything and wreaked havoc everywhere. For ten years, China was condemned to political unrest and economic unrest. Perhaps the only factor that prevented the total collapse of the country was the incomparable resilience of the people and their ability to chi ku -LRB- eat bitterness, or endure difficulties -RRB-.
Mao's reign is also attributed to positive changes. It banned child brides and polygamy, built Beijing's first subway line, and launched a space program with the launch of China's first satellite. In 1972, the People's Republic of China replaced the Republic of China - LRB-Taiwan-RRB - at the United Nations.
However, for three decades under Mao, China tried to get out of its backwardness and isolation, but only achieved modest success.
Mao died in 1976 and his remains are preserved in a mausoleum in Tiananmen Square. Take an audio-visual tour of Mao's hometown
Soon, Deng Xiaoping became the new supreme leader. Deng revoked most of Mao's policies and embarked on reforming the economy and opening the country to the outside world.
Its quest for stability and prosperity took off in the early 1990s, driven by its pragmatic policies to attract foreign investment and build China's private sector.
Just south of Tiananmen, a landmark is a symbol of Deng's bold open-door policy. In the early 1980s, Kentucky's first exit Fried Chicken opened in Beijing, a stone's throw from Mao's mausoleum. Today, the fast food chain still does fast business, with a large portrait of the founder Colonel Sanders hanging in the three-story building.
Not all Chinese adopted Deng's policy of reform and open doors. The old guards and conservatives inside and outside the communist party accepted Deng's reform policies, but with a lot of distrust.
The reaction escalated in 1989, when Tiananmen witnessed an outpouring of support for students calling for freedom and democracy, and more reforms. After six weeks of intense demonstrations, the Tiananmen movement was brutally repressed. See iconic moments in China’s 60th anniversary
China has returned to world prominence through a 20-year economic boom, whose speed and breadth are unprecedented in human history. China moved from global economic irrelevance to the third largest economy in the world. The People's Liberation Army, which is no longer a scrap army, has emerged as a formidable military power capable of throwing a human being into space and tearing down satellites. Take a look inside China's space program
The People's Republic of China celebrates its 60th anniversary Thursday with 300,000 participants and 60 floats to highlight the country's achievements in various sectors of society and the economy. See the preparations for the anniversary in photos
A military parade will feature stepped troops marching along the Avenue of Eternal Peace. Modern military equipment -- tanks, armed personnel carriers, missiles, helicopters and combat aircraft, all manufactured in China, will be displayed. The fireworks will cover the festivities. See how China has changed over 60 years
But apart from pomp and spectacle, China’s extraordinary economic growth over the decades has led to unintended consequences: rising unemployment, growing income differences, endemic corruption, increased crime, environmental degradation and social unrest. Millions of Chinese live on less than $1 a day, and social tension sometimes turns into violent confrontations.
Chinese President Hu Jintao is pressing to promote democracy in the party, curb corruption and seek a harmonious society. To build a well-to-do society for 1.3 billion people and a democratic, civilized, harmonious and modernized country, he recently told a communist party meeting, China must firmly push reform and open up and follow its own path. Meet some of China’s Young Communists
Like the state-of-the-art CCTV tower that formally intended to open this year, but did not do so after a celebratory fireworks display went wrong and caused a fire, China’s great achievements remain alongside daunting challenges.
label: C1

text:
What do you need to map a billion stars? A billion-pixel camera certainly helps.
Scientists hope to get more clues about the origin and evolution of the universe, and in particular our own galaxy, after a camera of this incredible scale -- adjusted to the Gaia space telescope -- was launched on Thursday.
Gaia, who retired from French Guiana, has been in charge of mapping the Milky Way in greater detail than ever before.
Designed and built by Astrium for the European Space Agency - LRB-ESA -RRB-, manufacturers say that the telescope is so sensitive that it could measure a person's miniature from the Moon, or to put it another way, detect the width of a human hair from 1,000 km -LRB- 620 miles -RRB- away.
The objective of the mission is to construct a three-dimensional image of our galaxy, measuring precise distances to one billion stars. Even this is a small fraction of the Milky Way, as astronomers believe there are at least 100 billion stars in our galaxy.
Tens of billions like Earth, study says
Astrium says that Gaia will also record a million quasars beyond the Milky Way, and a quarter of a million objects in our own solar system, including comets and asteroids.
You can do it with incredible precision. It is the largest camera ever put into space, said Ralph Cordey, head of science and exploration at Astrium.
He said that the spacecraft cost 400 million euros - LRB- 549 million dollars -RRB- to build, but the total cost of the mission would be 740 million euros -LRB- 1.020 million dollars -RRB- when it includes the costs of launching and carrying out the mission for its expected life span of five years.
If it succeeds, Gaia will join the knowledge gained from the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, which is still in operation, and the ESA Hipparcos satellite, which collected data until 1993.
Hubble stains the blue planet where it can rain glass
The value of putting a billion-pixel camera into space has been defended by Robert Massey of the Royal Astronomical Society of the United Kingdom.
Gaia is an amazingly ambitious mission, he said.
So far astronomers have relied on very indirect methods to measure the distance to all but the nearest stars, which means that the basis on which we build a map of the universe is surprisingly weak.
Based on the work of the pioneer satellite Hipparcos who mapped the stellar neighborhood in the 1990s, Gaia will be used to carry out works similar to the cartographers who inspected the Earth in the 19th and 20th centuries, building the first exact charts of the cosmos and helping us to better understand the structure, history and destiny of the galaxy in which we live.
One of Gaia's goals is to help in the search for exoplanets -- new worlds beyond our own solar system.
NASA's Kepler mission has so far confirmed the existence of 167 exoplanets with hundreds more being investigated, but Cordey anticipates that Gaia will probably discover thousands of new planets, while other missions will be able to discover more details about them.
In a recent interview with CNN, George Whitesides, CEO of Virgin Galactica -- the company that plans to take tourists into space -- said he thought that within a lifetime it would be possible to detect stations on distant worlds.
You may not have much time to wait, as Astrium is already working on design concepts to examine exoplanets atmospheres, which can provide signs of seasonal variations.
We're designing missions that could probably do that... it's not science fiction, Cordey said.
label: C1

text:
Such is the fate of today's chemist: you expect ages for a new element to appear and then four come at once. Discovered by researchers from Japan, Russia and the United States, the four new elements are the first to be added to the periodic table since 2011, when elements 114 and 116 were included. The new elements, all spectacularly ephemeral and highly radioactive, complete the seventh row of the periodic table and make scientific textbooks worldwide obsolete.
The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), the world organization governing chemical nomenclature, terminology and measurement, verified the elements on 30 December 2015 after studying the studies carried out in 2004. Scientists who found them now must present formal names to replace the clumsy Latin-based position markers –ununntrium, ununpentium, ununseptium and ununoctium – which reflect their atomic numbers, 113, 115, 117 and 118. The atomic number is the number of protons found in the atomic nucleus of an element.
IUPAC announced that a Russian-American team of scientists from the Joint Nuclear Research Institute in Dubna and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California had submitted sufficient evidence to claim the discovery of elements 115, 117 and 118. The agency gave credit for the discovery of element 113, which had also been claimed by the Russians and Americans, to a team of scientists from the RIKEN Institute in Japan. The decision means that Japan becomes the first Asian country to name an element. Under IUPAC rules, new elements can be named by mythological concepts, minerals, a place or country, or a scientist.
When formal names were assigned to elements 114 and 116 in 2012, scientists chose flerovium and liver, respectively, after the Flerov Laboratory at the Dubna Joint Research Institute and Lawrence Livermore Lab in the United States, where the elements were discovered. Kosuke Morita, who led the RIKEN investigation, said his team now planned to “look at the unexplored territory of element 119 and beyond.” Jan Reedijk, president of IUPAC’s Inorganic Chemistry Division, said: “The chemical community is eager to see its most appreciated table finally complete to the seventh row.”
It is believed that the Japanese team is considering three names for ununtrium: japonium, rikenium and nishinarium, after the Nishina Center for Science Based on Accelerater, where the element was found. “They’ll have been thinking about it for a while,” said Polly Arnold, a chemistry professor at Edinburgh University. “This is a laborious job. All this trying to understand Mother Nature helps us with our models and with the understanding of radioactive disintegration. If we understand this better, I hope that we can better deal with nuclear waste and the things that are important in the real world. It also leads to fantastic technological advances in the construction of the kit to make these observations.”
Along with new names, scientists must propose two-letter symbols for the elements. When IUPAC has received the suggestions from the researchers, they will be subject to public review for five months. That allows scientists and others to raise any objections. In 1996, the Cp symbol was proposed for copernicium, or element 112, but was changed to Cn when scientists complained that Cp referred to another substance.
To discover the elements, the researchers of the three laboratories struck the lighter nuclei among themselves and sought characteristic radioactive decays that should come from the new elements. Ununtrium and ununpentium are believed to be metals, while ununseptium could be a metalloid, a material that possesses some metallic properties. The fourth element, ununoctium, can be a noble gas, like other elements of group 18, helium, neon and argon. It's hard to know for sure because so few atoms of each element have been made.
Paul Karol, president of the IUPAC panel that verified the elements, said: “For now, most of the successes will be used by nuclear theorists to improve their understanding of the structure and stability of these very heavy cores while the experimenters seek the supposed but highly likely “island of stability” in or near element 120 or perhaps 126. Those elements may have enough lives to explore their detailed chemistry. The practical applications of the new elements, if any, are far away because of the difficulty in synthesis.”
label: C1

text:
The client next to you in the queue seems pretty innocent. But, instead of a shopping list, note that it carries handwritten notes about the appearance and cleanliness of the store. She's been timing the tail progression on her phone... and is that a small camera lens sticking out of her purse? The odds are you just saw a mystery buyer.
According to the Mystery Shopping Providers Association, approximately 50,000 mysterious shopping trips are made each month in the UK and, as online spending increases, the demand for mysterious buyers increases. “Detailers are increasingly aware that buyers who are willing to set foot in a physical store want a service and experience they cannot get online,” says Simon Boydell, Marketforce spokesperson, who has over 300,000 mysterious buyers in his books. “Our customers want to measure how well their stores are doing with that experience.”
“We assign different store locations to each buyer and rotate them so that they never return to the same store within three months,” says Jill Spencer of the mysterious shopping company ABa. “Every day, they usually spend up to eight hours visiting from five to ten stores, plus another hour or two filing detailed reports on each aspect of their visit.” For that, mystery buyers can earn up to £155 a day. They are also reimbursed for petrol and hotel stays, and are compensated for the depreciation of their car (buyers can be expected to drive up to 20,000 miles a year). Meanwhile, buyers of mysterious videos, filming their visits with a hidden camera placed in an eyelet or purse, can earn even more, about 300 pounds a day.
Buyers are usually reimbursed for any money they spend in stores and can also be allowed to keep the products they buy. “I’m usually given between £5 and £20 to spend on each store, to evaluate the service I receive in the box,” says Laura, a 50-year-old mystery buyer from Devon, who has been paid to visit about 7,000 stores since 2001. The purchase usually has to be related to a service or a type of product that the retailer wants her to check. “I’m always given a scenario, like buying something from a specific department or a new range of products, but, within that framework, I can often buy whatever I want – and keep it.”
Like most full-time mystery buyers, Laura works on her own, taking jobs from ABa and other mystery shopping companies like and when they appear. Your income is typically from £30,000 to £40,000 a year and that does not include all the gifts you get at work. “With the advantages, it’s enough to live. But I don't because I love shopping. In fact, I hate shopping now. When I’m not working, it hurts me to have to go out and buy a pint of milk.” She, however, finds it satisfying to go back to a store she had previously bought mystery and see that standards have improved. “I know it must be because of my comments or why would they pay me to give it to me? Some of the retailers I buy in winning prizes for customer service and I think that's up to us mysterious buyers. I feel like I’m not just doing a service to my company; I’m doing a service to all buyers everywhere.”
Sadly, the regular assignments of mysterious purchases they pay like Laura's are few and far away. In fact, the competition is so fierce, it keeps its work secret and even its friends and family do not know who it works for (Laura is not his real name).
It is estimated that more than 500,000 people have registered as mysterious buyers in the UK, but only 10% or less manage to get regular work every month and this has led to a dramatic reduction in compensation. “When once you have a fee, refund for your purchase and mileage, now you often only get a contribution for a purchase,” says Val, a 51-year-old mystery former buyer. “I worked for 40 different mystery shopping companies for nearly 20 years, but I completely quit three years ago because I had accounts to pay and very few assignments paid what I considered an acceptable fee.”
Today, mysterious shopping companies rely mainly on the promise of freebies to incentivize their workers. “Market buyers usually receive a couple of pounds for a visit as a symbolic gesture for their time and effort,” Boydell says. “At most, we will pay 15 to 25 pounds more reimbursement for, for example, a meal for two or a stay in a hotel. We do not directly employ any buyer so we do not have to pay them the minimum wage.”
“I would go on a cruise for nothing,” says Laura. “But I think mysterious shopping companies that pay you a nominal fee to travel to a restaurant and eat a meal are exploiting people. I won’t touch those jobs anymore.” However, there are many people who would. Hannah, a 41-year-old city attorney, has carried out nearly 500 visits to the Mystery Dining Company in her free time without receiving remuneration or travel expenses. As a prestigious “platinum diner”, it is regularly chosen by hand by the Mystery Dining Company to carry out its most exclusive tasks, enjoying 200 £ meals in Michelin starred Mayfair restaurants, five-star hospitality in Ascot and stays in boutique hotels.
But there is no such thing as a free lunch, even if you work for a mystery restaurant company. Hannah says it usually goes from two to four hours after each visit by writing detailed reports about everything, from the quality of food to specific interactions with staff, who always need to be able to name or describe “usefully.” More difficult of all, you must memorize all these details while eating – of course, you can't write openly anything.
“There is much to remember and sometimes it can downplay the experience. You are expected to give feedback while it is cool, so I had to get up at 5am to write a report before working. It’s a difficult thing to do; you need to be focused, articulated and detail-oriented.”
label: C1

text:
As colorful fish swam next to him off the Greek coast, Cathal Redmond was convinced that he had taken some great pictures with his first underwater camera. But when he looked at the results on dry ground, the images were brown and cloudy. After taking the photos while holding his breath underwater, he blamed the limited time he had to prepare the shots. All he needed, the industrial designer thought, was a little more time to properly capture the fish in their natural environment.
He swore to make the little extra time he needed come true and the result is his invention of the Express Diving – a rechargeable air storage device, kept in his mouth, which allows users to swim underwater for two minutes. Its goal is to bridge the gap between snorkeling, with its limited scope, and diving, which gives divers the freedom to breathe underwater, but at the cost of using cumbersome and expensive equipment. The prototype of the invention, which is still in the initial stages of testing individual parts, looks like a crossing between a dive nozzle and a water bottle.
“I wanted to let people do more. So, instead of getting under the water and spending 30 seconds holding my breath, I wanted to do a little more than they could do,” says Redmond, 27. In 2006, the Irish designer completed a diving course and loved the feeling of being able to breathe underwater and observe fish in their natural surroundings. However, less pleasant were the fins, the weight belt, the neoprene suit, the air tank, the mask and all the rest of the equipment.
“I was well aware of the fact that I had about 50 kg tied to me and getting into the water was quite strange when you’re used to trying to stay on the surface. It was a very surreal experience,” he says. “The real problem is that it is very limiting in terms of what you can do. Although it allows you to stay underwater longer, you have to plan your entire day around it. You have 20 kg to 50 kg of equipment with you - you can't be walking on the beach and decide you want to enter. Planning is a very important part of it. It takes a lot. There is a lot of re-learning required.”
It was during a senior project for his degree in product design at Limerick University that Redmond produced the Express Dive. The device has two main parts. When above the surface, the unit uses a ventilator to vacuum air through a vent in the nozzle. The air, accelerated around the motorized turbine, is compressed through a series of valves and stored in the connected tank, which has a green blinking display light when it is full. When the air no longer enters, the vent goes out and, as the user dives, the air feeds through the nozzle.
That screen, which is in the user's eye, then acts as a health bar turning from green to red when the air runs out. The device can take enough air for two minutes of diving and takes about the same amount of time to be recharged. “When you put the compressor in the unit with all the rest of the stuff, batteries and electronics and membranes for the delivery of diving, the big trick was to be able to get small enough so that it could be held through the teeth and out of the mouth,” says Redmond.
Electrics are protected from housing water and recharged by inductive energy transfer – a system that uses an electromagnetic field, similar to pads that can wirelessly charge mobile phones, so there is no need for exposed cables.
Redmond says the nozzle feels similar to using a snorkel. It compares it to an extension of the lungs in which the user is taking a deep breath and then using it underwater. “It’s an extension of the body’s ability to store air,” he says. The prototype, made of high density foam, aluminum and silicone, has been tested in parts. Redmond says he has shown that the engine can compress two minutes of air in the unit and that the design can be effectively maintained in the mouth of the diver. What he hasn't done yet is test the device in a diver, completely submerged for two minutes. But, with enough evidence, Redmond is confident that he can get a fully functional device that doesn't endanger swimmers underwater.
Redmond recently arrived as runner-up of the International James Dyson Award, which will give him £5,000 to develop the project. The first indications are that the device would have a price of £280, he says, and is likely to weigh between 1kg and 3kg depending on the necessary safety features.
For anyone who thinks that two minutes of air is just a small improvement in snorkeling, Redmond says he could make all the difference underwater. The typical swimmer can hold his breath for about 40 seconds while under water, he says. “Two minutes isn’t much time, but it’s much longer than that,” he says.
label: C1

text:
One of the most influential figures in human history is Charles Darwin. Darwin has been called the father of evolution for his work in evolutionary science. In the United States, Darwin has become the symbol for atheists in the country, as his theory of evolution strikes against creationism. His theory states that all species on Earth have descended from their ancestors, and have adapted to their surroundings throughout history. He also claims that each species has a common ancestor. Darwin introduced his theory in his historical book on the origin of species in 1859.

His book was received with suspicion from both the scientific community and the general public, but by the 1870s, his work was beginning to gain massive acceptance. One of his most significant studies arrived when he sailed with the HMS Beagle, a British maritime vessel, to the Galapagos Islands. The islands have long been isolated from the South American continent, providing a unique vision of the evolution process.
While sailing from island to island, Darwin noticed similarities between island species and continental species. Most were similar in many ways, but some had subtle differences. He also found that the same species differed from island to island. For Darwin it was clear that the reason for the slight differences was the individual environment of each island. These islands showed Darwin the process of evolution in the process of elaboration.
Darwin has many critics of religious circles. A very famous Darwin cartoon depicting him as a half-human monkey was published in 1871 in response to his theory that humans evolved from monkey-like creatures. It spawned a movement of non-believers called Darwinism, which includes people who feel that their theories are rooted in the scientific method rather than religious dogma.
label: C1

text:
“There are certainly drug addicts MOOC, who take them for no other reason that they are not free and like to leave,” smiles Dr. Ben Brabon of Edgehill University, whose massive open-line course on vampire fiction is one of the two accredited MOOCs currently offered in the UK. Brabon is not denigrating people who enroll in MOOC courses: he is simply pointing out the motivation that drives certain people to enroll. When a course is open – MOOCs do not have enrollment criteria and do not have to pay fees – then participants will behave very differently from students in a traditional higher education environment.
MOOCs are the newest in the search to allow higher education for all. A large amount of venture capital is being invested in emerging online platforms, which allow the delivery of increasingly sophisticated and interactive course content to participants who can count on hundreds to tens of thousands. For these investors, the Holy Grail is to find a business model for MOOCs that makes them profitable – so far, the courses have depended on universities being prepared to finance the curriculum design of their star teachers and the time of online teaching. Extracting captured data on how, why and when millions of participants choose to enroll, interact with their material, send their tasks, communicate, and leave the course can be a way to get a return on investment.
However, part of the dilemma surrounding the direction the MOOCs will take in the future is that no one can define who they are intended to benefit exactly. Universities eager to attract international students who pay fees to postgraduate courses showing their best programs online? Are students in developing countries hungry for access to first world universities? Do employees want to develop their professional knowledge? People who lack qualifications and want to use MOOCs as a bridge to higher education? Or amateur students, who are interested in learning about a thematic area in which they have an interest?
Although they may be popular to start with, MOOCs have extreme termination rates, notes Brabon. For his vampire fiction course, that meant 1,000 inscriptions and 31 endings. “And almost all of them had a first degree or had been educated at grade level,” he says. “So the MOOC trend may not be opening up to sectors of the population that have not yet reached.”
“Learning online is a different thing, it needs quite advanced learning skills,” confirms David Kernohan, program manager for eLearning Innovation at Jisc, a charity that advocates the use of digital technologies in education and research in the UK. “With MOOCs, there is very little support available: the student drops off and tends not to receive any individual attention. While this may mean that online study is unattractive or difficult for someone without high-level qualifications, yes, he says, he suggests that MOOCs could be “a very good tool for continuing education.”
At a time when the number of part-time students has fallen sharply as the price of a degree increases, could this kind of open and open-access courses provide a new path to university education? Could a full degree be taught through MOOCs? “I don’t think MOOCs work that way,” says Brabon. Instead, he suggests “a mixed approach that combines a university experience with a MOOC; also, perhaps, the use of MOOCs to create a global degree, with students taking courses from all over the world, might be possible.”
But that's a bit in the future: for now, no future employer will worry a lot if you are shaking your MOOC completion certificate, without any quality assurance in the course content or your evaluation standards. Therefore, accreditation is now the central challenge for MOOCs to gain credibility with academics and employers, says Brabon, who is part of a Quality Assurance Agency working group, with the aim of developing an agreed approach to standards and marking.
There is idealism around the MOOC concept that brings the best of first world teaching to students from less developed countries. But there is also cynicism, with the suggestion that universities could use MOOCs to advertise their products on campus to a greater number of lucrative – though certainly not always wealthy – students from outside the EU.
Mike Sharples, president of Educational Technology, doesn't swallow that cynicism. MOOCs are seen primarily as a way to show and share the best teaching talent in universities, as well as encourage interaction and solicit feedback from students around the world, he says. He believes that recruiting international students in university courses is just a secondary goal of directing MOOCs – although they could certainly be a very canny marketing movement, as he notes that “if 20,000 people enroll in a MOOC – well, it only takes 20 of them to enroll later to lead a master’s degree.”
Meanwhile, any politically correct doubts about whether UK academic institutions are condescending with developing countries exporting small fragments of elitist education can soon be totally irrelevant, warns Matthew Poyiadgi, managing director of Pearson VUE. "I think we can come to a situation in the future where universities may have no choice, and where British universities are saying, "If we don't have a presence in China, then we'll be left behind," he says.
“In South America, China, countries in Africa, there is a huge appetite to learn and some of the best courses in the world are offered online,” Sharples adds. “If people are truly fascinated by learning, then why not? The real challenge is to allow these countries not only to consume and study MOOCs, but also to create them.”
label: C1

text:
Secretary of State Hillary Clinton was hospitalized on Sunday after doctors discovered a blood clot during a follow-up test related to a concussion she suffered this month, her spokesman said.
She is expected to stay at the Presbyterian Hospital in New York for the next 48 hours so that doctors can monitor her condition and treat her with anticoagulants, said Philippe Reines, Undersecretary of State.
Your doctors will continue to assess your condition, including other problems associated with your concussion, Reines said. They will determine whether further action is necessary.
Reines didn't specify where the clot was discovered.
Clinton, 65, suffered from a stomach virus earlier this month when she fainted due to dehydration, causing concussion.
Clinton spent the holidays with her family last week after working from home.
She was scheduled to return to work at the State Department this week after she had been marginalized for the past three weeks. Her illness forced her to withdraw from testifying on December 20 to the House Foreign Affairs Committee about the deadly attack on the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya. Deputies Thomas Nides and Bill Burns appeared in their place.
The medical setback occurs when Clinton is finishing his busy term as Secretary of State, during which he has recorded more than 400 days of travel and nearly a million miles. He plans to leave office when the Senate confirms President Barack Obama's decision to replace her.
label: C1

text:
The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used for large productions. On the edge of the Sahara Desert and in the center of the North African film industry “Ouallywood”, it has hosted large budget shots in Lawrence of Arabia, The Mummy, The Living Daylights and even Game of Thrones.
Now, the commercial city, nicknamed the “desert gate”, is the place for another blockbuster – a four-mega-connected solar plant complex, which, along with hydroelectric and wind power, will help provide almost half of Morocco’s electricity from renewable energy by 2020 with, it is expected, some spare to export to Europe. The project is a key point in Morocco's ambitions to use its unexploited deserts to become a global solar superpower.
When the entire complex is complete, it will be the largest concentrated solar power plant in the world and the first phase, called Noor 1, will become operational in November 2015. The mirror technology it uses is less widespread and more expensive than photovoltaic panels that are now familiar on roofs around the world, but will have the advantage of being able to continue producing energy even after the sun sets.
The solar energy potential of the desert has been known for decades. In the days following the Chernobyl nuclear accident in 1986, German particle physicist Gerhard Knies estimated that the deserts of the world receive enough energy in a few hours to meet the energy needs of mankind for a whole year. However, the challenge has been to capture that energy and transport it to the population centres where it is needed.
While engineers give the final touches to Noor 1, their 500,000 crescent-shaped solar mirrors shine across the desert horizon. The 800 rows follow the sun as it travels through the skies, buzzing silently every few minutes as its shadows slide further east.
When they are finished, the four plants of Ouarzazate will occupy a space as large as Rabat, the capital of Morocco, and will generate 580 megawatts (MW) of electricity, enough to feed a million homes. Noor 1 has a generating capacity of 160MW.
Morocco's Minister of the Environment, Hakima el-Haite, believes that solar energy could have the same impact on the region in this century as oil production in the last. But the $9 billion project to make your country's desert boom was triggered by more immediate concerns, he said.
“We are not oil producers. We import 94% of our energy as fossil fuels from abroad and that has great consequences for our state budget,” el-Haite told The Guardian. “We also used to subsidize fossil fuels, which have a high cost, so when we found out about the potential of solar energy, we thought, 'Why not? '"
Solar energy will account for one third of Morocco's renewable energy supply by 2020, with wind and hydropower in the same proportion.
“We are very proud of this project,” said el-Haite. “I think it’s the most important solar plant in the world.”
Each parabolic mirror is 12 meters high and focuses on a steel pipe that carries a "heat transfer solution" (HTF) that is heated to 393C as snakes along the channel before rolling into a heat engine. There, it mixes with water to create steam that rotates power generating turbines.
The HTF consists of a synthetic thermal oil solution that is pumped into a heat tank containing molten sands that can store thermal energy for three hours, allowing the plant to feed homes at night. Mirrors are spaced in level formations to minimize the damage of sand blown by desert winds.
Technicians say plants Noor 2 and 3, which will open in 2017, will store energy for up to eight hours, opening the perspective of 24/7 solar energy in the Sahara and surrounding region.
“The biggest challenge we faced was to be able to finish the project in time with the level of performance we needed to achieve,” said Rashid al-Bayad, the project director.
But, despite the fact that the first phase of the project is about to be completed, Morocco is observing great international ambitions. “We are already involved in high-voltage transport lines to cover the entire south of Morocco and Mauritania as a first step,” says Ahmed Baroudi, manager of the Société d’Investissements Energéticas, the national renewable energy investment company. But he says the final impact of the project will be much broader, even in the Middle East. The ultimate goal given by His Majesty the King is Mecca.
It remains to be seen whether this ambition is achieved, but the export of solar energy could have stabilizing effects within and among countries, according to the Moroccan solar energy agency (Masen). Discussions are under way with Tunisia and energy exports to the north throughout the Mediterranean remain a key objective.
“We believe it is possible to export energy to Europe but, first, we would have to build the interconnectors that do not yet exist,” said Maha el-Kadiri, Masen’s spokesperson. “Specifically, we would have to build interconnections, which would not go through the existing one in Spain, and then start exporting.”
Spain itself has banned new solar projects due to the lack of interconnectors to transmit energy to France. The EU has set itself the objective of ensuring that 10% of energy from each Member State can be transported abroad by cable by 2020.
In the meantime, Morocco focuses on using solar energy to meet its own resource independence needs. One day, this could include desalination of water, in a country that is increasingly affected by drought as the climate warms up. Officials are well aware of the functioning they are implementing in what is the most advanced renewable energy programme in the Middle East and North Africa region. “We are at the forefront of solar energy,” says el-Kadiri.
About $9 billion has been invested in the Noor Complex, much of it coming from international institutions such as the European Investment Bank and the World Bank and backed by guarantees from the Moroccan government. Undisclosed energy subsidies from Morocco's unelected ruler, King Mohammed VI, have prevented the cost from being transferred to energy consumers.
A month before the launch, more than a thousand workers, mostly Moroccans, continue to run to fix electrical cables, demolish scaffolding and wrap rock wool insulation around steel pipes. They pass busy in yellow and orange bibs, working 12-hour shifts on a backdrop of the Atlas Mountains. Harnesses with hammers and gloves tied to their belts swing from their sides. ubiquitous hard hats, security shoes and ear plugs give the scene a theatrical camp air.
For Hajar Lakhael, a 25-year-old security and environment manager from Meknes, rehearsals are almost finished and blockbuster production is almost ready for action.
“We’ve done the construction and, now, we’ll see what these projects look like when they start,” he says. “It’s exactly like preparing for a great performance.”
A global audience will be watching with interest.
label: C1

text:
More than a million British workers could be employed on zero-hour contracts, new figures reveal, suggesting that British companies are using controversial employment terms much more widely than previously thought.
The figure – derived from a survey of more than 1,000 employers by the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD) – prompted new calls for the government to launch a full investigation into the use of contracts, after a week in which a number of organizations – from retail chains to Buckingham Palace – have been criticized for hiring staff but do not offer job and pay guarantees every week. Employees on zero-hour contracts often do not receive vacations or sick pay and have to apply for leave before seeking additional work elsewhere. The ICPD found that 38% of zero-hour contract workers describe themselves as full-time employees, usually working 30 hours or more a week. One third of employers in the voluntary sector use contracts and one in four public sector organizations.
The latest issues also cast doubt on the accuracy of official data on the subject. The National Statistical Office has increased its estimate of the number of workers in the United Kingdom from zero hours by 25 per cent to about 250,000.
Peter Cheese, the executive director of the ICPD, said: “It is necessary to examine more closely what a zero-hour contract means, the different forms it takes and clearer guidance on what good and bad practices are like in its use. And this must take into account both the advantages and disadvantages in practice for companies and employees.”
Retailer Sports Direct recently became the focus of controversy in zero hours when it emerged that the company employs about 20,000 of its 23,000 employees in contracts. The use of the contracts by the retailer was followed by details of a number of other companies using the offers, including the film chain Cineworld and Buckingham Palace, which uses them for their 350 summer workers.
The J D Wetherspoon Pub Group has 24,000 employees (80 per cent of its staff) on established terms.
Vidhya Alakeson of the Resolution Foundation, an independent think tank, added: “If it is true that there are about a million people on zero-hour contracts, then that would be a substantial part of the workforce – this could no longer be ruled out as a problem affecting only a small minority.
“The new estimate underlines the urgent need for a thorough and thorough review of zero hours by the government, taking into account not only the magnitude of the problem, but also the impact these contracts have on workers’ labour rights, earning capacity and personal well-being.”
Trade unions and anti-poverty groups have accused employers of pressuring staff to sign contracts in order to evade their responsibilities and reduce staff benefits.
Dave Prentis of the Unison union said: “The vast majority of workers only have these contracts because they have no choice. They can give flexibility to a few, but the balance of power favors employers and makes it difficult for workers to complain.”
Workers on zero-hour contracts are often only told how many hours they go to work when weekly or monthly shifts are made, but are expected to be on call for additional work in a short time. They must be entitled to holiday payments based on the number of hours they work, but they do not qualify for sickness benefit.
The National Trust charity, which employs many of its seasonal workers on zero-hour contracts, said it offered the same salary and benefits to those prorated workers as full-time staff, but needed some workers to be in a more flexible arrangement.
“We believe that zero-hour contracts are essential in our organization, as we depend a lot on the weather,” said a spokesperson. “Our properties have told us that it is important to be able to reorganize staff shifts quickly to respond to time and zero-hour contracts allow us to do this.”
Politist Chuka Umunna said contracts should be the exception to the rule. “While some employees welcome the flexibility of such contracts, for many, zero-hour contracts leave them insecure and insecure of when the job will come,” he said.
Some people have argued that the flexibility of zero-hour contracts may have allowed the UK to avoid higher levels of unemployment during the economic recession, while ICPD research suggests that only 16% of those with zero-hour contracts report that their employer often does not provide them with enough hours each week.
The Institute ' s figures also suggest that 17 per cent of private sector employers used zero-hour contracts, significantly less than 34 per cent of voluntary sector organizations and 24 per cent of the public sector.
The industries in which employers were most likely to report at least one person on a zero-hour contract were hotels, restaurants and leisure (48 per cent), education (35 per cent) and health care (27 per cent).
label: C1

text:
Wales will become the first country in the UK where people will be presumed to have given their consent to have their organs donated unless they choose not to.
The Welsh Assembly has voted for the adoption of the voluntary exclusion policy, which will allow hospitals to act on the assumption that people who die want to donate unless they have specifically registered an objection.
The final stage of a bill to approve a system of presumed consent was adopted by 43 votes to 8, with 2 abstentions, despite objections by religious groups on moral grounds and concerns that the plan might add to the distress of grieving families.
“This is a great day for Wales, for decentralization and, more importantly, for the 226 people in Wales waiting for an organ transplant,” said Wales Health Minister Mark Drakeford.
“I am proud that Wales is the first nation in the UK to take this step. As a society, we have shown that we are ready to take steps to increase organ donation and give hope to people who expect a transplant every week.
“Family denial is an important factor affecting the number of organ donations and the main reason for the refusal is the lack of knowledge of your loved one’s wishes.
“The family of the potential donor has an important role to play in organ donation. The aim of the bill has always been to respect the wishes of the deceased; however, family members or friends may object to consent being considered to be based on what they know about the opinions of the deceased.
“When family members know that organ donation is what the deceased would have wanted, they usually agree to participate in the donation process. The new law will work by clarifying people's wishes on the issue of organ donation and, in turn, increasing the rate of consent to donation.
“Today is a historic day for Wales and I hope the rest of the UK is watching with great interest when legislation is implemented in 2015.”
The issue is controversial, and opponents are concerned that the pressing need for more kidneys and hearts will lead to the wishes of those who have died and that their family will be nullified. But ministers insist that there will be safeguards.
Inevitably, some people do not come close to registering their opposition. In response to concerns, the government recently announced that families would play a more important role.
Family members must have a “clear right of objection”, giving them the opportunity to prove that the deceased would not have wanted to be an organ donor.
Wales has acted because of an acute shortage of organs. “We have the permanent problem of not having enough organs for people who need them,” Drakeford said. “Almost one person dies every week in Wales while on a waiting list. We've been working to improve the organ donation rate and we've had some success, but we're looking to take the next step forward.
“Around one third of the Welsh population is on the organ donor registry, but more than two thirds in the polls say they are happy to be organ donors. That other third are the people who don't come up with their names. We hope to make progress on that.”
The new law would apply to any person over the age of 18 who has lived in Wales at least one year before his or her death. The donated organs would go not only to people who need a transplant in Wales, but to anyone in the UK.
The doctors are delighted with the move. The British Medical Association has long campaigned for a system of voluntary exclusion due to its concern over the growing number of people in need of transplants as a result of medical progress in transplantation.
The number of young donors decreased significantly when the seatbelt legislation came into force. In recent years, great efforts have been made to increase the number of people carrying an organ donation card, with great success. Hospitals have also introduced improved systems for coordinating transplants, including crucial discussions with family members when there is no indication of the wishes of the deceased. But the increase in the number of organs harvested is still not enough.
Some religious groups, on the other hand, strongly oppose the plan, arguing that it would cause further distress to the failing relatives. Members of the Muslim Council of Wales and the Council of Jewish Representatives of South Wales have expressed reservations, while the Archbishop of Wales, Barry Morgan, said that “donation must be a gift of love, of generosity. If organs can be taken unless someone has explicitly registered an objection, that is not an expression of love. It is more a medical use of a body.”
label: C1

text:
Male bosses are being paid bonuses that double the size of those given to female partners in identical positions, a disparity that means that men enjoy a wage increase of £141,500 more than women throughout their working life.
The figures, published by the Chartered Management Institute (CMI), reveal that men in managerial positions in the United Kingdom earned average premiums of £6,442 in 2012, compared to £3,029 for women. In the highest positions, female directors received premiums of £36,270 over the past 12 months, compared with £63,700 for male directors.
The latest figures highlighting the inequity of remuneration in British companies led to calls for action by activists for equality in the workplace. Ann Francke, executive director of CMI, said: “It’s time to move this issue to the top management agenda.
“It’s about changing our management approach to allow for greater flexibility, fewer male cultures, more emphasis on results rather than office time, and greater transparency around performance and rewards. “In resolving this issue, we actually raise the performance of organizations and the well-being of people at work. What are we waiting for?” added Dr. Ruth Sealy, senior researcher at the Cranfield School of Management: “It’s not surprising. Bonuses are a method of payment that can be used with discretion. As for what needs to be done in this regard, these things must be made more transparent.”
While statisticians warned that some of the data may be skewed by factors such as women entering occupations where there is less bond pay culture, discrepancies in the size of awards seem to aggravate Britain's pay gap, which the government says is closing, but still sees full-time male employees earn 10% more than women.
Maria Miller, Minister of Women and Equality, said: “The CMI figures are another harmful example that highlights that, in the world of work, women continue to lose to their male counterparts and that the playing field is far from leveled. “The changes in the workplace are happening and it is good that the pay gap is closing, but much remains to be done before we see full equality in the workplace.
“The government is playing its part: we have outlawed wage secrecy clauses, given the courts the power to force employers who violate wage equality laws to conduct wage equality audits and signed 120 companies up to our Think, Act, Report plan, which encourages businesses to improve the way they hire, promote and pay women. “We have also examined other causes of wage gap, such as having to juggle work and family responsibilities, introducing shared parental leave and the right to apply for flexible work from all employees.”
Large companies such as Tesco, BT, Unilever and the international law firm Eversheds are among those registered in Think, Act, Report. The plan has attracted only 120 supporters in almost two years of existence, with an increase of 54 participants in November 2012. However, the CMI data did provide some evidence to support Miller's claim that the overall wage gap is narrowing: the difference between the average wages of male and female chiefs appears to have decreased, from an average of £10,060 in 2012 to £8,502 in the most recent CMI figures. However, the institute warned against direct comparisons between the 2012 and 2013 samples – which polled around 40,000 managers – as they are not identical.
A subset of 17,000 individual managers, whose salaries and bonuses have been followed over several years, showed that the income of male managers is increasing faster than that of women for the first time in five years, and men enjoy total increases of 3.2 per cent compared to 2.8 per cent for women when wages and premiums are combined.
At the highest level, the income of male directors increased by 5.3 per cent in the last 12 months, compared with only 1.1 per cent for female directors.
label: C1

text:
With a list of star customers including Catherine Zeta-Jones, Lindsay Lohan, Julia Roberts and Michelle Pfeiffer, Trelise Cooper is an internationally known fashion designer.
Starting with a boutique shop in Auckland, New Zealand, in the mid-1980s, Cooper's rise to the fashion stage -- and the cover of Vogue and Marie Claire -- is made more remarkable by the fact that he never received any formal training as a designer or seamstress.
Instead, Cooper relied on his self-confessed obsession with detail as well as a natural eye for fashion. I was born a fashion designer, she says, and shortly after setting up a shop, her clothes acquired a reputation for their bold use of patterns and intricate seams.
Cooper took on the challenge of Fusion Journey to travel from New Zealand to New Delhi, the capital of India. Although it is a city he had been on business many times before, he says he had never been allowed to study his traditional dress seriously.
See more Merging trips
There he was commissioned to create a new fashion line that would combine his own sophisticated modern style with the vibrant colorful traditions of Indian sewing.
In his own words, Cooper takes up the steps of his Fusion journey.
Trelise Cooper: I love the historical aspect of clothing. My ranges are full of influences from 19th century French, English, even vintage American styles. So I'm not surprised you've always enjoyed combing flea markets in small towns and finding rare old jewelry to steal some inspiration.
I am also obsessed with details, so when I find a Victorian dress or a fifties wedding slip that I like, then it is important for me to be able to emulate the exact sewing, embroidery or beads used at that time. In the West, unfortunately, most of our expert hand-sewing traditions have been lost; the skills have not been passed on and the sewing geniuses of Europe's sewing houses have not been replaced.
That's why I often travel to India. It is one of the best places in the world to find that experience continues to thrive. From one village to another there are whole families, generations, who have their own specialities of stitch work.
Honestly, I can give you any old historical piece I've found and either you'll take it and recreate it almost perfectly, or you'll say hmmm... I don't know this seam, but I know a nearby place that does. It's a fashion designer's dream!
So in a sense, I've been merging my clothes with Indian influences for a while. However, I think this was the first time I traveled to India with the conscious intention of creating a fusion of styles: his own traditional dress with my most modern and western creations.
I love the color and vitality that is India. New Delhi is exciting and chaotic and noisy and dusty and smoked and hot. Everything is so full of intense color and I realized that, on a subconscious level at least, I have been influenced by the Indian style... In fact, when it comes to the bold use of colors and the use of these rich and deep dyes, how can anyone deny India's enormous influence on fashion all over the world?
Walking through the streets, you see combinations of colors that you would never imagine would work. I remember a beautiful woman wearing a bright and radiant rose sari mixed with a lime green print. I mean lime and rose! It sounds elegant, but in it, with the quality of the dye and the way in which the colors had been combined it looked absolutely impressive.
We made our way to a store that I can only describe as a treasure of fabrics and other treats. This was the place to find all the accessories, textiles, ribbons, bows, buttons, and beads that I could take back to my studio in Auckland to use as inspiration for the final creations.
There were ideas there, old and new, that I had never thought about. I could already imagine opportunities to use all kinds of different laces and braids, detailed examples of hand seams, with some other old dresses that we had collected from a local supplier.
As much as I love them personally, I don't sell things like saris -- and I never would -- it's not a style that attracts the tastes of my particular customers. However, what I brought back to New Zealand was its techniques, its intense colors of celebration, its embellishments details, its expert use of beads and sequins.
I worked on the new line for many months, and these are the elements that I hope I have succeeded in incorporating into them. I think they've added an opulence, an affair. But I'll only know that I've finished the creative process when someone comes in and says, whatever happens, they have to have it.
The garment carries them on a journey, and so my journey with the garment is over.
label: C1

text:
David Mitchell, a regular contender for the Man Booker literary prize, is used to his novels that are chosen by critics. Therefore, it is a relief, says the British author, that his last work – finished at 1:00 a.m. on Tuesday before a car arrived to take him to the airport to take a flight to Norway – is not seen by anyone until 2114.
Mitchell is the second contributor to the Future Library project of Scottish artist Katie Paterson, for which 1,000 trees were planted in 2014 in the Nordmarka forest of Oslo. Starting with Margaret Atwood, who delivered the manuscript of a text called Scribbler Moon in 2015, each year for the next 100 years, an author will deliver a piece of writing that will only be read in 2114, when the trees are cut to make paper on which the 100 texts will be printed.
Each author – his names revealed year after year and chosen by a panel of experts and Paterson, while alive – will walk to the place in the high forest over Oslo, where they will deliver their manuscripts in a brief ceremony.
“It’s a little ray of hope in a season of highly depressing news cycles, which claims we’re on a civilizational opportunity in a hundred years,” Mitchell said. “Everything tells us that we are doomed, but the Library of the Future is a candidate on the ballot for possible futures. It brings hope that we will be more resilient than we think: that we will be here, that there will be trees, that there will be books and readers, and civilization.”
Mitchell said he found writing the book “very liberating because I will not be around to take the consequences of whether this is good or bad... But, I am interspersed between Margaret Atwood and certainly some other brilliant writer. So it better be good. What a historical fool of age proportions I would look at if it were opened in 2114 and not good.”
Usually, says Mitchell, who was shortlisted for the Man Booker for his 9dream and Cloud Atlas novels, he “pulsed and polished” his writing. “Actually, I exaggerate. But, this was very different – I wrote down the cable. Therefore, the first two thirds were polished and the last third had no time. And it was a liberation.”
The future creator of the Library, Paterson, whose past works have involved her mapping of dead stars and the compilation of a slide archive of the history of darkness over the centuries, asked writers to address “the theme of imagination and time, which they can take in so many directions.” Mitchell revealed only the name of the manuscript, From Me Flows What You Call Time, during a ceremony in the Norwegian forest next to where the 1,000 Paterson trees are planted. The title is taken from a musical piece by Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu but, apart from admitting that “it is something more substantial than I expected,” the author would say nothing.
Delivering his text in the forest, protected from intermittent rain by an umbrella and amidst the shoots of 1,000 high pines, Mitchell read his wet audience of children and adults a short story and William Wordsworth's dream made my spiritual seal. Its end, “Round rolling in the daytime course of the earth / With rocks, stones, and trees”, felt appropriate in this small section of forest, carpeted with blueberry bushes, which will be carefully attended by the next 98 years before it becomes manuscripts of the Library of the Future.
“How vain to suppose that the doodles of the little old self will be of lasting interest to future generations. However, how discreet and discreet, to enslave upon a manuscript for which no one is going to pat you on the back and say, ‘Good ’ or ‘ God, I loved how little she did that and he did this... ’” Mitchell wrote in a piece for the Library of the Future.
Your manuscript, now handed over, will be sealed and placed next to Atwood’s in a wooden-covered room in Oslo’s new public library, which will open in 2019. Watched by a trust of experts until it is finally printed, it is now, says the novelist, “it has disappeared from me like a coin that fell into a river.”
label: C1

text:
Four positive books about the world
Reality – Hans Rosling with Ola Rosling and Anna Rosling Rönnlund
Actually, Professor Hans Rosling, along with two collaborators, asks simple questions about the world. Questions like "How many girls finish school?" and "What percentage of the world's population is poor?" It turns out that most of us have the answers to these completely wrong questions. Why is this happening? Reality aims to explain why, showing that there are several instincts that humans have to distort our perspective.
For example, most people divide the world into US and ELLOS. Besides, we often think things are getting worse. And we're consuming large amounts of media that use a sales model based on making us afraid.
But according to the authors, the world is not as bad as we think. Yes, there are real concerns. But we must adopt a mindset of factfulness – just bring opinions that are supported by strong facts. This book does not address the underlying reasons for poverty or progress, or what needs to be done on these issues. It focuses on our instinctive prejudices, offering practical advice to help us see the good and the bad in the world.

Lighting now – Steven Pinker
Do things get worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Illustration Now, Steven Pinker looks at the overall picture of human progress and finds good news. We live longer, healthier, freer and happier lives.
Pinker asks us to stop paying so much attention to negative headlines and news that they declare the end of the world. Instead, it shows us some carefully selected data. In 75 striking graphics, we see that security, peace, knowledge and health are improving all over the world. However, when the evidence does not support his argument, he dismisses it. Economic inequality, he says, is not really a problem, because in reality it is not so important for human well-being. One cannot help but wonder how many people actually living in poverty would agree.
The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the values of the Enlightenment of Reason and Science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to tribalism, fatalism and people's distrust, then we run the risk of causing irreparable damage to important institutions such as democracy and global cooperation.

The Rational Optimist – Matt Ridley
For more than 200 years pessimists have been winning the public debate. They tell us things are getting worse. But in fact, life is improving. Income, food availability and service life are increasing; diseases, violence and infant mortality are declining. These trends are happening all over the world. Africa is slowly emerging from poverty, just like Asia before. The Internet, mobile phones and world trade are greatly improving the lives of millions of people.
The best-selling author Matt Ridley not only explains how things are improving; he also gives us reasons why. It shows us how human culture evolves in a positive direction thanks to the exchange of ideas and specialization. This bold book analyzes all human history, from the Stone Age to the 21st century, and changes the notion that everything is going downhill. The glass is half full.

The Great Surgeon – Steven Radelet
Most people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: they suffer from incredible poverty, ruled by dictators and with little hope for significant change. But, surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is that a great transformation is taking place. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their incomes and emerged from poverty. In addition, six million fewer children die each year from disease, millions more girls attend school and millions of people have access to safe drinking water.
This is happening in developing countries around the world. The end of the Cold War, the development of new technologies and courageous leadership have helped to improve the lives of hundreds of millions of people in poor countries.
The Great Wave describes how all this is happening and, more importantly, shows us how we can speed up the process.
label: C1

text:
