text:
Two weeks after the end of the U.S. government and, days before a possible breach, President Barack Obama has made one last attempt to restore credibility to the world's largest economy.
By proposing Janet Yellen as president of the powerful Federal Reserve, the president has tried to calm the markets that have already been affected by Washington D.C. disputes.
Do investors care if Yellen is a woman? Of course not, I hear you crying. What they care about is whether you're going to print more cheap money and keep rates low.
The most powerful woman you've ever heard of
But apart from her immediate inclinations in quantitative easing, Yellen's nomination is an important milestone for women's representation in the world of monetary policy.
Why? Because for the first time a woman is being entrusted with the value not only of any currency but of the most important reserve and trading currency in the world.
Their actions will affect the lives of millions of people in the country and abroad, giving patriarchal societies a pause to reflect.
READ MORE: Horrible way to fill one of the most powerful jobs in the world
Women may not be allowed to vote in Saudi Arabia, for example, but the country's main export, oil, has a price of dollars. Men can dominate the financial sector, but for the next four years they will have to hold on to every word of a woman.
However influential it may be, Yellen cuts a solitary figure in the global central bank organization chart, especially in Europe, where both the ECB and the Bank of England are currently devoid of female power at the top of the tree.
A superficial look at the Central Bank Board shows that only 12 of the world's 160 central banks had women governors last year. That's about 6%. Such figures would not be acceptable on the board of your mid-list company.
Last year, 15% of the directors of FTSE 100 companies were women, while the EU is pushing for management boards to increase that quota to 40% by the end of the decade.
READ MORE: Women are still missing on Asian boards
Yellen is not an ordinary woman or economist. She is an extraordinarily experienced and trusted pair of hands that faces a formidable task ahead of her in trying to wean the world's five-year money markets basically for free.
But by raising it to the helm, the Federal Reserve joins an unfortunately short list of national banks with governors that includes countries not exactly influential such as Belarus, the Kyrgyz Republic and Samoa.
Although her appointment has yet to be approved, Yellen's promotion will make her the second most powerful person in the United States.
If women can take on such a large position as that, it is surely time for them to have more voice in the clubby world of monetary policy.

A suspected leader of the Juárez drug cartel told the authorities that he had ordered the death of some 1,500 people, a Mexican federal police official said on Sunday.
Federal police detailed charges against José Antonio Acosta Hernández, known as El Diego, a day after authorities announced his arrest. He was one of the most wanted criminals in the country, with officials offering a reward of 15 million pesos - LRB- $1.3 million -RRB- for his arrest.
Collaboration with the U.S. Drug Administration led to the arrest of Acosta, said Eduardo Pequeno, head of the Mexican federal police anti-drug unit.
Acosta is accused of being a leader of the drug gang known as La Linea, the application arm of the Juarez cartel, the Mexican authorities have said.
Pequeno told journalists that Acosta said he ordered the murder of some 1,500 people, mostly in Ciudad Juárez and the capital of Chihuahua.
An investigation points to Acosta as the brain behind the murder of three people related to the U.S. Consulate in Juarez, Pequeno said.
More recently, Acosta ordered operatives to hang banners with threatening messages addressed to the DEA and other U.S. authorities, Pequeno said.
Juárez, Mexico's most violent city, shares a border with El Paso, Texas.
Pequeno also accused Acosta of having connections to some of the most notorious acts of violence in the border city over the past two years, including the murder in 2010 of a state prosecutor, a car bomb outside a police station, and a massacre at a party that killed 15 people, most of them students with no links to organized crime.
Acosta told the authorities that the targets of his criminal organization were police, government officials, rival drug gangs and civilians, Pequeno told reporters.
Earlier this month, the U.S. consulate in Juárez issued a statement warning U.S. citizens to remain vigilant based on information they had received that cartels could attack the consulate or entry points on the U.S.-Mexico border.
The northwest of the Mexican state of Chihuahua, which contains the capital, as well as Juárez, has been a breeding ground for drug-related violence.
The federal government has been attacking cartel operations, and especially its leaders, in an ongoing battle.
Mexican authorities have arrested several others accused of being related to the murder of three persons related to the consulate last year.
The shootings occurred on March 13, 2010, when consulate employee Lesley Enriquez and her husband Arthur Redelfs were shot to death as they left a birthday party in their white SUV.
Jorge Alberto Salcido Cinderos, husband of another consulate employee, was killed in a separate vehicle.

text:
Unveiling the complex stories of the more than 200 pardons issued by the former governor of Mississippi. Haley Barbour is revealing serious questions about how the pardon review decisions were carried out.
But maybe no forgiveness is as confusing as the case of Harry Bostick. The pardon of the retired Internal Revenue Service investigator has been called atrocious by Barbour critics.
Someone did not do their homework on this case, said Democratic State representative Steve Holland.
When Barbour pardoned Bostick in January, the DUI convict was sitting in a cell in Oxford, Mississippi, for violating the terms of an earlier DUI sentence and was awaiting formal charges of another drunk driving accident in October that ended in the tragic death of 18-year-old Charity Smith. Who is to blame in that accident has not yet been determined.
Okolona's teenager, Mississippi, had great dreams of saving money and going to college to get a degree in business. The young woman's death and the controversy surrounding the case have devastated Linda Smith, Charity's mother.
She should still be here with me. She should still be here with me. This shouldn't have happened, Linda Smith told CNN during a two-hour emotional interview.
Bostick was pardoned for a serious crime of drunk driving dating back to March 2009. That crime was Bostick's third drunk driver's arrest in just over a year.
The Mississippi and Barbour Parole Board have issued statements saying they didn't know Bostick had another DUI arrest in October. He arrived after his pardon case had already been reviewed.
Oxford Police Sergeant. Hildon Sessums arrested Bostick twice for a one-year DUI period.
Just before I put the handcuffs on him, he said, "Don't do this to me."And my comment to that usually is, you did it to yourself, Sessums told CNN as he related details of the two arrests.
By the third DUI, Bostick had been sentenced in March 2010 to one year's house arrest and four years in the Mississippi drug court program, an intensive drug and alcohol abuse treatment program with strict guidelines that convicted offenders like Bostick must follow.
Bostick was still going through the drug court program when he started applying for a pardon last summer. High profile friends wrote letters to Barbour promoting what they called Bostick's genuine lifestyle change.
The letters detail what friends described as Bostick's slide into alcoholism after the tragic death of his teenage son in a strange fire in the house and after Bostick's divorce, according to documents of pardon and parole obtained by CNN.
One letter said that Bostick no longer drinks alcohol and has changed his life.
Harry Bostick has led a tragic life. A life that has now been changed by a grace that is greater than he. Now it can be a positive factor in many lives, wrote retired US attorney Jim Greenlee.
On September 30, the Mississippi Parole Board sent its review of the Bostick case to Barbour. The board recommended Bostick for a full pardon with a split vote of 3-2.
About a week later, on October 7, Bostick drove under the influence again, according to the Mississippi Highway Patrol. Charity Smith tried to get off a highway just outside Tupelo when Bostick's truck crashed into one side of his car.
Charity Smith was murdered and her older sister suffered serious injuries.
Bostick has not yet been charged by a grand jury in that accident. Because his third DUI was pardoned, a conviction in DUI's last case would technically be his third offense, but that would make him a felony in Mississippi.
The Mississippi and Barbour Parole Board are at a loss to explain how Bostick's forgiveness could have developed the way he did. State officials say there is no mechanism to alert them to situations like this.
A Department of Corrections spokesman referred all questions about the case to the Mississippi Parole Board.
Bostickspardon application package sent from the Parole Board to the governor's office is full of references to the accelerated investigation into the circumstances surrounding Bostick's crime, i.e. his third DUI of 2009.
According to a state prison official, the accelerated rush was the result of a flood of pardon requests as the clock was counting towards the end of Haley Barbour's term as governor.
Barbour rejected CNN's request for an interview, but its spokesman, Laura Hipp, issued a statement.
In reviewing Mr. Bostick's case, the governor. Barbour took into consideration the recommendation of the Parole Board, and was not aware of subsequent charges, he said.
Shannon Warnock, president of the Mississippi Parole Board, issued a statement saying: I can say that Mr.Bostick's request was supported by testimonies from reliable and prominent members of the community. While the reported circumstances of such detention are worrying, our justice system considers everyone innocent until proven guilty.
Linda Smith, Charity's mother, worries that her teenage daughter's death has been forgotten in all of this. She struggles to understand how state officials could not have known that the man involved in her daughter's violent accident was the same Harry Bostick who had applied for a pardon.
It was a person. She wasn't just a name on a piece of paper. “A beautiful person,” Linda Smith said.
His days are now spent crying over his daughter's death.
She cried during most of her interview with CNN while showing pictures of the beautiful girl with great dreams.
Linda Smith described her daughter as an artist with a great heart, and proudly spoke of the powerful emotions she feels holding a collection of her daughter's paintings.
One of the paintings was a gift from Charity Smith to her mother. Instead of signing the painting, Charity left her handprint on the back.
But perhaps the most touching painting was of rotating blue and purple and orange that says life is short.
The girl with the artist's heart now laments for her mother with her heart broken.

text:
It could be the best thing since Trevor Baylis's radio on the pre-internet of 1990, a cheap light that takes energy out of gravity and could end the use of dangerous kerosene-powered lamps in Africa and India.
But when British designer Patrick Hunt went through the conventional bank or venture capital route to get his invention started commercially, he had a problem. “We’re trying to get funds to make this happen, but it’s slow and complex and untested and nobody wants to take a risk,” he said.
So he tried crowdfunding on an American website, Indiegogo, which had recently opened in the UK. In five days, he had reached his goal and raised £36,200. So popular was his campaign in late 2012 to attract donations from the public that in 40 days he had raised a colossal £400,000.
LED light is powered by a dynamo driven by the descent of a bag of 10 kg of rocks. The weight is attached to the light, raised to a height of about 2m, and while it is allowed to fall slowly to the ground it will generate enough energy for half an hour of light.
Hunt is preparing for production in China and will test the market again by delivering 1,000 of the lights to Africa before full mass production of what he expects to be millions of units.
He is one of a new wave of entrepreneurs turning to the fast-growing crowdfunding industry for finance. Another new site is InvestingZone, which combines rich individuals with start-up entrepreneurs.
Indiegogo does not offer actions, but it allows users to offer “perks” for different levels of donation – those who help fund Hunt’s innovative light not only have to feel good to help the less rich, but also have their own light.
For Danae Rigelmann, co-founder of Indiegogo, “gravity light” is a perfect example of how meritocratic crowdfunding can be and how it can test an entrepreneur’s idea. “It’s the first time that finance has been fast, efficient and meritocratic, because it’s not about ‘How can I have access to decision makers in that bank?’ or 'Who do I know on that venture capital team?' This is all about proving your worth to your customers and fans, getting them to validate your idea and fund it.
“Even ideas that aren’t considered worthy of funding are worth trying, because you’ve saved a lot of time to find out that it wasn’t a good idea and be smarter faster,” he says.
United States-based Rigelmann began his career as a Wall Street analyst. In 2008, she decided to give up and use her skills to try to help friends working in the arts raise money.
The site originally focused on the film business and was launched at the Sundance Film Festival that year.
Five years later and is raising about $2 million a week for new businesses in stages of creation and growth. In December 2012, he launched a euro and a pound sterling service to get a foothold on this side of the Atlantic and says Britain is his third largest market. International activity has increased by 41 per cent since December.
There is no shortage of competitors, be it Kickstarter, Seeds or Financing Circle, but, unlike rivals, says Rigelmann, Indiegogo is the only crowdfunder where anyone can launch a campaign. No project is considered too crazy.
The site charges a 4% fee for successful campaigns. For those who fail to increase their target amount, users have the option of returning all the money to their taxpayers free of charge or keeping all the money raised but with a 9% fee.
A British woman, Lauren Pears, raised £100,000 to open a “cat cafe” in London through the site.
Known as Lady Dinah’s Cat Emporium, it has not yet been opened, but it is counted as a place where people can “enter from the cold into a comfortable backchair, a cup of hot tea, a book and a cat.”
“We’ve seen campaigns that go to venture capitalists to be rejected because the kids at risk say, ‘Great idea but I don’t know if the market really wants it; it could be a gadget that nobody cares about,’” said Rigelmann.
“Employers make an Indiegogo campaign – they don’t even launch the project, but the campaign itself is enough market evidence for venture capitalists to say that there is a market for this.
“It allows you to test your market, test your prices, test your features, discover new revenue streams, get vital feedback,” says Rigelmann.
With his background on Wall Street and the experience of helping 100,000 companies and services raise funds, Rigelmann has fine-tuned his advice for the budding entrepreneur.
“Ideas is ten cents per dozen. It's about execution and, if you're afraid that your idea will be stolen by someone who could execute it better and faster than you, then you're not the right person to execute that idea. It’s all about trust to move fast and learn,” he says.
For Rigelmann, the expansion to Europe and an agreement with a web transaction provider, which will allow payments to be made through local card services such as Master in the UK and Carte Bleue in France, as well as PayPal, are part of a dream to democratize finance. More than 7,000 funding campaigns are live on the site.
While crowdfunding as an alternative to banks has grown, it has a limited appeal to big business investors, who are content with nothing less than a stake in a promising business. This could begin to change in the UK with the launch of InvestingZone.

text:
It's not over in Steubenville, Ohio.
Although a judge has found two teenagers in Steubenville guilty of raping a 16-year-old girl in a case that showed amazing examples of teen alcohol consumption and texting wrapped in cover-up charges, the Ohio Attorney General said Monday is time for a grand jury to see if anyone else should be charged.
I think the Steubenville community really needs two things. One is to end this, Attorney General Mike DeWine said in a wink at the frustration that the ongoing investigation is likely to cause in the city -- a small city of Ohio River Mill that has been the focus of intense criticism and media coverage for months.
But the other is to believe that justice has been done, that we have left no stone unturned and that anyone who is criminally responsible has been brought to justice, he said.
The healing process after rape never ends
The victim's mother told CNN that the verdicts are the beginning of a new start for my daughter. But he added, “We need to emphasize the importance of helping those in need and defending what is right.
“We hope that something good will emerge from this,” he said. I feel like I have the opportunity to make others known, possibly change a young person's mentality, or help a father become more aware of where his children are and what they are doing. Adults must take responsibility and guide these children.
But the emotions inflamed by the case echoed last Sunday's verdict, with sheriff's deputies and state investigators arresting two teenagers on Monday for threatening the victim on Twitter. The girls -- a 15, a 16, both from Steubenville -- were in a youth dungeon on Monday night, waiting for a judge to appear Tuesday morning, Jefferson County Sheriff Fred Abdalla said.
Grand jury
DeWine said state researchers have examined tens of thousands of text messages, images and videos and talked to 56 witnesses, ranging from teenagers attending the parties to assistant football coaches and the high school principal.
But 16 people who may know something about what happened that night in August have refused to talk, he said.
I have come to the conclusion that this investigation cannot be completed -- that we cannot end this matter -- without the convening of a grand jury, he said in a statement on Sunday.
The grand jury will begin to meet around April 15 and could take several days to complete its work, DeWine said.
And I must point out that convening a grand jury, of course, does not necessarily mean that the charges will be returned or that charges will be brought, he said.
A grand jury is a unique investigative tool to ensure fairness and to complete this investigation, DeWine said in Sunday's statement. And this community needs assurance that no stone has been left unmoved in our quest for truth.
Guilty sentences
The Grand Jury's DeWine announcement came shortly after Judge Thomas Lipps found Trent Mays, 17, and 16-year-old Ma lik Richmond, guilty of rape. Lipps, who was listening to the case without a jury, also found Mays guilty of spreading a nude photo of a minor.
Authorities accused Mays and Richmond of sticking their fingers into the girl's vagina while she was too drunk to consent, an act that constitutes rape under Ohio law. The incident took place during a series of alcohol-fed end-of-summer parties in August.
Some of the abuses were documented in photographs shown in court and in texts read aloud during testimony, including a text in which a state forensic investigator testified that Mays wrote, should have violated as everyone believes I did.
The essay focuses on text messages
Lipps sentenced Mays to a minimum of two years in a juvenile correctional facility. Richmond received a minimum of one year. The juvenile authorities may decide to hold both detainees until they reach the age of 21.
Richmond's father, Nathaniel Richmond, said he still believed his son was innocent even though he apologized in court.
The evidence they had against Ma Lik was minimal, he told Piers Morgan of CNN tonight. Ma Lik was in the wrong place at the wrong time. I know my son isn't a rapist, even though he's been convicted of rape.
Both Mays and Richmond must undergo treatment and they will have to register as sex offenders, Lipps said. Richmond's attorney, Walter Madison, said his client would appeal in an attempt to avoid that designation.
Meanwhile, the victim and her family remain under surveillance after the threats were posted online, Abdalla told CNN.
She's still a victim and victimized... over and over again, she said. And that's the sad part.
One of the tweets that led to Monday's arrests warned that if the poster saw the victim, it's gone, it's a homicide. Another threatened a beating.
The girl accused of tweeting the death threat surrendered after learning that the investigators were looking for her, the sheriff said. However, they will have to answer her, she said.
“We are dealing with children again,” Abdalla said. But the Attorney General had just left the building -- the judge was still in the building -- when I received messages that there were already death threats against the victim.
No charges had been announced against the suspects on Monday night, but there's no doubt they're going to prosecute.
I hope this sends a warning, he said. And I can assure you, we've been monitoring Twitter for 24 hours and we're still doing it. If there's anyone else there who crosses a line and makes a death threat, they're going to have to face the consequences.
Internet atrocity
The case received much attention after a blogger who once lived in Steubenville discovered some of the materials published on social media.
Blogger Alexandria Goddard wrote clearly about the possibility that teenagers would have been given preferential treatment because they played in the city's prestigious football team. The police have denied that claim.
Later, the freely organized group of hackers Anonymous became involved, posting a long video in which another teenager -- who has not been charged -- made jokeal references to rape.
The anger that followed on the case attracted national attention and criticism of the city throughout the country, leaving city officials struggling to defend the community and residents tired of media attention.
Teenage Rape Trial Shines in Ohio City
Wider problem
Recognizing the frustration of the city, DeWine said Monday that it would be a mistake to focus on a small community in Ohio, thinking that something unique in their culture is behind the incident.
“I’m afraid people are going to leave and say that all this was for Steubenville,” DeWine said. It's not. It's a cultural problem.
I guarantee you that there are very similar crimes to this that happen every Friday night and every Saturday night in communities across this country where there are people, particularly young people, who are drinking too much and a girl is taken advantage of, and a girl is raped, he said.
Such incidents have their origin in a broader social problem, a lack of respect and unbridled human decency, he said.
One of the lessons of life is that we have to take care of each other, and we have to try to help people and we have to do the right thing. DeWine said. And there were very few people that night who were doing the right thing.
Teenagers treat the girl like a toy, says the prosecutor
CNN's Poppy Harlow, Brian Vitagliano, Yon Pomrenze, Matt Smith, Steve Almasy and Chelsea J. Carter contributed to this report.

text:
Gang rape and the murder of a young woman in New Delhi in December has raised awareness in India in a way she has never experienced before: it has forced Indians to face a terrible truth that for our girls and women, violence and discrimination are facts of everyday life, an epidemic that, according to researchers, nearly 2 million lives are claimed in India every year.
But now the real work begins for each of us who take to the streets in protest. How do we channel the energy of these manifestations into real solutions for our communities?
Earlier this month I tried the challenge, when officials from the Barabanki district of Uttar Pradesh, a state adjacent to New Delhi, asked me if I would run a workshop to promote adolescent safety and gender sensitivity in government schools.
I was disappointed to see that they had invited only the principals of the girls' schools. So I agreed on one condition: that district school principals also attend. Because if there's one thing I'm sure is that all the candlelight vigils, the passion and the protests will be in vain if we don't figure out how to make men and boys part of this growing movement to transform gender relations in my country.
For more than a decade I have worked for the poverty group CARE as a community educator on health and gender issues. I have seen how deep inequalities between women and men trap millions of Indian families in the cycle of poverty. But along the way, I have also met countless men who, given the opportunity, were willing to examine and improve their behavior towards girls and women in their lives.
The fact is that most people want what is best for their loved ones. Aggressive behavior towards women is not innate. It is learned and may not be learned. When asked to reflect on their attitudes towards women's education, sharing domestic chores, having girls and even violence, the boys and men with whom I work every day can and change.
It often starts with something simple, like laundry.
I think of Ram, a man I worked with in the village of Pavaiya Viran. A husband and a father with a male job -- drilling underground bombs -- Ram attended sessions where he was given the opportunity to analyze gender roles in his life. He understood that men and boys are under pressure to express power and that when they feel weak or frustrated, their intestinal reaction is often to show power, even if that means violent or abusive behavior.
Ram finally adopted a new view; that truly strong men do not show power, show care. “Let the other men laugh at me for cooking and washing clothes,” he told me. Why should my wife do all things alone?
Now I'm not saying men doing laundry is the solution. But every time he folds the sheets, Ram shows his children that he respects his wife and treats her as an equal, not a servile.
So I kept thinking about Ram as I met with the group of 53 school principals for boys and girls earlier this month. We are concerned with the importance of installing security cameras on the school doors, ensuring that a driver is on every school bus, and having clean and functioning bathrooms in schools so that girls and boys are not forced to go out and ease themselves. All this was necessary. But it looked like we were playing defense. Only when educators were forced to hold a mirror to their own lives, did it feel like we were playing the offensive, too.
Many recognized that it is their duty as parents and community leaders to lead the next generation by example. A director realized that he had not even considered doing household chores, not as a child or, now, as a husband and a father. Another promised to make gender equity a necessary part of parent-teacher conferences. At the end of the session, every man and woman in the room was thinking of changing not only others, but also himself or herself.
We have a long way to go, and not just in India. A World Health Organization global survey revealed that 59 per cent of rural women in Ethiopia report sexual violence by their partner, 62 per cent of women in Peru report physical violence by their partners, and 30 per cent of rural women in Bangladesh claim that their first sexual experience was forced. The problem is also not limited to the developing world. Almost one in five women in the United States had been raped or had been subjected to attempted rape.
Still, I am confident that the Indian people can demonstrate to the world that we are not powerless in the face of any global epidemic. We can change. That begins by treating this moment not as a global issue of our dirty clothes, but rather as a national awakening to the reality that all of us -- girls and boys, women and men -- must do our part in cleaning up.

text:
Edward Dolman is Christie's first executive director who has been a specialist, who understands the pressure and nature of valuing art. Part of your mission is to attract other highly motivated specialists in your business.
Christie's employee is next to a painting at Christie's auction house in London on July 4.
Dolman was born in London in 1960 and attended Dulwich College between 1971 and 1978, before studying Art History at the University of Southampton.
He later graduated from the Centre for Studies of Fine Arts and Decorative Arts, which had a close relationship with the Victoria and Albert Museum.
Not being born of blue blood, he joined Christie's because of the link with Christie's South Kensington, starting as a doorman in the furniture department.
After a year he took on the role of a specialist in the furniture department of South Kensington, where he would see everything, from European furniture to Chinese furniture, in the large sales room for the next 10 years.
Meanwhile, he became an auctioneer, making a series of off-site sales on rural farms and traveling to France and Belgium to generate business in the middle furniture market.
At that time he was on the Management Committee, and South Kensington started making big sales. Finally, in 1995, he decided to become a manager and took a course at the Institute of Directors at the Mall to learn the language of business and the motivation of people.
Dolman was later appointed CEO of Christie's Amsterdam, applying new techniques and marketing to increase interest in high-quality art.
Twenty months later he returned to Christie's London on King Street as commercial director to lead Christie's Europe. In trying to develop new categories to win business, he was appointed Director General.
In 1999 Dolman moved to New York as International Managing Director and later as Chief Executive. Together with Christie's International Management Group, they developed a five-year intensive business plan, and Dolman took over Christopher Davidge, approved by Francois Pinault.

I am writing to ask for your help after a change in my circumstances.
As you know, I am enrolled in the basic Spanish course at your university, which begins in September. However, due to unforeseen family events, I have had to leave the country for a while to help my parents in Hong Kong.
It is currently unclear when I will be able to return and, unfortunately, I will not be able to start the course as planned.
I would like to request a refund for the course fees already paid. I apologize for the brief warning and any inconvenience caused. In case a refund is not possible, I would be grateful if you would postpone my registration until my return.
Thank you in advance for your help and I hope to be able to inform you about the situation soon.
Sincerely,
Honor Singh

text:
As soon as children in a primary school in Stirling hear the words “daily mile,” they lower their pencils and leave the classroom to start running around the school camp. For three and a half years, all students at St Ninian’s Primary have walked or run a mile each day. They do it randomly during the day, apparently happy, and, despite the increase in childhood obesity throughout the UK, none of the school children are overweight.
The daily mile has done so much to improve the physical condition, behavior and concentration of these children in classes that dozens of nursery and primary schools across Britain are following suit and getting students to get up from their desks and take 15 minutes to walk or run around the school or the local park.
Elaine Wyllie, director of St. Ninian, said: “I receive at least two daily emails from other schools and local authorities asking how we do it. The idea of children running around the country every day for something we have done is phenomenal.”
One in ten children is obese when they start school at the age of four or five, according to figures from the Center for Health Information and Social Assistance, and in the summer of 2015 a study found that schoolchildren in England are the least fit they have had. Therefore, primary schools have quickly taken note of the benefits of the daily mile. It has been introduced in schools in London, Gateshead, Wales and other parts of Scotland, while others are planning to launch the initiative during the 2015-6 academic year. Only in Stirling, 30 schools have already started or are going to start the daily mile.
“It is a common sense approach to children’s fitness, which is free and easy. The most important thing is that children really enjoy it; otherwise, it could not be sustained. They come back with bright eyes and pink eyes, how the children looked. It’s good to see,” Wyllie said. At St Ninian’s, teachers take their students out of class to a specially constructed circuit around the school’s playing field for their daily mile when it best suits that day’s schedule. Only the ice or the heavy rain stop them.
The extent of the benefits has not yet been determined, but researchers at Stirling University have started a comparative study to look for quantitative evidence of the physical, cognitive and emotional benefits of the daily mile. Dr. Colin Moran, who leads the study, said: “The children of St. Ninian do not seem to have problems with obesity; they seem happier and the staff says they settle in lessons faster, so we designed a study that would test all these things. There is a lot of anecdotal evidence about the benefits, but there is still no scientific data.” The students of San Niniano will be compared to the children of another Stirling school that has not yet started the plan.
Kevin Clelland, a primary school teacher at Leeds, visited St Ninian before convincing his colleagues that it was a great idea. He said: “It’s such a simple thing to do, but it seems to have such an amazing impact. We are truly committed to improving the fitness of our students beyond the two statutory hours we are expected to meet.” Your school is now building a track.
Active Cheshire, a strategic body for sport and fitness in Cheshire and Warrington, is taking a group of senior local authority figures to Scotland to evaluate the results of the daily mile. The hope is to introduce it into the 450 schools in the region if a pilot succeeds.
Paralympian, Tanni Grey-Thompson, president of ukactive, the UK’s leading non-profit health agency for physical activity, said: “All children need to reach 60 active minutes every day, whether in a lesson, on a walk to school or in the playground. It is fantastic to see initiatives such as the established daily mile, showing true leadership from the education sector to improve the physical fitness levels of children and their cognitive behavior, and to make a real difference for schools, teachers, parents and young people. We know that sitting still kills; not sitting still helps children develop skills that will remain with them for life.”
The Scottish government also supports. One spokesman said: “Learning in physical education is enhanced by initiatives such as the daily mile, which can encourage and support parents to foster healthy habits with their children from an early age. We are pleased to see that many Scottish schools participate or plan to do so.”

text:
Protests broke out across Northern Ireland on Friday against the decision of Belfast City Council members to stop flying the Union flag all year round.
Most of the protests were peaceful, although the road network in Belfast and across the country was disrupted, police said in a statement.
One of the most serious incidents occurred on O'Neil's Road in Newtownabbey, where about 100 protesters, many of them teenagers, threw concrete blocks, paving slabs, bricks, wooden planks, petrol bombs and Molotov cocktails at the police.
They targeted about 30 armoured police vehicles and up to 100 police officers dressed in riot gear. At least one officer looked hurt. His head bowed, the officer was helped by the comrades.
In the midst of rain and temperatures above freezing, the police brought two water cannons, deploying one of them to push back the troublemakers. The police were trying to get control of a main road.
In Images: Flag Protests in Northern Ireland
In total, four police officers were injured, one of whom required hospital treatment, and two people were arrested, the police said. During the demonstrations, 33 petrol bombs were thrown at the police, after which all roads were reopened.
The eruptions occurred after two nights of calm that followed five consecutive nights of riots.
Belfast has been at the centre of a wave of protests brought about by the City Council decision of 3 December to limit the wave of the flag to 18 days a year.
The disorder has resulted in more than 100 arrests and 66 officers have been injured.
The flag was raised on Wednesday for the first time since the controversial vote to commemorate the birthday of Prince William's wife, Catherine. It was lowered at the end of the day.
The leaders of the two main trade union political parties met on Thursday to discuss concerns within the trade union community.
The Northern Ireland authorities have accused loyal extremists of exploiting the Belfast officials' decision to put an end to the centuries-old tradition of flying the Union flag over the City Hall 365 days a year.
The British flag has long been a flash point between loyal British and Irish nationalists, who want Northern Ireland to join the Irish republic.
The Belfast City Council vote followed a summer of intense tensions between the Catholic and Protestant communities in Northern Ireland. The September riots left dozens of police officers injured.
Most of Ireland gained independence in 1921 after two years of conflict. But six of the nine counties in Ulster province chose to remain in the UK, eventually becoming Northern Ireland.
Police: extremist group orchestrating violence in Belfast by the union Jack
In the late 1960s, the conflict between the main loyal Protestants, who want Northern Ireland to remain part of the United Kingdom, and Roman Catholic nationalists, who want it to meet with the rest of Ireland, broke out in a political and sectarian war, known as problems.
The three decades of violence that followed between loyalists and the IRA claimed more than 3,000 lives, most of them north of the border. While the 1998 Good Friday Agreement, also known as the Belfast Agreement, effectively ended the conflict, mistrust between Catholics and Protestants persists.
Under the terms of the agreement, groups on both sides dropped their weapons, and members of Sinn Fein, the political affiliate of the IRA, now work with pro-British politicians in the power-sharing Northern Ireland government.
CNN's Laura Smith-Spark wrote in London and Nic Robertson and Peter Taggart reported in Belfast.

text:
Your manager stops you and says you need to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry all weekend, wondering what you've done wrong. When you enter her office on Monday morning, she starts by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that begins with the typical "feedback sandwich". You know how the comment sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.
In an attempt to inject some positivity into your feedback, many managers rely on negative feedback between two positive feedbacks. However, when feedback becomes a routine, employees can begin to perceive positive feedback as simply a way to sweeten negative feedback, thus decreasing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered to reinforce and promote good performance. Below are three tips to help you make positive feedback count.
1. Do not always follow positive feedback with negative feedback
When positive and negative feedback always seems to go hand in hand, positive feedback can be devalued and ignored. Make sure there are times when positive feedback is given for itself and resists the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
2. Cultivating a "growth mentality"
Carol Dweck, a psychologist and advocate of "growth mentality," spoke of the plasticity of the brain and of our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at. Many of us tend to focus our praises on the end result and seemingly innate talents, for example. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organizing events'. However, research suggests that if we focus on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation, and problem-solving strategies – we can foster the development of new skills and the continuous improvement of talents.
3. Create a culture of positive feedback
Make positive feedback part of your team/department/company culture. Don't expect special moments like evaluations to give feedback. Offer informal positive feedback by making a little chat or walking down a hallway. Feedback doesn't just have to come from the higher ranks either. Encourage peer feedback among team members and colleagues and actively ask them for positive feedback on each other's actions in the tasks.
It may take time to counteract the effects of an environment in which there is a cynical view of positive feedback, but in the long term, by adopting positive feedback, you can not only improve job performance, but also enrich the quality of life in the workplace.

text:
On a dry, dusty football field, the boys squealed and screamed like children in the middle of a highly competitive football match often do.
One neighborhood resident pointed at three other guys on their bikes outside the side view.
See where they are? That's where the cars would stop, he told me. They'd take a man out and execute him. Some days it was more than one.
Just a few years ago, this same football field was an Al Qaeda extermination camp where, like a clock every day before evening prayers, executions were carried out, and the young people -- the same ages as those who now play football in front of us -- gathered to see the macabre event, seemingly immune to the horrors they were witnessing.
That was in February, when we were in Iraq filming stories for the tenth anniversary of the beginning of the Iraq war. In April, I found out that a couple of the guys we filmed died in a bombing on the road. The bomb -- containing 2 kilograms of highly explosive material -- was hidden in a plastic bag, placed outside a three-story building that had a popular ice cream shop on the first floor. The boys were there.
This is the tragic rule of Iraq by which the people are forced to live. The violence few understand, the fear that permeates all aspects of life, where even a simple action such as leading children to eat ice cream can result in death.
Last year there was a marked increase in attacks, especially coordinated simultaneous attacks, a trademark of ISI -- the Islamic State of Iraq -- a coordinating organization that includes Al Qaeda in Iraq.
Baghdad is a maze of blast walls and checkpoints, with Iraqi security forces strengthening security, but barely achieving anything but creating increasingly frustrating traffic jams. The government promotes cases in which it has managed to spread bombs, but the harsh reality is that they simply cannot stop the violence.
July was the deadliest month in Iraq in the last five years since the peak of sectarian violence in 2006 and 2007. According to the UN, 1,057 Iraqis were killed and 2,326 others injured in acts of terrorism and violence last month.
And on Saturday the bombings from Nassiriya in the south to Baghdad to Mosul in the north claimed dozens of lives and wounded nearly two hundred more. It was Eid, the three-day feast marking the end of the sacred month of Ramadan.
Most of the explosions exploded in predominantly Shia areas, in cafes, markets and bus stops.
Where are the security forces? A man at one of the bomb sites asked angry. If you -- Prime Minister Maliki -- can't take care of security, someone else will!
The anger and frustration among Iraqis are bleakly palpable.
The Islamic State of Iraq claimed responsibility in a statement, saying that violence was intended to be a message to the animals of Rawafdh Shiite and his government.
Al Qaeda in Iraq—LRB-AQI-RRB—was once described by the U.S. military before withdrawing from Iraq in 2011 as a flight. But it is clearly no longer the case.
To begin with, Iraq's security forces were never able to contain the security gains of the U.S. military era.
The AQI and other Sunni extremist groups have capitalized on the failure of the predominantly Shiite government to introduce Sunnis into the political fold. The Sunni population in Iraq claims that it is being systematically attacked by government forces and becomes more alienated and stripped of its rights by the day. Iraq remains a nation where violence and politics go hand in hand.
AQI has also expanded its operations to Syria under the umbrella of Al Qaeda in Iraq and the Levant – LRB – Syria –RRB. His head, which passes by the pseudonym Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi or Abu Dua'a, among others, is believed to be mainly operating from Syria.
But the resurgence of Al Qaeda and its operations are only part of the messy and vicious patchwork of forces that govern this part of the world at the expense of the civilian population and that plunged into an existential battle that began millennia ago.
These forces include the regional struggle that confronts Shiite Iran against Saudi Arabia and Sunni Qatar -- a regional power that has found indirect battlefields in Syria and Iraq -- along with Russia and the United States.
The fates of Iraq and Syria are increasingly intertwined day by day, and it is civilians who always remain victims of this lethal network of dynamics over which they have little control.
Iraq: 10 years later
Why the war in Iraq was fought by the Great Oil
What Iraq Could Teach Us About Syria

text:
An Alaskan judge has denied Bristol Palin's petition for his court to fight with ex-boyfriend Levi Johnston over his son's custody to avoid a media circus.
The daughter of the former governor of Alaska. Sarah Palin is looking for full custody of Tripp, 1 year old, holding that Johnston is too immature to be a responsible father and that her mother's drug conviction makes her a danger to the child.
Bristol Palin applied for full custody in November, but Johnston is looking for shared custody. Both parents are 19 years old. Her teenage relationship fell under intense public attention after Senator John McCain elected Sarah Palin as his vice president formula partner in August 2008.
Court documents, now unsealed, were published online on Monday by Anchorage Daily News.
Johnston joined the family at the Republican National Convention after the campaign confirmed that Bristol, then 17, was five months pregnant with her son. The couple broke their engagement about two months after the birth of their son in December 2008.
Johnston has asked that the case conducted in public to protect himself from Sarah Palin, whom he said was powerful, politically ambitious and has a reputation for being extremely vindictive. But Bristol Palin's request for the case to be sealed said public proceedings will turn this custody case into a media circus that's not best for Tripp.
In this day and time of the Internet, media stories remain available for years, even decades, after they are first published, and anything printed in the media - LRB- whether true or not -RRB- will be available to Tripp when he is old enough to read, Palin said in an affidavit.
She said Johnston wanted a public case so he could keep making a spectacle of this custody dispute for his own self-promotion. Johnston was going to participate in a reality show in Alaska, he said.
I don't think it's in Tripp's best interest that Levi's reality show is filming this case as it unfolds, or that Levi Johnston is capitalizing on this custody case through his reality show, Palin said.
Johnston's affidavit said he feared what Sarah Palin could do against him if the case was kept secret.
I really believe that closing the court could make this matter very uncivil and potentially open the door to poor influences in Bristol and his lawyer who can be extremely inappropriate and potentially detrimental to Tripp, he said.
While Johnston said that his ex-girlfriend would never be malicious to him, his mother is powerful, politically ambitious and has a reputation for being extremely vindictive.
So, I think a public case could help a lot to reduce Sarah Palin's instinct to attack and allow the real parties to this litigation, Bristol and I, to resolve things in a much more peaceful way than we could if there was more interference from Sarah Palin, Johnston said.
Bristol Palin's affidavit said her mother is not involved in the custody case, except as a grandmother. But Johnston's lawyer, Rex Butler, said in his own affidavit that his client does not trust closed proceedings because Sarah Palin is known for dealing forcefully with those she perceives as political enemies.
He feels that Sarah Palin, through her lawyer, under the guise of Bristol Palin's name, would run over her bones, Butler said.
The judge's ruling, signed last week, concludes that Bristol Palin did not prove that this case involves matters of a sensitive and highly personal nature of such magnitude that the protection of the party's name outweighs the public interest in disclosure.
His presentation for full custody argued that Levi was not ready for paternity claims and sacrifices that would involve a 19-year-old aspiring actor/model.
Levi remains without a regular job or constant source of income, the petition states. Although he is not enrolled in school to learn a trade or get a degree, he has made money by selling stories about his son and the Palins to the media and participating in luxury models for Playgirl magazine, he says.
The photos published last month showed Johnston in semi-naked poses, not with the complete frontal nudity that is Palin's file cited.
The petition cited a series of posts posted on the online social network Twitter.com as evidence that Johnston may have substance abuse issues, based on statements he has made about the search for grass.
Johnston's response said he doesn't have a Twitter account and hasn't made such statements about marijuana use.
But Palin's toughest attack was on Levi's mother, Sherry Johnston, who pleaded guilty to a felony drug offense earlier this year.
Palin asked to be prevented from having unsupervised visits with Tripp. His petition said he could go back to offending, keep drugs around the house that could be accessible to the baby, that illegal drug users come to the house -LRB- or that he could take the baby in his car during a drug sale -RRB-.
Palin also said that from Sherry Johnston he could fall asleep or be too sleepy to properly monitor the baby.
She is also a chronic pain patient and suffers from regular and sustained daily narcotics infusions, Palin's petition said.
Johnston's response said his mother's chronic pain condition is currently being handled in coordination with the Department of Corrections.
Sherry Johnston will not be left to take care of the little girl alone, but she will simply be there to help the best of her ability, said Johnston's presentation.
She was released from an Alaskan prison last week to serve the remainder of her three-year sentence under house arrest at her home in Wasilla, Alaska. He must wear an ankle bracelet for electronic monitoring, said Richard Schmitz, spokesman for the Department of Corrections.

text:
Build it and they'll come. That seems to have been the strategy for urban development in China over the past decade, during what could be said has been the largest and fastest urbanization of a society in modern history.
In Zhengzhou, the capital of the central province of Henan, this approach has had mixed results. Just a few years ago, a new development area, a complement to the main city, was labeled China's largest ghost city: rows and rows of luxury apartments and office buildings were empty in vast desert boulevards.
But now the locals here say that signs of life have emerged and that the city is growing.
At a recent national holiday, visitors came to a new park by the river. It was a remarkable green oasis of willows, ponds, fountains and swamps made by man surrounded by new bright towers of glass and steel.
In the middle of the vegetation, several married couples posed in tuxedoes and dresses for professional photographs, the brides pampered by make-up artists.
Among them were the Zhangs, newlyweds who traveled more than a hundred miles for this photo shoot.
Although they clearly appreciated their surroundings, they said they could not afford to live in the recently built large Zhengzhou district.
The same happened with Li Cai Juan, 25, and his friends. Several years ago, she had an office job at a construction company that built some of the rows of Zhengzhou towers.
Pictures of fantasy for Chinese weddings
Now a school teacher, Li said, The housing prices are too high here, in the newly built part of Zhengzhou.
According to the local statistics office, the average monthly income in Zhengzhou is approximately $483 while property prices in the new district are $1,660 per square metre, and is expected to rise.
Amid growing unrest over swollen housing markets, Prime Minister Li Keqiang has made affordable property prices a pillar of his leadership. However, tighter controls on real estate markets, such as limitations on housing per person and increased transaction taxes, have failed to control speculative buyers since they were first applied in 2010.
The following year, as part of its twelfth five-year plan, the government promised to build 36 million low-income homes by 2015 in an attempt to suffocate struggling home buyers.
The rush to the cities
The demand for housing has followed the migration of workers from rural areas to cities where work is better paid and easier to find. In early 2012, for the first time in history, figures showed that more than half of the country's population lives in urban areas.
The pace of urbanization has been staggering and the government has it as the main engine of economic growth over the coming decades.
Currently, China’s urban population is just over 700 million people, said Tom Miller, author of China’s Urban Billion.
By 2030, we expect it to be a billion. One in eight people on Earth will live in a Chinese city. So they still need to make a lot more building.
Miller predicts that there will always be a high demand for housing in China. The challenge will be to make it affordable for the Chinese people.
The rise of the population of Zhengzhou
According to the city's government statistics, the population of Zhengzhou grew by 30% between 2000 and 2010, and today stands at about nine million people, approximately the same population as that of New York City - LRB- 8,245 million in 2011 -RRB-, London -LRB- 8,174, 2011 -RRB- and Bangkok -LRB- 8,281, 2010 -RRB-.
But the city seems to have grown even faster physically.
In an area nearly twice the size of San Francisco, new tower districts have emerged where 10 years ago locals say there were empty fields.
The armies of the construction teams continue to work hard. Dozens of new towers are in several stages of completion, despite the fact that real estate companies are still clearly struggling to fill some of the finished buildings.
On a street corner, two college students distributed advertising leaflets to passing drivers and raised a two-storey purchase for the price of a deal for a residential development called Harmony Building.
In the office of another real estate development company, a sales representative told CNN that all units of the neighboring residential towers had been sold. If so, no one bothered to keep the grounds around apartment buildings where grass and weeds grew between 30-story towers.
Speculators move in
Meanwhile, real estate sales seemed to move faster at the Zheng Dong Business Center, where visitors were greeted by soccer tables, plush velvet sofas, a piano, wine and entremess arranged around giant illuminated models of an office park.
Upon arrival, a sales team accompanied CNN to a 180-degree cinema, IMAX screen that played an elaborate computer illustrated film announcing five-star hotels, gyms, shopping malls, offices and restaurants that would one day populate the new development.
It would be another five or six years before this virtual city center was completed, said a saleswoman named Song Lei.
Asked whether or not she expected enough customers to fill the gigantic office park, Song said, Overall, probably not.
There are some people who buy office buildings for investment and there are others who are using it themselves, he explained.
Some of China’s growing real estate market seems to be driven by wealthy Chinese who prefer to park their money in property rather than in banks where interest rates remain the same as inflation. In less than a year, real estate prices in Zhengzhou increased by 14 %, while the reference interest rate remains at 3 %.
Two Chinese men working as contractors in the construction industry were finalizing an agreement on the purchase of two offices in the unfinished office park of the Zheng Dong Business Center.
Both men said they owned several properties in the area, some of which were vacant.
He owns 20 apartments here! said one of the employer's employees, laughing. Return after 10 years and take a look and it will be completely different, he said, when asked about Zhengzhou's ghost city label.
The businessman, who asked not to be named, said he earned much better returns on real estate than on banks.
Miller said the purchase of properties in China is encouraged by the fact that, unlike many Western countries, there is no annual property tax.
You pay transaction taxes when you buy a property, but once the purchases do not pay anything, which is remarkable, he said.
Build them and they'll come?
Compared to China, the history of urbanization in the West is different. Things happened at a much slower pace, said Behzad Yaghmaian, a political economist and author of The Accidental Capitalist -- A People's Story of the New China.
China is a huge country with the ability to supply the world and now its own market. Things are going to happen faster and with more mistakes.
The jury is still aware of whether major urban development projects and the new Zhengzhou districts will become vibrant urban centres.
But Miller challenges critics who quickly labeled Zhengzhou a ghost city.
He said that in recent years city planners had built 14 new university campuses in the city, predicting that it would secure a quarter of a million new residents.
China is different because it has this very authoritarian power structure. Power is in the hands of very few people, and that means that local government officials can make big decisions for the future 10, 15 years... and create something for a society that has not yet arrived, Miller said.
“It is to build them and they will come,” Miller added, “and build them and force them to come.” But, of course, there will be some great wasteful developments, white elephants, along the way.

text:
Vienna is the best city in the world to live, Baghdad is the worst and London, Paris and New York don't even make it the top 35, according to international research on quality of life.
German-speaking cities dominate rankings in the 18th Mercer Quality of Life studio, with Vienna in the top seven places.
Paris has fallen through the league, dropping ten places at 37, just ahead of London at 39, almost entirely due to the city's vulnerability to terrorist attacks.
The study examined social and economic conditions, health, education, housing and the environment, and is used by large companies to assess where they should be located and how much they should pay staff.
Helena Hartlauer, 32, born in Vienna, said she was not surprised by the highest position in her city. The municipality’s social democratic government has a long tradition of investing in high-quality social housing, making Vienna almost only affordable among major cities.
“I live in an apartment of 100 square meters at the beginning of the century in a good area about 20 minutes walk from the city center. But my rent is only €800 (£625) per month.” An equivalent apartment in London would cost more than £2,000 and even more in New York, which occupies 44th place on the table.
American cities have relatively poor performance in the study, largely due to problems related to personal security and crime. The highest city in the United States is San Francisco, in 28th; Boston is 34th. Canadian cities, led by Vancouver, far surpass their American rivals at the table.
“You don’t realize how safe Vienna is until you go abroad,” Hartlauer said. “We also have excellent public transport, with 24-hour underground work on weekends, and it costs only €1 per trip.”
Vienna benefited greatly from the fall of the Berlin Wall, becoming the gateway to the countries of Eastern Europe that often have historical ties to the former Austro-Hungarian empire.
“Our great USP is our geographical location,” said Martin Eichtinger, Austrian ambassador to London, who lived in Vienna for 20 years. “The fall of the Berlin Wall helped define Vienna as the centre of businesses that want to do business in Central Europe.”
According to the World Bank, Austria has one of the highest per capita GDP figures in the world, just behind the US. and ahead of Germany and Britain, though well below neighboring Switzerland.
Zurich in Switzerland is named by Mercer as having the second highest quality of life in the world, but the Viennese say their city is much more fun. “There are more students in Vienna than in any other German-speaking city,” Hartlauer said. “It is a city of very rapid growth, young and lively,” he added, although he acknowledged that he works for the city’s tourist board.
Vienna has long been overlooked by British holiday weekend tourists in the city, who instead come to Barcelona or Berlin and tend to think of Austria as a place for skiing, lakes and mountains. But, after an increase in budget flights from British regional cities such as Manchester and Edinburgh, Vienna is rapidly catching up as a popular destination. In 2015, there were 588,000 British visitors to Vienna, 18% more than the previous year. The flow is both ways; Eichtinger said London has become the city's number one destination for Austrian visitors.
“Vienna ranks first in the last seven published rankings,” Mercer said. “It has a high score in several categories; it provides a safe and stable environment in which to live, a high level of public services and transport facilities and good recreational facilities.”
The European migrant crisis, which has seen a large number of refugees and asylum seekers pass through Vienna on their way to Germany, has had little impact on the city of nearly 1.8 million people, Eichtinger said. “We have managed to house 90,000 refugees in Austria, but the numbers have fallen in recent months.” London has never been in the top 10 quality of life, says Mercer, damaged by its low rates of air pollution, traffic congestion and climate. After London, Edinburgh is the next British city, in the 46th place.
Paris has suffered the biggest drop in the most recent rankings. “Paris remained stable for several years, but this year has fallen ten places in the overall ranking,” Mercer said.
“The fall was essentially due to the terrorist attacks of 2015. However, it is important to note that security issues are a very weighted factor within the ‘basket’ so that any small adjustments can have a great impact on the ranking.”
Auckland in New Zealand was the highest English-speaking city in the survey, thirdly followed by Vancouver in fifth place. Australian cities also have a very high performance in the survey, with Sydney 10 and Melbourne 15. The Economist has always rated Melbourne as the most habitable city in the world, although its poll has been criticized as too Anglocentric.
War and political unrest are behind all the worst-class cities in the world. Surprisingly, Damascus is named the seventh worst, ranked better than not only Baghdad, but also Bangui in the Central African Republic, Sana’a in Yemen, Port-au-Prince in Haiti, Khartoum in Sudan and N’Djamena in Chad.
label: C1

text:
Unveiling a car with a maximum speed of 25 mph, two seats and no pedals or steering wheel may not make much impression on a motor show. But Google, in the US, sent a minor earthquake through the automobile and taxi industries, as it revealed the latest version of its driverless car.
The electrically powered vehicle, which Google has started testing around its headquarters in Mountain View, California, dispenses with all normal controls, including pedals. Instead, it has an application for smartphones that invokes it and tells you the destination, and a single STOP button mounted between the two front seats in case the occupants need to override the computer.
The car, in fact, takes over all navigation, steering, acceleration and braking tasks.
The company is building about 100 prototypes for a two-year test. The company’s co-founder, Sergey Brin, said at a conference in California that the vehicle was “still in the prototype stage,” but that the project was “about changing the world for people who are not well served by transportation today. ”
He said about the car: “You’re just sitting there; there’s no steering wheel, no pedals. For me, it was very relaxing. About ten seconds after I walked in, I forgot I was there. It reminded me of the capture of a chairlift by yourself - a bit of loneliness seemed really nice to me.”
Google says that the main objective of the project is to improve safety and that, because the car is built with shock absorbent foam on the front and a plastic windshield, “it must be much safer than any other car for pedestrians.”
Cars, which have been specially built by a company (still unnamed) in Detroit, will be used to further investigate the best way to run vehicles without a driver. Google will run a pilot program using cars, which are not yet for sale.
A challenge is to create high definition road and surrounding scans before cars can drive along them because they cannot collect and process enough information in real time.
So far, there are large-scale maps of some 2,000 kilometers of California roads, but the state has more than 170,000 kilometers of public roads.
Google says it is interested in licensing technology to traditional vehicle manufacturers once it has been sufficiently refined. Team members had been working on the project even before joining Google for more than a decade.
But the prospect of driverless cars replacing taxis with a human engine has been the cause of some alarm.
“If you get rid of the driver, then they’re unemployed,” said Dennis Conyon, the southeast director of the UK National Taxi Association. “It would have a big impact on the workforce.”
London has about 22,000 licensed black taxis and Conyon estimates that the total number of people driving rental taxis in the UK is about 100,000.
However, Steve McNamara, general secretary of the 10,500-person London Taxi Drivers’ Association, said: “You won’t have these driverless cars in London for 20 or 25 years. Perhaps, by then, they have a charging point, because now there is not one in London.”
Other car manufacturers, including Volvo, Ford and Mercedes, are working on driver-assisted vehicles, which, unlike the Google version, do not dispense with driver controls.
But Chris Urmson, director of the self-driving project at Google, said the new prototypes dispensed with the steering wheel and brakes because there was no guarantee that a human occupant could take charge of an emergency, and that it was easier to have just one emergency stop button.
Urmson said: “Vehicles will be very basic. We want to learn from them and adapt them as soon as possible. But they'll take you wherever you want to go just by pressing a button. And that is an important step towards improving road safety and transforming mobility for millions of people.”
So far, Google versions of self-driving cars have covered 700,000 miles without an accident caused by the computer. The company notes that thousands of people die every year on the roads and that about 80% of accidents can be attributed to human errors.
But, they might have some way to go match Conyon at the National Taxi Association. At 79, he's been driving a taxi for 50 years and claims he's never had an accident.

text:
In American cities like New York and Los Angeles, many people live in small apartments. Despite not having houses with large patios, some apartment dwellers still seek the company that pets like dogs and cats offer. Some people feel that having a pet, even in a small space, is good at teaching the responsibility of children.

However, many owners prohibit tenants from having pets, specifically cats and dogs, due to the damage animals can do to carpets. Some landowners even forbid birds because of the noise they make. Many owners charge an extra fee, known as a pet deposit, to tenants who want to keep pets. This is to pay for repairs or cleaning caused by the pet.
Many times apartment dwellers will choose animals, such as fish, hermit crabs, guinea pigs or hamsters, which make little noise, little mess, and do not chew furniture. Other people keep lizards as pets, as they do not require much space and can be kept in small cages or tanks. Another benefit of these smaller pets is that they do not need to be walked. However, some people living in apartments have pets that are not so common. Some of these pets, which are not common, include mammals such as hedgehogs, amphibians such as frogs, and spiders such as tarantulas. However, not all exotic pets are legal.
To maintain public safety, some cities and states have laws that prohibit specific animals like pets. New York City, for example, forbids people to keep ferrets, turtles, pythons, and scorpions as pets. It seems unlikely that a family will have a polar bear named Fluffy or a whale called Bubbles as a pet, New York has specific laws prohibiting these wild animals from the residences. These laws exist for good reason. In 2003, a man in a Manhattan apartment was discovered to have a 350 pound Bengal tiger as a pet.

text:
You can no longer legally smoke a cigarette inside a bar in the drinking capital of the world, New Orleans, Louisiana. City after city has banned indoor smoking, but that is different because other cities do not attract tourist dollars by aggressively announcing an attitude of “good times move,” as New Orleans does. An indoor smoking ban here will have consequences as unique as New Orleans' own cultural ecosystem.
As the Wall Street Journal recently reported, the New Orleans City government, since Hurricane Katrina in 2005, has begun trying to reduce the volume a little. With the support of neighborhood groups, the city has begun to more strictly monitor bars and nightclubs, while at the same time struggling to implement a new “noise order” (read: musical ordinance).
“This is the wrong time for them to have pursued something like this,” complains bar owner William Walker, who, for reasons of personal choice, hates tobacco law. “To force people to smoke outside the bar will exacerbate the tension that already exists.”
Many of New Orleans' best bars and some of its live music venues are located in relatively quiet residential neighborhoods. This neighborhood cohabitation is a large part of what makes New Orleans different and charming. However, recently this unique social contract has become unacceptable to some people and the fate of New Orleans' musical personality is at stake.
Martha Wood lives next to a noisy bar that hosts live music. “The bar was one of the decisive factors in my purchase of the house, so I will never complain about the noise,” says Wood, who also runs a live music bar that, after a series of noise problems in 2013 (including complaints about loud smokers outside), became one of the first bars in New Orleans that legally is not allowed to serve drinks to go. “Now, any small infraction could close us,” Wood says. “We recently installed a smoke dining room to help with the smoke because we can’t open the doors at night because of the ‘noise’.”
The Maple Leaf club was voluntarily smoke-free in 2014 as was another club where artists had been demanding smoke-free nights. “Many of the performance venues were already beginning to show that consideration to the performers, so I would like the city to have let that happen instead of forcing the ban on every corner bar that doesn’t host music,” says Zalia BeVille, manager of the All Ways Lounge, who ran out of smoke in 2013 because, he says, “The trumpeters and singers, they asked us.”
Luckily, All Ways has an outdoor patio, unlike Lost Love Lounge, whose owner, Geoff Douville, adores the ban – had previously felt compelled to live in smoke to keep his bar economically viable. “There’s no way I could have banned smoking in my bar without it being a rule throughout the city,” Douville says. “People act like I have that choice, as a business owner. But if I make that rule, they walk around the block to a smoking bar. So I need everyone to be in uniform.”
Many small business owners also fear loss of revenue without smoke. Smoker Neil Timms owns an English pub and complied with the smoking ban earlier in England. “Back home in Coventry, every pub where I was a regular closed within a year of the smoking ban,” recalls Timms of the UK ban, launched in 2007. To avoid the same fate, he's spending money on building a courtyard.
However, Lost Love’s Douville feels that prohibition is a great business opportunity. “The number of people who would enjoy going out to our bar, with our food, but they would never come because they didn’t want to smell smoke for the next seven days – now we’re an option for all those people.” Neither does Douville worry about noise complaints like Walker does: “No court will label a bar as “nuisance” after the city has ratified a smoking ban that requires you to leave,” he says. “I want to see a judge reconcile ‘not loitering’ with ‘not smoking inside’.”
Councilwoman LaToya Cantrell, who introduced and advanced the ban, disagrees: “The bar owner’s responsibility is to keep his clientele respectful outside their establishment as well,” she says. “The owners and waiters need to tell them to go smoke but be respectful of their communities. The idea that we can't have clean air because it will cause noise problems is ridiculous. It can be a win-win. I think it’s about communication and building partnerships between communities and businesses.”
Cantrell recognizes the uniqueness of the city in terms of smoking ban. “How does New Orleans differ from the rest of the country? New Orleans is known as "the city that cares about oblivion," he says. “New Orleans needs to stand up and say ‘We care about our people.’ The most vulnerable people who are working in smoke conditions, these citizens are the backbone of our hospitality industry, which drives the economy in the state of Louisiana.” Add, “New Orleans is also different from other places because you have the option of drinking your drink outside with you when you go out to smoke.”
Many were concerned that the already tense New Orleans Police Department did not need to be involved in monitoring smokers. So the health department will take care of warnings and fines. Bar customers are encouraged to “come to fill out a form or call 311 and include time and date photographs documenting illegal smoking.” For this reason alone, Neil Timms says he will comply with the ban: “I don’t want someone sitting on the corner smoking and someone taking a picture of them and getting hit.”
No worries, Geoff Douville says he's already used to noise complaints, so he brings the ban. “Look: the nosy neighbors who complain about the noise are now going to be the same ones who wanted the smoking ban to start.” In the end, Douville shares Cantrell's optimism. “Of course they’re going to complain,” he accepts. “But that doesn’t mean they’re going to win.”

text:
Yellowstone National Park, located in Idaho, Montana and Wyoming, was established as the first national park in the United States. The park is a popular destination for visitors who enjoy ecotourism as it offers forests, mountains and abundant ecosystems to explore. Some of Yellowstone's best-known monuments are its geothermal and geysers hot springs, the most famous of which is called Old Faithful.
Last fall, Lisa and her friends decided to take a camping trip to Yellowstone National Park. They were arranged to stay in one of the many convenient campsites in the park. For their camping trip, they brought their backpacks, sleeping bags and a refrigerator of food and drinks. They set up their tents immediately after arriving at their camp.
During their journey, Lisa and her friends walked along the park's numerous trails, exploring its natural surroundings. In the forest, they saw a lot of local wildlife. Lisa was surprised to see a family of brown bears, some grey wolves, and even bald eagles flying over. Outside the forest, they admired the beauty of some of Yellowstone's natural waterfalls.
Since Yellowstone contains many thermal sources and the world's largest area of active geysers, Lisa and her friends visited many different geysers sites. They even spent an afternoon swimming in the Yellowstone Boiling River. Of all places, Lisa and her friends agreed that Old Faithful was the most impressive. Lisa and her friends were patiently waiting for the geyser to explode. After about 40 minutes, a boiling stream of water more than 100 feet high sprayed from the ground and upwards in the air. Luckily, no one got wet!
