text:
When exploring New York City, there are several different options for activities during a one-day excursion. Some visitors come to see a show, to visit art museums or simply to buy at many of the city's high-end retailers. However, many tourists simply come to New York City for sightseeing. One of the most visited monuments in New York City is the Empire State Building.
The Empire State Building, built in 1931, is a 102-story skyscraper, the ninth tallest building in the world, and the fourth highest structure in the United States. It is located in Midtown, Manhattan. This skyscraper is an iconic symbol of the city, having been featured in more than 90 popular films (from 2018) throughout the history of cinema. Tourists come from all over the world to visit this building and see the city from its famous observation decks.
Matthew, an enthusiast of historic buildings, was excited about this trip to New York City because he has always appreciated architectural design. Matthew bought a ticket that gave him access to beautiful 360-degree views of the city. The ticket included an elevator ride that stopped at two different points of view, one on the 86th floor and the other at the rooftop observatory on the 102nd floor. From these observation decks, Matthew took incredible photographs of the entire New York City horizon. The rooftop views gave Matthew perfect aerial perspectives of Central Park, the Brooklyn Bridge, Times Square, the Statue of Liberty and many other important landmarks of the city.

text:
A new study published in the journal Science shows definitive evidence of organic matter on the surface of Mars. The data was collected by NASA's Rover Curiosity. It confirms previous findings that the Red Planet once contained carbon compounds. These compounds, also called organic molecules, are essential ingredients for life as scientists understand it.
Organic molecules were found in the crater Gale de Mars, a large area that could have been an aqueous lake more than three billion years ago. The rover found traces of the molecule on rocks extracted from the area. The rocks also contain sulfur, which scientists speculate helped preserve the organic ones even when the rocks were exposed to harsh radiation on the planet's surface.

Scientists are quick to say that the presence of these organic molecules is not sufficient evidence for ancient life on Mars, as molecules could have been formed by non-living processes. But it remains one of the most amazing discoveries, which could lead to future revelations. Especially when one considers the other surprising finds that Curiosity discovered about five years ago.

The rover periodically analyzes the air around it, and in 2014 found that the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means something, somewhere on Mars, is resupplying the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at once. The methane level rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet were breathing it.

NASA suspects that methane comes from the depths of the planet's surface. Temperature variations on the surface of Mars cause the molecule to flow upwards to higher or lower levels. For example, in the Martian winter the gas could be trapped in underground ice cream crystals. These crystals, called clatrates, melt in summer and release the gas. However, the source of methane remains a complete mystery.

The world of astrobiology considers both studies as historical milestones. According to this information, Mars is not a dead planet. On the contrary, it is quite active and may be changing and becoming more habitable.

Of course, this means that further research is needed. Scientists say they need to send new equipment to Mars, equipment that can measure air and soil more accurately. Missions are already underway. The European Space Agency's ExoMars ship will land in 2020 and will be able to drill on Mars to analyze what it finds. In addition, NASA is sending another Mars Rover in the same year to collect samples of Martian soil and return them to Earth.

The possibility of living on Mars has fascinated humans for generations. He has been the subject of endless novels and science fiction films. Are we alone in the universe or have there been other forms of life within our Solar System? If the current missions to the Red Planet continue, it seems as if we can discover the answer very soon.

For 85 years, it was little more than a grey spot without features on the class maps of the solar system, but, on July 15, Pluto was first seen in high resolution, revealing spectacular mountain ranges made of solid water ice on a scale to rival the Alps or the Rockies.
The extraordinary images of the ancient ninth planet and its great moon, Charon, carried 4 billion miles back to Earth from the New Horizons spacecraft, marking the climax of a mission that has been on silently for almost a decade.
Alan Stern, the main investigator of the mission, described the images as a “home run” for the team. “New Horizons is already returning amazing results. The data looks absolutely magnificent, and Pluto and Charon are simply mind-blowing.”
One of the biggest surprises was the discovery that “there are mountains in the Kuiper belt, ” the mysterious “third zone” of the solar system, where Pluto sits among some 100,000 smaller frozen objects. John Spencer, a mission scientist, said the mountains seem to be about 11,000 feet tall and several hundred miles wide. “They are quite important mountains.”
The detailed picture of an edge of the dwarf planet did not show a single crater, indicating that the surface has recently been “paved” by geological activity, which could include dramatic geysers firing ice feathers into the atmosphere or cryovolcanos bursting into ice explosions instead of molten rock.
In a wink at the former status of Pluto as the ninth planet, until it was degraded to a dwarf planet in 2006, the NASA press conference began with a reduction of spectacular images of the sun and the eight official planets. “We’ve focused what used to be a blur point of light,” said NASA spokesman Dwayne Brown, as scientists and journalists expected the image to be unveiled.
Stern described the images as “only skiing the surface” of what would be learned about the planet over the next year. They've already produced some surprises. Scientists believe that mountains are made of water ice with only a thin layer of “exotic” ice, methane and nitrogen. “You can’t make mountains with methane and nitrogen,” Spencer said.
“The water ice is strong enough to hold big mountains and that’s what we think we’re seeing here. This is the first time we've seen this. Methane and nitrogen are just a coating.” It is likely that the Pluto Mountains have not formed more than 100 million years ago, most recently given the 4.56 billion-year-old solar system. This suggests that the foreground region, which covers about 1% of Pluto's surface, may remain geologically active. The images are the first to show mountains of ice outside the moons of giant planets and raises the question of what kind of geological process the mountain landscape could be generating.
The structures, along with the softness of Pluto's surface, suggest that geological activity is taking place and softening depressions caused by asteroid impacts. Scientists believe that this process of “pavementation” could be the result of the internal heat that softens the rock and ice or snowfalls that cover the surface. For the scale, the images are so detailed that, if the ship was flying over London, we could choose the tracks at Heathrow Airport.
The distance to Pluto – 5 billion km – means that it takes hours of New Horizons to send a single photo and it will take 16 months to send all the data you have accumulated during the flight. The team also announced that the visible heart-shaped feature in Pluto will now be known as the Tombaugh Regio, in honor of Clyde Tombaugh, who discovered the dwarf planet in 1930.
Charon's new vision reveals a varied and complex terrain. An area of cliffs and valleys that extend about 1,000 km suggests a generalized fracture of Charon's surface, which could also be the result of geological activity. The image also shows a dramatic cannon estimated to be 7 to 9 km deep.
Cathy Olkin, a missionary scientist, said: “Charon just blew his socks off when today we have the new image. The team just got booed.
Only in this image is there so much interesting science.” Pluto is believed to be composed of about two thirds of rock enclosed in a pile of ice, with surface temperatures of about 230C. As the £460 million mission travels to Kuiper's belt, scientists expect it to open a window over the ancient solar system and the origins of the planets, potentially helping to explain the formation of the Earth itself.
Andrew Coates, head of planetary science at Mullard Space Science Laboratory, said: “These Kuiper belt objects are the building blocks of the outer solar system. They are all very cold – it is like a deep cosmic freeze. It is the best way to preserve the history of the solar system. That's what's fascinating about this. It’s a really exciting time for the exploration of the solar system.”
In August 2015, the mission scientists will choose which of the two objects they will visit next. NASA estimates that the ship will be able to continue recording and broadcasting until the mid 2030s. Then, your plutonium energy source will run out and shut down, drifting outward to the edge of the solar system and deep space beyond.
New Horizons also observed smaller members of the Pluto system, which includes four other moons: Nix, Hydra, Styx and Kerberos. A new sneaky image of Hydra is the first to reveal its apparent irregular shape and size, estimated at about 43 by 33 km. “New Horizons is a true exploration mission, which shows us why basic scientific research is so important,” said John Grunsfeld, associate administrator of NASA’s Scientific Mission Management.
“The mission has had nine years to create expectations about what we would see during the closest approach to Pluto and Charon. Today, we get the first sample of the scientific treasure collected during those critical moments and I can tell you that it dramatically exceeds those high expectations.”
Observations also indicate that Hydra's surface is likely to be covered with aquatic ice. Future images will reveal more clues about the formation of this, and the other moon, billions of years ago.

text:
According to Oxfam, the vast fortunes of the world’s 100 richest billionaires are increasing inequality and hampering the world’s ability to cope with poverty.
The charity said that accumulation of wealth and income on an unprecedented scale, often at the expense of safe jobs and decent wages for the poorest, undermined the ability of people who survive with help or low wages to improve their situation and escape poverty.
Oxfam said the world's poorest could get out of poverty several times if the 100 richest billionaires gave away the money they made in 2012.
Without pointing the finger at people, the charity argued that the net income of $240 billion accumulated in 2012 by the 100 richest billionaires would be enough to make history of extreme poverty four times more.
It is rare for charities to attack the rich, who are generally seen as a source of funding. Bill Gates and Warren Buffett are among a group of 40 U.S. billionaires who have pledged much of their wealth to help projects, but there is little detail about the level of their annual donations. Nor have their actions been matched by Russian, Middle Eastern or Chinese billionaires.
In the report, The Cost of Inequality: How Wealth and Income Extremes Hurt Us All, published just before the World Economic Forum in Davos, the organization calls on world leaders to restrict income extremes and commit themselves to reducing inequality at least to 1990 levels.
The report found that the richest 1 per cent had increased their income by 60 per cent in the past 20 years, and the financial crisis accelerated rather than slowed the process.
Barbara Stocking, Oxfam’s executive director, said extreme wealth was “economically inefficient, politically corrosive, socially divisive and environmentally destructive.”
He said studies show that countries suffer from low levels of investment and growth, as workers are forced to survive with a lower proportion of total income.
She said: “We can no longer pretend that the creation of wealth for a few will inevitably benefit many – too often the opposite is true.”
The report says that the issue affects all parts of the world. “In the United Kingdom, inequality is rapidly returning to levels not seen since the time of Charles Dickens [the 19th century novelist]. In China, the top 10 percent now takes home almost 60 percent of income. Chinese inequality levels are now similar to those of South Africa, which is now the most unequal and significantly more unequal country in the world than at the end of apartheid.”
In the US, the share of national income reaching the top 1% has doubled since 1980 from 10 to 20%, the report says. For the top 0.01%, the share of national income is above the levels last seen in the 1920s.
The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have argued that extreme income inequality undermines growth and both organizations have sought to link their loans to programmes that limit the growth of inequality.
It is estimated that members of the richest 1 per cent use up to 10,000 times more carbon than the average United States citizen.
Oxfam said world leaders should learn from countries like Brazil, which has grown rapidly while reducing inequality.
Stocking said: “We need a new global deal to reverse decades of growing inequality. As a first step, world leaders should formally commit themselves to reducing inequality to the levels observed in 1990.”
He said closing tax havens, which the Tax Justice Network says have up to $31 billion, or up to a third of all world wealth, could produce $189 billion in additional tax revenue.

Michael Jackson's ex-wife and the mother of her two older children, Debbie Rowe, has agreed not to challenge the singer's mother for child custody, according to a joint statement by Rowe and Katherine Jackson's lawyers.
Debbie Rowe will not pursue custody of the children she had with Michael Jackson, says a lawyer.
The agreement does not imply any financial payment to Rowe other than the continuation of the spousal support payments that Michael Jackson personally agreed to make to Rowe after his divorce, lawyers said.
Rowe will get visiting rights with the children and the time, frequency and form of the visits will be implemented in accordance with the best interests of the children, as determined by a child psychologist selected jointly, and paid jointly by Jackson and Rowe, the announcement said.
Rowe never publicly said if she was going to fight Jackson's 79-year-old mother for the custody of her son and daughter, 11 and 12, and a court hearing on custody was delayed several times this month while both of them's lawyers spoke. Jackson's youngest son, 7 years old, was taken by a surrogate mother, whose name has not yet been released.
Katherine Jackson obtained temporary guardianship from the three children shortly after her death last month. Learn about other notable custody cases
The agreement must be approved by the judge. A custody hearing is scheduled for Monday before Los Angeles County High Court Judge Mitchell Beckloff.
Beckloff will also hear discussions on Monday about Jackson's estate and who will control it. Katherine Jackson is asking the court for more involvement in the estate business. Look what could have happened in Jackson's last few hours.
Jackson's family attorney, Londell McMillan, said the family was pleased that the custody issue was resolved and handled carefully, thoughtfully and politely by the parties and their representatives.
We were all united in our goals to do what is best for Michael's wonderful children, and both Mrs. Jackson as Debbie Rowe were on the same page, McMillan said. Consequently, although important issues had to be resolved, it was not a legal challenge, but rather a process - LRB- of -RRB - which did the right thing for the right reasons.
Rowe's lawyer, Eric George, said that women and their lawyers participated in a dignified discussion that resulted in a worthy outcome.
The only consideration between the parties was the best interests of the children, George said. I am proud to have worked with those professionals who represented Mrs. Jackson, and I'm particularly proud of Deborah for her integrity and self-denial.
Efforts to resolve who will control Jackson's estate have not been so friendly.
Earlier this month, Beckloff granted temporary control to executors named in his 2002 will: John Branca, Jackson's long-time personal lawyer, and John McClain, a music industry executive and long-time friend.
McMillan, in a statement issued on Wednesday, said Katherine Jackson was not disputing the will. But, he said, she wanted the judge to order the executors to disclose information about what he said was a suspicious circle of relationships involving them.
He said that the executors have denied Ms. Jackson access to critical information or have insisted on onerous and unreasonable restrictions on information about the dealings they are doing in the name of the inheritance.
McMillan, in an interview with CBS on Thursday, estimated that the Jackson estate was worth $2 billion, while the executors have estimated in court that its value is about $500 million.
The will placed all assets in a family trust that benefited her mother, her three children, and nameless charities.
Jackson's children have been living with their paternal grandmother in their Encino, California, home since their father's death on June 25.
They read the news on the Web and the reports, McMillan said. I really tried to push the media to be responsible for how they try to handle this issue because there are three precious children involved.
The eldest son, Michael Joseph Jackson Jr., better known as Prince Michael, was born in February 1997. One daughter, Paris Michael Katherine Jackson, was born the following year.
Details of how children were conceived -- and who the biological father was -- have been carefully guarded in the midst of much public speculation.
The couple divorced in 1999 with Rowe giving Jackson full custody while she got a $8.5 million settlement, according to court documents. Jackson later agreed to additional support.
Rowe resigned from Jackson's parental rights in 2001, but changed his mind more than two years later and sought temporary custody of the children. A California appeals court later ruled that his rights were unduly suppressed, opening the door to a possible custody battle.
CNN Randi Kaye, Kay Jones and Allison Blakely contributed to this report.

text:
Protesters in a Turkish border town hit by a double car-bombing a week ago clashed with police on Saturday, while expressing anger over the government's response to the attack.
About 50 people were killed and about 100 injured when the explosions exploded in the southern city of Reyhanli, across the border of Idlib province in Syria, on 11 May. One was in the town hall of the community and the other was in front of a post office.
Saturday's protest began relatively peacefully, but went down into chaos when street clashes broke out with the police.
Protesters threw stones and bottles at the police, who responded by firing tear gas canisters and high-pressure paint balls. The officers also pulled out a water cannon.
Women and children ran out of the scene as thick clouds of tear gas spread through the streets at the heart of the confrontation.
Police prevented protesters from reaching the explosion site in the centre of the city, which is located in Hatay province in southern Turkey.
The police have not yet commented on the clashes, which calmed down after less than an hour.
The protest, which began with several thousand people but was reduced to a hard core of several hundred when the problem broke out, was intended to show support and solidarity for the people of Reyhanli following the deadly bombings.
Many people in the city are angry at the government's response and say their decision to take Syrian refugees fleeing the conflict in their country has made Turkey a target of attacks.
The crowd sang for Erdogan and the government to resign.
A family of protesters mourned the death of Ayten Calim, a 20-year-old secretary of Reyhanli who died in the bombings last Saturday.
His brother, Halim Calim, said: We are here to express our pain. He and another brother wore Turkish flags and a banner with Ayten's photo on it that read, "We won't forget it."
Some have criticized Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for traveling to the United States this week rather than coming to Reyhanli to show support.
Erdogan has had talks with U.S. President Barack Obama and other U.S. officials in Washington.
Turkish President Abdullah Gul visited Reyhanli on Thursday, when he promised that those responsible for the car bombs would be held accountable.
Celalettin Lekesiz, governor of Hatay province, said on Saturday that security forces had arrested 17 people so far in connection with the bombings and are hunting four others, said the semi-official agency Anadolu.
The 21 suspects are Turkish nationals, he said.
Lekesiz said the security forces now had detailed information on how the suspects allegedly acquired the explosives and carried out the bombings, the news agency reported.
Interior Minister Muammer Guler and other Turkish officials have accused a former Marxist terrorist group of allegedly maintaining relations with Al Muhabarat, the Syrian intelligence services, according to Anadolu.
CNN's Laura Smith-Spark contributed to this report
label: C1

text:
Sony has reduced the price of the PlayStation 3 by $100, or 17 percent, in the United States, a measure that should boost the out-of-the-box sales of the video game console.
Starting Monday, the current 60 gigabyte PS3 model will cost $499 -- a $100 drop in prices.
The PlayStation 3, which includes a 60 gigabyte hard drive and a Blu-ray HD DVD player, will now cost $500, or $20 more than Microsoft's most expensive Xbox 360 version.
The PS3 continues to cost twice as much as Nintendo's Wii console, whose $250 and motion detection controller has turned it into a best-seller despite its lack of cutting-edge graphics and hard disk.
Our initial expectation is that sales will at least double, said Jack Tretton, executive director of Sony Computer Entertainment America, in an interview.
We have managed to put our production problems behind us on PlayStation 3, reaching a position to pass on savings to consumers, and our attitude is the sooner the better.
The price drop on Monday was widely anticipated by industry analysts despite Sony President Ryoji Chubachi telling Reuters last week that the company had no immediate plans for one.
Michael Pachter, an analyst at Wedbush Morgan, said Sony's price reduction would not double sales, but could increase them by 50 percent to about 120,000 units a month.
The biggest importance is that Sony is pointing to the market that we're lowering the cost curve pretty fast at doing this thing. It's a very consumer-friendly move, Pachter said.
Sony's move comes two days before the start of the annual E3 fair of the gaming industry in Santa Monica, California, where some expect Microsoft to respond with its first price cuts on the Xbox 360.
Nintendo, whose Wii is selling so well that it is still hard to find in stores eight months after its launch, is not expected to move in prices.
The Xbox 360 and Wii have sold the PS3 on several occasions in the crucial US market, leaving Sony, whose PlayStation 2 dominated the latest generation of consoles, in the unknown position of catching up.
Sony has the price reduction to help you significantly increase PS3 sales before the crucial holiday shopping season that represents most of the annual sales of highly profitable gaming software.
Sony is also presenting a new version of the PS3 with an 80 gigabyte hard drive and a copy of Motorstorm, an all-terrain racing game that has already sold a million copies.
The new model will sell for $600 and is aimed at players who expect to download a lot of games and other content from Sony's flourishing online network.
Sony also expects the PS3 to win some converts after Microsoft's admission last week that the failure rate of its Xbox 360 console had been unacceptably high, forcing it to reserve $1 billion in repair costs.
We are especially proud that the PlayStation 3 has the lowest failure rate of any PlayStation product. It's absolutely the gold standard, Tretton said.
The quality of the product and the long-term viability is what ultimately wins. E-mail to a friend

text:
Much of today's business is carried out across international borders, and while most of the global business community could share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication could differ greatly from culture to culture. The lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can lead to unfair trials, misunderstandings and ruptures in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in business labeling around the world that could help keep you in a good place when you are then working with someone from a different culture.
Addressing someone
When discussing this topic in a training course, a German apprentice and a British apprentice entered into a heated debate about whether it was appropriate for someone with a doctorate to use the corresponding title on their business card. The British apprentice argued that anyone who was not a doctor who expected to be treated as 'Dr' was disgustingly pompous and full of themselves. The German apprentice, however, argued that the hard work and years of education he put on winning that the doctorate should give them full rights to expect to be addressed as 'Dr'.
This marked difference of opinion about something that could be conceived as minor and thus easily overlooked shows that we often assign meaning even to the most mundane practices. When the things we are used to are done differently, it could provoke the strongest reactions in us. While many continental and Latin American Europeans prefer to be treated with a title, for example, Mr or Mrs and her surname when they meet someone in a business context for the first time, Americans, and increasingly British, now tend to prefer to use their first names. The best thing you can do is listen and watch your conversation partner go and, if you're not sure yet, don't be afraid to ask them how they'd like to be approached.
Smiling
A famous Russian proverb claims that "a smile without reason is a sign of idiocy" and a so-called "smile of respect" is seen as insincere and often regarded with suspicion in Russia. However, in countries such as the United States, Australia and Great Britain, the smile is often interpreted as a sign of openness, friendship and respect, and is often used to break the ice.
In a research on smiles across cultures, researchers found that smiling individuals were considered smarter than non-smiling people in countries such as Germany, Switzerland, China and Malaysia. However, in countries such as Russia, Japan, South Korea and Iran, the images of smiling faces were described as less intelligent than the non-smiling ones. Meanwhile, in countries like India, Argentina and Maldives, the smile was associated with dishonesty.
Visual contact
An American or British person might be looking their customers in the eye to show that they are paying all the attention to what is said, but if that customer is from Japan or Korea, they might find direct contact to the eyes uncomfortable or even disrespectful. In some parts of South America and Africa, prolonged eye contact could also be considered a challenging authority. In the Middle East, eye contact between genders is considered inappropriate, although eye contact within a gender could mean honesty and truthfulness.
Being more aware of possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of bad communication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to the building of good business relations. Although national cultures could play a role in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also greatly influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. Therefore, knowledge of potential differences must be something we have in our minds, rather than something we use to frame individuals of an entire nation.
label: C1

text:
Virunga National Park, home to rare mountain gorillas, but targeted for oil exploration by a British company, could earn $400 million a year because of tourism, hydropower and carbon credits, a WWF report said.
But if the UNESCO World Heritage that extends over the equator is exploited for oil, as the Congolese government and SOCO International exploration company expect, it could lead to devastating pollution and permanent conflict in an already unstable region, says the conservation agency.
SOCO International is the only company that seeks to explore within the boundaries of Virunga Park. SOCO insists that its operations in the Congo would be limited to an area in the park known as Block V, and would not affect gorillas.
SOCO President Rui de Sousa said: “Despite WWF’s views, SOCO is extremely sensitive to the environmental importance of Virunga National Park. It is irrefutable that oil companies continue to play a central role in today’s global energy supply and that a successful oil project has the potential to transform the economic and social well-being of an entire country.”
He added: “Unfortunately, the park has been in decline for many years, and has officially fallen below the standards required for a World Heritage site. The development potential could only be the catalyst that reverses this trend.”
However, Raymond Lumbuenamo, director of the Democratic Republic of the Congo at the Kinshassa-based WWF, said security inside and around the park would deteriorate further if SOCO continued its exploration plans.
“The security situation is already bad. The UN is involved with combat units and the M23 rebel force is inside the park. Oil would be a curse. Conflict always increases. It would attract human sabotage. The park could become the Niger Delta. Developing Virunga for oil will do nothing better.
“The population is already very dense, with more than 350 people per square kilometer. When you take part of the land (for oil), you put more pressure on the rest. Oil would not provide many jobs; people would flood in search of work,” he said.
One fear is that the area is seismically active and another eruption of one of the volcanoes in the park could damage the infrastructure of the oil company and lead to oil spills in the lakes. “Virunga’s rich natural resources benefit the Congolese people, not foreign oil seekers. Our country’s future depends on sustainable economic development,” Lumbuenamo said.
“For me, choosing the conservation option is the best option. Once you’ve started drilling for oil, there’s no turning back,” he said.
But Lumbuenamo agreed that while gorillas were safe today, the chances of the park generating its potential of $400m per year were remote. “It would be difficult to make the amount of money the report talks about. Virunga used to be a very quiet place and can be again. The security situation at the moment is bad. The UN is involved with combat units. It’s not as quiet as it used to be.”
According to the WWF report, park ecosystems could support hydropower generation, fishing and ecotourism, and play an important role in safe water supply, climate regulation and soil erosion prevention.
The park, the oldest and most diverse in Africa, houses more than 3,000 different types of animals, but is now heavily populated by desperately poor people, many of whom fled there after the Rwanda massacre in 1994.
“In total, the park could support 45,000 permanent jobs in the region. In addition, people around the world could gain immense value simply knowing that the park is well managed and safe for future generations,” the report says.
“Virunga represents a valuable asset for the Democratic Republic of the Congo and contributes to Africa’s heritage as the continent’s oldest and most biodiverse park,” the report continues. “Plans to explore oil and exploit oil reserves put Virunga’s potential value at risk,” he says.
“This is where we draw the line. Oil companies are at the door of one of the most precious and fragile places in the world, but we will not rest until Virunga is safe from this potential environmental disaster,” said Lasse Gustavsson, executive director of WWF International. “Virunga has snow fields and lava fields, but it should not have oil fields.”
The UNESCO World Heritage Committee called for the cancellation of all Virunga oil permits and appealed to the Total SA and SOCO International plc concessionaires not to conduct explorations at World Heritage sites. Total is committed to respecting Virunga's current limit, leaving UK-based SOCO as the only oil company with plans to explore within the park.

text:
A few months before his death, Carl Sagan recorded a message of hope for potential Mars explorers, telling them: “Whatever the reason you’re on Mars, I’m glad you’re there. And I wish I was with you.
Seventeen years after the pioneering astronomer presented his hopeful vision of the future in 1996, a company from the Netherlands proposes to make Sagan's dreams of reaching Mars a reality. The company, Mars One, plans to send four astronauts on a trip to the Red Planet to establish a human colony in 2023. But there are a couple of serious problems.
First, when on Mars their bodies will have to adapt to the surface gravity that is 38% of that on Earth. It is believed that this would cause such a total physiological change in bone density, muscle strength, and circulation that travelers could no longer survive under Earth conditions. Secondly, and directly related to the first, you will have to say goodbye to all your family and friends, as the agreement does not include a return ticket.
The Mars One website states that a return “cannot be anticipated or expected.” To return, they would need a fully assembled and fed rocket capable of escaping from the gravitational field of Mars, life support systems on board capable of a journey of up to seven months and the ability to dock with a space station in orbit on Earth or perform a safe re-entry and landing. “None of them is a small effort,” says the site, which requires “substantial technical capacity, weight and cost.”
However, the project has already had 10,000 applicants, according to the company's medical director, Norbert Kraft. He told The Guardian that the applicants to date were between 18 and 62 years of age and, although they included women, tended to be men.
The reasons they gave for wanting to go were varied, he said. An American woman named Cynthia, who was 32 years old, told the company that it was a “childish imagination” of her going to Mars. She described a trip that her mother had taken to a conference at the University of Wisconsin in the early 1990s.
He said the professor had been Sagan and asked him if he thought humans would land on Mars in his life. Cynthia said: “He in turn asked me if I wanted to be trapped in a ’tin tin’ spaceship for the two years it would take to get there. I said 'yes', he smiled, and he told me in all seriousness, yes, I absolutely believed that humans would come to Mars in my life.
She told the project: “When I first found out about the Mars One project, I thought, this is my chance – that the childhood dream could become a reality. He could be one of the pioneers, building the first settlement on Mars and teaching people back home that there are still unexplored territories that humans can reach.”
The main attributes Mars One is looking for in sitting astronauts are resilience, adaptability, curiosity, confidence and ingenuity, according to Kraft. They must also be over 18 years of age.
Founded in 2010 by Bas Lansdorp, engineer, Mars One says he has developed a realistic road map and funding plan for the project based on existing technologies and that the mission is perfectly feasible. The website states that the basic elements necessary for life are already present on the planet. For example, water can be extracted from the ice in the soil and Mars has sources of nitrogen, the main element in the air we breathe. The colony will be powered by specially adapted solar panels, he says.
Mars One said he had signed a contract with the U.S. firm Paragon Space Development Corporation to take the first steps in developing the life support system and space suits suitable for the mission.
The project will cost $6 billion, a sum Lansdorp has said it expects to be partially met through the sale of broadcasting rights. “The broadcasting revenue from the London Olympics was almost enough to fund a mission to Mars,” Lansdorp said in an interview with ABC News.
Another ambassador of the project is Paul Römer, co-creator of Big Brother, one of the first and most successful reality TV programs.
On the website, Römer gave an indication of how the project could proceed: “This mission to Mars could be the world’s largest media event,” Römer said. “Reality meets the endless talent contest and everyone is watching.”
The aim is to establish a permanent human colony, according to the company's website. The first team would land on the surface of Mars in 2023 to begin building the colony, with a team of four astronauts every two years after that.
However, the project does not lack its skeptics, and concerns have been raised about how astronauts could reach the planet and establish a colony with all the necessary life support and other requirements.
Professor Gerard’t Hooft, winner of the 1999 Nobel Prize in Theoretical Physics, is the project’s ambassador. T Hooft admits that there are unknown health risks. Radiation is “of a very different nature” from anything that has been tested on Earth, he said.
The mission hopes to inspire generations to “believe that all things are possible, that anything can be achieved,” as well as the landings of Apollo Moon.
“Mars One believes that it is not only possible, but imperative that we establish a permanent settlement on Mars to accelerate our understanding of the formation of the solar system, the origins of life and, of equal importance, our place in the universe,” he says.

Russell Crowe, born in New Zealand in 1964, is a musician, actor and philanthropist. He has gained considerable success in the film industry. Crowe spent much of his life living in Australia and the United States, but it was in New Zealand that he first became involved in the entertainment industry. As a teenager, Crowe began to develop his musical talent, but found little success. He had several of his songs played on New Zealand radio, but none made the lists. He performed again after moving to Australia, where he appeared in several stage productions, including the Rocky Horror Picture Show. He obtained a role in the television comedy Necinos, and made his film debut in 1990.

Crowe became a popular movie star for her performance in the epic film Gladiator. In the film he portrays a Roman general who is programmed to become a high-ranking officer, but the leader dies, and is replaced by his evil, neurotic son. The new leader fears Crowe's character, and strips him of his rank. He was put into a state of slavery, but becomes a gladiator champion, and leads a revolt against the leader's regime. The film won the Academy Award for Best Film, and Crowe won the Best Actor Award.
He continued his success at Gladiator with a series of highly entertaining films, culminating in the 2001 film A Beautiful Mind. The film follows the life of Nobel Prize winner John Nash. Crowe plays expertly Nash, who is brilliant, but suffers from paranoid schizophrenia. Crowe's performance earned him several awards for Best Actor and Best Oscar for Film. Crowe was also critically acclaimed for his portrayal of the fictional character Captain Jack Aubrey.
Crowe has been generous with his fortune. He has donated money to several cases in his home country, New Zealand, Australia, and the United States.

text:
The controversial auction of a Banksy mural that disappeared from the wall of a shop in Northern London under mysterious circumstances stopped dramatically moments before it was to fall under the hammer.
Slave Labour, a spray painted artwork depicting a child making the Union flag pay off and viewed as a critical social commentary on last year's diamond jubilee, was expected to be sold for about $700,000 at a street and contemporary art sale in Florida.
But auctioneer Frederic Thut, the owner of the art house of the Miami Fine Arts auction, who had refused all week to disclose the seller's identity or how he became ready for sale through his gallery, announced that the piece, along with a second work by the secret British street artist, had been withdrawn.
It wouldn't give a reason, but the community leaders in Haringey, who led a vocal campaign to stop the sale of the artwork that was imprisoned from the wall of a Poundland in Wood Green, were jubilant.
“One of our two demands was that it doesn’t sell and the other was that we get it back, so we’re halfway there,” said Alan Strickland, Haringey’s councilman.
“I will write to the auction house as a matter of urgency to clarify what happened and what will happen next, but for now we are very happy that because of the pressure and strong opinions of the people of Wood Green, a community campaign in London has had an impact on the United States. It is a real victory for the people.”
Claire Kober, leader of the Haringey Council, wrote to the Arts Council of England and the Mayor of Miami, Tomás Regalado, asking them to intervene to stop the sale, but it seems that the decision to withdraw the article came from the gallery owners in consultation with their lawyers. The FBI refused to confirm the reports they were asked to investigate.
Several hours after the auction was concluded, the auction house issued a brief statement claiming that it had persuaded the owners of the two Banksys to remove them from the sale. “Although there is no legal problem with the sale of lots six and seven by Banksy, FAAM convinced its sellers to withdraw these lots from the auction.”
Nearly 30 potential buyers attended the sale of 106 lots listed in the catalog for the sale of modern, contemporary and street art in the modern Wynwood neighborhood of Miami. The three-hour auction continued with other early lots selling in excess of their order prices.
Critics have accused the auction house of selling stolen goods, but Thut insisted earlier in the week that the seller, whom he described as a “well - known collector, ” was the rightful owner and that the sale was legal.
He added that his gallery had been flooded with emails and phone calls from the United Kingdom, saying that many of them were abusive or offensive, but said he supported the inclusion of parts in the sale because he would preserve them.
The second Banksy to be auctioned, a 2007 work of art entitled Wet Dog that was removed from a wall in Bethlehem and estimated to be worth up to $800,000, disappeared from the online catalog of the auction house at lunchtime on Saturday, but Slave Labor was still on sale until 3pm start time.
Thut said that the two pieces, supplied to him by separate owners, none of them British, were important works on the street art scene and deserved buyers “whose first interest is in art and its preservation. ”
He said he'd keep the collector's privacy for sale. “We respect our customers and their confidentiality. It's not our decision to [Banksy] come back. We just sell it. We don't have control of her.
A spokesman for Poundland said he had no idea who took the 4-foot x 5-foot slab off the side of the tent he rented in Turnpike Lane. Lawyers for the owner of the building, a company called Wood Green Investments Ltd, have refused to confirm whether it had anything to do with the episode.
Banksy himself has not commented on the furor of Slave Labour, but has previously condemned those who have tried to sell their works of art, speaking before the proposed sale of five of their pieces at a 2011 auction in New York. None of them found a buyer.
Stephan Keszler, the distributor behind that auction, believes that selling Banksy's works without his permission is legitimate.
“He does something on other people’s property without asking. The owner of the property can do whatever he wants with it,” Keszler said.

text:
Brazil's latest funk sensation, Anitta, has won millions of fans by taking the sound of the favela in the main stream, but she is at the center of a debate about skin color.
Anti-discrimination activists and social commentators say the fastest rising star in the music industry has had to sacrifice its blackness to become the predominantly white middle class market.
The controversy was provoked by the publication of photographs of that time and now showing a dramatic lightening of Anitta's skin tone since she signed an agreement with Warner.
In the first, when it was relatively unknown, it seemed darker. In the second – a marketing photo after it became famous – it seems paler. If this was the result of whitening products and aesthetic surgery or – most likely – Photoshop retouching, the contrast has rekindled the discussion about whether it is necessary to be pale to get ahead in Brazil.
Jarid Arraes, a psychology student and blogger, wrote a post criticizing the latent discrimination in the media and marketing that Anitta's makeover felt represented. “People refuse to accept that they are racist and think they live in a multiracial democracy, but statistics show that they are far from the case. Whitening shows us a deeply intolerant society that does not support diversity. White is the image of the rich, the pleasant, the successful, the good, while people see black as the opposite of all that.”
Born Larissa of Macedo Machado, the future diva was a church singer in her childhood. In her adolescence, a name was made on the scene of the funk dance of Rio de Janeiro as a dancer and singer.
It has now exploded into public consciousness with an album and a highly successful single, Show das Poderosas, which topped the charts and attracted 52 million YouTube hits.
Although first worshiped as a pop idol with a strong message and some catchy melodies, its sponsors project it as a cultural bridge between predominantly black and mixed race peoples on the slopes of Rio and the richest and whitest communities below.
He has toned the suggestive dance, the gangsta references and the explicit lyrics of the funk dance. Now, however, questions are being asked about whether she – or her marketing team – have gone too far in redefining her image to attract a more lucrative population. “If pop stars have curly hair, they will feel compelled to straighten it out. If they have a large nose, they will be forced to get rhinoplasty,” Arraes said. “Create a vicious circle for self-esteem.”
This is a delicate issue in this nation largely of mixed races. Brazil, one of the last major countries in the world to ban slavery, has the largest population of African descent outside Africa, but race and descent are less important here than color. And, despite the nation's goal of being a multiracial democracy, there is a clear link between skin tone and inequality.
In Brazilian cities, white workers earn about twice as much as those of African descent. Until 2011, black or mixed students also spent two years less in school on average.
The government says the gap is closing thanks to quota systems for university places and other forms of affirmative action. But the gulf is still obvious. The vast majority of business and government executives are white, while most of the smaller jobs are done by black and mixed-race workers. Stroll through Ipanema, Gávea or other luxury districts and you are much more likely to see black babysitters pushing strollers with white children than a white babysitter pushing a black child.
Defining color is complex. People who defined themselves as white were in the minority for the first time in the most recent census in 2010. Among the 197 million inhabitants, 82 million said they were “pardu” (mixed race), 15 million blacks, 2 million Asians and 0.5% indigenous.
Sylvio Ferreira, professor of psychology at the Federal University of Pernambuco, believes that Anitta has won the hearts of the middle class by taking a rebellious sound and making it tamed and more enjoyable for everyone.
“Was this achieved with racial whitening? No,” he said. “What happened was a change in the social space where Anitta produced her art: from the periphery to the center.”
Others agree that the question of colour is exaggerated. Maycon of Mattos Batista, a financial analyst who worked with Anitta while she was an intern, said there had been a big change in Anitta's image, but not in her color.
“I don’t think it’s whitening; it’s more the way they’re producing it with makeup, stylists and the way it’s dressed,” he said. “I don’t think that was because of the pressure being exerted on her. He always liked to brag, sing and dance. That was a natural thing for her. I think it is because of this naturalness that she is where she is today.”
Leandro Silva de Souza, a racial equality activist in the northeastern city of Salvador, said that prejudice did not lie in society, but in music producers and media executives. The audience, he said, showed that they were interested in music for their own good by choosing Ellen Oléria – a black lesbian – as the recent winner of the The Voice Brazil talent contest.
The Guardian was unable to reach Anitta for comments. But, in a recent interview, he described the need for identity to be self-defined.
“Almighty is a woman who does not need to be beautiful, but has so much attitude that she is wonderful, she is powerful. What I try to convey in my work for everyone is that we can be what we want.”
label: C1

text:
Although much of his work, and possibly almost all the best of it, was firmly within the discipline of blues, BB King was always open-minded and interested when found in other environments, bridging musical and cultural differences with affability and skill. Perhaps it’s premature to talk about “the last of the bluesmen,” but it’s hard to imagine any future blues artist pairing King’s influence on musicians by the thousand and the audience by the million in a career spanning 65 years.
Riley B King (the B did not seem to represent a name) was born near Itta Bena, Mississippi and grew up with the limited prospects of an African-American agricultural worker, a barrier that he gradually worked to overcome when he learned the basics of the guitar from a friend of the family and tuned his singing with a quartet of gospel singers. At the age of 20, he moved to Memphis.
In a couple of years, he was playing regularly at a bar in West Memphis, Arkansas. He also became a disc jockey, presenting a program at a Memphis radio station. His billing, “The Beale Street Blues Boy”, was reduced to “Blues Boy King” and from there to “BB”. After a single session in 1949 for a Nashville label, King began recording for the West Coast-based Modern Records in 1950.
It had its first success in 1952, with a dramatic rearrangement of Three O’Clock Blues, who headed the R&B list for 15 weeks; it was the first on a hit list like Please Love Me, You Molest Me Baby and Sweet Sixteen. In these and his dozens of other recordings, most of them his own compositions, King developed an innovative style rooted in the history of blues. He was always willing to praise the musicians who had influenced him and usually mentioned T-Bone Walker first.
“I’ve done everything I can to get that sound,” he told Guitar Player magazine. In an interview in 2001, he said: “If T-Bone Walker had been a woman he would have asked her to marry me,” but he would also quote blues guitarists Blind Lemon Jefferson and Lonnie Johnson and jazz musicians Charlie Christian and Django Reinhardt.
He once explained that his guitar technique was based in part on his lack of skill: “I started folding notes because I could never play bottleneck style, like Elmore James and Booker White. I loved that sound, but I just couldn’t do it.” He was equally self-predating about his singing, a sumptuous blend of honey and lemon, mixed half and half of crooners like Nat King Cole and blues screams like Joe Turner and Dr. Clayton. Probably his favorite composer and singer was Louis Jordan, whose music commemorated on the 1999 album Let the Good Times Roll.
Throughout the 1950s, King was the main blues artist on the black theater and club circuit in an endless one-night series. In 1956, it was supposed to fulfil 342 commitments. In 1962, he tried to change that pattern of work by signing with an important label, ABC, but the first albums under that contract, which he tried to remodel as a pop singer, were as unsatisfactory for his admirers as for ABC accountants.
The 1965 Live at the Regal album, however, demonstrated the durability of King's blues repertoire and has become iconic, a turning point in the early listening of many younger musicians. He had more hits on R&B with blues numbers, including How Blue Can You Get and Paying the Cost to Be the Boss, and, in 1969, he reached the top of the pop charts – where no blues artist had been for many years – with The Thrill Is Gone.
It took him some time to settle down with a rock audience, for which blues was largely defined by the Chicago school of Muddy Waters and Howlin’ Wolf, but was brought to his attention by musicians who admired him. “About a year and a half ago,” he said in 1969, “the kids suddenly started coming to me saying, ‘You’re the best blues guitarist in the world.’ And I would say, 'Who told you that?' And they said, 'Mike Bloomfield' or 'Eric Clapton'. It is to these young people that I owe my new popularity.” He gained more rock credibility with the 1970 Indianola Mississippi Seeds album, in which he collaborated with Carole King and Joe Walsh.
From then on, King was firmly established as “the chairman of the board of blues singers.” Guided by his manager, Sidney Seidenberg, he embarked on international concert tours that took him to Japan, Australia, China and Russia. He also gave concerts to prisoners at Cook County Prison in Chicago and San Quentin, experiences that led to their long participation in rehabilitation programs.
In 1990, King was diagnosed with diabetes and reduced his tour, but not so much so that his followers outside the US. They couldn't catch up with him every year or two. Although he would now hand over most of his sitting act, the strength of his singing and the fluidity of his game were only very gradually diminished. Celebrations for his 80th birthday in 2005 included an award-winning album of collaborations with Clapton, Mark Knopfler, Roger Daltrey, Gloria Estefan and others, tributes by musicians as diverse as Bono, Amadou Bagayoko and Elton John, and a farewell tour that proved not to be a farewell at all.
In 2009, King received a Grammy Award, for the best traditional blues album, for One Kind Favor. In 2012, he performed at a concert at the White House, where U.S. President Barack Obama joined him to sing Sweet Home Chicago. King got married twice and divorced twice. He is survived by 11 children by several companions; four others prejudged him.

Hillary Clinton sounded a populist tone in a burning campaign appearance on Wednesday, as she continued to reveal a political message before the mid-term elections.
The other side has done everything possible to divide you, he told several thousand Louisville fans. This choice is about the future.

Let's put another crack in the glass ceiling, and choose this amazing young woman for the U.S. Senate, Clinton urged the cheering audience.

Isn't it amazing that it's 2014, and we're still debating whether women deserve equal pay for equal work? She asked. If there's only one reason why you're going to vote in the next 20 days, put that on top of the list.
