text:
Sometimes life just isn't fair. Mark Zuckerberg created Facebook and is now worth an estimated $48 billion. James Goodfellow also invented something that millions of people around the world used every day, the ATM, but it didn't make him rich. In fact, he won only £10 from the patent and hasn't earned a penny more from it since.
“You can imagine how I feel when I see bankers receiving £1m bonuses. I wonder what contributed more to the banking industry than I did to deserve a £1m bonus. It doesn’t make much sense to me, but that’s the way of the world,” says Goodfellow.
It also bothers him that he is not seen as a good role model for inventors and engineers. He came up with an innovative invention that generated billions of pounds “and I have nothing, so who will want to follow James Goodfellow’s footsteps and get £10 if they have a fantastic success?”
There have been arguments for years about who should officially go down in history as the “inventor of the ATM” and, in 2005, a man named John Shepherd-Barron received an honor from the UK for banking services as the “inventor of the ATM”. However, the British government now says that it was Goodfellow who invented the ATM, so it seems that, after all the disputes, its place in history is now secured.
In the mid-1960s, Goodfellow worked as a development engineer and had been asked to devise a way to allow customers to withdraw money from banks on Saturdays. “Most people who worked during the week could not reach the bank. They wanted a solution. The solution was a machine that would issue cash on demand to a recognized customer,” he recalls. “I set out to develop a cash-emission machine and, for this to be a reality, I invented the PIN [personal identification number] and a coded token associated.”
This token took the form of a plastic card with holes pierced in it. The patent documents proposed a system that incorporated a card reader and buttons mounted on an external wall of the bank and said: “When the customer wishes to remove a package of banknotes from the system, simply insert his perforated card into the card reader of the system and operate the set of ten pushbuttons according to his personal identification number.”
Apart from the punched hole cards, which more or less describes today's ATM. After Goodfellow successfully demonstrated the methodology by producing a model, prototypes were built and the first machines were installed in 1967.
At about the same time, Shepherd-Barron was developing a rival cash distribution device. His machine did not use plastic cards, but checks impregnated with carbon-14, a slightly radioactive substance. The machine detected carbon-14, compared the check to a PIN and paid for the cash.
It is widely accepted that the Shepherd-Barron ATM was the “first in the world” when it comes to being installed and used by the public; the first, in a bank in northern London, was inaugurated on June 27, 1967, a month before Goodfellow ATM made its public debut. However, the patent for Goodfellow's machine was filed on May 2, 1966, 14 months before the London ATM came into service.
The rivalry between the two men bubbled when Shepherd-Barron received an official honor for his achievement. Goodfellow says: “My only great regret is that I never said anything about it until John Shepherd-Barron received the OBE in 2005. This honor was granted on the basis that he was the inventor of the ATM. That really stuck in my throat and ruined a bit of a fuss.” Shepherd-Barron is no longer alive to put his case, but, in a 2005 interview, he was withering quite a bit about his rival: “I don’t know him, but it’s clear that the difference between Goodfellow and us was that we thought through the whole concept of the system and that it was important for the banks that bought it. Your invention reminds me of the hovercraft, an elegant flaw.
The ATM has become a piece of technology that conquers the world and nothing – the contactless revolution, bitcoin, wearable technology, etc. – seems to be slowing down its growth: there are now 3 million ATMs worldwide, with a projected number of 4 million by 2020.
Goodfellow accepts that he did not invent the concept of a cash-emitting machine “but I did invent a way to do it. When people talk about the Wright brothers, they didn’t invent the concept of flying – everyone was trying to do it – but they did and got the credit for inventing the plane, so I think I should get the credit for inventing the ATM.”
The good news for Goodfellow is that this is starting to happen. The ATMInventor.com website concludes: “Who invented the idea of an ATM? We think it was Luther George Simjian. Who invented the ATM as we know it? We have to think it was James Goodfellow in Scotland for having a patent date of 1966. Who invented the ATM design we recognize today? We believe it was John D White for Docutel in the United States.”
Even better for Goodfellow, his achievement has been officially recognized in the latest edition of a 180-page guide called Life in the United Kingdom. In the section on “Great British Inventions of the 20th Century ” he says: “In the 1960s, James Goodfellow (1937-) invented the ATM or cashpoint machine.”
So after all these years, Goodfellow is finally being spoken in the same breath as John Logie Baird (TV), Alan Turing (Turing machine), Sir Frank Whittle (reaction engine) and Sir Tim Berners-Lee (World Wide Web). When asked what he did with the £10 he received in the 1960s, Goodfellow says he thinks he ruined it on a wild night, adding, “It didn’t change my life.” But, he concludes, it has been a good working life: “I was very happy doing the work I was doing.”
label: C1

text:
Immigration into the United States is a complicated and controversial issue. Since the founding of the country people have come from different countries in search of a better life and opportunities. However, immigration laws are always changing and complicated. This leads to many people arriving in the United States without adequate legal status. While some people call immigrants coming and staying in the United States "illegal," many find this term offensive. The most acceptable term is "undocumented" as they do not have the correct legal documents.

It is estimated that there are more than 11 million undocumented people in the United States. Although some people will say that there is no reason for immigrants to be undocumented in the United States, there are limits on the number of green cards, or legal permanent residence cards, people from certain countries can get. There are also long waiting lists, up to 14 years in some cases, for people coming from certain countries, to apply for legal status in the US. In addition there is a limited amount of visas, or permits, for people coming to the US. with manual work skills. Millions of undocumented people have been deported or returned to their home country under President Obama.
In 2013, the United States Senate passed a immigration reform bill. The law adds additional border security along the U.S.-Mexico border, and also makes it easier for immigrants to become citizens. The bill, which must also be approved by the House of Representatives, has not yet been tabled or voted by Congress. Because of this, many are asking President Obama to take steps to protect some of the undocumented, many of whom have been in the U.S. for many years and have children who are U.S. citizens.
label: C1

text:
More than six decades ago, the founder of the European Movement, Jean Monnet, shared his vision of the region's nascent union, prescribing money as a means of healing the wounds left by two world wars.
The merger of Europe's economic ties would force its nations to merge their sovereignty into that of a single European State.
For the French, a federal Europe was the natural progression of the new stability of the bloc.
A collection of like-minded countries whose shared goals were so clear that they would willingly surrender to their own governments for the greater good of the group.
That was 1952. A time when the future had great promises after the horrors of the past and everything seemed possible, even creating a new pseudo country. A place now known as the European Union.
Fast forward to this day and, although the EU has some shared governing bodies, such as a committee and a parliament, it is certainly not the whole of the United States that Monnet expected. Those with the same deeply rooted convictions and beliefs.
The glue that held their common ideologies was unleashed with the fall of the Berlin Wall.
Since then, a crisis between countries sharing the euro has reopened old wounds. Ironically, instead of uniting nations, their finances have threatened to destroy them.
This leaves us with a fundamental question: if the main task of the EU is no longer to provide peace, nor can it guarantee prosperity, then what should its role be?
Born from the ashes of Europe's turbulent past, the EU has achieved much for its members.
It has taught its citizens the value of commitment to violence, providing protection and strength in number.
It has increased prosperity thanks to the free movement of goods and labour caused by the single market, while the rights of consumers and workers have been strengthened and their health improved through the ban on smoking.
But the EU has also moved away from its original concept, its ranks swollen by a massive bureaucratic machine based in Brussels that, according to critics, is suffocating the industry and pushing members like the UK into the exit door.
The borders of the bloc have doubled with its endless absorption of former communist countries, extending the definition of Europe to its limits, making membership of this former elite club more a useful tool of foreign policy than an appreciated vision.
The EU faces a constant challenge that meets the expectations of its citizens and without two-tier policies has no hope of serving both the strong and weak economies of the bloc.
The EU needs a new vision of a new project for which its citizens can feel passionate.
And where else to start then this week's fundamental parliamentary elections.
label: C1

text:
For a traditional master navigator like Tua Pittman from Raratonga in the Cook Islands, a canoe is much more than a means of transportation. “The canoe is our island, the crew are the community and the navigator is the leader,” Pittman says. He goes on to explain that the opposite is also true. “An island is our canoe, the community is the crew members and the politicians and leaders are the sailors. In a canoe, you don't just go from one destination to another using the stars, the moon, the sun and the birds. Navigation is using the philosophies of being a leader to show its crew members the light of life.”
It has been a whirlwind week for the crews of the flotilla of four sailing canoes since they arrived in Sydney for the start of the World Park Congress. Tua's trip began in the Cook Islands on September 25. The first stage led the islanders to Samoa, then Fiji, Vanuatu and the Gold Coast, before heading south to Sydney. About 100 crew members participated in the various stages of the journey and their objective was to travel using only traditional navigation techniques. Unfortunately, Tua said, crews were forced to rely on modern navigational equipment sometimes to arrive in Australia in time for Congress.
The official title of the expedition is Mua Voyage and is a partnership between the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Oceania Regional Office and five Pacific island countries: Samoa, Tonga, New Zealand, Cook Islands and Fiji. The main objective of the 6,000-nautical-mile journey (11,000 km) was to convey a special message to the World Park Congress.
In part, the message read: “We see the signs of overexploitation. We no longer see fish and other marine creatures in the size, diversity, or abundance of the past. We are witnessing change as foreign fishing fleets fill our waters in a race to strip us of our resources. Our coral reefs, the largest in the world, and our mangroves and wetlands are disappearing. Our ocean is vast but not unlimited. The growing world population and the relentless pursuit of unsustainable development are reducing our ocean’s ability to sustain life.”
Despite the effort and urgency behind the Pacific Islander's message to congressional delegates, much of the last days of the Marine side of Congress were taken with an attempt to set a revised target for the amount of the ocean that needs to be protected in marine sanctuaries. According to IUCN, as of 2013, the number of world oceans in marine protected areas was not even three percent and less than one percent of that is ‘no take’. This was despite a target of 20-30% of exclusion zones established by the last World Park Congress in South Africa in 2003.
Professor Callum Roberts of the University of York was one of the scientists who helped set the target of 20-30% in 2003. But he said it wasn't enough. “IUCN should now raise its target from 30 to 33%. The new investigation reinforces the argument for the 30% target set earlier to be raised now. Any reduction in efforts at this stage and time in history would be disastrous for our oceans.”
After difficult negotiations, the delegates of the World Park Congress approved a motion that will dramatically change the objectives for global marine management. Instead of the 20-30% aspiration goal, the new official position of IUCN is “to urgently increase the ocean area that is effectively and equitably managed in environmentally representative and well-connected systems of marine protected areas or other effective conservation measures by 2030; these should include strictly protected areas that represent at least 30 per cent of each marine habitat and address both biodiversity and ecosystem services”.
Tua Pittman was delighted with the news that a strong resolution on the planet's oceans had passed Congress. “It’s like a big reward for all the effort we made to be here and be heard. Listening to what they did to that resolution is fantastic. It is a step in the right direction.” He says that, while many of the traditional navigational aids were things like the sun, the moon and the stars that never changed and that, at least on a human scale, would always be there, other impacts of environmental degradation were becoming clearer by sailing the Pacific.
He said he was 55 years old and, in his life, he was already beginning to see that it was much harder to fish in the open sea. He also said that pollution was getting worse, particularly as canoes approached big cities like Sydney. And the effects of climate change were already beginning to seriously affect Pacific Islanders. “The decisions of large countries have two, three, four times the impact on small countries than on large developed nations. Many times, people don’t even know where our islands are and, from the eyes of a traditional navigator, our people have a very, very deep concern because we’re talking about decisions taken away from that impact on our homes.”
Mua Voyage had been a massive logistics company, Tua said. Years of preparation and navigation planning went on such a journey and it was critical for travelers that the world listen to their message and act. The leaders of the rich countries, he continued, need to start thinking more like traditional sailors who recognize their ships are mere stains on a huge sea. Most importantly, and speaking as a true navigator, Tua says that politicians must look for a different route to avoid the pending ecological crises that are beginning to overtake small island nations. “The world needs to find a different path.”
label: C1

text:
A
Thanks to the field of linguistics we know a lot about the development of the 5,000 more languages that exist today. We can describe your grammar and pronunciation and see how your spoken and written forms have changed over time. For example, we understand the origins of the Indo-European language group, which includes Norwegian, Hindi and English, and can trace them to tribes in Eastern Europe at about 3000 BC.
Therefore, we have traced a large part of the history of language, but there are still areas of which we know little. Experts are beginning to look into the field of evolutionary biology to find out how the human species developed in order to use language. So far, there are many more questions and a half theories than answers.
B
We know that human language is much more complex than that of our closest and intelligent relatives like chimpanzees. We can express complex thoughts, transmit subtle emotions and communicate on abstract concepts such as the past and the future. And we do this by following a set of structural rules, known as grammar. Only humans use an innate system of rules to govern the order of words? Perhaps not, as some research may suggest that dolphins share this ability because they are able to recognize when these rules are broken.
C
If we want to know where our capacity for complex language comes from, we need to see how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to something more than the size of the brain; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; the artifacts left by our ancestors do not tell us what discourse they were able to make. One thing we can see in the remains of the first humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat, and tongue. About 100,000 years ago, humans had developed the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess if the first humans communicated using more basic sounds.
D
Another question is, what does the human brain have that allowed language to evolve in a way that it did not in other primates? At some point, our brains became able to make our mouths produce vocal and consonant sounds, and we developed the ability to invent words to name things around us. These were the basic ingredients for a complex language. The next change would have been to put those words into sentences, similar to those used by children as they learn to speak for the first time. No one knows whether the next step – adding grammar to point out past, present and future, for example, or plurals and relative clauses – required further development in the human brain or was simply a response to our increasingly civilized way of living together.
Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, however, we began to see the evidence of early human civilization, through cave paintings, for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans became more complex and smarter. Was it the use of language that made your brains develop? Or did your more complex brains start producing language?
E
More questions arise when examining the influence of genetics on brain development and language. Are there genes that mutate and give us the ability of language? Researchers have found a genetic mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection to talking and how our brains control our mouth and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to tell how much influence genes have in language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
label: C1

text:
They are the seekers of darkness – and they are growing in number. At Black Fell, looking down at Northumberland's beautiful Kielder water reservoir, a group of people wait in a parking lot next to a strange wooden building with a minimalist design with rays of the future. This is the Kielder Observatory, the center of the nascent British astroturistic industry. And the ones waiting outside were the lucky ones. Many more had requested a star observation night at the observatory, but the numbers are strictly limited.
Inside, next to a wood burner and under dimmed lights, the observatory's founder and main astronomer, Gary Fildes, a former Tarzan-haired mason, offers a talk of encouragement to his colleagues and volunteers. The team discusses the prospect of seeing the Northern Lights, but Fildes is doubtful. Instead, they decide to train their powerful telescopes on Jupiter and Venus and later choose stars such as Capella and Bethelgeuse. An additional attraction is the emergence of the International Space Station.
“Remember,” Fildes tells his team, “it’s about interaction, it’s about entertainment, it’s about inspiring people.” Pink Floyd, the Jam, the Pogues. “By 9.30, the sky is going to be sexy,” Fildes says. “It’s going to be epic.”
Fildes, 49, is at the forefront of the UK's flourishing astrotourism industry. The crucial moment for Northumberland came in 2013 when the entire national park that houses the Adriano Wall, along with Kielder Water and Forest Park, about 1,500 km2, was awarded the status of Dark Sky Park, the only one in England. Dark Sky Parks are rare. The 2013 Star Count revealed that only 5% of the UK population can see more than 31 stars on a good night.
The Dark-Sky International Association (IDA) based in Tucson, Arizona, confers status only to places that take important steps to prevent light pollution. The receivers must also prove that their night skies are dark enough. In Northumberland Dark Sky Park, as the area was renamed, it is so dark that Venus casts a shadow on Earth.
Duncan Wise, a visitor development officer at the Northumberland National Park Authority, helped lead the campaign for dark sky status after the Council for Rural England Protection found it to be one of Britain's quietest places. “We tend to see the landscape as everything to the horizon,” Wise said. “But what about what is above?” Sabio and others spent years preparing their submission to the IDA, collecting resumes of light readings and forming an alliance of local councils, park bodies and community groups to produce a master plan of outdoor lighting that influences the construction of new developments in the area.
Their efforts have been vindicated. Many of the 1.5 million visitors to Northumberland each year are now aware of their Dark Sky status. “We have a lot of people coming here to see the sky now,” says the man from the car rental company in Newcastle. “They come in autumn and winter, when it is darker. Good for B&Bs as they have business throughout the year.” Local hoteliers now emit guests with night vision torches and put sun loungers at night. Those who have acquired some knowledge of astronomy can receive a badge confirming that their hotels are “Dark Sky Friendly”.
Wise recognizes that Northumberland needs to do more to capitalize on its scarce resources and believes that the region needs a couple more observatories to make sure visitors see what they are looking for. A £14 million national landscape discovery center, which he describes as the northern response to Project Eden, will have an observatory when completed in a couple of years.
Fildes has great designs. He is planning Britain’s first “astrovillage”, which would house the world’s largest public observatory and feature a 100-seat auditorium, a 100-seat planetarium, a one-metre aperture telescope, and radio and solar telescopes. The multi-million-pound project would have a hotel and attract 100,000 people per year, four times the current number of people able to use the observatory. Fildes is cryptic about his sponsors, but believes that astrovillage will be a reality for 2018.
However, Northumberland faces competition. Galloway Forest Park in Scotland also has the status of Dark Sky Park. Since Exmoor was designated the first International Dark Sky Reserve in Europe – a notch below Dark Sky Park – in 2011, a series of local businesses have emerged that offer breaks and safaris. The United Kingdom will have to go somehow to eclipse northern Chile, which has more than a dozen tourist observatories and has some of the clearest skies in the world. The Teide National Park in Tenerife is also becoming an important destination for astrotourism.
So what is driving the desire to look up? The media has helped. Television presenters like Brian Cox have attracted a new generation of stargazers. “Brian Cox has made astronomy accessible,” Wise says. “It is no longer seen as the province of professors in studies with brass telescopes.” Technology has also played a role. Applications like Stellarium now turn smartphones into pocket planetariums. Ultimately, however, Fildes believes that people are beginning to appreciate what is above. “If you had to build a visitor attraction from scratch, what could be better than the universe?”
label: C1

text:
Organic foods have more antioxidant compounds linked to better health than regular foods, and lower levels of toxic metals and pesticides, according to the most comprehensive scientific analysis to date. The international team behind the work suggests that switching to organic fruits and vegetables could bring the same benefits as adding a portion or two of the recommended "five a day."
The team, led by Professor Carlo Leifert of the University of Newcastle, concludes that there are “significant and significant statistics” differences, with a range of antioxidants “substantially superior” – between 19% and 69% – in organic foods. It is the first study to show clear and wide-ranging differences between organic and conventional fruits, vegetables, and cereals.
Researchers claim that the increase in antioxidant levels is equivalent to “one or two of the five portions of fruits and vegetables recommended for daily consumption and would therefore be significant and significant in terms of human nutrition, if the information linking these compounds to the health benefits associated with increased consumption of fruits, vegetables and whole grains is confirmed.”
The findings will add to the controversy about organic foods and if it is better for people, with an expert saying that the findings were exaggerated. Tom Sanders, professor of nutrition at King’s College in London, said the research showed some differences. “But the question is, are they within natural variation? And are they nutritionally relevant? I’m not convinced.” He said that Leifert's work had caused controversy in the past. “Leifert has had many disagreements with many people.” Sanders added that research showed that organic cereals have less protein than conventional crops.
The research results are based on an analysis of 343 peer-reviewed studies from around the world – more than ever – examining the differences between organic and conventional fruits, vegetables, and cereals. “The crucial thing about this research is that it breaks the myth that the way we grow does not affect the quality of the food we eat,” said Helen Browning, executive director of the Soil Association, who is campaigning for organic farming.
Plants produce many of their antioxidant compounds to fight pest attacks, so higher levels in organic crops can result from their lack of protection by chemical aerosols. But scientists say that other reasons can be important, such as organic varieties that are raised for tenacity and are not supercharged with artificial fertilizers.
Leifert and his colleagues conclude that many antioxidants “have previously been linked to a lower risk of chronic diseases, including cardiovascular diseases, neurodegenerative diseases and certain cancers.” But they also note that there have been no long-term studies showing health benefits from a broad organic diet. Researchers found much higher levels of cadmium, a toxic metal, in conventional crops. Pesticide residues were found in conventional crops four times more often than in organic foods. The research was funded by the EU and an organic farming charity.
The research will surely be criticized: the inclusion of so many studies in the analysis could mean that poor quality work biases the results, although the team performed “sensitivity analysis” and found that excluding the weakest work did not significantly change the result. Moreover, the highest levels of cadmium and pesticides in conventional products remained well below regulatory limits. But researchers say that cadmium accumulates over time in the body and that some people may want to avoid this, and that the limits of pesticides are set individually, not for cocktail chemicals used in crops.
Another criticism is that the differences observed may be the result of different climates, soil types and crop varieties, and not organic farming, although researchers argue that combining many studies should average these other differences. The biggest criticism, however, will be about suggestions for potential health benefits. The most recent main analysis, which took 223 studies in 2012, found little evidence. “The published literature lacks solid evidence that organic foods are significantly more nutritious than conventional foods,” he found.
This was also the conclusion of earlier and smaller studies published in 2009 in a scientific journal and by the Food Standards Agency of the United Kingdom, although the latter considered only 11 studies. The 2012 study noted that eating organic foods could help people avoid pesticide residues. Sanders said he wasn't convinced by the new job. “You won’t be better nourished if you eat organic food,” he said. “The most important thing is what you eat, not whether it’s organic or conventional. It's if you eat fruits and vegetables at all. People are buying into a lifestyle system. They are confident that it is not being grown with chemicals and is not cultivated by large companies.”
Opinion polls show healthy eating (55%) and avoiding chemical residues (53%) are key reasons cited by buyers for buying organic products. However, many also say that environmental care (44%) and animal welfare (31%) are important, as is taste (35%). Browning said: “This research supports what people think about organic foods. In other countries, much higher levels of support and acceptance of the benefits of organic food and agriculture have long been recorded. We hope that these results will bring the UK in line with the rest of Europe.”
label: C1

text:
From choosing the right festival to tips for camping and going through the shows, here you have -LRB- almost -RRB- everything you need to know about getting ready for your next music festival.
When I went to my first summer music festival a few years ago, I wasn't ready and I could have used a little guide. Since then, I have covered Lollapalooza, Pitchfork Music Festival, moe.down and other summer festivals, acquiring along the way a list of things I wish I had had before embarking on the first.
Experienced veteran or festival novice, I hope these tips will make your experience more rocking, relaxing and fun.
Find the right festival for you
One of the best places to start is Jambase.com, an aggregator of all things related to music festivals and concerts. Take a look at the history of each particular festival through its website or third-party music blogs/sites.
Each festival tries to differentiate itself, creating a specific inclination through alignment, location and general atmosphere. In general, the festivals will unite with local and regional media and artists to offer unique parallel shows ranging from improvisational theatre to art exhibitions, record shops and campaigners' booths promoting voter registration and ecological initiatives.
Matador Network: 10 wildest electronic music festivals in the world
When doing your research, ask yourself the following four questions:
1. How much can you spend?
Festival passes range from $50 to $250 or more, depending on the location, location, and who is leading and promoting the festival.
2. What kind of music do you want to hear?
The musical tastes are quite diverse these days, as most people enjoy various genres, and festival formations reflect this. Although some are unique in genre, most of the show shows play everything, from bluegrass to hip hop.
3. Are you ready to camp?
For festivals like Bonnaroo and Coachella, much of the experience consists of launching your tent and camping during the weekend. Some camping events offer luxury cabins or tents in exchange for higher prices.
Home page: What is Bonnaroo?
Most festivals provide maps before arrival, so you want to know where the camping areas are related to the parking and stages. If the distance is far, try to keep your equipment light or invest in a small traction car or cart.
Depending on how much sleep you want to sleep or how close you want to be to the action -LRB- many festivals run 24 hours -RRB-, you want to know if the campsites are close to the stages, scattered over the grounds, or both.
Bring the usual camping equipment -- shop, sleeping bag, etc. -- and don't forget a car charger for your phone, laptop and other gadgets.
The best music festivals in the world
4. Are hotels an option?
If you are attending a festival located in a city or metropolitan area, such as Pitchfork in Chicago, getting a hotel room for the weekend on your own is an option, or you can take advantage of the festival's accommodation offers.
Learn the local story before you leave
As with all trips, having a cultural awareness of where you're going can enrich your festival experience and take you beyond the simple enjoyment of music. The uniqueness of many of the best festivals is rooted in its locality. For example, Glastonbury in the UK is held on the basis of festivals that have been used as such for centuries.
Being informed about local culture and history will also help if you plan to venture during the show to give your ears a break or want to make a pre or post-festival excursion to visit nearby attractions.
Stretch out your comfort zone
One of the best parts of the summer music festival experience is watching the mix of different cultures and being around new groups of people. As more and more festivals incorporate different genres, I have seen an increasingly diverse cross section of fans in festivals.
Take the opportunity to interact with other festival attendees, and don't be afraid to order the camping tool you forgot. Talk about last night's set or join a Frisbee game.
Matador Network: 10 Bluegrass festivals for the summer of 2011
Be smart about drugs and alcohol
I don't include this advice to be a party pooper, but only as a word of caution. I've seen festival experiences come to an early and nightmare ending as a result of irresponsible drug and alcohol consumption.
It is a fact that the culture of music and drug culture overlap, especially in a live music environment, but be wise about bringing drugs or large amounts of alcohol with you. In most festivals, you're going to be thoroughly searched before you even get through the doors. Security will confiscate the prohibited materials or ask you to leave without refund of tickets.
Matador: A first-minute guide to participating in Burning Man
Make time to relax.
One of the biggest lessons I've learned is to plan a few break intervals and not run back trying to see each band. If you've done an initial investigation into the area, make a short trek to one of the quiet places you learned from and give your cochleas a break.
Many festivals have also started with morning yoga classes, a great opportunity to recharge the mind and body.
I cannot emphasize this enough: whatever you do, either reading a book, taking a nap, or taking a diary in a quiet place, make time to give your ears and other senses a break. Knowing the design of the festival and programming in time to relax is the most important advice I can give.

label: C1

text:
Mrs Sally Davies, medical director of England, has compared the problem of antibiotic resistance to the risks posed by international terrorism. Although this might sound like an exaggeration, the threat was in fact, in any case, underestimated. Every year, the global number of deaths to which bacterial resistance contributes far exceeds those caused by terrorist attacks.
While it is difficult to monitor the global impact of antibiotic resistance on all bacterial species, the World Health Organization estimates that for tuberculosis alone multidrug resistance causes more than 150,000 deaths each year. Antibiotic resistance is no longer an abstract risk: it is now a war.
Over the past hundred years, our life and survival expectations have changed beyond recognition. At the beginning of the twentieth century, life expectancy in the United Kingdom was about 47 years for a man and 50 years for a woman, a number greatly affected by the very high infant mortality rate in those days. About one third of all deaths occurred in children under five years of age, mainly due to infectious diseases.
On the other hand, a child born in Britain today has a better chance of turning 100. That is why we have to thank the public health systems, vaccination and antibiotics. It is by these means – the prevention and treatment of diseases caused by microorganisms – that the real war against diseases is mainly won.
In other places, we have pushed the limits of survival, especially in intensive care. This, the specialism in which I chose to train, is where antibiotic-resistant organisms are most prevalent. In this case, potent antibiotics, essential in the treatment of life-threatening diseases, are routinely used. These drugs decimate common bacteria. But what they leave behind are resistant species that have begun to learn tricks that allow them to evade antibiotics.
As a newly qualified physician in the late 1990s, I learned about Staphylococcus Aureus, the infamous MRSA, a bacterial species resistant to methicillin and all other penicillins. In the fight against it, there were a handful of exotic sound drugs - vancomycin and theicoplanin among them. These were supposed to be our last lines of defense, but antibiotic-resistant bacteria became more and more common; just like species with new resistance patterns. The drugs we had barely heard of became commonplace. New last-line drugs emerged to replace the old ones. We used to this state of affairs; a constant escalation in the arms race between us and the bacteria.
But the balance has been constantly changing. In our hospitals and our GP surgeries we have abused drugs that gave us a huge advantage over infectious diseases, using them too often and indiscriminately. And some of the worst abuses have occurred outside health care, with antibiotics introduced into the food chain, through agriculture and the burden of feeding livestock with antibacterial drugs. We assumed antibiotic therapy was an advantage we could enjoy forever. We were convinced that the pharmaceutical industry would continue to advance the game.
But it's not like that anymore. New, more resistant species have been identified. The vancomycin we used to trust to treat MRSA infection was defeated. Vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (VRSA) emerged in our hospitals. And other bacterial species were learning the same trick. Enterobacteria, which are usually found in the intestine, had also acquired resistance to vancomycin. Today, infections with formidable and highly resistant organisms are common and the pharmaceutical industry does not keep pace. Fewer and fewer new antimicrobial drugs come out of their production lines. It is becoming increasingly difficult to develop new active drugs against resistant strains. For every method of attack that pharmaceutical companies invent, bacteria rapidly evolve a defense. All simple approaches to the problem have been exhausted.
Antibiotics have become expensive drugs to develop, which are only used in short courses and which quickly become ineffective due to the evolution of bacterial resistance. As a result, the incentive of the pharmaceutical industry to manufacture new drugs that can combat them is low.
Almost as soon as antibiotic use became widespread in the 1940s, the first evidence of bacterial resistance to antimicrobial therapy emerged. Initially, these were little more than curiosities. When the patients were infected, the numbers were so small that at first they were not enough to deserve much attention. But today, they have become a fact of medical life. Less than a century after the discovery of penicillin, we are beginning to lose the fight.
Since the first deaths of MRSA in healthy children in the U.S. in 1998, the number of deaths due to MRSA infection in the US. has increased to tens of thousands each year, exceeding the number of deaths caused by AIDS. Bacterial resistance in hospitals is everywhere. This is a war like no other. There needs to be a cultural change in our prescribing behaviour and greater restraint in the use of antibiotics in agriculture and agriculture. And somehow, pharmaceutical companies have to be convinced to pursue the development of these less profitable drugs.
During my working life, the pattern of antibiotic resistance in medical care has evolved from a rare but noticeable event to an epidemic-proportion problem. If we want to avoid a return to pre-antibiotic time with all its excess mortality, we must be bold. Deploying the advantage we have gained so recently against microorganisms in the struggle for life would be unthinkable.
label: C1

text:
On a day in August, one in seven people on Earth, a billion people, used Facebook, according to founder Mark Zuckerberg. In a decade, the social network has transformed people's relationships, privacy, their businesses, the media, helped overthrow regimes and even changed the meanings of everyday words.
“A more open and connected world is a better world.
It brings stronger relationships with those you love, a stronger economy with more opportunities and a stronger society that reflects all our values,” Zuckerberg wrote in the post announcing the numbers. These are just some of the ways your company changed everything, for better or for worse.
1 Facebook has changed the definition of “friend”
“To the Friend” is now a verb. And, unlike real life, when the end of a friendship can be deeply traumatic, it is easy to “not be friends,” a word invented to describe the abandonment of a casual acquaintance when they are no longer improving their Facebook news source. Although the meanings of the words “share” and “like” are essentially the same, Facebook has brought a whole new weight to the terms. School and college meetings have become redundant – you know whose career is going well, if the perfect couple has split up and you've seen endless pictures of your schoolmates' babies. You won't be surprised by an ex on the street with a new girlfriend or boyfriend: you know they're dating someone else from the romantic selfies.
But, unlike real life, Facebook has no hierarchy of friendships. A classmate of a college project you haven't seen in 15 years, a friend-of-a-friend of a deer or a colleague you've never really talked to in person – they're all Facebook friends the same way your closest partner or your spouse or your mother.
It does not necessarily mean that we see them in the same way. Professor Robin Dunbar is famous for his research suggesting that a person can only have about 150 people as a social group. Facebook hasn't changed that yet, he believes, but, in an interview with New Yorker, Dunbar said he feared it would be so easy just to end friends on Facebook that eventually there might no longer be a need to learn how to get along.
2 We care less about privacy
There is a wise saying: if you are not paying for it, you are the product. Facebook embodies that philosophy and created an entire industry from it. The amazing thing is that users know it and that they voluntarily deliver that information.
Pew Research Center found that most young people are more than willing to give their details.
An overwhelming majority of 91% publish a photo of themselves, 71% publish the city or town where they live, more than 61%, more than half give email addresses and a fifth give their phone number. But, as much of a person's life is shared online, Facebook offers a platform for everyone to cultivate an image and a fan base. In an article in Frontiers in Psychology, scholars described a new phenomenon, the emergence of “I Facebook. ” More than 80% list their interests, allowing brands to address them in the most effective way. But most younger users restrict their profiles, with 60% allowing only friends.
3 Facebook has created millions of jobs – but not in their own offices
Facebook has essentially created an entire sector, including indirect employment for people whose job it is to make the platform work for their brand.
“It’s a tool like no other,” said Michael Tinmouth, a social media strategist who has worked with brands like Vodafone and Microsoft. “Markers have an understanding of consumers of a brand like they’ve never had before. The data and analysis available to you are extraordinary. You know who your customers are, who they are friends with and how they get involved with your brand.”
And advertisers pay a lot for that. Facebook reported that advertising revenue increased by 46%, reaching $3.320 million. Facebook is also a minefield for brands. Suddenly, instead of complaining about conversations that take place over the phone with a customer service representative or on a small specialized Internet forum, angry customers can post their complaints to hundreds of their friends to see or even on the page where all loyal brand fans have been carefully cultivated. And an injustice can go viral.
4 Facebook has been the tool to organize revolutions
Although the Arab Spring was nicknamed the Twitter revolution, the organization of demonstrations and direct actions has been revolutionized by Facebook. Olga Onuch of Manchester University discovered that Facebook had been the key means to reach half of all Euro-Maid protesters in Ukraine. Facebook posts pointed to the beginning of Maidan protests during the hours after it was announced that Ukraine would not sign a free trade and association agreement with the EU, Onuch found. Posts organized live action, not just online anger. Mustafa Nayyem, the Ukrainian activist, published: “If you really want to do something, don’t like this post. Let us meet near the monument to independence in the middle of the Maidan.
Many of those interviewed in Onuch's research said they trusted Facebook for the truth about what was happening – unable to trust traditional media.
5 Facebook makes news, gives news and decides what is news
Approximately 71 per cent of 18-24 year olds say the Internet is their main source of news and 63 per cent of users in general, according to the Pew Research Center. About a third of Facebook users post about politics and government.
Most people will first encounter a piece of journalism or a last-minute article via Facebook or other social media, and most of those encounters will be on mobile.
Users may never have to leave the site to get their news: Instant Articles will see stories executed within Facebook. It allows news companies to sell ads around their articles, earning them 100% of that revenue, while Facebook can also sell ads around that article, with 70% of the advertising revenue from the social network also going to news companies.
Facebook has also changed the way journalists write stories. It's a resource that many reporters can't live without now. For better or (often) worse, it is a directory to find, contact and collect information for almost any ordinary person, who could suddenly be at the center of the biggest news of the day. Facebook has its own news cable, sharing users' most useful reaction to last-minute stories, including photos and videos.
6 Users are Changing Facebook
It used to be a place to connect students, with only elite U.S. universities. allowed access.
In 2014, a decade after its launch, 56% of Internet users over the age of 65 have a Facebook account. And 39% are connected to people they've never met in person.
The groups have given way to pages, writing on the walls of others is out of fashion and carefully curated albums have given way to instant mobile loads. More than ever, the site is a gateway not only to your friends, but to the rest of the Internet.
We can also get used to it, said David Kirkpatrick, author of The Facebook Effect. “It may go further along the way, but something this big takes a long time to disappear,” he told BBC Radio 4’s Today. “Facebook has demonstrated its ability to change and will remain a very, very important player.”
label: C1

text:
On June 17, 1964, President Lyndon Johnson explained to New York Times reporter James Scotty Reston why he had to stay in Vietnam stabilizing the government of South Vietnam so he could fight communism.
Johnson rejected the calls for withdrawal being made by the Liberal Democrats, as well as the proposal for neutralization promoted by Frenchman Charles de Gaulle.
So all you have left, Johnson said, is to try to make this thing more efficient and more effective and keep it as strong as you can and keep this government as stable as you can and try to improve it as you can and we're doing it day and night.
During his recent speech at West Point, President Obama rejected the lessons that these kinds of stories tell us about Afghanistan. The president, saying that the comparison with Vietnam is based on a false reading of history, pointed out three differences.
The first is that the United States is now part of a broad international coalition. The second is that in Vietnam the U.S. faced a broad-based popular insurgency, while today, according to most polls, a large number of Afghans support foreign assistance. Finally, Obama added, is that today Americans are responding to a very real threat that began with the September 11 vicious attack.
Clearly, Obama feels defensive about this analogy and hopes to undermine liberal critics who are frustrated and disappointed with his decision.
However, in trying to break away from Johnson’s experience, Obama did not give an accurate account of what many commentators have been saying recently, and he lowered crucial aspects of the 1960s that actually offer warnings for today.
Mark Twain once said that history does not repeat itself, but rhymes. Most of those who have compared Afghanistan to Vietnam do not say that the situations were exactly the same from a political or strategic point of view. Nor is it inevitable that the increase in Afghanistan will be fruitless.
The point of comparison is that it is impossible to ignore the fact that Obama faces similar challenges, as Johnson did when Vietnam's Americanization began in the spring of 1965.
Both presidents entered the war despite the fact that many high-level advisers in the White House and Congress were strongly warning against the escalation.
In 1964, Johnson heard from voices ranging from the Frank Liberal Church of Idaho to Georgia's hawk Richard Russell that Vietnam was not critical of fighting communism and that war was invincible. Their warnings turned out to be accurate. In making this decision, Obama also heard comparable criticisms.
Both presidents also expanded the war just as they were trying to shape a broad internal agenda. Johnson was much ahead of the game when he increased the number of ground troops in the war he inherited. The war devastated Johnson's domestic efforts. Obama faces the same threat.
Both wars have been justified as wars of necessity. With Vietnam, advocates warned that the fall of Southeast Asia to communism would greatly strengthen the Soviet Union and China.
At a time when American schoolchildren were being taught to hide and cover under their desks in the event of nuclear war, this warning about Vietnam also made war seem essential. Today, the need arises from the assertion that failure would resurrect the dangers we face before 11 September.
And both presidents intensified wars where the road to victory and possible costs -- in terms of human capital and budgetary obligations -- were unclear.
Despite the fact that Johnson faced a very different type of enemy, the risk today is enormously high. In Afghanistan, the U.S. is dealing with a war front that is notoriously treacherous, as the Soviets learned in the 1980s and the U.S. has learned since 2001. The U.S. also relies on a highly corrupt and unreliable government in Afghanistan.
Although the promise of withdrawal in July 2011 could be accurate, presidential guarantees of benchmarks and final games are historically not realized. The only constant in the war is that it is unpredictable and difficult to control. One day after Obama's speech, Defense Secretary Robert Gates indicated that the deadline was not firm.
And the administration could very well be espousing a strategy of more war, as it continues to offer serious warnings about what a victory for the Taliban would mean.
These warnings will make it difficult in the long term for the administration to contain the operation or withdraw forces unless it is absolutely clear that the Taliban have been defeated.
Democrats might feel like their predecessors in the 1950s who were under political pressure to abide by the contentions outlined by President Harry Truman with the Truman Doctrine in 1947, first with Korea in 1950 and then with Vietnam.
Obama should not be so defensive about comparisons with Vietnam. Rather, you should use Johnson's experience to help guide you as you make crucial decisions in the coming months and try to navigate the challenges of the presidency in times of war.
In a conversation with some of his closest advisors, Johnson said in 1964 that it's fucking easy to get into a war, but it'll be very hard to get out of yourself if you come in.
In 1965, Johnson made the mistake of excluding those who tried to warn him of the dangers of war. Let's hope this time around Obama doesn't repeat this mistake.
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of Julian Zelizer.
label: C1

text:
The swimming superstar Michael Phelps once claimed that he mocked up to 12,000 calories a day. Yohan Blake, the great opponent of Usain Bolt's sprint, says he sucks 16 ripe bananas every 24 hours.
A small Japanese athlete easily hid 50 pieces of sushi after training, while another marathon runner swallowed raw minced meat dishes.
Or what about the weightlifter who drinks the first milk from a cow he just gave birth to?
With extreme eating habits like these, it can be a surprise to know that inside the Olympic Village lies a culinary trap that can potentially tip athletes over the fine line between success and failure in London 2012.
Competitors spend years perfecting their bodies, scrupulously eating the right foods, avoiding the wrong ones... and then?
They meet the Olympic dining room.
With a McDonald's at one end and machines dispensing other sponsors soft drinks and confectionery, the giant feeding area provides mountains of forage from all over the world - a complete range of gluttony from one end of the health spectrum to the other.
Cooking for an Olympic Champion: A Recipe for Success
It is a 5,000-hour, 24-hour facility where organizers expect 25,000 breads, 232 tons of potatoes, 75,000 liters of milk and over 330 tons of fruit and vegetables to be consumed by the end of the Games on August 12.
About 1.2 million meals will be served -- 60,000 a day.
For younger athletes it is an exciting new experience, says sports scientist Jess Corones, who works with the Australian Olympic swimming team.
It's all free. There's thousands of athletes and there's almost every kind of kitchen you might want. There's a stand that gives you unlimited McDonald's, there's machines that pump unlimited amounts of soft drinks for you.
That's exciting and can be a distraction for them. They think, oh this is great, and they just run to it -- but you have to remind them that it will still be there when they're done competing and that until they're done competing they have to stay in their normal routine.
What happens as normal can vary enormously.
Phelps, after winning a record eight gold medals in Beijing 2008, told the NBC that he punctured himself with pasta and carb-heavy pizzas at the peak of his extreme training. Blake, Jamaica's 100-meter world champion, says he eats so many bananas to maintain his potassium levels.
British weightlifter Jake Oliver says every morning he drinks a milkshake containing colostrum, a form rich in milk proteins produced during the last stages of cows' pregnancy. I tried to get people to try it, but they didn't. “Only the smell of it is enough to put people out,” The Guardian told the British newspaper.
Or even Japan's former Olympic marathon champion Naoko Takahashi, a tiny runner who told CNN she could eat about 2 kg of fish after a big session.
I only ate twice a day. But I ate a lot, said Takahashi, who won the gold in Sydney 2000 and now works on television.
British Olympian Explains Ideal Meals
However, it is rare for athletes to eat a lot, says Corones, who worked for the first time with Australia’s athletics and field team at the 2004 Athens Games. Phelps really admitted this year that the report of his gigantic appetite was a myth, saying such an intake would be impossible.
“I find it hard to believe,” Corones said. I'll tell you what, if he's eating that he has a very exceptional metabolism! The only people I've seen eat around that are hammer throwers, and they're all weighing 120 kilos.
However, Corones has had some experience of peculiar diets, citing marathon runner Sisay Bezabeh, born in Ethiopia in Australia, from the 2004 team.
We had our camp in Italy and all that used to eat every dinner was a bowl of raw minced meat. I found it pretty gross but I needed iron to run, and that's what he did. You wouldn't get a lot of athletes doing that these days.
Good nutrition from an early age can be vital if you want to be an elite athlete.
Becky Stevenson, a British dietitian based in the Netherlands, has researched the importance of vitamin D to improve performance and prevent injuries.
He cites reports that Chinese adolescents with adequate vitamin D had significantly higher bone mass and muscle strength. Questions have been raised about the incredible performances of teen swimmer Ye Shiwen in London 2012, but this research has not yet shown that high levels of vitamin D could contribute to its success.
We know that low levels can affect muscle strength and bone rotation, but if an athlete has adequate levels there is no evidence of an improved performance benefit, so natural talent and athletic ability is more likely, Stevenson told CNN.
Meanwhile, studies have shown that young athletes in countries in northern Europe such as Britain, Finland and Germany often suffer from vitamin D deficiency. Adequate levels may reduce the risk of stress fractures, inflammatory lesions, and upper respiratory tract infections.
You can get vitamin D from food sources - LRB- such as eggs, dairy and fish -RRB-, but it is not as effective as producing sun, Stevenson said.
Those at risk are athletes who train at 35 degrees or more of latitude -- northern Europe, northern China and North America -- as UVB rays are inadequate during the winter months from November to April.
When we measured our elite tennis players we only found one athlete who was marginal with vitamin D, as he had been injured and was rehabilitating indoors.
There needs to be more research evidence on vitamin D and injury prevention; most of the work is retrospective.
Most athletes use supplements to strengthen their dietary intake, all of daily vitamins such as magnesium and iron plus products such as serum protein, creatine, carnitine and branched-chain amino acids -LRB- BCAAs -RRB- specifically aimed at improving performance and recovery.
However, with the improvement of drug testing standards year after year and the increase of the list of banned substances, there is a strong responsibility for athletes to be very aware of everything they put in their mouth.
Most athletes are using enough supplements. They live an extreme life, the amount of training they do is extreme, they exercise far beyond what the normal person would do, so it is important to supplement their diet, says Corones.
There is a very fine line and it is something that athletes need to stay at the top. The responsibility is 100% on the athlete and we make it very clear to them from an early age that they are responsible for what happens in their mouth. It doesn't matter if it comes from your coach or your parents or your brother or your friend, you need to know what they're putting in your body.
You may trust your 100% coach, but if he gives you a bottle of tablets and tells you it's iron, it's still your responsibility to check. We have hotlines where athletes can call and check anything, so it's pretty easy to figure out if it's okay to take.
At this stage, with the Games in progress and many athletes still waiting to start their competitions, the emphasis is on refining rather than building strength.
It varies depending on where we are in the year, says Corones, who works for the New South Wales Sports Institute in Sydney.
First we want them to carry a little extra weight to reduce the chances of injury and disease, but when it comes down to racing it gets stripped to a minimum, he says.
We don't really make them count calories, we look more at what areas of food groups are eating. You are looking to get quality fats, making sure you get enough carbohydrates, and also the time of food - whether you are swimming or doing gymnasium.
If you're doing gymnastics there's a major mechanical breakdown of the muscle so we need to eat more protein after the session, with a little bit before the session.
A large part of Coronesjob is to make sure athletes learn the right eating habits -- and this usually means breaking the eating patterns formed at an early age.
It's a pretty big educational process for athletes. There are still some who struggle with that concept that the less processed it is, the better it is for them, he says.
Often, at the beginning of their careers, in their young teens, they do a lot of training and want to take the first thing that is available faster because they are always hungry after training. So they have the habit of having a bucket of hot potatoes after each training session. Obviously that's not great, so we're trying to break those habits.
We often find that processed foods -- with high salt and high sugar content in them -- that the body may want them. It's about trying to break those cycles and make them eat as best they can.

text:
Forrest Gump is a 1994 film depicting the life of a simple man born in Alabama who achieves great success in life despite being mentally slow. The main character is played by the great Tom Hanks, who is involved in many of the most significant moments in American history. The film and character have become iconic figures of American society because of their message that any feat can be accomplished regardless of the obstacles they face.

Gump was born to a single mother in rural Alabama during the 1950s. He is a slow minded boy who seems to have no knowledge of his surroundings, or purpose in life. A school counselor tells his mother that Gump's IQ is so low, and would be placed in a special vocational program. His mother convinces the counselor not to consider Gump's low index. Forrest is allowed to attend an ordinary public school.
Due to his athletic skill, Gump gets a scholarship to play football at the University of Alabama, where he excels in the game. When he graduated, he was approached by an army recruiter, and joined the military, where he excelled again. Gump is awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor for saving the lives of many of his comrades during a fierce shooting in the Vietnam War.
After his time in the service, Gump wins an international ping pong competition in China, knocks down President Richard Nixon while staying at the infamous Watergate Hotel, meets three presidents, and goes on several cross-country races that gain mass media attention. Throughout his life, Gump has a strong relationship with his army friends, and loves his only childhood friend and affection, Jenny. Forrest Gump plays the American spirit like no other movie.
label: C1

text:
The vision of colleagues and acquaintances crawling into an electronic cigarette has become commonplace. But have we reached “peak vape”? Statistics suggest that vaping among recent smokers and former smokers, who make up the vast majority of vapers, may already be in decline. The figures will be studied closely by major e-cigarette companies, which have invested millions in promoting a technology that was thought to have grown in popularity.
The figures published in 2014 by the charity Action on Smoking and Health (ASH) reveal that the consumption of e-cigarettes among adults in Britain – which do not contain tobacco and produce steam, not smoke – tripled from about 700,000 users in 2012 to 2.1 million in 2014.
However, the figures collected by the Smoking Toolkit Study, a research agency supported by the Department of Health that provides quarterly updates on smoking trends, show that vaping’s attractiveness may be decreasing. Vaping rates among smokers and former smokers increased steadily until the end of 2013, when about 22% of smokers and former smokers were vaping. But this proportion stabilized throughout 2014 before falling to 19% during the last quarter of 2014. Early indications suggest that the decline has continued in 2015. The fall is described as “statistically significant” by Professor Robert West of the UCL Department of Epidemiology and Public Health, who compiles the figures for the Instrumental.
Smokers are the key group for e-cigarette companies because seven out of ten vapers are smokers. Only about 1% of people who have never smoked have tried an electronic cigarette. “The numbers that use e-cigarettes while they continue smoking are dropping,” West said. “We’ve only been tracking vaping for just over a year, so it’s a short period of time, but we’re not seeing the growth in the number of former long-term smokers or ‘never’ smokers using e-cigarettes. That does not mean that vaping rates do not change, but, at this stage, they seem to remain the same.”
The stabilization of vaping popularity in the UK seems to disagree with what is happening in the US, where technology has been aggressively promoted and where recent reports suggest it is growing in popularity. However, West questioned the interpretation of American data, which made little distinction between people who had once tried an electronic cigarette and those who regularly vaped.
According to experts, fears that vaping may become fashionable among young non-smokers seem to be out of place. Only 1.8 per cent of children are regular users, according to the ASH study. On the other hand, e-cigarettes seem to be more popular among adults trying to quit. “Although figures released this month by Smoking In England show that the use of e-cigarette by smokers has stabilized, their data also show the huge increase in use since May 2011,” said James Dunworth, director and co-founder of ecigarettedirect.co.uk. “Our customers are still very happy with the product, and hardware technology and innovation is improving users’ experience and helping them change traditional cigarettes.”
“Electronic cigarettes behave like a nicotine patch in soup,” West agreed. “They are more popular than nicotine patches and may or may not be more effective. One third of attempts to quit use e-cigarettes, making them the most popular method of stopping.”
Hazel Cheeseman, ASH's policy director, said it was too early to say whether vaping had reached its peak. “Although there are indications that the market has not grown in the UK for about a year, there does not seem to be a decrease in the number of people using e-cigarettes to help them quit smoking. Using an electronic cigarette is safer than smoking; some people, but not all, find it useful to help quit smoking and there is little evidence that it will lead to an increase in the number of young people who smoke.”
It recently emerged that the European Commission (EC) is studying the increase in taxes on e-cigarettes, which could have an impact on their popularity. A new EU tobacco directive will enter into force in 2016 to limit the amount of nicotine in e-cigarettes to below current levels. This may mean vapers will need to increase your use to get the same hit, again something that can make e-cigarettes more expensive.
West suggested that policymakers view e-cigarettes as an aid to quit smoking and not subject them to the same rules as tobacco. “There is a tendency among some local authorities and organizations to treat e-cigarettes as cigarettes and ban them in public places and outdoors,” he said.
label: C1

text:
Crispy, full of protein and found under a rock near you. Insects have long been overlooked as food in all parts of the world, except in a handful, but are now crawling closer and closer to our dishes. Spring 2013 will see an impulse towards eliminating the yuck factor and putting insects not only on the experimental gastronomic menus, but also on the shelves of the supermarket.
In April, there will be a festival in London, Pestival 2013 – an insect appreciation event supported by Wellcome Trust where the consumption of creepy bugs is high on the agenda. It features a two - day pop - up restaurant by Nordic Food Lab, the Scandinavian team behind the Danish Noma restaurant, which brought ants to the table for a ten - day delivery at the Claridge hotel in Mayfair in 2012.
Noma has been named the best restaurant in the world by Restaurant magazine for three consecutive years. His chef, René Redzepi, says ants taste like lemon, and a puree of fermented grasshoppers and moth larvae tastes like strong fish sauce. Bee larvae make a sweet mayonnaise used instead of eggs and scientists are constantly developing new ways to use small creatures.
In March, a BBC documentary will present food writer Stefan Gates looking for and eating fried lobsters and roasted tarantulas. But behind all the tricks and jokes about flies in the soup is a very serious message. Many experts believe that there is a clear environmental benefit for humans who eat chilling.
The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) has been funding projects since 2011 to promote insect feeding and breeding in South-East Asia and Africa, where it is estimated that two billion people already eat insects and caterpillar larvae as a regular part of their diet. In 2012, FAO published a list of 1,909 edible species of insects and, under the patronage of the Dutch government, plans a major international conference on “this valuable food source” in 2013.
Insects are abundant – globally, for every human being there are 40 tons of insects – so there is not too much chance that they are in danger, and they are unlikely to have been dosed with chemicals. “I know it’s taboo to eat bugs in the Western world, but why not?” said Redzepi. “You’re going to Southeast Asia and this is common. You read from everyone that people are eating bugs. If you like mushrooms, you've eaten so many worms you can't imagine. But we also eat honey, and honey is the vomit of a bee. Think about it the next time you pour it in your tea.
He said the basic premise behind Nordic Food Lab was: “Nothing is edible.” Insects are critical to life on Earth and, with more than a million species, are the most diverse group of creatures on the planet, yet they are misunderstood, hated and often killed by humans just because they are there.
In the next 30 years, the human population of the planet will increase to nine billion people. Already a billion people don't get enough food. The increase will put more pressure on agricultural land, water, forests, fisheries and biodiversity resources, as well as on nutrients and energy supply.
The cost of meat is increasing, not only in terms of cash, but also in terms of the amount of rainforest that is being destroyed for grazing or for the cultivation of livestock food. There is also the problem of methane excreted by cows. The livestock contribution, in terms of greenhouse gas emissions, is enormous: 35% of the planet's methane, 65% of its nitrous oxide and 9% of carbon dioxide.
Edible insects emit fewer gases, contain high-quality proteins, vitamins and amino acids, and have a high rate of food conversion, requiring a quarter of the intake of sheep food, and half of pigs and chickens, to produce the same amount of protein. They emit less greenhouse gases and less ammonia than cows and can be grown with organic waste. China is already successfully creating huge worm farms. Zimbabwe has a thriving Mapan caterpillar industry and Laos received almost $500,000 from FAO to develop an insect harvesting project. It is already a big deal in the UK, though not always official: a man was recently arrested by Gatwick Customs when he got off a flight from Burkina Faso with 94 kilos of mapone, worth almost 40,000 pounds, in his luggage.
A study by FoodServiceWarehouse.com suggested that the exchange of pork and meat for crickets and lobsters could help reduce greenhouse gas emissions by up to 95%. But perhaps the fairest thing about eating worms and insects comes when we are dead – then they have the chance to nibble their own back.
label: C1

text:
Apple's brand and logo have been named the world's most valuable – worth nearly $119 billion, or more than all of Morocco, Ecuador, or Oman's gross domestic product.
Silicon Valley, already the world’s largest company – with a $591 billion stock market valuation – has seen its brand value increase by 21% in 12 months, according to Interbrand Best Global Brands’ annual report.
Apple, which is recognized worldwide for its simple emblem of “Apple with a bited miss”, led a wave of technology companies in the 2014 report, which has pushed more traditionally valuable brands – such as Coca-Cola, McDonald’s and Gillette – through the table.
The value of the Google brand increased by 15% to $107 billion to take second place, followed by Coca-Cola, up to 3% to $81.5 billion, IBM ($72.2 trillion) and Microsoft ($45.5 trillion).
Facebook is the biggest increase in the chart, increasing its brand value by 86% to $14.3 billion and taking 29th place on the chart, ahead of long-standing global corporate names such as Volkswagen, Kellogg’s and Ford.
Jez Frampton, executive director of Interbrand, which is part of Omnicom’s global advertising group, said: “Beneficiating immensely from the rise of digital technology and later mobile, smart brands like Apple became stronger. New category killers like Google, Amazon and Facebook have re-established customer expectations and significantly raised the bar for brand experiences.”
Apple, which former CEO Steve Jobs founded in his Los Altos garage in 1976, appeared among the top ten in Interbrand's annual studio in 2011.
Its logo, created by advertising executive Rob Janoff in 1977, was designed with a bite taken from it to avoid confusion with a cherry. “One of the deep mysteries for me is our logo, the symbol of lust and knowledge, bitten, all crossed with the colors of the rainbow in the wrong order. You couldn’t dream of a more appropriate logo: lust, knowledge, hope and anarchy,” Janoff said.
Graham Hayles, marketing director at Interbrand, said that "it wasn't out of kilter" that Apple's brand could account for one fifth of the company's entire market value. “Apple makes a lot of money because it has a very strong brand,” he said. “There is a very strong correlation between branding and profitability.”
Hayles said Interbrand, which has been conducting the annual study since 2000, calculates the value of the brand by examining the financial performance of companies, the “brand leadership” of consumers and the “brand strength analysis”.
While many technology companies climbed the list, there were big falls, too. The Finnish mobile phone company Nokia dropped 41 places to 98th to $4.1 billion, just ahead of Nintendo in 100th position (down 33). “Now it’s just the two of them on the chart,” Hayles said. “It shows the importance of getting the right innovation. If you don’t keep up, it’s very penalizing.”
For the first time, a Chinese company has reached the top 100, with Huawei’s mobile phone and broadband firm entering the ranking at 94th place with a brand value of $4.3 billion. Huawei has been partially banned by U.S. governments. and Australia due to fear that their team could be used by the Chinese for cyber-espionage.
Most of the top 100 brands are US-owned, the top non-US brands are Samsung (6a) from South Korea, Toyota (8a) from Japan and Mercedes-Benz (10a) from Germany. The highest British brands are HSBC (33rd), Shell (65th) and Burberry (73rd).
Other top 100 fashion brands include Boss, Prada and Ralph Lauren. The Louis Vuitton design label is the best name in fashion, in position 19, with a value of $23 billion, just ahead of the H&M high street clothing chain, with a brand value of $21 billion and ranked 21.
The Nike sports brand, which ranks 22 with a brand valued at almost $20 billion, is well ahead of rival Adidas, with 59 in the top 100 worth $7 billion.
Frampton said that consumers' ability to interact and criticize brands on Twitter and other social media means that companies must react faster to retain and improve their brands' reputation.
“The client, empowered by social media in the ‘age of experience’, now has more control than ever,” he said. “In this world of bidirectional conversations, defense, influence and commitment are the new rules for brand creation.
“Customers expect seamless interactions, responsiveness, 24/7 accessibility, customization options, and high levels of customization,” he said. “In a sense, they are increasingly waiting for brands to know them.”
