text:
In 1982, composer San Bao fell in love with musical theatre -- then an alien art form in China -- when he saw a video-recorded version of CATS, which became the longest musical in Broadway history.
Fast forward three decades, and San Bao, who has enjoyed a successful career writing pop songs and leading music production at the Beijing Olympics, wants to do national musicals to rival some of Andrew Lloyd Webber's greatest hits.
This is what I want... a real musical with Chinese characteristics, he told CNN.
San Bao has performed seven musicals since 2005 and his last Nie Xiaoqian and Ning Caichen, currently touring in China, are inspired by a collection of supernatural tales written during the Qing dynasty.
Undersigned by government funds, none of its musicals has yet earned any benefits, much less broken box office records, although a 2005 production called Butterflies reached South Korean stages on a 2008 tour.
It takes time for people to appreciate this art form, San Bao said.
Ten years ago, no one in China would spend money buying a movie ticket, but now? People don't talk about what movies they saw, they talk about which movies they missed.
READ MORE: Shanghai Culture Square: Building Broadway in Asia
Rave tests
Some Broadway shows have captivated the Chinese public. The epic French revolution Les Miserables was a success when it debuted in Shanghai in 2002.
More recently, a Chinese version of Mamma Mia! that toured in August 2011 gross 20 million yuan -LRB- $3.2 million -RRB- in less than a month and according to China Daily, a 2013 production of The Phantom of the Opera was sold five months before its release.
But high ticket prices mean that these programs reach a limited audience, and it's usually only Broadway's most accessible hits that resonate with a Chinese audience, says Zhou Yinchen, the head of the Folk Music and Music Research Center at Beijing University's Academy of Arts.
Mamma Mia is entertaining, so the Chinese accept it, she says. Of course there are other Broadway musicals, but they are only those with the most valuable entertainment work in China, he adds.
However, public criticism has given these shows that music producers like San Bao are confident that combining the Broadway show with Chinese plot lines will one day result in a sure success.
Cartoon character
In addition to China's imperial past, San Bao has also performed shows on a Chinese cartoon character similar to Tintin, and the long march of the Chinese Communist Party, a 6,000-mile journey that helped consolidate Mao Zedong's stature as a great leader.
San Bao says one of the biggest challenges it faces is the shortage of interpreters of all kinds.
Few Chinese actors and actresses have equally strong singing and dancing skills that musical theatre requires, he said.
And although China offers some undergraduate courses in musical theatre, these departments are relatively new and the level of experience is not deep.
Xu Luyang, a classical music critic, also says that music productions often cannot afford the high salary needed to attract the best talents.
The music industry is China is still immature, he said.
Instead of continuing to rely on the generosity of the government, San Bao says he is looking for investors to fund his next project and hopes it will give him a freer creative rein.
The reason I produce musicals and I will continue to do so is because I like it very much.
READ MORE: Spin: Chinese Musicals Take Center Stage · Global Voices
Serena Dong reported from Beijing, Katie Hunt wrote from Hong Kong.

text:
Nelson Mandela, the imposing figure of Africa's struggle for freedom and hero to millions of people around the world, has died at the age of 95.
The first Black president of South Africa died in the company of his family in Johannesburg after years of deteriorating health, which had led him to withdraw from public life.
The news was announced to the country by the current president, Jacob Zuma, who, in a grim televised speech, said Mandela had “deserted” around 8.50 pm local time and was at peace.
“This is the moment of our deepest pain,” Zuma said. Our nation has lost its greatest son. What made Nelson Mandela great was precisely what made him human. We saw in him what we seek in ourselves.
“South African Followers, Nelson Mandela brought us together and it is together that we will fire him.”
Zuma announced that Mandela would receive a state funeral and ordered the flags to fly half a pole.
Archbishop Desmond Tutu led a memorial service in Cape Town, where he called for South Africa to become a nation what Mandela had been like a man.
Barack Obama paid tribute to world leaders, referring to Mandela as a clan – Madiba. The U.S. president said: “Through his fierce dignity and unwavering will to sacrifice his own freedom for the freedom of others, Madiba transformed South Africa – and moved us all.
“His journey from prisoner to president embodied the promise that human beings – and countries – can change for the better. His commitment to transfer power and reconcile with those who imprisoned him is an example to which all humanity must aspire, whether in the life of nations or in our own personal life.”
UK Prime Minister David Cameron said, “A great light has come out into the world,” and described Mandela as “a hero of our time.”
FW de Klerk – the South African president who freed Mandela, shared with him the Nobel Peace Prize in 1993 and paved the way for him to become South Africa’s first post-apartheid head of state – said the news was deeply sad for South Africa and the world.
“He lived reconciliation. He was a great uniter,” he said of Klerk.
People gathered in the streets of South Africa to celebrate Mandela's life.
In Soweto, people gathered to sing and dance near the house where they once lived. They formed a circle in the middle of Vilakazi Street and sang songs of the anti-apartheid struggle. Some people were covered with South African flags and the colors green, yellow and black of the Mandela party, the African National Congress (ANC). Mandela's death leads South Africa to deep mourning and self-reflection, almost 20 years after having led the country of racial apartheid to inclusive democracy.
But his death will also be greatly felt by people from all over the world, who venerated Mandela as one of the last great statesmen in history, and a moral paradigm comparable to Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi and Martin Luther King. It was his act of forgiveness, after 27 years in prison, 18 of them on Robben Island, that will ensure his place in history. With South Africa facing a possible civil war, Mandela sought reconciliation with the white minority to build a new democracy.
He led the ANC to victory in the country's first multiracial elections in 1994. He then voluntarily resigned after a term of office.
Born Rolihlahla Dalibhunga in a small town in Eastern Cape on July 18, 1918, Mandela received his name in English, Nelson, by a teacher at his school.
He joined the ANC in 1943 and became a co-founder of his youth league. In 1952, he founded South Africa's first black law firm with his partner, Oliver Tambo.
Mandela was a charming and charismatic figure with a passion for boxing and an eye for women. He once said: “I can’t help it if the ladies take note of me. I’m not going to protest.”
When the ANC was banned in 1960, Mandela went underground. After the Sharpeville massacre, in which 69 Black protesters were shot to death by the police, he made the difficult decision to launch an armed struggle. He was arrested and finally charged with sabotage and attempted to overthrow the government.
Leading his own defense at Rivonia’s trial in 1964, he said: “I have appreciated the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all people live together in harmony and with equal opportunities.
“It is an ideal that I hope to live and achieve. But, if necessary, it is an ideal for which I am prepared to die.”
He escaped the death penalty but was sentenced to life imprisonment, a big blow for the ANC, which had to regroup to continue the struggle. But the riots grew in the municipalities and international pressure on the apartheid regime slowly hardened.
Finally, in 1990, FW of Klerk lifted the ban on the ANC and Mandela was released from prison amid scenes of joy witnessed all over the world.
His presidency mounted a wave of tremendous global goodwill, but it was not without difficulties. After abandoning the frontline policy in 1999, he admitted that he should have moved earlier against the spread of HIV and AIDS in South Africa.
Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who led the truth and reconciliation committee after the fall of apartheid, said: “He transcended race and class in his personal actions, through his warmth and willingness to listen and empathize with others. And he restored the faith of others in Africa and in Africans.”
Mandela continued to make occasional appearances at the ANC events and attended the inauguration of the current president, Jacob Zuma. His 91st birthday was marked by the first annual “Day of Mandela” in his honor.
He married three times, had six children, 17 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren.

text:
1 Flappy Bird
Be careful what you want, especially if you want to invent something new. Recently, Dong Nguyen, the mobile game designer Flappy Bird, pulled him out of app stores, saying that his success – had been downloaded more than 50 million times, and was making him about £30,000 in advertising revenue every day – had ruined his simple life. He went to his Twitter account to say, “I can’t do this anymore.”
OK, so regretting to do Flappy Bird isn't exactly the same as regretting to make a rifle, but Nguyen is just the last in a long line of inventors who wish they hadn't created a monster.
2 The Labradoodle
The labradoodle is not a monster – it is adorable, obviously. But the monstrous thing is the way the cross dogs have been raised and marketed since the inventor of the labradoodle, Wally Conron, first created the breed in the 1980s. “I’ve done a lot of damage,” he told Associated Press. “I have created many problems. There are a lot of unhealthy and abandoned dogs out there.” Conron came with the labradoodle when he was working for the Royal Guide Dog Association of Australia to provide a dog for a blind woman whose husband was allergic to dog hair. What I didn't expect was that the labradoodle – and its other variants of poodle-cross, many of which have health problems – would become so popular.
3 AK-47
Six months before his death in December 2013, Mikhail Kalashnikov, the assault rifle designer, wrote to the head of the Russian Orthodox Church: “My spiritual torment is unbearable. One and the same question: if my father killed people, does that mean that I, Mikhail Kalashnikov, 93, son of a peasant, Christian and Orthodox by faith, am responsible for the death of people, even if they were enemies?”
4 Electronic marking
The electronic label was originally conceived in the 1960s as a way to track former prisoners' attendance at schools and workplaces, and reward them for their good behavior. His inventors, Bob Gable and his brother Kirkland, were later horrified that the label had become a form of control and punishment. “It’s not nice,” Kirkland Gable told the Guardian in 2010, “but I don’t have control of the universe. I have to realize that there are some things out of my control.
5 pepper spray
After the police sprayed peaceful protesters with pepper spray on a campus at the University of California in 2011, one of the scientists who helped develop it in the 1980s denounced its use. “I’ve never seen such inappropriate and improper use of chemical agents,” Kamran Loghman told the New York Times.
6 The office cubicle
In the late 1960s, a new form of office was launched, designed to give workers privacy and increase productivity by providing more work space. Instead, it became a way for companies to stack employees in narrower spaces, a visual shorthand for uniformity and soulless work. His inventor, Bob Propst, said in 1997, “the cubicle of people in modern corporations is monolithic madness.”

Paula Broadwell, a woman who was romantically involved with former CIA director David Petraeus, will not face federal charges of cyberbullying another woman friend of Petraeus.
The Tampa Prosecutor's Office informed Broadwell's lawyer Robert Muse of the decision in a brief letter dated 14 December.
As an objective of our investigation, we believe it is appropriate to inform your client that our office has determined that no federal charges on cyberbullying charges will be filed, wrote U.S. Attorney's Assistant W. Stephen Muldrow.
Muse told CNN that he was very pleased that the U.S. Attorney's office in Tampa resolved this matter very quickly.
A source near Broadwell said the letter had been received on Monday.
He is satisfied with the prosecutor's decision and happy that it has been resolved, the source told CNN.
Petraeus resigned on 9 November after revealing that he had been involved in an extramarital affair.
U.S. officials said the FBI found that Petraeus was involved with Broadwell, a woman under investigation for sending allegedly harassed and anonymous emails to Jill Kelley, a socialite from Tampa who was a friend of Petraeus and his wife.
Sources close to Kelley said she had not been romantically involved with Petraeus.
During the investigation, the FBI obtained Broadwell's computer and discovered that it had classified materials. Researchers also searched Broadwell's house in North Carolina. Sources said the materials were technically classified but not very sensitive. Still, FBI and DOJ prosecutors have not resolved whether Broadwell will face charges for having such materials in his personal possession.
Sources close to Broadwell acknowledged that the issue has not been resolved.
Broadwell, 40, wrote a biography of Petraeus, a retired general who led U.S. forces in Iraq and later in Afghanistan. A former Army reservist, Broadwell's security clearance was suspended after details of her possession of classified materials appeared.
During the investigation it was also revealed that Kelley and Army General John Allen were exchanging emails, some of which might have been considered inappropriate. That matter was handed over to the Pentagon Inspector General for investigation.

DES MOINES, Iowa -LRB- CNN -RRB- The 2016 Republican presidential race in Iowa had its unofficial start on Saturday with a marathon of speeches, giving about a dozen potential candidates the opportunity to introduce -LRB- or reintroduce -RRB- themselves to a central group of caucus-goers about a year before the competition.
Immigration and Islamic extremism took the front and center as the White House hopefuls sought to test their stump speeches. In the same way, it was the Wisconsin government. Scott Walker and Texas Senator Ted Cruz saw strong receptions from the audience, although support for a large number of candidates was expressed in the corridors after the event.
Government of New Jersey. Chris Christie also sought to establish a deeper link with Iowa. The Hawkeye State receives excessive attention in the presidential years thanks to its first-ever status in the nation during the primary season.
Time for the marathon
During the day of 10 hours of consecutive speeches, the candidates, as they were called, joined other high-profile Republicans at Hoyt Sherman Place, an ancient and intricate theater built in 1877 that also became the first public art museum in Des Moines.
Conceived as the Iowa Freedom Summit, the event was co-hosted by United Citizens and representative Steve King, a revered legislator representing the northwestern part of the state and has considerable influence among the party's most conservative social and right-wing Christian faction.
It was no secret that it was considered a cattle call for the presidential race. Former governor of Arkansas. Mike Huckabee, for example, said the reason he ended his Fox News program was for a bigger target he has in mind.
It wasn't just to go hunting deer every weekend, I can assure you, he said.
Others were more brazen.
I'm a potential presidential candidate, yes, former CEO of Hewlett Packard Carly Fiorina told CNN.
Even Palin longed to enter part of the action, joking before his appearance on Saturday that he was now seriously considering a career. And real estate titan Donald Trump told reporters on Saturday that he will make his decision before June.
I'm the only person who can make this country big again, that's all I know, he told the reporters on Saturday. No one else can.
Palin, in his remarks, was less progressive. Passing through a rather dizzying and difficult to follow speech, Palin suggested that the country is ready for a leading woman, but not Hillary Clinton.
Hey Iowa, can anyone stop Hillary? She said, inciting the public to cheer. For borrowing a sentence, we can!
The class of 2016
Speakers, who were normally given 20 minutes, used most of their speeches to share their own personal teachings. Ben Carson and Christie talked about their strict but sharp mothers, while Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas talked about having pastors as parents.
Other better-known names in Iowa, such as former Pennsylvania Senator Rick Santorum who won the state caucus in 2012 and Huckabee, who won in 2008, tried to remind the Iowans why they chose them first, diving into their personalities, but also focusing on issues.
Given King's credentials as a frank opponent of illegal immigration, it was no surprise that problems at the border became a focal point in many of Saturday's speeches.
Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, argued that there would be no people coming in here without a magnet to attract them, suggesting that there should be a criminal punishment for employers hiring undocumented workers.
However, the main objective in the immigration battle was President Barack Obama's executive action to delay the deportation of up to five million undocumented immigrants. Or, as Palin said, in his popular fanfare, Obama's decision makes him look like an overgrown child who is acting a little spoiled.
Speakers opposed the President's promise to use his pen and phone to work around Congress, with immigration as an example of what many called the president's exaggeration.
That was scored when DREAM Act Coalition protesters interrupted Rick Perry's speech, leading to an arrest and a theater full of Iowa citizens trying to drown the protesters.
Potential candidates also warned about what they see as a difficult road for the country, particularly when it comes to foreign policy, an issue that, along with immigration, also seems to be about to become a turning point in the 2016 presidential race, unlike 2012.
Santorum argued that the growth of ISIS is a consequence of the isolationism and weakness of the Obama administration. Cruz, like several speakers, said the President will fail in the war on terrorism if he refuses to use the words radical Islamic terrorism.
Huckabee criticized Obama for spending more time on climate change in the State of the Union speech than talking about terrorism.
A decapitation is a much greater threat to Americans than a sunburn, Huckabee said.
Issues
There was a lot of Iowa's usual charm on stage, speeches with pig analogies and corn references. And there was more than one reference to how people in Iowa are somehow higher than average.
On a large screen on the stage you could see an image of a red barn sitting on a green hill surrounded by white fences. Steve King's name, on all the casings, was wrapped in banners on stage, as well as on the podium.
The contenders also distributed a large amount of red meat, blowing up Obamacare, Common Core, the media, Hillary Clinton and the $18 trillion debt. Cruz won big applause for proposing to place 110,000 IRS employees on the southern border, joking that they will do a better job to deter illegal immigration than anything else.
Screaming at the newly elected U.S. Senator Joni Ernst was also a popular topic on the agenda for potential candidates. Almost everyone referred to her as their friend, and almost as much affection and time was dedicated to the other beloved senator of the state, Chuck Grassley.
Walker, who, like Cruz, stepped on stage as he spoke, gave an impressive speech that perfected his history as governor. He spoke about the implementation of voter identification laws, and painted himself as the brave warrior who confronted public employees and won during the 2011 collective bargaining rights debate.
He also did not forget to mention that he has been elected three times in the last four years.
Shortly after his speech, two men, both from Council Bluffs, spoke outside about how they were impressed by Walker's comments.
If he could do on a national scale what he did in Wisconsin, this country would be, a man, Michael Patomson, began to say, before his friend, Bill Hartzell, intercepted: Transformed. The country would be transformed.
The reception
Many attendees had difficulty choosing only one favorite in the line of potential contenders. Several mentioned Fiorina as a surprise blow.
“There was only one pantheon of people to listen to,” Eric Rosenthal of Cedar Rapids said.
Rick Perry was better than the last time I heard him... that's good. He needs it, said Ernie Rudolph, from Dallas County, Iowa.
Christie also saw a warm reception and challenged the idea that a Republican governor of a blue state who has a Jersey-type reputation will not connect with voters in Iowa.
That somehow I am too strong, too direct and too direct, Christie said, rejecting criticism as the conventional wisdom of Washington experts. They're wrong.
However, it was remarkably different from its usual style. His behavior was toned and he read from his comments prepared on the podium, a stark contrast with his preferred method out of control.
Some of the talks in the hallways and reporters also had two potential contenders who were not there: Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney.
Trump said it simply: Mitt had his chance. He should have won and drowned. As for Bush: We've had enough of the Bushes.
Sens. Rand Paul and Marco Rubio, as well as the governor. Bobby Jindal also skipped the event, but since it's a year before the Iowans start caucus, losing an event is unlikely to hurt them.
Saturday's event was more of a backdrop, taking the first look at what is likely to be a competitive Republican primary.
Walker, closing his speech, offered a promise that will probably be reflected by several of the speakers on stage over the next year: I will come back many times more.
Adam Levy of CNN contributed to this report.

text:
The United States is one of the most diversified countries in the world. It is made up of many different cultures from Latin America, Europe, Asia and Africa. It is truly a melting pot of diversity. All these cultures have come together to create a new culture - an American culture. Many of the traditions, customs, religions and celebrations of these cultures have been adopted in American culture, including the funeral traditions.

Traditional American funerals are basic. They usually include some kind of religious ritual, followed by a procession to cemeteries, and a small ceremony at the tomb site, but these vary depending on the culture. At most American funerals, the deceased's family sends a death announcement called an obituary. These obituaries usually serve to transmit information to others about the deceased, and the time and day of the funeral event. In church service, the deceased is often praised by friends and family. This is where a person goes up to the front of the crowd to say some things about the deceased, and how he or she affected his life. The procession usually takes the form of a caravan of private cars, and trucks that follow the hearse, which contains the coffin of the deceased, and remains.
In the tomb, another small ritual takes place where the deceased receives a blessing from a member of the clergy. Friends and family are allowed to say goodbye to the deceased. There is an American tradition of picking up a handful of land, and throwing it in the coffin as a way of saying goodbye to the deceased. The family then meets in a house, or restaurant with some of the attendees to eat, and exchange stories before moving on. Most cultures in the United States have adopted this traditional American funeral ritual, but many include features that are unique to their individual culture.

text:
Because of the wide range of crimes that can be punished by imprisonment, some people argue that not all offenders are equal and that it would therefore be more appropriate to provide community services to certain offenders instead. I agree that in some cases prison may not be the best solution and community service would probably have more benefits.
One justification for prisons is to keep society safe by taking criminals out of the outside world. So the first thing to consider is whether someone who has violated the law is a danger to other people. In the case of violent crimes, there is an argument to keep the perpetrator away from society. However, the theft or possession of drugs, for example, does not involve violence against others, so the criminal does not pose a direct danger to anyone in the community. Keeping such criminals in prison is expensive for the taxpayer and does not seem to be an effective punishment, as they often commit the same crime again when they leave prison.
Personally, I also believe that punishments must reform people so that they do not commit crime again. One more reason not to imprison these people is that they can mix with more dangerous and violent criminals, potentially committing a worse crime when they are released. By keeping them in the community, helping others, they not only learn new skills, but can also develop more empathy and care for others. If this happens, society can only benefit.
Critics of this more rehabilitative approach to crime believe that justice should be harsh to deter people from committing similar crimes and that community service might be less likely to have that effect. However, there is very little evidence to suggest that long prison sentences deter offenders.
In conclusion, putting criminals who are not a danger to society in prison is expensive and, in my opinion, ineffective, both as a deterrent and as a form of rehabilitation. Community service for non-violent crimes benefits both society and the offender. Having said that, it would be useful to have more data to determine whether community service or prison is more likely to detain a repeat offender. I firmly believe that decisions on how best to treat criminals should be based on evidence of what really works.

text:
Peruvian President Ollanta Humala has removed 30 of the 55 generals of the national police, the biggest purge in the history of the institution.
The forced retirements, announced in the official gazette over the weekend, are widely seen as an attempt by Humala to combat corruption.
Among those expelled was the head of the national police.
The new chief of police, Raúl Salazar, mentioned the need to fight corruption no less than six times during a speech at his induction ceremony.
We have to discover any act of corruption that stains the name of the police. From the least to the most important, it doesn't matter, whether one sun or more are stolen, he said, referring to Peru's currency.
In a separate interview on the state radio station on Tuesday, Salazar said the fight against drug trafficking would remain a priority.
The movement means that until new generals are named, many regions of Peru, including many within the country, will be led by colonels rather than generals, something that opposition politicians have criticized.
Critics also expressed concern that the movement was a stratagem of Humala, as the new president, to place commanders loyal to him in senior positions.
His Minister of the Interior, Oscar Valdés, said Tuesday that the retirements had to do with a reorganization of a swollen institution, reported the Andean news agency, led by the state.
This is a measure studied, it's a police restructuring, he said. It's not possible that the police have so many generals.
Before the purge, the police had 55 generals, 900 colonels and more than 2,000 commanders, he said.
Journalist Maria Elena Belaunde contributed to this report.

text:
Sweden is the best country for the elderly, Afghanistan the worst, but overall wealth does not necessarily mean better conditions for those over the age of 60, according to the world's first ageing index. Although Sweden’s highest ranking – followed by Norway, Germany, the Netherlands and Canada – can be predictable, the Global AgeWatch index gives some surprising results.
The United States, the richest country in the world, has fallen to eighth, while the United Kingdom does not reach number 13. Sri Lanka ranks 36th, well above Pakistan, with 89, despite similar levels of gross domestic product (GDP). Bolivia and Mauritius score above the size of their economies, while the emerging economies of Brazil, Russia, India and China are a mixed stock exchange. Brazil and China occupy a relatively high place in the index; India and Russia are much lower.
“This survey shows that the story tells,” said Mark Gorman, director of the defense group at HelpAge International. “Best ranked countries are what would be expected, but Scandinavian countries were not rich when they introduced universal pensions. Sri Lanka ' s older population was now benefiting from good basic education and health care: those countries had made certain political decisions. Everyone faces scarce resources, but they must not forget that when making investment decisions, they must also address the problems of old age.”
The index, developed with the United Nations Population and Development Fund, covers 91 countries and 89 per cent of the world ' s elderly. The survey comes in the midst of a major demographic change: by 2050, two billion people over the age of 60 are expected to comprise more than one fifth of the world's population.
Population ageing – when older people account for an increasing proportion of the population – is occurring more rapidly in developing countries.
More than two thirds of older persons live in poor countries; by 2050, this proportion is expected to be approximately four fifths. While the oldest population in France took 115 years to double from 7% to 14% between 1865 and 1980, Brazil is likely to make the same change between 2011 and 2032, in only 21 years.
The index shows that the fastest-growing countries (Jordan, Laos, Mongolia, Nicaragua and Vietnam, where the number of older people is expected to more than triple by 2050) fall into the lower half of the ranking, suggesting that policymakers need to address ageing head-on if they are to adequately support their populations.
There are gender differences between ageing populations, and women generally survive men. In 2012, for every 84 men aged 60 and over, there were 100 women. Lack of paid work (hence savings), reduced decision-making power in the family and vulnerability to violence contribute to the disadvantage that many women face in old age.
However, if appropriate measures are implemented, the ageing of the population does not inevitably lead to a significant increase in spending on health care, according to the report, which highlights the importance of long-term investments in education and health care for older persons. Bolivia, which ranks 46, despite being one of the poorest countries, has introduced progressive policies for older persons, with a national plan on ageing, free medical care and a universal non-contributory pension. Nepal, ranked 77, introduced a basic pension in 1995 for persons over 70 years of age without other pension income. Although its value and eligibility are limited and its coverage is uneven, it is an example of how a poor country has chosen to begin addressing poverty in old age.
Good basic health care introduced decades ago in Chile and Costa Rica has served the ageing population of those countries. A good education system – basic literacy is crucial for older people, as they deal with pension bureaucracy – is of great benefit in the future. In the Philippines, older persons have benefited from post-independence education reforms in 1946, which made primary and secondary education compulsory. The same applies to Armenia, which, like other countries of the former Soviet Union, benefited from a strong education system. South Korea, a surprisingly low 67 in the ageing index, had worse results than similar countries on the basis of GDP per head, partly because it introduced a pension recently.
The ageing index is calculated using 13 indicators under four headings: income security, health care, employment and education, and an enabling environment. All indicators have the same weight, with the exception of pension income coverage, life expectancy at age 60, healthy life expectancy at age 60 and psychological well-being. These categories were given greater weight because of improved data quality and only countries were included if sufficient data were available.
Professor Sir Richard Jolly, creator of the human development index, said: “This innovative index expands the way we understand the needs and opportunities of older persons through its pioneering application of human development methodology. It challenges countries in all parts of the world to raise their eyes as to what is possible.”

text:
The Marlboro Man was a fictional character who appeared in several advertising campaigns for the Philip Morris Corporation. His announcements were broadcast on television from 1964 to 1999, effectively entering the collective consciousness of the American people for generations. Philip Morris is one of the largest tobacco companies in the world, and the corporation used Marlboro Man with great success over the years.

Marlboro's man was a strong and robust man riding a mighty horse, and he traveled all over the country promoting tobacco products. It appeared on television, radio, the press and advertisements for decades. When the U.S. General Surgeon considered tobacco smoke unhealthy in the 1960s, the beginning of the end for Marlboro Man had begun. The Surgeon General launched an anti-smoking campaign demanding that all cigarette companies place their warning label on every package sold in the country. The warning included the phrase that "smoking can cause lung cancer." Soon the pressure was on tobacco companies to stop their advertising campaigns.
In 1955, tobacco sales reached $15 billion in the United States alone. After the Marlboro Man was presented to the American public, that total reached $20 billion. This increase was largely based on the Marlboro Man campaign. The company also started an advertising scheme offering authentic Marlboro Man equipment for sale. These goods were of high quality that attracted the type of person outdoors. The team varied from camping equipment, hats, to outdoor clothing. He was very successful in his time. However, this success had a great cost. Four men who portrayed Marlboro Man died of lung cancer, earning Marlboro cigarettes as the cowboy killer. Marlboro Man is still popular in some parts of Europe and Japan, where smoking is still in vogue.

text:
Standing on the edge of space over the deserts of New Mexico, Felix Baumgartner stopped slightly. It was a small step away from the capsule, but a 24-mile drop to Earth. Our guardian angel will take care of you, said the control of the mission, and the man known as Felix Intrepid jumped.
Ten minutes later, the Austrian returned to Earth, reaching speeds of up to 725 mph, and breaking three world records, including becoming the world's first supersonic paratrooper by breaking the sound barrier in Mach 1.24. “We love you Felix,” applauded the control room as her mother, Ava Baumgartner, cried. Baumgartner, who claimed the records for the higher altitude and paratrooper balloon manned flight, raised his arms in a victory salute to thank his team.
He was wearing a specially designed survival suit that kept his body intact against the enormously varied pressures that marked his return to Earth. Without her, her blood would have boiled and her lungs could have exploded. Baumgartner later said at a press conference: “When I was standing there at the top of the world, you become so humble, you don’t think about breaking records.” He admitted that all he could think about was coming back alive, but he added: “Sometimes you have to go up too high to see how small you are.”
After two aborted attempts the previous week, the mission was cleared on Sunday morning with climate cooperation. Baumgartner was transported to the crystal clear sky by a giant balloon, measuring 30 million square cubic feet and whose skin was one tenth of the thickness of a sandwich bag. At the bottom of the balloon was a capsule, where Baumgartner sat in his suit.
As he reached the desired height, Baumgartner went through a list of 40 articles with his mentor Joe Kittinger, the previous holder of the higher altitude balloon manned flight.
There was some concern that a heater for his visor was not working, causing his visor to cloud. “This is very serious, Joe,” he told Kitttinger. “Sometimes it gets cloudy when I exhale. ... I don’t feel hot.” But they decided to move on, watched by a record 8 million people as the jump was broadcast live on YouTube.
The two-and-a-half-hour journey upwards, during which the curvature of the Earth became visible and the skies gradually turned black, was paired with a faster descent.
Three cameras connected to Baumgartner's suit recorded his free fall of just over four minutes, which failed to break the record of free fall existing for a long time, and then the parachute opening.
The success of the mission, and of the suit, raises the prospect that astronauts could survive a high-altitude disaster of the kind that hit the Columbia space shuttle in 2003 by actually rescuing themselves from their ship. Baumgartner's best doctor at the trick was Dr. Jonathan Clark, whose wife Laurel Clark died in the Columbia accident. Clark is now engaged in improving the chances of survival of astronauts in a high-altitude disaster.
Baumgartner has made himself a name with acts of boldness. The former paratrooper has parachuted out of buildings and mountains and once into a 600-foot deep cave. He had already practiced two free falls in preparation for this attempt: one from 71,000 feet in March and one from 97,000 feet in July 2012. But no feat can have coincided with his jump above the city of Roswell, a conveniently chosen place famous for his connections with UFO sightings.
He pursued five different albums: the first human to break the sound barrier in free fall; the highest free fall altitude jump; the highest manned balloon flight; the longest free fall; and his jump platform is believed to be the largest manned balloon in history. The trick, which was seven years in planning and sponsored by Red Bull drinks, beat two of Kittinger's records: the retired colonel of the U.S. Air Force. previously had records of height and skydiving speed. Kittinger jumped from a balloon 19 miles above the planet in 1960. Conveniently, the only voice on Baumgartner's radio headset guiding his ascent was that of Kittinger, now 84.
Asked after the jump what I wanted to do next, Baumgartner said: “I want to inspire a generation. I'd like to be sitting in the same place for the next four years as Joe Kittinger. There is a young man who asks me for advice because he wants to break my record.” He said the most exciting moment for him had been when he was standing outside the capsule “at the top of the world.” To laugh, he added: “The most beautiful moment was when I was standing in the landing area and Mike Todd [the life support engineer who dressed Baumgartner in his suit] appeared and had a smile on his face like a little boy.”
Baumgartner said he had come to feel like Todd’s son, adding, “I was so happy he was alive.” Earlier, Todd had told the press conference: “The world needs a hero right now, and they have one at Felix Baumgartner.” To keep laughing at the press conference, Kittinger said: “I would like to give a special one-finger greeting to all the people who said that he [Baumgartner] was going to fall apart when he became supersonic.”
“This will be the last leap,” Baumgartner said. He has promised to settle down and enjoy his years after the jumps with his girlfriend, Nicole Oetl, flying helicopters on rescue missions in the United States and Austria.

2009 has given employers and employees a career for their money -- literally. Budgets had been cut, layoffs and permits had been put in place, and profits and benefits had evaporated.
Earlier this year, 38 percent of employers said the economy would force them to make administrative cuts sometime during 2009, according to a CareerBuilder.com survey.
Sixty-five percent of those employers indicated that they would reduce the company's social events, 61 percent anticipated the reduction in business travel, 25 percent expected to reduce health care benefits, and 11 percent planned to reduce welfare benefits.
Other areas in which companies planned to cut expenses included special office benefits, such as coffee, ice machines or discounted sales - LRB- 34 percent -RRB-, incentive trips -LRB- 28 percent -RRB- and philanthropic activities -LRB- 21 percent -RRB-.
These advantages and benefits that are taken away from them make the situation difficult for employees. Not only are they working harder to maintain their jobs, but workers have to do more for less. While some argue that it is difficult to keep employees motivated in this situation, others say they should not focus on incentives, but rather think about the overall picture.
When benefits and benefits are taken away, management often does this to allocate resources where they are needed, elsewhere. The money you save by not buying bagels every Friday or buying Christmas gifts for employees can go toward your salary, said Tom Gimbel, founder and CEO of LaSalle Network, a staff and hiring company.
If you had to choose between taking a pay cut and not having free coffee versus being let go, most employees would probably take the first.
Urmil Tracy Marshall, coordinator of the Bureau of Diversity and International Affairs at Fort Valley State University in Fort Valley, Georgia, agrees that it is important not to focus on what is being removed. He said that due to budgetary constraints, licences were applied at school; but instead of being discouraged, he focused on the positive.
“I remembered how blessed I was to have a job,” Marshall said. We have to remember our priorities in life, placing greater emphasis on what we have, not on what we don't do.
Communication is key
Although it is understandable for employees to be upset, frustrated and discouraged when benefits or benefits are removed, Kevin Sheridan, founder and CEO of HR Solutions, who specializes in helping organizations keep employees engaged, said that employees are less likely to be upset if management communicates with employees.
In fact, 82% of employees surveyed at HR SolutionsInternational Normative Database say it is important for their organization to allow them to choose from a variety of benefits to meet their individual needs. The survey consisted of more than 3.3 million responses from 2,400 organizations.
If an organization’s leadership team simply decides among themselves what benefits it would be best to reduce, employees will be upset and their engagement will be negatively affected, says Sheridan. Open communication is a key driver of engagement, and employees will immediately recognize the fact that they had no voice in the situation. If leadership had simply asked employees what benefits were important to them, this situation could be avoided.
Attitude is everything.
Despite having to deal temporarily with a few travel benefits or benefits, there are benefits to staying with your employer until those things are restored.
It's a good time to remember that the advantages were never the reason you liked the job. Nobody gets up in the morning saying, “I’m very excited to go to the office because there is free coffee,” said Paul Glen, author and managing columnist. If people feel that the cuts – LSB-RSB – are being made in a good faith effort to save jobs, they will be even more loyal than before, as they believe the company is working on their behalf, not just for executives.
In addition, according to the HR Solutions survey, 37 percent of employees have thought of resigning in the last six months. Twenty-three percent said they were thinking of leaving because of pay; 18 percent because of a supervisor or manager; 15 percent because of professional promotion; and 5 percent because of benefits. 39 percent considered it for other reasons.
This statistic is especially important because many organizations have reduced profits over the past six months, and illustrates that most employees have not thought of giving up as a result of tight profits, Sheridan said.
These employees recognize the advantages of staying with a company, benefits or not, for advantages such as professional development and compensation. Moreover, as soon as the economy recovers, many benefit programs will be re-evaluated; employees staying with these organizations will not remain without benefits forever.
Workers should also remember that there could be consequences to quit a job just because you lost free coffee or a transportation refund. If you are thinking about quitting your job for such reasons, make sure that your lost advantages outweigh any possible career advancement or opportunities you would receive if you stayed.
In this economy, it can be very difficult to find another job, and there is no guarantee that one will have free coffee, either, Glen said. In addition, in the new job, even if it is good, the employee will have less tenure and is more likely to be reduced in future layoffs.
If you have had benefits or benefits removed in recent months and need help to stay motivated, remember these five tips from our experts:
1. Get over it.
The longer you talk about it to your fellow employees, the longer you will have bad feelings, make others have bad feelings and be less productive yourself, which is not what will help the company be able to restore what has been taken, said Aubrey Daniels, author of Oops! 13 Management practices that waste time and money - LRB- and what to do instead -RRB-.
2. Find the Motivation
Sheridan encourages employees to find motivation through professional planning with supervisors, interact with co-workers, or be proud of where they work. For example, an employee could volunteer to act as a polling board for job candidates who consider employment in the organization.
3. Create your own advantages
Nancy Irwin, a motivational speaker and author, said employees can take turns bringing coffee, bagels or potluck lunches to help fill the void of things that have been cut off.
4. Understand what is still being offered and take advantage of it.
Darcy Eikenberg, president and creative director of coach Darcy LLC, reminds a client who did not enroll in a course because he thought the training costs had been eliminated. He realized that a co-worker was taking the course and getting paid for the tuition reimbursement, an area that had not been cut off. Do a deep dive into your company's programs, policies, and even discounts because there's probably something you can use now, he said.
5. Focus on the solution, not the problem
Focus on today's actions that will affect your organization's success and growth tomorrow, said Jonathan Berger, Human Resources Director of Direct Agents, an interactive advertising company.
Take this time as an opportunity to offer new ideas to your managers and take an active and entrepreneurial role in helping your company overcome tense times. If you do a good job, you can be rewarded for your efforts when things get better, he said. In addition, by taking on new challenges and opportunities, you can develop your skills and become a more valuable asset for any organization.

text:
Chinese passenger families aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 have participated in a rare nocturnal act of civil disobedience in this heavily controlled city.
After unsuccessfully demanding a meeting with the Malaysian ambassador at his hotel for more than eight hours, angry family members pushed police officers who tried to prevent them from making a midnight march through the Chinese capital. Your destination: the Embassy of Malaysia.
The ambassador kept saying he would come but he never showed up, an old man told CNN that he and many others were walking quietly through the streets of Beijing. As has been the practice of many other Chinese passengers close to their relatives, the man asked not to publish his name.
They're lying. They're lying to us, the man repeated. And now we're going to the embassy. If they don't come to us, we'll go to them.
The surreal night procession was closely followed by police patrols.
Around midnight, more than a hundred relatives organized a sit-in before dawn outside the embassy gates.
Although Chinese security forces far outnumbered the number, relatives continued their stubborn vigil throughout the morning. They remained encamped by the diplomatic mission more than 15 hours later.
Periodically, they sang to fulfill their commitments! No more delays! No more lies! During the sit-in, no Malaysian diplomat went out to meet the protesters.
Protesters finally dispersed peacefully before Friday evening, after camping by the diplomatic mission for more than 17 hours.
The small meeting left after delivering a letter of protest to the embassy demanding an explanation of how the Malaysian Prime Minister has come to the conclusion that the plane ended its flight over the Indian Ocean.
Broken pledges
For weeks, distressed family members have requested face-to-face meetings with Malaysian officials. They demand a report on the details of the last moments before it was believed that flight 370 had disappeared over the Indian Ocean. In the absence of information from Malaysian authorities, many relatives still believe that their missing loved ones are still alive.
On several occasions, in the past two weeks, Malaysian officials in Beijing and Kuala Lumpur publicly committed themselves to meeting with Chinese families within 24 hours, but then failed to report to the talks.
We just want them to stop breaking their promises over and over again, said Steven Wang, family spokesman, whose mother disappeared when Boeing 777 disappeared on March 8.
He spoke to CNN in the area of a journalist outside the sight of the Malaysian Embassy protest. Even early on Friday morning, Chinese police had cordoned off a media area around the corner of the sit-in. During the day, security forces continued to prevent journalists from reaching families.
Public protests are extremely rare in China. The Malaysia Airlines crisis, which has involved the highly emotional disappearance of 153 Chinese citizens on board the plane, has put the Chinese authorities in an uncomfortable position.
The Chinese government has tolerated, but has stopped far from supporting, the political mobilization of the closest relatives of the flight. Families have organized committees, issued press releases and printed T-shirts and hats with the slogan Orar for the MH370. But they have also been largely prevented from organizing public exhibitions outside the hotel's windowless conference room which serves as the improvised family headquarters.
On Friday, a spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, Qin Gang, asked families protesting outside the embassy to express their appeals in a legal and rational manner while committing themselves to providing them with more help. He urged the Malaysian authorities to actively pursue the investigation.
EXCLUSIVE: Malaysia to publish MH370 report, Prime Minister tells CNN

Photographs show the Boeing VC-25 making a steep bench that is usually not seen with passenger planes
Three months after the White House published a single photograph taken during an Air Force One photo operation flying over New York City, a flight that caused panic on the streets below, the United States Air Force released on Friday the remaining 145 photos taken during the flight.
The photographs show the Boeing VC-25 -- a military version of a 747 -- making three steps next to the Statue of Liberty, at one point accompanied by an F-16 fighter aircraft and at another point making a steep bench that is not usually seen with passenger planes. That last movement may have contributed to the chaos below.
The photographs and several long email channels of the government were published in response to the requests of CNN and other news organizations for the Freedom of Information Act.
E-mail chains show that the organizers of the flight government were aware that many New Yorkers feared planes flying low before the April 27 flight, and show a gust of second questions, finger markings, damage control and occasional expressions of regret in the hours immediately after the flight. View a compilation of fixed overflight images
Thanks for the sensitivities notice in the New York area, an Air Force colonel wrote in an email two days before the flight. This is an issue that has also concerned PAG -LSB - the Presidential Air Transport Group -RSB. As a result, their coordination has been substantial.
But while the White House, the army, and numerous federal and local agencies coordinated the escape, the federal government demanded secrecy, preparing a press release that would be distributed only if there were investigations in the media.
These investigations arrived during the morning flight, triggering a rapid chain of emails among government officials.
We need to build some kind of timeline when people realized that if that's possible, an Air Force officer wrote, responding to the public interest.
I agree that... we have to get damage control, but we're not the POC-LSB-RSB contact point, says the answer. I also don't want to become a belly button for NORAD to press this one.
He wrote a top Pentagon spokesman: Nothing like having everyone pointing their finger at someone else so we can all look like a big group of buffoons... can you say Moe, Larry & Curly!!????? !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
In addition to informal e-mail jokes, documents show the regime system used by the Pentagon to monitor and respond to breaking news.
A U.S. North Command document provides this assessment of history: Last 4 hours: Story reported quickly. Covered by AP, CNN, FOX's main news media. Very critical local reports, highlighting the chilling. Local population very critical of the event, due to 9-11 sensitivities.
Continue: Web site blog comments angry better. Twitter search reveals tweets about two commercial planes chasing F-16. Rate of 1 tweet per minute and growing.
It is not possible to take a positive turn. Admit the error, concludes.
In another email, Colonel Scott M. Turner, commander of the Presidential Air Transport Group, was doing just that. Again, my apologies, sir. The real intention here was to honor New York, not cause massive chaos, he says.
The next day, the Northern Command's internal memo included representations of New York's three main tabloids with headlines, Scare Force One, Just Plane Stupid! And what a fool this was!
The photographs published on Friday, meanwhile, show the presidential plane making a steep bank, apparently beyond the 30-degree maximum for Boeing 747s carrying passengers, according to an airline pilot consulted by CNN. This may have contributed to anxiety on the ground.
The Pentagon estimated the cost of the flight at $328,835, which includes the Boeing aircraft and the two fighter planes that accompanied it. But, they said, the hours would have been flown independently, and the expenses would have been accumulated on a different mission.
The VC-25 plane is designated Air Force One only when the president is on board. President Obama was not on the plane during the photo shoot.
After the incident, Louis Caldera, the director of the White House Military Office responsible for the overflight, resigned.
I have come to the conclusion that the controversy surrounding the Presidential Air Transport Group's air photo shoot on New York City has made it impossible for me to effectively direct the White House Military Office, Caldera said in a letter to Obama. In addition, it has become a distraction for the important work you are doing as president. After a lot of reflection, I think it's up to me to file my resignation and resign as director of the White House Military Office.

text:
Five Clichés of Horror Movies
Since almost the beginning of the cinema, we've had scary movies. Of all the genres that exist, horror is perhaps one of the most conventional. Many horror movies are based on specific plot devices, also called tropes, to scare their audience. When a trope is used too much, it can become a cliché. But when used well, it can really make us jump off our skin. Here are some of the most used, and perhaps abused, clichés in horror movies.
1
No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror movies. Usually, that's where something hides or where the evil psychopath has hidden his tools. The basements are always dark and often humid. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there's nothing down there.
2
In the older horror films, when the protagonists were desperate, it was difficult or impossible for them to ask for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a little less credible now. What is the solution to keep the suspense going? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror movie, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to ask for help, you won't have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just like you're making the call. Or both.
3
Horror movies love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, an empty house of fear or a ghost town. There's something in lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they're so quiet, they can also be very scary. Of course, abandoned places are also useful for horror movie directors in the sense that it is more credible that you will not have phone coverage there either (see above).
4
The hero's been driving for hours. It's night and it's starting to rain. Suddenly he sees a person on the side of the road. Maybe the company will keep him awake? In horror movies, taking a walk to someone is looking for trouble. The hero always does, and it always ends badly.
5
This horror film cliché was especially popular among the horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers enjoying themselves, and ends with all the dead except one girl. At first, the child is often innocent, shy and not particularly strong. In the end, he has become the hardest and most resourceful person in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.

The best-selling title on Amazon in the U.S. It's not Harper Lee's second most anticipated novel, Go Set to Watchman, nor George RR Martin's song from the ice and fire fantasy series, not even Zoella very moody but very bought young adult success, Girl Online. Instead, Scottish illustrator Johanna Basford is beating the charts with her color books for adults, taking the top positions on Amazon.com's bestseller lists.
The intricate flora and fauna drawings of Basford at Secret Garden have sold 1.4 million copies worldwide to date, and the newly released enchanted forest has already sold just under 226,000 copies. They have attracted fans of Zooey Deschanel, who shared a link about the book with her Facebook followers, to South Korean star Kim Ki-Bum, who posted an Instagram image for her 1.6 million followers.
“It’s been crazy. The last few weeks since the Enchanted Forest came out have been total madness, but fantastic madness,” said Eleanor Blatherwick, head of sales and marketing at the book publishing house, the small British press Laurence King. “We knew the books would be beautiful, but we didn’t realize it would be such a phenomenal success.”
And not only is Basford reaping the benefits of the adult hordes that, it turns out, just wanted something to color. In the UK, Richard Merritt’s Coloring Book of Artistic Therapy ranks fourth on Amazon’s bestseller lists, Millie Marotta’s Animal Kingdom – detailed photos of colored animals – ranked seventh and a mental coloring book ranked ninth. Basford's titles are in second and eighth place – that's half of Amazon.co.uk top ten taken by adult coloring books.
In UK independent editor Michael O’Mara, who has sold nearly 340,000 adult books to date, Chief of Advertising, Marketing and Online, Ana McLaughlin, attributes madness to the way the category has been reimagined as a means of relaxation. “The first we did was in 2012, Creative Coloring for Grown-Ups. It was sold strongly and reprinted, but it was in 2014 that everything really spread with Art Therapy. It really took off for us – selling the anti-stress angle gave people permission to enjoy something they might have felt was quite childish,” he said.
The book Mindfulness Colouring Book pushes this perspective in a particularly strong way, as its publisher tells readers that it is “full of templates for exquisite scenes and sophisticated and intricate patterns, prompting them to meditate on their artworks while filling these pages consciously and creatively, ” and urges potential colorants to “take a few minutes of their day, wherever they may be, and color their way to peace and calmness. ”
“I think it’s really relaxing to do something analogous, disconnect,” Basford said. “And it’s creative. For many people, a blank leaf is very discouraging; with a colorful book, you just have to bring the color. Besides, there's a little nostalgia there. So many people have told me that they used to do the secret coloring when their children were in bed. Now, it's socially acceptable; it's a category of its own. These are adult books. The art in my books is super intricate.”
The illustrator, who lives in Aberdeenshire, has been amazed at the reaction since she launched Secret Garden in 2013. “I had a children’s book in charge and told them that I would like to make one for adults. It wasn't really a trend then. I prepared the first story and they thought, 'Let's go get it.' I was just thinking that people like me would like to do it. My intention was to make a book I'd like to have. So it has been a real surprise to see the category flourish.”
He is currently working on a third book and Michael O’Mara, who already has 17 adult color books in circulation, will increase this to 22 by May, with upcoming titles including the Classic Comic Coloring Book and The Typography Coloring Book. “It’s just a huge trend and shows no signs of deceleration,” McLaughlin said, adding that those who buy the titles are willing to show their ability to stay within the lines of the world in general.
“Photos are all over Twitter and Instagram. People are very proud of them – they are so intricate,” he said. “You don’t have to have any artistic talent, but what you think is unique. People send us pictures of them, framed and laminated. The appetite is simply enormous. I think people are taking their children’s photos out of the fridge and replacing them with theirs.”

text:
Trucks transporting supplies to NATO troops crossed from Pakistan to Afghanistan for the first time in seven months on Thursday after Islamabad agreed to reopen routes, officials said.
The four trucks, under strong security, crossed the border from Chaman in Balochistan Province, Pakistan.
Because Afghanistan is a landlocked country, many supplies for NATO-led troops fighting Islamic militants have to be transported from Pakistan.
On Tuesday, Islamabad decided to reopen the crucial closed supply routes on 27 November, a day after coalition forces mistakenly killed 24 Pakistani troops.
The incident plunged relations between the United States and Pakistan to a low historical level.
Pakistani routes offer a shorter and more direct route than NATO has been using since November that passed through Russia and other nations, completely avoiding Pakistan.
It's costing the U.S. $100 million more a month to use alternative routes to the north.
Imran Khan, founder of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf-LRB-Movimiento por la Justicia-RRB party, criticized the decision to reopen the routes, saying it was done without meeting the conditions set by Parliament.
He also criticized the current government for being a pawn of the United States.
Talks to reopen routes had stalled on two key issues: Pakistan ' s demand to load more per container shipped across its border, and Pakistan ' s demand that the United States apologize for the friendly fire incident in November 2011.
Pakistani Taliban threaten to reopen NATO supply routes
On Tuesday, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton apologized.
We regret the losses suffered by the Pakistani military. We are committed to working closely with Pakistan and Afghanistan to prevent this from happening again, Clinton's statement said.
Until his apology, the U.S. government had only expressed regret for the incident, but had not issued a direct apology.
Under Tuesday's announcements, Pakistan agreed not to impose any transit charges with the routes reopened, Clinton said in a statement.
The Pakistani route costs about $250 per truck. Pakistan has been seeking $5,000 per truck as a condition for reopening supply lines, which the United States refuses to pay.
The U.S. military will now pay Pakistan $1.1 billion that it owes as part of the agreement reached to reopen NATO supply lines, according to U.S. officials who were aware of the details of the agreement but were not allowed to speak publicly.
The money is part of a U.S. military program called coalition support funds, which reimburses the Pakistani military for their counter-terrorism efforts. The United States stopped paying Pakistan's bills as tension increased between the two countries.
The Pentagon will consult with Congress on the payment of bills before paying Pakistan in full, according to one of the U.S. officials.
Meanwhile, the Pakistani Taliban have threatened to attack NATO trucks, saying that supplies are used to attack their members fighting the occupation in Afghanistan.
Carriers who resume supplies will be considered friends of the United States and face the consequences, a spokesman for the militant group said Wednesday.
The Taliban have attacked NATO supplies in the past, killing drivers and other crew members.
Safe exit route from Afghanistan from the United States and NATO
Journalist Ayza Omar contributed to this report.

text:
The quiet chorus of the natural world is in danger of being lost to today's generation as people project the noises around them, warns a high-level U.S. researcher.
The rise in background noise levels in some areas threatens to cause people to ignore the uplifting sounds of bird singing, dripping water, and trees that burrow in the wind, which can often be heard even in urban centers, said Kurt Fristrup, a senior scientist at the United States National Park Service.
The problem was exacerbated by people listening to music through their headphones instead of tuning in with birds and other sounds of nature that can easily be drowned by traffic, music and other noises, he said.
“This learned deafness is a real problem,” Fristrup told the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in San José. “We are being conditioned to ignore the information that reaches our ears.”
“This gift with which we are born – reaching out and listening to things hundreds of meters away, all these incredible sounds – is in danger of being lost through a generational amnesia,” he said.
“There is a real danger, both of hearing acuity loss, where we are exposed to noise for so long that we stop listening, but also a loss of listening habits, where we lose the ability to interact with the environment the way we were built,” he added.
Over the past ten years, the United States National Park Service has recorded sound levels at over 600 sites in the United States, including Yosemite in California, Yellowstone and Denali in Alaska. None were affected by any form of noise from human activity, whether flying over planes, motorcycles, motorboats or tourist buses.
The Fristrup team combined the sound levels recorded in national parks with similar urban environment data to create a noise level model in the United States. They predict that noise pollution is growing faster than the U.S. population and more than double every 30 years.
“It’s not surprising that people are putting on headphones or even that noise cancels headphones to try to create a quieter or more pleasant environment,” he said.
“As you raise background sound levels, it has the same effect on your hearing that fog would have on your vision. Instead of having this expansive experience of all the sounds around you, you are aware of just one small area around you,” he said. “Even in most of our cities, there are birds and things to appreciate in the environment, and there may be very rich natural choirs to pay attention to. And that’s getting lost.”
People quickly get used to changes in their environments, including rising noise levels, and, over time, Fristrup fears that we will accept far worse environmental conditions than we should and forget how much quieter the world could be. “If finding peace and quiet becomes difficult enough, many, many children will grow up without the experience and I think it’s a very real problem,” he said.
The warning came as other scientists reported beneficial health effects of listening to natural sounds. Speaking at the same meeting, Derrick Taff, a social scientist at Pennsylvania State University, described preliminary experiments suggesting that listening to recordings of national parks, waterfalls, bird singing and wind, helped people recover from stressful events.
In one experiment, Taff told the participants who visited his lab to give an impromptu talk that would be judged by researchers behind a one-way mirror. Measurements of his heart rate and stress hormone, cortisol, before and after the speech found that people calmed down faster when they listened to recordings of nature than when the same audio tracks were interspersed with sounds of road traffic, airplanes and even normal conversation.
“We know that natural sounds are very important to people. These are some of the main reasons why people visit protected areas. They want to hear the natural tranquility, the singing of the birds, and the wind and water,” Taff said. “We can be losing this as people are listening to iPods all the time, but I think the audience is grateful for these sounds. My advice is to go to your protected areas and experience what you're missing.
It is not clear why natural sounds can reassure people, but Fristrup speculates that, over millions of years of evolution, we could have come to associate the quieter sounds of the natural world with safety. “I suspect there is something in these intact soundscapes that reminds our ancestral brains of a safe place, where there is no sense of a predator nearby, and that these more disordered soundscapes are problematic for us because we know that we have lost that surveillance capability,” he said.

text:

Facebook is expanding its gift function to include plastic gift cards that carry balances for multiple shops and restaurants.
Cards only work in four stores so far: Target, Jamba Juice, Sephora and The Olive Garden. So if you've been wondering how to give your little sister a birthday gift that combines fruit smoothies, lip gloss and unlimited breadsticks, this product is for you.
When you buy a card on the social network for a friend, they receive a message informing them of the gift immediately -LRB- ideal for scrambling at the last minute -RRB-. The cash amount is loaded on a plastic card that is delivered in the mail, probably in some kind of paper envelope.
The recipient can then take that physical card in a physical store and buy physical goods. For an Internet company, everything is deliciously outdated.
The cards will be gradually deployed to Facebook users in the United States.
Facebook is entering a field full of people and offers a couple of features to differentiate itself from other gift cards. The gift giver can choose which of the stores available to give money to -- say $5 to cover a drink in Jamba Juice and $20 for home items in Target. The recipient can monitor the balances on your card from the Facebook app -LRB-, but they cannot move the money among the sellers, no matter how much they prefer to have mascara than pasta -RRB-. Any amount of gift you receive in the future is automatically added to the same card.
Facebook launched its September gift function for physical products such as chocolate, shirts, flowers and wine, as well as virtual items such as charity donations, Uber credit and Netflix subscriptions. It also offered gift cards for specific suppliers such as Starbucks and iTunes. This new card is different because it will work on multiple retailers, is rechargeable and integrates with the Facebook app.
Although you can see the balance of your card on a smartphone, there are no mobile payment options at this time. Facebook cards are not compatible with existing mobile payment technology such as NFC, QR codes or barcodes that allow people to pay for goods with their mobile phone. For now, the company adheres to the traditional plastic rectangle and magnetic band technology that is more widely accepted in the United States.
The new product is somewhere between store-specific cards and open gift cards issued by the bank that can be used in almost any place where credit cards are accepted.
You can also create some privacy issues. To receive the card, the recipient will have to share their postal address with Facebook, which could make some people uncomfortable.
Gift cards are an easy solution for people who do not have enough time or personal knowledge to choose a specific gift. Like money, you know it'll be useful and there's no danger of getting people something they'll hate. Choosing specific seller cards like a favorite coffee spot or clothing store can be a little more personal than a Visa card to be used anywhere. With this card you can mix and pair stores.
Facebook has been experimenting with all kinds of plans to make money in the past year, such as paying to send messages to strangers. Most of the company's revenue comes from advertising -- 84%, according to the latest profit report -- but it also makes money with games and programs like Facebook Gifts. The social network says it has more than a billion active users, and that is a largely untapped resource.
