text:
A mirror that sends heat to the frigid expanse of space has been designed by scientists to replace the air conditioning units that keep buildings cold on Earth.
Researchers believe that the mirror could reduce the amount of energy used to control air temperatures in business premises and shopping malls by eliminating energy-hungry cooling systems.
About 15 per cent of the energy used by buildings in the United States is used in air conditioning, but research estimates suggest that, in some cases, the mirror could fully compensate for the need for additional cooling.
In a comparison on the roof of the device in Stanford, California, scientists found that, while a black painted surface reached 60C more than the ambient temperature in sunlight and bare aluminum reached 40C more, the mirror was up to 5C cooler than the surrounding air temperature.
“If you cover significant parts of the ceiling with this mirror, you can see how much energy you can save.
You can significantly compensate for the electricity used for air conditioning,” said Shanhui Fan, a photonic expert at Stanford University, who led the development of the mirror. “In some situations, calculations say you can completely compensate for air conditioning.”
Buildings are heated in several different ways. Hot water boilers and cooking facilities release heat in their immediate surroundings. In hot countries, hot air enters through doors and windows. Then there is visible light and infrared radiation from the sun, which also heats buildings.
Stanford's mirror was designed in such a way that it reflects 97% of the visible light falling on it. But, more importantly, it works like a heat radiator. When the mirror heats up, it releases heat to a specific wavelength of infrared light that easily passes through the atmosphere and into space.
To do anything fresh requires what engineers call a heat sink: somewhere to throw away unwanted heat. The heat dissipator has to be cooler than the object that needs cooling or will not do its job. For example, an ice cube will cool a bottle of wine because it becomes a sink for heat in the liquid. Stanford's mirror is based on the ultimate heat sink: the universe itself.
The mirror is built from several layers of thin wafer materials. The first layer is reflective silver. On top of this, layers of silicon dioxide and hafnium oxide alternate. These layers improve reflectivity but also turn the mirror into a thermal radiator. When silicon dioxide is heated, it radiates heat as infrared light at a wavelength of about ten micrometers. Since there is very little in the atmosphere that absorbs at that wavelength, heat passes directly into space. The total thickness of the mirror is about two micrometers or two thousandths of a millimeter.
“The cold darkness of the universe can be used as a renewable thermodynamic resource, even during the hottest hours of the day,” scientists write in Nature. In the tests, the mirror had a cooling power of 40 watts per square metre at room temperature.
When writing in the diary, Fan puts the cost of the mirrors installed between $20 and $70 per square meter and calculates an annual electricity saving of 100MWh in a three-storey building.
Fan said the mirror could cool buildings – or other objects – by simply putting it in direct contact with them. Covering the roof of a building with the mirror would prevent the heating of sunlight, but do little to remove the heat from its interior. Most likely, the mirror was used to cool water or some other liquid that would then be pumped around the building.
He ruled out the idea of using mirrors to stop global warming. “The ceiling space represents only a small portion of the Earth’s surface so, at this point, we don’t think this is a geoengineering solution. Rather, our contribution to the issue of greenhouse gas emissions is simply to reduce electricity consumption,” he said.
“I’m very excited about the potential it has and the applications for cooling,” said Marin Soljačić, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. “You can use this in buildings to spend much less on air conditioning or you may not need it at all. You could put it over the malls. With a sufficiently large surface, substantial cooling could be achieved.”

A bachelor's degree in Spanish got me my first job as a journalist, with an international press agency in Mexico City, but it didn't stop me from making a mistake as a novice journalist.
I just arrived in the Mexican capital after a Greyhound bus ride from New York and the job interview was a test of my language skills. In my new role, the day shifts were spent in the streets at political rallies and the nights were spent alone in the office, coordinating the coverage of El Salvador, Nicaragua, Guatemala and the rest of Central America. However, I also had to report on occasional disasters: fires, floods and explosions in reconstruction factories.
It was as a journalist that I soon discovered that it was as bad to understand the numbers in Spanish as to calculate them in English. The phone calls to the police took the Mexican grandmothers out of bed at 2 a.m. because she had misinterpreted a number and dialed a dubious digit. Worse still, the victims were too high in my stories – almost 83 dead in a fi re at 6pm turned out to be only 38 by 7pm; 12 people injured in a car accident soon became two and so it continued. Finally, I got a call from the head office in Washington. “I don’t know what training you’ve had,” one editor shouted, “but no one has told you that a number of dead can’t come down? !"
Why are the numbers in another language so riddled? It may have to do with different numbering systems. If we consider that, in German, for example, which belongs to the same Indo-European language family as English, the 2.30 am become halb drei (half of three) and 21 become einundzwang (one and twenty), clearly different numerical systems can cause confusion and that without even considering indigenous languages with so rare numerical systems that they are in danger of extinction.
Some experts believe that there is a link between dyscalculia – the difficulty of understanding arithmetic – and the problems of learning foreign languages, especially if languages are learned by memory, as this implies the sequential processes with which students with disccalculia struggle. But, some students who struggle to learn languages with a grammar textbook may thrive in a foreign language environment, where learning is more natural and less dependent on sequences of adjectives, prepositions and so on. In my case, I have always found languages quite easy, apart from the numbers.
But, perhaps it is also because numbers in a non-native language are often heard out of context or in isolation, when the listener may have turned off from the foreign language and be unable to tune in suddenly. A survey of multilingual friends straw found that many can be flowered in French or Italian when ordering from a restaurant menu, for example, but freeze if they have to transmit numbers, especially by phone. The numbers seem to be taxed, but no one could really say why.
In my case, the numerical challenge in a foreign language followed me from Mexico to other countries and from Spanish to German and Portuguese. But, in that first journalistic work, wrong numbers didn't always add up to failure.
One night, a Mexican colleague learned that the American consul in the port city of Veracruz was being taken hostage at gunpoint in his office. Without a high-level English-speaking reporter in the office, it remained for me to try to reach the consulate by phone. Having misunderstood the number, they put me to an extension elsewhere in the building and the identity of the person who took my call was unmistakable: I spoke for 15 minutes with the gunman. I may not have persuaded him to put his gun away, but my reputation as a rookie journalist rose overnight.

The United States government consists of three main sections. It is based on the Constitution of the United States of America which entered into force in May 1789. The three parts of the United States Government are the executive, legislative and judicial branches. Each branch works independently of the other two, and each has its own responsibilities. This system is in place to ensure that no branch can have more power than the other. This is called the separation of powers, which was written in the Constitution.

The executive branch is the branch with which most Americans are familiar. It includes the President of the United States, the Vice President and the Cabinet. The president is the leader of the country and the commander-in-chief of the U.S. military. The vice president is second in command, and will act as president if the president dies, resigns or is dismissed. The Cabinet acts as agents of the President of the United States and performs the functions entrusted to it.
The legislature consists of the House of Representatives and the Senate. Together they form the congress, which can collect taxes, mint money and establish federal courts. It can also declare war, and raise and support the army, navy and air force to protect the country. The House of Representatives has 435 members, and the Senate is composed of 100 senators, with two from each of the states. Any legislation, or new law, must be passed by both the House of Representatives and the Senate.

Do you want your child to be good at sport, make the school team and, maybe one day, even compete on the world stage? Well, try to make sure that your aspiring Olympic or World Cup winner is born in November or, failing that, in October. A study conducted by one of the UK's leading experts in children's physical activity has found that school pupils born in those months are more fit than all others in their class.
Children born in November and October emerged as fitter, stronger and more powerful than their peers born in the other ten months of the year, especially those whose birthdays fell in April or June. Dr. Gavin Sandercock of the Sports and Exercise Science Center at the University of Essex and his colleagues discovered that children born in the autumn enjoyed “a clear physical advantage” over their classmates.
The research involved 8,550 boys and girls between 10 and 16 years of age from 26 State schools in Essex. All were tested between 2007 and 2010 in three different fitness measures: resistance, manual gripping force and lower body power. The results revealed that a child’s month of birth could make “significant” differences in his or her levels of cardiovascular fitness, muscle strength and ability to accelerate, all of which predicts how good someone is in the sport, in which such attributes are vital. Proceedings on school sports days in the coming weeks can corroborate the results.
The children born in November were the most fit in general, as they had the greatest resistance and power and were the second strongest. Those born in October were almost as fit, scoring more strength and arriving third for power, with the children of December near behind.
The gap in physical skills among children in the same class but born in different months was sometimes very wide. “For example, we find that a child born in November can run at least 10% faster, jump 12% higher and is 15% more powerful than a child of the same age born in April. This is, potentially, a great physical advantage,” said Sandercock. Such gaps could ultimately decide who became a high-level athlete because, as the newspaper says, “selection in elite sports can often depend on very small margins or differences in an individual’s physical performance.”
The study, which has been published in the International Journal of Sports Medicine, found that, when the scores of the three types of physical fitness were combined, those born in April were the least suitable, and then those in June. That could see those kids excluded from school teams and become unsuccessful players, Sandercock said.
The findings seem to show that children born in the first months of the school year enjoy a double “fall advantage” – they are already known to have an academic advantage and, now, also seem better equipped for sport. The results show that more than “the effect of relative age” – the greatest maturity of those born at the beginning of the school year – is at work, especially because the fittest children were not the tallest or the heaviest, he added.
The authors believe that the increased exposure of children born in autumn during the summer months, towards the end of pregnancy, to vitamin D – the “vitamin of the sun” linked to a number of health benefits – is the most likely explanation. “The seasonal differences in intrauterine vitamin D concentrations seem more plausible,” they say. John Steele, executive director of the Youth Sport Trust, said the quality of a young person’s introduction to physical education and sport at school can be “an important factor” in his sports development. “Children who get a first high-quality experience, which develops their physical literacy, are the ones who will have greater agility, balance and coordination, and are more likely to develop a enjoyment of physical activity and excel in sport as they grow up,” he said.
UK Sport could not say whether a disproportionately high number of the 1,300 athletes through 47 sports that the funds were born in November and October. Natalie Dunman, her director of pathways, said that, while the differences highlighted in the new findings were confirmed by teenagers competing in junior level competitions, they had disappeared when athletes participated in adult competitions. She said: “Looking at the elite, high-level athletes, there are many factors that are going to make a champion and our work has discovered nothing to suggest that the month of birth is one of the key ingredients.”

Some rivals still hope that, over time, even Trump supporters will tire of what critics consider to be their relentless attacks on minorities in particular. Other opponents wonder if Trump has a very broad political ideology. “He is an egomaniac; he is a narcissist. He is not a conservative, he is not a liberal, he believes in himself,” former presidential rival Bobby Jindal told The Guardian shortly before leaving the race.
Liz Mair, a Republican strategist who organizes a fund-raising committee against Trump, is concerned that many of the comments seen as gaffes by the liberal media are, in fact, carefully designed to boost her position with her main constituency. “I personally think it’s better for people who don’t like Trump and his policies to do some work to try to undermine him actively,” he says. “And not just pray that he kills himself politically.”
However, there is more to Trump than the outrage that draws attention. As he delights in telling his supporters, the three issues he criticizes most – immigration reform, free trade agreements, and Barack Obama’s national security policy – have perhaps become the issues that define the elections.
His policies to deport all undocumented immigrants to the United States and demand that Mexico pay for a border wall – “A real wall. A very high wall, taller than that roof.” – It may seem unrealistic, but it may have destroyed Jeb Bush’s campaign hopes, which favors immigration reform.
So what does it take to stop Trump? A source of optimism among opponents is the strong evidence that polls so far from election day are an average of eight percentage points, simply because most people have not decided. Among Americans who identify as Republicans, current polls suggest that they have 25-30% of the votes.
In the battle for the heart and mind, it will be difficult to convert the passionate supporters of Trump. To avoid their advantage, another candidate would have to take advantage of their support base without compromising theirs. Poll experts believe this is unlikely, as it is difficult to imagine someone who makes Trump better than Trump, let alone anyone who does Trump without sacrificing their own support.
This scenario can be better understood by looking at the answers to the question: “Are there any of these candidates who would definitely not support the Republican nomination for president?” While 20-30% of voters say they would support Trump, another 20-30% say they would definitely not.
Steve Deace, a prominent conservative from Iowa, said Trump’s pranks are “a good thing and a bad thing. On the one hand, it produces a loyal follow-up that is attracted to that person who will not leave you. On the other hand, limit your ability to grow beyond that.
The first Republican pollster, Frank Luntz, believes Trump speaks for voters who, for the first time, feel like they have a spokesperson and like the fact that they feel they are being heard. As the pollster points out: “Trump says what you are thinking and, the more outrageous he is, the more you agree with him. He’s saying what no politician would say and that’s another reason they like it.”
That is certainly the sentiment among ordinary supporters who have attended their increasingly crowded campaign events in recent months.
“I like the way he speaks,” says Sandra Murray of Dubuque, Iowa. “This country is a huge disaster and we have to get out of this and, honestly, he could be the man to do it.”
Other supporters offer a simpler explanation. “He is not afraid of anyone or anything. That’s pretty cool.”

text:
A nasal spray with oxytocin "Hormone of Love" could help children with autism learn to better handle social situations, American researchers say. Exploring children with autism spectrum disorder showed that a single dose of the chemical improved brain responses to facial expressions, a change that could make social interactions more natural and rewarding for them.
The scientists behind the research said that an oxytocin course could boost the success of behavioral therapies that are already used to help people with autism learn to cope with social situations. “Over time, what is expected to be seen is a more appropriate social response, being more interested in interacting with other people, more eye contact, and more conversational ability,” said Kevin Pelphrey, director of the Child Neuroscience Lab at Yale University.
Autism is a developmental disorder seen in more than one in 100 people. The condition affects individuals in different ways, but is characterized by difficulties in social interaction and communication. So far, there is no established treatment for social problems caused by autism. Yale researchers have studied brain chemistry oxytocin as a potential treatment for social deficiencies caused by autism because it plays a crucial role in union and trust. However, the results have been mixed: a recent study found no significant benefit for young people given the chemical for several days. But Pelphrey said oxytocin could help the brain learn from social interactions; it would work better when used with therapies that encourage people with autism to become more socially involved, she said.
“Our study shows that oxytocin affects the brain and opens the possibility that, when combined with behavioral treatments, it will function as a social enhancer,” he said. Scientists used a technique called functional MRI to scan the brains of 17 young people aged 8 to 16 years with autism while looking at images of cars or the eyes of people expressing different emotions. The scans were given 45 minutes after participants inhaled placebo or oxytocin through a nasal spray.
The scanners showed that the reward circuits in the children's brains behaved more normally after an oxytocin snort, being more active when the person looked at the faces and less active when he saw the inanimate cars. The study appears in the latest issue of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences in the United States. “If this is replicated, it suggests that oxytocin might treat something so we don’t have a treatment in autism, and that’s the main social motivation,” Pelphrey told the Guardian.
He warned that it was too early to use oxytocin as a treatment for social difficulties caused by autism and warned against buying oxytocin from online suppliers. “We don’t want them to run out on the basis of this or any other study and try oxytocin at home. You don't know what they're buying. We're not even close to thinking this is a ready treatment. He needs more follow-up,” he said. “This is an important new study to identify changes in brain activity in key brain regions involved in the social cognition of autism following the administration of oxytocin,” said Simon Baron-Cohen, director of the Autism Research Center at Cambridge University. A surprising finding, however, is that oxytocin nasal spray did not change performance in social cognitive task. It is also not clear whether oxytocin only has benefits for people with autism or has unwanted side effects.
Finally, the effects of oxytocin only last about 45 minutes, so there may be practical considerations as to whether this could be used as a treatment.
“From a scientific perspective, this study has a lot of evidence of animal and human work to justify serious attention, but more research is needed. Doctors should be cautious about the clinical potential of this hormone until we know much more about its benefits and risks, in much larger studies,” said Simon Baron-Cohen.
Uta Frith, who studies autism at University College in London, said: “According to this study, oxytocin may have the effect of making faces more interesting, as assessed by a greater activity in brain structures that deal with the evaluation of rewards. Disappointingly, this effect is seen only in brain activity and not in behavior. Demonstrate an effect on behavior will be critical if nasal spray treatment is of any value.”

text:
He is not the first person to express skepticism about Mars One, a very ambitious private mission with the aim of settling humans on Mars from 2025 onwards. But Joseph Roche is different from most critics: he is on the astronaut list.
Roche, an astrophysicist at Trinity College Dublin who was announced in February as one of the 100 people online for the mission, has written for The Guardian expressing serious doubts about Mars One's viability.
The selection process, Roche writes, “was not rigorous enough to reach the required level of the most traditional astronaut selection programs.” He also says that the Dutch Mars One team has shown “some naivety” by believing that they can succeed alone in the so-called $6 billion mission and should now accept that it is highly unlikely to happen.
He writes: “Increased openness and transparency would greatly benefit Mars One, but I believe that the shortcomings of the selection process, along with its lack of willingness to engage and collaborate with the scientific community, mean that the time might have come for Mars One to recognize the implausibility of this particular enterprise and direct its efforts towards supporting other more exciting and viable future space missions.”
Roche also expressed concern about the way in which the organizers of the mission gave publicity to the so-called ten candidates. The ranking, he said, did not mean that these were the most likely potential astronauts, but was based on how many “support points” each had won through acts such as the purchase of official merchandise.
He writes: “These points are Mars One’s points of support that represent the degree of their support for Mars One’s mission.” These points play no role in the selection process and serve only to show how much each supporter has donated to Mars One.”
The official schedule of the mission says that the group plans to send a stationary landing and a satellite to Mars in 2018, followed by a rover in 2020 and cargo missions from 2022. Humans would begin arriving in 2025 and crews of four would be sent every two years to add to the settlement. They wouldn't go back to Earth.
In February, a prominent supporter of the project, Gerard’t Hooft, a Dutch Nobel Prize winner in physics, said he did not believe this calendar was realistic. He said: “It will take a lot longer and will be far more expensive. When they first asked me to get involved, I said, "You have to put a zero after all."
Roche also spoke to Medium, an American blogging platform that has previously expressed serious skepticism about Mars One, reporting among other things that the alleged 200,000 applications to be astronauts actually totaled 2,761.
He told Medium about the selection process in more detail: “I have not met anyone from Mars One in person. Initially, they said there were going to be regional interviews; we were going to travel there, they were interviewing us, they were testing us for several days and, in my opinion, that sounded at least like something that was approaching a legitimate astronaut selection process.
“But then they made us sign a confidentiality agreement if we wanted to be interviewed and then suddenly it changed from being a proper regional interview for several days to being a ten-minute Skype call.”
Roche told the Guardian that he did not want to give any more interviews, as he was cautious about being negative about the idea of traveling into space.
In his commentary article, he writes: “I am passionate about pushing the limits of scientific effort and that’s why I was attracted to the ambition of the Mars One plan. Although Mars One was never likely to overcome financial and technical barriers during the proposed timeline, it was refreshing to hear a new idea that challenges us to think about our own role in the future of space exploration.
“Being part of the subsequent public debate on the ethics and morality of future missions has been one of the most interesting and enjoyable aspects of my candidacy with Mars One. If a one-way mission to Mars were possible, then it would always be voluntary. For an astrophysicist, that’s not a hard decision to make, but it’s also a moot point because I don’t think we see a one-way mission in my life.”
label: C1

text:
More than one third of women worldwide (35.6%) will experience physical or sexual violence during their lifetime, usually from a man, according to the first comprehensive study of this type by the World Health Organization (WHO). The report reveals the scandalous extent of attacks on women of men with whom they share their lives, and 30 per cent of women are attacked by their partners. It also notes that a large proportion of murders of women (38%) are committed by intimate partners.
“These findings send a powerful message that violence against women is a global health problem of epidemic proportions,” Dr. Margaret Chan, Director-General of WHO. “We also see that the world’s health systems can and must do more for women who suffer violence.”
The highest levels of violence against women are found in Africa, where almost half of all women (45.6 per cent) will suffer physical or sexual violence. In low- and middle-income Europe, the proportion is 27.2%. However, richer nations are not always safer for women: one third of women in high-income countries (32.7%) will experience violence at some point in their lives. Of women who suffer violence, 42 per cent are injured, which can bring them to the attention of health personnel. That, the report says, is often the first opportunity for domestic violence to be detected and for women to be offered assistance. Violence has a profound impact on women ' s health. Some arrive at the hospital with broken bones, while others suffer from complications related to pregnancy and mental illness.
The two WHO reports – one on the prevalence of violence and the other on guidelines to help women – are the work of Dr. Claudia Garcia-Moreno, WHO Senior Specialist in Gender, Reproductive Rights, Sexual Health and Adolescence, and Professor Charlotte Watts, Epidemiologist specializing in Gender, Violence and Health, School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, London.
“For the first time, we have compared data from around the world on the extent of partner violence and sexual violence by non-partners and the impact of this type of violence on health,” García-Moreno said. These include HIV and other sexually transmitted infections, depression, women who resort to alcohol, unwanted pregnancies and low birth weight babies.
There were variations in the rates of violence against women in different regions of the world, but, Garcia-Moreno said, “in any region we look at, it is unacceptably high.” Even in high-income countries, 23.2% of women will suffer physical and/or sexual violence from a partner in their lives, according to data from 81 countries. The global number of women attacked by their partners was 30 per cent.
More sexual assaults and rapes by acquaintances or strangers are reported in high-income countries than in other countries – the report says that 12.6% of women in rich countries will be sexually assaulted by a non-partner in their lives, which is higher than the African rate of 11.9%. However, data on such crimes are not well collected in all regions.
The authors claim that their previous research shows that women with better education are less likely to suffer violence, as are those with work, but not in all regions. There is a need to address social norms, Watts said. “What is society’s attitude towards the acceptability of certain forms of violence against women?” he asked. “In some societies, it’s not right, but not all.”
“I think the numbers are a wake-up call for us all to pay more attention to this issue,” García-Moreno said. Over the past decade, there has been growing recognition of the problem, he said, but “it must be recognized that it is a complex problem. We don’t have a vaccine or a pill. ”
The new WHO clinical and policy guidelines recommend that health personnel be trained to recognize signs of domestic violence and sexual assault, but rule out general screening: there are no cases to ask all women who arrive at a clinic if they have been subjected to violence.
“But if you see a woman come back several times with undisclosed injuries, you should be asking about domestic violence,” García-Moreno said. “When I was training at medical school, it wasn’t something you learned or knew. Years later, I sometimes found myself in a situation where I could say that there was something else in the woman I was interviewing, but it made no sense that domestic violence was the problem. Now, I think I would take care of the interview in a very different way.”

text:
What skills will the workforce of the future need?
As technological innovations continue to change the workplace, we see more industries entrust their operations to new devices, software and programs that can transform the workplace. One of those technologies that has the potential to revolutionize workplaces in the coming years is RPA (Automatization of Robotic Processes). With more industries starting to adopt RPA software, RPA robots would be able to handle mundane and repetitive tasks as part of administrative work normally handled by administrative staff, thereby reducing operating costs and increasing productivity.
There is a common concern that companies using technology such as RPA are only interested in increasing their profit margins by reducing costs, and that this trend would eventually leave most of the labour force unemployed. However, while it is true that the minor tasks of administrative and administrative work are likely to be undertaken through automation, the requirements of the average office worker will evolve to include more creative work, management tasks and communication with customers and suppliers.
With this shift in focus, the skills required for future workers are also required to change. Moving away from basic data entry skills, the worker of the future is expected to have transferable problem-solving and critical thinking skills that enable him to address any difficult situation and work independently to find solutions.
The ability to adapt and be agile would also be essential in a world that is likely to become increasingly volatile, uncertain and complex. Having such flexibility, along with the desire to continue learning and the initiative to take a step forward, the successful worker of the future is the one who will be able to use his skills to seek opportunities, make improvements and take on new challenges wherever they work.
By equipping our future generation of workers with such entrepreneurial skills, we can ensure that when automation takes full charge, our workers will have survival skills to become better employees and leaders of the future.
label: C1

text:
If the amount of food wasted around the world were reduced by only 25%, there would be enough food to feed all people who are undernourished, according to the UN. Each year 1.3 billion tons of food is wasted, about one third of all food produced, including about 45 per cent of all fruit and vegetables, 35 per cent of fish and seafood, 30 per cent of cereals, 20 per cent of dairy products and 20 per cent of meat. Meanwhile, 795 million people suffer from severe hunger and malnutrition.
Widespread attempts to combat food loss, such as recent laws in France requiring supermarkets to distribute unsold food to charities, have highlighted the problem of food waste, identified by the UN as one of the major challenges to achieving food security. Estimates suggest that by 2050, food production will have to have increased by 60% over 2005 levels to feed a growing world population.
Reducing food waste would alleviate the burden of resources while the world sought to meet future demand. The problem is global but manifests itself in very different ways. In developing countries, there are high levels of what is known as “food loss”, which is unintentional waste, often due to a lack of equipment, transport and infrastructure.
In rich countries, there are low levels of unintentional losses, but high levels of “food waste, ” which means that consumers throw away food because they have bought too much or by retailers who reject food because of strict aesthetic standards.
In developed countries, consumers and retailers waste between 30 and 40 per cent of all food purchases, while in poorer countries only between 5 and 16 per cent of food is disposed of. According to a 2011 report in Europe and North America, each person wasted 95 to 115 kg of edible food per year, while in sub-Saharan Africa and South and South-East Asia the equivalent waste was only 6 to 11 kg.
“In the developing world, food waste is virtually non-existent,” says Robert van Otterdijk, coordinator of the Save Food programme of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). “Food waste is happening in countries where people can afford to throw food away. One statistic is that the amount of food wasted by consumers in industrialized countries [222 million tons per year] is almost the same as the total net food production in sub-Saharan Africa [230 million tons]. But food losses, on the other hand, are really rampant in developing countries because of the underdeveloped conditions they have, from production management to transportation and distribution.”
The environmental impact of food loss and waste is high. The carbon footprint of food produced and not consumed is estimated at 3.3 gigatonnes of CO2, which means that, if food waste were a country, it would be classified as the third highest national emitter of greenhouse gases after the US. and China. About 1.4 billion hectares, or about 30% of the agricultural land available, is used to grow or grow food that is then wasted. And more surface and groundwater, or “blue water,” is used to produce wasted food around the world than for agriculture by any country, including India and China.
“The whole issue of climate change has to do with our economy of production and consumption being out of balance with what the Earth can provide,” says van Otterdijk. “Food production is one of the largest production sectors in the world and, if a third of all this occurs in vain, you can imagine the enormous impact this has on natural resources – on land, water, energy and greenhouse gas emissions.” The worst offenders are the US, Canada, Australia and New Zealand, where consumers waste 39% of all food purchased, followed by Europe, where about 31% of all food purchased by consumers is discarded. In the United Kingdom, 15 million tons of food are lost or wasted each year. British consumers throw 4.2 million tons of edible food each year. This means that 11.7 per cent of all purchased food is wasted in a avoidable manner, at an estimated cost to each family of £700 a year or nearly £60 a month.
The most common foods in British cubes are bread, vegetables, fruits, and milk. According to a national analysis of food waste in UK households, bread is the most wasted food in the UK by weight, and consumers throw 414,000 tons (22.4%) of all bread purchased. In percentage, the most wasted food is lettuce and leafy salads, of which consumers discard 38% (64,000 tons) of everything they buy.
The most wasted meat, both in percentage and weight, are poultry, of which 13% of all edible parts (not including bones) are wasted and the most wasted fruit in percentage is melon, with the equivalent of more than a quarter of each melon thrown into the trash.
The United Kingdom has made progress over the past ten years, following a concerted campaign to reduce waste. Van Otterdijk has pointed it out as “one of the greatest successes” in the fight against food waste. Between 2007 and 2012, the amount of avoidable food waste produced by households in the United Kingdom decreased by 21%, from 5.3 million tonnes to 4.2 million tonnes, largely due to increased awareness. Of the foods that are not eaten, less is ending up in the landfill. In 2000–01, only 14% of household waste was recycled or composted, but by 2011-2012, the amount of composted food had increased to 43%.
Van Otterdijk says there has been a “very encouraging, unexpected and continuous interest” in the issue of food waste, allowing popular campaigns around the world to gain momentum. “We have to do much more and need the involvement of the public and private sectors,” he says. “But if it continues like this, with the same momentum, maybe, after ten years, we will have significant results at the global level.”
label: C1

text:
Scientists have created a “brain atlas” that reveals how the meanings of words are arranged in different regions of the organ. Like a colorful quilt placed on the bark, the atlas shows in rainbow colors how individual words and the concepts they transmit can be grouped into groups of white matter.
“Our goal was to build a giant atlas that shows how a specific aspect of language is represented in the brain, in this case semantics or the meanings of words,” said Jack Gallant, a neuroscientist at the University of California, Berkeley.
No region of the brain has a word or concept. A single brain stain is associated with a series of related words. And, each word illuminates many different brain points. Together they form networks that represent the meanings of every word we use: life and love, death and taxes, clouds, Florida and bra. They all turn on their own nets.
Described as a “tour de force” by a researcher who did not participate in the study, the atlas demonstrates how the modern image can transform our knowledge of how the brain performs some of its most important tasks. With new advances, technology could have a profound impact on medicine and other fields.
“It is possible that this approach can be used to decode information about the words a person is hearing, reading or even thinking about,” said Alexander Huth, the first author of the study. A potential use would be a language decoder that could allow people silenced by motor neuron disease or blocked syndrome to speak through a computer.
To create the atlas, scientists recorded people's brain activity while listening to stories read on The Moth Radio Hour, an American radio show. They then paired transcripts of stories with brain activity data to show how groups of related words triggered neural responses in between 50,000 and 80,000 pea-sized spots throughout the cerebral cortex.
Huth used stories from The Moth Radio Hour because they are short and convincing. The more captivating the stories, the more confident the scientists will be that the people who are scanned focus on the words and don't move away. Seven people heard two hours of stories each. Per person, that was equivalent to listening to about 25,000 words – and more than 3,000 different words – while they were on the scanner.
The atlas shows how related words and terms exercise the same regions of the brain. For example, on the left side of the brain, above the ear, is one of the tiny regions that represents the word “victim”. The same region responds to “dead”, “condemned”, “murdered” and “confessed”. On the right side of the brain, near the top of the head, is one of the brain spots activated by family terms: “wife”, “husband”, “children”, “parents”.
Each word is represented by more than one point because words tend to have several meanings. One part of the brain, for example, responds reliably to the word “top,” along with other words describing clothing. But the word “top” activates many other regions. One of them responds to numbers and measurements, another to buildings and places. Scientists have created an interactive website where the public can explore the atlas of the brain.
Surprisingly, the brain atlases were similar for all participants, suggesting that their brains organized the meanings of words in the same way. However, scientists only scanned five men and two women. They are all native English speakers and two are authors of the study published in Nature. It is quite possible that people from different backgrounds and cultures have different semantic brain atlases.
Armed with atlases, researchers can now build brain networks that represent very different concepts, from numbers to murder and religion. “The idea of murder is very much represented in the brain,” Gallant said.
Using the same data, the group has started working on new atlases that show how the brain contains information about other aspects of language, from phonemes to syntax. However, a brain atlas for the narrative structure has so far proved difficult to achieve. “Every time we come up with a set of narrative characteristics, they tell us that they are not the right set of narrative characteristics,” Gallant said.
Uri Hasson, a neuroscientist at Princeton University, praised the work. Unlike many studies that looked at brain activity when speaking an isolated word or phrase, Gallant's team had shed light on how the brain worked in a real world scenario, he said. The next step, he added, was to create a more complete and accurate semantic brain atlas. Ultimately, Hasson believes it will be possible to reconstruct the words a person is thinking about from his brain activity. The ethical implications are enormous. Another benign use would be brain activity used to assess whether political messages have been effectively communicated to the public. “There are so many implications and we’re barely touching the surface,” he said.
Lorraine Tyler, cognitive neuroscientist and director of the Cambridge University Center for Speech, Language and Brain, said the research was a “tour de force in its scope and methods.” But, the brain atlas in its present form does not grasp the fine differences in the meanings of words. “Although this research is pioneering in its scope, there is still much to learn about how semantics is represented in the brain.”
label: C1

text:
James Hamblin, senior editor of the American magazine The Atlantic, recently joined the unwashed masses. As part of his series, ‘If Our Bodies Could Speak’, Hamblin, a relatively sane man, faced an unshowerful challenge to examine the effect of excessive body cleansing. He reduced the number of showers he had and removed the shampoo and soap when he did. In doing so, he discovered what thousands of other people have: the more fervently we try to clean ourselves with soaps, body washes and those silly little body polishers, the more difficult it is for our skin to work to restore balance, encouraging us to start the whole disconcerting process again. Shower strip the skin of its own oil and bacteria – what, many would say, is the point of showering – but, apparently, this sometimes works a little too well, especially when hot water and cleaning products are added to the mixture.
Do you know that feeling after a shower when you feel like you're stuck in a two-size suit too small? This is because much of the natural moisture of your skin has been washed down the drain. In addition, our skin, like our intestine, houses millions of beneficial bacteria. Showers destroy these happy bacterial colonies; they are completely erased by all our frequent rubbings and washings. And, when bacteria are washed by repopulating soap, they tend to favor germs that produce a smell – yes, showering too often can actually make you smell more. However, when you stop showering and using soap, the skin goes through an initial period of adjustment (probably gross), after which the skin normally restores balance, oil production decreases and healthy bacteria bloom.
After everything was said and done, Hamblin realized what other devotees without soap/shower have known for years: that the human body, functioning on its own, is really quite charming. It is not just aroma or aesthetic, either – although dermatologists suggest that slowing down soap use can improve acne and eczema.
Reducing the frequency of showers (and the number of cleaning products used) has very real implications for our environment. The average shower lasts seven minutes and uses 65 liters of water. There are 65 liters of clean drinking water that we are infused with soap and washing the drain every day, sometimes more than once.
The vital importance of clean water is becoming increasingly difficult to ignore, as California enters another drought summer. It is becoming clear that clean water is one of the most valuable raw materials in the world and will soon be scarce. Add on the environmental effect of all those body wash bottles and you have a handful of very convincing reasons to let your body go au naturel.
If all this is giving you the heebie-jeebies as you remember the last time you stood face to face with those who evidently already spare in the showers - and clearly have not reached the odorless stage yet - relax. Many cleaner-reducing enthusiasts still use deodorant if they deem it necessary (the natural smell of each varies in intensity and can be affected by a number of factors such as diet, hydration, and exercise) and hand washing with soap is still recommended as a vital way to reduce the spread of infectious diseases.
You do not need to go to cold turkey, as Hamblin did, but between three times a day disinfecting sessions and giving up showers completely there is room for our simple family advice. Reduce. Take a few showers, put down the soap and let those lovely little bacteria bloom a little bit, will you?
label: C1

text:
Girl Scout doesn't seem to have a break.
Under fire in years past by including trans fats, high fructose corn syrup and palm oil in their cookies, the current season of sale of Girl Scouts cookies is under fire due to policies that have nothing to do with the actual composition of cookies.
A group calling themselves HonestGirlScouts.com has posted a video on YouTube calling for a boycott of Girl Scout cookies in response to a Colorado troop decision to allow a 7-year-old transgender child into their troop. Gay and transgender rights groups have reported a LGBT grassroots movement of supporters buying Girl Scout cookies in response to the video.
I have decided to buy as many boxes as my modest budget allows and donate them to the local LGBTQ community center, says Mara Morken, a lesbian mom staying home in Fargo, North Dakota. I want to show support for the GSUA in its honorable decision to allow all girls to participate in its programs. However, I don't want that support to show up on my thighs, so I'm going to donate the entire cookie order!
After an initial burst of publicity around the nearly 8-minute video with a teenage Girl Scout using a Girl Scout band, the video has become private on YouTube. However, it is still available for viewing in other parts of the Internet.
I ask all Girl Scouts to want a real girl experience that doesn't sell any Girl Scouts cookie until GSUSA -LRB- Girl Scouts of the USA -RRB- addresses our concerns, says the girl, identified as a teenager named Taylor, a member of the California troop, in some news reports. I ask all parents who want their daughters to be in a safe environment to tell their leaders why you won't let their daughters make more money for GSUSA.
The video was driven by the case of Bobby Montoya, whose mother told a CNN affiliate in October that a troop leader initially told her that Bobby could not join the troop because Bobby has parts of children, even though his son identifies as a girl.
The Colorado Girl Scouts blamed the initial decision to exclude the child from ignorance of Scout policy. State scouts said Bobby was welcome to join the Girl Scouts. If a girl identifies herself as a girl and the girl's family presents her as a girl, Girl Scouts of Colorado welcomes her as a Girl Scout, the Colorado Girl Scouts said, in a statement to a CNN affiliate.
The Honest Girl Scouts website says that Girl Scouts use cookie revenue to promote abortion and LGBT agendas, introduces Girl Scouts to the concept of sexual rights for children without parental consent, and is rewriting identification books to include radical activists and role models.
On its website, HonestGirlScouts.com states that the group is made up of current and previous Girl Scouts, leaders, parents, volunteers and lifelong members. When contacted through your Gmail account listed for comment, someone responded that the group's legal advisor has advised us not to comment or interview until further notice.
Mara Keisling, executive director of the National Center for Transgender Equality, rejected the video as an attempt by conservative activists to raise funds. This issue, however, Girl Scouts are a very good organization, says Keisling. It's been a really good place for kids to learn things. - LRB- This controversy - RRB- will die. We, as a society, are progressing and the old-fashioned reactionary attitude to which the poor girl was put in that video, those attitudes are dying out.
Other LGBT groups are taking a linguistic approach to the debate, encouraging people to eat more Girl Scout cookies. Girl Scout cookies may not be as good for your waist but they are great to be inclusive, says Liz Owen, spokeswoman for Lesbian and Gay Parents and Friends – LRB-P-FLAG-RRB. Owen reports hearing from people who decided to break their New Year's resolutions to go on a diet with a Girl Scout cookie purchase.

text:
North Korea is possibly facing its worst drought in 50 years, state media reported this week.
May is on track to be the driest since 1962, with rains of less than a quarter of an inch - LRB- 2-5 mm -RRB- registered in major cities, including the capital, Pyongyang, said Korea's Central News Agency.
Dry conditions are expected to continue in early June, reported North Korean newspaper Rodong, citing a state climate official.
Rain during the last 30 days has been less than normal in the north, according to Jang Hyun-sik with the South Korean Weather Administration.
On average, it is supposed to rain in the range of 70-90 mm - LRB- 2.75 to 3.5 inches -RRB- during this period, Jang said, noting that South Korean forecasters do not communicate directly with their counterparts in the north.
Rodong reported that the drought has delayed the planting of maize and has already damaged crops such as wheat, barley and potatoes, but said irrigation can fight the damage.
North Korea's food shortage is well documented. The World Food Programme says that more than 6 million people in the prison nation do not have enough to eat.
South Korean Ministry of Unification spokesman Kim Hyung-suk Seoul is open to allowing private organizations to provide humanitarian aid to the North.
Food aid from the United States is likely not to be forthcoming. Washington cancelled its food shipment plan after Pyongyang launched a rocket on April 13.
North Korea said the launch was going to put a satellite in orbit, but much of the international community saw it as a cover-up to test its ballistic missile technology.
The measure torpedoed an agreement reached in February under which Pyongyang agreed to suspend its nuclear activities in exchange for food aid shipments.
label: C1

text:
Tigers are more numerous in Nepal than at any other time since the 1970s, a new census has revealed, giving conservationists the hope that large cats, whose number has been falling across South Asia for 100 years, can be saved.
The number of wild royal Bengal tigers in Nepal has increased to 198 – 63.6% in five years – the government survey showed.” This is very encouraging,” said Maheshwar Dhakal, an environmentalist from Nepal’s Department of National Parks and Wildlife Conservation.
The census is based on the examination of images of more than 500 cameras placed in five protected areas and three wildlife corridors. More than 250 conservationists and wildlife experts worked on the survey, which cost around £250,000.
Dhakal said a parallel survey was conducted in India and the results of both countries will be published later in 2013.” India will take a few more months, which now has 1,300 large cats in several huge protected areas, to complete the data,” he added.
Nepal is committed to doubling the tiger population by 2022, compared to 121 in 2009, when the last systematic tiger count took place. Increased prosperity in Asia has increased the prices of tiger fur and body parts used in traditional Chinese medicines. International gangs pay the poor local Nepali significant sums to kill cats. The skin and bones are delivered to the intermediaries, who easily pass through the porous border to India, where the main traders are located.
A major problem is the complicity between senior officials and mafia networks involved in trade. Conservation experts attribute increased numbers to effective monitoring of national parks, intensified efforts against poaching and better management of tiger habitats in Nepal, where forests cover 29 per cent of the land. But they say Nepal needs to do more to protect the habitat and animals in which tigers take advantage so that big cats have enough space to roam and eat.
As the number of tigers has increased over the years, so have incidents of conflict with villagers. Seven people died in tiger attacks around national parks in 2012, compared to four in 2011, park officials said. Villagers are also looking for better protection.” The government is making conservation plans for tigers. But it should also come with plans to protect people from tigers,” said Krishna Bhurtel, a local village chief in Chitwan, to the Nepali newspaper Nagarik.
Wildlife authorities captured a tiger in Chitwan after he killed two people, including a villager who was taken out of bed in May. Thousands of tigers roamed the forests of Bangladesh, India and Nepal. But its number has fallen to about 3,000, a 95% drop over a century. Chitwan National Park in central Nepal has the largest number of adult tigers, with 120, followed by Bardiya National Park (50) and Shukla Phanta Wildlife Reserve (17).
Diwakar Chapagain, who runs a unit of Nepal's Global Wildlife Fund that oversees wildlife trade, said tiger skins were in demand in Tibet, where people in heels wear them as party suits.
In Nepal, kings used to stand on tiger skins in front of stuffed tigers for special occasions. Some wealthy Nepalis have mounted tiger heads on the walls of their living rooms. Tiger bones are in great demand for use in traditional Chinese medicines.” Trade in tiger parts is lucrative and brings thousands of dollars into illegal markets,” Chapagain said, highlighting the threat faced by tigers.

text:
David and Melissa had been a happily married couple for six years. They lived a comfortably modest life in a small apartment and had been saving for years in preparation for the next giant step in their life: a baby. However, after repeatedly trying to get pregnant for a whole year, they consulted a doctor and received devastating news. Melissa couldn't conceive a child for the rest of her life.
The bad news hit Melissa terribly hard. Seeing his wife in such a distressed and depressed state broke David's heart. "Don't worry," he said. "I'm gonna make you the happiest woman on the planet, even if it's just the two of us." Then he went to the bank, took out all his savings that had been held for the baby, and set out to do everything he could to encourage his wife.
Since they no longer had to be careful about the amount of money they spent, David began to strip everything he could think of. First, she took Melissa shopping for the best and most beautiful clothes she could dream of. Then, they took an exotic vacation to the Florida Keys, where they spent a month exploring each island and spending thousands of dollars on the most beautiful hotels, and most of the delicious foods they could find.
When they finally came home. Melissa said, "Oh, David! Everything is perfect! I'm glad we don't have a child." David smiled, contented with his wife’s happiness, and approached to check her voicemails from when they were away. The machine blushed and then his doctor's voice came saying, "Hey, guys. Good news! There was an error in the test results. You're six weeks pregnant! They're triplets."

text:
The American Civil War took place from 1861 to 1865. The main cause was that the southern states feel that the U.S. federal government in Washington, D.C., should not have the power to tell them what to do. This was especially true on two issues, taxation and slavery. The economy of the South was based on agriculture, while the economy of the North was based on manufacturing. Southern crops such as cotton were sold to factories and then Southerners had to pay taxes on finished products sold to them again as clothing. Many Southerners felt this was unfair. Moreover, the agricultural economy of the south depended on the work of enslaved Africans and their descendants. Many people, especially from the North, felt that this was wrong and that slavery had to be abolished. Southerners felt that abolitionists threatened their way of life. Seven southern slave states, united, declared their secession and formed the Confederate States of America. The government in Washington, D.C., and its army were known as the Union, as they were fighting to keep the country together.

Abraham Lincoln was president of the United States during the Civil War. The President of the Confederate States was Jefferson Davis. The first battle was the Battle of Fort Sumter. During the war, President Lincoln issued the Proclamation of Emancipation, which declared the freedom of slaves in the Confederate States of America. This action was supposed to show that Lincoln was still in charge of all the United States.
The Civil War was the bloodiest war ever waged within the United States. 620,000 people died and millions more were injured. One of the bloodiest battles of the Civil War was the Battle of Gettysburg in Pennsylvania. 51,000 people on both sides died, more than in any other battle. The Civil War ended in 1865 when General Robert E. Lee of the Confederate Army surrendered.

The next time you decide to check your Facebook page to see if you have any new messages, like them, or just to see what your friends are doing, you can thank Mark Zuckerberg. Zuckerberg is the man who changed the way people keep in touch. It literally changed the world.

Born in White Plains, New York, on May 14, 1984, Zuckerberg developed an interest in computer programming at an early age. When he was only 12, he had developed a messaging system that his father Edward used in his dental office. Zuckerberg had many friends who were artists, and they came and drew for Mark. Then he designed a computer game based on the characters drawn. In high school, Zuckerberg developed a music software program that attracted the interest of several large companies. He enrolled at Harvard University in 2002, where he developed his first social networking site for students only. The site was very popular, but it was closed by the school because it was inappropriate.
During his second year at Harvard, Zuckerberg began working on Facebook, a site that allowed its users to create a profile, share photos and communicate with other members. He left his second year to dedicate his work to his site. He moved his operation to Palo Alto, California. By the end of 2004, Facebook had more than 1,000,000 members.
Zuckerberg's rise to the top has not been without controversy. Some of his Harvard colleagues claimed he stole his ideas, and filed a lawsuit against Zuckerberg. The case was resolved, but it remains a problem. Facebook generates more than $1.5 billion in net revenue today.

A wake is when people go to a deceased person's house or a funeral home to pay their last respects. A funeral home is a place where the preparation of the body for burial takes place. Part of the preparation can be to dress the deceased, make them up and place them in a coffin for people to see. Some people have a closed casket wake, where the dead person cannot be seen; some people are not even choosing coffins for their dear departed loved ones.

In the United States, more and more families choose not to have traditional stelae. There is a recent trend of people who have non-traditional stelae with the deceased inn doing something they loved to do when they were alive. For example, a family in New Orleans had their dead loved one sitting on a table with a cigarette between his fingers and a can of beer. A funeral home in Puerto Rico has become famous for its non-traditional wakes. It all started in 2008, when a family asked for their dead loved one to be leaning against the wall of their home for the wake. When a paramedic died, his family had his body in the seat of an ambulance driver. Another family had a man leaning on a fake boxing ring for their wake. A dead man was placed on top of his motorcycle. Recently, a grandmother was an inn sitting on her rocking chair.
However, these non-traditional wakes have their critics. Some people think they're disrespectful. They think of death as a solemn and sad occasion, not as a time to pose the dead as toys. Fans feel it helps them remember the dead as they were when they were alive.

I could hack your phone easily, said security investigator Tomi Tuominen. Obviously, I noticed.
Over the next 20 minutes, Tuominen and information security researcher Robert Lee gave me a tutorial on how to make my iPhone hacker-proof. text:
(1) Fairies today are the material of children's stories, few magical people with wings, often shining with light. Typically beautiful and feminine, like Tinkerbell in Peter Pan, they often use their magic to do small things and are primarily human friendly.
(2) We owe many of our modern ideas about the fairies to Shakespeare and the stories of the 18th and 19th centuries. Although we can see the origins of the fairies as far back as the Ancient Greeks, we can see similar creatures in many cultures. The earliest fairy creatures can be found in the Greek idea that trees and rivers had spirits called dryads and nymphs. Some people think that these creatures were originally the gods of earlier pagan religions worshiping nature. They were replaced by the Greek and Roman gods, and then later by the Christian God, and became smaller and less powerful figures as they lost importance.
(3) Another explanation suggests that the origin of fairies is a memory of real people, not spirits. Thus, for example, when tribes with metal weapons invaded lands where people only used stone weapons, some people escaped and hid in forests and caves. Another support for this idea is that it was thought that fairies were afraid of iron and could not touch it. Living outside society, hidden people probably stole food and attacked villages. This could explain why fairies were often described as playing with humans. Hundreds of years ago, people believed that fairies stole new babies and replaced them with a "changer" – a fairy baby – or that they took new mothers and made them feed fairy babies with their milk.
(4) Although most people no longer believe in fairies, only a hundred years ago some people were very willing to think that they might exist. In 1917, 16-year-old Elsie Wright took two photos of her cousin, Frances Griffiths, nine, sitting with fairies. Some photography experts thought they were fake, while others were not sure. But Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of detective stories Sherlock Holmes, thought they were real. He published the original photos, and three others that the girls took for him, in a magazine called The Strand, in 1920. The girls only admitted that the photos were fake years later in 1983, created with pictures of dancers that Elsie copied from a book.

text:
Once a child completes the fifth or sixth grade in primary school, they graduate and move to middle or secondary school. This school is a separate building or set of buildings. Most high school students are between 10 and 14 years old. The qualification system continues in middle school. High school usually begins with 6th or 7th grade and ends with 8th grade. Although less common, some primary schools range from kindergarten to eighth grade.

Most students are assigned a middle school based on where they live. However, there are public, private and specialized secondary schools that have an application process. The purpose of middle school is to provide a transition period between primary and secondary school. High school prepares students for life in high school. In middle school students don't stay in a classroom all day with a teacher. Students change classes for different subjects and have different teachers for each subject. In middle school some students may even be able to choose some of their own classes, called optional. There is a set of basic classes that all students have to take. These include classes in English, mathematics, science, and social studies or history. Gym classes or physical education are also required.
A common feature of middle school is a classroom, which is a scheduled time visit once a day or once a week. A home teacher takes the assistance and makes announcements of the things students need to know. The classroom also helps students feel that there is a common place and a common teacher they see regularly. This is to help transition from primary to secondary school. Once a student finishes middle school, they have a graduation ceremony and go to a high school assigned to them or a high school they chose.

text:
Debbie Benzine lost her first husband to heart disease when she was 44. Her death left her alone to raise a little boy. For 16 years, she stayed single because, going through it once was enough for me.
When he met Dale Benzine, he weighed about 300 pounds, but he was in very good physical form. However, over time, she saw how the former football player began taking pills for her high cholesterol and high blood pressure, more for anxiety and gout, and insulin injections for her type 2 diabetes.
His circumference became larger, just like his neck, which caused sleep apnea, he remembers. After the couple in Atlanta got married, he found himself buying her ever bigger clothes.
When her insurance company announced that bariatric surgery, or weight loss surgery, would be covered by the couple's plan, she told her husband about it. I knew I had to do something, but I wasn't sure I was ready for something so drastic, he says.
It was.
The doctor told Benzine: Lose weight or die. I was tired of taking so many medicines and not having enough energy to just live my life.
One day... you find out you're 56 and if you want to see 66, you better do something about it, he says.
There are several types of bariatric surgery. With gastric bypass, a new stomach the size of a golf ball is created by cutting through the upper stomach and connecting the smaller bag with the intestines.
Another type consists of placing an adjustable band around the top of the stomach. The device may be tightened or loosened at subsequent doctor visits. It can help make patients feel more full faster and eat less. Unlike gastric bypass, adjustable gastric band procedures can be easily reversed.
Benzine decided to do gastric bypass surgery. Although doctors are not sure why, studies have shown that gastric bypass puts type 2 diabetes in remission in most obese patients. Dale didn't want to have the option of reversing the surgery either.
At the bottom of your mind you can always remove the band, says the procedure of the lap band. I didn't want to be able to come back.
Being approved for surgery was harder than I expected. Many people who have bariatric surgery gain weight again, so insurance companies are often cautious about paying for the procedure. Benzine saw her primary care doctor, a nutritionist, a cardiologist, a pulmonologist, a gastroenterologist, and a psychiatrist, all of whom had to sign.
The psychiatrist told Benzine that he rejected more than half of his patients because they were not prepared to make the necessary life changes after surgery. Benzine admitted that 10 years ago he wouldn't be ready either.
I'm from Wisconsin, he says. I enjoyed my beer, brats and cheese too much. But children and grandchildren change things. I was ready.
In time, he had the go-ahead. On the day of his surgery, his wife remembers that it was an emotional disaster. I tried to dissuade him -RRB - from having him. What if they made a wrong cut? What if he doesn't wake up? What if he had a heart attack on the table?
The surgery was a success, but it was far from the ideal patient. Shortly after the surgery he ate a paddle too fast and began to vomit. When he came home, he continued his trial and error period, getting sick as he learned his limits.
Imagine after eating your big Thanksgiving dinner... 10 times, he says he eats too much on his smaller stomach. And you can't do anything about it. You're so miserable and you have to go up or out.
He started off on a liquid diet, then I cleaned his food. Slowly introduced solids.
We didn't go to happy time or dinner with friends because I was uncomfortable, says Debbie Benzine. I started hiding to eat because I felt guilty.
It was like being a baby and learning to eat again, says Benzine. He realized that the meat -- steak, chicken, turkey -- was too hard to handle for his stomach. But popcorn fell easily. He developed 10 rules for himself, and other bariatric patients, and weight began to fall.
In six months, he had lost more than 125 pounds.
The hardest thing for him was to fill the time. He had to learn to reward himself with activities instead of food. Now smoke a cigarette instead of eating a bag of chips, or plan a big weekend getaway to celebrate a successful job. Order an appetizer instead of a plate when you go out to play cards with friends during the week.
Their daily diet consists routinely of Greek yogurt, protein bars, soup, popcorn, cheese, and cookies. He doesn't eat large meals, only smaller portions when he's hungry.
Somehow, his wife has had to alter her lifestyle to suit hers. It wasn't easy, says the couple, but it was worth it.
I'm 57 years old in 37, says Benzine with a laugh. No pun... I'm like a kid in a candy store. He plans to attend his 40th high school meeting in June with pride: I know I will be one of the only people who can say they weigh less at that meeting than at high school.
More importantly, I will have my husband and my best friend for a long time, says his wife.
Follow Dale's 10th Bariatric Surgery Commandments.
1 -RRB- Set your goals early, both in pounds to lose and the date you want to achieve this loss. Keep a daily record or scoring card of your weight loss.
2 -RRB- The trial and error of food and liquids will be necessary, but painful. Blueberries were terrible to me, but butterless popcorn worked. Imagine. Tip: Keep your anti-nausea pills close -- you will definitely need them at first.
3 -RRB- Find a breakfast with high protein content and a lunch you can live with every day. -LRB- Mine was Greek yogurt for breakfast and smoothies with strawberry, banana and chocolate protein. -RRB- Also, stay true to your vitamin regimen, especially vitamin B12, vitamin D, and calcium.
4 -RRB- Focus on changing your daily eating habits from three large meals a day, plus snacks, to five to six small meals.
5 -RRB - Stay hydrated! It is very important that you avoid dehydration, so avoid caffeine, carbonated soft drinks, beer and alcohol.
6 -RRB- Move more while you eat less. Start walking 30 minutes, four to five days a week. Build to walk farther and faster, and more often, while adding weight lift from two to three days per week. You will be surprised how quickly the weight will begin to fall once you enter this routine, plus your dog will love it even more than you!
7 -RRB- Start rewarding your new body with activities instead of food. Reward yourself by going to see a favorite artist if you reached a weight loss goal. Join a card club, start reading again, or make a movie appointment with your partner every week. Replacing your time going out to eat with activities will possibly be the best movement you will make throughout this journey.
8 -RRB - It's okay to leave food on your plate! Regardless of what your mother said as you grew up, children in Africa, India, or China will not be affected if you leave food on your plate when you eat at home or away from home. People will ask why, but trust me, you won't hurt their feelings if you say you're full.
9 -RRB- Ask for an appetizer as your main meal when eating outside. You will be surprised how full you will be after eating the smallest portions and your pocket will also thank you.
10 -RRB- And last but definitely no less important, welcome and embrace your support network, be it a wife, friend, business colleague, etc. You will have good morning and a few bad and unconditional love and support to these people will show you that it will help you push through the bad and be there to help celebrate the good!

text:
Most people do not know that the full name of the Statue of Liberty is "The Statue of Liberty illuminating the world." It is a symbol of freedom, especially for many immigrants. When many immigrants arrived in the United States at the end of 1800, Lady Liberty at the New York Port was a sign to tell them that they had arrived in the United States. Inside the base of the statue is a plaque with a famous poem written on it. The poem is "The New Colossus" by Emma Lazarus. Many immigrants feel that this poem tells them why they came to the United States. One line of the poem is: "Give me your tired, your poor, your crowded masses longing for free breath." Lady Liberty wasn't always green. She used to be copper, but the years have caused the copper that the statue is made to change color.

The 151-foot sculpture was a 100-year gift from France to the United States in 1886. It is located on Liberty Island just off the southern end of Manhattan, New York. The only way to get there is to take a ferry. Inside the base of the statue is a museum. To get to the crown, people have to climb 377 steps down a double spiral staircase from the feet of the statue. There's no elevator. People have to be in good shape to get to the top. People used to be able to climb the statue torch, but it was closed because it was too easy to fall.
About four million people visit the Statue of Liberty every year. People who can't go to New York can see replicas in Las Vegas and other parts of the world.
