text:
A Canadian man who emerged to fame after offering a free trip around the world to a woman with the same name as his ex-girlfriend has returned from the excursion with his chosen homonym, although, to the dismay of those following the story, love did not flourish among the couple. Jordan Axani, a 28-year-old Toronto real estate developer who became the founder of charity, returned to Canada with Elizabeth Quinn Gallagher, but said the couple had “forged a sister-sister relationship.”
Axani had made headlines in 2014 after offering a plane ticket to any Canadian named Elizabeth Gallagher. He had booked a three-week vacation with his ex-girlfriend but, after they split up, he could not change his name on the flights.
That's where Axani's new travel partner, a 23-year-old student from Cole Harbour, Nova Scotia, came in. Gallagher, named Quinn, responded to a post Reddit that Axani had presented – along with another hopeful Elizabeth Gallaghers – and was selected. Gallagher had made it clear before the trip that he had a "very serious" boyfriend, but that he had not stopped the romantics, and the journalists, from waiting for the globetrotters to fall in love with each other. Unfortunately, it wasn't.
“It wasn’t easy and it certainly wasn’t immediate. It took us about a week to meet each other,” Axani said. There was a certain amount of “natural escort” around “the two and not traveling together” as the couple came to know each other.
“I’m going to be explicitly clear,” Axani said, shortly after the pair returned to Toronto. “This was never a romantic effort. It was strictly platonic. I don't think of Quinn as a romantic light in the slightest. There's no future for us romantically. She's a good friend. I think of her as a little sister, but that'll be it. And his feelings are totally mutual in that sense.” However, it took work to establish that brother-sister relationship, good friend, non-future-for-us-romantically. Another one. “In the end, we had developed a really big rhythm of, a second, having very funny jokes inside, and, the next second, knowing when the other needed space.”
Although the couple did not fall in love with each other, Axani said the trip, which took place in Milan, Venice, Vienna, Prague, Khao Lak (in Thailand) and Hong Kong, was “fantastic.” A favorite place was Prague, said Axani, where “they had the largest pool of people that spread.”
“In the course of two and a half days, I think we met about two dozen people. So that’s a lot of stories, that’s a lot of individuals and that’s a lot of love for your hometown of Prague.”
People were following the couple on Twitter and Instagram, Axani said, and were even recognized on the street in Hong Kong. “It was a real adventure. We had a big explosion. We learned a lot about ourselves and about others. I don’t think I can imagine it going much better when I leave it than it did.”
Axani returned to Toronto at 3 a.m. on Monday, January 12, when the party stopped abruptly. He went directly to a board meeting with other board members in his charity, Un Ticket Forward. Axani began the non-profit organization after his post on Reddit went viral and intends to offer travel around the world to survivors of abuse, cancer and war.
Along with that, Axani is also in talks to turn his story into a TV or movie show, although he would not comment on the form that such productions could take. “Suffice it to say that there has been a significant interest from many producing companies. In terms of his love life, Axani said he was not yet looking for his next Elizabeth Gallagher. “I’m not looking for anything, per se, but life happens and we’ll see,” he said. “As always, life is a journey.”

The Lakers are one of the most successful teams in the history of the NBA. They have appeared in 31 championship finals, more than any other league team. text:
What does it mean to be innovative in business?
For a business to survive in today's world, it is important that we regularly review what we are doing and how we are doing it. By considering new ideas and ways to do things, and trying to innovate, we can improve our products/services, increase sales, reduce costs and make our processes more effective and efficient. Innovation is key to increasing profits.
There are several ways a company can be innovative with its products and services. Today we will see four of them.
1. Using the latest technology to improve your product/service
When we think about innovation, we often think about new technologies. Although they could be impressive, we should not use new technologies just because they are available. It is important to consider how technology can improve our product/service and make a difference to our customer. Companies producing cars, toiletries, household appliances, etc. They often have a large R & D department to work on improving their products.
2. Responding to customer demands by changing what is offered
By listening to customer feedback, we can get their opinions on how we are doing and find out what they want. We also need to be aware of changes in customer demands and keep up with the times. When McDonald's fast food restaurant realized that the market wanted healthier options, they introduced fruits and salads, while removing the "super-size" option from their menus.
3. Offer a new product/service to reach new customers
Your business might be going well, but there is no growth or development and there is a risk that your competitors might take some of your customers. Innovation sometimes means the development of a new product that targets a different market. Although video games were often played by children, in 2006, the gaming giant Nintendo introduced the Nintendo Wii game console, successfully targeting girls and older customers with games like Cooking Mama and Brain Training.
4. Changing the way you provide a service
When we examine changes in the customer's lifestyle and needs, we sometimes realize that there might be better ways to serve him. Customers who don't have much time might prefer to have their food or purchases delivered to their homes, or would like to make their banking online rather than in a real bank.
Not all innovation will bring success to our companies, but it can give us the opportunity to grow and learn more about what we do and what our customers might want.

text:
For 13-year-old Arrianna Merritt, the words mother and hero go hand in hand.
Three years ago, Arrianna Sunday saw her mother Kim Dahl drive a school bus loaded with children across the Mississippi River when the bridge began to fasten from top to bottom. Thirteen people died in the collapse of the bridge in Minneapolis, Minnesota. What Arrianna remembers most was the choice her mother made that day after the bus leaned upward on a steep slope.
Either you let us fall freely... or you hold that brake to the ground and you stay where you are. Dahl held the brake with his foot until he could reach the parking brake.
Millions of spectators saw the impressive images of the school bus as it staggered on the edge of a broken stretch of the road, with nothing but a railing separating it from a deadly fall. Arrianna sat on the bus with her brother, another 50 children and eight adults.
The bus went up, and then fell, Dahl recalls, adding that it soon became a free fall and she was holding on for her dear life. I thought this was it, I'm not going out, and I'm going to die.
The New 35W Bridge: Is America’s Safest?
With the parking brake on, Dahl kept the bus in place while everyone managed to exit through the rear emergency door safely. Arrianna, 10 years old at the time, and her brother David, 5 years old, were the last and had refused to go out with the others.
We didn't want to leave our mother, David, now 8, remember.
“I am like pulling your asses off the bus,” Dahl said. Eventually they did.
Dahl says he managed to free himself after a jolt on the bridge seemed to release his seat belt, which had been jammed.
Since that day, those on the bridge and their loved ones have never been the same. This particular mother-daughter couple says they have always had a close bond but Arrianna says she and her mother have come even closer since their test.
“We have always been close, but I believe that after the accident we approach because we share the same experience and know how it is,” Arrianna said.
The physical reminders of that day often overshadow the emotional ones.
It hurts to see my mother suffering because she can't do the things she liked to do.
Dahl broke it in the fall and that's been the main cause of complications ever since.
“It is like a new me I am living with,” Dahl said. I can't go shopping alone because I can't raise the milk and put it in the cart.
“My children and my husband... could not ask for a better family,” Dahl said. I mean, my kids stand up and do a lot of work that I can't do or help me do things that I can't do. They're pretty good at saying yes.
“I don’t know if life will ever be normal as before July 2007 and before, but we have done our best for it,” Dave Dahl said. We've adjusted our lives, we've changed our way of life. But we have to be positive.
Dave Dahl reminds himself that things could have been worse. Our family unit here in this house is five people, he says. In an instant it could have been two.
Arrianna in particular has taken on a number of tasks, such as cleaning the toilets and washing clothes, which she says has taught her to be an adult.
Most of the time when my mother is in the hospital or surgery, I have to intervene and be the surrogate mother of my younger siblings, Arrianna explains. The family also includes another daughter, Brianna, 11 years old.
And my dad's working a long time, so he doesn't have much time.
It teaches me how to grow a little and how to be an adult and how it is.
He adds that it can be difficult from time to time, but these days you simply remember who you are doing it for.
Now I understand why I have to stop and why sometimes I have to be the adult.
Kim Dahl also deals with post-traumatic stress, and still sees a therapist twice a month. And although Arrianna no longer has her own therapy sessions, she occasionally still struggles. Kim Dahl is among 122 victims and their families who have filed a lawsuit against URS Corp., an engineering and construction company contracted by Minnesota DOT to conduct engineering analysis on the bridge before it collapsed. A federal investigation report blamed the collapse of the support plates that were too thin, and increased the weight on the bridge of construction equipment. The amount of punitive damages the plaintiffs are looking for against URS is hard to say, said Dahl attorney Bill Harper, who estimated it could be as much as $100 million. URS was hired by the state to make sure the integrity of the bridge was safe for the public, Harper said on Wednesday. They didn't do what they promised to do -- and as a result -- that bridge collapsed. The URS lawyers said that the company's work was not related to the causes of the bridge collapse... the URS did not design the bridge, it was never asked to verify the original bridge design, and it did not know that the original bridge design was defective. Hennepin District Judge Deborah Hedlund is expected to decide on punitive damages in mid-October. Painful Reminders
On Tuesday Kim Dahl and Arrianna visited the site of the collapse, where the new I-35 West Bridge is located. The sound of a pneumatic hammer in the distance is enough to remind Arrianna of the construction noise that took place on the bridge at the time of the accident. It makes her cry.
Fortunately, Mom's close.
“He is like my counselor because he listens,” Arrianna said. She doesn't need a therapist anymore, but it's these rare times when mom's useful.
And from time to time, Arrianna says, her roles are reversed. Remember to listen to your mother sometimes say things about how life would be easier if none of this had happened.
Arrianna's advice?
You need to move on, and you need to be strong and live your life to the fullest.
Those are words that the family is living. Kim Dahl has had to give up what her husband Dave Dahl would call the wildest motorsports, and the five of them have taken a new hobby: road trips.
Kim Dahl says he'll never be able to drive a bus again... something he misses more than anything else. She had the same bus routes for years and knew the children and their parents well.
But the family camper can be the best. So far, they've reached Florida to the east and Colorado to the west.
My mother could never afford it... we never went anywhere, Kim Dahl remembers her childhood. And we went on -LSB- our -RSB- first trip and it was just awesome. Learning things and seeing things was just amazing.
As Dave Dahl describes it, there's no stress, no itinerary, nothing, just come on.
Wherever we get there is where we get there, he adds. We have a goal where we like to be at the end.
Given the path Kim Dahl and her loved ones have taken since 2007, that phrase could also be the family motto.

text:
Most individuals do not think of numbers, or numerical representations of quantity, but they play an important role in everyday life. To be sure, numbers determine how long individuals will wake up in the morning, how much money employees earn per hour, what day of the year it is, and much, much more.
In addition, the figures affect daily life on a much smaller scale. In the supermarket, for example, the numbers determine the prices of the products, the quantity of a product available for purchase, how much money will have to be paid for the products, and much more.
To understand larger (and more intimidating) numbers, interested people first need to understand basic numbers, or numbers from one to ten, as they comprise each and every advanced number, or a number of multiple digits indicating a larger quantity/quantity.
The basic numbers are as follows:
One (1)
Example: "Buyed a watermelon at the supermarket."
Two (2)
Example: "Buyed two kinds of bread from the store."
Three (3)
Example: "He decided to buy three bags of onions when he went shopping."
Four (4)
Example: "In preparation for the party, Janice bought four boxes of ice cream from the store."
Five (5)
Example: "Joe collected five boxes of cereal from the breakfast corridor."
Six (6)
Example: "A pound of meat costs a lot of money in my favorite grocery store."
Seven (7)
Example: "Seven of the 10 corridors of my local supermarket contain pasta."
Eight (8)
Example: "I bought eight cookies for the price of four at the store."
Nine (9)
Example: "There were only nine breads left in the supermarket."
Ten (10)
Example: "Ten pineapples are many, don't you think?"
After ten, eleven (11), twelve (12), thirteen (13), fourteen (14), fifteen (15), sixteen (16), seventeen (17), eighteen (18), nineteen (19) and twenty (20) follow. These numbers are seen less in grocery stores, as most prices are $10 or less; however, it is worth knowing these numbers, in general and, in terms of grocery purchases, for when the account should be paid.
After twenty, numbers like twenty-five (25), fifty (50), seventy-five (75) and one hundred (100) follow. As long as one knows the core number, or the number located in the tens or hundreds position that determines the overall amount, understanding these more complicated numbers will not be difficult. For example thirty-three (33) is simply "thirty" plus three; sixty-seven is "sixth" plus seven; and sixty-nine is simply "sixth" plus nine.

Two tank barges loaded with light crude oil hit a bridge on the Mississippi River early Sunday morning.
The Coast Guard said it was trying to determine how many gallons could have been spilled in the river near Vicksburg, Mississippi.
The leaking tank contained 80,000 gallons of oil.
A Coast Guard team has stopped the source of the spill, the agency said in a press release.
The river is closed from kilometer 425 to 441.
No one was injured in the accident, which occurred at 1:30 a.m.
The Mississippi River in Vicksburg moves around 890,000 cubic feet of water per second, according to the U.S. Geological Survey. If the ship lost all its oil, that would be about 11,000 cubic feet.
In February 2012, a tank barge spilled 10,000 gallons of oil in the Mississippi after a collision near New Orleans. The coast guard drained the barge and towed it to a repair facility.
CNN's Chandler Friedman contributed to this report.

Jenny's a fifth grader. She's considered one of the most popular girls in her class. She's very pretty, but that's not why she's considered popular. She is popular because she is known to be one of the brightest in her class. You can do the most flips in a row, but above all, you have the talent to dance.

Last year, he entered the school dance contest and won the first place. Her whole class was there to support her. Since that day, she has been the attraction of the class. This year, the school is holding another dance contest, but there has been a change in this year's competition. Competition has to be done in pairs.
Jenny's class admired her with high expectations that she would win again this year. On the other hand, Jenny wasn't sure about this year's result. She wanted to enter the competition, but she had never danced with a couple before. She decided to ask some of the boys in her class to come in with her. Everyone said no because they couldn't dance. Jenny was hesitating about joining.
He finally decided to turn to one of his closest friends, Carl. Jenny and Carl have known each other since the first grade. Carl was reluctant to join at first because he couldn't dance either. Jenny insisted. He finally agreed to join the competition. Jenny was happy and relieved. However, she was still worried because she knew that her class was counting on her to win this year's competition.

text:
Manhattan is a small island that is a part of New York City. New York City, "the Big Apple", is actually composed of five sections called boroughs. These districts are Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island and the Bronx. Manhattan has most people in all districts, about 1.5 million, even though it is the smallest district by size. If you send a letter to someone living in Manhattan, don't write Manhattan on the envelope. You should write "New York, New York," like Frank Sinatra's famous song.

Because the island is so small, most people live and work in tall buildings. Some of these buildings are called skyscrapers because they seem to be touching the sky. Some famous skyscrapers in Manhattan are Empire State Building, Chrysler Building, 70 Pine Street, Trump Building, GE Building and Citigroup Center. Manhattan is connected to the other districts by a series of bridges and tunnels. The most famous bridge can be the Brooklyn Bridge due to its brick arches. The New York City subway, a massive mass transportation system that mostly operates underground, also connects the island to the rest of the districts.
Manhattan, like the other districts, has many different neighborhoods, many of which bear the name of the ethnic communities that lived there for the first time. Some of these neighborhoods include Little Italy, Little Germany, Little Brazil, Chinatown and Koreatown. One of the most famous parts of Manhattan is Times Square. Times Square is called the crossroads of the world. Every year millions of people gather there on New Year's Eve to see an illuminated crystal ball. There are many theaters around Times Square. Most of these theaters are on Broadway, a famous street considered home to the American theatre industry. Another famous Manhattan street is Fifth Avenue. A part of the avenue features expensive designer shops such as Tiffany's. Fifth Avenue is also famous for its Museum Mile.

text:
While many women are involved in planning their wedding showers, a baby shower usually comes as a complete surprise. A baby shower is a party where a pregnant woman is "showed" with gifts and good wishes. A baby shower is usually given by a close friend or relative of the future mother. Sometimes a pregnant person’s co-workers also throw a baby shower.

The baby shower is usually given when the future mother is between 6 and 9 months pregnant. However, sometimes, because predicting a baby's birth date is not always accurate, a baby shower can occur after the baby is born. A baby shower can be carried out in someone's house or outside, such as in a restaurant or catering room. Traditionally only women are invited to a baby shower. However, more and more baby showers also include the future parent. Like a wedding shower, a future mother will often register a wish list of things she wants in one or more stores. This list usually consists of things the mother wants for her baby, including clothes, diapers, and even furniture like high chairs and cots. This way friends and family can go to the store and buy something from the list. Registration helps make sure there are no repeated items, like 30 bottles when a new mother only needed 15.
Some baby showers also feature a paper mache that you want well. This isn't just for decoration. People can put cards inside with wishes for the new baby and mom. Most of these cards also contain money or gift cards to help the future mother buy anything else she needs for the baby. Sometimes there are games in a baby shower. In a game everyone guesses the date of birth of the baby. Another game has people taste of baby food and guess the taste

text:
It's a Sunday night in Bridgetown, Barbados.
Here on this Caribbean island, and in the others that make up what is known as the West Indies, life revolves around one thing: cricket.
Tonight, locals gather at the historic Kensington Oval, which hosted the 2007 World Cup final. There are no national teams on display this time, but there is a local trophy at stake.
It is enough to attract a large crowd of bustling fans. In the contest, a familiar face opens its way among the crowd.
This is Franklyn Stephenson, and he's the best he's ever played for the West Indies, all because of a decision he and his teammates made 30 years ago.
He left each of them, forever, marked as a rebel.
In 1983, the West Indies cricket team was on top of the world. Team captain Clive Lloyd of Guyana had led them to consecutive World Cup victories in 1975 and 79.
Contact Marked as a rebel presenter Don Riddell on Facebook
Abounding with talent, the islands of the West Indies could have run at least two teams of world-class players. But with all the hype and success, the money didn't go on. Playing international cricket and the club wasn't enough to make a living.
At the same time, in a distant world, South Africa was deep in the heart of apartheid. His government's policies had divided life into different classifications for whites and so-called non-whites.
Such oppression of the non-white population escalated into violence, arresting young protesters like Nelson Mandela in prison. Thousands more were arrested or killed.
As the world tries to put pressure on South African leadership, sanctions are applied and sport is no exception.
In 1970, the International Council of Cricket banned South Africa from competing internationally, leaving the country's cricket fans deprived of the sport they loved, and their cricket players from the races they dreamed of.
“You are always optimistic,” former South African cricket Clive Rice said. The stupidity that existed would change and South Africa would change much faster, and we would be back playing international sport. But he held on and held on.
" Rebel tours "
To save cricket in South Africa, sports managers knew something had to be done.
So, secretly, they started planning rebel tours, inviting several teams from around the world.
It was a bold move to challenge the ICC ban by offering lucrative contracts. In March 1982, England's first rebel team arrived in Johannesburg.
From our point of view, we knew we had the best cricket players in the world, said former president of the South African Union of Cricket, Joe Pamensky, one of the rebel organizers of the tour. We wanted to show them to the world so they could see it just like we did.
At the end of that year, a team from Sri Lanka followed.
And it wasn't long before many began to suspect that South Africa was also targeting a team from the West Indies, the dominant force in the world cricket.
You heard a lot of whispers around the place that maybe these guys were going to South Africa, recalled announcer Tony Cozier.
But at that time, we could not believe that they could assemble a team of West Indies players given the background of the anti-apartheid movement.
Many of the great stars of the West Indies were frank in their refusal to play in South Africa's apartheid.
Captain Clive Lloyd said that no amount of money could take him there. Future Captain Viv Richards called it bloody money.
But other players were tempted.
South Africa's offers were more than they would likely see in their lives -- estimated at between $100,000 and $150,000 per player.
It was enough to draw in names such as Lawrence Rowe and Alvin Kallicharran, fast bowling player Sylvester Clarke and wicketkeeper David Murray, one of the best in the game.
He also agreed to participate in the 1979 World Cup hero Collis King.
I made the decision because they were not treating me well as far as the West Indies - LRB- team -RRB- was concerned, King said. And I said to myself, well, cricket is my job. You're not gonna pick me, I'm gonna go play cricket somewhere where people see the right cricket. And that's why I went.
More than just cricket
The rising star Stephenson was only 23 years old in 1983, with a promising career in front of him. He had repeatedly rejected offers to play in South Africa.
But the day the team left, Stephenson changed his mind.
I knew the tour was more important than just being cricket, Stephenson said. I think cricket can make a difference, and I'm gonna be part of that team.
On the plane, Stephenson recalled, some of the players began to have doubts. But it was too late, they were on their way to South Africa, to face apartheid head on.
When we arrived in South Africa, I realized that separation, and it wasn't just black and white, he said. It's the language you speak in, the area you live in, and it's what you're allowed to do, and where you can go. So the divisions were very real when we got there.
The West Indies rebels prepared for their first test match.
But their concerns soon turned out to be unfounded... in crowds, crowds went out to see the famous cricket players.
“We packed them,” Murray said. We turned out to be 20,000 in Pretoria, the heart of apartheid.
As the tour continued, players began to believe something more important than cricket was taking place.
The young children -- the white ones -- asked for autographs. It seemed that South African fans could not have enough of the black cricket players in the West Indies.
For the first time, they were seeing blacks hitting whites, said journalist Al Gilkes, the only Caribbean journalist to go to South Africa.
Here was a country where no black man had seen a black person competing with a white person, and beating him. For me, that's where the real victory was.
`Destroyed as cricket players '
But the critics of the tour disagree. They say that the presence of a team of black men in South Africa did not help to end apartheid, but strengthened and supported it.
Even within the country itself, non-whites protested against the rebels of the West Indies.
In the Caribbean, the reaction was worse. A deep sense of betrayal crossed the Caribbean. Cricketers who were once seen as heroes were now seen as sellers.
When the month tour ended, the rebel players knew they would have to face the repercussions of their decision at home.
“I felt sorry for them,” Gilkes said, “because I knew they would never survive what they were returning.
The fate of his cricket careers fell on the West Indies Cricket Control Board.
Players were aware that they could face a ban -- after all, England's rebel team had been banned for three years; Sri Lanka's was banned for 25 years.
But they didn't expect to be banned for life.
Many of them were destroyed as cricket players, said Professor Hilary Beckles of the University of the West Indies. His cricket careers came to an end.
Murray, once a star, is now drifting, unable to keep a job in Barbados. In the years after the tour, he finally lost more than just his career.
His wife gave birth to her little daughter in Australia, while Murray played in South Africa.
They faced deportation from Australia for their role in rebel tours, and were also not welcome in the Caribbean. They had a newborn, and they had nowhere to go.
They didn't want me to come back, Murray said. Politics got into this.
When asked if his current situation was the result of his decision to leave, Murray replied: Most likely.
Mercenaries?
For Stephenson, the star that once emerged, his cricket past is behind him. He is now a golf instructor at a country club in Barbados.
But he still finds a way to connect with the sport he loved at the cricket and golf academy that began near his home.
There, a photo of his rebel team sits proudly on the shelf. It's not the memories of the tour that you want to forget, but what came next.
“No one took care of us,” Stephenson said.
For players, their lives defined by this unique moment in the history of sport, every day is a reminder of what they lost when going to South Africa.
But they also won something... strong ties forged on a tour condemned by the rest of their world, appreciated by the participants.
And to this day, they cling firmly to the belief that being in South Africa in 1983 made a difference in the dissolution of apartheid, less than a decade after West Indies players were there.
Gilkes wrote a seven-part series on the tour. In the last article, he stated that the trip could have started with players being seen as mercenaries, but he saw them as missionaries who turned white South Africans to accept that blacks were their equals.
“I know I went there as a missionary,” King said.
Murray agreed. I don't see the mercenary part of it or anything. We were just professional cricket players. You have work to do.
What do mercenaries do? Stephenson asked. They go and fight someone else's cause.
Well, yeah, I was a mercenary for the cause of blacks, because wherever I've been, I've been ambassador to my country, my race, and cricket game. So if that's being a mercenary, then it was.

text:
Improvements in Oak Hall
Introduction
This report aims to describe the problems at Oak Hall of Residence and discuss possible maintenance work to solve them. The two most important topics were discussed at a meeting held on May 12, attended by 165 of the 250 students living in the building.
Question 1: Room temperature
Several students complained that the bedrooms on the second floor were too hot. Concern was expressed about the lack of sleep and the difficulty of students to study in their rooms. It was suggested that air conditioning be a possible solution.
However, there is no budget left to install air conditioning this academic year. In addition, the facility can only be carried out during the holidays, as students cannot be present in the building while the work is being carried out.
Issue 2: Improved wheelchair access to the Oak Café
It was noted that wheelchair users can only access Oak Café from behind and not from the front entrance near the elevators. This makes it difficult for wheelchair users to access the cafeteria. The university is looking to improve its wheelchair access in general by installing ramps in key areas and the work can take place during the time period without problems for staff or students.
Conclusion and recommendations
Taking into account the above factors, August would be the best time for the installation of air conditioning. Until then, the university could consider supplying fans to every room on the second floor so that students can sleep and study comfortably.
The front of the cafeteria is recommended as an ideal place to install a wheelchair ramp. This work can be carried out immediately and must be a priority.

Andrea's acne got worse day by day. Not only did it not look good, but it made her feel self-conscious. I wanted to go see a dermatologist about her skin condition. Andrea had health insurance through her work. When enrolled in the health plan, he chose a primary care physician. That doctor would take care of Andrea's basic needs. However, the primary care physician was not a dermatologist. If Andrea wanted the health insurance to pay for the dermatologist, she first needed to make an appointment with her regular doctor. Otherwise, Andrea would have to pay out of her own pocket to see a dermatologist.

Andrea called her primary care provider. He had to wait a week for an appointment as his acne was not an emergency. When it was time for the appointment, she showed her doctor the acne problem. Her primary care doctor was able to prescribe a skin cream for Andrea. Andrea used that skin cream for a week, but her acne didn't get better. He called his doctor. The doctor couldn't do anything else for her. So the doctor gave him a reference to see a skin specialist, a dermatologist.
Andrea called the dermatologist, but had to wait another three weeks for an appointment. His acne had worsened during these three weeks. When he finally saw the dermatologist, he did a series of blood tests and allergy tests. The dermatologist told Andrea that acne was actually an allergic reaction to fried foods. Andrea thought it was a lot of trouble to finally figure out what was wrong. She was happy though now that she knew that all she had to do was not eat fried food, which was not good for her waist or her skin.

text:
During the past week, I have been flooded with questions about swine flu, via Facebook, Twitter, CNN blogs and email. So this week I'm empowering people with information about swine flu: how to protect themselves, what all the numbers mean, and why you shouldn't be scared.
The most recent advice from the CDC is that non-essential travel to Mexico should be avoided.
1. Hasn't there been a swine flu for a while?
Yeah. The swine flu was first identified in 1930 when researchers isolated the virus in a pig. In 1976, more than 200 soldiers in Fort Dix, New Jersey, had swine flu. From 1976 to 2005, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention received approximately one or two annual reports from people with swine flu. Between December 2005 and January 2009, 12 cases of swine flu were reported.
2. The people who have it now, did they get it from pigs or people?
It seems that no one in the United States with swine flu had contact with pigs. Dr. Richard Besser, acting director of the CDC, said at a press conference on Friday that among the first seven cases, no one had contact with pigs. At another press conference on Monday, he added that investigators have sought to see if any of the infected people had contact with pigs, and we are not finding that link here.
3. The swine flu is transmitted from animals to humans. Does it happen a lot?
Yeah. More than 200 zoonotic diseases are transmitted from animals to humans, including diseases caused by bacteria, viruses and parasites. Rabies and the variant of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease - LRB- better known as mad cow disease -RRB- are two well-known examples.
4. Should I cancel my trip to Mexico?
Yeah, you should, unless it's essential. That's the advice of a recent CDC travel notice. See Elizabeth Cohen answer your questions
5. Should I be freaking out?
A new virus that spreads rapidly all over the world. Young and healthy people died in Mexico. Should we all be panicking?
Of course not, said Dr. William Schaffner, president of the preventive medicine department of the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine. The swine flu, he said, is not spreading so quickly. Take St. Francis School in New York. There has been very little transmission from schoolchildren to family members, and it has certainly not spread through Queens. iReport.com: Share your thoughts, worries about swine flu
But, Schaffner added, this does not mean that we should not pay attention to swine flu. We must be alert, keep up with the information that comes out daily, and take control by being attentive to their hygiene. Wash your hands very, very often and avoid people who are coughing and sneezing.
6. How close do you have to be to a sick person to get swine flu?
You can acquire this infection if you are within the breathing area of a sick person, who is about three to six feet, Schaffner said. And we usually mean being so close to someone in a confined space. We're not talking about fleeting contact. We're not talking about walking past someone on the street. You need sustained contact. If you think you may have had contact with someone who is ill, read this guide to the CDC website.
7. Wow! Every day I'm so close to countless people... at work, on the bus, in church, in a movie theater. Could I have swine flu from them?
Yeah.
“If you’re next to someone on a bus, or sitting next to someone or in front of someone in a theater, you could acquire the infection that way,” Schaffner said. That's why people with the symptoms of any type of flu -- fever, diarrhea, body aches, vomiting, etc. -- they are urged to stay at home and away from groups of people.
8. Wasn't there a vaccine at the same time? Is there one now?
Yes, a swine flu vaccine was given to 45 million people in 1976. There is no vaccine now, although researchers are working on one.
The 1976 vaccine would not be useful anyway, according to Dr Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
That was a completely different virus from the virus we are dealing with right now, completely different in the sense that genes are different, and it has no relationship, Fauci said. The designation of each was called swine flu, but from a viral point of view and the spread is very, very different.
Here are two scientific articles on the swine flu outbreak and vaccination program in 1976:
• Reflections on the 1976 swine flu vaccination programme
• Swine flu outbreak, Fort Dix, New Jersey, 1976
9. Many young and healthy people have become ill in the United States. Many of the dead in Mexico have been young and healthy. What's going on? We usually think that the flu affects the very young and the very old.
This happens sometimes with new viruses. For example, in 1918, when a new influenza virus emerged, many of those affected were young and healthy. One theory is that young people, who have strong immune systems, mount a particularly vigorous response to new viruses. But there is a potential side effect on the response: the body releases dangerous levels of signaling proteins, called cytokines, that can damage the lungs. Scientists believe that these cytokine storms can be fatal.
Here is a scientific article on the proposed mechanism of cytokine storms.
10. Why are there a large number of people dying in Mexico, but not in other countries?
This is the great mystery that doctors are trying to solve right now. Many experts in infectious diseases say it is very likely to be a matter of numbers: with more diseases in Mexico, there are also more deaths. Other explanations: that in Mexico people have, in addition to swine flu, other viruses that make a combination more deadly than swine flu alone. It is also possible that the virus that infects the rest of the world is a weaker version than Mexico. Among the mysteries of swine flu: Why only the deaths in Mexico?
11. Could this new swine flu virus have been manufactured by bioterrorists?
That's the theory of some conspiracy theorists websites. But experts don't believe it.
If you were a bioterrorist, you'd want to create something far more deadly than this, said Dr. Gerald Evans, associate professor of microbiology at Queen's University in Canada. The problem with the flu is that the second one that gets into people, replicates and mutates very quickly. Even if you created the perfect biological weapon, within a few generations of transmissions, I wouldn't do what you planned I would do.
12. I get flu shots every fall. Will that help me protect myself from swine flu?
The short answer is that the CDC says it is highly unlikely, Schaffner said. But he said it might be possible. I think it's a bit of an open question whether repeated influenza vaccines for years would provide a protective measure.
13. I was in Mexico two weeks ago. Could he have contracted swine flu, and the symptoms have not yet appeared?
No. The incubation period for swine flu is one to seven days.
“If you’ve just traveled to Mexico and you’re home and you’re feeling well, you should get on with your daily life and not worry about it,” Evans said.
14. Can the swine flu virus live on inanimate objects? If someone with swine flu touches a knob, then I touch it, could they have swine flu?
Flu viruses can live on inanimate surfaces. So theoretically, you could get swine flu by touching a knob that was touched by an infected person. However, that is quite unlikely, according to Dr. Arthur Reingold, head of epidemiology at the University of California School of Public Health, Berkeley.
Personally, I wouldn't have a big fear of environmental pollution, he said. Virtually all the flu is transmitted by sneezing and coughing.
Schaffner agrees, adding that flu viruses do not survive in large quantities on surfaces. A doorknob is not a warm and nutritious environment for a virus, he said.
15. What should I do if I have symptoms of swine flu?
Call your doctor... don't drive around here, Schaffner advised. Follow the instructions of your doctor. He may not want you in the waiting room spreading germs to others, he said.
CNN medical producer John Bonifield contributed to this report.
label: B1

text:
To the unaccustomed eyes, a man who takes 120 books while riding a stubborn ass looks nothing less than a circus show. But for hundreds of children in the rural villages of Colombia, Luis Soriano is far from being a clown. He is a man with the mission of saving rural children from illiteracy.
“There was a time when many people thought I was going crazy,” Soriano, a native of La Gloria, Colombia said. They'd scream, the carnival season is over... now I'm over that.
Soriano, 38, is a primary school teacher who spends his free time operating a bibleblioburro, a mobile donkey library that offers reading education to hundreds of children living in what he describes as abandoned regions in the Colombian state of Magdalena.
In -LSB- rural -RSB- regions, a child must walk or ride a donkey for up to 40 minutes to get to the nearest schools, Soriano said. Children have very few opportunities to go to high school... There are -LSB- few -RSB- teachers who would like to teach in the field.
You know a hero? Candidacies open for 2010 CNN Heroes
At the beginning of his 17-year-old teaching career, Soriano realized that some students had difficulty not only learning, but also completing their tasks. Most of the backward students lived in rural villages, where illiterate parents and lack of access to books prevented them from completing their studies.
To help bridge the learning gap, Soriano decided to personally bring books to the children.
I saw two unemployed donkeys at home and had the idea - LSB - to use them -RSB- in my library project because they can carry a heavy burden, Soriano said. I put the books on their backs on saddles and they became my work tools.
Every Wednesday at dusk and every Saturday at dawn, Soriano leaves his wife and three young children to travel to certain villages, up to four hours per journey, aboard a donkey called Alpha. A second donkey, Beto, is still behind, tying up additional books and a sitting blanket. They visit 15 villages on a rotating basis.
“It is not easy to travel through the valleys,” Soriano said. If you sit on a donkey for five or eight hours, you get really tired. It's a satisfaction to reach your destination.
In each village, about 40-50 young people await their opportunity to get help for homework, learn to read or listen to any variety of high stories, adventure stories and geography lessons that Soriano has prepared.
You can see that the children are excited when they see the biblehead coming this way. “It makes them happy to keep coming,” said Dairo Holguín, 34, whose two children participate in the program. For us, their program complements what children learn at school. The books they don't have access to... they're taken out of the bible.
More than 4,000 young people have benefited from Soriano's program since it began in 1990. Soriano says countless others have been helped, too; parents and other adult students often participate in the lessons.
Soriano has spent almost 4,000 hours riding his donkeys, and has not traveled unharmed. In July 2008, he broke his leg when he fell from one of the donkeys; in 2006, he was assaulted by bandits at a river junction and tied to a tree when they found out he had no money. Despite these wounds, which left him limping, Soriano has no intention of stopping.
In addition to the library program, he and his wife built Magdalena's largest free library next to her home. The library has 4,200 books, most of which are donated, some as far away as New York City. They also have a small community restaurant.
Soriano's hope is that people understand the power of reading and that communities can improve by exposing themselves to books and diverse ideas.
For us teachers, it is an educational triumph, and for parents -LSB - it is -RSB - a great satisfaction when a child learns to read. This is how a community changes and the child becomes a good citizen and a useful person, Soriano said. Literature is how we connect them to the world.
You want to get involved? See Luis Soriano's website at www.fundacionbiblioburo.com and see how to help.

text:
For most people, an ideal morning might consist of waking up to the warm sun creeping through the bedroom window, along with the joyful singing of the birds of a nearby tree. Unfortunately, this is not the case with Michael, a part-time student who works at night as a warehouse manager. Michael arrives home at around 2:00 a.m. every night, and heads straight to bed to sleep as much as possible until his classes start at 10:00 a.m. However, over the past week, Michael has had a new "alarm clock" that he unfortunately has no control over. It is a energetic, noisy, nightingale who has decided to make the tree outside Miguel's window his new home.

Every morning, the bird begins to sing as loudly as possible at exactly 5:55 a.m. and does not stop until late at night. Most birds in the city start the day with sweet and soft chirps that can hardly be heard indoors, but the sounds of nightingale are very different and consist of several noises that the nightingale hears and then imitates. This may include chirps from other birds, or even car alarms and school bells.
After a week of losing sleep as a result of bird noises, Michael decided to do something. "Go away!" He screamed out the window. When that didn't work, he started throwing things into the tree to try to scare the bird. This just made the bird get even stronger! As a last resort, Michael phoned his local Animal Control, and asked someone to take the bird out of the area. "We can't do that," the Animal Control Specialist replied. "Ruffians are a valuable feature of North America's wildlife and are protected by many laws. You should consider yourself lucky to have one so close to home. Just enjoy the beautiful sounds of nature."
Furious, Michael hung up the phone, and threw himself on the couch, sleeping in the deepest sleep he had experienced all week. Only five minutes later he woke up to a loud "cow-cow!" It's coming from outside.
label: B1

text:
Having your own space is a sign of success in the United States. However, renting an apartment is not easy. There are a number of steps you need to take. First, you have to figure out how much you can pay per month.

When you first move to a new place, most landlords expect you, the tenant, to pay a security deposit. A security deposit is an amount of money that you pay a landlord kind of insurance that you will not destroy your property while you are living there. Usually, the security deposit is equal to the amount of a month's rent. If when you move, the apartment is in the same condition as when you moved, the owner will return your security deposit. If the apartment has any damage, including holes in the walls because it hung posters, the owner can legally use that money to fix the apartment.
Once you know how much you can pay, you can start looking for apartments to rent. You can look in the newspaper or online. Also walk through a neighborhood where you want to live and be in search of signs of "In Rent".
There are two ways to rent an apartment. Most landlords rent apartments annually. This means that you will sign a document called a lease, which says you will stay on the property for a year and pay the rent on a monthly basis. If you decide that you want to break the lease, or leave before your year is over, there are usually fines you will have to pay. Another way to rent an apartment is from month to month. This means that you pay per month, and are not required to stay for more than one month at a time.
label: B1

text:
Cinco de Mayo, or May 5, is a party celebrated by Mexicans in the United States. Before 1776, much of the southern and western states, such as Texas, New Mexico, Colorado, Nevada, Arizona and California, were part of Mexico. After the war between the United States and Mexico in the 1800s, these states became part of the United States, but there was still a very large Mexican population.

The Latino population is the largest ethnic group in the country. It represents 17 percent of the country's population, and 63 percent of those Latinos are of Mexican origin. Cinco de Mayo is a great celebration in the southwestern region of the country. It celebrates the Mexican victory at the Battle of Puebla, against France on May 5, 1862. Interestingly, the day is celebrated more in the United States than in Mexico itself.
In Los Angeles, the city celebrates the event with the Broadway Fiesta, which is the celebration of the world's largest Cinco de Mayo. More than half a million people come to downtown Los Angeles to participate in the 24 square block street fair. The celebration takes place on the last Sunday of April. There are rides, games, and especially food in this celebration and it is growing every year. Los Angeles is not the only city in Southland to host the May Five celebrations. The cities of Corona, West Los Angeles and Commerce also have events, and the famous Olvera Street celebration in downtown Los Angeles is also very popular.
One of the most unique events of the Cinco de Mayo takes place in the Hancock Park district of Los Angeles. It's called the May Single. This celebration is an annual charity event that began in 1999. It is a private party that benefits the homeless by providing shelter and support. Cinco de Mayo is a truly American celebration.

Matthew Hoffman, 30, who lives in the house where Sarah Maynard was found, provided the information that led to the discovery of the three bodies, Barber said. Hoffman is currently facing a kidnapping charge in the kidnapping of Sarah Maynard, Barber said.

It is estimated that about 40% of the world's population uses social media, and many of these billions of social media users seek influencers to help them decide what to buy and what trends to follow.
So what is an influencer and how do we become one?
An influencer is a person who can influence the decisions of his followers because of their relationship with their audience and their knowledge and experience in a particular area, for example. fashion, travel or technology.
Influencers often have great follow-up from people who pay close attention to their views. They have the power to persuade people to buy things, and influencers are now seen by many companies as a direct way to the hearts of customers. Brands are now asking powerful influencers to market their products. With some influencers charging up to $25,000 for a social media post, it's no wonder that more and more people are willing to become influencers as well. If you are one of them, then here are five tips on how to do it.
1. Choose your niche
What is the area you know the most? What are you more excited about talking about? Find the specific area you are most interested in and develop.
2. Choose your medium and write an interesting biography
Most influencers these days are bloggers and microbloggers. Decide what means – like your own online blog, Instagram or Snapchat – is the best way to connect with your followers and chat about your niche area. When you have done so, write a biography that describes you and your area of expertise in an interesting and unique way. Make sure that people who read your biography will want to follow you.
3. Regular and systematic posts
Many influencers publish daily on their social media accounts. The more you publish, the more likely people are to follow you. Also, make sure your publications are consistent and possibly follow a theme.
4. It tells an interesting story
Whether it's a photo or a comment you're posting, use it to tell a story that will capture the attention of your followers and help them connect with you.
5. Make sure people can easily find their content
Post your posts on a variety of social networks, use catchy hashtags and titles, and make sure they can be easily found. It makes no sense to write the most exciting blogs or publish the most attractive pictures if no one is going to see them.
Most importantly, if you want to become a social media influencer, you need to be patient. Keep publishing and your followers will gradually increase. Good luck!

There was a time in the United States when blacks were not allowed to play baseball with white players. That was before the big Jackie Robinson broke what was called the color line at baseball. Prior to April 15, 1947, the Major Baseball Leagues were an exclusive "white-only" organization that prevented the participation of black players. Black Americans could only play in the Black Leagues that existed between about 1920 and 1948. Robinson, and the Brooklyn Dodgers, put an end to baseball segregation that year, and began a movement for racial equality in the United States.

Robinson was born in Cairo, Georgia on January 31, 1919, but grew up in Pasadena, California, near Los Angeles. He was a leading athlete who played baseball and football at Pasadena City College, then at the University of California in Los Angeles (UCLA). During his time with the Dodgers, the team won a championship, and appeared in the World Series six times. From 1949 to 1954, Robinson was named a member of the All-Star Team, and won the National League's Most Valuable Player Award. He was also named the New Year of Baseball in 1947, the first year he was awarded the award.
Today, Robinson is honored by every team in the National and American Leagues at Jackie Robinson Day. On that day, all MLB players wear the number 42 in honor of Robinson. That number, used by Robinson, was removed universally by all baseball teams, so it's the first time any league has withdrawn a number. No player on any MLB team can use that number again. Robinson was included in the Hall of Fame in 1962. He died on October 24, 1972, and was posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom and the Congressional Gold Medal for his part in changing American society.

Paintings of angels protecting sheep or a masterful interpretation of the manger scene certainly evoke emotion. Then there's a good Christmas story. In 1843, Charles Dickens gave us a Christmas Carol. This literary gift had the power to make us give a couple of things to those in need.
However, it is music and song that has no rival in the ability to stir raw emotions. No matter what your religious persuasion is. Most people can recite and hum the Christmas carols they have heard repeatedly since childhood.
Among the most familiar are the pop songs: Santa Claus is Coming To Town, which the four stations, Bruce Springsteen and Bing Crosby all performed; Gene Autry's Here Comes Santa Claus ; Elvis Presley's Blue Christmas ; and Brenda Lee's RockinAround the Christmas Tree.

That was not the case, and the song was a great success decades later -- in 1943. These songs evoke old family photos of relatives here and long gone. We said, oh, look, here's an old kind of Aunt Emily... she was so kind and generous. Even if we never liked it... but then it's Christmas. - RRB-
Below are the seasonal songs that really have little or nothing to do with vacations. Once again, those vendors have perfected their skills to pull our sentimental strings. Dean Martin singing Let It Snow! Leave it snow! Leave it snow! Dinah Shore and Buddy Clark making Baby, it's cold outside. -LRB- This song of trying to lure a young woman to stay was written for the film Daughter of Neptune, with Esther Williams and Ricardo Montalban. - RRB-
Judy Garland singing Have Youself A Merry Little Christmas in the 1944 movie Meet Me In St. Louis and dozens more all have great images, and they are all seasonal. Did you know that Jingle Bells was originally titled One Horse Open Sleigh and was written in late 1850 by James Pierpont, to be performed during a Thanksgiving service at his Unitary Church in Savannah, Georgia? The congregation enjoyed it so much that it was repeated during Christmas services, and Jingle Bells left there.
Of course, Christmas is for children. There are new songs written for children, such as the most famous reindeer of all, Rudolph. He entered our lives when we were young with his bright red nose and never came out of the roof. Then there's all I want from Jimmy Boyd for Christmas are my two front teeth, the version of the singing dogs of Jingle Bells and Homer and Jethro's grandmother was run over by a reindeer. Songs that only a child can like.
But my favorite has to be Dominic de Lou Monte the Italian Christmas Donkey. What if I want a hippo for Christmas, Gayla Peevey? Someone please explain why someone would buy that song.
So here's the question: What's all this about? The emotional and often wonderful snapshots of our lives, past and present, all wrapped up for Christmas. Have we been tricked into loving this holiday? Of course not.
A while ago I realized we all need a little Christmas. The security of home, family and friends is essential.
So this marketing campaign that started with our first steps is okay, we need it. Is there a Santa Claus? Have I been a good boy? Wouldn't it have been nice if those marketing guys had figured out a way to make those 12 days of Christmas last the other 353 days of the year?
So cover the halls and please stop leaving Santa those chip fattening chocolate cookies -- he's gained a lot of weight over the last 200 years. And I say to you, Fa la la la la, la la la la.
Happy holidays, cousins.

Not so long ago women in the United States were treated as second-class citizens. They do not have the same basic rights as their male counterparts. King was a professional tennis player, who won great success during her career on the women's tennis court. He won 39 Grand Slam Titles, 12 singles, 16 female doubles and 11 mixed doubles. The 29-year-old king, who was at the top of his professional career at the time, faced a former Wimbledon champion, Bobby Riggs. Riggs was one of the best male players during his best time in the 1930s and 1940s. Riggs, 55, challenged King to an exhibition game claiming that the game of women was far inferior to that of men. King defeated Riggs without a problem. The game was later exposed by what many people said would be: a showcase for King to show that women could compete against men. When you apply for public housing, on request you need to give the names and ages of everyone who will live with you. You will also need to give the address where you currently live and a telephone number you can contact.

In your application, you need to explain why you think you qualify for public housing support. Some reasons may include being veterans, being poor, or living in poor conditions. Bad conditions can mean that the place where you live now is dangerous or can mean that you are in a domestic violence situation. The government will also want to know the name and contact information of your current owner and any owner you had in the past. This is so the government can figure out if you're a good tenant. You'll also have to tell the government how much money you make in a year and how you earn that money. You can't invent that information. You will need to provide your boss's information, old checks, and bank statements.
The government can visit you at your current home and interview you and the people you live with. Other things the government will ask for are your birth certificate and birth certificates from all the people who will live with you and proof that you pay taxes, such as a tax return. If you are eligible for any public housing assistance, you will receive a letter. If you get approved, they'll put you on a waiting list. You can be on the waiting list for a long time before you can actually move to a public housing unit. This is because there are many people who ask and can receive help. Sometimes you can be waiting for years.

Editor's Note: CNN.com has a business partnership with CareerBuilder.com, which serves as an exclusive provider of job and service listings to CNN.com.
You can sell your skills, your time or your things used to make some extra money.
With an abundance of job losses, wage cuts, eliminated bonuses and a decrease of 401 - LRB- K -RRB- matching contributions, their income is shrinking - but the bills are not n'.
If your normal job isn't to earn enough money or you've lost your job completely, these simple side jobs can help put some stuffing in your pockets until, even later, you get back on your feet.
Here are 10 ways that real people creatively take home some extra mass:
1. Self-employment
Felice Premeau Devine left her lucrative full-time job two years ago to raise her son. In the meantime, she has collected writing and editing independent work and started a blog, where she is able to earn some cash from advertising.
Today, almost any work can be done on a contractual or independent basis. Check out sites like Sologig, which lead job seekers to hire, consult, freelance, temp-to-fire and part-time project opportunities in their field.
2. Sell your books
If you are a college student or stick to your college textbooks thinking you might want to read them again somewhere on the line, select retailers like Barnes & Noble let you sell your textbooks for some quick money. Or, take some classics from your personal library and sell them in a second-hand local bookstore.
3. Find currency in circulation
Susan Headley, the coin guide at About.com, is a lifetime coin collector who has been increasing her revenue by looking through coin circulation for the past six years. In 2008, he won about $2,500 and so far in 2009, he has won approximately $500 of the coins he has found.
People looking for the currency successfully to get a secondary income do so in very large numbers, he says. They buy rolls of coins from banks, typically in whole boxes, and fix them to find things that don't belong, Headley says. Half of the dollars, for example, were no longer made from 90% of the silver after 1965, but they still had 40% of the silver in them until 1970; either of these is a good gain. Presidential dollar errors can be worth $50 to $5,000 each; uncirculated quarters can sell $10 to $50 per roll; and rare error coins can value up to $35,000.
4. Start a business
Turn your hobby, skills, or experience into a part-time business. Sites such as Jobvana can help you do so by providing you with free tools to market your services and offer specialized skills to those seeking help.
Peter Olson says he built a profile in September 2008 offering to teach guitar lessons. Since then he has won two students, earning about $240 an additional month and raising about $1,000 since he started teaching.
5. Enter local and online draws
Wendy Limauge has been entering draws since 1993 and teaching others to win through her website, Sweeties Sweeps, since 2002. Although winning draws rarely provides real cash, her winnings have consistently provided her and her family with 200 to 300 prizes a year, many of them great items that she and her husband could not afford to earn alone.
Among the prizes he has won are three television sets, two of which are flat screen; a home theater system; three dishwashers, each won on separate occasions; at least $1,500 in gift certificates for groceries; a voucher of $18,000 for the vehicle of his choice; a trip to France valued at $25,000; and, in March 2009, he won $5,000 in a game he instantly won.
The Internet has so many options to save money, get something free, win a prize or earn money from home, says Limauge. Just find those resources that offer useful information and sign up in the right direction to get started and stay motivated.
6. Give your opinion... and you get paid.
Linda Childers, a California-based freelance writer, says many of her friends participate in focus groups. Contribute an hour of your time can earn up to $100, sometimes more. Online surveys, phone surveys, and product testing can also earn you from $5 to $150. Check out the free paid surveys or FindFocusGroups.
7. Sell your trash.
Terri Jay earns $2,000 - $3,000 per month only with the sale of scrap metal. On eBay, Jay not only sells things he's not using, but visits local second-hand stores at 99 cents, garage sales, and tackle sales, looking for things she knows the value of. She says that her best sale was for a 70s beverage tray: she paid 25 cents for it and sold it for $87.
The trick is -LSB- to sell -RSB- what you know, she advises. Therefore you can list them -LSB- at correct prices -RSB- so they will be collected in searches -LSB- on eBay -RSB-.
8. Join a Direct Selling Company
Direct selling is one of the easiest ways to earn some extra money, especially if you sell products you love. Avon, for example, allows you to start your own business for $10 -- your taking home depends on your efforts. Some full-time representatives earn six-figure salaries, others own Avon Beauty Centers on license, and many simply sell Avon part-time around their family schedules.
Haizel MacIntyre started his Avon business in June 2008 to earn additional income to his full-time job when her husband was fired. Since joining Avon, MacIntyre has an average of $1,800 a month in sales and her husband is helping her run the business. Her income from Avon helps pay bills, provides extras for her three children, and she is hoping to earn enough to put in for her college tuition when she returns to school to get her master's degree in Social Work.
9. Being a secret buyer
Eyes for detail, as well as a good memory are really all it takes to succeed as a secret buyer, says Zippy Sandler, who has been shopping mysteriously for about 13 years. After registering with a secret commercial company, you are basically paid to go undercover and report on a company's operation from the customer's point of view.
Sandler decided to start secret shopping not only to earn money by eating, traveling and buying, but also to learn customer service skills to pass on to the employees he ran at a retail store. Depending on the customers you're buying for, Sandler says he's won anywhere from $100 to $2,000 a month.
10. Sell your photos to stock agencies
It doesn't matter if you're an amateur, an amateur or an experienced photographer - anyone can send their photos to stock photo agencies like Shutterstock.com. If your images are accepted, they will be available for download by subscribers. Every time someone downloads your photos, you get 25 cents.

Today many people are fans of social media. They are always looking at their mobile phones or tablets, and updating their Twitter or Facebook accounts. They're taking pictures of what they eat, or taking pictures of themselves, which is called "selfies." When people don't share too much, they are constantly reading or looking at what friends and family members are publishing. Social media is getting addicted.

Research shows that most people spend almost 4 hours a day on social media on average. That's almost 30 hours a week. While some people need and use social media to work or to stay in touch with friends, others find that using social media causes anxiety and stress. People also tend to use social media as a way of procrastinating. So like many religions asking people to abstain, or not to have certain foods or drinks for a while, many people are taking fasts on social media. They're not updating their states, and they're not reading what other people are publishing either. They choose to stay away from social media for 30 days.
Ironically, the details of these fasts can be found on social networking sites all over the Internet. The reasons why people undertake a fast are varied. Some people want to reconnect with their families or friends by disconnecting from their cell phones. Some people want to be more productive at work. What did some do faster instead of logging in? Some decided to connect with friends by sitting down and having face-to-face conversations. If friends or loved ones were far away, they would instead call them on the phone. Some even wrote postcards or handwritten letters. The results were mixed. Some people felt that not using social media made them more anxious. Others developed more positive habits such as daily or meditation.

His was one of the first pictures of a missing child that appeared in a carton of milk. Almost 30 years later, Etan Patz is still missing.
Etan Patz, who disappeared in 1979, was the first child to disappear in the milk carton campaigns of the 1980s.
Etan was 6 years old when he disappeared on May 25, 1979, Friday before Memorial Day. I was on my way to school in what is now the exclusive Soho neighborhood of New York.
It was the first time I walked to the bus stop alone. It was a few blocks from here. Etan, like any 6-year-old, argued that all his friends walked to the bus stop alone, and his parents gave in.
His mother, Julie Patz, found out that Etan had not been to class when he did not return home. He called the school at 3:30 p.m., then called all his friends' houses. When no one had seen Etan, he called the police and filed a missing person's report.
At night, more than 100 police officers and search engines had met with hounds. The search continued for weeks, but no trace of Etan's whereabouts was found. See an update on the case
The disappearance of the child was one of the main events that inspired the movement of missing children, which raised awareness about the abduction of children and gave rise to new ways of searching for missing children. The case of Etan was the first of the milk carton campaigns of the mid-1980s.
In our minds there were only two possibilities, said Stan Patz, the child's father. Either Etan was taken by a stranger and killed or was taken by a very sad woman desperate for a child of her own, and we hoped that such a woman would at least take care of him and keep him safe.
Patz lived with this hope until 1982, when he found out about José Antonio Ramosarrest and the surprising connection between him and an old nanny from Etan.
Ramos was a vagabond who in 1979 lived in Alphabet City, a neighborhood not far from Soho. In 1982 he was arrested after the boys in a Bronx neighborhood complained that he had stolen his bags of books while trying to put them in a drain under a bridge, where he lived, said the Patzes and federal prosecutor Stuart GraBois, who spent years investigating the case.
When the police found Ramos in his house, they found that he had many photographs of blond little children. They realized that they looked a lot like Etan Patz, according to author Lisa R Cohen's book on the case, After Etan: The Missing Child Case that Held America Captive.
The Bronx police questioned Ramos, and denied having anything to do with Etan's disappearance. But he told the police that his girlfriend used to take care of the child, GraBois said.
The Bronx and Manhattan prosecutors followed this lead, but concluded that they did not have enough evidence to connect Ramos to Etan's disappearance, said GraBois and a spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney's Office.
Ramos was released when the parents of the Bronx children decided not to press charges against him, according to published reports. He left town and disappeared for six years... until Grabois reviewed Etan's case. Grabois said he focused on Ramos as the prime suspect.
GraBois said he learned in 1988 that Ramos had been arrested and convicted of child abuse and was serving a sentence in a Pennsylvania prison.
GraBois said he took Ramos to New York to question him and surprised him with the question: How many times did you have sex with Etan Patz?
Ramos told GraBois that he had taken a little boy to an apartment he had on the lower East Side the same day that Etan disappeared. I was 90 percent sure it was the same thing I had seen on the missing news, GraBois said.
According to GraBois, Ramos claimed that he released the boy and took him to a subway station so that the boy could visit his aunt in Washington Heights.
Etan didn't have an aunt in Washington Heights, GraBois said. When asked more, Ramos refused to say anything else and asked for a lawyer, according to GraBois.
Ramos is serving a sentence of 10 to 20 years in prison in Pennsylvania. It is scheduled to be released in November 2012, said GraBois.
GraBois said he had moved Ramos to a federal prison, and planted informants as cellmates. I wouldn't go into details about what Ramos might have told you, but he said he's convinced he's looking at the right suspect.
GraBois handed over his evidence to the Manhattan District Attorney's Office, but prosecutors have not filed charges. They say without a body, they don't have enough evidence.
The case of Etan is still considered by the NYPD as an unsolved case.
Anyone with information about Etan Patz's whereabouts or leading to the arrest and conviction of the person responsible for his disappearance should call the FBI/NYPD Etan Patz hotline: 212-384-2200.

Green is not the first word that appears in most people's heads when they think of New York. However, in the middle of Manhattan Island is the most visited park in the United States, with 35 million visitors a year. Central Park, a National Historic Monument, occupies 843 acres of land. It is a green space where people will escape the noise and crowds of urban life. Before opening in 1857, it was not an empty space. People lived in that land. They were mostly poor free blacks, Irish and Italian immigrants. They were forced to leave the grounds to build the park.

A section of the park is called Sheep Meadow. Now it's just a lawn area where people can lie in the sun, but the royal sheep used to graze there from 1864 to 1934. The sheep from there were finally moved to another park in the city. Many events take place in Central Park, especially in the hot spring and summer months. There is an open-air theatre, where Shakespeare's plays are performed. The works are free, which causes such a high demand that people align for hours before the performances to enter. There are also free music concerts. Every summer a stage is set up. These Summer Stage concerts feature musicians from all over the world. Both the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and the Metropolitan Opera also host free performances in the park in spring and summer. There are also two small zoos inside the park, and a series of small lakes in the park. One of the lakes rents small mechanical sailboats. There is also a puppet theatre and a children's carousel.
The park isn't dead in winter. When it snows, families usually go sledding or ice skating on an outdoor rink owned by Donald Trump.

Since photos are usually taken on a cell phone, many people tend to share these pictures with friends and even strangers on different social media websites. Some of the popular social media platforms people use to share selfies include Instagram, Snapchat and Facebook.
