text:
Cameron Russell intends to open the media landscape to divergent voices a little at a time. In March, he helped launch the magazine Interrupt, initially a webzine, so that these other perspectives can join the media conversation. His first issue is dedicated to body image.
Russell is familiar with how women are portrayed in the media. He has been a model of brands such as Victoria's Secret, Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren and Benetton and has appeared on the pages of Vogue, Harper's Bazaar and W.
She is also known for her TEDx talk, Looks Aren't Everything, about those who win the genetic lottery and how society rewards the conventionally beautiful.
To celebrate the launch of the magazine Interrupt, it is inviting the public to an art lab called You Are a Genius in the Lower East Side of New York until Monday. It's on 215 Bowery Street.
CNN recently spoke to Russell about his new project.
CNN: How did the idea come about?
Cameron Russell: I had been thinking about an online participatory magazine for a while. After the incredible response to my TEDx talk, my Brooklyn-based art lab decided it was time to make this a reality. At Big Bad Lab, we build participatory art and media platforms for causes, communities and organizations that matter to us. I run the magazine with Hannah Assebe and Allison Bland, as well as hundreds of contributors who provide writing, photos, editing help and moral support.
CNN: Why interrupt?
Russell: Statistics show that diversity in the media is rather sad. In many important conversations critical voices of women and people of color are lacking. Have you ever seen an immigration panel without any immigrants? Abortion without women? Marriage rights without LGBTQ people? We knew it was crazy to start another media platform, but we found a lot of authentic online and offline voices that we felt we could gather and show. Sometimes you just have to interrupt!
CNN: What are the highlights in the first issue?
It's all about body image. We found that 50% of 8-year-old girls don't like their body. But they're not just girls. Many women said they couldn't remember a time when they liked their bodies, that they couldn't remember how they felt.
We collaborated with the interrupted photographer Marie C. who interviewed girls under the age of 8 asking what they liked about their bodies. Their responses shed light on a missing perspective in media conversations. These girls liked their bodies because they worked well! Instead of the usual negative views -- I'm too fat or I don't like my nose -- these girls appreciate the fact that they can draw with their hands and run fast with their legs. It's refreshing. His story was a great success and obtained more than 5,000 shares.
Then there's Teagan Widmer, a transgender woman who wrote about trying to find the right bra. His story is not exactly something the general press would cover. But when we published his advice to our Tumblr site it became one of the most popular stories.
The lesson here is that when we value a narrow range of experiences and perspectives, we not only have a media that lacks diversity, we actually underestimate our audience. There are not only a few types of experiences that matter -- there are countless.
CNN: With so many publications in digital format, what made you decide to publish a magazine?
Russell: Our first printed number is a simulated tabloid. Starting this week, it appears free of charge in beauty salons, kiosks, dentists' offices and other not-so-hidden places in New York City. Improving access to the media means not only focusing on first adopters. We are spending our resources on building a community of collaborators who can share unique and critical views.
CNN: What has been the most interesting experience in the launch of Interrupt?
Russell: Actually, I think working at Genius Offline Lab. We wanted to build a space where people felt comfortable and great in their identity. We have two walls of selfie because taking a selfie is an innate and obvious way that attracts many young people. We have a You Are to Geniusbar, where people can explore online resources for social services, civic engagement, health and well-being, and creative production.
Having an offline physical space where kids, teens, and random passers-by can get in and get involved is amazing. Take a look at our Tumblr feed. Many of these people spent more than an hour here, took pictures, wrote pieces for the next issue and came out. Sometimes, a great collaboration is difficult to nurture online so doing it offline is the way to go. We hope to run another one this fall. Stay tuned.
CNN: How do you spread the word?
Russell: The first hundreds of presentations came from people who learned about the project online, mainly via Twitter. Now that we are more involved in the project, we have cultivated many more collaborations. For example, -LRB- check out -RRB- a great piece we did with teenagers at the South End Technology Center in Boston. We have found artists like Ernest English, who made a piece that is attracting the greatest attention at the Genius Laboratory.
CNN: What is the biggest difference between your webzine and Buzzfeed?
Russell: There are a lot of new media startups strongly focused on getting big traffic and high growth, but that's not our central goal. We want to build something that alters the way we think the media can be done.
Can interruption have an impact?
Russell: Every time someone who is not a media creator creates something that goes viral, every time someone whose perspective is left out of mainstream media proves to have an impact, every time a collaborator collaborates with someone new to do a better job, we improve the media landscape a little bit.
CNN: What did you want to be when you grew up?
I always wanted to be president! When I was a kid, I was obsessed with politics. The first long book I remember reading was -LRB- Richard -RRB- Neustadt's presidential power in fourth grade. But as I learned more about our democracy, I realized that who participates, who votes and who is elected is not as simple as it seems. That made me interested in how to bring people together and turn on alternative networks of power, and that's why I started the Big Bad Lab.
Who are your heroes?
Russell: I'm inspired by the people I work with. At Genius Lab, we have three amazing artists. Ernest English makes huge public works of art participative. Adalky Capellan is a young woman who creates a large-scale job. When I saw his photos, I knew it was perfect to make our selfie of dreamy wall background. And then there's the graffiti artist and muralist known as miss163. She is a joy working with her, and her piece is all about love, which is great for us as one of our next issues is about LGBT.
CNN: If you can give advice to young women, what would it be?

text:
Taxes are special fees charged by a government to people living in a country, state or city. These fees help pay for public services such as police, road and bridge repair, and public schools. In the United States, people have to pay national, state and local taxes. Income tax is a tax applied to how much money a person earns in a year. There are federal and state income taxes. These have to be paid every year by April 15. There are special ways that the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), the government agency responsible for collecting taxes, asks people to fill in. There are tax credits that low-income people, college students and parents can get. These credits could mean recovering money from the government. This money is called a tax refund. People can get a federal and state tax refund. Anyone who works has to be taxed regardless of immigration status. Failure to pay income taxes could mean a fine or even a jail time.

Payroll taxes are taxes that are taken directly from a person's paycheck. There are federal and state taxes on payroll. These include Social Security and Medicare taxes. Social Security taxes pay for retirement and disability benefits received by millions of Americans each year. Medicare taxes pay for the federal health insurance program that covers the elderly and the disabled.
People who own houses pay property taxes. The amount paid depends on how much the property is worth. This tax is usually paid once a year. Sales tax is a tax that almost everyone pays. Sales tax is a specific additional percentage that is charged on almost all purchases. Everything, from soap to furniture, has a sales tax when bought. The amount of sales tax is different between states and cities.

text:
On 26 December 2004, a 10-minute earthquake with a magnitude of 9.3 occurred in the Indian Ocean. This massive earthquake, the third strongest ever recorded in history, triggered several powerful tsunamis that reached more than a dozen coasts of countries. Nearly 230,000 people died from the catastrophe, and hundreds of thousands of others were injured or missing. In the midst of all the devastation caused by this disaster, many surprising and inspiring survival stories have emerged. One of the most extraordinary is the story of a young woman named Wati.

The tsunami hit his hometown of Aceh when he was only eight years old. Like so many others, the powerful waves separated her from her family, and she ended up being dragged into an unknown village. After many years of searching for her, her family surrendered and assumed that she had died after being swept away. Miraculously, Wati was returned to her parents seven years later, at the age of 15.
According to Wati, she had been "adopted" by a stranger who found her in the streets after the tsunami. Although the woman took her to live with her, she forced Wati to beg in the streets and often beat her if she did not earn enough money. The girl had tried to find her family asking for help from strangers, but she did not remember the names of her parents and could only vaguely remember that she had a grandfather named Ibraham.
Finally, one day, a taxi driver who heard the story of Watti met an old man with that name in a nearby town and decided to take her with him. Although the old man did not recognize her at first, he took Wati to see his daughter. "When I saw my mother, I knew it was her," said the 15-year-old. "I just knew." The parents were able to confirm that she was really his daughter based on a scar and birthmark on the girl's hip. This miraculous story is unfortunately one of the only confirmed meetings between families that were separated by the disaster.

Susan grew up in Lincoln, Nebraska, the heart of the United States. Remember to play in the corn fields as a child, and see miles and miles of land stretching as far as I could see. One day her aunt took her to see the 1997 Titanic film starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet. He marveled at the vast ocean. It was something she'd never seen before. Remember he turned to his aunt to say, "I'm going on a boat like that one day, Auntie."

True to his words, Susan left Nebraska and moved to Los Angeles, California. She wanted to live near the ocean, and was delighted to discover that Queen Mary was permanently docked in Long Beach. The big boat, which is the same size as the Titanic, is now a museum and a tourist attraction. He didn't hesitate to book a boat tour. "This is wonderful," she thought herself.
Upon arrival on board, Susan was not disappointed. It was all she expected it to be. The ship was restored to its original state, which was very luxurious. His tour highlighted the history and importance of the ship over the years. He ate at one of the three restaurants, and stayed the night at the boat's hotel. Queen Mary was built in the 1930s in Britain, and enjoyed many years sailing across the Atlantic Ocean. He hosted many dignitaries such as Winston Churchill, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, and many Hollywood celebrities. During World War II, the ship was assigned as a troop transport where it was used to transport up to 18,000 allied soldiers per trip.
After the war, he was restored to his original state, and began his transatlantic journeys. In 1967, the city of Long Beach bought the old transatlantic, and has been a popular attraction for the city ever since. "It's a living story," Susan said, after her visit.

For five years, New York fashion designer has been selling low-priced clothing and home furnishings at Target. But with her new book comes a new job -- like Liz Claiborne's creative director.
CNN talked to Mizrahi about his love of theater, the most common fashion mistakes and why bad flowers are never right. The following is an edited version of that interview:
CNN: You started performing at the High School of Performing Arts. How do you combine that love and your love for design?
Isaac Mizrahi: Well, you know what, I think it's all theater. I think fashion is a form of entertainment. And I think these days, as a fashion designer, it's almost like you represent a political party or something.
As women say, that's a brand name I associate with because I've used it before. I love it. It seems to fulfill who I really am easily. But more than that, I have designs -LSB- in -RSB- the entertainment business. There's a movie called Unzipped about me that was a very successful movie. I had two TV shows. I design costumes constantly for theatre, ballet and opera. So it's a great world for me. It's perfect for me.
CNN: How is your daily schedule? It's got to be crazy about everything you do.
Mizrahi: It changes every day, and I really like that. There's a basis for it. I wake up, go swimming every day, and eat the same breakfast almost every day. But when I get to work, that's when it changes.
Some days I work in the exhibition room; some days I work in the design room; some days I really work in my own private studio, where I only do sketches and sketches and sketches. Other days I work in the TV studio recording segments and my web program.
I don't love traveling. I feel like you really interrupt what I like to do the most, which is this creation, you know what I mean? When I finally let myself enjoy it, I can enjoy traveling. Say you're walking down the street. What's the most common style mistake you see in people?
Mizrahi: I see a lot, a lot, a lot of bad hair. I'd say that's the most common style mistake I see is bad hair.
You know people have excuses for bad shoes -- because you know some people have back problems, it's the street and they're walking and walking and walking -- but I think people have no excuse for bad hair. Because you know what? There's a hat, if your hair is so bad that day.
But I always think women should be encouraged to spend a lot of money on their hair. It's like you should spend more money... on your hair. You'd think I had a chain of hairdressers, but I don't have them. - Lsb-Laughter-RSB-.
CNN: What about home decoration? You make a line for Target that ends this year. What is the most common mistake that people make there?

And people think bad flowers are better than nothing, but I don't agree with that. I think nothing's better than bad flowers. Either you have beautiful flowers, or you don't have flowers. Like dinner, I'd rather there aren't flowers than the flowers people have on the table. That's horrible, but it's true.
CNN: How has your personal style evolved over time?
Mizrahi: It has become much quieter, my personal style. I used to dress, dress, dress, dress, dress, and I don't know, dress in a very particular way now and it's almost like a watch. And every now and then I go out and do something crazy.
CNN: Can you describe your personality to me, and how it affects your style?
I don't know. It's very difficult to describe one's personality. I can't say about my personality, but I like to think that I'm very exposed to what's happening in the world culturally, and that's what influences my design.
It's like here are the 360 degrees of what's going on -LSB- in -RSB- the world culturally, you know? Socioeconomically, culturally, and here is my answer to it. And it's like a wonderful edge, you're standing, and yet there's enough space there for your own interpretation or to move in one direction or another.
Oh! Here is a good description of my personality: claustrophobic. I'm very claustrophobic. I don't like to commit to one thing necessarily, but when I commit to it, it's complete and complete.

There is a measure of creativity involved with writing in a journalistic style, but it is different from English.
Soon, Chris obtained his certificate, and then obtained his master's degree in journalism. Now he works for a great daily newspaper. That's how we did it when I was a kid, but I think I'm lucky to be able to see much more of their lives than my grandparents.
Ironically, Sheila's grandchildren are less likely to use Facebook themselves. Children under the age of 17 in the UK are leaving the site (only 2.2 million users are under the age of 17), but they are not far from their smartphones. Chloe, 15, even sleeps with her phone. "It's my alarm clock, so I have to," he says. I look at him before I go to sleep and as soon as I wake up.
Unlike her grandmother's generation, Chloe's age group is spending so much time on their phones at home that they're missing out on spending time with their friends in real life. Sheila, on the other hand, has made contact with old school friends she hasn't heard of in forty years. "We use Facebook to organize to meet across the country," he says. It's completely changed my social life.
Teenagers can have their parents to thank for their smartphone and social media addiction, as their parents were the first to adopt the smartphone. Pedro, 38 years old and father of two teenagers, reports that he used to be on his phone or laptop constantly. "I was always connected and I felt like I was always working," he says. So, at nights and weekends, you pull your SIM card out of your smartphone and put it on an old-style mobile phone that can only make calls and send text messages. "I am not completely isolated from the world in case of emergencies, but the important thing is that I am setting a better example for my children and spending more quality time with them."

An 85-year-old woman in Tennessee named Astrid became a multimillionaire overnight after winning a $500 million lottery jackpot. However, his path to wealth was not completely smooth. His story reminds us that to win the lottery, there are two crucial requirements. The first and most obvious need is a lot of luck. The second requirement is just as important, but much less often it is mentioned: to organize.

Astrid's story began when he lined up for a lottery ticket at his local supermarket. The woman ahead of her decided to let me cut her in front of her to pay. This woman was also planning to buy a lottery ticket. If I hadn't given Astrid his place on the line, the lottery money would have been his!
The day the winners were announced, Astrid realized he had won, he could not contain his emotion. He danced joyfully throughout his house and jumped on the phone to tell his closest relatives what had just happened. The next morning Astrid woke up and prepared to go and claim his prize, but suddenly he realized that he could not remember where he had placed his ticket. Since his memory was no longer as sharp as it used to be, he searched and searched his messy house for hours in vain. He had absolutely no memory of where he could have stored or dropped the ticket.
Astrid had received thirty days to claim his prize, or else it would be cancelled. For 27 days, his schedule was dedicated to searching every surface and square foot of his house for the lost ticket. Just three days later, he finally decided to call his daughters for help. She had been too embarrassed to call them from the beginning because her house was so messy, but now she had no choice. Assuming that helping his mother find the ticket would probably assure them at least an extra million dollars, Astrid's three daughters immediately headed home.
In the first half hour of searching, the youngest of her daughters shouted, "I found him!" Turns out Astrid had left it in a plate closet. "Oh, thank you, daughter!" Astrid cried. "I owe you so much!" Her daughter's smile shone with pride as her two sisters frowned at her from the next room.

text:
One of the most important lessons you should learn is when you drink, you shouldn't drive. I learned this the hard way. Last year, I got a DUI, which means driving under influence. If you're stopped and smell of alcohol, the police will ask you to take an alcohol test. When you do the test, you have to blow really hard on a machine, which then will tell you if you are over the limit to drive a vehicle. The limit is usually.08 volume of alcohol in the blood. So, if you go through that, you're going to jail.

Even if you don't go to jail for a long time, you'll be suffering the consequences of your mistake for a long time. Here is a list of things you will have to do if you get a DUI: go to court, go to alcohol education classes, go to Alcoholics Anonymous, pay a lot of money in fines. If you don't want to pay, you'll have to do community service. I have my DUI almost two years ago, and I'm still suffering the consequences. I still have 56 hours for community service.
I have to update my insurance policy, and deal with the Department of Motor Vehicles. You're wasting a lot of time and money. It's hard to get a job, because you have to let your future employer know you've been arrested. It's not worth it. If you're thinking about going out and celebrating with friends and family, do one of the following things: get a designated driver, take the bus or train, or call a taxi. It may cost you a little money, but compared to how much money you'll lose if you get a DUI, it's nothing. Don't drink and drive.

text:
Public schools are available to children from kindergarten to 12th grade free of charge. However, many families choose to pay for their children ' s primary and secondary education by sending them to private schools. There are many different types of private schools and many different reasons why parents send their children there. Some private schools are military schools and others are boarding schools where students live on campus. Some private schools are affiliated with a certain religion. These schools teach the beliefs and traditions of a specific faith, as well as regular academic subjects. There are schools run by Catholics, Protestants, Jews, Muslims and Orthodox Christians. There are also private schools specializing in the teaching of disabled students.

Some parents choose private schools because they feel they offer better education than public schools; others choose private schools because they offer a different kind of curriculum. Waldorf schools, for example, only allow children to play and use items made of natural materials.
Private schools are also called independent or non-State schools because they are not run by local, state or national governments. They can choose which students go to their schools. They do it through entrance exams and interviews. There is often an application for admission. Some private schools accept anyone who can pay tuition to send their children there. Some schools charge up to $45,000 a year. Private schools charge tuition because they do not receive money collected from local, state and national taxes. Some private schools offer a limited number of scholarships to help pay for the school. Many of these scholarships are based on needs, which means for students who cannot afford tuition. Other scholarships are offered for students with very good grades or for students who have a talent in a sport or art.

LRB-CNN-RRB-Feidin Santana, the man who recorded a South Carolina police officer fatally shooting a man who was fleeing, unarmed, told CNN on Thursday night that another cop told him to stop using his phone to capture the incident.
One of the officers told me to stop, but it was because I - LRB - told them -RRB - that what they did was an abuse and I witnessed everything, he told Anderson Cooper 360 of CNN.
Santana told Cooper to wait where he was, but he finally left the scene to go to work.
In other interviews, Santana has said she feared for her life, which almost prevented her from revealing the recording.
Santana recalled the moments in which she recorded a video of approximately three minutes of North Charleston police officer Michael Slager shooting Walter Scott as Scott escaped on Saturday. That evidence led the officer to shoot and arrest on a murder charge.
Santana said that when she first appeared on the scene as she walked towards her work she saw Slager on top of Scott, who was on the floor. I could hear the sound of a Taser in use.
At no time did Santana see Scott go after the Taser. He thinks Scott was trying to escape.
Mr. Scott never tried to fight, Santana told CNN.
Police said Slager used a Taser against Scott, but Slager would also later tell a dispatcher that Scott had at some point taken the Taser.
After Slager shot Scott five times, the officer picked something up again.
Santana thinks it was the Taser but she said she wasn't 100% sure of what it was.
Neither the fight nor the use of a Taser were captured on video, because Santana had not yet started recording.
What we know about Officer Slager
The video of the cell phone, which Santana revealed this week, revived the national protests around the police treatment of African Americans and led to a murder charge against Slager, who is white. Scott was black.
Police said Slager arrested the 50-year-old Scott for a brake light that didn't work Saturday morning. Scott, according to a video from the camera, fled Slager for unexplained reasons, and the officer chased him on foot.
When Santana's video starts, Scott starts running away from the officer, with Scott back to Slager. The video shows Slager shooting Scott eight times before Scott falls.
Who was Walter Scott?
Scott's mother, Judy Scott, told Cooper this week that she would like to thank Santana for coming.
He was there. God planned it. “He is the ram in the bush... I really believe so,” Judy Scott said.
Santana agreed.
I think he was right, he said. God put me there for a reason.
Judy Scott said she couldn't watch the whole recording.
When I saw my son running and I saw the cop behind him, I couldn't stand it, he said. I had to turn around. I couldn't handle it.
In an interview with Matt Lauer of the NBC, Santana suggested that she was giving interviews to the media in part to protect herself from retaliation.
At some point I thought of remaining anonymous, and not showing my face, not talking about it. “But... if I didn’t show my face, everyone there knows, including the police, who I am,” Santana said.
Santana didn't say if she had received threats.
His lawyer, Todd Rutherford, said that Santana's video would be useful in an investigation, not only of the shooting, but also of whether Scott received prompt medical attention.
In the last half of the video, a second officer seems to examine Scott with his hands tied together.
Video of witnesses, official accounts raise questions
Santana said that after she stopped recording, she watched for a few more minutes, but never saw anyone perform CPR.
A police report says that a third officer, not shown in the video, reported seeing an officer administering first aid, and that the third officer approached and helped that person with first aid and CPR.
On Wednesday, he asked if the CPR took place in Scott, North Charleston police chief Eddie Driggers said: In the end - LRB- the video -RRB-, what I saw was -LRB- what I -RRB- believed was a police officer who took off the individual's shirt and performed some kind of life-saving procedure - LRB-RRB-, but I'm not sure what happened there.

text:
America is a country that has people from all over the world. Not only do many people speak different languages, many people practice different religions. Most people in the United States identify themselves as Christians, but only half of them regularly attend church. The second most popular religion is Judaism. The third most common religion in the United States is Islam. Other religions practiced in the United States include Hinduism and Buddhism. About 20 percent of all people in the U.S. They say they don't practice any religion. One of the founding principles of the United States is religious freedom, which means that people can practice whatever religion they want without being discriminated against. This is guaranteed even in the United States Constitution. This is one of the reasons why the United States has no official religion.

Because there are so many different religions in the United States, there are many different types of houses of worship. Christians attend churches. Jews and Hindus attend temples. Muslims attend mosques. Many people use what they use to reflect their religious beliefs. For example, some Islamic women wear a scarf called "hijab" to cover their heads. It is disrespectful to ask a Muslim woman to remove her hijab or to ask her to show him what is underneath it. Male followers of an Indian religion called "Sikhism" usually wear cotton turbans. Again, it's wrong to take off a person's turban or ask him to take it off. The male followers of Hasidism, a branch of Judaism, have long curls on their heads. They wear a prayer shawl with fringes. Other Jewish men may wear a small cap on their heads called yarmulke. This is supposed to be a constant reminder that God is above them.

In her neat and classic white shirt uniform, Carolina Herrera exudes the kind of elegance and easy grace that has defined her fashion label for over 30 years.
It is a look that has been sought by some of the world's leading ladies, from the Jackie Onassis style icon to actress Renee Zellweger and comedian Tina Fey, who came out with a Herrera dress at this year's Oscars.
Herrera's rise to the top of the fashion world began in 1981, when he launched his Carolina Herrera flagship brand in New York.
Today, its empire encompasses the firm's fashion collection, a nuptial collection, fragrances and accessories. Herrera has more than 280 stores in 104 countries and all this brings billions of dollars.
Herrera says she was more interested in horses than in fashion when she grew up in Caracas, Venezuela, where father here was governor. But he adds that he was lucky to always be surrounded by exquisitely dressed women. Today, women in her life include her four daughters, two of whom also work for the Carolina Herrera brand.
Here, Herrera talks exclusively to CNN about style, business, family and getting ahead in a man's world.
About the construction of a business...
- LRB- Fashion is -RRB- a very difficult business, as you know, because fashion is a business. If you don't sell, then you're not in business.
You may be the best designer and you are so creative and new, you have the most beautiful ideas, but if everyone stays in your room and doesn't go out to be used by someone, then you're not in business.
The hardest thing - LRB- part -RRB- of this business is to have the right equipment, because I - LRB- couldn't have done -RRB- everything I've done alone.
If I - LRB- didn't have -RRB- my teams behind me, I wouldn't be sitting here. Fashion is a collaboration with many people.
More by Leading Women: Women-only hotel apartments take off
On Herrera's team...
I have a team, a fantastic president who takes care of the company's numbers. If you ask me to take care of that side, I'd be sitting there crying because I don't know what to do. If I asked him to design clothes, I wouldn't know how to do it. But I always tell young designers to separate the creative side from the business side. You have to have someone very capable of running the side of the business. Because then, you succeed.
In style...
The style is so different in everyone. But one style is something you do that is totally different from the other or something you're using that's the same as the other person, but it looks different in you. It's a special touch. Some people have it and some people don't.
About juggling at work and family life...
Women managed to do a lot of things at the same time. Men, no. Men do one thing at a time. I see my husband say why are you doing all this at the same time? You're gonna do something wrong here.
I say, no. Because women, we're capable of doing that. Because we have children; we have to work sometimes; we have a house; we have a husband and everything works. It's a question of organization.
More of the top women: Women! Embrace your inner nerd
At the Carolina Herrera brand...
I think that women in Carolina Herrera... I like that they are sophisticated and I like that they are classic with a modern twist.
You can be dressed by Carolina Herrera New York, but you can have CH accessories and it's like a lifestyle.
Dressing up for your age and figure...
It's about finding the style for the right figure or the right age. Sometimes you see women who don't realize that age is changing your style, and they don't change.
What you wore when you were 15 doesn't look so good when you're 30 and it certainly looks terrible when you're older. So, you have to change with the times. It is the same with a more complete figure or a very thin one.
In the white blouse...
The white shirt is one of the easiest things to wear, because it can be worn with jeans or worn with a ball dress. I mean with a ball skirt. It's so easy.
It's like a safety blanket to me. When I don't know what to wear, I say a white blouse. You can take your own look.
More of the Top Women: Interactive: Power in the Boardroom: Women vs. Men
In the egos of fashion...
You have to deal with the egos of fashion. You know, there's a lot. It should not be treated so seriously because fashion is just making dresses to make women look beautiful. We're not inventing anything new.
Because of your inspiration...
Inspiration comes from things you've seen all your life. Sometimes you see collections that are inspired by the 20s and 30s and the 40s and 50s. That means that fashion is a repetition of ideas. It's the way you put it together that makes it modern...
In his management style...
I don't think I like going around screaming. I don't believe in this. I think you have to treat people who work with you like your family.
On advice to fashion women...
First of all, you have to love him. Secondly, you have to remember that it's not going to be easy. You're in a lot of trouble. You have to have perseverance. You have to do it even if it doesn't work and you have to move on. You have to be strong about it. They have to have the talent to do it, because without talent, how can you make fashion?

text:
Two years ago, Amy left her small hometown in England and moved to one of the largest cities in the United States, New York. Amy knew the transition would be difficult at first, but she was confident that she would love her new life and become a Broadway star. She had imagined herself getting off the plane and immediately making new friends with whom she would spend her nights exploring The city that never sleeps.

Unfortunately, the reality of Amy's situation was far from the perfect life she had imagined. His days were spent jumping from the theater to the theater looking for auditions. Although she was very pretty, and very good at acting, her accent made it difficult for her to be hired for any role. The directors kept telling him to work on his American accent, but the more he practiced it, the more he looked like a cowboy instead of a New Yorker.
Amy's nights were spent working in a restaurant to pay for her ridiculously expensive one-bedroom apartment where the washbasins always dripped and the hot water never worked. To top it off, the city I had imagined filled with bright lights and friendly faces as in the movies was composed mainly of stinky alleys, big rats and angry crowds who were always in a hurry to get somewhere. Still, Amy didn't let anything crush her spirit, and she was determined to keep working hard until her dreams came true.
Eventually one day, Amy was cleaning some tables at the restaurant while singing her favorite song as usual. "Excuse me," one man said in a nearby booth. "I couldn't help but notice that you have a beautiful voice." Amy blushed and thanked the man. "I'm actually casting for a star in my new Mary Poppins Broadway musical," he continued. "How would you feel about acting?" Amy's heart accelerated with emotion just as Frank Sinatra "New York, New York" began playing at the restaurant's rocola. I was finally gonna make it.

Food trucks used to be somewhere fast to get food for office workers in cities across the United States. Food used to be average, certainly nothing to brag about. Food trucks were a matter of convenience, and generally offered cheap meals. At lunchtime in cities across the United States, workers lined up to order a sandwich and canned soda. Food rarely costs more than five dollars. They took their food and ate as they walked. Some workers took their food to their offices and ate in the company's dining room or at their desks.

The food trucks have come a long way. They are no longer considered just fast food on wheels. Food trucks are now considered a gourmet gastronomic experience. There are food trucks that sell kitchens from all over the world. There are Korean barbecue food trucks and food trucks that sell lobster rolls. There are even food trucks that specialize in desserts. These dessert food trucks sell more than just ice cream cones. They sell cakes and cakes. There's even cupcake trucks.
Food trucks have become so popular that many use social media to reach customers and create a fan base. Some food trucks use Twitter to inform customers about their day menu. Other food trucks use Facebook to inform customers at which corner they will be parked.
These clean food trucks, with their gourmet food and great fan base, however, are no longer a bargain. You can rarely get a meal from a food truck for less than ten dollars. Some people think the price is worth the quality. Others only bring home sandwiches.

text:
It was a beautiful summer night and I decided to go swimming at Doolin Pier in Clare County, Ireland, where I moved in 2012. There was a woman in the water with Dusty, a dolphin who has a great relationship with a group of people with whom nothing regularly.
Dusty arrived in Doolin around 2008 and hundreds of people have been swimming with her since then, giving the impression that she is totally tamed. She has even starred in an advertising campaign on the Irish tourist board where a girl says she would like to touch a dolphin.
That night, this woman tickled Dusty's belly and looked so attractive. There were about 20 tourists and locals on the dock, watching this beautiful show. Just after I got into the water, Dusty left the woman she was with and got ballistic – I found out after she was very territorial when she was with someone. Her tail was flapping wildly and, at first, I thought it was an exhibition, but then I twisted: maybe she's angry. I knew I had to get out of the water so I was swimming towards the dock but, in microseconds, Dusty had ploughed me with his snout. It was very powerful and painful, and the speed was incredible. I went forward.
All these people on the dock were looking at me with their mouths open. Dusty was still in the water next to me, his tail flapping madly. That was more frightening than anything: I thought, if she hit me with the tail, I could go down; I was gone.
I was at the dock, but I couldn't get out because of my wounds. I felt pure terror. I screamed for help and a guy put his arm in my arm and pulled me out on the steps. Then another man appeared and said he was an orthopedic surgeon who specialized in marine trauma. He had been driving to Doolin when he saw what was going on at the dock. I was so cold and so worried – I didn't know how bad my wounds were and my biggest fear was internal bleeding. He looked at me and it was very reassuring, saying he couldn't feel any evidence of it, but he probably had broken bones. I later learned that I had six spinal fractures, three broken ribs, and one damaged lung.
I was in the hospital for five days, on a back brace for several weeks and out of work for five months with limited mobility, stiffness and pain. Then I was diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder. My near-death experience had left me anxious about everything and overreacted in a way I had never done before. I felt that people looked at me the wrong way, I started fighting loud noises and suffered from memory loss. Three months before the accident, I had opened a health food store, but I had to let it go because I couldn't work anymore. It was the hardest year ever, but now, everything's behind me. I had craniosacral therapy, osteopathy and massage, and I'm building my own osteopathy practice now. I have a new empathy with patients because I've been one.
I'm grateful that I'm healthy and I really want to keep other people from getting hurt. We have this lovely idea about dolphins and we have faith in them – who would think a dolphin could attack a person? If you see a ferocious animal coming at you with bare teeth, it's scary, but dolphins have this beautiful, broad smile.
I don't have any anger at Dusty. I respect her. But I was on her turf and she's a wild, unpredictable animal. People need to know that. Many come here to swim with her and don't understand how dangerous she can be. My injuries were reportedly several of the injuries that occurred that summer.
After the man pulled me out of the water, Dusty swam, but then she came back and was floating vertically beside me, looking at me. We closed our eyes and felt that there was complete remorse in her. She was a completely different dolphin; the anger was gone. The people on the dock were amazed. When he had that little moment with me, that was the end of terror. I made peace with her.

text:
On the market square in Rjukan is a statue of the city's founder, a notable Norwegian engineer and industrialist named Sam Eyde. The great man looks north through the square on an almost pure hillside of the mountain in front of him.
Behind it, to the south, rises the equally pure peak of 1,800 meters known as Gaustatoppen. Between the mountains, along the narrow Vestfjord valley, is the small, but once powerful, city that Eyde built in the early years of the last century, to house the workers for their factories.
Eyde took advantage of the power of the 100-meter Rjukanfossen waterfall to generate hydroelectric power in what was, at the time, the world's largest power plant.
But one thing I couldn't do was change the rise of the sun. Deep in its east-west valley, surrounded by high mountains, Rjukan and its 3,400 inhabitants are in the shade for the middle of the year. During the day, from late September to mid-March, the city, three hours northwest of Oslo, is not completely dark, but certainly not bright.
However, recently the statue of Eyde has looked out to a view that even he may have found surprising. At the top of the mountain, 450 meters above the city, three large mirrors with computer-controlled solar energy constantly follow the movement of the sun through the sky, reflecting its rays towards the square and bathing it with bright sunlight.
It's the sun! Ingrid Sparbo screams, disbeliefing, raising his face to the light and closing his eyes. A retired secretary, Sparbo, has lived her whole life in Rjukan and says that people “get used to the shadow. You end up without thinking about it, really. But this... this is so warm. Not just physically, but mentally. It’s getting mentally warm.”
Two young mothers take their children to the square and stand in the sun. On an icy day, a couple of elders sit on one of the new benches, smiling at the heat on their faces. The lightning of the children. A lot of people take pictures. A shop assistant, Silje Johansen, says it is “incredible. Just awesome.”
Pushing his son's buggy, electric engineer Eivind Toreid is more cautious. “It’s a funny thing,” he says. “It’s not real sunlight, but he likes it a lot. As a center of attention.”
Heidi Fieldheim says he heard everything on the radio. “But it’s much more than I expected,” he says. This will bring a lot of happiness.
On the other side of the road, in the Nye Tider café, the man responsible for this unexpected access to happiness sits. Martin Andersen is a 40-year-old artist who moved to Rjukan in the summer of 2001.
The first impression of a work of art Andersen called the Solspeil, or mirror of the sun, came to him as the month of September began to fade: “Every day, we would take our little boy for a walk in the buggy,” he says, “and, every day, I realized that we were having to go a little further down the valley to find the sun.” By September 28, the sun completely disappears from the market square in Rjukan. It does not reappear until 12 March.
Over the months that seemed endless, Andersen says: “We looked up and saw the blue sky above, and the high sun on the slopes of the mountains, but the only way to get there was to get out of the city. It’s sad, a people that people have to leave to feel the sun.”
Twelve years later he first dreamed of his Solspeil, a German company specializing in the so-called CSP – concentrated solar energy – by helicopter in the three 17-square-meter glass mirrors that are now above the market square in Rjukan. “It was taken,” he says, “a little more than we had imagined.”
It really works. There were objectors – and many of them – petitions and letter writing campaigns and an organized Facebook page against what a large number of locals initially considered a project of vanity and, above all, a waste of money. But even now they seem largely conquered.
“I was firmly against it,” admits Nils Eggerud. Like many others, he believed that the money could have been spent better elsewhere: on a couple of additional caregivers to take care of the elderly in Rjukan, perhaps, or on better school facilities, bicycle lanes, a little rural path that was resurfacing.
“And I still have my doubts about ongoing maintenance costs,” he says. What will they be, who will pay them? But... well, it feels good, standing here. And, in reality, you just have to look at people’s faces.”
In his office overlooking the square, the energetic young mayor of Rjukan, Steinar Bergsland, is interested not so much in the cost, but in the benefits that mirrors could bring to the city.
Already, says Bergsland, the number of visitors has increased during the time of the year and the shopkeepers of Rjukan have reported their shots following the example. A high-tech company is interested in moving to Rjukan, attracted by state-of-the-art technology at the top of the mountain and the advertising it has attracted.
“This is a powerful symbol for Rjukan,” says Bergsland, and, aided by various government grants and a donation from a local business, the city needed to find only 1 million crowns – 100,000 pounds – of the total cost of 5 million crowns of mirrors.
And, seen against the city’s annual budget of 650 million kroner, he says, 1 million kroner wasn’t really much to pay for something that “gives us a much, much better opportunity to raise the money we need for better schools and more nursing care. And look out the window. Look at those happy faces. Now it’s here, people love it.”

text:
Charles Lindbergh is an American hero, who took the nation, and the world by storm as a 25-year-old pilot in 1927. That was the year Lindbergh flew from New York to Paris across the Atlantic Ocean alone. Aviation technology was not very advanced during that period. The Lindbergh plane The Spirit of St.Louis was believed by many simply too small to make the solo flight across the great Atlantic. Bringing enough fuel for the flight was a challenge, and so was the journey itself. Because of the speed limitations of the aircraft at that time, it would take many hours to make the trip; it was generally accepted that a pilot could not do it alone. Lindbergh would not be deterred however.

Lindbergh was working as a mail pilot when he decided to make his flight across the Atlantic. Six well-known and trained airmen had lost their lives trying to make the flight before him, so his chances of success were not in his favor. On the morning of May 20, 1927, Lindbergh launched his small plane from Roosevelt Field in New York, and decided to arrive in Paris. The flight was an international event as Lindbergh's progress was reported by reporting stations during his flight. Lindbergh faced many dangers and challenges during his flight, including bad weather, and flying blind through the thick fog. He also had to fight his fatigue during the almost 54-hour flight.
It was all worth it when Lindbergh landed in Paris on Saturday, May 21, 1927 at night. More than 150,000 French citizens had gathered to join the celebration of their historic flight. Lindbergh had become an international superstar literally overnight. He returned home with an American public worshiper celebrating his fame with a parade through the streets of New York City.

Many young Americans dream of becoming a rock star at one time or another in their lives. American culture is largely defined by the music enjoyed by young people. During the 1960s, music in the United States was heavily influenced by the social problems of the time. Many call the decade a revolutionary period in the history of the country, and music was a big part of that revolution.

When David was young, he was in love with the Beatles. The English band was possibly the most striking group of the generation. He revolutionized music like no band or artist before them. Most young boys wanted to be Paul McCartney, or John Lennon - the band's two founders. Getting rich and famous in America is one of the attractions of living in America, and becoming a rock star is one way to achieve it. David knew this, so he met with three of his friends and convinced them to form a band together.
Many American Rock ‘N’ Roll bands began their journey in someone’s garage. A notable group to start this way was Van Halen. David and his friends were convinced that they could become the next Beatles with a little luck and a lot of practice.
The band practiced regularly over the years, and soon became good enough to perform in front of some young audience, but it never reached the big hour unfortunately. The road to success in the music industry is not easy to travel, but that does not deter some American dreamers. David's philosophy was "You never know what the future holds," and he is dedicated to the music industry to this day. A couple of their original band members are also in the industry enjoying marginal success, and they are still pursuing their dream.

text:
Good people, not to mention good tips, exist. Christina Summit knows for sure now after what happened on Saturday night.
The fingerprint tattoo on Summit's wrist often leads to conversations with strangers about her love for animals; she volunteers with a pit bull rescue group and spends a lot of time finding homes for animals of all kinds.
While taking care of a bar at the Holiday Inn in Clinton, New Jersey, Summit had to chat with a friendly couple before the night was taken care of. The man asked her if she had any dogs of her own; he trusted that her baby, a Great Dane-black Labrador mixture called Tucker, was in the veterinary hospital after having had emergency surgery hours before she swallowed a hard plastic ball. I was worried about him.
The man said something about the surgery being expensive. She trusted that the estimate was about $2,700, but she would do what she had to do for the dog, whom she adopted in 2011. Governments across Europe dream of finding a magic solution to rising unemployment. However, in the most affected parts of the EU, unemployment rates continue to rise and the rhetoric recently to shorten the unemployment queue.
Now, in a troubled corner of Italy, a mayor believes he has found a response to his city's chronic lack of work, although, instead of a solution, it seems to be more of an admission of defeat. Valter Piscedda, mayor of the centre-left of Elmas, a small town near the capital of Sardinia, Cagliari, wants to pay residents to leave. The council will pay ten local unemployed to take intensive English classes, board a cheap flight and seek employment elsewhere in Europe.
“This is, above all, an idea born of common sense and experience,” he told the Guardian. “During the last year and a half – especially in recent months – I have been receiving young people, almost every day, who are desperate for their job search. Some are looking here and asking for help to find him here. Others have tried everything and are so discouraged that they no longer want to stay and wait. And they want to go and acquire work experience abroad; life experience, too.
“So my reasoning was this: put everything in place that the board administration can put in place for those who want to gain experience abroad to be able to do so,” he said.
As the national economy continues to stagger, Sardinia, along with much of southern and central Italy, is struggling with high unemployment, with a general unemployment rate of 17.7% in the second quarter of 2014, according to the National Institute of Statistics of Italy, Istat. More than 54 per cent of persons under 25 are unemployed.
For the program Adesso Parto (now I'm leaving), the board of Elmas has allocated 12,000 euros per order of arrival to candidates between 18 and 50 years old. As long as they are unemployed and have lived in the city for three years, they are eligible. They do not have to pursue university studies and their annual income should not exceed 15,000 euros.
The idea of encouraging people to pick up sticks is delicate at a time when the floods of Italians – many of them brilliant young graduates – are leaving their country every year. But Piscedda, who belongs to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi’s Democratic Party, denies that he is facilitating a brain drain and believes that the people he is sending can “come back and give me back 100 times what they were given.” More importantly, he wants the plan to give an advantage to those most in need.
“It’s a program for those who don’t have another resource; it’s the last chance room. It’s about allowing them the dignity of not having to ask a friend for money or imposing burdens on families that can’t do it,” he said.
In early 2014, he added, the council launched a scheme whereby companies received financial incentives to hire young Elmas workers. “We announced 20 of these posts,” he said. “We have 120 applications.”
In Elmas, the scheme has provoked mixed reactions. “The reality is that there is little work here,” Alessandro Macis said. “The opportunity to go abroad to learn about the workplace and experience other cultures can be very valuable. The son of a friend of mine who didn't study much has finished in London and is really finding his way. He started as a waiter. Now, he’s a cook and he’s learning English.”
Others were perplexed. “I heard about it, but I thought it was strange. If you have that money to pay for people to leave, why don’t you use that money to keep them here?” said Consuelo Melis, who works behind the bar in a local cafeteria. On Twitter, one of the many reactions was disbelief. “The admission of the state of defeat,” said Marco Patavino. “The institutions are raising the white flag,” said Carlo Mazzaggio.
Piscedda, however, is not discouraged, commenting to his online critics: “Probably, they are people who are not in need... Every day, I deal with people’s problems and I have to do something to try to solve them. These people, if they had an alternative, wouldn't be asking for help.
“The work I can create, as mayor, is temporary. I can clean a piazza. I can clean it up again. I can clean the streets. But these are all temporary things that give nothing beyond that little bit of money for a few months. I want to go beyond that.”

Stockwell learned to walk with her new leg and be independent, but knew she wouldn't feel like herself until she returned to sports.

You basically fit amputated with artificial limbs, he says. I didn't know the field existed until I needed a leg, but then I thought, well, that's great.
After moving to Minnesota, he joined his first competitive swimming team. A presentation on the Paralympic inspired her to fight for her country on a new battlefield.
He dreamed of going to the Olympics when he was younger, he says. And now it was almost like I had a second chance. So I decided to try the swimming sport. It was easy for me to swim. I didn't have to wear a prosthetic leg.
In 2008, Stockwell became Iraq's first war veteran to be elected to the US paralympic team. I felt that his life had reached the whole circle: it made me feel so, so alive.

Whether you travel to the islands or to the mountains of Thailand, you are likely to spend at least one night in your capital on the way. Bangkok can be noisy and contaminated, but it is also an exciting city with many things to see and do. Why not make it a longer stay?
Where to stay
The Khao San Road was a famous traveller's spot even before Leonardo di Caprio's character in the film The Beach stayed there. But it's noisy, not very pretty and not very Thai. For something more authentic, Phra Kanong offers an alternative place to stay, with its fantastic street markets where every day the people of Bangkok eat, work and live. Not so convenient for major tourist sites, but it has a Skytrain station so you can be in the Grand Palace in 20 minutes.
How to move
Bangkok traffic can be a nightmare. Sure, you can easily take a taxi – if you want to spend hours stuck in traffic jams – but there are two much better ways to move around the city. To explore the temples and historic sites, take an express taxi or a long-tailed boat along the Chao Phraya River and canals. For the modern part of the city, Skytrain is a quick and cheap way to travel from the river to the shopping malls and nightlife of Sukhumvit, and the famous Chatuchak Street market.
Where to eat
The simple answer is: everywhere! Street Thai food is one of the best in the world, and for about $5 you can eat a full and delicious meal. Some food stalls have small plastic seats where you can sit and eat and cook the same dish over and over again, such as fried chicken in rice or Pad Thai noodles. Head to Chinatown – Yaowarat Street – and choose what seems most interesting among the excellent Chinese and Thai restaurants and food stalls.
What to do

Three hours to wash all the clothes, bathe, wash dishes and water animals to be done. See how he manages cash

Volunteers take turns three days a week driving a tanker truck or diesel fire truck from Orme 1961 to a water mouth near Bridgeport, Alabama, 2 1/2 miles down the road. Several round-trip trips carry around 25,000 gallons of water back to Orme every day.
Bridgeport, which receives its water from the Tennessee River, does not charge its neighbor. Stevenson and New Hope, Alabama, also help, occasionally carrying trucks full of water to the mouth of water, where it is transferred to the Orme trucks. Look where Orme has to go for water.
But things are getting better in Orme. A Bridgeport pipeline is almost finished, built with the help of a $378,000 grant from the federal government.
“With this new water entering, then we will have it made,” Cash said. Now we don't have to worry about that anymore.

Salem in the state of Massachusetts is called the "City of the Witch," but don't be afraid. There are no women in pointed black hats riding brooms. The city of New England is called the Witch City due to an infamous set of evidence that occurred there in 1692 to 1693. At that time, the city was just a town in the British colony of Massachusetts. The Salem witch's trials accused more than 200 people of being witches. People thought witchcraft was real and criminal. The defendants included women, men and even children. Nineteen people were sentenced to death. They were all hanged. One of the defendants was tortured with heavy stones placed on him until he was crushed below weight. Seven others died in prison.

There was never evidence that the defendants and convicts were witches. Historians think people would accuse people of family disputes. Other historians think there was a domino effect, with people becoming hysterical after an accusation. Fear of witches spreads like a disease.
The Salem Bruges Trials have become part of the city's history. "The Crucible", a play about Arthur Miller's trials, has become a film. The city is not ashamed of its past, but uses it to teach tolerance and earn some tourist dollars. There's a monument dedicated to the innocent people who died because of the witch hunt. There's a "Witch Museum" that tells the story of what happened. Many people visit Salem around Halloween. Salem police cars have witch logos. A local public school is known as the Witchcraft Heights Elementary School, and the sports teams at Salem High School are called the Witches. Movies and television shows featuring fiction witches have been filmed in Salem, including "Hocus Pocus" and "Bewitched".

text:
March 14th is my favorite day for being a nerd.
Throughout the country, the mathematical geeks of museums, schools, private groups and other places gather to celebrate the number pi, approximately 3.14. That's why March 14th -- 3-14 -- is Pi Day. Besides, Albert Einstein was born on this day.
A quick review: Pi is defined as the distance around a perfect circle, or the circumference, divided by the distance through it, or the diameter. He is also involved in calculating the area of a circle, the volume of a sphere, and many other mathematical formulas that he might need in the sciences.
Throughout history, people have been captivated by this number because there is no way to calculate it exactly by a simple split in their calculator. What is more, its digits continue infinitely, without any pattern in numbers. 3,1415926535897932... etc. Even that many digits are more than most people would need for their daily use, but some people have been inspired to memorize thousands of digits of pi, or even use digits to create poetry or music.
On Pi Day, a number smells like mystery'
Math can be terrifying, but pi is not, as the great fun of Pi Day shows. You could say... gasp! - It's great to like Pi these days. Even the House of Representatives supported the designation of 14 March as National Pi Day in 2009.
In countries where the day is written before the month, Friday is 14-3, which looks less like pi. And so Pi Day is an acquired taste, mathematician Jonathan Borwein, at Newcastle University in Australia, said in an email.
Conveniently, pi sounds like cake, and the cakes are round. You could celebrate Pi Day in a casual way by grabbing a slice of pastry or pizza. If you're enrolled in school, your math class or math department might be doing something special by now.
But if you live in a particularly pi-happy place, you might be able to take part in some larger-scale, pi-inspired activities.
Where Pi Day began
If you want to go where the day is said to have been invented, look no further than the San Francisco Exploratory. Larry Shaw, who worked in the electronics group at the museum, began the tradition in 1988. Last year was the 25th anniversary of Pi Day.
Pi Day began as a small meeting with most museum staff. Now it is a public extravagance with a procession of pi, whose assistants get a number -- 0 to 9 -- and line up in the order of pi digits: 3,14159265... you get the idea.
The parade ends at the shrine pi - a pi symbol with spiral digits around him embedded on the sidewalk, which was unveiled last year.
For those who cannot attend in person, the Exploratory has a Second Life Pi Day event that includes irrational exhibitions, fireworks, cheerleaders, music and dance. The museum also lists a lot of educational activities to teach about the concept of pi.
Pi's day, is it an attack on Piunder?
Where Einstein lived
On the opposite coast, the lush university city where Albert Einstein spent the last 22 years of his life is showing community exuberance for pi.
Princeton, New Jersey, kicks off the Pi Day weekend on Thursday night with a reading from physicist Charles Adler, then heads for a full day of activities on Friday, including a walking tour of Einstein's neighborhood and a pastry pizza contest.
The cake eating contest is held at McCaffrey's supermarket, while an Einstein competition will resemble mustaches and wild grey hair at Princeton Public Library.
Pi fans who have been spending the last year memorizing digits can show up and compete in the library, where the winner between 7 - at 13 years of age, can take home a fresh pi-hundred -LRB- That is, $314.15 -RRB-. The Princeton Historical Society is having an Einstein birthday party. Tetsuya Miyamoto, inventor of the KENKEN puzzle, will also speak in the library.
Here's 10,000 digits of pi for you to memorize.
The residents of the Brainiac city love this event because it is a way to celebrate how peculiar they are, said Mimi Omiecinski, owner of the Princeton Tour Company, which started Princeton Pi Day in 2009. A lot of them get super into this. Last year some 9,000 people participated, he said.
Along with his fascination with Albert Einstein, Omiecinski was inspired to launch a Pi Day throughout the city after he learned that Princeton University's mathematics department celebrates March 14 with eating cakes and pi-reciping -LRB- As a Princeton student, I got second place for most digits in 2005 and 2006 -RRB-.
Even more pi
Chicago is also getting into the pi business. Many restaurants and bakeries offer Pi Day specialities. The Illinois Scientific Council and Fleet Feet Sports are organizing a 3.14 mile ride/run Friday night, with discounts for anyone named Alberta or Albertina. Philly.com highlights two options to satisfy your cake cravings in the City of Fraternal Love.
Bostonians can go to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology at Pi time -LRB- 3:14 p.m. -RRB- for pi-themed activities such as Pie Throw to your best friend in high-speed camera.
The Boston Science Museum has Pi Day educational events, and the Seattle Children's Museum will also celebrate it.
Even the Salvador Dalí Museum in St.Petersburg, Florida, will celebrate the day, as Dalí loved irrational Pi and Phi numbers, often using them and other mathematical principles in his art, according to the museum. If you live in the area, check out their math-inspired movie program and tour all day.
There are also many resources online, as requested.org.
Outside the physical classroom, Pi Day will be held online through Google's virtual classroom project. David Blatner, author of the full book The Joy of Pi, is organizing a Pi Day contest in which students from three classrooms approach to see who can recite the most pi digits of memory.
How did Pi Day become such a big thing?
Blatner says Pi Day has become a success for the same reason that the new Cosmos TV show is getting so much attention.
People around the world are hungry to make science and mathematics fun and interesting, he said in an email. We know that mathematics and science are important, we know it's fascinating, but we often don't know how to make it fun and interesting. Pi Day gives us a great excuse to throw away our fear of math and say hey, it's a little clean!
If you agree, you just have to wait until 14/03/15 -- or as a popular Facebook group calls it, the only Pi day of our lives.
That's because pi to four digits after the decimal is 3,1415, and it's unlikely that we survive until 2115 to see that second instance of perfection pi.
So get ready next year to take a picture of your digital clock at 3/14/15 at 9:26:53 a.m. That'll be worth over a thousand digits.
Follow Elizabeth Landau on Twitter on @lizlandau

Over the decades, celebrities have chosen various ways to deal with an increasingly intrusive medium. Such methods have included suing - LRB- Jacqueline Kennedy -RRB-, hitting -LRB- Marlon Brando -RRB- and putting a bag over the head -LRB- Shia LaBeouf -RRB-.
But Alec Baldwin's coping mechanism opens a new chapter in the paparazzi wars. After the TMZ celebrity gossip site published images of Baldwin shouting blasphemy to an aggressive videographer -LRB- with audio cushioned that may or may not have contained a gay insult -RRB-, Baldwin published a bitter farewell to the essay of public life in New York magazine.
Before we permanently lose other celebrities to their secret hideouts, it's time to consider a way to fight the paparazzi. In fact, Baldwin was on the cusp of discovering a new â€$ weapon that he didn't notice.
After the first reading of Baldwin's diatribe, the solution - LRB- may have been lost after all, the piece is quite long and sometimes exhausting -RRB-. But the answer is to look us in the face. In fact, he's looking us all in the face. Every day.
“These days,” Baldwin said, “everybody has a camera in their pocket. Not only the Ron Galellas of the world, but all the audiences of John Q. looking for the opportunity to embarrass a celebrity. This kind of world is too much for Baldwin, who is prone to lose his temper.
But if the cameras are small, cheap and omnipresent, why not use them in their favor? Why not take one with you when you go in public, ensuring that the public can always see your side of the story? “They are harassing you,” Baldwin said in his farewell to the world. You can say they want to get into it with you. Some people bump into me or block the entrance to my apartment... exactly. Then why don't we get them on the spot?
Does that sound like too much trouble? Maybe. But if you're rich like Baldwin, why don't you hire someone to follow you and record your life as it happens? Go on with your daily life, but have a trusted and well-paid photographer at your side, documenting how rude, invasive and aggressive celebrity chasers can be.
Does it still sound unreasonable? There is another solution that has just been made available. You can record your daily interactions with a portable camera embedded in your glasses. If you want to show the world what really happened to that idiot photographer, just upload the images from your Google Glass. As USA Today reported earlier this month, police departments are using portable cameras to protect both the police and citizens from unfair accusations.
All this may sound extreme. Why do celebrities have to go so far to protect themselves? It may be a lot of trouble, but isn't it better than being repeatedly humiliated by outbursts out of context? Isn't it better than retiring from a job you love and living as a hermit for the rest of your life? Baldwin said in his diatribe, “You are out there in a world where if you make a mistake, it echoes in a digital cannon forever.” Right, but not if you can show your side of the story.
It may be too late for Baldwin, but not for other celebrities. Don't disappear from public life just for in spite of the paparazzi. If you do, celebrity gossip sites will win. It is time for a twenty-first century solution. It's time to fight photos with photos.
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of David R. Wheeler.

She is the daughter of a Beatle, everyone's fashion designer, from Madonna to the British Olympic team, winner of a Queen Elizabeth medal, and counts Kate Moss among her friends.
From all appearances, Stella McCartney's life has been a haunted life, not that she necessarily sees it that way.
The fame has followed Paul McCartney's second son and the wife of American photographer Linda from the moment she was born.
And it has been both a blessing and an obstacle.
As McCartney was awarded this year with the prestigious Lincoln Center Corporate Fund Women's Leadership Award, CNN spoke to mother of four about sustainability in a notoriously irresponsible fashion industry.
Influence of parents
CNN: You had models to follow very famous -- do you think that helped you, or do you think it was actually an obstacle?
McCartney: It certainly opened many doors and certainly closed some minds. So I think there was a balance.
CNN: What do you think was the biggest inspiration you got from your mother, Linda McCartney?
M: I learned a lot from your ethics. Both my mother and father - LSB - former Beatle, Paul McCartney -RSB - are known for being vegetarians, activists for world rights and environmentalists, and that definitely came to my place of work.
Once you have children, add another layer of responsibility to what you're doing. You have to be a role model for them, so it makes you question your actions -- in a good way.
The Biggest Challenge
CNN: What is the biggest challenge you've ever encountered to get to where you are now?
M: At first, when I wanted to go back to London and start my own fashion house, a very well thought-out executive in the industry told me: Name a designer who comes from Britain and has had any kind of global success.
I wanted to show him I was wrong. Obviously there have been great women in Britain in design, but there is actually less than I thought. So that was a small obstacle for me.
Since the first day I've never worked with leather or leather. I don't work with PVC, and I'm very aware of the supply and manufacturing of fashion. That's an obstacle, it's a challenge, but it's worth it.
CNN: Do you feel a lot of pressure from the industry because you chose to follow the path of sustainable fashion?
M: It's been difficult, it's still difficult, but I'm fine with the difficult, it's what keeps me on my feet. I've made people tell me: you'll never sell bags, you won't work with leather and leather is luxury.
To me it is quite the opposite, the leather is everywhere, it is so cheap a material, it is so mass produced. More than 50 million animals a year are killed only by fashion. It doesn't have a luxury element for me.
CNN: So you feel comfortable turning that idea into your head, that leather is luxury?
M: Many things have existed for a long time, that doesn't mean they have to stay forever. When you're in design it's your job to change, push, modernize.
The fashion industry, it's not really that responsible for any reason. We are not expected to respond to the fact that it is not sustainable to kill so many animals for shoes and bags. And you don't have to! Ninety percent of the people who come to my stores have no idea I don't work with leather.
Tell him not to.
CNN: You get really strong when you talk about people who tell you you can't do anything.
M: Not everyone, who likes to be told they can't do something? Anyone can do what they want, if they really want it.
I'm not going to pretend that I don't come from a privileged starting point. I'll always admit it was easier for me to interrogate people by telling me that I couldn't do something because I had a very nice place to fall back into. So maybe that gave me a little more spark and struggle.
I'm learning as I get older, you don't have to try to fight everything from a man's house. I guess I got here for a reason, it wasn't because I was a woman.

After they told him for the umpteenth time that the beer he wanted would be “too dark and too strong for you, love – have something sweeter,” Rebecka Singerer had had enough.
“No, I don’t want a fruit beer. Women can drink whatever they want,” she says.
Now Singerer, a nanny, has joined FemAle, a group of like-minded drinkers in Gothenburg, to launch the first Swedish beer made by women.
We can do it, a pale bottled beer, just came out for sale in stores all over Sweden. Its label is a capture of Rosie the Riveter, the creation of a World War II propaganda campaign that went on to become a symbol of women's power in the workplace.
The group's founder is 25-year-old Elin Carlsson, who paints cars at the Volvo factory outside the city. “We can do it It’s not a female beer, but a beer made by women that anyone can drink,” he says. “It has nothing to do with feminism; it’s about equality – we wanted to show that we can do it.”
FemAle faces decades of prejudice in the beer world. In an irony that is not lost in FemAle, Carlsberg and other big brewers have spent millions in recent years trying to sell beer to women, trying to “shrunk it and shrink it” to appeal to perceived female tastes. The offers of Carlsberg Eve and Copenhagen, Foster’s Radler and Coors’s Animée were among the lightest, aromatized and even “swelling resistant” beers that could not find a market.
FemAle's approach is different, with tastings only for women that allow potential customers to experiment with flavors and styles of beer that they usually can't taste. This educational process is the way to “introduce more girls into the beer world,” the group says. “Bring your mother, sister, girlfriend, aunt and grandmother so we can all learn more about beer.”
FemAle's idea arose after women continued to crash into beer festivals.
We Can Do It was the idea of Felicia Nordström, a bar worker who said she was sick of bearded beer snobs saying, “What do you know about beer, honey?” She approached FemAle and joined Ocean, an independent local micro-cervestry. One weekend they invented the recipe and the next they prepared 1,600 liters.
“This is not a beer for women, it’s our most juicy beer,” says Thomas Bingero, Ocean’s main brewer. “When large breweries target women, it usually fails. This is something completely different.”
The first batch of We Can Do was sold almost before it was made. FemAle has already been approached by other breweries asking if they can prepare new beers with them.
We can do it Use three malts – Maris Otter, Amber and a Thomas Fawcett wheat malt – and the Galaxy and Cascade hop varieties. Its IBU, or bitterness level, is 65 and its alcohol content is 4.6%.
“Women opt for a glass of wine because they don’t know what beer is about; they don’t know what to order,” says Carlsson. “We open new worlds for you.”
“I didn’t like the strong ones, but at the time I only drank Pripps [a light, Swedish beer],” says Singerer, 38. “Guinness tastes like water to me now. There are imperial stouts that are like drinking biscotti submerged in espresso coffee.
Women are part of a brewing explosion in Sweden, which is developing a passion for artisanal, bottled and current beers. The standard Stor Stark beer (big strong) is now “almost extinct” in Gothenburg, say women, as pubs and bars replace the big brands with a selection of specialized beers.
“All girls are different – there is no typical beer-loving woman. Anyone can do it,” says Emma Henriksson, 22, a member of the group working in a garden equipment company.
“Every pub wants to learn how to reach women,” Singerer adds. And Elin has found his way. It's amazing. We are very proud.”
