One of the favorite American parties is Christmas. The party has a special meaning for most Americans today. It is an official government holiday held on December 25. Most Americans get both Christmas Day and Christmas Eve from their jobs so they can spend time with their families. Many people are busy buying gifts for their loved ones in preparation for the big day. Christmas Day is the time when families open the gifts that have been given. Gifts are wrapped in beautiful paper, and usually include a colorful bow and a label with a person's name on it. These gifts are placed under a tree that is brought home and decorated with bright ornaments throughout the family.

When Michelle was a little girl, she loved helping her parents decorate the Christmas tree. It all began by going to a lot of Christmas trees, where sellers sold freshly cut trees to the public. Families can walk through the lots to pick up the tree that is suitable for them. Michelle loved to go buy a tree for the sweet aroma that came from the trees. "I like this one, Dad," Michelle said. "It's perfect," his father accepted and bought the tree. It was the right size, with full green branches.
Once the tree was brought home, Michelle helped her mother put the tree in the right place, and started decorating it. His brothers and sister would also help. This was always a great family tradition. They put a series of flashing lights around the tree, along with beautiful ornaments of different types. Each member of the family was able to place their own special ornament on the tree just where they wanted it. The colors blue, red, yellow and red flashed and went out and glowed brightly, reflecting on the ornaments. While the family stood up and saw the decorated tree, they all smiled. Michelle turned to her father and said, "Thank you, Dad."

Chicago is known as the Victoria City. Some people think this is because of the breeze that blows almost constantly. The city is located in the state of Illinois on the shore of one of the Great Lakes, Lake Michigan, which is the fifth largest freshwater body in the world. Chicago can also be called the windy city due to the wind tunnel effect created in the center by many tall buildings.

The skyscrapers are an important part of Chicago's history. The first skyscraper in the United States was built in the city in 1884. With only 10 stories, it was impressive for his time. The skycraper was finally demolished. Chicago is home to other famous scoops. It was the birthplace of the refrigerated train, mail order catalogues, car radio, TV remote control, the first wheel, the first steel railroad, the first planetarium in the Western Hemisphere. Chicago is also home to the first blood bank and first entry bank. It is also home to The Lincoln Park Zoo, the oldest public zoo in the United States.Perhaps the windy city should be called the city of firstfruits.
Chicago is the third most populous city in the United States, after New York and Los Angeles. A little over two and a half million people live in the city that has more than 100 neighborhoods. President Barack Obama lived in Chicago.
Almost 40 million people visit Chicago every year. Many of them visit the Willis Tower. Formally known as the Sears Tower, it is the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere. It takes only a minute to reach the 103 Skydeck floor thanks to some of the fastest lifts in the world. From Skydeck visitors can see four states: Indiana, Illinois, Michigan and Wisconsin.

Driving in the United States can be confused not only by all the rules and laws that drivers must follow, but also by driving habits. Many people in the U.S. They really depend on their cars to get to work and school. In fact, most American workers spend an hour driving to work every day. In order to drive in the U.S., you have to go to your local motor vehicle department first, and take a written test to get your apprenticeship permit. If you pass this test, you can practice driving so you can pass a road test and get your license. The Department of Motor Vehicles or DMV has free brochures that you can go and get to study for your apprenticeship permit. You can also access the information online and even take a practical written exam. To prepare for the road test, you can have a friend teach you how to drive or pay to take classes at a driving school. However, you cannot practice driving on your own. If you get caught driving with just an apprenticeship permit, you can get in trouble with the law.

Once you get your driver's license in a state, you can use it to drive all over the United States. Wherever you drive, you will see signs placed along the road indicating the speed limit. These numbers are not a suggestion. You can usually drive faster on a road than on local streets. Local police use special equipment to detect their speed. If they find you're speeding or driving above the speed limit, the police can stop you and give you a ticket. You will have to pay a fine, and some of the fines are over $100. In January I spent three weeks volunteering as an English teacher in my city. I've been thinking about becoming an English teacher for a while, so it was a good opportunity to see how it is. Students had just arrived to start a new life in the UK and had a range of levels from beginner to intermediate. They came from a variety of countries and had very different backgrounds and experiences.
For me, the most important thing was the relationship with the students. At first I was nervous and I didn't feel sure to talk in front of people. However, I found it easy to build good relationships with students as a class and as individuals and soon relaxed with them. It was a challenge to encourage lower-level students to speak English, but at least they understood much more at the end of the course.
At first, lesson planning took a long time and was not happy with the results. Classes seemed too difficult for some students and too easy for others, who quickly ended and got bored. I found it better to teach without a course book, adapting the materials I found online to suit your needs. I learned to take additional activities for students who finished early and that was much better.
I still have to keep improving my lesson planning. I would like to have more ideas to teach mixed skill groups and want to better plan the whole course next time. That way students have a focus on each lesson and a sense of progress and what they have covered. I will also make students safer with beginners when working in pairs so that conversational activities give everyone more opportunity to talk and students can help each other.
Overall, it was a very positive experience and I learned a lot. I've decided I'd like to be an English teacher in the future.

There was a march through Boyle Heights neighborhood in Los Angeles. The march was sponsored by a coalition of local organizations and agencies. The purpose of the march was to raise awareness of violence in the community. Many people have been killed because of gun violence and other crimes.

The march began at 9 a.m. in a crowded corner. Many parents brought their children to the march. The crowd began to walk along the sidewalks of the neighborhood. Occasionally the crowd stopped, and an organizer who used a megaphone told the story of a person who was killed. After the organizer told the story, there would be a prayer followed by a moment of silence. There were relatives of people who had been killed participating in the march. Some of these relatives left candles, balloons, or flowers in remembrance of the people who died. A woman who died was found at Hollenbeck Park Lake. The police suspect her boyfriend killed her. I had a little daughter. Her ex-husband participated in the march and asked the organizers to include her in their prayers.
The march continued for 20 blocks, and ended in Wabash Park. While the march was bleak, the atmosphere inside the park was more celebratory. Different organizations had booths with information about local programs. There was a craft table for the children to draw the kind of neighborhood they wanted to live in. Different bands played among speakers offering solutions to neighborhood problems.
The same day there was another march on a nearby housing project. In the spring, four houses were bombed. The police suspect that the attacks were racially motivated. The organizers planned to celebrate the march again next year. They really expected conditions in the neighborhood to improve so they wouldn't have to leave, though.

text:
Clay Cockrell is sitting in his office in Columbus Circle, opposite 1 Central Park West, which houses the Trump International Hotel and Tower. In front of the tower is Central Park, where Cockrell holds his popular walking sessions and conversation therapy.
Cockrell, a former Wall Street worker who has become a therapist, spends most of his days walking through Central Park or Battery Park in downtown Manhattan, near Wall Street, as a confidant and advisor to some of New York's richest people.
“I turned to her naturally,” he said, becoming an expert in wealth therapy. “Many of the extremely rich – 1% of 1% – feel that their problems are not really problems. But they are. Many therapists do not give enough weight to their problems.”
So what problems is 1% of the United States struggling with? “There’s guilt for being rich in the first place,” he said. “There is a feeling that they have to hide the fact that they are rich. And then there is the isolation: being in 1%, it turns out that it can be lonely.” It seems that F Scott Fitzgerald was right: the very rich “are different from you and me.”
Councillors argue that things have gotten worse since the financial crisis and the debate about income inequality that have driven movements like Occupy Wall Street and the $15 campaign to fight for a fair wage.
“The Occupy Wall Street movement was good and had some important things to say about income inequality, but it pointed to 1% and painted them globally as negative,” said Jamie Traeger-Muney, wealth psychologist and founder of the Legacy Group of Wealth. The media, he said, are partly guilty of making the rich “feel like they need to hide or feel ashamed.”
“Sometimes, I’m surprised by the things people say. You would never refer to another group of people in the way that it seems perfectly normal to refer to wealth holders.”
“It’s really isolating having a lot of money. People’s reactions to you can be terrifying,” said Barbara Nusbaum, an expert in money psychology. “We are all taught not to talk about money. It's not polite to talk about money. Ironically, it's harder to talk about having money than talking about not having money. It is much more socially acceptable to say 'I am broken. Things are hard. You can't say 'I have a lot of money'. You have to keep a big part of your private life.”
As a result, Cockrell points out, the rich tend to go out with other rich Americans, not for snobbery, but to be close to those who understand them and their problems.
The widening gap between rich and poor is a global phenomenon. According to Oxfam, the richest 1% has seen their share of world wealth increase from 44% in 2009 to 48% in 2014 and is on track to own more than 99% by 2016.
In the US, in the last three decades, wealth owned by the top 0.1% households increased from 7% to 22%, even when wealth from the poorest 90% of households declined.
The number of extremely rich people has also increased. According to an investigation by the Spectrem Group, in 2014, the number of U.S. households with assets of $1 million or more (excluding the value of their primary housing) increased by $500,000 to $10.1 million. In 2007, that number was 9.2 million. Households worth $5 million or more reached 1.3 million and 142,000 households are now worth $25 million or more.
Since the 2008 financial crisis, the income gap has expanded and the situation “has worsened for the rich,” Cockrell said. The main reason? Not knowing if your friends are friends of yours or your money.
“Someone else who is also a billionaire – they don’t want anything from you. Never be able to trust your friends with people from different media, I think that’s hard,” Cockrell said. “As the gap has widened, the rich have become increasingly isolated.”
These are real fears faced by the richest of the rich. In 2007, the Gates Foundation partnered with the Boston College Center for Wealth and Philanthropy to document what it felt like to be in 1% of the United States. Over the next four years, researchers surveyed 165 of the richest households in the United States: 120 of those households have at least $25 million in assets. The average net value of respondents was $78 million. The resulting study, The Joys and Dilemmas of Wealth, was 500 pages long and seemed to prove the old adage that money cannot buy happiness.
“Wealth can be a barrier to connecting with other people,” confessed a spouse of a technology entrepreneur who earned about $80 million. Some Americans have taken to keep their wealth secret. “We speak of it as stealthy wealth. There are many people who are hiding their wealth because they are concerned about the negative judgment,” said Traeger-Muney. If rich Americans talk about the unique challenges that come with their wealth, people often discard their experience.
"People say 'Oh, poor you.' There’s not much sympathy there,” he said. “Wealth remains one of our last taboos.”
Speaking in his soft, soothing voice that makes you want to spill all your worries, Cockrell said that a common mistake many of his rich customers make is to let their money define them.
“I don’t think it’s healthy to rule out your problems. If you are part of 1%, you still have problems and are legitimate for you. Even when you say, 'I don't have to fight for money,' there are other parts of your life. Money is not the only thing that defines you,” he said. Your problems are legitimate.

text:
Laura was confused. He came to the United States a year ago. I didn't understand the difference between Memorial Day and Veterans' Day. I knew that both parties had to do with remembering and honoring the people who had fought in wars for the United States. I also knew that both days were national holidays. On both days the banks, schools and post offices were closed; on both holidays, the shops offered special sales; on both holidays, people hung the American flag, and sometimes even there were fireworks. Laura had seen on television that on both days the President of the United States gave a speech and visited a cemetery placing a crown in the grave of a soldier. Laura decided to ask the postman Brian what the difference was. She thought he'd know since he had two days off from work.

The next day, when Brian was leaving Laura's mail, she asked him. Brian explained that Memorial Day is generally observed on the last Monday in May. This meant that it could be on a different date every year. The commemorative day is a day to remember and honor the soldiers who died, especially if they died in a battle. Brian also told Laura that Memorial Day was also considered the unofficial start of summer. Many public beaches would open on Memory Day. Veterans' Day is a day reserved to thank and honor all the people who served in the U.S. Army. Brian explained that Veterans Day is also to remember those who are still alive. Brian told Laura that Veterans Day's date never changes. It is always celebrated on November 11, which was the date when World War I ended in 1918.

A wedding shower is a party when a woman who is about to get married is "showed" with gifts and good wishes. A future bride will often register in one or more department stores and create a list of things she would like people to give her as gifts. This makes it easy for guests of both the wedding shower and the wedding itself to know what kind of things the bride wants. A record also ensures that there are no duplicate gifts. A bride may want a blender, but she certainly doesn't want to get three and has to deal with the hassle of returning extras. Most wedding shower gifts are items a newly married couple needs to start their life together. These gifts include dishes, pots, pans and even appliances such as toasters and microwave ovens. Many brides also expect to receive some money. Cash or cheques are considered appropriate gifts for a wedding shower. The money is useful to help pay for an expensive wedding. Sometimes people bring gifts of bad taste like lingerie to the nuptial showers. Some people think these gifts are good because they help the new couple "spit" their married life. Others find this kind of gift embarrassing.

While many nuptial showers are surprises, others are planned with the contribution of the future bride. A nuptial shower can be small and intimate and hold in someone's house. It can also be a bigger affair held in a restaurant or catering room. Appetizers and desserts are sometimes served or a full meal can be offered. Traditionally, nuptial showers were only women's affairs. However, more and more showers are not co-ed, with men and women. Traditionally men are not invited to the nuptial showers, but now more showers include men and groom-to-be. Like many parties in the United States, there would be no dancing in the bridal shower, just eating and people chatting. Some wedding showers even have games.

text:
The Taj Mahal
The Taj Mahal is a famous mausoleum located next to the Yamuna River in the Indian city of Agra. A mausoleum is a building where people bury the dead. The name Taj Mahal means "the crown of palaces".
1.
The most famous part of the Taj Mahal is the large white dome in the center. It is 35 meters high and is surrounded by four smaller domes. The rooms inside the building are decorated with beautiful arches and precious stones on the walls. The buildings are surrounded by gardens with trails, swimming pools, fountains and green gardens.
2.
The construction of the Taj Mahal began in 1632 and ended in 1653. It was built with materials from all over India and Asia, but the main material is white marble. Historians believe that the materials were transported by more than 1,000 elephants for construction.
3.
Emperor Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal as a burial place for his wife, Mumtaz Mahal. According to legend, I wanted to build another Taj Mahal in black across the river, but this never happened. During the Indian rebellion of 1857, many parts of the Taj Mahal were damaged by British soldiers, who took some of the precious stones from their walls. Over the years, the Taj Mahal has suffered environmental damage, and there have been many attempts by the government to preserve its beauty.
4.
The Taj Mahal is one of the most famous monuments in India. There are millions of visitors to the mausoleum every year. The Taj Mahal is almost always included in the lists of famous buildings to visit and is considered one of the New Seven Wonders of the World. It is also a World Heritage Site by UNESCO.
5.

During the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin, Germany, Chancellor Adolf Hitler promised to use the games to show Aryan superiority to the rest of the world. Hitler was convinced that the white Aryan man was part of the higher race, and promised that his games would prove this superiority on the Olympic scene. American athlete James "Jesse" Owens, had a different idea.

Owens was an excellent athlete at Ohio State University during the 1930s. During a track encounter in 1935, Owens set three world records, and tied another, in what has been called "the best 45 minutes in sports". Although Owens found great success in his athletic career, he grew up for a time in the United States where Black people were still highly discriminated against. The segregation laws were still in force in many parts of the country, and Owens felt this prejudice directly. He could not stay in the same hotel rooms as his white companions, nor was he allowed to eat in the same restaurants. Ironically, Owens was treated better during his time in the 36 Olympics in Germany.
During the games, Hitler got angry because Owens was winning so many gold medals. Owens was proving that Hitler's racist claims and rhetoric were false. Hitler didn't like it. Owens ended up winning four gold medals in these games. Hitler refused to shake his hand. One of the defining moments of the games is when Owens was a friend of German athlete Luz Long. Owens appreciated his friendship with Long, especially because he knew Long could fall out of favor with Hitler's brutal regime.
Many German fans shook Owen's hands, although Hitler did not, but when Owens returned to the United States, he found that he had not changed much there.

text:
One of the greatest tragedies in the world was the sinking of the Titanic luxury line. Although it was a British ship, many Americans were on board during the terrible night of April 15, 1912. The ship was on its inaugural journey that night when it hit an iceberg in the deep waters of the North Atlantic Ocean. The ship was en route to New York City from Southampton, UK when it arrived at the iceberg, killing more than 1,500 of the 2,224 passengers. The ship was the largest ship ever built until that date, and it was thought to be insumable.

Ship passengers ranged from some of the richest people in the world at the time, to thousands of immigrant workers who were trying to find work in the United States. The Titanic was equipped with technological security features such as remote-controlled watertight doors and watertight compartments, but did not carry enough lifeboats for all passengers. Due to the immense size of the ship, it was thought to be insumable, a fact that contributed to the small number of lifeboats carried on the ship. In addition, many of the lifeboats were not filled to their capacity when they were launched, causing further loss of life.
Most of the dead that night were men. The protocol followed by the ship's officers required "women and children first," when lifeboats were loaded. The accident was affected by international shock and pain. Many of today's maritime rules have been established because of this disaster. Only 705 passengers floating in lifeboats were saved that night. The ship broke in two parts before sinking. It's more than a mile deep in the North Atlantic. The sinking of Titanic has been documented in cinema and literature over the years.

text:
Apples don't grow in New York, so that's not why it's called the Big Apple. There are many legends about how the city that never sleeps got its name. One story says that a famous brothel owner named Eve gave the city his name. Another version of the story claims that the name has its roots in show business with artists calling New York the "Big Apple" as it was the best place to be noticed. There is a legend that the city received its name due to the large number of unemployed who sold apples on the streets of New York City during the Great Depression.

The most likely term has its roots in horse racing in the 1920s. The awards were called "apples" and a newspaper reporter when writing about the races used to call the big prize the big apple. In fact, the "big apple" was soon used to mean any big city. In the late 1920s until the 1940s, "The Big Apple" wasn't just a nickname for New York, it was also the name of a song, a dance, and a place to dance and sing. New York was the heart of the jazz musical scene in the 1930s and 1940s. In Harlem, Manhattan, there was a club called The Big Apple. There was also a short film of the same name from 1938 with black jazz musicians and dancers.
In the 1970s, the city's tourism agency began to use the term "Big Apple" on purpose. There's even a corner in Manhattan called Big Apple Corner. A New York City baseball team, the Mets of New York, have a big red apple coming out every time the Mets hit a home run in their Citifield stadium. Although the origins of the nickname "Big Apple" are unclear, it seems to be here to stay.
label: B1

text:
Molly Haskell will always have brotherly love for Ellen Hampton. After all, Hampton was once named John Cheves Haskell Jr. and used to be Haskell's brother.
Until 2005, Hampton lived as John -- or, as his family called him, Chevey. That year, she told her sister that she had been living with gender dysphoria, which the American Psychiatric Association defines as a marked inconsistency between experienced/expressed gender and assigned sex.
This was my 59-year-old brother, Haskell said of the revelation in a phone interview. It had been a little boy, and all my memories had been of a boy. It makes you go through your whole past.
Haskell details the experience with a critical but compassionate eye in his latest book, My Brother My Sister.
At the time of the announcement, Chevey was married to a woman, Eleanor, and a loving stepfather with his two children.
Hampton, now divorced, lives as a heterosexual woman after gender reassignment and facial reconstruction surgeries, hormone therapy, and a wardrobe review.
Haskell recently talked to CNN about his own family and emotional journey with his transgender brother. The interview has been edited for clarity and brevity.
CNN: Obviously you've reached an agreement with Ellen's decision. What took you for your part?
Haskell: First of all, I realized very soon that it is very overwhelming. I knew I could never say not to do this.My brother would never have hurt anyone, so he really told me how powerful feeling was. Seeing her go through it and evolve -- not only was she radiantly happy, but she was completely in front of her. Seeing how he handled it -- I'd talk about it if people wanted to -- he showed me that this was meant to be.
CNN: However, you write frankly about having unexpected anxiety about the news.
Haskell: I was afraid for her. I was shocked that this was happening. There was shock and apprehension. I had been in favor of more diversity, and the challenging binary roles for male and female behavior, but somehow I didn't include my brother changing sex.
The only thing is that we're born men or women, and we need those boundaries to rub against. I think one interesting thing a feminist told me is that I seem to embrace these binary principles in the book. I think there is such a thing as a man and a woman; we need these dichotomyes, like good and evil. We make these divisions to keep us standing in the world.
The sex we are born is not immutable, and that is very difficult to understand. You really can't call his decision a choice. It's too painful, too dangerous, it has to be an impulse that we don't even have a word for.
CNN: What was your part of Ellen's trip?
Haskell: I think many people who are transsexuals emphasize the strangeness of all this. For example, the director of The Matrix Larry Wachowski, now Lana Wachowski, has this wild red hair. My sister's not like that. This book is an attempt to unmask the whole subject. I think it's more puzzling for people when the person seems so normal, but I think we have to remember that they're not many people.
So many changes, but much doesn't change. You can take hormones to change this, operate to change that, but you can't change your voice, hair, love... there's a core of yourself that doesn't change.
CNN: How was it different to have a sister instead of a brother?
Haskell: It's wonderful. It's like I've been given two for the price of one. We have differences... it takes so long to get dressed! We're a lot closer than we've ever been. It is difficult to say that change has not made her happier.
At first I thought I was losing a brother. It was like a penalty, a death. But your happiness is crucial. It's more open, more gregarious. I think my mother would have been very, very upset but, in a funny way, Ellen is the kind of person my mother wanted me to be Chevey.
CNN: How was it different from 59 years old than it could have been before?
Haskell: I think the reason he didn't do it before is because there was no acceptance. Why is this happening so much now? Because he can. There's a word for it, and there's people doing it. This submerged desire finally had a means of being released.
CNN: Having Ellen in your life took some adjustments, even in small areas like the right language, right?
Haskell: The first time we went out in public, I was very aware of myself and nervous. We went to dinner at a fancy restaurant and the waiter asked us how we liked our food. I said mine's good, but yours is fabulous. She - LRB- Ellen -RRB - smiled and I smiled.
I often called her Chevey by mistake when it was just the two of us. And on the phone, the voice is a huge thing that's not improvizable. There's no good surgery. When she gets on the phone, I'd see her as Chevey, my brother.
Recently, however, I have stopped doing that. It's automatically Ellen.
Ellen initially didn't want you to write the book, but then she changed her mind. Why?
Haskell: She wanted to have this book when she was fighting with him. I wanted it to be your book as much as my book. I think of it as a society.

With the deployment of HealthCare.gov -- the portal for registration in Obamacare's new health-care exchanges -- being beaten by critics and users, CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta sat down with Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius for an exclusive interview.
Here are Gupta's conclusions from the interview:
1. Full speed ahead
I was surprised to learn how extensive the concerns were before the launch of October 1. Congressional researchers claim that just weeks before the planned start-up, more than two-thirds of the insurers had concerns that the system would be viable by October 1. A few days before the launch, the website crashed while testing with just a few hundred people entering, according to the Washington Post.
Despite all that, the White House decided to move forward. When I pressed Sebelius on this point, she said, “We advance because millions of people have been waiting for health insurance, and they don’t want to delay any longer.
Sebelius at the Obamacare launch event
She said it a few times: A few weeks didn't make that much difference since open enrollment lasts until the end of March, and millions more people could have health insurance by that time.
2. Didn't Obama know?
According to Sebelius, President Barack Obama was not aware of any significant problems until a couple of days after the website had been launched.
The Affordable Care Act is promoted as a signing achievement for the Obama administration, and I was surprised that the President was not being kept up to date -- according to Sebelius -- on concerns about deployment.
Sebelius: Obamacare troubleshooting website Blind President
3. Team Late to arrive
Sebelius said that for the website to run smoothly, she has asked contractors to bring her best and brightest, her A-Team. I was surprised that the A-Team had not been assembled before, given the magnitude of the ACA, and the challenge of establishing the website.
When I pressed the Secretary on this point, she simply said she wants new eyes and ears, and put all her hands on deck, working toward a solution as quickly as possible.
4. Open to dilatory fines?
Sebelius did not back down on the individual mandate, which requires people to have health insurance or pay a fine.
I asked how it was possible that people could face a fine, if they had tried to register and had not succeeded. At that point, it seems that she may have left the window open to a delay, saying only: I don't think that's really the question right now.
The problem is whether people will be able to enroll for affordable health care in the six-month open enrollment period? And I think the answer is absolutely yes.
It is not clear whether this question is raised again or not. For now, the Secretary said that the individual mandate is here to stay.
Administration to initiate the effort to promote registration
5. Falling on his sword?
Finally, I asked him about the calls for his resignation. In recent days, his friend, Senator Pat Roberts, as well as the Republican vice presidential candidate, Representative Paul Ryan, have raised the possibility.
Although not decisive, Sebelius again reinforced the mission of this task, saying it was the most important work he had ever had. He also reinforced that he served at the President's pleasure.
label: B1

text:
The original World Trade Center opened in New York in 1973. The most famous part of the building complex was the Twin Towers. They were named because there was almost exactly the same thing. The only difference is that one had a high antenna on top.

When they were built, the 1,368-foot tall buildings were the highest in the world. Such tall buildings needed a way for people to travel in them. The towers had 95 lifts in total. Visitors used to travel to the 107th and 110th floors, where there were observation decks from which you could see the whole city and New Jersey. Inside there were offices, shops, a hotel, and on the top floor of one of the towers there was a restaurant called "Windows on the World". The restaurant even organized a salsa night on Thursdays. A series of subway lines ran under the towers. The World Trade Center Complex, with a total of seven buildings, was so large that it had its own zip code. In 1974 a Frenchman walked a loose rope between the twin towers.
The World Trade Center survived a bombing in 1993. The horizon and spirit of New York City were changed after September 11, 2001. That morning, two planes crashed into the World Trade Center in central Manhattan. At first the upper floors of the buildings were on fire. Soon they collapsed, covering the lower part of Manhattan with hot metal and ash. A total of 2,753 people died. For weeks the air smelled of burnt metal and plastic. It took eight months for the site to be cleaned. Years later, the World Trade Center is rebuilding. There's a new tower, called the Tower of Freedom. There is also a monument and a museum to honor those who died in the 2001 attack.
label: B1

text:
The Beatles are a group of English musicians from Liverpool, England. He took America for the storm with his appearance on Ed Sullivan's first-hour television show. The group's first appearance was seen by more than 73 million viewers in February 1964, presenting the band to the American people. In the following months, the band became the largest rock band ‘N’ Roll in history in the United States.

The group's success opened the door for other British bands to go to America. Bands like The Rolling Stones, The Who, The Kinks and The Dave Clark Five soon played their music for the American public.
The Beatles were formed by four of the best musicians who played rock music. His lead singer was Paul McCartney, and drummer Ringo Starr. Both still play to this day. Two of the original members, singers and composers, John Lennon, and George Harrison, have died tragically, but their music lives in American culture to this day. The Beatles have sold more records in the United States than any other country in the world.
There was controversy in the United States before the first appearance of the group. American conservatives regarded the Beatles as an adventitious, brazen, new ideas, lyrics, and sound. The young generation of the time was ready for change, and the Beatles gave them what they wanted. The "Mop Tops" were nicknamed because of their long bowl-like haircuts that flew on the face of the convention in the 1960s. But nothing was going to stop the Beatles. His music is as popular today as it was 50 years ago. This February, the Grammy Awards aired a special broadcast to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the group's first appearance on the Ed Sullivan Show.
label: B1

text:
In Los Angeles, places associated with death are often popular. One of those popular places is the Department of Forensics. When someone dies and the cause of death is indeterminate or suspicious, the body is brought here for examination. It's the coroner's job to determine the time, cause and form of death. Sometimes the coroner will have to perform an autopsy, which is like an operation on a corpse to try to figure out how the person died. One of the reasons L.A.'s coroner's office is so popular is because of the number of famous people who have been examined there. Some of these people include Marilyn Monroe, Robert F. Kennedy, Michael Jackson and Whitney Houston.

The L.A. Coroner's office is so popular that there's even a gift shop where visitors can buy items like shirts, caps and cups with the coroner's logo. A T-shirt that people can buy even says, "Our work bodies speak for themselves." They even sell beach towels with body contours. The store is open five days a week. They also have a website and a paper catalog for those who are not close enough to visit. The coroner's office claims that the purpose of the store is to tell people how fragile life is and to create awareness and responsibility for one's actions. Some people feel that having a shop in the same place where the dead are is disrespectful.
There's been a series of TV shows about the LA coroner's office. Some of these are reality TV shows with what workers really do there. An example is called "Death Detectives." Other programs are fictional like "Quincy M.E." The coroner. means a forensic doctor, the person who performs the autopsies.
label: B1

text:
Boston is the capital of Massachusetts. It is the largest city in the state of New England and is rich in history. That's why more than 12 million people visit the city every year. It is a very ancient city, founded in 1630 by English settlers fleeing religious persecution. The American Revolution, when settlers, known as patriots, fought for their independence from the British, began in Boston with the battle of Lexington. Other key events of the revolution took place in the city. One was the Boston Massacre, when British troops shot at protesters, killing five. The Boston Tea Party, when settlers threw a whole shipment of British tea into the port to protest against taxes, was not a party at all. Paul Revere's "night trip," where he warned settlers of British troops approaching, also occurred in Boston. Many of these sites can be accessed by taking a walk through the "Trail of Freedom", a red line of bricks embedded on the ground across the city.
Boston is also a city of notable firstfruits. The first public school in the United States was founded in Boston in 1635. Boston Common, where British troops camped during the American Revolution and where the first settlers hung people, is the oldest public park in the United States. Boston is also home to the oldest subway system in the United States.
Like many cities in the United States, immigrants played an important role in their development. Irish immigrants who settled in Boston, for example, played an important role in local and national politics. Boston also has a large and active Puerto Rican community and an Italian community. President John F. Kennedy and his family have ties to Boston.
Boston is also well known for many schools and universities around it. Some of the most famous are Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Boston attracts more than 350,000 college students from all over the world.
label: B1

text:
Nobody's ever outdone Magic Johnson. Since he was young, Johnson has been known for his great attitude toward life. It just happens that Johnson is also one of the best basketball players who have played in the National Basketball Association. Johnson played his entire career for Los Angeles Lakers. The Lakers are the best franchise in the NBA in the last 40 years, having won more championships than any other team.

During the 1980s, the Lakers were known as "Showtime" due to the team's high-pace and high-scoring style of play. Much of this style can be attributed to the charismatic Johnson. His style developed at an early age when he played basketball in his home state of Michigan. He attended Michigan State University, and directed his team to the National Collegiate Association of Athletics (NCAA) degree in 1979.
He was taken by the Lakers as his first choice in the college draft, and he never left. Johnson played for the Lakers from 1980 to 1991, and then played for some games in 1996. During the 1980s, he took the Lakers to eight championship games, and won five. No other team had mastered the game in a single decade since the Boston Celtics in the 1960s. He also won an Olympic Gold Medal in basketball, and won the Most Valuable Player Awards several times, but his most lovable quality remained one of the most enjoyable and appreciated players in the game.
Today Johnson still calls L.A. his home. He's gone from basketball player to coach, to team owner and entrepreneur. He owns a successful movie franchise called Magic Johnson Theaters. Johnson was also part of the investment group that bought the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team in 2012. He is married and has two children and a daughter.
label: B1

text:
Parenting styles in the United States are often criticized. One type of parenting that is criticized is a father in a helicopter. These types of parents hang over their children like helicopters, which means that these parents are always on top of their children.

Although being a conscious and involved parent is not a bad thing, the helicopter's parents take him to the extreme. The actions of the parents of helicopters actually hurt the children by not teaching them to be responsible for their actions. For example, parents of a helicopter would call their adult college-age child to wake them up to go to class when part of the university is learning to be responsible and learn to manage their own time. The parents of the helicopters are also too concerned that their children will be injured. This means that the helicopter's parents retain their child's natural curiosity. Part of growing up means your child has to get hurt, physically and emotionally. This is how lessons are learned. Instead, the children of the parents of helicopters can grow up to be too needy and dependent adults. Some people blame the rise of helicopter rearing for the rise of cell phones. Mobile phones make it easy for parents to track their children all the time.
The opposite of the mother helicopter is the mother of free reach. The free-range mom follows a slow-rearing style, which means she lets her kids explore the world at their own pace with little direction. The free-range name comes from the idea that children should have the freedom to explore their world or rank in a way that makes sense to them. This often means that free-range moms will not schedule activities such as extra classes or play dates for their children. Instead, a free-range mother will let her child play in a park. There's less emphasis on things like the last toys.
label: B1

When a film is to be released, the theater will usually show the film during a midnight screening. Anthony Baker and his girlfriend Linda Moore love watching new movies at midnight. A lot of people usually show up early to line up. Anthony likes to line up and talk to different people in line. Anthony told Linda about the new movie he was dating. Linda got online to buy the tickets. He wanted to make sure they got tickets.

Linda got an email from the theater. He said he could pick up the tickets at the theater. Anthony took Linda to lunch before he went to the theater to wait in line. Anthony was excited because the movie they were going to see was the sequel to one of Anthony's favorite movies. When they arrived at the theater, Anthony and Linda went to the back of the line and started talking to the people behind. Everyone seemed friendly, and some of them really knew Anthony and Linda.
After an hour of waiting in line, the theater began to let people in. Anthony hugged Linda and started jumping up and down. Linda loved going to the theater with Anthony. He looked like a little boy when he was there. She always put a smile on Linda's face. When they came in, Anthony and Linda found their seats. They realized that everyone in the theater started singing a song that came out in the first movie, so Anthony got up and started clapping and singing. Linda looked at Anthony and thought, "It's a completely different experience to see a midnight screening.

text:
Not all children's birthday parties in the U.S. They think they're the same. Sometimes it seems that birthday parties try to show and entertain the children's parents, in addition to the children.

Most of the children's birthday parties are held at the birthday boy's house. It used to be that children's parties were only for children. The parents left their children and returned when the party was over to bring them home. It is now more common for the parents of the guests to stay for the party as well. This gives adults time and space to socialize while children play. Children and adults do not always have the same taste in food. So when adults are invited to stay for a child's birthday party, there is usually more elegant food for adults such as cheese, biscuits and fruit dishes. Meanwhile, children eat hot dogs and chips. While children drink punch, juice, or soda, parents may be drinking cocktails, beer, or wine.
Entertainment for an adult and mixed children party also goes beyond the usual clown or magician. Sometimes there will be a DJ, and adults will dance. Party games aren't just for kids either. While children play traditional games such as fixing the tail on the donkey, adults can play casino games such as blackjack or poker.
Not everyone likes this trend of adults and kids partying together. Some consider that the parties should be kept separate. Some people worry about adults getting drunk in front of children. Others are concerned that children are abused by adults they do not know. For others, it is about allowing a child to have a special day. It is also concerned that these mixed parties foster a sense of competition between parents in a community.

The store had many bargains for common items such as paper towels, but also for large screen TVs. Mark thought this was a good thing too. It seemed like a good idea to be able to get a variety of things in one place instead of going from one store to another. I'd save time and money. Superstores could sell groceries and clothes under one roof.
Another set of flyers contradicted the positive messages about the superstore however. Some local residents were organizing a superstore protest. Section 8 is also called the housing option voucher program. Very poor families, the elderly and persons with disabilities can earn up to $2,000 a month to help pay rent in single-family homes and apartments. However, qualifying families do not receive a completely free ride. To qualify, you must be able to pay about 30 percent of the rent yourself. The rest of the rent is paid directly by the government to a landlord. Not all owners accept Section 8. If you qualify for Section 8, it is your responsibility to find an owner who accepts the program.

Eligibility for the program depends on your annual income and how many people are in your family. To qualify you have to be a U.S. citizen. or a legal resident of the U.S. If you are undocumented or have a tourist visa, you cannot apply for this program. As with all public housing programs, you will need to fill out an application to see if you qualify. In the application you will have to say how much money you make, how much money you have in the bank, and how many people are in your family. You'll have to prove how much you earn. The government will ask to speak to your boss, see your bank statements and proof that you pay taxes.
If you qualify, you'll probably be put on a waiting list. Section 8, like other public housing programmes, has many people applying for them. You might be waiting many years before you really get a voucher, which is like a coupon that says how much rent the government is willing to pay for you. If an owner accepts you and your Section 8 bonus, you still have to sign a rental agreement, or rental agreement.

text:
Introduction
Did you know that, in the UK, there is no legal requirement for restaurants to convey advice to staff? It is a fact that is covered in a government-led review, published in May 2016, in which workers, employers and customers were asked their opinion about the tipping process. From behind, ministers said they were interested in changing the rules and making sure low-paid workers received the money left to them by grateful customers. The government has announced a two-month consultation on proposals that said they would end injustice.
Among the revelations of the review was the fact that some waiters charge up to 15% of the rate of administration on tips left by credit or debit cards. In some restaurants, the government has seen evidence that waiters are forced to hand over their own money, if they do not collect enough tips, to cover these fees. The government said it would consider prohibiting employers from charging workers an administrative fee or any other deduction.
The government also said it wanted customers to know that tips are voluntary, asking for the system to become more transparent, with restaurants clearly showing their tip policy.
We asked waiters all over the UK what they think of the tipping process (including how much they take home advice and whether it's fair) and what would be better for them.
1. Rodri, 37, London: "About 50% of a waiter's income is advice"
Average tips: £60 per eight-hour shift
I think they treat bartenders better in... America. Everything has become fairer since the tip scandal was exposed in the summer of 2015. This is when it was revealed that dozens of restaurants were exposed for skiing staff tips for management fees. However, there are still horror stories of new employees in some chains. I've heard of restaurants that don't pay their chefs a portion of the log (a payment arrangement used to distribute tips). Some restaurants will take 4% of all sales to pay chefs and as a management fee. So, if you sell £1,000 of food, the company will take £40. This is regardless of how much you earn in tips. This means that if a table has a £100 ticket and does not tip, the waiter has to pay £4 of his own money. This leads to a culture that hoards money and, ironically, to bad service. If a table doesn't tip, the waiter feels like they're being robbed by the company and ends up resenting customers.
I can average about £60 in tips per shift but, on a good night, this goes up to over £100 and, on a poor night, it's about £40. About 50% of a bartender's income is advice. All restaurants should have to publicly declare their exact tip procedure. The U.S. has it pretty good – everyone tips.
2. 22-year-old Elle, Edinburgh: 'We never know if it's fair'
Average tips: £20 per eight-hour shift
I think they treat waiters better in France.
I work three jobs, all on zero-hour part-time contracts, catering and hospitality. My main day job is in a cafeteria where the small number of employees work both in front of the house and in the kitchen so that all our tips are put in a pot and shared equally. My main job at night is at a restaurant where we don't receive our advice, but our wages are the minimum wage plus an extra £2.50 per hour (which apparently has been worked to account for average advice when shared with kitchen staff). My third job is catering events and no one tips.
In restaurants, because many customers add tips through card payments, staff never really see how much tips are being given, so we don't know if we're getting our fair share or not. The system seems better in France, where they don't give a lot of tips, but the waiting tables look like a proper job, offering job security and decent income.
3. Ashley, 22 years old, London: 'Tips are heading for customer breakups'
Average tips: £10-15 per eight-hour shift
I think they treat waiters better in Australia.
I work in a pub in southeastern London at night and do day shifts at a local restaurant. In both places, tips are collected and distributed at the end of the night. The money is also taken from the tip jar to cover breaks by staff or customers. If a team member leaves early, they will rarely see their advice because it is shared just before the pub closes.
It is incredibly unfair for our advice to be shared, especially when a team member is not well. Likewise, when a team member does incredibly well, they don't get what they've earned. It's really unfair that advice goes into breakups made by customers. Managers should have ways to pay for broken glasses and plates without docking our tips. I do about 20 pounds a turn, but they'll only give me 10 to 15 pounds of that money. When I'm well tipped, tips impact my finances enormously. Every once in a while, I'll earn more than 50 pounds in one night, which almost doubles my earnings for that day. However, I never receive more than 30 pounds of that money after it has been distributed. I really trust tips because they only pay me £7 an hour.
I would prefer to earn a good basic salary (as in Australia) and therefore did not have to rely on tips to make ends meet.
4. Tom, Manchester: 'A big tip night can help pay the rent'
Average tips: £40 per eight-hour shift
I think they treat waiters better in Italy.
Where he used to work, the floor staff kept 80 per cent of cash tips and 40 per cent of card tips. The other 20% cash went into a pot for the waiters of the commissars and the service bar. Sixty per cent entered a log system, which helped raise kitchen wages. I'm not really sure if this was to help pay the agreed salary or provide bonuses.
It's hard to say how much I won a turn; maybe around £40, £20 of card tips. You can make a massive change in your weekly finances. Sometimes people needed a big night to pay their rent.
They have tips right in Italy, where people don't add a service charge, but usually round their bill so, if they get a meal for €19, they leave a €20 note and don't ask for change. They respect staff and often see people making a career of waiting and experience shows.

Gas prices in the United States have dropped for four weeks in a row and now average more than 20 cents per gallon cheaper than a year ago, according to a new nationwide survey.
The average cost of a gallon in the continental United States of regular is $3.71, 3 cents less than two weeks earlier, said Trilby Lundberg, editor of the Lundberg survey. Prices have dropped almost 9 cents per gallon in the last four weeks and are 22 cents cheaper than at this point in 2012, Lundberg said.
The lowest Brent crude oil prices of reference in Europe are largely behind the most recent fall. More U.S. refining capacity returning online after seasonal maintenance also contributed, Lundberg said.
From there, in the short term, we can see more price reduction soon, perhaps in the order of this approximate decrease of 3 cents, he said. But the current picture suggests it's not big.
Gas prices broke a three-month upward spiral in early March, which had risen almost 54 cents since the end of December.
The Lundberg survey investigates about 2,500 filling stations in the 48 lower states every two weeks. The most expensive fuel in the last survey, conducted on Friday, was in Chicago, where pump prices averaged $4.10 per gallon; the cheapest could be found in Billings, Montana, at $3.33, Lundberg said.

Haggerty had ventured out to the 24-hour supermarket of Sainsbury in Harringay, north-east London with a friend hoping to pull out a large flat-screen TV. “But so many people pushed in the queue that we didn’t have a chance,” he said. “The poor woman who was second in line was pushed by a crowd of young people. She didn't get anything. People behaved like animals – it was horrible,” he said. I only saw two security guards.
Frustrated for not being able to buy a reduced Blaupunkt 40” TV from £299.99 to £149.99, Haggerty hurried to pick up a Dyson Animal Vac, from £319.99 to £159.99. “I don’t even know how much it costs; I don’t even know if I’m going to buy it. Back in line, Christine Ball, 62, was not impressed. “I arrived here at 10.15 p.m. and now I am further behind than when I arrived,” he said. “None of those many know what a tail is.”
Ball, who, like most buyers, hadn't heard of U.S.-inspired Black Friday sales so far, said he had come out especially to buy his grandson a TV for Christmas. “Not one of those massive ones; just one normal 100 pounds or so,” he said. In his basket there was a pint of semi-decremated and a loaf of bread. “Tela, milk and bread – the needs,” he said.
Mel Mehmet, 23, had been on Black Friday sales in 2013 and had waited for queues, but said the atmosphere in Tesco scared her this time. “It’s crazy, actually, to have it at midnight – the police must have more important things to do at night than being called to sales. Let’s go to PC World first thing - its sale starts at 8am.”

A law called No Child Left Behind Act requires high schools to get federal money for students to take a standardized exam each year. Secondary school classes are designed to prepare students for college. Some high schools offer specialized skills so that students can find work after graduation without going to college. text:
Every time you're online, you're bombarded by photos, articles, links and videos trying to tell your story. Unfortunately, not all these stories are true. Sometimes they want me to click on another story or ad on their own site, other times they want to annoy people for political reasons. Today it is so easy to share information. These stories circulate quickly, and the result is... false news.
There is a series of fake news: from crazy stories that people easily recognize to more subtle types of misinformation. Experts in online media studies and psychology have been examining the phenomenon of fake news. Read these tips, and don't kid yourself!
1. Check the source
Look at the website where the story comes from. Does that sound real to you? Is the text well written? Is there a variety of other stories or is it just a story? Fake news websites often use addresses that sound like real newspapers, but they don't have many real stories about other topics. If you are not sure, click the "About" page and look for a clear description of the organization.
2. Watch out for the fake photos.
Many fake news stories use images that are Photoshopped or taken from an unrelated site. Sometimes, if you look closely at an image, you can see if it has been changed. Or use a tool like Google Reverse Image search. It will show you if the same image has been used in other contexts.
3. Check that the story is elsewhere
See if the story you're reading is in other news sites you know and trust. If you find it on many other sites, it is probably not false (although there are some exceptions), as many big news organizations try to review their sources before publishing a story.
4. Find Other Signs
There are other techniques that use fake news. These include the use of ALL CAPS and lots of ads that appear when you click on a link. Also, think about how history makes you feel. If the news pisses you off, it's probably designed to piss you off.
If you know these things about online news, and you can apply them in your everyday life, then you have control over what to read, what to believe, and the most important thing to share. If you find news that you know is false, the most important advice is: don't share it!

Maybe there isn't a bigger cartoon character than the world-famous Mickey Mouse. Mickey Mouse is a creation of the late Walt Disney, who pioneered the era of theme parks in American popular culture. Today, Mickey is the official mascot of the Walt Disney Corporation. He is what is called an anthropomorphic character, which is a term used to describe a non-human character that has human characteristics. Mickey can talk, laugh, cry and use his hands as a human. He also walks on two legs instead of four. His red shorts, big yellow shoes, white gloves and large mouse ears make him one of the most recognizable cartoon characters in America and the world.

Mickey was created by Disney in 1928 in the short film Steamboat Willie. That film was the first of 130 films starring the famous mouse. She has also starred in 10 feature films. In the 1930s, Mickey began appearing in comics, and on November 18, 1978, he got his own star on Hollywood Walk of Fame. He became the first cartoon character to win a star on the historic sidewalk. Ten of his films have been nominated for the Academy Award for Best Short Film Animated with Lend a Paw winning the award. Walt Disney received an Honorary Award for creating the character in 1932.
One of the most popular children's shows in U.S. history was the Mickey Mouse Club, which ran from 1955 to 1996. Mickey has a girlfriend named Minnie Mouse, a dog named Pluto, and a number of friends including Donald, and Daisy Duck, who are stars on their own.
Today, Mickey Mouse merchandise can be found all over the world. It appears in all Disney theme parks around the world. The stereotype is that Americans are lazy, but studies show that people in the United States have less vacation time than people in other parts of the world. A typical American worker is given two or three weeks of full-year vacation. Most American workers cannot take those two or three consecutive weeks. They usually have to be extended throughout the year. Even when American workers are on vacation, they are often expected to be in communication with their boss. This means registering by email and mobile phone. Most American companies do not encourage their employees to take every vacation day they are entitled to. In fact, most American companies discourage him.

Other countries, especially countries in Europe, have much longer vacation time. In Germany many people have six weeks of paid vacation. At least three of these weeks can be taken consecutively. Perhaps this is why Europeans and other holiday travelers in exotic faraway places. Most American families tend to stay closer to home, rarely leaving the country.
The difference in the amount of vacation time is legal. Most companies in countries outside the U.S. you have to give your employees paid free time or else pay heavy fines. In the United States, however, there is no federal law requiring employers to give workers paid leave. In fact, the United States is the only developed country that does not guarantee workers annual free time. There have been efforts to pass laws that give American workers a week's vacation paid for by law, but so far those efforts have not been successful.
Even when American workers have free time, many are afraid to take it because they are concerned that they may be seen as unproductive workers and lose their jobs. Other workers worry about going on vacation and having a mountain of work when they return.

Queen's Day is a national holiday in the Netherlands, the Netherlands Antilles and Aruba. Tradition began in 1885 and celebrates the queen's birthday.

Angela Erdmann never met her grandfather. She died in 1946, six years before she was born. But, on Tuesday, April 8, 2014, he described the extraordinary moment when he received a message in a bottle, 101 years after he had pressed him into the Baltic Sea. Considered the oldest message in the world in a bottle, it was presented to Erdmann by the museum that now exhibits it in Germany.
“It was very surprising,” said Erdmann, 62, remembering how he found out about the bottle. “A man stood at my door and told me that he had a position of my grandfather. Then he told me that a message had been found in a bottle and that the name on the card was that of my grandfather.” His visitor was a genealogical researcher who had managed to locate her in Berlin after the letter was delivered to the International Maritime Museum in the northern port city of Hamburg.
The bottle of brown beer, which had been in the water for 101 years, was found in the capture of Konrad Fischer, a fisherman, who had been in the Baltic Sea opposite the northern city of Kiel. Holger von Neuhoff, curator for the ocean and science at the museum, said this bottled message was the oldest he had ever found. “There are documents that have been found without the bottle that are older and are in the museum,” he said. “But, with the bottle and the document, this is undoubtedly the oldest at the moment. He's in very good condition.
Researchers believe that Erdmann's grandfather, Richard Platz, threw the bottle into the sea as he walked with a group of appreciation of nature in 1913. I was 20 at the time.
Much of the postcard was indecipherable, although the address in Berlin at the front of the card was legible, as was the author's kind request that the search engine send the note to his home.
“It also included two stamps from that time that were also in the bottle, so the search engine would not incur a cost,” Erdmann said. “But he didn’t think it would take 101 years.”
She said she was moved by the arrival of the message, although she had not met her grandfather because he died, at the age of 54, six years before she was born.
“I knew very little about my grandfather, but I discovered that he was a writer who was very open-minded, believed in freedom and that everyone should respect each other,” he said. “He did a lot for the young people and later traveled with his wife and two daughters. It was wonderful because I could see where my roots came from.
Like his grandfather, Erdmann said, he also liked culture and traveled the world. She also described herself as open-minded. “What he taught his two daughters, my mother taught me and then I gave it to my sons,” she said. Despite his joy at receiving the bottled message, he said he hoped others would not repeat what his grandfather had done and throw bottles of messages into the sea. “Today, the sea is so full of bottles and garbage that it shouldn’t be thrown there anymore,” he said.
The message and bottle will be displayed at the Hamburg Maritime Museum until early May 2014, after which experts will try to decipher the rest of the text. It is unclear what will happen to the bottle, but Erdmann expects it to stay in the museum.
“We want to make some photos available to put with the bottle and give it a face, so visitors can see the young man who threw the bottle in the water,” he said.

Most children in the United States start school at the age of 5, when they go to kindergarten. This is the beginning of primary or primary school. Most children remain in primary schools until they are about 11 years old. Primary schools are divided by grade. Younger children start in kindergarten at age 5 and then go to first grade, second grade and so on. Most primary schools go up to the fifth or sixth grade.

The focus of a primary school is on basic academic and socialization skills. Most children learn to read, write, count, add, subtract, multiply, and divide. Students also learn the rules of grammar, spelling and vocabulary in English. Children also learn basic social studies or history, science, art and musical skills, and participate in gymnasium or physical education. In primary schools, children also learn to follow instructions, share and work in groups. Students usually stay in a classroom all day with a teacher who stays with them throughout the year. Students can leave the classroom to visit the school library, the school gymnasium and attend special science, art and music classes. Students also usually leave the classroom for lunch and recreation. For lunch the students sit at the tables, separated by grade, in a large cafeteria. Recreation usually lasts half an hour when children go out to play in a courtyard. The typical school day starts around 8:00 a.m. and ends around 3:00 p.m. Students go to school Monday through Friday and have the weekends off.
Primary school teachers are authorized by the state where they work. They have to graduate from college, or even graduate school by taking special classes in early childhood and primary education. These schools offer a second opportunity to international students who may have had difficulty attending university in their home countries. text:
Plato's Republic focuses on a simple question: is it always better to be just than unjust? The puzzles in Book One prepare for this question, and Glaucon and Adeimanto make it explicit at the beginning of Book Two. To answer the question, Socrates takes a long way, outlining an account of a good city on the basis that a good city would be just and that defining justice as a virtue of a city would help define justice as a virtue of a human being. Socrates is finally close to answering the question after he characterizes justice as a personal virtue at the end of Book Four, but is interrupted and challenged to defend some of the most controversial features of the good city he has outlined. In Books Five to Seven, he addresses this challenge, arguing (in effect) that the righteous city and human being just as he has outlined them are indeed good and are in principle possible. After this long digression, Socrates in Books Eight and Nine finally delivers three “proofs” that it is always better to be just than unjust. So, because Socrates not only wants to prove that it is always better to be just, but also to convince Glaucón and Adeimanto of this point, and because the evidence of Socrates opposes the teachings of the poets, he reinforces his case in Book Ten by accusing poets of representing the truth and by offering a new myth that is consonant with their proofs.
As this general view makes clear, the center of Plato's Republic is a contribution to ethics: a discussion of what is the justice of virtues and why a person should be just. However, because Socrates links his discussion of personal justice with an account of justice in the city and makes statements about how good and bad cities are arranged, the Republic also holds reflections on political issues. It is not that ethics and politics exhaust the concerns of the Republic. The account in Books Five to Seven of how a righteous city and a righteous person are in principle possible is an account of how knowledge can govern, including the discussion of what knowledge and its objects are. In addition, the accusation of poets implies a wide discussion of art. However, this article focuses on the ethics and politics of the Republic of Plato. For more information on what the Republic says about knowledge and its objects, see Plato: mid-term metaphysics and epistemology, and for more information on the discussion of poets, see Plato: rhetoric and poetry.
This article seeks to provide a constructive guide on the main ethical and political issues in the Republic. Two assumptions shape your organization. Firstly, it assumes that a relationship of ethics and politics in the Republic requires a preliminary understanding of the question that Socrates is facing and the strategy that Socrates uses to answer the question. Secondly, it assumes that politics in the Republic is based on moral psychology in the Republic, and therefore the former is discussed more usefully after the latter.
label: C2

Here are some answers about the Swat Valley, its history and what is happening there.
What is Swat Valley? Swat Valley is located in the province of Pakistan's northwest border, near the border with Afghanistan and about 185 miles - LRB- 300 kilometers -RRB - from the Pakistani capital of Islamabad.
The Alpine region was once one of Pakistan's main tourist destinations, with the nation's only ski resort until it was closed after Taliban militants invaded the area. It was also a draw for trout fishing lovers and those who wanted to visit the ancient Buddhist ruins in the area.
What's going on in Swat Valley? In recent years, Taliban militants unleashed a wave of violence that claimed hundreds of lives in the province. The militants wanted Sharia or Islamic law to be imposed in the region. They took over the valley in 2008.
The central government of Pakistan, which for a long time exercised little control in the area, launched an intense military offensive at the end of July to drive out militants. In retaliation, the Taliban carried out a series of deadly attacks and began to gain ground by establishing checkpoints in the area.
Has the government intervened? The militants and the Pakistani government reached a peace agreement earlier this year, which was recently signed by Pakistani President Asif Ali Zardari.
Under the agreement, sharia law was enforced in the region. While the peace agreement was criticized by the Pakistani government, some analysts and political observers say that the government had no choice but to capitulate, as militants have terrorized the region with beheadings, kidnappings and the destruction of schools.
What's going on now? This week, the Taliban took control of Buner's neighboring district, bringing it closer to Islamabad since the beginning of the Taliban insurgency.
What is sharia? Sharia is Islamic law. Although there are different interpretations, the strict interpretation of the Taliban prohibits women from being seen in public without their husbands and parents, requires veils for women and beards for men, and prohibits music and television.
The consequences are severe; during the Taliban's struggle to impose the sharia, anyone who was disobeying was caught on the ground and beaten. Others were beheaded and hung on posts, with warnings attached to their bodies that anyone who dared to remove the body before 48 hours passed would also be beheaded and hanged.

text:
They may not know who Steve Jobs was or even how to tie their own laces, but the average six-year-old understands more about digital technology than a 45-year-old, according to a new authorized report.
The advent of broadband in 2000 has created a generation of digital natives, says Ofcom (which verifies standards in the UK communications industries) in its annual study on British consumers. Born in the new millennium, these children have never known the dark ages of Internet dialing and the younger ones are learning to operate smartphones or tablets before they can speak.
“These young people are shaping communications,” said Jane Rumble, Media Research Director at Ofcom. “As a result of growing in the digital age, they are developing communication habits fundamentally different from older generations, even compared to what we call the first adopters, the 16-24 age group.”
Ofcom devised a "digital quotient", or DQ, test to put 800 children and 2,000 adults through their steps, which, instead of measuring intelligence, as an IQ test, would attempt to measure awareness and self-confidence around smartwatch tablets devices, super-fast Internet knowledge, 4G mobile phone networks and mobile applications.
Among children aged 6 to 7, who have grown up with YouTube, streaming Spotify music and online television, the average DQ score was 98, higher than for those aged 45 to 49, who scored an average of 96. Digital comprehension reaches its peak between 14 and 15 years of age, when the average is 113 DQ, and then gradually decreases throughout adulthood, before falling rapidly into old age.
People are now invited to test their digital knowledge with an abbreviated version of the questionnaire that will give any member of the public a DQ score, along with tips on how to improve their understanding and protect themselves and their families online.
The ways in which millennial children come into contact with each other and consume entertainment are so different from previous generations that predictors now consider their preferences a better indication of the future than those of young adults who set trends.
The most notable change is in the time spent talking on the phone. Two decades ago, teenagers devoted their nights to monopolizing the home phone line, dissecting loving affairs and friendships in conversations that lasted hours.
For people aged 12 to 15, phone calls represent only 3% of the time spent communicating through any device. For all adults, this figure is 20% and, for young adults, it remains three times higher, at 9%. Today's children do most of their remote socialization by sending written messages or through photographs and shared videos. “The millennium generation is losing its voice,” says Ofcom.
More than 90% of your device's time is based on messages, chatting on social networks like Facebook, sending instant messages through services like WhatsApp or even shooting traditional text messages from mobile phones. Only 2 per cent of children ' s time is passed by e-mail, compared to 33 per cent for adults.
Far from their phones, children aged 12 to 15 also have a very different relationship with other media. A seven-day digital diary shows that live television accounts for only half of the audience for this age group, compared to almost 70% for all adults. They spend 20% of their time watching short video clips, for example on YouTube, or news clips distributed through Facebook and other social sites. The rest of its display is shared among DVDs, content transmitted via Netflix or iTunes and TV shows recorded.
Young people between the ages of 16 and 24 are voracious consumers of almost all media. However, live radio and print media have virtually disappeared from their daily diet.
Young people are moving away from live television and into broadcast and catch-up services. Even among adults, television is becoming less important. Television among 16 to 24 year olds has been submerging every year since 2010, but 2013 was the first year in which researchers found that vision fell in all age groups. The theory is that tablets – one of the most popular Christmas gifts in 2012 and 2013 – have brought many older people online for longer. With large screens and simple touch-based interfaces, tablets are being credited with a leap in Internet access among those over 65.
“For years, those over 65 have had a very stubborn resistance to accessing the Internet,” said James Thickett, Director of Research at Ofcom. “In the last three years, we’ve seen that change and we think it’s reduced to tablets.”
Britain is adopting Internet-enabled devices across generations, as the balance between sleep and screen-based activities has now tilted. The typical adult spends eight hours and 41 minutes a day communicating or consuming media, including old-fashioned books and newspapers, and only eight hours and 21 minutes asleep.
