China's top foreign policy official met North Korean leader Kim Jong Il on Thursday and the two sides reached consensus on reducing tensions on the Korean peninsula, officials said.
The meeting marks the first between Kim and a senior official from China since the outbreak between the two Koreas.
The two sides reached consensus on bilateral relations and the situation on the Korean peninsula following frank and in-depth talks, said Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Jiang Yu.
She did not explain in detail what Kim discussed with Officer Dai Bingguo during his visit to Pyongyang.
Tensions on the Korean peninsula intensified following North Korea ' s bombing of South Korea ' s Yeonpyeong Island last month, as well as the sinking in March of a South Korean warship -- supposedly by a North Korean torpedo -- and recent revelations that it is enriching uranium for nuclear weapons.
North Korean officials have been pushing for the resumption of talks between the six parties, including China and Russia.
China has also called for emergency talks between the six countries -- North Korea, South Korea, China, the United States, Japan and Russia -- to address tensions on the Korean peninsula.
But the United States has refused so far, seeking first of all evidence that North Korea is serious about not fuelling military tensions and serious about stifling the development of its nuclear program.
For the second day in a row, the head of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff called on China to use its influence to control North Korea to avert a total crisis. China is North Korea's strongest ally and the largest trading partner.
In fact, I believe that, because these provocations continue and apparently in a frequent interval, the danger is increasing and that measures must be taken to ensure that they stop, he said at a press conference in Tokyo.
Much of this volatility is due to the unwise behavior of the North Korean regime, allowed by its friends in China.
CNN's Jo Kent contributed to this report

text:
After receiving nearly 100 reports of gas pedals stuck in Ford and Mazda vehicles, federal regulators said Tuesday that they have initiated an investigation into the problem, which is an alleged cause of death and nine injuries.
Stuck accelerators are being investigated for their potential role in a fatal accident, 13 non-fatal accidents or fires, and eight injury accidents, according to the National Road Safety Administration.
Ford and Mazda said 591,245 vehicles were potentially affected, according to car manufacturers' reports to NHTSA in 2004. More than half of the vehicles were 2001-2004 Ford Escapes model year. The remaining vehicles were the Mazda Homenajes 2001-2004.
NHTSA has identified 730,000 potentially affected vehicles, extending the scope of the vehicles concerned. All 730,000 are 2001-2004 Ford Escape and Mazda Tribute SUVs with V6 engines, according to NHTSA.
Mazda and Ford issued souvenirs in 2004 on models of sports utility vehicles that had 3.0-liter six-cylinder engines. Several of the NHTSA reports involve vehicles not covered by previous reminders, the agency said in a letter to Ford's Global Director of Environmental Compliance and Safety on Thursday.
One complaint is based on a fatal accident in January 2012, said NHTSA. Some of the allegations claim that the judgements may have been related to reparations made in response to the security reminders initiated in 2004, according to the summary of the investigation.
The 2004 Ford and Mazda remembers were for vehicle speed control cables in their affected vehicles. Letters were also sent to distributors and customers, according to presentations on the NHTSA website.
In your vehicle, the accelerator cable may prevent the accelerator from returning to the idle position, which can result in high engine speeds while driving, Ford's letter to customers reads. An unexpected increase in engine idle speed can increase the stopping distance and cause a vehicle crash without notice.
The Center for Automatic Security requested NHTSA to open a similar investigation on 8 July. The petition was denied on Thursday because part of the application is being covered by the agency's newly opened investigation.
NHTSA has opened the investigation to assess the scope, frequency and consequences related to the safety of the alleged defect, the agency said.
Neither Ford nor Mazda responded to CNN's requests for comment.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge won the first round in their battle for privacy on Tuesday, when a French magazine was banned from selling or reusing images taken from the couple in a private castle in Provence.
But the war is far from over, as French prosecutors must now decide whether criminal proceedings will be initiated against the magazine's editor and the photographer or photographers responsible for taking photos of the Duchess sunbathing in topless while on vacation in southern France.
The Tribunal de Grande Instance in Nanterre, Paris, issued a court order ordering the gossip magazine Closer to deliver the digital archives of the images within 24 hours and to prevent their further dissemination, including on its website and tablet application.
The four-page ruling, which only concerns Mondadori Magazines France, publisher of Closer, also ordered him to pay 2,000 euros in legal costs. The magazine faces a fine of €10,000 for each day that does not comply with the order. The couple did not seek compensation.
“These snapshots, showing the intimacy of a couple, partially naked on the terrace of a private house, surrounded by a park several hundred meters from a public road, and being able to legitimately assume that they are protected from passersby, are by nature particularly intrusive,” he said.
The judges ruled that every photograph published in France by Mondadori, the publisher owned by former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, would in future carry a fine, also of 10,000 euros for non-compliance.
But the failure refers only to the 14 images that have already been published. Closer's editor has hinted that he has other more intimate images.
The Palacio de Santiago said the couple “welcome the judge’s ruling.” One source said, “They always believed that the law was broken and that they had a right to their privacy.” Maud Sobel, a lawyer for the royal couple in Paris, described it as “a wonderful decision,” adding: “We have been vindicated.”
Although his civil action has been successful, the couple has taken the rare step of seeking a much more public criminal trial for violation of privacy against the magazine and photographer or photographers responsible.
The prosecutor will have to decide the objectives of any criminal procedure and the complaint cites "unknown persons". But it is understood that the couple want a trial against the publisher of Closer, who published the photos on Friday, and who took the images of the couple sunbathing in the castle, which belongs to Lord Linley, son of late Princess Margaret.
The Paris police opened a preliminary investigation on Tuesday. Under French law, violation of privacy carries a maximum penalty of one year ' s imprisonment and a fine of 45,000 euros.
This is the legal action that will really put a marker, and in pursuing it the couple indicates a determination to convey a broader message to the world and, they hope, deter the paparazzi in the future.
His lawyers had not requested that copies of Closer magazine be removed from the shelves.
On Saturday the Irish Daily Star published the photos, which led the editor to be suspended on Monday night pending the outcome of an internal investigation. Also on Monday, the famous Italian magazine Mondadori Chi launched a special edition with 26 pages dedicated to the frank photos of the future queen.
The couple’s lawyer, Aurélien Hamelle, had told the Paris court that it was necessary to block the “highly intimate” images of the Duchess without her bikini, as she was a “young woman, not an object”.
But Delphine Pando, defending Closer, said the action was a “disproportionate response” to the publication of the photographs. He added that the magazine could not control its resale, as it did not possess the original images.
Copies of Closer magazine were doing fast business on the eBay online auction site, with a sale of £31.01, until the site removed all listings after “strong feedback” from their community.

The New York City Board of Health voted Thursday to ban the sale of sugary drinks in containers of more than 16 ounces in restaurants and elsewhere, in a movement aimed at combating obesity and encouraging residents to live healthier lifestyles.
The council voted eight in favour, with one abstention.
It's time to face the facts: obesity is one of America's most deadly problems, and sugary drinks are one of the main causes of it, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg said in a statement earlier this month. As sugary drinks have grown in size, so have our waists -- and also diabetes and heart disease.
Bloomberg Visionary Movement Against Obesity
But the bill is expected to generate more protests from the soft drinks industry and those concerned about government participation in their personal choices.
What we need in New York are sensible solutions to the obesity problem that focus on a holistic approach to addressing an extremely complex problem, said Eliot Hoff, spokesperson for a group sponsored by the beverage industry called New Yorkers for Beverage Choices. New Yorkers are smart enough to decide for themselves what to eat and drink.
Critics, including McDonald's and Coca-Cola, have attacked the ban as wrong and arbitrary, although Bloomberg has billed it as both a health and fiscal initiative.
New York City spends approximately $4 billion each year on medical care for overweight people, the mayor said in an earlier statement.
Big Gulp? Meet your older brother.
One in eight New Yorkers also suffers from diabetes, a disease often related to obesity, his office said, calling sugary drinks the biggest driver of these alarming increases in obesity.
About 58% of adults in New York City are considered obese or overweight, the mayor added.
In 2007, the health board appointed by Bloomberg adopted a regulation that forced restaurants to eliminate the use of partially hydrogenated vegetable oils and spread, the main sources of trans fats in the American diet.
Thursday's decision is expected to come into effect in six months and be implemented by the city's regular restaurant inspection team, allowing restaurant owners to adjust to changes before facing fines.
Six months from today, our city will be an even healthier place, tweeted Bloomberg on Thursday.
The ban would not apply to grocery stores.
Forget about the big sodas, how about banning the fries?

text:
The current feminist political philosophy is indebted to the work of previous generations of feminist scholarship and activism, including the first wave of feminism in the English-speaking world, which took place from the 1840s to the 1920s and focused on improving the political, educational and economic system mainly for middle-class women. Its greatest achievements are the development of a language of equal rights for women and the acquisition of women ' s voting rights. It is also indebted to the second wave of feminism, which, beginning in the 1960s, was based on the language of civil rights movements (for example, liberation language) and a new feminist consciousness that emerged through women's solidarity movements and new forms of reflection that discovered sexist attitudes and impediments throughout society. In 1970, feminism had moved from activism to scholarship with the publication of The Sexual Dialectics of Shulamith Firestone (Firestone 1971); Kate Millett's Sexual Policy (Millett 1970); and Robin Morgan's Brotherhood is Powerful (Morgan 1970).
One of the first theoretical advances of second wave feminism was to separate the biological conceptions of the identity of women from those socially constructed to refute the notion that biology was destiny and, therefore, the main role of women was as mothers and caregivers. Based on social sciences and psychoanalytic theory, anthropologist Gayle Rubin developed an account of a “gender/sex system” (Rubin 1975; Diet 2003, 401; and the entry on feminist perspectives on sex and gender). The gender/gender distinction pointed to “a set of provisions whereby the biological raw material of human sex and procreation are shaped through human and social intervention” (Rubin 1975, 165). Although biological sex was fixed, in Rubin's opinion, gender was a social construct that served to divide the sexes and privilege men. Because gender was mutable, the sex/gender distinction gave feminists a powerful tool to look for ways to address women's oppression.
With this socially constructed notion of gender, early second wave theorists sought an understanding of women as a universal subject and agent of feminist politics. An important set of flaws in feminist thinking since the 1990s is about the questions on the subject of “women.” According to Mary Dietz's 2003 article exposing the camp, there are two large groups here. One defends the category of woman (in the singular and universal), arguing that the specificity of the identity of the woman, her sexual difference with men, must be appreciated and revalued. (The other, discussed below, deals with the diversity of women.) This "differential feminism" includes two distinct groups: (i) those who look at how the gender sexual difference is socially constituted and (ii) those who look at how the sexual difference is symbolically and psychoanalytically constructed. The first, the feminism of social differences, includes theories that value motherhood and care and has developed largely in the Anglo-American context. (See, for example, Tronto 1993 and Held 1995.) The second, the feminism of symbolic difference, is that of what is often known as French feminists, including Irigaray, Cixous, and Kristeva. They belong to this group insofar as they value and distinguish the specific sexual difference of women from men. Irigaray's focus on sexual difference is emblematic of this. Social-differential and symbolic-differential feminisms have very little to do with each other, but, Dietz argues, they share the notion that a feminist policy requires a woman of category who has a certain meaning (Dietz 2003, 403; Nicholson 1994, 100).
Just as Marxist theory sought a universal theme in the person of the worker, feminist theorists sought it in a shared and common condition that afflicted women of all cultures. But this notion of universal femininity was interrupted by other thinkers, such as bell hooks, saying it excluded the experience and concerns of non-white and middle-class women. The 1981 book of Hooks titled "Am I Not a Woman?" exposed dominant feminism as a movement of a small group of white middle- and upper-class women whose experience was very particular, barely universal. The work of hooks and later Cherrie Moraga, Gloria Anzaldúa, Maria Lugones, Elizabeth Spelman, and others in the foreground the need to account for the multiple and complex identities and experiences of women. In the 1990s debates on whether there was a coherent concept of women who could sustain feminist politics were further challenged by non-Western women by challenging the Western women's movement as trapped in Eurocentric ideals that led to the colonization and domination of the people of the Third World. What is now known as postcolonial theory further accentuated the debate among feminists who wanted to identify a universal feminist issue of women (e.g. Okin, Nussbaum and Ackerly) and those who call for recognition of multiplicity, diversity and intersectionality (e.g. Spivak, Narayan, Mahmood and Jaggar).
The effects of this movement of diversity would be felt more in the 1990s and beyond. Meanwhile, in the 1970s and 1980s feminist theory began to develop in the various areas of social sciences and humanities, and in philosophy began to emerge in what were already different traditions and areas of research. As a branch of political philosophy, feminist political philosophy has often reflected the various divisions in work in political philosophy in general. Before the fall of the Berlin Wall and the end of the Cold War, political philosophy used to be divided into categories such as liberals, conservatives, socialists and Marxists. Except for conservatism, for each category there were often feminists working and criticizing at their side. Therefore, as the classic text of Alison Jaggar, Feminist Politics and Human Nature, explained, each ideological approach attracted feminist scholars who would take their example and take the language of a particular ideology (Jaggar 1983). Jaggar's text brings together feminist political philosophy in four areas: liberal feminism, socialist feminism, Marxist feminism and radical feminism. The first three groups followed the lines of the global political divisions of the Cold War: American liberalism, European socialism and revolutionary communism (although few in the West would embrace Soviet-style communism). Radical feminism was the most indigenous of feminist philosophies, developing its own political vocabulary with its roots in the deep criticism of patriarchy that feminist consciousness had produced in its first and second waves. Otherwise, feminist political philosophy largely followed the lines of traditional political philosophy. But this has never been an uncritical follow-up. As a field bent on changing the world, even liberal feminist theorists tended to criticize liberalism as much or more than they embraced it, and embrace socialism and other more radical views rather than reject them. However, in general, these theorists generally operated within the language and framework of their chosen approach to political philosophy.
Political philosophy began to change enormously in the late 1980s, just before the end of the Cold War, with a new invocation of an old Hegelian category: civil society, an arena of intermediate political life between the state and the home. This was the arena of associations, churches, trade unions, reading clubs, choral societies and many other still public non-governmental organizations. In the 1980s political theorists began to focus their attention from the state to this intermediate kingdom, which suddenly took the center stage in Eastern Europe in organizations that challenged the power of the state and eventually led to the fall of communist regimes.
After the end of the Cold War, political philosophy and political life were radically realigned. New attention was focused on civil society and the public sphere, especially with the timely translation of the early work of Jürgen Habermas, the Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere (Habermas 1989). Volumes soon appeared on civil society and the public sphere, focusing on the ways in which people organized and developed public power rather than on the ways in which the State obtained and exercised its power. Indeed, there was a sense that the public sphere could ultimately exercise more power than the State, at least in the fundamental way in which public will is formed and serves to legitimize State power or not. In the latter sense, John Rawls' work was influential in developing a theory of justice that tied the legitimacy of institutions to the normative judgments that a thoughtful and deliberative people could do (Rawls 1971). In the early 1990s, Marxists seemed to have disappeared or at least become very circumspective (although the fall of communist regimes should not have had any effect on Marxist analysis itself, which never adhered to Leninist or Maoist thought). Socialists also withdrew or became “radical Democrats” (Mouffe 1992, 1993, 2000).

text:
Hume proposes that feeling, not thought, informs us that an object is beautiful or ugly, or that an action exhibits virtue or vice: “The feeling itself constitutes our praise or admiration” (T, 471). Feeling or feeling is in itself an aesthetic or moral discrimination. It precedes, and the basis of, any subsequent expression of praise or admiration. Feeling is the beauty of the object and is the virtue of desirable human action. Feeling is the only source of values that govern human activity. Taste is a “productive mastery, and shining or staining all natural objects with colors, taken from the inner feeling, raises, in a way, a new creation”. That the new creation is "beauty and deformity, virtue and vice" (EPM, 294). However, the feeling is calmer than violent, so an unphilosophic perspective treats it as a property “of the object” (S, 218).
This moral and aesthetic subjectivism attracts Hume for the same reason that attracts Hutcheson. The appeal to feeling offers an intermediate position between the two prevailing theories in English letters, Hobbesian selfishness and ethical rationalism. Hutcheson argues that virtue and beauty are not the qualities of the people and the things to which they are attributed. We can speak as if objects and people have moral and aesthetic properties, but the relevant property is merely an “idea posed in us”. Hume alters Hutcheson's theory by imposing his own philosophical vocabulary, making beauty an impression rather than an idea. But they agree that describing a person as virtuous or such a beautiful object is to make a claim about his tendency to cause a certain response. Is it reckless and “too strong,” Hume asks Hutcheson, to sum up the thesis in the following terms (HL, I, 39–40)? “[When you pronounce any action or character to be vicious, you mean nothing, but from the constitution of your nature you have a feeling or feeling of guilt of contemplation of it. Therefore, vice and virtue can be compared with sounds, colors, heat and cold, which, according to modern philosophy, are not qualities in objects, but perceptions in the mind” (T, 469). Highlighting Hume's debt to Hutcheson, Kivy (2003, pp. 307-310), argues that Hume understands the beauty in the color model a lot. Although they are secondary qualities and therefore do not directly reveal the properties of the object it causes, some perception of color is “true and real” (SOT, 272), and therefore is for Hume equally with beauty. However, virtue and beauty are not strictly analogous to secondary qualities, such as heat and cold, because the claim of a critic that a work is beautiful implies a backing element that does not arise in the observation that the ice is cold. The case against the reading of Humean beauty in the model of ideas of secondary qualities is provided by Shiner (1996) and Taylor (2011).
Hume defends the centrality of feeling with the following reasoning. Recognitions of virtue and beauty require particular feelings in human observers. If the discriminations of taste took place without these feelings, we would lack motivation to do what we consider moral. Moral and aesthetic judgments have practical consequences that lack mere reason. So taste differs from the assent that characterizes understanding or reason (T, 458; EPM, 172; S, 219). Although taste responds to the real qualities of objects, we cannot substitute the exercise of taste for the assent of reason. In many cases, beauty and grace (both aesthetic and moral) are inexplicable; they resist our efforts of explanation, and we must rely on the “safe testimony of taste and feeling” (EPM, 267).

text:
In 1932 Marcuse published one of the first reviews of the recently published 1844 Manuscripts entitled “Neue Quellen zur Grundlegung des historischen Materialismus” (New Sources on the Foundation of Historical Materialism). According to Marcuse, the manuscripts of 1844 had the possibility of accomplishing two things.
These manuscripts could put on a new basis the discussion about the origins and original meaning of historical materialism, and the whole theory of "scientific socialism". They also make it possible to raise the question of the real connections between Marx and Hegel in a more fruitful way. (Wolin 2001: 86)
However, these manuscripts also provided Marcuse with the theoretical tools necessary to develop a critical and philosophical anthropology that would assist him in developing his own brand of critical theory.
In this context, “anthropology” does not refer to the study of past cultures, as is often the case in the United States. Instead, it refers to the German idea of anthropology, which is rather a philosophical and social scientific examination of human nature. The 1844 Manuscripts are important to Marcuse because in them Marx provides a philosophical basis for his subsequent critique of political economy, as well as a philosophical anthropology of theoretical action. Philosophical categories such as work, objectification, alienation, sublation, property, and others explored in Hegel's philosophy were dialectically analyzed by Marx (Kellner 1984: 79).
In short, what Marcuse sees in the manuscripts of 1844 is an analysis of the social conditions for a communist revolution. Revolution itself requires the development of a radical subjectivity. Radical subjectivity refers to the development of a form of self-awareness that finds the current social and economic conditions intolerable. The radical act is a rejection of these conditions and a orientation towards social transformation. To make sense of Marcuse's position, we must ask ourselves: what are these intolerable conditions and how do they occur? Philosophical anthropology and radical subjectivity are connected here to the extent that the intolerable conditions that must overcome revolution or radical act represent social distortions of human essence. It is Marx and Hegel who provided Marcuse with a philosophical anthropology that reveals the human essence and social mechanisms by which it is distorted. The key category here is that of “alienation” which cannot be understood without examining the role of work and objectivity.
According to Marcuse, Hegel and Marx, human beings develop through a self-forming process in which the external world (nature) is appropriate and transformed according to human needs. Work is one of the main areas for this self-training activity. The idea that work is an essential part of a self-training process is what distinguishes Marx from classical economists such as Smith, Richard, etc. In the classical economy, work is simply the means by which individuals make provisions for themselves and their families. In these theories work is not considered as the activity by which the human subject is constituted. The Marxist view of work as a self-forming process is what makes possible the Marxist theory of alienation and revolution.
Marcuse argues that in the Manuscripts of 1844 Marx shows how the role of work is reversed as self-realization or self-forming process. Instead of having its claimed subjectivity, the individual becomes an object that is now shaped by external, alien forces. Therefore, Marx's theory makes a transition from an examination of the self-forming process of work to a critique of the forms of alienation caused by the historical facticity of capitalism. Within the Historical Facticity of Capitalism
this fact appears as the total reversal and concealment of what criticism had defined as the essence of man and human work. Work is not “free activity” or the universal and free self-realization of man, but his slavery and loss of reality. The worker is not man in the totality of his expression of life, but something not essential [ein Unwesen], the purely physical subject of "abstract" activity. The objects of work are not expressions and confirmations of the human reality of the worker, but strange things, which belong to someone other than the worker—“basic products.” (Markuse 2005b: 104)
Marcuse will spend the rest of her life carrying out the investigations initiated in these early works. What distinguishes his project from that of Marx is the way in which each one will deal with the problem of concealment mentioned in the above quotation. Marx will develop two different but related approaches. His criticism of the political economy is an attempt to reveal the internal logic of capitalism (how it works) as well as the contradictions that will lead to the collapse of capitalism. The second approach is to elaborate a theory of revolution that presupposes the awakening of self-awareness in the working class. In both approaches, concealment will give way to outreach and social transformation. Earlier we saw that Marx's predictions did not come true for either reason. This failure in part led to what has been called the crisis of Marxism to which the birth of the Frankfurt School was a response. Marcuse's work will go through many phases as he tries to unlock the key to revolutionary action. The next key move for him is to participate in a deeper study of Hegel as a source for critical social theory.
label: C2

text:
An influential branch of feminist ethics developed in the last four decades, the ethics of care, is an area of philosophy that implicitly recognizes the assets of personal relationships because “care” is, in itself, a main good of relationship that has been affirmed to play a central role in moral thinking and, more recently, in political thinking.
Perhaps the best way to identify the ethics of care is as a thread of ethics that deals with the satisfaction of the needs of others within personal relationships (Tronto 1993). But “care” is used in feminist ethics to refer to slightly different things (Collins 2015). The reference to needs is the common link between different accounts of the appropriate subject-matter of care ethics. (In this entry, “needs” and “important interests” are used interchangeably.) The ethics of care is, first of all, about a type of work, or work, such as when someone is said to be “careful” of another person in situations such as nursing a baby or caring for a sick person. Some care ethics professionals attribute a special, if not exclusive, moral value to the care of people who are unable to meet the needs in question (Bubeck 1995). This meaning often extends to a wider range of activities such as education or physical and mental health care. According to a second view, the ethics of care refers to close relationships between people, based on a special emotional bond and including a commitment to the well-being of others (Ruddick 1998). Much of the ethics of care, at least in the early stages, has focused on close personal relationships, such as motherhood or friendship; the assumption here is that care satisfies the need for bonding, or attachment (Gheaus 2009: 64). Thirdly, “care” is understood as a willingness to behave in certain ways: to be attentive and sensitive to the needs of others and willing to help them. In this sense, “care” is a virtue, and the ethics of care is a form of virtue ethics. As a virtue, care is a general attitude, opposed to insensitivity and indifference to the needs of others.
Whether understood as an activity, relationship or willingness to meet needs, care has been attributed to universal moral value. Many care ethics professionals were interested in the crucial role of agency care provision and for individual and species survival. First, without receiving attention within relationships, babies are unlikely to survive, let alone thrive (Ruddick 1989). In addition, care is necessary for the existence of people: only within relationships with good caregivers can children acquire moral knowledge and dispositions and, ultimately, full activity (Held 1993). Similarly, some care ethicalists argue that friendship is necessary to develop a rich sense of autonomy, as friends give us the most direct access to particular values and conceptions of good (Friedman 1993) Second, as Eva Kittay argues, care has universal value because most individuals require it to varying degrees throughout their lives beyond childhood or childhood: some of us only during illness and old age, while others — people who are chronically ill or disabled — more or less continuously (Kitay 1999).
Because it is necessary for the creation of people, care ethics professionals have stated that care is more basic to morality than rights and duties, since in their absence most rights are useless. Care being so basic to our survival and flowering provides a presumptive reason to assume that there are duties to ensure that everyone is given sufficient care. It is difficult to determine what some ethical careists think about such a duty, because the ethics of care has been coined, at least in the beginning, in opposition to the language of rights and duties (Gilligan 1982; Noddings 1984). More generally, much of the ethics of care arose from scepticism about moral principles (Collins 2015). Therefore, the question of whether we have a general welfare duty to extend our care to those who seem to be excluded has not received much attention (but for a recent exception see Collins 2013).

The latest news I heard before boarding a plane to Seoul a few days ago was that North Korea had just fired 100 artillery shells at the sea near the border with South Korea.
Disturbing news from North Korea comes as often as stories that make us laugh in disbelief. The many peculiar, disconcerting and disconcerting developments in Pyongyang make their young ruler, Kim Jung Un, an irresistible target for comedians.
It was difficult to suppress a laugh, for example, when North Korea severely declared a forthcoming Hollywood satirical film to be an act of war and lodged an official complaint with the United Nations.
Those are both sides of North Korea, deliberately terrifying and inadvertently comic. Then there's a third side... the part that makes us gasp with horror.
A one-year investigation conducted by the United Nations found that North Korea is a country whose depth of brutality has no parallel in the contemporary world.
According to the report, North Korea commits murder, torture, slavery and mass famines to terrorize and subdue the population. The stories of refugees who have escaped from North Korea are a chilling reminder that the regime is not only a military threat but is causing a terrible humanitarian crisis.
North Korea is a Fiery Kingdom that at the same time is threatening, strange and brutal. The unpredictability of the regime is one of the factors that enable a small and impoverished State, unable to feed its own people, to face far more powerful rivals.
It is those random, capricious and often dangerous behaviors that allow North Korea to be fragile, fragile and bankrupt, forcing its dazzling and successful neighbor, South Korea, to maintain a constant state of alert, to wonder if its capital can survive an attack across a border that is just 35 miles away.
With its conventional and nuclear arsenals, North Korea manages to sustain the international community, including the United States, fighting for an approach that can neutralize the danger and send a lifeguard to the victims of the cruel regime.
It is tempting to ignore North Korea's antics as haunting, as empty threats. But Pyongyang has launched deadly attacks. For example, in 2010, he bombed a South Korean island about 70 miles from Seoul, killing four people. He could also have launched a torpedo that same year that sank a South Korean navy ship, killing 46. In 2013, the North detonated a nuclear device and threatened to launch a preemptive nuclear attack on the United States.A fourth nuclear test could be imminent.
After the most recent escalation, South Korean President Park Geun-hye spoke to the military leaders and told them to prepare for reprisals. She described Pyongyang as so erratic that you can't see an inch forward.
News from North Korea can be so disconcerting that parody and rumors regularly come to news and social media as if they were made. Before the World Cup finals a satirical video supposedly showing a North Korean newsman declaring the North team as a World Cup finalist went viral, repeated as if it were true, as another fun time for Pyongyang.
And why not? Truth and fiction are hard to tell.
Pyongyang has created its own version of the world for domestic consumption. North Korean government researchers announced that their country is the second happiest country in the world, only second to China. The last ruler, Kim Jung Il, was informed that he had played a perfect game the first time he set foot in a bowling alley. He was also supposed to be the best golfer in the world.
The official biography of the country's rulers has been seen as something outside of a history of Marvel Comics' book. No official biography of the current Kim has been published, apart from a story that says he was born in heaven. That would fit his father's official story, Kim Jong Il, who claims that he was born under a double rainbow with the seasons changing spontaneously and a new star appearing in the sky for the occasion.
The three generations of Kim men who have ruled the North are painted as supernatural to the local population. Abroad, they are cartoon figures, whose behavior can leave diplomats and strategists scratching their heads.
Just a few months ago, the government published a racist diatribe against President Barack Obama, calling him a clown who does not even have the basic appearance of being human. I suggested he lived with monkeys in a zoo. Racism, a myth of racial superiority, is a notable feature of the culture promoted by the regime.
The authorities have created their own reality, brainwashing the population to maintain the functioning of the State and the safe regime. For anyone who commits what the government considers a violation, the punishment is inconceivably harsh.
It's all part of the riddle that keeps the world guessing, disbalancing and nervous. By firing missiles, threatening neighbors and acting erratically, North Korea presents itself as mysterious and volatile, and even that perception magnifies its ability to create fear, increasing its power and helping to keep the despotic regime in control.

The value realism of truth is the view that every well-formed mathematical affirmation has a unique and objective truth value that is independent of whether it can be known by us and whether it is logically derived from our current mathematical theories. The view also holds that most of the mathematical statements that are considered true are in fact true. So the realism of the value of truth is clearly a metaphysical vision. But unlike Platonism, it is not an ontological view. Because while true value realism claims that mathematical statements have unique and objective truth values, it is not committed to the distinctively Platonist idea that these truth values must be explained in terms of mathematical object ontology.
Mathematical Platonism clearly motivates realism of real value by providing an account of how mathematical statements get their true values. But the first opinion does not imply the second, unless more premises are added. Because even if there are mathematical objects, referential and quantitative indetermination can deprive mathematical statements of a unique and objective truth value. On the contrary, the realism of truth-value does not itself imply Existence and therefore does not imply either object realism or Platonism. Because there are several accounts of how mathematical statements can come to possess unique and objective truth values that do not pose a realm of mathematical objects. [6]
In fact, many nominalists support the realism of truth-value, at least on more basic branches of mathematics, such as arithmetic. Nominalists of this kind are committed to the slightly strange opinion that, although the ordinary mathematical assertion
(1) There are prime numbers between 10 and 20.
is true, in fact there are no mathematical objects and therefore in particular there are no numbers. But there is no contradiction here. We must distinguish between the LM language in which mathematicians make their statements and the LP language in which nominalists and other philosophers make their own. The statement (1) is made in LM. But the nominalist's claim that (1) is true but that there are no abstract objects is made in LP. Therefore, the statement of the nominalist is perfectly consistent provided that (1) is translated from LM to LP in a non-homofonic manner. And in fact, when the nominalist states that the truth values of LM prayers are fixed in a way that does not attract mathematical objects, it is precisely this kind of non-homophonic translation that he has in mind. The view mentioned in the previous note provides an example.
This shows that for the Existence statement to have its intended effect, it must be expressed in the LP language used by us philosophers. If the claim was expressed in the LM language used by mathematicians, then nominalists could accept the claim while still denying that there are mathematical objects, contrary to the purpose of the claim.
A small but important tradition of philosophers calls for the debate on Platonism to be replaced by, or at least transformed into, a debate on the realism of the value of truth. One reason offered in support of this view is that the first debate is irretrievably unclear, while the second is easier to deal with (Dummett 1978a, pp. 228-232 and Dummett 1991b, pp. 10–15). Another reason offered is that the debate about the realism of the value of truth is of greater importance for both philosophy and mathematics than the debate about Platonism. [7]

The deadly attack in Kabul on the Shiite faithful celebrating the festival of Ashura adds yet another layer to the overlapping security crises in the country. And they evoke violent sectarian rivalries in Iraq and Pakistan, where the animosity between Sunnis and Shiites is deep. Afghanistan has its own cultural divisions -- between the Pashtun and Tajik ethnic groups, for example -- but it is rare to see such an explosion of religiously motivated violence.
Kate Clark, with the Afghan Analyst Network in Kabul, described the attack as a real shock.
Whatever happened in the last 30 years we haven't had this kind of sectarian attack aimed at killing a lot of people, he told CNN on the phone from the Afghan capital.
The first claim of responsibility for the bombing in the Afghan capital comes from a Sunni militant group in Pakistan with a history of sectarian attacks against Shia. A man who identified himself as a spokesman for Lashkar-e-Janghvi al-Almi, a group with links to al-Qaeda and the Pakistani Taliban, claimed responsibility for the attack in an appeal to Radio Mashaal, a Pashto-Language station in Pakistan sponsored by the United States government. A similar call was reportedly made to the BBC Urdu language service.
The group is a branch of the powerful Lashkar-e-Janghvi-LRB-LeJ-RRB, which has a history of high-profile suicide attacks in Pakistan, including the attack on the Marriott Hotel in Islamabad in 2008. Al-Almi's most destructive attack to date was a double suicide bombing in north-west Pakistan last year. The bombers, wearing burkas, killed 42 people belonging to tribes opposed to the Pakistani Taliban, also known for their antipathy towards the Shiites.
If Al-Almi's assertion were valid, it would not surprise some Afghan Shia, who hastened to point out some form of Pakistani involvement in Tuesday's attacks.
LeJ has a long history of attacking the Shia Hazara community in Pakistan. The Hazaras are numerous in both Pakistan and Afghanistan, and constitute a large part of the Shia minority in Afghanistan. They have suffered decades of persecution in both countries, and Sunni militants have often then painted as collaborators of the occupying powers.
This year, apparently in retaliation for the murder of Osama bin Laden, LeJ shot and killed several Hazara in Quetta, the capital of Balochistan province, and also home to Afghan Taliban political leaders. In a subsequent open letter, the LeJ warned: We will rid Pakistan of -LSB- this -RSB - impure people. Pakistan means land of cigars, and Shiites have no right to be here.
In October, Sunni militants killed dozens more from Hazara. In one case, they stopped a bus of Shia pilgrims on their way to Iran from Pakistan Balochistan and shot 26 male passengers in front of their families.
Lashkar-e-Jhangvi has obviously not been active in Afghanistan since he maintained training camps there during the Taliban government in the 1990s. However, other Sunni militants -- especially factions among the Pakistani Taliban -- have established a presence in some Afghan border provinces. And regional analysts perceive fluid links, contacts and cross-fertilization among the countless groups operating in the Afghanistan-Pakistan border region.
The Taliban hastened to repudiate and condemn the attacks. Kate Clark says that while he is prudent about the Taliban's denial, such an attack would disagree with the Taliban leaders' claim to be a national movement, and is not part of a pattern of such attacks by the group.
Clark also notes that last month, in his Eid message, Mullah Omar urged Taliban fighters to protect the lives, wealth and honor of ordinary people. That said, 80 percent of all civilian deaths in Afghanistan are attributed to the armed opposition; and the orders of the Shura of Quetta, as is known, are only applied irregularly by field commanders. The Taliban are not a monolith, as an Afghan observer says, and there may have been collaboration at the local level between a Taliban operation and LeJ.
The Taliban have not played the sectarian card since they became an insurgency. But when they were in power in the 1990s they brutally persecuted the Hazara community of Afghanistan. Human Rights Watch documented two massacres in Hazara in 2000 and 2001 by Taliban forces. And after capturing Mazar and Sharif in 1998, Taliban fighters killed hundreds of Hazara in retaliation for the mass execution of their own soldiers the previous year.
Since the overthrow of the Taliban, Afghanistan’s hazaras have prospered: in higher education, government and military, and have embraced new democratic processes. The annual Ashura celebration in Kabul has become more elaborate. That may have been enough temptation for the Hazarasenemies.
If Tuesday's bombings were an attempt to sow sectarian struggles in Afghanistan, the most obvious thing is that they imitate Al Qaeda in Iraq, which when led by Abu Musab al-Zarqawi tried to ignite a sectarian war between Sunnis and the country's Shiite majority in a series of attacks directed at Shiite sacred occasions and shrines.
Kate Clark of the Afghan Network of Analysts believes that moderation will prevail in Afghanistan. Hazara leaders have already asked their community to remain calm and do not gag the hook offered by these attacks. Everywhere, Clark says, there is an understanding that sectarian conflict is a situation in which tet-for-tat attacks would take hundreds of lives.

The investigation found that farmers were willing to participate in crop insurance in the municipality of Dormaa in the Bono region of Ghana. The essential information of 167 respondents who were chosen using a multistage sampling method for the study was collected through a structured questionnaire. The elements influencing the preparation for crop protection by cocoa producers were assessed using the probit regression model and, finally, the limitations of cocoa producers were assessed using the Kendall concordance coefficient. The study found that the average amount farmers were eager to pay was GH215.59 per year for crop insurance. Most 96.7 per cent of respondents were eager to participate in crop insurance, but 3.3 per cent of respondents were unwilling to participate. Important factors influencing farmers ' preparation for crop insurance include age, marital status, access to extension service and experience in cocoa farming. Again, the main limitation affecting farmers was pests and diseases. The study therefore recommends that agricultural extension agents and other stakeholders in agricultural insurance raise farmers' awareness of the importance of crop insurance policy. Insurance companies must provide crop insurance to farmers at moderate rates of GH¢ 215.59 per year to encourage their participation.
Keywords: Harvest insurance, cocoa, probit regression, Dormaa municipal assembly, Ghana.
Introduction
Agriculture is central to the economy of each emerging nation, including Ghana, as it uses about 66 per cent of Ghana ' s labour force, both formal and casual. The agricultural subsector grew by 4.8% in 2018, in contrast to a development rate of 6.1% in 2017. The share of the gross domestic product of agriculture decreased from 21.1% in 2017 to 19.7% in 2018. Crops are another important commitment in Ghana to a portion of 14.5% of gross domestic product (Ghana Statistical Service, 2019). Although the contribution of agriculture to Ghana's gross domestic product has declined over the years, it remains a powerful force in the economy (ISSER, 2011). A key profitable area and a major source of export earnings for Ghana in recent years has been cocoa. Briesinger et al. (2011) showed an increase in the percentage of cocoa in agricultural gross domestic product from 13.7 per cent in 2000 to 2004 to 18.9 per cent in 2005/06. The crucial role of cocoa in Ghana's income, in addition to the reality that it helps as a key source of work for many Ghanaian farmers, implies its future in the face of any unexpected conditions must be assured. This is because any significant disaster in this sector will negatively affect both the macroeconomic and microeconomic areas of the economy. Although the danger in the agricultural sector is inevitable, it can be managed.
Annual cocoa production differs significantly due to unforeseen weather conditions, pest and disease invasions and sporadic economic situations that cause crops and prices to move widely. More attention should be paid to cocoa production in order to increase Ghana ' s income and, in addition, to help solve food security problems in some parts of the country.
According to Oluyole and Sanusi (2009), previous research acknowledged some significant explanations behind differences in cocoa production that include low harvest, environmental impulses, extreme weather situations, occurrence of infections, pest invasion and regular hazards such as heavy downpours, erosion and long dry seasons. High risks and uncertainties related to agricultural production have been attributed to the decline in cocoa production (Aderinola and Abdulkadri, 2007). This is because, like other crops, cocoa needs a wide and uninterrupted interaction with the forces of nature. These threats and vulnerabilities are unforeseen and beyond the capacity of agricultural households; subsequently, farmers can only cope with them. Cocoa farmers suffer enormous savings and income losses due to the losses suffered by these dangers and uncertainties. In light of this, Ajakaiye and Adeyeye (2001) discovered that smallholder households in many emerging nations of the world, without exception to Ghana, are trapped in the insane pattern of insufficiency. This succession is represented by the low production and low yields of the farm, causing virtually no savings of funds, necessary for the revolution of its agricultural expedition, which adds to the low position conferred on farmers within the population. On the contrary, Quagranie (2006) prescribed that insurance could be used to reduce the financial costs of numerous hostile events, such as deaths, accidents, thefts and weather damage. Insurance is defined as an agreement between two parties in which a party called an insurer accepts an exchange called a premium to pay the other party a fixed measure of money in the event of a sudden incident (Adams 1995). As Sarris (2002) indicates, insurance guarantees a basic cost for an explicit amount for a fixed duration for which the security network provider pays a direct premium. However, insurance offers the possibility for companies to replace risk with a known rate. People acquire insurance coverage in the hope of receiving a sum, at any time that the policyholder finds the protection assured misfortune (Nimo et al., 2011). As indicated by Aidoo et al. (2014), a large part of Ghana's insurance agencies offer numerous protection schemes (e.g. accident coverage, medical and life coverage, fire protection and theft) in addition to the crop insurance scheme.

text:
The threat of extinction of the tiger in India, the dangerous existence of the orangutan in Indonesia, the difficult situation of the panda: these are wildlife emergencies with which we have become familiar. They are very dear animals that no one wants to see disappear. But, now, scientists fear that the real impact of declining wildlife may be closer to home, threatening creatures like mariquitas that pose the greatest threat to biodiversity.
Climate change, the decrease in the number of animals, the increase in the number of human beings and the rapid rate of extinction of species mean that an increasing number of scientists now declare us in the Anthropocene, the geological age of extinction when humans finally dominate ecosystems.
The WWF Living Planet Index 2014 seemed to confirm that grim image, with statistics on the world's wild population showing a dramatic reduction in the number of species. The LPI showed that the number of vertebrates had decreased by 52% over four decades. The loss of biodiversity has now reached “critical levels. ” Some populations of mammals, birds, reptiles and amphibians have suffered even greater losses, with a decrease in freshwater species of 76 per cent during the same period.
But it is the creatures that provide the most “natural capital” or “ecosystem services” that are putting many scientists really worried. Three quarters of world food production is believed to depend on bees and other pollinators such as aerodynamic flies. No matter how cute a panda is or how impressive a tiger is – it is the worms that are crushing our waste and taking it deep into the ground to become nutrients, and the bats that are catching mosquitoes and keeping malaria rates low. A study in North America has valued the loss of pest control by ongoing bat declines at over $22 billion in lost agricultural productivity.
“It is the loss of the common species that will impact people, not so much on the rarest creatures because, by the very nature of their rarity, we do not depend on them in such an obvious way,” said Dr. Nick Isaac, a macroecologist at the Oxfordshire Center for Ecology and Hydrology. He says the recent work he and his colleagues have been doing suggests that Britain’s insects and other invertebrates are decreasing as fast as vertebrates, with “serious consequences for humanity.” “The really interesting thing about this work is that we’re learning that it’s not just about the number of species that are extinct, but about the real numbers of a population; that’s the beginning of a fundamental change in our understanding,” he says.
He noted that between 23 and 36 per cent of all birds, mammals and amphibians used for food or medicine are now in danger of extinction. In many parts of the world, wildlife food sources are a critical part of the diet, especially for the poor.
Most people agree that unsustainable human consumption damages ecosystems, creating climate change and destroying habitats at a much faster rate than was thought. But, this time, it is not only the “big and tender mammals” that we have to worry about losing, but the smaller and less visible creatures on which we depend – insects, creepy ones – kittens and even worms. They may not face immediate extinction, but a decrease in their number will affect us all. “We will feel the impact of those losses. With UK species, the pattern is the same with invertebrates as with vertebrates. It's not as simplistic as "fish dies and people starve" – it's more complex," Isaac said.
Humans, television naturalist Sir David Attenborough said in 2013, are a “plague on earth,” but WWF claims there is still time to stop rotting. His UK Executive Director, David Nussbaum, said: “The extent of the destruction highlighted in this report must act as a wake-up call for all of us. All – politicians, companies and people – have an interest, and a responsibility, to act to ensure that we protect what we all value: a healthy future for people and nature.
“Human beings are cutting down trees faster than they can grow again, harvesting more fish than the oceans can replenish, pumping water out of our rivers and aquifers faster than rains can replenish and emitting more carbon than oceans and forests can absorb,” he said.

text:
The new laws that will enter into force on Sunday cover some of the nation's most controversial issues, from immigration to abortion, while others deal with tanning beds, tuition and where you can sell a pet.
In total, nearly 40,000 laws were enacted in 2011, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Some of them take effect on New Year's Day.
Among them is a controversial California provision that requires schools to add lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender Americans to the list of those whose contributions to the development of California and the United States should be taught in schools.
Another California law adds gender identity and gender expression to the list of characteristics that require equal rights.
New laws in Delaware and Hawaii make same-sex couples eligible for civil unions and grant them the same rights and benefits as couples married under the law, the legislative group said.
NCSL: New state laws for the new year
In New Hampshire, as of January 1, children will have to inform their parents before they abort or apply for a court order to avoid parental notification.
Governor. John Lynch had vetoed the bill, saying there must be an exception for rape, incest and abuse. The legislature repealed its veto.
New laws in Louisiana, Tennessee, South Carolina, and Georgia require companies to enroll in the federal E-Verify program to ensure employees are eligible to work in the United States, says the National Conference of State Legislatures.
California, meanwhile, is banning any state or local government office from requiring employers to use E-Verify, unless required by federal law as a condition for receiving federal funds.
E-Verify is a controversial program designed to check the citizenship or immigration status of a potential employee. Supporters say it helps businesses avoid involuntary recruitment of illegal immigrants. Critics complain that it's expensive to operate, push undocumented workers underground, and it's not always accurate.
Some future laws for the new year focus on health issues.
One in California prohibits the production or sale of beer to which caffeine has been added. Another in the state would ban the sale of dextromethorphan, or DXM, to minors without a prescription. DXM is in many over-the-counter cough suppressors, but it has been used as a recreational drug, says the National Conference of State Legislatures.
California will also prohibit stores from selling expired infant formulas and foods.
Another law in California focuses on school athletes suspected of having a concussion or head injury. A school should withdraw the athlete from that activity and not allow him to resume it until a health care provider gives him the approval.
Many of the new laws cited by the legislative group are in California, including one that prohibits the use of ultraviolet tanning devices by minors and another that makes it a crime to sell a live animal on any street, road, right of public passage, parking, carnival or promenade.
Both Oregon and California will ban the sale of shark fins in the new year.
Oregon is demanding that state colleges and universities waive the tuition and tuition fees of children under the age of 25.
Some new state laws amend penal provisions. Kentucky will require certain inmates convicted of drug offences to serve the last six months of their community sentences under supervision.
Oregon will require ignition interlocking devices -- computer breath analyzers -- for people convicted of driving under influence and people under intoxicant distraction agreements, which allow for delayed prosecution for a DUI charge.
And more states are joining a national movement by tougher laws against distracted driving. Nevada will ban all drivers from texting and using portable devices, says the National Conference of State Legislatures. North Dakota is banning drivers under the age of 18 from using cell phones in their cars and forbidding all drivers from sending text messages.

Tokyo -LRB-CNN -RRB- A Japanese court has issued a court order to stop plans to restart two nuclear reactors in the west of the country, citing security concerns, a court official told CNN.
The nuclear warden of Japan, the Nuclear Regulatory Authority, had previously given a green light to the reopening of reactors 3 and 4 at the Takahama nuclear power plant of Kansai power company.
But the locals successfully petitioned the court in Fukui Prefecture, where the plant is located, raising concerns about whether the reactors would survive a strong earthquake.
Japan's 48 nuclear reactors are disconnected following the Fukushima disaster in 2011, when a tsunami triggered by a massive earthquake sent a water wall to the power plant.
Since then, the island nation has imported larger quantities of expensive natural gas and coal to meet its energy needs.
Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has pressed for a return to nuclear power, arguing that it is essential for the country's economic recovery to reduce utility bills that are triggered by energy imports.
But opinion polls have consistently shown public opposition to a nuclear restart.
Keith Henry, general manager of Tokyo-based Asia Strategy, who advises companies on Japanese public policy issues, says the decision will force Abe to rethink the economy of its energy policy.
That was a blow to the body - LSB - for Abe - because it is no longer a political matter, it is a legal matter. Change the calculus and dynamics, he said.
He's in court now. And the government has no power to do anything about it.
READ MORE: Electric company leaves robot stranded inside Fukushima plant
Anti-nuclear activists celebrated after the Fukui District Court decision in their favor on Tuesday.
The nuclear plant operator had argued in court that the plant was safe, complying with the strictest safety standards introduced by the nuclear warden after the Fukushima disaster.
He said in a statement that scientific and professional findings showed that reactor safety was assured.
But the court ruled that the new security regulations were loose, lacked rationality and could not guarantee the safety of the plant, one official said.
The electric company said it would appeal the decision. We deeply regret that our statement has not been well understood and cannot be accepted at all, he said in a statement.
Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga told reporters on Tuesday that the country's nuclear warden had considered the plant safe according to the world's highest safety standards.
The government had no intention of changing the course of its planned nuclear restart, he said.
Takahama was one of two nuclear facilities authorized to resume operations.
The Sendai nuclear power plant in Kagoshima Prefecture has been approved by the governor of the prefecture to reopen the courtroom, although local residents are trying to challenge it in court.
Analyst Henry said that the renewable energy sector could benefit from Takahama's decision, as the country weighed solar and hydropower as alternatives.
Before the Fukushima disaster, approximately 30% of Japan's energy was nuclear.
CNN Junko Ogura contributed to this report from Tokyo.

text:
Calculus, originally called infinitesimal calculus or "the calculus of infinitesimals", is the mathematical study of continuous change, in the same way that geometry is the study of form and algebra is the study of generalizations of arithmetical operations.
It has two main branches, differential calculus and integral calculus; the first refers to instantaneous rates of change, and slope curves, while the integral calculus refers to the accumulation of quantities, and low areas or between curves. These two branches are related to each other by the fundamental theorem of calculus, and use the fundamental notions of convergence of infinite sequences and infinite series to a well-defined limit. [1]
The infinitesimal calculus was independently developed in the late 17th century by Isaac Newton and Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz. [2][3] Today, calculus has widespread uses in science, engineering and economics. [4]
In mathematical education, calculus denotes elementary mathematical analysis courses, which are mainly devoted to the study of functions and limits. The word calculus (plural calculus) is a Latin word, which originally means "small pebble" (this meaning is maintained in medicine – see Calculus (medicine)). Because such pebbles were used for the calculation, the meaning of the word has evolved and today usually means a method of calculation. Therefore, it is used to name specific methods of calculation and related theories, such as propositional calculus, Ricci calculus, calculus of variations, lambda calculus, and process calculus.
Differential calculus is the study of the definition, properties, and applications of the derivative of a function. The process of finding the derivative is called differentiation. Given a function and a point in the domain, the derivative at that point is a way to encode the small-scale behavior of the function near that point. When you find the derivative of a function at each point of your domain, it is possible to produce a new function, called the derivative function or only the derivative of the original function. In formal terms, the derivative is a linear operator that takes a function as its input and produces a second function as its output. This is more abstract than many of the processes studied in elementary algebra, where functions usually enter a number and output another number. For example, if the duplication function is given input three, then it comes out six, and if the square function is given input three, then it comes out nine. The derivative, however, can take the function of square as an input. This means that the derivative takes all the information from the square function—like two is sent to four, three is sent to nine, four is sent to sixteen, and so on—and uses this information to produce another function. The function produced by the derivation of the square function turns out to be the duplication function.
In more explicit terms, the "duplicate function" can be denoted by g(x) = 2x and the "quad function" by f(x) = x2. The "derivative" now takes the function f(x), defined by the expression "x2", as an input, which is all the information—like two is sent to four, three is sent to nine, four is sent to sixteen, and so on—and uses this information to produce another function, the function g(x) = 2x, as it will result.
The most common symbol for a derivative is an apostrophe brand called prime. So, the derivative of a function called f is denoted by f′, pronounced "f prime". For example, if f(x) = x2 is the square function, then f′(x) = 2x is its derivative (the duplication function g above). This notation is known as Lagrange's notation.
If the input of the function represents time, then the derivative represents the change with respect to time. For example, if f is a function that takes a time as input and gives the position of a ball at that moment as output, then the derivative of f is how the position is changing in time, that is, it is the velocity of the ball.

Tempier's conviction is only one of the approximately sixteen censored thesis lists that were published at the University of Paris during the 13th and 14th centuries. Most of these proposition lists were grouped into systematic collections of prohibited items. One of the first of these collections of medieval condemned articles originated at the end of the 13th century under the name of Parisian articles or also Collectio errorum in anglia et parisius condempnatorum. Initially this collection consisted of twenty-two chapters presenting the errors condemned in 1277 by Archbishop Robert Kilwardby in Oxford, in 1241 by Bishop William of Alvernia in Paris, and in 1270 and 1277 by Bishop Stephen Tempier in Paris (in this order).
During the 14th century, this Collection grew significantly, so, in fact, a second augmented Collection came into existence. All the proposals added to the first compilation had been condemned in the fourteenth century at the University of Paris. It can be seen as a collection of verdicts, which at the opening of each new set of verdicts provides information about the parties involved and the date. The verdicts are not motivated, nor does the collection account for the facts (narratio).
The collection of Parisian articles must have had some sort of official status, and must have circulated among medieval scholars. On the other hand, many medieval philosophical and theological texts contain references and quotations of “Parisian articles”, which in no way should always be identified with Tempier’s list of condemned articles.
If one compares Tempier's program 1277 with the other lists of errors gathered in the compilation of Parisian articles, two characteristics stand out, namely the anonymity of its objectives and its promulgation by a bishop. Tempier does not specify the people behind the false views, but simply states that the errors were spread by "certain scholars in the faculty of the arts." The other convictions, however, all refer to specific scholars whose names are explicitly mentioned in the Collectio errorum. Moreover, it is one of the few censorships in which a bishop was involved from the beginning, and not, for example, at a later stage of the proceedings as an appellate judge.
In his introductory letter to the bug program, Tempier indicates that he responded to information received from important people (magnarum et gravium personarum crebra zelque fidei accensa insintiavit relatio). The allegations were that “some art scholars in Paris” (nonnulli Parisius studios in artibus) had transgressed the limits of their own faculty (proprietary powers of surplus limits). In all probability, this complaint originated in theological circles.
In his introductory letter, Tempier also reports that he sought the advice “not only from the doctors of Holy Scripture, but also from other wise men” (tam doctorum sacrae Scripturae, quam aliorum prudent virorum communicato consilio). From other suspicious teaching cases we know that the task of theologians was to examine certain works and draw up a list of errors. In cases where a list of alleged errors already existed, theologians were in charge of assessing the degree of error of the listed propositions. The theologian John of Pouilly reports that sixteen teachers of theology were Tempier's advisers to the conviction. One of the members of the commission was Henry of Ghent, as he himself testified in his Quodlibet II. It is unknown when these teachers met, but it must have been after Henry of Ghent had become a regent master in theology, a position he obtained in 1276. That there were some tensions between Tempier and theologians is attested by Giles of Rome, a contemporary testimony of the events of 1277: he affirmed that some articles were condemned not on the basis of the counsel of the teachers, but rather because of the "obstinity of a few." This observation has been taken in relation to Tempier, but it could also have included some of the "wise men" who had helped him.

text:
Cities often do not decide to pack, get up and move along the way. But that is exactly what Kiruna, an Arctic city in northern Sweden, has to do – to avoid being swallowed up on earth.
“It’s a dystopian choice,” says Krister Lindstedt, from White, the Stockholm-based architect’s firm, charged with the biblical task of driving this city away 23,000 people from a gigantic iron mine that is quickly swallowing the ground under its streets. “Or the mine must stop digging, creating massive unemployment, or the city has to move – or face some destruction. It is an existential problem.”
Founded in 1900 by the state mining company Luossavaara-Kiirunavaara (LK), Kiruna has been enriched with the vast seam of iron ore below the city, but now faces destruction by the same phenomenon that created its wealth. “We are symbiotic: the city is here because of the mine,” says Deputy Mayor Niklas Siren. Otherwise, no devil would have built a city here.
Located 145 km within the Arctic Circle, Kiruna is subject to a brutal climate, durable winters without sunlight and medium temperatures below -15C. But the deep deposit of magnetite has proven to be a magnet strong enough to keep people here. Driven by the insatiable global appetite for construction, the mine has become the largest underground iron-gold extraction site in the world, producing 90% of all iron in Europe, enough to build more than six Eiffel towers a day. And demand continues to grow.
In 2004, the mining company broke with the city that its days were numbered: digging its wells towards the city at an angle of 60 degrees, the subsidence would soon lead to the general cracking and collapse of the city's buildings. A decade later, fissures are beginning to appear on the ground, crawling closer and closer to the city.
“The people of Kiruna have been living in limbo for ten years,” says Viktoria Walldin, a social anthropologist who works with architects. “They have put their lives on hold, unable to make important decisions such as buying a house, redecorating, having a child or opening a business.”
After years of dilation, the city has finally unveiled a master plan for how it will proceed. “Imagine it as a millift of a city,” says Lindstedt, developing a plan that shows the streets and squares of the city that start crawling eastwards on a new high street, until the whole place has moved safely out of the mine road by 2033.
A new city square is already underway, 3 km east, with a circular town hall planned by the Danish architect Henning Larsen, while 20 key buildings have been identified to be dismantled and resurrected piece by piece in their new home, as a large-scale flat Ikea package. The rusty red wood church of Kiruna, built in 1912 in a form reminiscent of the Sami indigenous tipis, and once voted the most beautiful building in Sweden, will occupy the place in a new park, while the cast iron bell tower will be placed once again on the town hall. But not everything will be saved.
“I talked to an old woman who passes by the bank every day where she received her first kiss,” Walldin says. “It’s things like that – the hospital where your first child was born, for example – that are important to people’s sense of identity and all that will disappear.”
The mining company has allocated the equivalent of Pound320 million to the project for the construction of new facilities, including a secondary school, a fire station, a community centre, a library and a swimming room. But the main concern of most people is where they will actually live and what process will determine the allocation of housing.
“These details have not yet been determined,” admits Lindstedt. “People are used to very low rents and very high incomes, but in the future, this will have to change.” LK has agreed to compensate residents for the value of their homes plus 25%, but many locals say this is not enough to pay for a new construction house at market prices.
To facilitate the valuation process, architects have monitored housing rentals in nearby cities over a period of years, and have “labelled” the homes in Kiruna with the assets they own, from the internal space and gardens to the proximity to the bus stops and the city center. They have also proposed a “Kiruna Gate, ” a kind of massive rescue yard, where materials can be brought from condemned houses and hopefully recycled into the construction of new buildings, although, as Sweden has no tradition of self-construction, it is difficult to see this take off.
A closer look at the plan shows that the new city has little relation to the original Kiruna at all. The current city is an extensive suburban network of winding streets, home to single-family houses with gardens. White's plan incorporates a much higher density arrangement of multi-story apartment blocks around shared courtyards, bordering straight boulevards, downwards, which the icy winds will climb.
It is an opportunity, say the architects, for Kiruna to “reinvent” in a model of sustainable development, attracting young people who would not have stayed in the city before, with new cultural facilities and “visionary” things like a cable car that jumps over the street. But it is a vision that many of the existing residents seem unlikely to be able to afford.
