The current selection of Boeing and SpaceX as suppliers of a U.S.-based capacity. to bring humans to the International Space Station - LRB-ISS -RRB- is an important milestone in the nearly six decades of history of space exploration. It's just the last sign that the old paradigm of government-only space travel is being replaced by something else, a new business ecosystem made up of new relationships between NASA and the aerospace industry.
NASA will no longer own the ISS truck company... specifying each nut and bolt. Instead, NASA is buying services from the American industry. Undoubtedly, the new announcement made it clear that NASA will carefully examine the safety aspects of each design. But the designs will remain those of Boeing and SpaceX and researched by NASA.
I think this new approach is America's secret weapon in what some have described as a space race with China. And, as far as I can tell, while the rest of the world is still stuck in an almost government-only mode, NASA, with the support of the Obama administration, is unleashing the creativity of American know-how.
Starting with the competition of NASA Commercial Orbital Transportation Services, continuing with the Commercial Resupply Services -LRB- Cargo -RRB- and now with the selection of Commercial Crew, NASA bet on the farm in commercial companies filling the void left by the removal of the space shuttle, with the Commercial Crew -LRB-SpaceX and Boeing -RRB companies replacing the Russians in bringing NASA astronauts to the ISS. This will allow NASA to invest savings in deep space capabilities such as SLS and Orion.
I think it is essential that both commercial cargo and crew succeed for at least two reasons: First, the proper role of NASA can be summed up in three words: Explore Deep Space. It is time for NASA to deliver the low-Earth orbit work to industry, while NASA focuses on bringing humanity to Mars, following the footsteps of Robotic Spirit, Opportunity, and Curiosity Rovers. Second, history teaches us that without an edge of commercial exploitation and profitability, large-scale exploration, routine human effort will not succeed.
As an aerospace professional and former NASA executive, I have found for decades many concepts for private space exploration. Until a few years ago, none of these ideas came across the smell test for what I call the practical visionary, that is, someone capable of seeing a new future, but solidly based on the lessons learned. There was always something missing in these early ventures: either the technical approach required that some unobtanium technology be invented, the defender had good ideas but neither money nor construction and philosophy would arrive showed total naivety in business and marketing.
Today's selection points us in a different direction. As with early 20th-century air mail routes that helped stimulate aviation, NASA's commercial programs are now the anchor tenants in the government's transfer of space services to the private sector. This, in turn, will enable a new solid company and allow NASA to focus on Mars, the ultimate goal for exploration.

According to experts, North Korea's latest nuclear test, following the successful launch of the December satellite, suggests that Pyongyang is moving towards the development of a nuclear warhead and deliverable missile system. The question remains: How close is it?
The answer, like the closing hermit kingdom, remains largely a mystery, as does much of its nuclear program.
It's a question about the delivery system and the reliability of those systems, said Daniel Pinkston, senior analyst at the International Crisis Group covering Northeast Asia. That is essentially unknown, or known to a few people within North Korea.
South Korean rocket successfully puts satellite in orbit
A 2009 report by the International Crisis Group suggests that North Korea probably has between six and twelve nuclear weapons, or at least explosive devices, but points out that experts are divided into whether one of these weapons is now usable as warheads, small enough to be mounted on missiles and durable enough to withstand the dangers of flight.
It is quite clear that these are advanced technologies and systems present a number of engineering challenges, and mastering these technologies requires a series of tests, Pinkston said.
North Korea in Google Maps: Monuments, nuclear complex, gulags
In December, on the first anniversary of the death of former leader Kim Jong Il, North Korea successfully launched a three-stage rocket that orbited the Shining Star-3 satellite. The launch also noted that the North's long-range missile programme now puts the United States at hand.
Last month, the United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution that strengthened sanctions against the North in response to the rocket launch in December. Declaring that the sanctions amounted to a declaration of war, North Korea threatened to conduct more nuclear and missile tests, which, he said, are a new phase of confrontation with the United States.
For the UN and North Korea: Game in
Tuesday's underground nuclear test is North Korea's third, after testing in 2009 and 2006. The test, probably carried out near P'unggye, produced several kilotons, according to assessments cited by the U.S. director of national intelligence.
Koreas in 2013: Watch Generational Policy · Global Voices
Estimates of the size, or performance, of the 2009 nuclear test range from 2.5 kilotons to 6 kilotons, Pinkston said. In comparison, the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima had a yield of 16 kilotons.
While the spectre of a North Korea capable of sending nuclear-powered missiles is worrying, equally problematic for the international community is Pyongyang's atomic technology that feeds the black arms market.
If his clandestine uranium enrichment program has made progress, Pyongyang could prove that he will gain access to a much larger stockpile of fissile material than simply his limited supply of weapon-grade plutonium, wrote Patrick M. Cronin, an Asian expert at the Center for New American Security, in a CNN op-ed. A greater stock of fissile material is a dual threat: as a vital part of an expanded nuclear weapons programme and as a commodity to be sold on the black market.
Chronology: North Korea's obsession with rockets
CNN's Jethro Mullen contributed to this report.

text:
President Obama announced Friday that NATO will develop a missile defense system to safeguard most of Europe and the United States.
The agreement, according to the president, followed a year of discussions to determine the best ways to coordinate efforts to protect members of the 61-year-old alliance.
The system would be strong enough to cover the entire territory and European populations of NATO, as well as the United States, Obama told journalists in Lisbon, Portugal.
The missile defense plan provides a role for all our allies in response to the threats of our times, the president said. It shows our determination to protect our citizens from the threat of ballistic missiles.
Obama addressed journalists on the first day of what he promised would be a historic summit with leaders from all 28 NATO member countries, as well as Russia. By the end of Saturday, the alliance aimed to produce a set of new initiatives aimed at revitalizing and redirecting NATO 20 years after the end of the Cold War.
NATO Secretary General Anders Fogh Rasmussen announced on Friday that the Heads of State had agreed on a new mission statement, calling it the alliance's road map for the next 10 years. The development of this so-called strategic concept had been one of the main priorities of the meeting, which Rasmussen considered last month to be one of the most important summits in the history of our partnership.
This strategic concept confirms the commitment of NATO members to defend each other against the attack, and that will never change, Rasmussen said in Lisbon. But it also modernises the way NATO defends itself in the 21st century.
The document, prepared on the basis of recommendations made by a panel led by former United States Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, sought to take advantage of NATO's work in Afghanistan to redefine the alliance as a global actor who would work with regional partners to combat threats outside Europe.
Under the new plan, NATO will strengthen its role in counterinsurgency efforts, as well as in the stabilization and reconstruction of key countries, according to Rasmussen. The defence alliance will also develop a permanent capacity to train local security forces and create a civilian arm to deal with other nations and groups.
Obama added Friday that NATO, under Rasmussen, was also looking for ways to deal with threats such as improvised explosives and cyber defenses, all at the service of the commitment that an attack on a NATO member is an attack on everyone.
Afghanistan will be at the forefront and center of Saturday's agenda, with NATO members working with others who have committed resources to the nation and its government to align our approach, according to Obama. He said that this includes the transition of Afghan forces from 2011 to 2014, taking over the security and governance mission in the country and forging a long-term partnership beyond that.
Russia's relationship with NATO and the United States is also a central issue on Saturday.
Obama said that from then on, NATO will work with Russia to build our cooperation with them in this area... recognizing that we share many of the same threats.
In an exclusive interview with Chris Lawrence of CNN, Georgian President Mikhail Saakashvili said he hoped that Russia's deeper association with NATO would make Moscow take a more civilized approach to dealing with its neighbors.
Russian troops have occupied Georgian territory since their invasion in 2008. Saakashvili, whose country has tried to join NATO has stalled for several years, said he hoped the alliance's involvement would push Russia to withdraw its troops from Georgia.
Once Russia becomes less paranoid, more cooperative, more self-confident in a more pleasant way -- because I think many things have emerged from its almost paranoid sense of insecurity -- hopefully Russia's small neighbors will feel safer, said Saakashvili, who met Obama on Friday.
Obama reiterated his belief that the U.S. Congress should approve the new START nuclear control treaty, which the U.S. and Russia agreed to last spring but which has not been ratified by the legislatures of any nation. Republicans in the U.S. Senate They have delayed a vote on START, citing a heavy workload, in the stupid session before a new Congress arrives next year, and concern for the strength of the US nuclear arsenal.
Obama said on Friday that NATO leaders had called for the approval of the treaty -- that, among other things, it would restart mutual nuclear inspections and limit the arsenal in the two countries -- critical to European and global security.
The failure to ratify—LSB—this treaty—RSB—will jeopardize the substantial progress that has been made in advancing our nuclear security and our partnership with Russia, Obama said.
The search for a new mandate for the entire alliance comes at a time when 16 of the 28 NATO members have announced cuts in defense spending. NATO officials said leaders are expected to agree at the summit on a list of the top 10 spending priorities, including helicopters, transfer aircraft, technology to combat improvised explosive devices, and increased medical capacity.
The outcome of the war in Afghanistan is intrinsically linked to the future of the NATO alliance, suggested a new analysis of the RAND Corporation. The report, released on Friday, warns that U.S. leadership in the war could undermine any future will to fight together if necessary.
In an alliance that finds consensus building is fundamental, having a clearly eclipsed partner all the others highlights the real limits of the transatlantic alliance, the report said.
The difficulty and duration of the engagement will weigh on the decisions of the alliance members to intervene or help in the future.
The scope of NATO's future functions abroad may be more limited, such as focusing on humanitarian assistance or on training, advice and assistance to nations seeking support. While these efforts may involve long-term commitments, they could not engage combat forces, RAND authors Andrew Hoehn and Sarah Harting wrote.
The new strategic concept will cite the current security challenges facing NATO members in the twenty-first century, such as terrorism, cyber war and piracy.
Rasmussen has encouraged NATO members to be more agile to respond to the threats of the twenty-first century and to continue investing in military technology despite the global economic recession. He urged allies to reduce fat, not military spending on muscle and pool.
The U.S. is pushing for a realignment of military spending priorities.
We have proposed and hope to have accepted a set of capabilities that the alliance, in a time of diminishing resources, will decide that it should finance, the United States. NATO Ambassador Ivo Daalder told reporters earlier this week. These are capabilities that deal with ongoing operations in Afghanistan, but also capabilities to address the threats of the twenty-first century, including strengthening our cyberdefences and adopting the deployment of missile defences to protect European territory and populations from the growing threat of ballistic missiles.
Obama will also hold a summit with European Union leaders, trying to reaffirm a partnership with Europe that many believe has drifted as the United States expands its partnerships in Asia. Employment and economic growth are expected to lead the agenda at a time of growing tension between the United States and European countries on the way to fixing the global economy.
While the U.S. has pressed to stimulate economic expansion with more public spending, many European allies are tightening their belts.
The future of some 80,000 US military forces in Europe will also be discussed. European leaders are looking for Obama to keep U.S. troops at their current levels, although the Obama administration has urged Europe to share more the burden of its own defense.
Adam Levine of CNN contributed to this report.

text:
Five exotic animals once owned by a man from Zanesville, Ohio, who released dozens of animals last year before committing suicide will be returned to the man's widow on Friday, the Ohio Department of Agriculture said.
Two spotted leopards, two macaque monkeys and a brown bear will be returned to Marian Thompson, widow of farmer Terry Thompson. In October he threw a big scare when he released 50 potentially dangerous animals from his farm before shooting himself.
Of the 50 animals Thompson released, 48 were killed by law enforcement, while two primates were killed by the other animals, zoo officials said.
Last fall in Ohio: Wild animals loose
The five animals that were returned to Marian Thompson were never released from their cages by her late husband. A sixth unreleased animal, a leopard, died in January at the Columbus Zoo and Aquarium, where all of Thompson's remaining animals had been housed for custody since the incident.
A state review committee concluded Monday that animals are free of dangerously infectious or contagious diseases. The finding required officials to lift a quarantine imposed on a movement in October to delay their return.
State officials said they were concerned that Marian Thompson said he would put the remaining five animals in the same cages that used to live on his Zanesville farm.
This raises concerns, as it has indicated that cages have not been repaired, and has repeatedly refused to allow animal welfare experts to assess whether conditions are safe for animals and sufficient to prevent them from escaping and endangering the community, said Erica Pitchford, spokesman for the Ohio Department of Agriculture.
State officials do not have the legal power to inspect cages before animals are returned, but they expect the local sheriff to seek a court order to inspect the farm to ensure the safety of animals and the public, Pitchford said.
Thompson had not allowed local police to enter the farm to check the pens, Muskingum County Sheriff Matthew Lutz told CNN Monday.
Thompson's lawyer did not immediately respond to a CNN call for comment.
Members are ready to deal with any problem with the animals returned, Lutz said.
“We have the zoo on fast dial,” Lutz said. If they push us to do what we had to do last time, we'd take care of it.
In April, the Ohio Senate passed legislation that would tighten rules for the private ownership of exotic animals and is now being heard in the House of Representatives. Zoo officials encourage legislators to quickly pass a bill to ensure public safety and protect animal welfare, the Columbus Zoo and Aquarium said in a press release.
Terry Thompson died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound on October 18, shortly after opening cages and opening the fences of the farm that kept his menagerie private of lions, tigers, bears, wolves and monkeys.
The authorities, which had no access to tranquilizing weapons, killed two wolves, six black bears, two brown bears, nine male lions, eight female lions, three mountain lions and 18 Bengal tigers.
Thompson's property is about two miles from Zanesville, which is east of Columbus along Interstate 70. The 62-year-old boy had been released from a federal prison three weeks earlier after pleading guilty to possession of illegal firearms, including five fully automatic firearms.
John Fricke and Chuck Johnston of CNN contributed to this report.

text:
For centuries, Timbuktu has existed in the western imagination as a motto for the most exotic and far-conceivable place.
Located at the southern end of the Sahara, it acquired almost mythical status in distant countries because of its inaccessibility fable, and because of the tales of the dazzling material and intellectual wealth found there.
The intrigued visitors continue to be attracted by the treasures that survive the medieval golden age of the city as an important academic, religious and mercantile center - its great mud mosques, and hundreds of thousands of academic manuscripts in public and private collections.
The city, today part of present-day Mali and known as the city of 333 saints by the Sufi imams, sheikhs and scholars buried there, was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1988.
But there are fears that this carefully preserved legacy may be threatened by armed rebel groups that have invaded the old city this month, in a vacuum left by the retreating Malian government forces.
Irina Bokova, Director General of UNESCO, has called on groups to respect and protect the city's heritage. The extraordinary architectural wonders of Timbuktu land that are the great mosques of Djingareyber, Sankore and Sidi Yahia, must be safeguarded, he said.
Together with the 16 cemeteries and mausoleums of the site, they are essential for the preservation of the identity of the people of Mali and of our universal heritage.
Timbuktu, which has a population of about 50,000, is in the hands of at least two rival groups that have participated in a northern uprising against the Malian government, based in the southern capital of Bamako.
One is Ansar Dine, a Salafist Islamist group seeking to enforce Sharia law. The other, the National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad (LRB-MNLA-RRB), has been fighting for an independent homeland for the Tuareg nomadic people in the north of the country, and earlier this month unilaterally proclaimed independence for the region they call Azawad.
Following the overthrow of Libyan President Moammar Gaddafi, many Tuaregs who had been fighting for Gaddafi's forces would have returned to northern Mali, bringing their weapons with them. Last month, a Tuareg uprising triggered a military coup against Mali's president, Amadou Toumani Toure, by unsatisfied officials with the government's efforts to end the insurrection. But in the disorder that followed the coup, the rebels seized large areas of the north.
Martin van Vliet, a researcher at the Centre for African Studies in Leiden, the Netherlands, said that although Timbuktu was no longer a city of vital economic or military importance, it stood out as an important prize for the rebels because of its symbolic significance.
The group that controls Timbuktu controls the symbolic capital of the entire region, because it is so well known throughout the world. If you control that city, you'll know.
Historically, the legend of Timbuktu began to spread throughout the medieval world when the emperor of Mali made his pilgrimage to Mecca through Cairo in 1324, and dazzled those who encountered the gold his party carried.
In the early 16th century, reports of the city on the sand, then part of the Songhay Empire, leaked back to Europe through Moorish diplomat and writer Leo Africanus, adding to the almost mythical status of the city as African El Dorado.
Becoming the first European to reach the city later became an obsession for Western explorers, many of whom perished in the sands of the desert. In 1824, the Geographical Society of Paris even offered a reward for the first European to perform the feat.
Two years later, however, the person who did it found a disaster. Scottish explorer Gordon Laing survived an attack by Tuareg nomads on his way to Timbuktu, only to discover upon his arrival that his wealth had greatly diminished since his heyday. Laing stayed in town for a month, then was killed two days after leaving.
During its golden age, Timbuktu was a thriving desert trading city at the heart of major trade routes of gold and salt, and an important intellectual and spiritual center, which played a key role in the spread of Islam in Africa. Islamic scholars traveled great distances to study at the city university, which had 25,000 students during its zenith, and was composed of three mosques.
The mosques of Sankore, Sidi Yahia and Djingarei-ber, built from mud and wood bricks in the characteristic Sudanese-Sahelian architectural style, have been maintained and remain the main attractions of the city today. The latter, the oldest in Timbuktu, was built in the early 14th century, while the Sankore, during its heyday, is said to have the largest collection of books in Africa since the Alexandria Library of ancient times.
Timbuktu in the 14th to 16th centuries was an important university city where many manuscripts were produced referring to knowledge of astronomy, economics, religion, mathematics, physics and medicine, said Lazare Eloundou, head of the African unit of the UNESCO World Heritage Centre.
Understanding the other significant component of Timbuktu ' s heritage, this immense trove of academic manuscripts -- estimated at hundreds of thousands -- remains in the city in state and private collections.
For generations, local families have protected fragile manuscripts, some of which date back to the 13th century, from invaders. Fearing that those responsible for the current riots may plunder or destroy the treasures, librarians and curators are making efforts to hide the texts or remove them from the city safely. Although local library offices have been reported to have been looted by gunmen, significant loss of documents has not yet been reported, according to Eloundou.
We're still worried about what might happen in case there's a fight. “We are concerned about the risk of damage,” Eloundou said. Nor do we know what the reaction of Islamist groups will be with regard to manuscripts.
He said that the city's heritage was very important to the locals, as a source of cultural pride, but also of income. Even if the city's treasures survived unscathed, they lost because of the uprising as it could sink the region into isolation once again. In addition, it is estimated that 200,000 people have been displaced by the uprising in the region as a whole.
The fact that this part of the country has been taken over by the Tuareg rebellion and Islamist groups do not allow more tourists to visit, and communities depend heavily on tourist revenues, he said. This is really going to affect their lives.

text:
The theory of sets, as a separate mathematical discipline, begins in the work of Georg Cantor. One might say that the set theory was born in late 1873, when it made the amazing discovery that the linear continuum, that is, the real line, is not accounting, which means that its points cannot be counted using natural numbers. So, even though the set of natural numbers and the set of real numbers are both infinite, there are more real numbers than there are natural numbers, which opened the door to the investigation of the different sizes of infinity. See the post on the early development of set theory for a discussion of the origin of set-theoretic ideas and their use by different mathematicians and philosophers before and around Cantor's time.
According to Cantor, two sets A and B have the same size, or cardinality, if they are debatable, that is, the elements of A can be put in a one-to-one correspondence with the elements of B. Thus, the set N of natural numbers and the set R of real numbers have different cardinalities. In 1878 Cantor formulated the famous Continuum Hypothesis (CH), which states that each infinite set of real numbers is accounting, that is, it has the same cardinality as N, or it has the same cardinality as R. In other words, there are only two possible sizes of infinite sets of real numbers. CH is the most famous problem in set theory. Cantor himself devoted much effort to her, and so did many other leading mathematicians of the first half of the 20th century, such as Hilbert, who listed the CH as the first problem in his famous list of 23 unresolved mathematical problems presented in 1900 at the Second International Congress of Mathematicians, in Paris. Attempts to test the CH led to great discoveries in set theory, such as the theory of constructible sets, and the technique of forcing, which demonstrated that the CH cannot be tested or refuted from the usual axioms of set theory. To this day, the CH remains open.
At first, some inconsistencies, or paradoxes, arose from a naïve use of the notion of whole; in particular, from the deceptively natural assumption that each property determines a set, namely, the set of objects that have property. One example is Russell's paradox, also known as Zermelo:
consider ownership of sets if they are not members of themselves. If the property determines a set, call it A, then A is a member of itself if and only if A is not a member of itself.
Thus, some collections, such as the collection of all sets, the collection of all ordinal numbers, or the collection of all cardinal numbers, are not sets. Such collections are called appropriate classes.
To avoid paradoxes and put them on a firm basis, the established theory had to be axiomized. The first axiomization was due to Zermelo (1908) and came as a result of the need to explain the basic theoretical principles underlying his proof of Cantor's well-ordered Principle. Zermelo's axiomization avoids Russell's paradox by means of the separation axiom, which is formulated as quantification of set properties, and therefore is a second-order statement. The additional work of Skolem and Fraenkel led to the formalization of the separation axiom in terms of first-order formulas, rather than the informal notion of ownership, as well as the introduction of the replacement axiom, which is also formulated as an axiom scheme for first-order formulas (see section below). Replacement axiom is necessary for the proper development of the theory of ordinals and transfinite cardinals, using transfinite recursion (see Section 3). It is also necessary to prove the existence of such simple sets as the set of hereditary finite sets, that is, those finite sets whose elements are finite, whose elements are also finite, etc. ; or to prove basic theoretical facts such as that each set is contained in a transitive set, that is, a set containing all the elements of its elements (see Mathias 2001 for the weaknesses of the Zermelo set theory). An additional addition, by von Neumann, of the Foundation's axiom, led to the standard set theory axiom system, known as the Zermelo-Fraenkel axioms plus the Axiom of Choice, or ZFC.
Other axiomatizations of set theory, such as those of von Neumann-Bernays-Gödel (NBG), or Morse-Kelley (MK), also allow a formal treatment of appropriate classes.

text:
It was after the robotic hummingbird flew around the auditorium -- and after a speaker talked about the hypersonic plane that could fly from New York to the West Coast in 11 minutes -- that things got really nervous.
Vijay Kumar, an engineering professor at the University of Pennsylvania, showed the more than 1,300 attendees at last week's TED conference several videos in which fleets of small flying robots carried out a series of intricate manufacturing, working together on tasks without colliding or interfering with the flight capabilities of others.
It seemed that, at least for some in the audience, a bridge had been crossed into a new era of technology, one that could change the way we think about robots and their application to fields such as construction, shipping and emergency response.
Kumar's devices - LRB - call them Autonomous Agile Air Robots -RRB- cooperated in the construction of simple structures and demonstrated that they were able to enter a building for the first time and quickly build a map that would allow evaluating and responding to a structural collapse or fire.
He held a robot, designed by his students Daniel Mellinger and Alex Kushleyev, which weighs just over a tenth of a pound and is about 8 inches in diameter. The device has four rotors; when they rotate at the same speed, the robot floats. If you increase the speed, Kumar explained, the robot flies up. Rotating a rotor faster than the opposite causes the robot to tilt. You can also turn around several times without losing your ability to fly and you can regain your stability when you launch into the air.
Robots are able to learn trajectories and manipulations that can literally allow them to fly through rings -- and other confined spaces.
When robots form in a flotilla, they calculate -LRB- a hundred times per second -RRB- and maintain a safe distance between them. He showed a video of 20 robots flying in a variety of formations -- and moving through obstacles -- inches from each other without interfering with the stability of their neighbors.
To finish his presentation, he showed a video, created by his students in three days, of nine flying robots playing the theme of James Bond in musical instruments.
TED began in the 1980s with the intention of focusing on technology, entertainment, and design, and its lectures are usually depleted, attracting a high-achievement audience willing to pay $7,500 to attend. TED, a non-profit organization, makes many of the conversations freely available on your site. -LRB-CNN has an association with TED in which it regularly publishes some TED talks -RRB-.
TED aims to offer state-of-the-art technology at its conferences, and this year's event, labeled Full Spectrum, was no exception. However, the difficult balance between technology and the social problems it generates seemed more prominent than ever when speakers came on the stage to give their talks -LRB- and be filmed by eight HD cameras for possible web viewing -RRB-.
In Tuesday's first session, there was a sharp contrast between the unlimited optimism that a technological solution could be found for each of Earth's problems and a vision of a planet that was headed for destruction because of humanity's inability to control its inventions and its consumption.
Paul Gilding, former head of Greenpeace, stated that the Earth is full, full of us, full of our things, full of our waste and full of our demands, and warned of a severe and potentially violent interruption in the future, as the calculation comes for a planet that lives beyond its means. The idea that the planet can sustain 9 billion people without making disturbing changes is wrong, he said.
Peter Diamandis, founder of the X Prize, responded with a catalogue of the ways in which technology has radically improved our lives -- it has lengthened human life, conquered many deadly diseases, expanded economic opportunities and made possible a global network of communication, already connecting 2 billion people, with 3 billion more on the way to logging in this decade.
Technology is a liberating force of resources, he said, maintaining that a planet bathed in solar energy and covered with water does not lack the ingredients for a productive life.
However, for every technological evangelist, there was a warning note sounded by other speakers.
NASA scientist James Hansen, one of the leading global climate change alert voices due to carbon emissions, presented an urgent case to take action to address the effects of economic activity before ice caps melt and cities flood with dramatic sea-level increases.
But a professor at MIT, Donald Sadoway, offered reasons to hope that the use of carbon-free solar and wind energy could become much more widespread through a new battery technology that he and his students are developing to store energy for use at a time when the wind stops and the sun sets. Sadoway, whose work has attracted an investment from Bill Gates, said the successful use of his liquid metal battery could reduce the need for new power plants burning fossil fuels.
Regina Dugan, who demonstrated robotic hummingbird and runs the Defense Advanced Research Project Agency, spoke of research on a prosthetic arm controlled by single thoughts, robust cars built with lighter metals than polystyrene foam and a robot that can function as a cheetah.
TED.com: Susan Cain in the Power of Introverts
And yet technology did not seem to have a solution to the problems highlighted by Bryan Stevenson, director of the Equal Justice Initiative. He spoke of the increase in the number of Americans imprisoned from 300,000 40 years ago to 2.3 million today, the large number of Black Americans who have been permanently deprived of their voting capacity due to persecution for low-level drug crimes and the question he said is raised by the death penalty -- not if criminals deserve to die, but if America as a society deserves to kill.
Stevenson's talk provoked a standing ovation -- and the next day, after TED curator Chris Anderson appealed for funds, Anderson said that $1.12 million had been raised for Stevenson's nonprofit organization on the spot.
For a long time digital technology enthusiast, MIT professor Sherry Turkle spoke of being on the cover of Wired magazine when his book Life on the Screen was published in the 1990s. In his new, darker book, Alone Together, he writes about daily family and social relationships put at risk by the compulsion to constantly interact with mobile devices as a substitute for face-to-face interaction.
People write during board meetings, buy and text during class, and even text during funerals, he said. Technology gives us the illusion of being constantly in contact with people, yet we evade the real demands of friendship. And Turkle noted that Japanese researchers are developing robots to provide care to the elderly and children.
As to emphasize his point, a day after his talk, the Danish scientist Henrik Scharfe demo'ed Geminoid-DK, a surprisingly realistic robot version of himself. Although their movement and speech are limited, robot technology is likely to evolve rapidly.
And so it seemed like it wasn't just a joke that Scharfe said, "In ten years, I'll be home having a beer in Denmark and the robot will come to TED for a chat.
Scharfe said after his talk that he recognized the dangers Turkle was talking about, but thought the robot's development was worth it.
This can never be about replacing the human being, he said in his talk, but about using technology to understand the whole spectrum of human being.

text:
According to Hartmann, impartial philosophical research moves through the three main stages of phenomenological, aporetical and theoretical development. The first stage is descriptive and requires the systematic collection of all available evidence relevant to what is under consideration. Most of the time, descriptions end in conflicting thesis, often in the form of aporias. More than anyone else, Hartmann rehabilitates the value of aporias (for two recent evaluations of Hartmann's aporetic method see Schlittmaier 2011 and Rescher 2011). The Apostries themselves are informative and should not be forced to disappear by fiat decisions, such as an a priori assumption about the general consistency of reality or the assumption that we have direct and transparent access to reality. The last phase of the philosophical method consists of using as few metaphysical assumptions as possible for the systematic coordination of the results of the first two phases (E, S).
Metaphysical assumptions are necessary for the task of incorporating aporias into a framework capable of making sense of them. Since metaphysical assumptions are not directly supported by descriptive data, it is advisable to keep them to a minimum, or to assume the weakest metaphysical assumptions possible.
An original way to distinguish between ontology and metaphysics underlies the third stage of theoretical development. Ontology, for Hartmann, refers to what may be subsumed into at least partially representative categories (see section 3 below). Two main consequences derive from this view of ontology: firstly, ontology is primarily a category theory, in the sense that all ontological distinctions have the form of categories (A.Intro1), and secondly, science in all its branches is the most successful and powerful ally of ontology. More precisely, for Hartmann, science is ontological in all its ramifications (G.37a). This rather disagrees with the general view of science as an eminently epistemological matter. This is one of the themes on which Hartmann is firmly departing from the Kantian legacy, to be precise, the neokantian. The assertion that the main orientation of science is ontological immediately implies that scientific categories are other specifications and subdivisions of ontological categories. In other words, contact with science is a characteristic feature of category theory, and therefore of ontology (A.Intro1). The philosopher's task is to develop the first and most general articulations of category theory, while scientists deal with their later specifications.

text:
Socialism is best defined in contrast to capitalism, since socialism has emerged as much as a critical challenge to capitalism, as a proposal to overcome and replace it. In the classical Marxist definition (G.A. Cohen 2000a: chap. 3; Fraser 2014: 57-9), capitalism implies certain relations of production. These include certain forms of control over the productive forces—the labor force that workers deploy in production and means of production such as natural resources, tools and spaces they use to produce goods and services—and certain social patterns of economic interaction that typically correlate with that control. Capitalism shows the following constitutive characteristics:
(i) Most of the means of production are privately owned and controlled.
(ii) Persons legally possess their labour force. (Here capitalism differs from slavery and feudalism, under which systems some individuals have the right to control, either wholly or partially, the labor power of others).
(iii) Markets are the main mechanism for allocating inputs and outputs from production and determining how companies ' productive surplus is used, in particular whether or not it is consumed or invested.
An additional feature that is typically present where i)–(iii) is maintained is that:
(iv) There is a class division between capitalists and workers, which implies specific relations (e.g., negotiation, conflict or subordination) between these classes, and the configuration of the labour market, the enterprise and the broader political process.
The existence of wage labor is often seen by socialists as a necessary condition for a society to be counted as capitalist (Schweickart 2002 [2011: 23]). Typically, workers (as opposed to capitalists) must sell their workforce to earn a living. They sell it to the capitalists, who (as opposed to the workers) control the means of production. The capitalists tend to subordinate the workers in the production process, since the capitalists have an asymmetrical decision-making power over what is produced and how it is produced. Capitalists also own production and sell it on the market, and control most of the investment flow within the economy. The relationship between capitalists and workers may involve cooperation, but also conflict relations (e.g. with regard to wages and working conditions). This more or less antagonistic power relationship between capitalists and workers develops in a number of areas, within production itself and in the broader political process, since in the economic and political domains decisions are made about who does what and who gets what.
There are possible economic systems that would present exceptions, in which (iv) is not maintained although (i), (ii) and (iii) all are obtained. Examples of this are a society of independent producers of commodities or a democracy of ownership (in which individuals or groups of workers own enterprises). However, there is a debate about what is feasible—accessible and stable—that is in a modern economic environment (O’Neill 2012).
Another characteristic that is also typically seen as the emergence where (i)-(iii) hold is this:
(v) Production is mainly oriented towards capital accumulation (i.e. economic production is mainly profit oriented rather than human needs). (G.A. Cohen 2000a; Roemer 2017).
In contrast to capitalism, socialism can be defined as a type of society in which, at least, (i) it becomes (i*):
(i) Most of the means of production are under social and democratic control.
Changes with respect to characteristics (ii), (iii) and (v) are heatedly debated among socialists. As for (ii), socialists hold the view that workers must control their labour power, but many do not assert the type of absolute rights of libertarian property in the labour power that would, for example, prevent taxes or other forms of compulsory contribution to meet the basic needs of others (G.A. Cohen 1995). As for (iii), there is a recent flourishing literature on "market socialism", which we discussed below, where proposals are put forward to create a socialist economy but which, however, has extensive markets. Finally, with regard to v), although most socialists agree that, due to competitive pressures, capitalists are obliged to seek the maximization of profits, some are puzzled if when they do this, it is "thank you and fear" and not the generation of resources to make others, in addition to them, better placed, which is the dominant, most basic impulse and, therefore, the degree to which the maximization of profits must be considered a problematic phenomenon normatively. (See Steiner 2014, in contrast to G.A. Cohen 2009, discussing the case of capitalists accumulating capital to give it away through charity.) In addition, some socialists argue that the pursuit of profit in a socialist market economy is not inherently suspicious (Schweickart 2002 [2011]). Most socialists, however, tend to find the motive for problematic gain.
An important point about this definition of socialism is that socialism is not equivalent to statism, and it could be said to be in conflict with it. (i*) involves the expansion of social power, power based on the ability to mobilize voluntary cooperation and collective action, unlike state power, power based on the control of the creation of rules and the imposition of rules on a territory, as well as economic power, power based on the control of material resources (Wright 2010). If a state controls the economy but in turn is not democratically controlled by the individuals involved in economic life, what we have is some form of statism, not socialism (see also Arnold n.d. in Other Internet Resources (OIR); Dardot & Laval 2014).

text:
When Chris Christie praises President Barack Obama as outstanding and incredibly supportive, you know something extraordinary has happened.
Obama updated on Sandy; praised by Christie
In this case, it was once in a lifetime superstorm Sandy, which caused the Frankish Republican governor of New Jersey to declare a state of emergency and seek federal help for widespread devastation.
Interviewed on Tuesday at NBC, Christie described Obama's response as outstanding, and told CNN that the president had been incredibly understanding and helpful to our state.
This is much more important than any election, Christie told Piers Morgan of CNN tonight.
Obama has been exceptional in dealing with this and I hope to see him tomorrow so he can see for himself what this hurricane has done to my state, Christie said Tuesday night.
Such effusive praise from a frequent critic of Obama and a strong supporter of Republican presidential challenger Mitt Romney put the campaign magnifying glass on a key electoral issue -- the role of the federal government -- a week before the November 6 vote.
Photos: Superstorm sequels Sandy
He also focused attention on how Romney would handle such a disaster if he were to defeat Obama in what is expected to be a very close election.
On Tuesday, the Republican Party candidate showed little inclination to address the issue. At a campaign event, Romney switched to a storm relief effort in Ohio, ignoring reporters' questions about whether he supported the role of the Federal Emergency Management Agency in disaster relief.
Instead, he focused his comments on supporters who donated relief supplies to storm victims in ways that contribute to meeting the overall need.
“We can’t solve all the problems with our effort this morning,” Romney said, adding one of the things you learn in life is that you make the difference you can, and you can’t always solve all the problems yourself.
Romney in the aftermath of the storm: People are suffering '
Romney's Democratic critics and his fellow formula -- the conservative House Budget President, Paul Ryan of Wisconsin -- argue their proposals to cut government spending and provide extensive tax cuts without generating more government revenue will end up damaging the economy and increasing the federal deficit.
Photos: New York recovers from Sandy
In particular, Obama's campaign challenges Romney's claim that increasing economic growth from tax cuts combined with shifting current federal responsibilities to states, the private sector, and humanitarian and charitable agencies can balance the budget.
Last year, Romney argued in a Republican presidential debate in New Hampshire that cutting federal spending should be based on prioritizing what is absolutely necessary and eliminating the rest.
Asked by CNN moderator John King if disaster relief efforts should be delivered to states, Romney said that every time you get a chance to take something from the federal government and send it back to states, that's the right direction. And if you can go even further and send it back to the private sector, that's even better.
Instead of thinking about the federal budget, which we should cut, we should ask ourselves the opposite. What should we keep? Romney added. We should take everything we're doing at the federal level and say, what are the things we're doing that we don't have to do? And those things we have to stop doing, because we're borrowing $1.6 billion more this year than we're getting.
King approached to ask if Romney specifically referred to disaster relief, a topic on the news at the time following a deadly Joplin, Missouri, tornado, and Romney continued: We cannot afford to do those things without endangering the future of our children. It is simply immoral, in my opinion, that we continue to accumulate increasing debts and pass them on to our children, knowing very well that we will all be dead and missing before it is paid. It doesn't make any sense.
Romney: States must manage emergency management
With Hurricane Sandy then on the East Coast on Monday, Romney's comments on the debate 16 months earlier became a topic of political discussion, and Romney's campaign issued a statement in response.
Sandy reminds us of climate change and other neglected issues of the campaign
Governor. Romney believes that states should be in charge of emergency management in response to storms and other natural disasters in their jurisdictions, spokesman Amanda Henneberg said. As the first responders, States are in the best position to help affected individuals and communities, and to direct resources and assistance to where they are most needed. This includes assistance from the federal government and FEMA.
Henneberg added another sentence to Tuesday's statement, saying that a Romney-Ryan administration will always ensure that disaster financing is there for those who need it. Period.
Craig Fugate, administrator of the emergency management agency, told reporters Tuesday that the agency had $3.6 billion left in its disaster relief fund. The agency works with state and local authorities, as well as with the American Red Cross and other agencies to help disaster victims rent temporary housing, repair their homes, obtain loans to cover the losses of small businesses and farms, as well as help clean up storm debris, including hazardous materials.
Vice President Joe Biden, meanwhile, said Tuesday that the federal response to Sandy was working as supposed, and highlighted reporters in Ohio what he described as unprecedented cooperation between municipal, state, and federal authorities and agencies.
A White House statement also emphasized such cooperation, noting that Obama spoke over the phone with a number of Republican and Democratic governors and mayors of storm-affected states.
Impact of Sandy: State by State
Romney has made political dysfunction in Washington a target of his campaign, blaming Obama for what he calls failed leadership in being unable to forge a deficit reduction agreement with Republicans.
Democrats blame Republicans for what they claim they are unwilling to compromise, and Obama and Biden's focus on cooperation seemed to be aimed in part at demonstrating the administration's ability to do things.
The question of the size and scope of the federal government is at the heart of both campaigns.
Obama and Democrats argue that rights programs such as Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid are vital to the social contract to provide taxpayers with basic needs, and that the government also has a role to play in education and technological development while providing services such as national defense and disaster relief.
Republicans, driven by the party's conservative wing, call for immediate steps to clear the chronic budget deficits and growing federal debt that they say threaten national security and stability. They want to reduce the size of the government and reduce taxes while reforming rights through partial privatization, reducing and delaying some benefits and other measures.
Sensitive issues such as disaster relief generally benefit the Democrats and their support for the government's benefits, especially in times of crisis when the images of victims who suffer dominate the waves.
Superstorm Sandy breaks records
Obama has avoided any direct political conversation in the last few days when the huge storm approached the east coast, cancelling the campaign events and focusing his attention on the administration's response. In statements on Monday and Tuesday about the storm and its aftermath, he stressed the need for a collective response and at the same time made sure to point out the federal role in relief efforts.
We have been able to get more than 1,000 FEMA officers instead, pre-positioned, said the president. We've been able to get supplies, food, medicine, water, emergency generators, to ensure that hospitals and law enforcement offices are able to stay operational while they're out there responding.
It also sounded like a main theme of the campaign by assuring those hit hardest by the storm that their administration and the entire nation were with them.
This is a difficult time for millions of people along the east coast, but the U.S. is tougher and we are tougher because we unite, leave no one behind, make sure we respond as a nation, Obama said.
Obama visits the Red Cross: Storm is not over yet
About the same time he spoke, the White House announced that Obama will travel to New Jersey on Wednesday, where he will join the government. Christie seeing the damage of the storm, talking to citizens recovering from the storm and thanking the first responders who put their lives at risk to protect their communities.
While the president and one of Romney's main supporters will be photographed together in response to the disaster, Romney is scheduled to be in Florida for three campaign events.
How to help after superstorm
CNN's Rachel Streitfeld, Kevin Liptak, Tom Watkins and Mike M. Ahlers contributed to this report.

text:
Young Cubans are coming to use the first open and free Internet service known in the communist island nation, which has been made possible thanks to one of the most famous artists in Cuba. A modest cultural center in the capital, Havana, has suddenly become a rare source of free Wi-Fi. The renowned Cuban artist Kcho is providing the service. Perhaps more surprising, its spokesman said that the measure had been approved by the state telecommunications company, Etecsa.
The service is reported to be very slow, especially when the center is crowded. However, in a country where it is estimated that only 5 per cent of the population has unrestricted access to the Internet, a facility that is free and free of restrictions is being hailed as an unprecedented blessing.
The opportunity to click on international news websites, communicate with friends and family abroad and use sites like Facebook and Twitter has created a great buzz. “I come as many times as I can,” said 20-year-old Adonis Ortiz, while chatting on video with his father, who lives in the United States and hasn’t seen him in nine years.
The gradual loosening of the prolonged diplomatic and commercial freeze between the United States and Cuba is expected to bring US technological giants like Google and Apple to the Cuban market as soon as they are allowed. Meanwhile, Cuba has installed a high-speed fiber optic cable under the sea from Venezuela and Internet users have access to Chinese equipment.
Another estimate, that one quarter of Cubans have access to the Internet – still one of the lowest penetration rates in the Western Hemisphere – actually measures residents who use a restricted domestic intranet with only certain websites and limited email.
Kcho has offered public admission to his own personal Internet connection. But instead of this being the counter-revolutionary, or post-revolutionary, movement of a free-market rebel, Kcho may have been selected as the acceptable face of a regime that consents to the inevitable attraction of the Internet.
Kcho, who has close ties with the Cuban government, announced that his actions had been approved by the Ministry of Culture. The artist said he wanted to encourage Cubans to become familiar with the Internet. “It is only possible through the will to do so and absorb costs,” Kcho told Associated Press. “It’s expensive, but the profit is tremendous. I have something that's big and powerful. I can share it and I’m doing it.”
Kcho's real name is Alexis Leiva Machado.
He won international fame for his painting, sculpture and drawings after winning the grand prize at a major art biennial in South Korea. It is currently preparing for the Havana Biennial in May. Born in one of the outer islands of Cuba, he is known for contemporary art with rustic, coastal and patriotic themes and images.
In the downtown courtyard, technology experts millennials stay all day long in wicker chairs under a white canopy or just outside when it is full, banging on laptops and tablets or glued to their smartphones.
Cuba has some of the lowest connectivity rates on the planet, with restricted dialing and almost unknown broadband accounts at home, except in the case of foreigners who pay hundreds of dollars a month for service in a country where the average salary is between 17 and 20 dollars a month. It is estimated that Kcho is paying $900 a month to provide free Wi-Fi.
Since 2013, Cuban authorities have opened hundreds of internet rooms, where an hour online costs $4.50, at speeds far below those of Kcho's studio of about 2mbps. A 2014 report from Akamai Technologies found that average Internet connectivity speeds are around 10.5 mbps in the US. and 23.6 mbps in South Korea's world leader. Globally, the average was approximately 3.9mbps.
With dozens of users at a given time, the strength of Kcho's wi-fi signal is diluted. One user said that sometimes it happens in the middle of the night, when there's no one else around, and finds that it's incredibly fast.

text:
The mayor of the city of Kharkiv, in eastern Ukraine, was subjected to emergency surgery after being shot in the back, city officials and police said Monday, in the midst of continuing riots in the region.
The attack on Mayor Gennady Kernes occurred around noon local time, the official Kharkiv office website said. It was not immediately clear who was responsible for the shooting.
After a two-hour operation, Kernes was out of surgery, but in critical condition, the city office said.
The surgery was successful. His life-threatening condition is expected to continue for several days, a statement said. He was unconscious when he was taken to the hospital.
The online statement also said that a bullet casing was found at the scene.
Police said an investigation unit was trying to determine the circumstances of the shooting.
In a great challenge for the new Kiev leaders, armed rebels have captured cities and government buildings throughout eastern Ukraine and have a team of European supervisors as hostages.
Western nations accuse Moscow of supporting separatist gunmen who are occupying official buildings in cities across the region.
Penalties
On Monday the U.S. imposed sanctions on seven Russian government officials and 17 companies linked to Russian President Vladimir Putin in his latest action to punish Moscow for its actions in Ukraine.
The White House said the seven Russians, including two from Putin's inner circle, are now subject to a freeze on their assets in the United States and a travel ban to the United States.
In addition, the United States will refuse applications for export licences for high-tech items that could contribute to Russia's military capabilities. The Department of Commerce and the State Department will revoke any existing export license that meets these conditions, the White House said in a statement.
Sanctions are based on those already in force. We are moving forward with an expanded list of people, U.S. President Barack Obama told journalists in Manila, Philippines.
The move, Obama said, was to encourage Putin to walk, not just to talk about resolving the crisis in Ukraine.
If the last round of sanctions doesn't work, the next phase could target economic sectors like banking, Obama said.
The European Union also announced on Monday that it was imposing sanctions on 15 people who are responsible for actions that undermine or threaten the territorial integrity, sovereignty and independence of Ukraine. A list of the people targeted by the latest sanctions will be published on Tuesday and will enter into force at the same time, the Council of the European Union said. The sanctions will include the assets freeze and travel ban.
Defense Secretaries of the United States and Russia Speak
Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel spoke on the phone with Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu on Monday.
According to a Pentagon description of his conversation, Shoigu reiterated his assurance that Russian forces would not invade Ukraine. Hagel, Pengaton said, called for an end to what he described as Russia's destabilizing influence within Ukraine and warned that continued aggression would further isolate Russia and lead to more diplomatic and economic pressure.
The description of the call by the Russian government said that Shoigu definitively denied the unfounded allegations of the presence of Russian military intelligence and sabotage groups on Ukrainian territory and criticized what he called anti-Russian hysteria recently unleashed in the Western press.
He also criticized what he said as an unprecedented increase in the activity of U.S. and NATO troops in Eastern Europe near the Russian border, as described by the Russian government's call.
Ukrainian soldier dead
A homemade bomb exploded near Ukrainian soldiers in the eastern Donetsk region on Monday, killing one and wounding another, the Ukrainian Ministry of Defence said.
The death occurred days after Ukrainian forces said they killed five pro-Russian militants in an operation to clear the barricades near the city of Slavyansk last week. The police are investigating Monday's explosion, the Ministry of Defense said.
A CNN team covering a pro-Ukraine rally in Donetsk saw violence unfolding on Monday when pro-Russian separatists wielded batons beating protesters who said they wanted to see a united Ukraine.
Observer released
Pro-Russian separatists who maintained a team of European military observers in eastern Ukraine released one of the observers for medical reasons on Sunday, shortly after marching them to the cameras.
At least seven of the inspectors of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe appeared at a press conference organized by Vyacheslav Ponomarev, the self-declared mayor of Slavyansk, who referred to them as prisoners of war.
The released observer was from Sweden and had been suffering from diabetes, Ponomarev spokesperson Stella Khorosheva told CNN. Michael Bociurkiw, OSCE spokesman in Kiev, described it as a positive development.
The monitors were captured Friday outside Slavyansk, one of the points of conflict in the confrontation between the interim government of Ukraine and the pro-Russian factions defying their authority in the east. They said that although they have diplomatic status, they joined the Sunday press conference because the mayor asked them to.
Germany strongly criticized the group's appearance in the media.
The parade of OSCE observers and Ukrainian security forces as prisoners is abhorrent and a flagrant violation of their human dignity, Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier said in a statement.
He added that Russia had a duty to influence the separatists so that the other members of the mission could be released as soon as possible.
Putin has repeatedly criticized what he says is the use of force by Kiev against Ukrainian civilians.

text:
Glastonbury Festival is fighting the scourge of the plastic water bottle as part of a long-term strategy to become the most ecological outdoor music event in the world.
The festival organizers are aiming at the disposable bottle, one of the most striking symbols of shooting culture, which every year leaves the 900-acre Somerset site crowned in plastic, with an estimated million plastic bottles used during the festival.
Reusable stainless steel bottles will be delivered to 2,000 members of the road team and the band, with thousands more for sale to festival visitors, to stop relying on plastic bottles. The 140,000 entry holders are also urged to carry reusable bottles that can fill 400 taps of potable water splashed all over the site.
Lucy Smith, Glastonbury’s green theme organizer, said: “We have incredible water quality in the UK, but everyone is obsessed with drinking bottled water.”
He said the initiative precedes a plan for Glastonbury 2015 to replace all plastic beer glasses and covered with reusable items in an attempt to eradicate the legacy of plastic waste from the huge rural area.
Environmentalists estimate that 150 million tons of plastic waste currently pollute the planet and oceans, poisoning ecosystems and killing wildlife.
Ultimately, the festival organizers hope to make Glastonbury the world’s greenest festival, emulating the American’s Burning Man festival in the Black Rock Desert of Nevada, which is a “no trace” event, where people have to take everything they bring.
Glastonbury resellers are also being urged to travel to the site by public transport or try to share the car with friends. “We want to be as sustainable as we can. We do everything we can, but facing the litter of 140,000 people is a challenge. We can’t put containers everywhere,” Smith added.
Activists say plastic water bottles can take hundreds or even thousands of years to fully biodegrade, with their manufacturing exacerbating their negative ecological impact. Millions of barrels of oil are used in the manufacture of plastic bottles and the transportation of mineral water across the planet produces even more carbon emissions.
In general, it is estimated that 13 billion plastic water bottles are sold annually in the United Kingdom, but only one in five is said to be recycled.
Smith said that, instead of buying bottled water, festival attendees should take advantage of the water in the tap, which is being pulled out of huge underground reservoirs, instead of outdated water tanks providing heavily chlorinated drinking water. The charity WaterAid will also install water kiosks around the site, supplying reusable bottles and cups and offering free refills. In 2015, kiosks, based on those found in Africa, will double as DJ booths at night.
Organizers say that almost half of the waste left in the site was recycled in 2013 and add that in 2014 there will be 15,000 containers to recycle throughout the festival grounds.

Although it is occasionally suggested that a concern for self-awareness is a peculiarly modern phenomenon, originating in Descartes (Brinkmann 2005), it is in fact the subject of lively ancient and medieval debates, many of which prefigure early modern and contemporary concerns (Sorabji 2006). Aristotle, for example, affirms that a person must, in perceiving anything, also perceive his own existence (De Sensu 7.448a), a suggestive affirmation of the opinion that consciousness implies self-consciousness. Moreover, according to Aristotle, since the intellect takes the form of what is thought (Kahn 1992), it is “thinkable as are the objects of thought” (De Anima 3.4.430), a statement that was interpreted by Aristotle’s medieval commentators as the view that self-consciousness depends on an awareness of extra-mental things (Cory 2014: chap. 1; Owens 1988).
On the contrary, Platonic tradition, mainly through Augustine's influence, writing in the fourth and fifth centuries, is associated with the vision that the mind "gains self-knowledge" (On the Trinity 9.3; Matthew 1992; Cary 2000) by being present to itself. Therefore, in this view, self-consciousness does not require awareness of external things. In a similar line, in the 11th century, Avicena argues, through her experiment of the thought of the Flying Man, that a newly created person floating in a void, with all the senses disabled, would nevertheless be aware of himself. Thus, the self that one knows cannot be a bodily thing of which one is conscious through the senses (Kaukua & Kukkonen 2007; Black 2008; Kaukua 2015). In such views, and in contrast to the Aristotelian picture, basic self-consciousness is neither sensory in nature nor dependent on the consciousness of other things. This last statement was accepted by Aquinas, written in the 13th century, which can be seen as synthesizing aspects of Platonic and Aristotelian traditions (Cory 2014). Because not only does Aquinas affirm that there is a form of self-consciousness—consciousness that exists—for which “the mere presence of the mind suffices,” there is another form—consciousness of one’s essence—that, as Aristotle had affirmed, depends on knowing other things and therefore “the mere presence of the mind is not sufficient” (Summa 1, 87, 1; Kenny 1993: chap. 10).
This ancient and medieval debate about whether the mere presence of the mind is sufficient for self-consciousness is related to another about whether self-consciousness is in itself of a sensory character or, in other words, whether the self is perceptible or not. Aquino has sometimes been interpreted as a positive answer to this question, sometimes a negative answer (see Pasnau 2002: ch. 11, and Cory 2014: ch. 4, for divergent opinions). These topics were also discussed in several Indian debates (hindu, Jain and Buddhists) (Albahari 2006; Siderits, Thompson, & Zahavi 2013; Ganeri 2012a,b), with a variety of perspectives represented. For example, in the writing of the 11th-century writer Jain Prabhācandra, there appears an argument very similar to the argument of the Flying Man of Avicena for the possibility of self-consciousness without body consciousness (Ganeri 2012a: ch. 2), while several thinkers at the Advaita Vendānta school argue that there is no self-consciousness without incarnation (Ram-Prasad 2013). There were, therefore, extensive debates in the ancient and medieval period not only about the nature of self-consciousness, but also about its relationship with other aspects of the mind, especially sensory perception and body consciousness.

Halloween (also known as the eve of all holes) is a party that is celebrated in the United States on October 31 of each year, regardless of the day of the week on which this date falls. Although rooted in religion, Halloween today is mainly enjoyed by its decorations, costumes, sweets, treats, and general emotion, and is also enjoyed by most of them.
Before Halloween, many individuals carve a design in an orange pumpkin, or a solid and durable vegetable. Once a personally satisfying design is carved, a lit candle is usually placed inside a pumpkin, so it is a Jack-O-Lantern. At night, this design lights up against the darkness.
In addition to carving pumpkins, some celebrate Halloween by putting decorations. Supernatural figures (referred in this case to unnatural creatures typically based on fiction), including vampires, ghosts, werewolves, zombies, and more, generally represent most of these decorations. Bugs, spiders, cobwebs, tombstones, and anything else that can be considered creepy (or unusual and possibly terrifying) can also be found on Halloween, in the form of decoration.
Only some adults celebrate Halloween, and usually do so by attending parties. Conversely, the vast majority of children dress in suits (Halloween costumes can be based on anything, from the above-mentioned supernatural creatures to the stars of today's movies) and walk door-to-door in search of candy, a practice known as trick or candy, on Halloween. After knocking on a door (houses participating in Halloween usually leave a light on), one says, "Trick or Deal" and one piece (or pieces!) candy is given to him or her.

According to a new scientific study, temperature increases resulting from uncontrolled climate change will be at the most severe of those projected. The leading research scientist said that unless greenhouse gas emissions were cut, the planet would heat at least 4C to 2100, twice the level that governments around the world consider dangerous. Research indicates that fewer clouds form as the planet heats up, meaning that less sunlight is reflected in space, further increasing temperatures. The way clouds affect global warming has been the biggest mystery surrounding future climate change. Professor Steven Sherwood of the University of New South Wales in Australia, who led the new paper, said: “This study opens new paths twice: first, identifying what is controlling changes in the cloud and, second, strongly discounting the lower estimates of future global warming in favor of the highest and most harmful estimates.”
“The 4C would probably be catastrophic rather than simply dangerous,” Sherwood said. “For example, it would make life in much of the tropics difficult, if not impossible, and would ensure the eventual melting of the Greenland ice sheet and part of the Antarctic ice sheet,” with a sea level rise of many metres as a result.
Research is a “great advance” that halves uncertainty about how much warming is caused by increased carbon emissions, according to scientists who commented on the study, published in Nature magazine. Hideo Shiogama and Tomoo Ogura of the National Institute of Environmental Studies of Japan said that the explanation of how fewer clouds form as the world warms up was “convenient” and agreed that this indicated that future climate change would be greater than expected. But they said there were more challenges ahead to further reduce future temperature projections.
Scientists measure the sensitivity of the Earth's climate to greenhouse gases by estimating the increase in temperature that would be caused by a doubling of CO in the atmosphere compared to pre-industrial levels, as is likely to occur within 50 years, according to current trends. For two decades, these estimates have ranged between 1.5C and 5C: a wide range. The new investigation reduced that range to between 3C and 5C, examining closely the greatest cause of uncertainty: clouds.
The key was to ensure that the way clouds are formed in the real world was accurately represented in computer climate models, which are the only tool researchers have for predicting future temperatures. When water evaporates from the oceans, steam can rise more than nine miles to form rain clouds that reflect sunlight; or, it can rise only a few kilometers and drift back without forming clouds. In fact, both processes occur and climate models covering this complexity predicted future temperatures significantly higher than those that only include nine-mile-high clouds.
“Climate skeptics like to criticize climate models for being wrong and we’re the first to admit they’re not perfect,” Sherwood said. “But what we’re finding is that mistakes are being made by models that predict less warming, not by those who predict more.” He added: “Sceptics can also point to the ‘hiato’ of temperatures since the end of the 20th century, but there is increasing evidence that this inapplicably called hiato is not seen in other measures of the climate system and is almost temporary safe.”
The global average air temperature has increased relatively slowly from a high point in 1998 caused by the El Niño oceanic phenomenon, but observations show that heat is still trapped in increasing amounts by greenhouse gases, with more than 90 per cent disappearing in the oceans.
In addition, a study conducted in November 2013 suggested that “pause” could largely be an illusion resulting from the lack of temperature readings of polar regions, where warming is higher. Sherwood accepts the work of his team on the role of clouds cannot definitively rule out that future temperature increases are at the lower end of projections. “But,” he said, for that to be the case, “a new dimension would need to be invoked to the problem involving an important missing ingredient for which we currently have no evidence. Such a thing is not out of the question, but requires a lot of faith.” He added: “The increase in the global average temperature from at least 4C to 2100 will have a profound impact on the world and the economies of many countries if we do not urgently begin to slow down our emissions.”

A Christian feast that means the birth of Jesus, Christmas is widely celebrated and enjoyed in all the United States and the world. The feast always falls on December 25 (regardless of the day of the week), and is usually accompanied by decorations, gifts and special meals.
Specifically, the legend behind Christmas (and the one that is told to most children) is that Santa Claus, an old bearded, muscular, cheerful and red shirt dress living in the North Pole, spends the year making gifts with his elves, or small, festive, enthusiastic Santa-assist. All children who behave throughout the year are admitted to the Good List, and presumably will receive their desired gifts at Christmas, while those who do not behave are placed on the Naughty List, and presumably (although the matter is determined by the parents) will receive a piece of coal.
Santa Claus is said to fly around the Christmas sky on a sled driven by its magical reindeer, or cold-resistant, mythically driven, individually called animals, delivering gifts to each child's home in the process. Santa is also expected to slide through chimneys to deliver these gifts (homes not equipped with fireplaces could "leave the front door cracked open"), and children sometimes arrange cookies or other treats on a plate for him to enjoy.
Gifts are placed under a Christmas tree, or a pine tree that is decorated with ornaments and/or lights and is symbolic of the party. In addition, smaller gifts can be placed inside a sock, or a piece of fabric in the form of a sock, specific to the holiday that is usually hung on the mantle of a fireplace (homes without fireplace can use the wall). The ornaments of a Christmas tree, or hanging ornaments, typically spherical, in addition to the above-mentioned lights, may be accompanied by a star, or a representation of the Star of Jerusalem that the Three Apostles followed while bringing gifts from the Child Jesus and honoring him, in the Bible.
