Although they refer mainly to moral issues, Cockburn's philosophical writings (which are taken here to include Mr. Locke's defense of human understanding (hereinafter, defense), Observations on some writers and Observations on the principles and reasonings of Dr. Rutherforth's essay) address a number of philosophical issues. In Defense, he answers Burnet on a number of questions concerning the deficiencies of Locke's empiricism, which include not only moral knowledge, but also the knowledge that human beings can have of the truthfulness of God and the immortality of the human soul. There is also a wide range of topics addressed in his work Observations on some Writers, in which Cockburn begins by addressing several philosophical issues – the necessity, the infinity of space, and the nature and existence of spirits with respect to the notion of substance. This latter discussion generally revolves around epistemological concerns about the knowledge of the real essences and the nature of the substance, in which it holds that spirits must have an extension of a species to be suitable substances. He makes this argument by appealing to a widely Lockean view of the substance.
However, it is his moral theory that is most prominently emphasized through his works. Cockburn dealt mainly with dealing with the flaws and strengths of some of the dominant issues in moral theory at this time. Cockburn's own position is an amalgam of three dominant strains of 18th-century morality: moral rationalism, moral fitness theory, and moral sense theory. Moral rationalism is, in general terms, the view that morality is the result of a rational process, by which the mind reasons over moral ideas and creates moral rules (although many thinkers, such as Cockburn, argued that the mind, by this process, is in fact somehow discovering eternal moral rules). The theory of moral fitness is a rationalist theory that includes the notion that the human mind is able to understand the various moral relationships that result from the essential nature of things in the universe; for example, the nature of human beings and God creates a relationship that requires the loyalty of human beings to their superior (this view was made more famous by Samuel Clarke). The theory of moral sense is the view that humans possess a special sensory ability that can determine, pre-rationally, what is good or bad (This vision was made more famous by Shaftesbury and Hutcheson). However, for many theorists, such as Cockburn, this sensory information is not definitive, but is seen as an aid to moralization that can and should be corrected by reason.
Cockburn's first philosophical work, Defense is a response to the work of one of Locke's critics, Thomas Burnet. In a series of critical pamphlets, Burnet raised doubts about the sustainability of Locke's epistemology as a basis, among other things, for moral knowledge. In the Essay and other works, Locke had suggested that morality could be known for reason and had emphasized the demonstrative character of morality, thus claiming the certainty with which moral ideas could be known. However, Locke never provided an explicit account of how fundamental moral ideas are derived. Burnet concludes that Locke's epistemology is simply insufficient for the task, and that moral ideas, in Locke's system, remain as uncertain as the ideas of God's nature and the immortality of the soul. Burnet uses his criticism of Locke as a springboard for his own moral position, best described as a mark of moral sense theory, in which consciousness is the human capacity to empirically discern the moral value of acts. In other words, for Burnet, one can, by observing a certain set of circumstances, know with immediate certainty whether that act is morally good or bad.

text:
In general we think that the observations we make are capable of justifying some expectations or predictions about the observations we have not yet made, as well as general statements that go beyond what we have observed. For example, the observation that bread of a certain appearance has been nourishing up to now seems to justify the expectation that the next similar piece of bread that as well will be nutritious, as well as the claim that bread of this type is generally nutritious. Such inferences from the observed to the unobserved, or general laws, are known as “inductive inferences”.
The original source of what has become known as the “problem of induction” is in Book 1, Part iii, Section 6 of A Treaty of Human Nature by David Hume, published in 1739. In 1748, Hume gave a shorter version of the argument in Section iv of A Research on Human Understanding. Throughout this article we will refer to the Treaty as “T”, and to Research as “E”.
Hume asks why we come to our beliefs about the unobserved on the basis of inductive inferences. It presents an argument in the form of a dilemma that seems to rule out the possibility of any reasoning from the premises to the conclusion of an inductive inference. There are, he says, two possible types of arguments, “proven” and “probable”, but none will serve. A demonstrative argument produces the wrong kind of conclusion, and a likely argument would be circular. Therefore, for Hume, the problem remains how to explain why we form any conclusions that go beyond the past cases we have had experience with (T. 1.3.6.10). Hume stresses that he is not arguing that we do draw such inferences. The challenge, as he sees it, is to understand the "foundation" of inference — the "logical process" or "argument" on which it is based (E. 4.2.21). The problem of meeting this challenge, while evading Hume’s argument against the possibility of doing so, has been known as “the problem of induction”.
Hume's argument is one of the most famous in philosophy. Several philosophers have tried to solve the problem, but a significant number have accepted its conclusion that it is insoluble. There is also a broad spectrum of views on the importance of the problem. Some have argued that Hume's argument does not establish any far-reaching skeptical conclusion, either because it was never intended, or because the argument is somehow misspoken. However, many have considered it one of the most profound philosophical challenges imaginable, as it seems to call into question the justification of one of the most fundamental ways in which we form knowledge. Bertrand Russell, for example, expressed the view that if Hume’s problem cannot be solved, “there is no intellectual difference between sanity and madness” (Russell 1946: 699).
In this article, we will first examine Hume's own argument, provide a reconstruction of it, and then study different responses to the problem it poses.

Most fictionalist hermeneutics about some particular discourse maintain that although we normally utter phrases within the discourse in a fictitious spirit, we could, and perhaps sometimes do, use these phrases literally. For example, a fictionalist mathematician might argue that when we pronounce “there are prime numbers” in ordinary contexts we mean this in a fictitious spirit, but add that when we pronounce this phrase in the philosophy room we sometimes pretend to speak literally. But at least you can imagine a different kind of hermeneutic fictionalism. Let's take the case of the speech on fictional characters. A name like ‘SpongeBob’ is introduced for the first time to tell stories and to make internal claims to history; for example, the claim that SpongeBob lives in a pineapple under the sea. But there is disagreement about the proper account of the use of names of extrafiction fictional entities, non-narrative contexts, for example. in “SpongeBob is a better model to follow than Superman.” Some philosophers argue that this ‘extrafictive’ use of fictitious names shows that ‘SpongeBob’ has a reference outside of fiction (for example, referring to an abstract entity). Others argue that while SpongeBob can be used significantly in such contexts, it is, however, in such contexts, a mere non-remitting empty name, together with Zeus and Vulcan. But we can imagine a third kind of vision, according to which the names of fictional characters are, so to speak, only significant within fiction. Anyone attracted to such a view should tell some special story about apparent extrafictional truths (Brock 2002). Likewise, and returning to fictionalism, one can imagine a fictionalist about some discourse that denies that the relevant phrases can even be used significantly outside the pretense; that it holds that prayers only have the purpose of pretense.
The view may sound crazy. But Yablo (1998) approaches suggesting such a vision when he says, after having motivated fictionalism about the use of city names, he does not know what it would be like to use “Chicago exists” more literally than he already does. Let us call fictionalism according to which there is a literal use of the phrases in question with which ordinary use contrasts with fictionalism; let us call the other fictionalism meaning. The distinction may correspond to the distinction of Armour-Garb and Woodbridge (2015) between extrinsic and intrinsic claim. Armour-Garb and Woodbridge say that what characterizes the extrinsic pretense is that we could take the expression made literally, while in cases of intrinsic pretense, “the pretense is integral to the expression saying anything at all.” Using fictionalism is arguably the most common doctrine. But it is worth mentioning the meaning of fictionalism as well, both because some fictionalists seem to support it, and because the distinction will be relevant to some of the arguments against fictionalism. Armour-Garb and Woodbridge call their own semantic fiction brand and oppose what they call pragmatic accounts.
There are other distinctions in the general neighbourhood. Following Yablo (2001), one can distinguish between the following fictionalist points of view (on the discourse on Xs):
Instrumentalism: The speaker is not “really” asserting anything, just pretending to.
Meta-fictionalism: The speaker is “really” asserting that according to a certain fiction, the X are like this and so.
Object-fictionalism: the speaker is “really” asserting that the world is in a certain condition, namely, the condition in which it needs to be to make it a reality in the relevant fiction that the X are so and so.
Figuralism: the speaker is “really” claiming that something is in a certain condition, but perhaps not in the world; the X are functioning as representation aids in a figurative description of the Y, where the Y can be themselves representation aids invoked to help us describe even more objects.
Let us take the number discourse as our example, and consider these fictionalist views as applied to the number discourse. The instrumentalist said that in an expression of “the number of apples is two”, the speaker simply intended to say something; nothing was actually said. The instrumentalist did not present an alternative account of what the speaker was doing. The metafictionalist says something is stated in the lines of: according to the fiction number, the number of apples is two. The fictionalist object says that what is claimed is something that has nothing to do with the real world, something that would make true in fiction that the number of apples is two: that there is an apple x and an apple and so that x and y are different and nothing other than x and y is an apple. The characteristic objects of speech, the numbers, are mere aids that we use to make statements about how things are in the real world. Yablo's preferred point of view, figurism, is supposed to be a close cousin of fictionalism, but with an added twist. Figurism does not differ from fictionalism in what it says about the example used so far. The differences only appear when we are considering the statements intuitively about these supports themselves, the numbers, such as “7 is less than 11”. Sometimes, says Yablo, numbers — and other accessories — are used as simple representation aids, but sometimes they also function as represented things. (Provides as comparison “pinpricks of consciousness record less than pains of consciousness.”) In a typical expression of “the number of apples is two”, the number functions as a representation aid. But in “there are numbers” as the Platonist uses them, numbers work as things represented. And in “the number of cousins is zero”, as a nominalist you can imagine to use it when you do philosophy, saying something that given your philosophical point of view is true, they work as much as representation aids (“number”) and as represented things (“even prime”). (Compare also the catalogue of fictitious opinions in Kalderon 2005a, ch. 3.)

When you see the word Amazon, what is the first thing that comes to mind – the world’s largest forest, the longest river, or the largest Internet retailer – and what do you consider most important?
These issues have been raised in an arcane but extremely important debate on how to redraw the boundaries of the Internet. Brazil and Peru have objected to an offer made by the US e-commerce giant. for a new piece of the first order of cyberspace: “.amazon”.
The Seattle-based company has requested that its brand be a high-level domain name (now “.com”), but South American governments argue that this would prevent the use of this Internet address for environmental protection, the promotion of indigenous rights, and other uses of public interest.
Along with dozens of other controversial claims about names, including “.patagonia” and “.shangrila”, the issue is reduced to the heart of debates about the purpose and government of the Internet.
So far, differences between commercial, governmental and other types of identity were easily distinguished in each Internet address by “.com”, “.gov” and 20 other categories.
But these categories, or first-level generic domains (gTLDs) as they are technically known, are about to experience the greatest expansion since the start of the global website.
The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) – a non-profit organization based in the United States that plays a key role in the governance of cyberspace – has received offers (each with a value of nearly $200,000) for hundreds of new gTLDs to join the existing 22.
Amazon has requested dozens of new domains, including “.shop”, “.song”, “.book” and “.kindle. But its most controversial application is for its own brand.
Brazil and Peru have requested the withdrawal of the “.amazon” application, saying that a private company should not be given a name that denotes a significant geographical area covering its territories and is also used for certain cross-border regions and organizations. “Allowing private companies to register geographical names such as gTLDs to reinforce their brand strategy or to benefit from the meaning of these names does not, in our opinion, serve the public interest,” said Brazil’s Ministry of Science and Technology.
Brazil said its views were endorsed last month by other members of the Amazon Cooperation Treaty (Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Guyana, Suriname and Venezuela).
Dozens of other protests have also been registered over proposed high-level domains that take on contested geographical, cultural or trademark names.
Argentina has presented an expression of its unhappiness that the U.S. outdoor clothing retailer, Patagonia, is claiming a domain name that has long been known as a region of spectacular beauty that also has its own parliament. “Argentina rejects the “.patagonia” request for a new high-level generic domain,” the government notes in an appeal. “Patagonia is a region relevant to the country’s economy because it has oil, fisheries, mining and agricultural resources. It is also a region with a vibrant local community and is an important tourist destination.”
Less convincingly, China has disputed the domain.shangrila, which is proposed by a hotel group of the same name. Beijing authorities say that the “shangri-la” label belongs to a region of Yunnan province, although it was only renamed as such in 2001 (long after the hotel group was formed) so that the local community could take advantage of the fame of the fictional paradise represented in the novel Lost Horizon, by British author James Hilton.
At a conference held in Beijing in April, the ICANN Governmental Advisory Committee, the leading voice of national governments within the institution, recommended that controversial proposals be frozen. They are expected to be discussed again at a meeting to be held in Durban in July. The first approved domain names should be in use by the end of 2013.

The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs demanded Tuesday that CNN's Jack Cafferty apologize for the comments he made last week, in which he called the Chinese thugs and thugs and said that the products manufactured in China are garbage.
Cafferty used the microphone in his hands to defame China and the Chinese people - LRB- and -RRB- gravely violated the professional ethics of journalism and human conscience, Foreign Ministry spokesman Jiang Yu said Tuesday, according to Xinhua news agency, led by the state of China.
He said that Cafferty's comments reflected his arrogance, ignorance and hostility towards the Chinese people, ignited the indignation of the Chinese - LRB- at home and abroad -RRB- and will be condemned by those who safeguard justice all over the world.
CNN issued a statement on Tuesday saying: We are aware of concerns about Jack Cafferty's comments related to China in the context of the upcoming Olympic Games, which were aired at The Situation Room on April 9, 2008.
CNN would like to clarify that it was not Mr Cafferty's or CNN's intention to offend the Chinese people, and -LSB-CNN-RSB - would apologize to anyone who has interpreted the comments in this way.
CNN is a network that reports the news in an objective and balanced way. However, as part of our coverage we also employ commentators who provide solid opinions that generate debate.
On this occasion Jack was offering his firm opinion of the Chinese government, not of the Chinese people, a point that he later clarified in The Situation Room on April 14.
It should be noted that, over many years, Jack Cafferty has expressed critical comments about many governments, including the U.S. government and its leaders.
Cafferty, who appears daily on CNN's The Situation Room, made comments as host Wolf Blitzer was comparing today's China to that of 20 or 30 years ago.
“I don’t know if China is different, but our relationship with China is certainly different,” Cafferty said. We agree with the Chinese to our eyes because of the war in Iraq, on the one hand. They have hundreds of billions of dollars in our paper. We're also carrying hundreds of billions of dollars of trade deficits with them, as we keep importing their garbage with lead paint on them and poisoned pet food and exporting, you know, jobs to places where you can pay workers a dollar a month to produce the things we're buying from Wal-Mart.
So I think our relationship with China has certainly changed, he said. I think they're basically the same group of thugs and thugs they've been for the last 50 years.
He made a clarification of his remarks in the Situation Room on Monday, saying that by thugs and thugs, he referred to the Chinese government, not the Chinese people. It was not clear whether the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs was aware of the clarification when it held the press conference on Tuesday.
However, in the days following her comments, the Immigrant Legal Association launched an online petition condemning her statements as racist and despicable and demanding that CNN discipline Cafferty and apologize to the Chinese people. Almost 45,000 people had signed it on Tuesday afternoon.
In the petition, the association describes itself as a leading organization of legal immigrants composed mainly of people from China. According to its website, the non-profit group is based in Santa Clara, California, and was founded in 2007 as an organization dedicated to the social welfare of employment-based immigrant professionals.
The Chinese Daily state newspaper also said in an editorial on Tuesday that an apology is requested, calling Cafferty pathetic and pointing out, it is rare for the world public to hear such blatant discrimination against an ethnic group of people with such a derogatory connotation.
Others enraged by Cafferty's comments were urging a boycott of CNN advertisers. E-mail to a friend

text:
Senate Republicans again blocked Democratic legislation on Tuesday that would require greater transparency in who is behind much of the secret, often negative campaign advertising, filling the waves this election season.
DISCLOSE Act supporters gathered 53 votes in an effort to advance the bill, but did not reach the 60 needed to break a Republican Party filibuster. The Democrats unanimously supported the bill, while the Republicans voted unanimously against it. The legislation, which needs 60 votes to succeed, failed in a 51-44 vote on Monday.
Legislation would require tax-exempt groups involved in political advertising -- which are currently not required to disclose the names of their donors -- to spread the names of those who donate $10,000 or more. A similar vote ended on Monday with the same result.
During these elections, the external expenses of the Republican Party shell groups are expected to exceed $1 billion, said Senate majority leader Harry Reid, D-Nevada, in a speech. The names of these front groups contain words like freedom and prosperity, but make no mistake: there is nothing free in a choice bought by a handful of billionaires for their own interest.
Democrats say the requirement is a much-needed response to the U.S. Supreme Court decision Citizen United, which opened the door to large amounts of campaign spending by corporations, unions, and other groups.
The political publicity of all these donations threatens to drown the voice of middle-class families in our democracy, Senator Sheldon Whitehouse of D-Rhode Island, a main sponsor of the bill, argued.
Senate minority leader Mitch McConnell, R-Kentucky, led the Republican Party's accusation against the bill and accused Democrats of drafting it to favor trade unions -- traditionally Democratic allies -- over other types of donors.
This legislation is an unprecedented requirement for groups to publicly disclose to their donors, stripping of a protection recognized and solidified by the courts, said McConnell, who has advocated for more outreach in the past, as long as it applies to all major actors in campaign financing, such as unions and court attorneys.
McConnell cited a recent analysis of the Wall Street Journal that found that unions spent $4.4 billion on campaigns between 2005 and 2011.
Obama Collects Campaign Money in Lone Star State
Predictably, unions are exempt from the kind of disclosure that Democrats now want to impose on others, McConnell said.
The Democrats disagreed with the Republican claim that trade unions are exempt from their legislation. However, concern for unions seemed to influence key Republicans such as Arizona Senator John McCain, a longtime vocal advocate for campaign finance reform, who said he would vote against the bill for that reason.
By conveniently setting a high threshold for reporting requirements, the DISCLOSE Act obliges some entities to inform the public about the origins of their financial support, while allowing others -- especially those affiliated with organized labour -- to fly below the regulatory radar of the Federal Electoral Commission, McCain said.
McCain argued that local trade union chapters would not have to disclose individual members' payments if the amount was less than $10,000.
Fiscal fight on the cliff: missing the overall picture
To influence voters, tens of millions were spent on health-care announcements

text:
The terms “idealism” and “idealism” are in no way used only within philosophy; they are also used in many everyday contexts. Optimists who believe that, in the long term, good will prevail are often called "idealists." This is not because these people are believed to be dedicated to a philosophical doctrine, but to their view of life in general; in fact, they may even be pitied, or perhaps envied, for showing a naive view of the world and not being philosophically critical at all. Even within philosophy, the terms “idealism” and “idealism” are used in different ways, which often makes their meaning dependent on context. However, regardless of context one can distinguish between a descriptive (or categorizing) use of these terms and a controversial one, although sometimes these different uses occur together. Its descriptive use is best documented by paying attention to the large number of different “idealisms” that appear in philosophical textbooks and encyclopedias, ranging from metaphysical idealism, to epistemological and aesthetic idealism, to moral or ethical idealism. Within these idealisms more distinctions can be found, such as those that exist between subjective, objective and absolute idealism, and even darker characterizations such as speculative idealism and transcendental idealism. It is also remarkable that the term "idealism", at least within philosophy, is often used in such a way that it gets its meaning through what is considered its opposite: as the meaningful use of the term "outside" depends on a contrast with something that is considered to be inside, so the meaning of the term "idealism" is often fixed by what is considered to be its opposite. Therefore, an idealist is someone who is not a realist, not a materialist, not a dogmatist, not an empiricist, and so on. Since many also want to distinguish between realism, materialism, dogmatism and empiricism, it is obvious that thinking about the meaning of “idealism” determined by what is intended to oppose leads to greater complexity and gives the impression that behind such characterizations there is some controversial intention.
Within modern philosophy there are sometimes considered to be two fundamental conceptions of idealism:
something mental (mind, spirit, reason, will) is the ultimate foundation of all reality, or even exhaustive of reality, and
while recognizing the existence of something independent of the mind, all that we can know about this “reality” independent of the mind is considered so pervaded by the creative, formative or constructive activities of the mind (of some kind or another) that all statements of knowledge must be considered, in some sense, as a form of self-knowledge.
Idealism in the sense (1) has been called "metaphysical" or "ontological idealism", while idealism in the sense (2) has been called "formal" or "epistemological idealism". The modern paradigm of idealism in sense (1) could be considered as George Berkeley’s “inmaterialism,” according to which all that exists are the ideas and minds, less than divine or divine, that have them. (Berkeley himself did not use the term “idealism”). The source for idealism in sense (2) could be the position that Immanuel Kant affirmed (if not clearly in the first edition of his Critique of Pure Reason (1781) then in his Prolegomena to Any Future Metaphysics (1783) and in the “Refutation of Idealism” in the second edition of the Critique), according to which idealism “does not refer to the existence of things”, but affirms only that our “modes of representation” of them, especially space and time, are not “determinations that belong to things in themselves”, but traits of our own mind. Kant called his idealism position “transcendental” and “critical”, and it has also been called “formal” idealism. However, Kant's position does not provide a clear model of idealism at all. While Kant himself claimed that his position combined “empirical realism” with “transcendental idealism,” i.e., combined realism over outer, space-time objects in ordinary life and science with the denial of the reality of space and time at the level of things as they are in themselves, he also insisted on the reality of things as they are in themselves existing independently of our representations of them, thus denying their reducibility or representations or the minds that have them. In this way, Kant's position really combines the transcendental ideality of space and time with a kind of realism about the existence of things other than minds.
So instead of using Kant as any kind of model for epistemological idealism, in this post we will distinguish between metaphysical and epistemological arguments for idealism understood as a metaphysical doctrine, namely, that everything that exists is somehow mental. So, we agree with A.C. Ewing, who wrote in 1934 that all forms of idealism
have in common the view that there can be no physical objects that exist apart from some experience, and this could perhaps be taken as the definition of idealism, provided that we consider thought as part of experience and do not imply by the passivity of “experience,” and whenever we include under experience not only human experience but the so-called “Absolute Experience” or experience of a God as the postulates of Berkeley. (Ewing 1934: 3)
In other words, while reducing all reality to some kind of perception is a form of idealism, it is not the only way—reality can be reduced to the mental in other conceptions of the latter. Thus Willem deVries' most recent definition of idealism as the general theory that reduces reality to some form or another of the mental is just:
Approximately, gender includes theories that attribute ontological priority to the mental, especially the conceptual or ideative, over the non-mental. (deVries 2009: 211)
We also agree with Jeremy Dunham, Iain Hamilton Grant and Sean Watson when they write that
the idealist, instead of being anti-realist, is in fact... a realistic with respect to the most generally discarded elements of reality. (Dunham, Grant, & Watson 2011: 4)
namely, the mind of some kind or another: the idealist denies the reality of matter independent of the mind, but hardly denies the reality of the mind (or, on his own, that goes back to Plato, Ideas or Forms, as well as minds; we are not going to consider premodern forms of idealism in any detail). However, following Ewing (see chapters II, IV-V and VIII), we will distinguish metaphysical arguments from epistemological arguments for idealism. Metaphysical arguments proceed by identifying some general limitations on existence and arguing that only minds of some kind or another satisfy such conditions; epistemological arguments work by identifying some conditions for knowledge and arguing that only objects that are in some sense or another mental can satisfy the conditions for being known. In particular, epistemological arguments for idealism assume that there is a necessary isomorphism between knowledge and its object that can be obtained only if the object of knowledge is in itself mental; we propose that this is the difference between epistemologically motivated idealism and a more neutral position, which could be identified with philosophers such as Rudolf Carnap, W.V.O. Quine, and Donald Davidson, arguing that, of course, we always know things from some point of view, but any “external” question as to whether our view “corresponds” to independent reality makes no sense or at least does not answer for theoretical reasons. It is in order to preserve the distinction between traditional idealism and positions like the latter that we recommend maintaining the assertion that reality is in one way or another exclusively mental and the thought of epistemological arguments for idealism rather than epistemological idealism as such.
Of course, these strategies can be combined by a single philosopher. Berkeley does, and Kant does as well by arguing for the transcendental idealist side of his complex position. Others separate them, for example F.H. Bradley and J.McT.E. McTaggart built metaphysical arguments for idealism, while Josiah Royce and Brand Blanshard offered epistemological arguments.
In what follows, we will focus mainly on the discussion of philosophical theories that support or affirm support idealism on an ontological and/or epistemological basis. However, at some points in its complex history, especially in the social and philosophical movement that dominated British and American universities in the second half of the 19th century and during the first world war, idealism in any of its philosophical forms was effectively connected to idealism in the popular sense of progressive and optimistic social thought. This was true for figures like Bradley and Royce and their predecessors and contemporaries like Thomas Hill Green and Bernard Bosanquet. Recently there has been considerable interest in British or more generally English-speaking idealism as a movement in social philosophy, or even a social movement, but we will not pursue that here (see Mander 2011; Boucher & Vincent 2012; Mander [ed.] 2000; and Mander & Panagakou [eds.] 2016).

An Austrian man who participated in a Nazi massacre of Jews during World War II and later obtained U.S. citizenship has been deported to Austria, U.S. officials said.
The Sachsenhausen concentration camp north of Berlin, where the United States says Krumpf worked as an SS guard.
Josias Krumpf, 83, lived years after the war in Racine, Wisconsin. The United States revoked its citizenship in 2005 after the Criminal Division of the United States Department of Justice attempted to denaturalize it.
Acting Deputy Prosecutor Rita Glavin announced the deportation of Krumpf on Thursday. It was not clear when he arrived in Austria, and representatives of the Austrian Ministry of Justice were not immediately available to comment.
His transfer ordered by the United States court to Austria is another milestone in the government's effort to ensure that people involved in crimes against humanity do not find refuge in this country, Glavin said.
The U.S. eliminated Krumpf because of his involvement in that and other Nazi-sponsored acts of persecution during the war, Glavin said.
Krumpf admits to being on duty on 3 November 1943, when SS guards at Trawniki Labour Camp in Poland shot and killed 8,000 Jews, including women and 400 children, in graves. Glavin said Krumpf said he had orders to shoot the prisoners who survived.
Krumpf also served as an SS guard at the Sachsenhausen Concentration Camp led by the Nazis in Germany and in slave workplaces in Nazi-occupied France, where prisoners under his watch built launch platforms for German missile attacks in England, Glavin said.
The November 1943 shooting was part of a larger Nazi operation called Aktion Erntefest, or Operation Harvest Festival, which led to the death of 42,000 Jews in three camps in eastern Poland in two days, the Department of Justice said.
In Trawniki, Krumpf said, he was assigned to watch victims who were still half alive or convulsing and prevent their escape by shooting them to death, the Justice Department said.
Krumpf, who was born in Serbia, emigrated to the United States in 1956 and became a U.S. citizen in 1964.
Her removal to Austria is part of an effort by several U.S. government departments and law enforcement agencies to identify and prosecute participants in Nazi persecution crimes living in the U.S., the Department of Justice said.
The Office of Special Investigations of the Criminal Division (LRB-OSI-RRB) started the operation in 1979 and has since won cases against 107 alleged Nazi criminals, the Department of Justice said.
The SBI also has a watch list for war criminals from World War II that has prevented more than 180 people from entering the United States, the Department of Justice said.

On Sunday, Libya's interim parliament approved a new government, led by Prime Minister Ahmed Mitig, in a controversial vote that threatens to deepen the country's political and security crisis.
A total of 83 of the 93 members present voted in favour of the Mitig government.
The legislators of the General National Congress dominated by Islamists - LRB-GNC-RRB - challenged a threat issued by militias allied with the renegade general Khalifa Haftar, who promised to assault, assault and arrest members.
The threat was issued by the same group that attacked the CNG headquarters in Tripoli last week, triggering fighting throughout the capital that left at least four dead and dozens injured.
Shortly before the vote in Parliament, the EU Special Envoy to Libya described the situation as the country's worst crisis since 2011.
This is the worst crisis Libya has ever known since the war. Political forces must understand the anxiety of the Libyan people, who expect effective solutions to their daily concerns and problems, Bernardino Leon told journalists.
Leon called on politicians to work in an inclusive and democratic manner towards a political road map and to allow for early and peaceful parliamentary elections.
Also on Sunday, the outgoing Minister of Culture warned the insistence of CNG to confirm that the Mitig government could lead to more violence.
Today CNG is hitting the drums of the war. They want to bring the country into armed conflict for power after all peaceful and political means have been exhausted... They are leading the country to a direct confrontation, Al-Habeeb al-Amin told Libya al-Ahrar TV.
Mitig, a businessman from the city of Misrata, was elected to form a cabinet earlier this month in a disputed vote driven by Islamist blocs.
For months, divisions between Islamists and more moderate blocks within CNG have almost paralysed the political process and increased tensions in the country among militias affiliated to different parties.
The emergence of Haftar and his self-declared Libyan National Army intensified tensions last week, as the retired general called for the overthrow of CNG that he described as illegitimate.
Haftar also launched what he called an open war against Islamist extremist groups and promised to purge Libya from them. His campaign has expanded the country's divisions with Islamist and anti-Islamic camps.
In an effort to try to ease tensions, the Libyan electoral commission announced that early elections will be held on 25 June.
On Friday, Libyans gathered in Tripoli, Benghazi and other Libyan cities in support of the campaign led by Haftar. While some Libyans do not support the former general and do not want the military government, they support what he is doing.
But some say their campaign is an opportunist strategy that takes advantage of the growing discontent in Libya with a weak central government and a deteriorating security situation.
Haftar was once a general in the Libyan army under dictator Moammar Gadhafi, but had a fight with him and emigrated to the United States, where he lived for nearly 20 years. He returned in 2011 to participate in the revolution that overthrew Gaddafi.

text:
In the philosophy of religion, creation is the action by which God brings an object into existence, while conservation is the action by which God maintains the existence of an object over time. The main monotheisms unequivocally affirm that God created the world and preserves it. However, it is less clear whether creation and conservation should be conceived as distinct types of action. The issue has its roots in the medieval and early modern characterizations of divine action, and has received renewed attention in recent decades.
In the traditional prevailing point of view, conservation is continuous creation. Supporters of this view often say with Francisco Suárez that God’s creation and preservation of things are “conceptually only different” (Suárez 1597, 120). Jonathan Edwards, for example, says: “The created substance which God sustains, or which causes its existence at every successive moment, is wholly equivalent to an immediate production of nothingness, at every moment... So this effect does not differ at all from the first creation, but only circumstantially...” (Edwards 1758, 402; emphasis on the original). In other words, there is no real difference between the act of creation and the act of conservation, although different words can be used for them. Descartes, Malebranche, Leibniz and Berkeley express similar views. More recently, Philip Quinn also deals with both God's creation and God's preservation as a kind of producing the existence of a thing. We call the act ‘creation’ if it occurs in the first time the creature exists, and we call it ‘conservation’ if it occurs at a later time, but the action is the same (e.g., Quinn 1988, 54).
The alternative to this vision is that the act of preserving beings that already exist differs from calling beings into existence from nothingness. Some argue that each persistent creature plays a causal role in its continued existence, so that God is not the only agent as in an ex nihilo creation. Some also argue that conservation must be a continuous act, while creation occurs in an instant.
A large part of what is at stake in the debate is the relationship between divine action and creature action. Theorists of continuous creation may reject a distinction between creation and preservation as an attempt to attribute a divine prerogative to created things. On the other hand, those who support a distinction may consider the theory of continuous creation as (to borrow a phrase) “one of those high-minded philosophical depreciations of God’s works that are disguised as compliments to the person of God” (van Inwagen 1988, 46 n4). The debate also raises a number of interesting questions about causality, time and their relationships.

Amsterdam remains liberal for tourists, to whom the Labour Mayor recently assured that the city's coffee shops selling marijuana would remain open despite a new national law addressing drug tourism. But the Dutch capital may lose its reputation for tolerance by planning to send annoying neighbors to “scum people” made of transport containers.
The mayor, Eberhard van der Laan, insists that his controversial new £810,000 policy to combat antisocial behavior is to protect victims from abuse and homophobia from harassment. The camps where antisocial tenants will be resettled for three or six months have been called “scum people” because politics echoes the proposals of Geert Wilders, the far-right populist, who last year demanded that “repeat criminals” be “sent to a village by scum.”
But Bartho Boer, mayor's spokesman, denies that the plans are not liberal. “We want to defend the liberal values of Amsterdam,” he says. “We want everyone to be who he and she are, whether they’re gay and lesbian or facing violence and then being harassed. We, as a society, want to defend them.” According to Boer, villages are not “the usual nuisance between two neighbors where one has the stereo too high on Saturday night,” but “people who are extremely violent and intimidating, and in a clear situation where a victim is being harassed repeatedly.”
Those found guilty of causing “extreme chaos” will be evicted and placed in temporary “basic” homes, including transport containers converted into industrial areas of the city. “We call it a living container,” Boer says. The housing of antisocial tenants in these units, which have showers and kitchens and have been used as student accommodation, will ensure that they are not “rewarded” by being relocated to better accommodation.
The Dutch newspaper Parool has pointed out that in the 19th century the troublemakers were moved to the villages of Drenthe and Overijssel, which quickly became slums. But Boer insists that the administration has learned from past mistakes and is not planning to house antisocials together.
It would be more necessary to call them “scum houses” than “scum people,” Boer says, “because we don’t want to put more of these families in the same area.” After up to six months in these houses, scattered throughout the city, tenants will be found in permanent houses. The city government plans to move around ten families a year to this program, which begins in 2013.
Temporary housing will be heavily guarded, but antisocial tenants will also have access to doctors, social workers and probation officers. “They are taken care of so that the whole situation is not repeated in the new house they are in,” Boer says.

Deutsche Bank made a small annual profit in 2020, its first since 2014, saying on Thursday that it had made big profits in its investment banking division.
Over the past 10 years, Deutsche has lost a total of €8.2 billion ($9.8 billion) and the return to profit marks an important milestone for Chief Executive Christian Cowing, as analysts had been predicting another loss in 2020.
“We have built firm foundations for sustainable profitability and we are confident that this overall positive trend will continue in 2021, despite these difficult times,” he said in a statement detailing the results.
The sewing was promoted in 2018 to turn Germany's largest bank after years of losses and fines for lack of money laundering and its role in the mortgage crisis.
Analysts expect Deutsche to make another profit in 2021, according to a consensus forecast of their estimates.
Deutsche said its net profit attributable to shareholders for 2020 was €113 million ($136 million), compared to a loss of €5.7 billion in 2019. Analysts expected a loss of some 300 million euros by 2020.
Deutsche's shares, which increased by 3.6% in Frankfurt's trade, were 1.3% lower at 08.15 GMT.
A big question is how sustainable the benefits will be like Deutsche, like its competitors, experienced a trade boom amidst market volatility linked to the COVID-19 pandemic.
This prompted its investment bank, whose revenues increased by 32% to €9,280 million in 2020, and 28% in its main sales and transactions of fixed income and foreign exchange.
However, low interest rates and the slowdown in world trade put pressure on the revenues of Deutsche’s other divisions, such as corporate and retail clients.
One regulatory source said that the boom in investment banking had provided positive relief for Deutsche, but although it is in a stronger position than a year ago, its global business force is still lagging behind competitors in the European banking sector.
The bank has been trying to be less dependent on its investment bank in an effort to stabilize its business.
Cosing, announcing 18,000 job cuts and the closure of his global equity business in a major renewal announced in 2019, said the investment bank should provide only 30% of basic income. In 2020 it accounted for about 40% of basic income.
Income from investment banking trade rose globally for the entire industry 2020, said research firm Autonomous in a recent report that said “nobody believes this is sustainable.”
Deutsche thinks a good part of his business is.
“We see a substantial part of the growth of investment banks as sustainable, even as markets normalize, as expected in 2021,” Sewing said, according to comments prepared to analysts.
Costura told the employees in a memo that the division had gone to a “good start” this year.
The bank, which broke the talks to merge with Commerzbank two years ago, is trying to adapt to a possible merger if an opportunity arises, the German bankers say.
A banker with direct knowledge of the matter said Deutsche is approaching the issue of potential mergers as consolidation pressures increase. The bank is addressing the issue, but it has no concrete plans, the person said.
Deutsche ended the year with a net profit of the fourth quarter of 51 million euros, compared to a net loss of 1.6 billion euros in the same period a year before and analysts expectations of a loss.

Barack Obama flew to Washington and his desk at the Oval Office on Wednesday, hours after delivering an election victory speech in Chicago in which he called for the country to join behind him.
“You voted for action, not for politics as usual,” Obama said in his speech, but there were few signs of his call being responded to, and the President faced the prospect of doing business with a hostile Republican-led House of Representatives for at least another two years and an imminent confrontation over spending and debt, the so-called “fiscal mirror.”
Unlike his election in 2008, it is unlikely that the President will have a honeymoon period.
Both the Republican Speaker of the House, John Boehner, and the Democratic leader in the Senate, Harry Reid, spoke of the need to work together to resolve the crisis, but it could become one of the biggest clashes between the White House and Congress under Obama's presidency.
While Obama easily overcame the challenge of his Republican opponent Mitt Romney, maintaining the swing state after the swing state, the election provided another reminder of how divided the United States remains.
Although the opening is not until January, Obama actually embarked on his second term on Wednesday. Having disappointed many supporters in his first term, he is now seeking to establish a legacy that will transform him from a mediocre president into a large one.
In addition to monitoring what he hopes will be a continuous economic recovery, he hopes to address issues ranging from immigration reform to investment in education and climate change, and, in foreign policy, from Iran to Israel-Palestine.
In addition to comfortably winning more than 270 votes from the required electoral university, it also ensured a higher proportion of the popular vote.
Boehner, in a statement, sounded conciliatory. He cited “the need for both sides to find common ground and to take action together to help our economy grow and create jobs, which is fundamental to resolving our debt.” Obama is reported to have called Boehner to start the negotiation.
Reid, so often in disagreement with Boehner, also sounded conciliatory, saying: “I see the challenges ahead and contact my Republican colleagues in the Senate and the House of Representatives. Let's meet. We know what the problems are; let’s solve them.”
Obama, in an interview initially off record during the campaign, expressed optimism for a “great deal” with Republicans, one that eluded him in 2011. The problem will come when the talks go into detail, with Republicans wanting to protect military spending while Democrats are looking for cuts. Obama has asked for tax increases from households earning more than $250,000; Boehner has rejected any tax increases.
The shares fell on the Dow in anticipation that the blockade would continue. At lunchtime, all major U.S. markets dropped by more than 300 points.
The new House, which will be formed in January, will look a lot like the existing one, which has a large Republican majority. The Senate also remained little changed, with the Democrats holding their scant majority, winning three and losing one.
In the presidential race, Romney won only one of the decisive states, North Carolina, while Obama celebrated New Hampshire, Virginia, Ohio, Wisconsin, Nevada, Iowa and Colorado.
In his victory speech in Chicago, Obama referred to the long queues to vote and said there was a need for electoral reform.
He returned to the great rhetoric that was his trademark during the 2008 elections, but he dispensed with it in 2012. Amid disillusionment with his presidency and harsh economic conditions, his campaign team decided it was inappropriate.
But after winning, he returned to the famous lines of previous speeches, once again returning to his 2008 slogan of “hope.”
Going up to the stand to the optimistic sounds of Stevie Wonder “Signed, sealed, delivered, I am yours,” Obama told the ecstatic crowd of supporters: “Tonight in this election, you, the American people, reminded us that while our journey has been difficult, while our journey has been long, we have risen, we have fought our way back. And we know in our hearts that for the United States of America the best is yet to come.” In a speech that lasted more than 25 minutes, after paying emotional tribute to his wife, Michelle, and her daughters, Malia and Sasha – as well as to his Vice President, Joe Biden – Obama returned to the message that first brought him to national attention.
“We are not as divided as our policy suggests,” he said. “We are not as cynical as experts think. We are greater than the sum of our individual ambitions, and we remain more than a collection of red states and blue states. We are, and forever will be, the United States of America.”
Obama made it clear that he had an agenda in mind for his second term, citing changes in the tax code, immigration reform, and, as he said, a United States “that is not threatened by the destructive power of a planet that is warming up.”
Shortly before, Romney had called the President to grant it. In a gracious speech in Boston, Romney told his supporters: “The nation, as you know, is at a critical point. At a time like this, we cannot risk partisan disputes and political positions. Our leaders have to get to the other side of the hall to do people’s work.”
He continued: “This is a time for great challenges for the United States and I pray that the President will succeed in guiding our nation.”
The campaign has almost been a referendum on Obama. Although there was widespread disillusionment with the slow pace of economic recovery and a high level of unemployment, the Americans decided to stay with him.
Historically, it would have been a disappointment for African Americans and many white liberals if the first black presidency had ended in failure, detained prematurely.

For a momentous day at Liverpool's Anglican Cathedral for the families of the 96 people who died so unnecessarily at Sheffield's football field on Wednesday in Hillsborough, one phrase dominated above all: the truth. These were the most infamously abused words by a headline in The Sun newspaper, above the stories we now know, with extraordinarily shocking detail, were fed by the South Yorkshire Police to divert their own guilt from the disaster to the innocent victims.
Margaret Aspinall, whose son James, then 18, died in what should have been a day of joy, a semifinal of the FA Cup between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest, said that families had been forced to fight, for 23 years, precisely for that: the truth. Aspinall, president of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, said that, although the loss of families would never fade, she was “delighted” by the unequivocal and “deep” apologies given by David Cameron for Hillsborough’s savage flaws.
The Hillsborough Independent Group had inspected 450,000 police-generated documents, Sheffield Wednesday and all other responsible bodies, and delivered its remarkable 395-page report accusing the victims and football fans of official misconduct.
Some of the events that caused the disaster, and the subsequent displacement of guilt by the police, have been previously exposed. But the depth of what families call a cover-up, particularly the deliberate police campaign to avoid their own responsibilities and falsely blame supporters, remained surprising.
In a concerted campaign – led by the panel, Peter Wright – the South Yorkshire Police published his story that drunk supporters or those without tickets had caused the disaster. The victims were given a blood test to detect alcohol levels. The panel said that it was “an exceptional decision ” for which it did not find “justification. ” When the victims had alcohol in their blood, the police checked if they had a criminal record.
The report, written substantially by Professor Phil Scraton of Queen’s University, Belfast, and unanimously accepted by the group of eight experts, found that “there was no evidence... to verify the serious allegations of exceptional levels of drunkenness, lack of entrances, or violence among Liverpool fans. ”
The report found that even though the nightmare began for the victims’ families, Wright met with his police federation at a Sheffield restaurant to prepare “a defense” and “a solid rock story.” The secretary of the South Yorkshire Police Federation section, Agent Paul Middup, told the restaurant meeting before Wright showed up: “The chief of police had said that the truth could not come from him, but had given the secretary a totally free hand and had supported him,” as did many senior officers.
The meeting took place only four days after the disaster. It was the day The Sun splashed its headline “The Truth” about lies fed by four high-ranking South Yorkshire police officers. Middup was encouraged to continue this police campaign of defaming Liverpool supporters for alleged drunkenness and misconduct and “transmitting the message – unity – by force. ”
The panel report upheld the argument made in parliament that the orchestrated change in statements by junior officers by senior officers of the South Yorkshire police amounted to a “black propaganda unit. “ The statements of the officers, presented as official police accounts to the subsequent investigation, were changed to eliminate criticism of the police itself in the day, and, to a large extent, to emphasize the bad behavior of supporters. The group considered that 116 out of 164 statements were amended “to eliminate or alter unfavorable comments to the South Yorkshire police. ”
The police had claimed that this was done only to eliminate the "conjecture" and "opinion" of the statements, but the group had no doubt that the operation, to elaborate a case rather than deliver truthful police accounts, went further. “It was done to eliminate police criticism,” Scraton said.
This propaganda did not convince the original investigation, which ruled as soon as August 1989 that the police stories of intoxication and bad behavior of the fans were false, and criticized the police for making the claims. The report revealed that Sheffield Wednesday's football field was insecure in crucial respects, that the Football Association had selected it as the place for the match without even checking whether Hillsborough had a valid security certificate, which it did not.
In this scenario of abandonment, it was the poor management of the crowd by the police, commanded by an inexperienced chief superintendent David Duckenfield, who was “the main cause” of the disaster. Police lost control off the ground, where 24,000 Liverpool fans had to be channeled through only 23 tourniquets, so Duckenfield ordered a large exit door to be opened and a large number of people allowed in. His “first - magnitude error, ” according to research, was the failure to close the tunnel that led to the already overpopulated central section of the Leppings Lane terrace.
The investigation report established it, but the police, fearless, repeated their claims to the subsequent investigation. His procedure was characterized by a decision by the coroner not to take evidence of what happened after 3.15 p.m. on the day of the disaster, thus excluding an emergency response that the panel found chaotic. The conclusion that 41 of the 96 who died could have been saved if the police and ambulance service had done their job decently is condemnatory of those bodies and, Aspinall said, difficult to consider for families.
In the light of the panel's report, the Attorney General will now consider requesting the High Court to annul the verdict of inquiry into the accidental death and the conduct of a new investigation. There may also be prosecutions, after all these years, of Sheffield Wednesday, South Yorkshire Police and Sheffield City Council, which failed to carry out their duty to oversee the safety of the football field. Trevor Hicks, the president of the HFSG, whose teenage daughters, Sarah and Victoria, died in love, said: “The truth is out today. Tomorrow is for justice.”

- LRB-CNN-RRB- Marco Rubio's inside. The Florida Republican senator has announced that he is looking for the Republican presidential nomination, with an optimistic message that it embodies the promise of the American Dream.
With its youthful energy and Hispanic roots, it is tempting to see Rubio as the new blood the Republican Party needs to compete against Hillary Clinton in 2016. However, Rubio has been his worst enemy in what could have been his two signature issues: immigration reform and relations with Cuba. It has little appeal to Latino voters. And unless you can offer new ideas, your promotion to the Republican nomination will be steep.
In 2013, Rubio was a member of the Senate Gang of 8, which drafted a bipartisan proposal for comprehensive reform, including a path to citizenship for the nation's approximately 11 million undocumented immigrants. He later distanced himself from the bill after he faced resistance from the House Republicans, and now says he is in favour of a piecemeal approach, starting with securing the border.
His withdrawal in immigration means that Rubio has missed the opportunity to differentiate himself from most of the alleged Republican presidential candidates. It's a shame, because this issue was supposed to be your Latino voter business card.
Instead, Rubio has adopted a conservative approach typical of immigration. He believes that President Obama's Deferred Action program, which offers help for the deportation of young immigrants, must end. It has stated that the President's executive action on immigration, pending a review by the circuit court, sets a horrific precedent.
Meanwhile, both President Obama's Deferred Action program and executive action on immigration are overwhelmingly favored by Hispanics. No wonder the Latin Decisions research firm reports that, We find no evidence that Rubio's candidacy gets significant Latino support for his candidacy or for his party in general. Therefore, if Rubio has his ethnicity and personal history as the son of immigrants to win over his Hispanic companions, he is wrong.
In a private breakfast Monday for supporters, Rubio described running against a candidate in the race that is yesterday, and one who wants to take us back to yesterday. But when it comes to Cuba's politics, Rubio himself seems firmly trapped in the past. During the weekend, he described the recent thaw in relations between the two countries as ridiculous.
He has warned that Cuba is taking advantage of the United States. Here, he is an increasingly lonely voice. Most Americans support better relations with Cuba, as do most Cuban Americans. By clinging to the idea that isolating Cuba is better than getting involved with the communist country, Rubio has marginalized himself on an issue in which he could have provided insight and leadership.
Leaving aside immigration policy and Cuba, Rubio's political philosophy will be difficult to sell to Hispanics. He is a fierce opponent of Obamacare and wants the law to be repealed. However, the Affordable Care Act has led to a 12.3% drop in the rate of uninsured Hispanics, making Latinos the population with the highest insurance gain, thanks to the law. -LRB- In fact, Rubio signed his own family for Obamacare at the Washington exchange, taking advantage of a generous federal subsidy offered to legislators. - RRB-
Rubio favors a smaller government, while Latinos are more likely than the general public to say they favor a larger government that provides more services over a smaller government that provides less. And while Rubio doubts that climate change is caused by humans, The New York Times has pointed out that Latinos see global warming as a problem and favor government action on the issue.
Of course, Rubio is young and charismatic. But despite his work on the failed immigration law, Rubio has a significant lack of achievements to show during his five years in the Senate. In February, the Politico website reported that it headed the list of absent legislators.
Another weakness of Rubio is his lack of bold political proposals. Consider that your fellow Republican Party presidential nomination candidate, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, has been willing to present new ideas to the Republican base, such as reforming the criminal justice system and legalizing medical marijuana. Or that another Republican Party presidential candidate, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, feels totally comfortable with his image as a conservative fire. In comparison, Rubio seems prudent and inappropriate for the task of awakening Republican voters.
With his first jump in the 2016 race, Marco Rubio is positioning himself as the next generation of GOP leadership. Unfortunately, a fresh face in old ideas is not a winning combination, not for Rubio, and not for Latino voters.

Although the term “nationalism” has a variety of meanings, it centrally encompasses two phenomena: (1) the attitude that members of a nation have when they care about their identity as members of that nation and (2) the actions that members of a nation take in trying to achieve (or sustain) some form of political sovereignty (see, for example, Nielsen 1998-9: 9). Each of these aspects requires elaboration.
raises questions about the concept of nation or national identity, about what it is to belong to a nation, and about how much one should care about one's own nation. Nations and national identity can be defined in terms of common origin, ethnicity or cultural ties, and while a person ' s membership of the nation is often considered involuntary, it is sometimes considered voluntary. The degree of nation-care that nationalists require is often, but not always, taken to be very high: according to such views, one's nation's claims take precedence over rival contenders for authority and loyalty. [1]
raises questions as to whether sovereignty requires the acquisition of full statehood with full authority over internal and international affairs, or whether anything less than statehood is sufficient. Although sovereignty is often considered full statehood (Gellner 1983: ch. 1),[2] possible exceptions have been recognized (Miller 1992: 87; Miller 2000). Some authors even defend an anarchist version of moderate patriotism-nationalism predicted by Bakunin (see Sparrow 2007).
There is a terminological and conceptual question of distinguishing nationalism from patriotism. A popular proposal is the contrast between attachment to one's own country as a definition of patriotism and attachment to one's own people and their traditions as a definition of nationalism (Kleinig 2014: 228, and Primorátz 2017: Section 1.2). One problem with this proposal is that love for a country is not really love for a piece of land, but usually involves attachment to the community of its inhabitants, and this introduces “nation” in the conception of patriotism. Another contrast is that between strong attachment and somewhat aggressive (nationalism) and mild (patrioticism), which goes back at least to George Orwell (see his 1945 essay). [3]
Despite these definitional concerns, there is a good deal of agreement on the classical, historically paradigmatic form of nationalism. It typically presents the supremacy of the nation's claims over other claims of individual loyalty and full sovereignty as the persistent goal of its political agenda. Territorial sovereignty has traditionally been seen as a defining element of state power and essential to the nation. He was praised in modern classical works by Hobbes, Locke and Rousseau and is returning to the center of the debate, although philosophers are now more skeptical (see below). Issues related to the control of the movement of money and people (in particular immigration) and the rights of resources implied by territorial sovereignty make the issue politically central in the era of globalization and philosophically interesting both for nationalists and anti-nationalists.
In recent times, the philosophical approach has moved more towards “liberal nationalism,” the vision that mitigates classical demands and seeks to unite pro-national attitudes and respect for traditional liberal values. For example, classical nationalists consider that the territorial state as a political unit is centrally “belonging” to an ethnic-cultural group and is actively charged with protecting and promulgating its traditions. The liberal variety allows the territorial state to be “shared” with non-dominant ethnic groups. The consequences are varied and very interesting (for more information, see below, especially section 2.1).

The National Security Agency (NSA) has obtained direct access to the systems of Google, Facebook, Apple and other U.S. Internet giants, according to a top secret document. Access to the NSA is part of a previously undisclosed program called PRISM, which allows officials to collect material including search history, email content, file transfers, and live chats, the document says.
The Guardian has verified the authenticity of the document, a 41-slide PowerPoint presentation – classified as an undistributed ultrasecret to foreign allies – which was apparently used to train intelligence agents in the capabilities of the program. The document states “received directly from the servers” from major US service providers. Although the submission states that the programme is implemented with the help of the companies, all those who responded to a request for comment denied knowledge of any such programme.
In a statement, Google said: “Google is deeply concerned about the security of our users’ data. We divulge user data to the government in accordance with the law and carefully review all these requests. From time to time, people claim that we have created a "back door" of the government on our systems, but Google does not have a back door for the government to access data from private users."
Several top technology executives insisted that they had no knowledge of PRISM or any similar scheme. They said they would never have been involved in such a program. “If you’re doing this, you’re doing it without our knowledge,” one said. An Apple spokesman said he had “never heard” from PRISM.
NSA access was allowed by changes in the U.S. surveillance law, introduced under President Bush and renewed under Obama in December 2012. The programme facilitates comprehensive and in-depth monitoring of live communications and stored information. The law allows the selection of any client from participating companies living outside the U.S., or those Americans whose communications include persons outside the U.S. It also opens the possibility that communications made entirely within the U.S. pick up without a warrant.
Disclosure of the PRISM program follows a leak to The Guardian on Wednesday of a top secret court order forcing Verizon telecommunications provider to deliver the phone records of millions of U.S. customers. The participation of internet companies in PRISM will be added to the debate on the scale of surveillance by intelligence services. Unlike the collection of such call records, this monitoring may include the content of communications and not just metadata. Some of the world's largest internet brands are said to be part of the information exchange program since its introduction in 2007. Microsoft – which is currently running an advertising campaign with the slogan “Your privacy is our priority” – was the first, with the collection starting in December 2007. It was followed by Yahoo in 2008; Google, Facebook and PalTalk in 2009; YouTube in 2010; Skype and AOL in 2011; and finally Apple, who joined the program in 2012. The program continues to expand, with other providers coming online. Collectively, companies cover the vast majority of email, search, video and online communications networks. The scope and nature of the data collected from each company varies. Companies are legally required to comply with user communications requests under U.S. law, but the PRISM program allows direct access by intelligence services to company servers. The NSA document states that operations are “assisted by communications providers in the United States. ” The disclosure also supports concerns raised by several U.S. senators during the renewal of the FISA Amendment Act (FAA) in December 2012, who warned about the scale of surveillance that the law could allow and shortcomings in the safeguards it introduces. When the FAA was first enacted, the advocates of the statute argued that significant control of the abuse would be the inability of the NSA to obtain electronic communications without the consent of the telecommunications and Internet companies that control the data.
But the PRISM program makes that consent unnecessary, as it allows the agency to directly and unilaterally seize the communications of the company servers.
A graph prepared by the NSA, contained in the top secret document, highlights the breadth of data you can get: email, video and voice chat, videos, photos, voice chats about IP (Skype, for example), file transfers, social media details, and more. The document is recent, dating back to April 2013. Such a leak is extremely rare in the history of the NSA, which prides itself on maintaining a high level of secrecy.
The PRISM program allows the NSA, the world's largest surveillance organization, to obtain targeted communications without having to request them from service providers and without having to obtain individual court orders. With this program, the NSA is able to reach directly the servers of the participating companies and obtain both stored communications and collect in real time from the selected users.
A senior administration official said in a statement: “The Guardian and Washington Post articles refer to the compilation of communications under section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA). This law does not allow any U.S. citizen or any person within the United States to be attacked. The programme is subject to the supervision of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Tribunal, the Executive and Congress. It involves extensive procedures, specifically approved by the court, to ensure that only non-U.S. individuals outside the U.S. are targeted and minimize the acquisition, retention and dissemination of incidentally acquired information about American people.
“This program was recently reauthorized by Congress after extensive hearings and debates. The information collected under this program is one of the most important and valuable intelligence information we collect and is used to protect our nation from a wide variety of threats.”

This study investigated the economic effects of malaria on cocoa producers in Ondo State, Nigeria, using the ordinary minimum square regression technique. Descriptive statistics were used to identify strategies to reduce malaria infection among cocoa producers. The sample framework for the study was obtained from secondary data obtained from the Ondo Ministry of Health records of registered cocoa producers who had malaria during the production season in 2015. Multistage, systematic and intentional samples were used to select 180 respondents for the study. Some of the variables included: annual income of farmers, direct cost of malaria treatment, number of days of incapacitation and additional labour costs incurred by farmers during periods of incapacitation. The results of the study showed that the average annual income estimate was 524,096. However, it was found that the cost of malaria treatment and the additional labour cost involved had a significant impact on farmers ' incomes; the number of days of incapacitation had no significant impact on the incomes of cocoa producers.
Keywords: Malaria, income, regression of ordinary minimum squares and cocoa.
Introduction
Economic growth and development are achievable in any nation with a viable agricultural sector. Most developed nations in the world are characterized by technology-driven agricultural production activities. This has increased self-sufficiency in the feeding of its population. In developing countries, however, agricultural production activities are highly dependent on the rural population using manual labour. Because of the physical nature of agricultural activities, farmers ' health could be negatively affected by diseases such as malaria if they have little or no medical care. It has been noted that medical issues have a negative impact on Nigeria ' s agricultural productivity and that malaria has contributed greatly to poor health in Africa (Breman et al., 2006). According to Kwadwo et al. (2009), human activities, including agriculture, have been recognized as one of the reasons for the increase in malaria intensity worldwide, because they support the breeding of mosquitoes carrying the parasite. Mohammed et al. (2018) stated that a higher percentage of small farmers in Nigeria are leaving (sic) rural areas. A typical rural village in the country is characterized by an indecent environment, poor housing, a muddy environment and water exposed in wells and sewers. These characteristics mentioned above are breeding grounds for mosquitoes that in turn inject malaria parasites into the rural population. Malaria as a life-threatening disease is caused by parasites that are transmitted to people through the bites of infected female anopheles (World Health Organization, 2016).
Despite being a preventable and treatable disease, malaria represents about 212 million cases and 429,000 deaths worldwide in 2015 alone (World Health Organization, 2016). Over 80 per cent of the estimated malaria deaths in 2012 occurred in only 17 countries, with 80 per cent of cases occurring in 18 countries, with the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Nigeria jointly accounting for 40 per cent of the global total estimated (World Health Organization, 2012; National Population Commission and others, 2012).
The recurrent nature of malaria and the coincidence of the high season of malaria with the harvest season accentuated the burden on the rural poor who are already dependent on subsistence agriculture and limited survival options (Adhanom et al., 2006; Chuma et al., 2006). Thus, malaria is expected to affect farmers ' incomes in the agricultural season. Evidence of the economic burden of malaria is important to prioritize prevention and treatment services at the national and subnational levels and facilitates better allocation of resources in the health care system (McIntyre et al., 2006; Larg and Moss, 2011). Comparing the evidence of the economic burden of malaria from different environments, time periods, patient groups and epidemiological profiles is difficult (Drummond, 2015), therefore, traditionally, studies that have attempted to estimate the economic burden of malaria have focused on private and non-private medical costs associated with the disease, as well as some measure of the income lost as a result of malaria morbidity and mortality (Jefferey and Pia, 2002).
There is no empirical evidence to investigate the effects of malaria on the incomes of cocoa producers, although studies have been conducted on the effects of malaria on farmers in general. Studies have also focused on how the disease generally affects cocoa producers; however, there is no study focusing on the economic effects of malaria on cocoa producers. Intensified and increased commitment and financial allocation for malaria prevention and control measures have reduced the burden of malaria mortality among children under five years of age by 29 per cent worldwide within five years of 2010 (World Health Organization, 2016), so a little understanding of the problems of malaria for cocoa producers will help policymakers, especially non-governmental organizations interested in boosting cocoa exports among developing countries, to formulate appropriate policies aimed at reducing the incidence of malaria among cocoa producers.
