In less than a week, Turkey will hold its first direct presidential elections, however, the mood about the country can hardly be described as electric.
This is strange given the usual enthusiasm for the elections in Turkey, the historic importance of this survey, and the exceptionally high level of socio-political tensions in recent years.
In addition to the summer heat and Muslim fast month of Ramadan, the relative calm could be explained by the widespread expectation that Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, candidate of the AKP ruler, will emerge triumphant from the polls, either in the first or second round.
Erdogan understands power and pursues it like no other politician in modern Turkish history.
It has stricter control over all key state institutions, except perhaps the Constitutional Court. He also has a deeply emotional relationship with his followers, who gather around his leader with more passion as he faces a tougher opposition to his increasingly personal government.
This is how it has survived massive anti-government protests, a damaging enmity with former Islamist allies and a high-profile corruption scandal, a terribly poorly managed industrial disaster and successive foreign policy debacles -- the latest is the kidnapping of 49 Turkish diplomats and consulate workers in Mosul by ISIS militants, whose rise some critics attribute in part to the open border policy of the AKP government to fight jihadists in Syria -- all in the space of a year.
This could also explain the gloomy tone around many of his opponents, who seem to believe that having been so close to realizing his long-standing ambition to become Turkey's first popularly elected president, Erdogan will not miss the opportunity.
But calm must not overshadow the critical importance of elections.
Without a doubt, an Erdogan victory would not amount to a regime change for Turkey.
It would be the most crucial step in its transformation from an imperfect parliamentary democracy under military tutelage to a plebiscite democracy characterized by a powerful executive, weak or obedient legislature, and a charismatic leader-follower relationship that is regularly reaffirmed in the general elections and referendums.
It would be a mistake to think of the presidency, under Turkey's current parliamentary system, as a ceremonial position that would deprive its occupier of the executive powers of a prime minister. Turkey has had ambitious presidents, such as Turgut Ozal - LRB- 1989 - 1993 -RRB- and Ahmet Necdet Sezer -LRB- 2000 - 2007 -RRB-, whose influence was controlled by hostile legislators or meddling generals. A President Erdogan would not face these obstacles: his party controls the parliament and the military have been tamed through EU-backed reforms and two highly politicized judicial cases.
The current constitution, drawn up by the military junta in 1982, gives the head of state important authorities, which Erdogan would push to the limit invoking the national will that he intends to embody; a demand that would be strengthened and further personalized in the event of his election.
Where would this scenario leave those who feel increasingly alienated, suffocated and marginalized in Erdogan's new Turkey? Another electoral loss would be sure to discourage even more those who expected to see some change in the political status quo after last summer's Gezi protests.
But in defeat, there could be a valuable and necessary lesson. The two main opposition parties, the secular Republican CHP and the nationalist MHP, have formed an informal coalition with the sole purpose of posing a numerical challenge to the relative majority of the AKP, with anti-Erdoganism being its main unifying cause.
Party leaders have chosen candidates and determined electoral strategies with minimal public consultation. Only a handful of people participated in the selection of Ekmeleddin Ihsanoglu, former Secretary General of the Organization for Islamic Cooperation, as a joint candidate for the presidency of the two parties.
Predictably, this uninspiring, ultra-pragmatic and top-down tactic fell short in local elections - LRB - even when the allegations of electoral fraud are taken into account, the AKP remains the clear general winner -RRB - and runs the risk of failing in the presidential election. More importantly, this style of politics is contrary to the popular, democratic and pluralistic vision that the gezi spirit has aspired to grasp.
Whatever the outcome of the presidential elections, those who wish this vision to be transformed into reality would benefit more from focusing on the long-term process than on short-term achievements, and from building organizational capacity at the local policy level rather than obsessing over the control of State institutions in Ankara.
Success in local politics paves the way for success in national politics, as Turkey's political Islamists have demonstrated over and over again over the past two decades. But a genuine democratic transformation also requires the return of political authority.
Since its founding as a republic 91 years ago, Turkey's over-centralized political architecture has allowed those who gain state control to force their will over the entire population.
The machinery that repressed ethnic minorities and pious Muslims in the past is now alienating non-practicing Muslims, alevis, LGBTI members and other social and political minority groups that do not fit Erdogan's vision of an openly religious neoliberal Turkey.
Only a well-organized movement that takes its strength from local politics and defends pluralism, decentralization and the democratic rights and freedoms of all citizens can break this vicious circle of repression and alienation.

text:
f we are going to discuss the question of whether there is a need for moral principles, we need an idea of what we mean by "moral principle". Unfortunately there are two radically different concepts to what moral principles are. The first conception, the ‘absolute’ conception, takes a moral principle to be a universal claim in the sense that all actions of a certain kind are generally incorrect (or correct). The principle ‘do not break your promises’ can be expressed in several ways: ‘it is wrong to break your own promises,’ ‘all actions involving breaking a promise are wrong,’ and so on. In absolute conception, all this means that each and every act of breaking a promise is a wrong action, anything else that can be said by it. Every action of this kind is in general wrong, despite any redemptive features it may have.
There is a very different way to understand a moral principle, as ‘contributive’ rather than absolute. Understandd in this second way, our principle holds that if an action involves breaking a promise, that counts against it. Action is worse because it is a promise that breaks. Of course, it may be worse to be a breaker of promises, but better for some other feature it has, being kind means, let's say. The contributory conception of moral principles allows more than one principle to be applied to the case before us, since it holds that each principle is, so to speak, partial; each one specifies how things are only in a certain respect. But actions have many relevant characteristics, some count for and others against. If the action is generally correct or incorrect it can only be determined by the general balance of the right and the wrong in it. The contributory principles do not tell us by themselves how to determine that balance. They only specify contributions one by one, and leave us to find out how they add up. Some people assume that the principles themselves can be classified in order of importance; if that were correct, it would be of some help to us in the elaboration of what matters most in a given case. Others assume that such a lexicon order is not available, and that the matter is left to ‘trial’ without help.
Since there are two very different concepts from what a moral principle says, our discussion will have to address both possibilities. If particularism is true, there is not much room for moral principles of any kind.

text:
Buber's best-known work is the short philosophical essay I and Thou (1923), whose basic principles he had to modify but never abandon. In this work, Buber gives expression to the intuition that we need to resist the temptation to reduce human relations to the simple or Apollonius or Dionysian, rational or romantic way of relating to others. We are beings who can enter into dialogical relationships not only with other humans, but with other animated beings, such as animals, or a tree, as well as with the Divine You. The duality of relations and, in their extreme, their coincidence, can serve as the key to Buber's mature thinking above all, from his approach to biblical faith to his practical policy in matters of Jewish-Arab relations in Palestine. You and I were first translated into English in 1937 by Ronald Gregor Smith and later by Walter Kaufmann. The original German was an instant classic and remains printed today. In the 1950s and 1960s, when Buber traveled and gave lectures for the first time in the U.S., the essay became popular in the English-speaking world as well.
While prior to World War I Buber had promoted an aesthetic of unity and unification, his later writings embrace a harsher and more elementary dualism. Buber was always opposed to the philosophical monism, which identified with Bergson, and opposed the “immersion doctrines”, which he identified with Buddhism. Complicated by the undifferentiated form of mystical experience (as sought by the medievals, including Eckhart, as an annihilation of self), the deeply dualistic view of the world presented in I and YOU refers to the coincidence of Cusa as an expression of human boundaries. Buber’s text reduces the relationship between people, animated objects and deity to three expressive meanings: “I”, “You” and “Lo”. They are the elementary variables whose combination and re-combination structure all experiences as relational. Individual elements realize in relationships, forming tractters that break into life, grow, disappear, and relive. Human intersubjectivity affirms the polymorphic encounter I-Thou. Based on the assertion that I do not exist isolated apart from the relationship with another, dialogue or “meeting” transforms each figure into a center of ultimate and mysterious value whose presence eludes the concepts of instrumental language. The heteronomic revelation of a singular presence calls the subject to an open relationship, a living pattern, which defies meaning, logic and proportion; while the I-It relationship, at its most degenerate stage, assumes the fixed form of objects that one can measure and manipulate. At the center of this model of existence is the notion of encounter as "revelation". As Buber understands, revelation is the revelation of "presence" (Gegenwart). Unlike the "object" (Gegenstand), the presence revealed by revelation as encounter occupies the space "between" the subject and another (tree, person, work of art, God). This space “between” is defined as “mutuous” (gegenseitig). Contrast with the Kantian concept of experience (Erfahrung), Erlebnis (encounter), or revelation of pure presence, is an ineffable, pure form that does not carry an apex of defined conceptual or linguistic content or object-like. Buber always insisted that the dialogic principle, that is, the duality of the primary words (Urworte) he called the I-Thou and the I-It, was not an abstract conception but an ontological reality to which he pointed but which could not be adequately represented in discursive prose.
The confusion (and/or confusion) between philosophy and religion is especially marked in Me and You. While Buber seems to lack a fully elaborate epistemology and sometimes delights in paradoxes bordering on mystical theology, it has been argued that Buber effectively resolved the inherent “difficulty of dialogues that reflects on and speaks of a human reality about which, in his own words, one cannot think and speak properly” (Bloch [1983] p. 62). The debates on the strength and weakness of Me and You as the basis of a system are based, in part, on the assumption that the five-volume project, to which this book was to serve as a prolegomenon (a project abandoned Buber), was in fact philosophical. Buber's lectures at the Freies jüdisches Lehrhaus and his courses at the University of Frankfurt, as well as letters to Rosenzweig show that, at the time of his writing, he was concerned about a new approach to the phenomenology of religion (cf. Schottroff, Zank). In Buber's cyclical conception of the history of religions, the revelation of presence mixes and animates the living and lived forms of historical religion (institutions, texts, rituals, images and ideas), becoming ossified and rigid and object-like over time, but structurally open to the force of renewal based on new forms of encounter as revelation. The history of religion described by Buber in the final words of Me and You is a spiral figure that contracts and intensifies that it has redemption as its telos. It would be artificial, however, to separate Buber's interest in religious phenomena from his interest in a general philosophical anthropology. Rather, Buber seems to have tried to find one in the other, or - put differently - to make religious belief and perceptive practice in the light of a general philosophical anthropology.
label: C2

text:
Body allergy tests are convincing thousands of people to take unnecessary treatments and put themselves or their children on inadequate diets, sometimes resulting in malnutrition, said a group of experts and charities. Allergies and food intolerances are increasing, but the confusion between the two, as well as the many wrong diagnoses, are causing real harm, said the Sense About Science information organization, which has produced a guide in collaboration with allergy specialists and charities.
“It’s probably the biggest disaster for scientific communication, where myths, misinterpreted studies, and charlatans clash with inadequate and excessive diagnosis,” said Tracey Brown, director of Sense About Science. “The costs are huge – unnecessary actions for some and not enough for those whose lives depend on it.”
Experts fear that restaurants and catering are seeing so many people who claim to have allergies (which can be dangerous to the individual), when in fact they have a food intolerance (which is not), that they do not take all the precautions they should take when serving a person who has a genuine allergy.
“It matters a lot,” said Moira Austin of the Anaphylaxis Campaign. “If a caterer thinks someone is simply avoiding a meal because they don’t want to swell, they may be less careful. There have been a series of deaths in which people have gone to a restaurant and alerted staff who have an allergy to a particular food and food has been served containing that allergen.”
The guide says that most Internet and allergy tests purchased from stores have no scientific basis. They include a home testing kit that looks for specific IgG antibodies (immunoglobulin G) against food in the blood. Although these antibodies are part of the immune system’s response to infections, “the best medical evidence has shown that elevated IgG levels do not suggest an allergy,” says the guide. “The results are often positive in individuals who do not have an allergy or food intolerance.”
It also discredits a test, a mixture of acupuncture and homeopathy, which attempts to measure electronic resistance through the skin while the child or adult has suspicious food in his or her hand. Hair follicle tests are also useless, says the guide. “The hair is not involved in allergic reactions, so hair sample testing cannot provide any useful information about the allergic state.” Nor should people be tricked into thinking that allergies are caused by a “energy block” that can be diagnosed by muscle tests and cured by acupuncture.
“I often see children who have been given unnecessarily restricted diets because their parents assume, in good faith, that they have multiple food allergies based on ‘allergy tests’ that have no scientific basis,” said Paul Seddon, a pediatric allergist consultant, on behalf of the UK Cochrane Centre, an independent organization that evaluates medical tests. “This has to stop, which can only happen if we deny these ‘proofs’.”
Another pediatric allergist consultant, Adam Fox, from Guys and St Thomas’ Hospital in London, said: “I get a number of patients, and my colleagues too, who will come to send hair for analysis or who have excluded a whole range of food for their children. It's very hard to untangle that. There are two challenges. Children have to receive adequate diets, but more of this is the unnecessary avoidance of things that are not harmful, which has a great impact on quality of life. A child who cannot eat wheat or drink milk cannot go to parties.”
The conviction that a child's chronic lethargy or headaches or eczema are caused by an allergy takes a long time and many tests to prove or refute. It is tempting to go to an alternative therapist who will do a single test and provide a quick but inaccurate response.
Allergies are on the rise in developed countries. The percentages of children diagnosed with allergic rhinitis and eczema have tripled in the last 30 years. Although there is now a better diagnosis, the increase in incidence is real, leading many more people to suspect allergies are the reason for their own health problems or those of their children. The guide lists a number of myths about sources of allergies, from the suggestion that they are caused by E numbers in food dyes to “toxic overload” and fast food.

text:
In hermeneutics, the interpretative experience is typically clarified in reference to understanding. In this context, when we say that we understand, what we mean is that we have actually achieved something through an attempt at interpretation; and, when we say that we do not understand, we mean that we have not really reached anywhere with our interpretation. For this reason, understanding can be described as a ‘success’ of interpretation (even if, from Heidegger, understanding is more commonly described as a fulfillment, realization, or promulgation). In hermeneutics, such a success of understanding is not measured by standards and methods typical of modern natural sciences and quantitative social sciences, as if our understanding derives from a repeatable experiment, nor by standards typical of much of modern philosophy, as if our understanding has undoubted epistemic foundations.
Now, philosophers associated with hermeneutics describe the success of understanding in various ways. However, the success of understanding is described, however, it is usually also described as edifying or educational. In fact, Hans-Georg Gadamer, the philosopher perhaps more closely associated with hermeneutics in our times, closely connects interpretative experience with education. By education, he has in mind the concept of formation (Bildung) that had developed in the classicism of Weimar and that continued to influence 19th-century romanticism and historicism in Germany (Truth and Method, Part I.1). [1] Education, as training, involves more than the acquisition of experience, knowledge or information; it refers to the expansion of our person through formal instruction, especially in the arts and humanities, as well as through a wide and varied experience. Consequently, the success of understanding is educational in the sense that we learn from our interpretative experience, perhaps not only on one issue, but also on ourselves, the world and others.
That the success of understanding is educational in this way can be clarified by an example, for example, by reading a text such as the History of Thucydides of the Peloponnese War. When we say that we understand this text, we mean that our attempts to interpret it (either rigorously, as in erudition, or more casually, as in evening reading) have come to something, perhaps: that in politics, prudent reasoning is not always persuasive enough to stop the tide of war. Certainly, we have not come to this understanding as a result of a repeatable scientific experiment or based on an undoubted epistemic basis. But it is not for this reason less educational. In this understanding, we have come to something that we can agree with or disagree with, something that in any case expands or changes our views on the role of reason in politics (and certainly also about public discourse and the causes of war), and, finally, something that can also teach us something about ourselves and about the world in which we find ourselves.

Twelve photographers from four continents have been shortlisted for the fourth Prix Pictet prize in photography and sustainability.
The issue of this year's power has an enormous breadth, encompassing contradictions and paradoxes to the same extent that it has discovered images and themes that are both impressive and disturbing, the organizers say.
The aim of the award is to use the power of photography to raise public awareness of the social and environmental challenges of the new millennium.
The winner will be announced by Kofi Annan, the honorary president of the awards, in October at the opening of the finalist exhibition of the works shortlisted at the Saatchi Gallery in London. The exhibition takes place from 10 to 28 October 2012.

text:
The private social audio application Clubhouse is attracting masses of new users from mainland China, where the U.S. app remains uncensored by the authorities despite the flourishing discussions on rights, national identity and other sensitive issues.
Western social media applications, such as Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube, are banned in China, where the local Internet is heavily censored to remove content that could undermine the ruling communist party.
The Clubhouse app, launched in early 2020, experienced explosive growth in the number of users earlier this month after Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev held a surprise discussion on the platform.
Its chat rooms are only accessible through invitations from current members, and starting Sunday, invitations to the platform were sold between 50-400 yuan (7.73 - 69.59 dollars) on popular Chinese e-commerce sites.
Reuters directly observed several ‘club’ conversations in Chinese in which thousands of users heard extensive audio discussions on topics such as Xinjiang detention camps, Taiwan’s independence, and the Hong Kong National Security Act.
China's cyber authorities have become increasingly tight in recent years, expanding the reach of banned applications, media and social networking sites in the country.
Although Clubhouse is not censored, it is only available on iOS devices and is not available in the local Apple app store, both major barriers to its widespread use in China.
Mainland Chinese users can access the app by modifying the location of their app store.
It is not clear why the app is still unlocked in China, although some foreign social sites with small Chinese followers manage to operate under censor radar, including 8kun, a central hub for QAnon followers.
In a Hong Kong policy-focused club talk, activists, journalists, and artists discussed former President Trump and his support base in the former colony.
Another popular Chinese language club on the site starting Saturday involved a rare open exchange between netizens in mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong for the increase in political tensions in the region.
The discussion became a hot topic on China's own Weibo social media website on Twitter on Saturday.
“I don’t know how long this environment can last,” said one user in a popular Weibo post who liked it more than 65,000 times. “But I will definitely remember this moment in the history of the Internet.”
(1 = 6,4664 Chinese renminbi yuan)

text:
In mathematics, the Taylor series of a function is an infinite sum of terms that are expressed in terms of function derivatives in a single point. For the most common functions, the function and sum of your Taylor series are equal near this point. Taylor's series is named after Brook Taylor, who introduced them in 1715.
If zero is the point where derivatives are considered, a Taylor series is also called a Maclaurin series, after Colin Maclaurin, which made extensive use of this special case of the Taylor series in the 18th century.
The partial sum formed by the first terms n of a Taylor series is a polynomial of degree n which is called Taylor's polynomial n of function. Taylor's polynomials are approximations of a function, which generally become better as n increases. Taylor's theorem gives quantitative estimates of the error introduced by the use of such approximations. If the Taylor series of a function is convergent, its sum is the limit of the infinite sequence of Taylor polynomials. A feature may differ from the sum of your Taylor series, even if your Taylor series is convergent. A function is analytical at a point x if it is equal to the sum of its Taylor series in some open interval (or open disk in the complex plane) containing x. This implies that the function is analytical at each point in the interval (or disk).
The Greek philosopher Zeno considered the problem of adding an infinite series to achieve a finite result, but rejected it as an impossibility;[2] the result was Zeno's paradox. Later, Aristotle proposed a philosophical resolution of the paradox, but the mathematical content was apparently unsolved until it was taken by Archimedes, as it had been before Aristotle by the Presocratic Atomist Democritus. It was through Archimedes' method of exhaustion that an infinite number of progressive subdivisions could be realized to achieve a finite result. [3] Liu Hui independently used a similar method a few centuries later. [4]
In the 14th century, Madhava of Sangamagram gave the first examples of the use of the Taylor series and closely related methods. [5][6] Although no record of his work survives, later Indian mathematicians' writings suggest that he found a series of special cases of the Taylor series, including those for trigonometric functions of sine, cosine, tangent and arctangent. The Kerala School of Astronomy and Mathematics further expanded its work with various serial expansions and rational approaches until the 16th century.
In the 17th century, James Gregory also worked in this area and published several Maclaurin series. However, it was not until 1715 that Brook Taylor finally provided a general method for constructing these series for all the functions for which they exist[7], after which the series is named.
The Maclaurin series was named after Colin Maclaurin, professor in Edinburgh, who published the special case of the result Taylor in the 18th century.
label: C2

text:
Scientists have implanted a false memory in the brains of mice in an experiment that they hope to shed light on the well-documented phenomenon by which people 'remember' events or experiences that have never happened. False memories are a major problem with witness statements in court.
Accused persons have often been convicted of crimes based on eyewitness testimony only to have their convictions overturned later when DNA, or some other corroborating evidence, is recorded.
To study how these false memories could form in the human brain, Susumu Tonagawa, a neuroscientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), and his team encoded memories in the brain of mice by manipulating individual neurons. The memories of experiences we have had are made of various elements, including records of objects, space and time. These records, called engrams, are encoded into physical and chemical changes in brain cells and the connections between them.
According to Tonagawa, both false and genuine memories seem to depend on the same brain mechanisms. In his work, Tonagawa's team used a technique known as optogenetics, which allows fine control of individual brain cells. They designed brain cells in the hippocampus of the mouse, a part of the brain that is known to be involved in the formation of memories, to express the gene of a protein called canalrhodopsin. When cells containing carajordopsin are exposed to blue light, they are activated. The researchers also modified the hippocampus cells so that the protein of the canalrhodopsin was produced in the brain cells that the mouse was using to encode its memory engrams.
In the experiment, Tonagawa's team placed the mice in a camera and allowed them to explore it. As they did so, the relevant memory-coding brain cells were producing the canalrhodopsin protein. The next day, the same mice were placed in a second chamber and given a small electric shock, to encode a fear response. At the same time, researchers shone light on the mouse's brains to activate their memories of the first camera. In this way, the mice learned to associate the fear of electric shock with the memory of the first camera.
In the final part of the experiment, the team placed the mice in the first chamber.
The mice froze, demonstrating a typical fear response, even though they had never been caught while they were there. “We call this ‘inceptor’ or implant false memories into a mouse brain,” Tonagawa told Science.
A similar process can occur when powerful false memories are created in humans. “Humans are very imaginative animals,” Tonagawa said. “Regardless of what is happening around you in the outside world, humans constantly have internal activity in the brain. So, like our mouse, it is quite possible that we can associate what we have in our mind with bad or good continuous events of high variation. In other words, there could be a false association of what you have in your mind instead of what is happening to you.
He added: “Our study showed that false memory and genuine memory are based on very similar, almost identical, brain mechanisms. It is difficult for the bearer of false memory to distinguish between them. We hope that our future findings along this line will further alert legislatures and legal experts to how unreliable memory can be.”
Chris French, head of the Goldsmiths Anomaly Psychology Research Unit, University of London, is a leading researcher in false memories of people. He said the latest results were an important first step in understanding his neural base.
“Memory researchers have always recognized that memory does not work, as is often assumed, as a video camera, faithfully recording all the details of anything we experience. Instead, it is a reconstructive process, which involves building a specific memory from fragments of traces of real memory of the original event, but also possibly including information from other sources.” He warned that false memories created in mice in experiments were much simpler than complex false memories that have generated controversy within psychology and psychiatry — for example, false memories of child sexual abuse, or even memories of unusually ritualized satanic abuse, alien kidnapping, or “past lives. ” “Such rich false memories will clearly involve many brain systems and we are still a long way from understanding the processes involved in their formation at the neuronal level,” said the French professor.
Mark Stokes, a neuroscientist at Oxford University, said the experiments were a “tour de force” but it was important to put them in perspective. “Although the results seem to imply that the new memories were formed by artificial stimulation (instead of the real environment), this type of phenomenon is still far from the memory idea of most people,” he said. Rather, he said, it was equivalent to implanting an association that perhaps someone cannot place but that makes them distrust a specific environment for no apparent reason. “It is unlikely that this type of pairing can lead to the rich set of associations related to normal memories, although it is possible that, over time, that pairing can integrate with other memories to build a more elaborate false narrative.”
Mouse models created by the MIT team will help scientists ask increasingly complex questions about memories in people. “Now that we can reactivate and change the content of memories in the brain, we can start asking questions that were once the realm of philosophy,” said Steve Ramirez, Tonagawa’s colleague at MIT. “Are there multiple conditions that lead to the formation of false memories? Can false memories be artificially created? What about false memories for more than contexts – false memories for objects, food, or other mice? These are the science fiction questions that can be addressed experimentally in the laboratory.
As technology develops, the Frenchman said, scientists need to think carefully about its uses. “Whatever means is used to implant false memories, we need to be very aware of the ethical problems posed by such procedures – the potential for abuse of such techniques cannot be exaggerated.”
label: C2

text:
Naturalism establishes an opposition between standards X (scientific, mathematical or scientific-mathematic) and other types of standards, e.g., astrological, theological, or common sense standards. Another example of standards that the naturalist sees on the wrong side of the tracks is ‘fundamental’ philosophical ones. Goodman and Quine (in their pre-naturalist phase) once began an article declaring that the basis of their nominalism was a fundamental philosophical intuition irreducible to scientific foundations (1947). Naturalists refuse to appeal to such rules.
An apparent problem with naturalism is that there seems to be no sharp boundary between science and non-science and between mathematics and non-mathematics. For example, the transition from physics to physics philosophy to physical-heavy metaphysics to common-o-garden metaphysics seems to be gradual. When a mathematician writes a research article, an undergraduate textbook, a popular book on mathematics, a book that exposes his personal philosophy of mathematics and his psychological associations with various mathematical theories, at what point exactly has he stopped doing mathematics? When research mathematicians meet after the seminar and agree on coffee that Riemann's Hypothesis is the most important problem in mathematics, is this a strictly mathematical affirmation or a personal judgment recognized by mathematicians as outside the province of proper mathematics?
Many philosophers follow Quine to quote a standard group of principles supposedly constitutive of scientific standards: empirical adequacy, ontological economy, simplicity, fertility, etc. (Quine 1955, 247; Quine and Ullian 1970, chap. 5). However, lists of this kind are unsatisfactory for several reasons. First, the principles come in different versions. However, it is doubtful whether the general versions are scientifically approved. Some writers claim, for example, that the scientific appeal to ontological parsimony does not extend to the postulation of abstract objects (Burgess 1998). Others argue that scientific appeals to simplicity are not better expressed by the totally general slogan "Prefer any T1 theory to a less simple T2 theory (in this sense)" (Paseau 2007). On the other hand, lists of this kind do not tell us how to balance the disclaimers with each other.
Since the explosion of scientific studies in the 1960s, more attention has now been paid to the nuances of scientific practice. However, a more precise articulation of scientific standards and their weights remains elusive. The existence of an algorithm that encapsulates the scientific method is generally questioned (although many humans apparently manage to implement the scientific method, so if the method is not algorithmic then neither are our minds). What is not questionable, however, is that your exposure currently escapes us.
Having said that, it is not clear how serious the border problem is for naturalists. Perhaps they can argue that there is a fairly sharp border, although it is difficult to define. Perhaps mathematicians know implicitly when something counts as a piece of mathematics and when it is a non-mathematical comment on mathematics. In any case, naturalism seems to survive the absence of an acute limit. It seems that naturalism can base its claims on a set of rules with blurred limits.
label: C2

text:
No one knows which one was the first: the economic crisis that destroyed Greece or Shisha, the drug now known as the “cocaine of the poor”. What everyone accepts is that Shisha is a murderer; and at 2 € or less a blow, he is one who has come to haunt Greece, the country for a long time in the front line of Europe's financial crisis.
“As drugs go, it’s the worst. It burns the inside of you, makes you aggressive and assures you that you become totally crazy,” said Maria, a former heroin addict. “But it’s cheap and easy to get, and that’s what everyone is doing.”
This drug crisis has put the health authorities in Athens, already overwhelmed by draconian cuts, under increased stress.
The drug of preference for thousands of homeless Greeks forced to go out on the street by poverty and despair, Shisha is described by addicts and officials as a variant of crystal methamphetamine, whose potential to send users to a state of senseless violence is backed by substances with which synthetic drugs are often mixed: battery acid, motor oil and even shampoo.
Worse still, it is not only easy to get, but easy to do, tailor-made for a society that sees little light at the end of the tunnel.
“He’s a killer, but he also makes you want to kill,” said Konstantinos, a drug addict. You can kill without understanding you've done it. And it's spreading faster than death. Many users have died.”
For Charalampos Poulopoulos, head of Kethea, Greece's pre-eminent anti-drug center, Shisha symbolizes the predations of a crisis that has led to record levels of misery and unemployment. It is, he said, a “austerity drug” – the response of traffickers who have become increasingly expert in the production of synthetic drugs designed for those who can no longer afford more expensive drug maxims such as heroin and cocaine.
“The crisis has given traffickers the opportunity to promote a new cheap drug, a cocaine for the poor,” Poulopoulos said at an addict center in Exarcheia, the anarchist bastion of Athens. “Shisha can be sniffed or injected and can be done in home laboratories – you don’t need any specialized knowledge. It's extremely dangerous.
Throughout Greece, the by-products of six consecutive years of recession have been brutal and cruel. Depression, along with drug and alcohol abuse, has increased dramatically. Crime and crime have skyrocketed as Greek society has disintegrated under the weight of austerity measures that have reduced the income of ordinary Greeks by 40%. Prostitution, the easiest way to finance drug addiction, has also skyrocketed.
“Desperation is such that many women agree to have unprotected sex because they will earn more money,” said Eleni Marini, a British-trained psychologist with Kethea. “Shisha has been linked to a very intense sexual drive, but it attacks your ability to think clearly and we are seeing many more pregnancies among drug addicts who engage in prostitution.” In 2012, two sex workers gave birth in the streets of Athens.
At a time when suicides have also skyrocketed and the spread of HIV infections has taken on epidemic proportions, drug addicts (a population believed to be about 25,000) have become increasingly self-destructive. And, according to experts, young Greeks marginalized by record unemployment rates (64% in Greece have the highest youth unemployment in the EU) are leading the way.
“The crisis has created a widespread sense of pessimism,” Poulopoulos said. “For those who might have left the drugs, there is now no incentive. Instead, there is an atmosphere of misery, where people who know they will not find work are becoming much more self-destructive. In Athens, where the economic crisis has hit hardest, Shisha is part of that.”
The conservative-dominated coalition government in Greece has tried to deal with the problem by expelling drug users and other homeless people from the city centre. A number of controversial police operations have swept the central streets, clearing crowded doors and shopping malls.
“But with such actions, the authorities are only sweeping the problem under the carpet,” Poulopoulos said. “What they are actually doing is further marginalizing these people by pushing them into the weapons of drug traffickers who offer them protection.”
Just as the demand for aid has never been greater, state-funded organisations such as Kethea have reduced their budgets by one third at the request of the “troika” – the EC, the ECB and the IMF – keeping the Greek debt-stricken economy afloat.
Since the outbreak of the crisis in 2009, Kethea has lost 70 of its 500 employees. The cuts occur despite studies that show that, for every euro invested in programs like Kethea, the state saves around 6 euros in costs for criminal justice and health systems. “The cuts we have witnessed are a false economy, a big mistake,” Poulopoulos said.
In the streets of Athens, the breeding ground for shisha, there is a growing fear that austerity not only does not work, but kills.
label: C2

text:
Egalitarianism is a controversial concept in social and political thinking. One could worry about human equality in many ways, for many reasons. As currently used, the “equal” label does not necessarily indicate that the so-called doctrine holds that it is desirable that the condition of persons be made equal in any aspect or that people are treated in the same way in any aspect. An egalitarian might rather be the one who holds that people should be treated as equal, as possessor of equal fundamental value and dignity and as equally morally considerable. In this sense, a non-egalitarian sample would be one that believes that people born in a higher social caste, or a favored race or ethnic group, or with a stock above the average of traits considered desirable, should somehow count for more than others in calculations that determine what should be done morally. (For the idea that the basic egalitarian ideal is to treat people as equals, see Dworkin 2000.) Other rules of equal conditions or treatment could be considered independent or derived from the claim of equal status. Controversy also revolves around attempts to specify the kind of beings to whom egalitarian norms apply. Some may consider that all and only human beings have the right to equal status. Some would argue that all and only people have the same moral status, with personality criteria that exclude some humans from qualifying (e.g., the unborn fetus or severely demented adult human being) and including some non-humans (e.g., intelligent beings inhabiting regions of outer space beyond Earth). Some would argue that sentient beings such as non-human primates who do not meet a person's criteria have the right to equal moral status together with people. Some are advancing other points of view.
Egalitarianism can be instrumental or not instrumental. Given the specification of some aspect of the condition or way of treating people that should be equal, one might argue that the situation in which stated equality obtains is morally valuable, either as an end or as a means. The instrumental egalitarian values equality as a means to some independently specific objective; the non-instrumental egalitarian values equality for his own good—as an end, or in part, a constitutive end. For example, someone who believes that maintaining equality in a group of people fosters relationships of solidarity and community between them, and is desirable for that reason, qualifies as an instrumental egalitarian. Someone who believes that equality of some kind is a component of justice, and morally required as such, would be a non-instrumental egalitarian.
Equality of any kind can be assessed conditionally or unconditionally. One values equality in the above way if equality is considered valuable only if there is any other condition. One could argue that equality in the distribution of resources among a group of people is valuable, but only on the condition that people are equally deserving.
Equality could be considered desirable or undesirable. A separate and distinct range of questions concerns whether or not people should act to achieve equality or are obliged to achieve equality (see Nagel 1991). The argument to come often merges these questions, assuming that if equality is valuable, that is at least a good reason to think that one should make it a reality.
For those who regard equality as a requirement of justice, the question arises whether it is an immutable and timeless requirement or a variable requirement. Michael Walzer is one who seems to have this last opinion. According to Walzer, a society is only if and only if its practices and institutions are in accordance with the shared values and cultural understandings of its people. Democratic egalitarianism becomes a requirement of justice in modern societies, because this egalitarianism is an important underlying element of people's shared cultural values and understandings (Walzer 1983). But this appearance can be misleading. Walzer can argue that everyone at all times and places has the same moral right to be treated in accordance with the shared norms and cultural understandings of his people or group. Walzer can also argue that everyone at all times and places has equal rights against free assault by people looking for fun, whatever the shared belief of local people in this matter. In any case, we can identify clear examples of theoreticians who consider equality of a certain kind as an immutable and timeless moral requirement. John Locke maintains that everyone at all times and places has the same natural moral rights that we all must always respect (Locke 1690). The contemporary moral philosopher Thomas Scanlon holds that all people everywhere alike have the moral right to be treated according to the outcome of a procedure: what constitutes morally correct and incorrect action is established by the principles that no one could reasonably reject (Scanlon 1998). It is yet another question, to what extent this procedure raises different principles that cannot be rejected at different times and places under different circumstances.
Egalitarianism can be formulated with a variety of roles in mind. For example, an egalitarian rule could be proposed as a fundamental moral principle. As such, it would be a declaration of the ultimate rule (or as a member of the final set of rules) to which individual conduct and institutional arrangements should be adjusted. A final rule may or may not be appropriate for the function of guiding individual decision-making or serving as an explicitly recognized principle governing institutions and the formation of public policies in a given society. If individual agents and public officials are responsible through limited cognitive capacity, limited knowledge, or limited loyalty to morality to misapply the supreme principles, it is quite possible that these principles can be applied to a greater extent if they are not directly used as decision-making guides for the choice of individual and public policies. (On this subject, see Hare 1981). Following this train of thought, one could favor as guidelines for individual and public choice simple, easily understandable and easily implementable rules that are to serve as substitutes for the moral principles that are the final norms. Or one might argue that the final moral principles that set what is right and what is wrong are well adapted to be practical decision-making guides. The point is simply that we must distinguish these distinct roles that moral standards could play and avoid criticizing a rule in one role for appropriate standards only if it is understood that the rule is playing a different role.
Egalitarianism could be sustained as a moral requirement, a component of what we fundamentally owe to each other, or as morally optional, a desirable ideal that we could permissiblely reject. When affirmed as morally required, egalitarianism typically figures in a theory of justice. For the most part, the discussion in this post focuses on egalitarianism as a morally required component of justice, but when considering arguments against a version of egalitarianism, it is worth taking into account the possibility that the norm in question is morally desirable but not morally binding.
Given some specifications of the type of equality being considered, it is clear what it means to say of a number of people who are equal in the declared respect. If we deal with equal utility, then a group has equal utility when everyone has exactly the same. If we deal with equal dollar tenure, then people are the same when everyone has exactly the same number of dollars. But to say this still does not suggest a way to determine, in general, whether inequality is greater in one situation than in another, when different people have different amounts of good that we care to match in the two situations. Inequality can be measured in different ways, and no measure seems to be strongly supported by the intuition of common sense about the meaning of equality. (See Sen 1997 and Temkin 1993). This entry is generally abstracted from this issue on the assumption that we can unequivocally determine, for any ideal of equality, how to measure the degrees of inequality in all areas.
label: C2

text:
Leading water scientists have issued one of the harshest warnings about the global food supply, saying that the world’s population may have to switch almost entirely to a vegetarian diet by 2050 to avoid catastrophic shortages.
Humans get about 20% of their protein from animal products now, but this may have to go down to just 5% to feed the additional two billion people expected to be alive by 2050, according to research from some of the world's leading water scientists.
“There will not be enough water available on the current farmland to produce food for the expected population of nine billion by 2050 if we follow current trends and changes towards common diets in Western nations,” said Malik Falkenmark’s report and colleagues from the Stockholm International Water Institute (SIWI).
“There will be enough water if the proportion of animal-based food is limited to 5% of total calories and a significant regional water deficit can be covered by a reliable food trading system.”
Terrible warnings of water shortages limit food production as Oxfam and the United Nations prepare for a possible second global food crisis in five years. Prices of commodities such as maize and wheat have increased by almost 50 per cent in international markets since June, caused by severe droughts in the United States and Russia, and weak monsoon rains in Asia. More than 18 million people are already facing severe food shortages throughout the Sahel.
Oxfam has predicted that rising prices will have a devastating impact on developing countries that are heavily dependent on food imports, including parts of Latin America, North Africa and the Middle East. Food shortages in 2008 caused civil unrest in 28 countries.
Adopting a vegetarian diet is an option to increase the amount of water available to grow more food in an increasingly climate-erratic world, scientists said. Foods rich in animal proteins consume five to ten times more water than a vegetarian diet. One third of the world’s arable land is used to feed animals. Other options for feeding the population include waste disposal and increased trade between food surplus and deficit countries.
“Nine million people are already hungry and 2 billion are undernourished despite the fact that food production per capita continues to increase,” they said. “With 70% of all water available in agriculture, growing more food to feed another 2 billion people by 2050 will put greater pressure on available water and land.”
The report is published at the beginning of the annual World Water Conference in Stockholm, Sweden, where 2,500 politicians, United Nations bodies, non-governmental groups and researchers from 120 countries meet to address global water supply problems.
Competition for water between food production and other uses will increase pressure on essential resources, scientists said. “The UN predicts that we must increase food production by 70% by the middle of the century. This will put additional pressure on our already stressed water resources, at a time when we also need to allocate more water to meet global energy demand – which is expected to increase by 60% in the next 30 years – and generate electricity for the 1.3 billion people who currently do not have it,” the report said.
Overnourishment, malnutrition and waste are on the rise and increased food production may face future constraints arising from water shortages.
“We will need a new recipe to feed the world in the future,” said the report’s editor, Anders Jägerskog.
A separate report from the International Water Management Institute (IWMI) said that the best way for countries to protect millions of farmers from food insecurity in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia was to help them invest in small pumps and simple technology, rather than developing costly large-scale irrigation projects.
“We have witnessed over and over again what happens to the world’s poor, most of whom depend on agriculture for their livelihoods and already suffer from water shortages, when they are at the mercy of our fragile global food system,” said Dr. Colin Chartres, Director General.
“Farmers from all over the developing world are increasingly dependent on and benefit from small-scale water supply solutions of local interest. [These] techniques could increase yields to 300 per cent and add tens of billions of US dollars to household incomes in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia.”

The Biden government said on Saturday that it was immediately suspending Trump-era asylum agreements with El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras, part of an attempt to undo the hardline immigration policies of its Republican predecessor.
In a statement, the Secretary of the State Department, Antony Blinken, said that the United States “has suspended and initiated the process to end the Asylum Cooperation Agreements with the Governments of El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras as the first concrete steps towards greater partnership and collaboration in the region outlined by President Biden.”
The so-called “safe third country” agreements, signed by the Trump administration and Central American nations in 2019, force asylum seekers in the region to seek refuge in those countries first before seeking asylum in the United States.
Part of Trump's controversial offer to repress illegal immigrants from Central America who constitute a large part of the migrants detained on the U.S.-Mexico border, policies were never implemented with El Salvador and Honduras, the State Department said on Saturday.
Transfers under the agreement between the United States and Guatemala have stopped since mid-March 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic, the statement added.
The measures announced on Saturday came after Biden released a series of measures aimed at renewing the U.S. immigration system, including a working group to reunite separated families on the U.S.-Mexico border and another to increase an annual limit for refugees.
One of the orders requested Blinken to “consider promptly” whether it should notify the governments of the three countries that the United States intended to suspend and terminate secure agreements with third countries. It also requested the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Attorney-General to determine whether a rule for the implementation of the agreements should be rescinded.

text:
The six-point peace plan for Syria proposed by Kofi Annan is doomed to failure for a simple reason: Neither President Bashar al-Assad nor the government opposition are interested in making it work.
For Al-Assad, the full implementation of the plan, which includes a political settlement through dialogue and respect for the rights of citizens to demonstrate peacefully, will put an end to his regime. From the beginning of the uprisings, his government knew that a repetition of protests in Egypt's Tahrir Square or Bahrain's Pearl Square in Damascus or Aleppo will mean a regime change. Al-Assad and his inner circle are not about to create conditions conducive to those sittings just because the Annan plan asks them to do so.
For opposition groups, Annan could devote as much time as he wants to the negotiations, but any conversation that is not based on Al-Assad's withdrawal will not be acceptable. Activists who are leading the Syrian revolution insist that the leadership of the opposition's exile has a limited mandate and that it is to discuss details for the transfer of power from the Assad family to the opposition.
The conclusion is that the two main protagonists of the conflict view the Annan plan as a means of achieving their respective mutually exclusive objectives.
By accepting the Annan plan, al-Assad follows a two-way strategy: appeases his Russian and Iranian allies, who have pressured him to accept a political solution, while working to get out of the crisis on the pretext that he faces terrorists and armed gangs.
The opposition wants the ceasefire to launch massive protests. As a Hama activist recently told me: We don't need military intervention, we don't need humanitarian corridors, we don't need safe areas. To enforce the ceasefire and millions of people will march towards the presidential palace demanding the expulsion of Assad.
After more than a year of uprisings, Syria remains trapped in a violent stalemate. Al-Assad has not been able to crush the opposition, and the opposition does not seem to be close to evicting al-Assad. Increasingly, the conflict is being framed in existential terms, and some are becoming more radicalized.
Most Alawites believe that their physical survival is at stake, because they are convinced that the death of al-Assad will lead to large-scale revenge killings. They will therefore not accept a solution that will produce a new regime in which they are not guaranteed a leading role. Similarly, opposition groups believe that if they stop now and al-Assad remains in power, he will pursue them.
In the absence of a game change that will tip the balance in favor of either side, the crisis in Syria will become a complete sectarian war that confronts the Sunnis against Alawites, which will probably spread to the neighboring countries of Iraq and Lebanon.
Although military options have been considered by the West, it is difficult to say whether that would make a difference in reversing the dynamics in the country. A military operation could cause a regional war involving Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran, with each country supporting its allies in Syria.
For now, Iran's Supreme Leader has strongly supported Al-Assad. A well-informed Iranian source told me that the Iranian regime will support Al-Assad no matter what happens to the end. On the other hand, Russia's policy in Syria seems to be on the move to judge by its vote in the United Nations recently. It is too early to say whether Russia will relieve Al-Assad as did Saudi Arabia in the case of Abdullah Saleh of Yemen. Russia and Iran will probably not abandon al-Assad until they are part of the negotiation process on Syria's future government.
A possible game change is whether the protest movement in Syria is widespread and covers large areas of the country.
To date, only four of Syria ' s 14 governorates constitute the main centres of the protest movement: Homs, Hama, Idlib and Daraa. While we have seen protests in other regions, they have not been as sustained and extensive as those in the four governorates. This is partly due to the state of fragmentation in the ranks of the opposition, especially among exiled groups, which do not inspire confidence among the fences.
Although large segments of sieges, including businessmen, have come to support the opposition, many remain ambivalent because they doubt that the opposition will succeed in overthrowing al-Assad. This perception is reinforced by the fact that Annan's plan does not call for al-Assad to withdraw, a detail that is not lost in the propaganda machinery of the Assad regime.
Although the opposition to exile remains divided, there are hopeful signs that the ranks of the opposition inside Syria are organizing better, training better and gaining legitimacy.
The future leaders of Syria will not come from the Syrian National Council or the National Coordination Committee for Change; they will emerge from the ranks of the revolutionary councils that are being formed in different parts of the country.
These councils bring together an eclectic mix of the most active local coordinating committees, independent activists, community and business leaders and military deserters. They are setting up an administrative infrastructure similar to a local provincial council, managing everything, from media affairs to helping families who lost their homes to provide legal assistance to imprisoned activists. They are also coordinating with each other to protect relief supply lines across their respective territories. In the process, the leaders of these councils, who come from different religious and ethnic groups in Syria, are developing political skills, cultivating local constituencies and learning through tests and mistakes in the business of governing.
In a country that is increasingly polarized along sectarian and ethnic lines, these councils may be able to provide the glue that holds the country together.
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of Randa Slim.
