text:
Conceptual difficulties have plagued quantum mechanics since its inception, despite its extraordinary predictive successes. The basic problem, clearly said, is this: It is not entirely clear what quantum mechanics is all about. What, in fact, describes quantum mechanics?
It might seem, since it is widely agreed that any quantum mechanical system is fully described by its wave function, that quantum mechanics is fundamentally about the behavior of wave functions. Naturally, no physicist wanted this to be true more than Erwin Schrödinger, the father of wave function. However, Schrödinger finally found this impossible to believe. Their difficulty had little to do with the novelty of wave function:
That it is an abstract, unintuitive mathematical construct is a scruple that almost always arises against new aids to thought and that does not carry great message. (Schrödinger [1935] 1980: 327)
Rather, it was that the “blurring” that the extended character of wave function suggests “macroscopically affects tangible and visible things, for which the term “blurring” seems simply incorrect.”
For example, in the same document Schrödinger pointed out that it may occur in the radioactive decay that
The emergent particle is described as a spherical wave that continuously affects a surrounding luminescent screen over its full extent. The display does not, however, show a more or less constant uniform surface brightness, but rather illuminates in an instant at a point... (Schrödinger [1935] 1980: 327-328)
And he observed that one can easily fix, for example, by including a cat in the system, "very ridiculous cases" with
the function of the whole system that has in it the live cat and the dead one (forgive the expression) mixed or smeared in equal parts. (Schrödinger [1935] 1980: 328)
Therefore, due to the “measuring problem” of macroscopic superpositions, Schrödinger found it difficult to consider the function of the wave as “representative of reality”. But then what does he do? With obvious disapproval, Schrödinger notes that
the prevailing doctrine rescues itself or us by resorting to epistemology. We are told that no distinction should be made between the state of a natural object and what I know about it, or perhaps better, what I can know about it if I take any trouble. In reality, they say, there is only intrinsically consciousness, observation, measurement. (Schrödinger [1935] 1980: 328)
Many physicists talk about the Copenhagen interpretation, that quantum mechanics is primarily about observation or measurement results. But it is increasingly difficult to find someone who, when under pressure, defends this interpretation. It seems clear that quantum mechanics are fundamentally about atoms and electrons, quarks and strings, not those particular macroscopic regularities associated with what we call measurements of the properties of these things. But if these entities do not identify in some way with the function of the wave itself — and if talking about them is not simply a shorthand for elaborate statements about measurements — then where are they in the quantum description?
There is, perhaps, a very simple reason why it is so difficult to discern in quantum description the objects we believe quantum mechanics should describe. Perhaps quantum mechanical description is not the whole story, a possibility more prominently associated with Albert Einstein. (For a general discussion of Einstein's scientific philosophy, and in particular of his approach to conflicting positions of realism and positivism, see the entry into Einstein's philosophy of science.)
In 1935 Einstein, Boris Podolsky and Nathan Rosen defended this possibility in their famous EPR newspaper. They concluded with this observation:
While we have thus demonstrated that wave function does not provide a complete description of physical reality, we leave open the question of whether such a description exists or not. We believe, however, that such a theory is possible. (Einstein et al. 1935: 780)
label: C2

text:
More than eight years after a Utah teenager disappeared from his room on a summer night, the man the authorities believe his kidnapping is being tried in federal court.
Brian David Mitchell, 57, is accused of abducting 14-year-old Elizabeth Smart at knifepoint from his family's house in Salt Lake City on June 5, 2002, a crime that shocked the nation and the city, which was then enjoying the glow of the 2002 Winter Olympics a few months earlier.
Mitchell faces federal charges of kidnapping and transporting a minor across state lines for inappropriate purposes. The jury selection at your trial is scheduled to begin Monday in Salt Lake City.
In the months following the disappearance of Smart, his distressed parents, Ed and Lois, became a familiar vision in the media as they continued to advocate for the safe return of their daughter.
But no one expected what happened in March 2003, when Smart was found walking down a street in the Salt Lake City suburb of Sandy in the company of Mitchell and his wife, Wanda Eileen Barzee. Mitchell, a vagabond, self-described prophet named Emmanuel, had done some handyman work at the Smartshome.
Utah prosecutors charged Mitchell with six counts of kidnapping, sexual assault, and robbery. But in July 2005, a Utah District Court judge declared him incompetent to be tried, leaving him in custody at Utah State Hospital.
However, the state case against Mitchell was suspended when federal authorities intervened. A grand jury in 2008 accused Mitchell and Barzee. District Judge Dale Kimball found Mitchell competent to be tried in March.
Barzee, 64, pleaded guilty in November 2009 to the kidnapping and illegal transportation of a minor in a federal court and was sentenced in May to 15 years in federal prison. He also pleaded guilty but mentally ill in the state court conspiracy to commit aggravated kidnapping in an attempt to kidnap Smart's cousin a month after Smart was kidnapped. He was given a sentence of one to 15 years, which would be served simultaneously with the federal sentence, and he was given credit for the seven years he had spent in custody.
As part of her plea agreement, Barzee agreed to cooperate in state and federal cases against her husband. However, his name does not appear on a list of witnesses presented by federal prosecutors, and it does appear on a list of witnesses presented by the defense.
Smart, her mother and younger sister, Mary Katherine -- who was sleeping in the room with Smart on the night of the kidnapping and was the only witness -- all appear on the prosecution's witness list.
Mitchell's lawyers tried to move his trial, saying it should be held outside Utah because the publicity in the case had harmed the group of potential jurors against him and jeopardized his right to a fair trial.
Kimball denied that application in August, and defense lawyers appealed his decision to the tenth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver, Colorado. A panel of three appellate court judges denied the application last week, saying it was premature as the jury selection had not taken place.
A jury may be sitting where all jurors meet Mr. Mitchell's point of view on fairness, said the 10th Circuit ruling.
Defence lawyers in July stated in court documents that they intend to use a defense of insanity and the intention to present expert testimony related to an alleged illness or mental defect.
Now 22, Smart testified as part of Mitchell's competition hearing last year that after wearing her - still dressed in her red pajamas - from her house, Mitchell took her to a wooded area behind her house and performed a mock marriage ceremony with her before sexually assaulting her. She testified that he repeatedly assaulted her during her months in captivity, and that he and Barzee took her to California before returning with her to Utah.
The federal court summoned 600 jurors to fill out a preliminary jury questionnaire in the case, according to court documents. About 500 potential jurors attended the sessions on September 30 and October 1. Some were released for hardship, documents said, but some 330 members of the jury completed the questionnaire.
Kimball reduced that number to just over 200 potential jurors, according to The Salt Lake Tribune newspaper.
label: C2

text:
We may not yet be living in an era of flying cars, as predicted in the 1985 movie Back to the Future II, but the emergence of smart phones and other new technologies is creating a reality that could be said to be so exciting and almost so crazy. Experts agree that economic and demographic changes, technological advances and environmental concerns are fundamentally altering the transport landscape. “It’s a very dynamic time,” said Robert Puentes of the think-tank of Brookings Institution’s Metropolitan Policy Program. “There is an approach to a closer connection between the role of transport and the economic health of cities and their impact on people.”
As the average U.S. travel lengthens And the country's infrastructure is aging badly, cities across the United States are forced to redefine what transport is. Increasingly, urban planners, transport experts and scientists are realizing that old self-centered models focused on alleviating traffic congestion are not enough to address issues such as population growth and carbon emissions, and transport is now, more than ever, an integral component of a city's larger sustainability efforts.
Large American cities like Los Angeles, Seattle and Chicago are working to make better use of their streets by adding more bus lanes, increasing pedestrian walkways and expanding their rail options, while at the same time working with the private sector on advanced technologies that will allow a vehicle to drive and communicate with other vehicles and their surroundings, essentially by making transportation intelligent. “The most sustainable places to live are those with multimodal transport systems,” Puentes said. “You can’t be a global competitive city if you don’t have a robust transport network.”
Here are three of the key trends that experts predict will shape the transport industry in the coming years.
Increased travel delivery services like Uber and Lyft, essentially reserved taxis with the click of a smartphone button, and apps like Waze, which uses real-time traffic data to find the fastest routes for drivers, are drastically changing the way people move and affecting the way traffic moves across a city. Communication between drivers and drivers, between different vehicles and between cars and infrastructure is taking transport to a new era, according to Allan Clelland, an expert in transport technology.
According to a recent study by the UCLA Institute of Transport Studies, vehicle travel has declined among millennials – people born approximately between the early 1980s and early 2000s – compared to previous generations. According to the study, those born in the 1990s are making 4% fewer car trips and traveling 18% less miles per year, on average, than members of previous generations at the same stage of their lives.
Meanwhile, those who still drive cars are dealing with less traffic thanks to Waze. Experts say that the traffic application has eased congestion on highways and reduced driver travel times, but it has also led to a problematic increase in cars moving through residential neighborhoods. This has enraged residents, who claim that the increase in traffic on their quiet streets reduces their quality of life.
This trend could continue as vehicle-to-vehicle data communication grows, as well as communication between vehicles and surrounding infrastructure. Currently, a traffic light can detect when a car is approaching, but that's it. Companies are working to develop technology that allows a vehicle to tell traffic control systems not only that it is present, but also where it is going and how fast it travels.
Driverless cars have been on the headlines since Google started testing vehicles in 2012 but no one really knows when driverless cars will become commonplace. However, partial automation of cars is already underway. Alexandre Bayen of the University of California expects automation to advance in stages: first, there could be automated buses with their own lanes, then maybe trucks in ports or mining cities: essentially, vehicles that are connected electronically and travel in a single archive.
The idea of a fully automated transport system is intriguing because it has the potential to improve safety by eliminating human errors and increasing the efficiency of car owners, who can go on with other tasks during a long journey. It can also help reduce carbon emissions and traffic congestion and allow more people to access cars. But, even if the driverless technology were ready to go on the roads now, it would take a long time to get fully automated since the average age of cars on the road is 11.5 years.
To see how cars can be without driver in action, go to the video at: vimeo.com/37751380.
As the world runs to prevent catastrophic climate change, and countries, states and cities work to achieve ambitious emissions targets, these policies could also have a major impact on the future of transport, stimulating everything, from zero-emission and low-emission vehicles to applications that encourage more walking, cycling and car sharing.
Sharon Feigon, Executive Director of the Shared Use Mobility Center, foresees a future where a person can use a transit pass that gives him access to numerous modes of transport on a given day. If your train is delayed, for example, you can access a city bike, take a ferry or rent a car through a shared car program using the same pass. “We’re going to see these systems packaged together and make it as easy as possible to connect them to each other so that people can seamlessly transfer between them,” he said.
When considering the future of transportation, it is also important to consider why people travel: they can go to work, meet friends or family, or do shopping. Technologies and trends that reduce the need for such travel – e.g. virtual meetings or teleworking – could also have a major impact on transport.
There was a time when the idea of a flying car represented the height of innovation, but the technologies that are now imagined and developed could be considered even more sophisticated and useful in dealing with the social and environmental threats we face in the coming decades.”
label: C2

text:
I will refer to the mark of knowledge that Descartes seeks in Meditations, as ‘perfect knowledge’. Famously, he defines perfect knowledge in terms of doubt. While he distinguishes lower degrees of conviction, and perfect knowledge, he writes:
I disagree as follows: there is conviction [persuasion] when there is some reason left that can lead us to doubt, but knowledge [scientia] is conviction based on a reason so strong that it can never be shaken for any stronger reason. (24 May 1640, letter to Regius, AT 3:65, CSMK 147)
In the Second Answers, he adds:
Now I will explain for the second time the basis on which it seems to me that all human certainty can be founded.
First, as soon as we think we perceive something correctly, we are spontaneously convinced that it is true. Now, if this conviction is so firm that it is impossible for us to have any reason to doubt what we are convinced of, then there are no further questions to ask: we have everything we could reasonably wish for. ... For the assumption we are making here is of such a firm conviction that it is absolutely incapable of being destroyed; and such conviction is clearly the same as the most perfect certainty. (AT 7:144f, CSM 2:103)
These passages (and others) suggest a story where doubt is the contrast of certainty. As my certainty increases, my doubt diminishes; conversely, as my doubt increases, my certainty diminishes. The requirement that knowledge be based on complete, or perfect, certainty is therefore equivalent to requiring a total inability to doubt one’s convictions – an absolute indubitability. This conception of the relationship between certainty and doubt helps underwrite Descartes' methodical emphasis on doubt, the so-called "method of doubt" (discussed in section 2).
That perfect knowledge requires that it is “impossible for us to have any reason to doubt what we are convinced of” marks an extraordinarily high standard of justification. Is this the only standard that deserves to talk about knowledge? This is a difficult question to answer, because Descartes did not write in English. But it could be said that it is a contextualistic epistemic, at least in the sense of invoking the notion of knowledge in divergent contexts that presuppose different epistemic standards. We will see, for example, that he argues that even deductive demonstrations of expert geometers do not meet the standards necessary for perfect knowledge; however, the type of terminology he uses to characterize his epistemic achievements is routinely translated in terms of speaking-knowledge, into standard English translations of his work.
The certainty/inubitability of interest to Descartes is psychological, but not merely psychological – not simply an inexplicable feeling. It also has a distinctive epistemic character, which implies a kind of rational insight. During moments of certainty, it is as if my perception was guided by “a great light in the intellect” (Med. 4, 7:59, CSM 2:41). This rational enlightenment enables me to “see with total clarity with the eye of my mind”; my feelings of certainty are grounded – in fact, “I see a manifest contradiction” by denying the proposition of which I am convinced.
label: C2

text:
Young children are much more likely to experience attention and hyperactivity problems if their mother develops diabetes during pregnancy and is born in a poor or low-middle-class home, suggests a new study.
The study, published this week in the Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine Archives, found that children whose mothers received a diagnosis of diabetes during pregnancy - LRB- known as gestational diabetes -RRB- were twice as likely as their peers to meet the criteria for hyperactivity attention deficit disorder - LRB- ADHD -RRB- at age six.
Living in a family with less than average socioeconomic status also doubled the risk of ADHD in six-year-olds. However, children with both risk factors -- those who were exposed to gestational diabetes and grew up in a less than tributary household -- had a 14-fold higher risk of ADHD compared to children without either risk factor.
Health.com: What Causes ADHD? 12 myths and facts
Findings do not show that gestational diabetes causes ADHD directly, but researchers say they send a message to mothers and doctors that gestational diabetes can pose hidden dangers for a child long after birth, especially if the child grows up in a difficult environment.
Mothers should be aware that gestational diabetes can affect their fetus, says Yoko Nomura, Ph.D., lead author of the study and assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at Mount Sinai School of Medicine, New York.
Gestational diabetes, which affects about 5% of pregnant women in the United States, usually develops during the second or third trimester of pregnancy, the same window of time in which a fetus undergoes a critical burst of brain development.
Health.com: Tips for Healthy Pregnancy with Diabetes
Women with gestational diabetes have an abnormally high level of blood sugar - LRB-glucose -RRB-. If the fetus is bombarded with excess blood sugar, the energy normally used for the development of the nervous system could be potentially diverted to absorb that excess, Nomura says. As a result, the central nervous system may not develop properly.
Growing up in poverty would probably aggravate any underlying deficits in the nervous system, Nomura says.
When babies are born in households of higher socioeconomic status, they have better access to health care - LSB- and -RSB- corrective activities, the intellectual stimulus is greater, they have better food, he says.
In addition, low-income women may not control their gestational diabetes, as well as the more prosperous future mothers, says Luigi Garibaldi, M.D., clinical director of pediatric endocrinology at Pittsburgh Children's Hospital.
Having diabetes during pregnancy alone may not be so bad, but if you don't take care of it, there may be consequences for the child's brain development, says Garibaldi, who didn't participate in the study.
Health.com: Exercise tips for people with type 2 diabetes
Nomura and her colleagues followed 212 children of various ethnic and socio-economic backgrounds living in Queens, New York, 10 per cent of whom were exposed to gestational diabetes. From preschool to six years of age, a trained psychologist or doctoral student evaluated each child annually the symptoms of ADHD.
The study had several shortcomings. It was relatively small, and although they did take into account the history of ADHD parents, the researchers did not collect data on whether children had siblings or other relatives with attention problems or hyperactivity. In addition, Garibaldi says, researchers did not measure how well mothers controlled their gestational diabetes.
However, the study is a valuable reminder that a child's environment, both inside and outside the uterus, seems to affect the risk of ADHD, says Joel Nigg, Ph.D., professor of psychiatry at Oregon University of Health and Science, Portland.
Health.com: ADHD linked to pesticide exposure
Previous research suggests, for example, that children are at higher risk for ADHD if they are exposed to lead and certain pesticides.
As a precaution, we could add -LSB- gestational diabetes -RSB- to the list of risk factors we know, says Negro, who wrote an editorial accompanying the study.

text:
A verb is transitive if and only if it usually occurs with a direct object, and in such occurrences it is said to occur transiently. Thus ‘te’ occurs transiently in ‘I ate the meat and left the vegetables’, but not in ‘I ate then to the left’ (maybe it is not the same verb ‘left’ in these two examples, but it seems to be the same ‘te’). A verb is intensible if the verb (VP) that is formed with its complement is anomalous in at least one of three ways: (i) replace one expression with another that is choreferential with it in the verb complement can change the truth value of the phrase in which the VP is produced – for example, Mark Twain can be admired but not Samuel Clemens, without realizing that his annoying neighbor Sam is the famous writer (in this case, the replacement of the reference ‘Samuel Clemens’ with ‘Mark Twain’ in the VP ‘admire Mark Twain’ will convert a true phrase, ‘you will look at Mark Twain’ in a false one, ‘you will admire Samuel Clemens’); (ii) the VP admits a special ‘unspecific’ reading if it contains a quantifier, or a certain type of quantifier (example of Quine’ (1956:185) is famous: it observes that if we want a special reading ‘inspecific’ as (specified) as an example, but it does not want to be.
The intense phenomena are disconcerting, and it is worth studying, because (a) it seems that the only way to account for the abilities of language speakers to produce and understand phrases from their native languages that they have never before found is to propose a compositional structure in language and an interpretative capacity in the speakers who exploit it. But (b) simpler ideas about what such a structure is like cannot accommodate intensity. So we want to know what is the smallest complication that allows intensification. The investigation of intentional verbs has focused mainly on verbs used to make reports of propositional attitude. These verbs take clauses instead of direct objects as their complements. However, as we will see below, the Intentional transitory verbs (hereinafter referred to as ITVs) are not limited to duplicating the problems posed by the propositional attitude verbs, but introduce special difficulties of their own.

text:
Why should philosophy be interested in what appears to be a purely linguistic notion? Because, especially in the first half of the 20th century, many philosophers thought that it could do a crucial epistemological work, providing an account, first, of our seemingly a priori knowledge of mathematics, and then — with a little help from British empiricism — of our understanding of claims about the space-time world as well. In fact, "conceptual analysis" soon became the same way that English-speaking philosophers particularly characterized their work.
Many also thought that he would carry out the metaphysical work of explaining the truth and necessity of mathematics, showing not only how we could know about these subjects regardless of experience, but how they could be true in this and all possible worlds. This latter ambition was sometimes not distinguished from the former, although it is no longer shared by most philosophers still interested in analysis. In fact, many have wondered how a prayer could be true, much less necessary, “only by virtue of the meaning”, for surely the truth of any prayer depends on the world being the way in which prayer represents it as being. Let us remember that Frege's ambition was to reduce mathematics to logic by showing how, replacing synonyms with synonyms, each mathematical truth could be shown to be logical. He did not go on to affirm (although some later philosophers did) that logical truths in themselves were true only by virtue of meaning. Therefore, "Bachelors are single" could be shown to be analytical by replacing "unmarried men" with "bachelors" and thus converting "unmarried men are single" to the logical truth. But what does this last truth do? As Devitt (1996) noted:[1]
It is partly true by virtue of what it means and partly by virtue of the way the world is, by virtue of the fact that all singles are single. ... [Such phrases] are true by virtue of the meaning given the logical truths (1996, p. 22)
In view of this, in the rest of this post we will focus mainly on the epistemological project.

Low-income countries will remain on the front line of human-induced climate change over the next century, experiencing gradual sea-level increases, stronger cyclones, warmer days and nights, more unpredictable rains and longer and larger heat waves, according to the most comprehensive assessment of the problem.
The last major United Nations (UN) assessment in 2007 predicted uncontrolled temperature increases of 6°C or more by the end of the century. Now it is believed that this is unlikely for scientists, but average temperatures of land and sea are expected to continue to rise throughout this century, possibly reaching 4°C above current levels, sufficiently to devastate crops and make life in many cities unbearably hot.
According to the report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), published in Stockholm and published online in September, as temperatures rise and hot, tropical and subtropical ocean regions face strong changes in annual rainfall.
East Africa can expect to experience an increase in short rains, while West Africa should expect heavier monsoons. Burma, Bangladesh and India can expect stronger cyclones; elsewhere in South Asia, more intense summer rains are expected. Indonesia may receive less rain between July and October, but coastal regions around the South China Sea and the Gulf of Thailand may expect greater extreme rain when cyclones hit land.
“It is almost certain that, in the long term, global rainfall will change. High latitude countries, such as Europe or North America, are expected to receive more rainfall, but many arid and semi-arid subtropical regions are likely to experience less rainfall. In humid tropical regions, extreme precipitation events are likely to be more intense and more frequent in a warmer world,” said the authors of the report.
They added: “The monsoon start dates are likely to be earlier or not to change much, while monsoon withdrawal rates are likely to be delayed, leading to an extension of the season.”
Scientists from developing countries and commentators have welcomed the report, which they said supported their own observations.
“The IPCC argues that climate change is real and is happening much stronger than before. We are already seeing the effects of climate change in Bangladesh and throughout South Asia. It's not news to us. Most developing countries now face climate change. They don’t need the IPCC to tell them that the climate is changing,” said Saleemul Huq, director of the Dhaka-based International Center for Climate Change and Development.
Scientists have also reduced projections of sea level rise. Depending on future greenhouse gas emissions, sea level will increase by an average of 40 to 62 cm by 2100. However, there will be significant geographical variations; many millions of people living in the big cities of the developing world, including Lagos and Calcutta, are threatened.
Weather disasters are also more likely in a warmer world, the report suggests. Although the global frequency of tropical cyclones is expected to decrease or remain essentially unchanged, they may be more intense, with stronger winds and stronger rains.
Life in many cities in developing countries could become virtually unbearable, as urban temperatures are already well above those in the surrounding countryside. Much higher temperatures could reduce the duration of the growth period in some parts of Africa by up to 20 per cent, the report said.
Dr. Camilla Toulmin, Director of the International Institute for Environment and Development, says: “Climate models are not yet robust enough to predict impacts at the local and regional levels, but it is clear that everyone is vulnerable in some way.”
Oxfam predicted that global hunger would worsen as climate change inevitably damaged crop production and disrupted incomes. They suggested that the number of people at risk of hunger could increase by 10 to 20 per cent by 2050, and that the daily availability of calories per inhabitant would decrease worldwide.
“Climate change is already jeopardizing achievements in the fight against hunger, and it seems to be getting worse,” Oxfam said. “A hot world is a hungry world. If the rest of the 21st century develops as its first decade, we will soon experience extreme weather far beyond the limits of human experience.”

text:
Many philosophers recognize a distinction between two types of mental events. (A) The first goes by many names, for example, phenomenal experiences, occurrences of qualitative consciousness, what-is-like experience, qualia. Pains, later images, and tastes can serve as examples. (B) Mental events of the second type are propositional attitudes that occur, for example, beliefs and desires (occurring). Arguments about epiphenomenalism can refer to any of the types of mental events, and it should not be assumed that a given argument for one type can be reformulated without loss to the other. However, the two types can often be connected through beliefs that one has their own experiences. Thus, if it is held that pains have no physical effects, then one should say that (i) pains do not cause beliefs that one is in pain, or (ii) beliefs that one is in pain are epiphenomenal. Because, if the pains caused beliefs that one is in pain, and the latter had physical effects, then the pains, after all, would have effects on the physical world (though indirectly). But epiphenomenalism says that mental events have no effect on the physical world. [1]
The central motivation for epiphenomenalism lies in the premise that whenever there is a sufficient cause of a physical event, there is a sufficient physical cause of that event. If a mental event is more than a physical event, then for it to make any causal contribution of its own in the physical world would require a violation of physical law. The interactionist model of Descartes (1649) proposed that non-physical events could cause small changes in the shape of the pineal gland. But such non-physical effects, however mild, would mean that the physical account of the movement is false, because that account says there will be no such change in form unless there is a physical force to cause it.
One can try to rescue mental efficacy by assuming that whenever there is a mental effect on the physical world there is also a physical force that is a sufficient cause of the effect. This view, however, offends the Occamist principles and does not satisfy the main anti-epifenomenalist intuition, namely, that the mental makes a difference to the physical, that is, that it leads to a behavior that would not have occurred in the absence of the mental. Vision also leads to an epistemological problem: If there is always a sufficient physical cause for what a mental event is supposed to produce, then one could never be in a position where one needs to assume that there is something non-physical at work, and therefore there could never be any reason to introduce mental causes into their account of neuronal events or behavior.
Many contemporary thinkers would respond to the central motivation for epiphenomenalism by denying its dualistic presupposition, i.e., by arguing that mental events are identical to physical events, and thus may have physical effects. Section 3 will explain the questions left over by such physicologistic views. For the time being, it should be noted that the argument set out in the two preceding paragraphs is not supposed to be an argument for dualism, but only for epiphenomenalism, once dualism is accepted.
The additional support for epiphenomenalism can be derived from the fact, pointed out by Wilhelm Wundt (1912), that “each simple sensation joins a very complicated combination of peripheral processes and the central nerve”, along with the fact that the causes of behavior are also complex neural events. This latter fact makes it natural to look for complex events along the causal chain that lead to behavior; and these can be found in neural events that are required for the occurrence of simple sensations. Sensations themselves could not contribute to behavior without first having more complex neural effects than themselves. Thus, an anti-epifenomenalist posture would require us to prefer the hypothesis that simple sensations cause (relatively) complex neural events over the hypothesis that complex neural events (which are required in any case for the causation of sensations) are adequate to cause the neural events required for the causation of behavior.

text:
Thanksgiving is a party held predominantly in North America, and has a different meaning in each of the countries where it is recognized.
In the United States, Thanksgiving is a federal holiday (that is, all government employees and most private employees receive a day off from work), and it always takes place on the fourth Thursday of November, regardless of the date.
The feast means the immense progress made by pilgrims, or some of the first travelers to North America, in Plymouth Plantation circa 1621. It was at this time that the hungry and tired pilgrims were taught (by Native Americans) how to grow and produce food on the unique terrain of North America. Once they had cultivated (and captured) an abundance of food, the pilgrims were gratefully awaited, and celebrated alongside the Native Americans who provided such valuable help. President Abraham Lincoln began the contemporary Thanksgiving practice by calling a "Thanks Day" during one of his Civil War speeches.
In America today, Thanksgiving remains firmly rooted in its historical roots, and is widely regarded as a day to give thanks for good food, good times and family. Thanksgiving dinner usually consists of turkey, mashed potatoes, stuffed, vegetables, sauce and large desserts. Without a doubt, giving in abundance is a cornerstone of the feast, as doing so could only be possible if one possesses abundance.
label: C2

An American man has been arrested in North Korea, two State Department officials told CNN.
Diplomatic sources speaking on condition of not being identified said the man is a Korean-American businessman. One of the sources said the businessman had a visa to enter North Korea.
The State Department is working with the Swedish Embassy in the capital of North Korea, Pyongyang, officials said. The United States urges the North Korean authorities, through the Swedes, to release man for humanitarian reasons.
Sweden represents the interests of the United States in North Korea because the United States and North Korea have no diplomatic relations.
The Swedes have had consular access to the man and have visited him, officials said. The Swedes are asking for regular visits, officials said.
A Swedish official in Stockholm confirmed to CNN that the embassy in Pyongyang is working on the case.
Sources refused to provide additional information due to privacy issues.
North Korea has detained several Americans in recent years, increasing levels of tension in what is already a rocky relationship between Pyongyang and Washington.
In 2010, former President Jimmy Carter helped secure the release of Aijalon Mahli Gomes, an American citizen who had been fined approximately $600,000 and sentenced to eight years of hard labour for crossing the Chinese border into North Korea.
Gomes, who attempted suicide while in custody of North Korea, was believed to be a Christian activist.
Two American journalists, Laura Ling and Euna Lee, who had entered North Korea in March 2009 and had been arrested and sentenced to 12 years of hard labour, were released in August 2009 following an intervention by former President Bill Clinton.
Tensions between North and West Korea have increased in recent years due in part to concerns about Pyongyang's nuclear development agenda. The United States and South Korea conducted joint military exercises in February, despite North to South Korea's warning not to conduct the exercises, calling them provocation and threatening to wrap Seoul in a sea of flames.
South Korea accuses North of torpedoing and sinking one of its warships in March 2010, killing 46 sailors, and last November North Korea bombed Yeonpyeong Island, killing two marines and two South Korean civilians.
CNN's Paula Hancocks contributed to this report

text:
CNN reported Monday on the heartbreaking story of Emily Bauer, a Houston teenager, who suffered a debilitating stroke after consuming what has become known as synthetic marijuana.
Although the role that synthetic marijuana played in Emily's medical condition is still unclear, what is clear is that these new chemicals could not even exist if it weren't for the ban on marijuana, a plant that has been widely consumed worldwide for thousands of years. A few years ago, people started using synthetic marijuana to evade drug testing, and they realized, once news reports spread their existence.
And even though President Obama and 41 governors have signed legislation criminalizing various forms of synthetic marijuana, this is not going to go away, that is, until we legally regulate marijuana itself.
To understand the use of drugs by adolescents, we must recognize that they have grown up with drugs everywhere. We urge young people to be drug free, but Americans are bombarded with messages that encourage us to absorb and medicate with a variety of substances: We use caffeine to increase our energy, drink alcohol to relax, and use prescription and over-the-counter drugs to help us work, study, and sleep. And despite the draconian punishments associated with illegal drugs, 44% of today's teenagers will test them before graduating from high school.
Marijuana itself is the most widely used illegal drug -- over 100 million Americans have used it and 20 million have been arrested by it since 1965.
It is not surprising that, given the laws of supply and demand, enterprising chemists have discovered a host of marijuana-like chemicals that can be sprayed on plant matter similar to potpourri and sold as incense. People who have tried synthetic marijuana often report psychoactive effects comparable to marijuana, but noticeably less pleasurable.
Almost no one would touch this synthetic matter -- actually, it wouldn't even exist -- except for the criminalization of the marijuana plant itself. Trying to ban one substance after another is like a nut game: every time one is banned, another untested and potentially more dangerous drug appears to replace it.
The synthetic marijuana Emily Bauer consumed was probably one of the second generation of synthetic marijuana chemicals. Since Congress and state legislatures banned a large number of them in the last two years, companies that produce these products have simply changed their chemical formulations to one of thousands of slightly different chemicals with marijuana-like effects.
These new synthetic marijuana products are not an example of effective legal regulation, but an example of sub-regulation. Like aspirin or soft drinks, they are not subject to age, leave, or other restrictions.
Interestingly, the rush to criminalize synthetic marijuana and other synthetic drugs comes at a time when public opinion is dramatically changing in favor of decriminalizing, and even legally regulating, marijuana.
More than three quarters of U.S. voters believe marijuana should be decriminalized, which has been done by 14 states. They also believe it should be available for medical use, that 18 states and the District of Columbia now allow it; and about half think it should be legally regulated more or less like alcohol, as Colorado and Washington are doing. After decades of ban on marijuana, elected officials and the public are finally realizing that regulating the production and sale of marijuana is the best way to reduce the damage of the illicit marijuana market and the damage of marijuana use itself.
It is important to note that the overwhelmingly approved marijuana legalization initiatives in Colorado and Washington last November create strictly regulated regimes - with age restrictions - LRB- 21 or older -RRB- accompanied by meticulous government oversight of retail producers and distributors. On the other hand, synthetic marijuana, either insufficiently regulated or totally prohibited, has never been subject to an adequate level of regulation.
Before rushing to criminalize a new drug, legislators should ask: What specific regulatory options would help reduce harm to individuals, families, and society? We need to ask ourselves how best to solve the problem -- how to reduce drug abuse and addiction -- and use the best evidence to guide us.
And the evidence clearly shows that effective legal regulation reduces drug harm better than prohibition. We have already learned a lot from the regulation of other substances, such as alcohol and tobacco. It has been shown that labelling requirements for products, as well as restrictions on marketing, branding and retailing, reduce young people's access to tobacco products and drive tobacco purchases.
Tobacco has contributed to more deaths than combined alcohol and illicit drugs. As a result of educational initiatives and restrictions on marketing and age, smoking has declined dramatically over time, despite its legality for adults, in one of the greatest public health successes of the last generation.
Direct criminalization only drives the demand for drugs to the illicit market. Under prohibition, regulators have no control over where the product is sold, who sells it, or who sells it. In addition, the detention of young people often causes more harm than the use of drugs in itself.
After 40 years of the war on drugs, evidence clearly shows that it is ineffective to use the criminal justice system to send public health messages. The ban simply creates new public health problems and maximizes the harm associated with the use of illegal drugs.
In fact, drugs, whether marijuana or synthetic marijuana, should not be regulated legally because they are safe; they should be regulated legally precisely because they can be harmful.
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of Jag Davies.

text:
It has been a common view among political philosophers that there is a special relationship between moral goodness and legitimate authority. Many authors (especially those who composed Prince's mirror books or royal council books during the Middle Ages and the Renaissance) believed that the use of political power was legitimate only if it was exercised by a ruler whose personal moral character was strictly virtuous. Thus, the rulers were advised that if they wanted to succeed — that is, if they wanted a long and peaceful reign and wanted to pass their office to their descendants — they should be sure to behave in accordance with conventional standards of ethical kindness. In a sense, it was thought that the rulers did well when doing good; they earned the right to be obeyed and respected insofar as they showed themselves to be virtuous and morally upright (see Briggs and Nederman nearby).
Machiavelli thoroughly criticizes precisely this moralistic view of authority in his best known treatise, The Prince. For Machiavelli, there is no moral basis for judging the difference between the legitimate and illegitimate uses of power. Rather, authority and power are essentially coequal: whoever has power has the right to command; but goodness does not guarantee power and the good person has no more authority by virtue of being good. Thus, in direct opposition to a moralist theory of politics, Machiavelli says that the only real concern of the political ruler is the acquisition and maintenance of power (although he speaks less of power per se than of “maintaining the state”). In this sense, Machiavelli presents an atrocious criticism of the concept of authority, arguing that the notion of legitimate rights of rulership adds nothing to the actual possession of power. The Prince intends to reflect the self-conscious political realism of an author who is fully aware — on the basis of direct experience with the Florentine government — that goodness and law are not enough to win and maintain a political office. Machiavelli thus seeks to learn and teach the rules of political power. For Machiavelli, power characteristically defines political activity, and therefore it is necessary for any successful ruler to know how to use power. Machiavelli believes that only through the correct application of power can individuals be led to obey and the ruler will be able to keep the state secure.
Machiavelli's political theory, then, represents a concerted effort to exclude questions of authority and legitimacy from consideration in the discussion of political decision-making and political judgment. Nowhere does this come out more clearly than in their treatment of the relationship between law and force. Machiavelli recognizes that good laws and good weapons are the dual basis of a well-ordered political system. But he immediately adds that since coercion creates legality, he will focus his attention on force. It says: “Since there can be no good laws without good weapons, I will not consider the laws, but I will speak of weapons” (Prince CW 47). In other words, the legitimacy of the law is based entirely on the threat of coercive force; authority is impossible for Machiavelli as a right apart from power to enforce it. Consequently, Machiavelli concludes that fear is always preferable to affection in subjects, as violence and deception are superior to legality in order to effectively control them. Machiavelli observes that
This can be said in general of men: they are ungrateful, disloyal, insincere and deceitful, shy of danger and avid for gain....Love is a bond of obligation that these miserable creatures break when it suits them to do so; but fear holds them firm for a fear of punishment that never happens. (Prince CW 62; revised translation)
As a result, Machiavelli cannot really be said to have a theory of the obligation separate from the imposition of power; people obey only because they fear the consequences of not doing so, whether it is the loss of life or privileges. And, of course, power alone cannot bind one, to the extent that the obligation assumes that one cannot do anything else in a meaningful way.
Concomitantly, a Machiavellian perspective directly attacks the notion of any foundation for authority independent of pure possession of power. For Machiavelli, people are obliged to obey purely in deference to the higher power of the state. If I think I should not obey a particular law, what eventually leads me to submit to that law will be either a fear of the power of the state or the actual exercise of that power. It is the power that is ultimately necessary for the application of contradictory views of what I must do; I can only choose not to obey if I possess the power to resist the demands of the State or if I am willing to accept the consequences of the superiority of the State of coercive force. Machiavelli's argument in The Prince is designed to demonstrate that politics can only be consistently defined in terms of supremacy of coercive power; authority as a right to command has no independent status. He maintains this statement by referring to the observable realities of political affairs and public life, as well as arguments that reveal the selfish nature of all human conduct. For Machiavelli it makes no sense and it is useless to speak of any claim of authority and the right to command that is separated from the possession of the higher political power. The ruler who lives alone for his rights will surely wither and die for those same rights, because in the harsh and tumultuous political conflict those who prefer power to authority are more likely to succeed. Without exception, the authority of states and their laws will never be recognized when they are not supported by a demonstration of power that makes obedience inescapable. The methods of achieving obedience are varied, and depend to a large extent on the foresight exercised by the prince. Therefore, the successful ruler needs special training.

Like most contemporary counterfactual theories, Lewis' theory employs a possible world semantics for counterfactuals. Such semantics establishes conditions of truth for counterfactuals in terms of similarities between possible worlds. Lewis advocates realism over the possible worlds, according to which the possible non-real worlds are real concrete entities at the same time as the present world (Lewis 1986e). However, most contemporary philosophers would try to display the framework of explanatoryly fruitful possible worlds, while distanced themselves from full realism over possible worlds (see entry into possible worlds).
The central notion of a possible global semantics for counterfactuals is a relation of comparative similarity between worlds (Lewis 1973a). It is said that one world is closer to the present than another if the former is more like the real world than the latter. In terms of this similarity relationship, the condition of truth for the counterfactual “If A (or had been) the case, C would be (or had been) the case” is stated as follows:
(1)
“If A were the case, C would be the case” is true in the real world if and only if (i) there are no possible A-worlds; or (ii) some A-world where C has closer to the real world than any A-world where C does not have.
We will ignore the first case in which the counterfactual is vaguely true. The fundamental idea of this analysis is that the counterfactual “If A were the case, C would be the case” is true only if it takes less than a deviation from the present to make the background true together with the consequence than to make the previous true without the consequent.
In terms of counterfactuals, Lewis defines a notion of causal dependence between events, which plays a central role in his theory of causality (1973b).
(2)
When c and e are two different possible events, and causally depends on c if and only if, if c would occur and occur; and if c would not occur and would not occur.
This condition states that whether or not e occurs depends on whether or not c occurs. Where c and e are events that really happen, this condition of truth can be simplified a little. Because in this case it is deduced from the second formal condition on the relation of comparative similarity that the counterfactual “If c would occur and happen” is automatically true: this formal condition implies that a counterfactual with true antecedent and true consequence is in itself true. Consequently, the true condition for causal dependence becomes:
(3)
Where c and e are two distinct real events, and it depends causally on c if and only if, if c did not occur and would not occur.
There are three important things to point out about the definition of causal dependence. First, it takes the primary relationship of causal dependence to be events. Lewis' own theory of events (1986b) constructs events as classes of possible time-space regions. However, different conceptions of events are compatible with the basic definition (Kim 1973a; for an alternative in general Lewisian assume the events see McDonnell 2016 and Kaiserman 2017). Indeed, it even seems possible to formulate it in terms of facts and not events (Mellor 1995, 2004).
Secondly, the definition requires that causally dependent events be distinct from each other. Distinction means that events are not identical, neither is it part of the other, nor does it imply the other. This rating is important if false non-causal dependencies are discarded. (For this point, see Kim 1973b and Lewis 1986b.) Because although you wouldn’t have written ‘Larry’ if you hadn’t written ‘rr’, and you wouldn’t have said ‘hello’ aloud if you hadn’t said ‘hello’, neither does dependency count as a causal dependence, as the paired events are no different from each other in the required sense.
Convinced of the need to leave room in his analysis for causation by (and) absence – as when the gardener's failure to water the plants causes his death – Lewis subsequently changed his opinion to the view that causal dependence is a matter of counterfactual dependence between events or their absences (Lewis 2000: §X; 2004b). We will largely ignore this complication in what follows: for some discussion of causality by absence see Schaffer 2000b, Beebee 2004b, McGrath 2005, Livengood and Machery 2007, Dowe 2009.
Thirdly, the counterfactuals used in the analysis should be understood according to what Lewis calls the standard interpretation. There are several possible ways of interpreting counterfactuals; and some interpretations give rise to false non-causional dependencies between events. For example, suppose that events c and e are effects of a common cause d. It is tempting to reason that there must be a causal dependence between c and e participating in the following piece of counterfactual reasoning: if c had not occurred, then d would not have occurred; and if d had not occurred, and would not have occurred. But Lewis says that the old counterfactual, which he calls a counterfactual of retrogression, should not be used in the evaluation of causal dependence. The correct counterfactuals to be used are unretroduced counterfactuals that typically keep the past fixed to the time (or just before the time) in which the background of the counterfactual is supposed to obtain. So if c hadn't happened, d – which actually happened before c – would have happened anyway; so in the standard interpretation, where the counterfactuals of recoil are false, the inference to the assertion that e causally depends on c is blocked.

text:
The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in favor of marriage equality this week. Marriage is an institution intended for two people who love each other, who want to commit to the union for life as a couple, and to form a family, either only the two of them, or also includes children.
The traditional concept of marriage has evolved over time. In recent history, it has been defined by most religions, and states, as a man and a woman. However, there are millions of human beings whose composition is such that they are attracted to the same gender and share the universal human desire to bond with a mate for life. They're gay.
In 2013, the vast majority of Americans have gone beyond prejudice towards gays and lesbians. Homosexual couples and their families have lived openly in our communities for more than 30 years, and we now know them as neighbors, family and friends. In the course of living their daily lives, raising families and contributing to society, we have come to see that American gays and lesbians share the same hopes and dreams as everyone else.
However, for decades, we have had a political debate about opposite gender vs. gender marriages that has created a constant stream of agitation. What many public figures have known to be true about gay people in their personal lives has been -- until recently -- unacceptable to openly recognize in the political arena. In recent years, however, public opinion has driven our political conversation dramatically. Four out of five young voters, of all denominations and political parties, support marriage equality, and even those who continue to oppose the marriage rights of same-sex couples can see that it is inevitable.
The problem is that despite the fact that public opinion has reached a historic peak in marriage equality, the old laws that discriminate against American gays and lesbians have remained in the books, wounding gay couples and their families. Congress passed a law -- the Defense of Marriage Act or DOMA -- that prohibited the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriage, although this is a constitutionally agreed matter for most states to decide. And that's the mistake the Supreme Court corrected this week.
The court found DOMA unconstitutional, and also allowed same-sex couples to return to California.
In writing for the majority, Judge Anthony Kennedy ruled that restricting marriage to opposite-sex couples forces same-sex couples to live as married for the purpose of state law but unmarried for the purpose of federal law, thereby diminishing the stability and predictability of basic personal relationships that the state has found appropriate to recognize and protect.
Kennedy also said that the law unfairly treated the 220,000 children of same-sex couples in the United States differently from the children of parents of the opposite sex -- which we should all agree is hard, unnecessary, and unfair. Ensuring that all children can grow up with the same federal benefits and protections as their parents offer is crucial, and Kennedy rightly saw the impact of not only making marriages equal to federal purposes, but also making their families equal.
Marriage is an institution that provides stability to society and the family. By quashing DOMA and dismissing the California Proposition 8 appeal, the Supreme Court has forged a bipartisan consensus that marriage is an institution important enough to apply to human beings equally, regardless of gender. It is important to note that the court also strengthened the basis on which advocates and officials will one day achieve marriage equality throughout the country.
That wasn't so hard right now, was it?
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of Donna Brazile.

European stocks expanded their rally to a fourth day in a row on Thursday, as investors expected a faster global economic recovery, while Unilever’s disappointing goals weighed on the London index.

The designated Prime Minister will conclude his formal consultations with the parties on Saturday, said the parliamentary press office in a statement on Thursday.

Global markets remained hopeful after Democrats moved forward on Wednesday with a move to approve US President Joe Biden's $1.9 billion COVID-19 aid package without Republican support.

The massive collection of phone records by government surveillance programs poses a clear threat to the personal privacy of ordinary citizens, according to U.S. researchers who used basic phone records to identify people and uncover confidential information about their lives.
Armed with anonymous “metadata” about people’s calls and texts, but not about the content of communications, two scientists at Stanford University drew up the names of people, where they lived, and the names of their partners. But that wasn't all.
The same data led them to discover potentially sensitive information about some people. One man was found to own a rifle, while another had recently been diagnosed with an irregular heartbeat. Other data point to a new pregnancy and a person with multiple sclerosis.
The results highlight the extraordinary power of phone metadata – the number called, when and for how long – especially when combined with publicly available information from services such as Google, Yelp and Facebook. The value of the data, which are not subject to the same legal protections as the content of people's communications, has long been recognized by the security services. As Stewart Baker, the former General Counselor of the United States National Security Agency (NSA), said, following Edward Snowden’s revelations: “Metadata tells you absolutely everything about someone’s life.”
Patrick Mutchler, a computer security researcher at Stanford, said that while the power of metadata was understood by those who collected the information, the public was largely in the dark because so few published studies have revealed how rich the data are. “That makes it difficult for people with strong opinions about these programs to fight against them. Now, we have strong evidence that that didn’t exist in the past,” he said.
For the study, researchers signed 823 people who agreed to have metadata collected from their phones via an Android app. The app also received information from their Facebook accounts, which scientists used to check the accuracy of their results. In total, researchers collected metadata in more than 250,000 calls and more than 1.2 million texts.
Analysts who entered the NSA metadata collection system were initially allowed to examine data up to three leaps away from an individual. A call from the target individual's phone to another number was a leap. There were two jumps from that phone to another. And so on. The records available to analysts were extended for five years. The collection window has now been limited to two hops and a maximum of 18 months.
Writing in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Mutchler describes how, on a tight budget, he and his graduate partner, Jonathan Mayer, discovered a lot of personal information, part of it sensitive, about the people who participated in the study. Through automatic and manual searches, 82% of people's names were identified. The same technique gave them the names of the businesses that people had called. When these were mapped, they revealed local business clusters, which scientists speculated surrounded the person's home. In this way, they named the people of the city living at 57% of the time, and they were almost 90% accurate when they placed the people within 50 miles of their home. Mutchler believes that some of the faults come from people who don't update their Facebook page when they moved from their parents' home, for example, to go to college.
The scientists then deepened into more personal territory. Using a simple computer program to analyze people's call patterns, they infer who among the study volunteers was in a relationship. Once they knew that the owner of a particular number had a partner, identifying the other significant was easy, they reported.
For the final part of the study, the researchers deepened further, to see what sensitive information they could extract from the phone metadata. They gathered details of calls made to and a list of organizations, including hospitals, pharmacies, religious groups, legal services, firearms retailers and repair companies. From them, they put together some extraordinary vignettes of people’s lives.
The metadata of one person in the study showed that they received a long call from a cardiology center, spoke briefly to a medical laboratory, responded to a series of short calls from a local pharmacy, and then made calls to a hotline for abnormal heart rate control devices. Another participant made frequent calls to a local gun supplier specializing in semi-automatic rifles and later made several long calls to the customer service hotline led by a major gun manufacturer producing the rifles. The metadata of two others suggest that one had multiple sclerosis and the other had just become pregnant.
“All of this should be taken as an indication of what is possible with two graduate students and limited resources,” said Mutchler, who argues that the findings should make policymakers think twice before authorizing mass surveillance programs. “Large-scale metadata monitoring programmes, such as those of the NSA, will necessarily expose highly confidential information about ordinary citizens,” scientists write, adding: “To strike an appropriate balance between national security and civil liberties, future policy formulation must be based on input from relevant sciences.”
Ross Anderson, a professor of security engineering at Cambridge University, said the study provided numbers on which discussions can now be based. “With the correct analysis of communications data at the national level, a large amount of sensitive information about everyone can be inferred. We always suspected that, of course, but here are the data.”

A classical formulation of a criterionological argument for miracles is employed by Charles Leslie (1697/1815: 13), who argues that we can safely believe a historical statement that meets four criteria:
Let matters of fact be such, as that the outward senses of men, their eyes and ears, may be judges of it.
Let it be done publicly in the face of the world.
Not only should public monuments be kept in memory of this, but some external actions should also be carried out.
That such monuments, and such actions or observances, should be instituted and begin from the moment the question of fact was made.
The first two criteria, Leslie explains, “make it impossible for any question of fact to be imposed on men, at a time when it is said that such a fact is done, because the eyes and senses of each man contradict it.” The last two criteria assure those who come after that the account of the event was not invented after the time of the supposed event. Leslie points out that these criteria are not necessary conditions for factual truth, but insists that they are — taken together — sufficient. Therefore, we can talk about Leslie's principle: If any reported event meets all four of these criteria, then its historicity is true.
In evaluating a criterionological argument, we have to ask ourselves not only whether the event in question meets the criteria, but also whether the criteria themselves are good indicators of truth. An argument for the criteria that Leslie gives cannot proceed altogether a priori, as there is no necessary connection between the satisfaction of an event the criteria and its true being. In this case, perhaps the most promising approach would be to argue that the criteria effectively rule out explanations other than the truth of the claim. Leslie's comments suggest that this is the direction she would go if challenged, but does not offer a fully developed defense of her criteria.
Leslie's argument is, in the sense described above, categorical: he maintains that, as the affirmation of the resurrection meets all four criteria (the monuments provided by the Christian commemoration of the last supper and the transfer of the day of worship from Saturday to the first day of the week (Sunday), the certainty of the question of fact in question is "proved". This rather bold statement opens up the possibility of refuting Leslie’s principle by counter-example, though supposedly Conyers Middleton, Hume’s contemporary whose criticism of ecclesiastical miracles was notable for his meticulousness, sought for years uselessly a counter-example of Leslie’s principle. In any case, a criterionological argument can also be constructed on the basis of a more modest principle, as if any reported event meets all four of these criteria, then it is reasonable to accept its historicity.
The main difficulty with criteria, whether bold or modest, is that they do not provide any means to take into account any other consideration that might weigh against the historical claim in question. Intuitively, the improbability of an extreme background must have some weight in our assessment of the credibility of a de facto statement. An advocate of a criterionological argument might answer that as long as the bar is high enough, the prior improbability will be overwhelmed by the fact that the event actually meets the stipulated criteria. But this is an affirmation that requires argument; and the bolder the conclusion, the more argument it requires.

As human rights defenders around the world celebrate the 64th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights this week, their counterparts in the United States are mourning the Senate's rejection last week of the international convention on the rights of persons with disabilities. Applauding in its own right, the defeat of the senatorial Republicans of the first human rights treaty of the twenty-first century is a sad but acute reminder that disinformation and fear can still prevail over the fundamental principles of human decency and common sense.
More importantly, it is another blow to the ability of the United States to play a leading role in promoting freedoms and human dignity in the world.
The international charter of rights adopted by the United Nations on 10 December 1948 remains the standard of gold in the daily struggle for basic human rights today. As our societies democratize, mature and progress, human rights defenders are winning long-standing battles to expand the boundaries of rights to women, children, indigenous peoples, LGBT communities and migrants. Economic and social rights are also ascending, and people claim the essentials of human life: water, food, health, employment and education.
The United States has a long and generally bipartisan tradition of concern for human rights, a pillar of its founding principles. Americans have also been at the forefront of the global human rights movement for generations and we consider ourselves a leading example for others in a rights-respecting society, even if we still have a lot of work to do to improve our record. In fact, it was Congress' approval of the American Disability Act in 1990 that paved the way for the international campaign for disability rights and served as a standard for the treaty that the Senate rejected.
However, when it comes to international law, some Americans get confused. The image of the United Nations as a supranational body with the powers to insert itself into our living rooms persists despite the fact that there is no evidence to support it.
This myth, and its inherent contradictions, are on display in Rick Santorum's strange essay of opinion published last week in The Daily Beast. In it, the leader of the conservative movement, in order to defeat the treaty, claims that unelected UN bureaucrats could take power away from parents to demand special education services for a disabled child. He then states that there is no point in ratifying the treaty because it would not oblige any foreign government to amend its laws or spend resources on the disabled. That is what these governments must decide.
Precisely. The hallmark of the United Nations human rights system is its success in developing international standards for the protection of a comprehensive set of human rights, monitoring States ' respect for those rights and making recommendations for improving their records. In exceptional cases of serious violations, such as war crimes and mass atrocities, governments - LRB - although not the United States -RRB - have agreed on a stronger set of mechanisms, such as the International Criminal Court, to hold people accountable.
The new doctrine of responsibility to protect civilians has even been applied to prevent the killing of civilians in Libya. But these measures are far from any alleged interference by UN lawyers in our schools and homes.
At the end of the day, however, national sovereignty overcomes these efforts, leaving any State free to follow its own path to govern its people. For better or worse, that's how it works.
There is a broader and disheartening message that the world hears from Washington on International Human Rights Day this year: America is losing its moral voice on human rights because it is not setting an example.
As a human rights defender recently told me, his government routinely cites the U.S. treatment of detainees in Guantánamo as justification for their own human rights violations. When the exceptional case, as well as the necessary measures taken to wage a battle against terrorists, becomes a norm, we have lost an important source of credibility to promote the basic principles of due process and innocence until proven guilty.
Unfortunately, the victory of the conservative movement in defeating the treaty on the rights of persons with disabilities is only the last example of our political leaders failing to turn high-level rhetoric into meaningful action when it comes to human rights. If a Republican war hero like Bob Dole, who uses a wheelchair, cannot persuade his colleagues to do the right thing, then we are all the losers in the battle for human rights.
The views expressed in this commentary are only those of Ted Piccone.

What is the connection between self-consciousness and the consciousness of others? In some points of view self-consciousness requires the consciousness of others, in other points of view the consciousness of others requires self-consciousness. In each case we can distinguish between those accounts according to which such consciousness is merely an empirical condition of those according to which it is a strictly necessary/sufficient condition. A distinction must also be made with regard to the sense of “consciousness of others” at stake: while some philosophers care about the knowledge of other minds, others are content with the representation of others, true or not.
A familiar account of our knowledge of others takes the form of an analogy argument (Slot 1970: chap. 4; Avramides 2001: Part I). The analogy argument presents an account of our justification for moving from judgments on the observable behavior of others to judgments on their unobservable mental states. I am aware of my own case that, say, winking is the result of pain, so, seeing someone else's wink, I am justified in judging that they are in pain. In this picture, self-consciousness, as manifested in the judgment on my own case, is a necessary condition of the knowledge of other minds. In this sense, the point of view is related to contemporary simulation theory, whose standard versions view our ability to attribute mental states to others as dependent on our ability to attribute them to ourselves (Heal 1986; Goldman 2006: ch. 9; for a simulationist theory that differs in this regard, see Gordon 1996). Associated with the analogy argument is a point of view according to which our understanding of the concepts of mental state is essentially a first personal matter. That is, we understand what, for example, pain is first of our own case (Nagel 1986: §2.3; Peacoke 2008: ch. 5–6; it has sometimes been claimed that this vision gives rise to the conceptual problem of other minds, see Wittgenstein 1958: §302; McGinn 1984; Avramides 2001: part II).
In opposition to this set of views on which our understanding and application of the concepts of mental state is neutral between the cases of first and third person. Theorists of theory, for example, claim that we attribute mental states to both ourselves and others through a psychological (tacitally sustained) theory. They can also argue that the possession of such a theory constitutes our understanding of the concepts of mental state (Carruthers 1996, 2011: ch. 8; Gopnik & Meltzoff 1997; for an account combining theory elements with simulation elements, see Nichols & Stich 2003). Although such views do not give priority to the case in the first person, they can see a close connection between self-consciousness and our ability to think about others: these are simply two aspects of the more general ability to think about the mind. A distinct but related family sees both self-consciousness and the consciousness of others as the emergence of a primitive “adualistic” state in which self and others do not distinguish themselves (Piaget 1937; Merleau-Ponty 1960; Barresi & Moore 1996; Hurley 2005; Gallese 2005; see also D. Stern 1985: Part II). Against such "adualistic" views, it is often claimed that neonate imitation phenomena, joint attention and regulation of emotion show that babies show a consciousness of others like others from the beginning of life (Meltzoff & Moore 1977; Trevarthen 1979; Hurley & Chater 2005; Eilan et al. 2005; Legerstee 2005; Reddy 2008). An empirical proposal is that it is from this early form of social interaction and ability to understand others that self-consciousness emerges as a self-directed form of mental reading (Carruthers 2011; Carruthers, Fletcher, & Ritchie 2012; for an early account of this type, see Mead 1934). In this view, the case in the first person is treated as secondary, reversing the traditional picture associated with the analogy argument.
label: C2
