All we know about the so-called founder of the so-called dialectical school, Clinomaco de Thurii, is that he was the first to write about preaching (katêgorêmata) and propositions (axiômata) and similar (DL 2.112). Our evidence for Diodoro and Philo confirms that they, too, conceived logic as a logic of propositions. It was the Stoics who systematically developed a logic of propositions and devised subtle classifications of predicates. (On the contrary, Aristotle's logic had been a logic of terms, where the terms subject and preached were in principle interchangeable.) Thus, the logic of dialectical school was a precursor to stoic logic.
In the time of Diodorus and Philon a distinction between simple and non-simple propositions was in circulation among the minor Greek socratic philosophical sects (DL 2,139). Simple propositions were divided into affirmations and denials (ibid.). Among the non-simple propositions, which were thought to be composed of simple ones, conditionalities, disjunctions and conjunctions were distinguished. Disjunctions or conditionalities were presented as premises in many of the logical paradoxes and sophisms discussed by the members of the dialectical school. Diodoro and Philo are likely to examine the truth conditions of the three kinds of non-simple propositions; however, we know their views only for the case of conditionality (see below sect. 3).
His treatment of conditionalities and modalities implies that —like most Hellenistic philosophers — Diodorus and Filo worked with a concept of proposition that differs from ours in that it allows the values of truth to change over time. For example, the standard example for a simple proposition, ‘It’s the day’, does not contain a fixed date or defined time determination; rather, it varies over time, changing its truth value twice a day, while it remains the same proposition. Thus we can think of propositions as understood by Hellenistic philosophers as functions of time. Diodoro Cronus may also be credited with the beginnings of temporal logic, since both his theory of conditionality and his narratives of modalities are constructed on logically relevant temporal properties of propositions (see sects below. 3.2 and 4.2). In addition, he distinguished between propositions at the present time as ‘Helen has three husbands’ and ‘These men are getting married’ and propositions at a time of completion (the aorist), ‘Helen had three husbands’ and ‘These men got married’, and observed that it is possible that propositions such as the last two are true, without there ever being a time when one of the previous corresponding types was true (Sextus Espiritus [SE], Against physicists 2.97-8).
Apart from the various logical puzzles and sophisms, there are only two topics on which we can be sure of a positive contribution to logic on the part of the members of the dialectical school. These are the positions of Diodorus and Philon on the theory of conditionals and on modal logic. Both issues involve notorious difficulties and were discussed extensively and intensively by Hellenist logicists; so much so that disputes became part of the general knowledge of the intellectuality of the time (SE, Contra los Grammarianos 309-10). In addition, the theory of modalities was believed to have far-reaching results in other areas of philosophy.
label: C2

It's called Godwin's law. The longer a debate lasts, the greater the likelihood that someone will compare another to Hitler.
And Hillary Clinton has done just that: On Tuesday the former Secretary of State told a private fundraising party that the actions of Russian President Vladimir Putin are similar to those of Hitler in the run-up to World War II.
His quote -LRB- according to the Long Beach Press-Telegram -RRB-: All the Germans who were... the ethnic Germans, the Germans of descent who were in places like Czechoslovakia and Romania and elsewhere, Hitler continued to say that they were not being treated properly. I have to go and protect my people, and that's what makes everyone so nervous.
Of course, what also makes everyone so nervous are state leaders who compare Putin to Hitler and therefore raise the spectrum of another world war.
It is unlikely that Clinton intended to win politically with these comments, and they were carefully qualified. He added that there is no indication that Putin is as irrational as the German dictator was. But they could indicate that if it wins the 2016 elections, the U.S. could win a slightly stronger president in foreign affairs, someone more willing to participate directly in Europe than Obama. You may remember that in the 2008 primary she was the candidate for Democratshawk, so much so that Ann Coulter preferred her to John McCain - LRB- Coulter called her our girl -RRB-.
But Clinton was right? Mostly not. It is true that Putin's justification for intervening in Ukraine is similar to Hitler's, that is, he threatens to invade sovereign territory to defend his ethnic brothers. But the situation is complex, and the historical comparison is tenuous at best.
After all, in the eyes of many ethnic Russians, it is the Ukrainian nationalists -- not Putin -- the Nazis. The Russians have stated, quite accurately, that the revolution that overthrew a democratically elected pro-Russian leader has led to the rise of the Russophobic fascists to key positions in government. For example, the new secretary of the National Security and Defence Council of Ukraine is Andriy Parubiy, co-founder of the Neonazi National Social Party of Ukraine (LRB-SNPU-RRB).
Another creator of SNPU is Oleh Tyahnybok, a high-profile leader of Kiev protests who has blamed Ukraine's problems for a Jewish conspiracy that has just ended in Moscow. The new Undersecretary of National Security of Ukraine is Dmytro Yarosh, leader of the right-wing sector group, who regards Tyahnybok as a soft liberal and who hoists the old flag of Ukrainian Nazi collaborators at their rallies.
In other words, in this situation, who exactly are the Nazis? Putin's ethnic Russian nationalists? Or aside from Ukrainian ethnic nationalists? Neither of us is particularly nice.
Of course, the Ukrainian Nazi movement is small, and Ukraine is dwarfed by Russia, which puts Putin in the role of the dominant regional power that gets into a small country and exploits its extremist policy for propaganda purposes. But Putin is not Hitler yet, because he lacks the German Fuehrer's global vision.
Hitler worked for a racist ideology of all scope that dreamed of turning Europe into a giant space of life for his people. Putin -- the leader of a democracy, though highly corrupt and politically stagnant -- simply meddles in the affairs of countries that could reasonably be said to fall within the historical sphere of influence of his country. Ukraine was part of the Soviet Union until two decades ago - LRB- while Crimea was part of Russia until 1954 -RRB-, the country contains millions of ethnic Russians and, crucially, has Russian military facilities that are key to Russia's strategic interests.
In other words, a Russian invasion of Ukraine is not going to be a stepping stone to the invasion of France. Unfortunately, it may well be a step towards participation in the affairs of the Baltic States, which are firmly in NATO and the EU. That is why Putin's last ambitions must be checked.
However, calling Putin Hitler is careless. Even reckless. As Marc Tracy points out in the New Republic, it is historically insensitive and ignores the tapestry of ongoing cultural clashes and political calculations. It also reeks of the Manichaean division of the world between good and evil that permeated the war on terror and led to so many terrible mistakes and so many American deaths abroad. Worse still, that provocative language should be applied to a confrontation with a state like Russia.
We are dealing with a major nuclear weapon power that has the ability to reduce the world to so much irradiated ash. The West must be careful with its words.
label: C2

Netanyahu has managed to remain in office during the investigations and three election campaigns, with a fourth election scheduled for 23 March.
He denies having committed a crime and a trial is likely to take years. He will fight to remain prime minister in March and possibly for years later. If he wins, he could try to secure parliamentary immunity, or pass laws to exempt a serving prime minister from trial.
How did you stay in the office?
Under Israeli law, a prime minister has no obligation to withdraw unless he is convicted. No other government minister is protected in this way, so there are legal and political reasons why Netanyahu wants to stay at the top.
ISRAELIS?
Yeah. The corruption case has had a polarizing impact on Israelis. Thousands of protesters gather weekly outside their official residence and through Israel under the banner of the “Minister of Crime,” demanding that they resign.
But his right-wing voter base has remained loyal. Supporters see the man they call King Bibi as strong in security and an influential voice for Israel abroad.
What are the charges?
The 4000 case alleges that Netanyahu granted regulatory favours worth approximately 1.8 billion shekels (about $500 million) to the Bezeq Telecom Israel telecommunications company. In return, prosecutors say, he sought positive coverage of himself and his wife Sara on a news website controlled by former company president Shaul Elovitch.
In this case, Netanyahu has been charged with bribery, fraud and abuse of trust. Elovitch and his wife, Iris, have been charged with bribery and obstruction of justice. The couple denies having committed a crime.
CASE 1000, in which Netanyahu has been charged with fraud and abuse of trust, focuses on allegations that he and his wife illegally received nearly 700,000 shekels of gifts from Hollywood producer and Israeli citizen Arnon Milchan, and Australian billionaire businessman James Packer.
Prosecutors said the gifts included champagne and cigars and Netanyahu helped Milchan with his commercial interests. Packer and Milchan don't face charges.
CASE 2000 alleges that Netanyahu negotiated an agreement with Arnon Mozes, owner of the Israeli newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth, for better coverage and that, in return, he offered legislation that would slow the growth of a rival newspaper. Netanyahu has been charged with fraud and abuse of trust. Mozes has been accused of offering a bribe, and denies evil.
What does Netanyahu say?
Netanyahu says he is the victim of a politically orchestrated “witch hunt” by the left and the media to expel him from office, and that receiving gifts from friends is not illegal.
Could you go to jail?
Bribery charges carry a prison sentence of up to 10 years and/or a fine. Fraud and breach of trust carry a sentence of up to three years.
Is a Verdict coming soon?
Not likely. The trial could take years. However, proceedings could be interrupted if Netanyahu requests a plea agreement.

text:
Long before “postmodernism” became fashionable, Adorno and Horkheimer wrote one of the most interesting criticisms of modernity that have emerged among progressive European intellectuals. The dialectic of Enlightenment is a product of his exile in times of war. He first appeared as a mimeographer entitled Philosophical Fragments in 1944. This title became the subtitle when the book was published in 1947. His book begins with a grim assessment of the modern West: “Illumination, understood in the broadest sense as the advance of thought, has always been aimed at freeing human beings from fear and installing them as teachers. However, the fully illuminated earth radiates under the sign of a triumphant disaster” (DE 1, modified translation). How can this be, the authors ask. How can the progress of modern science, medicine, and industry promise to free people from ignorance, disease, and brutal work and mental numbness, yet help create a world where people will willingly swallow fascist ideology, deliberately practice genocide, and vigorously develop lethal weapons of mass destruction? The reason, they respond, has become irrational.
Although Francis Bacon is cited as the chief spokesman for an instrumentalized reason that becomes irrational, Horkheimer and Adorno do not think that modern science and science are the only culprits. The tendency of rational progress to become irrational regression arises much earlier. In fact, they cite both Hebrew scriptures and Greek philosophers as a contribution to regressive tendencies. If Horkheimer and Adorno are right, then a critique of modernity must also be a critique of premodernity, and a turn toward the postmodern cannot be simply a return to the premodern. Otherwise, the failures of modernity will continue under a new appearance in contemporary conditions. Society as a whole needs to be transformed.
Horkheimer and Adorno believe that society and culture form a historical whole, so that the search for freedom in society is inseparable from the search for enlightenment in culture (DE xvi). There is an opposite side to this: the lack or loss of freedom in society—in the political, economic and legal structures within which we live—points to a concomitant failure in cultural enlightenment—in philosophy, the arts, religion, etc. The Nazi extermination camps are not an aberration, nor are they studio films with no sense of innocent entertainment. Both indicate that something fundamental has gone wrong in the modern West.
According to Horkheimer and Adorno, the source of today's disaster is a pattern of blind domination, domination in a triple sense: the domination of nature by human beings, the domination of nature within human beings, and, in both forms of domination, the domination of some human beings by others. What motivates this triple domination is an irrational fear of the unknown: “Humans believe themselves free from fear when nothing is unknown anymore. This has determined the path of demytologization... Enlightenment is a mythical radicalized fear” (DE 11). In a non-free society whose culture pursues so-called progress regardless of cost, which is “other”, whether human or non-human, it is left aside, exploited or destroyed. The means of destruction may be more sophisticated in the modern West, and exploitation may be less direct than direct slavery, but blind, fear-driven domination continues, with ever-increasing global consequences. The engine that consumes this whole process is a constantly expanding capitalist economy, fueled by scientific research and the latest technologies.
Contrary to some interpretations, Horkheimer and Adorno do not reject the 18th-century Enlightenment. Nor do they provide a negative “metanarrative” of universal historical decline. Rather, through a very unusual combination of philosophical argument, sociological reflection and literary and cultural commentary, they build a “double perspective” on the modern West as a historical formation (Jarvis 1998, 23). He summarizes this double perspective in two interrelated thesis: “The myth is already enlightenment, and enlightenment returns to mythology” (DE xviii). The first thesis allows them to suggest that, despite having been declared mythical and outdated by the forces of secularization, the oldest rituals, religions and philosophies may have contributed to the process of enlightenment and may still have something worth contributing. The second thesis allows them to expose ideological and destructive tendencies within modern secularization forces, but without denying that these forces are progressive and enlightening or that the older conceptions they displaced were themselves ideological and destructive.
A fundamental error in many interpretations of the Dialectics of Enlightenment occurs when readers take such thesis as theoretical definitions of immutable categories rather than critical judgments on historical trends. The authors are not saying that myth is “by nature” a force of enlightenment. Nor do they claim that enlightenment “inevitably” returns to mythology. In fact, what they find really mythical in both myth and enlightenment is the thought that fundamental change is impossible. Such resistance to change characterizes both the ancient myths of destiny and modern devotion to facts.
Consequently, by building a “dialectic of enlightenment” the authors seek simultaneously to carry out a dialectical illumination of enlightenment not unlike the Phenomenology of the Spirit of Hegel. Two Hegelian concepts anchor this project, namely, determined negation and conceptual self-reflection. The “determined denial” (bestimmte Negation) indicates that immanent criticism is the way to uproot the truth from ideology. A dialectical illumination of enlightenment “discovers each image as a script. It teaches us to read from [the image] the admission of falsehood that nullifies its power and surrenders it to the truth” (DE 18). Beyond and through such determined denial, a dialectical illumination of enlightenment also recalls the origin and goal of thought itself. Such a memory is the work of the concept as the self-reflection of thought (der Begriff als Selbstbesinnung des Denkens, DE 32). Conceptual self-reflection reveals that thought arises from the very corporeal needs and desires that are forgotten when thought becomes a mere instrument of human self-preservation. It also reveals that the goal of thought is not to continue the blind domination of nature and human beings, but to aim towards reconciliation. Adorno develops the details of this conception in his subsequent lectures on Kant (KC), Ethics (PMP) and Metaphysics (MCP) and in his books on Husserl (AE), Hegel (H), and Heidegger (JA). His most complete statement occurs in Negative Dialectica, which is discussed later.

One day that began with a new round of dawn raids at the Baur Au Lac Hotel in Zurich ended with 16 football officials being charged with corruption charges in the U.S., including five current or former members of the FIFA executive committee. Among them were the famous former head of the Brazilian federation Ricardo Teixeira and his successor, Marco Polo Del Nero, who recently resigned from the FIFA executive committee.
They were among 16 persons charged with fraud and other crimes by the United States Department of Justice, as it established a series of bribery schemes in a new 240-page indictment that replaced the previous one in May 2015. The number of defendants indicted by the United States is required for 27. with 24 other nameless co-conspirators including former FIFA executive committee members. “The betrayal of trust here exposed is outrageous,” said U.S. Attorney General Loretta Lynch. “The magnitude of the corruption alleged here is completely unacceptable.”
On a day when the FIFA executive committee expected to present new reforms in the midst of an ongoing corruption crisis, the Swiss police led the president of the South American football confederation, Paraguayan Juan Ángel Napout, and Alfredo Hawit, the head of the governing body of North America and Central America and the Caribbean. Hawit only succeeded Jeffrey Webb in May 2015, after Webb was arrested as part of the US operation that launched FIFA into the crisis and precipitated the fall of Sepp Blatter. Webb's predecessor, controversial Jack Warner, was also captured in May.
The Swiss Federal Office of Justice said of the latest arrests: “They are detained pending extradition. According to U.S. arrest requests, they are suspected of accepting bribes of millions of dollars.” Webb and former Colombian executive committee member Luis Bedoya were among those who pleaded guilty in the United States. Lynch said eight people, five of them nameless in the original indictment, had pleaded guilty since May.
Eleven current members and former members of the FIFA executive committee have been indicted in the investigation, which alleges $200 million in bribes, mainly as bribes from television and marketing contracts, but also from FIFA's development programs. The last three chairmen of the regional bodies CONCACAF and Conmebol have been charged.
“The message of this announcement must be clear to every guilty individual who remains in the shadows, hoping to evade our investigation: you will not escape our focus,” Lynch said. Teixeira, the former son-in-law of the former FIFA president, João Havelange, was accused along with Del Nero and his predecessor, José María Marin, who was charged in May.
Fourteen men had been charged in May 2015, when four more guilty pleas were filed. Days later, Blatter won a fifth term as president, but later agreed to resign as the crisis grew. He was then provisionally suspended with UEFA President Michel Platini for a supposed £1.3 million “unfair payment” to the French. Both men face possible life bans when their case is heard by the FIFA ethics committee in December if they are found guilty of the charges.
Among those who were also charged on Thursday were Rafael Salguero, a Guatemalan who left the executive committee in May; former Secretary General of the South American Confederation, Eduardo Deluca; former president of the Peruvian football federation, Manuel Burga; and the president of Bolivia, Carlos Chaves, already imprisoned in his own country.
Lynch said: “The Department of Justice is committed to ending the rampant corruption we have described in the midst of international football leadership, not only because of the magnitude of the plans alleged before and today, or because of the breadth of the operation needed to sustain such corruption, but also because of the affront to the international principles represented by this behavior.”
The acting president of FIFA, Issa Hayatou, refused to comment on the details of the latest arrests. But neither he nor the organization was corrupt. When he first appeared before the media since he took over the role in September 2015, when Blatter was suspended, Hayatou responded similarly to his predecessors by improbably claiming that the current crisis was due to a handful of wandering individuals.
“FIFA is not corrupt. We have individuals who have shown negative behavior. Don’t generalize the situation,” said Hayatou, president of the African Football Confederation for more than 25 years. “There are many people who have been in FIFA for more than 20 or 30 years who have not been accused of anything.”

text:
When it comes to climate change, we have the bad habit of focusing on the first part of history, the part about the problem, and forgetting the second part about the many solutions available. These solutions are accelerating recycling, slowing emissions and providing sustainable alternatives to plastic, air conditioning, smartphones and fast fashion.
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change recently met in Copenhagen to present its latest report on the impact and pace of climate change. Climate change is now measured on all continents and our efforts to reduce emissions must be intensified to prevent it from getting out of control. In addition to outlining risks and challenges, Copenhagen also adopted and focused on solutions.
In the spirit of focusing on what can be done, the Sustainability Award, chaired by Arnold Schwarzenegger, celebrated ten outstanding sustainability solutions deployed in 84 countries. From food to fashion, energy to transport, education to health, the awards showed an alternative to the grim and future scenarios that are often presented to us and make sustainability tangible for innovators, investors, consumers and policy makers in all sectors and regions.
From California, we saw how we can now produce plastics from greenhouse gases that are competitive with normal oil-based plastics in price and quality. From Switzerland, we have learned how we can recycle and reuse old clothes and shoes more effectively in a recycling system currently deployed in more than 60 countries. And from Canada, we learned how smartphones can make bike sharing more convenient.
The ten projects presented each offered unique solutions to sustainability challenges, but it was the Nigerian initiative, Wecyclers, that won Arnold Schwarzenegger, and the rest of the jury, that voted and received the 2014 Sustainability Award.
The Wecyclers allow low-income communities to make money from waste that accumulates on their streets. By deploying a fleet of cargo bikes to collect and recycle unmanaged waste in Lagos, Wecyclers allows families to exchange garbage for consumer goods through an SMS-based point system.
Recycling companies buy Wecyclers classified waste for reprocessing into products – they turn it into mattresses, pillows and garbage bags. Wecyclers is a response to local waste problems, where it is estimated that only 40% of the city's garbage is collected. According to the World Bank, only 46 per cent of municipal solid waste is collected in Africa. To date, more than 5,000 households have been registered and plans are under way to extend the initiative to other cities in Nigeria.
Solutions to combat climate change are often perceived as high-tech innovations focusing on emission reduction, infrastructure development or efficiency. However, to successfully solve the variety of challenges, we also need variety in our solutions. Sustainability is not just a matter of reducing emissions; it is also a matter of using our natural resources smarter and creating healthier lives for ourselves. Initiatives can be low-tech in innovation but high-impact when it comes to creating sustainable change for entire communities.
With a wide range of solutions addressing the equally wide range of challenges, we must focus more on the important part of history that creates enthusiasm and momentum, and stimulates action to bring about the much-needed changes.

Regius attributed his appointment at the University of Utrecht to his familiarity and support for Cartesian philosophy, which was initially acquired by reading Descartes' first book, the Discours de la Méthode... plus the Dioptrique, les Météores et la Géometrie, 1637 (AT, vol. VI). Regius was sympathetic to the natural Cartesian philosophy of his initial reading and began to teach it to students, in private classes, and to dictate notes in order to publish his own summary of natural philosophy based on Cartesian principles. This objective was further encouraged when he read a copy of Descartes' unpublished manuscript, Le Monde (AT, vol. XI), in 1641. Le Monde's natural philosophy rejected scholastic forms and qualities as philosophical entities that contributed nothing to an explanation of natural phenomena. However, there was a significant difference in a university like Utrecht between not relying on scholastic forms and publicly criticizing them. The transition from the first to the second, in the case of Regius, occurred in 1641.
While preparing Physiologia (Regio 1641a), Regius sent advance copies of the draft disputes to Descartes. Since they were presented in Utrecht as examples of Cartesian philosophy, Descartes recommended several changes, both to avoid unnecessary controversies (e.g. on blood circulation) and, more importantly, to avoid accusations of heresy against himself or Regius. He therefore asked Regius to correct the thesis that the human soul is threefold, and to argue instead that “in human beings the soul is one, that is, a rational soul” (AT III, 369–74: Bos 2002, 63–69). During the year 1641, this previous consultation pattern with Descartes continued; Regius accepted many of Descartes' suggestions, and incorporated them into the final versions of the disputes.
In November 1641, however, the professor of Utrecht opened another series of disputes in which he transgressed from medicine to philosophy and, by implication, to theology, and provoked a controversy that continued for more than a decade. The most explicit challenge to established Aristotelian teaching occurred when one of Regius' students, Henricus van Loon, stated in a dispute (8 December 1641) that the human mind and body are two distinct substances that unite in an accidental union [unum per accidents]. This thesis addresses, perhaps by inadvertence, one of the most controversial issues in Christian philosophy and theology, namely. how to understand the unity of human nature, as experienced by each subject, and at the same time defend traditional Christian beliefs in the immortality of the human soul or mind and the resurrection of the body. The immortality of the soul seemed to suppose that the mind or soul was able to exist without the body and, for that reason, that it should be classified as an Aristotelian substance. When Descartes was informed of this dispute (when it was too late to recommend amendments), he replied that there was hardly anything more likely to offend or antagonize theologians than to say that a human being “is an accidental being” (AT III, 460: Bos 2002, 90-91).
Voetius, with the support of his fellow professors of theology, responded to Regius by adding corollaries to his own theological disputes, in December 1641, in which he accused the defenders of the ‘new philosophy’ [that is, Cartesianism] of a series of errors: to teach that a human being is an accidental being, to defend copernicanism, and to support skepticism and irreligion by denying substantial forms. In the course of these responses to Regius, the name Descartes was also mentioned, and it was clear that Reius and Descartes were perceived by Voetius as a joint attempt to undermine the philosophical foundations of Calvinist theology as taught in Utrecht. Initially, Descartes joined the debate simply advising Regius how to respond appropriately to Voetius. Part of that advice was that Regius should have dealt with substantial forms such as Descartes had done in the Météores (AT VI, 239): that he should not have explicitly rejected, but should have simply omitted as redundant genuine explanations.
However, Descartes also provided Regius with philosophical arguments in response to Voetius. He outlined a number of reasons why they were jointly opposed to describing the human mind as a substantial form. To say that humans think because they have a ‘thinking way’ does not explain anything; secondly, those who postulate the existence of substantial forms cannot say more precisely what they are, and therefore appeal to ‘hidden’ realities that they do not understand; and, perhaps most importantly, if the supposed substantial forms of other natural phenomena were redundant by the developments of physics, there would be a danger that the spirituality of the mind or soul would be compromised by similar advances in science. “All arguments used to demonstrate substantial forms can be applied to the shape of a clock, although no one claims to be substantial” (AT III, 505: Bos 2002, 115). Many of Descartes' suggestions were incorporated, as amendments, into the final version of the Regius' response to Voetius, which appeared as Responsio, sive notae in Apppendicem (Regius 1642) on February 16, 1642. This further enraged the situation. The following month, Regius was banned by the University to teach natural philosophy in public or private, and was restricted to teaching in traditional medicine. The Academic Senate, with the approval of the city council, also issued an official condemnation of Cartesian philosophy.

text:
For nearly 100 years, police and intelligence agencies around the world have relied on lie detectors to help convict criminals or dig up spies and traitors.
The polygraph is very much loved by the films, with countless dramatic moments that show the culprits sweating profusely while they are connected.
But the invention could disappear soon. Researchers in Britain and the Netherlands have made a breakthrough, developing a method with a test success rate of more than 70% that could be in use in police stations around the world in a decade. Instead of relying on facial tics, talking too much or waving your arms – all seen as lying signs – the new method consists of monitoring the movements of the whole body to provide an indicator of signs of guilty feelings.
Polygraph is widely used in the U.S. in criminal and other cases and for security clearance for the FBI and the CIA, but it is much less popular in Europe. There has been a lot of scepticism in the scientific and legal communities about their reliability. On the contrary, the new method developed by researchers has worked well in experiments.
The basic premise is that liars become more concerned and therefore the wearing of an all-body motion suit – the type used in movies to create computer-generated characters – will collect this. The costume contains 17 sensors that record movement up to 120 times per second in three dimensions for 23 joints.
One of the researchers, Ross Anderson, a professor of security engineering at Cambridge University, said: “Deads of deception research show that the interviewer will tell the truth of lies only slightly better than random, about 55 out of 100.
“Polygraph has existed since the 1920s and, by measuring physiological stress induced by anxiety, you can reach 60. However, it can easily be abused as interrogation support and many people are anxious anyway against a polygraph on which their work or freedom depends.”
He said that the new method, on the contrary, achieved a reliability rating of more than 70% and was sure they would be able to do better. In some tests, the team has already achieved more than 80%. Anderson said, “The message to take is that the guilty people are shaking more and we can measure this firmly.”
Anderson added that the investigation had a special significance at the moment, in the context of the U.S. Senate report on CIA torture. Apart from the moral case against torture, Anderson pointed out that it was a very unreliable way of gathering accurate information. “We’ve known for a long time that torture doesn’t work,” he said. The new method offers a pragmatic and scientifically supported alternative to conducting interviews. The research work was written by Dr. Sophie van der Zee of Cambridge University, Professor Ronald Poppe of Utrecht University, Professor Paul Taylor of Lancaster University and Anderson.
The polygraph was created in 1921 by police officer John Larson, based on the investigation of psychologist William Marston. It records changes in pulse, blood pressure, sweating, and breathing to determine if a subject is lying.
Although film representations suggest that the device is almost infallible, the United States Supreme Court ruled, in 1998, that there was no consensus that the polygraph was reliable, a finding supported by the United States National Academy of Scientists in 2003. The experiment carried out by Anderson and his colleagues involved 180 students and employees of Lancaster University, half of whom were told to tell the truth and half of whom lied. They were paid £7.50 for their participation in the 70-minute experiment, which included two tests.
Some were interviewed about a Never End computer game, which they played for seven minutes, while others lied about playing it, with only notes shown about it.
The second test included a lost portfolio containing £5. Some were asked to take the wallet to a lost box, while others hid it and lied about it.
“In general, we correctly classify 82.2% (truths: 88.9%; lies: 75.6%) of those interviewed as truthful or misleading based on the combined movement in their individual members,” the report says. Anderson said: “Our first attempt examined to what extent different parts of the body and signs of the body indicated deception. It turned out that liars shake their arms more, but, again, this is only at the 60% level that can be obtained from a conventional polygraph.
“The dirt of pay was when we considered the total movement of the body. That turns out to tell the truth of lies more than 70% of the time and we believe that it can be further improved if combined with optimal questioning techniques.”
Another advantage is that total body movement is not affected by cultural background, anxiety, and cognitive burden (how much you're thinking), which confuses other lie detection technologies, Anderson said.
The use of all-body suits is expensive – they cost around £30,000 – and can be uncomfortable, and Anderson and his colleagues are now looking for low-cost alternatives. These include the use of computer game motion detection technology, such as the Kinect devices developed by Microsoft for the Xbox console.
Anderson recognizes that agencies like the CIA could teach agents how to counter the whole body movement method by freezing their bodies, but said it would itself be a gift.
label: C2

The United Nations Security Council adopted a resolution on Monday to send 4,200 peacekeepers to Abyei, Sudan, as part of a recent agreement between the Sudan and Southern Sudan.
The resolution will establish, for six months, the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (LRB), UNISFA (RRB), consisting of up to 4,200 military personnel, 50 police officers and appropriate civilian support, as set out in the resolution.
He passed the council unanimously, 15-0.
In a statement issued by the State Department, Secretary Hilario Clinton commended the speedy adoption of the resolution.
Abyei has been a source of regional tension for many years, the statement said. We urge the parties to reach an immediate ceasefire and to provide humanitarian workers with the necessary unhindered access to provide humanitarian assistance to innocent civilians affected by the conflict.
A week ago, the Government of the Sudan and the Sudan People ' s Liberation Movement signed an agreement to allow Abyei peacekeepers to end the conflicts that have ravaged much of the country. The two parties agreed in principle on the need for a third party to monitor the ill-defined border between the north and the south before the independence scheduled for the south on 9 July.
United Nations peacekeepers will monitor and verify the redeployment of all Sudanese Armed Forces, the Sudan People ' s Liberation Army or its successor to the Abyei Area, among other tasks, notes the Security Council resolution.

text:
It is difficult to know exactly where the noise comes from, but it is impossible to miss it from anywhere in Damascus: all day long and night you can hear the clumsy blow of artillery, rockets or planes hitting rebel positions – the sound of the war approaching the capital of Syria. But little more than two years after the Syrian crisis – the longest and bloodiest of Arab revolts – ignoring the sound of death and destruction nearby has become the new normal for Damascenes.
During the weekend, men could be seen blowing in the water pipes in a palm shaded park, children playing between the flower beds and couples chatting on the benches as the unmistakable thunder of high explosive could be heard a few kilometers away – the smoke rises among the minarets of a nearby Ottoman-era mosque. No one seemed to notice.
“You actually get used to it after a while,” said George, an IT technician from a coastal town. “But you never know exactly what they’re hitting.” That usually becomes evident after video clips posted by opposition media on YouTube.
The sinister background noise is doubly disturbing because the government strives both to preserve an air of leisure as usual. “As you can see, everything here is fine, but we have to attack the terrorists, these extremists,” an army officer announced. One official, whose return route has been attacked by rebels in Daraya, said: “If I were afraid, I would just close the door and stay inside. I have to work and I'm not afraid. If I don't defend my country, who will?
Common citizens, in private conversation, are less challenging. In the center of the city, a shopkeeper sadly complained that his little girl was crying over the sound of the bombings. Zeina, a 20 - year - old student, fears that suffering will become desensitized, and perhaps also dangerous. “At first, when there were explosions, I used to have nightmares,” he reflected. Now I can sleep with anything.
And, the risks multiply even closer to home. In Sabaa Bahrat Square, in what was supposed to be the safest part of Damascus, detonated a car bomb, leaving a blackened concrete facade, broken windows and shattered metal, as well as damage to the imposing structure of the Syrian Central Bank next door. The mourning notices for two of the 15 victims – Muhammad al-Sufi and Manal al-Tahan – are attached to the opposite wall. Militians machine guns and machine gun shrapnel grind around the square, often used for televised pro-regime rallies with public officials on mass bus to chant slogans under the giant flags of President Bashar al-Assad.
That bombing was not the worst Damascus has ever experienced, as the situation has deteriorated. In February, 80 people, including schoolchildren, reportedly died near the Baath party headquarters in Mazraa. The crater remains visible, marked by a huge piece of fresh asphalt on the main road heading north. “I live nearby, but fortunately I wasn’t there,” Munir, a university professor, recalled.
The mortar bombs, fired from rebel-controlled areas now inside the easy-to-reach area of the city, have become a sinister novelty. The bombs killed 15 students in a university cafeteria on March 28. The intended target was believed to be a government building.
Security measures have intensified since the devastating bombing of the national security crisis cell in July 2012, when four of Assad's most important assistants were killed. The explosive concrete barriers, often painted in black, red and white from the Syrian flag, now protect official premises, not just military or defence installations that are obvious targets. The Iranian embassy in Mezze, its turquoise mosaic forehead that takes an exotic look at Isfahan or Shiraz, looks like a fortress. “The regime managed to mount a steel ring around Damascus,” said a foreign diplomat. “But for whatever reason the perimeter is beginning to be pierced and that brings home the reality of the war.”
All this means that moving has become difficult, unpredictable and time-consuming – another aspect of the new normality in an understandably nervous city. Control points in the funnel traffic of main roads for identification controls and luggage search with portable explosive detectors – vital to stop future bombers. Only drivers with an official safety clearance can use special fast lanes to avoid waiting.
It is difficult, however, to avoid the question in everyone’s mind: will there be a battle for Damascus – the world’s continually inhabited city, as the guides say – as it has damaged Aleppo so much? Some parts of the city already feel like a war zone: their most ritzier hotel is strangely deserted, although many rooms are being used as offices by international agencies drawn by the deep crisis – blue helmets and bullet-proof jackets piled on Persian carpets in a decorated reception room, white UN vehicles parked behind the blast barriers on the outside. The streets are empty shortly after 21:00.
One view is that the fight for the capital of Syria is coming, but not yet – in the summer perhaps, some predict, when the rebels have consolidated their profits in the south. Others argue that it is unlikely that either side will win an absolute victory and expect a political solution imposed from abroad. But few here seem to expect things to get better.

text:
As “rationalism” and “empiricism”, “existenceism” is a term that belongs to intellectual history. Therefore, its definition is to some extent of historical convenience. The term was explicitly adopted as a self-description by Jean-Paul Sartre, and through the wide dissemination of the post-war literary and philosophical production of Sartre and his associates, in particular Simone de Beauvoir, Maurice Merleau-Ponty and Albert Camus, existentialism was identified with a cultural movement that flourished in Europe in the 1940s and 1950s. Among the main philosophers identified as existentialists (many of whom – for example Camus and Heidegger – repudiated the label) were Karl Jaspers, Martin Heidegger and Martin Buber in Germany, Jean Wahl and Gabriel Marcel in France, the Spanish José Ortega y Gasset and Miguel de Unamuno, and the Russians Nikolai Berdyaev and Lev Shestov. 19th-century philosophers, Søren Kierkegaard and Friedrich Nietzsche, became seen as pioneers of the movement. Existentialism was both a literary and philosophical phenomenon. Sartre's own ideas were and are better known through his fictional works (such as Nausea and No Exit) than through his most purely philosophical (such as Being and Nothing and Critique of Dialectic Reason), and the post-war years found a very diverse collection of writers and artists linked under the term: retrospectively, Dostoevsky, Ibsen and Kafka were recruited; in Paris there were Jean Genet, André Gide, André Malraux, and expatriate Samuel Beckett; the Norwegian Knut Hamsun and Romanian Eugene Ionesco belong to the club; artists such as Alberto Giacometti and even abstract expressionists such as Jackson Pollock, Arshile Gorky, and Willem de Kooning, and filmmakers such as Jean-Luc Godard and Ingmar Bergman were understood in existential terms. By the mid-1970s the cultural image of existentialism had become a cliché, parodized in countless Woody Allen books and films. [1]
Therefore, it is sometimes suggested that existentialism is simply this past cultural movement rather than an identifiable philosophical position; or, alternatively, that the term should be restricted to Sartre's philosophy only. [2] Two recent books, both sustained attempts to engage critically and constructively with existentialism in the context of contemporary philosophical debates, adopt versions of these positions. Jonathan Webber argues that “as originally defined by Simone de Beauvoir and Jean-Paul Sartre, existentialism is the ethical theory that we must treat freedom at the centre of human existence as intrinsically valuable and the foundation of all other values” (2018: 2). If we stick to this definition, we can both recognize the fissures within what is called “existentialism” in the expansive sense and also see how existentialism can “found sophisticated contributions to social psychology, the philosophy of the mind, moral philosophy, cultural theory and psychotherapy” (2018: 19). Taking the other stance, Noreen Khawaja points to the perennial difficulty of specifying precisely who is supposed to belong to the “movement” of existentialism, since the term itself was unknown to some who are recruited or rejected by others. But, he argues, this is a problem only if existentialism is considered a movement. Although aspects of such a movement can be found in the historical record, existentialism itself “is a tradition, not a movement,” that is, “a pattern of intergenerational influence, in which later figures read and appropriated the work of earlier figures” (Khawaja 2016: 4). What encourages this tradition — exemplified here by Kierkegaard, Heidegger and Sartre — is its struggle against religion and the fact that the writing of even the so-called existentialists “atheistics” “feels religious to their readers” (2016: 16). Interestingly, either of the two positions leads to the same place: For Khawaja, “the idea of personal authenticity is at the center of existential thought” (2016: 24), while for Webber, the existentialism of Sartre, Beauvoir and Franz Fanon begins with “the eudaimonist arguments for the virtue of authenticity” and finally affirms “a categorical moral imperative of authenticity” (2018: 19).
In this entry, I will use elements of both approaches. Like Khawaja, I consider existentialism to be a usefully broad term in intellectual history that can illuminate the work of philosophers and others who preceded the emergence of “movement” or rejected the label. In this sense, “existentialism” chooses a distinct group of philosophical problems and a relatively different current of philosophical research from the 20th century and now from the 21st century, one that has had a significant impact on fields such as theology (through Rudolf Bultmann, Paul Tillich, Karl Barth and others) and psychology (from Ludwig Binswanger and Medard Boss to Otto Rank, R. D. Laing and Viktor Frankl). On the other hand, I do not believe that the “tradition” of existential thought should be addressed exclusively in terms of the (very real) struggle with religion that gives some of the works of existential philosophy a religious “feel” (see Westphal 2012). I agree with Webber that there is a core of philosophical content (category) to existential thinking that can be understood regardless of the type of religious “retoration” (Khawaja 2016: 16) characteristic of many of the classics of existentialism. Unlike Webber, however, I believe that this categorical content is widely shared—beyond Sartre, Beauvoir and Fanon—and should be understood as based on the phenomenological approach that Sartre is so excited about (see Crowell 2012b). The phenomenological approach gave philosophical form to the basic existential insight that thought about human existence requires new categories not found in the conceptual repertoire of ancient or modern thought; human beings cannot be understood either as substances with fixed properties, or as subjects interacting with a world of objects.
From an existential point of view, to understand what a human being is, it is not enough to know all the truths that natural science, including the science of psychology, could tell us. The dualist who holds that humans are composed of independent substances — “mind” and “body” — is no better in this regard than the physicist who holds that human existence can be adequately explained in terms of the fundamental physical constituents of the universe. Existentialism does not deny the validity of the basic categories of physics, biology, psychology and other sciences (categories such as matter, causality, force, function, organism, development, motivation, etc.). He only states that human beings cannot be fully understood in terms of them. Nor can such understanding be obtained by complementing our scientific picture with a moral one. Categories of moral theory such as intention, guilt, responsibility, character, duty, virtue, etc. They capture important aspects of the human condition, but neither moral thought (ruled by the norms of good and law) nor scientific thought (ruled by the norm of truth) are sufficient.
Therefore, "existentialism" can be defined as the philosophical theory that holds that a new set of categories, governed by the norm of authenticity, is necessary to understand human existence. Addressing existentialism in this categorical way may seem to conceal what is often considered its “heart” (Kaufmann 1968: 12), namely its character as a gesture of protest against academic philosophy, its anti-system sensitivity, its flight from the “iron cage” of reason. But while it is true that the great existential philosophers wrote with passion and urgency something infrequent in our time, and while the idea that philosophy cannot be practiced in the selfless manner of an objective science is in fact central to existentialism, it is equally true that all topics popularly associated with existentialism — reading, boredom, alienation, absurdity, freedom, compromise, nothingness, etc. — find their philosophical meaning in the context of the search for a new categorical framework, along with their rule of government.

text:
The world war on drugs has failed, a high-level commission composed of former presidents, public intellectuals and other leaders studying drug policies concluded in a report published on Thursday.
International efforts to suppress drug producers and users and seek to reduce demand have had devastating consequences for people and societies around the world, the report of the World Commission on Drug Policy said.
The commission, which includes former United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan, the founder of the Virgin Richard Branson Group and Nobel Laureate Mario Vargas Llosa, challenges conventional wisdom on drug markets and drug use.
Among the recommendations of the group:
- Ending the criminalization and stigmatization of people who use drugs but do not harm others
-- Encourage Governments to experiment with the legalization of drugs, especially marijuana
-- Provide more harm reduction measures, such as access to syringes
- Ditch has just said no and zero tolerance policies for young people in favour of other educational efforts.
The theory that increasing police action would lead to an increasingly reduced drug market has not worked, says the report. On the contrary, the illegal drug markets and organized criminal organizations that traffic them have grown, the group found.
The report comes as countries like Mexico suffer from widespread drug-related violence. More than 40,000 people have been killed in Mexico in the past four years as rival cartels fight each other for lucrative smugglers and as the army fights against cartels.
The Commission's conclusions add more high-profile voices to a growing movement calling for a radical approach to drugs. Other leaders, such as former Mexican President Vicente Fox, have called for the legalization of drugs as part of a solution to their country's problems.

Clashes near Mali's northern city of Kidal between government forces and armed rebel groups Tuareg have left eight Malian soldiers dead and 25 others injured, the country's Ministry of Defence, the state newspaper L'Essor National, reported on Sunday.
There were also 28 dead and 62 wounded on the Tuareg side, the ministry said, according to L'Essor National.
The government issued a statement on Saturday saying that Tuareg rebels from the Azawad National Liberation Movement, along with jihadists, attacked government buildings.
The Azawad National Liberation Movement -- known as the MNLA, the initials of its name in French -- is fighting for independence from the northern part of Mali, a region referred to as Azawad.
The MNLA issued a statement on violence, describing it as self-defense and resistance.
The group claimed to have taken 30 prisoners, including 24 soldiers and three regional government officials. Two wounded Malian soldiers were handed over to the International Committee of the Red Cross, MNLA added.
The United Nations Mission in Mali condemned the clashes and stated that they violated the preliminary agreements aimed at achieving peace and security in the northern regions, including in Kidal.
French soldier killed in the fight against militants in Mali

SeaWorld has suffered an 84% collapse in profits as customers have abandoned the controversial water theme park company after claiming that they mistreated whales orca.
The company, which trains dolphins and killer whales to perform tricks in front of stadiums full of spectators, has reported decreases in attendance, sales and profits due to “continuous brand challenges”.
SeaWorld has been on the headlines since the 2013 Blackfish documentary detailing claims that its treatment of whales caused violent behavior, contributing to the deaths of three people. After the documentary was published, attendance collapsed, the company lost more than half of its market value on Wall Street and its former CEO was expelled.
Since then, the company has launched a national marketing campaign to combat animal rights activists claims that, among other things, captive whales die at a younger age than their wild counterparts.
Despite cutting ticket prices and spending $10 million on marketing bombing, which has its whale-care veterinarians, SeaWorld CEO Joel Manby was forced to admit that the company is still struggling to convince the public that it treats its whales well.
“We realize that we have a lot of work ahead of us to recover more from our support base, increase revenue and improve our performance, as going back to historical performance levels will take time and investment,” Manby said. “On the reputation side, early feedback on our campaign has been positive. However, we recognize that the complete resolution of our brand challenges in California will require a sustained approach and commitment to correct misinformation.”
“We will continue to fight the facts because the facts are on our side,” he said recently in a telephone conference with journalists and analysts.
Manby, who joined the company as CEO in 2015 to help the company rehabilitate, said he will present his vision for the company's future at a special event on November 6. Plans for a new shark exhibition in Orlando and an attraction in San Antonio are already underway that will allow customers to swim with dolphins in a “naturalistic” environment.
The company's financial report, published on August 6, showed that net revenue in the second quarter fell from $37.4 million in 2014 to $5.8 million in 2015, a decrease of 84%. Income decreased from $405 million to $392 million. Assistance decreased by more than 100,000 people, from 6.58 million to 6.48 million. Analysts will now be watching SeaWorld's sales and attendance numbers closely in the third quarter, which is traditionally the company's most profitable and covers the summer holiday season.
The assistance may suffer a new scandal in July 2015, in which a SeaWorld employee would have infiltrated animal rights protest groups against the company. Jared Goodman, Animal Law Director at People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA), who has been running campaigns against SeaWorld, said: “SeaWorld is in the middle of a spying scandal, animals are dying in its tanks and tens of thousands of people have opposed its attempt to build a new orca prison, so it should not be surprising that SeaWorld’s quarterly revenue has plummeted once again in the second quarter. Families simply don’t want to buy tickets to watch the orcas go crazy inside small tanks and SeaWorld profits, like the orcas, won’t recover until the abuse park emptys its tanks and builds coastal sanctuaries.”
The shares of SeaWorld, which were worth $39 in 2013, were changing hands for just under $18 in August 2015.

text:
The idea that science is a collective enterprise of researchers in successive generations is characteristic of the Modern Age (Nisbet 1980). The classical empiricists (Francis Bacon) and the 17th-century rationalists (René Descartes) urged that the use of appropriate research methods ensure the discovery and justification of new truths. This cumulative view of scientific progress was an important ingredient in the optimism of the 18th-century Enlightenment, and was incorporated in Auguste Comte's positivism program in the 1830s: by accumulating empirically certified truths science also promotes progress in society. Other influential trends in the 19th century included the romantic view of organic growth in culture, Hegel's dynamic account of historical change and the theory of evolution. They all inspired epistemological views (for example, between Marxists and pragmatists) that viewed human knowledge as a process. Philosophers with an interest in the history of science (William Whewell, Charles Peirce, Ernst Mach, Pierre Duhem) gave interesting analyses of some aspects of scientific change.
At the beginning of the 20th century, the analytical philosophers of science began to apply modern logic to the study of science. His main focus was the structure of scientific theories and patterns of inference (Suppe 1977). This “synchronous” research of the “finished products” of scientific activities was questioned by philosophers who wanted to pay serious attention to the “diachronic” study of scientific change. These contributions include N.R. Hanson’s Patterns of Discovery (1958), Karl Popper’s The Logic of Scientific Discovery (1959) and Conjects and Resurrections (1963), Thomas Kuhn’s The Structure of Scientific Revolutions (1962), Paul Feyerabend’s incommensurable thesis (Feyerabend 1962), Imre Lakatos’s methodology of scientific research programmes (Lakatos and Musgrave 1970) and Larry Laudan’s Progress and Is Problems (1977). Darwinist models of evolutionary epistemology were defended by Popper's objective knowledge: an evolutionary approach (1972) and Stephen Toulmin's human understanding (1972). These works challenged the vision received on the development of scientific knowledge and rationality. Popper's falsificationism, Kuhn's account of scientific revolutions, and Feyerabend's thesis of meaning variance shared the view that science does not grow simply by accumulating new established truths about old ones. Except perhaps during the periods of Kuhn's normal science, theoretical change is not cumulative or continuous: the earlier results of science will be rejected, replaced and reinterpreted by new theories and conceptual frameworks. Popper and Kuhn differed, however, in their definitions of progress: the former appealed to the idea that successive theories may approach the truth, while the latter characterized progress in terms of the problem-solving capacity of theories.
Since the mid-1970s, numerous philosophical works have been published on the themes of change, development and progress of science (Harré 1975; Stegmüller 1976; Howson 1976; Rescher 1978; Radnitzky and Andersson 1978, 1979; Niiniluto and Tuomela 1979; Dilworth 1981; Smith 1981; Hacking 1981; Schäfer 1983; Niiniluoto 1984; Laudan 1984a; Rescher 1984; Pitt 1985; Radnitzky and Bartley 1987; Callebaut and Pinxten 1987; Balzer et al. 1987; Hull 1988; Gavroglu et al. 1989; Kitcher 1993; Pera 1994; Chang 2004; Maxwell 2017). These studies have also led to many important developments that are added to the toolbox of the philosophers of science. One of them is the systematic study of intertheoretical relationships, such as reduction (Balzer et al. 1984; Pearce 1987; Balzer 2000; Jonkisz 2000; Hoyningen-Huene and Sankey 2001), correspondence (Krajewski 1977; Nowak 1980; Pearce and Rantala 1984; Nowakowa and Nowak 2000; Rantala 2002), and review of beliefs (Gärdenfors, 1988; Aliseda, 2006). Another was the recognition that, in addition to individual statements and theories, it is also necessary to consider the temporary development of units of activity and scientific achievements: normal science led by Kuhn paradigms, Lakatos' research program, Laudan's research tradition, the dynamic evolution of Wolfgang Stegmüller's theory (1976), Philip Kitcher's consensus practice (1993). A new tool used in many realistic points of view defenses of scientific progress (Niniluoto 1980, 2014; Aronson, Harré and Way 1994; Kuipers 2000, 2019) is the notion of likelihood or likelihood (Popper 1963, 1970).
The keen interest in the development of science promoted close cooperation between historians and philosophers of science. For example, case studies of historical examples (e.g., the substitution of Newton's classical mechanics by quantum theory and the theory of relativity) have inspired many philosophical treatments of scientific revolutions. Historical case studies were important for philosophers who began studying scientific discovery (Hanson 1958; Nickles 1980). Historically oriented philosophers have shown how instruments and measurements have promoted the progress of physics and chemistry (Chang 2004). Experimental psychologists have argued that the search for broad and simple explanations shapes learning and inference (Lombrozo 2016). Another interesting material for philosophical discussions on scientific progress is provided by quantitative approaches in the study of the growth of scientific publications (from Solla Price 1963; Rescher 1978) and scientific indicators (Elkana et al. 1978). Sociologists of science have studied the dynamic interaction between the scientific community and other social institutions. With their influence, philosophers have analyzed the role of social and cultural values in the development of science (Longino 2002). One of the favorite themes of sociologists has been the emergence of new scientific specialties (Mulkay 1975; Niiniluoto 1995b). Sociologists are also concerned about the pragmatic problem of progress: how best to organize research activities to promote scientific progress. In this way, models of scientific change are relevant to scientific policy issues (Böhme 1977; Schäfer 1983).

text:
Chinese regulators have hit the online discount retailer Vipshop Holdings Ltd with a fine of 3 million yuan ($464,000), the largest to date in a recent crackdown on anticompetitive behaviour among Internet companies.
In a sign that regulators are increasingly willing to use more tools in a new zeal to curb monopolistic behavior in the technology sector, Vipshop was punished for violations of a law prohibiting unfair competition, which allows fines of up to 5 million yuan.
By comparison, other companies that have been fined since the end of last year were fined under China's antitrust law of 2008, which allows for a maximum fine of much less than 500,000 yuan.
The Vipshop fine comes immediately after the State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) issued updated guidelines on how the antitrust law affects Internet companies, who said regulators were willing to avoid pricing, as well as the use of data and algorithms to manipulate the market.
SAMR said on Monday that from August to December last year, Vipshop had developed a system for obtaining brand information that gave Vipshop a competitive advantage. He added that Vipshop used its system to influence users' options, transaction opportunities and to block sales of certain brands.
Vipshop, which has a market value of about $22 billion, said Monday that it accepted the findings of SAMR and would strengthen compliance.
The increased scrutiny by Chinese regulators since December has included the announcement of an investigation into the Alibaba e-commerce giant, penalizing Alibaba-backed and Tencent-backed companies for not seeking antitrust reviews for the agreements, while other companies have also been fined for irregular prices.

text:
Federal officials said that more needs to be done on Thursday to warn rescuers of special hazards at the scene of small plane crashes.
While firefighters are well aware of the dangers of burning fuel and sharp debris, they may not know that some aviation systems -- systems that are considered air safety devices -- become particularly dangerous on the ground. Among the hazards: ejection seat rockets, airbag components and explosive charges that deploy parachutes that can lower the entire aircraft to the ground.
These explosive components, if they remain loaded and are unknown to the first responders and investigators, pose a high level of risk to those working inside and around the remains of the aircraft, said the National Transportation Safety Board.
The safety board cited five incidents since 2001 in which the first responders and accident investigators who responded to aircraft wrecks were clearly unaware of the danger of explosive components.
In some cases, they began to carry out rescue, firefighting and accident investigation activities that could have inadvertently activated the explosive component, posing a high risk of injury, the safety board said. None resulted in the death or injury of the responders.
In one incident, the fatal accident of January 2012 of an experimental plane near Rainbow City, Alabama, a police officer realized the hidden dangers only after a NTSB investigator told him on the phone not to allow the pilot's remains to be recovered until the pilot's expulsion seat could be deactivated. In another incident, firefighters attempting to set fire to a Cirrus SR22 accident took additional safety precautions after the aircraft was told that it had a BRS, a solid fuel rocket used to deploy the aircraft's parachute.
NTSB recommends that the Federal Aviation Administration take additional measures to address the issue of safety. The FAA should require aircraft owners to disclose the presence of explosive safety devices when they register their aircraft every three years. Online registration is easily available for the first responders, said the NTSB.
The FAA should also issue a safety bulletin to the first responders, the board recommended.
FAA said it will review the recommendations. We have collaborated with ballistic device manufacturers, aircraft manufacturers, firefighting organizations and other first aid groups to develop training on potential hazards in an accident scene and to ensure that warning marks comply with the necessary guidelines, FAA said in a statement.

text:
Coal is likely to rival oil as the world’s largest energy source in the next five years, with potentially disastrous climate consequences, according to the world’s leading energy economy authority.
One of the major factors behind the increase in coal use has been the massive increase in shale gas use in the United States.
Further research by the International Energy Agency (IEA) shows that coal consumption is increasing worldwide, even in countries and regions with carbon reduction targets, except in the United States, where shale gas has displaced coal. The decline in coal consumption in the US has helped to reduce coal prices globally. This has made it more attractive, even in Europe, where the use of coal was supposed to be discouraged by the emissions trading scheme.
Maria van der Hoeven, Executive Director of the IEA, said: “The share of coal in the global energy mix continues to grow every year and, if no change is made in current policies, coal will capture oil in a decade.”
Coal is abundant and found in most regions of the world, unlike conventional oil and gas, and can be extracted cheaply. As a result, coal was used to meet almost half of the increase in global energy demand over the past decade. According to the IEA, demand from China and India will boost coal use in the world over the next five years, and India will likely outperform the United States as the world's second-largest consumer. China is the largest importer of coal, and Indonesia is the largest exporter, temporarily surpassing Australia.
According to the IEA’s Medium-Term Coal Market Report, the world will burn 1.2 billion tons more of coal per year by 2017 compared to today, the equivalent of current combined coal consumption in Russia and the United States. Global coal consumption is expected to reach 4.3 billion tonnes of oil equivalent in 2017, while oil consumption is expected to reach 4.4 billion tonnes on the same date.
With the highest carbon emissions from any major fossil fuel, coal contributes enormously to climate change, especially when burned in outdated and inefficient power plants. When these are not equipped with special scrabbing equipment to eliminate chemicals, coal can also produce sulphur emissions – the main cause of acid rain – and other pollutants such as mercury and soot particles.
Van der Hoeven said that, without high carbon prices to discourage growth in coal use and promote cleaner technologies such as renewable energy generation, only competition from lower-priced gas could realistically reduce coal demand. This has happened in the United States, due to the extraordinary increase in shale gas production in that market over the past five years.
He said: “The experience of the United States suggests that a more efficient gas market, characterized by flexible prices and fueled by unconventional indigenous resources that are produced in a sustainable manner, can reduce coal use, carbon dioxide emissions and consumers’ electricity bills. Europe, China and other regions should take note.”
That would mean producing much more shale gas, as conventional gas resources are being depleted in their easy-to-access locations.
In Europe, the emissions trading scheme was supposed to discourage high-carbon energy generation by imposing a price on carbon dioxide emissions. This was done through the issuance of generators and energy-intensive companies with an established quota of emission permits, which required them to purchase additional permits if they needed to issue more than their allocation. But an over-allocation, coupled with the effects of the financial crisis and recession, has led to a large surplus of permits on the market, which in turn has led to a fall in permit prices. At current levels, a few euros per tonne of carbon, there is little incentive to look for lower carbon fuels, and coal is enjoying a renaissance in Europe.
This means that one of the only global market regulatory mechanisms aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions is failing in its key objectives. The world faces the likelihood of a higher risk of climate change as a result of this uncontrolled consumption of higher carbon fossil fuel.
