The very concept of a “non-existent object” has an air of paradox in this regard, at least for those philosophers whose thinking is rooted in the Humean tradition. For Hume suggested that thinking of an object is always and necessarily thinking of an existing object, or to put it differently, that thinking of an object and thinking of the same object that exists are just one and the same thing. Immanuel Kant resumed Hume's idea and affirmed that existence is not a "real preaching," an affirmation that is often interpreted as an anticipation of Gottlob Frege's famous doctrine that existence is not a preaching of individuals. (See Hume 2000, Book 1, Part 2, Sec. 6; Kant 2003, B 627; Frege 1966, pp. 37f.) Kant’s motivation to reject the view that existence is a “real preaching” was the so-called “ontological proof” of God’s existence, which says, more or less, that God’s perfection implies the existence of God, for a being who would have all the perfections of God except existence (i.e. omniscience, omnipotence, benevolence) would be less perfect than a being with the same perfections plus existence. For centuries, philosophers have felt that there is something wrong with this test, but Kant was the first to point out a possible error: he argued that the error of the “ontological argument” lies in the treatment of existence as “a real predicate.”
If Hume is right, then the concept of an object includes the concept of existence, and the concept of a non-existent object would be as contradictory as the concept of a round square. If existence is not a predicate of individuals, then one might assume that it is not non-existence either. Therefore, if Frege is right, to say of an object that is non-existent is a kind of nonsense that arises from a violation of logical grammar. (For Frege and those who follow him, an affirmation like "God exists/does not exist" must be understood as an affirmation about the concept of God, or about the property of being God. In this view, the logical form of "God exists" does not exist (God)—where he exists is a predicate of individuals, but rather: The concept of God applies to something, or something possesses the property of being God.)
Thus, to take seriously the idea of non-existent objects, one must renounce the views of important philosophers on the nature of existence and adopt the view that existence is some kind of preaching of individuals. This view implies, among other things, that saying, for example, that there are some white elephants is to say that some white elephants have the property of existence (or, to put it another way, that not all white elephants are non-existent)—a consequence that could affect some as strange.
Moreover, in order to affirm that “there are non-existent objects” without implying that “there are non-existent objects”, it must be assumed that sentences in the form “There are Fs” mean something different from sentences in the form “There are Fs”. [1] Some philosophers reject a distinction between "there is" and "there is" (see, for example, Lewis 1990, Priest 2005, Quine 1953), some philosophers (for example, Meinong 1960, Parsons 1980, Zalta 1988) think that there are good reasons to make this distinction. Some of the latter think that the distinction between “there is” and “there is” is rooted in ordinary language, but others firmly deny it (see, for example, Geach 1971). Obviously, although there might be a tendency among competent English speakers to use “there is” and “there is” in different contexts, the use of ordinary language is too hesitant and not uniform in this sense to be a stable ground for philosophical theory. Of course, this does not exclude that there are theoretical reasons to distinguish between “exist” and “exist”, some of which are discussed below.
label: C2

text:
Planned Parenthood in New York City shattered the city's new teenage pregnancy prevention campaign on Thursday, saying it doesn't deter teenage pregnancy and that it inappropriately shames and stigmatizes its target audience.
The campaign creates stigma, hostility and negative public opinions about teenage pregnancy and parenthood rather than offering alternative aspirations for young people, said Haydee Morales, vice president of education and training of the organization. The city's money would be better spent on helping adolescents access health care, birth control and high-quality sexual and reproductive health education, not on an advertising campaign aimed at creating shock value.
The New York City Human Resources Administration/Department of Social Services announced the $400,000 initiative, which includes photos of babies delivering messages to their hypothetical parents as honestly, Mom... it's likely that she won't stay with you. What's wrong with me? The small print adds that 90% of teenage parents do not marry.
Dad, you'll pay to keep me for the next 20 years, says another one of the ads, which adds in smaller print than New York State law requires a parent to pay maintenance until a child turns 21.
You got a good job? It costs thousands of dollars each year, says another, adding that teenage parents should expect to spend more than $10,000 a year to raise their child.
Teenagers who give birth before they are ready to provide emotional and financial support are not a good way to raise children, said Administration Commissioner Robert Doar. We cannot dictate how people live their lives, and sometimes even the best plans don't work, but we must foster responsibility and send the right message, especially to young people.
Planned Parenthood, a advocacy group and provider of reproductive health and education services, said Wednesday in a statement that advertisements spread stereotypes and do not address social problems leading to teenage pregnancies.
A city spokesperson defended the ads, calling them only part of a larger initiative that will include an interactive campaign of text messages and social networks and a public service video ad on YouTube.
This campaign is part of the city's comprehensive adolescent pregnancy prevention program, which includes sex education, increased access to birth control, and partnerships with community organizations, said Samantha Levine, deputy press secretary to Mayor Michael Bloomberg.
The city has a school education program in which teenage mothers and fathers discuss with their peers the challenges of raising a child. A State family planning benefit programme covers reproductive and sexual health care, including contraceptives, for adolescents and low-income adults.
And a city-wide relationship abuse prevention program exposes the consequences of teenage pregnancy and how to avoid peer pressure and coercion.
Since 2011, the city has ordered comprehensive sex education in public schools.
The pregnancy rate of women in the city has decreased by 27% in the last decade, but it remains higher than the national average, according to the mayor's office, which launched the campaign on Monday.
Daughters of teenage fathers are more likely to become teenage mothers, while children are more likely to go to jail, he said in a statement. On the other hand, parents who finish high school, find full-time work and get married before having children have a 98% chance of not living in poverty.
Planned Parenthood said it supports initiatives and recognizes the importance of awareness-raising and education, but added that the rate of teenage pregnancies is affected by economic and social factors such as poverty, violence, limited access to health care, as well as gender, racial and ethnic inequalities.
Adolescent parenthood is not simply the disastrous and life-threatening event that these ads portray, he said. It is time for us to focus on the root causes instead of pointing fingers at teenage parents and their children.
Last year, Bloomberg promised a $250,000 gift to the Family Planning Federation of America after the Susan G. Komen Foundation in Cure cut the Planned Parenthood breast cancer screening grants. Subsequently, the foundation reversed its decision.
According to data collected by the National Campaign to Prevent Teenage Pregnancy and not planned in its 2012 publication, Why It Matters: Teen Childbeing, Education, and Economic Wellbeing, approximately 48% of mothers aged 15-19 lived below the poverty line.
As their children grow, their likelihood of living in poverty increases according to Jessica Sheets Pika, spokesperson for the organization.
About 41 per cent of women who gave birth before age 20 lived in poverty during the first year of their child's birth, while the chances of living in poverty increased to 50 per cent when their child reached 3, Pika said.

text:
Digitized material piles – from blogs, tweets, photos and videos to official documents such as court decisions and emails – can be lost forever because the programs needed to see them will become dead, the vice president of Google warned. The first steps of humanity in the digital world could be lost to future historians, Vint Cerf told the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in San Jose, California, warning that we are facing a “forgotten generation or even a forgotten century” through what he called “bit-podication,” where old computer files become useless rubbish.
Cerf called for the development of “digital vellum” to preserve old software and hardware so that outdated files can be recovered no matter how old they are. “When you think about the amount of documentation of our daily life that is captured in digital form, such as our email interactions, people’s tweets and the entire global network, it’s clear that we’re standing to lose a lot of our history,” he said. “We don’t want our digital lives to disappear. If we want to preserve them, we need to make sure that the digital objects we create today can still be rendered in the future,” he added.
What is 'bit rotting' and is Vint Cerf right to be worried? Being able to access digital content in the coming decades could be less of a problem than one of the "Internet parents" has involved. The warning highlights an irony in the heart of modern technology, where music, photos, letters and other documents are digitized in the hope of ensuring their long-term survival. But while researchers are making progress in storing digital files for centuries, the programs and hardware needed to make sense of the files are continually out of use.
“We are unreservedly throwing all our data into what could become a black hole of information without realizing it. We digitize things because we think we will keep them, but what we don’t understand is that, unless we take other steps, those digital versions may not be better, and even worse, than the artifacts we digitize,” says Cerf. “If there are pictures you really care about, print them out.”
Ancient civilizations did not suffer such problems because stories written in cuneiformes on baked clay tablets or papyrus rolls only needed eyes to read them. To study the current culture, future scholars would be confronted with PDFs, Word documents and hundreds of other types of files that can only be interpreted with dedicated software and sometimes hardware, too.
The problem is already here. In the 1980s, it was routine to save documents on floppy disks, upload Jet Set Willy from cassette to the ZX spectrum, kill aliens with a Quickfire II joystick and have Atari game cartridges in the attic. Even if the discs and cassettes are in good condition, the equipment needed for their operation is now mostly only in museums.
The rise of the game has its own place in the history of digital culture, but Cerf warns that important political and historical documents will also be lost to rot. In 2005, American historian Doris Kearns Goodwin wrote Team of Rivals: the Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln, describing how Lincoln hired those who ran against him for the presidency. She went to libraries around the U.S., found the physical letters of the people involved, and rebuilt her conversations. “In today’s world, those letters would be emails and the chances of finding them will fade very small within a hundred years,” Cerf said.
He acknowledged that historians would take steps to preserve material considered important according to current standards, but maintained that the importance of documents and correspondence was often not fully appreciated until hundreds of years later. Historians have learned how the greatest mathematician of antiquity considered the concept of infinity and anticipated calculus in 3BC after the Archimedes palimpsest was found hidden under the words of a 13th-century Byzantine prayer book. “We have been surprised by what we have learned from objects that have been purely preserved by chance that give us a vision of an earlier civilization,” he said.
Researchers at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh have advanced towards a solution for bit rot, or at least partial. There, Mahadev Satyanarayanan takes digital snapshots of computer hard drives while running different software programs. These can be uploaded to a computer that mimics the software that worked. The result is a computer that can read files that would otherwise disappear. Under a project called Olive, researchers have archived Mystery House, the original 1982 graphic adventure game for Apple II, an early version of WordPerfect, and Doom, the original 1993 first person shooting game.
But inventing new technologies is only half the battle. Even more difficult could be browsing legal permissions to copy and store software before it dies. When IT companies get out of business, or stop supporting their products, they can sell the rights, so it's a nightmare task to get approval. “To do this correctly, preservation rights may have to be incorporated into our thinking about things like copyright and patents and licenses. We are talking about preserving them for hundreds or thousands of years,” Cerf said.

text:
The Spinoza Letters are a cumbersome work, their disjointed composition indicates the haste with which it was created. The first edition opens with the text of a poem by Goethe which, however, was abandoned in the second edition. The poem bore the name of its author, but had been edited mechanically by Jacobi to remove, printing certain key phrases in relief, images especially important to him. Thus edited, the poem conveyed the idea that pagan gods are the man written great, and therefore should be praised, as they reveal what is nobler in man. Brute nature has no feelings or discernment, while humans can judge, make distinctions and dare the impossible. They transcend nature. This was a humanist message with which Jacobi wholeheartedly agreed. After a brief explanation of how the exchange of letters with Mendelssohn originated, the main text continues with a somewhat abbreviated version of the correspondence itself. The first letter reported Jacobi’s conversation with Lessing on the subject of Spinoza during his visit to Wolfenbüttel, and included the text of another poem by Goethe — the Prometheus, which had been the occasion of the conversation in the first place. This poem, hitherto unpublished, was printed without the author's name (some thought it was Jacobi himself) and transmitted a quite different image of the gods found in the other poem. He suggested that they, no less than mortal men, are subject to the blind ‘almighty time’ that rules over all. In such a universe governed by the "eternal destiny", they are, therefore, even more miserable than human beings, since the latter have at least the power to rebel against the order of things and thus preserve their dignity. At least as Prometheus typifies it, humans can rejoice in their own sufferings, and for this challenge sustain their individuality before destiny.
In the rest of the letters we see Mendelssohn trying to downplay Lessing's supposed admission to spinozy. Since Mendelssohn initially thought that Jacobi himself was a spinozist, we also see him attacking the basic doctrines of spinozism as he understood them, while at the same time suggesting how they could be reformulated in a more internally consistent way to be reincorporated into the accepted teachings of school metaphysics. Jacobi, for his part, intended to show his scholarly (and indeed more accurate) knowledge of Spinoza's philosophy. In response to Mendelssohn's criticism of Spinoza, he argued that spinozism represented, on the contrary, a perfectly self-consisting position. It was school metaphysics that would logically lead to spinozism, if its implications were fully understood, not the other way around. Jacobi also gave an explanation for his sudden decision to publish the letters. Since Mendelssohn had announced the imminent publication of his Morgenstunden,[5] a book in which, as Mendelssohn said, he would address the subject of spinozism, Jacobi thought his opponent was unfairly trying to make a public advantage in a controversy that was agreed he would have to remain private before being called to public attention by mutual consent. Jacobi then concluded the book with extensive rambling quotes from various theologians, and sealed it' (his expression) with an extract from Lavater.
Mendelssohn bitterly complained to Kant that Jacobi's volume was like a monster deporting Goethe to the head, Spinoza as torso, and Lavater for the feet. There was a point in his complaint. However, in spite of the many ramblings and the penetrating preaching tone of the text, there was a definite philosophical message that Jacobi was transmitting. Philosophers are temperamentally inclined to reconstruct reality according to the requirements of explanation, in total ignorance of the requirements of existence. They are possessed, so to speak, by a logical fanaticism that leads them to confuse the abstract principles of explaining the principles of existence. Since the individuality of things is the first victim of this confusion, however, individuality is the necessary condition of all existence, it follows that in the world, rebuilt by philosophers, there is no room for truly existing subjects, let alone for agents who can seriously assume responsibility for their actions and relate to each other as a person to person, a “I” to a “you”. Everything that is nobler in human nature (as described in Goethe's first poem, implies Jacobi), especially the ability to make decisions and transcend brute nature, is thus denied, and there is no alternative for human individuals, if they care to preserve at least a minimum of dignity, except to enjoy their declared sense of freedom only misleading (according to Goethe's second poem, as Jacobi also seems to imply). The humanism of the Enlightenment so praised, based on the ideal of pure rationality, was only a farce. In fact, it led to "nihilism" (a term, by the way, that Jacobi made popular).
According to Jacobi's report on his conversation with Lessing, after a disquisition of his part on the devastating effects of a thought based solely on the demands of reason, and on Lessing's apparent statement of sympathy for Spinoza, Jacobi had urged the latter to make a mortal leap (Jacobi, 1785: 17), that is, a kind of leap, heels on his head, which would correct his position. Enlightened philosopher he was, Lessing had been walking on his head. The leap — which Lessing humorously refused to execute citing old age as an excuse (Jacobi: 1785, 33–34) — would have brought him to his feet, back on the solid ground of common sense. Jacobi's obvious agenda, in other words, both at the time of this encounter with Lessing and later, in the exchange of views with Mendelssohn, was to attack the rationalism of the Enlightenment. However, it also implied a criticism of Goethe. The latter had led the Sturm und Drang reaction against the same rationalism that Jacobi was now condemning. Jacobi's veiled message was that the followers of this new cultural phenomenon had not been able to escape the rationalism of philosophers, since the new rebel humanism they advocated made sense only in the presumption that the conception of the reality of philosophers was the correct one. It is the desire to convey this message that alone explains the disconcerting presence in Jacobi's volume of Goethe's two poems. For Jacobi's contemporaries, who lacked the background knowledge of Jacobi's special relationship with Goethe, and even did not know Goethe's authorship of the second poem, his inclusion in the volume remained a mystery until the end.

text:
Valdevaqueros is one of the last unspoilt beaches left in southern Spain, where the sky above the golden sands is full of kites carrying surfers on the waves. Currently, the beach has little more than a road bordered by motorhomes from Germany, France, Italy and Great Britain, full of windsurfers and kitesurfers attracted by the strong winds of the area.
For decades it has been a world apart from the concrete-covered beaches of Torremolinos and Marbella along the coast, but on 29 May the municipality of Tarifa approved plans to build a tourist complex right next to the beach, with 1,400 hotel rooms and 350 floors. Environmental and conservation groups have protested that the project will damage protected species habitats, but for most councillors here the issue is simple: jobs. In this population of 18,000, 2,600 are unemployed as Spain faces its worst economic crisis in at least half a century, one that has cast doubt on the future of the euro.
“Traditional sources of income such as fishing are disappearing, now that fleets are being dismantled and fish stocks are exhausted, so tourism is the only way out, as long as it is sustainable,” said Sebastián Galindo, a councillor of the Socialist Party, who is in opposition in Tarifa but voted with the ruling People’s Party to give the green light to the project.
The mayor of Tarifa, Juan Andrés Gil, refused to comment on the project, but Galindo said it meets environmental standards.
The complex would be 800 meters from the coast, comfortably beyond the minimum of 200 meters stipulated by a law aimed at avoiding more ugly developments such as those that affected much of the Spanish coast when mass tourism first descended to its coasts in the 1960s and 1970s.
Opponents of the complex say that the last thing anyone needs is more housing in a country that already has a million empty homes, although the central government proposed a sale last week by granting non-Spaniards residence permits in exchange for buying a property worth at least €160,000.
The socialist opposition in Madrid attacked the proposal, and Galindo said it discriminated against migrant workers who went to Spain during the boom years, many of them from Morocco, whose coast is only 14 km away and can be seen from Tarifa. “It’s in favor of classes with money instead of those who came here to help Spain get ahead,” he said. Surfers fear that new buildings in Valdevaqueros will reduce the strength of the famous local Levante wind, but do not attract traditional tourists. “It’s not really a familiar place. Just wait for them to see what an Levant looks like,” said Henning Mayer, who has regularly made the journey from Augsburg to Germany for 20 years. “Ten years ago they said they would build a new road here. It didn’t happen, so I think it will be impossible to build new hotels.”
At the southern end of Spain, Tarifa is the strategic crossroads between Africa and Europe, where the Mediterranean Sea meets the Atlantic. Activists say it also has a vital role in the animal world as a crossroads for migratory species.
The campaign to save the beach was launched hours after Tarifa's council voted for the project. The campaign has a Facebook page and is supported by groups such as Greenpeace, the World Wildlife Fund and the Spanish branch of the Birdlife conservation network. “It’s the environmental equivalent of putting a shopping center right in the middle of the Alhambra,” said Noelia Jurado, who uses her multimedia experience to campaign against the complex. He also noted that the complex would be close to the ancient Roman city of Baelo Claudia. “They could be building on more Roman ruins here. Nobody knows.
It also joins the opposition to the planned complex of the Andalusian College of Geographers, which, in a preliminary study plotted on its website, concluded that “free areas, ” including parking lots if not real buildings, will overlap part of the Alcornocales National Park. Geographers also estimate that the site interferes with two wildlife conservation areas. One of the areas of Valdevaqueros is home to two species of bats whose survival is threatened.
“Once again, money is being put before urban laws and European environmental directives,” said Raúl Romeva, a member of the European Parliament who is Vice-President of the Green Group. In Romeva's opinion, the project is also to blame because the proposed site has very little water in a city that already suffers from scarcity in the summer climate that burns the southern region of Andalusia. The lack of water recently led the Supreme Court of Andalusia to defend an appeal against plans to build a complex elsewhere in the region, which would have included golf courses, hotels and luxury homes.
Many locals also wonder why a complex should be built 10 km away, instead of on the vacant grounds near the picturesque old town of Tarifa, with its typically Andalusian white walls and winding streets, dominated by a Moorish castle of the 10th century. “My opinion and that of catering is that we agree with the complex as long as it creates jobs in the city, which is what is needed, but we are against it being for the benefit of a few,” said Cristóbal Lobato, who has worked at the same beachside bar in Tarifa for 30 years. “If you put it in the center of Tarifa, where there is space, guests can visit shops, tapas bars and restaurants.”
With a view to the green fields for construction, biologist Aitor Galán, who conducts environmental impact studies to earn a living, pointed out one of the only two coastal vulture farms in Europe. “Anywhere else in Europe, this place would have maximum protection, but here they want to get rid of everything and cover it with buildings,” he said. “What they want to do is turn this into Benidorm, but what attracts people here is wildlife and wind. But taking advantage of the current crisis and unemployment, builders and mayors who agree with them can justify any amount of destruction.”

text:
Some of the daily heroes in the United States are the country's paramedics. These young men and women are often the first people to respond to public medical emergencies. Paramedics should complete a very extensive physical training program that is designed to eliminate those who cannot make the cut. A paramedic must be in good condition and mentally strong to perform his duties in the face of danger. Many of these heroes must endure life-threatening situations when responding to emergencies. Paramedics are often linked to a county, or city fire department, but there are also some private paramedic organizations.

In Southern California, there are two primary schools for paramedic training. They are the Daniel Freeman paramedic program of UCLA and the Institute of Paramedical Training. Both schools provide candidates for the Los Angeles County and City Fire Departments. To become a paramedic for a county or city organization, candidates must also pass a psychological exam and a physical training program.
Some of the teams that paramedics carry are highly specialized. They carry basic and advanced life support equipment, such as forced entry tools so that they can reach people in danger, saws to cut obstacles and other emergency equipment. Paramedics provide valuable service to the communities they serve. They should be certified in Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) techniques and trained to handle all situations.
Some paramedics are trained to respond to what is called Mass Casuality Incidents (CMI). These emergencies occur whenever there is a tragic event such as the 11 September 2001 attacks on the country, and other emergencies such as earthquakes, landslides or floods. Paramedics can also be sent to emergency situations by citizens who call the 911 emergency phone number.

The crop has consistent reliable yields, due to the

text:
It has charted the highest peaks in the world, the ocean floor, the Amazon rainforest and has even taken a look at North Korea. But Google's mission to map the world has remained largely far from the inhospitable Arctic.
Now, however, the search engine signature is embarking on what could be the most significant update of centuries of polar cartography – and one that expects it to help provide a better understanding of life in permafrost for millions of web users. Google has taken a small team to Iqaluit, the largest city in the Canadian territory of Nunavut, armed with its warmer winter equipment, a stack of laptops and a telescopic camera mounted in a backpack of 18 kg.
With the help of an inuit mapping expert, and harassed by curious locals, the team spent four days touring the terrain and collecting images and information that will give the isolated community of the tundra of the island of Baffin what urbanists around the world now take for granted.
The city of 7,000 people will be displayed through Google’s popular Street View app in July 2013.
Aaron Brindle, project leader, said: “I live in Toronto and assume that everything is where it should be and that this map is a kind of my world, but for so long it has not been the case in the north.”
Unlike the most populous and accessible parts of the world, which have been mapped with a special camera mounted on a car roof, the Iqaluit project had mappers hiking the city's snow-filled roads and walking little-known trails, some of which are made of ice and disappear in the brief summer months.
The team also cut a road along a part of a 15-km dead end known as the Path to Nowhere, despite warnings about the risk of polar bears and other wild species.
Mayor John Graham said digital cartographers were, however, hunted down by a pack of excited and curious locals, or Google stalkers.
Graham understands enthusiasm. The Street View project, he said, follows in the footsteps of English explorer Martin Frobisher, who in 1576 sailed to the bay where Iqaluit now sits as he seeks the northwest passage, and the 1941 flight of Captain Elliott Roosevelt, a reconnaissance officer and son of the President of the United States, which led to the site being chosen for a military air base. Its exploration led to the foundation of the modern city of Iqaluit, which is the seat of the government, as well as a transportation and communications center for Nunavut.
One of the initial challenges Google faced was the collection of the raw data needed to fill in its existing map. What they had created using satellite images was quite accurate, although the rapid rate of growth of the city, which has been fueled by a mining boom, meant that they lacked a road that had been created in the last year, said Arif Sayani, city planning director.
Another difficulty was how to place many companies and homeowners who have mail sent to the local post office rather than hand it over to their address. The layout of the addresses of the post office box would result in a map with companies, banks and schools grouped around the Canada Post building in the city centre.
About 30 Inuit elders, entrepreneurs and high school students attended one night to help correct these problems. They were provided with a laptop and instructed how to ensure that their homes, shops and meeting places appeared accurately on the map.
The project is more than a cultural novelty or philanthropy. Sayani, 32, said the city could use maps as a promotional tool for those who think about visiting or moving to the area. It can also speed up planning decisions that will affect Iqaluit's growth.
The test for the Iqaluit mapping exercise took place last summer in Cambridge Bay, a much smaller city of Nunavut of about 1,500 people located 1,700 km and a time zone west of Iqaluit.
The gravel roads and muddy puddles that can now be seen online, however, give little meaning to life on a land generally covered with snow, which is one reason why Google selected the least hospitable month of March to travel to Iqaluit.
Brindle said he hoped to see the work continue in other northern cities, although high shipping costs and air tickets to move people and equipment around the vast Arctic territory seem to be weighing on Google's ambitions.
The next site in the north has not yet been identified, but, when selected, Brindle said the company could simply send one of his high-tech backpacks and rely on volunteers to literally get on the map.
“I hope that in three, four, five years we will look back and see a very different map of northern Canada,” Brindle added.

text:
A long time ago, film audiences were transported to a galaxy far, far away: one where imperial cruisers fought rebel fighters, where droids rubbed circuits with wookies, and where a spaceship called the Millennium Falcon could make Kessel's career in less than 12 parsecs. That was 1977, but, in 2015, when the franchise approaches its seventh series of big screens, interest in Star Wars shows no signs of diminishing – now there is news of a new film about Han Solo and a reappearance for Darth Vader. “Uncountable fans around the world are in a constant state of vigilance waiting for the release of new poster art, new trailers and other information,” said Paul Dergarabedian, senior media analyst at the Rentrak box office monitor. “It’s hard to imagine any other film franchise that can evoke a level of passion, enthusiasm and excitement.”
The latest Star Wars mania dates back to the purchase of the Hollywood Disney studio by Lucasfilm from the creator of the film, George Lucas, in 2012; the acquisition of $4 billion was accompanied by an announcement of three more sequential “episodes” – VII, VIII and IX – in addition to unspecified plans for spin-off and stand-alons films to fill the gaps in the release schedule. The details of the second spin-off have now been made public: a “history of origins” about Han Solo, the intergalactic smuggler played by Harrison Ford in the first three films, which is scheduled to be released in May 2018.
It will continue the release in December 2015 of Episode VII, directed by JJ Abrams and titled Star Wars: The Force Awakens, the unnamed Episode VIII scheduled for 2017 and the already announced spin-off, Rogue One, which will reach theaters in 2016.
That film will outline a rebel mission to steal the plans of the Death Star, a key element of the plot of the first film in 1977. Levels of interest in the rumor that Rogue One will also feature the reappearance of Darth Vader, the black villain of the original series, only confirmed the power of Star Wars' nostalgia.
By creating a multifaceted and multifaceted “universe” of film around Star Wars, Lucasfilm-Disney is taking his example from the phenomenally successful series produced by Marvel Studios, which Disney also acquired in 2009.
Disney has brought a new level of marketing knowledge to an already popular product: Dergarabedian cites the decision to make the six existing Star Wars movies available in streaming services as “a brilliant way to build anticipation for the new movie and revitalize the idea of Star Wars in the minds of fans.”
It is questionable whether it needs to be revitalized. The level of enthusiasm that has surrounded Star Wars for at least the last two decades is evident in what has become known as the “Expanded Universe”: the plethora of novels, comics, video games and merchandising that Lucasfilm has created or licensed over the years.
This additional material began to emerge since 1978, but was given a massive kick by the proliferation of the Internet in the 1990s. Role play and fan participation show no signs of deceleration: in the UK, the film brand Secret Cinema has found considerable commercial success with its live staging of The Empire Strikes Back.
Michael Rosser, news editor at Screen International, suggests that it is this “shared universe” of highly infectious nostalgia that keeps Star Wars in the pole position among film franchises. “The good thing about the original films was that they created a huge universe of characters and possibilities that caused the imagination of viewers,” he said.
“For years, people have been wondering how the different threads would develop. This new film, because it’s going back to Han Solo and Luke Skywalker, looks like it’s reconnecting with the original Star Wars in a way the prequels failed.”
Rosser refers to the three films directed by Lucas between 1999 and 2005 – The Phantom Menace, Attack of the Clones and Revenge of the Sith – which narrated the life of Luke Skywalker's father, Anakin, who transforms into Darth Vader. Despite having been received with less than stellar reviews, the prequels took $2.5 billion into the world box office, shortly after the launch of the restored and augmented “special editions” of the first trilogy had net $469 million in 1997.
“It shows the power of Star Wars that, although disappointing, the prequels still made a lot of money,” Rosser said.
In a film business where branding is everything and a successful franchise the answer to everyone's prayers, is there a risk that film studios will simply become branding machines and lose their interest in film for their own good?
Rosser doesn't think so. “They are desperate to ensure the longevity of the franchise and ensure that quality is maintained. They are also trying to take people to the movies at a time when many are staying home for entertainment. But you don’t want to see Star Wars on your iPhone, so I don’t think you’ll run out of steam anytime soon.”
Meanwhile, Dergarabedian is anticipating a massive business when The Force Awakens arrives at the cinemas in December 2015. “We are certainly facing a record opening for December and should continue to earn at least a billion dollars worldwide. Truly, Star Wars is the latest film brand.”
label: C2

text:
Needless to say, human beings (identifiable mammals such as those standing and being comparatively advanced and capable of detailed thought) have rather remarkable bodies, given all they have accomplished. (In addition, an especially intelligent human brain produced this text!) Human beings have undoubtedly overcome predators, diseases and all kinds of obstacles for thousands of years.
To fully understand and appreciate these achievements, let's take in some of the best known parts of the human body!
The head, or the spherical part of the body that contains the brain and rests on the top of the human body, has enough individual organs and parts of the body in it. (It should be mentioned quickly that the hair occupies the space at the top of the head, and the ears, the organs responsible for hearing, are on both sides of the head.) From top to bottom, eyebrows, or horizontal strips of hair that can be found above the eye, are the first components of the head. The eyes are under them, and they are round, orb-like organs that allow humans to see.
The eyes give way to the nose, or to an external organ that plays an important role in the respiratory and bacterial removal processes. Below is the mouth, or a large, cavernous organ that chews food, eliminates bacteria, helps with breathing, and more. The mouth contains teeth, or small, white, pointed parts of the body that are used to chew food, and the tongue, or a red, boneless organ used to chew food and talk.
The neck is the part of the long body that connects the head to the chest (the part of the muscle body that protects the heart and lungs), and the stomach, or the part of the body that contains food and fluid processing organs, is below that.
Legs are the long, muscular parts of the body that allow humans to move from one point to another and perform a variety of actions. Each leg contains one thigh (a thick, especially muscular part of the body used to perform strenuous movements; the upper part of the leg) and a calf (thinner, more flexible part of the body that absorbs shock associated with movement; the lower part of the leg). The feet can be found at the bottom of the legs, and each foot consists of five toes, or small appendages that help balance.
The arms are long and powerful body parts that are on both sides of the chest, under the shoulders; the arms are composed of biceps (the thickest and most powerful upper portion), and forearms (the thinner and more flexible lower portion). The hands, or small, body parts that grab used for a large number of actions, are at the end of the arms. Each hand contains five fingers, or small appendages used to grab objects.
The shoulders mentioned above are rounded body parts that help the flexibility of the arms. One's back is on the opposite side of the stomach, and it is a flat section of the body that contains important muscles that are intended to protect the lungs and other internal organs, in addition to helping humans perform certain movements and actions.
label: C2

text:
At Addis Ababa airport, visitors are greeted by images of golden grains, ochre red seeds and a group of men gathered around a giant pancake. The Billboards boast: “Teff: the ultimate gluten-free crop!”
Ethiopia is one of the poorest countries in the world, well known for its precarious food security situation. But it is also the native home of teff, an ancient, highly nutritious grain that is increasingly found on its way in health food stores and supermarkets in Europe and America.
The small seeds of Teff, the size of the poppy seeds, are high in calcium, iron and protein, and have an impressive set of amino acids. Naturally gluten-free, grain can replace wheat flour in anything, from bread and pasta to waffles and pizza bases. Like quinoa, the Andean grain, the magnificent nutritional profile of teff offers the promise of new and lucrative markets in the west.
In Ethiopia, Teff is a national obsession. Cultivated by some 6.3 million farmers, agricultural fields cover more than 20 per cent of all cultivated land. Ground in flour and used to make injera, the fermented flat bread that is basic for Ethiopian cuisine, the grain is central to many religious and cultural ceremonies. Across the country, and in neighbouring Eritrea, diners gather around large pieces of injera, which double as cutlery, gathering stews and feeding each other as a sign of loyalty or friendship, a tradition known as gurusha.
Outside diaspora communities in the west, Teff has flown under the radar for decades. But the growing appetite for traditional crops and the boom in healthy, gluten-free food markets are instilling new life to the point, increasingly promoted as Ethiopia’s “second gift to the world,” after coffee.
Sophie Kebede, a London-based entrepreneur who owns a British grain company, says she was “glazed” when she discovered her nutritional value. “I didn’t know I was so wanted. I am of Ethiopian origin; I’ve been eating injera all my life.”
The growing demand for so-called ancient grains has not always been a direct victory for poor communities. In Bolivia and Peru, reports of rising incomes due to current global trade in quinoa have been added to those of malnutrition and land conflicts, as farmers sell their entire crop to meet Western demand.
Ethiopia's growing middle class is also increasing demand for teff and rising domestic prices have put grain out of reach of the poorest. Today, most small farmers sell most of what they grow to the city’s consumers.
This may have helped raise incomes in some rural areas, but it has had nutritional consequences, says the government, as teff is the most nutritionally valuable grain in the country. Estimates suggest that while urban dwellers consume up to 61 kg of teff per year, in rural areas the figure is 20 kg. The type of consumption also differs: the rich eat almost exclusively the most expensive varieties of magna and white teff; the less well-off consumers tend to eat less valuable red and mixed teff, and more than half combine it with cheaper cereals such as sorghum and maize.
The Ethiopian government wants to double the production of teff by 2015. Its strategy, published in 2013, argues that grain could play an important role in school meals and emergency relief programmes, and help reduce malnutrition, especially among children and adolescents.
Although Ethiopia has a fast-growing economy, it remains on the UN list of least developed countries. It is estimated that 20 per cent of children under 5 years of age are undernourished or stunted.
The government's Agricultural Transformation Agency aims to boost yields by developing improved grain varieties, along with new planting techniques and tools to reduce post-harvest losses.
Government restrictions, introduced in 2006, prohibit the export of raw teff grain, allowing only shipments of injera and other processed products. But this could change: the goal is to produce enough teff for domestic consumption and a strong export market, according to the government's strategy.
Mama Fresh is a family business that has been selling injera to the best restaurants and hotels in the Ethiopian capital for years. It also sends flat bread to Finland, Germany, Sweden and the United States, mainly for consumption by diaspora communities. But, the company has its eye on the gluten-free market. It aims to double exports to America in 2014 and will soon start producing pizzas, bread and cookies based on teff.
“Typically, these products will pass through many hands before reaching the Sainsbury shelves or wherever. There are profit margins at every step and small farmers are not necessarily well placed to negotiate with big traders,” says David Hallam, Director of Trade and Markets of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. He considers the popularity of quinoa to be a warning story about how export opportunities can be a mixed blessing for poor countries.
Regassa Feyissa, an Ethiopian agricultural scientist and former head of the National Biodiversity Institute, warns that, without careful planning, increased production of teff for export can displace other crops important to farmers. And efforts to boost production could benefit business interests at the expense of small farmers.
With little Ethiopian teff on the international market, farmers in the US They've started planting the harvest. Farmers in Europe, Israel and Australia have also experimented with it.
Kebede says he gets his grain from farms in southern Europe, although he would rather get it from Ethiopia. “Teff is the second nature of an Ethiopian, so who better to supply it? We have this coveted grain grown in the country, so why can’t an Ethiopian farmer benefit from this?”

text:
Singapore's economy declined by 4.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2008, the Ministry of Trade and Industry said Thursday, as it predicts that the economy would contract between 2 and 5 percent this year.
The boats sail under a bridge near the financial district of Singapore.
Compared to strong growth of 7.8 percent a year earlier, the economy grew by 1.1 percent throughout 2008, the ministry added.
He called the gross domestic product growth prospects for 2009 weak... due to the pessimistic global economic outlook.
All major sectors, except construction, business services, and information and communications, saw contractions, the ministry said.
The Ministry cited a decline in private sector investment and private consumption spending to reduce total domestic demand.
The decline in global demand for electronic products, pharmaceuticals and chemicals was also likely to have an impact on the manufacturing sector.

text:
Like the veins that carry the blood of a city, a subway system is full of billions of inhabitants: the bacteria of Swiss cheese and kimchi, bubonic plague and drug-proof insects and human skin. Now, for the first time, scientists have started cataloging and mapping bacteria circulating in a city's subway, and have found a lot of curious results.
Dr. Christopher Mason, a geneticist at Weill Cornell Medical College, led a team that, for 18 months, made a sample of New York City's subway system for microscopic life forms that cover their tourniquets, seats, lockers, and stations. In what Mason called “the first scale genetic profile of the city,” his team found meningitis in Times Square, a trail of anthrax in the hand of a train car and bacteria that cause bubonic plague in a garbage can and a ticket machine at the stations in central Manhattan.
In an investigation published in Cell Systems magazine, the team sharply lowered the findings of plague and anthrax, pointing to the extremely small trail of the latter, that rats probably carried the first and that no one has fallen sick of plague in or around New York for years.
“The results do not suggest that the plague or anthrax is frequent,” the study says. “They don’t even suggest that New York residents are at risk.”
In fact, most bacteria identified by the team are harmless to humans or beneficial in the city's thriving world of microorganisms, many of which process toxic hazards and residues in the same way that bacteria within each human being help with digestion and bodily functions.
Some of the results were expected, Mason said, including some bacteria associated with fecal matter, which he said “should be a gentle reminder for people to wash their hands.” He also said that many bacteria of the same genus that “are beneficial and useful, such as the one used to make cheese,” also appeared in New York.
Bacteria seemed to reflect eating habits in several neighborhoods. Around the metro, bacteria associated with cheeses – brie, cheddar, parmesan and mozzarella appeared from the ubiquitous New York pizza. The distinctive Swiss cheese bacteria were more localized in downtown Manhattan and the financial district, and the bacteria used to ferment cabbage for kimchi and sauerkraut appeared in the financial district and Bay Ridge. The computer also identified cucumber DNA throughout the city, Mason said.
Bacteria associated with diseases and infections were extremely common. Species that cause diarrhea and nausea, both benign and bad E.coli (mostly benign), and bacteria that can cause skin infections and urinary infections were common throughout the city. The species that produces tetanus appeared in Soho and the bacteria that cause dysentery appeared at one station in the Bronx and another in Harlem.
With over 1,000 samples collected from all 466 open subway stations in New York City, Mason and his team passed the organic materials through a DNA sequencer and then through a supercomputer armed with genetic databases. They identified 15,152 different species, almost half of which were bacteria.
The good news, the researchers wrote, is that these “potentially infectious agents” are not spreading diseases or diseases all over New York, but seem to be “normal cohabitants” and “can even be essential.” They represent a normal and 'healthy' metagenome profile of a city.
In short, researchers conclude, the subway and the city are as safe as everyone thought.
Mason said people shouldn't worry about getting urinary tract infections from the subway seats. “You should wash your hands,” he said, “and probably get some sleep and eat salads and go to the gym, and that’s almost the same today as yesterday.”
“In any case,” he added, “I’ve become much safer on the subway.”
Many findings made sense: traffic stations like Grand Central and Times Square had more bacteria and more diversity among them; the subway was more enriched for skin-associated bacteria. The Bronx, with its various neighborhoods and seasons, had the greatest diversity of bacteria; Staten Island, with only three stops, had the lowest.
Researchers found marine bacteria in South Ferry, a season that flooded during Hurricane Sandy, but were surprised to note that species included some normally associated with Antarctica and fish.
The next steps, Mason said, are studies of other cities, which have begun in Paris, São Paolo and Shanghai, and continued studies of New York, for example, to see how the microbiome changes with the seasons. He said he hoped the research would provide a “base” of research for health officials and geneticists, and could help health officials to be better prepared to prevent and track diseases and pathogens.

text:
The Nietzschean method of genealogy, in its application to modern subjectivity, is another facet of philosophical postmodernism. The application of Michel Foucault's genealogy to the formative moments of the history of modernity and his exhortations to experiment with subjectivity place him in the realm of postmodern discourse. In the 1971 essay "Nietzsche, Genealogy, History", Foucault explains his adaptation of the genealogical method in his historical studies. First of all, he says, genealogy “is opposed to the search for ‘origins’” (Foucault 1977, 141). In other words, genealogy studies accidents and contingencies that converge at crucial moments, giving rise to new epochs, concepts and institutions. As Foucault points out: “What is found in the historical principle of things is not the inviolable identity of their origin; it is the dissension of other things. It is disparity” (Foucault 1977, 142). In Nietzschean fashion, Foucault exposes history conceived as the origin and development of an identical subject, for example, “modernity”, as a fiction, modern discourses invent after the fact. Behind the fiction of modernity is a sense of temporality that excludes the elements of chance and contingency at stake at every moment. In short, linear and progressive history covers the discontinuities and interruptions that mark the points of succession in historical time.
Foucault deploys genealogy to create what he calls a “counter-memory” or “a transformation of history into a totally different form of time” (Foucault 1977, 160). This implies dissolving the identity of the subject in history by using the materials and techniques of modern historical research. Just as Nietzsche postulates that religious will to truth in Christianity results in the destruction of Christianity by science (see Nietzsche 1974 [1882], 280–83), Foucault postulates that genealogical research will result in the disintegration of the epistemic subject, since the subject's continuity is broken by the gaps and accidents that historical research discovers. The first example of this research is the Histoire de la folie à l'age classique, published in 1961, the full version of which was published in English as History of Madness in 2006. Here, Foucault gives an account of the historical beginnings of modern reason as it comes to be defined against madness in the seventeenth century. His thesis is that the practice of confining madmen is a transformation of the medieval practice of confining lepers in lazar houses. These institutions managed to survive long after the lepers disappeared, and so there was already an institutional structure of confinement when the modern concept of insanity as a disease was conformed. However, while institutions of detention have been maintained in the past, the practice of confining mad persons constitutes a break with the past.
Foucault focuses on the moment of transition, as modern reason begins to take shape in a confluence of concepts, institutions and practices, or, as he would say, of knowledge and power. In his nascence, reason is a power that defines itself against another, one whose truth and identity is also assigned by reason, thus giving reason the sense of originating from itself. For Foucault, the question is that madness is not allowed to speak for itself and is at the disposal of a power that dictates the terms of its relationship. As he points out: “What is original is the cassura that establishes the distance between reason and non-reason; the subjugation of the reason of non-reason, taking away from it its truth as madness, crime or disease, derives explicitly from this point” (Foucault 1965, x). The truth of reason is found when madness becomes in the place of non-reason, when the difference between them is inscribed in their opposition, but it is not identical to their dominant side. In other words, the reason that opposes madness is not identical to the reason that attributes its difference. The latter would be the reason without an opposite power, a free floating power without definite form. As Foucault suggests, this floating mystery could be represented in the nave of foolish motive, which, in medieval times, represented madness. Such is the paradoxical structure of historical transformation.
In his later writings, especially in The Use of Pleasure (Foucault 1985 [1984]), Foucault uses historical research to open up possibilities of experimenting with subjectivity, showing that subjectivity is a formative power of the self, overcoming the structures of knowledge and the power from which it emerges. This is a power of thought, which Foucault says is the ability of human beings to problematize the conditions in which they live. For philosophy, this means “the effort to know how and to what extent it might be possible to think differently, rather than legitimizing what is already known” (Foucault 1985 [1984], 9). Thus he joins Lyotard in promoting creative experimentation as a leading power of thought, a power that surpasses reason, narrowly defined, and without which thought would be inert. In this sense, Foucault joins others who profess a postmodern sensitivity to contemporary science, art and society. It should also be noted that Foucault's writings are a hybrid of philosophy and historical research, just as Lyotard combines the language games of the expert and philosopher in The Postmodern Condition. This blend of philosophy with concepts and methods from other disciplines is characteristic of postmodernism in its broadest sense.

text:
Up to one billion people will remain in extreme poverty by 2030 unless countries focus on inequalities and confront social, economic and cultural forces that block their escape or drag them back to impoverishment, a major report warns. The report of the Chronic Poverty Advisory Network (CPN) states that many people can rise above the poverty line of $1.25 a day, only to retreat when they are affected by a combination or sequence of shocks such as drought, disease and insecurity or conflict.
Based on household group surveys, the report found that, in some rural areas of Kenya and South Africa, between 30 and 40 per cent of those who escaped poverty receded and increased to 60 per cent in some areas of Ethiopia between 1999 and 2009. Even in successful countries such as Indonesia and Vietnam, the proportion has been 20%. Individual cases highlight the ease with which people can return to poverty.
Amin, 61, from rural Bangladesh, has seen her livelihood gradually decline, due to her own illnesses and those of her wife, the cost of her child's marriage, the death of her father and the loss of assets such as fishing nets. Lovemore, 74, from Zimbabwe, has become one of the poorest people in her village. He recently lost his job as a parking assistant due to poor health and had to receive his five grandchildren after the death of his daughters.
“We need to ensure that people emerging from poverty remain permanently above the poverty line. Too many families are experiencing 'two steps forward, one step backwards', where they struggle to recover from personal or major setbacks. Governments should not assume that, just because someone’s income reaches $1.25, that means work done,” said Andrew Shepherd, a researcher at the Overseas Development Institute, partner of the CPAN, and lead author of the report.
A high-level UN panel considering a new development framework to succeed the Millennium Development Goals beyond 2015 said the goal of eliminating extreme poverty by 2030 was within reach. However, the report argues that “more of the same” will not reach zero.
Despite the decline in extreme poverty from 1.9 billion in 1990 to 1.2 billion in 2010, the report says that progress over the next 15 years will be much more difficult. China ' s great achievements are unlikely to be accompanied by similar progress elsewhere, while climate-related shocks and deep poverty in some parts of sub-Saharan Africa will slow the momentum. The report calls for a change in thinking about poverty to focus on the chronic poor – those who are poor for many years or their entire lives – and a greater emphasis on stopping impoverishment, falling to poverty. “Governments have been good enough to move people above the poverty line because that’s relatively easy – there’s a tendency to reap the low fruits, but they’ve moved away from the hardest task of tackling chronic poverty,” said Shepherd.
The report says that progress in poverty reduction, although impressive to date, has had less impact on the chronic poor than on those who were already closer to the poverty line. It will not be possible to reach zero unless development policies give priority to those living in chronic poverty, he adds. Policy makers must aspire to a “zero tripod” of separate but interdependent goals: to address chronic poverty; to stop impoverishment; to sustain the escape from poverty. They presented a trio of policies, all of which require massive global investment.
The first is social assistance – a safety net – to bring the poorest people closer to a decent standard of living. One example is Ethiopia ' s productive safety net programme, which enabled thousands of vulnerable households to withstand drought without having to reduce spending on education. The second is education, from early childhood to the beginning of work, so that people can escape and stay out of poverty. Education also has the advantage of being a “portable” asset. The third is economic growth policies that favour the poorest to ensure that the benefits of increasing national prosperity reach the poorest people.
“Economic growth is really critical, but not any old growth,” said Shepherd. “It has to generate not only employment, but decent jobs, not just insecure and low-paid jobs. There are ways to do this, such as India’s rural employment guarantee scheme, which has boosted urban wages not just rural.” Another example cited in the report was the extension of South Africa ' s minimum wage to groups such as domestic workers.
All this will require money and the report says that an obvious implication is that stronger national tax systems and higher tax revenues will be needed. Support will also be needed to cover the initial costs of social assistance, universal health coverage and education funding, including scholarships for the poorest children. “Help continues to play a huge role in the next 20 years, as many developing countries spend less than $500 on each of their citizens each year. Even Nigeria, with its oil wealth, spends only $650 per capita,” said Shepherd.
In a context of crisis in Syria, South Sudan and the Central African Republic, conflicts and environmental disasters must be addressed, and the report said that it was essential for Governments to work to reduce the risk of conflict and establish inclusive peace settlements.
Choose the best answer according to the text. 1. Who are the 'chronically poor'?
The incorporation of “reducing inequality (income)” as a post-2015 goal would lead the international agenda in the right direction, given that the reduction or containment of inequality accelerates the impact of economic growth on poverty reduction. The report argues that addressing inequalities affecting the poorest people – such as access to land, labour markets and power relations between men and women – would address two goals at the same time: reducing chronic poverty and inequality.
The authors urge Governments to develop an inclusive national development plan and to work with civil society to ensure that the poorest people are politically represented, as well as to address the difficult social norms such as dowry and witchcraft that contribute to extreme poverty: “This often means challenging and, perhaps, sweeping aspects of the status quo and represents the sharpest deviation from “business as usual”.

text:
His Edinburgh and Cambridge mentors were to give decisive shape to Darwin's philosophical attitudes and his scientific career. It was Henslow who was the last link to Darwin in a chain connected to Captain Robert Fitzroy of H. M. S. Beagle. Fitzroy sought a fellow knight who could also collect information on geology and natural history during a proposal of circumnavigation of the world. Henslow’s note to Darwin, asking if he would be interested in being recommended for this position, came to Darwin’s house, ‘the Mount’, while Charles Darwin was in a geological study of North Wales with Adam Sedgwick. After his father's resistance had been overcome, Darwin offered the position and accepted it.
The combination of meticulous field observation, collection and experimentation, taking notes, reading and thinking during what became the five-year journey of the Beagle through a very wide cross section of the earth's environments was to establish the course for the rest of his life. During the trip he read and re-read the Principles of Geology of Charles Lyell, a three-volume work that articulated a philosophical view of rigorously empirical historical science, centered around five key ideas:
The geologist investigates both the animated and inanimate changes that have taken place during Earth's history.
Its main tasks are to develop a precise and complete record of these changes, encapsulate this knowledge in general laws, and search for their causes.
This search should be limited to the causes that can be studied empirically—those that “are now in operation,” as Lyell puts it in the subtitle of his Principles.
Records or ‘monuments’ of the Earth’s past indicate a constant process of ‘introduction’ and ‘extinction’ of species, and it is the task of the geologist to look for the causes of these introductions and extinctions, according to the note of strictions in 3. above.
The only serious attempt to do so according to the idea that species are capable of ‘indefinite modification’, that of Jean Baptiste Lamarck, is a failure for methodological reasons. All evidence supports the view that species variability is limited, and that one species cannot be transformed into another.
This vision deeply influenced Darwin, as he freely admitted. While he was convinced by his observations and his reading that the fossil record and the current distribution of species could only be due to the gradual transformation of one species into another, he was determined to articulate a theory that conformed to Lyell's principles. The crucial event to convince him that this was going to be the work of his life was probably a visit to Cape Town, South Africa, during the Beagle's return trip to England. John F. W. Herschel was in Cape Town on a mission to do for the southern hemisphere what his father William had done for the north, namely, to develop a complete star map with the new powerful telescopes developed by his father and aunt. As noted earlier, Darwin had been deeply impressed by Herschel's preliminary speech on the study of natural philosophy when he first appeared a year before the Beagle set sail, and in his private diary he referred to his meetings with Herschel during a one-week stop in Cape Town in June 1836 as one of the deepest events of the entire trip. Just five months before meeting Darwin, Herschel had finished reading the second edition of the Lyell Principles. He sent Lyell a long letter full of detailed constructive comments. The letter opens by praising Lyell for addressing the issue of the ‘introduction of new species’ — which Herschel calls ‘that mystery of mysteries’ — scientifically, and for advocating that we seek ‘intermediate causes’ to explain these ‘introductions’ — code for natural causes, rather than ‘miraculous’ causes. [5] This part of the letter was cited in Charles Babbage's Treaty of Bridgewater, published in 1837 as Darwin struggled to develop such a theory. Reading Herschel’s quotation in Babbage, Darwin wrote in his private ‘species’ notebooks:
Babbage 2d Edit, p. 226.—Herschel calls the appearance of new species. the mystery of mysteries. & has big step over problem.! Hurrah.— “intermediate causes”. (Barrett et al. 1987, 413; original score)
He clearly recognizes that Herschel is here providing a philosophical justification for the project that Darwin was working on in secret. And, in the first paragraph of On the Origin of Species, Darwin looks back at this Hurrah, attributing the idea that the origin of the species is ‘that mystery of mysteries’ to ‘one of our greatest philosophers’, not to mention Herschel by name. The first mention of the possibility of an evolutionary solution to this problem is in its Ornithological Notebooks, in a note written shortly after leaving Cape Town.

text:
The so-called Meinong self-presentation (Selbstpräsentation) generally counts as a mark of consciousness, of the manifest mental. Experiences, that is, conscious mental occurrences, are able to present themselves. This type of self-presentation is not yet the presentation of self or ego, which was not a problem for Meing. It must also be separated from self-evidence in the sense of infallibility, and from internal perception, self-observation, and higher-order thinking. All manifest mental life is self-presentation, that is, all the experiences of a subject are self-presentation to the subject who experiences. If you're happy it's raining, you can capture your happiness in inner perception, but not through separate mental content. That your mental experiences are presented to you means that they refer to your instant experiences without the intermediary of an additional representation of them. You are able to reflect on your momentary anger or your feeling of shame without needing a kind of mental symbol of your anger or your feeling of shame.
Generally, the objects of experiences are not constituted by their experiences: they are something independent of the mind and not immanent to the consciousness. What is immanent to the mind (consciousness) are one's own experiences. When you have a red representation, for example, you are aware of the red object. In such a representation of red, the red content serves as a kind of sign of something, that is, red, and is in itself a mental piece of the whole representation. To present the red content as the object of an internal reflexive experience, no additional, separate representation is required, with an additional mental content to which the red content corresponds as an object. The red content has the ability to present itself to your mind. In general, reference to one's own experiences does not require the intervention of additional content. Meinong thinks that all internal experiences and all parts of them are capable of being apprehended through self-presentation. Meinong (1910, §20: 138 [103], §43: 264 [190-1]; 1915, §33; 1917, §1) calls it the self-presentation of internal experiences in opposition to the other-presentation [Fremdpräsentation], where the content functions as a sign of something else. Since experiences do not need to be carried within the range of apprehension by their own presentations (and contents), Meinong calls the self-presenting parts of an experience (act component and content component) and all quasi-content self-presenting experience. The quasi-content coincides with the object to be apprehended or intended. When you want something, it may also happen that you judge about your desire. All desire, then, is presented to you without any additional content that interferes. It plays the role of a content, so to speak, hence the name “quasi-content”.
Meinong (1906, 11 and 13; 1910, 43) thinks that attention allows us to do two different things with one and the same experience and content respectively: (1) If we turn our attention to our inner experience, for example, to the red content of a representation of red, this same content serves the inner perception of itself — the red content becomes an intended object and serves the apprehension (perception) of itself. It also says that in this case the content is turned inwards (introversion, [Einwärtswendung]). (2) If the content contributes to a perception or thought of something red, the content refers to something external to the mind — it serves for the apprehension of the co-ordinated outer objects and can therefore be called out (extraversion, [Auswärtswendung]).
label: C2

text:
Twitter is on the verge of its initial public offer and the panties around the world have been in a knot all week because of the lack of diversity of company management, i.e. women. Like the New York Times said last week, the board? All white men. Investors? All men. The executive officers? All men except the attorney general, Vijaya Gadde, who has had the job for five weeks.
Question: Why Is This a Problem?
First, there are not enough women on Twitter or in the world of technology because there are not enough women anywhere.
Some facts: Women make up 6% of the executive heads of the top 100 technology companies, and that has taken years to achieve. Most startups have male boards. In 2012, women held 16.6 per cent of the seats on the Fortune 500 Board of Directors. Colored women accounted for 3.3 per cent of the total. One tenth of the total had no women serving on their boards. Over the past five years, women and minorities have lost ground despite strong evidence that gender parity and diversity of boards have a positive impact on profitability.
Twitter had more than a year to prepare for this IPO: Where are the women? The company's immediate response focused on a shortage of candidates. The technology industry has a well-documented pipeline problem, one of the results of much of the gender stereotypes that reach the education system.
However, companies tend to attract executives from outside their own industries -- sometimes, yes, even women -- when seeking high-level positions and boards of directors. It allows them to pollinate crossed ideas, diversify their experience and innovate. For example, Apple has hired Angela Ahrendts, CEO of Burberry. During his tenure in Burberry, the company doubled its revenues and tripled its share price. Companies redefine the pipeline every day, especially when it comes to profits.
The technology sector is dressed as progressive when it actually shows all the indications of being, at its core, powerfully retrograde. Despite investing in diversity programmes, the management of technology companies is not clearly diverse, and indeed the industry continues to dazzle with incidents in which men joyfully show their biases even implicit. Last month's Titshare debacle -LRB-, click and cry -RRB-, as well as the long-awaited dismissal of Business Insider from CTO Pax Dickinson -LRB-, who for years has been squeezing such sexist, racist tweets as Jesus is violated by a package of n **** s. It's his own fault for dressing up like a whore although -RRB- are two recent examples.
Secondly, sexism is perfectly combined with the distribution of capital.
The September launch by Bryan Goldberg of Bustle, a women-centred website - LRB- news and global politics along with beauty tips -RRB- was a strong case in point. After announcing the site in a post deaf tone, Goldberg was largely mocked by his personal failure to understand, among other things, how ridiculous his claim to be starting the first of his kind for women was. The real problem is not Goldberg's lack of clues, but institutional biases that allowed him to raise $6.5 million when women are much more capable, knowledgeable and experienced can't.
Companies with at least one female founder account for only 13 per cent of those funded. Risk capitalists are less likely to invest in startups if women are involved in their management; investors actively reduce participation in companies that appoint directors. These are particular irony, as new start-ups run by women use 40% less capital to launch them. These facts do not reflect women who lack ideas of trust. They illustrate discrimination, whether conscious or not.
Thirdly, while we think of Twitter as a technology company, it is a media company and part of a broader environment that recently corrected its failure in diversity. Year after year, studies as one of last week's Americas Directors Association, as well as reports from Who Makes the News and the Women's Media Center Status on Women in Media document exactly how distorted media ownership, management and production remain. Only online is improving the situation. But even there the difference is to a large extent increases in the pink neck content oriented towards women.
How can we separate these facts from the property? We can't. As the Federal Communications Commission reported, our media is almost entirely owned and managed by white men.
Finally, what does this have to do with the speech? Everything. Male experiences, interests, expectations and voices, mainly white, inform the way we think, decide how our resources are dispersed and define our rules. The ghetto status of women and minorities in the media and technology, along with the lack of venture capital investments, means that our attempts to express ourselves are limited, distorted and regularly reworked so that what we say is acceptable to a sexist status quo.
And this status quo is not entirely interested in the idea of women as capable and autonomous leaders who could change the rules in an unsettling and risky way. Declaring these facts baldly is not an accusation of white men as individuals. It is a description of the systemic problems that we refuse to face with systemic solutions.
The presence of a carefully selected handful of women in technology, regardless of how determined, capable and prominently visible they are, has done little for decades to alter the composition of management and ownership. Gender diversity on Twitter, as elsewhere, is not a priority because people make reasonable decisions about what they think will be profitable and successful: Twitter is looking for experience and experience within a comfort zone.
This is not a gender issue for me, it is an innovation issue, explained Dick Costolo, CEO of Twitter. Gender issues are not innovation issues only if their gender is dominant and the norm. This reason, and others like her, are exactly the kind of marginalization of 1,000 paper cuts that result in fewer women pursuing technological careers to begin with.
