Probatory research on the psyche was a major concern for Nietzsche throughout his career, and this aspect of his thinking has been correctly assigned to a central importance along a long stretch of reception, from Kaufmann (1950) to recent works by Pippin (2010), Katsafanas (2016), and others. Some of Nietzsche's own programmatic reflections highlight the centrality of this company: perhaps the most famous thing is that it closes an extended treatment of the deficiencies of the previous philosophy (in Part I of Beyond Good and Evil) with a demand
that psychology be recognized again as the queen of science, for whose service and preparation the other sciences exist. For psychology it is once again on the road to fundamental problems. (BGE 23)
In section 2, we saw that the critique of Nietzsche's morality is based primarily on psychological analysis that purports to expose the self-destructive effects of moral attitudes such as guilt and ascetic abnegation, as well as the corrosive mismatch between the official claims of altruistic morality and its underlying motivation in resentment. On the positive side, Nietzsche is equally willing to detail the psychological conditions he thinks would be healthier for both individuals and cultures (see, for example, GS Pref. and 382; BGE 212; IT V, 3 and VIII, 6-7). Thus, Nietzsche's psychology is central to his evaluative agenda and projects as a cultural critic. Apart from his instrumental support for these other projects, Nietzsche pursues psychological research for his own good, and apparently also for the self-knowledge that intrinsically implies (GM III, 9; GS Pref., 3 and 324; but cf. GM Pref., 1). However, despite the widespread appreciation of Nietzsche's psychological insight that began with Freud himself — and despite the centrality of psychology in his philosophical method, his central questions and his evaluative objectives — even the most basic schemes of his substantive psychology remain controversial. The debate begins with the object of psychology itself, the psyche, the self or the soul.
A significant body of Nietzschean texts express extreme skepticism that there is such a thing as a “me,” or “soul,” as well as doubts about the traditional faculties of the soul and the basic abilities they were supposed to exercise (think, want, feel). This passage from the notebooks is typical—“To consent to the fable of ‘unity’, ‘soul’, ‘person’, we have forbidden this: with such hypotheses one only covers the problem” (KSA 37[4] 11: 577)—and there are many, probably hundreds, like him (see D 109; GS 333; BGE 12, 17, 19, 54; GM I, 13; IT III, 5 and VI, 3). At the same time, Nietzsche’s own psychological analyses freely appeal not only to the self, but even to some of the traditional faculties, such as the will, of which he is more skeptical elsewhere: for example, GM II’s “sovereign individual” 1-3 is distinctive in developing a “memory of the will” that supports his ability to keep promises and “vote for himself as the future” (GM I, 13); or again, Nietzsche’s preferred strategy of deploying a multiplicity of perspectives in knowledge (see section 3.2.6) assumes the existence of a cognitive self that deviates from certain impulses and affects, and thus has “the ability to control and dispose of Pro and Con” in support of the broader cognitive project (GM III, 12, see also BGE 284).
This apparent conflict in the texts has fostered contradictory interpretations, with commentators emphasizing the threads in Nietzsche to those who have more philosophical sympathy. For example, strongly naturalistic performers such as Brian Leiter (2002, 2007) and Matthias Risse (2007) focus on Nietzsche's scepticism about pure will and soul to reject any Kantian-style agency source that can stand apart and direct the basic impulses of the person or fundamental nature. Similarly, readers attracted by a Cartesian conception of consciousness as the essence of mental dualism, but repelled by the Cartesian, highlight Nietzsche's emphasis on the importance of the body (GM III, 16; Z I, 4) to suggest that his apparent claims about psychology should be heard as a kind of physiology of impulses that reject mental psychology altogether (for different versions, see Poellner 1995: 216-29, 174; Haar [1993] 1996: 90, et passim). Attacking unity rather than mentality, a group of readers interested in Nietzsche's agonistic conception of politics tends to emphasize his similarly agonistic conception of self, internally contested (Hatab 1995; Acampora 2013). In a diametrically opposed direction to the first three, Sebastian Gardner (2009) insists that, while Nietzsche was sometimes tempted by skepticism about a self that can turn away from inclination requests and control them, his own doctrines on value creation and self-overcoming actually compromise him to something like a Kantian transcendental ego, despite his protests to the contrary.
Nietzsche's actual psychological explanations depend largely on appeals to sub-personal psychological attitudes. As Janaway observes (2009: 52), a large number of different types of attitude enter these accounts (including not only the standard beliefs and desires of current moral psychology, but also “wills”, feelings, sensations, moods, imaginations, memories, evaluations, convictions, and more), but possibly the central attitudes that work most for him are impulses and affects. These types of attitude have been studied intensively in recent works (see esp. Richardson 1996 and Katsafanas 2011b, 2013, 2016; see also Anderson 2012a, Clark and Dudrick 2015). Although much remains controversial, it is useful to think of impulses as provisions for general patterns of activity; they point to activity of the relevant type (e.g. a feed boost, an energy boost), and they also represent some more specific object or occasion of activity in a particular case (e.g. this ice cream, or overcoming a particular problem in the course of writing a document). Affections are emotional states that combine a receptive and felt response to the world with a tendency towards a distinctive pattern of reaction—states such as love, hatred, anger, fear, joy, etc. Typically, the sub-personal attitudes postulated in Nietzsche's psychological explanations represent the world in one way or another. Since it supports Leibniz's thought that representation, not consciousness, is the decisive mark of the mental (GS 354), it is reasonable to treat these attitudes as distinctly psychological, whether they are conscious or not.

It began with a fake scallop, but a menu scandal that has engulfed some of Japan's most prestigious hotels and department stores now threatens to undermine Japan's international cuisine reputation.
Since a luxury hotel chain admitted to lying about the origin of ingredients on their menus, Japanese media have served almost daily revelations of similar transgressions by restaurants run by well-known hotels and department stores.
The frenzy began when the Osaka-based Hankyu-Hanshin hotel chain admitted that it had given false descriptions of dozens of menus at some of its restaurants between 2006 and October 2013, affecting some 78,000 diners.
Among the main minor offenses on the menu was a plate of red salmon caviar that turned out to be the less sumptuous eggs of flying fish.
A televised attempt by the president of the hotel group, Hiroshi Desaki, to limit the damage by announcing a 20% cut for himself and 10% for other executives, failed to appease angry consumers.
Days later, Desaki resigned, admitting that the hotel group had “betrayed our customers,” although he added: “We never intended to deceive them.” One of the hotel's chief chefs later declined a medal of honor to be received from the government.
So far, the company has reimbursed more than 10,000 consumers worth 20 million yen; the bill is expected to reach 110 million yen.
The Japanese version of the horsemeat scandal in the UK has since extended to several household names in the restoration. While, as in the United Kingdom, no one has fallen ill from eating ill-labelled products, the outbreak of anger shows no signs of diminishing. Consumers who thought they had eaten prized Kuruma prawns, for example, were told that they had actually eaten in the much cheaper version of the black tiger.
The first incident went almost unnoticed. The Prince Hotel in Tokyo was forced to confess after a diner complained on a blog that a "callope" dish he had ordered contained a similar but cheaper type of seafood.
The hotel started an investigation and then corrected more than 50 menus in dozens of its restaurants. His report frightened Hankyu-Hanshin and other hoteliers to admit that they, too, had fooled diners who believed they were paying high prices for premium ingredients.
The Okura Hotel chain – whose guests have included Barack Obama – confessed countless sins, including injecting fat beef to make it more juicy and incorrectly describe tomatoes as organic.
“We deeply apologize for betraying our customers’ expectations and trust,” he said in a statement.
The list of fraudulent ingredients continues to grow: orange juice from boxes sold as freshly squeezed; Mont Blanc desserts topped with Korean chestnuts instead of the promised French; chocolate cream bought disguised as homemade; imported meat sold as high-end wagyu.
Even the main government spokesman, Yoshihide Suga, was moved to comment on the scandal. “These incidents have arisen one after the other and this inappropriate labelling has led to a loss of confidence among consumers,” he told reporters. “These are clearly cover-ups.”
The fraudulent menu scandal broke out at the wrong time. Japan was trying to persuade South Korea and other countries to lift the bans on food imports imposed in response to the Fukushima nuclear accident, while UNESCO was considering adding Japanese cuisine to its list of intangible cultural heritage.
A local newspaper published the headline, “The Proud Food Culture of Japan in Tears,” while mass circulation Yomiuri Shimbun said “was amazed by the industry’s lack of morale.”
The newspaper expressed concern that the scandal could “damage the credibility of the brand Japan, products and services, which are praised by foreign countries and tourists for their safety.”
Industry experts said that the global financial crisis in 2008 had forced luxury hotels to reduce costs while trying to court diners with detailed menu descriptions.
“The menu descriptions were created to satisfy consumers’ preference for branded products, and when they could not get the ingredients indicated on the menu, hotels simply used food from different places of origin,” Hiroshi Tomozawa, a hotel and restaurant consultant, told Kyodo News.
Although they count the cost to their reputation, it is unlikely that the hotels and restaurants involved will face legal action. Menus are not covered by the law on agricultural regulations or by a new food labelling law that will enter into force in 2015. The only legal weapon of the authorities is a law prohibiting misleading representations of goods and services.
The industry's biggest nemesis will be the demanding and demanding consumers in Japan. In a 2009 survey conducted by an online restaurant guide, 72% of respondents said that provenance was the most important factor in selecting dishes from a menu, followed by caloric and nutritional details.

Scientists have connected the brains of a couple of animals and allowed them to share sensory information in an important step towards what researchers call the world’s first “organic computer.”
The American team equipped two rats with devices called brain-brain interfaces that allow animals to collaborate on simple tasks to earn rewards, such as a drink of water. In a radical demonstration of technology, scientists used the Internet to connect the brains of two rats separated by thousands of miles, with one in the Duke University researchers' laboratory in Durham, North Carolina, and the other in Natal, Brazil.
Directed by Miguel Nicolelis, a pioneer of devices that allow paralyzed people to control computers and robotic arms with their thoughts, researchers say his latest work can allow multiple brains to connect to share information. “These experiments showed that we have established a sophisticated link of direct communication between brains,” Nicolelis said in a statement. “Basically, we are creating what I call an organic computer.”
Scientists demonstrated for the first time that rats can share and act on each other's sensory information by electrically connecting their brains through small networks of electrodes that reach the motor cortex, the brain region that processes movement.
The rats were trained to press a lever when a light lit above it. When they carried out the task correctly, they got a drink of water. To test the ability of animals to share brain information, they place rats in two separate compartments. Only a compartment had a light that lit above the lever. When the rat pressed the lever, an electronic version of his brain activity was sent directly to the brain of the other rat. In the trials, the second rat responded correctly to imported brain signals 70% of the time by pressing the lever.
Surprisingly, communication between rats was two-way. If the receiving rat failed in the task, the first rat was not rewarded with a drink, and seemed to change her behavior to make the task easier for her partner. In other experiments, rats collaborated in a task that required them to distinguish between narrow and wide openings using their moustaches.
In the final test, scientists connected rats on different continents and transmitted their brain activity back and forth over the Internet. “Even though the animals were on different continents, with the resulting noisy transmission and signal delays, they could still communicate,” said Miguel Pais-Vieira, the first author of the study. “This tells us that we could create a viable network of animal brains distributed in many different places.”
Nicolelis said the team is now working on ways to link the brains of several animals at once to solve more complex tasks. “We can’t even predict what kind of emerging properties would appear when animals start interacting as part of a’brain network’,” he said. “In theory, you could imagine that a combination of brains could provide solutions that individual brains cannot achieve on their own.” The research is published in Scientific Reports.
Anders Sandberg, who studies the ethics of neurotechnologies at the Future of Humanity Institute at Oxford University, said the work was “very important” to help understand how brain information is coded. But the implications of technology and its possible future uses are much broader, Sandberg said. “The main reason we are leading the planet is that we are incredibly good at communication and coordination. Without that, although we are very intelligent animals, we would not dominate the planet.”
“I don’t think there is any risk of survival rats for this,” he added. “There is a big difference between sharing sensory information and being able to plan. I'm not worried about an imminent invasion of rat multiborgs.
Very little is known about how thoughts are coded and how they could be transmitted to another person's brain, so it is not a realistic prospect at any time. And a lot of what is in our minds is what Sandberg calls a “project” of what we could do. “We often don’t want to reveal those drafts; that would be embarrassing and confusing. And many of those drafts have changed before we act. Most of the time I think we would be very grateful not to be in someone else’s head.”

Not only the identity of the man in the parking lot with the crooked spine, but the terrible last moments and humiliating treatment of Richard III's naked body in the hours after his death have been revealed at an extraordinary press conference at the University of Leicester.
There was applause when Richard Buckley, Chief Archeologist in the search for the king’s body, finally announced that the university team was convinced “beyond reasonable doubt” that he had found the last King Plantagenet, bent by the scoliosis of the spine, and further twisted to fit into a hole dug hastily in the church of the grey friars, which was slightly too small to hold his body.
But, by then, it was clear that the evidence was overwhelming, as the scientists who carried out the DNA tests, those who created computer engineering technology to look into and into the bones in extraordinary detail, the genealogists who found a distant descendant with DNA at stake, and the academics who went through contemporary texts for the King's death and burial accounts outlined their findings.
What a morning. What a story,” said Philippa Langley of the Ricardo III Society. She had been driving the project for years, faced with the disbelief of many people, and the search for funds from all over the world when it seemed as if the money would run out before the excavation had begun.
A new tomb has begun to be designed in Leicester Cathedral, just 100 metres from the excavation site, and a ceremony will be held to put it in its new tomb there, probably next year. Leicester Museum Service is working on plans for a new visitor centre in an old school building overlooking the site.
Richard died in Bosworth on August 22, 1485, the last English king to fall into battle, and researchers revealed how for the first time. There was an audible breath when a slide appeared showing the base of his skull cut by a terrible blow, which is believed to be from a halberd, a fearsome medieval battle weapon with a sharp iron axe blade weighing about two kilos, mounted on a wooden pole, which was turned to Richard at very short distance. The blade probably penetrated several centimeters into his brain and, said human bone expert Jo Appleby, he would have been unconscious immediately and dead almost as soon.
The injury seems to confirm contemporary accounts that he died in close combat in the bulk of the battle and without riding, as in Shakespeare’s great desperate cry to him: “A horse! A horse! My kingdom for a horse!” Another sword, which also crossed the bone and entered the brain, would also have been fatal. But many of the other wounds were after death, suggesting a horrifying ritual on the battlefield and when the king's body was brought back to Leicester, when he was stripped, mocked and mutilated.
A terrible injury, a stab wound through the right buttock and pelvis, was certainly after death and could not have occurred when his lower body was protected by armor. He suggests that the story that his naked corpse was brought back sunk on a horse, mocked and abused all the way, is true. Bob Savage, an expert in medieval weapons from the Royal Armouries who helped identify the wounds, said it was probably not a weapon of war, but the kind of sharp knife or dagger any worker could have carried.
Michael Ibsen, the Canadian-born furniture manufacturer, proved to be the descendant of Richard's sister, heard confirmation on Sunday and heard evidence unfolding in scandalized silence. “My head is not clearer now than when I first heard the news,” he said. “Many, many hundreds of people died in that camp that day. He was a king, but only one of the dead. He lived in very violent times and these deaths would not have been quick or beautiful.”
It was Mathew Morris who first discovered the body, in the first hour of the first day of the excavation. I didn't think I found the king. The mechanical excavator was still chewing on the road to the council parking lot, identified by years of research by local historians and the Richard III Society as the likely location of the lost church of grey friars, whose priests courageously claimed the king's body and buried it in a grave excavated hastily, probably still naked, but in a position of honor near the main altar of his church. The bones of the legs that were shown across the earth were covered again.
Ten days later, on September 5, when a new dig showed that Morris had reached the crucial point, he returned with Lin Foxhall, head of the archaeology department, to dig the body. “We did it the usual way, lifting up arms, legs and skull first, and gradually advancing toward the torso – so that’s only when we finally saw the crooked thorn that I thought: ‘My word, I think we have it. '"
As for Langley, Richard was the true king, the last king of the north, a worthy and courageous leader who became the victim of some of the brightest propaganda in history, in the hands of Tudor image creator Shakespeare. There remains the dark shadow of the little princes in the tower, an infamous story even in the days of Richard: the boy Edward V and his brother Richard were declared illegitimate when Richard III claimed the throne, imprisoned in the Tower of London and never again seen alive. Although it is by no means certain that the bones found in the tower centuries later are theirs, there may be more DNA detective work to do there.

It's fun to show how stupid they are and, as I say, the looks on his face, 76-year-old Arpaio said of suspects wanted by DUI, drug charges, missing court dates, and other crimes. Look Arpaio explain his methods

He's going to celebrate a sheriff who frankly scares this community, a sheriff who's seen violent crimes increase significantly in his county, a sheriff who's racially profiling the Latino community, and I doubt the program will reflect that, said Paco Fabian, spokesman for the America's Voice immigrant rights group.

Earlier this year, the mayor of Phoenix wrote a letter to the U.S. Attorney General's office, asking the FBI and the U.S. Department of Justice's civil rights division. to investigate Arpaio's aggressive illegal immigration measures. Mayor Phil Brown wrote that Arpaio's sweeps show a pattern and practice of conduct that includes discriminatory harassment, inadequate stops, searches and arrests.
The letter came after Arpaio, who had already been the target of hundreds of lawsuits, launched a series of what he calls crime suppression patrols in largely Latino neighborhoods. “We are the only ones fighting against the law of smuggling human beings from the state,” Arpaio said.
Fabian said America's Voice is considering pressuring the companies they advertise during the Arpaio show. Either way, the series offers another moment in the spotlight for a man of the law who has never strayed from it.
“I will not brag,” Arpaio said, “but there is no one in the world who does not know who this sheriff is.”

There are several paradoxical elements in Camus' approach to philosophy. In his long-lasting essay, The Myth of Sisyphus, Camus presents a philosophy that disputes philosophy itself. This essay belongs directly to the philosophical tradition of existentialism, but Camus denied being existentialist. Both The Myth of Sisyphus and his other philosophical work, The Rebel, are systematically skeptical of the conclusions about the meaning of life, yet both works objectively assert valid answers to key questions about how to live. Although Camus seemed modest in describing his intellectual ambitions, he had sufficient confidence as a philosopher to articulate not only his own philosophy, but also a critique of religion and a fundamental critique of modernity. While rejecting the very idea of a philosophical system, Camus built his own original building of ideas around the key terms of absurdity and rebellion, with the aim of solving the problems of life or death that motivated him.
The essential paradox that arises in Camus' philosophy refers to his central notion of absurdity. Accepting the Aristotelian idea that philosophy begins with astonishment, Camus argues that human beings cannot escape by asking the question, “What is the meaning of existence?” Camus, however, denies that there is an answer to this question, and rejects any scientific, teleological, metaphysical or man-made purpose that provides an adequate answer. Thus, while accepting that human beings inevitably seek to understand the purpose of life, Camus takes the skeptical position that the natural world, the universe, and human enterprise remain silent about any purpose. Since existence itself makes no sense, we must learn to endure an irresolvable vacuum. This paradoxical situation, then, between our impulse to ask final questions and the impossibility of achieving an adequate answer, is what Camus calls absurd. Camus' philosophy of absurdity explores the consequences of this basic paradox.
Camus' understanding of the absurd is better captured in an image, not in an argument: of Sisyphus who strives to push his rock up the mountain, watching it roll, then descending after the rock to begin everywhere, in an endless cycle. Like Sisyphus, human beings cannot help but ask about the meaning of life, just to see our answers fall again. If we accept this thesis on the essential absurdity of life, and Camus' antiphilosophical approach to philosophical questions, we cannot fail to ask ourselves: What role remains for rational analysis and argument? Does not the philosopher Camus preside over the death of philosophy by answering the question of whether to commit suicide by leaving the realm of discussion and analysis and turning to metaphor to answer it? If life does not have a fundamental purpose or meaning that reason can articulate, we cannot help but wonder why we continue to live and reason. Could Silenus not be right to declare that it would have been better not to be born, or to die as soon as possible? [1] And, as Francisco Jeanson wrote long before his famous criticism of El Rebel that precipitated the break between Camus and Sartre, is not absurd philosophy a contradiction in terms, strictly speaking no philosophy but an anti-rational posture that ends in silence (Jeanson 1947)?
Was Camus really a philosopher? He himself said no, in a famous interview with Jeanine Delpech at Les Nouvelles Littéraires in November 1945, insisting that he “did not believe enough in reason to believe in a system” (Camus 1965, 1427). It was not simply a public position, as we find the same thought in his notebooks of this period: he describes himself as an artist and not as a philosopher because “I think according to words and not according to ideas” (Camus 1995, 113). However, Jean-Paul Sartre immediately saw that Camus was carrying out an important philosophical work, and in his review of The Stranger in relation to Sisyphus, he had no trouble connecting Camus with Pascal, Rousseau and Nietzsche (Sartre 1962). After becoming friends Sartre publicly spoke of his friend’s “philosophy of the absurd,” which distinguished him from his own thinking by accepting the “existentialist” label that Camus rejected. In the years since then, the apparent anti-systematic and non-systematic character of his philosophy has meant that relatively few scholars have appreciated all its depth and complexity. They have more often praised their imposing literary achievements and presented themselves as a political moralist, while pointing out their dubious claims and problematic arguments (see Sherman 2008). A recent major exception to this is Ronald Srigley's Critique of Modernity by Albert Camus (Srigley 2011).
This entry will negotiate Camus' deliberate ambivalence as a philosopher as he discusses his philosophy. It is not just a matter of giving a philosophical reading of this playwright, journalist, essayist and novelist, but of taking his philosophical writings seriously, exploring their premises, their evolution, their structure and their coherence. To do so is to see that your writing contains more than a mood and more than sweeping images and affirmations, without support, although it contains many of both. Camus takes his skepticism as far as possible as a form of methodical doubt — that is, part of a presumption of skepticism — until he finds the basis for a non-sceptical conclusion. And it builds a unique philosophical construction, whose premises are often left unmentioned and not always clearly discussed, but developed in different stages throughout its brief life. Camus' philosophy can be read as well as a sustained effort to demonstrate and not just affirm what the absurdity of human existence implies. In the Camus process, he answers the questions posed by The Myth of Sisyphus, "Why shouldn't I kill myself? "and by El Rebel, "Why shouldn't I kill others?"

Thousands of anti-coup protesters marched in towns and cities across Myanmar on Monday, witnesses said, demonstrating for a third day in a row against the removal and detention of elected leader Aung San Suu Kyi a week ago.
The nurses show the greeting of three fingers as they gather in a protest against the military coup and demand the release of the elected leader Aung San Suu Kyi, in Yangon, Myanmar, on February 8, 2021. REUTERS/Stringer
Calls to join the protests and support a campaign of civil disobedience have become increasingly strong and organized since last Monday's coup, which attracted widespread international condemnation.
In Yangon's largest city, a group of saffron monks marched in the vanguard of Monday's protest with workers and students. They flew multicolored Buddhist flags alongside red banners in the color of the Suu Kyi National League for Democracy (NLD), witnesses said.
“Free our leaders, respect our votes, reject the military coup,” a signal said. Other signs say “Save democracy” and “Say No to Dictatorship”. Many protesters wore black.
Protests sweeping the country on Sunday were the largest since the “saffron revolution” led by Buddhist monks in 2007 that helped push for democratic reforms that were overturned by the February 1 coup.
“Marchers from every corner of Yangon, please go out peacefully and join the people’s meeting,” activist Ei Thinzar Maung urged his followers on Facebook, using VPN networks to mobilize protesters despite an attempt by the junta to ban social media.
Thousands marched in the coastal city of Dawei, in the southeast, and in the capital of Kachin State, in the far north, where they were dressed in black.
So far, the meetings have been peaceful, unlike the bloody repressions during the previous widespread protests in 1988 and 2007. A convoy of military trucks was seen passing to Yangon at the end of Sunday, which increases fears that could change.
Reuters has not been able to contact the board to comment on the protests and state television has not mentioned them.
The government lifted a one-day internet ban on the weekend that sparked even more anger in a country fearful of returning to isolation and greater poverty before the transition to democracy began in 2011.
Activists Maung Saungkha and Thet Swe Win posted on their Facebook pages that the police had been searching their homes, but that they were not there and were still free.
In addition to street protests, a campaign of civil disobedience has begun, first with doctors and along with some teachers and other government workers.
“We asked government staff from all departments not to attend work from Monday,” said activist Min Ko Naing, a veteran of the 1988 demonstrations that first highlighted Suu Kyi.
He won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991 for campaigning for democracy, and spent nearly 15 years under house arrest during decades of struggle to end nearly half a century of army rule.
Suu Kyi, 75, has been held incommunicado since Army Chief Min Aung Hlaing took power in the early hours of 1 February.
He faces charges of illegal importation of six walkie-talkies and is detained by the police for investigation until 15 February. His lawyer said he wasn't allowed to see her.
The United Nations Security Council called for the release of Suu Kyi and other detainees last week and the United States is considering targeted sanctions.
“Protestors in Myanmar continue to inspire the world as actions spread across the country,” said United Nations Special Rapporteur on Myanmar Thomas Andrews on Twitter. “Myanmar stands up to release all those who have been arrested and reject the military dictatorship once and for all. We're with you.

Like Franz Rosenzweig (who goes a long way in The Star of Redemption and Understanding of the Sick and Healthy to show that God, man and the world support three fundamentally different and irreducible bases of explanation that have shaped our history), Rosenstock-Huessy was convinced that the attempt of humanism to free itself from all gods (making humanity and/or nature the foundation of reality) was based on the inability to grasp older ideas about the nature of the real and the relationship between reality, language and history. To this important measure, again like Rosenzweig, he argued that language was more fundamental than philosophy or religion and the attempt of philosophy to liberate itself and reduce religion to a deficient type of philosophy was based on its failure to take language, and therefore reality, seriously enough. As a letter to Cynthia Harris would say: ‘Not religion but language compels man to distinguish between this world and the real world, the world as we know it and the genuine, or better known world. The quid of theology is a quid of language, and all our rationalists do not protest against religion, but against speech’ (1943, 162).
But unlike Karl Barth or Paul Tillich, for example, who saw themselves as a philosophy of fusion and theology, Rosenstock-Huessy refused to see himself primarily as a philosopher or theologian, although when the term philosopher was termed by the former ‘social’, he was more willing to accept that designation. [2] His criticisms of theology and philosophy were numerous, varied in content and highly nuanced, and therefore unable to receive a complete treatment here. In general, however, he thought they were both, what he called, ‘second-order activities’, or mind-reflective products in the ‘game’. The philosophical and theological discourse was left behind and depended on the most urgent and creative acts of ‘foundation’, that is, those acts that emerge from the demands of life, that are epochs that make ‘events’ and that are at the source of human institutions and new forms of life, and that cannot be separated from vocabulary, or, more specifically, from the shared names and foci of orientation that connect us through space and time. [3] In the most philosophical of all his works, the first volume of his Soziologie, contrasting the respective limits of theology with philosophy, says that theology is guilty of reducing us to sinners and angels and therefore not adequately account for our being flesh and blood, while philosophers tend to reduce us to objects and things in the dead space of the universe and to "reflect the objective world in their subjective world" (1956, 286). "Religion," he says in the same section, "is unjust against nature and the human spirit (Geist)", while philosophy is blind to "the forces that give time" ("die zeitstiftenden Gewalten"). [4]
Against philosophers and theologians, he saw his task as restoring our tune to the powers embedded in our discourse and institutions so that we could harness the power of past times in order to strengthen our openness to the promise of the future in the present. To this end, while his corpus encompasses numerous disciplines, his main systematic work, rewritten one throughout his life, was his two parts Sociology Im Kreuz der Wirchlichkeit (On the Cross of Reality)—the first volume of which will appear with Transaction in 2017: volume one originally appeared (to use the English title) in 1925 as The Forces of the Community, and then reworked as The Hegemony of Spaces; volume two being The Count Complete of Times. His social philosophy refers to how, when a world implodes or devours them—through what he calls the four social diseases of anarchy, decay, revolution and war (1970a, 11-16)—people can escape the tyranny of the forces that have come to govern the space in which they live by founding a new time that will then open up other space possibilities. For him, then, the key to human freedom is the ability both to found the new and to harness the powers encapsulated in bodies of the past that allow us to live in a present in which we feel blessed by the future. Rosenstock-Huessy repeatedly maintains that philosophy in general is particularly weak to help us in this task and that, ultimately, Rosenstock-Huessy became sociology as "the way to regain our freedom over spaces and through times" (2009,1, 22). Therefore, against the Cartesian cogito, which he saw as the basis of the formulation of the philosophy of modernity, Rosenstock-Huessy replicates with the far more archaic Respondéo etsi mutabor—‘I answer though I will be changed’ (1938, 817-830; 1970b, 17-33). In other words, we are fundamentally receptive creatures—and our creations are shaped by our responses to the weight and thrust of the past, the burdens or joys of the present, or the attraction and call of the future. As Vico, whom Rosenstock-Huessy admired a lot, believes that we are inevitably rooted in history, even though our great revolutions try to tear us out of it, in order to start again and build a much better world, thus opening up new ways of self-being. [5]
The main deficiency of philosophy, for Rosenstock-Huessy, is that it is not sufficiently sensitive to time, speech or history. To a large extent this is because the logic itself is timeless. As it says in ‘The Terms of the Creed’, ‘logic is that spiritual way of life in which the divinity of time is omitted.’ Logic transports us out of time and offers the mind a stable but unreal space. For Rosenstock-Huessy, this search for a stable space is reflected in recurring philosophical elements that favour the implacability of space (or a particular space) over the incessantness of time. The division of things into subject and object of modern philosophy (space configuration) is an example, but it goes back to the ancient ones whose building blocks as themes (from the place moles), ‘categories’ (from kata = ‘down’ and agora = ‘public assembly’, that is. To proclaim in the assembly, the sphericality of reason, and ideas (the same term idea, eidein = ‘see’, referring to something visible to the eye of the mind) all suggest a commitment to the primacy of space (the mental). The same point is made somewhat more elaborate in the first volume of the In the Cross of Reality (2009, 1,307 – 311) where he argues that dialectic thought is triadic, but anything that really happens and manifests itself, that is. appears (erscheint), is at least quadrilateral. [6] It must be something in space and time, and therefore conform to the inner/exterior or subjective/objective matrix of space, as well as to the trajectory and prejective of time. He called this matrix quadruple the cross of reality and is repeatedly applied through his works.
While Rosenstock-Huessy provided a series of arguments against philosophers who want to make more of reason and less of the language, time and history than their due, and although he preferred to be classified as a sociologist, he can also be seen as a social philosopher who argued the philosophical need for the fusion of history, linguistics, anthropology, sociology and religion. Franz Rosenzweig certainly saw Rosenstock-Huessy in this light, and once said to him: ‘You have never... been anything to me but a ‘philosopher’’ (1969, 82). [7] In this regard it belongs to that long line of critics of philosophy ranging from the ancients to the modern and comic poets to religious thinkers, from Aristotle to Lucian, to Rabelais, from Tatian to Tertullian to Luther, and Pascal to Marx and Nietzsche. All these critics have provided criticisms of philosophy that have ended, in different ways, and at different times, transforming the direction and content of philosophy.

Foot was one of the pioneers of writing on questions of applied ethics, the treatment of abortion and euthanasia. For reasons only explicit in later writings, Foot rejects consistent views of value, including utilitarianism. Charity, for its part, demands that we help others, but we cannot do so at the expense of violating the rights to non-interference or negative rights. As Foot says, “to the extent that man’s charity is limited only by his righteousness... he is no less than perfect in charity” (Md 57). But what does justice demand? For Foot, answering this question depends on finding out the scope of our moral rights, and this is a project she carried out reflecting on several thought experiments, some of which have entered popular culture.
Consider a couple of scenarios called Rescue I and Rescue II (MD 80). In both cases, we are driving a jeep along a shore of the sea and we have the opportunity to save several configurations of stranded people from an incoming tide. In the first case, we're about to save one person from the tide, and detect another five we can save, but we can't save both. In Rescue II, we can save five, but to reach them, for some reason we would have to run over a person, killing him. Pie believes that there is a morally significant difference between these cases. She thinks it is inadmissible to save the five in Rescue II; while it is permissible (at least) to save the five in Rescue I. In Foot's view, the significant difference lies in the fact that in Rescue II, saving all five would require initiating a causal sequence that kills one. In Rescue I, on the contrary, saving the five is permissible because in this scenario we allow a mortal causal sequence that we do not initiate to follow its course. This does not mean that all instances of allowing mortal causal sequences to run their course are permissible, or that the distinction between doing and allowing always makes a difference in the moral state of an action. The assertion is only that distinction sometimes makes a significant moral difference, as it does in this couple of cases. According to Foot, “more is needed to justify interference than to justify the retention of goods and services” (MD 83). At least, this means that it is inadmissible to kill one person to save another. [5] This distinction refers to the distinction between negative rights, rights to non-interference, versus positive rights, which oblige others to provide some service. Negative rights would oblige others not to initiate a fatal causal sequence, and positive rights may result in an obligation to prevent a fatal causal sequence from continuing. Foot's claim is that negative rights have more weight than positive rights.
In “The Problem of Abortion and the Doctrine of the Double Effect”, (1967) Foot raises a related case that has been the subject of much further discussion: an uncontrolled cart is directed towards five people who will be killed by the collision, but could be directed to a track where there is only one person (VV 23). Intuitively, it seems permissible to turn the cart to hit and kill a person, but the problem is that it does not seem permissible to kill one to save five in cases like Rescue II. Why, Foot asks, can't we argue for the permissibility of killing one to save five in those cases by appealing to the Trolley case? As we have seen, Foot argues that negative rights are generally stronger than positive rights. In Rescue II, we must violate someone's negative rights in order to satisfy the positive rights of others, and this is unacceptable because negative rights have priority over positive rights that are not offset by the need for assistance of five people. In Trolley, on the contrary, we are not violating negative rights to comply with positive rights; the situation faces the negative rights of the five against the negative rights of one, and both options involve violating someone's negative rights. In such a case, it seems clearly preferable to minimise the violation of negative rights by turning the car (VV 27).
In Foot's view, we are generally not allowed to do anything that interferes with someone's negative rights, for example, we cannot steal someone's property; however, we may not be required to actively secure their possession, that is, we may allow them to lose their property. In this way, Foot defends a principle that establishes a moral distinction between doing and allowing; it also defends a version of the doctrine of double effect, which states that it is sometimes permissible to produce a result that is foreseen as a result of one's action, but which does not pretend that it is inadmissible to aim as a means or as an end (MD 91). Pie believes that this principle is necessary because the principle of making and allowing does not cover some morally significant distinctions. For example, consider a case where we own a certain drug, but only enough to cure a person who suffers from a fatal condition, or to save five others who are suffering from a milder, though still fatal, disease. In such a circumstance, we can allow the medication to be given to the five who are suffering in the mildest form of the disease. If we could save the six, we'd probably do it. Clearly, we have no intention of one's death, even though we foresee it as a consequence of our actions. On the other hand, it is not permissible to retain a life-saving drug to use its organs to save the lives of the other five after they die. In this case, one's death is an essential means to the attainment of the end and therefore his death is strictly intentional. Although in such a case I would be allowing someone to die instead of perpetrating a murder by my own agency, what I do is inadmissible. Only the doctrine of double effect captures the distinction between these cases, according to Foot's point of view. However, the doctrine of double effect cannot be upheld alone, according to Foot; we need both the principle of double effect and the principle of doing and allowing. After all, sometimes we can initiate damage impermissibly with indirect intent. She gives the example of the evil traders who knowingly sell the poisoned oil: their intention is not to harm their customers, but only to make profits, however, they are clearly starting a harmful causal sequence.
These principles systematize the non-consequential ‘common moral’, and Foot puts these principles into use in its treatment of abortion and euthanasia. Pie is skeptical of any attempt to resolve the debate on abortion without resolving the question of whether and when the fetus has moral rights, and she considers it an intractable issue (MD 87). In this view, she takes sides against Judith Jarvis Thomson, who argued that some abortions are permissible even if we allow for the argument that the fetus has a complete moral status. Thomson argues by analogy: Imagine that while we sleep a group of music lovers stealthily unite us to a famous violinist who is suffering from a disease, and we can keep him alive for about nine months, as he is convalescent (Thomson 1971: 48). The question is: can we separate the violinist, causing his death? Thomson argues that we can, since our negative rights have been violated and no one has the right to use someone else's body, even to save their own life. Of course, the analogy here is limited to cases of non-consensual impregnation, such as those resulting from the violation.
Foot argues that the analogy has a devastating flaw. There is a morally significant difference between unhooking someone from one's own body, which does not imply initiating a fatal causal sequence, since the person was already in the grip of a fatal condition before being hooked on us, and abortion, which does initiate a fatal sequence. Foot thinks this makes abortion look like Rescue II, while the violinist's unhook is like Rescue I. As Foot says,
the fetus is not in danger because it is in the womb of its mother; it simply depends on it in the way the children depend on their parents for food. (MD 87)
Rejecting Thomson's point of view, which attempts to show that some cases of abortion are permissible even if the fetus is fully a moral person, Foot's considered position on abortion is that it revolves precisely on the question Thomson wishes to put aside. On this subject, she surprisingly abandons her commitment to objectivity, stating that it is a matter for a community to decide whether to count the fetus as a human being (MD 7).
Perhaps Foot’s most penetrating article on applied ethics is his “Eutanasia” (1977). Foot defines euthanasia as a murder that is for the good of the individual in question, and she asks if such an act can be permissible. A central question here is whether it can be good for an individual to be deprived of his life, and therefore one of Foot's central purposes is to determine what kind of good life is for a person. She rejects the narrow hedonistic view that the value of life is determined by the balance of pleasure versus the pain it promises. In his opinion, life often remains a good for someone who is suffering and who is likely to continue in such a state. However, he also argues that simply being alive without suffering is not a good (VV 42). What has value, in his view, is ordinary human life which contains at least a minimum of “basic human goods”, including:
that a man is not driven to work far beyond his ability; that he has the support of a family or community; that he can more or less satisfy his hunger; that he has hope for the future; that he can rest at night. (ibid.)
In the absence of such minimum goods, he argues that life is not a good for a person.
The question of the permissibility of euthanasia to the foot, then, concerns questions of justice and charity (VV 44). In his view, even if it seems better that someone does not survive, we must respect that person’s rights. Therefore, in his opinion, involuntary active euthanasia can never be permissible. On the other hand, the right to assistance in keeping alive requires the charity of others and not justice, except in the case of a doctor who has a contractual duty to help us stay alive. However, even in the case of a doctor, where assistance is a matter of justice, our claim to such assistance is limited by the claims of others, as well as by respect for our well-being. That is, there may come a time when such ‘assistance’ as a doctor can offer to prolong a patient’s life does not really confer any benefit, and in such a case, it is not contrary to justice or charity that the doctor holds back treatment; as Foot points out, such cases of passive euthanasia are already widely practiced (VV 56). However, he argues that it may be justifiable not to prolong the life of someone who wants to live, giving the example of a dying soldier whose life could be prolonged with a certain drug, but who would therefore face death by starvation. According to Foot, passive non-voluntary euthanasia is permissible in such a case.
Of course, the central controversy here is whether active voluntary euthanasia is permissible. He dismisses James Rachels' claim that if we allow passive euthanasia, then the only consistent position is to allow active euthanasia in similar circumstances because it is "more human" than passive euthanasia (Rachels 1975). Foot argues by analogy that it may be ‘more human’ to deprive someone of the property that is bringing him evil, but removing it would be contrary to justice (VV 50). On the other hand, someone can give permission for the destruction of their property, and as Foot concludes,
If someone gives you permission to destroy your property you can no longer say that you have no right to do so, and I don't see why it shouldn't be the same with taking a man's life. (VV 53)
However, Foot admits that the moral question is not fully resolved by the question of rights, so it does not follow that there is no moral objection to doing something because it would not imply any violation of rights. So it's about whether it would be good for the person to die and, therefore, if it would be contrary to charity. This rules out cases where death is desired by someone who faces a life of dependence because they are concerned about being a burden to others. In such circumstances, being other things the same, death would not be for the good of the person. Foot also has concerns about the practice of euthanasia that make her hesitate to suggest that the practice should be more widely legalized.

text: Unfortunately, Nietzsche’s ideas about the nature of value creation and his suggestions about what specific values should be “created” have not seemed so clear to readers as his negative criticism of traditional values. (The disparity is often marked in literature by doubts as to whether Nietzsche has a “positive” ethic to offer.) There is something in this reaction: Nietzsche's criticism has a clear goal and develops on an extended scale, while his suggestions about alternative values may seem scattered or telegraphic. That said, it is not as if Nietzsche is the least shy about making valuedly charged claims, including the “positive ones.” To a certain extent, disappointment among commentators in search of “positive views” arises from our search for the wrong things, for example, seeking a systematically organized axiological theory when Nietzsche himself is skeptical of any such project, or waiting for any “positive” ethics to accommodate certain “moral intuitions” that Nietzsche is more inclined to challenge than to save. This section examines some territories that Nietzsche covers under the heading “Creation of value”. After mentioning different options to understand the nature of such “creation,” explore some of the values it promotes.

Prove that we represent objects or an objective world has a key role in most versions of this reading. In Strawson's interpretation, for example, "the fact that my experience is of a unified objective world is a necessary consequence of the fact that only under this condition could I be aware of my diverse experiences as one and all of mine" (1966: 94). Some interpreters disagree; Karl Ameriks, for example, argues that Strawson's conception of the Deduction is motivated by the desire to see it as a sign that the skeptic of the outside world is wrong, while, in fact, refuting this type of skeptic is not one of Kant's objectives for this argument (Ameriks 1978; also Allais 2011, 2015). Patricia Kitcher (2011: 115–18) argues against the unique premise on the interpretation of self-consciousness on historical and textual bases.
An incontrovertible role of §17 is to provide a characterization of an object, or more to the point, of a representation of an object, which facilitates a challenge to associationism by smoking. Kant's proposal is that an object is "in whose concept a multiplicity of a certain intuition unites" (B137). Here the "object" should be read in the broad sense of the objective characteristic of reality, a characteristic whose existence and nature are independent of how it is perceived (B 142; Bird 1962/1973 130-31; Strawson 1966: 98–104; Guyer 1987: 11–24). Allison is an advocate of the view that §17 contains not only this challenge to Hume, but also an attempt to demonstrate that we represent objects on the basis of the conclusions on self-awareness set out in §16. This interpretation is a component of Allison's broader view of Deduction-B, according to which Kant demonstrates that the unity of perception implies that we represent objects, and, conversely, that our representative objects imply the necessary unity of perception (Allison 1983: 144ff; 2015: 352-55). In fact, the crucial assertion for Allison's interpretation is that the unity of perception is not only a necessary condition but also sufficient for our representation of objects. This is called the reciprocity thesis. Other commentators, including Richard Aquila (1989: 159), Howell (1992: 227-8) and Schulting (2012a) agree that Deduction-B presents the thesis of reciprocity and an attempt to establish its truth, while Ameriks (1978) disagrees. Because of the kind of favors of Ameriks, the unity of perception, and more precisely, the synthesis that explains our consciousness of the identity of the subject, is only a necessary condition for the representation of objects (cf. Allais 2011).
Allison's interpretation is particularly attractive because it promises influence against the skeptic who denies that we represent objects, and also because this influence is generated by premises about the self-consciousness that this skeptic is likely to accept. However, there are textual and charitable reasons to resist this reading (Ameriks 1978, Pereboom 1995; Patricia Kitcher 2011: 115–60; Vinci 2014: 193–94). First, in 18–20 Kant makes significant assumptions about the characteristics of our representations of objects that exceed anything he has defended in §17 or earlier. In particular, §18 assumes that our representations of objects manifest a certain type of necessity and universality, and this is not intended to establish in §17 or earlier. On the other hand, the summary of the previous steps of Deduction B in §20 Kant does not include the premises of 15-16. What we actually find in §20 indicates that Kant intends, with some help from §13, to constitute a unique and autonomous argument that does not depend on the conclusions on self-awareness developed in §15-16.

text:
The Three Friends -- or, as they are more formally known, the leaders of the United States, Canada and Mexico -- announced on Wednesday an agreement to work on a plan to streamline trade and travel, including border controls between countries.
US President Barack Obama, Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper and Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto agreed to simplify border controls to facilitate the movement of people through the establishment of a trusted traveler program.
They also spent a lot of time during the American Leaders Summit discussing efforts to negotiate a new trade agreement with Pacific nations, they said at a joint press conference after the summit in Toluca, Mexico.
Obama has called on the Congressional commercial authority to accelerate the search for the so-called Trans-Pacific Partnership, a massive free trade zone.
But members of their own party, including House minority leader Nancy Pelosi and Senate majority leader Harry Reid, have expressed strong opposition to such authority.
Republicans took advantage of Vice President Joe Biden's remarks at last week's Democratic retreat in Maryland. There, it was heard that the granting of the trade issue was rapidly becoming a source of frustration within the party, especially among the working groups that are key to the mid-term reviews next fall.
The jobs they care about most are the Democrats in Congress, not the families across the country willing to join the ranks of the employees, said Senate minority leader Mitch McConnell in a statement.
Senior Obama administration officials denied reports of Biden's comments as coming from second-hand accounts. But, they added, the White House remains firmly committed to its business agenda.
One official said it would not be in the interest of the United States to put this in the background.
White House spokesman Jay Carney insists that differences between Democrats on trade issues go back to several administrations.
The different opinions on these issues are not new, and the fact that there are different opinions within both sides is not new, Carney said on Tuesday.
Another area of friendly disagreement for the Three Friends is the Obama administration's handling of the Keystone XL pipeline.
Canadian officials have been impatient with the long process of approval in the United States for the contested project, which would transport oil from Alberta to the Gulf of Mexico.
While a recent State Department environmental impact study seemed to welcome the prospects for approval, senior management officials indicated that Harper is unlikely to receive the news that many in his nation want to hear during the summit.
I think what President Obama will do is explain where we are in the Keystone pipeline review, and indicate that, of course, we will let our Canadian friends know when we have reached a decision, said a senior administration official.
The Keystone project has also divided the Democrats, that is, the environmentalists who see the pipeline as a symbolic battle in the biggest struggle for efforts to address climate change.
While in Mexico, Obama faced another delicate act of balance on the issue of immigration reform.
The plight of undocumented immigrants in the United States, in particular the considerable number of migrants who crossed the border from Mexico, is a major political problem south of the Rio Grande.
Latino special interest groups, a central district of the Democratic Party, have criticized the administration for its aggressive deportation policy as it struggles to find a long-term solution to the immigration problem.
Senior administration officials told journalists last week that Obama remains committed to comprehensive immigration reform that includes a path to citizenship for undocumented workers.
But that legislative priority has reached a blockade in Congress, where Republican leaders have indicated that there is little hope for a breakthrough this year before the partial exams.
Regarding immigration, I think President Peña Nieto has a very good understanding, frankly, of the state of play in the United States, said a senior administration official.
label: C2

The shares of GameStop and other companies caught in the recent social media-driven commercial frenzy bounced off Friday, after the online runner Robinhood lifted all the tax purchase curbs at the top of the battle between amateur investors and Wall Street hedge funds.
The video game retailer, the initial trigger for the slugfest market after gaining popularity on the social media platform of Reddit WallStreetBets, closed 19.20% at $63.77 after hitting a maximum session of $95, although the wild spins seen in the last two weeks seemed to be relaxing.
“The influence of WallStreetBets is decreasing to some extent because there are many people who burned,” said Dennis Dick, head of the market structure and owner of Bright Trading LLC in Las Vegas.
“From a short salesman’s point of view, a week and a half ago I got scared to cut any small hat because I was worried that WallStreetBets could squeeze me in it,” Dick said. “I’m not scared anymore; I kind of went back to normal trade, so I can say that WallStreetBets’ influence isn’t as strong as it was last week.”
Robinhood, among the commission-free online brokers accredited to fuel operations, said by the end of Thursday he had removed all purchase restrictions imposed due to an increase in the deposit requirements of the clearing house last week.
With many of the shares involved in the so-called “Rally of Reddit” collapsing this week, hedge funds with bottom positions at GameStop earned $3.6 billion in profits compared to $12.5 billion losses in January, Ortex’s financial analysis firm said on Friday.
The fall of the fall is reduced in what goes this year for GameStop shorts to $8.73 billion in realized and unrealized losses until Friday morning, according to the S3 Partners analysis firm.
The number of GameStop shares is further reduced -- S3 Partners
Analysts noted an impressive debut in Hong Kong for Kuaishou Technology, backed by Tencent, as more evidence of the growing power of small investors, but at the WallStreetBets forum at the heart of last week's action there were few signs of consensus around new stock market favorites.
“The speculation is fading now, but that doesn’t mean I can’t come back within a month or two months,” said Peter Cardillo, chief market economist at Spartan Capital Securities in New York.
“Many small investors may have burned, so it will take time to heal that wound,” Cardillo said. “It may not appear in the actions that have already been attacked, but it could happen in other companies and perhaps on a wider scale.”
Other actions that have seen sharp declines as their fortunes are invested in the social media phenomenon, such as Koss Corp and Blackberry's shares on the U.S. list closed higher on Friday, while others like Bed, Bath & Beyond saw their price fall slowly.
Janet Yellen, U.S. Treasury Secretary, met with senior officials on Thursday to discuss volatility, and sources told Reuters that securities regulators were examining all aspects of the rally and all parties involved.
GameStop shares have fallen to just $51.09 after climbing to $483 last week, but it continues to rise by about 22% from the levels at the start of the rally in mid-January. The AMC Entertainment film operator's shares have been reduced by more than half since a closing peak of $19.90 and closed 3.67% on Friday.
The shares of the insurance company Clover Health, which on Thursday became the first company to be targeted for a short sales report in weeks, increased by 5.7% due to a late rally provoked by comments by risk capitalist sponsor Chamath Palihapitiya in response. The company said earlier on Friday that it had received a letter from the Securities and Exchange Commission after the report published by Hindenburg Research.
Meanwhile, at WallStreetBets, participants continued to urge investors to continue with GameStop.
“GME YOLO/PHOMO my second mortgage. 35k to 5 thousand to 300k. I won’t sell!” reads a post from a participant with the u/Rhollow1 handle.

text:
According to Kant, what is unique about the motivation for duty is that it consists of pure respect for moral law. What naturally comes to mind is this: Duties are rules or laws of some kind combined with some kind of restriction or incentive felt in our choices, whether from external coercion by others or from our own powers of reason. For example, the statutes of a club set out the duties of its officers and impose them with sanctions. Municipal and state laws establish the duties of citizens and enforce them with coercive legal power. Therefore, if we do something because it is our “civic” duty, or our “boy scout” or “good American” duty, our motivation is respect for the code that does our duty. To think that we are obliged to do our duty is simply to respect, as such, certain laws that belong to us.
As intuitive as it is, this cannot be all Kant's meaning. First of all, as with the Jim Crow laws of the ancient South and the Nuremberg laws of Nazi Germany, the laws to which this type of “duty actions” conform can be morally despicable. Respect for those laws could hardly be considered valuable. For another, our motive for conforming our actions to civic and other laws is rarely unconditional respect. We also have an eye to do our part in maintaining civil or social order, in punishing or losing prestige and reputation in violating such laws, and other results of legal behavior. In fact, we respect these laws to the extent, but only to the extent, that they do not violate values, laws or principles that we have more expensive. However, Kant thinks that, in acting from duty, we are not at all motivated by a prospective result or some other extrinsic characteristic of our conduct, except to the extent that these are requirements of duty itself. We are motivated by the mere conformity of our will to the law as such.
Acting out of respect for moral law, in Kant's opinion, is being moved to act by the recognition that moral law is a supremely authoritative norm that unites us and to experience a kind of feeling, which is similar to fear and fear, when we recognize moral law as the source of moral requirements. Humans inevitably have respect for moral law although it does not always move us and although we do not always comply with the moral norms that we recognize as authoritarian.
Kant's account of the content of moral requirements and the nature of moral reasoning is based on his analysis of the unique force that moral considerations have as reasons to act. The strength of moral requirements as reasons is that we cannot ignore them no matter how circumstances might conspire against any other consideration. The basic moral requirements retain their motivational force under any circumstances, have universal validity. Therefore, anything else that can be said about basic moral requirements, its content is universal. Only a universal law could be the content of a requirement that has the force of right morality. This leads Kant to a preliminary formulation of the IQ: “I should never act but in such a way that I too could want my maxim to become universal law” (G 4:402). This is the principle that motivates good will, and that Kant regards as the fundamental principle of all morality.

Hyundai Motor Co of South Korea said on Monday that it is not now in talks with Apple Inc in autonomous electric cars, just a month after it confirmed the initial talks with the technology giant, sending the automaker's shares slip.
Slideshow ( 3 images )
Eliminating $2.1 billion from its market value, Hyundai's shares plummeted by 4.2% before 0330 GMT. Shares in its subsidiary Kia Corp, which had been tipped in local media reports as Apple's likely operating partner, fell 12% - a $4.3 billion hit.
The announcement puts the curtain in weeks of internal divisions within Hyundai Motor Co Group - father of both car manufacturers - on the potential tie, with some executives raising concerns about becoming a contract maker for the US tech giant.
“We are receiving requests for cooperation in the joint development of autonomous electric vehicles from several companies, but they are at an early stage and nothing has been decided,” said car manufacturers on Monday, in compliance with securities market rules that require regular updates to investors in relation to market rumors.
“We are not having discussions with Apple about the development of autonomous vehicles.”
Kia's shares had jumped 61% after Hyundai seemed to confirm a local media report in early January that Apple and Hyundai were in discussions to develop electric motor vehicles by 2027 and develop batteries in U.S. factories operated by Hyundai or Kia.
“Apple and Hyundai are under discussion, but as it is in the initial stage, nothing has been decided,” said Hyundai, before publishing subsequent statements that removed all Apple mentions, but said Hyundai was receiving requests for cooperation from electric cars from parties that it did not identify.
Reuters reported in December that Apple was moving forward with autonomous automotive technology and was aiming to produce a passenger vehicle that could include its own advanced battery technology as early as 2024.
Apple, known for keeping product plans under tight bandages, has never recognized discussions with the car manufacturer about vehicle construction, and was not immediately available for comments outside business hours in the United States.
Analysts said the talks could have collapsed due to leaks from the media partnership plan, or due to Apple's possible insistence that Hyundai's role in any tie would be that of a team manufacturer, rather than a strategic partner.
“With numerous news reports on discussions between the two companies, which should have concluded confidentiality agreements, it would have been uncomfortable,” said Kwon Soon-woo, an analyst at SK Securities.
Kevin Yoo, an analyst at eBEST Investment & Securities, said: “It seems clear that Hyundai Motor Group has not been too happy to deal with Apple... They made it clear that they don’t want to be treated as Apple’s supplier or manufacturer.”
