text:
In houses and cafes all over the country, a cup of tea, baked beans in toast and fish and chips have played a key role in the British gastronomic experience. However, the scope of a change of taste over generations has been captured in a recent data set published in the National Food Survey, which was created in 1940 by the government after concerns about health and access to food.
Despite the apparent British love of tea, consumption has declined by more than half since the 1970s, from 68g of tea per person per week to only 25g. With a bag of tea or loose tea weighing about 3g, that means the British are drinking on average only eight cups of tea a week today, starting from 23 cups in 1974. And while tea is still the drunkest hot drink in the UK, households spend more on coffee.
The data, published by the Department of Environment, Food and Rural Affairs as part of its “open data” plan, are for 150,000 households that participated in the survey between 1974 and 2000, combined with information from 2000 to 2014. It shows some movements towards healthier diets in recent decades, with changes to low-calorie soft drinks, from whole milk to skimmed milk and increasing consumption of fresh fruit. But, the weekly consumption of chips, pizza, chips and ready meals has skyrocketed.
There has also been a dramatic shift from white to brown, whole flour and other bread, but figures suggest that the amount people are eating has fallen from 25 to 15 slices a week in the last four decades, based on a slice of 40g of a medium sliced bread. The consumption of beans baked in salsa has decreased by a fifth despite an increase in other types of food of convenience, particularly Italian dishes. Adults in the UK now eat an average of 75g of pizza each week, compared to none in 1974, while pasta consumption has nearly tripled over the same period.
Fresh potatoes are also becoming less essential, with a 67% decrease since 1974, when adults ate the equivalent of 188g a day. Other vegetables such as cucumbers, zucchini, eggplants and mushrooms have gained space on the table. The consumption of carry-on food has almost doubled since 1974, from 80g per person per week to 150g. About 33g of this amount is fries and 56g is meat, with kebabs (10g), chicken (7g), hamburgers (5g) and “meat-based foods” (32g) particularly popular.
Some trends suggest that the British are becoming more prudent in what they put in their dishes, with the average consumption of fruits, both fresh and processed, increasing by 50% since 1974. In 2014, UK adults ate an average of 157g of fruit per day, equivalent to nearly two portions of the government's five-day recommendation. Bananas have been the most popular fruit in the UK since 1996, reaching 221g per adult per week in 2014, well above apples (131g) and oranges (48g). Low-calorie soft drinks accounted for half of all soft drinks consumed in 2014 for the first time.
Other social changes arise from the survey, with questions about the possession of chickens and getting their own eggs to fall in 1991 and a somewhat late end in the same year to ask the “housewife” to fill out the questionnaire. The British are spending a lower proportion of the pay on food today – 11%, compared to 24% in 1974.
Elizabeth Truss, United Kingdom Environment Secretary, said: “Food is the heart and soul of our society and this data shows not only what we were eating 40 years ago, but how a change in culture has led to a food revolution. Buyers are more connected to where their food comes from than ever before, the Internet has brought quality products to our doors with the click of a button, pop-up restaurants are showing the latest trends and exciting global cuisines are now as common as fish and chips.”
“By opening this data, we can look beyond what, where or how previous generations were eating and point out the moments that changed our habits forever. We have only scratched the surface of what the National Food Survey can tell us and, from local food maps and school projects to the prediction of new food trends, I hope to see how this data can be used to learn more about our past and grow our world’s leading food and agricultural industry in the future.”
label: C2

text:
The health warnings covering almost two thirds of cigarette packages and the ban on menthol cigarettes across the EU have come a little closer after a vote in the European Parliament. On the other hand, Parliament considers that most e-cigarettes, which are increasingly popular as alternatives to tobacco products, do not need to be regulated in the same way as medicines.
Health officials and the e-cigarette industry in Britain are trying to clarify what this means, for example, if rapidly expanding market companies face the same sponsorship and promotion bans at sporting events as tobacco companies.
The Department of Health shall not comment on the issue of publicity until officials have studied the decisions of Members of the European Parliament. But, in a statement, the DH said: “We are very happy to see the progress towards tougher action on tobacco, with controls at European level banning aromatized cigarettes and the introduction of stricter rules on pre-package health warnings. “However, we are disappointed by the decision to reject the proposal to regulate nicotine-containing products, including e-cigarettes, as medicines. We believe that these products should be regulated as medicines and we will continue to raise this point during further negotiations.
“The figures show that smoking levels in England are the lowest since registration began – 19.5% – but we are determined to further reduce smoking rates and believe this important step will help.”
The British e-cigarette industry, which welcomed Parliament’s vote, said it was already in discussions with the Advertising Standards Authority, but added that it would not be “sensitive, proportionate, reasonable or useful” to ban any advertising.
MEPs decided that e-cigarettes should only be regulated as medical products if manufacturers claimed that they could prevent smoking, a decision criticized by the government's main drug regulator.
They want to put the products, used by an estimated 1.3 million people in Britain by 2014, on the same legal basis as gums, patches and mouth sprays intended to help smokers quit smoking, but industry says the costly licensing process would help force tobacco alternatives from shelves.
MEPs voted in favour of putting health warnings on 65% of each pack of cigarettes, instead of 75% proposed. At present, warnings cover at least 30 per cent at the front and 40 per cent at the back. The United Kingdom Government has delayed the decision to follow Australia through the introduction of standard packaging until there is evidence that such measures reduce tobacco consumption.
The votes of Members of the European Parliament at the first reading of the draft tobacco directive, which could become law in 2014, will be followed by negotiations with the EU Council of Ministers.
The Regulatory Authority for Medicines and Health Products had already invited manufacturers to cooperate by opting for voluntary regulation in June 2013 ahead of what it still expects to be mandatory across Europe. “The legislative process has not yet been completed and there will be new negotiations. The UK continues to believe that the medical regulation of CPNs is the best way to offer a benefit to public health,” said a spokesperson.
Linda McAvan, Yorkshire Labour MEP and Humber and spokesperson for the Socialists and Democrats Group in Parliament on tobacco, said: “We know that it is children, not adults, who start smoking. And, despite the downward trend in most Member States of adult smokers, World Health Organisation figures show worrying upward trends in some of our Member States of young smokers.
“We need to stop tobacco companies targeting young people with a variety of gymmicky products and we need to make sure that cigarette packs contain effective warnings.”
Martin Callanan, the Conservative MEP for northeastern England, said: “It would have been madness to force e-cigs to leave the shelves. These are products that have helped countless people stop smoking more harmful cigarettes and yet some MEPs wanted them to be more difficult to make than ordinary tobacco."
Katherine Devlin, president of ECITA, the e-cigarette industry association, said that “the really important decision” of MEPs not to support the regulation of medicines meant that that was already out of the question.
Parliament also called on the Commission to draw up an action plan for the protection of consumers against the risks posed by tobacco consumption in the internal market.
label: C2

text:
An important international line with broad implications for global drug policy has erupted over the right of indigenous Indian tribes in Bolivia to chew coca leaves, the main ingredient of cocaine. Bolivia had obtained a special exemption from the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs of 1961, a framework governing international drug policy, allowing its indigenous peoples to chew on leaves.
Bolivia had argued that the Convention opposed its new Constitution, adopted in 2009, which obliges it to "protect native and ancestral coca as cultural heritage" and maintains that coca "in its natural state...is not a narcotic."
South American Indians have chewed coca leaves for centuries. The leaves supposedly provide energy and are said to have medicinal qualities. Supporters of Bolivia's position praised her for defending the rights of indigenous peoples. “The Bolivian movement is inspiring and innovative,” said Danny Kushlick, Head of Foreign Affairs of the Drug Policy Transformation Foundation, which promotes drug liberalization. “It shows that any country that has had enough of the war on drugs can change the terms of its commitment to UN conventions.”
However, the UN International Narcotics Control Board (INCB), which oversees the implementation of the world drug treaties, has accused Bolivia of threatening the integrity of the international drug control regime. Several countries – including the United Kingdom, the United States, Italy, Sweden, the Netherlands and Russia – opposed the demands of Bolivia.
The UK’s submission to the UN, which oversees the convention, said that it “recognizes and respects the cultural importance of coca leaf in Bolivia,” but adds: “The UK is... concerned that the reserve can lead to increases in coca production and – crucially – the amount of coca diverted to the cocaine trade. As such, the reservation would weaken international law in terms of the global effort to deal with the drug trade and could weaken the international community’s response to that trade.”
The right of indigenous communities in the Andean region of South America to chew coca leaf was eliminated in 1964 when Bolivia was under a dictatorship and acceded to the convention. But, under the terms of the agreement, Bolivia received 25 years to implement the ban. This expired in 1989 and since then the issue has been the subject of controversy.
In 2011, Bolivia – whose president, Evo Morales, is a former coca producer – formally notified the UN of its withdrawal from the convention. On Friday he joined the convention again, but with an exemption from the ban on chewing coca leaves.
This measure is the first of its kind in the history of the United Nations drug control treaties and has raised concerns that other countries may request amendments. The Russian government has argued that the bill will lead to “an increase in the illegal circulation of cocaine” and warned that it “also sets a dangerous precedent that could be used by other states to create a more liberal drug control regime.”
The Select Committee on Internal Affairs of the British Parliament has recommended that Bolivia's request be supported by the UK government, arguing that it was important for countries to remain within the single convention. Bolivia's re-accession could only be blocked if one third or more of the 184 countries that had acceded to the Convention objected to its request. There are suspicions that the United States and the United Kingdom are frantically pushing other countries to get enough numbers to block Bolivia's petition.
Nancie Prud’homme, Project Director of the International Centre for Human Rights and Drug Policy, criticized the coordinated opposition to Bolivia’s demands. “These objections are legally questionable,” he said. They supported an arbitrary and excessively broad provision and applied international drug laws in a vacuum. This is not appropriate. No State has paid attention to decades of development of international norms on cultural and indigenous rights, which support Bolivia’s efforts.”
The decision to ban coca chewing was based on a 1950 report by the United Nations Commission of Inquiry on Coca Leaf, which, according to advocates of drug liberalization, was not based on supporting evidence. In an interview in 1949, Commission chief Howard B Fonda noted his opposition to coca leaf chewing before he began his investigation. Fonda told an interviewer: “We believe that the daily and inveterated use of coca leaves chewing...not only is it completely harmful and therefore harmful, but it is also the cause of racial degeneration in many population centers, and of the decline that manifests visibly in many Indians... Our studies will confirm the certainty of our claims and we hope to be able to present a rational plan of action... to achieve the absolute and safe abolition of this pernicious habit.”
Coca leaf cultivation is legal and licensed in Bolivia. The policy has been credited with a fall in cocaine production in the country, which has led some experts to see the Bolivian model as a way forward for other countries.
label: C2

text:
Spain is expelling the Libyan ambassador to Madrid and three other Libyan diplomats here, the Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement on Thursday.
The government of Spain has decided to put an end to the mission of the ambassador accredited to Madrid by the authorities of Tripoli-LRB-Libya-RRB, because the Gaddafi regime has lost all legitimacy due to its continued repression against the Libyan population, the statement said.
Libyan ambassador to Madrid, Ajeli Abdussalam Ali Breni, has 10 days to leave Spain, the ministry said.
The government is also expelling three other diplomats at the Libyan embassy who engaged in activities incompatible with their diplomatic status, the statement said.
But Spain has not broken diplomatic relations with Libya, said a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which is not usually identified.
Spain still has an embassy in Tripoli, although it evacuated its personnel from the city, like many other nations, while fighting between the Moammar Gaddafi regime and the rebels intensified at the end of March.
The Spanish Embassy in Tripoli, composed solely of local Libyan personnel, is not closed in a diplomatic sense, the spokesman said.
He added that it was not clear immediately how many Libyan diplomats or local Spanish staff could remain at the Libyan Embassy in Madrid, following the expulsion of the ambassador and the three other Libyan diplomats.
On 8 June, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Spain, Trinidad Jiménez, visited the Libyan rebel stronghold of Benghazi, where it declared that the rebel National Transitional Council of Libya was a valid interlocutor and a legitimate representative of the aspirations of the Libyan people, the spokesman said.
Spain has participated in United Nations-led NATO-led military operations in Libya. Spain has deployed four F-18 fighter aircraft and one refuelling aircraft to help enforce a no-fly zone, and a frigate, submarine and surveillance aircraft to help enforce an arms embargo against the Gaddafi regime.

text:
Supreme Court Judge Sonia Sotomayor was put at the centre of national attention on two hot topics this week.
It has nothing to do with the cases involved: same-sex marriage in Utah and the requirement for birth control coverage under Obamacare.
The two emergency appeals on New Year ' s Eve came because the cases originated in the western parts of the country -- Colorado and Utah -- which are under their jurisdiction for reviewing time-sensitive federal motions.
Sotomayor looked for more information about a Utah appeal to keep its voter-approved ban on same-sex unions in the state.
But she made headlines on the case with political positions around the Affordable Care Act just as the new rules were about to come into effect.
Sotomayor issued an order that, for the time being, was maintained as a requirement under the comprehensive health law for certain affiliated religious groups to ensure that employees receive contraceptive coverage at no cost.
The Denver-based organization dealing with the poor elderly, the Little Sisters of the Poor, is opposed to complying with the rules of the law that would guarantee an exemption, but, in theory, still require a third party to provide contraceptive insurance.
Ultimately, he believes that authorizing a form that passes the ball to another entity still means contraceptive coverage for its employees and that, for nuns, it is objectionable for moral reasons. The Catholic Church opposes artificial contraception.
While Sotomayor's emergency order or any follow-up to extend it or seek the opinion of his fellow judges for further review may seem like a blow to the health law with political charges, it is not.
Nor does it give any meaning to the position of Sotomayor, a liberal jurist, on the broader issues raised in the appeal in general.
He just put a single case on hold. She didn't dump Obamacare, CNN legal analyst Jeffrey Toobin said.
His decision at the end of Tuesday simply curbed the fulfillment of the Little Sisters of the Poor and allowed the Obama administration to present its arguments.
The Department of Justice said Friday that the appeal was without merit. The charity, he said, is eligible for an exemption and in addition, the entity that administers its insurance plans, the non-profit Christian Brothers Services, is also exempt under certain conditions in the Obamacare rules applicable to religious institutions.
Toobin said Sotomayor acted based on his view of the law by upholding the rule in this case.
Sotomayor voted for the Affordable Care Act in 2012 in a Supreme Court ruling that gave Obama a huge political victory.
Obamacare seeks to extend health coverage to millions of Americans without it and is the national achievement of the President's signature. It is being relentlessly attacked by conservatives who have made numerous attempts to revoke or otherwise sink it, and it is the focus of numerous legal challenges.

text:
Loneliness has finally become a hot topic – the National Bureau of Statistics has found Britain to be the most lonely country in Europe. The British are less likely to have strong friends or meet their neighbours than residents elsewhere in the EU, and a relatively high proportion of them have no one to trust in a crisis. Meanwhile, Professor John Cacioppo's research at the University of Chicago has found that loneliness is twice as bad for the health of older people as obesity and almost as great a cause of death as poverty.
But, however shocking this may be, such studies overlook the epidemic of loneliness among younger adults. In 2010, the Mental Health Foundation considered loneliness to be a greater concern among young people than among the elderly. Young people aged 18 to 34 surveyed were more likely to feel alone often, to worry about being lonely, and to feel depressed because of loneliness than those over 55.
“Loneliness is a recognized problem among the elderly – there are day centers and charities to help them,” says Sam Challis, information manager at Mind’s mental health charity, “but when young people reach 21, they are too old for youth services.” This is problematic due to the close relationship between loneliness and mental health – it is related to increased stress, depression, paranoia, anxiety, addiction, cognitive impairment and is a known factor in suicide. In a new essay, Paul Farmer, the executive director of Mind, and Jenny Edwards, the executive director of the Mental Health Foundation, say it can be both a cause and an effect of mental health problems.
But what can young people do to fight loneliness? Dr. Grant Blank, a researcher at the Oxford Internet Institute, points out that social media and the Internet can be both a blessing and a problem. They are beneficial when they allow us to communicate with distant loved ones, but not when they replace face-to-face contact. “People present an idealized version of themselves online and hope to have social lives like those presented in the media,” says Challis. Comparing the seemingly perfect life of friends with ours can lead us to retreat socially.
Although meditation techniques and applications such as Headspace are fashionable solutions that are frequently recommended for a number of mental health problems, they are not necessarily helpful for loneliness, as they actively encourage us to live alone in our thoughts. “It would be better if you first addressed the underlying causes of being alone – what is stopping you from going out and seeing people?” asks Challis.
In fact, a social media study at the University of Michigan in 2013 found that while Facebook reduces life satisfaction, the use of technology to help you meet new people can be beneficial. And, if for any reason, you are unable to venture outside, the Internet can bring comfort. Mumsnet has been “an absolute blessing” to Maddy Matthews, 19, a student with a two-month-old daughter. From birth, he rarely sees his college friends and his partner works most nights. “In the early days, I was awake until late at night feeding him and worried that he was doing something wrong. Being able to publish on Mumsnet has helped me feel less alone.”
Helplines can also reduce loneliness, at least in the short term. One in four men who call charity emotional support Samaritans mention loneliness or isolation and connect is a free confidential helpline for young people, where they can seek help with emotional and mental health problems often related to loneliness. There are also support services on websites like Mind’s that can remind you that you’re not alone.
At work, it may be beneficial to tell your employer how you feel. John Binns, who advises companies on mental health and well-being, was admitted to the hospital for stress-related depression in 2007 and took two months of work. It felt like there was no one to talk to and he wasn't close enough to his colleagues to notice the changes in their behavior. Greater openness with his employer and colleagues made his return to work easier. “People often find that colleagues are more supportive than they expected. Mine began to reach out, asking me to have lunch and making sure that the world had not advanced so much since I left.”
Office chit-chat may seem like a waste of time, but it helps protect us from the emotional and psychological effects of work stress. “If you form connections with your team, you can be stressed but not isolated,” says Rick Hughes,
The British Association of Counselling and Psychotherapy (BACP) is the leading advisor for the workplace.
“We treat the networks we have as incidentals, but they are fundamental to our well-being,” says Nicky Forsythe, a psychotherapist and founder of Talk for Health, a social enterprise that empowers people to give and receive peer support in groups. “The most important thing is to have a regular time and place to reflect on your life and have an empathetic listener.”
To develop personal skills such as empathy, counseling can help. The BACP website allows you to search for counselors in your area. “A problem transmitted is a shared problem and sometimes you need to talk to someone impartial and independent of your friends and family,” Hughes says. Most universities offer students such advice and many organize group sessions that specifically address loneliness.
If it is believed that recent research, loneliness is killing the elderly and, with an ageing population, we should try to reduce our isolation before it is too late. “Aging doesn’t have to mean being alone anymore,” says Ruth Sutherland, executive director of the Relate relationship advisory service, in a new report. “But much of this rests on laying the foundations for good quality relationships earlier in life.”

text:
Before we proceed to the evaluation of ontological arguments, we need to clarify what the correct objectives of ontological arguments may be. Suppose we think the arguments have defenders and objectives: when a defender presents an argument to an objective, the defender's goal is to achieve some change in the objective. What could be the objectives of the ontological arguments, and what could be the changes that the advocates of these arguments intend to achieve in these objectives?
Here are some proposals; no doubt the reader can think of others:
The targets could be atheists, and the goal could be to turn them into theists.
The objectives could be agnostic, and the goal could be to turn them into theistic.
The objectives could be theistic, and the goal could be to improve the doxastic position of the Theists.
The objectives could be professional philosophers, and the aim could be to advance the understanding of the consequences of adopting particular logical rules, or to treat existence as a real predicate, or to allow definitions to have existential significance, or something similar.
The goals could be undergraduate philosophy students, and the goal might be to give them some frustrating enough examples in which to cut their critical teeth.
In the next discussion, the objectives are supposed to be atheists and agnostics, and the goal is to turn them into theists. Suppose a defender presents an ontological argument to an objective. What conditions should these arguments meet if they are appropriate for the intended purpose? One plausible suggestion is that, minimally, it should make the objectives recognize that they have good reason to accept the conclusion of the argument that they did not recognize that they had before the presentation of the argument. The adoption of this plausible suggestion provides the following criterion: a successful ontological argument is one that should make atheists and agnostics recognize that they have good reasons to believe that God exists that they did not recognize they have before the argument was presented. Note that this criterion has a normative dimension: it announces what atheists and agnostics should do when the argument is presented.
There is an important discussion as to whether we should assume that the objectives of the ontological arguments are atheistic and agnostic, and that the aim is to make them theistic. However, it is simply beyond the scope of this entry to continue that debate here.

text:
Leaving aside epic moments of disaster films such as volcanoes, hurricanes and earthquakes, there are two key natural factors that can make a city vulnerable to gradual disintegration or even total disappearance: water and sand.
If climate change made the planet colder than hotter, we could add ice to the list, as nothing destroys a city like a billion-ton glacier that goes down a valley. The impact of a rare “tsunami of ice” in 2013 in the Canadian municipality of Ochre Beach was only a taster: an iceberg wall melted on Lake Dauphin was blown by the winds on the shore, splintering every house on its way.
But Ochre Beach was an anomaly. In other places, the melting of the planet's ice is making cities vulnerable by the less dramatic route of raising sea level. A century ago, Venice, one of the most beautiful and low-lying cities in the world, used to flood about ten times a year. Today, its lowest point, Piazza San Marco (only three feet above sea level) is flooded with water approximately 100 times a year.
But the rise in sea level is not entirely to blame. In many parts of the world, the land is also sinking – in the case of Venice, the compaction of the subsoil (due to the industrial exploitation of the surroundings) reduced the city by 20 cm between 1950 and 1970. Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam is also sinking by about 2 cm per year, but that is nothing compared to Jakarta, which is falling from 10 to 20 cm per year. Over the past three decades, the city has sunk about four metres, making its 40-year-old marine wall less and less effective. Unfortunately for the Indonesian capital, it has pumped so much groundwater to support its population that the land above is drying and compacting, thus creating a bowl. The rivers that used to flow through the city to the sea have had to be diverted because they cannot drain uphill.
Although there are many plans to save Venice – and Ho Chi Minh City and Jakarta are taking the problem seriously – the same cannot be said of Miami, where politicians refuse to admit that the city has a serious environmental problem.
Miami's difficulties are triple. The Florida complex is less than ten feet above sea level; an increasing number of tropical storms are flooding the city; and it is built on porous limestone, which is absorbing rising sea water. This water then fills the foundations of the city and bubbles through drains and pipes, forcing the sewage up and polluting its fresh water. There's every chance that Miami will one day become uninhabitable.
In Maldives, entire island populations are trying to leave their homes. The capital, Male, with a population of 153,379 and only four feet above sea level, has used Japanese investment to build a 10-foot sea wall at a cost of $63 million, but in the long term, only a stabilization of sea level rise will save it and the rest of the islands.
And it's not just the sea: rains also endanger cities around the world. Recently, a whole summer of rain fell on a morning in Detroit, overwhelming its obsolete sewage systems. Impoverished by the collapse of the U.S. car industry, the city is struggling to build a system to cope. Drinking water is also affected because Detroit is particularly vulnerable to water-borne pathogens.
In Africa, desertification is causing the Sahara to spread south at a rate of 30 miles per year, threatening settlements in northern Mauritania. Over the past 20 years, for example, the desert has grown by more than 260 acres around the Chinguetti shopping and religious centre, which has seen its population decrease from 20,000 in the mid-20th century to just a few thousand now. Trading has almost stopped when the sand accumulates in the streets.
Similarly, the Californian Rancho Mirage complex, near Palm Springs, may have to be abandoned in the next decade. This city is just one example of a problem caused not so much by global warming as by human over-expansion against finite resources. California's dream of cultivating the desert made sense while its total population remained around half a million (in 1870) – but, now, the state is home to 38 million people, who, among them, own 32 million vehicles and expect to be surrounded by lawns and golf courses.
The daily use of water in Rancho Mirage is more than 200 gallons per person, which is leading to a man-made drought. A 25% reduction in water consumption has been applied, but it is unlikely to stabilize the complex, which is surrounded by sand and dust. The long-term response in the California desert is likely to be the abandonment of some cities while consolidating the populations of others.
Human flight is the final test of a city's disintegration. Once we stop maintaining a city, nature takes over very quickly. The Hashima Island of Japan became a concrete city in 1887 to exploit the underwater coal reserves, but in 1974, with the supply of coal about to run out, the mine was closed and Hashima was abandoned. Now, the sea spray is causing its concrete walls to collapse.
Fire is a growing threat to urban settlements in America – in fact, forest fires cause the greatest damage after severe storms, with 800 major fire disasters declared there between 1953 and 2014. A recent report by the USDA Forest Service shows the growing number of urban localities that are particularly vulnerable to forest fires.
Similarly, in Australia, some of the tourist centres in Victoria and several suburbs in Melbourne have been placed on a list of the 52 most vulnerable forest fire sites in the state because long-term droughts are making trees highly combustible. A forest fire is unlikely to destroy an entire city, but a succession of fires could make it uninhabitable, and abandonment remains one of the most powerful causes of urban collapse.
Many cities are fighting a lost battle against the ravages of nature, but is it possible to identify the most vulnerable metropolis in the world? Natural events are notoriously difficult to predict, but Malé's prospects seem particularly bleak, as, although its new marine wall remains effective, the islands around the capital of Maldives will soon disappear. And if they disappear, so does Male's raison d'être.

text:
A man more interested than most in what President Barack Obama will have to say in his address to the nation on Wednesday night is the leader of Al Qaeda Ayman al-Zawahiri.
In his hiding place somewhere in Pakistan or Afghanistan, he will probably be waiting for the President to establish a plan to exterminate the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria – LRB-ISIS –RRB – a group that has overshadowed Al Qaeda and made al-Zawahiri seem virtually irrelevant.
Al-Zawahiri and the Al Qaeda core are trapped in battle with ISIS for the leadership of the global jihadist movement, offering very different visions and strategies. ISIS was expelled from Al Qaeda in February after rejecting al-Zawahiri's demand to restrict its activities to Iraq.
ISIS has captured the imagination of a new generation of jihadists, both from Arab and European states, with their ruthless pursuit of a Caliphate, their dramatic territorial conquests and their relentless propaganda machinery.
Their chilling brutality towards non-Muslims and Muslims who do not share their rigid interpretation of Islam echoes the behaviour of their predecessor, Al Qaeda, in Iraq, whose brutal attacks on Shiite Muslims and moderate Sunnis provoked the wrath of the late Al Qaeda leader, Osama bin Laden.
In short, ISIS' journey through Iraq represents a serious organizational, strategic and ideological blow to al Qaeda, wrote analyst Barak Mendelsohn at Foreign Affairs in June.
So far, the leaders of Al Qaeda affiliates have remained loyal – LRB – if not enthusiastic – to al-Zawahiri. After the death of its leader Ahmad Abdi Godane last week, Al-Shabaab quickly reiterated its loyalty to the leader of Al Qaeda, and Nasir al Wuhayshi, No. 2, remains at the helm of al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula - LRB-AQAP-RRB.
Prominent jihadist preachers such as Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi and Abu Qatada have condemned ISIS for diversion.
Call for a new generation of jihadists
But the younger generation of jihadists seems to be more impressed by action than by sermons. Al Qaeda's standing soldiers, coming from Yemen, Libya, Saudi Arabia and elsewhere, are reaching ISISstandard. For them, their leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi confronts the apostates and builds the Caliphate, while al-Zawahiri speaks.
It is impossible to know the scale of this exodus. But last week, a group calling itself The Supporters of the Islamic State in Yemen posted a video promising allegiance to al-Baghdadi, calling him the Muslim Caliph — the mujahid in the front row of attack on America.
Even AQAP, the most effective of the group's affiliates, has expressed solidarity with ISIS fighters, condemning what it calls the U.S. declaration of war against Muslims in Iraq, and calling on all Islamic groups to support their brothers by afflicting the U.S.
On the contrary, it has been a long time since Al Qaeda Central has carried out any major attacks. Four years ago, a strategy paper set out ideas for attacking targets such as cruises, dams and bridges, as well as aircraft. But far beyond the lone wolf attacks by distant Al Qaeda sympathizers, it has occurred since then.
In the past three years, the most significant terrorist attacks against Western interests have been against the U.S. consulate compound in Benghazi, Libya, where there may have been some involvement of members of Al Qaeda affiliates; the gas plant in southern Algeria in January 2013, carried out by a malevolent group that pledged allegiance to Al Qaeda but did not appear to have acted according to its instructions; and the Westgate Mall in Nairobi, Kenya -- Al-Shabaab's work, apparently planned without reference to Al Qaeda leaders, even if it was exactly the type of operation that al-Zawahiri had called for.
Attacks on U.S. military, diplomatic and government targets in Afghanistan have largely been carried out by the Taliban and the Haqqani Network, although Al Qaeda fighters are entangled with these groups.
Some Al Qaeda affiliates have been forced to the defensive in the last two years. The French intervention in Mali pushed back the groups linked to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (LRB-AQIM-RRB), which had taken over half of the country. AQAP seized and then lost several cities in southern Yemen in early 2012, resorting to suicide bombings and fighting against Yemeni government forces from remote hiding places.
Al-Shabaab lost its leader Godane in a U.S. missile attack last week and has lost large areas of Somalia that were once controlled by Kenyan, Ethiopian and African Union forces. He has also suffered merciless internal strife. And in Pakistan, the army has gone on the offensive against the Pakistani Taliban -- an Al Qaeda affiliate also divided by division -- in the tribal area of North Waziristan.
Al Qaeda strongholds still exist
There are still many places where Al Qaeda supporters are active and their operations are growing: eastern Libya, Syria and the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt, where they have found space to breathe in the midst of a collapse of state authority. But in the midst of these rapid events, al-Zawahiri has looked more like the cheerleader than the leader, reacting to events rather than directing them.
Last week, in an effort to regain relevance, he announced the creation of al Qaeda in the Indian subcontinent, led by Asim Umar, which will include at least one faction of the Pakistani Taliban. According to a translation from the SITE Institute, the spokesman for the new branch, Usama Mahmoud, said that its basic objectives included jihad against the United States, support for the Taliban and the establishment of a Caliphate - LRB - implicitly rejecting the Caliphate claimed by al-Baghdadi -RRB.
The announcement intensifies the philosophical battle between Al Qaeda and ISIS over how the dream of the Caliphate is achieved, to which Muslims around the world owe allegiance. Mahmoud spoke of a Caliphate where the Emirs are proud of their closeness to honest scholars... a Caliphate in whose shadow even the unbelievers of dhimma-LRB- non-Muslim citizens of an Islamic state-RRB- have a life of security.
The last condition was clearly directed at ISIS and its ruthless campaign against non-Muslims and non-Sunish Muslims both in Iraq and Syria. In order not to be overcome, the ISISpropaganda machine recently published photographs showing residents of the Iraqi city of Nineveh enjoying prosperity under the shadow of the Caliphate.
Al Qaeda’s Hope for the Future
Al-Zawahiri may be seeking the withdrawal of most U.S. combat forces from Afghanistan as his best chance to revive Al Qaeda's fortune. Last week's announcement reiterated Al Qaeda's loyalty to Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar as leader of the Islamic Emirate. Several analysts have also noticed a stream of statements by Al Qaeda suggesting the arrival of a counter-Caliphato.
Daveed Gartenstein-Ross and Thomas Jocelyn pointed out in Foreign Policy that despite the U.S. surge in Afghanistan, the remote provinces of Kunar and Nuristan are home to important cadres of al-Qaeda fighters, and al-Qaeda continues to operate side by side with its allies in other parts of the country.
There is also the prospect, or as some would say, the probability that the ISIS will overtake itself like its predecessor, Al Qaeda, in Iraq, alienating the Sunni tribes, taking territory that cannot defend and mobilizing more enemies than it can resist. If the coalition that is now being built against it can divide Syrian and Iraqi possessions and reward cities like Mosul from its reach, the crucial momentum for its success and appeal will be lost.
The Obama administration seems willing to borrow a page from its anti-Qaeda strategy to deal with ISIS. Last week, Ben Rhodes, deputy national security adviser, said: We have been able to significantly degrade the Al Qaeda core in Afghanistan and Pakistan, decimating their leadership positions, reducing the threat they pose.
Now a repeat in Iraq of the U.S. strategy that reduced al-Zawahiri to a spectator may be your best chance of overcoming the challenge posed by ISIS. The risk is that Washington and its allies will neglect the imminent challenges in Afghanistan while at the same time refocusing on the militant challenge in Iraq. We've also seen that movie.

text:
Although in Western philosophy the first formulation of a version of the cosmological argument is found in Plato's Laws, 893–96, the classical argument is firmly rooted in Aristotle's Physics (VIII, 4–6) and Metaphysics (XII, 1–6). Islamic philosophy enriches tradition, developing two types of arguments. Arab philosophers (phalasipha), like Ibn Sina (c. 980–1037), developed the contingency argument, which was taken up by Thomas Aquinas (1225–74) in his Summa Theologica (I,q.2,a.3) and in his Summa Contra Gentiles (I,13). Influenced by John Philoponus (5th c) (Davidson 1969), the mutakallimūm — theologists who used reason and argumentation to support their revealed Islamic beliefs — developed the temporal version of the argument from the impossibility of an infinite regression, now known as the cosmological argument kalām. For example, al-Ghāzāli (1058-1111) argued that everything that begins to exist requires a cause of its beginning. The world is composed of temporal phenomena preceded by other temporarily ordained phenomena. Since such a series of temporal phenomena cannot continue to infinity because a real infinity is impossible, the world must have had a beginning and a cause of its existence, called Allah or God (Craig 1979: Part 1). This version of the cosmological argument entered the medieval Christian tradition through Bonaventure (1221–74) in its phrases (II Sent. D.1, p.1, a.1, q.2).
The Enlightenment thinkers, like Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz and Samuel Clarke, reaffirmed the cosmological argument. Leibniz (1646-1716) appealed to a reinforced principle of sufficient reason, according to which “no fact can be real or existing and no true statement without sufficient reason to be so and not otherwise” (Monadology, §32). Leibniz uses the principle to argue that the sufficient reason for the "series of things understood in the universe of creatures" (§ 36) must exist outside this series of contingencies and is found in a necessary being we call God. Samuel Clarke also used the principle of sufficient reason in his cosmological argument (Rowe 1975: chap. (2).
Although the cosmological argument does not feature prominently in Asian philosophy, a very short version of it, which comes from dependence, can be found in Nyāyakusumjali of Udayana I.4. In general, the philosophers of Nyāya tradition argue that since the universe has parts that come into existence on one occasion and not on another, it must have a cause. We could admit an infinite regression of causes if we had evidence of it, but without such evidence, God must exist as the non-dependent cause. Many of the objections to the argument argue that God is an inappropriate cause because of God’s nature. For example, since God is still and has no body, he cannot be properly told that he causes anything. The Naiyāyikas respond that God could assume a body at certain times, and in any case, God does not need to create in the same way as humans (Potter 1977: 100-07).
The cosmological argument was seriously attacked in the 18th century, first by David Hume and then by Immanuel Kant. Hume (1748) attacked both the vision of causality presupposed in the argument (that causality is an objective, productive and necessary power relationship that has between two things) and the Causal Principle—each contingent being has a cause of its existence—which is at the center of the argument. Kant argued that the cosmological argument, by identifying the necessary being, is based on the ontological argument, which in turn is suspicious. We will return to these criticisms below.
Both theistic and non-theistic in the latter part of the 20th century and in the first part of the 21st century generally show sound skepticism about the argument. Alvin Plantinga concludes “that this piece of natural theology is ineffective” (1967: chap. 1. Richard Gale argues, in Kantian fashion, that since the conclusion of all versions of the cosmological argument invokes an impossibility, no cosmological argument can provide examples of sound reasoning (1991: chap. 7). (However, Gale seems to have changed his mind and in recent writings proposed and defended his own version of the cosmological argument, which we will consider below.) Similarly, Michael Martin (1990: chap. 4), John Mackie (1982: chap. 5), Quentin Smith (Craig and Smith 1993), Bede Rundle (2004), Wes Morriston (2000, 2002a, 2003, 2010), and Graham Oppy (2006: chap. 3) reason that no current version of the cosmological argument is solid. However, dissenting voices can be heard. Robert Koons (1997) uses merology and modal and non-monoton logic to take a “new look” at the contingency argument. In his widely discussed writings William Lane Craig deals with the multidisciplinary evidence of the truth of the premises found in the kalam argument. Richard Gale and Alexander Pruss propose a new version based on a so-called weak principle of sufficient reason that leads to a finite God who is not omnibenevolente, and Richard Swinburne, while rejecting deductive versions of the cosmological argument, proposes an inductive argument that is part of a larger cumulative case for the existence of God.
There is a great possibility that if there is a God, he will do something about the finitude and complexity of a universe. It is highly unlikely that a universe existed without cause, but rather more likely that God existed without cause. The existence of the universe... can be made understandable if we assume it is produced by God. (Swinburne 1979: 131–32)
More recently, Michael Almeida built a new version of the argument based on modal realism. In short, unlike the first half of the last century, contemporary philosophers provide increasingly detailed, complex and sophisticated arguments on both sides of the debate.
label: C2

text:
Colonialism is not a modern phenomenon. The history of the world is full of examples of a society that is gradually expanding by incorporating adjacent territory and settling its people in newly conquered territory. The ancient Greeks established colonies as well as the Romans, the Moors and the Ottomans, to name just a few of the most famous examples. Colonialism, then, is not limited to a specific time or place. However, in the 16th century, colonialism changed decisively due to technological advances in navigation that began to connect more remote parts of the world. The fast sailboats made it possible to reach distant ports and maintain close ties between the center and the colonies. Thus, the modern European colonial project arose when it became possible to move a large number of people across the ocean and maintain political sovereignty despite geographical dispersion. This entry uses the term colonialism to describe the European settlement process and political control over the rest of the world, including the Americas, Australia and parts of Africa and Asia.
The difficulty of defining colonialism stems from the fact that the term is often used as a synonym for imperialism. Both colonialism and imperialism were forms of conquest that were expected to benefit Europe economically and strategically. The term colonialism is often used to describe the settlement of North America, Australia, New Zealand, Algeria and Brazil, places that were controlled by a large population of permanent European residents. The term imperialism often describes cases in which a foreign government administers a territory without a significant settlement; typical examples include the struggle for Africa at the end of the 19th century and U.S. domination of the Philippines and Puerto Rico. The distinction between the two, however, is not entirely consistent in literature. Some scholars distinguish between colonies for settlements and colonies for economic exploitation. Others use the term colonialism to describe dependencies that are ruled directly by a foreign nation and contrast this with imperialism, which implies indirect forms of domination.
The confusion over the meaning of the term imperialism reflects the way in which the concept has changed over time. Although the English word imperialism was not commonly used before the 19th century, the Elizabethans already described the United Kingdom as “the British Empire.” As Britain began to acquire dependencies abroad, the concept of empire was used more frequently. Imperialism was understood as a system of military domination and sovereignty over the territories. The daily work of the government could be exercised indirectly through local assemblies or indigenous rulers who paid tribute, but sovereignty rested on the British. The change of this traditional understanding of the empire was influenced by the Leninist analysis of imperialism as a system oriented towards economic exploitation. According to Lenin, imperialism was the necessary and inevitable result of the logic of accumulation in late capitalism. Thus, for Lenin and later Marxists, imperialism described a historical stage of capitalism rather than a transhistoric practice of political and military domination. The lasting impact of the Marxist approach is evident in contemporary debates on U.S. imperialism, a term that generally means U.S. economic hegemony, regardless of whether such power is exercised directly or indirectly (Young 2001).
Given the difficulty of systematically distinguishing between the two terms, this entry will use colonialism as a broad concept that refers to the project of European political domination from the 16th century to the 20th century that ended with the national liberation movements of the 60s. Postcolonialism will be used to describe the political and theoretical struggles of societies that experienced the transition from political dependence to sovereignty. This entry will use imperialism as a broad term referring to the economic, military and political domination that is achieved without a meaningful permanent European agreement.

Contemporary analytical philosophers, feminists and non-feminist, can be more or less characterized as follows: they consider (some of) Frege, Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein and the Logic Positivists as their intellectual ancestors; they tend to value explicit argumentation and the literal, precise and clear use of language; they often value the roles of language philosophy, epistemology and logic; and they often see their collection of philosophical concepts, methods and assumptions as (a) consistent with their modern European heritage; and (b) in contrast to the methods originating in continental Europe of the twentieth century, most recently those with names beginning with “post”: post-structuralism and postmodernism widely conceived.
Of course, every thread of the mid-20th century, “classical” analytical philosophy has changed a lot. Many central dogmas have been undermined, and non-feminist and non-feminist alike have “naturalized”, “socialized” and otherwise modified previous, more abstract and highly normative companies and doctrines. However, regardless of the extent of the evolution of “analytical philosophy”, the degree to which methodological limits are blurred today, and the fertility of the intersections between methods, several feminist and non-feminist philosophers continue to think of themselves in the historical trajectory of analytical philosophy and find tradition valuable. They claim that the term ‘analytical philosopher’ for themselves, even if some others could find the most appropriate term ‘post-analytic’. [2]

Every morning, before temperatures in the capital of India begin to rise, a handful of old friends gather together. In the dry grass not far from the India Gate monument in the center of Delhi, they spread, breathe and meditate.
“It’s the only healthy way to start the day. Much better than an egg or sandwich or a cup of tea,” Arvind Singh said at 6.15 a.m. while doing his breathing exercises on a bench.
Singh, a 42-year-old salesman, and his friends are far from alone. Similar scenes are being reproduced throughout India, in overcrowded cities, in whatever green space remains.
June 21 – the new International Yoga Day – Narendra Modi, Prime Minister of India, hopes the world will join. The grass near India Gate will become the place for what, expected, will be the largest yoga session ever held, with up to 45,000 people running through a 35-minute routine.
Participants will include Modi, 64, most of his government and, they hope, a number of celebrities. Officials have been sent to gather volunteers from many countries to strengthen the international credentials of the former Indian practice.
Get Indians, and others, the stretching has emerged as something of a focus for Modi, who led his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to an overwhelming electoral victory in 2014. In May 2015, schools were directed to ensure that students attended the yoga events scheduled to coincide with the grand demonstration in Delhi, although it is being held on a Sunday.
Officials have already pointed to the introduction of mandatory yoga for famous Indian police officers out of shape and have said that daily yoga classes will be offered free of charge to three million public officials and their families. Air India, the national company, has also said it will introduce yoga for trainees. More controversially, high-level politicians in India have suggested that a more widespread practice of yoga could reduce the high levels of sexual violence in the country.
Modi, an ascetic who is a committed vegetarian and an enthusiastic yoga practitioner, suggested an international yoga day when he spoke to the United Nations on a visit to New York in 2014.
“Yoga is an invaluable gift from India’s ancient tradition. It represents the unity of mind and body, thought and action, moderation and realization, harmony between man and nature, a holistic approach to health and well-being. It’s not about exercising, it’s about discovering the sense of unity with yourself, the world, and nature,” Modi said at the time, adding that yoga could help in the fight against climate change.
The discipline is between 3,000 and 6,000 years old and originated somewhere in the Indian subcontinent, possibly among religious ascetics. His meditative practices, as well as his physical exercises, have long been associated with local religious traditions such as Buddhism and Jainism, as well as Hinduism practiced by 80% of Indians.
Modi, who began his career as an organizer of a hard-line Hindu nationalist organization, has previously been criticized for promoting a vision of Indian culture that has little place for other traditions. One commentator said the June 21 event was “a mixture of cultural nationalism, commercialization and subtle coercion.”
The novelist Ajaz Ashraf wrote on the Scroll website of India: “Based on it is the hope of bringing modern gurus and their abundant followers, who largely constitute the urban middle classes, to the BJP store.”
Others, however, point to a recent U.S. court ruling. who said that yoga was not inevitably linked to faith. A California court ruled that: “Although the practice of yoga may be religious in some contexts, the yoga classes taught in the [San Diego] district are, as the court of first instance determined, ‘devoid of religious, mystical or spiritual traps. "This came after two parents claimed yoga in schools promoted Hinduism and inhibited Christianity.
Amish Tripathi, the author of the best-selling novels set 4,000 years ago in India that recount stories of Hindu mythology, said the characters in his books practice yoga.
“In ancient India, it was part of everyday life, both physical and mental. Every culture has given something to the world and this is our gift,” Tripathi said.
Suneel Singh, a South Delhi guru, agreed that yoga did not belong to any religion: “Is t’ai chi only Chinese? Is football only English? Same with yoga. It is a complete package for everyone’s body and a cheap way to keep the hale and heart.”

The clear indications of panpsychist doctrines are evident in early Greek thought. One of the early presocratic philosophers of ancient Greece, Thales (c. 624-545 BC) displayed an analogical argument for the attribution of the mind that tends toward panpsychism. The argument depends on the idea that beings in mind move themselves. Thales points out that magnets and, under certain circumstances, amber, can move and concludes that they therefore possess minds. It is claimed that Thales went far beyond such particular powers and supported a true panpsychism and pantheism. For example, as reported by Barnes (1982: 96-7), Diogenes stated that Thales believed that "the universe is alive and full of spirits", but this observation stems from an earlier statement by Aristotle: "some say that a soul is mixed throughout the universe—and perhaps that's why Thales thought that everything is full of gods." While Barnes disputes the pantheistic reading of Thales, he allows Thales to believe in the “ubiquity of animation.” [1]
The presocratics were struck by a dilemma: either the mind is an elementary feature of the world, or the mind can somehow be reduced to more fundamental elements. If one chooses reductionism, it is up to one to explain how reduction occurs. On the other hand, if one opts for the panpsychistic view that the mind is an elementary feature of the world, then one must realize the apparent lack of mental characteristics on the fundamental level. Anaxagoras (c. 500–425 BC) strongly denied that novel elements could emerge from more basic characteristics of reality and instead advanced the view that “everything is in everything” (there are interesting parallels between this and much more recent arguments for the panpsychism of Thomas Nagel and Galen Strawson, discussed below). Anaxagoras explained the appearance to the contrary in terms of a “principle of domination and latency” (see Mourelatos 1986), which affirmed that some qualities were dominant in their contribution to the behavior and appearance of things. However, Anaxagoras' views on the mind are complex, as he apparently considered that the mind did not contain any measure of other things and therefore did not fully comply with its mixing principles. Perhaps this can be interpreted as the affirmation that the mind is ontologically fundamental in a special way; Anaxagoras seemed to believe that everything has some part of the mind in it, while abstaining from the assertion that everything has a mind (even this is controversial, see Barnes 1982: 405 ff. ).
On the other hand, Empedocles, an almost accurate contemporary of Anaxagoras, favored a reductionist narrative based on the famous doctrine of the four elements: earth, air, fire and water. All qualities had to be explained in terms of the proportions of these elements. The general distribution of the elements, which were themselves eternal and immutable, was controlled by “love and struggle” in a cyclical dynamic grand universe. [2] The purest form of reductionism was proposed by the famous atomist Democritus (c. 460-370 BC). Its principle of emergency was based on the possibility that multiform atoms “enclosed” to form an infinity of more complex forms. But Democritus had to admit that the qualities of experience could not be explained in this way, and so he chose to relegate them to non-existence: "by sweet convention and bitter convention, by hot convention, by cold convention, by convention color of convention; but in reality atoms and void" (Taylor 1999).
What draws attention to these early attempts to formulate an integrated theory of reality is that the mind and particularly consciousness continue to emerge as special problems. Sometimes it is said that the mind-body problem is not an ancient philosophical concern (see Matson 1966), but it does seem that the problem of consciousness was annoying philosophers 2500 years ago, and in a redolent form of contemporary concerns.
We found these concerns re-emerging at the beginning of the scientific revolution, such as the mechanical picture of the world inaugurated by Galileo, Descartes and Newton put the problem of the mind at the center of the stage while paradoxically sweeping under the carpet. Galileo's matematization of nature seemed to leave no room for the qualities we find in the experience: the redness of the tomato, the spice of the paprika, the sweet smell of flowers. Galileo's solution, in a movement reminiscent of Democritus, was to strip matter of such sensory qualities. This led to the distinction between the “primary qualities” — such as form, size, and movement — that were thought to exist really in matter, and the “secondary qualities” — such as colors, smells, and tastes — that were thought to exist only in the mind of the observer (or to exist as powers to cause ideas in the mind of observers). [3] Galileo and Descartes did not take the radical Christian step of denying the existence of secondary qualities, but placed them in the soul. [4] However, this, of course, led to a radical form of dualism, with a sharp metaphysical division between souls with their secondary qualities and bodies with their primary qualities.

Illegal discharge is a kind of “moral emptiness” and theft, as much as getting into someone’s pocket and stealing their wallet is a robbery, says author Philip Pullman. In an article for Censorship Index, Pullman, who is president of the Society of Authors, makes a robust defense of copyright laws. It's very critical of Internet users who think it's okay to download music or books without paying for them.
“The technical brilliance is so dazzling that people cannot see the moral misery of what they are doing,” he writes. “It is outrageous that anyone can steal an artist’s work and get away with it. It’s a robbery, as sure as getting into someone’s pocket and taking their wallet is a robbery.”
His article comes after music industry leaders met with British Prime Minister David Cameron on Downing Street, where the issue of web piracy was discussed.
Pullman, writer of the His Dark Materials trilogy, says authors and musicians work for years in poverty and darkness to bring their work to the level “that delights their audiences and, as soon as they succeed, they are taken away from the possibility of earning a living.” He concludes: “The principle is simple and unaltered by technology, science or magic: if we want to enjoy the work that someone does, we must pay for it.”
Pullman is writing in the upcoming issue of the campaign group magazine in a dialogue with Cathy Casserly, Executive Director of Creative Commons, which offers open content licenses “that allow creators to take copyright into their own hands.” Casserly argues that there is much wrong with copyright, which was created "in an analogue era". She writes: “By default, copyright closes the door in countless ways that people can share, build and remix each other’s work, possibilities that were unimaginable when those laws were established.”
He says artists need to think creatively about how they distribute and monetize their work, citing science fiction writer Cory Doctorow, who said, “My problem is not piracy, it’s darkness.”
The Censorship Index agrees. The magazine’s editor, Rachael Jolley, said: “The existence of copyright laws does not work in the digital age and runs the risk of criminalizing consumers. We need new models for how artists, writers and musicians make a living with their work.”
The debate is lively and the magnitude of the illegal discharges is enormous. Data collected by Ofcom (the independent regulator and the competition authority for the UK communications industries) suggest that, between November 2012 and January 2013 in the UK, 280 million music tracks were digitally hacked, along with 52 million television programmes, 29 million films, 18 million e-books and 7 million software or game files.
Ofcom has said that 18% of Internet users over 12 years of age admit to hacking content recently, and 9% say they fear being caught. Pullman writes in his article: “The ease and speed with which music can be purchased in the form of MP3 downloads is still surprising for those of us who have been building our iTunes list for some time.”
One thing to emerge from the Downing Street meeting was Cameron's appointment of conservative MP Mike Weatherley to be his advisor on the subject. A spokesperson for the BIS, the commercial agency of the record industry, said: “Mike Weatherley is a strong advocate of copyright and creative artists and producers that he is there to protect. We hope that your influence and Prime Minister’s support for copyright will be affected by the approach of the UK Intellectual Property Office.”

David Hume (Hume 1748/2000; cf. Voltaire 1764/1901: 272) defined a miracle as “a violation of the laws of nature”, and this definition has been the focus of lively discussion ever since. Hume evidently means to denote something beyond mere changes in the regular course of nature, raising the highest bar so that something qualifies as a miracle, but also raising the potential epistemic meaning of such an event if it could be authenticated.
Bringing the concept of natural laws to the definition of “miracle” is, however, problematic, and for various reasons many writers have found it unsustainable (Brown 1822: 219–33; Beard 1845: 35; Lias 1890: 5–7; Huxley 1894:154–58; Joyce 1914: 17; Hesse 1965; Montgomery 1978; but see Wardlaw 1852: 27–41). First, the concept of a miracle precedes any modern concept of a natural law for many centuries. Although this does not necessarily exclude the concept of Hume, it does raise the question of what concept or concepts previous thinkers had in mind and why the Humean concept should be considered preferable (Tucker 2005). One benefit of defining miracles in terms of violations of natural law is that this definition implies that a miracle is beyond the productive power of nature. But if that's the key idea, then it's hard to see why we shouldn't just use that as the definition and leave out the problematic talk of laws.
Secondly, it is difficult to say in some cases exactly which natural laws are being violated by the event in question (earman 2000). The fact that the dead remain dead is widely observed, but it is not, in the ordinary scientific use of the term, a law of nature that the dead remain dead. The laws involved in the decomposition of a corpse are all at a much more fundamental level, at least in the level of biochemical and thermodynamic processes and perhaps in the level of interactions of fundamental particles.
Thirdly, there are deep philosophical disagreements about nature and even the existence of natural laws. In Hume’s view of the “regularity” of natural laws, it is difficult to see what it would mean to violate a natural law. If natural laws are simply complicit assertions of natural regularities, an apparent “violation” would, of course, be an indication, not that a supernatural intervention in the course of nature had occurred, but rather that what we had thought was a natural law was, in fact, not one. In the metaphysically rich conceptions of natural laws, violations are problematic since laws involve relations of necessity among the universals. And in the view that there are no natural laws at all, the set of events that satisfy the Humea definition of a miracle is, trivially, empty.
Speaking of miracles as violations of the laws of nature also raises questions about the nature of rape. Richard Swinburne (1970) has suggested that a miracle could be defined as a non-recurring counter-instance to a law of nature. If a putative law has a wide scope, great explanatory power, and attractive simplicity, it may be more reasonable, Swinburne argues, to retain the law (defined as a regularity that virtually invariably maintains) and to accept that the event in question is an unrepeatable counter-installation of that law than to discard the law and create a much more complex law that accommodates the event.
One way to overcome all these problems and still retain the Humea formulation is simply to redefine the laws of nature. J.L. Mackie summarizes this perspective clearly:
The laws of nature... describe the ways in which the world — including, of course, human beings — works when it leaves itself, when it does not interfere. A miracle occurs when the world does not leave itself, when something other than the natural order as a whole meddles in it. (Mackie 1982: 19-20)
With the concept of “natural law” thus redefined, the definition of “rape” becomes virtually equivalent to the earlier definition of a miracle as an event that exceeds the productive power of nature. And in the formulation of Mackie it has the desirable characteristic that makes evident the connection between a miracle and a supernatural agency.

Two planes came too close to each other while attempting to land at a Detroit airport, a federal official said early on Saturday, days after another nearby incident involving three planes at a Washington, D.C. airport.
A Delta flight from Phoenix was scheduled to land Friday night at Detroit Metro Airport as a small regional plane attempted to land, said Elizabeth Cory, spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.
The two planes were separated by approximately two horizontal miles. “The standard distance of separation is three miles,” Cory said, noting that an investigation is ongoing.
CNN first learned about the incident of an alleged passenger who said he could see a regional plane under them from his cabin window.
Air traffic control was aware that they had a situation where separation was less than they wanted, Cory said.
Both pilots had visual contact with each other and neither of the two aircraft ran the risk of colliding with the other, he added.
Friday's incident in Detroit occurred one day after federal authorities acknowledged that three aircraft operated by US Airways at Reagan National Airport came closer than they should have due to a lack of communication in air traffic control.
Feds investigate 3 planes that fly too close to DC area airport
The incident occurred on Tuesday afternoon when air traffic controllers were making adjustments to land and leave aircraft due to bad weather.
Chautauqua Airlines' flight reached 800 vertical feet and.82 nautical miles after the departure of an arriving aircraft, identified as a Republic Airlines flight, authorities said.
The third aircraft involved was another Republic Airlines flight, which took off and was 2.07 nautical miles and 800 vertical feet from the flight arriving.
During the change of operations, the lack of communication between Tracon and the DCA tower resulted in the loss of the necessary separation between two regional aircraft leaving runway 1 and a regional aircraft entering runway 19, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.
Tracon, or terminal radar approach control, is a reference to a regional radar installation. DCA is the code of the International Air Transport Association for Reagan National Airport.
At no time were the three planes on a head-to-head course, Transport Secretary Ray LaHood said.
The FAA is investigating and plans to take appropriate action to address the miscommunication of Tuesday's incident.
Such nearby flaws and any operational error are called to action, said Representative John L. Mica, R-Florida, after Tuesday's incident. I'm asking our Aviation Subcommittee staff and FAA to thoroughly review what happened.
Last year, an air traffic controller was suspended for not responding to two planes heading to the national airport after he fell asleep on the midnight shift.
The two planes landed without incident.

text:
The four seasons are spring, summer, autumn and winter, and although several areas of the United States experience a drastically different climate during these times, all portions of the country recognize the seasons; winter in California can bring heat, and winter in New York can bring blizzards, but both periods are winter nonetheless.
After winter, spring begins on March 20 and ends on June 20 or June 21, in the United States (this date may vary slightly from year to year and hemisphere to hemisphere). For most, spring is a time of "dishes", when winter cold and snow are replaced by the sun, reasonable temperatures, green grass, and more. It is also the season in which the bees and butterflies that had been inactive resurface, and when the birds become more active.
Summer follows spring and ranges from June 21st to September 22nd, in America. Summer is the warmest, longest, and (probably) the liveliest of the four seasons; college kindergarten students are given two or more summer months out of class, and to be sure, there are more young individuals out and around during this season than any other. It is not uncommon to see shorts, t-shirts and sunglasses worn by those who are absorbing the hot summer sun, and to stay fresh, many individuals take air conditioning, take a bath in a pool and/or explore the waves of the ocean, which are increasingly comfortable.
Autumn (or autumn), rather than just being a forerunner of winter, is one of the most beautiful and exciting seasons. Waste from September 22 to December 21 (technically, that is, snow will begin to fall long before this last date, in most parts of the country, leading many to classify the period as winter) in the US, autumn is characterized by the fall of leaves, Halloween (October 31), and Thanksgiving. During autumn, traditional farmers harvest their produce, and the fallen leaves mentioned change to beautiful orange, red and yellow colors; these colors are usually associated with autumn itself, in turn.
In the United States, winter runs from 21 December to 20 March, and is, as one might expect, the coldest of the four seasons. In the eastern, northern and central parts of the country, winter snowfalls may be considerable; in the western and southern parts of the country, winter snowfalls are highly unlikely, but temperatures, however, fall from the usual ones. Winter is best known for its snow and Christmas holidays, but it also has New Year's Eve (December 31, in recognition of the beginning of a new year) and other special days. Ice skating, sledding, ice hockey and snowball fights are often enjoyed in winter.
