The Senate Intelligence Committee has passed a bill that would provide greater transparency in the massive collection of American telephone records by the National Security Agency, but will allow the controversial practice to continue. Sponsored by President Dianne Feinstein, the bill allows the NSA to continue collecting telephone metadata from millions of Americans for 90-day renewable periods and allows the government to retain them. Some legislators have alternatively proposed allowing telephone companies to maintain metadata. He approved the committee by a vote 11-4, paving the way for a full Senate vote.
The bill allows analysts to search through the data if they suspect that there is a "reasonable suspicion" that a suspect is associated with international terrorism. In addition, the bill allows the NSA to continue to monitor foreigners outside the U.S. if they enter the country "for a transitional period not exceeding 72 hours".
The bill is a direct challenge to one presented by Senator Patrick Leahy that would end the collection of national telephone records. Also opposed was Mark Udall, a leading member of the Intelligence Committee, who said he did not go far enough. "The NSA's invasive surveillance of Americans' private information does not respect our constitutional values and needs fundamental reform, not incidental changes. Unfortunately, the bill passed by the Senate Intelligence Committee does not go far enough to address NSA’s over-scope internal surveillance programs,” Udall said.
Another Democratic member of the committee, Ron Wyden, said the bill maintains “business as usual” and “is still far from anything that can be considered meaningful reform.” Feinstein defended the NSA's massive collection program, but said it was necessary to rebuild public confidence. “The NSA’s call record program is legal and subject to extensive parliamentary and judicial oversight, and I believe it contributes to our national security,” he said in a statement. “But more can and must be done to increase transparency and foster public support for privacy protections.”
In his statement, Feinstein said that the bill would also make a number of improvements to the transparency and oversight of the NSA, including: requiring an annual public report of the total number of NSA telephone metadata database queries and the number of times the program leads to an FBI investigation or probable cause order; requiring the foreign intelligence court to impose limits on the number of individuals in the NSA who may authorize or consult the call record database; establishing criminal penalties of up to 10 years in prison for unauthorized access to data acquired under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) by the United States; ordering the FISA court to impose a limit on the number of contacts that an analyst may receive in response to a bulk communications record consultation.
After the committee hearing, Feinstein strongly supported the NSA's main national programme. “I think there’s a big misunderstanding about this NSA database program, and how vital it is to protect this country,” he told reporters.
Concern over the Intelligence Committee bill was expressed by independent legal experts, who said that the scenario was now ready for a confrontation with the U.S. Freedom Act, a bill submitted by Leahy and Jim Sensenbrenner that would prohibit the massive collection of U.S. telephone records.
Elizabeth Goitein of the Brennan Center for Justice said: “The Intelligence Committee Bill and the U.S. Freedom Act present two opposing views of the relationship between law-abiding Americans and the state of national security. The fundamental question is: should the government have any reason to suspect that it has committed a crime before sweeping the most personal information from Americans to feed itself in its databases? Leahy and Sensenbrenner say yes; Feinstein says no.” Wyden suggested that the recent concern over NSA spying on foreign leaders had distracted the real focus on mass domestic surveillance in the United States. “The statements that U.S. intelligence officials have made about collecting about the intentions of foreign management, that’s consistent with the understanding I’ve had for years, as a member of the Intelligence Committee,” he said. “That has implications for foreign policy. My top priority is to put an end to mass surveillance, digital surveillance, of millions and millions of law-abiding Americans.”
Feinstein unexpectedly announced that he was “totally opposed” to the foreign leader spying on the NSA’s behavior of German Chancellor Angela Merkel. Feinstein has been a strong supporter of the NSA's massive collection of American telephone records.
“Americans are making it clear that they never – I repeat, never – agreed to give up their constitutional freedoms because of the appearance of security,” Wyden said. “We’re just going to keep fighting this battle. It’s going to be a long one.”
On the other hand, Feinstein said that James Clapper, the Director of National Intelligence, had agreed to provide him with a written statement about a Washington Post story that claimed that NSA had intercepted data in transmission between Google and Yahoo data centers. She said she was holding back the trial of history until she saw Clapper's rebuttal. His firm support for the collection of national telephone records indicates that the powerful Senate Democrat is not yet ready to expand the criticism of the NSA he has launched, “totally opposing” his surveillance of foreign allied leaders – a more traditional intelligence activity than surveillance of massive telephone metadata.
Wyden would not comment on the Washington Post's report on Google and Yahoo's interceptions. But the senators suggested that it had implications for Americans' privacy of communication. “For decades, countries had their own communication systems. Now that you’ve had the fusion of global communications, I think you’re going to have many more challenges spying on foreigners with implications for American citizens,” Wyden said.

Gilbert Ryle listed Anderson among the “greater” who had preceded his own generation: philosophers such as Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Bradley, Stout, McTaggert, Alexander, Laird and Kemp Smith. For Ryle, Anderson’s generation represented “the old gang,” many of the products of “the dominant Scottish teachers” who had established philosophy as academic discipline at English-speaking universities around the world. Anderson was an exact contemporary of Wittgenstein and Heidegger, yet only seven years older than Ryle himself. But Ryle seems to have a point in suggesting a generation gap that separated him from the “pieces, lords, sagacity, equipment – yes, and fetishes” of that previous generation (Ryle 1976: 383). Ryle was describing the generation of philosophers who were adults before or during the Great War. He only became familiar with Anderson in the 1950s and was struck by the way Anderson had continued a form of philosophy in modern times that had given way to other philosophies more related to linguistic use. Despite this recognition of the interpretative challenges, for many of Anderson’s followers at that time Ryle radically misinterpreted Anderson’s work (Ryle 1950), reading it from the perspective of “linguistic turn.”
For current readers there are indeed several obstacles to approaching Anderson's work. His published works, mainly articles for the Australasian Journal of Philosophy and Psychology and in local magazines and newspapers, are difficult without the context of Anderson's broader teaching. They are generally considered as subsidiaries of Andersonian lectures and learning programs. It seems that they were written for the benefit of students who already had the value of their personal contact. Without this contact, we must rely on the publication of several series of conference notes from Anderson's works by Sydney University Press (see Bibliography). Anderson's isolation from his fellow intellectuals and his apparent reluctance to participate in the international debate also deprive contemporary students of the opportunity to place their work within a more familiar territory.
A point of access to Anderson's work for contemporary students, of course, is found in the work of his students as D. M. Armstrong, John Passmore, and J. L. Mackie. But there is a danger even here that your specialties may distort our view of Anderson's work as a whole. Anderson, as Passmore pointed out, was a generalist (Passmore, Introduction to Anderson's Posthumous Work, Studies in Empirical Philosophy, EMP). Unlike the next generation, he hoped that all spheres of philosophical research would be open to his research and his philosophy would extend to all spheres: logic, metaphysics, ethics, political thought, aesthetics, education.
Anderson describes his position as an empiricist, realistic, naturalist, physical, positivist and pluralist, conceiving each of them as different aspects of the only truly empirical philosophy. But their use of these terms is problematic for the uninitiated. Anderson's empiricism has no time for representative visions of truth, nor for traditional empiricist entities of data or sensory ideas. Empirism for Anderson is an ontological doctrine that affirms a single form of being to which we belong as researchers. Although certainly committed to empirical research and the fallible nature of all propositional claims, Anderson's empiricism is only secondary to an epistemological point of view related to how we come to know things within this space-time world. Anderson's realism rejects traditional realistic-nominalist choices about the existence of universals. Universals are brought to earth (space-temporal), but there are no such things as pure universes or pure details outside their roles within complex states of affairs. Mentality is a product of physicochemical processes in the brain, but this does not prevent our research into the nature of the mind as a field of conflicting tendencies, feelings and emotions. Whatever special sciences tell us about their particular subjects, philosophy retains its authority in questions of logic, that is, in terms of the conditions of possibility of discourse. In fact, modern science is seriously infected by the instrumentalistic and technological viewpoints of its research and needs to become more truly philosophical and critical, more concerned about establishing what is the case within specific fields, and less about being practical and useful in relation to perceived social needs (EMP, 290). Positivism is then for Anderson a commitment to what is objectively and positively the case, and not an instrumental or operational truth program, nor a means of distinguishing between meaningful words and meaningless words. Anderson’s call for an “ethical science” is not an assimilation of ethical research to special science standards. It is a request for an objective investigation of ethics, focused on the existing ethical qualities of human activities, rather than on the pieces of traditional moral philosophy: questions of law, obligation, duty, etc.
Ryle was the first of many to be accused of misinterpreting Anderson. The criticisms of Anderson's position from within English philosophy have always seemed to his followers to lose their mark. They have not generally recognized the ontological, non-representative, non-semantic basis of their empiricism. Robert Brandom’s recent criticism and rejection of the “theoretical, explanatory and strategic commitments” that motivate Anglo-American philosophy in the twentieth century lists them as: empiricism, naturalism, representationalism, semantic atomism, formalism on logic, instrumentalism on practical norms (Brandom 2000). It is extraordinary that none of these criticized traits touch John Anderson's philosophy as they are (at least as Brandom describes them). Brandom considers that the notion of “facts” and “states of things” is emblematic of atomic and representative thinking. Anderson would have responded impatiently as he did with Gilbert Ryle’s “representative” criticisms: “That’s nothing to me.”
Many of the problems that contemporary readers encounter in Anderson's work are the result of his relative international isolation. But for many of his students it was precisely Anderson's traditional secessionist stance that was the key to the great value of Andersonian education. He may have failed in his project, but remained alive in Sydney supporting the values of traditional philosophical research at a time when dominant philosophy was obsessed with linguistic use on the one hand or deference to natural sciences on the other. Many of Anderson's students expected their philosophy to resurface stronger after the inevitable decline of linguistic philosophy and renewed interest in the metaphysical issues that followed this decline. But if his work played any part in this renewal it was only indirectly through the work of his student D.M. Armstrong. Contemporary philosophers interested in metaphysical issues do not refer to Anderson's work and are frankly bewildered by Armstrong's enthusiasm for his master's work. Anderson exists today almost exclusively in the footnotes of his most committed and accomplished students.

text:
While eating in a restaurant is a pleasant and convenient taste from time to time, most people and families prepare their meals at home. To make breakfast, lunch, and dinner daily, these people must have the food and ingredients required by hand and ready to go; foods and ingredients are typically purchased at a supermarket, or an establishment that distributes food, beverages, household products, and other items that are used by the typical consumer.
Production, or the term used to describe fresh fruits and vegetables, is commonly bought by grocery shop buyers. In terms of fruits, most grocery stores offer bananas, apples, oranges, blackberries, raspberries, grapes, pineapples, melons, watermelons, and more; other grocery stores with selections of larger products could offer the fruits listed, plus less common fruits, including mangoes, honeys, stellars, coconuts and more.
Depending on the grocery store, customers can buy fruits in several different ways. Some stores will charge a fixed amount per pound of fruit, and will weigh customers' fruit purchases and bill them accordingly; other stores will charge customers for each piece of fruit they buy, or for fruit parcels (a bag of bananas, a bag of apples, etc. ); other stores will however simply load through the container.
Vegetables, including lettuce, corn, tomatoes, onions, celery, cucumbers, mushrooms, and more are also sold in many grocery stores, and are purchased in a similar way to the way fruits are. Grocery stores tend to store more vegetables than fruits at any given time, as vegetables stay fresh longer than fruits, generally speaking.
It would take quite some time to list everything else sold by today's huge grocery stores, but most customers take the opportunity to buy basics, or foods that play a prominent role in the average diet, in establishments. Staples include pasta, rice, flour, sugar, milk, meat and eggs, and bread. All the listed commodities are available in pre-packaged packaging, but you can buy "fresh" from some grocery stores, where employees will measure and weigh fresh products and then provide them to customers.

text:
Pregnancy and childbirth have been increasingly medicated in most parts of the world since the early twentieth century. In other words, there are more and more processes that, in fact and as a social ideal, are managed and supervised by medical professionals, usually involve a high degree of technological medical intervention and contact with clinics and hospitals, and are evaluated by medical experts who are the authorities on their progress. Amy Mullin explains that medicalized pregnancy “involves the interpretation of pregnancy itself as a health disorder that necessarily requires expert medical intervention, and think of pregnancy as primarily about health and disease” (Mullin 2005, 54). The concept of medicalization is useful to make clear how this type of insertion in a medical context is not (or not simply) a response to fixed biological facts, but rather a contingent social and institutional process. Death, depression, and short attention span are other examples of processes or conditions that have suffered intense medicalization. In general, medicalization carries benefits and burdens, and the medicalization of pregnancy and birth is no exception. More and more obstetricians would say that intensive medicalization directly promotes good birth outcomes for mothers and babies; rather, almost everyone would recognize that although medical interventions have decreased many risks (e.g. previous placenta death and ectopic pregnancy), other medical interventions have become routine despite not having any proven benefit and some added risks tested for patients (e.g. routine foetal control, normalisation of the position of the litotomy for delivery and episiotomy). Partly because of these mixed effects of increased medicalization, the opposite narratives of pregnancy and birth continue to grow in visibility and support. These narratives may aim to demedicate the notion of normality in pregnancy and birth, or centralize midwife knowledge and competence (e.g., Lyerly 2012; Shaw 2013)
The medicalization of pregnancy and birth takes many forms. Births in North America usually involve a variety of technological interventions, including regular labor-inducing drugs, spinal epidurals, fetal monitoring, and, in about one third of births, surgical delivery. Prior to birth, most pregnancies will involve medical interventions such as genetic testing, ultrasound, prescriptions to control various symptoms and risks, and often increasing technological assistance for conception. However, it is important to note that the rate and intensity at which such interventions are offered or imposed is far from uniform. Dorothy Roberts highlights the striking disparity of benefits she enjoys as a result of medicalization: "The multimillion dollar apparatus dedicated to technologically facilitating the reproductive choices of rich couples contrasts with the high infant mortality rate among blacks, which remains more than double the rate for whites" (2009, 784, citing Mathews and MacDorman 2007). Some dimensions of pregnancy medicalization do not directly involve medical interventions. Both inside and outside the clinic, pregnancy is treated as a medical event that requires intense risk management, monitoring and appeal to expert medical knowledge: pregnant women are expected to regulate and monitor their diet, drink, fetal kicks, weight gain, sleeping position, emotions, exposure to household commodities, exercise, sexual activity, and many other aspects of their lives in accordance with standards set by medical professionals (Kukla 2005). Recently, a strong mandate has been given for medical professionals to participate in helping women regulate their bodies in accordance with medical standards to minimize the risk of reproduction even before conception. CDC now recommends that all primary care for all women who may eventually become pregnant (including prepubescents) be treated as “preconceptive care” (Kuehn 2006). Most women cover at least some aspects of medicalization; many take it as part of responsible motherhood to maximize the expert management of their pregnancies and carefully follow the risk minimisation advice (Seigel 2013).
The general tendency to medicate pregnancy and birth has had several ethically significant effects (Davis-Floyd 2004, Duden 1993, Mitchell 2001, Morgan 1998, Sherwin 1992). First, medicalization has encouraged us to imagine pregnancy and birth as inherently high-risk pathological processes that it is irresponsible to undertake without a lot of expert help and surveillance. Secondly, when medical professionals become the main managers of reproduction, the epistemic privilege of pregnant women is undermined and can be said to be reduced to passive roles in their own pregnancies and births (e.g., Freeman 2015). Thirdly, some have argued that medicalization has made pregnancy in general, and childbirth and birth in particular, more alienating and stressful for women, subjecting them to constant and complicated responsibilities for risk management and body and behavioral surveillance (see, for example, Mykitiuk and Scott 2011; Savell 2012).
Among the voices that oppose the medicalization of reproduction are those that insist that pregnancy is a ‘natural’ process that usually does not need technological assistance, and advocate for ‘natural’ childbirth, free of work and pain medications and attended by midwives rather than doctors. There are reasons for philosophers to be as cautious with the ‘natural’ birth movement as with uncritical and uncontrolled medicalization (Kukla 2005, Lyerly 2006 and 2012, Purdy 2001). Typically, their advocates do not specify a clear concept of the “natural”, for example, they do not realize why prescription pain medications are “unnatural” while acupuncture or pain-relieving herbs are “natural”. Nor do they explain why "natural" is a better or more ethical prima facie case. More generally, this account of pregnancy and birth implies comparable pressures on pregnant women to conform to rigid standards of attitudes and behaviour, and, like the medicalized narrative, risks depoliticizing and essentializing the experience and management of pregnant women (Beckett 2005, Malacrida and Boulton 2014).

For the Baron and many others, Leonardo Bruni (1369–1444) was regarded as the paradigm of Italian civic humanism (Hankins 1995: 327; Witt 2003: 392–442), the example of the synthesis of humanist study and public engagement: he served twice as Chancellor of Florence and was intermittently employed in administrative positions by the papacy. At the same time, Bruni was a prodigious author and translator, composing a multi-volume history of the Florentine people (based on their access to primary sources), producing Latin versions of works by Aristotle (including Politics) and other Greek texts, writing biographies of Italian notables for popular consumption, among many other literary activities.
More significantly for today's purposes, Bruni used his great scholarship to defend and promote the cause of the Republican government, especially as practiced in Florence during his time. His Laudatio (1403–1404 [1978]) are paeans to the city in general (for example, in terms of architectural and artistic beauty, its cleanliness, its location, and its abundant resources) but also specifically to the virtue of its citizens and its institutions. (Remember a central feature of the “Thesis of Baron” mentioned above derived from the statement that the crisis of Milan in 1402 gave rise to civic humanism both in theory and in practice, with Bruni as his exemplary exponent.) Like his contemporaries, Bruni believed that Florence had been founded by the Romans during the republican era, making its citizens typically lovers of freedom who also opposed imperial and tyrannical domination. This legacy of Rome also gave rise to the peaceful and peaceful relations of Florence with other Italian cities and its citizens, marked by the protection of all Italy from domination threatened by the Milanese. Florence was indeed the savior of the Italian people.
Both the Panegyrian and the Laudatio explain the greatness of Florence in terms of its autonomous political system. The institutions promote and promote the public virtue of citizens. Bruni postulates a triad of fundamental republican principles that Florence brings together: freedom (freedoms), equality (aequalites) and just right (ius). The Florentine constitution is so organized that citizens are free because they are equal before the law. These qualities lead us to one of Bruni's favorite concepts in his political theory: harmonious cooperation and balance among all groups and classes within the city. Other Italian cities, he observes, are full of class conflict between the great men and the mass of the people. The Florentine Republic differs because the whole body of its citizens participates, as appropriate, in the government, which, because it is controlled in its power, resists the temptation of tyranny, either by a few or by many. Civic humanism, at least as the Baron and scholars who work in a similar line understand it, is perfectly captured in the stories of Florence in the Panegyric and Laudatio.

text:
The number of Americans submitting new applications for unemployment benefits fell even further last week, suggesting that the labour market was stabilizing as authorities began to loosen pandemic restrictions on business.
Despite signs that layoffs are declining, the Department of Labor's weekly unemployment claims report on Thursday showed that at least 17.8 million Americans were in benefits by mid-January, indicating that long-term unemployment was likely to be entrenched. That could boost President Joe Biden's momentum for the U.S. Congress to approve his $1.9 billion recovery plan.
Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen told ABC's Good Morning America that the massive stimulus plan was needed to overcome the economic pain caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.
“It’s too early to predict that this starts a strong investment of extremely high layoffs,” said Robert Frick, a corporate economist at the Federal Navy Credit Union in Vienna, Virginia. “Another round of stimuli is important.”
Initial State unemployment benefit applications decreased from 33,000 to 779,000 seasonal for the week ending 30 January. That was the third weekly decline in a row. Economists surveyed by Reuters had predicted 830,000 applications for the last week.
Unadjusted claims decreased from 23,525 to 816,247 last week. Including a government-funded program for self-employed, concert workers and others who do not qualify for regular state unemployment programs, 1,165 million people filed complaints last week, compared to 1,243 million in the previous period.
The claims remain above their peak of 665,000 during the Great Recession 2007-2009, but well below the record of 6.867 million last March, when the pandemic hit the United States.
Part of the rise in claims reflects people reapplying for benefits after the government renewed at the end of December an unemployment supplement of $300 up to March 14 as part of a pandemic aid package worth nearly $900 billion.
“The decline in new claims in recent weeks adds to the evidence that the worst months for the labor market could be very well behind us,” said Sarah House, senior economist at Wells Fargo Securities in Charlotte, North Carolina.
Shares on Wall Street were higher. The dollar went up in front of a basket of coins. US Treasury prices were mostly lower.
Although January was the worst month since the beginning of the pandemic, the decline in economic activity stabilized in the second half of the month in the midst of signs of a peak in the recent wave of coronavirus.
The data from Homebase, a payroll programming and monitoring company, showed their measure of employees in the work flattened in the last two weeks of January, stopping the decrease observed between December and January.
Other Thursday data from global company Challenger, Gray & Christmas showed that job cuts announced by U.S.-based employers increased by only 3.3 per cent to 79,552 in January.
The claims report also showed that the number of persons receiving benefits after an initial week of assistance decreased from 193,000 to 4,592 million during the week ending 23 January. Some 17,836 million people received unemployment benefits in all programmes in mid-January, compared with 18,322 million in the first week of 2021.
The data from last week's complaints have nothing to do with Friday's employment report, which is examined closely in January, as it is outside the survey period, which was in the middle of the month. However, signs of stability in other labour market measures support expectations that recruitment rebounded in January after the economy stopped working in December for the first time in eight months.
Expectations that the economy would create jobs last month were boosted by Wednesday's reports showing rebounds in private payroll and employment in the service industry in January. A survey this week also showed that manufacturers hired more workers in January.
According to a Reuters survey of economists' payrolls, it probably increased by 50,000 jobs in January after declining by 140,000 in December. Following rather optimistic reports, Goldman Sachs raised his payroll forecasts from 75,000 to 200,000.
However, some economists are struggling for a second consecutive month of job losses in January. Last week's Conference Council survey showed that consumers' perceptions of labour market conditions deteriorated even further last month.
The economy has recovered 12.5 million of the 22.2 million jobs lost in March and April. The Congressional Budget Office estimated Monday that employment would not return to its pre-pandemic level before 2024.
Economists were not disturbed by a separate report on Thursday from the Labor Department showing that workers' productivity fell at an annualized rate of 4.8 per cent in the fourth quarter. This was the deepest rate of decline since the second quarter of 1981 and followed a rate of expansion of 5.1 per cent in the third quarter. The pandemic has brought about radical changes in productivity.
“This decline came after very strong productivity growth in the middle quarters of the year, and we believe that the pandemic has led to a shift in economic activity in some low productivity sectors that has led to a reaffirmation of productivity growth through some noise in quarterly readings,” said Daniel Silver, an economist at JPMorgan in New York.

text:
When Leondra Garrett wanted to acquire three new pairs of shoes earlier last year, North Carolina resident split an online purchase of $161 into four installments through a “buy now, pay later” service, in what seemed like a convenient deal.
When purchasing now, paying later (BNPL) supplier tried to withdraw a payment from Garrett's bank account a few months later, she did not have enough funds to cover it. Shortly thereafter, the 42-year-old girl was charged $40 in penalties and her credit score dropped 10 points to 650, a reading generally classified as ‘just’.
“It’s important that consumers always read the fine print and we don’t always read it,” said Garrett, a community organizer from Charlotte.
So called buying now, paying for later services - offered by providers such as Affirme Holdings Inc, Klarna, Afterpay Ltd and PayPal Holding Inc “Pay In 4” - have flourished through retail websites during the coronavirus pandemic as people have become more into online shopping.
However, the ease with which many buyers can shop concerns some regulators around the world, who fear that consumers are spending more than they can afford.
Nearly 40% of American consumers who used “buy now, pay later” have lost more than one payment, and 72% of those who saw their credit score decrease, according to a study by Credit Karma, which offers customers credit score check for free.
The study, conducted for Reuters, surveyed 1,038 adult consumers in the United States to measure the interest in “buy now, pay later” and found that 42 percent of respondents had used the service before.
“The percentage of consumers missing payments is remarkable and not as low as expected,” said Gannesh Bharadhwaj, general manager of credit cards at Credit Karma.
“When you do something so convenient, people may not really be thinking, ‘ Do I have the budget? Can I afford this payment?’ You get more from that impulse buying behavior that leads you to realize that you may not be able to make the payment.”
A lower credit score tells lenders that a consumer can be more risky and makes it harder for the consumer to borrow, either to secure a mortgage or a new credit card. It can even make it more difficult for a consumer to establish utility accounts or find housing, as owners usually make credit score checks before renting apartments.
Management consultants Oliver Wyman estimate that BNPL companies provided between $20 and $25 billion in transactions in the United States last year, although analysts estimate that the size of the BNPL industry varies because it is relatively new and some of the companies are private. Individually, they described explosive growth last year as their services became more frequent.
Afterpay, headquartered in Australia, said it saw US customers more than double to 6.5 million in the fiscal year ended June 30, 2020, and its sales more than triple in the July-September quarter of a year earlier.
More than half of Afterpay's customers in the United States are millennials, aged 25-40, he said.
BNPL models vary, as some companies earn most of the profits by charging fees to traders at the point of sale, and others by charging interest and late fees to consumers. They say their services help traders boost sales and consumers to buy the things they need, and cause less financial damage than credit cards because of the restrictions they impose.
However, regulators in Britain and Australia are reviewing or tightening the rules around industry. BNPL service providers, classified as fintech companies, should be subject to stricter rules, such as banks, say some regulators.
It's not clear how to buy now, paying later fits in with U.S. regulations. Because the companies that offer these services do not have bank charters, some do not charge interest and the laws vary according to the state. However, some experts hope that the sector will be given greater scrutiny during the Biden administration.
“One of the questions with the new administration is, what position will the Consumer Financial Protection Office take? – which we hope will be more aggressive,” said Mark Palmer, finance analyst at BTIG Research.
Based in San Francisco, Affirmante saw its revenue increase from 93%, to $509.5 million, in the fiscal year that ended in June. It allows buyers to split purchases in terms ranging from six weeks to four years, with interest rates from 0 to 30%.
Affirming shows customers how much a dollar loan will cost and does not charge late fees or compound interest. Although lost payments may affect credit scores, they claim that they have been working with borrowers who fell in difficult times during the pandemic.
“We approve borrowers only for what they can comfortably pay,” said Silvija Martincevic, Commercial Director of Affirmation. “The reason our technology is significant is that we use machine learning to make subscription decisions.”
In Australia's Afterpay, customers are prohibited from using their services after losing a payment.
The company says 95% of its global transactions are paid on time and late fees contribute less than 14% of the company's total revenue.
The PayPal ‘Pay in 4’ service, launched extensively in the United States in November, allows customers to split purchases ranging from $30 to $600 into four interest-free payments. Late rates can be applied for lost payments, depending on the user's state of residence, according to your website.
The PayPal ‘Pay in 4’ product in the United States does not report transactions or late fees to credit offices, said Greg Lisiewski, Global Pay Later’s Global Vice President.
“We’re working with industry and consumer credit offices to develop the right framework,” he said.
Klarna, based in Sweden, experienced rapid growth over the past year, especially purchases in the range of $100-200, said its U.S. chief, David Sykes.
Most of Klarna's loans are small, short-lived and interest-free, which is safer for customers than credit cards, he said. Customers can delay a payment without penalty. Late rates vary according to the state in line with the regulation, up to a maximum of $21 and the company is implementing a 25% cap.
“No one is being buried in debt to Klarna,” Sykes said. “We’re not borrowing for several years in a car or house.”
Smaller loans with a shorter duration have benefits, but they are not risk-free, experts said. Customers may be taking on more debt than they can handle, even if it comes in portions the size of a bite.
Tamika Rivera, a 35-year-old insurance agent from Springfield, Massachusetts, uses multiple purchases now, pays for later services, and has lost payments. In one case, she didn't have enough money to cover a $43 sweater purchase, resulting in a $35 overdraft rate from her bank.
“These services are convenient but there are some negative things that can happen,” Rivera said.
Alan McIntyre, head of Accenture's global banking practice, says the credit impact of the purchase now, the later payment trend is yet to be seen.
“The optimistic idea is that millennials don’t want to go into debt and want to build a better budget – this is deferred debit and are not tempted to change it,” he said.
“The pessimistic view is that about 40% of people who use it do so because they cannot access traditional credit, either because they have reached their credit limit or because of a poor or non-existent credit history, and some of these loans may not have a good season.”

text:
Margaret Thatcher, the most dominant British prime minister since Winston Churchill in 1940 and world champion of the economic revival of the free market at the end of the 20th century, has died. The British government announced that it would receive a ceremonial funeral with military honors at St. Paul's Cathedral.
British Prime Minister David Cameron, who is cutting off his trip to Europe to return to London after the news, said: “It was with great sadness that I learned of Lady Thatcher’s death. We have lost a great leader, a great prime minister and a great British.” He added: “As our first female prime minister, Margaret Thatcher succeeded against all odds, and Margaret Thatcher’s real thing is that she not only ran our country, but saved our country, and I think she will become Britain’s greatest prime minister in peace time.”
In a statement, President Barack Obama said: “Here in the United States, many of us will never forget his shoulder to shoulder with President Reagan, reminding the world that we are not simply driven by the currents of history, we can shape them with moral conviction, unwavering courage and iron will.”
The first woman elected to lead a major western state, Lady Thatcher, when she became after the longest premiere since 1827, served 11 uninterrupted years on No. 10 Downing Street.
Thatcher, 87 years old, has been deteriorating health for a few years, suffering from dementia. After a series of mini strikes in 2002, Thatcher retired from public life, he is no longer able to make the kind of wasp statements that had been his fort in office – and beyond.
His death was received with tributes from the entire political spectrum.
As Labour sources announced that the party would suspend the campaign in the local elections as a sign of respect, its leader, Ed Miliband, said: “It will be remembered as a unique figure. He reformed the politics of an entire generation. She was Britain's first female prime minister. She moved the center of British politics and was a huge figure on the world stage. The Labour Party disagreed with much of what it did and will always remain a controversial figure. But we can disagree and also respect to a great extent their political achievements and their personal strength.”
Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg said: “Margaret Thatcher was one of the defining figures in modern British politics. Whatever side of the political debate he is in, no one can deny that as prime minister he left a unique and lasting footprint in the country he served.”
In describing it as a political phenomenon, former conservative Prime Minister Sir John Major said: “Its outstanding characteristics will always be remembered by those who worked closely with it: courage and determination in politics, and humanity and generosity of spirit in private.”
The “Iron Lady” proved to be an important cold war ally of U.S. President Ronald Reagan in the final confrontation with the Soviet Union, which broke under reformist pressures led by Mikhail Gorbachev, Kremlin leader with whom Thatcher declared that he could “do business. ” As a result, many voters from the former Soviet bloc states saw her as a bold advocate of her freedom, a widely shared opinion across the spectrum of US dominant opinion, though not at home or among the EU's main partners.
Thatcher was an unprecedented middle-ranking conservative until she unexpectedly became party leader in 1975. In a decade, she had become known all over the world – both admired and hated – for her pro-market internal reforms and unrelenting foreign policy attitudes, including her long battle with the IRA, which almost succeeded in killing her when she planted a bomb at the Grand Hotel, Brighton, in 1984.
At home, the emerging doctrine of Thatcherism meant the denationalization of state industry – the new word "privatization" came into use in many countries – and the defeat of militant trade unionists, in particular the National Union of Miners, whose one-year strike (1984–85) was bitter and traumatic.
Driven by the newly arrived revenues from the North Sea oil fields, Thatcher had room to maneuver and change the aging industrial economy and took the opportunity to defeat his enemies, including moderate members of his own party.
But he also deployed in the European Union his notorious “handbands,” or verbal attacks, to get a British discount – “my money,” as she called it. She was less successful in defending herself from the centralizing ambitions of the “Belgian Empire”, her description of the European Commission, especially in the years when she was headed by the French socialist Jacques Delors.
Her allies in the tabloid press excited her. And as the British economy recovered from the severe recession its monetarist medicine had inflicted on it – to tame trade unions and cure inflation – it seemed briefly invincible.
But unbridled power, with the defeat or withdrawal of the allies who had kept it under control, led to errors and growing unpopularity. When Sir Geoffrey Howe, nominally his deputy, finally fought with Thatcher – mainly about Europe – his devastating resignation speech triggered a leadership challenge. Thatcher gave way to John Major instead of risking losing him in a vote.
In retirement, he wrote highly successful memoirs in two volumes and campaigned energetically on behalf of the Thatcher Foundation, which tried to promote its values around the world.

text:
As we commemorate the twenty-fifth celebration of World AIDS Day on 1 December, we have a golden opportunity to begin ending the HIV/AIDS pandemic.
To begin with, this has been an extraordinary year for research on HIV/AIDS, with advances in headlines that are undeniable proof of progress towards a cure.
The first documented case of a child cured of HIV, reported in March, was followed in July by a report of two adult HIV patients who no longer showed any signs of viruses after having undergone stem cell transplants and stopping antiretroviral treatment.
Much remains to be done before these and other scientific advances can be translated into a widely applicable cure that can be made available to the 35 million people living with HIV/AIDS around the world.
But it is an irony that borders on the tragedy that, like a cure for HIV/AIDS is beginning to look like a realistic proposal, tight austerity measures could stop our momentum, paralyze our progress and frustrate our hopes for ending AIDS in our lives.
As a result of the hijacking of the United States budget, the National Institutes of Health -- the engine of progress in AIDS research for 30 years -- will lose $229 million in AIDS research funding next year.
This limits a sad decade for AIDS and other support for biomedical research: From 2003 to 2012, NIH lost 22 of its purchasing power as a result of stagnating funding levels.
This hammer blow to AIDS research funding will be accompanied by cuts to a number of other HIV/AIDS programmes, cuts that will have a negligible impact on the federal deficit but will have real consequences for people living with HIV/AIDS in the United States and around the world.
Alicia Keys: Out loud on the fight against HIV
Based on the latest available data, amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research, has estimated that the reduction in funding for the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief - LRB-PEPFAR-RRB - could only result in 228,000 fewer people receiving HIV treatment. This could lead to up to 52,000 AIDS-related deaths and could leave more than 100,000 children orphaned.
The Institute of Medicine has said that PEPFAR has been globally transformative and has had significant positive effects on the health and well-being of individual beneficiaries, on the institutions and systems of partner countries and on the overall AIDS response.
Interactive: World AIDS Day and what it means
Why, then, are we shortening a program that enjoys broad bipartisan and popular support, has done more than any other foreign policy initiative in recent years to burn the image of the United States abroad, and has already altered, but not irreversibly, the trajectory of the HIV/AIDS pandemic?
Nor will people living with HIV be saved here in the United States. amfAR also estimates that the kidnapper could cause some 15,000 Americans who need help paying for their medications to lose support from the AIDS Assistance Program.
And more than 4,000 households could lose housing aid as a result of cuts in the federally funded housing opportunities program for people with AIDS. All these cuts will fall disproportionately on people of color.
Just a few years ago, many considered the notion of a cure for HIV heretical. I was creating false hopes. It wasn't technically feasible. It couldn't be done. All this changed with the first reports, in 2008, of Timothy Brown, the Berlin patient.
While on HIV treatment, Brown was diagnosed with leukemia. To treat leukemia, she received a stem cell transplant... with a twist. His wise German doctor deliberately sought, and found, a stem cell donor among a very small group of people born with a genetic mutation that makes them highly resistant to HIV infection. After the transplant, Brown was able to stop HIV treatment without experiencing a return of the disease.
Zero new HIV infections among children can be a reality
Similarly, the idea of an AIDS-free generation today is shaken with abandonment. It wasn't always like that. But for more than 30 years, we have developed a series of tools that enable us to effectively prevent and treat HIV infection. In addition, research has shown us conclusively that treatment is prevention. Putting people on antiretroviral drugs makes them less infectious and less likely to transmit the virus to others.
Combine a wider deployment of these tools with an expansion of programs such as PEPFAR and a sustained investment in research, and you have a trifecta: a winning combination that could achieve the conquest of the AIDS pandemic in the foreseeable future.
Back off on AIDS, and you'll practically guarantee that we'll take care of it for generations.
Bill Gates: Where to put the smart money to end AIDS
The views expressed are only those of Kevin Robert Frost and Sharon Stone.

text:
The beginning of the year is probably the first time to feel sad about work: it is ages until the next vacation, and it is night in the morning and when you arrive home. And, if you're stuck in a job you don't like, it might be enough to have to get to your CV.
But, before you start looking through job ads, try to put things in perspective. So what else could you be doing instead? We asked five people who did some unusual jobs how much they were paid, what the worst parts were and why they enjoyed their work.
1. Dog food taster
Work: Tasting food for dogs to make sure it meets the quality standards of a premium brand
What it means: Open sample cans of each newly made batch of dog food (or cats), smelling it and eating it. “Although the palates of dogs are different from ours, the taste is an important quality control to ensure that each different ingredient is perfectly balanced in the right way,” says Philip Wells, the main taster of the Lily’s Kitchen pet food. “Trying food is also a good way to capture the nuances of cooking; this works especially well in dry food.”
Typical salary: £20,000 for an entrance level job in the quality department. However, Wells says that £50,000 or more is “easily achievable” for an experienced technical director who, as well as tasting products, is also likely to be responsible for developing new recipes and advising the business on technical and regulatory issues. The worst part of the job: The deadlines, for Wells, who admits he likes food. The meat used in pet food has to be derived from animals passed as fit for human consumption, according to the Animal Feeding Regulations 2010, and says that the company uses “fresh food of fresh human quality” in its recipes. He adds: “There are some rather gruesome pet foods out there and, although I don’t taste them, the smell is enough to turn the stomach when I do some market research.”
Job satisfaction: “There are not two days that are always the same.” It is gratifying, says Wells, that a project he has worked on “will help pets be happier and healthier.” However, he acknowledges that part of the credit should go to another “key member” of the tasting team: Lily, the border terrier.
2. Hygiene technician
The work: Disinfect areas that have been potentially exposed to biohazard situations
What it means: Clean up crime scenes, traffic accidents and suicides. Cleaning the houses of hoarders full of garbage, rats and excrement... among other things. “The job is to keep people safe,” says Richard Lewis, a hygiene technician at Rentokil. “We take care of some very disturbingly dirty places.”
Typical salary: The entry level salary is usually around £14,500 and a higher salary can be up to £22,000. Worst part of the job: Cleaning after suicides. “You get used to the work being disgusting, but the emotional side of it remains difficult.” You learn not to take your job home, he says. “You also have to have a sense of humor, as some days can be difficult.”
Job satisfaction: Lewis finds the variety of tasks exciting. “One day, I’m cleaning after a corpse; another day, I’m in a prison cell or 100 feet in the air being lowered to a silo to clean it.” He also takes pride in the transformation it produces: “It’s satisfying to return a potentially dangerous site to a safe environment. And bene fits with society.”
3. Biogas engineer
Work: Creation of biogas plants in developing countries
This involves: Linking a digester system – which can be filled with human excreta, animal manure and other waste products – to toilets to produce biogas that can be used for cooking and lighting. “We need to know what size and shape the mixer well should have, how to create the optimal temperature for digestion and where to place the biogas plant,” says Baburam Paudel, technical director of the Renewable World charity in Nepal. “We also need to convince poor communities that poo can be productive – many are repelled by the idea of connecting their toilets to their kitchens.”
Typical salary: An entry level salary is about £10,000, while a typical salary for a technical chief is £30,000. The worst part of the job: For Paudel, it is to see people struggling to survive on very little income. But, admit, anyone who doesn't change a diaper would fight. “You have to be willing to get your hands dirty during the construction process and inspections. As expected, anaerobic digestion (the process that occurs when bacteria eat decaying waste and produce methane) smells like rotten eggs. It can be disgusting and there is no place for mistakes.”
Job satisfaction: “It’s immensely satisfying to know that I’m helping people increase their income and allowing girls to attend school by replacing the need to collect firewood,” says Paudel. “My work improves the health and hygiene of entire communities.”
4. Eel Ecologist
Work: The conservation of European eel in critical danger
What it means: Watching the size of endangered eels, environmentalists enter the Thames and other rivers and swamps in London full of eels, sometimes up to their armpits, and reach a network full of up to 20 adult eels to grab one with their own hands. “Adult eels can be one meter long, or even larger, and weigh up to 2 kg. They are not dangerous at all, but they are almost pure muscles and can be a little viscous,” says Stephen Mowat, eel conservationist and environmentalist of the London Zoological Society. “We have to weigh them and measure them, and they twist... a lot. It is difficult to look professional while crawling on the ground chasing an eel through the grass.”
The worst part of the job: “Eels are really complicated creatures to work with – and being smarter than an eel can be pretty embarrassing,” says Mowat. “You also have to be ready to jump from one project to another. I once had to dissect a tub of dead eels to examine the parasites living in them, moments before jumping into a suit for a meeting with government officials. I remembered washing my hands.” But, for Mowat, the worst part of the job is definitely not to handle eels – he believes that baby eels (known as elvers) are “as cute as pandas”: “The worst part of the job is to learn regularly how much damage we are doing to the environment, the British population.”
Job satisfaction: “Getting to work outdoors and seeing British wildlife close up is the best part of the job,” says Mowat. “Eels are beautiful creatures and working with eels not only benefits eel: it helps entire river systems, estuaries and coastal habitats. That’s something worth working on.”
5. Leader of the shopping channel
Work: Sale and demonstration of a wide range of products on live television
What it means: Present hours and hours of monotonous content, at the same time as demonstrating the products and seem enthusiastic and knowledgeable about everything you are selling. “I prepare and research as much technical and practical information as possible about each product in advance,” says Shaun Ryan, host of Ideal World TV. “But you also need the ability to relate to each genre of products and to each viewer.”
Typical wage: An apprentice presenter would start with a minimum of £30,000, while an experienced presenter can expect more than £55,000.
The worst part of the job: “Insociable hours,” Ryan says. “An experienced presenter like me usually works at maximum audience times, which means that every weekend, holidays and very late at night, in addition to the occasional 5 a.m. shift.” His worst task, he says, was just to sell some women’s slimming pants: “It was a very difficult hour and not my fi nest.”
Job satisfaction: “I love the rush to show up live and have to think up every second,” Ryan says. “It also gives me a lot of adrenaline to know that sometimes I have thousands of spectators asking for the product I just presented.”

It is becoming difficult, even for a defense attorney, to follow up on the charges against Bill Cosby. Recently, the lawyers of the beleaguered comedian filed a motion to dismiss a lawsuit accusing the comedian actor of sexually assaulting the plaintiff Judith Huth in 1974 at the Playboy mansion when she was 15.
Huth claims that she and a 16-year-old friend met Cosby in a Los Angeles movie. A week later Cosby allegedly gave them drinks at a tennis club, after which the lawsuit says Cosby took her to the Playboy mansion. At the mansion, Cosby allegedly forced her to perform a sexual act with him.
Cosby and his lawyers aren't gonna go quietly into the good night. They have filed a death complaint challenging the legal sufficiency of the claims or the complaint itself. A demurrer essentially says that the complaint is as flawed as it is written, that it must be dismissed His lawyers have also gone to the offensive, asking the court to impose sanctions on the lawyers who filed this lawsuit.
In the public opinion court, many have already come to the conclusion that there is something in these growing accusations. On the other hand, perhaps the public opinion jury will be influenced by Camille Cosby's replica today that her husband's media coverage is comparable to the article about the alleged gang rape of Rolling Stone UVA. The verdicts in the public opinion court are mercurial and are rarely restricted by the same restrictions applied by the judiciary.
However, in the royal court, the rules are different. Huth's lawyers should have complied with these rules. If they knew it was impossible to comply with the rules, then the lawyers knew when they filed the complaint that it was fatally flawed. Regardless of the breakdown in communication between counsel and client, this complaint should probably be dismissed.
Cosby breaks his silence
Huth filed his complaint long after the time allowed by the prescription. Statutes of limitations are laws that establish the maximum period during which one can wait before filing a claim, and vary depending on the state and type of case. By definition, they deny access to a substantive claim for a purely procedural reason.
Although statute of limitations were arbitrary, public order was not arbitrary: defendants also deserved the protection of the law. It makes sense that you don't have to be brought to court tomorrow for a fender party that you got into with your 1977 AMC Gremlin... in 1977.
But there's a big difference between a minor traffic accident and cases of sexual assault. Prescription periods are more controversial in cases of sexual assault because complainants, sometimes children, repress memories or fear. In fact, the abject terror or trauma caused by an aggressor may be the reason why the victim allows the statute of limitations to extend.
Accordingly, some jurisdictions have special rules that extend the time limit for filing complaints in cases of child sexual abuse. Under California law, the only way an alleged victim of child sexual abuse can file a lawsuit that would otherwise not be enforced is to claim that the psychological injury was repressed and was only discovered in the last three years.
Since this is a period of potentially unlimited limitations, the rule contains two important safeguards to avoid unfounded claims and protect the rights of potential defendants.
First, in asserting claims based on alleged child sexual abuse, a complainant over 26 years of age has to submit certificates of merit, documents executed by an authorized mental health professional certifying that the allegations are substantiated. Cosby's lawyers correctly point out that Huth did not submit the necessary certificates, which exposes the complaint to attack. The public policy behind this rule is sound: taking the word of a plaintiff who repressed a memory that made them lose the statute of limitations invites uncertainty and fraud.
Huth was 15 years old in 1974, when the alleged abuse took place, and at least 55 years when he filed this lawsuit. However, Cosby's lawyers point out that he tried to sell this story to tabloids more than nine years ago. Even if Huth is allowed to present these certificates, which medical professional will certify his memory lost until three years ago from an event he tried to profit from by selling the word a few years before that?
Secondly, the rule provides some protection to potential defendants and their privacy. After all, demanding some initial scientific proof of a repressed memory and injury is a good idea, but a medical provider cannot really provide any assurance about the identity of an aggressor -- apart from relying on the patient's words.
That is why a plaintiff is prohibited under the rules of identifying the defendant by name until the court gives him permission. Huth could have complied with this rule by naming Cosby as John Doe, or some anonymous designation. He didn't. His lawyers filed his complaint by naming Cosby.
You might think that this is just a clerical joke that could be remedied, as many are, by filing a modified complaint - LRB- as she finally did -RRB-. Cosby's lawyers point out that this is not a simple mistake that can be fixed. The plaintiff already identified Cosby in the complaint before obtaining judicial permission.
Even if Huth amended his complaint, Cosby's name is out there. Like Jennifer Lawrence, Kate Upton, and many in Sony have learned, you can't unhook the privacy bell -- once your name -LRB- or image -RRB- is out there, it's out there.
Child sexual abuse is a detestable crime, and injuries last a lifetime. Recognizing this, modern jurisdictions have modified the statute of limitations normally inflexible to allow victims their day in court, while trying to protect future defendants from unmeritorious claims. Huth's case illustrates that these rules are not merely procedural. Violating these standards of protection threatens the public perception of other legitimate victims who want their day in court.
The public opinion court will probably ignore these violations as technicalities, and will continue to judge and condemn Cosby. That's how that court works... unfettered by the inconvenience of the rules of procedure or evidence. But, under the California High Court rules, this complaint must be dismissed.

She is the star of one of the longest and most successful film series in the world, with 23 films and over $6 billion accumulated in the global box office, but James Bond shows no signs of a slowdown. In fact, Bond's brand is stronger than ever, after Skyfall's record performance, which became the biggest movie ever at the UK box office in 2012 and, with its total profits of $1.1 billion, it is currently in ninth place of the highest revenue ever.
Hence the intense interest surrounding the announcement of a few more details of the film of the 24th Bond, especially its official title, Spectre. Question number one is this: Can Spectre repeat Skyfall's trick? Will Skyfall remain a high water mark for Bond film or can Spectre extend this winning race?
Charles Gant, film editor of Heat magazine, says the indications are that it’s going in the right direction.” Skyfall was a brilliant strategic movement,” he says. “It intelligently positioned itself as modern and retro at the same time. He appealed to fans of the Daniel-Craig era, who are relatively newcomers to the franchise, and also managed to involve the oldest and nostalgic elements of the audience, who may have lost interest in the few previous films. With the new title,” he adds, “they’re about to win. My feeling is that Spectre announces that they want to cling to nostalgic Bond fans with more age diversity, as well as retain the younger audience.”
The initial signs are that Eon Productions, the company originally founded in 1961 to make Dr. No and behind all the “officials” Bonds, is doing its best to ensure that lightning strikes twice installing the key creative talent behind Skyfall in Spectre. Daniel Craig has been tied to at least Bond 25, while the same writers have produced the script.
But it's Director Sam Mendes' recapture that gives Bondwatchers the greatest hope. A director mainly known for character studies such as American Beauty and Revolutionary Road, Mendes has taken the Bond series to new heights. Gant says: “Mendes managed to relate to both modern and traditional Bond audiences, and also attracted high-caliber actors like Ralph Fiennes. To attract actors like Fiennes, they have to be happy with the director.”
Among other achievements, Skyfall almost doubled the box office of its predecessor, Quantum of Solace, which achieved a global figure of $586 million at its launch in 2008. Nobody expects anything like that this time, but Eon won't be complacent.
Although the Bond series was not in trouble before the arrival of Mendes – and Craig – there was a sense of a certain amount of rancid towards the end of Pierce Brosnan's career. The series had survived the drying up of Bond's real stories to adapt, the films that had long been drawn from any resemblance to the originals of Ian Fleming, but lacked a certain dynamism.
This cycle, however, was nothing new: the story of the Bond series has been of reflux, stasis and renewal, spinning more obviously around the main actor: first, Sean Connery; then, successively, George Lazenby, Roger Moore, Timothy Dalton, Brosnan and, now, Craig. Each appointment has been a response to the status of the series and some have worked better than others.
Lazenby lasted only one film, while Dalton's two efforts, The Living Daylights and License to Kill coincided with a period in the late 1980s when the film 007 had been completely overshadowed by more aggressive and skillfully produced Hollywood action films. According to Gant, “the period of Roger Moore’s last, entering Dalton, did not really excite the public. Brosnan saw a small commercial upturn, while Craig has taken him to new levels. On the other hand, the first Bonds were incredibly commercial, sexy and exciting movies, and there was very little around like them.”
It is worth noting that, although Skyfall's real revenue dwarfs all the other Bond films, the performance of some of the 1960s entries in the series was almost as brilliant in comparison. With the figures adjusted for inflation, the 1965 release, Thunderball, is just a hair wide below Skyfall, while Goldfinger and You Only Live twice surpassed Craig's other films (like the 1970s bonuses, The spy who loved me and lived and let me die). According to this calculation, License to Kill is the worst performance of all Bonuses, with Moore's last effort, A View to a Kill, in second to last place.
However, Bond brand has remained immensely powerful over the decades, with Eon being forced to defend himself against rival teams' attempts to capitalize on the popularity of the series. Through a rare ownership of the rights, the adaptations of Casino Royale (in 1967) and Thunderball (like Never Say Never Again, in 1983) were launched in competition with Eon's productions. Although subject to legal disputes for several decades, Eon now has full control of both books.
Casino Royale, whose rights had been sold individually by Fleming in 1955, finally passed to Eon in 1999 as a result of an agreement between Eon sponsors, MGM, and Hollywood's rival Sony studio - thus clearing the way for the 2006 version. Thunderball, on the other hand, owed its disputed status to writer-producer Kevin McClory, who helped Fleming sketch the original story and claimed ownership of the novel for decades thereafter, and produced Never Say Never Again as a result. After McClory's death in 2006, his family finally settled with MGM and Eon's parent company in November 2013.
If the initial wave of enthusiasm for Bond films lasted until the 60s and 70s, it is fair to say that the series almost stopped after the poor figures of License to Kill. Goldeneye, the first of Brosnan's efforts, announced a dramatic renewal: not only for a new actor, but, more importantly, for whom he was behind the camera.
However, after a six-year break, Eon installed Martin Campbell in the chair: another experienced British director who was able to orchestrate one of the most elaborate stunts in Bond's history. Goldeneye's opening scene, during which Bond freely falls into the cockpit of a light aircraft without a pilot, did much to revitalize and modernize the series on his own. In addition, a whole new generation was reached through a hugely successful Goldeneye video game spin-off, making a significant contribution to the perception that Bond's film was no longer stale and outdated.

The inventor of a state-of-the-art computer-assisted autopsy system that is increasingly used in European hospitals has stated that the technique could mean that there is no such thing as a "perfect murder."
The method, called 'Virtopsia', is now being used in selected forensic medical institutes in Europe, having been pioneered by a group of scientists at the University of Zurich. Instead of looking for the scalpel and making the Y-shaped incision in the chest with which a traditional autopsy begins, pathologists can now examine the body in 3-D through computer screens.
Michael Thali, director of the Zurich Institute of Forensic Medicine in Europe, and one of Virtopsia's inventors, said he had the potential to revolutionize criminal investigations. “Basically there will no longer be such a thing as the perfect murder, as a virtual autopsy allows you to find every piece of evidence,” he said.
Virtopsias combine images of high-power magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), computed tomography (CT) and superficial scans of dead bodies. Combined, devices are called 'Virtobot'. The technique allows the detection of injuries such as injuries and often undetectable blows during a traditional autopsy, as well as air bags, heart attacks and even cancer.
“Virtopsia has the potential to replace the autopsy one day,” said Richard Dirdorfer, one of the pioneers of DNA analysis in criminology, and a Virtopsia developer founder, to the German scientific journal PM. “I think we’ll see this happen gradually, just as DNA analysis gradually replaced blood group analysis,” he said.
Computerized imaging techniques allow doctors to obtain in-depth information about the deeper interiors of corpses. The method has already allowed the discovery of hemorrhages and fractures that were not collected during conventional autopsies. The initial objective is to use the new method to complement the traditional autopsy.
“It will allow forensic scientists to plan their autopsies much more efficiently,” he told Spiegel Dominic Wichmann, an internal medicine specialist at Hamburg University Hospital. Criminologists from all over the world have been traveling to Switzerland in recent years to see the development of the new method for themselves.
The U.S. medical forensic drama CSI has already presented Virtopses twice. In one, the system was able to prove that a murder victim was killed by a bullet in the cheek; in another, a virtopsia in a murdered man meant that his desire to be cryogenically frozen could move on as his body remained intact.
The method has been in development for decades, with the scientists behind it first housed in an unheated laboratory on a university campus where they were considered a bit of a laughing stock. Later, a donation from a rich ophthalmologist allowed the project to take off. Even then it was initially rejected for its potential to undermine the traditional skills of forensic scientists and pathologists. But a new generation seems to view it as a lesser threat and rather as something that will complement and underlie conventional methods and possibly even one day will replace them, although probably not entirely.
“To analyze the color of the blood, the consistency (of the body fluids) or odors, we will have to continue with the conventional cut,” said Lars Oesterhelweg, Deputy Director of the Institute of Forensic Medicine at the Charité Hospital in Berlin, who is using a version of Virtopsia.
He added that the new method was particularly useful in revisiting cases where the cause of death was unclear. “It means that third-party opinions can be gathered, investigations can be re-examined and cases can be reopened,” he said.
Scientists using the new method said that relatives of the dead, who are often reluctant to have autopsies performed because of the disfigurement they cause, were much more interested in the non-invasive method.

That formulation of the basic idea is perhaps too short to be easily intelligible, and it certainly benefits from a little elaboration. The characterization of alienation offered here—as a social or psychological evil involving the problematic separation of a subject and an object belonging to oneself—includes three constitutive elements: a subject, an object and the relationship between them. It will be useful to say a little more about each of these in turn.
First, the subject here is a self; typically, but not necessarily, a person, an individual agent. ‘Not necessarily’ because the topic could also be, for example, a group of some kind. There seems to be no good reason to deny that both a collective agent and an individual agent might be alienated from some object. For example, just as Anna is alienated from her government, it could be that women or citizens are alienated from her government.
Secondly, the relevant object may take various forms. These include: entities that are not a subject; another subject or subjects; and oneself. The object here could be an entity that is not a subject; for example, Beatrice could be alienated from the natural world, from a social practice, from an institution, or from social norms, where none of those entities is understood as agents of any kind. In addition, the object could be an entity that is another subject, another person or group; for example, Beatrice might be alienated from her childhood friend Cecile, and Beatrice might also be alienated from her own family. Finally, the object here could be the original subject; that is, there could be reflexive variants of the relationship, for example, in which Beatrice is alienated from herself.
Thirdly, the relationship is one of problematic separation between a subject and an object that properly belong together. In this account, all these elements are required: there has to be a separation; separation has to be problematic; and it has to be obtained between a subject and an object that belong properly together.
The idea of separation is important. Not all problematic relationships between the relevant entities imply alienation. For example, being overly integrated into some other object could also be a problematic or dysfunctional relationship, but it is not what is often thought of as alienation. Imagine, for example, that Cecile has no life, no identity, no meaning, other than her belonging to the family. It is tempting, at least for modern individuals, to say that she has an ‘unhealthy’ relationship with her family, but it would seem strange to say that she was alienated from her. Alienation is typically a problematic separation from something.
What I call problematic separations could be indicated by a wide variety of words and phrases. No particular vocabulary seems to be required by the basic idea. The linguistic variety here could include words that suggest: breaks ("splits", "ruptures", "bifurcations", "divisions", etc. ); isolation (‘indifference’, ‘insignificance’, ‘impotence’, ‘disconnection’, etc. ); and hostility ("conflicts", "antagonism", "dominion", etc.). All this, and more, could be ways to indicate problematic separations of the relevant type. Of course, particular authors may use language more systematically, but there seems to be little reason to insist that a specific vocabulary is required by the basic idea.

The anarchist rejection of authority has application in epistemology and in philosophical and literary theory. A significant use of the term appears in American pragmatism. William James described his pragmatist philosophical theory as a kind of anarchism: “A radical pragmatist is a kind of happy-fortunate anarchist creature” (James 1907 [1981: 116]). James had anarchist sympathies, connected to a general critique of systematic philosophy (see Fiala 2013b). Pragmatism, like other anti-systematic and post-hegelian philosophies, renounces the search for an arche or foundation.
Anarchism thus appears as a general critique of dominant methods. An influential example is found in the work of Paul Feyerabend, whose counter-method provides an example of “theoretical anarchism” in epistemology and philosophy of science (Feyerabend 1975 [1993]). Feyerabend explains:
Science is an essentially anarchic enterprise: theoretical anarchism is more humanitarian and more likely to foster progress than its public order alternatives. (Feyerabend 1975 [1993: 9])
Their point is that science should not be limited by hierarchically imposed principles and strict compliance with the rule.
Post-structuralism and trends in postmodernism and continental philosophy can also be anarchists (see May 1994). The so-called “post-anarchism” is a decent and free-flowing discourse that deconstructs power, questions essentialism and undermines systems of authority. Following the deconstructive and critical work of authors such as Derrida, Deleuze, Foucault and others, this criticism of the arch goes down. If there is no arche or foundation, then we are left with a proliferation of possibilities. New trends in globalization, cyberspace and post-humanism complicate anarchist criticism of the “state”, as the traditional celebration of anarchism of freedom and autonomy can be critically examined and deconstructed (see Newman 2016).
Traditional anarchists were primarily interested in the sustained and focused political activism that led to the abolition of the state. The difference between post-anarchism free-flow and traditional anarchism can be seen in the realm of morality. Anarchism has traditionally been critical of centralized moral authority, but this criticism was often based on fundamental principles and traditional values, such as autonomy or freedom. But post-structuralism—along with the criticisms articulated by some feminists, theorists of the critical race and critics of Eurocentrism—questions these values and principles.
