Although widely and commonly confused with republicanism, civic humanism forms a separate and distinct phenomenon in the history of Western political thought. Republicanism is a political philosophy that defends a concept of freedom as non-dominance, and identifies the institutions that protect it (Pettit 1999). In particular, republicanism opposes two alternative theories of politics. The first is despotism, especially as it manifests itself in any form of one-person government; a republic is self-governing, and so are its inhabitants. The second is liberalism, which postulates the primacy of the autonomous individual vis-à-vis public order and government; the Republican values civic commitment to realize a form of freedom achievable only in and through the community. Republican theorists sometimes refer to writings by historically antecedent authors, such as Aristotle or Machiavelli, but their concern is not primarily the exact interpretation. Rather, to the extent that they show interest in the past, it is as a source of ideas that they find useful.
On the contrary, civic humanism is a historiographical construction. As conventionally used by scholars, the term refers to a group of thinkers who emerged during the period of the Italian Renaissance, especially in Florence, and who were committed to public commitment (in theory as well as in practice) and whose values were fundamentally antithetical to the medieval past. The “invention” of civic humanism is mainly associated with Hans Baron (1900-1988), the famous German-American historian (Fubini 1992). Although he first used the phrase in its original German form (Bürgerhumanismus) as early as 1925, its popularity derives from the publication in 1955 of his classic book The Crisis of Early Italian Revival: Civic Humanism and Republican Freedom in an Age of Classicism and Tyranny (Revised 1966). In this volume, as well as in later writings that were based on it (many collected in Baron 1968 and 1988), he developed what has become called the “Thesis of Baron” (Witt 1996; Hankins 1995). Baron was not, however, the first scholar to propose the form of humanism that emerged during the 15th century in Italian cities mainly promoted active civic vit rather than literary and philological searches normally attributed to humanists. In two books from 1952 and 1954, written and published in Italian, Eugenio Garin defended a position almost identical to that of Baron: Renaissance humanism, especially as proposed in Florence, reflects a pronounced shift from the emphasis on the typical contemplation of the Middle Ages to the priority of civil action to achieve a common good (Garin 1947 [1965]). (If not for purely contingent reasons, the historiographic label for civic humanism could easily have been “the Garin thesis”). In the current context, it should be noted that some defenders of civic humanism were ready for republicanism, but the latter is not involved by the former.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has called on Washington to resolve its finances after the U.S. would withdraw from the brink of debt default and hundreds of thousands of federal employees would return to work after a 16-day government shutdown.
As US President Barack Obama warned, “We have to get out of the habit of ruling by crisis,” IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde called for more stability.
“It will be essential to reduce uncertainty about the conduct of fiscal policy by raising the debt limit in a more lasting way,” he said.
“We also continue to encourage the United States to adopt a budget for 2014 and replace the hijacker with gradual measures that do not adversely affect recovery, and to adopt a balanced and comprehensive medium-term fiscal plan.”
A peace agreement drafted by the Senate that almost contained no concessions to the conservatives who had led the country to the precipice of a new financial crisis was approved by the Republican-dominated House of Representatives a few hours before a deadline to extend the US debt limit.
The World Bank also expressed its relief that the world economy “has dodged a potential catastrophe, ” with its president, Jim Yong Kim, urging policymakers in all countries to “continue to focus on developing and implementing policies that promote economic growth and boost employment and opportunities for all. ”
The stock markets in Japan, China, Hong Kong and South Korea initially reflected relief after Republicans finally capitulated in their failed attempt to undermine Obama’s health reforms. But, in Asia and Europe, stock markets in general showed a silent reaction, and traders apparently expect another battle in Washington in early 2014.
It is estimated that the closure cost 24 billion dollars, according to the rating agency Standard & Poor’s. China's official agency Xinhua News Agency had accused Washington of endangering the dollar assets of other countries. China is the largest creditor of the U.S. government.
Obama signed the necessary legislation to defend himself from non-compliance shortly after midnight Thursday after a Republican split in the House of Representatives. The bill had easily been passed with broad bipartisan support in the Senate, where Democratic and Republican leaders forged the agreement. It offers a temporary solution, financing the government until January 15 and raising the debt ceiling until February 7.
But the president made it clear that he did not expect another bitter struggle and closure of the budget in 2014.
In brief remarks in the White House shortly before the House vote, Obama said he expected the deal to “lift the cloud of uncertainty” he had hung over the country in recent weeks.
“Once this agreement reaches my desk, I will sign it immediately,” he said, in a statement issued at the White House. “I hope the next time isn’t in the eleventh hour. We have to get out of the habit of ruling because of the crisis.”
As he left the stand after his Wednesday night press conference, a journalist asked the president if the crisis would happen again in a few months. Speaking over his shoulder, Obama replied, “No.”
Earlier, Republican Senator Mike Lee had set a challenging tone, perhaps indicating more problems ahead: “The media keeps asking, ‘Was it worth it?’ My answer is, it is always worth doing the right thing.” He added, “This is not over.”
However, the political agreement was one of the worst possible results for Republicans. None of their stated goals were achieved and polls showed that voters overwhelmingly blamed them for the crisis.

Valentine's Day (or Valentine's Day) is a feast that, in the United States, takes place on February 14, and technically means the achievements of Valentine's Day, a Roman saint of the third century.
With that said, most Americans, instead of honoring Valentine's through religious ceremony, enjoy the feast by participating in "romantic" behavior with their significant other or someone who wants to be their significant other; gifts, special dinners, and other affection recognitions include the Valentine's Day celebrations of most individuals.
Chocolates and flowers are commonly given as gifts during Valentine's Day, as well as the greeting cards they accompany (the greeting card companies launch new Valentine's Day designs annually). Red and pink are generally understood as "the colors" of Valentine's Day, and many individuals, instead of romantically celebrating, spend the holidays with their friends and/or family.
The variations of Valentine's Day are celebrated all over the world throughout the year. In the United States, the holiday, although recognized by the vast majority of the population, is not federally recognized; no time off is granted for Valentine's Day.

A promising place to begin to understand transcendental idealism is to look at the other philosophical positions from which Kant distinguishes him. In "paralogism fourth", it distinguishes transcendental idealism from transcendental realism:
This [transcendental] idealism is opposed to transcendental realism, which considers space and time as something given in itself (independent of our sensitivity). Therefore, the transcendental realistic represents the outward appearances (if their reality is recognized) as things in themselves [Dinge an sich selbst], which would exist independently of us and our sensibility and therefore would also be outside of us according to pure concepts of understanding. (A369)
Transcendental realism, according to this passage, is the view that objects in space and time exist independently of our experience of them, while transcendental idealism denies it. This point is reiterated later in the Critique when Kant writes:
We have sufficiently demonstrated in Transcendental Aesthetics that everything intuited in space or time, therefore all objects of a possible experience for us, are nothing but appearances, that is, mere representations, which, as they are represented, as extended beings or series of alterations, have no existence based on themselves outside our thoughts. I call this doctrine transcendental idealism. The realist, in transcendental significance, makes these modifications of our sensitivity in the things that remain in themselves, and therefore makes mere representations in things in themselves [Such a sich selbst]. (A491/B519)[3]
Appearances exist at least partly by virtue of our experience of them, while the existence of things in themselves is not based on our experience at all (cf. A369, A492/B521, A493/B522). Kant calls transcendental realism the "common prejudice" (A740/B768) and describes it as a "common but fallacious presupposition" (A536/B564; cf. Allison 2004: 22). Transcendental realism is the pre-theoretical view of common sense that objects in space and time are “things in themselves,” which Kant, of course, denies.
Kant also distinguishes transcendental idealism from another position he calls empirical idealism:
It would also do us an injustice if it were to attribute to us this long-deceased empirical idealism which, while assuming the very reality of space, denies the existence of beings spread in it, or at least finds this existence doubtful, and therefore in this sense admits no satisfactorily demonstrable distinction between dream and truth. As for the appearances of the inner sense in time, he finds no difficulty in them as real things, in fact, he even claims that this inner experience alone gives sufficient proof of the actual existence of his object (in itself) along with all this determination of time. (A491/B519)
Empirical idealism, as Kant characterizes it here, is the view that all we know immediately (not inferentially) is the existence of our own temporarily ordained minds and mental states, while we can only infer the existence of “outside” objects from us in space. Since the inference of an effect known to an unknown cause is always uncertain, the empirical idealist concludes that we cannot know that objects exist outside of us in space. Kant usually distinguishes two varieties of empirical idealism: dogmatic idealism, which affirms that objects in space do not exist, and problematic idealism, which affirms that objects in space may exist, but we cannot know if they do (see A377). Although never mentioned by name in edition A, Berkeley seems to be Kant's dogmatic idealist paradigm, while Descartes is named as the problematic idealist paradigm. [4]
Transcendental idealism is a form of empirical realism because it implies that we have an immediate (non-inferential) and true knowledge of the existence of objects in space merely through self-consciousness:
[...] external objects (bodies) are mere appearances, so there is nothing more than a sort of my representations, whose objects are something only through these representations, but are not separated from them. Thus, external things exist just as my self, and in fact both exist in the immediate testimony of my self-consciousness, only with this difference: the representation of my Self, as the thinking subject is merely related to the inner sense, but the representations that designate extended beings are also related to the external sense. I am no longer obliged to draw inferences with regard to the reality of external objects than with regard to the reality of my inner sense (my thoughts), because in both cases they are merely representations, the immediate perception (consciousness) of which is at the same time sufficient proof of their reality. (A370–1)
Only through self-conscious introspection can I know that I have representations with certain contents and since appearances are “no more than a sort of my representations” does this constitute an immediate and true knowledge of the existence of objects in space.
Understanding transcendental idealism requires understanding the precise meaning in which things themselves are, and appearances are not, “external” or “independent” of the mind and Kant makes a useful distinction between two senses in which objects can be “outside me”:
But since the expression outside of us carries with it an inevitable ambiguity, since it sometimes means something that, as a thing in itself [Ding a sich selbst], exists distinct from us and sometimes merely belongs to the outward appearance, then to escape from uncertainty and to use this concept in the latter meaning — in which it is taken in the appropriate psychological question about the reality of our outer intuition — we will distinguish the empirically external objects from those that could be called “outside” in the transcendental sense, calling them directly “things to be found in space”. (A373)
In the transcendental sense, an object is “outside of me” when its existence does not depend (or even partially) on my representations of it. The empirical sense of “outside me” depends on the distinction between external and internal meaning. The inner sense is the sensitive intuition of my inner states (which are in themselves appearances); time is the form of the inner sense, which means that all the states that we intuit internally are temporarily ordered. The external sense is the sensitive intuition of objects that are not my internal states; space is the form of the external sense. In the empirical sense, “out” refers simply to objects of outer sense, objects in space. Transcendental idealism is the view that objects in space are “external” in the empirical sense, but not in the transcendental sense. Things themselves are transcendentally “external” but appearances are not.

According to the United Nations, Syrian opposition forces may have executed up to 30 people, most of them Government soldiers, in the rural areas of Aleppo, who cited videos of the killings published on the Internet in July.
Navi Pillay, United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, called the accusations deeply shocking and called on Friday for an independent investigation into the incident, which appears to have taken place in Khan al-Assal, in northern Syria.
A thorough independent investigation is needed to determine whether war crimes have been committed, and those responsible for such crimes must be brought to justice, Pillay said in a statement.
The videos, posted on the Internet between July 22 and 26, show government soldiers being ordered to lie down on the ground, bodies collected by doctors, bodies scattered along a wall and bodies in Khan al-Assal with gunshot wounds to the head.
Pillay's office also has information that Syrian rebels are still holding government officials and soldiers in prison, the statement said.
Reminding opposition forces that all captured or injured soldiers must be treated in accordance with international law, Pillay said, opposition forces should not think that they are immune from prosecution. They must fulfil their responsibilities under international law.
The UN. The International Independent Investigation Commission on the Syrian Arab Republic has previously stated that both rebel groups and government forces and their affiliated militias are demonstrating incipient patterns of summary executions and killings.
The news of the killings came when the Local Coordination Committees, an umbrella group of the opposition, said 19 of their loyalists had been killed, including two children. Most of the deaths occurred in Damascus, the LCC said.
In a speech to government forces on Thursday -- Army Foundation Day -- President Bashar al-Assad said he was confident that the government would triumph over the opposition, according to the Syrian Arab News Agency.
If in Syria we had not trusted victory, we would not have been able to stand firm and resist aggression for more than two years, said the president, according to SANA,
The United Nations human rights office also said on Friday that investigators have been allowed to visit rebel-controlled Khan al-Assal as part of a separate investigation into the alleged use of chemical weapons.
The rebels announced on Friday that they had written to UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon requesting an investigation and demanding that anyone involved in the deployment of chemical weapons in Syria be held responsible for these crimes.
According to the United Nations, more than 100,000 people have died since the fighting began. Nearly 2 million have fled the country and 4 million more have been internally displaced.
CNN's Eliott C. McLaughlin contributed to this report.

text:
Europe will become the first place in the world to impose ‘real’ emission tests on car manufacturers, opening a new front in the fight against air pollution. New regulations will introduce tests to reveal what car emissions are like when driving on roads and in traffic rather than in ideal conditions, such as laboratory ones, as is currently the case.
Green illuminated by European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermans, the tests are designed to impose a limit of 80 mg nitrogen oxide per kilometer, a level reached by only one 16 car, according to researchers. Other countries, such as China and Korea, which are also considering emission testing in the real world, will be closely observing what will happen next.
Contaminants from diesel engines, such as nitrogen oxide, carbon monoxide and particulates, are believed to account for at least one quarter of the 29,000 pollution-related deaths per year in the United Kingdom. This figure is likely to increase when the committee on the medical effects of air pollutants publishes what it calls “stronger evidence” of public health damage caused by nitrogen oxide emissions at the end of 2015.
But the current laboratory test of the "New European Cycle of Production" to measure these emissions is a quarter of a century old and has been surpassed by technological advances in the automotive industry. Studies have shown that the results of laboratory techniques to measure automobile emissions can be easily fixed by using techniques such as door and window taping to minimize air resistance, driving on unrealistic smooth roads and testing at improbably high temperatures. Activists say car manufacturers also use tricks like programming vehicles to enter a low-emission mode when their front wheels rotate and their rear wheels are stationary, as is the case in such laboratory experiments.
“The Commission is finalizing a proposal to introduce a new emission test procedure that will allow a proper assessment of real-drive vehicles,” said Commission spokesperson Lucia Caudet. The proposal still needs the approval of other commissioners and a technical committee, but “we do not expect any major internal obstacles,” added a source from the European Union (EU).
“A key reason why air pollution kills 400,000 citizens a year is that car manufacturers cheat tests for diesel cars, causing many times more pollution on the road,” said Greg Archer, Clean Vehicle Manager for Transport and Environment. “The development of a new engine emission test in the real world is an important step forward in the fight against urban air pollution. The EU states should now support the Commission's proposals and ignore the complaint by car manufacturers that the rules are too strict."
According to research by the International Clean Transport Council in 2014, actual emissions of nitrogen oxide from cars are seven times higher than the 80mg/km standard, and some models operate 22 times above the recommended limit. Only a 16-year-old car hit the 80g target. About one third of all nitrogen oxide pollution comes from road transport – mostly diesel – and, in urban areas, concentrations can reach 64%, the figures from the European Environment Agency indicate.
Activists say the automotive industry has tried to delay reforms to auto testing cycles, but industrial groups deny it, arguing that a five-year period is necessary for technical and economic reasons. “Real driving emissions (RDE) is an entirely new regulation that will force significant changes in the emission control hardware that can be demanded in the midst of a vehicle’s production life,” said Cara McLaughlin, spokesperson for the European Automobile Manufacturers Association (ACEA). “However, ACEA fully accepts that RDE will apply to new types of cars as of September 2017.”
In an unusual move, the automobile association sent Timmermans a draft own regulation for him to consider, after EU representatives finally agreed on a regulation to implement nitrogen oxide limits with reinforced road testing and strict control of exhaust gases. The draft ACEA Regulation would have covered less pollutants and further delayed the gradual introduction of the Regulation until 2020. The test distances would have been reduced from 1,300m to less than 700m, the minimum temperatures would have been raised from -7C to -3C and more rural roads would have been used. The lobbyists were all over this, Archer said. “This was a real attempt to subvert the legislative process.”
Following Timmerman's apparent rejection of the ACEA proposal, the regulation will now be passed to the rubber seal commissioners, and to the Member States for the final amendments, before an introduction scheduled for September. By 2017, the first real-world car emissions tests are expected to start seriously. A similar battle already looming over the testing of CO2 emissions for cars by the end of 2015 – and with comparable discussions in other countries – will closely follow the introduction of new EU emission tests.

text:
Brazil experienced one of its biggest nights of protest in decades, when more than 100,000 people took to the streets across the country to express their frustration at the heavy police work, poor public services and high costs for the World Cup.
Major demonstrations in Rio de Janeiro, São Paulo, Brasilia, Belem, Belo Horizonte, Salvador and elsewhere began peacefully, but several led to clashes with police and arson attacks on cars and buses.
The large turnout and geographical dispersion marked a rapid escalation after earlier smaller protests against the rise in bus prices, causing complaints that the police responded disproportionately with rubber bullets, tear gas and violent blows.
Coinciding with the start of the Confederations Cup – a World Cup test event – the rallies brought together a broad coalition of frustrated people with rising costs and persistent poor quality of public services, luxurious investment in international sporting events, low standards of health care, and broader unrest about inequality and corruption.
Although the vast majority of the demonstrations in Rio were peaceful, several police officers were injured in clashes at the city's legislative assembly, at least one car was overturned and burned, and windows were broken in the offices of banks and notarial offices.
The riots intensified during the night when a large crowd set fire to several fires outside the legislative assembly, smashed the windows of the building and painted graffiti on the walls proclaiming “Revolution”, “Down Paes, Down Cabral [the mayor and governor of the state]” and “Police of Hate.” The police inside responded with pepper spray and perhaps more – the Guardian saw a fainting protestor and bleeding heavily from a wound to the upper arm.
The causes pursued by the protesters varied widely. “We are here because we hate the government. They don’t do anything for us,” said Oscar José Santos, a 19-year-old who was with a group of hooded youth from the Rocinha favela.
“I’m an architect, but I’ve been unemployed for six months. There must be something wrong with this country,” said Nadia to the Husin, raising a banner asking the government to do more for education.
In a much smaller demonstration in Brasilia, protesters crossed police lines to enter the high security area of the national congress. Several went up to the roof.
In Belo Horizonte, police confronted protesters who tried to break a cordon around a football stadium that hosted a Confederations Cup match between Nigeria and Tahiti.
In Porto Alegre, protesters set fire to a bus and, in Curitiba, protesters tried to break into the state governor's office. There were also rallies in Belem, Salvador and elsewhere.
In São Paulo, which had witnessed the fiercest clashes of the previous week and the main allegations of police violence, large crowds gathered once again, but initial reports suggested that the marches had passed peacefully.
Reflecting the importance of social media to spread the message about the protests, some in São Paulo – where the figures were estimated to be between 30,000 and 100,000 – carried banners declaring “We came from Facebook.”
Most of the protesters were young and, for many, it was their first experience of such a giant demonstration. “My generation has never experienced this,” said Thiago Firbida, a student. “Since the dictatorship, Brazilians have never bothered to take to the streets. They didn't think they had a reason to. But now Brazil is again in crisis, with a steady rise in prices, so people are finally reacting.”
Comparisons have been made with rallies in Turkey and elsewhere. Another global link was evident in the handful of protesters wearing Guy Fawkes masks, associated with the Anonymous and Occupy Wall Street protests.
Brazilian demonstrations are called the “wine revolution” (after police arrested people for bringing vinegar to counter tear gas), as well as the “twenty cent revolution” (due to the rise in bus prices) and the Passe Livre (after demand for free public transportation).
Some said the protests felt unBrazilian but liberating. “Our politicians need to see the strength we have as one people. Brazilians tend to be too nice sometimes – they enjoy the party instead of protesting – but something is changing,” said Deli Borsari, a 53-year-old yoga instructor.
After extensive coverage of the costs of the new and renewed stadiums, the Confederations Cup football tournament has been one of the focus of the protests. Before the inaugural party in Brasilia, crowds of protesters were dispersed by riot police. The shooting showed frightened Japanese followers running out of the area holding their children, while the sound of the shooting was heard, perhaps rubber bullets or tear gas.
Another protest march, near the Maracana Stadium in Rio, received an equally heavy police response.
Most of the demonstrations appeared to begin peacefully until they confronted the security forces, which are largely organized at the regional level. President Dilma Rousseff approves of the protests, according to her assistants. “The president believes that peaceful protests are legitimate and appropriate for a democracy, and that it is natural for young people to demonstrate,” said Helena Chagas, from the president’s office.
However, the president was booed at the opening ceremony of the Confederations Cup. With the economy in bad shape and the social unrest on the rise, it faces a serious political challenge, both now and in 2014, when Brazil will not only host the World Cup, but will also have a presidential election.

The classic Sorites, or "heavy argument", seeks to show that even 10,000 grains do not make a lot, on the ground that (a) three grains do not make, and (b) the addition of a grain could never be enough to turn a non-heavy into a pile: however, often one grain is added further, there is no exact limit between the non-heavy and the pile. The applications of this form of argument were widespread in the Hellenistic era, and the logical stoic Crisipus wrote many books trying to solve it. Diodoro is a likely source or inspiration for this Hellenistic concern (see previous paragraph).
Soritas are a particularly lethal weapon when used in the field of semantics, threatening to erase the limits on which rigid definitions depend. It may therefore be relevant that Diodorus has proposed his own semantic theory (Aulus Gellus, Attic Nights 11.12.1-3; cf. 1 above, the story of his change of name to his slave, reported by Ammon, In the interpretation of Aristotle 38.17-20. This was based on the ‘conventionalist’ thesis expressed by the character Hermogenes in Plato’s Cratylus, according to which nothing but convention — whether national, local or simply private — determines the meaning of a word, and any convenient string of sounds can in principle be used to convey any meaning. Diodorus' inference of this was that the only determinant of the meaning of a word is the intention of the one who utters it on any occasion in which it is used. He continued to imply that there are no real ambiguities: given the assumption that a word is pronounced on each occasion with a specific meaning in mind, a word has only one meaning at any time.
One may wonder whether this semantic theory, which reduced the meaning to the meaning of professing, was designed to remedy the kind of harm the soritas threatened. If meanings are purely determined by the speaker's intention on each occasion, a radical reconsideration of the definitional theory appears in any case to be necessary. And it may be that counting the grains becomes simply irrelevant to determining what constitutes a lot.
Diodorus was also closely associated with the paradox "Veiled" (Diogenes Laertius, 2,111; Lucian, Sale of Life, 22-3): you know who your father is; you don't know who the man veiled there is; but that man veiled is your father; so they both do and don't know who their father is. We could guess that Diodoro's own solution has once again been semantic. In each of its occurrences ‘knowing’ has, in the mind of the defendant, a distinct meaning appropriate to the case (knowledge, recognition), and therefore there is no contradiction.

text:
Europe’s forests – and suburbs – are resounding with the grunts, howls, and silent padding of large predators, according to a new study showing that brown bears, wolves, and lynxes are thriving on a crowded continent. Despite fears that large carnivores are doomed to extinction due to increased human populations and excessive consumption, a study published in Science has found that populations of large predators are stable or increasing in Europe.
Brown bears, wolves, Eurasian lynx and worms are found in almost one third of continental Europe (excluding Belarus, Ukraine and Russia), and most people live outside natural reserves, indicating that changing attitudes and landscape-scale conservation measures successfully protect species that have suffered massive persecution throughout human history.
Bears are the most abundant large carnivores in Europe, with about 17,000 individuals, along with 12,000 wolves, 9,000 Eurasian lynxes and 1,250 wolves, which are restricted to the northern parts of Scandinavia and Finland. Only Belgium, Denmark, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, like Britain, have no breeding populations of at least one large carnivorous species. But the main author of the newspaper and other conservationists said that the surprising distribution of these animals in well-populated regions of Europe showed that even the British countryside could support large predators.
Guillaume Chapron of the Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences and researchers from all over Europe found wolves, in some cases, living in suburban areas along with up to 3,050 people per square kilometer, more than the population density of Cambridge or Newcastle. On average in Europe, wolves live on land with a population density of 37 people per km2, lynx in areas with a population density of 21 people per km2 and bears among 19 people per km2. The Highlands population density is nine people per km2.
“To have wolves, we don’t need to get people out of the landscape,” Chapron said. According to Chapron and his colleagues, the revival of large carnivores shows the success of a conservation model based on “land sharing”, in stark contrast to keeping predators and people separate by surrounding “unknown” areas, as is the case in North America and Africa.
“I’m not saying it’s a story of peace and love – coexistence often means conflict – but it’s important to manage that conflict, keep it low and solve the problems it causes. Wolves can be difficult neighbors,” Chapron said. “We should not talk about conflicts between people and predators; we have conflicts between people over predators. These animals are symbolic of difficult questions about how we should use the land.”
According to researchers, this “share land” approach could be applied in other parts of the world. Among the reasons for its success in Europe are political stability, the flourishing of dam populations such as wild deer and financial support for the protection of non-lethal livestock, such as electric fences, which means that farmers do not resort to wild predator hunts. The most crucial thing, Chapron said, has been the EU Habitats Directive, which has forced Member States to protect and revive rare species.
“Without the Habitats Directive, I don’t think we would have had this recovery,” he said. “It shows that if people are willing to protect nature and if political will translates into strong legislation such as the Habitats Directive, it is possible to achieve results in the protection of wildlife.” The revival was welcomed by author and commentator George Monbiot, who is launching Rewilding Britain, a new charity to encourage the return of the wild landscape and extinct species.
“It’s great to see that the upward trend continues, but Britain is completely anomalous – we’ve lost more of our great mammals than any other country except Ireland,” he said. “Apart from the accidental reintroduction of the boar, we have done almost nothing, while, in much of the rest of Europe, we have bears, lynx and wolves coming back. It is a massive change of the centuries of persecution.”
The survey found that the Eurasian lynx lives permanently in 11 population groups in 23 European countries, of which only five were native populations, indicating the success of reintroduction efforts. According to Monbiot, the momentum is increasing for the reintroduction of the lynx into the Cairngorms in Scotland.
“If it works in the rest of Europe, there is absolutely no reason why it can’t work in the UK,” he said, noting that bears and wolves are found an hour from Rome. “There is no demographic reason why we cannot have a similar return to wildlife in the UK.”

Hedging funds are once again becoming bullish in oil, betting on the pandemic and the environmental approach of investors has seriously damaged the ability of companies to increase production.
The opinion is an investment for hedge funds, which shortened the oil sector in the run-up to global closures, landing revenues from energy-centered hedge funds of 26.8% in 2020, according to eVestment data. Under their quick-moving strategies, hedge funds are quick to detect new trends.
The global benchmark for Brent oil has jumped by 59% since early November, when news of successful vaccines emerged, after last year's COVID-19 slowed down and blocked fuel demand and collapsed oil prices. Last week it reached prepandemic levels close to $60 a barrel.
U.S. crude oil has risen 54% to about $57 per barrel during the same period.
“By summer, the vaccine should be provided widely and just in time for summer trips, and I think things are going to be wrong,” said David D. Tawil, co-founder of the New York-based hedge fund, Maglan Capital, and acting CEO of Centaurus Energy.
Tawil predicted prices from $70 to $80 a barrel for Brent at the end of 2021 and is investing for a long time independent oil and gas producers.
Hedge Funds' bullish bets come despite the International Energy Agency's warning in January that an increase in new coronavirus cases will hamper oil demand this year, and a slow economic recovery would delay a total upturn in global energy demand until 2025.
Normally, oil producers would increase production as prices increased, but the shift of environmental-focused investors from fossil fuels to renewable energies and the caution of lenders leaves them under heavy pressure to respond, say hedge funds and other investors.
The rate of recovery of production in the United States, No. 1 oil producer is expected to be slow and will not exceed its record of 12.25 million barrels per day (bpd) in 2019 until 2023. Production in 2020 fell by 6.4% to 11.47 million bpd.
However, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which has also reviewed demand growth, still expects production reductions to maintain the market deficit for 2021.
According to Rystad Energy, global crude and condensed production declined by 8 per cent in December from February 2020, before the spread of the pandemic accelerated.
North American output declined by 9.5 per cent and that of Europe decreased by only 1 per cent during the same period.
The US sanctions against Venezuela and the decline in oil fields in Mexico have slowed Latin American oil production.

text: Without further heating, radiative gas cooling in the halos of massive galaxies (Milky Way and above) produces cold gas or stars in excess of what is observed. Previous works suggested that AGN jets are probably required, but the form of jet energy required to shut down remains unclear. This is particularly difficult for galaxy simulations, in which resolution is orders of magnitude thicker than necessary to form and evolve the jet. In such scales, uncertain parameters include: jet energy form (kinetic, thermal and cosmic ray energy (CR), energy, impulse and mass flow, force and geometry of the magnetic field, angle and precession period of the jet, opening angle and work cycle. We investigate all these parameters in a 1014M® halo using high resolution non-cosmological MHD simulations with the FIRE-2 (Feedback In Realistic Environments) star feedback model, driving and viscosity. We explore what scenarios coincide with observational constraints and demonstrate that RC-dominated jets can more efficiently shut down the central galaxy through a combination of CR pressure support and a modification of thermal instability. Jets with most of the energy in the work of thermal plasma slightly relativistic (meV or 1010 K), but require a larger 10 factor energy input. For a fixed energy flow, jets with more specific energy (longer cooling times) are turned off more effectively. For this halo size, kinetic jets are less efficient in cooling unless they have wide opening or precession angles. Magnetic fields play a minor role except when the magnetic flow reaches 1044 erg s−1 in a kinetic jet model, which makes the jet cocoon expand significantly, and cooling becomes explosive. We conclude that the criteria for a successful jet model are an optimal energy flow and a sufficiently wide jet cocoon with sufficient cooling time in the cooling radius.
